text: Wow wow wow.  The views are everything.  We all shared different cuts of meats and they were all delicious and cooked to perfection. The wine list offered a very nice selection from all the major wine regions. The craft cocktail list was over the top. Maybe a little too extra if you want my honest opinion. Nonetheless, this is a 5 star place with five star food and beverages. Service= 5 as well.

I tried Brugge last night for the first time ever. It was alright. I'm not sure what I was expecting. Maybe I wasn't really expecting anything... Or maybe I was expecting more without really expecting anything in particular? 

I had heard that the mussels were delicious. I LOVE mussels, but I was alone in that boat, and the 2 pounds of muscle portion seemed like a bit much for me at the time, so I figured I would come back another time. I ended up ordering some sort of fruity beer. It was pretty good. VERY sweet and bitter. Almost wine-like, but good. After I had gorged myself on my dinner, I was glad that I had gotten the fruity beer because I don't think I would have been able to continue drinking any other type of beer with my stuffed belly. 

For dinner, well, the menu didn't leave much for me to actually give you a name of what I had. So. For dinner, I had some sort of meatball, and something (beer?) swiss cheese blah dee blah. Yeah. That was the name of it, or soemthing like that. Thank you for giving me a name to call in for short. And ordering it? Do I call it meatball and you just know before I finish? Or do I finish the whole name (or rather, construction of the meal) of it? 
All it all, it was okay. The bread was a bit stiff, as it was toasted, and swallowed the meatballs, cheese and sauce. 
The fries (OH, SORRY! Frites!- They were fries, really) were not special. The sauces were special, though. I ordered horseradish and sesame mayo. I usually feel kinda bad getting mayo- like I should be making a more healthy choice for myself, but I LOVE sesame. The horseradish was good, but man, that sesame mayo was GREAT! 

Really, the food was eh. The beer was pretty good (I'm sure I'll like the regular wheat. Actually, I tried the black wheat, and it was really good! )- The ambience was nice- I liked the atmosphere a lot, even if we were getting eaten alive by mosquitos and had several visits by either separate spiders or the same one. 

I might change my mind when I go back for the mussels, but I thought the food was pretty mediocre. I had heard so much about the frites, and eh. 

They ARE open 'till 12:30, though. I like that, so there's more chance to win me over. I'm a late night diner, and I'll be back to give it another shot.

I think this is a place to go and get a sweeter breakfast or to enjoy a cup of coffee in the inside/outside seating with the windows open.

Wasn't super impressed but I think I just ordered the wrong type of crepe.

I had a thai tea or something there made with honey and cardamom! OH DELISH!
To be honest it is the first time had something from here that stayed in my mind.

Visited on 7/19/12. My co-workers for the week raved about Jim's.  They told me to forget about the tourist traps of Geno's and Pat's and go to Jim's.   They were so sure of this recommendation that we left early for lunch and walked a bunch of blocks to Jim's on south street.  I ordered a Mushroom steak with provolone, when one of the looming individuals asked if I wanted onions, I said no.   Soooooo.... why did I get dirty looks from several individuals when THEY messed up and put onions on my sandwich ?!?!?!?!   They had an attitude but made the correction.  The sandwich was nothing to write home about !!  Note to self.... don't take anymore recommendations from said co-workers !! I would not go back here !

First, this is has a cool old-school atmosphere, and they even make their own sodas. 
Our server was friendly and helpful. And the menu basically breaks into two sections: German sausages and hamburgers. We tried both. 
The hamburger was better. The patty is on the thin side, but fresh beef and ingredients give it a good flavor. 
The sausages also had a good flavor, but were a little dry. The sauerkraut that came with them was very good. 
Overall, everything was above average although nothing was so outstanding it can't be missed. A solid choice for a burger.

The worst. I see a lot of positive feedback for the hotdogs, but unfortunately, that's not what I had. I ate part of a chicken pastela (?) and then realized that it was not chicken. The employee I spoke with said it was a chicken product that they purchased at Costco and was made up of chicken parts. One of the most sickening things ever-it was sponge-like and awful. I puked and called the health department.

Sigh...I literally hate to update a review to less of a rating than what I originally rated.  HOWEVER,  I'm doing it.  It's New Year's Day. The only place open on Mass Ave is here,  and they have a great brunch. We just wanted drinks which is why we sat at the bar. The greeter was warm and made us feel welcome. There were two other staff members who were very cordial. I don't know what the problem was with the bartender. We sat down and told him we just wanted drinks. I asked him if they had a brand,  and he looked at me like I had three heads and said he'd never heard of it. Well,  check with your Mass Ave business neighbors because at least three of them carry it. I opted for a standard. After he served our first drinks,  he never asked us if we wanted anything again. I finally said,  "Yo Adrian!" to a lovely young lady who really is named Adrian and who was already working her butt off and asked her if I could get another drink. She got it for me. We had a total of three drinks in two hours. Then we had to ask for the check. This just really chaps me. It's unacceptable behavior and service. The worst part is I'm on here recounting this negative experience when so many of the staff are so nice. One bad potato stinks up the whole place.

Devil's Acre Tavern is a very attractive reuse of an old roadhouse along Easton Road (Rt. 611), Plumsteadville, PA. It takes it name from the nearby Devil's Half Acre, originally a stone tavern built in the 18th Century close on the Delaware River that sold alcohol and other services to the river traffic navigating upstream and down in a time the the river was the primary means of transportation in this part of colonial America. In fact, they had no license to make nor sell alcohol, and the joint was a place where violence and shady characters abounded. Legend and history say there were many people killed there and buried in the backyard. 

Perhaps, to lessen the reliance on that unsavory history, the name was chosen without the word "Half," but the connection is not lost on those aware of these facts. Still, it appears often enough in the menu and on the walls of the establishment to hint at the local lore. 

Luckily, this house is totally legit. Ownership has created an attractive utilitarian space, German American in nature, with excellent cross section of Deutsch brews, quality cocktails, reasonable happy hour choices and a strong kitchen. We stopped in on Saturday afternoon at the start of HH, and thoroughly enjoyed the entire experience. After a little confusion with our new server about availability of happy hour and where to sit to capture those prices, everything was resolved quickly and we waited for delivery to our dining room table of Three Onion Soup, Dragon Wings and Pierogi of the Day apps/sides, and two DHA Burgers and a DHA Dog. 

Everything was very good to terrific. My stepson wouldn't share his potage, so it must have been great. We all sampled the wings @$.50 per. They were not too big, but were amply meaty with a good sweet/hot glaze with sesame seeds sprinkled on top. The pierogi were the weak link. The dough was thick, too chewy and dominated the flavor of the seasoned veggies within. Ate one and took the rest home. Maybe sour cream would have helped. 

The burgers were huge with double patties, bacon, lettuce, red onion, and their DHA sauce. Both were past the medium well finish requested, but there was still plenty of flavor and moisture. I loved the double dog with chopped red onion, dark mustard and well done bacon in a fresh crisp torpedo roll. Great taste and texture. @$5 HH price it was a star of the show. 

Devil's Acre Tavern is a 35 minute drive from home, but when in the mood for German beer and cuisine it is well worth the trip. Tuesday Burger Night sounds like a winner, too.

Reading through the more recent reviews of the Continental Tavern I had the impression that while most people liked the atmospherics, they were less enthused with the cuisine. While the two of us only had their "Best of Bucks" burgers, fries and soft drinks, we departed thinking we have had better elsewhere.

Opened this place Saturday morning @ 9.  It was nice to have a head start on what was to be a full house at Full Moon.  

Clayton, our host and server had his act together and brought all of us coffee as we perused the breakfast menu.  Various omelets for my family and friend, and French Toast for me.  While the conversation gathered momentum, the plates were brought out and laid before us.  Everything looked very good, although I only tasted the homemade Potato Chips, which were good.

My French Toast was off the mark, however. I had asked for it "crunchy," and was told it would be left on the grill longer to make it all well done.  What came out with the real Maple Syrup were a half dozen pieces of French Demi Loaf that were actually lukewarm at best, and far from the cauterized ends I requested.  I was surprised given the repartee at the ordering.  They had not been on the grill long enough, and had been off the grill too long before serving. Wrong on both sides.  Disappointing, but not wanting to poop on the party I ate everything and enjoyed the real Maple Syrup. 

My mates were satisfied, and the gestalt of the room was pleasing. 

Three out of four ain't bad.

Saw that these guys were setting up at my old high school today, so just had to stop by for lunch.  I love seeing the food trucks outside of the big summer events.  It may just be me, but I seldom encounter trucks just around town very often, and I love to jump at getting to stop by one in the "food truck off-season".  Beyond that, I also love, love, love Hawaiian food, so this is right up my alley.

Setup should be familiar to any food truck enthusiast.  These folks set up at different spots on different days, you walk up, place your order, and either take it to go or find a seat and enjoy your meal.  They have two or three main courses, some sides, as well as drinks.  Today I ended up going for the Kalua Pork platter, coming with rice and macaroni salad, along with a side order of their Asian slaw, all for like $12.  Good deal, for sure.

All in all, this is some of the best Kalua Pork I've had in our region.  These guys get top marks for that alone, and make me excited to try some of their other entrees when next I can track them down.  The macaroni salad was pretty good, with lots of garlic, though the addition of olives doesn't strike me as very "island", except maybe if you mean Mediterranean island.  The slaw was quite nice, too, with a light yet sweet sauce that really helped cut the richness of the pork.

If you are looking for good Hawaiian-style food, definitely give their webpage a look, check their calendar for upcoming locations, and keep an eye out at any big events or food truck gatherings in hopes that the Aloha Shack makes an appearance.

Mahalo, guys!

Gotta say been many times but consistency has been lacking.  Staple I used to get was Goldman's hotdog and it is still 9 but almost half the size. sorry not acceptable see previous pic and today. On fence if I'll be back.

I gotta' tell you that the highlight of this place were "the best fries in the universe." Seriously, that's what they're called on the menu. And my two kids and I ate every single one of those fresh-cut, skin-on, perfectly-fried slivers of awesomeness. Which was good since my kiddos didn't care for their mini corn dog nuggets and tater tots that looked like what I reheat at home, and my sandwich was just so so (it felt peppery just to be peppery, instead of it being a necessary part of the taste?). The place is super laid back, the waitstaff were cool, and there's no beating a place with a variety of beer and TWO different outdoor seating areas. The front one is pretty typical, but the back patio with a view of the Monon Trail is a sweet surprise. I'll be back for a beer and a snack on a nice day with friends, just won't be aiming for a full lunch or dinner with the kiddos here again.

It's like stepping into a swanky restaurant from 40 years ago, and that's the good part. The food is so-so -- the chicken is not seasoned at all, but it is crispy and moist. The sides are OK. But it's a fun place -- especially with a group. As long as you don't go for the food.

We used to love this place. Ordered a medium pizza, 2 orders of chicken fingers, mozzarella fries, and pasta e fagioli soup. Total was over $42.00.  The pizza was very thin...way thinner than we remember. Like, you could call it thin crust it was so thin.  I guess they must be really cutting back. The chicken fingers were ok - not worth $7 for 4. The mozzarella fries were fine. But the "soup" was terrible. It was literally tomato sauce with over cooked pasta and beans. No broth at all. I've had this soup many times at many places as it is one of my favorites, and this...just , no. Way too expensive for sub-par food.

Let me say that this is a very westernized Asian fusion restaurant. If you want really authentic Asian food, there is plenty of other places but Buddakan definitely caters to Americans. 

I went for restaurant week. Honestly the food was pretty good, even if not "traditional" so I don't have any complaints about that. The bbq pork was delicious, maybe one of my favorite pork dishes I've had in a while. My main complaint is the portion sizes- for the price, you really do not get a ton of food. I went for restaurant week lunch and got 4 courses but my party went out to get second lunch after. 

The pork belly bao was alright at best- nothing special but it wasn't bad either. The Kobe beef slider was also pretty good, but again, not incredible anyway and the portion is tiny- I've had real Kobe steak in japan and it was ok a completely different level, the "Kobe beef slider" is basically slightly nicer ground beef. The dip sum donuts are basically fried dough covered in sugar- while the sauces are interesting, it's nothing mind blowing. As I said earlier, the bbq pork is the only thing that stood out. 

Service was okay until we got to dessert- for some reason it took 30 minutes just to make the dessert. We were basically ignored for half an hour while everyone else got their entire meals. 

Overall, food was pretty good but service and portions were not. It was worth going once for the restaurant week deal, but would not return.

This place is more of a 3.5, probably closer to what the average review is. The beef noodle soup is pretty good, it will warm you up on a cold rainy day and remind you of when your parents grounded you and the only good part of the day was eating beef noodle soup. The sushi is also decent- they have lunch specials for that as well.

While it may be a little pricey, overall the food is fine and the seating is readily available so you can easily go with a big party.

Dinner last night with a friend.  We both agreed that the place is really cool as far as decor.  Our server, Denise, was excellent.  I started off with a whiskey ginger, which was quite tasty.  We shared an order of the dry rub chicken wings, which were delicious.  For the entrees, I had the shrimp and grits.  My friend had the pork belly tacos. The shrimp and grits was tasty, but I was disappointed at the portion size. Also, the grits were a bit more soupy than I prefer.  My friend said the pork belly tacos were just okay.  He would not order them if we go back.  The overall experience was very good.

Bravissimo!!  New York style pizza with as many toppings as you want for one low price. How could it get any better?  The toppings are excellent and fresh. The choices are plenty. $7.87 for an 11" pie.  The crust looked like it would be too thin when they were making the pizza, but the texture and thickness turns out New York style.

Stopped here a few months ago with my family to celebrate a birthday. We liked the décor of the restaurant with the paper lanterns hanging throughout the entire space and some cool art work on the walls. 

Service was friendly and prompt. Was hoping for more depth in the Tan Tan Ramen and Tonkotsu broth, but overall not bad. The sushi and takoyaki were just okay. No real standout in any of the dishes we had, but not the worst either.

This place had been open a week when we went for a weekend dinner. I'm writing an honest review in the hopes that it helps my next experience be 5-stars. 

Hosts were all fantastic, even sought us out to tell us how much longer it would be for a table and make sure we had gotten a drink. Love the Ms. PacMan and other video games in the entrance and there's a pool table in the back (I wish there was skeeball but that's like wishing there was a unicorn). Decor is cool, but they need more concert posters to balance out the expanse of wall space. Surprisingly, the noise level was acceptable. Tables are well-spaced so you're not going to be rubbing against other diners as you eat (like at Refinery). 

My boyfriend stood at the bar for 15 minutes and was pretty much ignored by all 4 people behind the bar. He claimed they avoided making eye contact. I went in. I caught the eye of one bartender fairly quickly, he greeted me, and took my drink order about 5 minutes later. After 10 more minutes I finally had my cocktail and boyfriend's beer. Nice beer selection, I was delighted with my Major Award cocktail. I love bourbon, egg white cocktails, and A Christmas Story. Really great flavor. 

The covered patio area is very pleasant. That's where we sat while waiting for our table. I wish there was a firepit for those cool nights. 

Our food came out in an acceptable amount of time but I was disappointed in the portion size and quality when compared to the price. I had the rabbit and dumplings, $24. There were 2 biscuit-style dumplings which tasted fine, and then there was shredded rabbit and copious celery with some slightly undercooked potatoes. The lima beans (one of my favorite veggie beans) were nowhere to be found. I thought it was possible they could've been pureed but the flavor and texture of the stew made me think it was not so. It tasted fine, but I have had better rabbit, better stew, and even better rabbit stew at or below this pricepoint. I was still hungry after finishing my entree. 

He had the fried chicken. The pieces were so small they may have come from a bantam. Seriously tiny pieces of chicken. They were also very dark brown...which would've been fine had the people to either side of us been eating chicken of that color...theirs was much lighter. For his 2 sides he chose cornbread and tomato rice. I tried both. The cornbread was good and the tomato rice was AMAZING. That was the star of our food experience. 

Our server never checked on us until our last few bites, when she asked if we saved room for dessert or just wanted the check. Water had run out awhile before this. We were very near the server's station and she walked by us probably 20 times. Unacceptable to not have an additional check-in or more water brought. 

To recap...nothing was terrible but the only amazing things were my cocktail and the tomato rice. Experience was "fine". A-ok in the truest sense. I appreciate the unique menu and what they're trying to do. I'm sure that things will only get better as they're open longer. 

We spent as much as we did the last time we went to Rooster & the Till or Ulele. Except unlike the other 2 spots, I left feeling hungry and that the service was subpar (except for the awesome hosts).

This should be a 5-star review, however, the guys behind the bar (who I hesitate to call "bartenders" or "servers" because they don't seem there to do either) are lost causes. So if you come in and sit down and no one even talks to you for 10-15 minutes despite the fact that they're standing right in front of you pouring beers or washing glasses, persevere! Flag them down! Call out! Wave your hand! The pizza (and beer) are worth it. 

There is seating for about 30 people inside (maybe 6 tables plus stools at the bar), and there's a courtyard outside too. If you have a group of 10, please don't come here. The kitchen is small, and you'll take up, very literally, ALL of the chairs. If you do decide you simply must come here with a larger group, have the decency to get only one check...for the sake of the other customers. 

I love the selection of beer here. There are 7 tap handles so there's pretty much always 6-7 draft beers to choose from. They're all microbrews or eurobrews. The offerings are balanced. It's not going to be "4 IPAs, plus 3 others"...look forward to a stout, a porter, a pilsner, a hefeweizen, an IPA, and maybe even something barrel-aged or a sour. BUT WAIT...THERE'S MORE! The entire back wall and about half of another wall are lined with beer in bottles and cans. Again, all craft and euro. Many hard to find. 80% or more are cold and ready for you to drink with your pizza or carry home to drink. Not a beer drinker? Well, there's craft soda and juices for you. 

There are games for the kids (or adults) to play. There's a community bulletin board. There's a stream of neighborhood people passing by (this is Tampa Heights, so anything goes). 

The pizza is FANTASTIC! This is my favorite pizza in Tampa, hands-down. The crust is chewy and the perfect thickness, lightly sprinkled with Italian herbs, lightly bubbled and not soggy. The sauce is bright and fresh-tasting. Toppings are evenly spread and there are plenty to choose from. The cheese is gooey and strings nicely. My go-to is: meatballs, fresh basil, spinach, and ricotta. MMMmmmm!! It's tastes like a lasagna pizza. My boyfriend gets sausage and pepperoni...he's a traditionalist. 

The entire menu is pizza or baked wings. If you have a limited diet for whatever reason (vegan, celiac, dairy allergy), this may not be your cup of tea. 

There is a record player but the needle has been broken for the entire time I've lived in Tampa. The flatscreen TV sits on top of the record player. I'm a sad panda.

I was more than pleasantly surprised when we ordered take out dinner on Christmas Eve, to eat with a family member at nearby Abington Hospital. 

We ordered through their online ordering platform, and appreciated that we could select a time for pick up. 

I ordered Dan Dan Noodles, which were delicious. I loved the spicy sauce, minced pork, and tender noodles. 

Others in our group ordered General Tso's Chicken and Mongolian Lamb - a hit with everyone. 

My husband ordered a mango salad with his GTC and I grabbed a bite - so refreshing and bright!

Pick up was super easy, and the folks behind the counter were super nice and helpful. Will definitely come back to Ban Ban when I'm nearby!

A delightful, simple, upscale cafe that I have been eager to check out for a few months. 

My partner and I went on a nice long walk and found ourselves around the corner from Res Ipsa - so we stopped by for a casual breakfast yesterday. The breakfast menu is tiny - maybe 5 or 6 options total - but the focus and clarity in food is clear.

I ordered the Avocado Toast (on the web menu, not on the board at the counter) and my partner ordered the breakfast sandwich with sausage. My avo toast was simple but packed with flavor.

The coffee was also delicious. Can't wait to come back - maybe for dinner :)
Charbroiled oysters are ok, not better than dragos or superior seafood.  The service was great and the crawfish were

So, the only thing I've ever gotten from Haydel's is king cake. So I can't speak to the rest of the pastries.  To be honest, I'm not the biggest fan.  I'll take Randazzo's or Caluda's over Haydel's any day. I just find Haydel's cake too dry and icing/sugar just off.  Don't get me wrong, I'll still eat it. It's king cake. after all.  Just not my first choice.  It does help that Haydel's is a but cheaper and partnered with UberEATS tho.

I came here with my SO for a dinner before meeting some friends for a birthday night out.  We decided to get a few small plates to split.  We got the sausage w/ cornbread and poached egg dish, the roasted cauliflower w/ pickled carrots and cucumbers, the parmesan frites, and the grand slam risotto.  The sausage was a pork sausage and was very good, and the cornbread and poached egg with it just made the dish rich and rustic.  The roasted cauliflower was, well, roasted cauliflower; and the pickled carrots and cucumbers were an interesting surprise - I still can't decide if I really like it or not...  The parmesan frites were fantastic - perfectly cooked and seasoned too perfection.  And the grand slam risotto was the bomb.  The risotto took place of grits, and it came with poached egg and fancy pork (I can't remember exactly, but I think it was pork cheek and another part of the pig), and the whole thing was just a very sophisticated (VERY) grand slam breakfast platter.

Came here on a Saturday night for a friend's birthday celebration dinner. So I'll say the only thing that I enjoyed was watching the firework candle that they give to the person having the birthday, but even at that, it took them 2 tries to get it right because the first try the fireworks were shooting in the chandelier so they had to get another one because we didn't have enough time to take photos because of the server having to adjust everything because the shooting fireworks. Even at that, while we were waiting for the second candle to come out, it took them forever while ALL of us were waiting with cameras. They had no sense of urgency. We waited about 10 min before the server came out again with the candle. 

Food wise, not great either. I ordered the Alcapulco poke bowl, full size and a dynamite crab roll. The alcapulco bowl was filled with WAY TOO MANY BEETS and too many peppers. It made the bowl pretty much not good to eat. I just picked at the tuna, which was overcooked, and ate it. Dynamite crab roll was decent but not exceptional. 

Also I ordered the SLAMgria. This was where the worst part happened. The guy running the drinks from the bar delivered the drink, and when he brought t in front of me, his hands were shaking and it dropped ALL over my pants. He didn't acknowledge or say anything about it either. The drink is pretty much a coronarita but with a bottle of champagne. But the bottle had already poured out all in the cup. 

Overall, I tipped for generosity. Should have wrote a letter to them how terrible they are.

I ordered the Panéed Chicken Over Crawfish Linguine with fried chicken instead of grilled chicken. It didn't taste good at all, pasta was very dry with little to no sauce. Other than the food, the waitstaff was very friendly and the restaurant was very clean. Also, the complimentary valet parking is a huge plus.

Meh.  Service was not great.  Slow, uninterested.  I ordered the biscuits and gravy.  Despite a generic description on the menu, it was so spicy, I couldn't eat it.  It took several minutes to flag down our server to get something else.  I went for the French toast next.  Not bad, not great, just average.  Same for the breakfast potatoes that seemed like lumpy mashed potatoes.

Hubby got cafe au lait and a breakfast pizza.  Our fault for not asking about the size, but the pizza was 12"!  Weird that it wasn't a smaller personal size.  Pizza was ok, a bit dry.  We assumed there would be tomato sauce or gravy on it, but it was sauceless.  The only moisture came from the cheese and eggs.  

If you're in the neighborhood and don't have another place to go, it's ok.  But next time, we'll try someplace else.

Omg,  the waitress was sooo sweet and the pizza was delicious!  I love the thin crust and the fresh toppings especially tomatoes provide this pizza with a bright and savory fresh flavor.  Oh and the drinks are AWESOME!  CHEAP AND STRONG!

So unfortunately I preferred the spot next door to Blue Crab and here's why: they are so overpriced and I just felt like the food lacked seasoning. There are a lot of tables very close together. I tried the crab and corn bisque and it was rather bland but after hooking it up with some tabasco and salt and pepper I was cool with it. We decided to try the seafood platter and what a mistake that was. The fries are sooooo bad lol. I know they are trying to push the home cut thing but yeah, they can let that go. Just save and get frozen because they were soft and mealy. The shrimp was the best thing on the platter; very large! and the fish wasn't crispy enough. the stuffed crab lacked enough spice to be featured in a cajun restaurant. I just felt like I had chewed but was unsatisfied. Maybe the grilled entrees are better. But it is too pricey to be dissatisfied when you can get seafood at plenty places here.

I stumbled across this place and decided to grab breakfast. The hosts texts you when your table is ready and I though that was pretty cool. I had a Bhaskar player that was pretty cool only thing is the space is extremely tight. But that's part of the Chartres street restaurant appeal. The strawberry mimosa was great and the waitstaff was pretty nice. only drawback is for such a basic breakfast and meal experience it is a bit pricey.  Overall an ok experience.

I wanted to love this place so bad. Grilled cheese is my type of food! I got so excited about the Mac n Cheese grilled cheese and built up my anticipation for it. Unfortunately, after the first bite, I was pretty let down. The Texas toast bread was nicely toasted but the Mac and cheese lacked any flavor. I think I should have spiced it up with some hot sauce. We also ordered the grilled cheese donut, which was good, but nothing spectacular and not worth the $4.
I'm not a big fan of the Honky Tonk bars in general but this place really sucked. The music was terrible and the beverage lineup left a lot to be desired. Overall much better options on Broadway.

I'm on the fence here. I enjoyed my grilled cheese w ham and tomato, the garlic parmesan fries with basil aioli, all for $9.25, but i felt horrible for the next 18 hours. Was it the food...hard to say. The food was heavy and greasy, thats to be expected. I needed to nap for 2 days. The price was a bit high in my book, but the food was pretty good. I guess if you have to sit on the curb to eat, that should be taken into account when pricing the food. $9.25 here should not be on par for similar product from a restaurant. Would i go back? Not right away, but I may try again some time.

When am I'm in this area I always stop here I really love that Tampa has this sort of place where you can indulge in all different types of food and beverages it's really the new adult hangout spot and sometimes when I'm in Tampa that even have yoga classes outside seating indoor seating bathrooms everything from BBQ to Sushi popsicles and sweets if you're in the area and looking for something different something new give this place a stop through

So much fun I'm a regular now good for groups couples even has space for teens at night great music lights up  makes for and even more eye catching night.  Really put a spin or the golf game I found myself bored with golf now I'm back at it and they have a bar and food indoor game areas if your into video games all around I still come and love it. Worth the money.

I came here with family to celebrate some birthdays in their new location. We were sat in the back room which was nice so our toddler wasn't too disruptive. I wanted something light to eat since it was mid afternoon and had a hard time finding something in their menu which is burger heavy. I ended up ordering a cup of chili which was pretty average and didn't have any crackers on the side which it could have used. I also ordered the green monster float which of course is why you go to Fitz's. It was delicious but floats are a pretty simple item. This is a fun place to take people who are impressed by big floats but I definitely don't come here for impressive food.

Brasserie continues to hit it out of the park every time we visit! You can always win going to a Gerard Craft restaurant and each one has its own appeal. We usually visit Brasserie on a special night out or a romantic night for my husband and I. The outdoor patio seating is always lively, the food is fantastic, and the service is top notch. Our visit last night was no different and we walked away full and happy. Can't wait to come back again!

We live in Maplewood and love supporting our local restaurants! We decided to try the Muddled Pig during their anniversary party which they advertised an all you can eat Hawaiian buffet and pig roast. We paid $30/person with three people and were greeted with leis when we arrived by a friendly staff. Hawaiian themed cocktails were included which were rum runners and mai tais. They were heavy on the alcohol which I'm sure some people appreciate but for us it was too strong for dinner. They seemed to have a good selection of local beers on tap though I'll have to come back and try sometime. As far as the buffet goes it was disappointing for the price we paid. They had a pig head and whole snapper for the main courses but didn't have much else for $30/person. They had some fruit, basic rolls, rice, fried green beans, and only one option for dessert which were tiny parfaits. They did have coconut shrimp which were delicious but the rare tuna I tried was chewy. The service was really attentive and I've heard great things about their burger special during the week which I will likely come back and try but I wasn't impressed with the buffet.

This is a great new diner addition to Cherokee. It's small and cozy with table and stool seating. We were seated in the last four top around noon on a Saturday. The menu is small but full of traditional dishes but with a twist. The waiter talked me into starting with the apple turnover which was delicious and had a generous amount of icing. After that I had the half order of biscuit and gravy with a side of cheesy hash browns. I don't love American cheese slices but the hash browns were pretty good. The biscuit and gravy was great with a generous portion of gravy. The only thing i would love even more is to have more coffee options. I know drip is the diner way but a simple cappuccino or latte would be a great compliment to my meal. Will definitely be back for breakfast again!

I'm not big on the ranch craze unlike my husband I don't add ranch to every meal so I'm probably not the best judge to begin with but I wanted to try Twisted Ranch since it was a new concept to come to the St. Louis dining scene. I've been here a couple of times during the Taste of Soulard. The first time I tried it I had a Mac and cheese with a hint of ranch that was really pretty good. This year they had a grilled cheese with ranch paired with tomato soup. The grilled cheese was just ok even though we were the first ones there. But the tomato soup was really yummy! I'm sure it had some kind of ranch in it as well but it was really tasty on a cold day!

The food is actually pretty good.  The salsa is bland but if you ask for the spicy and mix in a little of it then it is pretty good.  I was SHOCKED that they charged for extra salsa with your chips.  What kind of Mexican restaurant does this?  I would not return simply for that reason.  And we weren't told of the charge until we got the check.

Visited this restaurant after doing an Xscape room a few blocks away.  This place is a feast for the eyes.  The decor and atmosphere is awesome.  I loved all the elements that make this place unique, such as the way the tables are set into railroad/trolley tracks, the simulated light poles and wiring, the barrels on the ceiling, the unique light fixtures and even the bathrooms carry the theme throughout.  The service was excellent.  Our waitress gave us a run down of the menu and helped us select a few items we were torn between.  Over all the menu has many  items with clever ingredient combinations.  

Tried the:
Hummus platter
Veggie and margarita thin crust pizza
Ribeye grilled cheese
Pulled pork sandwich
And pulled pork and pineapple appetizer

Everything came very well paced out, drinks and refills were done promptly. My honey got the watermelon margarita which was delicious. Overall good food and a nice place for some familiar and some not so familiar food items.

I went here tonight because of all of the good reviews - and cause I was craving sushi.  Now I've read the reviews here and they are all based on the fact that we're land locked here in St. Louis.  My review is based on my country wide sushi experiences.

First, I was greeted by such a friendly staff.  They seated me next to the heater (it was so cold outside) which I greatly appreciated.  I asked for some green tea and it came out nice and hot and was refilled all the time I was there.  

I ordered three rolls and was given the complimentary soup and salad - both of which were a-ok.

The sushi arrived and it was pretty good, but I felt that there wasn't much fish in my rolls. What fish was in there was good enough, but certainly not the freshest tasting sushi I've ever had.  

Overall a nice dinner in a great atmosphere, just not the best sushi I've ever had.

For the all you can eat all you can drink Sunday brunch, I'd give 5 stars for the drinks and 3 stars for the food.

First the fantastic, the drinks.  Before we went I read that you could get all you can drink mimosas and bloody marys.  I did not expect them to give each person who ordered that an unlimited supply of bottles of champagne!  They also gave us a couple shots of vodka to make bloody marys.  They had 8 different types of juice for the mimosas!  I ended up loving the mango and sticking with that.  They also had a couple bloody mary mixes and all the fixins.  If you feel like getting hammered early afternoon on a Sunday, this is your place.

Honestly, the food was just ok in comparison.  You can opt out of the drinks for a cheaper price (although then I don't see this brunch as worth it and you don't get access to the seafood).  They have a variety of brunch foods and desserts.  Really nothing special, but not terrible either.

You can choose to sit inside or outside, but since we went in the summer, it made more sense to eat inside.  There is a wall of T.V.s if you want to catch the game.

Service was slow and the meal didn't feel worth the cost.

I'm actually surprised by the amount of people who have given this place a good review.  Now, I'm not saying the food was bad, but I think this meal was worth $20, not $50.

First, the service was very slow.  There were only a couple other tables there so I'm surprised it took us so long to get our food.  It got to the point that my husband and I started trying to calculate how long we had sat there for (we estimated about 45 minutes) before getting our entrees.  It took a while to get our salads and then after they took away our salad we sat and waited for our entrees.  That put a damper on the evening.

We both got caesar salads.  They were fine, nothing special, but the croutons tasted like they came out of a bag.  Again, at this price point I was pretty underwhelmed.

I got the Grouper and my husband got the Chicken Parmesan.  I think the Grouper was fried.  That surprised me.  However, everything tasted good.  The Chicken Parmesan was also good, but the penne it came with tasted exactly like something we could make at home with dry noodles and marinara sauce from a jar.  

I guess the theme of the night for us was underwhelmed.  I'm disappointed, because we live right across the street in Feather Sound and was hoping for a good place close by.

Feel healthy and eat delicious food all at the same time.

This is another place I ventured to thanks to Yelp. I saw that many Yelpers visited and raved about this place, so I had to check it out. Pro tip: make a reservation. The waitress seemed to visibly relax when I told her I had a reservation. It's a small place, so calling ahead is a must. (Random fact: I called six times to finally get through to make a reservation. It's up to you about whether you are that obsessive, but I seriously think we may have been turned away if we didn't have that reservation. Note that we were there on mother's day, so it may have been busier than normal).

I went with the roasted chicken plate. I know, I struggled with whether I should order the fried chicken or not, but in the end, I decided my health is important and non-fried chicken can still be good. I chose cole slaw and mashed potatoes for my sides. I also ended up taking home an appetizer of wings for my husband (after reading Dave W.'s review, I couldn't come here and not get them). 

This is going to sound super weird, but I ended up enjoying the chicken more cold the second day. It is so much food that I took half the chicken home and ate it the next day for breakfast. I found the chicken a tad dry at the restaurant, but when I ate it later it was super tender. It might have been that the portion of the chicken I saved was a juicier part, but I absolutely devoured that chicken the second day. This brings me to a conundrum with this review. I would probably give the chicken I ate at the restaurant four stars, but the chicken I ate at home was definitely five stars worthy. I think the chicken wings are going to have to tip this over to five stars. They were plump, juicy, and I absolutely loved them. Also, I'm not sure how healthy their food is, but I definitely felt like a health superstar eating it. 

I think this is a gem in Safety Harbor. If you're in the area, this is a place that should be high on your list.

Disappointing food.

I had high hopes for Carrabba's. My husband and I have accumulated a ton of gift cards over the past couple of years and it is finally time for us to start redeeming them. I do appreciate that Carrabba's gift cards also work at Bonefish, Outback, and Fleming's, since they are all owned by the same parent company, Tampa-based Bloomin Brands. Honestly, what sealed the deal about which restaurant we went to came down to two factors: I wanted free bread and to go to a restaurant I hadn't been before. Although I adore Fleming's and Outback is always a solid bet, we have been to the ones closest to our house and I like to try new things. I knew there was a Carrabba's in Clearwater and I read they serve complimentary bread before the meal so that sealed the deal.

After reading some yelp reviews, I saw that it can get busy on a Friday night (thank you yelpers!). To avoid one of my all-time pet peeves of waiting to eat, I went to their website right before we left to put us on the "waitlist". This basically put us in line before we got there. When we arrived, it was packed. They told the people in front of us that it was about a 15 min to 20 min wait. There were people sitting outside and inside waiting to be seated. When I checked in, they found me on their online system and told me it was about a 20 minute wait! This was exceptionally frustrating, because the people in front of me obviously did not check in online, because they had to give the hostess all their information, and they were told the same wait time. I asked the hostess the point of their online system and she vaguely said that it would help us skip a couple people. This did not fly with me, but after a couple minutes of stewing, my name was called that our table was ready! It took about five minutes and that was without me even expressing my frustration with the online system. It really works! Crisis averted, they get a star just for that.

The bread came and at first I thought, why is it such a tiny loaf? Me and my American bias. It was warm and the size turned out to be fine, but I'm not in love with this bread. Usually when I think about carbs I enjoy I immediately think, I need some of that now (like Newk's croutons or Maggiano's bread), when I think of Carrabba's bread, I just think meh. My husband got the Chicken Marsala and I got the Johnny Rocco's salad. The Chicken Marsala came with either soup or salad so he chose a Caesar salad. It was absolutely drenched in dressing. He didn't enjoy it, because he wasn't a fan of the dressing. He felt it was off. I thought the dressing was fine, there was just so much of it! He also wasn't a huge fan of his Chicken Marsala. He felt like the sauce was just poured on the chicken and there wasn't really a marsala flavor to the actual chicken. The garlic mashed potatoes were fine. I was also disappointed by my salad. I enjoyed the grilled shrimp and scallops, but the handful of cheese was an odd presentation. It was like someone just dumped cheese on my salad and called it a day. It wasn't a very impressive salad to me. At first I thought I was just being picky, but the next day we went to Grill One Sixteen and I had a house salad to start and I realized that I do know when I love a salad and the Johnny Rocco just didn't do it for me. It needs something more than just scallops, shrimp, a smattering of roasted red peppers, and cheese. It is definitely missing something. 

I have a feeling everyone else here has their favorites, probably a pasta, something breaded, or a super cheesy dish, and come here for that. Unfortunately, this place just doesn't do it for us. Lucky for them, they are packed with people, so I'm sure they won't miss us.

Solid meal, but I'm not racing to come back. 

I might have liked this place better if it wasn't called Toast. I would think that by being named after toast, their bread would be fantastic. There is a quote on the wall that says toast is a name for grilled cheese, I'm totally paraphrasing, but that's how I remember it, but even a good grilled cheese needs good bread. The bread here is just the normal loaf you can get at Publix. It was fine, but nothing remarkable. 

The meal itself went along those same lines, it was fine, but nothing remarkable. I got a Greek Omelet with hashed browns. I liked the tzatziki sauce that came with it and I smothered the omelet in it. Otherwise, there wasn't that many piece of gyro meat and the pieces that were there had a manufactured look to it. I put ketchup on the hashed browns to give it some taste. Overall, I wasn't upset with my meal, but I don't really care to repeat it. 

The service was prompt and there weren't that many people there at noon on a Friday. This does seem like a good place to bring young kids, because it was pretty casual.

Ok experience that didn't blow me away.

I've actually wanted to try Capital Tacos for a while. I had heard great things so I had it on my list of restaurants to try. My friend threw out a last minute invite that she was driving up to Wesley Chapel to meet up with other friends at Capital Tacos and the draw of hanging out with them and Capital Tacos made me say yes - taking an impromptu trip to Wesley Chapel is much more rare now that I have the baby, whom I left with the husband.

Since it was an impromptu trip I didn't get to do the research I normally do before trying a place - i.e. look at the menu and read Yelp reviews. We were late so when we got there we immediately went to stand in line. I got to the front way too quickly and decided in a split second on the Hen House bowl. 

It came quickly which was good, but the actual meal didn't wow me. All the flavors kind of fell flat and I found the pieces of chicken a little small. I honestly like Chipotle better and it pains me to say that because I feel like Capital Taco is an institution. I talked to a friend after who loves Capital Taco and said that it could be that as they grow they become more uniform across the locations and lose some of their charm. 

The space itself is bright, open and inviting. It is a great place to bring a family. 

I wish I liked my meal here better. Being that Wesley Chapel is so far for me, I probably won't be back any time soon. I still have to say I didn't dislike my meal, I just expected more.

Still a great place, but different options than the last time I wrote a review.

Since I was here with work colleagues, I didn't want to be weird and take pictures. Now I wish I did, because it would have helped me remember the names of all the dishes. I decided I had to update my review, because I mentioned a fish dish and vegetable korma and neither of those exist anymore. Never fear, they still have a great variety of delicious dishes.

We got here at 11:45 a.m. on a Wednesday and there were a couple spots to the left side of the gas station. There isn't a lot of parking, but there isn't a lot of space in the restaurant, so I feel like it evens out. There is parking right in front of the restaurant, but I always just park in the side parking to be on the safe side.

The naan is warm and addicting like always. It is fluffy yet sturdy which I like. They also had lemon rice when I went, which was delicious. I got seconds of that. Beyond that, I'm now avoiding meat so I tried all their vegetarian dishes (which is indicated on the name card). There was a great variety - I had at least four different hot dishes. 

After sampling all the vegetarian options, I opted to get more lemon rice, naan, and a white curry. If you aren't vegetarian, there are chicken dishes. I was surprised there was no other type of meat other than chicken, but since I wouldn't have been able to eat it, it didn't matter to me.

With 20% tip, my meal came out to about $15. Service was quick and they kept our waters filled the whole time.

This is still one of my favorite Indian buffets in the area. Yes, it is weird that it is attached to a gas station, but it is legit.
Bagels are small, cream cheese was ok. Very pricey for a bagel with cream cheese! It was very confusing when I went in as well! Too much going on everywhere!

We are regulars at Myung Ga. Went last night and as usual the food was outstanding! Lisa told us that they had Korean fried chicken. We ordered that and all I can say is watch out KFC! The Korean chicken had a candy like crunch to it which was awesome. You must try it! The banchan was really good too. Love the corn in some cream sauce and the ham the best too.  My other fav is the potatoes.  I can eat them all day! We also got the BBQ set for two kalbi.   Nicely grilled awesome flavor!

My conscience binds me to preface this by saying that this experience was over a year ago, so maybe this situation would never happen again with current staff. But I still need to get this off my chest. 

My senior year of high school I was voted "Least Likely to Write a Petty Yelp Review." So when you read this, try to keep that in mind. 

Like most mammals, I love food. But I also really love good customer service. Now I'll admit that I've never been to Italy, so if an authentic Italian dining experience involves trying to treat your mother to a nice dinner, and not even getting offered a glass of water while sitting in a 1/4 full restaurant for 15 minutes while the wait staff chats amongst themselves, then maybe I'm just not cultured. Heck, maybe I was overwhelmed by the authenticity of it. Maybe Italian culinary experiences just aren't for me. But this place definitely isn't for me.

I dislike chain restaurants and went here only because my father kept pestering me to go.

I was about as basic as it gets. The menu says you get one complimentary basket of chips with one complimentary bowl of salsa, but they brought me a refill and didn't charge me. That was the highlight.

I ordered a steak quesadilla. They brought me a chicken quesadilla. It was ok. I ate it with refried beans that probably came from a large can.

The service was ok. I needed a minute or two with the menu. The server gave me like ten. 

Prices were what you would expect from a chain place. Charge as if you're an authentic Mexican cuisine dining experience, right?

If you want the predictable taste of semi-real Mexican food that's dumbed down so Americans will want to eat it, this is probably the place for you. Otherwise, spend some time on your Yelp app and find someplace near you that doesn't say "multiple locations" next to it.
It's good but not great bbq.  Smokehouse bbq was the best but I think they went under.  Dierbergs had their ribs but not sure where think are with them.
It's not easy to find tasty vegetarian food in this city, and I love the food here! Their kottu is sooo good! The Esmeralda salad is nice too, just the added tofu, too salty, but overall 4 stars!
Came here after shopping. Recommend the lamb and salmon here. Everything is in a big portion, too much for a girl

Formosa Seafood Buffet is owned by the same people who own 8 China Buffet, just up the road.  It's shiny and brand new right now, and obviously meant to go head-to-head with Journey for the higher-priced buffet market.  The theme, at least in the room we were in, was astrological; there was a large image of a bridge of stars and two Chinese mythological figures on one wall, and smaller plaques of the Western zodiac signs around the room.

The waitstaff are of more varied ethnicity than I'm used to at an Asian buffet, friendly, and fast-moving.  Upon arriving at our table we were greeted by a woman with a cart of various soups such as congee (a personal favourite).  There were also a few carts of dim sum items going around.

I feel bad that we weren't hungry enough to do the place justice on this trip.  The food was varied and kept refreshed, and there was a long counter with a wide variety of sushi rolls.  My personal favourite for sheer novelty was what appeared to be kappa uramaki topped with slices of kiwi fruit and a dot of strawberry sauce on each slice!  The buffet items were about what you'd expect; fried items, main dishes, various shellfish, roast meats, salad, pastries, fruit/vegetables, and a large cooler table full of ice cream.  The food that we tried was good and kept refreshed, with a good balance of buffet standards and more unusual items.

It was very good overall, and we're definitely going to come back on a day when we're a little hungrier!

We have been coming here for years.  Unfortunately this time we decided to eat the buffet in the restaurant rather than our normal takeout.  Let me tell you....we were extremely disappointed!!  My stars for takeout is the opposite for dine in so I had to go in the middle.  The food on the bar was far from freshly made.  There were 6 in total customers eating in on a Thursday night.  Those in my party (3) felt like we were being stared down by the male owner.  Instead of stairing at customers AND playing on his phone he should have been clearing tables and getting fresh food out on the bar.  If he needed to he could have asked his fine in customers what they were insmtereatinf in having on the bar that was fresh.  As far as unclear tables.....there were four that we could see from our seats and our plates continued to pile up since we continued to try to find good fresh food.  The lady 'owner' kept going to the kitchen and yelling in what we believe to be Chinese.  Did she think her customers could not hear her in the empty restaurant?!?!  Even though I do not speak Chinese I could tell it was an angry voice and she was not happy much less that she was yelling at her kitchen employees..... as everyone could hear her in the dining room. I do not think I will EVER come back here and eat in.  The takeout has ALWAYS been excellent.  There were constant take out orders while we were there which proves my point.  Stick with takeout!!!

Have you ever been trying to kill a spider and end up trying to light it on fire and soon your entire bedroom is engulfed in flames and all that can cross your mind is "This was a mistake"?  That's how I feel about this place.

Mother's came highly recommended, based off the fact that it was apparently featured on a Travel Channel food show of some sort.  And let me just say...why?

Rant begin:

So I don't mind the line.  The line is not an issue.  Some people may think that a line guarantees quality, but having lived around the LA food scene I can very much guarantee you it does not.  But as lines go, this wasn't a long wait, even if it looks like one.

I don't mind that service was a little weird.  Now no one working here seemed like bad people, but it's a definite culture shock coming from California where service is apparently super friendly and then in NOLA it's just sort of "I'll help you, but I don't have to like it".  Nothing for me to get angry at, just a bit of a shift.  But that's still not the problem.

The problem was the Ferdi Special.  I'm going to be here possibly once in my life, I'm going to go for the Ferdi Special because it's at the top of the menu and it is a specialty of Mother's.  Therefore, this is them saying "This is our best effort, enjoy".  And...

Who in their right mind looked at "Au Jus" and seriously thought "Hey, you know that runny, wet sauce people like to dip roast beef sandwiches into?  Hear me out, let's puddle it onto the bottom of the plate and let the sandwich just sit in it.  Just let it swim in those juices.  Just let that bread soak it all in and disintegrate before your very eyes.  Because that's what sandwiches were made for.  They were made so you can't pick them up."  Like I'm all for open faced but sandwiches are literally made to be eaten with hands what is this?!  It's a mess.  It's a mess of salty meat.  Was it good?  No.  Not even close.  I came in wanting a nice hot meal and I get half of a sandwich and it's not very good.  And just so I'm clear, this wasn't a bit of soggy bread.  This bread was full on paste by the time it got to me.  You CAN'T pick it up, it just crumbles into goop.

And part of me wants to give them the benefit of the doubt and say "Well maybe they have good gumbo or something" but this was the specialty at the top of the menu!  If I went to an actual mother's house and said "Cook me your specialty" and they're all "Okay, let me make you some delicious meatloaf" and the meatloaf comes out and it's made of paper towels and used syringes you don't get a chance to offer me some soup.  You had your shot and squandered it.

I give them two stars because there is still care and hope for this business and obviously someone must like it, and the food wasn't inedible I suppose.  But the Ferdi Special is not the way to go.  Some other reviews might disagree, but they lie.  That's right, I'm calling you out.  You know you're valid opinion?  It's wrong.  You have a wrong opinion.  and your favorite movie isn't very good either.  I'm feeling salty.  It's probably from all the salty meat.

Reduce a star for the noise level (I feel like that old man in black socks and sandals, Turn down that damn noise and get off my lawn...) and one star reduction for the douchebag factor (holy crap if I saw one more backwards baseball cap and basketball jersey I think I might actually beat a guido).  Outside of these two factors this is a cool place to watch a game if not going into the stadiums especially if you can score one of the seats out back.  Victory beer hall is the place to be (or outside of it preferably).  Did'nt try the food so cant really comment but it seemed the usual ballpark fare.  Night out with the boys before or after the game and this place is spot on.

HipCityVeg is ALWAYS packed. Whenever I attempt to buy lunch here, the line that leads out the door discourages me and I usually end up next door instead. 

Just my luck, the other day when it was raining, I walked by and the place was NOT crowded... So it was finally my chance!

A girl with an iPad greeted me and took my order. I got a mushroom burger and some sweet potato fries. I told the cashier my name and she rang me up. The mushroom burger was pretty delicious, and I love me some sweet potato fries. Lunch was great - but a little steep on the price tag: $14. 

Usually I spend $7-$8 on lunch in Center City, so as much as I want to come back, I won't be doing it too frequently.

Every time that we've ordered from Vic Sushi Bar, I've always ended up standing around by the door, trying to respect the space of all the other customers who were waiting for a table. Vic's is THE smallest sushi bar I've ever been to, it's ALWAYS packed whether it be early evening or late night, and the sushi continues to hit the spot everytime! Seriously, Vic's is one of the better sushi bars in Philly.

Their rolls have very little rice, with big cuts of fresh fish - which I absolutely love! We like to order the specialty rolls (go big or go home), and I think we've had almost every one (without crabstick) on the menu. My fave is the Naruto Roll - the cucumber is so refreshing! Other good rolls: I-Roll, Ocean Brother Roll, Lover Roll, Romantic Roll, Spider Roll and Shrimp Tempura Mango Coconut Roll. 

The service is decent - there are 2-3 sushi chefs, and the cashier is really nice. Even though we usually have to wait an extra 20+ mins for our sushi, the cashier recognizes that and usually apologizes to me for the extra wait.  

Thank goodness for Lent, because when the bf can't eat meat on Fridays, we get to have sushi from Vic's!

Stopped their on our first day in town. The menu on the website had so many interesting items we wanted to try. When we got there the real printed menu was very different.  After a little discussion we decided to stay. Waitress was Very understanding if we had decided to depart.Very glad we did stay. Had gumbo, fried seafood platter and several other dishes. The server who I don't remember her name but she's been there for 11 years treated us so well and took such good care of us since we decided to stay after the menu issue. The food was very,very good and we would return in a heartbeat. We did speak to the owner about the online menu issue but he has a good following and I don't think he grasped the importance of keeping his on line presence up to date. If it wasn't for the server's initial chat with us we probably would have left. The owner was a really nice gentleman who was fun to talk to. I guess he has a following because of his place being on diners, drive ins and dives. We were not aware of that nor would it have influenced our decision.  Go and enjoy! You won't be sorry. And I'll change to 5 stars when he fixes his online menus.

Wow. Abominable last night. Cafe Adelaide, you lost me.  Probably the worst service I have ever had and being a service industry vet, I can be pretty forgiving. I actually felt bad for server X last night, who was utterly incompetent but very nice but wow, worthless.  Coupled with the amateur service we had last time, I'm thinking it is not a one time fluke.

Host told us to sit in the bar area. Sat there for 15 minutes ignored. Went to ask host if we should go to the bar and order, he said no, that our server would be right with us. We waited another 15 minutes before receiving 1 menu for 4 people. Placed drink order and waters for all.  Cocktails came 20 minutes later, no water. Appetizers took close to an hour and were ice cold when we got them. Had to ask for bread. Never took entree order, although we expressed wanting to, so we decided to cut our losses and go to La Boca for dinner, which was STELLAR.  Two rounds of drinks and appetizers took us two hours at Cafe Adelaide! And the food nor the drinks were as good as I remember. This time the sauce on the crab pound cake tasted like Campbell's cream of mushroom and there was hardly a speck of crab to be seen. Flatbread was burnt.  You get the point.  Not worth the time or money.

While I can't speak to the dine-in experience, I consider myself a "take out regular" as China King II is my go-to delivery every few weeks via the Yelp Eat24 setup.

Our New Year's Eve meal was simple, consisting of orange chicken, fried rice, crab rangoons, and pork egg rolls.  Our order was to our door in 45 minutes and within the window quoted.  Food was piping hot and delish as usual.  I can safely say that I've never had a bad experience with delivery from CKII.  

I regularly make substitutions on delivery items and they are always honored - I even asked for them to knock on my door and leave it at my doorstep once (I was having a moment) and they obliged no problem.  

The only reason for 4 vs 5 stars is simply that I've had better Chinese delivery in town when I lived downtown.  I have no reservations about CKII being my go-to delivery in our SoBro neighborhood based on the consistent delivery and food quality.

We have been coming to Elena Ruz, perfectly attached to Black Circle, since they opened.  The owners are tremendously nice and have worked to make improvements since day 1.

-outdoor patio seating created separate from the brewery patio creating a family friendly food option
-newly expanded menu adding new sandwiches and (my fav) a larger, app size of the mariquitas in addition to numerous dessert offerings 
-BRUNCH. To be reviewed soon*
-delivery via total takeout and grubhub

Food I am obsessed with here:
-Mariquitas: paper thin sliced plaintain chips, dried up to perfectly crisp perfection and paired with a garlic oil dipping sauce.  Don't go kissing anyone after eating these
-Black Bean Bowl: seasoned black beans served over coconut rice and topped with that heavenly garlic oil.  So indulgent and so good.
-Elena Ruz Sandwich: this namesake involves turkey breast, cream cheese, and a tasty guava jelly  on delicious bread 
-Medianoche Sliders: With a buddy and want something small to eat? Split an order of these.

It's so exciting to see the growing success this restaurant has had in partnership with Black Circle, and big things are on the horizon for expanded indoors seating, full-service brewpub style grub, and a potential event space.  If you haven't been here yet, get here and support this great local business.

This is the strangest restaurant I've ever been to. 

Every time I come here when I'm traveling I am served a different burger. 
One time I got a hand made burger patties, the next time a little frozen burger patties, the next time a tiny little burger patty. It is random if you get fresh beef, frozen beef, two patties or one patty. 

I hate this inconsistency. The price this last visit was appx $17 for a small tiny burger patty (single), small fries, and small drink. This is nuts for a cheap burger. 

From here on out I'll eat a burger at the restaurant right next door at U'Lele. Yes they are expensive. But for a couple dollars more, I will get an excellent burger and a nice place to sit.
Shitty service and the ice cream machine is always broken. Try to order my fries without salt and am told they are not allowed to do that. Very rude staff at times.
The staff is friendly. The restaurant itself really needs a revamp, but I usually get take out anyways. BEST PHILLY ANYWHERE AROUND HERE!
Over priced, Snooty service, bland food.... I can make better food on a camping stove.

Have frequented one of the other locations quite a few times.  This particular Ott's is a bit of a disappointment. Beer selection and service were good, but the food wasn't much to rave about, and the interior still feels more like a Friendly's. Lots of TVs, non-descript decor. Nothing much to draw us back here, sorry.

Don't be deceived by the outside or indoor decor, the food here is excellent and made-to-order. I did not phone in advanced and watched the two cooks make everything fresh. 

Drunken noodles are pretty unparalleled, and the portion size is significant compared to some of the other Thai competition in the area. If you're looking for something more sit down in the area, I would either suggest Erawan Thai Cuisine or Jasmine Rice. However, if you want something cheap and are looking to take away, definitely give this place a shot.

Solid set of ribs, the sauce is excellent and has a good heat and tanginess to it. They can give you small plastic containers if you want more sauce. $12 for a half rack. Although the ribs were flavorful, they were a bit dry. Will stop by again to try the chicken and rib combo. This location is ideally for take-out, as it's literally a small shop with like 4-5 seats next to a window. I would also try their house root beer and bourbon pecan pie. All of it is rock solid and affordable.

Great service. I'd avoid anything ground beef as it seems like some items like the hard shell tacos or enchiladas are pretty highly processed and heavy. None of the items on the combo tasted fresh or made on site. Chile relleno was pretty much impossible for me to eat. Would recommend the fajitas or anything that is cooked right then and there.
The prices feel steep but honestly the food is very good. Presentation is super clean and the food is flavorful. We walked out feeling full in a good way and not bloated.

I was in town for a bachelorette party with a group of 11 other girls.  We mostly hung out in the upstairs area and on the roof deck.  The band that was on when we first got there wasn't that great, so we moved to the outdoor area where there was plenty of seating for all of us.
When the next band came on a few hours later, we moved inside.  We purchased jello shots (which were absurdly expensive, but hey... all in the name of a good time).  Since it was late afternoon, all of us were a little hungry, so we ventured to the small food bar in the back corner of the upper floor.  I purchased a BBQ pulled pork sandwich for $12 and it was awful.  It was covered in an overabundance of BBQ sauce. I was starving at that point so I ate it anyway.  Other girls in my party purchased hot dogs ($6) and pretzels ($9) and they were equally disappointed.  

We definitely had a good time.  The second band was great and played lots of good music to dance to.

Just a few notables:
No cover or wait to enter on a Saturday afternoon which was great. 
The bathroom on the upper level was so hot and stuffy... hotter than it was outside ( and it was 90ºF outside).
A lot of the reviews said the staff was not friendly, but we had no such issue.
The food on the upper floor was awful.

Foie Gras Soup, lets be honest, we've all heard about it. Regardless of your feelings of foie gras (either in beliefs or in taste) you will love this soup.  It's great. 

Eggplant, this is what I ordered.  Very good, but it was no foie gras soup.

Gruyere popover is obviously a favorite at the table; crispy yet fluffy on the outside while being warm and cheesy inside.  Not too over powering in flavor but just right.  

Risotto was outstanding.  This was my favorite of the night.  The black truffles mixed with the crispy flake of what I believe is a parm crispy and some sort of squash puree (note i'm totally guessing, i just went to their menu online to confirm but their menu on their website is not up to date).

Meatloaf, mixed reviews, it was good but it wasn't meatloaf.  It was more of a light meatball with foie gras as the binding.  It was a nice take on meatloaf.

Lamb, I'm glad this is what i ordered.  I love lamb. It was very approachable.  The lamb itself was small, but perfectly cooked.  The lamb belly was new to me.  I liked it.  It's different than porkbelly but has all the same characteristics of 'a belly'. 

Gnocchi, very light and fully (as you would expect it to be) we ordered this for the table as we all wanted to try it.  I'd suggest the same to you.

As for drinks, the wine pair is the way to go.  I'd rather not think about what I want to drink.  For the actual wines themself, let me know what you think.

As for cocktails - la vie en rose was outstanding.  I took a picture of it so check it out.  I'd order that again anytime. 

Sbraga is going to be a great great restaurant.  It's new to the market and has lots of eyes watching it.  I think for the four course dinner and wine pairing it is an excellent deal with some quality ingredients and preparation.

I went to the deck at the Moshulu for the first time this weekend with a few friends this weekend. I wanted to love this place since it is a 5-minute walk from my house but sadly I didn't. The view and décor are great, and I love the Mushulu but the deck was a major flop. We sat down at a bar seat and asked a waitress if we could order drinks and a few apps and she went to get us menus. She came back a few minutes later and told us they were no longer serving food on that deck and we would have to sit on the other side. We went to the hostess on the other side of the deck and asked for a table for 4 and she told us it would be one minute. After about 10 more minutes we checked back in with her to see how long it would be to decide if we should get a drink at the bar while we waited, and she again told us one minute. Another hostess then went to seat another table that walked in after us, so we checked in with her about our table and she told us that we weren't on the list. There were about ten open tables, so we were very confused about the wait. Finally, the second hostess came back and walked us to our table but after a few minutes we found out we couldn't order appetizers in this section and that we would need to find a table in the top section. We had asked if we could sit in the top section when we first walked in and were told no so we were all confused. Basically, every single person working at the restaurant except for our waitress seemed like they didn't have a clue. Our drinks and our food were great but not worth the hassle we had to deal with to get a table.

Most of my airport restaurant reviews start this way:  If you're stranded in an airport ... well, sorry, this one is no different.  It's at least got nice decor and amazing service.  My husband had the pepperoni flatbread, the pizza was clearly not that homemade, but passable.  I had a burger with bacon and mushrooms, the burger was not fresh, but the fries were decent, and overall, the accompaniments to the burger salvaged it.  My amazing bartender served up a nice cold Patron shot for me (double for $2 more, the devil), but service is great here, food is passable, give it a try, it beats the other places in the Reno-Tahoe Airport.

My husband and I dined here for Thanksgiving dinner.  The restaurant is beautifully appointed, but the three hostesses (yes three) were enough to knock a star off.  We arrived about 20 minutes early for our reservation, as we tend to do, and I tell them that I know we're early.  Almost every other restaurant hostess has seated us immediately with grace.  These three looked at us and said in a condescending tone, one said, "it will be closer to your reservation time."  She told us we could wait in the lounge and she'd come get us.  The lounge was nice, but after waiting nearly an hour - and over half an hour after our reservation, I nicely asked our bartender how long the reservations were running.  She made a phone call, and then snotty hostess number 2 appeared.  This was off-putting, when they said they would come get us.  But our server was absolutely wonderful. She was gracious and noticed as she opened our bottle of wine (fabulous wine list) that the cork was soaked with wine, and immediately replaced it for us, with apologies.  She made the whole evening special.  

The bread is delicious, soft and tender.  The crab cakes were good, not the best I've ever had.  The bean and chorizo soup was just okay.  I had the tenderloins with wine sauce, so tender and delicious, the mashed potatoes were good, and the green beans were fresh and cooked perfectly.  My husband had the Thanksgiving dinner, which he loved.  For dessert, the pecan pie - quite possibly one of the best ones I've had, the right amount of sweet, the crust was flaky with a savory taste.  Oh, and the wine list is wonderful, a little of everything, including our favorite Paso Robles wine.  

Don't be put off by the snotty hostesses, why restaurants have "pretty" girls greeting others, I will never know, if you're not going to be nice, pretty doesn't do much.  The food and the rest of the service here was wonderful.

Out of all the Vietnamese restaurants in town this is the place I go again and again.  If you can make it through the menu that is the size of War and Peace.  Way too many things on the menu, but if you look close they are all the same ingredients.  The vermicelli bowels are what I usually get 143 is what I got today.  The spring rolls are a must and the vermicelli  patties are great.  The place is lite like an interrogation room and the art on the walls is okay, throw in some ugly silk flowers you got the place.  
The food is great and the service is not bad.  The best thing is I can eat before going shopping at Lee Lee's.

I have been a patron of Tania's for the last 20 years, I have gone morning, noon and whenever, I have ordered their food for catering and so on.  Today I am not a frequent flyer, I miss the days of Rudy behind the counter asking a million questions, sweating profusely, and telling me of his latest business ventures ( one of which was real estate, plastered all over the wall were his listings).  Today the food is still good the restaurant is run down, there is no Rudy, service is slow.  I will still go by and get food but the soul of the place has gone down a deep black hole.  The soul was one of the main reasons for me going there, now is gone, so sad.

I have been eating here fro years, and now I can't even think about going back.  The food has been going down for years, but I kept hoping it would get better, because it is so very close to the Loft.  The moussaka is has a bitter after taste, and the baba ghanoush is scary bad, inedible.  I don't know what they are doing, but I will not go back for a while.

I have a Love, Love,  and Dismay with this place.  With the change of the menu from 147 pages to mere maybe 28 pages, it does not help me pronounce any menu item any better, so I still always order by number.  #7 is a Vietnamese Sausage spring roll 4 to an order which is my new fav, my favorite noodle bowel is now number 76.  It's still straight up prison/retirement home/interrogation room ambiance.  The service is remains terrible, and after 30 or 40 or 50 times there is no acknowledgment of knowing me from the last time I came in or friendliness, no Cheers moment (which is the dismay), maybe I want it, maybe I don't.  There is always the same disgruntled old man waiting on us, or forgetting on us (I go and get most of what I need), the same owner who sits up in front, doing what I don't know, it is nothing but consistent.  Here is the real deal I still love the food, it is as close to what I've had in Asia.  Lee Lee's is still one of my favorite places to shop, so it's all right there, a little bit of the world right here at home.  I spent 30 plus years eating street food, just pointing at food someone else is eating and signaling I want the same, this place is not that different.

I adore the fact that they have happy hour everyday from 3pm-close, and that the size of their beers is considerably large. My only complaint is that I wish their male bartenders were a little more polite. I understand that they prefer to serve female customers; that's only natural.
