But you can't ignore and be rude to your male customers, seeing as how they're just important for business. That being said though, CasaBlanca has great happy hour food and drinks that I have fallen more and more in love with since I moved downtown.

I met some cousins for lunch here the week before Thanksgiving. Loved that it was counter service... no pesky dividing of the bill. And my falafel sammich was HUGE and tasty. 

My cousins got gyro and a falafel plate (which doesn't seem to be included on the online menu). Everyone loved their food. Service was good and the bread was amazing. And they had good quality iced tea which is becoming a rarity these days. 

Decor is minimal and make sure to park legally.

Y'know when you feel dumb for showing up at the airport hungry? Because you know the food will be terrible and expensive...WELL, on concourse B you have a tasty (if expensive choice).  

I made a yummy meal out of two sides, collard greens (cooked with out meat) and mac-n-cheese. The collards were nice and spicy, although I added Crystal anyway.  The mac-n-cheese was fine and had some crunchy bits which made me happy.  

Bonus points for fresh brewed yummy iced tea (unsweet, of course). Price was high but you're at the airport so what are you going to do.
Mikimoto is not my go-to restaurant for sushi, but they are pretty good.  And very helpful.

Le sigh I saw that friends liked this place and it was around the corner from where I was parked so I took a chance.

Our server (see Katie A's review) was...a little lost. Pretty much everything we said seemed to confuse him.  The space itself is lovely both inside the restaurant and the attractive patio I peeked into

I got a cup of the seafood gumbo and it was mediocre at best. I also had a special salad which was grilled romaine with shrimp. The salad was OK. Some of the romaine was overcooked and it just made me long for the superior version at Boucherie.  I sampled a couple of companions items. The ceviche wasn't...it was a cold seafood salad. The roasted okra was amazing. The rest, meh.

So maybe next time I'll try the bar instead

I stopped in cause I read a friend of mine recommended the food. I ordered a burger and it was ok. Not bad but not good. I guess this is what you get when eating at a diner. Service was great, people were very nice but the burger was less than impressive.

Went back this Sat, course little later then usual, tried the nutella CREPE, with bananas & Fresh cream..OMG!! Light -unusually , & of course the coffee & service was great!! always a plus. Can't wait to go back try something else .Love it!!!

This Pizza joint is like the Late night  Lorenzo's in Philly~ but in South Jersey. For your pizza craving after bar, club, here it is. Been a staple for many years in NJ, burned down awhile ago & they rebuilt it. I wasn't impressed with the consistency of pizza or employees.  Just like one Yelper said, the workers are quite rude, Who cares about  service, take it or leave it, Always come back -based on reputation. I went few times, the slice was little bigger, but what it made up in size, did Not make up in taste or grease. Ewphhh..nothing spectacular..not my 1st or second choice., let alone 3rd choice. Go back, I haven't..just not good choice. Plenty of others with average or better quality in service & pizza.

Not being from Philly, I normally wouldn't venture in here, But its right  next door to one of my Favorite Brunch spots. My brunch buddy wanted to go in, she frequents in here . We walked in, I was SO amazed!!!! It had alot of things, own deli, made to order salads, sandwiches, etc.. I perused around , found some gourmet rosemary flat-bread -would pair good for my get together last week. Ended getting this gelato as well.They have fresh produce to frozen section .I was quite impressed with selection & not typical run of mill items. The help were very attentive, the place was clean and organized. If I lived in the area, this would be one would frequent, without a doubt!!! Great little place!!!

I went with friends to this fun place and it was great. The 3 story tall driving range is fun for beginners and experts of all ages. Even 4 year olds can play, although maybe not score too many points they enjoy hitting the ball, ha. 

The free to use pool tables are nice on the lower level, and there is even an elevator for those who don't like stairs. The food is priced about right for this type place, and is presented very nicely. 

Once you enter the front doors, they ask if you have been there before, if so you are in their computer system and if not they direct you to new members to sign up. It's about $5 for the membership, and if you lose or choose not to bring your card each time, it's a $1 fee to replace your card each time, ha. 

The lines for new member sign up are long and take about 15-20 minutes to complete. Then you must get into the members line and wait another 15 minutes for them to get to you, and assign you an area to play. So this is a slow process just to get started. Seems like it could be stream lined and made to move must faster. 

Once you get to your assigned playing area there are several golf clubs you can choose from to hit the balls that automatically drop out from your tee off green area. The lounge couches you sit in around a table are very low to the ground, especially for tall or large people people, haha. They're about 1 foot off the floor. The table is decent sized but not really large enough if you have more than 4 plates of food brought out at a time, such as for group orders.

It took our server a while to finally get to us and get our drink orders, then took a while to receive our drinks. Although she was friendly, and nice, service was slow. Then it took a while for her to get our food orders, and took a long time to get our food, as we started with appetizers, which we thought would come out quickly, but they did not.

When our hot wings finally arrived and were quickly dropped off at our table, I realized that we did not have any silverware or any napkins at all. And we all know how fun it is to eat bone-in wings covered in sauce with our fingers without any napkins. So we all had BBQ fingers until our server finally returned and I asked why we didn't have any napkins with our messy finger foods, so several minutes later she returned with napkins and silverware.

Prior to returning with the napkins and silverware, she went ahead and took our main food orders, which after waiting so long for her to return I had forgotten what I even wanted and used my BBQ covered fingers to flip thru the menu and find my order. Then let the server take the BBQ covered menu with her, lol. 

She had also finally dropped off our drinks at this time too, refills were slow to come, so either order extra drinks on your first order, or drink very slow. 

Half of our food came out and we ate it while the rest of our group waited another 10-15 minutes for their food to arrive. how nice to watch others eat, and finish while waiting on your food to arrive. The food was tasty and good sized portions. Just very slow to arrive, and it comes out in random intervals. 

Guess Top Golf thinks since you might stay 2 or 3 hours to play, that they can serve you very, very slowly. To the servers credit the place was pretty busy the day we were there, but still you would think they would have plenty of servers to get people their drinks and food in a timely manner. But you would think wrong, lol. 

5 star rating for the fun golf and other available games for a family.
1 star rating for the very slow service.
3.5 star rating for the taste of the food.
So 3 star rating average is what I give this location.

I agree with Kevin's sentiments below. The food definitely has good flavors but at least a couple of items' prices are a bit steep. The tacos are tiny. You need at least three, but most likely four to make it a meal. That will cost you more than $10 if you get a water or drink to go with it. We were also a little surprised by how little Kimchee you get for $2. We are talking about liquid-sauce-to-go size container for these. I have no service or flavor complaints and I think the pricing is fair for mobile food trucks where I'm expected to pay a bit more for convenience, but for a stand-alone store, for the same money, I could always mosey down to U City Grill and get a big bowl of Bibimbop with a much bigger side of kimchee.

Maybe it was just too hyped up from its Washington D.C. reputation, but I was underwhelmed by our brunch buffet dining experience.  The service was good, the ambiance/decor was sooo nice, but the food wasn't too remarkable.  Not bad, but not memorable either.  Their donuts had the texture of cake (like box mix cake, not cake donut) and the items that I did want seconds of ran out quickly.

This is a small place but it's still good for groups of 8 or so. My group of 3 stopped by in hope to get a quick bite before calling it a day on a Saturday night. We were quite excited to find that the restaurant wasn't packed. After 15 minutes passed no one even gave us water nor attempt to take our orders when there's clearly servers standing around not busy. Instead they took the order of the table next to ours that arrived 10 minutes or so after us. When we notified a server, another server returned 5 minutes later to take our orders in stead :\.. Reason why it is one star because the food wasn't great with the beef being over cooked and the service being too slow when there's at least 4 servers dealing with no more than 8 tables with 4 tops. Boost the service a notch.

Was really looking forward to trying this place. We are here on vacation and we waited about 10 minutes at the front counter and no hostess came to us. We had to go look for the hostess for us to even try to get a table. When we finally found her,  we asked if we could be seated and she got an attitude. She then proceeded to go to another group that was behind us in line and take care of them first. Her attitude was unprofessional and utterly rude. This is very unfortunate and unacceptable.

Yes...there a many places other then Yakatori Toilet
You got to be fricking kidding....Was here long enough to leave!!!
Visited yakatori boy because of all the great reviews and rumors of celeb sightings
This place is a urinal..As we entered the building with alot of excitement we were 
greeted by the over whelming smell of bleach....The unfinished concrete floor had cracks and divots...The table and chairs are old and smelled of smoke,  The place is very dark ...our guess was it was to hide all the other inperfections.It reminded us of an old basement night club with the smell of smoke, bleach and split beer
We were seated at a table that wobbled because of the uneven concrete floor.The table was dirty and smelled so the server tried to wipe it clean but the cloth she used smelled of old dirty bleach.
The only chardonay was canyon road.. A cheap, sweet $3 bottle 
Unable to order because of the smell and condition of the restaurant my wife and I got up and left like the place was on fire...
Not sure why all the reviews are good..
Take my word and do not waste your time to park to visit this  toilet
The absolute worst place we have ever visited

wife and I loved this restaurant....would go once a week...but after last night we are going to stop wasting our money. The service is consistently getting worse.
Waited 15 minutes last night before walking out. No one ever greeted us. Waiting 10 to 15 minutes just to get noticed is unexceptable. The servers have no idea how to sell the menu or even explain it...They do love fighting over the regular customers though. The owner Amy is clearly lacking any official restaurant experience and it reflects on the entire dining experience. The food is average to begin with although we do love the sushi. We won't miss the terrible service. There are plenty of other places to to spend your hard earned money
One note, its seems they focus on take out not the in house customers

This place lives up to its name and the awards they display. I got the beef brisket noodle soup. The hand made noodles were great and went down easily.  The beef brisket had a great authentic  flavor and the soup well seasoned. The marinated egg was alright, the flavor wasn't really there and it was very overdone.

Overall this is a must visit place with a great variety of noodles with a great price. The staff are attentive and the food comes out fast.

The kimchi was great, was a bit sweet for my taste, but good. I came here twice with my friends. The gogi special is a must have and it is delicious. The fried seaweed wrap worked very well with the snowcrab and tuna mix. On the other hand the yangyum tongdak (wings) were disappointing. They were just regular wings fried and tossed in a sauce (not marinated like real yangyum wings). This would've been a 4 star review if I didn't find hair in my bibimbap.

I love ramen and my search brought me to this place. It's a quaint little place right next to Milk-Boy. Usually it isn't too crowded and they have the interior set up with booths and a Japanese-esque counter. I have to say this is one of the best places in the city.

First and foremost the noodles were great and cooked to perfection. The broth for Gates of Hell was flavorful and filled with umami. (Only wish it was spicier, but that's just me) The egg was well marinated. So far the best marinated egg I've tried.
The pork belly melts in your mouth, bursting forth with flavor.

My friend got the vegetable ramen. Presentation is a delight to the eyes. The assorted vegetables melded well with each other and cooked properly. The flavor of the broth is very delicate and light. For some people it might be too light. So for those that eat chicken I would recommend getting the Fried Chicken and add some to the vegetable ramen.

The fried chicken is a dark meat fatty chicken. The crispy shell gives way to a juicy soft chicken that is well balanced and isn't overpowering. Perfect combination with the vegetable ramen.

The Tako-Yaki was alright. The inside was a bit underdone, but still edible. For those that aren't into soft textures or a slight slime like texture I wouldn't recommend it.

Overall the price is reasonable, the food taste as good as it looks, and the setting is relaxing. Defiantly one of the best locations to eat some good ramen to fill you up.

Out for one of our anniversaries for dinner and it was wonderful as usual. We shared a Caesar Salad and it is a bit different from the traditional. It is topped with crispy prosciutto and fried capers. I loath capers but fried completely changed the texture and taste and I actually liked them. Who doesn't like prosciutto? The fresh bread and flavored butters are great starters. Main course Filet and Flemings Potatoes. I did a shiitake rub with Gorgonzola on my steak. I also loath mushrooms but drying them out and using as a rub is so good. The Flemings potatoes were slightly burnt tonight but burnt cheese is also good cheese. Dessert I got a pecan chocolate pie concoction it was out of this world. Hubby got the lava cake after it was remade with out pistachios it was also to die for. Service was great even with the pistachio boo boo. Always great food and much easier on the wallet than Ruth's Chris. Very nice evening out after a trying week.

They have been my favorite for years. I always get Beef and Broccoli and Crab Rangoon's. Not sure what's happening at PHO. Last two times I have not been happy with the food. They have changed vendors or brands or their recipe. The flavor is off somehow. I thought the first time was a fluke that's why I tried one more time. Looks like I'm on the search for these two dishes elsewhere.

Worst service ever at Maggiano's. Our server was new and I can let some things slide because of that. We sat down he was friendly. He took our drink order and got those and then took our dinner order. Then we never saw him again. I never got my salad which was the main part of my meal. Spinach salad with a piece of salmon and a side of spaghetti. I got the side of spaghetti with the salmon on it. Husband got his entree of four cheese ravioli. We never got bread and we never got drink refills. The server never came back. My husband had steam coming out his ears. I wasn't worried about the salad we just weren't paying for what we didn't get and I was full without the bread, but the bread is one of my husbands favorite parts of the meal. I had a bus boy get me a manager and I was very nice about it. The server had too many tables and we were forgotten about. Our meal got comped and the manager brought us out a piece of cheese cake and refilled our drinks. Felt like we were doing a dine and dash when we left. I have never complained to a manager at Maggiano's. I'm pretty easy on servers. If you've been one you are more sympathetic. Our relaxing meal out wasn't.
Still great pizza and hummus. Only complaint. Ditch the pint jar drinking glasses. They are way too small.

So I've been passing this place for a while, and I decide I'm going to go have one of my favorite sandwiches at this location. I have never been to this one and I walked in at 7:48. I was on the phone with my son trying to figure out what he wanted. The guy behind the counter interrupted me to let me know that they are not making sandwiches anymore tonight. There's a neon open sign in the window. There is a sandwich board out front with their specials. It's Saturday night at 7:50. I wonder how long this place will be in business because they just lost mine forever.
 So I decided to call at 7:55 they didn't answer, so I called again. They answered after 10 rings and I asked to pick up a sandwich. They said they were closed do I asked when they closed on Saturday night. He said 7. Then said I mean 8. I said it's not 8 yet. He then said they stop making sandwiches at ten till.

The culmination of our unexpected overnight stay in Nashville and it was not bad at all. We all had breakfast and, while it was not spectacular, it was certainly good enough to get our engines started. We had Eggs, over easy, with bacon, Spanish Scramble and a Spinach/Mushroom Scramble. Add a side of bacon along with coffee and tea and you get a good meal from an airport restaurant.

Clean environment, nice view and attentive servers. Not too bad at all.
Outdated, smells musty and well the food is blah. Roast beef is dry , chicken parm dry, food over priced. Wings were decent. Won't be returning

Price: Expensive, but better than the kbbq in chinatown. 
Food Taste: Galbi is Satisfying and delicious.
Parking: Plenty in the lot.
People: Asian, hipster. 
Staff: In a hurry, really busy all the time. 
Place: New and modern and relatively big. 

Bottom-line: I would come back, but rarely. If the price was cheaper, I would come back frequently.

Salad bar not labeled at all. Well done Meats were very very salty that I could spit out the grains of salt. The medium ones were not as salty. Meats had good flavor regardless. The we'll done Meats were also sometimes not well done whole other times too overcooked to the point of dry very dry. Cheap for a steak house. Would I go here again, yeah. Plenty of parking nearby. Spacious inside. Clean. I had coconut truffle for desert it was very good but all the other ones didn't look too good. You can order by the pounds or all you can eat. For two people or ended up being like 65$ then u gotta tip. I ended up drinking 4 glasses of water because of how salty the Meats were. Better than I expected in terms of northeast rest

The appearance and the taste of the crepes are very lackluster. I expected a lot better from the place, but I regret spending $23 for two crepes, one steak egg and cheese that was very bland, roasted chicken crepe that was slightly better but not memorable, and 2 minute maid juices. Overall, I would not recommend this place.

Drink was nasty at the bar and expensive. I think it's disgusting the pipes in the ceiling are not covered st all. Food was OK. Only thing about the place is the view but other than that please go somewhere else for a nice dinner.

The boss took the entire office out to lunch for my last day.  I have not been inside a Fridays in well over 10 years.  I was immediately impressed with the layout of this location.  It vaguely reminded me of a hard rock cafe as it had steps that wound around to an upstairs area and that is were we sat.  We got the big rounded booth which was very nice as you can see everybody and engage in conversation much easier in a round shaped table vs. square or rectangle.

i got the pick two and had wedge salad and a cheeseburger...both were above average in flavor and preparation.  

Everybody seemed to enjoy their selections which were a combination of salads, soups, sandwiches, and flat bread.  Prices for lunch range around 12-15.00 per head if you figure in tax, tip, and drink.

DEFINATELY not worth the 40 MINUTES I had to wait. My wife and in laws ordered 1 north shore and 2 reubens. Nothing special, nothing was changed nor did we have any special requests. Waited 20 minutes then inquired on where our sandwiches were. We were told they would be "done soon." Waited another 20 minutes and finally our food was finished. MULTIPLE customers had come in after us ordered a sandwiches and a beer, sat down and was able to finish their food and beer before my order was even complete. All while I got to stand there and watch with a hungry 1 and 3 year old. Will not go back. Go to Capriotti's if you want to be treated like an actual customer.

I agree with the general sentiment that others have shared. Blume is a BEAUTIFUL bar, that certainly is cool for instagram photos and lighting. I don't consider myself a conniseur, but I think the cocktails are fine. I happily downed Purple Rains which I found quite nice. The food is clearly a gap and that becomes very apparent when you realize (as I did) if you make a reservation, that almost everyone there is just there for drinks and much of the venue is oriented that way. I think I was literally the only reserved table when I went on a weekday evening.
Anyhow, the menu was sort of weird in terms of offerings, it seems like a bunch of mashup ideas that just don't work. Case in point, I ordered the Gruyere sticks to nosh on with my drinks. Maybe I'm not sophisticated, but man would I have preferred mozzarella sticks, they were just not good and maybe not even a good concept.
In summary, great atmosphere, fine drinks, just don't count on the food. I have heard they are changing their menu, so perhaps things will come up.

Cool cafe with good free wifi. Plenty of seating place. We could see lot of people working on their laptops and lot hanging out with their friends. 
We ordered drip coffee, matcha latte and their Conductor panini. My drip coffee was ok, but matcha latte had a very strong taste. Didnt like it. Panini was ok too. Nothing special to rave about. Coffee refills are 50 cents. The servers were nice and courteous.  It looked like a very busy evening on Saturday. 
I would go there again to hangout or do my work. But would stick to regular coffee.

Was in the area for an oil change and decided to give Sake Sushi a go. The best part of the meal were the tempura vegetables, which were crisped to perfection. On the other hand, I wasn't impressed with the Rainbow Roll. The rice was a bit dry, and there was a weird sweet flavor to each bite. Not terrible, but there are decidedly better options within a 10-mile radius. And maybe it's ridiculous of me to mention this, but suggested tips should reflect the pre-tax total, not post (as is the case here).

Let me place you in the mood I was in when I walked into Green Eggs. I was hung over, not your normal, a mild headache hung over, I was "how did i get out of bed and why am I supposed to be upright, and most importantly, who drove us here b/c i dont think it was me" hung over. Alright, you got it? that's how I felt. 

Upon walking up to GE it's pretty obvious just how new this place looks. Even though it's situated on a corner in south philly, it really stands out as different from it's counterparts. Walking inside we noticed there was outside seating available but it was like crazy hot so we couldn't do that. When we came in we were greeted by the hostess who informed us there was a 20 minute wait. Seeing as I could barely move, we said that was fine and took to sitting down and waiting in their lovely waiting area. There's a counter you can sit at over here too and it's very nice with cute tiling work. The wait area has two large modern leather couches and some nice light fixtures and I believe hardwood floor.

After a brief wait (less than they speculated) we were seated in the main dining area. The main dining area isn't like life changing its just nice wood tables and chairs, but the windows make the lighting great (although a bit bright for my hang over at the time- sunglasses stayed in place). The waitress was friendly even though I sat debating how my stomach would react to a coffee. And helpful when we had questions. The service area where all the coffee etc comes from has the same nice tiling that the counter top in the other room had which created a nice flow.

I opted for a Short Stack of pancakes with fruit compote and some scrambled eggs. I am not a pancake person, I should let you know that up front. I believe my hang over was what was motivating me for something plain, yet hearty. The pancakes were gorgeous. Like they looked like cake- a real hearty awesome fluffy batter. The fruit compote was also great. The scrambled eggs were a bit dry. but I needed some protein so let's not complain. my friend had south Philly Eggs benedict. pretzel roll. pork loin cut thin. cream cheese. hollandaise sauce. It was simply irresistible. really it was fantastic. and it didn't make me sick- also a big win.

There were a lot of different kinds of people here, which I like to see in a restaurant, families, hipsters, old south philly couples, which to me means the place definitely has draw. I like it a lot, and will definitely be going back in the future. 

Did I mention they have like 3 different kinds of french toast on the menu + a french toast on special- that is a lot of FT my friends and definitely worth the trip!

How Have I never been here? How did we eat only bread and cheese and beer and get completely full? How How How??? 

Well, we stopped in here after seeing a show in the fringe on a Sunday. On Sundays Tria offers what the call their "Sunday School" additions, a cheese, a wine, and a beer (maybe something else too?) at a supremely discounted price, and offers you the chance to School your taste buds in some really awesome things. 

Now I realize I should probably go back and eat something other than bread and figs and beer before saying this, but I feel confident (and it seems other yelpers agree with me) that this place is a win for any type of eats or drinks. Additionally, I think it's safe to say I will be back!

Best fish and shrimp tacos in the city. At first I was hooked on the beer battered version, which has a fluffy and crispy crunch to them. So good. Recently I tried the tequila lime glazed shrimp and it was packed with so much flavor! Now I don't know which I like better. I also love the guacamole. One time I got an agua fresca with tamarind and I thought it would be refreshing but it was a bit too sweet and sour at the same time! I had to let the ice melt a little before I could drink it. I also love that they have Boylan sodas in their soda machine.

It's greasy spoon diner food to eat when you've had a late night of drinking or partying.  It's simple omelets and sandwiches and breakfasts.  It's affordable and right on South Street.  Don't expect gourmet and you'll be happy.

Let me first say, the place was crowded when we got there, and it was just starting to get cold out, so we took the first table we could get and it was outside.  It was so cold!!  That really affected my dining experience, but at no fault to the restaurant.

That being said... I ordered the Sidecar Burger which came with delicious fries.  The burger itself was cooked perfectly and had a slightly spicy Cajun sauce on it.  There was also a small salad, so I did not leave hungry.  Still, I must say that the Royal Tavern and Good Dog are still the top burgers I've tried in this town.

My boyfriend had the grilled cheese which also came with a mound of fries and a salad.  They had Russian River beer on tap which reminded me of home.  

Overall it was a great experience, except for the cold.  I have the same problem with this restaurant that I have with most good restaurants in Philly, it is just too small to accommodate its fans.

As far as bruncheries go, Green Eggs is a worthy contender but definitely is no K-O. In a NoLibs Bruncherie Boxing match it surely go the distance (full number of rounds). 

As an avid brunch go-er, I've grown tired of the off-the-wall french toasts and giant portion size gimmicks. I do still love me some brunch, but I've long ago stopped being impressed and dazzled by dessert atop french toast and heaping mounds of average breakfast food..

With that said, the food is A-OK but nothing to write home about. I do like their extensive benedict options as I am a fan of those hollandaise doused, running egg smothered, heart attacks. Only downside is sometimes their over easy eggs come out borderline over hard. :( The specials board usually has something that is worth trying. In general, the food is cooked well, seasoned well, and is fairly tasty, Plus, their coffee is pretty good.

Brunch waits are pretty outrageous. I don't think GE is worth the wait, however, I would happily jaunt down there for a weekday or early weekend breakfast.

Servers are incredibly personable but a little slow if they're busy.

In all fairness, if I could, I would give good old GE 3.5 stars.

I figured out why this place is called Blanco - because it's Mexican food for white people. Nashville is home to many authentic Mexican and taco places and if you're looking for that, please skip coming here. 

Many friends of mine attended the opening last week and raved about their margaritas and appetizers, but this place was extremely mediocre.

The margaritas weren't bad, but they weren't good either. The queso and guacamole were bland and had no flavor. The menu is terrible and is pretty much the same exact thing no matter
if it's in taco, enchilada or bowl form. I also don't like that there isn't an A La Carte menu and you can't purchase items on the side.

The carnitas tacos and black beans were good, but our rice was cooked like risotto....
Mexican rice should not taste like risotto!!! 

We enjoyed our waiter Chris, and this location is convenient if you're on Broadway, but truly it is for tourists and if you're a foodie or know what real Mexican food tastes like, do yourself a favor and go somewhere else. Chuy's and Bartaco are chains and they're way better than Blanco.

This is just a place for true Philadelphians to take tourists as real Philadelphians don't frequent Pat's or Geno's... they go to Tony Luke's, John's Roast Beef or Jim's!

This is merely a tourist attraction for those who are truly not in the know as to what is the best and where to go.

Typical chain mediocre food with lack luster almost piss poor service!  Everything from beverages not being refilled to waiting for condiments was ridiculously slow.  Ice tea glass sat empty 90% of the visit . Waiter said they'd be back to refill never happened.  Asked for tobasco was offered siaracha not the same! 

Son asked for more bread which was brought with dessert.

East Nashville is full of delicious breakfast and brunch spots, but many of the trendy new brunch spots coming to town come with a high price tag. It was nice to find a good basic breakfast for such an affordable price. I had coffee, pancakes, eggs, and bacon for under $10 and I found them just as delicious as some of the $20 dishes you would pay for elsewhere. My husband had the homefry bowl with several extra add ons (spinach, mushroom, etc) but he did not seem as impressed. So, it seems like the basics (pancakes, biscuits, eggs, bacon) were the way to go. This place is nothing fancy, just your basic diner. But if you are looking for a  basic breakfast, this is your place!

I've been here several times and its not my favorite.

The service is kind of spotty.  The people who work here are generally nice but they really don't have a strong idea of how to be servers.  Filling water glasses, checking on customers before and after food is delivered, bringing out drinks and other food items in a timely manner.....

Something that was a pleasant surprise here - the croisant I ordered w/my coffee (while waiting for my main breaky plate to arrive) was toasted and buttered.  This was a noticable touch to how I was expecting it to be served - cold, on a plate - quite the opposite!  Nice going, Hoaglin!

The food is not really anything awesome.  Some of their breakfast items are recalling desserts.  I love sweets, but the red velvet pancakes and other breakfast items similar to this are a little over the top for me - I would order it as a fun dessert but to have as an entire breakfast entre is really too much sweet.

I think my few visits here confirmed that I can do everything on this menu better myself at home.  It was not a terrible experience by any means but just a little more money than I cared to pay for what I actually experienced and got on my plate.

On the beach, plenty of seating and decent food. There was nothing that really jumped out at me to make this place really special. However if Frenchy's has too long of a wait I would happy come back to Palm Pavilion.

Ordered 3 sandwiches and they messed them up. One wasn't cut in half, ordered extra onions, no extra onions, ordered extra mayo, got no mayo at all... I asked to speak to the manager and he remade the sandwiches and AGAIN couldn't get the order right. You guys need to hire people who know how to read and pay attention to the details. These sandwiches are too expensive for them not to be right. 3 sandwiches with chips & side orders of pasta salad cost $50. For $50 I expect my order to be right. Disappointed. Also they always have a sign in the window saying hiring, so maybe they have a problem keeping quality people. The manager said the guy who made my sandwiches the first time was new. I'll have to try another location.

This is a hidden BYOB gem that I am trying to tell all my I-think-I-know-it-all-Philly-foodie friends about. And now I am telling you.

Let's start with their motto: "Till the fat salmon sings." This sushi joint is funny, creative and colorful. The walls are painted yellow, green and orange, but don't worry - it is dimly lit at night for date dinners as well. Although it is probably only 400 square feet, Shinju has a little Tiki Bar (aka: sushi bar covered in palm reeds) and about 10 tables. The walls are lined with a graphic artist's portrayal of dancing, cartoon-like sushi pieces. 

Anything you get here is going to be delectable. And I don't know what everyone's Genji deal is . . . this is a lot better!

To make your choice a lot easier, I have created a menu for you and your loved ones.

Caitlin's Menu:
Beef Gyoza (Japanese dumpling) to start
Rock & Roll (tuna, salmon, cucumber inside; tempura crunch outside)
M & M (marinated beef inside)
Spicy Tuna Crunch (tuna, tempura crunch, cucumber, tobiko)
Green Tea Ice Cream

At this point of the meal you are converted.

I was starved for lunch and stuck in Northern Liberties. I wanted a quick sandwich to go and soon found my favorite market.

This place is so cute and also clean and friendly. They sell organic products, healthy food and Soy milk as well as all the other normal deli fare. They make their own egg salad, chicken salad and potato salad and you can get any of their sandwiches on gourmet Metropolitan bread, onion rolls and other interesting slices.

They have tables in the sun where you can read one of the magazines you bought (they have all the good new ones like US, Vogue, etc.) and snack on your Kinder dessert. That's right, this market also sells European chocolates and candy!

You really can't beat the location of this place, considering it's right on the beach in Goleta and a five dollar Uber  ride from The airport. I've been here several times and the outside patio is fantastic if you can get a seat out there, which didn't happen for me until my third or fourth visit. Aside from the location and the view, this place is pretty much so so. The menu is predominantly seafood. My last visit, I had the Ahi sandwich. It was very uninteresting. A hunk of seared ahi on a plain toasted hamburger bun, with lettuce and tomato on the side. Nothing to write home about, except for the fact that this is the closest beach front restaurant with a view in flying distance of The central valley.

Holy meatballs!

I love a place that knows what they're good at and sticks to it. 

Their pork meatballs made me think Nonna had come down from heaven and rolled out a batch. And even though the mere concept of a vegetarian meatball is blasphemous, 13 years of Catholic school taught me that sometimes it's good to be bad. They were definitely worth a  couple extra Hail Marys next time in the penalty box. Sitting at the counter even makes you feel like you're in the family kitchen ready to get smacked with a wooden spoon for dipping bread in the sauce. Love it!

Try the meatball sampler. Excellent. The only reason it's not a 5 star review is that $9.50 for 4 meatballs and crostini is just a tad on the high side.

I had the chicken salad which was very good. My wife had the tuna salad which she didn't care for. I also tried the regular hamburger which was fairly good. The cost was fairly reasonable with all the items.  They have a large selection so we will return to try more.

This was exactly as I expected but with fresher ingredients and a great atmosphere.  Service could have been a little better maybe take on a little bit of a team approach it really makes a difference!
Had a regular coffee, Chai Tea Latte and an Old Fashioned Donut on a Sunday morning around 9:30 a.m.  All were good and the price was reasonable.  Service was prompt and the coffee was hot.

I've been here a few times to get sandwiches to go. Its been pretty busy every time I come here so it takes a while to get your food.  Yesterday i decided to try the online ordering. I ordered at 12:00 pm for a 12:45 pm pickup.  When i arrived at 12:50 pm my order was ready to go.  Ordering online was so easy and everything was made as ordered.  I've dreaded comin back here because it is busy and takes a while.  Now that i know the online ordering is so easy and have had a good experience i will certainly do it again. 

All the bread, meats, and toppings have been fresh and good quality each time.  Everything has always been  made correctly and the prices are reasonable.  I haven't found anything earth shattering about the sandwiches but it's a solid, reliable lunch place.

I have been here a few times to try the different selection of burgers and despite them being "gourmet" and try to be a unique selection, they continue to fall short of wow. I have tried the montecito burger and the funk zone burger and it's a meh flavor. The mushrooms on the montecito burger was overdone as the meat was well done despite asking for medium rare. The meat was well done on the funk zone as well as the egg on it was too over done. You barely get a decent serving of onion rings on the side and the fries are just ok. I do not think they are worth the price point as there are other places in town that you can get something with more bang of flavor and bang for your buck.

I came here at 310pm on Sunday when the listed opening hours both online and on the window is 4pm. However, all chairs were folded over the tables and the girl said we would only be able to buy pastries for take away. If you are listed as open until 4 that means you should have full service until then.

I was so happy to see that there was another late night option opening up in Midtown. Plus--they delivery!! This is huge for me! When I'm looking for a quick delivery option I will almost always choose Pizzava since it is local. There are also a lot of unique combination options. The Chicken Alfredo is one of my faves!! The pizza overall is good but not so unique that I feel the need to tell everyone about it. It's affordable and easy and the combos are beyond what is typically offered. 

I've experienced delivery to my home, delivery to a local brewery for a birthday party, pickup, and dine-in. I highly recommend delivery!! It is super simple to place your order online or over the phone. The delivery drivers are on top of it and super friendly! It's always a bonus when the driver can find my front door-it's a little confusing on a house-turned-duplex unit. However, every employee that I have interacted with in-store has been unfriendly, unaccommodating, and unknowledgeable about the menu/loyalty program/etc. It honestly seems like they don't even realize that they are supposed to be providing the customer with service. The most recent visit in-store was luckily saved by the owner's genuine apology for our pizza being almost sent out for delivery to our house. He offered to make us anything on the menu for the inconvenience. (We simply requested a ranch.. Ha!)

Get in on the loyalty program as well! There are actually some good deals. (I just got $10 off my next order, and I only needed 25 points... Crazy!!) The only thing this place is missing is a stuffed crust option. Hmmm... yum yum!

Usually love the service and food here. However, we had a birthday party last night  and the service was very poor.  Waiter had no idea who to bring the food to, or even which side of table had ordered it. We had to grab his attention to attempt to get water and drink refills. Asked for salt and pepper at least 3 times before we finally got it.  We had an issue with one of the plates not being cooked accurately,and the manager resolved it quickly and must have  picked up on the fact service was slacking and assisted more, which was greatly appreciated.  We stood to take some pictures and servers started clearing table with full glasses of sangria.  We would have hung out and drank the wine but party was clearly over when glasses were dumped and pitchers taken away.   We definitely felt rushed.  To top the night off valet dinged the door on the car.   I am giving 2 stars because the kitchen did a great job on taste.

place is gorgeous on the inside, however we waited and hour and fifteen minutes because the host forgot to buzz us... manager was very apologetic and offered a free appetizer... our server was very nice but the food was just not good, in my opinion. it was bland, the pasta was hard , just not a good food experience. the server was great, even though it seemed everyone had plenty tables to tend to, she did a good job.

There's thing about this place and some things I didn't , I got the generals chicken which I figured would be generals tso chicken but it was more like a honey chicken and we also got something that we thought was lo mein but it was called chow mein it was good but wasn't noodles it was just chicken and vegetables with chow mein noodles to put in it which I actually liked it was different , it's just some of the stuff is confusing comparing it to other Chinese restaurants , my other complaint was that the pieces were really big and so you kinda need a knife

How does a Mexican Restaurant not have guacamole!  
This place is definitely needing new management  or at the least re-train the ones here. When we asked about the guacamole we were given some excuse about a strike in Mexico and avacados being sky high right now. Strange how the price is not that high in any grocery store or fruit stand in the area. 
The tacos didn't have any taco seasoning on the beef. Just browned some Very bland hamburger. Maybe there's a strike at the taco seasoning plant.
 My wife went to the rest room and there was no paper towels.  Instead the had stacks of cocktail napkins to dry your hands on. Maybe a strike at the paper towel plant?

We come in around 6pm for the awesome happy hour specials.  The prices are perfect; pizzas, salads, cheeses, and wines all around $5 a pop!  I ask the waiter if anything is gluten free, he checks and there are some options.  Now I ask if a certain mixed drink is gluten free.  He looks at me and says "we don't put FLOUR in our drinks".  Strangely rude and ignorant, but ok, we don't have to try this drink.

I order a red wine, we get a couple apps and time elapses.  We are ready for another drink and a bit more food.  Its 6:45, happy hour ends at 7, and we haven't seen our waiter since he brought the first round.  We catch another server walking by and ask him if he could call our waiter.  I am not kidding you, his response was "patience is a virtue".  

When I open my Yelp app to note the remark (in case I got too tipsy to remember), I notice the restaurant has a check-in offer for $5 off any glass of wine.  This + the happy hour prices account for the two stars I have given this restaurant.  If I could give another half star, I'd offer to it to the SUPER friendly waiter who also waited on me last week at Miss Saigon Bar and Grill and stopped by to say hi.

The rest of my experience was tainted with strange looks and oddly rude comments that seemed to come out of nowhere.  The three of us came out with a mere $50 bill and a sour taste in our mouths.  TWO STARS!

For a quick place to grab a sandwich for lunch this place is great. They come out fairly quickly. The place really prides itself on the local ethos and great sandwiches that manage to be both familiar and unique at the same time.

The dining room is interesting. It is a painting room attached to the room with the food counter. Kinda leaves something to be desired. I liked the concept of the water cooler and jars for glasses but eating in rather than carrying out make you feel like you are eating in a kindergarten art room.
Walked in and was seated.  Then waited almost 15 minutes with no one acknowledging us.  They weren't busy.  We left. Place seemed old and expensive.

I swear I've been having "mediocre restaurant week". Everywhere i've been lately has been "meh". Including this place. Charran's in a nutshell- decent service by fairly friendly if not bored waitresses. Decent food. Could be better but it seemed like everything was just a little off. 

The chili on the chili cheese fries was... interesting. It had heaps and heaps of black pepper in it. I happen to like black pepper, but a few people at our table declared it to be overwhelming. I'd say it was certainly on the verge of overwhelming, but not bad. Their fries and tater tots (where can you even FIND tater tots anymore?!) are super yum. Potato skins are very good also. 

I want to throat punch everyone that says Charran's has the best Philly. LIARS! It was a good Philly, but definitely light on the meat and they use pickled peppers instead of sautéed. What the fuck? I bit into it and got this weird tangy flavor and I was like oh hell no. These lazy bastards gave me peppers out of a jar. HOW HARD IS IT TO SAUTÉ PEPPERS?!? Needless to say I picked all those nasty ass pickled peppers out if my sandwich. 

*sigh* Pickled peppers in a Philly. I call bullshit. 

I'd give Charran's 2 1/2 stars. I'm rounding up because they're local and they have tater tots.

I really wanted to be impressed by Da Kine. I ordered the #12 which is a combination of their shoyu chicken, steak, and ribs, along with a side of rice and macaroni salad. Everything was good, but not great. The meats basically tasted identical because they were all obviously cooked with similar (if not the exact same) sauces. I found myself longing for more flavor variety. My favorite of the 3 were the ribs, because they had a slight char, so they stood out from the others. The rice was rice, the macaroni salad was unlike any macaroni salad I've ever had- still figuring out if that's a good or bad thing. Overall, I enjoyed the food, but was a little crest fallen by the monotony. I'll definitely be back to try the loco moco, though!!

I'm not really seeing what everyone else is seeing in City Fish. Almost everyone at our table felt pretty "meh" about their food. 

The service was good, although our waitress was a little odd. The food took forever to come out, but I'm sure that problem lied more with the kitchen than with her. 

The drinks were questionable. First off, their water is TERRIBLE. Just don't get a water, trust me. The sweet tea was also pretty bad. I actually had to ask if it was sweetened, because I thought she had mistakenly given me unsweetened tea. Same goes for the mojito of one of our dining companions. There was almost zero sweetness to it. Maybe they're running low and rationing sugar in the back? Idk. 

As for the food, we started with calamari. The flavor was good, but it was quite chewy and over cooked. For my entree, I got the Bimini stuffed grouper. The grouper itself was quite bland. It seemed they relied solely on the sauce for flavor, but there wasn't much sauce to go around. It was stuffed with crab (didn't see any), shrimp (slightly tough and overcooked), and scallops (sadly tiny and chewy). Again, it wasn't bad, but for the price ($24) it should have been MUCH better. My husband said he's had better fish at Red Lobster. The two diners that had salmon, my husband being one of them, said that it was a bit dry. Not bad, but not great. My mother in law, who was the birthday girl, really enjoyed her scallops, so at least there was one solid win in there. 

All in all, I was really looking forward to some good seafood and was pretty disappointed, especially considering the price point. Chances are good that we won't be coming back.

Thai food is still very new to me, and I'm not exactly sure if I love it or just find it slightly odd. 

This was my first time trying Pad Thai, which everyone has told me is a good "starter Thai" dish. It was good, but again, I'm not sure I'm totally sold on Thai flavors quite yet. I actually thought it tasted better the next day and doused with a little soy sauce. 

Speaking of eating it the next day- the portions are insane. The beef Pad Thai was $9.95 and I got three meals out of it! And I'm no wimpy eater. Great value and quality for the price. 

The decor is beautiful and the service is quick and polite. 

Although I'm not 100% sold on Thai food just yet, I'm looking forward to coming back soon and trying one of their curries!

Mmm, Nicki's. I've been here twice and both times I've been quite pleased. The service is prompt and friendly, and the food is tasty. 

The first time I had the corned beef omelette, which was good, but wasn't as stuffed as I'd hoped. The second time I ordered the regular corned beef with eggs on the side. Much better, although I have to say, Ranch House beats them on flavor. I was excited to try their homemade bread, but it was just too dense for me. Points for having apple jelly though- this is the only diner I've seen that offers it & I love me some apple jelly! 

All in all, a good diner with friendly service, yummy food, and not too much grease.

Love this place! If you've never tried ethiopian food, this is the place to go! It's a quaint little hole in the wall, but don't let that decieve you, the food is absolutely delicious. I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because sometimes the portion size varies, and depending on the chef, the food doesn't always taste exactly the same.

My review of this place will be simple, the food not that great. I have had many Cuban dishes and I am actually half Cuban so I know good Cuban food when I eat it, this place had lots of Cuban food but what I ordered ( ropa vieja) with rice and beans and platanitos was not that great I have had better food then this place and also the food came out Way to quick for having to make a dish like that witch sounded and alarm in my head. 

The service not bad, the atmosphere is good and the place was not empty or full but had some people and we were seated right away but from what I have heard this place has gone down recently due  to some unknown reasons. 

I might give this place a chance next time I am in town and try something simple like a Cuban sandwich. 

There prices are cheap and that is one good thing.

Huge disappointment. Was really looking forward to trying this place out. Started off with the Baby Spinach Salad. The pickled mushrooms were one of the grossest things I've ever eaten. I like picked peppers, jalapenos, and well, pickles, but I just couldn't handle the cold, slimy, vinegar-y pickled mushrooms. I just stopped eating after one bite.

For my entree, I got the Cowboy Bone-In Ribeye. Fattiest steak ever. It was gelatinous. Just giggly and wobbly and not good. I'm surprised I ate as much as I did (I really tried), but I just couldn't finish it. It was bad. Bad bad bad. And $40. Ugh.

I'm very pleased with my brunch visit to Cask. The decor is modern - there are bright yellow booths in the main eating space and large windows where natural light beautifully shone through. There was a lot of attention to detail in design with with walls, ceiling and floors - modern hipster decor.  

The music was modern with top 40s lightly playing at the perfect volume. The only option for parking was valet.I was with a party that asked tons of questions and the server was kind, patient and professional.

Food:
I had the Buffalo Cauliflower and French Toast. The Buffalo Cauliflower was good, hopefully it's a seasonal item as I would rather try another veggie starter on my next visit. As for the French Toast - it was a large hunk of bread covered with berries. 
Overall great service and positive vibes.

During my visit to the big easy I had Merchat bookmarked as a breakfast option and I'm glad I made it. The space is modern with beautiful large windows facing the street. There is also a hallway space with additional seats. 

Eats: 
I had a french vanilla latte which was absolutely delicious. I also had the apple cinnamon sugar crepe which was okay, if I visit again I'll probably try something else. Good vibes.

The food consists of small appetizer portions and really didn't impress me that much.  Don't come here expecting to be able to eat a full meal as it is just snack size portions.  Nothing I ate really appealed to me and I won't be eating here again.  The beer selection was small, overpriced and not very impressive (seriously no Abita Amber).  They do have a large selection of cocktails.  The bowling alley portion is nice enough but the overall experience just doesn't rate a return visit and I'm sticking to Rock and Bowl for my bowling excursions as it is FAR superior in every way to this venue.

Tip:  You can bring children here so for those with kids this can be a spot where you can drink adult beverages with the offspring in tow.

The ambiance here is just old, dirty, complete DIVE with all sorts of great stuff on the walls from many years ago and the totality of the place makes the atmosphere a complete 5!  Unfortunately the po boys here are not the best in the city but some of the po boys are certainly tasty.  I do like the fact they put several kinds of mustard on some of the sandwiches (as I'm a bit of a mustard freak!).  The portion size here is smaller than you get at most other places so I find it takes at least two po boys to fill me up here.  They also only take cash which makes it very inconvenient.  It is certainly worthy of a visit just to experience the place but it isn't on my regular rotation.

This bar has always been a consistently good place to enjoy yourself and I've been to MANY private parties and events in their upstairs venue over the years.  They food is decent and much better than most of the other bars in the Warehouse District.  They have a lot of tables set around the outside so it can be a patio like experience when it is nice outside and then they have a great balcony upstairs to enjoy for private events.  I've always found the bartenders here to be outstanding and they have always delivered extremely rapid service no matter how crowded and crazy the bar is (and this includes insanely crowded times like Running of the Bulls).  This is probably my favorite bar in the entire Warehouse District simply due to the consistent and excellent service.

This is a beautiful building, on the exterior and interior, that beckons you to investigate it with an elegant and understated small sign framed by dancing gas lights which tempt you to investigate this slightly mysterious establishment.  Unfortunately once you enter you discover that they have marred the interior with artwork that doesn't really fit the New Orleans soul of the building (the art is mainly drawn from "contemporary British artists" who have no connection to New Orleans).  Further disappointment is found in that the focus on everything here is small and limited.   

CellarDoor has an exceptionally small menu with very limited offerings of both food and drink.  Their website describes that, "CellarDoor is best described by its creators as a conceptual work of art.  Conceptual art, also referred to as 'idea art,' is based on the notion that the idea is more important than the end result." I must heartily disagree as results are ALL that matter in the real world and only offering 6 beers (one of them non-alcoholic), 4 white wines, 4 red wines etc. is not a good result.  The food menu is also very small and the choices are best described as... "interesting" but not always in a good way.  New Orleans is a city of excess and severely limiting my choices with inadequate service does not bring me bliss or create a good end result for my bar or restaurant experience.  

Overall this is yet another attempt at a gastropub, or as CellarDoor describes it "gastro-lounge," and for the most part I've not been a fan of of this new trend in establishments offering small menus of food and drink along with inflated prices and pretentious snack food. This will be a place for those that need their fancy craft cocktails to sip while they eat a tiny snack but it just isn't the type of establishment that I enjoy.  The building is a five star while the food, drink, service and artwork hover around a 1 or 2 for me.  The only New Orleans thing about this place is the building and once you get past that the rest could be anywhere else in the world as it seems to have no connection to New Orleans other than the stage upon which the rest is set.

For those that are fans of places such as Bellocq, Bouligny Tavern and Cure this will definitely be your type of environment.

I do like the building and location so I hope they get out of their initial opening unrealistic dreamland and wake up back to the reality that their results are all we can judge them by.

I would say don't eat here just drink here except the drink prices are more expensive than Ernst right next door.  I wish I could say more positive about the food but just don't eat it!  I went to Ole Miss, I was in graduate school when Eli played for us, I grew up with Archie playing for the Saints.  I just think they need to start totally over with the menu.  The interior, patio and bar are a great places to watch a game and if just rating that this place is probably four stars but the food and drink prices really drop the ball here.

This location of Martin's is far less exciting than the downtown location but still manages to have a nice long line to stand in as you wait to order.   It is easier to park here and a bit easier to eat at this location and much easier to get drink refills on iced tea.  The BBQ actually tastes better to me here than at the downtown location as well but it still could use some tweaking for my taste (and by tweaking I mean bring in some Texas Hill Country folks to do it right).  The brisket chili actually had better texture and flavor to me than the regular brisket.  To my taste I think the nearby Edley's has better brisket but they will sometimes sell out there so you can have this location of Martin's as a backup BBQ plan.

I've been here a few times for happy hour and it is in a great location in the Roosevelt Hotel.  The interior design is a bit too modern and "hip" for my taste as it doesn't seem to match the classic ambiance of the rest of the Roosevelt.  The happy hour food special here is the half priced pizza.  I've sampled a few of the pizza options here and several of the appetizers and everything was good but nothing was really outstanding.  There are a few entrees on the menu that looked interesting that I would like to sample at some point in the future.  Overall it is a good place for a few drinks but I've had much better pizza and, even at half price, I think I would recommend getting something else off the menu.

This is pretty basic and overall pretty bland Mexican food located at the small corner of a strip mall.  The service is nice but you had certainly better point to the exact item on the menu you want or you might get something else.  This is the kind of Mexican food that makes me not such a big fan of Mexican food as most of the selections are just something rolled up into a tortilla of some kind and in the end most things end up tasting exactly the same as each other.  They do have some decent combos and you can get some items not rolled into a tortilla.  Overall basic and very bland Mexican that will please the most New England spice hater.  The Margaritas will work some special magic on you sometimes though and then if you check out the patio it might turn into a fiesta.

I had heard many great things about this place and it took me awhile to finally meander my way out to try it.  Overall it is decent sushi but nothing really knocked my socks off and it was more on the expensive side.  Taking into account the distance I have to travel from the Garden District, the limited street parking and price there are lots of other sushi places I would choose before this place.  If I were already in the area and had folks that had a need for sushi I wouldn't object to returning but I wouldn't make a special trip just to eat here.

This is a pretty great spot for people watching as the restaurant is surrounded by full length windows.  They have some good specials and do some decent seafood.  The burger seems to be made from a pre-formed patty and while it isn't inedible there are far better burgers to be had in NOLA and this one also seems an over priced poor value.  Generally I would probably stick to the specials and entree menu items here while skipping the burger.  Breakfast and brunch are also offered here and because they are a part of the Blake Hotel they are also open during holidays when many other places might be closed.  They also have a nice happy hour here with good drink specials.  The combination of a great people watching spot along with good happy hour prices makes this an interesting spot to check out.

With a name like Green Goddess, you'd expect a vegetarian restaurant. But in New Orleans, it's called Green Goddess because it has vegetarian OPTIONS, which is rare in a city of meat. :) 

The first night we attempted to go, we were greeted by a snobbish hostess who told us that a VERY famous wine guy was going to be there that night with wines from France and Italy and if we weren't on the LIST, then we wouldn't be eating there. First of all, I wasn't on the list, so I didn't need all of that information. Second of all, she could have been a lot friendlier about it. Customer service has been known to SUCK in New Orleans. 

BUT that didn't stop us from going back a couple nights later because we were, indeed, craving some vegetarian options. 

We waited about an hour or so, maybe a bit longer. The place only has about 10 tables and the clientele like to SIT....and sit....long after they've finished their meals. We ended up being seated outside. 

We ordered the Indian lentil pancake, the Armagnac-Soaked Mission Figs and the Notorious Bacon Sundae. I know we got something else, but I can't recall it now. They have an EXTENSIVE cocktail and beer list, but I think I just drank cheap beer for some reason. :/

The figs were REALLY good, but REALLY expensive for what you got. The pancake was interesting, but not quite flavorful enough. The sundae was fantastic....it was actually the reason I wanted to go there in the first place. It is notorious, after all. :) 

All in all, I think this place is overpriced and overhyped. Bad customer service can sour a place from the start. The food was good, but the portion sizes were way too small and it was wayy too pricey.

The burgers r good.  The chicken and fish although good meat the breading is bland.   Fries and cheese curds are always cooked just right. Golden brown and crunchy.   Need more flavor for the breading to get four stars.    The lemon ice is my favorite treat there. Not a custard fan but friends and family live their custard.   They have a ketchup stingyness issue.  They never give u ketchup with ur Togo fries and if u ask they give just 1 for large fries...  Happened Many times... Wazzup?
Had the vegetarian pho and it is full of flavor.   Just the right amount of veggies and tofu and came out hot.   Lovely atmosphere.    Ill be back.

I was craving some good juicy seafood. The Blue Crab Juicy Seafood was just what was needed. I called the order in for pickup. I ordered the Juicy special med. it was 1lb of shrimp, 1lb of crab legs, corn, potatoes I added broccoli (the broccoli is a must) ummmm...I also added a boiled egg (this missed this). Upon arrival you have to go and pick up your order. Everyone in line was practicing social distancing but be prepared to wait. Finally I received my order and the aroma made me even hungrier. When I got home, mask off, hands washed...I tore into it! It was sooo good...but my boiled egg was missing. Lol. Other than a couple of little hiccups this was a great experience and I will definitely be trying it again.

Went to Charleston's for Valentines Day with the Hubby. Charleston's is located off 82nd street near 465. At first upon arrival the parking lot was completely full. I finally found a space as someone was leaving. I was a little concerned about going and just expected service to not be the greatest since they were packed. But they proved me wrong!  

We walked right in to our reservation at 7:00pm and was seated with no wait! Next the server got our drink orders right away. She asked about appetizers but we were a little indecisive so she offered to come back. She did take a little while to return but it wasn't too bad. I had a Cesar salad, Prim Rib and broccoli. My husband had the pork chop dinner with cole slaw and fried okra.  It was all cooked to perfection and delicious. 

Charleston's is often our go to after church. To spend our Valentines Day at Charleston's with great service and a tasty dinner was awesome.

St Elmo isn't really an everyday kind of place, but 1933 Lounge certainly could be. Imagine a dimly lit bar, couches and bar tables scattered about, a nice fire going and cocktail waitresses walking around in red dresses. That's 1933 Lounge!

I never stray off my usual here.. an Elmo Cola (Coke and Bourbon with their special cherries) with two filet sliders and mac and cheese. Delicious and it'll only set you back about $25, which is a heck of a lot better than downstairs!

When I'm in the mood for take out Chinese food, this is where I go. Make sure you call ahead though... sometimes the kitchen gets backed up and food is slow to leave. Always piping hot and fresh.. YUM!

Okay, I hate to say anything bad about Yat's because I LOVE it, but the layout of this Yat's makes it quite difficult to move about the space. The food and service is as excellent as any location I've been to, but I'll seriously consider coming back to this location simply because of the logistical nightmare it is to get from one end of the store to the other.

When you walk in, the counter is dead ahead on the left. There are bar stools wrapped around it, and these people become  your buddies while you're in line and they're trying to eat. When someone gets their food (or needs a drink refill) they also get to walk back and forth, meaning two lines of traffic are trying to fit into a tight spot.

Again, the food is fantastic and the staff couldn't be nicer. Heck, they even serve beer and take credit cards here, unlike some of the other locations. I just think whomever came up with the design and layout was probably mad at the world the day the plans were drafted, and this is their payback.

With the holidays coming, here's my tip on how to serve a great antipasto platter without doing any of the work thanks to the fine folks at Goose.

It's called "The Tour".. an board of the best meats and cheeses they can find, piled high on a board for however many people you need it to feed (minimum of 2) for $10 a person. It really doesn't get any easier than that folks! Anytime I've got people coming over and I need to feed them, I ring 'em up and they've got it waiting on me.

Nice place , awful food!! Tortillas taste like plastic, you can stretch them like gum, and pancakes have no flavor, is like you're eating paper pancakes. Coffe sucks too. I'm sorry for the review but the owner should be tasting the food once in a while. Is like eating astronaut food lol. Frozen food is much better

So from an atmosphere standpoint, there is more elbow room and a better, less hectic, calmer feel to Davidsons Dockside over Rusty Bellies but the food quality and authenticity is so much better there than here. I liked the fresh crisp batter on the battered fish although nothing reflected the "beer batter" menu description and the fish was a bland white fish like swai or basa. The clam strips were resemblance of Long John Silvers frozen but the shrimp were of good size and flavor. The fish dip and conch fritters were a bit touristy and nothing stood out about them. The outside seating was nice and the marina was a nice backdrop. I was hoping residing beside the water and it having a homey, mom and pop feel that we would get better seafood than red lobster but it just didn't happen today.

Stopped in today for something new for lunch and discovered a very flavorful very tasty Cuban sub. My beautiful wife had the Cuban pork with rice and black beans and she loved it. My Cuban sub was traditional with pulled Cuban pork, a delicious spicy mustard, mayo pickle ham on a buttered and pressed Cuban roll. The pork wasn't too vinegary wasn't too greasy and was seasoned to perfection. Very tender pork. Very good Latin food or sure.

This was my first time here.  We were looking for a new breakfast/brunch spot to go to before the Saints game and ran into here! I had the crab meat, spinach and brie omelet which was fabulous (a tad more brie would of made it even better though).  There was an unbelievable amount of crab meat but too bad I was only able to eat half of it.  The eggs were fluffy and you get to choose either toast or a biscuit.  I chose the homemade biscuit which was enormous and delicious! We also ordered the usually breakfast plate consisting of 2 sunny side up eggs, bacon and a biscuit which was a good as a normal breakfast could be.  

The desserts looked delicious but it was too early for me to eat a cupcake  so I'll have to come by again to try it out.  The menu is plentiful of seasonal and special items that sound delicious to try.

There's a lot of things that are really great at Korean Grill House.  

We headed over there on a very cold Friday evening to celebrate Panda's birthday.  He loves Korean BBQ, which is a quite common way to dine in China as well.  When I say very cold, I mean 'record cold', and just after a snow.  

We arrived to find the parking lot mostly plowed, there was still a lot of snow around, so we kind of rested in the edge of the snow and hoped we wouldn't get stuck.  

The restaurant itself is nicely laid out, you walk in and to your right is a buffet of raw proteins and veggies for you to select, along with rice and soup.  Turn left into the dining room, where there's a variety of tables, each with a grill and a fume intake dangling above from the ceiling. We had called ahead so our tables were set up and ready to go.

I mention the cold here because the restaurant had difficulty keeping their rooms warm.  The staff did their best, setting up mostly ineffective space heaters, however we ended up dining in our coats.  

We ordered mostly the 'standard'  buffet of meats with a couple of 'deluxe' orders that included shrimp and bulgogi.  We selected a good variety of proteins and veggies, which Panda and the NMT eagerly began grilling.  

The food was...nice.  OK.  I missed having some variety in spice and savory.  The chicken came out well and there were thumbs up on the shrimp and squid.  I think they would do well though to install a sauce and spice area in their buffet so people could be creative with flavoring.  Also having butter to grill with also helps with flavor and reduces stickiness on the grill tops.

The staff were really very nice, helpful, and attentive without  being overbearing, even helping us with the cake we brought and served.  They really are an asset to the restaurant, as they made a ho-hum experience into a yay, I'm a fan place.

The great parts: Easy to get to, ample free parking, buffet means you can get what protein you want when you want it rather than having to flag someone down, super attentive staff, and an overall pleasant family atmosphere.  The would love to see done better: sauces/spices and butter for cooking.  

We'll probably be back, though next time we might BYOSS (Bring Your own Spices and Sauces, of course. *smile*

This year, the Patriarch decided to allow the Eldest Young 'Un (AKA the Newly Minted Teenager or NMT) to choose a restaurant for his birthday celebration.  NMT chose Mad Mex, primarily because NMT loves tacos.  Off we go.

We ordered a variety of dishes, and they were all pretty "meh".  Biggest thumbs up of the salads.  Burritos are all square, not cylindrical as is per usual, and even the spicy ones were bland.  Tacos had meat so greasy they soaked through the shells and honestly made me feel a bit nauseous.  Chicken Chimi was the only cylindrical burrito and it was served with a strange sauce coating it - not quite marinara, not cheese, I don't know it was orange-ish and odd tasting.  It was drowned in that sauce, and even scraping it off left an aftertaste.  

Our server was fantastic, she was very attentive and friendly and made good suggestions.

I'm not sure exactly how I'd categorize the food.  It's not Tex Mex, it's definitely not pure Mexican. I'd have to say if Olive Garden and Bennigan's got together and had to interpret Tex-Mex, you would get Mad Mex. Maybe that's why they call it Mad Mex, because anyone would have to be mad to think this was Mex?  Or maybe if you came here thinking you'd get good Tex Mex, you'd end up pretty mad? Either way, we won't bother again.

Feeling flush with success at finding good breakfast on Christmas day at nearby Hymies, the merry band of hungry people set off to experience breakfast at the 'other' Jewish deli in Bala - Murray's Delicatessen, just a1/2 block away, this time New Year's Day (it's a holiday theme).

Murray's has a similar setup, half deli, half restaurant, though the dining area is noticeably smaller than that of Hymie's. The decor is also more retro-20's and 30's with some beautiful stained glass and tin.  Smaller meant that 6 of us could not fit at a booth, so a 2 top table was added to the end of our booth. It also meant that other patrons had to walk in a zig zag pattern to get around us.  

Again, we were a mixed order - some with breakfast, some with lunch.  One everything bagel with lox (seriously?  So not challenging), one mushroom omlette with tomato side, one french toast.  One hot dog, one "Texas Tommy" (hot dog stuffed with cheese then wrapped in bacon) and one turkey club.

All were....well, just OK. Bland.  The turkey club was 98% turkey, and so huge it had to be deconstructed to eat, but for all the meat, there really wasn't  a lot of taste to it (and it was ordered with mayo).  Next time they should think about less meat (so jaws do not need to be unhinged to eat) and more flavor.  French toast was also just 'meh', not nearly the flavor you'd expect from challah bread.  Texas Tommy was not loved -bacon was in that chewy not really cooked state that only some love.  Fries were not battered but also lacked any kind of flavor.  If I had to put one word to the meal it would be "bland".   

Service was reasonably efficient and friendly, and the place was clean.  We may go back at some point but we were generally so not-impressed it wouldn't be an enthusiastic decision.  

One nice note - free parking behind the restaurant, accessed by an alley next to Aldair (next-door restaurant).

Many years ago, before the age of television and cars, people were entertained by going to huge movie houses located conveniently close to major public transportation stops.  One of these palaces was located at Suburban Square, it was the "Suburban" movie theater and what was cool about it was that it had a semi-circular lobby and two entrances - one on Coulter and one on St. James Place.

Alas, that age is gone, and one of the early casualties was the Suburban.  It closed in 1979.  It was subsequently a farmer's market, which at first was 'bare bones' and then became more 'upscale'.  Then it became a clothing store.   Now it is the site of a Not Your Average Joe's location.  NYAJ has actually made use of the curving marquee, converting it to a dining patio above street level.  

Why am I telling you all this?  Because the thing I liked most was that the restaurant pays homage of a sort to the history of the building.  One two story wall has the word "SUBURBAN" in silver letters near the top and a smooth space where they project movie trailers - everything from "Lawrence of Arabia" to "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".  This was not something I'd expect a chain to do, and it pleased me.

The Reverend Dr. Steak and I had an enjoyable lunch there.  Unusually, we both chose the meatloaf.  Usually we make an effort to get different items, both so we can sample more of the menu and so we can get a better sense of the offerings for ourselves.  Alas, the spaghetti squash bolognese was not available for lunch that day, and that meatloaf looked so darn good.

It generally did not disappoint, served almost as a sandwich with mashed potato "Bun" and fried onion strings.  The sauce - BBQ - was quite tasty.  The dish relies on these elements, as the meat itself is fairly tasteless.  Be warned: Don't order it plain. That would disappoint.  

Service was excellent, attentive, thoughtful and friendly. Price was reasonable. We'll be back, and next time we'll do our best to broaden our choices.

I have not visited here yet, but my wife has, twice. She likes it, but decided to bring me takeout (kung pao beef) to show me how good this restaurant was.

Upon tasting the takeout meal, I stated I had no interest in visiting this restaurant. The meal had no taste, almost no peanuts, and although she asked for a 3 on a heat level of 4, this was very bland, with almost no taste at all.
