My wife meant to bring me a meal to show me I should join her in visiting this restaurant, but given the meal provided, I have no interest at all in checking this place out further.

Shame on this restaurant for providing such an inadequate meal.

This place is cool! Right on the corner, it's a small spot with a lot of seating. A lot of menu options and a great lunch special. Menu options are customizable as well. Staff is friendly but it seems like they need more waiters, there was only one person working. Took a while to get our checks and boxes, probably from being understaffed.
I got the spicy noodles, made extra spicy with chicken. Portions are large.

I've visited Fogo a few times and have always been disappointed with the food. Maybe I just don't understand the concept of a Brazilian steakhouse? For almost $50 per person you get an endless buffet of overdone, dry pieces of meat. All the cuts of beef that I've tried were underwhelming and rather flavorless, and eating the pork is like eating sawdust. The only meat that I enjoyed was the rack of lamb. 

I think dinner here might be a good deal for someone who just wants to eat a lot of red meat for the price of a good steak dinner elsewhere. However, if you don't enjoy your meat well done, I wouldn't recommend this restaurant. I will say that the biscuits are phenomenal and the salad bar is quite extensive and well thought out, but the experience as a whole is just not worth the price tag.

Nice. Fine. Does the job. Pleasant. That's about it. Nothing extraordinary about this place. The hype baffles me. You won't hate the place but why you'd love it is beyond me. A safe bet for a "nice" lunch if you're passing by.

This was the favorite of my friends when we'd see a movie at the Bridge, er, Rave. I always balked going there because I want my Mexican food cooked with more love and care. The food had the elements of Mexican food, but it never seemed worth the calories. What I can say is that it's fast, which is important to make a movie showing. The food is also filling, but not in a soul satisfying way. 

I think Qdoba is successful because it fits a certain need - food for people who don't have the money or time to invest in a full restaurant experience. And it is a better alternative to the McDonalds that is a block away.

The food is consistently great, the service is consistently bad. If the service was up to par, this would be a 5 star review.  They either need to hire better servers, more servers, or have management to train, direct, and improve the service. 

I am not expecting the best service in the world, but we have gone in and sat down, and left after 10 minutes of not even being acknowledged.  We have gone full means with our drinks never filled, and they struggle with getting the order right.  The staff is always very friendly, they are just either too busy or too inefficient.

I know, I know, no pictures but listen, each time I have been, I was always engulfed in conversation that I forgot to take them. Anyways, the food here is simple but food.  Service is always fast and friendly. The place is clean and welcoming. Each time I usually get eggs and turkey sausage and an English muffin.  My last trip to Keke's, I got an omelet with 3 meats. It does not come with veggies so I had to add peppers and onions. The home fries are fresh and everything honestly is tasty. I enjoy my visit each time I go to Keke's.  Open one up in St.Pete. As they say.... "If you build it, they will come"

I really am not a fan of paying a high price for a burger, but I decided to check out Hamburger Mary's to see what they had to offer.  the ambiance was exactly as I expected it to be however I was  also expecting more that what I got.  we did get seated quickly which is always a good thing, but little impressed me after that. 

the "show" started shortly after we got there, and while some entertainment is good for dinner, and a good drag show can be just that, entertaining.. the loudness of the music being performed was way to hard to talk over and i was finding it rather annoying to have to talk so loud.  The booths at the table we were sitting at also seemed like they had built in booster chairs and everyone that sat across from us looked like they were sitting in high chairs..

The food arrived and for the most part was tasty.  I ordered the "Mary Burger" without the special sauce and an order of fries.  the burger was good, but as I ate it I found it to be more pink as I progressed, far from a medium well burger like I requested, the fries were seasoned and actually rather tasty which somewhat made up for the burger.

let me clarify things, I wasn't completely unhappy with my burger, I was just expecting a little more that what I got, especially with the word hamburger in the name of the restaurant.. would I make a return visit to Hamburger Mary's?  yes I would be willing to give them another shot to see if  I can get satisfied from one of the meals there.

Fuddruckers is my all time favorite burger joint hands down. I have been coming to this location for many years and it always satisfies without a doubt.    The meat is actually chopped right on site,  which tells you it's fresh from the start, which makes it even tastier..

Their burgers come in 1/3, 1/2, 2/3, and one pound (pre-cooked) weights, to suite many different appetites,  they offer combination platters with a burger of your weight choice, some delicious seasoned fries, and a beverage. depending on your burger size is what the final cost is, and even with the largest burger they offer, the price is still undoubtedly reasonable.

you place your order at the counter, then take your drink cups, get your beverage and sit down.   they will call your name, (a nice personal touch) and you go pick up your order at the counter, which happens to be in the center of a huge fixings bar to load up your burger however you choose to do so. 

They offer free refills on your drinks and have a nice little bakery section that has some cookies for sale for desert. The restaurant is rock and roll themed, and although it's the same decor it's been since the 80's, Fuddruckers is still a great place to go to get a great tasting burger!

I was not impressed with this place at all. The inside looks like a normal diner. It's not dirty and in fact it looks fairly clean. My reasoning behind the 2 stars is only because the waitress was very good. She was friendly and attentive and even made ginger ale for me because they didn't have it. It was probably a mixture of sprite and Pepsi which is simple enough but still she didn't have to do it.
I ordered the chicken quesadilla. I asked for everything that they put in it except the chicken. So basically Cheese, mushroom, onions and so forth. I made myself perfectly clear on what I wanted. The cook messed up my order and had to make me another one. When it came out it was completely soggy and was flapping all over the place. Totally disgusting. It's pretty hard to screw up a quesadilla but this cook managed to do it. It was completely inedible. Even my fruit cup looked like the fruit had been sitting around for days. My husband got a burger and he seemed to be happy with it. The grilled cheese my daughter got was acceptable and the fries were delicious.

Had breakfast there it was served with a side of biscuits and gravy an hour later I was sicker than a dog well how do I explain that I have no idea it did kind of taste different well I have biscuits and gravy there again no way

The salsa is the best of any Mexican restaurant I've been to, the chips not so much.  If the could ship in some fresh chips from (great, I can't remember the name of the place off West End with the great chips) I think I would probably get fat on pre-meal food.

The food, probably in my top 5 for taste, but it seems a little light.  I should, with how many chips I eat there, combined with a meal, be full when I leave... I'm not that much of a fatty... 

You have your standard vegetarian options - beans, cheese, tortilla or nacho in any combo you can think of, and a couple of other things if I remember right.

Only drawback is the time it takes to get a beer when it's busy.  I'm tempted to order two when ordering as the waiters do not get back that fast.

If you're looking for a place on Cinco de Mayo to go and get a table, this is the place.  I went there once a good hour early to secure a table for 12 and basically sat at a table for 12 the entire hour with a total of 5 other people in the restaurant.

I dig it

I wanted to love them, that pizza they delivered was not to love.

The garlic knots were below the threshold of garlic I can taste. I really thought they might just have forgotten the garlic or used weak garlic salt at one point.

The pizza was not bad, but unremarkable. The cheese tasted like generic non-pizza cheese, the sauce didn't have any kick, I did like crust but it didn't have flavor, the veggies were there but that was about it. 

I felt like this had all the components of being good but missed out in the quality of the ingredients, or maybe crisping the crust a bit, or throwing oil or something on the crust, or dousing the knots in oil and garlic.

This is probably not a stylistic difference of culinary opinion based on where I was born. I've been to Brooklyn and as a very bad vegetarian subsisted mainly on pizza. Lived in Long Island for a couple of years and had more pizza in the five boroughs than I care to admit. Something was just diminished.

Were you to WiKi what a pizza was, this satisfied the requirements.

Whether the blandness was a one time thing or not I don't know. It was expensive enough and disappointing enough to not merit a retry.

Pros: they have veggie dogs.
Cons: the veggie dogs are kind of tasteless, just a delivery system for condiments.

Can't comment on how good the non-veggie dogs are, I have friends who love it and friends who say it's ok.  The place is pretty cool, parking would be hell at most times people want to eat.  It's supposedly a great place for kids.

The condiments are ok, nothing super special.  When I've been it's been deserted, but I'm told that's not normally the case.

If you see some people looking around the place on their hands and knees as though they've lost something but are trying not to be noticed looking, ignore them.  There's something hidden there, they don't know what it is though so they can't tell you what they're looking for.  The manager can tell you but won't tell you where it is.

Pretty decent place, I'll give it another few tries, hopefully they'll get slightly better veggie dogs in the future, although I don't know that these things exist.
Casual bar with decent food and drinks, a neighborhood favorite. They normally have a live band every night. Music can get rather annoyingly loud but overall a good neighborhood bar.

We decided to try this place after we tried a sample of their food at the Seagrapes food and wine festival. We loved what they had there-it was one of our favorite stops.

It has a great location, next to the water-wonderful breeze. Our server was great.

The food was good as well, not as good as I was hoping for the prices but it was still good. 

We had the Chana masala appetizer-it was ok, would not highly recommend it and it only comes with a couple small pieces of naan. Nothing to rave about at all, a little bland. (I normally really enjoy Chana masala.)

We decided to split the lamb shank "Moon under the water" style curry with 32 spices. The lamb was very good and it was a large piece(definitely enough for two). The sauce was good-not amazing-but good. We decided to get all the extras that you can add to the platters-naan, sauce platter and something else. Not worth the extra $ at all. If you order a platter, don't bother upgrading and adding all the sides they have listed at the bottom of the menu-just order a side of naan. 

I got the chai tea-amazing-really really good. We also tried a coffee/alcohol drink with lots of whipped cream for dessert and it was awesome. 

Overall...not bad, I have had much better Indian in Tampa so I was not hugely impressed but still a nice restaurant.
Nothing special about this take out/delivery Chinese spot but good food and we have never had a problem.

I visited yesterday because some of our friends had bought us pizza one night here and they told us about their daily specials! 2 of which are right perfect for us! 1 is Wednesday. On Wednesday they offer  $.35 wings! The wings are small and not all are cut right but the flavor is there! Coming in 2 styles, buffalo or plain, these wings are yummy and priced so that you can make a meal of them! They ring up at $7 for 20, 4 of us ordered 40 and were all satisfied! That night too they had $10 pitchers and my friend ordered a basket of fries too! Let me say the food was all yummy, very yummy! 2 is Thursday, if I remember right is Tahoe Thursday?! Anyway it's half off pizza! Their pizza is delicious and at half price a deal you shouldn't pass up! The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because I think $5 & $6 for well cocktails is way high! I highly recommend Wednesdays and thursday night's for a good night out with friends or a casual date night!

I like this place. I don't love it, but I like it.

The food is pretty good (it's pub food) and they have great specials if you can catch them.

Stopped by this popular place based on the constant traffic alone, place always seems busy. It was on Saturday night around 7 so no complaints on the brief wait for seating or slightly congested service. The chips and salsa and plenty of water before our meals came was a pleasant touch. She ordered the fish taco's and I went with the chicken quesadilla, both were well cooked and seasoned. I will definitely be back.

This pizza would even do well in Brooklyn, and that's hard for me to say. We have ordered on grub hub twice and both times received fast service and a damn good pizza. We had the Mediterranean pie and it was excellent. Keep up the good work.

Omg this place is tacky. Like disco balls basically every inch of the ceiling, neon lights, and mirror walls tacky.

But it's also tacky to the point where it's a little fun just to go just for the experience. Granted, the level of fun is directly proportional to the level of drunkenness.

The crowd:  My big takeaway for the night was that there were a LOT of really tall people. I'm average height but I'm pretty sure there was a special section of the dance floor reserved for those people are who are 6'0 and above. There were also definitely some creepers around. 

The song choice was questionable. Some good hits, some good hits if it was 2008 and then some completely random music. And after about 2.5 hours (which, granted, is probably longer than you need to stay at Talayna's), they started repeats (and no, I didn't really want to singalong to Don't Stop Believing a second time).

We actually went as part of a karaoke-crawl experience but having gone there once, I can't actually imagine myself karaoke-ing here.

Went for happy hour with friends. Nice day so the rooftop got super crowded super fast. Get there early to get a spot or you're out of luck. The standing room is very unpleasant. Happy hour specials are great, $5 drinks and $5 apps. The drink menu has a lot of great options. The fries are unique and so good. Pretzel bites are also very good and come with that amazing mustard. Hummus was excellent as well! All in all a great spot for dinner or happy hour. Will be back!

Went in as a single but very comfortable. Was offered seat at one of the bars or table and I chose table as they had live performer this evening. He was outstanding by the way and was direct from the Emerald Isle according to the posted info. Hostess also had a heavy accent which led to the comfort of the place. Fare was authentic, Scotch Eggs very good and the Fish and Chips prepared properly and tasty. Large, flaky white fish with steak fries and slaw. Smithwick's was delicious and ice cold. I'll be back on me next trip.

Food - Fresh...we had the halibut & ahi tuna.  Both were very good.

Service - Waitress was very nice....but our food took forever.  They did give us a free dessert though which we took to go.

EVERY SINGLE TIME I GO TO THIS PLACE!!!!!!

I used to go to this place once every few months for a pick up lunch order.  It's hard to mess up a pick up lunch order and they usually didn't.  Sometimes I'd have to stand at the vacant counter searching for an employee for too long but that was usually the worst of it.

Dining in is a whole different story.  It seems every time I get dragged in here by some family member or friend something goes wrong.   Sometimes the food is cold. Sometimes the food is wrong.  Sometimes the drinks never get re-filled. Sometimes the silverware is dirty.  Sometimes something is floating in the water.  Sometimes the check never shows up.  Sometimes the waiter disappears.  

My mother and my kids went to IHOP on the 25th of July.  I got dragged along of course and - not surprisingly something went wrong - the bigger story is that surprisingly - everything mentioned in the previous paragraph went wrong!!! WOW!!!!  

The table was sticky.  The food was sub-par.  The drinks never got re-filled.  We tried to find our waiter to rectify the situation but he had disappeared.  My daughters ranch took over 10 minutes to come out.  I had to get different silverware.  The check was late.  

Every time we go to this place it's not even a quarter full.  It just amazes me that the food and service is so consistently poor.  

I've had my fill of IHOP.  Thankfully so has the rest of my family so we never have to "give it another try" again.

**I'm giving it 2 stars instead of 1 because the "to-go" orders were never messed up.

Uh oh.  I think I'm in the minority here and I would like to make it very clear that I am just putting in my opinion and not trying to upset anyone.

Spicy Pickle is definitely a chain kind of Sandwich shop.  I say this because nothing about the experience or food seemed extraordinary or special.  The parking is fine and they have a decent amount of seating which is nice.  I went on a very busy day and it only got busier.  I had to sit at the bar area which faced the front window sharing it with another patron.

It's a very cute place.  Sharp and modern purple, blue and green decorations and patterns occupy the walls giving it a pretty trendy feel.  I ordered a wrap, pasta salad and an ice tea which all came to just under $10.00.

Once the order was ready a server brought the meal to me, on a glass plate (which seems to be the new norm in a non fast food-esque sandwich joint).   I was a tad irritated when I saw that the pasta salad could not have been larger than one or two very small spoon fulls (and by this I mean maybe 1/4 total) - I don't think I would have paid for a "side" of pasta salad if I knew it would total 2 bites.  True to the name the pickle on the side that is included was spicy - I didn't eat the whole thing as I don't so much care for spice on things that shouldn't be spicy.
The wrap was passable but just like any other wrap I've ever had. 

The day I went was a gloomy and grey day - the shades in front of the bar were down so rather than letting any kind of sun or light in the place relied on overhead lighting and I stared at the window shade while I ate rather than outside.  The staff was friendly though.

One final note - upon visiting the bathroom I noticed that opposite the open toilet they have a bulletin board full of business cards as many places do.  I thought at first that this was a smart idea.  People can look at the cards while they *ahem* deal with business......but then I remember that toilets spray bacteria in the air several feet around the area when flushed and decided i would not be taking any of the cards from the board.............I'm not sure how I feel about bathroom bacteria cardboard in my purse........

 Long story short - I was not blown away and somewhat deflated when I left.  I think my expectations might have been too high going in.

A little overrated. My first problem is the ordering process...it's a "serving line" style where you tell them what you want and they slap it on a tray for you. Here's the problem with that...I was 4 people back once my food was ready. By the time I paid for my food and got to my seat my sausage was cold and my brisket was getting cold, that was disappointing. 

The food...
The sausage had great flavor on it's own so I'm curious how it may have tasted hot. The brisket was excellent, tons of flavor and just the right amount of meat to fat ratio. The brisket was so well prepared that it didn't need any sauce. The burnt ends....very disappointing! The people who have raved about these either have never had REAL burnt ends or I just had a bad batch. Mine were sloppy and dry and almost the consistency of a pulled pork. 

The Sauce..

Not good...actually ruined the taste of the meat for me. Not sure how to describe it but I didn't like anything about it. I didn't try the spicy sauce. 

The sides...

The beans were awesome!!! Chunky, thick sauce and a great flavor profile! Definitely a must have! The sweet potato casserole was very plain almost as if I was eating it straight out of the potato with no add-ons, disappointing.

Sweets...

I was excited to see that they have a sweets bar as well, everything made in house and it all looked amazing! I was excited to see that they had carrot cake because it's one of my favorite desserts. As a carrot cake snob, this was no good...I didn't even finish it. It had a very heavy cinnamon taste, no pineapple, no coconut and I'm not sure what the frosting was but I don't feel like it was a butter cream...which by the way is the ONLY frosting to go on carrot cake. 

As for BBQ joints in the bay there are way better spots. This placed is very overpriced and not worth the hype.

Fado is a pretty chill sports bar that I've been frequenting more lately.  I seem to always have a great time here.  Plus, they have a pretty decent beer list.  Some nights it's low key and some nights it gets pretty packed.  I love the unpredictability :).  

I usually sit at the bar - much closer to the alcohol and the flatscreen tv (I'm lazy and enjoy watching sports at bars, so the closer I am, the better!).  But, there's also plenty of sit down area for people to have dinner as a group.  Plus, the food is awesome!  I love their cheese dip and wedges, chicken tenders, and chicken boxty quesadillas.  I order these every single time...I should really try some other things on the menu soon.

This place has great seafood, and though you might be skeptical to order based on your surroundings, it really isn't to be missed. The grunge and worn in look of the building and seating areas isn't reflected in the quality of the food. And the less organized, graffiti on the bathroom walls, music posters and sticker all over the place just set up the perfect atmosphere for a night out with friends or a relaxed stop after a long day of work. The music is always a mix of genres, and the stage and seating for patrons also sets up a cool vibe. Overall this is a neat place to eat, hang out, or go see a concert. I'm definitely a fan!

Typical Mexican fare done just a little bit better than normal.  Excellent margaritas and fishbowls of beer.  Portions are huge, me and my wife often will split a single entree and are still satisfied.  Also if you save room then you get to have the chocolate chimicunga which is awesome.

I went in to Holland House fully expecting to not like it.  I like a well made drink, but I cannot stand pretentious restaurants.  I was pleasantly surprised to find almost no pretension and a ton of very well made, well thought out drinks.  

I had two excellent drinks (the Black Lemon Old Fashioned and the Beatnik) and sampled several others.  The ingredients were fresh and you could tell that they were made with care.  They all had something different and interesting to offer.  In fact the drink menu is expansive enough to please just about any booze aficionado.   It would take some serious drinking to try everything on the menu, but I am sure some will try.  

Some of the other reviews have mentioned issues with service, but at our table of 8 the service was prompt, informed and friendly.  The drinks and appetizers also made there way to our table in a very reasonable amount of time.  Overall, our whole group was very impressed with every aspect of Holland House's service and atmosphere.  

The only reason I am withholding a star is because I did not get a chance to sample anything of the main food offerings.  Also, I know it is not out of line with similar places in town, but a $10 cocktail is still a $10 cocktail.  They were very good, but the price can get steep very fast if you are not careful (hint; I was not careful).  

Overall a great addition to East Nashville.  I hope they continue to refine the restaurant and bring some fresh air to the other side of Gallatin Road.

---START EDIT 45 minutes after posting review---

One thing I forgot to include which is key here was my expectation that the fondue (meaning the cheese and bread) should be the star and that simply wasn't the case here.  It almost felt like an afterthought to the main course, etc. when fondue itself should BE the main course.

Please take this into account if you are reading this review.  The broths, meats, salads, etc. make this more of a mish-mash fondue fusion type place and just not what I was expecting.  Coupled with all the reasons mentioned below is how I arrived at two stars.

We return to your regularly scheduled review.

---END EDIT---

This will sound snobby (and I don't care) but this isn't fondue in the purest sense.  Having travelled to the Fribourg region of Switzerland and had traditional Swiss fondue, a trip to the Melting Pot is kind of a love/hate thing.  More hate than love...haha.

Love: the concept of fondue.  It begs participation, conversation, laughter, etc.  You can talk about the cheese, the bread, what is coming next, etc.  It can be fun, romantic, or any number of adjectives.  A terrific date night place.

Hate: the imposed stuffiness and forced formality.  You can't be in a hurry coming here (which is fine don't get me wrong).  Service was entirely too spotty for the cost.  Waiting 30 minutes for a refill at these prices is not acceptable.  I like being left alone but not at the expense of being ignored.  Serving sizes and amount of cheese, etc. is not commensurate with the cost.  Breads, vegetables, and salads were uninspired.  Dessert was the best part by far and we really liked this.

The decor varies from semi-public to very private with dark woods and paint and a decidely 90s feel.

The kids liked it because it is something different.  But in all honesty, if you do your homework on traditional fondue you can have something much more enjoyable at home for a much lower cost.  I know this isn't the point of going out but the experience and cost of coming here just leave a lot to be desired.

GREAT beer list and delicious pizza. Four stars because they lack light options, but if you want good pizza and an outstanding beer or two or three, you can't go wrong here. The staff know the brews well. Atmosphere is funky but welcoming, and it's kid-friendly, despite being a beer joint next to the U.

Lacroix, without a doubt is definitely Michelin contender of the year. 

Must get: tasting menu, mocktails, Dan as your waiter
Missed out: wine pairing
Meh: nothing

We celebrated our anniversary here and immediately felt as if we were transported to another world of culinary and service excellence. The staff were highly attentive (the one's who'll fold your napkin if you leave your table for longer than 10 seconds), the decor was beautiful with large windows that overlooked the rittenhouse square. On arrival, we were treated to complimentary glasses of champagne, and multiple rounds of flavorful mid-meal snacks. Our main meal was white asparagus, halibut, rabbit, beef, with a multi-course dessert tasting including frozen coconut, marshmallow on a stick, and decorative cake, and truffle tasting and chocolate desserts to go. My favorite dish was definitely the wild rabbit with fava bean, sauce royale and the smoked sturgeon with chavings of white asparagus. Still have mouth watering memories.

At the end, we ate and were treated like kings and queens. This was a meal that I will never forget in Philadelphia. 

Food: 5 stars
Ambiance: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars
Price: 5 stars

I was truly disappointed at my time at ACME, not because the free concert was one of the best I've ever listened to, or the three stories of hang-out space that catered to almost post-event crazy. I gave it three stars because the food was really...sub par. I came here with a group of friends, who bought a bunch ribs and I decided to try out the fried chicken, which is highly voted on as a must-try item. Prior to this event, my only spicy fried chicken exposure was in RI, in which, while amazing, I thought had much room to be one-upped, especially when I'm in BBQ nation. Unfortunately, the fried chicken was burnt, tasted more of the bread crumbs and was not spicy at all. The ribs, in which many were leftover (uh-oh), were more fatty and chewy and kinda tasteless. The only saving grace is actually the collared green and coleslaw, which were quite refreshing after a few days of constipation-inducing meaty meals during my time in Nashville.

Food: 2 stars
Staff: 3 stars
Price: 3 stars
Ambiance: 3 stars

Having gone to this popular establishment multiple times with friends and colleagues, I can comfortably say that Han Dynasty is...ok, not great, but not bad either.

My recommendation is to get the Han Dynasty tasting menu option as it comes with so much food that you'd be waddling your way with the inevitable food coma. Of the menu items, I recommend the dan dan noodles, the twice fried (insert protein here, but I like the fish), and the eggplants. The food that didn't live up to expectation were the pork buns (really dry meat), the rabbit w/peanuts (which was more like peanut with rabbit bones) appetizer, and the dumplings in chili oil (more carbs than protein). The other dishes, like the bak choy and mapu tofu were standard.

One of the main reason why I was disappointed at Han Dynasty was the lack of communication between the staff for large party organizations. I called ahead 1 month in advance to prepare a dinner with specific food and spices request due to individual preferences. When I arrived on that evening, the waiter had no idea of the previous arrangement, and I spent 15 minutes trying to re-order the entire menu and we ended up getting multiple dishes with the wrong level of spices and excessive amount of meat dishes even though we had multiple vegetarians in our group.

I think at the end of the day Han Dynasty isn't bad, but if you're trying to impress a native Chinese foodie, there is much room for improvement.

Food: 3 stars
Price: 3 stars
Service: 2 stars
Ambiance: 2 stars (very stuffy, despite the tall ceilings)

I am not often known to stop by bars at 7am, but when you're post-overnights and dragged by your colleagues for a post-third shift hangout, then Milkboy is your [only] option. Just remember that food starts at 8am.

When we arrived, the staff welcomed us with a bright smile that woke our spirits and happily took our drink orders. Even though the kitchen was closed when we arrived, she took pity on our baggy eyes and got the special honey-covered bowl-o-bacon and fries before 8am. I tried the hot-toddy equivalent and a bite of the bacon (which I found to be a bit too chewy but helped warm the soul).

Overall, this was a pleasant morning dining experience and I would return if I'm dragged here again.
It's okay for cheap, DIY pizza. It's also conveniently located on Freret st, so I ate there a lot as a Tulane student. My only complaint is that it's not very hygienic, and the service is not great.

I have been here 3 times because it is near where I live.  

I think the crust tastes like cardboard and it is WAY over-priced.  But it is a good bar atmosphere with large screen tvs.

This is an interesting bar. Most of the beers they have are all in cans. They have a good amount of craft beers in cans as well. It is not a large bar and has a bit of a divey feel to it. If you are in the area and looking to bar hop, this is a cool place to check out. There is an upstairs but it is very small. It holds a few tables and a video game.

Oh Vivace. How I wanted to love thee. But alas, it was not to be. 

I attended a work-related dinner at Vivace with a dozen or so of my colleagues. We were a bit early, and our table wasn't set up yet. But we made ourselves comfortable at the bar. No biggee. 

This gave me a chance to take a gander at the decor. Kind of outdated. Kind of what you'd expect from a trying-to-be-fancy Italian restaurant. White linen table cloths, warm golden rod colored walls, and a faded conglomeration of a map of Italy on the back wall. Meh. 

We were seated and immediately brought wine and baskets of warm bread. There were also small dishes of pesto...but none of them had serving spoons. We ordered several appetizers and waited. 

While we waited I noticed that they had assigned TWO waiters to our group, which I thought was great. Too often I've been to big dinners like this that take upwards of 4 hours because we have one poor guy burdened with everything. 

We ordered the antipasti ($15.95)  (they say this feeds 2, but 3 of these were appetizer enough for 13 people). It had some marinated zucchini, prosciutto, a caper/olive tapenade , herbed goat cheese, sauteed & green beans and garlic toast.  I thought it was pretty standard. Nothing really wowed me. The tapenade was salty but SUPER cold. My favorite thing on the platter were the little greenbeans. Delicate, just the right amount of balsamic. Yum. 

The next appetizers to come out were the Fresh Mozzerella over Eggplant ($10.50) and the Stuffed Whole Mushrooms ($8.95). The mushrooms were decent but not up to temperature and still mostly raw. The Mozzerella was amazing, but the eggplant (which was pretty well grilled) was too blackened. Combined with the sweet balsamic, they tasted like roasted marshmallows to me. Yuck. 

I had the Pear/Walnut Wedge salad. Which was pretty hysterical because there was no wedge to be found. In fact I thought they had brought me the wrong one at first. It was just some semi-crispy lettuce. The rest was fine. Nothing special. Double Meh. 

The menu seemed pretty comprehensive. But, I must admit. I come from New York where the Italian restaurants are on every corner. Which naturally makes me a bit biased to Italian fare. But this menu was just kinda meh. I like when I don't have a ton of choices, but the choices I did have didn't wow me. I settled on the Special of the Day - Hawaiian Sea Bass, topped with fresh crab,  with a vegetable/rice medley on the side. 

The rice was cooked fine. It was a bit cheesey, and had some freshly steamed veggies mixed in. It was nothing special and was in dire need of salt. The fish was grilled and the strength of the char flavor overwhelmed the entire dish for me. The fact that it was topped with some steamed crab was an absolute waste because the crab just got lost in the flavor of the char on the fish. And the entire plate was the same texture...mushy, soft, etc. It needed some crunch, or contrasting texture. Maybe the crab could've been mixed with breadcrumbs and parmesan to give a little crisp? Meh. I was underwhelmed and felt like I was eating at the cafeteria of an old folks home. 

WHICH, by the way was another factor. The median age of the patrons was EASILY around 65. It felt stuffy, and old fashioned...and not in a good way. 

Listen, it was FAR from the worst meal I've ever eaten. But it was eons away from the best. I would likely not choose to go back to Vivace on purpose. (i'd go if I had to for work and someone else was paying). It was pretty milk toasty...pretty meh. 

Did I mention MEH?
Snobby hosts. Sat at the bar for drinks. Decent service. Good drinks. I just like the delmar location instead.

Use to be much better. The bread they served us was so hard, I'm surprised I didn't dislocate my jaw eating it. My pasta had hard spots in it. The men's bathroom was really dirty as well. New owners maybe? Who knows, but we're not coming back. Service was ok though

Great taqueria with some awesome food. The ambiance is, well, lacking... but it is the place to go for some amazing tacos with corn tortillas made from scratch.

My favorites are the chicken taco, barabacoa, and lengua. Seriously, try the lengua... it is incredibly juicy and tender. The thick, homemade, chewy corn tortillas are really the perfect vessel for all that flavor. 

The horchata is also oh-so-refreshing --especially on a hot summer day in Tucson.

My least favorite was the fish taco. For me, the amount of mayo kinda ruined it for me. But you should definitely try it for yourself because many others rave about it and I'm just not too crazy about fish tacos in general.  The carne asada was also just meh. Was a little dry and under-seasoned.

I don't know how many hours I spent studying here in the last few months.  This is a great place to drink coffee/tea and surround yourself with smart-looking, productive young minds. Finding a spot can be tight on weekday nights or weekends during the school year, but I've never had to leave because I couldn't find a seat. It is a very dark shop though, so it can be very difficult to read a book at night or even during the day if you aren't located by the window. The seats can also be hard on the glutes after a few hours. 

I don't drink coffee so I can't comment on that, though I hear it's good. I do like the herbal teas and LOVE the chai. Best chai I've had so far in town. I also think it's great when coffee shops serve alcohol. Sometimes you just need a beer during your study sesh. I have tried their muffins and was quite impressed as well. 

Love Cartel--it's is my go to spot when I just can't be productive at home.

I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could. I have been to the Aristocrat a few times before, but this experience was just subpar. I expected it to be way more crowded this past Saturday night when I went. It was basically empty. It was super quiet and just was not the best environment for my party of 8. There was also a live band that had decent music. However, we were seated right next to the band so it was difficult to hear each other.

In regards to the food and drink menu, Aristocrat has an awesome selection of beer. I had Gumballhead and was very pleased. I ordered the tenderloin sandwich with a side salad. The tenderloin was amazing and the side salad was great. My boyfriend ordered the cottage pie and was not very impressed. I tried a bite and it was pretty dry and tasteless. He did enjoy the appetizers our party ordered.

Overall, I would return to Aristocrat. However, I would probably just sit in the bar area for a couple beers and an appetizer.

We ordered the tofu pad Thai and the pad broccoli. The pad Thai was basically drenched in sugar, the broccoli was undercooked and the chicken was tough. We also had the steamed dumplings, which were OK. After seeing so many positive reviews, this was a disappointment.

Ok so I ended up here because I wanted falafel and was just too lazy to walk to mamas. Anyway because I was short on time I got the samosas.. and omg they were amazing, I'm a giant fan of samosas, and usually I can get them for like .85 .. These samosas were 2.50 for 2 and were enormous, (well compared to the ones I usually get) and delish.. I can't wait to go back here and try some of their other food.. I love a place where I can eat practically everything on the menu.. makes like great :D 

my one qualm is with that groty dipping sauce they serve the samosas with. However, I hate bbq sauce or anything that resembles it or it's equally as disgusting counterpart ketchup, so perhaps my judgement on that can't be taken as seriously. 

anyway try to SAMOSAS because they were niceeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee
ehhh.. same as the one in old city but instead of jersey flooding the place. .it's a ton of st joes and manayunk people.. hmm go on a tuesday or thursday night.. good DJ, great music..

This review is based on the opinion of my meat eating partner who refuses to join yelp and write it himself lol. 

He had the classic burger and fries medium. He loved the burger but was underwhelmed by the staff . Turn around from ordering was rather quick however. The fries were well made and even I enjoyed them.

A coworker and I stopped by for lunch today and I'm kinda sad about the experience because I really like the area that restaurant is located. 

When we entered, we weren't seated by anyone. I actually left my coworker at the front, went to the restroom, and came back, and no one had still acknowledged her so I flagged someone down (not our waitress)-- I noticed that they didn't apologize about it, but that's not a terribly big deal really. 

Our waitress a sweet, lovely person, but unfortunately she forgot to put in our order. So we ended up having to ask for boxes concurrently with our meals. I know that those things can be a fluke, so I'm not actually factoring that into my score. Accidents happen-- that would be like scoring them poorly because a waiter spilled a water on the table. Not really kind or indicative of what the next experience would be like. 

Unfortunately, the food didn't make up for the gaffe with not getting seated. I ordered the corned beef reuben with brussels sprouts.  It came out completely dry and burnt-- very sad because I love corned beef. The bread was so hard it cut my mouth, so I tried to just eat it like an open sandwich-- fork and knife style, but the Brussels sprouts were dry yet a bit undercooked so the bitter flavor completely overwhelmed the meal. The beef was hard and dry-- about the texture of shredded jerky. :( I describe that sandwich with a heavy heart, people. I get no joy from this. 

I picked the dried meat off the bread and ate just that and the fries-- which I will say the fries were super tasty! 

It wasn't a cheap meal, and I was so disappointed with the experience and the taste. I will certainly go back and give it another try in case they were just having a bad day.

3.5 stars. If youre a local this is a nice place to check out. If youre a tourist, it is outside the touristy areas and honestly not worth the trek outside as there are better mexican places in the tourist areas (Casita Taquerita, Capital Taco & Red Mesa are all better for tacos).

I love coming here honestly bc of 2 things: (1) the outdoor patio is beautiful and dog friendly and (2) the large menu. The food is better than average hence why we have been here a few times and will continue to go. The food just doesnt have that wow factor to bump up to 4.

We have dined here for brunch and dinner. The menu here should have chapters it is so long! They even have a vegetarian menu! With so many options it is a solid choice for a group party. The drinks have been weak at dinner. So heads up.there. 

For brunch the omelettes were light, not too greasy and there was a decent amount of veggie stuffing. The house potatoes were not good - greasy and even though there was seasonings the taste fell flat. Not worth the carbs for sure.
Very good little dive. Food is wonderful and the service is very good. Wed is dollar taco day. Highly recomended!

I waited 1 hour 20 minutes for my pizza here and it was dry, bland, and CRAAAAAAAAP!!!!!! Only reason we ate here was because we were staying at Grand Sierra and were all sore from boarding all day.  NEVER AGAIN!!

After coming here several more times, I really feel it is necessary to mention the sheer lack of quality with regards to making sure orders are correct and lack of friendly customer service when issues are identified. I still enjoy the food, but these issues are a huge negative. A friend from work recently ordered her favorite soup and a lunch special she always gets for take out. Unfortunately she did not check it before she left, because the entire order was wrong. A completely different kind of soup and a totally different entree. I don't get it. These are the simple things that you would expect they would be getting right or at least trying to improve, but I just see it get worse. Also, if you happen to have an issue with your order, have fun explaining it to the surly older gentleman that appears to be "in charge." He gets frustrated and acts very unprofessionally in resolving the issue(s).

Buffalo Wild Wings, while the concept is good - Sports Bar where you can get appetizers - the service is horrid. Our first visit left us wondering if we were supposed to serve ourselves or if we'd get served. We were stuck behind a booth where no one would know we were there unless we were sitting on top of the table.

We had to keep going up and asking for our food, for utensils and anything else we might need. We were pretty much forgotten by our server who seemed it was better to flirt with the guys than to see if we might want anything else. We were interested in some dessert, but seeing as we might never see it, opted to pay our bill (Again, had to go up to the counter) and went to Coldstone. Such a shame. I doubt we'll be back again anytime soon.

Best dive bar in Nashville. Amazing jukebox. I see myself becoming a regular. It is your best home-away-from-home bar to date. Great back room. Good for late nights, not pre-drinking. 

Warning: Must love darts, smoke, smoke, and more smoke. Seriously, one of the last bars to smoke in here so you can imagine your clothes after leaving. It's like the Bog of Eternal Stench so make sure to put your clothes in the wash or hamper immediately!
The hosts we're not very happy to see or greet you, and looked like they did not know where to seat us. Food was good for the price.

This place was amazing, love the outside seating! Def will be back.  Katrina our server was awesome  and really knows the menu. The food was GREAT!! Fried chicken taco mmm chicken crispy and juicy, the sauce out of this world, spicy but yummy.. Beef filet taco so great and meat was sooo tender.. The side rice was so good, great flavor...the corn OMG  LOVE LOVE LOVE my husband says that veggies are not suppose to taste this good

Wish I could give Cooper's 3.5 stars.  I don't think it deserves a full 4 stars but I wouldn't necessarily consider it "average" either.  We arrived early on a rainy Friday night and were quickly seated in one of the long, lush, and plush red booths.  We ordered tasty dry and slippery wet reds, the new pork pizza, the pear/gorgonzola/spicy pecan salad, and a side of lemon spinach.  It was all tasty, but nothing entirely memorable.  I would have nixed the spinach since it definitely wasn't worth the $5.  We finished off the meal with the taco desert that was scrumptious.  The taco shell tasted like a super-sized cinnamon toast crunch graham square and was piled high with vanilla ice cream, white chocolate swirls, and an assortment of berries.  The entire taco of happiness was swimming in a bed of caramel and berry lava.  Quite good but I don't think I'll be back anytime soon.

We found ourselves in need of a snack after disappointing food selection at a festival we'd attended and saw great reviews of the bahn mi here.  We were not disappointed!  We did the grilled chicken bahn mi and the Brian's Special (grilled pork with egg).  Both were on wonderfully fresh bread, loaded with lightly pickled daikon and carrot (I could eat these veggies by the pound).  The filling to bread ratio was good and my dining buddies appreciated that the herbs and jalepenos came on the side.  I appreciated it too since I ended up with everyone's cilantro.  

The Child Who Eats Almost Nothing (seriously, she won't eat chicken) decided Pho sounded good.  When her tummy got full, we ended up with about half the portion.  As we were eating, we noticed some interesting ingredients in the Pho and asked her what she had told the cashier when she ordered.  She's never been one for bothering to read very closely or taking out her ear buds when ordering and apparently she requested with everything - including tripe and tendon.  When we pointed this out, she shrugged and said "Oh, I wondered what that was.  Tasted pretty good".  So, well done Seasons - you got someone who refuses to eat poultry and most veggies to blithely scarf down tripe and proclaim it pretty good.  No small feat!

Annnd we're back to 4 stars!

Ordered take out last night and had the Mango Chicken, Chicken Jal Frazie and roti. It was excellent! Only complaint is that the spice level was swapped on the dishes, (mine was medium, my friends was hot) but that's OK. It was still delicious and not greasy like last time!

Thinking my poor dish was just a fluke due to their high volume of customers. Keep it up!! :)

Martin's downtown location is absolutely the best. You can't beat the food, atmosphere, and perfect location (downtown but far enough from Broadway that it's not obnoxious). 
I can't speak much for the downstairs dining area because every time I come here I'm going up to the outdoor space on the second floor. It's an open aired rooftop area with a lot of seating, two bars, and a stage. I've often found myself here to begrudgingly watch some kind of sporting event but the food and awesome location always win me over. Their BBQ nachos can't be beat... it comes with a vinegar coleslaw on top which sounds weird but is incredibly delicious. Martin's is the best BBQ in town though, so you can order anything and you won't be disappointed. Also unless you are ravenously hungry, the nachos are plenty for two people to share. It's a nice quantity of food! 
They also offer a full bar with house cocktails, wine, and beer that is a perfect compliment to the mouthwatering BBQ. 
Martin's is a hit for tourist and locals alike!

We walked in on a Sunday morning and were told we're faced with at least a 20 minute wait, but we're told we can sit outside. It's a little cold outside but we're told the patio is "heated".

The one heater on the patio served it's purpose, but I did see others get up and go back inside.

My (server recommended) Copper Queen skillet and my wife's omelet took over half an hour to get to the table after we ordered. This could have been magnified by the fact that we had someplace to be all the way across town. The skillet was supposed to be eggs with all kinds of meat and stuff mixed in, on top of hash browns, covered in gravy. Had the menu not said it, I would not have believed there were eggs in there. I just couldn't taste them with all the other stuff. The gravy was good, but not the best I've had. The biscuit they served alongside was fluffy and really good... probably the best thing I had.

I can't say I am as gaga over this place as others. Maybe the extremely long wait  wait for our breakfast had a lot to do with it. Between that (what I hope was a) hiccup and the fact that this is way out of my way, unless I happen to be in the neighborhood, I doubt I'll return.

I work at a construction company within walking distance and wanted to try this as I drive by daily.   The BF and I went in at about 11AM for an early lunch.  There was four spots at counter.  We took two. The place is all counter seating.  It is basically a counter around a small kitchen.   Very small place, very small parking lot.  Anyway... Sat there for over 10 minutes just talking to each other while waiting for the waitress or one of the guys to get to us.  Not one person even acknowledged that we were there.  My other half asked if I wanted to leave.  I said, no, give it a couple of minutes.  Sat there, still nothing for another 5. ( I was on my lunch hour, so I keep an eye on what time I left and got in there.  I was clock watching, not to be a jerk, but to make sure I made it back to work on time).  A couple was standing and they had been standing since we walked in.  I thought they were there to get a to go order.  I asked the gentleman if he had been helped at all yet, he said no one had gotten to him yet.   At that point we decided to leave. They had been in there since before we parked and were still waiting, so this did not look good for us.  
I would have like to give a good review as I love small dives and mom and pops, but we were never even greeted or anything.     Maybe I will try again another time.

Legal Sea Foods gives seafood a bad rap - why is everything so expensive, why is the decor super cheesy, and why does the waiter service suck?

The first time I got the fish combo - 3 chefs selections of fish and 2 sides.  I asked the server what the fish were; he told me; I ordered.  Out comes 2 of the types that were mentioned, and swordfish.  Did I mention, I HATE SWORDFISH!?  That ruined my meal, bleh.

I figured that might be a fluke, so I gave it another shot this weekend while I was out shopping at KOP.  The clam chowder lacked something, but I'm not sure what.  Everyone else seated around us got rolls, except us, and I had to ask the server twice for ours.  They didn't arrive until after our entrees were almost polished off.  The rest of the food was ok, but seriously I'd rather wait an hour or two to eat at Cheesecake Factory, than eat at Legal Sea Foods ever again.

This has been one of my go to diner's since I was a little kid. Even in my high school years, from time to time, I would skip homeroom and or first period and head over to grab some always great breakfast at Ponzio's. I cant believe after being with my fiance for so many years, I have never taken her there. We needed to grab some food on our way to run some errands one Sunday morning, so we stopped in to grab a bite.

One of my friends lives nearby and always rants and raves about the place. He recommended getting the eggs benedict, so I wish I had gotten his recommendation first and not after I had already ordered, but I went the omelette route with pork roll and cheese, extra crispy hash browns, and an english muffin, while my fiance got a Belgian waffle with a side of scrambled eggs. Our server was super nice, and offered us great service throughout. My coffee cup was never less than half full the entire meal. The food was up quick, and we devoured it once it came out. Being a Jersey boy, pork roll is always a winner for me, and in an omelette, it is just as good. My one complaint about my breakfast was that the hash browns still werent crispy enough for me. I guess I like them borderline burnt, so it just wasnt quite enough texture for me, but the flavor was good. My fiance's waffle was excellent as well. It had a great crunch on the outside, but was still light and fluffy inside. Adding some butter and syrup created the perfect storm of breakfast goodness. It was an excellent waffle. 

The service is quick, the place is enormous, and the food is delicious. It is one of the best diners I have been to in the area for sure. I will definitely be trying the eggs benedict next time I go, and I am sure there is plenty more great things on their menu. Definitely worth a visit.

Ok at best. Definitely expected a lot more. Service was spotty at best and the food was merely ok. The dishes and glasses that came out of the back were dirty. Dirty so much that it was very off putting and gross. The coffee mugs on the table were dirty too. Get a new dishwasher folks. Not worth a visit

I really was not as impressed with this place as I thought I would be. I had seen it Diners Drive-Ins and Dives a while ago, but had  never made it out to Kensington to try it. My fiance's cousin was visiting from Miami, so we met her and her boyfriend there on a Sunday morning.

I loved the neighboorhood bar feel of the place and the beer selection was amazing. I was also really impressed with their vegan options. However, I wasnt very impressed with the execution of some of the food we ordered. I ordered the tailgate chilaquiles I have had chilaquiles before, but these were less than stellar. The chips had lost some of their crunch and were a bit soggy. I definitely felt like it needed some kind of sauce to pull it all together too. Maybe salsa or a queso sauce would work well with it.  I was extremely disappointed in the bacon and sausage. The bacon was undercooked leaving it limp and chewy and the sausage had no char on it at all as if it wasnt cooked enough either. The eggs and cheese were really great though.

My fiance had the Eggs Bednarik and hers was just ok as well. Again the meat wasnt cooked properly, and the holladaise wasnt special by any means. The eggs were cooked perfectly and the english muffin was tasty. The things that we were most impressed by were the bloody maries and the peanut butter and banana french toast. The bloody maries were very well done and had a nice blast of heat to them. It was a perfect hair of the dog fixer upper for me that morning. The stuffed french toast was sublime. The bread was fantastic and the combination of peanut butter and banana made for heavenly bites. I was so glad we all shared it, but after tasting it, I wish i had ordered it for my breakfast!

I want to come back to Memphis Taproom to give it another shot. I have heard the coconut club is outstanding, and I think they may fare a bit better with lunch or dinner selections. Definitely check it out.

I've now been to DT three times and I was really hoping my experience would improve from the first visit, however, it has not. I am writing this review as I sit waiting on my food that I JUST ordered after an hour and a half. Both times I have visited with a large party, the reservation somehow fell through. Each time, they placed the party on the patio and told us we could snag tables as they open up. Of course, this method resulted in TERRIBLE service (hence the long wait) since servers were confused on who was taking care of who. The manager formally apologized on my second visit with a large party and sent the table appetizers on the house, yet nothing changed. Our first waitress was extremely unprofessional and whenever we asked for help from other wait staff, we were told that they were taking care of other parties so they couldn't help. Understandable but you'd think SOMEONE would find a waiter to solve the issue. 

The visit I made with a small group for a weeknight dinner was better but the food was subpar at best. 

They either need to nix their reservation policy on the weekends or figure out a way to make it MUCH better than it is currently.

Small place hidden away on Alt 19 in Dunedin. I usually stop by on the weekends a few times per month. Very wide selection of bottled and draft beers, so there is something to fit any beer lovers taste buds. My favorites lately are the victory golden monkey (hello 10% alcohol content) and banana bread ale, although there selection does change from time to time, so always new ones to try. Both indoor and outdoor seating is available and there is usually a live band playing. You can also bring your dog on the patio if you'd like to have your trusty companion along. I wish they served more food than just chips or peanuts as I am usually ready for a hearty snack after a few beers, but I suppose food is just not their specialty. My other complaint that brings HOB down a notch is sometimes the bartenders seem a bit cold,
uninterested or arrogant. Some are better than others but I've had a few sour experiences on certain occasions. Overall, It's a nice hang out spot to chill with friends and enjoy some local beers.

On our way to Orlando for the weekend, we stopped in search of fast food without the heavy, greasy feel. My trusty yelp app lead us here. Fresh kitchen allows you to build your own bowl from the base to the toppings. 

I chose the sweet potato zoodles and green rice with Thai chicken, mushrooms and a ginger sauce. Very flavorful and fresh. The portion size for the smaller option was still filling although I'd probably choose the 6 option next time. Even my super picky toddler liked her bowl with zoodles, chicken and broccoli. 

All in all, it's a great option for those who want a quick bite without breaking your diet

My fiancé and I had come to try this out about a week ago and it wasn't open yet, well they were having their trial run so we finally got to try it today! We also were given a free coffee so that was a added bonus.

The decor inside is very fresh and welcoming. The staff were welcoming and polite. There wasn't a line when we came but there was one after we ordered and sat down. Menu wise it is similar to that of Panera with the panini's, salads, sandwiches and dinner items. I order the Chicken Apple Sausage Panini and a coffee. When walking to the Coffee area there were employees gathered in front of the coffee and I attempted to excuse myself and no one moved (thus the 3 stars). So after I politely moved my way into the coffee i decided on the Cafe Euorpa which was pretty decent.  My sandwich however was amazing! The panini was pressed to perfection! The amount of sausage and egg was more than enough. So much so that I could only eat half of it and gave the other half to my fiancé. 

I will defiantly come back to try some new things in the future!

Where to start? First visit tonight with our 6-yr old. Should have turned around and walked out when we walked in at 5:30 and there was barely room to stand and wait and there were only a few people ahead of us. The restaurant has 6 tables and 4 are "community seating" style. To add injury to insult, the seats are short, barstool types leaving you no place for your coat or purse. We were told the wait would be "15 mins, maybe less" and waited on the flip side of 30, finally walking out without having been seated. The staff (hostesses) were aloof with no sense of urgency or purpose.  Won't be returning.

This location has the slowest and least friendly service of any McD's I've ever visited. I don't expect much because... it's McDonalds, but...this location lowers the bar to new sub-standards. The drive-thru is sloooowww and if you go in? It's often dirty. Do yourself a favor and drive five minutes into the Zionsville village and go to that location.

My husband and I stopped by here during an impromptu trip to St. Charles. I'm so glad we did!

Our server was awesome!! We found out we have both moved from Huntington Beach so we had a common denominator right off the bat. She was so personable and knowledgeable about the wines and menu.

We had one of the flatbread specials - it had prosciutto, mascarpone, and butternut squash. We took her advice that it was good and it was! We also had spinach and artichoke dip. It was great but way overshadowed by the pizza.

We both loved the ambiance and feel of the restaurant. There's a great patio out front but we opted for indoors because it was chilly. 

I highly recommend a stop here!

Surprised to find an Asian dessert place in Tucson!  We tried the white snow with panna cotta (reminds me of almond jello), coconut jelly, boba and red beans and an egg puff (Hong Kong bubble waffle).  The former was pretty good, but the "snow" was nonexistent.  I was expecting a huge mound of snow like they give you in LA, but you end up with mostly topping.  

The waffle was very good, but fairly small for the price.  I'm glad to have this variety in Tucson, but I'm not sure we'll come back as it just seems a bit expensive for what you get.

Came in on a weeknight at 6:30 ish for dinner.....the place was empty, apparently the almost full parking lot was an indication of Mudbugs Bar being busy. The lone server/cashier/waitress seemed out of it...she actually rested her head on the counter as if we were an imposition while we considered at this point of we would eat there at all and looked at the menu..... Nobody in the kitchen as if she was the last man standing so to speak.  End of story.....we left...only because we have eaten here before and the food was good...I give it 2 stars.

NO. We ordered a meal with steamed broccoli. The broccoli came out literally raw, slightly warm. I told the server. He said sorry. And that was it. He also claimed that they had the best sushi in town. I ordered the tiger roll; it was $15 and small and not as advertised on the menu. Only saving grace was the 2-4-1 beers during happy hour. I will not return. It was also dead; any restaurant in Nashville that's dead on any given night is a big red flag.

I wanted to like this venue, but the food is just terrible. 

I ordered a cobb salad, and I was so grossed out I could hardly touch it. First of all, the lettuce tasted old and fishy--like they left it out on the sushi bar all night. I did not eat any of the lettuce. That left me with chicken and avocado for my meal. The avocado was fine, but the chicken was rubbery and tasted processed. The meal grossed me out so badly I could never go back for that reason alone. But that wasn't all. 

Another at the table ordered the Margherita pizza. She offered me some because she felt bad that I had nothing to eat. Bland. Not good. I did not want another piece. 

The other at the table ordered a half sandwich and soup. It did not even look appetizing. I did not bother asking to try it. 

I would never go back.

Terrific value on the west side.   When you think of sushi in Indianapolis, you usually think of the Castleton area, not W. 10th St.   However, you would be missing a real diamond in the rough.   Located in a converted Pizza Hut, the restaurant is not much to look at.   Sparse decorations, outdated booths and tables get you when you step inside.   After you are seated tell your server your party is having the all you can eat sushi.   'Nuff said.  Don't mess around with ordering from the a la carte menu.   It's pointless.   When you get your plastic laminated sushi menus, you also get a dry erase marker to mark your orders.   And it's not just sushi.  There are soups, salads, and appetizers to choose from.   Don't make the rookie mistake of ordering to much the first round.   For one, you want your rolls, nigiri, sashimi, etc, to come out fresh and not sit on your table for too long.  Also if you waste more than 7 pieces, they will charge you extra.

There is a vast array of hot and cold rolls for you to share amongst you party.   There is also a decent selection of nigiri and sashimi for the true sushi connoisseurs.   All for $24 per person (less Mon-Wed).

This place definitely does not stand out in this new world of burger joints on every corner.

From the start, I knew service here was going to be spotty.   There was a sign outside that clearly stated there were happy hour beer specials on this day.  However, when I asked the clerk at the counter which beers were on special, she said those specials were only for lunch (which if were true, would be in violation of state liquor law).   Fortunately, when she rung up my order, I noticed my beer was in fact discounted.

So, as you may have guessed, at Flamme Burger you order from a counter, get a number, and they bring your food (and beer) to your table.   However, our food came out in waves instead of all at once.   I really would have liked to have my fries (more on those later) when my burger arrived.

As for those fries, they were advertised as truffle parmesan fries.   Now I know they wouldn't use real truffle oil (too expensive), but how about some real parmesan cheese instead of that sawdust that (I believe) doesn't even require refrigeration?

The burger itself was pretty good.   I ordered their namesake burger expecting it to be amazing.   It had good flavor, but it was pretty small for $9.95 (fries not included).

As for the atmosphere, it seems very corporate and sterile.  I know it's supposed to be a "local" place (there is only 1 other location in Whitestown). but it just doesn't feel that way.   There are a lot of TVs, which would make one think this is a good place to catch a game, but the way the TVs are mounted results in a lot of obstructed views so I would find another place to cheer my team.

Maybe if I lived in the condos above the restaurant I might visit Flamme Burger a few times per year (for the convenience alone), but there are far too many burger joints that are miles ahead of this place.

SKB is still going strong after all these years.   Even after all the expansion and opening of satellite locations, the original retains some of that microbrewery feel.   If course some things have changed : there's a deli (Smoking Goose) inside where you can get food, there are a lot more beers on tap (about 30 instead of just 4 when they opened), there's a nice outdoor deck, etc.

I dined in this building many times when it was a Jamaican restaurant with a lunch buffet and a DJ.   I kind of wish it was still that.

I had the chicken and waffle at the new place and it was kind of expensive for what I got.    The chicken was OK, but not any better than what I could get at any national chain fast food chicken restaurant.    The waffle was pretty disappointing though.   It was soggy and had very little flavor.   I swear it was just Bisquick.

I also had their sweet tea and it was downright terrible.    I guess it's a good thing I was never offered a refill (even though I was seated directly in front of the checkout area where my waitress was standing the entire time).

I was trepidatious at first when approaching Pei Wei.  I know it is the lower-priced outlet of P.F. Chang's and did not have high expectations.  However, once inside, all those preconceptions were washed away (in endless soda!).  You order from the counter in front by the door off of an LCD menu.  You take your drink cup and walk to the back and then experience the coolest Coca-Cola machine ever.  It looks like an old refrigerator, except it has a big touchscreen in front.  There you select what base pop you want (i.e.  Sprite, Fanta, Coca-Cola, Coke Zero, etc.) and thne you select what flavor you want to add (i.e. grape, orange, raspberry, peach, etc.).  Make REAL cherry coke!

As for the food itself, it is by no means great (or even authentic), but it is definitely not bad and it's cheap as well ($7-9).  There are plates on each of the tables so you can dine family-style as Asian food is meant to be served (a definite plus in my book).

I would definitely return if even just to order a drink.

I've never seen a restaurant with so many cooks, yet so few servers.   There were at least 10 guys cooking on the line (I noticed because there were always 5-ft high flames flaring up on the stove - I actually think they do it on purpose for the show).   They were churning out dishes like crazy that just died in the window waiting to be picked up.     Our food arrived lukewarm and our quick lunch took almost an hour.

The Beef a la Sichuan was OK flavor-wise, but the meat was dry and overcooked.   The honey chicken was cooked alright, but had almost no flavor.  The white rice was an embarrassment.   I admit, I'm a bit of a rice connoisseur (i.e. snob), but this stuff was so dry and lacking of any character whatsoever.

The ambiance is actually quite classy and seems appropriate for a business lunch or a casual date.

I had been to the former Chinese buffet at this location and when I returned to see its resurrection as Formosa Seafood Buffet, I was astounded.   The owners must have spent a fortune renovating the interior.   I barely recognized the place.  The only feature I remember is the big fountain at the entrance and even that was changed significantly.   The whole place is done in kind of a trendy black marble look.

First of all, everything about this place is huge (see my pictures).   In the buffet room, there are no fewer than 8 buffet islands to go along with the buffets that line the walls.

The price is a bargain as well.   $15.99 for dinner?   This completely blows away the competition considering the number of items they have available.

I think the $9.99 Saturday/Sunday brunch (i.e. dim sum) is the best deal.   Dim sum in Indianapolis has a sad and sordid history.   Traditional dim sum (the kind with rolling carts that pass by your table) just doesn't seem to be able to survive in this town.   The alternative that has managed to hang on is ordering a la carte.    Formosa manages to up the ante by offering a buffet version.   There are about a dozen hot/cold items to choose from.

Formosa Seafood Buffet really lives up to the "seafood" part of its name.   There are several grilled fish and shrimp dishes.   There is a large sushi bar in the back with nigiri, maki, and sashimi.   They also have crawfish, squid, and several other seafood dishes that are too numerous to remember.

As in most Chinese buffets now, there is a Mongolian grill on the right side where you can choose your ingredients and have someone cook it for you on the flattop.

A nice addition in the back is the noodle soup bar.   Pick your ingredients (shrimp, onions, fish balls, napa cabbage, etc.), your noodle (pho or ramen) and your broth (beef or chicken).  Then someone cooks it for you.   Yum.

There is a huge room on the right side which can be reserved for large parties/wedding receptions, etc.   In addition, there are 3 "VIP Rooms" on the left side which can be reserved for smaller functions.   There is no additional charge to use these rooms.  Simply call ahead and let the restaurant know how many people will be attending.   They will simply charge you the normal buffet price based on the number of guests.

Ohhh this place is going to hurt my bank account but make my body so so happy. The pricing here is really good don't get me wrong! Actually the pricing is way better than what I was paying back home when I lived in Texas. The reason why it's dangerous is because I'm addicted to them. Their juices are made to order and you have to try their signature "It's not easy being green".

This place is walking distance so I'll be back I'm certain of it. They also do delivery and you can get your fave juice in a half gallon or galloon size!

Also make sure to utilize their Yelp check in special.

I've ordered breakfast from here through Uber Eats when I'm hungover and not in the mood to get out of bed or cook at that. It's held up perfectly fine and gets the job done. It's within a short distance so I get the food delivered fairly quick. Pricing is more than fair and I do like the hashbrowns here.

During my visit to New Orleans for VooDoo Music Festival, I had a chance to check out Who Dat Coffee Cafe. I'm a night owl so it's nice to know this spot was opened late. This city gem has such character and I had a great iced latte.

There's a few outdoor tables to take advantage of and they even have a few food options. I'll need to come back to try.

Some of the friendliest folks work here and their hospitality alone is worth coming back for.

I was struggling on this rating since the food itself was actually not bad, but it is not good enough to justify other aspects of the experience. The main thing is that the prices are quite high for what you are getting, and this does not appear to be because a tip is included. I ordered some basic alcoholic drinks and expected a high price, but on top of the liquor price I was charged for the diet coke mixer separately. I have never been anywhere where they charged a high price for liquor and then charged extra for a basic mixer. In addition as others have mentioned nothing is included with the food price, even white rice. The portions are also relatively small, but none of these details would bother me if the food itself was mind blowing, but it was not. Perhaps a different dish would have made the experience seem better, but as it stands I am not motivated to return. It is probably the best Asian food in that part of town, so as I always say, your experience may vary and judge for yourself.

Used to be one of my favorite place but it gets old even if you do try everything on the menu.  Still pretty good place to go for a good soup and or salad.  If you do crave a sandwich, my fav. is the Thanksgiving Turkey.

Nada is ONE CLASS ACT!!!  Indianapolis has been rewarded with a great honor to be home to this beautiful dining experience.  This is not a Mexican restaurant. Nada is a Latin American vacation.  When is the last time you had cold chills when walking into a restaurant ?  The beauty and comfort of Nada is unlike anywhere in the city.  A special and                                                            roomy table for any size party of two to much larger groups.  Our server, Rick was one of the most knowledgable and attentive we have had in a long time. It is apparent that the entire staff is well trained. The communal menu offers so many interesting dishes that we let our well educated server make the suggestions for us. We were not disappointed. My recommendation is start with a unique margarita, salsa and a taco entree with one side of Nada Fries. We saw so many interesting plates being delivered, that I will remain purposely vague. You deserve to make the hard decision for yourself!!  Nada is on our list to entertain friends and family. I love to be complemented on restaurants I choose for dining dates.

Pretty good, but you could easily beat it with a Weber Smoker at home. The sauce was the best part. I waited in a line that was out the door, only to learn at the counter they had been out of Brisket for hours. Got chicken, it was just ok  Customer service pretty weak, reminded me of the BMV.

Our family went to Dave and Buster's to go bowling, the Friday before Christmas.  We were there about 20 min, and we told our server, as we had ordered some food, that the floor was sticky and impacting our ability to bowl properly.  A little while later, I asked our server, again, about it, and she said she would send the manager over.  In short, the manager said it was a known issue between their cleaning product and the shoes and that the floors are only cleaned once a week.  The manager did not offer to do anything to resolve the issue or to make us feel good about it.  To add insult to injury, the monitors that show our scores regularly post to let mgmt know if the floors are either sticky or slippery so they can take care of it.  We were not pleased, at all.
Great food made to order. I tried chicken red curry and chicken pad thai. Both were great. I highly recommend stopping by.
the food is great and they have an extensive bar, but the service is lacking. the waiters/waitresses are very slow and the background music didn't suit the setting.

This place has great ambience. But the food is not good. The food is very weird. Like it's from a place that borders pak, afghan and india (th truth is the three countries don't share a border) the food is as unreal. Lot of heavy cream and colors. The prices are too high. I guess they charge for the ambience. I have heard a few folks praise the food here. My guess is they haven't tried true indian food! Here is a tip: if after you eat at an indian restaurant you feel full and sleepy. It's not good indian food. Indian food made with good oils and clarified butter will not make you feel too stuffed or heavy.

One Shot Coffee is a whimsical, refurbished place near the heart of NoLibs, offering delicious Stumptown Coffee and various breakfast items for purchase.
