We were seated right at the entrance, even though there were several low and high-top tables available near the main attraction of the restaurant - the car bay. Although servers were generally attentive, they seemed more interested in selling me more beer than making sure we had utensils for the dishes ordered. I had a chili bowl and a fajita chicken salad. Common sense is that when the table set-up only includes a knife and fork, you bring a spoon out with soup or chili. Chili was pretty much flavorless and could have been gotten from a can. Not asking for five alarm product here, but it needs to be at least seasoned. Same with the chicken on the salad; I'm sure it was microwaved hours ago and then cut-up because there were no grill marks and it wasn't seasoned at all. It was also cold and rubbery at this point. Chicken should be warm when served on a salad and be seasoned and grilled. Girlfriend's burger was ordered medium rare, but came well done. You could see where cook had cut into the burger several times to check doneness. Sure sign of a cook that doesn't know how to. I would think that would have helped him get it right, but that didn't happen. Fries were of the Sysco catalog variety. Definitely not cut in-house and surely not seasoned there. You usually find this kind in dive bars that serve them with packaged chicken fingers or something. I'm not saying this place is going to be on Restaurant Impossible tomorrow or anything, but if they don't get the food and service shored-up, it'll be curtains for them in 3 years max. I don't think the project car garage and the bar will keep them afloat forever.

This spot head absolutely amazing food.  The beer can be ordered in flights and is good.  Yet, the food is still the reason to visit.  I did not sit in their beer garden at the back of their lot but it looked really nice.

We felt very welcomed since we walked through the door by the bartender who knows what he is doing.  The drinks (manhattan  and dirty martini) were good and all were made correctly.  We only dropped in for a drink but have come for food before and this place is small but a staple on main street.  And, to date, the only place we've found that serves a pickle martini, which is good!

Went here on a Wednesday afternoon, not that busy. It was a nice day, but a little on the warmer side, so we sat inside where there was A/C. There is a seating area in the back that I wish I had checked out.

Service was friendly and prompt. I had eggs benedict floretine with lox and it was delicious. I'm not a fan of the potato wedges, I kinda like hash but the seasoning on the potatoes made them really tasty. We left totally full. They had so many awesome stuff on the menu, it was really hard to choose!

I hope I can find another weekday to come around and try the rest of their food. They really lived up to the hype!

I've been here for a wonderful Father's Day brunch and the food was great! I loved the warm bread with the delicious strawberry butter. The food was also good and the portions were just right. We were seated by an open window with a nice breeze.

Recently I came here with a groupon for a Monday night dinner. It wasn't busy and I called ahead and they said we could just walk in. The outdoor seating didn't look very comfortable so we sat inside. We had a great server, I think her name was Ashley. She had a lot of input on the food and answered our questions. Great service! We ordered 2 small plates, the Thai chili shrimp which was really tiny pieces but very tasty and the short rib mac and cheese which was also very good. We still had room for our entrees, the flat iron steak and the scallops. My guy loved his steak and really enjoyed it and I also enjoyed the food and the friendly service. Had to end it with profiteroles :)

The Groupon really saved over 50% of the bill so that made the experience a lot more satisfying.
Food was delicious! It may be the best seafood gumbo I've ever had. My husband had oysters and said they were delicious! Service is ok, not great but not terrible. Would recommend for food alone!

Should had read the reviews before I ordered! I always check, but decided to trust the hotel staff! what a joke of place! I called and they hung up after i waited 20 min on hold, (fine they were busy) so i called back. Ordered and would be 45-60 min wait, i am still fine with that, when the Establishment is busy that's good pizza. (well that's what I thought) 2 hours later no pizza, and when i called they said they tried to delivered, and called me. I asked to speak with the manager, and the manager was out delivering pizza because they were short handed... once the ordered finally arrived (over 3 hours after the order) the pizza was cold and the drinks were hot... I still tipped the delivery, since he was only the delivery guy and following orders... needless to say will not be ordering from this place again...

Took a couple friends to Los Betos for breakfast burritos on the way to the lake this morning.  We ordered 3 breakfast burritos and the woman taking our order and serving us at the window was VERY rude!  She only got the first 2 orders to begin with.  I made sure she added the 3rd burrito.  However,  when we got home EVERY burrito we ordered was WRONG!  
It's not too hard to mess up... One bacon, one sausage, and one breakfast burrito with NO meat.  Very disappointed because we were bragging to our friends how huge and delicious their burritos were.

This is the second time we have had really really bad service here. Unfortunately we will not be coming back. Our server was nice, she did a horrendous job but she was  nice. Our food came out after a long time, and our fries were cold. We couldn't find our server bc she was so busy doing side work that my husband finally messed with the tablet on the table to "call server" so we could get some drink refills. She did refill them finally and then disappeared again, we finally just used the tablet to check out because we couldn't locate our server. If my husband has a craving for bottomless fries again we will have to try the Sparks location.

I ordered the chicken Katsu take out which came with a generous portion of chicken, rice, and macaroni salad.  The downside was that the chicken katsu was not freshly prepared.  I appreciate the speediness of the business (probably trying to accommodate lunch hour folks from nearby businesses) but I would have gladly waited the extra 10-15 mins for freshly fried chicken katsu.  The macaroni salad didn't have much flavor but it wasn't bad per se and I ended using my own katsu sauce that I had in the fridge than the one prepared by them. Sadly the best thing was the sticky white rice lol. (Hard to come by in a town where there is very little good asian restaurants!) I'll try this place again but will opt for something grilled on menu and hope that it is better!

I headed to Woodlands earlier this week for a group outing. The Indian, vegatarian, no alcohol setting isn't exactly the ideal hot spot for this carnivorous drinker who doesn't like Indian food. Nonetheless, I enjoyed the experience! I tried the appetizer sampler which seemed to me to just be various breaded,deep-fried vegetables, and weren't particularly exciting, but did come with some interesting sauces, one which was bright green and great for people like me who enjoy some spicy flair. I was very hungry and didn't want to be stuck with a dinner I didn't like, so I wussed out and ordered the vegetarian noodles (spicy, of course). The noodles were great, though probably more Chinesey than Indian. In short, I really enjoyed my visit against all odds. Thus, if you like vegatarian Indian food (hold the glass of wine), I bet you'll love Woodlands!

In my Ramen hunt around the Bay area & after seeing so many good reviews i REALLY wanted to check this place out for quite some time. After my visit, i'm sad to say i couldn't help but walk away just a little disappointed. 

Maybe my taste buds have been spoiled by having had the chance to eat ramen at a few memorable places in NYC (ippudo, momofuku ... just to name a few) this one fell a little short in comparison. 

Chashu Ramen - the ramen was very salty. A friend who also was eating with us also considered herself a "ramen snob" and has had ramen at numerous spots in California also thought the same. I was totally shocked! The pork pieces in the ramen were huge but a little tough and seemed like it had been cooked a little too long. The noodles were good but what killed it was the salty broth. 

Takoyaki - This was the one dish i was also really excited to have because i dont know of any other places in the bay area that has this authentic Japanese dish. This dish consists of Battered deep fried balls of octopus pieces covered with shaved bonito flakes. Although it came with four pieces, they were very small and the batter just tasted like globs of fried fat.

Karaage appetizer - Deep fried pieces of chicken which pretty much tasted just like that ... deep fried pieces of chicken. nothing out of the ordinary here in taste as it was just flavorless to me even with the mayo like tasting sauce it came with.

Maybe it was just the fact that it was super busy here when we arrived (A Wed's night), the place only had one cook at the time & the waiter was very nice so ill give it a silght pass. this place has a lot of potential and i really hope they do well but for now ill just have to keep on with my ramen search.

OMG!  What a place!  Old house with green and brown-yellow walls, only 6 tables and two employees-owners. This husband and wife team works really hard. It feels like you are eating in your grandma's kitchen. She actually told us: "You ate good today" when we were finished with our meal.  The owner wears a tee shirt: "Trust me, I'm a ninja". 

So we tried pineapple fried rice, shrimp pad Thai. Both were just amazing. Fried ice cream was awesome.  Try it, you won't be disappointed.

I used to love this place and come regularly but lately the service has become terrible. At first I was as thinking it's an isolated incident but this terrible service has become consistent. Food remains good but terrible service truly kills entire experience.

I ordered chicken lunch special. The portion was small, but what can one expect for 5 bucks?  The chicken was very good, moist and had very good flavor. Hummus and salad were ok, but not amazing. The owner was very friendly. I looked around the store which is attached to the restaurant, but was disappointed how few options they had. All in all, I would eat there again.
Great addition to Carmel and its proximity to UBC.  Goat curry was solid and the jerk chicken was also very good.  Portions were a tad small, but the flavors were spot on.

Lunch is solid, but after three lunches here, I'd say dinner is and will continue to be the star of the show.  As many other reviewers have noted, this place has a super-cool aesthetic; especially the bar area.  Service is consistently friendly, attentive, and helpful; providing additional detail and context around the dishes, the space, and the components/flavors to expect.  While Indy has certainly seen it's ramen-game raised over the past few years, you'd be hard pressed to say Bluebeard's is not the best.  
Each dish we've had was well-executed, used high quality ingredients, and were all dishes I would re-order if they appear again on the menu.
I'll leave you with this: an acquiantance of ours ,who is a local chef, said without a doubt, Bluebeard is his top pick in Indy.  I'd say it would be foolish to argue that opinion.  By the way, you need to get dessert here. . . or take it home like we did after we hit the wall from charcuterie, salad, seafood, and ramen.

First time here.  Wanted to try something new.  Food wasn't too bad.  With the prices,  I expected it to be a lil better.  I didn't really care for the alcoholic drinks, we had Long Islands.  The service was great.  Nice friendly staff.  Clean bathrooms.

After watching crowds outside for a while had to try it for breakfast since I live right around the corner.   The place the almost empty at 8 on a Saturday which was a change from what I had observed driving by so decided to stop in.   

I got the biscuits and gravy with grits and eggs ordered over easy.   Eggs came out burnt with hard yokes.   Biscuits are not fresh made and were dense and chewy like they were frozen and thawed.    I sent the eggs back and a few minutes later got back slightly above raw eggs which was clearly an angry line cook making a statement.    

The coffee and grits were good though.   But that won't bring me back.   First Watch and The Brunchery are better options in the area.  Even Waffle House above this place.

Went here for lunch based on Craig LaBan's review...the cumin beef skewers appetizer that he recommended in the review were amazing! Also had the Ma-La Hot with chicken, and boy was that spicy. Make sure to have plenty of water handy.  My husband had the spicy beef noodle soup which was very good but not as spicy as the Ma-La Hot.  On another occasion, my husband tried the spicy sour minced pork noodles, which is actually a soup, and he loved it.

The atmosphere of this restaurant is "basic Chinatown" so don't come here expecting anything fancy.  There is a tv screen on the wall that has a running slide show of photos of various menu items.

Because the restaurant was busy, we sat with some other people at one of the two large round tables in the back and got to see a few things they ordered. The Biang Biang noodles looked interesting, they are a huge thick, long noodle I am not sure what the sauce is. They also had the liang pi noodles, which were mentioned in LaBan's review, as these did not all get eaten they may not have liked them as much.

When I return I will plan to try more items under the "Chef's Recommendations" like the Chinese Hamburger and the sauteed spicy chicken and noodles.

This is one of the nicer bar/restaurants in Manayunk, with an upscale atmosphere and prices to match.

Both times I've been here, I've had the salads and pizza rather than the entrees which are bit pricey at 25 and up. The pizzas are fairly good size, so if you have a moderate appetite two people could order salads (12-15) and share one pizza (about 15), and your meal would be in the range of $45-50 before drinks. 

My one knock on this place would be the wine by the glass selection- for a place that bills itself as a wine bar, I would think they could come up with a better tasting selection.  The wines by the glass are in the range of 11-12, and taste like they are from $12 bottles of wine.  They do have an extensive list if you are willing to buy a bottle, and I think that would be the better way to go here. 

On the other hand, there is a nice selection of beer on tap as well as about two dozen craft beers in bottles.  So I give Jake & Coopers two thumbs up for the beer, pizza and salads.  As a wine bar, though, it doesn't hold  candle to the wine bars in Philly like Tria and Zavino.

Edit:  Apparently the restaurant won a Wine Spectator award, as the manager informed me when he read my review here on Yelp. So, if you are impressed by that, you may want to discount my comments about the disappointing glass pour list. I'll just say that I  wasn't impressed with what I drank and leave it at that.

I've been to Mikes two times...once for an Italian hoagie, which was good but nothing that stood out in my mind. 

One time for cheesesteak.  I did not like the meat which was sliced, not chopped, and came out very dry.  I only ate half of it.

My take: if you are in the Comcast Center, Di Bruno's is a better bet for sandwiches.

I had the Shack-cago dog, It was delish with pickles, onions, hot peppers, relish etc. The crinkle cut fries were crispy and good dipped in ketchup.

My husband had the Shackburger with cheese, and he thought it was not as good as Big Mac.:(

One nice thing, you can have beer with your meal.  I plan to return to try the shakes next time.

Tucked away in the Chinatown food court on Race St, this fast food restaurant dedicated to delivering curry dishes has two different levels of spice. The milder Japanese spicy level and the spicier Southeast Asian.

I'm not sure how much curry the typical diner expects, but I ordered the Southeast Asian curry dish and I felt like my food was swimming in a soup of oily spicy curry. The curry was a little overwhelming and if I come back I'll ask for less curry.

That said, there is a very enjoyable hint of peanut in the curry sauce and the chicken katsu I ordered was crispy and very well seasoned. If you enjoy crunchy breaded chicken, then you can't go wrong with katsu.

The staff was very welcoming and very patient. I recommend their sour dipping sauce available at the register. The staff rightly recommended that it would accompany my rice really well.

You'll also find some Japanese potato buried in to get soup of curry. It tasted a little less well done than I'd like but that could just be traditional preparation.

My mom had been wanting to try this place for awhile. It's a very cute restaurant and bar. The menu looks amazing, so many good options. The food, pretty pretty bad. My dad got a roast beef sandwich, the waiter said it was as thinly sliced as you could get. In reality it was a bunch of thick fatty pieces, he didn't even eat it. My mom got salmon which was good but not cooked the way she asked, and she asked multiple times. I got scallops which were okay, a few were cooked perfectly and a few were almost raw. Overall come to this place for the bar, do not eat, especially in the dining room. The service was so slow we had to ask multiple times for them to fill our waters or even give us any attention.

I have been to Hawkers several times and almost every time has been amazing. There has only been one instance where my order was mixed up, however the staff was always polite and apologetic. 

The food here is always on point. I normally get the pork belly steamed buns and the roti bread for starters. If you have never tried either, I suggest that you do....seriously, you'll thank me. For my main entree I normally get the pad thai because it is some of the best I have ever had! The only food item I did not like was the meatballs they have as an appetizer. 

Service is generally pretty good and the staff here is always polite. It can get crowded sometimes which can make the kitchen become a little backed up, but nothing out of the ordinary. I highly suggest anyone who has not tried Hawkers, to try it out.

The location is a plus and negative. French Quarter, so parking is a pain, but amazingly it's in a relatively quiet part of the Quarter, so once you're inside it doesn't feel like it's in the Quarter.

Great breakfast, I believe I had the Eggs Stanley. The coffee is decent, not great but the food was really good and for the area moderately priced. It is really small so there could potentially be issues with wait times, luckily we came when they were slow.

I took my wife here for her birthday, and of course we did the Feed Me 4 course option.

The restaurant was a lot smaller than I expected, which was a good thing. The staff was very attentive, and very nice. The chef then came over to ask us about allergies/preferences, and we told him we were 100% open to anything.

Before I start this next part of the review, let me just say that all the food far passed my expectations in terms of taste and quality. That being said I was a little disappointed to hear/see that the tables around us getting the Feed Me option received all the same courses we did. While the food was excellent, that fact that we weren't given a "unique" menu as we expected was disappointing.

The only thing I'd complain about if I have to is the limited wine menu, but that won't stop me from going back in the future.

This was my third visit to Buenos throughout the years.  First visit was about 8 years ago, second 2 years ago and then yesterday.   The food has been consistently bland.  I thought I would try it again craving Mexican food in the area and thought maybe it has changed or I just ordered something bland in previous visits. 

This order: chicken taco, chicken burrito, and fish burrito with side of beans and rice.  $30

Very basic chicken taco. Cabbage, chicken, some salsa. 

My side order of beans and rice were both thrown into one small container rather than separately.  I thought they forgot one and realized there were about 4 bites of each mixed in one container. 

Burritos:  black beans, rice, chicken and salsa for chicken burrito. 
Fish burrito same substitute fish instead of chicken. 

Didn't realize that you have to ask and pay extra for cheese?  Figured this out when I brought it home and everyone asked where it was.  

Pros: Atmosphere is inviting inside and out. Good location, though Eclipse pizza which never disappoints and Walden's which is great for breakfast is in the same shopping center. 

Customer service: Decent, fast, fairly friendly but it's apparent the regulars are treated with more interests. 

The bottom line in my opinion?  You can get a better burrito with more flavor and ALL the fixings at Laughing Planet, Super Burrito, and some of the Mexican restaurants on Wells Ave for less than $10 as well with cheese!
For fast food, staff is friendly place is clean. what else can you really say about a fast food joint
Compared to the Chestnut Street location in Center City, this place is a joke.  The (primo-sized) hoagies are about $2 more per sandwich and they put noticeably less meat in them.

The best Vietnamese food in Tucson. The menu features Vietnamese, Chinese and Thai food. GET THE VIETNAMESE FOOD because, uh, that's what kind of restaurant it is. Don't be like those weirdos who order hamburgers at a Mexican restaurant. Be sure to try one of their Boba tapioca slushie drinks.

We went for a late dinner after drinking at Bacchanal. The Joint doesnt look like anything special - it's out of the way but MAN is it worth finding. The BBQ was fantastic. Decent bar scene, but the food was what we were there for and we didnt leave disappointed. I had a full rack of ribs with baked beans and potato salad, and the ribs were perfect. The meat was literally cooked so well it was falling off the bone. I ate every bite, and would have maybe eaten the plate as well. The sides were great and I could have had three more of them. Our table also had pulled pork and brisket, and everyone loved everything. Not one complaint. What a feast. Price was great, service was fine (they were super busy but it was cool because we had a round of drinks and were just hanging out chatting). BBQ doesnt get any better then this.

visited  restaurant again on Saturday night to redeem the offer by the manager for poor customer service. We arrived in the parking lot and there were no lights. We walked in the restaurant and no one was at the hostess stand. Waited ten minutes and was sat by the manager Jason. We explained to him about the lights but he said it was due to sublet issues. We sat down with menus and was greeted another ten minutes later by the hostess who asked if we had a server. We did not apparently. She took our drink and food orders and brought us bread. Again, she had dropped the silver knob on the shaker on our bread plate followed by three more times. Ordered food however Jason came over shortly after asking us what we ordered. We waited a total of 40 minutes for our food which we had to ask a server where it was. Jason brought out our main course but no appetizer. My guest and I got very upset at the lack of service and no appetizers which we originally ordered. Jason brought out the rest of the food. I never got a drink refill to say the least so I was forced to wait on myself for drinks. It was a horrible night. You're restaurant seriously needs help! I am not sure what you have done to fix the issues bit nothing has been resolved. I am most likely not returning to your restaurant. At the end of the night all Jason had to say was that your restaurant is short staffed. This continues to be a recurrent theme. Very poor service! I would suggest you hire another manager Jasons solution was "I'm sorry".
People seem to like to hang out here and the lounge section is great as a music venue. Now for the food, truly horrible. Great place for coffee, tea or glass of water. Again the food sucked.

Today I came here for lunch because they are usually great for the lunch buffet. Unfortunately the chicken I had was raw. Didn't notice until after I had a few bites. I showed the server and got no apology or discount. Shame on them. Disappointed. Hope I don't get sick. I still left a tip because I have a heart.

Went there because I was told they had great wings. What a disappointment!! The wings were very chewy and the skin was not even edible. I have had smoked wings before and they were not like that. The BBQ sauces on the table left a lot to be desired as well. Service was also lack luster but I don't go out for the service, I go out for the food. Maybe it was an off night but I will not go back

Brasil Arts Café is one of our favorite lunch stops this part of State Street. The food is always good and offers a nice selection for our party. The kids usually go with an acai bowl or smoothie, while I enjoy the X and BAC burgers (adding a fried egg of course;)   And, the house hot sauce is for real good. The even sell the hot sauce to go and it is worth it. I mix it with some ketchup for the fries and put it directly on everything else (that isn't a frozen treat). There is usually plenty of seating, which is probably not a good sign for longevity but not for lack of quality. My only complaint this time was that they were out of A LOT of items including all salads, Yucca fries, and TopaTopa beer (which is partly what I was looking for this time). The food was still good but something is off on the backend. So, I reluctantly dropped a star for that. Oh, and there is some new deal where kids eat free on Wednesdays 5-8 PM! So, we will be back for that for sure.

You know that diner atmosphere you see in the movies, where you get the same waitress every time you come and she calls you "Hon'" and has the big hair and big nails and runs around like a mad woman but with a smile on her face?

Yeah, that's South Street Diner. Adorably familiar feeling, whether it's your first time or your fiftieth.  Great greasy grub, from burgers to omelets.  The best onion rings in the city. This place is like the Philadelphia "Peach Pit".

Friendly feel with waitresses that call you "hon" and omelets that just won't quit.

Plus, they stayed open during Hurricane Sandy and provided Budweiser during the trying times..;)

Came here for lunch with a client. The place was bustling at noon on a Friday, but things were moving quickly and the service was fast.

Biggest plus: breakfast served all day and the omelets looked fantastic.

Anything you could possibly imagine, they have it here. I went with an Ahi Tuna wrap which was dry and less flavorful than expected, but I think if I'd have gone with something more traditional I'd have been pleased.

For locals, West Ave seems like a perfect weekend brunch spot.

If you decide to make your way over to Fette Sau, please take time to prepare in advance, by which I mean please do not eat for 24 hours ahead of time and then plan not to eat for another 24 hours after.

Such an original Barbecue joint with the best pork belly I have ever had. The chicken was surprisingly delicious, as was everything else.

Extensive whiskey selection and the bartenders are extremely informative.  Great spot for the summertime, with tons of picnic tables outside and conveniently located right by the Beer Garden. You'll feel like a fat kid when they finally roll you out, but it's worth it..Bacon brownie dessert and all. Yes, bacon in the brownie. I was skeptical at first, too.

Vegetarians: Beware.

This is another place that I definitely wouldn't have tried without a groupon.

As far as service goes, our waitress wasn't very friendly. Then again, it was about 2 degrees outside, so I wasn't in the friendliest mood either. We'll chalk it up to winter crankiness. 

Two friends and I ordered three dishes to share:

Penne alla vodka
Chicken battuta w/ potatoes and asparagus
Spaghetti with red sauce & meatballs 

Each entree/pasta dish comes with a side salad, which I definitely appreciate, but the pastas were just OK. The penne vodka was better than the spaghetti. The chicken came in one of those wanna-lick-the-plate-sauces, and the portion was generous.

Overall, I don't think I'd come back here. There's too much good italian food to be eaten elsewhere.

We had reservations and sat down quickly. That will be the last time the word quick will be used in my review. After 20 minutes, we finally got to place our drink order and appetizer order. After 43 minutes, we got our water and two of our five drinks. After 62 minutes, we got our appetizers and after 90 minutes our entrees. We were never checked in except of the manger whose only question was if our server had been to the table yet. The food was also not good. Seriously, save yourself and go to Maggianos.

4 Stars for the food...2 stars for the plastic cutlery that doesn't cut through food. Of course, this IS the airport, so maybe a regular restaurant would use real cutlery and non-plastic serving containers.

I ordered the red beans and rice, which came with a local sausage. It was just enough food and had an excellent flavor.  Next time I'm in NOLA, I'll stop in to the non-airport restaurant and give them a shot!

On Monday, my California friend and I enjoyed our last dinner together before he had to head out of town and based upon my daughter's recommendation of their French fries, we chose Brugge.  Totally cute place right off the Monon Trail.  Although a tad bit on the warm side, we walked from my home and enjoyed the shady trail on the way back.  Because the restaurant is pretty small and it was too warm to sit outside, we sat in the bar and ordered a small smoked gouda plate, a large order of the French fries with three dipping sauces:  Pesto, Sea Salt Vinegar, and Garlic Aioli.  We also shared a chicken Crepe with Aioli sauce.  All very yummy.  My friend enjoyed one of Brugge's brews while I had the iced tea.  I'll definitely come back here to try other items on their menu.

Stopped in here for dinner because we heard tons of great things about this restaurant. Here's why I gave Claim Jumper 3 stars:

The hostess was friendly and we were seated on a Friday night with no problem. The server was quick to come greet and take our drink/appetizer order. (Quick item of note: Claim Jumper has a great happy hour menu) when the server made his way back with our drinks, we ordered our entree's. I ordered the smoked tri-tip with Mac and cheese and a side salad. My wife ordered the 7oz filet mignon, side salad and Mac and cheese. 

I have to be honest, once our food arrived after about 1 hour of waiting, I was ready to devour everything on my plate, but was disappointed after the first bite. Our food was cold and didn't really have any flavor, something you'd expect from Applebee's or Chili's, but with a much heftier price tag. 

We may give this restaurant another shot because we have heard so many good things, but I'm skeptical about spending another $90 on Applebee's equivalent food. 3 stars and a half a thumb up for this place...

Its so sad to witness the decline of this place. When they first opened the flavors were amazing!! we would go there several times a week. But with in the last several months the burgers have gotten blander and blander. Now its not even considered for date night or to go food to feed my bosses as we are not willing to fight the obnoxious crowd to sit through a less than mediocre greasy burger. The staff is nice but they need to gut that kitchen staff and hire chefs and line cooks that can bring back the flavor. #sadandgross

I came here with the bf since his old classmate was visiting from Texas.  What a pain it was to get here since a lot of the roads were closed from construction.  We ended up going down some weird and creepy alley way that was blocked off.  But parking wasn't too bad when we got there.  

The front end of the place where the bar was is a bit tightly packed.  They did have a large variety of craft beers on tap.

The arcade selection is great and a lot of fun.  But the place is a bit dark and feels dirty.

I've never been so disrespected as a customer as me being in the food service myself I was totally appalled embarrassed and so are the other customers and other employees definitely like the product but was very absurd how I was treated and disrespected as a customer

Mixed emotions!
Lasagna was amazing, however a bit pricey for the portion. Spaghetti meatballs was great, a little pricey even though my son raved about it. Caesar salad had "ok" flavor but was a little too "wet" for my taste. 
The service was amazing, very pleased with all the staff and their knowledge. I hate big companies that suck the life out of the restaurant business, and I always prefer to  shop and buy local. On that note I do feel that Brick Oven is just a tiny bit over priced. But we will happily visit again.

I was a big fan of Sapori when it first opened. The owner would always come around and ask how the meal was prepared etc. I was always satisfied. Lately, I have been disappointed with my meal especially for the price. I had a really good artichoke appetizer last time but other than that the meal was bla. I hope they get their act together.

We had a variety of dishes including zucchini chips, gyros, chicken skewer, veggie skewer, baklava and a curry style soup (can't recall the name of it). The food was mostly pretty tasty with the highlights being the gyros and soup, but the portion size was extremely small. Granted, we stuck to a bunch of the smaller sized plates, but these plates were miniature. For all that above it cost ~$45 + tip.

The interior looks very nice and is very well done. Service was average. The bathroom has a hand dryer instead of paper towels.



Food Quality/Taste =  4 Stars
Portion Size Given Price = 2 Stars
Price = 3 Stars
Service = 3 Stars
Experience with Staff = 3 Stars
Decor = 5 Stars

Oh, Treehouse...

Why aren't you just located in my backyard?

Perhaps, I'm sounding a bit spoiled since you're just located a few miles away, but I put all the blame on you. YES. Indeed. It is your fault that I now have this sense of entitlement that now has me actively campaigning for your 2nd location to be conveniently located behind my loft. 

If you wouldn't have knocked my socks off with your thoughtful and diverse menu which also includes an enticing assortment of dishes that are vegan, vegetarian, and gluten free. The fact that the menu clearly denotes which dishes are specific to the dietary needs is much-appreciated added bonus. And, while I can't make this statement about the mass majority of dining spots that I have frequented, I can cross my heart and swear by the statement that "I've NEVER had an experience that I haven't absolutely loved here." 

(LOUD THUD)

What was that? Oh, just the sound of the mic being dropped. 
I've enjoyed myself here since they opened their doors  7 months ago - so this 5 star review is quite delayed but well-deserved.

From the Cauliflower Steak, Fideo, and Kale + Quinoa ($10) dishes to their tasty concoction of Plantains ($6) or Beets + Radishes the menu stays innovative with unique flavor mashups. Plus, I haven't even touched on the fact that you're not acquiring debt to enjoy the "good life" here. There's no excuse to ingest toxic foods elsewhere when the menu is so affordable here. The 10 After 10 Menu proves my point as you can enjoy some of their signature items for $10 after 10pm. Goodbye, drive-thru. Hello there, Sunchokes and Empanadas.

Ready to chitty chat about libations? 
Yeah, me too. 

The bar program here is solid. If ciders, drafts, or bottles and cans make your world go round, you won't be disappointed. Perhaps, the grape variety is more your bag? I can attest that the the list isn't overbearingly extensive but the consolidated options that they do offer will please your palate. Give their Madeira and Port options a whirl. Wine snob? All good. Bring your own goodies and you'll only have a $15 corkage fee.

NOW, THE COCKTAILS. Oh, the cocktails. 
Vodka, lemon, Casoni 1814, and grapefruit bitters happen to be the ingredients to one of my favorite cocktails in town. Order the "Don't Mind If I Do"  ($10) and after a couple of these, you'll feel A-OK, my friends. Is Bourbon your BFF? The "Kentucky Hussy" ($10) is the way to go. Comprised of Old Forrester 100, lemon, ginger beer, and sugar, you'll feel a bit of the heat but the sugar softens the blow a tad. Admittedly, portion control can be an issue when you pony up to this bar.... better have that Uber app downloaded on your iPhone, yelpers. Bottoms up.

With the recent expansion of the treehouse in the back dining area, it opens up the space a bit more from the cozy 40 seat main dining area. The intimate yet well-designer layout of The Treehouse just adds to the overall charm especially since this property  has been in the Co-Founders family since the roaring 20's and before The Great Depression. The aforementioned treehouse in the back was actually built by the patriarch of the family when this location was used for residential purposes. I also just adore that they also utilized local and regional makers to craft the lighting, tables, seating, and bar areas. And, is it odd that the bathrooms are one of my favorite touches? I won't give it all away but you'll find some unexpected "Steampunk" and "Rock and Roll" influences in there... a little mischief, never hurt anybody, right?

So, I hope this helps explain why we all need a bit more of The Treehouse in our lives. We certainly aren't asking them to alter the beautiful space and dynamic energy that they already have in place... BUT if this this young restaurant were going to add a secondary location, I just wanted to throw my very own backyard in the hat.

TIP: There is currently a Yelp Deal where you can purchase a $20 certificate for only $10

What a fabulous brunch spot Indy!
My friend Carla is a native to Indy and almost pouted when she thought that we may have missed the brunch menu here... that's how good it is, folks. 

The blackberry prosecco ($6.95) libation that I inhaled was a delicious and refreshing way to compliment my Lentil Pate sammich ($9.75). YUM. I added some avocado to the mix and this vegan was very very satisfied! My meal came with a tasty side salad too. All around, the prices were fair especially for the caliber of food that was presented on my plate. Overall, I had hoped that there were a few more vegan friendly options on the menu but our server was able to make some suggestions on how to alter the menu to appease my diet. 

The bright and airy feel to the space was welcoming along with the petite but charming patio area. Service was speedy and friendly too.

I also love their branding: "A Student Union For Adults"

I popped in here again on Friday evening. I have finally come to realize that I will likely not spend extended periods of time here especially during the prime-time cocktail hours. 

I can honestly say that I have never had more than one libation here at a time because I get the itch to move on because it's just too much...
Too crowded and too loud for my sanity for a night out on the town but could still be a good option for happy hour or dinner. 

Too bad I drink more than I eat? 
Kidding.
No. Not really.

I am still in awe over the sheer size of this place... WOWZA.
Admittedly, I never thought that yours truly would actually attend the Indy 500 as I have never had a fascination of automotive racing. However, my good friend suggested a few weeks before the event that she'd be heading up to visit with some friends and to take in the race as she was previously employed there so I was a bit intrigued. It's only a 4 hour drive away from Nashville and a nice little weekend away made a bit of sense for me... why not?

Fast forward to now and I am HOOKED on the largest sporting event in the world! I was pleasantly surprised by the great condition of the grounds and great cutomer service that we received throughout the door. From the pit area and Gasoline Alley to the grassy mound on Turn 3, the Speedway does not leave you disappointed!
There is even a museum located on the grounds and many areas to tail-gate before and after the race. I certainly appreciate that this venue allows attendees to bring in their own coolers and food too. I'm a vegan so I brought some healthier alternatives than the track food that was offered but would appreciate if they added a veggie burger to the menu! It's 2012 Indy, let's step up your veggie game, eh?

And, how happy was I that Dario won? VERY!

I will likely make my way back for another Indy 500 and look forward to hanging out at the Indy Motor Speedway... especially for the people watching.

My friend and I love Mexican and decided to try this place out on a Thursday evening. We were there for about 15 minutes before we got chips and salsa. (No one else came to our table.) After another 10 minutes a table that had been seated quite a while after us had their order taken. I finally got the attention of a server and he came over to take our drink order and queso order. I ordered a margarita and my friend ordered a soft drink. When I got my margarita, it was delicious (The one great thing that I ordered.) The chips didn't quite taste like normal tortilla chips. They were corn with red and green colored chips. I assumed that's why they tasted different (I wasn't a fan, but was starving so ate them.) We were almost done with our chips when we got our queso. It had a nice flavor, but was a little runny. We didn't get to finish it because half of our chips were broken and we never got a refill. My friend ordered a combo meal and she said it was just OK. I ordered Carnitas. (I usually order them at every Mexican restaurant I try.) Normally the pork is shredded, but this time it was in huge chunks. No problem since I can shred it myself. The problem was that each piece of meat was at least half fat. I did eat about half of a taco, but the pork had very little flavor. One plus, the refried beans and rice were very good. A few of our friends told us how great of a place this was. Because of that fantastic Margarita I think I would go back and give it another try.

The Bubble House never really blew my hair back. Actually, I found it peculiar that it's supposed to be Vietnamese-inspired since it's truly so far from it.

When I used to live in University, the wealthier folk considered this a restaurant, others just acted like a coffee shop. From what I gathered for food, it was ehhhh. For coffee, nothing to write home about. To me, The Bubble House was always the weakest link on Sansom Street, and while there certainly are people who love it, it never really did much for me.

Cut the fame and hooplah b/c this place ain't nothing but a big fat square of nine...Three star rating. 

You can go to any place in the city (of New Orleans) and get a similar dish with more seafood for a cheaper price with the same quality of taste, if not better. 

1. Seafood platter...is like half the size of most platters I encounter around the city. The fry itself is average. It's just about location.

2. Gumbo. Never been a fan. And this dish is just average.

3. Red beans and rice (as a side dish). Pretty weak in my opinion. Popeyes is better. And what's better than these two? Freakin' Blue Runners (in a can at your local grocery store). Those beans in a can is sicktastic -- so good with just the twist of a can opener.

4. Bread Pudding? Okay. This thing is LEGIT. I ain't a fan of bread pudding but this place does it right. It's like God created this before Adam and Eve took their place. It's like an aphrodisiac in your mouth that even Bacchus fell prey to the ecstasy that lay before him...with its bit of raisins and a hint of rum just massaging the oh-so-goodness in your mouth. I should just give this place a FIVE for their rum cake but dang the average food for a high price. Three stars for you. 

P.s. It can get cold in the second room so bring a jacket...even if it's the summer.

Festive Mexican restaurant with great patio and lively atmosphere. I've been impressed with several of the dishes, though now almost exclusively order the tortas - they are amazing. It's worth indulging in the ice cream too. I love trying the unique flavors. Coconut pineapple was my most recent treat.

I'm surprised to have stumbled on this spot. With the quality of the food and great location, I figured there would be more buzz around this cute little Mediterranean restaurant. There should be. I'm still thinking about the hummus. The owner was the sweetest server I have ever had.

Every time I come here with my job they always treat us well. I ordered the chicken parm mini meal. And let's just say it's not mini at all. Your get so much for your money with a small, I can't imagine what the regular sizes are like. I plan on coming back again in the near future with my friends and family.

This is my third time coming. I love the place I get the Cajun shrimp pasta and my husband got the lobster Mac n cheese. First and foremost the Cajun shrimp pasta is amazing!! It tastes the same every time. But the lobster Mac and cheese was very soupy and did not have any flavor. For it to be higher in price you would think it would have been better. Overall I love the place and the live band is great as well. But I go for the shrimp pasta. I will definitely be back. I'm a rewards member. So if your just trying this place for the wings they are amazing as well as the salad and the toasted ravioli we will try the onion rings next time. But I did get their pear tree onion sauce for my salad and it was amazing. Overall I recommend this place if your out, but go to the dining section if your with family. The bar is a bit loud. Well done Syberg's.

I'd definitely recommend this place if you are craving seafood! This is the place to go! Upon entering it was very nice, the workers wore masks and you can tell the social distancing was enforced. The food was amazing! I'm not a seafood person. But it was worth every penny, maybe more! I got the shrimp platter, and my friend for the seafood bowl. Don't let the prices fool you it is definitely worth it! All of it was well seasoned, you would have thought it was made from a family member! I was shocked that a restaurant could make me love seafood! I would definitely be returning to the place and bringing others! Especially during these times, going out is hard to do. But I do recommend if your looking for a great date restaurant or just something to entertain the family I recommend coming here! I will be back! Next time for margaritas! Well done.
Cool vibe and good coffee.  I had a sugar free frappuchino which definitely rivals starbucks.  To quote the terminator "I'll be back".
Just got back from Amada for restaurant week. I was so impressed! Everything was so flavorful.  It was worth every penny. I can't wait to go back.

Strange donuts is one of those places I go more for my dog than for myself...

I could take it or leave it, but my dog means a lot to me... So four stars it is.

The maple bacon is one of my dog's favorite things ever... She knows it by appearance and will bark trying to get me to give it to her she adores it so much. Personally, I prefer Vincent Van Doughnut's version... But Strange's is cheaper and since my dog loves it, I go with it. You can't deprive a dog named Moscato, right? So on special doggie days (her birthday, the day I brought her home, the day we reunited after she got lost, etc) she gets one.

I personally only get excited about the Campfire donut. And even then I think it's more nostalgia related than taste related. I certainly don't bark/gruff or dance on my hind legs at the sight of it. We can't all have the joys in our lives that dogs do though... But seeing it in their eyes is nearly as good

When I was in high school I worked downtown one summer and would meet my father for lunch. We would get pizza at the spot right by where there is now a Starbucks (an extra slice for this homeless man my father had befriended) and go to South Bend for hot chocolate.

12 years later and a Starbucks nearby later? I still adore this place.

Service is hit or miss. One time I was standing by the register and the woman helped everyone at the display case before helping me. And no I did not get there after them... I was there first and had been waiting for awhile prior.

But when the service is friendly, it is quite friendly.

And the hot chocolate there is the absolute best i have ever had (minus That French Bakery in St. Louis). The price for it is equally phenomenal.

Oh and you must also try the chocolate covered Oreos.

The chocolate cover pecan clusters were not my favorite.

What else?

Oh apparently in all these years I never noticed the frozen treats in the back.

Oh and also the restroom is in the basement...

Looking for a solid brewpub restaurant without having to go downtown or up north? This is your place. 

I've actually been here several times, but it's always too crowded, so this was my first time eating at this place. The beverage selections are nice, which is why I would go back here. The food? At least for vegetarians, it's a pretty normal "you've got a couple of options but nothing extensive" menu. 

I had the veggie burger with a salad on the side with a fresh Black Acre brew. The beer: 5 stars. The service: 5 stars. The food: 4 stars. It definitely wasn't the best veggie burger I've had. I felt like I was mostly eating a bun, and the burger patty was quite thin, so it was hard to even tell I was eating a veggie burger. 

Overall, it wasn't bad. The biggest downfall of this place is how crowded it is. It is ALWAYS crowded. Expect a long wait if you have a group. I was lucky enough to walk right in for once. 

Would I go back? Yes, just not for the veggie options food.

Since my last two reviews, many, many more options have been added to the menu, including vegetarian options! 

Looking for a delicious, fresh grilled cheese-esque sandwich? Look no further. It's one of my favorites! (It's listed under the chicken sandwich on the menu.)

LOVE. THIS. PLACE.

The ambiance is LOVELY. I titled my review as basic as I possibly could because that is what I think of this place. It is #BASICAF. Take traditional Mexican food, add some fusion spins on it, put it in a swanky restaurant with cool decor, add some cool toy displays in the hipster bathroom, slap on a brunch menu and BOOM... you got a fantastically basic place to eat!

The food is FANTASTIC for the money. No, it doesn't compare with authentic Mexican joints. This place is sort of like an ugly Milktooth getting run over by a taco truck and then getting some reconstructive surgery to stage a comeback as a Gal Gadot (or whoever you find stunningly attractive). I LOVE THE POUTINE and also like the Moo Shoo Tacos, those are my top choices. If you are still hungry, get the CHURROS, the chocolate dip is crack & the caramel isn't too shabby either.

Real talk... if you are looking for a place to eat near the circle with tons of seating & has nearby indoor parking, this is your best bet. The prices are very reasonable considering the food quality and overall experience.

I recently dined at Gabi with my friend Chris W after much fanfare from the people in my inner circle. We ordered the Steak Tartare as an appetizer and were immediately impressed with the presentation, taste, and portion size. The tartare was presented mixed with brined capers, freshly chopped onions, finely chopped parsley leaves, and a raw egg on top. Cornichon's, mustard, and lightly toasted baguette wafers accompanied the tartare. It was a really great tartare, one of the best in the city! Unfortunately, the entrées left a lot to be desired. My friend's Beef Bourguignon (burgundy-style beef stew, bacon, pearl onions, mushrooms) was a bit overcooked. The bacon and beef were tough chews. My Duck Confit (duck leg cooked in its own fat, orange sauce) was just okay and cooked a bit too long, too. I've had a better duck confit at Parc and Bistrot La Minette. The side vegetables of puréed potatoes and French green beans (haricot verts) were exceptionally done, however. Oftentimes, chefs cook them a little less than I'd like, making them more raw than cooked. These vegetables were prepared and spiced perfectly. I'm not fond of the Mercer-style bistro plates. I get why they chose them, but it leaves a lot of empty space on my dish. My drink, La Minette (blood orange, vodka, Lillet, soda water), lacked the usually tang of blood orange. It tasted more like regular orange. I typically order dessert from a place I really like, so perhaps I'll try this place again at some point and order different things to see if my luck changes.

I've always thought of Rouge as a posh lounge with an award-winning burger. Little did I know that a fantastic meal can be had here, too. My Steak Tartare and Seared Tuna were really good and my friend Chris' Pan Seared Duck Breast with chorizo corn hash and morel mushrooms was excellent. I was particularly impressed with the accompanying black rice with maitake mushrooms in my tuna dish and the hash in Chris'. A top chef always cares about the side items that accompany the featured item. The flavors in each dish were very nicely done. The drinks were very good, too, not the usual jet fuel they serve to patrons sitting and drinking under the canopy. Rouge exceeded my expectations. I had doubts, but my doubts were totally obliterated.

A great sushi spot in the CBD if you're into the club scene during the weekend and don't mind a good bit of waiting if you arrive after 7pm on a Friday or Saturday, I mean it's the perfect time to scope out who will be down at Republic  later and it probably doesn't get poppin' till midnight anyway.

That being said, I'm not a huge "club" goer and on a Tuesday night, despite it being pretty easy to grab a table for 8, I'm not huge on the blaring house music (though I will say we were right under the speaker but I can't imagine a full restaurant with the music playing that loud on a packed night). What's great is the staff doesn't take on the club like atmosphere mentality and are very attentive from my personal experience recently. 

We went for my boyfriend's birthday though were were having trouble nailing down exact numbers. Reservations for 10 or more have an 8 point reservation policy and trying to get a call-back to make a res was a little hard, but during the early part of the week, you should be fine sans reservation. 

We had edamame, miso soup, cucumber salad, and a handful of rolls including the spicy tuna, Red Dragon*, and Salmon Zest*. The Salmon Zest (Robert's choice) was okay, the lemon zest added a nice hint of flavor, but I'm not huge on snowcrab, and I don't think we received the spicy ponzu dipping sauce on the side now that I think about it since they all came on one plate. The Red Dragon roll was solid, and I would absolutely order that one again. Sometimes sushi rolls seem a little mushy to me, so the tempura flakes and roe give the spicy tuna (which I already love) extra texture making it easier to enjoy.

I would also suggest the Hawaii 5-O roll with coconut shrimp and cream cheese rolled with mangoes and avocados on the outside. I liked the sweet crunchiness of it, though I only stole one piece from our friends. 

I would go back during the early part of the week since their weekend crowd isn't really my scene, but it wouldn't hurt if they chose a more zen playlist for their less busy days.  

Salmon Zest:  Fresh salmon and snowcrab rolled in soybean paper and topped with fresh salmon and fresh grated lemon zest served with spicy ponzu dipping sauce on the side. 

Red Dragon Roll: Spicy tuna with crunchy tempura batter flakes rolled on the inside topped with fresh tuna, spicy mayo, green onions, smelt roe, and crunchy tempura flakes on the outside.

I've been meaning to try this Panera since they came out to MidCity. I had them once before in Florida, and really enjoyed this chain. I finally has some time and some hangry to squash and decided to pop in. 

The menu's got a lot going on. I guess I've gotten so used to food trucks, ordering the "usual" and shorter menus that when I get to a place like this, I'm overwhelmed with a gaping mouth and squinty eyes trying to read the board. For some reason I assumed all Panera sandwiches were paninis 'cause I think that's why I fell for them in the first place. 

I order the very economical Pick Two with the Turkey and Avocado BLT half and the Autumn Squash Soup with a kettle chips and a drink. The lady at the counter was very pleasant and handed me my buzzer for when my food was ready. 

I had no idea how expansive this location was. Tons of places to sit, though odd that a lady chose to sit caddy-corner from me to stare into my soul...I digress. There is Free Wi-Fi if you're saving hoarding MBs of data, I know I am. 

Buzzer buzzes, and I grab my food. The sandwich bread (for a place that is part bakery) looked haggardly and obviously wasn't panini (since this was a sandwich) atop my half sandwich, but I was hungry so I wasn't going to ask about it. The sandwich was pretty good, though when I've got avocado on a sandwich there is very little need for the reduced-fat olive oil mayo, especially as much mayo as I got. The soup was pretty good, with a hint of cinnamon and the little seeds on top like how the fancy places do it. I really enjoyed it, and should've asked for some bread to dip in it. The kettle chips (in a town where Zapp's is king) were meh. 

The portions were perfect and the price was right, so I would say if I was taking out a band of younger people I was paying for and didn't want to go the fast food route, Panera is a pretty great option. I'd go back to get an actual panini and a soup someday, I'm sure, but would skip the chips.

Met my buddies after work for some wings and a few brews....
It was after 8 pm and quite crowded. The wings were good, the beer was cold. My biggest complaint was that we were seated in the bar area at a high top table and they had a guy on guitar singing....for what reason I don't understand. He was SSSoOOOO LOUD that we couldn't carry on a conversation. We literally had to yell at each other to hear. Get rid of the live entertainment in the small bar area......nobody cares if he's there, they go there to meet friends and have conversations..............and have some cocktails.....

This is my favorite fast food place, and really the only one that I visit, being a vegetarian. Sometimes it's late, you're starving, don't feel like cooking or getting out of your lounge clothes. Sonic to the rescue! Standard order includes a grilled cheese, fries (theirs are so good - the best!), and a strawberry limeade. Occasionally there are cheddar bites consumed. It's always consistent and good. The drinks are the best! It's cheap too. Always give your car hop a buck and they will love you for it!

This place has been in my bookmarks for quite awhile now, and today my sister and I went there for lunch. I'm glad I checked the website because they open at noon on Saturdays and we usually count on places opening around 11. We walked in to a cute little place, cozy feel with cool decor. Our waitress was the only worker we saw in the place, and luckily it wasn't too busy because she was also the bartender. Service was pretty good though, and she was always nearby in case we needed something. That is where the positive things I can say about Maya Cafe end though.. the rest left me supremely disappointed.

I knew what I was going to order before I went because I noticed they have squash blossom quesadillas and I recently had a religious experience with them at Milagro. I should've just left it at that and been patient for the next time they have them, but I wanted to try them again darnit!! We also ordered guacamole as a starter and I tried a glass of sangria, which they highlight on the menu as being sweet and a specialty. The drink came out quickly and I was disappointed. It wasn't sweet. I've had sangria at many places and this is at the bottom. I forced myself to drink it because I didn't want to waste money, but I didn't finish the little glass because it really wasn't good. The chips were good but extremely salty. The "salsa" was more like pico de gallo - all tomato and onion chunks. Not my thing, I only like mine pureed, so I didn't try it. The guacamole was totally bland. Just avocado taste. No spices, nothing. We didn't finish it or take it home because it just didn't hit the spot. Bummer! On to the entree - I got "Mayan corn" on the side instead of saffron rice. The plate came and I dug in to the corn right away. It was frozen corn, not fresh. Had that kind of gummy, distinctive taste of freezer corn. And no flavor! It looked like it had some spice or something on it but I couldn't taste a thing. Ugh. The rice was a little better but not much - I tried my sister's. The quesadillas looked really greasy - and when I cut in, grease poured out. The taste was decent, but again, greasy. I liked the spinach and cheese but that's all I tasted. I saw the blossoms amongst the grease but tasted no cilantro (which is actually good because I'm not a big fan of it). 

We walked out very disappointed and wished we had eaten somewhere else.

Chevy's is A-OK in my book.

The service? Great. The waitress was just attentive enough and so were the bussers. The location is HUGE and was remodeled pretty recently. 

The chips are light and the salsa has a little kick just like I like it.

Whenever I come to Chevy's, instead of ordering something really heavy, I like to order the house salad. It has this corn salsa on it that is really yummy and the ranch is delicious too. It also has little tortilla strips, which add a nice crunch to it. And the tamalito. YUMMMMM. It's this kind of corn bread pudding tasting thing that I always order a side of. I could eat it all day long. 

I enjoyed my meal. The next time someone suggests going there for lunch, I'll probably start thinking about that tamalito and jump on it!

Living in the city, I'll hit Chinatown quite often. Dim Sum has become one of my favorite meals.  While I cannot speak to Authentic vs Americanized, I do know what I like.  Overall, I liked Dim Sum Factory, especially considering the lack of other Dim Sum options in the 'burbs.

The Caviar Soup Dumplings were good, but they only give you four pieces.  I'd recommend just going for the crab & pork or pork soup dumplings as the caviar ones weren't that unique and you get more with the standard.

The Shanghai Shumai are made with sticky rice.  I really enjoyed them, but they are more rice than other filling.  I think they also offer shrimp shumai.

The Squid with Salted Pepper was my favorite dish of the day.  Decent quantity and good quality on the squid.  They could have been a bit crispier, but really not complaining.

Rounding things out, service was friendly, prices were in line, and pace was quick.  It might not be city quality Dim Sum, but it was good.  I'd recommend a visit.

Nothing helps me get over the "oh god it's only Monday" feeling better than a big bowl of pho for lunch.  A bunch of my coworkers are also  hooked, meaning I'll have company when in need of my fix.  Unfortunately, working in the great NE, our options are limited.

Pho Palace will certainly help you with your Pho fix.  Yes, its not authentic, but its decent.  The place is clean and service is friendly, although no the fastest I've ever experienced.  Portions are a bit small for the price.  Overall, Pho Palace is worth a stop if you can't fit a trip down to Washington Ave.

BTW... Cash Only!

Unfortunately, a majority of my review will focus on some very unacceptable things Zesty's did in the service department instead of focusing on the food.  That's a real shame too, since the food was pretty good.

We arrived around 4 o'clock and were promptly seated.  Menus and bread quickly arrived starting the experience off on the right foot.  However, about 10 minutes later a large group of people arrived and were followed by a constant stream of additional people.  I later found out that a wedding reception was being held in the restaurant around 4:30 and they decided not to close while hosting.  No biggie I said in my head.  Unfortunately, I couldn't get pass it - especially with the large crowd standing so close to our booth that I could join their conversations.... I was rather glad we didn't take the table originally offered to us!

No matter, we were determined to enjoy our food and did our best to ignore.  As we wrapped up, we decided it would be best to box up some leftovers.  Our waitress gladly offered to take care of it for us... then walked OUTSIDE with our food to go around the reception crowd.  Once boxed, the food came back from OUTSIDE to our table.  I won't go to the "is that even legal or a health code violation" level, but we certainly won't be eating those leftovers!  When asked, she told us her manager required they not go through the reception crowd and instead recommended they walk OUTSIDE with food.  Hey, its still March here in Philly!

Maybe on another day, Zesty's would have wowed us without these little snafus and earned itself a solid 4 maybe even a low 5 star review.  Instead, I'm left wondering if I should bother to give them another shot...

Fancy decor.  Yes, very much fancy decor.  Unfortunately, once you take your focus off of it, you begin to realize the value proposition of the food (price/quantity/quality) doesn't metric more than 3-stars.  Yes, I've made multiple visits and yes the food and prices have stayed consistent.  Maybe that is why I am finally writing this review and landing right in the middle...

Have to say I was not impressed what so ever.  I would not eat inside so  decided to try the drive-through I was hoping it was one of those diamond in the rough types of places, unfortunately it was not. i got a chicken taco and a steak on the onions or clearly dried out along with the limes the chicken had no flavor and was dry the steak had a lot of fat in it. I won't be back

When I initially moved to Philadelphia, I went to this place multiple times because it was iron chef's creation. The place is beautiful, and the lighting is really spectacular.  There is usually a wait here, so I would recommend getting a reservation if possible  Many times I have gone for work related events, so we do rent out the upstairs.  The upstairs has a bar, however it is a little cramped with more than about 50 people.

Service is on point here.  Everybody is far nice and respectful.  They are also very knowledgeable about the menu.  

Unfortunately the food here is really not that great.  I know it has the iron chef connection, so everybody wants to check it out, but it really isn't that good.  I came here many times before finding other much better sushi places in center city.  I tried multiple different rolls, and nothing really impressed me.  The tuna tartare is different, and something I would try as a first timer.  I have tried many of the rolls, but the ones that seem to come to mind are the tempura roll and the king crab rolls.  These are decent and tasty, but they don't knock my socks off.  

The drinks here are just average, and nothing to write about in a review.

Overall, a solid choice of a restaurant.  This is a place that you can take your visiting friends/family, and they will be happy.  It would not be my go to choice for a casual Friday night sushi dinner.  There are many other places that seem to have better food, however they all lack the atmosphere of Morimoto.

Hmmm. I'm sad...was expecting more. I saw a yelper say this place had same owners as Si Amigos, but quality seemed to lack. 
Started off with of course a margarita. Was asked if we wanted small or large, still happy hour. NORMALLY difference between sm and lg, sm 16oz, lg 20oz. We opted for large, server tells us it's like getting 2 for 1. GREAT! What arrived were two fish bowl sized margaritas! To boot, they were, $15 EACH. We weren't told of this. Should've been warned. THAT was half our bill.

Now on to food... I noticed a couple if dishes with "cream sauce". Unusual for Mexican cuisine. I thought I'd try, I got the Pollo Nogales... Their "cream sauce" is merely melted cream cheese with jack cheese incorporated in it. TOO MUCH CHEESE. He had a shrimp fajita style dish...it just lacked....it all just lacked. I think the apps and cocktails might be my only interest here. Good luck though I really hope they do well, but it's just not for us.

It's not very often I'll go to a brewpub and, after trying a few of their beers, ask for a mass produced light beer. Don't get me wrong, the beers were okay. But, after three pretty heavy beers I was in the mood for something a little more forgiving, especially since I'm trying to lose some weight.

Well, the almost devoid of personality bartender did not appreciate my request and pretty much laughed at me telling me they don't sell any beers but their own. Respectable, I guess, but there are defintiely better ways to inform a patron that they're SOL when it comes to wanting a beer that wasn't produced in the back room.

We had a fried appetizer sampler as well, not bad. Pretty much tasted like what you'd get if you bought a box of frozen appetizers from a club store and heated them. Not that that's a bad thing, but I'm sure their specialties lie elsewhere.

Overall, I'd give this place another try. Most of the employees were nice and friendly aside from our second bartender who was either having a bad night or just didn't want to deal with us (we weren't loud or obnoxious or anything.. for the most part).

Nothing was really remarkable at Nodding Head, definitely a little out of my way for the sub-par experience. Happy Hour isn't a bad deal though.

This is a perfect addition to the Conshohocken neighborhood. Their food is spot on and the layout of the place is great. I'm a big fan of the bar one side and the restaurant on the other. The courtesy valet parking is a nice tough too.

Yes, the happy hour deals are LEGIT: $5 martinis! YAY! Fancy a mojito? DONE! But we tried all three of the wines (white, rose, red) and none were stand-outs (plus the red tasted stale). $1 oysters were decent - low in salinity, unlike my beloved Welfleets, but fresh & clean - and served with cocktail sauce, lemon, horseradish (ask for it!), hot sauce. But we received no info about where they were from, etc. Fried cauliflower is still the yummiest dish we've had here - salty, sweet, crunchy. Shrimp & zucchini skewer was nothing to write home about. 

Our bigger issue was with the service. There were ~3 waitstaff milling about when we arrived (all of whom seemed to get busy later, but having them waiting by the bar was a little strange). And the poor bartender - there's only one! - got caught making ALL of the drinks (including those $5 martinis, which the HH crowd was definitely taking advantage of), serving all the bar patrons (where most people were seated), and expediting. She was clearly spread a bit thin, and that explains why it took 10 minutes to order a second round, but still not a good sign. 

The atmosphere is also a bit... strange. Decor is unusual. But sitting at the bar on the right you get a view of a bunch of coolers and a glimpse at some some prep areas; sitting at the bar on the left you watch the raw bar and kitchen prep. 

Overall, Pinefish thinks it's high dining, but can seem like a (granted, elevated) dive bar.

Great product but get it together.
So excited Crushcakes moved into the neighborhood. I ran in late afternoon to an empty baked goods case and empty cake stands. Staff said "Sorry. We're out of everything."
I assumed it was my fault for coming after 3pm. "What time do you close?"
"We don't know yet. We just opened today."
I know it's challenging to open a business but aren't business hours basic?
I turned to leave & could not turn away from the exposed boob and suckling child who appeared to be family of the owner. Said woman smiled at me as if I should be honored by this miracle but ewwwww.
Because I may have a sugar addiction, I came back a few days later. Who doesn't love a golden retriever puppy? The owners new dog was draped completely across the door threshold so you had to take a running long jump. You know what's not adorable? Dog hair in your food.
Owner, I would love nothing more than for you to stick around and sell me your sweet delicious products but stop treating your business as an extension of your living room.

tl;dr Reading Terminal's go-to breakfast spot, offering both a takeout counter and a full-service breakfast bar

Reading Terminal is stuffed with cafes, bakeries, and groceries left-and-right. So, it's no small feat for the Dutch Eating Place to be named by me as the top breakfast spot in the market. My decree is anything but arbitrary -- tucked around the corner from Beiler's Bakery, this no-frills eatery cooks up some greasy spoon-esque dishes for just pennies on the dollar. Think blueberry pancakes as big as a dinner plate and a wide selection of breakfast meats fried and served to-order, all for under $5 or less per order. Or, if you have a particular early-morning sweet tooth, go with for the renowned apple dumplings, nearly the size of a softball and served with heavy cream.

The M-shaped bar fills up quickly; anytime after 8:30AM, expect there to be a line. If you're in too much of a hurry to bother with wild waits, then stick with the take-out counter. During my last visit, I opted to skip the wait and ordered a Sausage, Egg, and Cheese on a Kayser Roll to-go. After about 5 minutes, my name was called, and I took my brown paper bag. As I opened my takeout carton, I burned my fingers on the piping hot sandwich. The two large sausage links, cut long-ways, were as flavorful as they were greasy (which, in case you were wondering, they were very). My egg patty was firm without being rubbery or overcooked, and my roll was flakey and buttery. The cheese was somewhat drowned out by the other ingredients, but that may well be a testament to the sausage. Without a doubt, this was a $4.50 well-spent. When I'm in the area for breakfast, the Dutch Eating Place will always be a temptation.

tl;dr a vegan bakeshop offering admittedly average and overpriced donuts

Dottie's Donuts prides itself on its 100% vegan menu. But with some stellar donut offering throughout Philly, Dottie's has some stiff competition for the title of best. Ordering was a breeze -- just wait in the short queue outside the window. Aiming to pinpoint your order in advance? Beyond Dottie's standard menu, specials items for the day are typically highlighted on Instagram.

My partner and I swung by Dottie's on a weekend morning and opted for an apple fritter, the donut of the day (a Nutella glazed, filled with banana cream), and a Thai iced tea. There wasn't any seating at Dottie's, so we made the short journey to Washington Square to enjoy the weather and our food.
The fritter was enormous, nearly the size of two standard donuts. It was on the dry side -- in fact, it reminded me more of a funnel cake than a donut. The saving grace was the apple-y glaze, which elevated the fritter above an otherwise one-dimensional dessert. The banana-Nutella donut was pleasant enough, but nothing to write home about. I did appreciate that it wasn't overwhelmingly sweet; rather, Dottie's let the banana and Nutella each speak for themselves. As a Thai tea aficionado, I was beyond pleased to find a spot in Society Hill offering it on the reg. However, while the flavors were all there, the drink lost some of its heartiness without any condensed milk.

Overall, despite some rave reviews, I found Dottie's to be surprisingly average -- the donuts reminded me of the $1 Dunkin variety. And at over $10 for our order, I couldn't help but feel a bit ripped off.

tl;dr this Italian BYOB just off of Rittenhouse Square might work for a large party just looking for a good time that doesn't care about the quality of food

I had heard mixed reviews for Melograno from a variety of sources. Some called it the best Italian BYOB in Philly, while others lambasted it for poor service and subpar food. If anything, all this controversy left me needing to find out the real deal for myself.

Walking into Melograno with my partner for an 8PM Friday reservation, I immediately took notice of the cozy decor. Melograno was lofted with exposed wooden beams overhead,  finished with heavy accent lighting, sliding barn doors, and knick-knacks around the walls (including a motor scooter!).

However, the coziness ended there. To say this restaurant was busy would be an understatement. Pop music playing in the background, which ended up being completely drowned out by how incredibly loud this restaurant is. It took nearly 15 minutes to be seated, despite our table having been ready for that whole time. We were seated next to the front window, with the hostess desk (and therefore a line of people still waiting to be seated) blocking us from any servers. And, to be quite frank, the service was awful. It took another 10 minutes after we were seated for anyone to even greet us at our table. Then, it took over 30 minutes on top of that just to get us water -- hilariously, we received our appetizers before our water! Finally, our "starter" bread came with our entrees, a full hour after we had been seated, despite us being promised several times that it was "on the way."

And I haven't even begun speaking about the food. We ordered the Calamari Puttanesca, the Polenta with Oyster Mushroom Special, the Pappardelle al Ragú di Cinghiale, and the Squid Ink Fusilli Special. The polenta, although described by our server as being served "crispy" was mushy and flavorless, with just a dab of red sauce on top. Any flavor that was in that dish came solely from the oyster mushrooms. The calamari was a bit rubbery, although the stew it was served in was really tasty especially with copious amounts of olives and capers. Onto to pasta dishes, I will say that, for both, the noodles themselves were clearly homemade and well-cooked. However, the fusilli lacking in flavor, even though it was served with a good deal of assorted seafood. Unfortunately, some of the mussels were sandy and inedible. On the other hand, the pappardelle, which had only a tiny scoop of the wild boar ragu, ended up leaving much to be desired. To top it all off, our waiter became defensive at the end of our experience when I told him our meal was only "okay."

Overall, I found our meal to be lackluster. In fact, I found myself complimenting the wine (which we BYOB'ed!) more than Melograno itself. In any case, I don't plan on coming back anytime, ever.

tl;dr a Manayunk staple offering standard American bistro fare, albeit for a premium price

"Have you been to Couch Tomato?" My partner swears that everyone has been asking her the same questions ever since she began her new job in Manayunk.
