Promising fresh and local ingredients, Couch Tomato offers an approachable American cafe menu, with an emphasis on artisan pizzas and options for gluten-free and plant-based diets.

The multilevel eatery is split into a takeout counter (the "Bistro") on the ground level with dine-in (the "Cafe") upstairs. The dining atmosphere leans toward a sophisticated take on rustic. Olive green walls are decorated sparsely with paintings and blown-glass lighting fixtures. Wooden tabletops, chairs, and floors are scattered below chandeliers made of repurposed wagon wheels fitted with incandescent bulbs. The space is decked out with multiple plasma screens.

I arrived for dinner with 2 friends, and we were prompted seated. The extensive menu (with a solid assortment of fairly priced draughts and cans) and wonky ordering system admittedly left us overwhelmed. We ended up opting to split 3 Personal-sized pies between us: the Buffalo Chicken, the Margherita, and the Veggie House Special (featuring feta, shitake, and artichoke). The surfboard-shaped Personals ran surprisingly large, a fair amount of food for a single individual. However, the former two pies tasted like amateur home cooking at best. The buffalo chicken was heavier on the celery than either buffalo or chicken (the house ancho was regrettably subdued), and the margarita pie felt incompletely spiced and one-dimensional. In contrast, the veggie special was quite enjoyable, with artfully rich undertones of garlic and olive oil to complement the cheese and veggies. Yet, for all the pies, the thin crust ran closer to thick and floppy than crispy.

Service was pleasant and appropriately attentive. But at ~$25 for a personal pie and a pint, Couch Tomato charges a bit of a premium for remarkable average eats. Despite its commitment to organic ingredients and reputation a crowd-pleaser, I unfortunately wouldn't go so far as to call Couch Tomato anything beyond forgettable.

Yummmmm. Had a bangin dinner here. Not gonna lie, we weren't impressed with this location on our first visit. But today blew us away. The food was awesome the sides were tasty and fresh and our server was so awesome. I'm blanking out on his name but I do remember he's from New York and lived in Vegas lol. Our server really made our experience today special. We came to fogo on a whim after walking around kop. He was so kind and was great on giving us recommendations and taking care of us. Will be back soon! If I could give any feed back which I think is kind of hard to control is that we had a little bit of a fruit fly issue. I think it may be because we were seated close to the front door. Also the filet mignon was requested so many times even with our servers help we got it one time. Can u share the love a lil bit?

Dined last night for my sisters birthday. It was a good experience overall. When we arrived there was a slow up at the front with where we should be seated. Mind you the place was literally 40% or less at capacity. There was a lot of tables that we could've sat at the entire duration of our meal. The front told us that we may not be able to sit.... at a half empty restaurant lol. 

Ended up sitting at a 4 top table and we had 5 people. 3 ppl sitting on a booth and two chairs opposite of us which made no sense. My mom sister and i were a squished so my fiancé asked a server if we could pull a chair at the head of the table which is a lot better than squeezing three people in a space fitted for two people. 

Our server was friendly and knowledgeable. The food was great. It is a little pricey but that comes with the quality of the food you get. Nothing was bland or anything it was all unique to my taste but in a good way. I would be back but if u have a larger party than 3 i would just call and make a reservation so they don't try to play you at the door sayin they have no seats when the place is half empty. 

My only feedback would be that the servers not turn their backs so quickly cus i didn't have a drink for basically 90% of my meal and i couldn't flag him down cus he just zipped around too fast. For the front i would suggest that they implement some better organization because i can not understand why we were told there may be a chance we can't sit when i can literally see the whole floor is basically empty.

Update: came to watch Kung fu panda. Ordered a corona and 20 mins later s corona light came. I said in sorry I ordered a regular corona. The runner looked at me really confused and said are you sure. I said yes. And he replied its the same thing. I said no thanks I'd rather have a regular one. I noticed it came with no lime
And I asked for a like with the next one. The corona did not come for additional 20 mins. When it came no lime. I asked our server for one. 5 mins nothing. Another 5 nothing. Turned a light on someone other than our server came and I asked her for one. Ten mins and nothing. No one came and my boyfriend went up to the bar to get it himself. The food came out cold. And was sub par. In the end I was charged for two coronas when I only had one. When I told my server she said it was because I ordered corona light and change my mind. I said I did not if I did I would've remembered because I never order corona light. She took it off in the end. Next time I'd rather just eat at a normal restaurant and then come here for the seats. 





Very clean but certain kinks can certainly be taken care of. The staff is obviously untrained and have little knowledge of certain procedures and things on the menu. The staff is confused in general everywhere. Upon arrival we tried to return one ticket and it literally took 20 minutes to figure it out. My sister and I got chicken tacos and fish tacos and I am allergic to mangoes so when the food was delivered I asked is this chicken or fish and he said chicken. I bit into it and it was fish tacos which had the mango salsa on it. Another visit I've had beer spilled on my uggs and we had a server who did not know what a old fashioned was and did not know what whiskey in general was. The experience itself is okay. Seats are great and love he concept of being able to drink and eat but the service could be trained further. 

Now for the food itself. It's sub par. Chicken tacos are good. Pizza are good. Burger is okay. French fries were not crispy and the bun of the burger was so oily that my whole hand was covered in oil after. The spicy pickles are pretty good too.

Dined last night for my husbands birthday and it was great! There's a lot of patio seating out on the curb and a bar with high tops in the front and a dining area in the back. It's not a huge place but you don't feel cramped

To start we ordered the buffalo flat bread which tasted more like bbq sauce so we asked out food runner if it was buffalo and she said it should be - the flatbread was really good tho so we kept it, it's probably their version of buff chic but overall rly good! We also got the fry flight which is generous in portion. Totally recommend coming here during their happy hour

Hubby got the burger and it comes w fries. While we were eating apps it dawned on him that he wished he could get a side salad and to our surprise while we were eating out apps - someone came out and asked him if they wanted more fries on top of our flight or a salad instead. LOVE this kind of service! How thoughtful. 

My scallop dish was amaze. It came w risotto and a lot of shrimp and asparagus.. bomb.com

Fried pound cake - it wasn't bad but it wasn't amazing. Prolly would order something else next time. 
Our server was awesome and super nice and had awesome recommendations

Their grill chicken and side dishes were all very tasty. The steak got room for improvement. I tried the dessert flan. It's also yummy. The whole place is cozy and comfortable. Good services, good price and good quality and quantity of food. Overall, I have no complain.

I ordered a steak salad listed on the blackboard as special. Before the entrée, the complementary  bread already impressed me. It was fresh, warm with garlic sauce and cheese. The bread tasted like garlic knot, so good. The clam chowder soup was also quite good- the broth tasted better than other's with big size of clam meat in the soup. My Salad was a big portion plate with fresh crispy romaine lettuce, tomato, cucumber,  and many  pieces of grilled steak. The tortilla hair garnish and the black bean, corn salsa adding a nice Mexican color for the salad. Very attentive service, wide selection of menu items and wine list, this is a hidden gem at Forest Hill Neighborhood. I heard the good reputation about this place.  After the visit, I was not disappointed.

Not a good example of the usual great food at Chic Fil-A!

I was in New Orleans for work... After a few nights of local food near Bourbon St. I was in the need for one of my regular staple meals. I was looking forward to my usual fresh chicken sandwich and hot waffle shaped fries. I typically think of Chic Fil-A as the top notch of fast food. Usually you get the convenience of fast food with higher end quality.

This one location represented them well in regards to service with friendly attentive staff but they were well below the standard of this chain in regards to food. The fries were soggy, the spicy chicken sandwich was thrown together. When I picked it up the lettuce and tomato slid out. The fry oil that they used must have been past it's time because the chicken breading was darker than usual. Limp non fresh food is not what I have grown to expect with this usually top notch fast food chain.

I will go back due to their reputation but not if I get served the same sub par food again.

Hash Browns greasy and hard. Biscuits cold and hard. Very disappointing.
Will not return.

I am SO disappointed.....why?? Because I love their pizza! But they can't get their crap together.  2 weeks ago I ordered to go and they sent me home with someone's leftovers.   Yes, of course,they made up for it once we called to complain.... but tonight we ordered a large and TWO slices of pepperoni for our girls. They showed up with our large and ONE slice.  I told the driver and he said he would go and bring it back. Well it's been hours and still no slice of pizza delivered...... come on Russo's!!  I want to promote you!  Stop letting me down!!!!

A friend of mine told me that we were going to "Mizu" to eat. Not gonna lie, at first I thought she meant "Mizzou," which clearly didn't make sense. Who goes to a university to eat? When I learned that she was taking me and a couple others to eat at Mizu Sushi Bar, I was pretty excited! 

The location is great and the atmosphere is very nice. The service was good and super friendly. They also have a giant screen for sports fans, which is also a plus. 

When the food came out, I was very excited. We had an assortment of sushi pieces (tuna, salmon, etc.) as well as some great rolls. I am a huge fan of unagi (eel), and was very pleased with the rolls that had it. We also had the classic Spider roll as well as few others. 

The coolest roll by far is called "The Imperial Guard," which came wrapped in foil that was shaped like a swan and had a fire going underneath it! I know it sounds amazing, and the taste was also just as good as the presentation. It has shrimp tempura, crab meat, avocado on the inside and eel, tobiko (fish eggs) and spicy mayo and special sauce on top. I'd recommend you try it! It could add to the fun if you're out on a date.

All in all, the night was very fun and enjoyable. The atmosphere was nice and the sushi quality was all very good and fresh. With all that in mind, it is definitely a notch above the other sushi places i have tried so far. Go check this place out if you get the chance! Special thanks to my friend for taking us here! 

Extra Tip: I realize that it is a sushi bar, but if you enjoy cooked fish, you have to try their "himachi," which is cooked yellowtail. It was cooked so well and the taste was amazing! It wasn't gamy at all and was so soft. I would even go back just for some more of it!

"Lorenzo's Trattoreeeeeeah" with a THICK Italian accent is how I always read it in my head... no I'm not racist, it's just more fun that way.

 I'd have to say that one thing I really enjoyed about this restaurant is the location and the atmosphere. Lorenzo's is found right in the middle of what seems like a very small-town residential area. It's a predominantly Italian area called The Hill. It was a beautiful day so we ate outside. It was so calm and peaceful, and my friends and I were able to talk without having to worry about any real distractions. 

On to the food! The atmosphere made everything pleasant and the food also was pleasant. Some friends ordered pasta dishes, while I opted for a sausage pizza. It tasted very good, definitely a good pizza. I would say though that it was a bit heavy; after a few slices, it was difficult to fully enjoy the rest. 

I'd definitely recommend this restaurant for those who want a peaceful night on The Hill with some good pizza. I'll have to update again if I ever go back to try their pasta dishes.

On the search for a 24-hour coffee shop? Look no further than Coffee Cartel. First of all, props on the name. Kinda gives the place an edge, an almost dangerous feel, no? "Meet me." "Where?" "At... the Coffee CARTEL!!" Awesome. 

Anyway, like the first line states, this place is open 24-hours, which is by far the biggest draw. If you're the type of person that needs to have things going around them to study better (I know, sounds counterproductive, but I know many feel this way), this is the place. They have free wi-fi, which isn't bad at all. The toughest part will be nabbing a good study-spot when they're busy. 

Onto the food and drinks. You can't go wrong with ice cream, and the food is okay, but a bit pricey for what you get. But overall, it's still good. I'm not much of a coffee drinker, but they have creamer and sugar/splenda, which is enough for me.

Remember, the place doesn't advertise itself as gourmet eats. If you need a place to chill and talk or do some late-into-the-night studying at a place where you can get up and grab a decent cup of Joe, some sweets or a quick bite, then look no further than where? "The Coffee... CARTEL!! MUAHAHAHA!!" Okay, seriously though, gotta stop with the maniacal laughter.

Came here during Final Four weekend for the first time ever.  It was PACKED as you can probably imagine.  We stood at the bar and drank, so I cannot speak as to the food here unfortunately.  I did try a little of the dip that everyone was ordering and it was good.  Like a buffalo chicken queso dip of some sort.

In terms of beer selection, they have 8 taps of domestic stuff and a few Irish staples like Guinness and Strongbow.  They also have about 30 or so bottle/can beer selections.  The ambiance is more American bar than it is Irish Pub unfortunately which makes you believe that someone wanted to simply open a bar and then decided to give it a theme later.

The prices, are probably the main reason it lost a star from 4 to 3.  A draft beer was $8!  Are you kidding? I know we are pretty much across the street from Lucas Oil, but give me a break, we aren't at the stadium.  I was pretty unhappy that 3 rounds cost me $56 before tip.  With all the places to drink in town that offer the exact same beers, why would one come here to pay nearly double the price?  No thanks.

Maru just spiced up the Westside! This place is not solely a ramen shop. Maru aims to share traditional Japanese culture through their menu. While they have a variety of ramen options ( tonkotsu, shoyu, tantan and miso) they also offer Udon noodles, curry and an array of appetizers. There are several kinks that need to be ironed out for Maru to be a four or five star experience due to factors such as the general confusion people experience in the ordering process. There definitely needs to be more signage around how to order. Perhaps placing a large sign up front with a"how-to" description.  From a food standpoint, Maru is a four, simply because the timing of your arrival will really dictate the quality of your experience. But the food is good! So keep on reading this review for tips on how to navigate Maru.

-Maru is order at that counter, but a server brings you your food.
-Head up the the front where the appetizer/hot bar is located. That's where the process begins.
-The appetizers bar offers a variety of items such as onigiri, tempura, egg rolls, gyoza, katsu, etc.  As mentioned, if you arrive during a busy time the bar may not be fully stocked. BUT, what they don't tell you is that if there is an item not currently on the bar, you can still order it. They will cook it for you. They are constantly replenishing the bar, so again, it's a timing thing. But all items can be ordered. 
-From the hot bar just grab the items you want. They are all labeled. The next step is the cash register where you can place your order for your noodles or non-appetizer items.
-Before you sit down, head to the toppings bar!
-Also not mentioned anywhere, they do have beer, we just didn't see a drink menu when we were there. They have soft drinks as well as other Japanese softs drinks and tea.

Highlights:
The tantan ramen was our favorite. Spicy, but not overwhelming. Rich broth and just super delicious. The katsu and gyoza were also very good.

The staff at Maru are super friendly and helpful. So, just ask questions if you're unsure on what to order!

Conveniently located on 4th avenue and they serve food until midnight- at least on Thursdays. We cruised in at 9:40pm or so and the place was packed for Trivia night. With no seating available at any tables, we opted for as spot at the bar. Our server was super friendly and service was really prompt. Considering this place is known for their sandiwiches, I probably should have ordered one, but I was in the mood for a salad and I am glad I did! The portions are quite generous too! I ordered the "That's what she said" salad and my brother ordered a salad with buffalo chicken on it. Mine was exactly what I was looking for! Grilled chicken with crispy peppered bacon, avocado, hard boiled egg and tomatoes over a huge bed of fresh leafy green. The vinaigrette on the side was perfect. I'm a salad person and often get stumped on where to go when I'm craving one, so I'm happy that I finally gave Bumsted's a try. It was A-Ok for sure. And the price ($9.95) was just right. I'll be back someday to brave one of their giant sammies.

First time trying hotpot. We went for lunch around 1pm Selection of ingredients was decent. Pretty attentive server. We were gonna use free ice creAm code after check in as a deal. But the server said that they ran out of ice cream, which was kinda hard to believe. It was just only lunch time. Not even the end of the day. Well. We didnt mind much. Quality of meat and vege were good. Taste fine. We will revist again

Stopped in today. We both ordered burgers. Mine was burnt and hers had a lot of gristle. Never had a bad meal there before. Then this happened. I will go back for the ribs. They used to have good burgers but don't know what happened. 

.

solid little trattoria in Gulfport.  Service was fantastic and the atmosphere was really great too!  Decent wine list with some great choices by the glass.  Lowering a star because this time we went for pasta and call me pasta snob but it was good, nothing fantastic.  Definitely not homemade and as I've been told a thousand times by my friends in Italy - Spaghetti Bolognese does not exist.  It should be a crime.  The sauce is just too much for thin spaghetti...  So we didn't order it.  I did get the penne with pesto sauce and sautéed shrimp.  The shrimp should have been grilled - they had absolutely no seasoning at all.  The bruschetta on the other hand was fabulous.  I could have made a meal out of that.

This is the 2nd landmark I've been to and I am not impressed. This time tried the crab dip and friend had a salad. Salad was good but the crab dip bread was stale and just nasty. The crab dip itself was bland. We had drinks and shots. My Mexican mule came in a plastic coffee mug, yes I said plastic, and it wasn't that good. Shots were great but you can't mess those up. Bar staff weren't really friendly. Same thing happened at the other landmark. Maybe they need better employees and better cooks.

You can skip Tracey's. 

Writing that, admitting that out loud, is hard for me. I loved the old Parasol's. I was so thrilled when the whole gang moved over to such a great space. I was so thrilled that New Orleans was getting a real sports bar that wouldn't be full of sweaty underage Tulane students. 

First, the positive: They have finally started to accept credit cards, but it may be too little, too late - though it's worth noting the $1.99 fee at the ATM is respectable.

As a restaurant, it falls flat. As other reviewers have noted, the food was better in the former location, and is now decidedly unremarkable.  Well, at best you can't make remarks. I've tried a few different po boys, the chicken fingers, the boudin balls, and the fries. Except the boudin balls (which were decent), everything was too dry and/or too salty. For the Rose Bowl this year, they went above and beyond, serving bratwurst in honor of the University of Wisconsin - but for some reason the kitchen was wildly understaffed, and it took 30+ minutes just to get a brat in a bun. Disappointing. 

As a sports bar, it is chaotic and has a poor layout. The tables fill very quickly, and most of the standing room is in a narrow corridor between the bar and a counter designed for people standing that divides the room. People arrive early - literally, 3 hours before kickoff - to save seats for large parties, and if you miss out on a seat, or the limited standing room at that dividing bar, you'll be left to uncomfortably stand through the entire evening.  This is because even though the space is enormous, there isn't really anywhere to lean without interfering with someone's table, or without blocking either the bar, the kitchen, the pool table, or the bathroom.

Parasol's was vibrant, and had a community feel with great personality. Tracey's is the opposite - soulless, cold, and uninviting. Do yourself a favor, and watch the game somewhere else.

Bibou is cash only and BYOB.  Any place with BYOB gets an extra point from me.  I've heard great reviews about this place so I finally was able to get a Saturday reservation for the chef's tasting menu that consisted of 7 courses.  It is $70 a person and only caters to a maxiumum of two people. Once we walked in, my friend and I were seated at the counter where we can watch the chefs cook and prepare.  We brought two bottes of champagne to drink with our 7 course journey.  Everything that came out was delicious.  My favorite dish was the 3rd couse which was fish (I forgot what kind it was) over pureed potatoes.  The bone marrow course was also good and tasty.  My least favorite was the dessert. It didn't do anything to my taste buds but overall it was a great time. The servers were excellent, the atmosphere was cozy, and I sure will come back again but maybe for a regular dinner not the chefs tasting course.  Make sure you make reservations ahead of time because this place gets booked up quickly.

Happy Hour is amazing here. 4-7 pm everyday.  Cheap food and great quality. It ranges from $2-4 tops along with $4 drink specials. We had the Kobe beef sliders medium and it was satisfying with every bite. Also the Korean BBQ satay is delish. The pork banh mi is also good if you like Vietnamese hoagies with more flavor because I think they used spicy mayo instead if the usual pate in Viet hoagies. We were full and satisfied all for under $30 for 2 people. I will definitely be back.

Breakfast menu was limited, kind of strange for a pizza shop to be making breakfast. Eggs could have been cooked longer and the bagels needed more butter and better grilling ( per my request). As I have learned they don't typically grill the bagels. An error on my part not the restaurant. Not great for a large variety of breakfast. Not sure how lunch or dinner is. I will say, the coffee was very good! The response to this post was quick and I will increase your rating for that and my error.

Well I really wanted to love this establishment. The menu is creative, the atmosphere is cool...so that part I love.

I'm rarely in Tampa but when we looked for some place unique to grab a bite . We found Mermaid Tavern and drove about 15 minutes away from where we were. 

We came in and figured out that you have to go to the counter to order, they give you a number and you wherever you sit they'll bring you your ordered based on your number. My friend order and then I ordered after a couple behind her.

Her veggie burger was delivered in  about 5 minutes. I ordered fried cheese curds and a salad with goat cheese,  nothing hot on the salad. After about 15 or 20 minutes I asked about my salad and they said it was coming up soon. It ended up taking over 20 minutes to get my salad, by that time my friend was done with her veggie burger. Five minutes later the cheese curds came out.  Over 20 minutes for a salad and cheese curds is a bit excessive especially when it only took 5 minutes for a veggie burger.

As for the food itself, it wasn't anything extrodinary,  it was just ok. The goat cheese was two big medallions on top of the F..Monsanto Salad ,which made it kind of hard to eat. Crumbled goat cheese would have been easier to eat and been distributed throughout salad rather then just on top. The lentil pilaf wasn't seasoned so it didn't do much for the salad in my opinion. In addition the salad was missing two components, the Asian pear and the asparagus. I asked if they were out of asparagus since it wasn't on my salad and they said no, so they just didn't put the items on. I love unique combinations with interesting produce but this salad didn't work for me. Now the cheese curds...the flavor was great , how can you go wrong with fried cheese curds.Well you can if you over cook them, they ended up frying out so I ended up with a big blob of fried cheese :-( 
Super bummed because the menu is so creative and most of the reviews are good. Maybe it was an off day or it was the items I ordered. Hoping I make it back and I have a better experience.

I keep trying to like this restaurant since it's so convenient to where I live but It constantly disappoints me.

Let me start with the positives, love love the decor.  Such cool murals and paintings which is the high point of the restaurant. 
The guacamole and salsa have also been good. This visit the salsa was just ok. 
I ordered a spicy Margarita,   it was jalapeño ...nice and spicy and tasty. 
Service was ok.
The food was ok, nothing overly exciting . The food was not hot, just warm. 
They were having bathroom issues, both bathrooms were flooded. I needed to use the restroom so I walked into the women's and there was a man in there using the bathroom with door open. I guess one of the employees told he could and he was suppose to stand at the door to let women know not to go in but he was off doing other things. I was told that I could across the street to McDonald's until they fixed both bathroom and reopened them. I wish I would have know this before I sat down, I would have gone somewhere else. 
There are a lot of options in St. Pete that I feel have better food, so I think I'm throwing in the towel and moving on.

OK first off, love the eclectic atmosphere. I really enjoy unique places, do the decor is great and fun. I've been in a couple of times and each time the food was ok. 

The last time I was in, one of our items was burnt and another was under seasoned so our food wasn't as good as the first time . As you can see from the picture, the black pieces in the veggie burger were burnt pieces and the onion rings weren't fully covered so the ended up getting dry and brown on the inside. 
I haven't tried the soulfood Sunday, I'm hoping it will be better than my last expierence at Ellas.

We are disappointed having to say our dining experience here was absolutely Salty, Salty, and more Salty.. :((  Euk..  There was a time when we gave it 4 stars.  When it first opened, it was okay.  We gave it another chance and it did earn our return time and again.  Enough that it became one of our regular restaurants.  Over the few years, we'd go about every 2-3 months.  The food experience was like riding a wave.  The quality would go up, then back down a little, then up again.  The staff was always different.  There was a time span though, of about 6 months, when it was really good.  Consistent.  You can taste the quality and the complexity of spices and seasoning in the sauces.  The meats and seafood was done perfectly.  Presentation was nice.  This time though, the many changes did not appeal to us.  Most of the dishes are now tapas and not so well prepared like before.  It looks great, much like previously prepared, but the excellent well balanced taste for those dishes are not the same.  It reminded me of the old Blush and the new Funk Zone Patio.  The quality did not match the price and worse of all, every bite of our dishes was just way too salty to eat.  My husband's (regular) Grill Salmon was mushy and salty but not as much as my Garlic Shrimp Pasta.  My dish was so overly salted that I couldn't taste the shrimp, the pasta, not even the garlic!  It was more like spoons of salt.  I ate 2 bites and just couldn't continue.  Hubby suggested I order something else.  I tried the tapa of Diver's Scallops, again, too salty to eat.  The Ahi Crostini was okay but the fish was hard and not sashimi/sushi grade like before.  The wine and service was fine.  We paid.  We left.  We cannot return.

I picked up the pizza, although I think they deliver. I ordered a cheese and pepperoni pizza and it had all the basics right. The crust was crispy and the sauce and pepperoni were good. The pizza wasn't great nor was it bad. In the south tip of St Pete there aren't many pizza choices. I would get one again.

Interesting concept. Like the fact that all of their fried poboys were automatically spicy.

Tried both the Da Yat covered in gumbo, and the Who Dat covered in bisque. I personally preferred the gumbo as it was better able to cut through the flavor fo the poboy.

However, for the price I don't believe that I can be back to try it. Certainly if you're on Bourbon and you are hungry. Or if you want to try an interesting concept that is tasty, come check it out

Pretty good/solid food

1. Baos - I got the ba chi bao. The meat was nice, tender, and fatty, but the bun was not uniformly moist. Not something that I would eat to get full as it was over $3 and I probably would have had to eat 5/6 to just not be hungry
2. Vermicelli bowl with the 3 types of meat. I enjoyed this very much. Large portions, lots of fresh vegetables. Well-marinated, tender meat. Sauce that you can pour on top. Generous portions.

If I'm in the area I'll probably be back to try some other bowls

This is in regards to the casino. Nothing special or negative to say as the staff is friendly enough and the layout is average. My personal preferance is to play the Hold'em table game. It is slower paced and doesn't take your money as fast as the othe games. The problem is they only have 2 tables open at a time and they are always filled while the other table games they have are usually open and have dealers just standing there waiting for people to show up and play. I really don't understand why they don't open a 3rd or 4th table for the Hold'em game (yes i do, the game is slower than blackjack and 3 card poker and probably doesn't take money fast enough). This appears to be a popular game and people who wait around to play eventually leave, like me! 
Hopefully they read this feedback and decide to open more tables and then I will return to the casino. Otherwise, I am and have stayed away for awhile now.

Breakfast buffet for $10.95, which includes coffee AND juice. Can't beat the price. The omelet station is full of good choices for your omelet fillings and the guy made an egg white omelet for my mom and soft cooked eggs for another lady who just wanted eggs and not an omelet. Worth the cost of the buffet just for the eggs, breakfast items and beverages. Also have lunch items like salads and soups (after noon).Menu says served to 2 pm on Saturdays and Sundays!
Halloween night at the Pub and worth the hour- long wait! Love their salad bar (especially Caesar salad) and steaks. Even better value with a coupon from the newspaper!

Sorry the food was not good at all. I do not mind paying a higher price for a meal IF the food is good. My meal was simple Shrimp and broccoli with white rice ( by the way you will pay extra to have rice) then I ordered a EGG ROLL. The shrimp and broccoli had a ton of garlic which I did not order and it was watery. I was given spring rolls instead of an egg roll.  We ordered take out and we got taken. I threw it all in the garbage I was very disappointed with this food. I will never eat at this establishment again.

I will be honest-their Beijing duck is pretty darn tasty. But everything else is average. And any time you take a fatty duck and bake it to a crisp, it's pretty hard to make it undelicious.

If you come here, come for the duck and maybe the walnut shrimp (which they don't make authentic btw, but it gets the job done if you're craving it). Don't get too excited about the other dishes though. Service is like their food, average. A solid "meh".

This is the real deal. I lived in Beijing for 6 months, and the way this shop makes their noodles is the authentic way. If you don't know what I'm talking about, the noodle-maker takes a ball of dough, stretches it out, slaps it down onto the board, folds in half and then repeats.

That probably didn't make any sense, so you've gotta go and see it for yourself. What to order? You can't go wrong with their niu rou tang mien (beef noodle soup). The beef isn't too fatty or too dry, and the soup base is seasoned just right.

If you're in Chinatown, I think this is one of the best quick meals to be had. Sure, the wait staff of one person isn't going to be the nicest nor most attentive server in the world, but you don't go to a real hole in the wall to be pampered.

Invited friends to try out with my husband and I for our first visit, and unfortunately it will probably be our last. Small little spot a block off the water, no views of the beach but quick walk to and from. Server was quick to pride themselves on being a "locals spot", explaining their laid back attitude and demeanor. But there's a big difference in catering to locals by offering good specials, yummy food and a friendly atmosphere and not putting much effort to impress each patron who walks in the door and is willing to give you some of their hard earned money. I'll give them credit for offering reasonable prices on drinks like $3 domestic bottles and $4 deep Eddy miked drinks. The food was about average cost for a place on Clearwater Beach, the menu options similar a mix of bar food like wings and burgers as well as seafood options. We decided to sample a few smaller dishes to share as apps. The wings were truly awful, very over done and dry. Coconut shrimp were large but almost flavorless with a odd tasting yogurt based dipping sauce. The one item we did enjoy were to the shrimp tacos. They came 2 per order and were well seasoned and portioned well. With the multitude of other dining options for locals and tourists alike, not putting the time and effort into your dishes isn't the recipe for success.

Should have listened to other Yelp reviewers. Ordered food on SkipTheDishes which is a GREAT service! Ordered this restaurant to try something new. First off the packages were toddler size! The Beef, Garlic and Onions was bland. My Chicken, lemon grass and onions was good (reason for two stars). The crab Rangoon was the worst thing I have tasted in a long time...first the fried wonton tasted like old oil, the filling I'm not sure if it was spoiled or what but had to spit it out. Ended up ordering from China King we were so displeased! If you're looking for quality in the area China King is cheap and WAY better, or for a nice sit down/delicious carry out check out the King and I!

[943]

This Chick Fil A is located on busy Baltimore Pike.   

It has two well run drive thrus.  They had people outside to help the line move quickly.

The inside is clean and well run.

My food was hot and prepared perfectly.

I'll definitely be back

Great prices- Great food

Stromboli is really good here, but depends on who makes it. Sometimes it's mediocre, sometimes it's AMAZING
Cheesesteaks are good (not great)
Pizza is not my favorite

All said and done it's a good neighborhood place

I love love love Tartes! Such a cute little pink building! My husband takes me every year for my birthday to pick out some treats. I've tried various flavors of their tarts and have come to the conclusion that the pear pistachio is the winner. The blackberry lemon and coconut cream tarts are amazing as well. You can't go wrong with any flavor really, the crust on the tarts is what brings me back, so flaky and good. I've also had their lemon bar and a chocolate chip cookie bar of some sort and both were really yummy.

I've been ordering the same dish from Karma for years - the Chicken Tikka Masala. It is truly the best version I have ever had anywhere! In the world! Seriously, it is really that good. 

I always do take out but have been dying to try their popular lunch buffet. I FINALLY tried it the other day. The did not have the tikka masala on the buffet so I was forced to try their other dishes. I loved their paneer, butter chicken, lamb korma, and rice pudding.

They really did a great job (except for some of the appetizers on the buffet which were just lumps of fried things). HOWEVER! I just love their chiken tikka and I will go back to ordering that on its own from here on out still :)

Zakes Cakes and Cafe opened as an outpost in the suburbs to serve "light fare" and continues to satisfy the community's collective sweet tooth today. Located in Fort Washington, Zakes (sometimes listed with an apostrophe) resides on the lower floor of a house at the bottom of a hill.

To quote directly from another review: "Zakes' salads, sandwiches and soups are all outstanding, but save room for dessert! Many delicious specials to choose from, in addition to a great menu. The only problem here is making a decision. Be prepared to wait for a table around lunchtime..." Unless you arrive early, you'll have to wait at least 15 minutes to get a table. After noon, the place fills up! You'll get to wait on the patio's couch (!) and appreciate the garden outside at least. The main room can seat a reasonably large party. Look around and you'll see regulars from the surrounding area: residents of Ambler and Fort Washington and droves of worker bees from the nearby industrial parks. On a sunny day the place is cheery and well-lit. On cloudy days, the ceiling lighting is well-arranged and doesn't overwhelm. The walls are decorated with framed photographs thrown about. I can't remember any music playing in the background.

The menu has Italian, Vietnamese, French, Chinese, and English highlights. Daily specials are available at Zakes. I had a bowl Mediterranean tomato soup with orzo. It was lightly flavored with tomato and herbs and had a light, pleasing taste. Chunky bits of orzo added substance to the dish.  The portabello sandwich tasted like pizza and had the consistency of a tomato pie. It was topped with brussel sprouts... I looked forward to taking another bite as soon as I took the first!

The mocha gatteau didn't live up to my expectations. I was disappointed that the mocha was not as strong as I would have liked. The level of the baker's expertise is evident in the clean presentation of the cake. 

Zakes is a comfortable place to go for lunch and a cup of coffee. Next time I go I think I'll get the Saigon salad, summer rolls (with chicken, shrimp) or the bourbon glazed salmon... so many choices...

I was here for a happy hour last month - the bartender (Nick) was friendly.

The space by the bar isn't the best for a happy hour, but their specials (free appetizers I believe) are hard to beat. The appetizers themselves were fine, typical Asian-styled fried food. Their happy hour is earlier than others too: 4:30pm-6:30pm.

Like their bar, their parking lot is also cramped, so get there early to avoid having to compete for a space. (UPDATE: There's a lower lot with more space that I hadn't noticed before! Bad news is that I tried some of their entrees and wasn't impressed...)

This McDonald's is right in Bryn Mawr, off of Airdale Road. Like most of their suburban locations, there's decent parking. However, I've only been here (and twice) for drive thru service - in fact, I made a late night run for Chicken McNuggets, only because it was Sunday night and even WENDY'S was closed. No problems with service here!

Friends and I met here for a late lunch. The restaurant's popular, so reservations are the way to go. Luckily, we only had a 20-minute wait.

Belgians sure must love to drink, for Monk's is known for having an extensive beer selection, one that fills multiple pages. Beer drinkers, this is your heaven. (Since I'm no beer expert, my eyes glazed over in confusion; I ordered a shot of tequila instead.)

Their Spanish Flies ($8.50) - chicken wings - were decent. The chipotle pepper sauce they're dry rubbed in was supposed to be "incredibly hot", but I only detected a wee kick. For my entree, I had the curry mussels ($9.95; small pot) which were simply wonderful: Rodenbach Red Ale, Thai red curry, basil, garlic, coconut milk, and tender mussels, all in a bowl. The string fries on the side were surprisingly crispy and went well with the dipping sauce.

I know they're a Belgian cafe, but if they tossed ramen noodles into the curry, they'd make a killing.

Solid beach breakfast standard.  Located next to the Columbia Restaurant on Sand Key.  Have indoor table and booth seating and outdoors tables overlooking Intercoastal Waterway.   Inexpensive, opens at 7 am.  Biscuits are really good and crispy - not gummy like a lot of places.

This location has changed  several times  since one of my favorites Adeles closed its doors, I really hope The Bridge becomes  a mainstay as the aforementioned Adeles was. I sat at the bar as usual and props to Emil the bartender was engaging and attentive, but my reviews are about the food...
I ordered the chicken sliders and first as you can see presentation was an afterthought, even a school lunchroom server wouldn't try to fit 3 sliders onto a small app plate. Taste wise the chicken was cooked well and was very juicy, the buns were good but they seemed to  provide the texture in the sandwich by being a bit over toasted  also the roasted garlic cloves should probably be spread a bit to prevent them from rolling out of the sandwich and off my giant plate . I will for sure go back because the place is in its infancy and we all know what growing pains are.  
 
As a yelper it's our duty to review with the intent being to improve the business not to hurt it because a thriving economy  is beneficial to us all 
More to come

My food was OK, the service was OK. The menu was unique (the first five or six items were "pork snacks"), but fairly limited. I heard after talking to friends that the limited menu is only on certain days. Why not a full menu every day of the week?

The smoked trout appetizer was my favorite part of the meal. The "Movie Theater Popcorn" had a great pitch, so I splurged out of curiosity, then felt slightly ripped off. Those at my table who had cocktails raved about them. The pizza not bad but not particularly memorable.

I guess I have to try another day, and I'll be sure to ask if they have a full menu or the abbreviated quirky menu before making a reservation.

So, as promised, I tried the guys across the street.  Overall, the steak was OK, the cheese good, but the bread was too chewy for my liking.  Good grease factor, but other things bring this place down:

1. Price.  $9 for a steak, $2 for a drink...I didn't even bother with fries.
2. I'm sure some of the cost of my food is going into funding all the touristy merch at this place.  Really?  You guys can't just serve steaks?
4. Service - surley...even for philly.  I've had better service from kidney thieves.
5. The pro-police, anti-immigrant crap.  I get it, cops are great.  What if I only speak italian, y'know, like some of your forefathers, do I still need to 'order in english'?

If you like it, great, but I'll spend my $ at Pat's.

We decided to have drinks and shrimp coconut on thursday night at bahama breeze. When we went to the restaurant outside seating was full so we decided to sit inside. We ordered bahama mama and virgin pina colado as well as coconut shrimp. The drinks came in 5-10 minutes but coconut shrimp didn't came. The waiter came to us and said that food will be ready in 5 minutes and we will soon have our food. But food never came. We waited for 20-30 minutes more but the food never came. So we decided to cancel our order. The waiter came and said sorry to us. He not only said sorry to us but sorry to other customers as well because like us they never received the order for food. It seems like kitchen never cared for the customers. Kitchen sucks for bahama breeze. It was a disastrous experience for us.
Standard Chinese restaurant menu options. Service is on the slower side and food is average tasting. Prices are reasonable.

I went to Blanco ready to be entirely underwhelmed: I don't hate Fox restaurants, but they tend to be all about hype, style, & $$$$$, and don't really deliver food/taste-wise. I'm happy to report that Blanco actually surprised me.

For starters, my friend and I ordered the guacamole and the ceviche. Let me point out that normally, the guacamole is $9 and the ceviche is $13, and the portions are no larger than the size of like, half a tennis ball. We meticulously made sure to eat during Happy Hour (50% off starters and drinks), but the moment those dishes were placed on the table, my friend and I glanced at each other and both said something to the effect of, "This would have been NINE DOLLARS? And this THIRTEEN? Whaaat?!" Either way, the guacamole is all the hype: rich, flavorful, and fresh. The ceviche was untraditionally (? compared to what I've had before) sweet and did not win over my super taster BFF, who was expecting something more conventionally acidic and spicy. However, I thought it was pretty yummy myself (though certainly not $13-for-an-appetizer yummy). The complimentary salsa was also addictive and a favorite of my BFF (RE: super taster).

For the main course, my friend and I told our server we would split a dish of mushroom tacos, which should have come with only 3 tacos. When our food came out and we each had a plate with 2 tacos and what I presume was an extra serving of rice and beans, we again found ourselves looking at each other all, "Are we gonna be charged for this? We're gonna be charged for this." Spoiler alert: we weren't charged for it, which was seriously beyond gracious and awesome. Unfortunately, the taco and side of rice and beans were bland and 100% not memorable. 

In conclusion: the appetizers are tasty (but not full-price tasty). The entrees are okay (but not full-price okay). The restaurant design is Tucson trying super hard to be trendy and modern. The service is awesome. I'd say this place is worth a shot. During Happy Hour.

I love Smashburger, but my experience at the airport location was truly unacceptable. The woman taking our order got all the burgers wrong & we tried to correct them, but with no success. During the wait for our order, we were told that they had run out of onion (at 2:00pm?). 
I asked for hot sauce on my burger & when I pulled it out of the bag,  there was more sauce on the outside than internally. I thought you had to go to Carl's Jr for a sloppy burger. I also noticed that the burger was bland, not juicy like all my other experiences at Smashburger (frozen patties?). Additionally, the patty was not cooked appropriately, but I didn't notice until I was nearly 3/4 finished.
My advice: avoid this location if you like Smashburger.
Great menu, good food and excellent service.

Two and a half stars really. Wife and I stopped in for dinner the other night. She had the clam chowder and I had the french onion. Both soups were excellent and huge. We really should have stopped there but, unfortunately, we opted to share an order of fish and chips. The chips were good, but the other, well I don't know what it was, but it wasn't like any fish I'd had. It was clearly something that had been processed off site and delivered frozen like some kind of fish stick or something. My pieces were largely flavorless but my wife thought hers were off. Either way it was nasty. I'd had other stuff there that is ok, but if you go, DO NOT order the fish and chips.

Arrived around 6pm on a Sat. just before it got to busy. Our server was very sweet and chatted with us and kept out glasses of brewed tea full and out table empty of used plates. There was so many options of food to choose from it was almost overwhelming. I took a tour around before I started filling my plate to get a feel of what was available. The desserts looked amazing so I knew I needed to save room for them. I started with the salad bar. It was fresh and clean and I grabbed some rotisserie chicken to put on top for chicken salad. Next I chose some popcorn shrimp and the Cajun sausage. Both were my favorites. They had steak & chicken grilled to order. Finally ended with a ton of desserts: cookies (warm and soft), apple coddler, bread pudding, and chocolate cake. Yum. The only huge downside was that as it got later in the evening the clientele got sketchy. It became a bit of a mad house with people running around, kids crying and general rudeness (people stepping in front of you waiting for food, etc.).

this is for the buffet. It was 15 dollars for adult and 10 for a 5 yr old kid. Food was non-greasy and non-spicy so the kids could eat all of the items. Service was good. Only problem was that the dishes could barely be called Indian. My daughter was right saying the sauces tasted like pasta sauce. Seemed more catered to bland american tastes. Whatever works for the owners. wish them good luck.

False gluten free advertising of buns for sandwiches and burgers. Jacob, our waiter was super nonchalant regarding the numerous mistakes on the menu and lack of items.  Food was a definite meh and the constant outdoor shower was a little too much.

We went for the Valentine's Day dinner meal on a Saturday. For the appetizers it was a old piece of something they obviously cooked on Thursday, one oyster that was not old but not prepared in anyway besides dry and a smear of OK liver on a broken piece of something. The steak tartare was full of fat and grizzle and big chunks of not good cuts of meat. The French onion soup was fine. The entrées were not noteworthy and not good. The desserts were blah. This was a big waste of calories and money. The drinks were fine. Go somewhere that cares about their food.

When I lived in Santa Barbara we used to go to this awesome brewery a lot but after a few months we started noticing they started to have terrible customer service as well as the drinks were terrible and not strong. They have awesome food especially their crazy mac and cheese dishes, amazing. Staff could be friendlier.

this super cucas location is pretty delicious but it also get pretty packed due to their lack of a parking lot (it is always packed and very difficult to get out of) as well as it being a little grocery store inside as well. They have delicious carne asada, super fresh and their assortment of salsas and sauces really spice the meat up. Their portions are also HUGE so if you get a large burrito, quesadilla or nachos do share that way you won't go home with a ton of leftovers.

Family owned place in Upper Darby next to the fantastic H Mart korean supermarket. The food was Ok but I cannot give it more than 2 stars as the folks I was with found hair TWICE in our pho. I cannot imagine what else was in there

Ugh. This is one of those reviews you just don't even want to write. Stumbled upon this place last night after the wait at John and Molly's down the road was too long. Walked inside and there wasn't a host. We stood at the front for a few minutes when a guy with an apron told us to have a seat. We sat at a high top in the bar area. We waited for at least 10 minutes before the same guy brought us menus over and at least another 5 after before we had a server. They advertise on the tables having wine from Iron Plow, but when I asked what they had they did not know and said the bottles were almost empty anyway. 

For entrees we ordered the chicken saltimbocca and the CHICKEN scampi. I emphasize the chicken because, as you can see from the picture, we didn't get chicken. We sent the shrimp back and waited another 10 minutes for the chicken scampi to come out. We also ordered both entrees without tomatoes and sure enough one still had tomatoes. The saltimbocca was okay, but the sauce was sweeter than I like and overloaded with thyme. The scampi sauce was pretty much just terrible both times it came out. 

When we asked for the check the waitress said the shrimp was still on there, but she would adjust the price difference. I gave her my credit card assuming it would be fixed when she returned. Nope. At that point it was not worth the extra dollar or two, I was just over this place and ready to go. 

I guess subpar is to be expected when you're in the middle of nowhere and don't have many dining options....

My expectations were high for this place, and I want to to give it four stars for the ambiance, but had to give it three for the food.  

I absolutely love the decor of this place, so trendy!  It has a great lounge area with comfy couches and pillows.  The ambiance of this place makes this restaurant.   For the food, well I cannot say the same.  

We started off with the tuna tartare- which was very good, and I was expecting our entrees to be the same.  I had the bronzino and my fiance had the seared tuna.  Both dishes were ok, but nothing to rave about.   The taste of both dishes just did not satisfy my taste buds, and I really wanted to like it.  

Overall, although the food was average, we really enjoyed the atmosphere.  I think the food is overpriced.  I would come here again for drinks and appetizers, but not for dinner.

Yes, I took off a star... I would love to give 4 1/2 stars but that doesn't seem to be an option... sorry... it's for the atrocious parking situation here, as well as for the very confusing and chaotic set-up of counter sales vs. hostess station. 
Once you're in the parking lot just to figure out that there are no spaces available, the task of getting back out of the lot is incredibly difficult. Between the waiting line that spills into the lot and more incoming vehicles and no way of turning the vehicle around.... this can get quite frustrating. 
The line of counter customers intermingles with the line to the hostess stand, so it takes a bit to figure out which way you are heading. I believe I may have cut in front of somebody, which was not my intention, but in my defense, I was pushed around a bit. I still have no idea which goes where, as there was mostly a ball of people swaying back and forth, I kinda hollered my name and size of party to a friendly lady and thought I would stop by the counter and get something to snack on while I waited or maybe some coffee... this effort was doomed as the people ball spit me out into the parking lot at some point. Oh well... when it was our turn the hostess parted the crowd and safely led us to our table... 
I have to say that my main problem with these up and coming famous and trendy small plates high prices spots is that a lot of them have this snooty attitude...BUT even so Milktooth is now nationally recognized as one of the best restaurants in the US, there is NO attitude here. Service is genuinely friendly and they are doing their best to serve you quickly and educate you about the fancy creations on the menu. 
If you are like me and not sure about some of these odd creations, then you know what I am talking about. You start to read a description and it sounds awesome and all of a sudden there is some sort of ingredient that makes you do a double take and for the life of you, you just cannot imagine why anybody would put this with the rest of the dish, ore you don't even have any idea what that even is.... yet somehow they pull it off and it is delicious... amazing. And even if you don't really care for a dish, you can taste the quality of ingredients used. too bad that every time I identify a favorite they no longer serve it next time I stop by... grrrr.... but if you get a chance to try the donut holes... OMG... so so good... and if they ever bring back that grapefruit with sea salt and honey comb somebody please call me... this visit my faves were the donut holes, the potato ladtke and some sort of lamb pancake thing...

Please, Jaco, come to Center City!!! What a delightful spot, and the walk-up window? Genius. 
I love that I can get a simple breakfast sammie, or a creative burrito. For my first visit, I went with the Killer Veggie; perfectly sized and delicious. The diagonal cut makes it easy to eat and you get all of the ingredients in one bite.

There's a variety of healthy juice/smoothie options, but I went for the Hipster smoothie of course...banana, chocolate syrup, NUTELLA, milk and graham; need I say more? This BLEW my mind and my taste buds. I would (and will) drive to West Chester just for this. 


Four stars overall because the service was cranky (but fast!), but the food and atmosphere are 5 stars for sure!

oh SNAP I love this pie!! For $8-10 you get an awesome, custom-made, fresh and filling pizza. Even on a busy night at 7 PM, I've never waited more than 15 minutes. These guys are efficient without sacrificing quality. If you're a thin crust person, Snap is for you!
May I suggest my all time favorite custom creation?
1. herb butter sauce (but their tomato is awesome too, very fresh!)
2. shredded mozz (AND fresh if you're feeling extra cheesy)
3. ricotta
4. artichokes and carmelized onions
5. lemon oil drizzle as the finishing touch
BOOM, PERFECTION. So refreshing and delicious.

The Gumbo Shop cycled in and out of my recent trip itinerary.  It has all the trappings of a tourist trap, including name and locale, yet a friend's whose taste buds I trust suggested giving it a try, so ultimately, we found ourselves one late evening at this French Quarter standby.

The dining room is large and filled with small tables, murals depicting historical scenes in muted mustard and sepia tones on most walls.  It is casual and unassuming.  There is courtyard dining but for the evening, we settled into a table in the bright dining room.  Wait staff were friendly and laid-back.  It was also very quiet on a mid-Sunday evening.

Gumbo, as with many other NOLA foods, is as varied as stars in the sky and unlike locals who probably have a personal favorite made at home, I have no baseline.  Belying their name, they appear to offer only two gumbos on their regular menu: seafood okra and chicken andouille.  The latter was better liked by the group, smooth and thin broth, salty with a spiced, layered flavor.  Seafood okra was thicker and slimy, courtesy of okra, with a pleasant enough if mild-mannered seafood flavor, but said seafood not much to be found, and where it was were unrecognizable bits.  The thick crawfish corn soup was filled with vegetables, decent enough but not especially memorable, as was a very ordinary side of smothered turnip greens.  My favorite was the crawfish etouffee; once past the size:price ratio of this very petite side order, it was one of my favorites, tasty with a very rich crawfish flavor, although no actual crawfish since the cup it was in doesn't fit much. 

With only a few gumbos tried in NOLA on two trips, I am of the opinion that I have more to try, although I like gumbo enough that I will continue to try new ones on future trips.  The Gumbo Shop seems like a decent, mid-tier choice for gumbo in the French Quarter if one isn't looking for a refined or innovative version, and very recommendable for the average tourist.  Doubtful for those with a specific gumbo preference.  Since they only serve two gumbos regularly, it should be noted that they offer a full menu of Creole food, with many classic dishes and sides.

This is my 3rd time here but I won't be back.  Yes the burgers are amazing. However, the restaurant is filthy and the cashiers are bored. Sticky floors, filthy toilets, stopped up sink. I get it the cashiers are young and probably students who would rather be anywhere else on a Saturday night, but I am paying for service. A smile wouldn't hurt for starters.

Dirty dishes and utensils. 

We went to brunch here last week (second time) for a party 8 to celebrate my son's birthday. Service was fine and the food was very good. However, the tables were dirty when they sat us and most, if not all of the dishes and utensils were not fully clean.

Not talking about streaks either, flat out old dry food stuck to them. One dish has crumbs all over it, like it was used already and not clean?
Obviously they have a faulty dishwasher, but the manager should be checking this. This place isn't cheap, you would expect better quality checks; our bill with tip was over $150. 

I emailed their corporate office for an explanation and sadly I still have not received an email or call. You would think a major business would care enough to follow-up on these things?

Won't be back...

"Y'all think you real fancy." That's what my neighbor says to her kids when they are putting on airs, and I'm saying it to Turkey and the Wolf. Let's break down why I'm hanging up a 2-star review for this new, chef-y hot spot:

- The space echoes too damn much. 

- I did not enjoy being part of the crowd here. Dude. This wasn't the service industry/eating from our buddies crowd that Turkey and the Wolf seems to want; it was the casual Uptown crowd that can afford to drop the money that they're charging for white-bread sandwiches. 

- Some of the details feel like they're trying too hard. Like some of the animals on sticks were just...obviously over-done. 

- But my biggest, grossest concern is this. The menu has a little paragraph about buying local and making stuff, but they also include this line: "...but we're also proud to serve the best of what we don't make, like american cheese and m and m's." Okay. You are naming that you serve American cheese. Got it. I'm down with that because I, too, eat American cheese. So we've got that vibe. Now, I walked up to the counter and ordered myself a ham and cheese sandwich ($11) and asked for it hot. The counter guy looked over his shoulder, got a nod from the kitchen, and turned back to me: "We don't recommend that." I'm sorry, what? You don't recommend a classic modification (a) because you are concerned about the purity of a sandwich that comes with canned cranberry sauce on it (b)? Nah. Y'all think you real fancy. And yeah, I got my hot ham sam. And yeah, it was DAMN GOOD. But I'm still pissy that a place that is proud of serving American cheese is too concerned about the purity of their food to make what the customer ordered. 

Goddamn. 

However, there were a few good things:

- The bar program is GREAT. 

- I am sorta fond of the vintage dinette tables they found to round out the space. 

- The food was good, despite my little pissing contest with the kitchen about their "purity." 

I'd probably go again, but I'd be grumpy about it. 

Accessibility notes: door opens out. Order at a medium counter. Bar is high. No Braille menu or signage. Can get loud at peak hours. Dining room is dim. Space for mobility devices between tables both inside and out. All indoor tables have chairs that can be removed for mobility devices.

Fine. Eating crow and upping the stars on this review. 

After a management change, an ownership change, and a complete staff turn-over, Avenue Cafe is looking up. Prices are now posted; the case of baked goods has expanded dramatically; and the tea selection is much wider. 

The customer base for Avenue Cafe is sort of weird, because it's in a really touristy area of St. Charles Ave (sorry, it's called the "hospitality corridor") that also has a huge residential population lurking just behind the hotels and restaurants. There is a parade of tourists looking peckish and/or under-caffeinated trickling in with confused looks and pristine athletic socks while social entrepreneur types (ya'll know what I'm talking about: snappy dressers with energy that's through the roof and the newest computer, smart phone, and headphones making 18 million contacts a day) hover quietly near outlets. The atmosphere is usually quietly jovial, although the afternoon/evening workers have much better taste in music. 

As long as cups of tea are large and plentiful, I'll keep popping around the corner for a little pick-me-up on boring days. 

Accessibility notes: Fully accessible for mobility devices. Door opens in. Low counter but high cases. No braille menu or signage. Not all prices are posted for hard-of-hearing customers.

Waaaaay overpriced for very average food quality and selection. On a positive note - service was great, the waitress was very attentive. However, we never came back after dining there our first night in despite the convenience.

Noise Noise Noise. The hotel is close to the airport and has a free shuttle. The lobby is clean and the staff is friendly. The rooms are older and if you can block out the noise from the hall and the airplanes it is ok. At least they keep a glass in the bathroom (sooooo many hotels don't). The curtains do a good job of blocking out the light. AC works well but is a bit noisy

We've been wanting to try this pizza for a very long time but living in Sparks doesn't make it convenient.  Turns out we haven't been missing anything.  My husband ordered 2 slices and I ordered 1 slice; he went with one sausage and one pep.  I had a pep.  My husband literally, and I mean literally, couldn't eat the sausage slice.  It was DISGUSTING.  The sausage has the most disgusting flavor I've ever come across.  He didn't eat much of the pep either as it was just saturated in grease.

Mine was MUCH better.  After I used countless napkins to degrease my pep slice, I actually enjoyed it to an extent.  The flavor of the sauce is quite good and I'm generally not a red sauce fan. The crust was bland and fairly tasteless.  

So needless to say, we'll never go back.

I used to come here about a year ago once a week with some friends and it used to be so well. Went and got the huge seafood platter which is a bunch of seafood and some fries. First of all, service was bad, waitress had a bad attitude and only started being polite when the food came. The seafood was not even seasoned, this is not traditional New Orleans sea food, I can tell when tourists start to come in, restaurants get full of themselves and start to get terrible like this one. Catfish was old also and it was the most thing on the plate, not enough shrimp, and some of the crab didn't even have any meat on it. I would not recommend for "traditional food" might as well go to a gas station for cheaper. PS service was even worse then the food surprisinly

To say I love this place might just be an understatement. Whenever I come to town, this place is one of my go to's and a place I always take someone unfamiliar with St. Louis. So, yea, it's good! It looks unassuming from the outside, but man do you get delicious drinks and mouth watering plates here

I can't live without the prime rib. Part of me actually thinks I need it to maintain breathing, or is it the rich risotto that keeps blood pumping through my veins? The risotto is rich, nicely seasoned and just begs you to eat more and more. And, when risotto asks nicely, who am I to argue?

Ok, so minor note, on my last visit, the prime rib wasn't fantastic. It was cooked to perfection, but the cut was just not as tender and succulent as it normally is. We came close to closing, so I think maybe this was just the one they had left? Or, more to say, I hope this is the case.  

Ask about the drink specials. They change, and you might find some random deliciousness. On my last visit, I got a bacon bloody mary that knocked my socks off. Our servers have always been incredible too. 

All in all, do I recommend this place? No surprise here: OF COURSE! I'd say to make this a must see on a trip to St. Louis.

Might have a cool vibe but that's it...  Coffee had just a hint of color to it?  Wondering if they put it through the pot twice.  Girls behind the counter kept bumping into each other.  Hot food sat at the window on more than one occasion while they were making coffee.  Wasn't busy at all and we kept waiting and waiting and waiting with no comment from our waitress about the wait.  $9.50 for a messy scramble that was luke- warm at best.  Sorry Café Deluxe....not for us.

I've had a really great time here on multiple different occasions, but somehow for me, it's never been a favorite brunch spot in and of itself. 

Cafe Lift has its own chill feel with an industrial interior, but I'm personally less of a fan of the whole vibe because it just feels a bit cold and stiff given their metal chairs, exterior pipes, plastic water jugs, grey/red color palate, etc. Their tables are also kind of fastened to the ground in rows in a factory-like and rigid manner that makes me feel a bit cramped, even though it's not like a particularly small space. 

Service is pretty good overall, and food isn't bad but I also haven't been wowed. For example, on my most recent visit, I ordered their egg mushroom toast but there were so few mushrooms that it felt like I was just eating egg toast. Also, I've had their famous lemon ricotta pancakes in the past, but in my opinion, those pancakes were too mushy and flat. I know others love how "moist" it is, but I think it tastes far too soggy for my ideal pancake. To date, it is still cash only as well. 

I feel like I must be missing something because quite a few other people I know seem to love it, so take it as you will!
My family and I are absolutely hooked on this place, it's probably my favorite burger joint at the moment. I have not had a bad meal here. Even the hotdogs are good

The eL Venezuelo food truck has started up a brick and mortar restaurant. If you've ever had genuine Venezuelan food then you already know! If you have not/ come on by and try one of the many many different items on the menu. You honestly can't go wrong with anything that they serve! They're located in the old Starbucks at 96th and Allisonville across from the Shell gas station.  Enjoy your arepas!
Great food, quick and well made. Great price. Try their super Nachos!

I actually liked this place even though all I had was Nachos. The drinks were definitely good, must try the jalapeno margarita. I liked the atmosphere and our server was absolutely adorable. He made sure we had drinks and food at all times. They also have good desserts. I have visited their location Downtown Boise and was not extremely crazy for the food, didn't think the price was worth to be honest. It was not fair to rate them lower since I didn't really have food. My reviews are based on the appetizers, dessert, drinks and service.

Dear Fast Eddie's,

I hate you.

Love Nicole


Explanation:
Two of my friends and I made a day trip to the other side of the river in late summer and in that trip we found ourselves in Alton.  We were starving so I called a friends that was from there and asked him where we should go to eat and he told me to go to Fast Eddie's.  Since then I have put much thought into weather said friend actually likes me because he sent me here.  First off you have to be 21 or older to get in, we are all over the age of 21 but that should have been the signal to not go any further.  We realized that we had to go to the back to order our food which was no big deal. We order the food and went to sit down and then were told by our waitress that we had to order drinks if we wanted to stay, those where her exact words.  We all ordered something, but were really off put by her attitude since we had ordered food.  We got our drinks and waited... and waited... and waited for our food.  We got a burger, a pork skewer and some fries and it took 30 minutes for us to get them!  It was four o'clock in the afternoon on a Thursday, isn't this place called FAST Eddies???  When we finally got our food it was alright, it was very cheap and we defiantly got what we paid for.  Every time our waitress came over to us she made it seem like we were wasting her time because we only needed one drink a piece.  All in all maybe this place in only a bar and my friend is just horrible at giving recommendations for places to eat.  Maybe some day I will go there to drink, but I know of better place that aren't 40 minutes away.

FINALLY got the chance to eat here the other weekend. Usually when I go, there's at least an hour late but this time I went on a Saturday morning. After about a 30 minute wait, we were seated at the bar. We placed our orders per our servers suggestions and enjoyed all of it! It took our food a bit long to come out so I ended up ordering a cronut to tide me over (pretty good!) but all the waiting was worth it in the end. If you're trying to get a table, I wouldn't suggest Sundays. I was once estimated about a 2 hour wait. I'd love to go back and try more on the menu.

My one gripe with Korean food is all those red chili flakes. I don't do spicy food well, and Korean food is normally go big or go home with respect to its heat level. So to whoever at Sammy Chon's had the foresight to allow you to adjust the level of spice, thank you for sparing me my normal sweaty/runny nose Korean food experience.  For this you earn 5 stars. 

We enjoyed the haemool pajun as an appetizer, your classically delicious scallion pancake with the added bonus of seafood. Definitely recommend this. Of the ban chan we had, I enjoyed the eggplant the most, but appreciated the fresh cucumber kimchee. 

As entrees, we had the spicy pork bulgogi, the meat was well flavored and well cooked without being overcooked. I ordered the seafood Soon Dubu, as it was cold outside and seemed like stew weather. The silken tofu had a great texture, and the broth had a rich flavor with just enough seafood.

A little pricey but absolutely worth it considering the love and care that goes into their craft. Picked up some spicy salami and fresh mozzarella to make pizza at home tonight. Their mozzarella has an amazing, slightly chewy consistency and a nice bit of saltiness to it. Salami packs the right amount of punch. I might be in love.

Yo dude WTF is up with this shrimp cocktail - you gotta either peel the shrimp or not peel the shrimp.  I don't like playing this "which abdominal segment is going to be covered in plastic-y hard stuff" game.

PS - I love you, really, though.

Decent place in Chinatown section of Philly that I am glad I checked out. The place is huge and the bar is very long. They have a decent amount of draft beers, so you're bound to find something. The food was decent; I had a spicy chicken sandwich and it was good, but not to spicy. Service was passable, but you had to make an effort to flag the bartender. This is still a cool place to get some food and booze.

Finally had a chance to go here with a few people after hearing about this place, and I was very satisfied. The bar has a very lax atmosphere and was a very large space. The waitress was real nice and attentive to our group, so service was great.  The draft list was a decent selection if craft brews. I also decided to get food, and I was happy I did. The burger was juicy and was even better with goat cheese as well as jalapenos. I will like to come back here for some food and drink when around the area.

So I am not a real fan of Japanese Steakhouses such as these because I am not a fan of pasta and rice; however, I went to try this one. Now I haven't been to a restaurant like this in over 10 years, so I don't quite remember the set up etc. This was my first time going to a Kobe so I thought this would be different than what I did remember from my last visit to Benihana's. Ok, let's get into the review. 

First Impressions/Appearance:  So when you walk in, the restaurant is very dry and doesn't give you anything to awe at. There is no real pop of red or anything to make this restaurant stand out from any other typical restaurant. The tables are very dark in color, which I typically don't mind but again it was very dry and dull. They seat you at 10 to a table which again I didn't mind, but it is very close and a bit uncomfortable when you're trying to enjoy dinner. 

Customer Service: I am big on customer service and theirs was on point. Their customer service was great. We were seated immediately and the wait staff was great and attentive. Our drinks were filled and they cleared our soup and salad bowls in time so we had more space at the small tables. At the end of our meal, there was another lady that came out to box up our left overs which she did in front of us so that gets an extra star from me. 

The Dinner Show:  our chef was very entertaining. He did all of the tricks, the 'egg roll', flipping the egg in his hat and flipping the shrimp tail in his shirt pocket. That was cool and so was the volcano and making the fire shoot out and up. He cracked jokes and made fun of all the latest commercials playing on the radio. He cooked the vegetables with such precision and made the noodles and rice with so much action. I don't remember noodles and rice being that entertaining, but he made them a real show. His knife techniques were astonishing and the cut of the meat and chicken all the same size. 

The Food:  the soup was ok and full of flavor. It was served hot which was good on a cold night. The salad was fresh and the ginger dressing was delicious, I really could have used more salad. The vegetables were cooked first. We had onions, zucchini, carrots, broccoli, and green beans. I think they were undercooked but I think most people like their veggies a bit more crispy. The onions were very pungent and could have been cooked a little longer along with the carrots and beans. Next came the noodles. Now as o stated earlier, I am not a pasta fan but I do cook it for my family. These noodles were under seasoned and overlooked. They could have used some salt and pepper and should have been a little less than al dente. That way, it can finish cooking on the grill. The rice was next, and it was not cooked, so when the chef went to fry it, it didn't steam enough, so we ended up with hard rice that was greasy and had no flavor. Lastly were the meats. The meat had good flavor and it was cooked well. I had the chicken and steak and both were prepared how I liked. The steak also came with potatoes, which surprisingly were pretty good. 

Rating: So why 3 stars? Simply put, the food could have been better and the establishment could have been nicer.
