I can spend the same amount and maybe a few dollars more on more food and much better food. I know the idea is a dinner and a show, but I think they need to work on their food more since they have the show down. I don't think I will be going back but glad I decided to give it a try since I have never been and now I have a platform to let others know what to expect.

I stopped in here for an informal business meeting and a drink with a good friend/potential business partner. You can tell that this is a place locals frequent. I mean, it's not in the touristy areas of Reno and it looked like university students hung around here too. I liked the fire pit outside.

Bottom line is for a uniquely Reno bar/restaurant away from the bustle of downtown, Sierra Gold is a great choice.

Royal India is now my favorite Indian Restaurant in the Reno-Sparks area. While there are other Indian Restaurants in the Reno-Sparks area with good food, they lack good customer service skills. 

The servers at Royal India were prompt, friendly and knowledgeable. They really made the effort to provide good service and seemed keen on making certain that we enjoyed our experience in the restaurant. 

My friend and I spilt several types of Naan Bread - a potato one (I wasn't totally crazy about, but my friend liked) and a very good Cheese Naan. Light, fluffy warm Naan interlaced with gooey cheese - just can't beat it!  My favorite sauce was their Cilantro Chutney - it was very different from normal sauces served at Indian Restaurants, but so light and refreshing with a little zig of spicy flavors. 

I ordered the Chickpea and Potato Curry (Extra Spicy of course) and a Mango Mojito. The Mango Mojito was a basic Mango Mojito, nothing spectacularly unique, but nothing awry - light, refreshing, tasty, sweet mixed drink. I'd order it again. The Chickpea and Potato Curry on the other hand was amazing! I always get annoyed when I order 'super spicy' and get a bland dish because the restaurant was too timid to listen to me - it is always insulting and always a disappointment.  The resulting dish had that warming spiciness that increased in heat with each bite and made your whole throat bask in the heat of spicy goodness! Oh yeah! Let it burn! Let it burn! The potatoes in the dish had been cooked perfectly and the chickpea ratio was generous. I would order this dish again in a heartbeat.  Their complimentary rice was super light and fluffy. 

Other details: Their prices were fair. The restaurant decor was nice and it was clean. Lastly, they have a large Vegetarian / Vegan Section, enough to keep me going back for months with a new dish each time.

Highly recommend!

Basically, everything you need in a dive bar. We were in Nashville for a wedding and decided to come here after the reception was over because who doesn't love late night burgers and beer after hours of dancing! The line for food/drinks was kind of long, but it was fine. The cheese burger was freakin' delicious. It was really greasy and probably 1000+ calories, but totally worth it. Good times, great oldies - y'all!

Stopped by here on a random Thursday night, we moved into the area a little over a month ago and have been meaning to check this place out. It definitely lives up to the hype food wise. The HH specials are pretty good and I would recommend that you go in around then so that you can take advantage of them. Basically they do deals on nachos, drafts, and margaritas, not too shabby. We started off with the guacamole which was actually a good size portion for 2 people and the chips were sturdy enough to be dragged through it. Everything was extremely fresh and it made a difference. For dinner we did a few chicken tacos, a shrimp taco, and a fish burrito. The tortillas here are legit and they hold up while you are eating the tacos/burritos which is really important in my opinion. Everything was great, no complaints at all. The service was good and our service was very friendly. I would recommend this place to anyone looking for some really good cheap Mexican. 2 of us tried our hardest left stuff with a bill around $40.

Great addition to the area, love going to Pizzeria Vetri and it's good to know that I now have the option to go here. So the deal is this is a really good fast casual taco place. They have about 9 different kinds of tacos and there are ones that you can get either grilled or fried. They have some good apps in the guacamole and they have Boylan's soda in the fountain machine which is amazing. If you sign up for their rewards program you get $10 off the next time you go in, which for me will be very soon. So we went on a Thursday night and got some guacamole and an assortment of tacos, chicken, shrimp, and all the different types of fish they had that day. Everything was grilled except for the house fish of the day (which was perch) I got one taco with it grilled and one with it fried to do a comparison. All the tacos were good, the shrimp tacos were awesome and there was a good amount of shrimp in each. I like the breading that they use to fry the fish and it isn't greasy but I think that I just still prefer to have everything grilled. All in all a great first experience and I am looking forward to the next one.

Yiro Yiro is the brand new Gyro spot in Roxborough.  Coming to Philly from Vienna, I was missing my Durum sandwiches and a gyro was as close as I was going to get.  Happily to report, this gyro with spicy tzatziki is a quality one....although what was spicy about the tzatziki remains a mystery.  It's more expensive than what I would pay in Vienna but in-line with Philly prices.  Adding on sides would make for a more substantial meal and can be done for only 2 more dollars.  Next time!

Hey I have a confession to make.  I'm done with so-called gourmet or upscale Grilled Cheese establishments.  Milk House, a new grilled cheese place in Center City Philly near Rittenhouse Square, was my latest attempt to like one of these places.  But here's the deal in my opinion.  The grilled cheese sandwiches and tomato soup served here don't really taste any better than those served at a diner or luncheonette.  They just cost a lot more and it's not worth it.  Maybe they use a supposedly better bread ... yes they have different things that can be grilled inside the sandwich .... at an added price of course.  But my guess is these places will ultimately never succeed because who wants to pay the same price for a grilled cheese sandwich as for a hoagie or cheesesteak and not even be filled up.  Everything was decent here ... the quality of the grilled cheese was fine.  But it would have been nice if they had salt and pepper available in case someone likes to add them.  I def like to put pepper in the tomato soup but there was none available and they couldn't find any in the kitchen.  Whatever.....

Restaurant Catracho is a hole-in-the-wall eatery right on the edge of Center City Philly. While it serves some Mexican dishes this is def an Honduran restaurant - hence the name.  I was surprised to find out many of my friends didn't realize that Catracho is a name for someone from Honduras.  It is not perjorative at all - no "bad hombres" connotation as one American leader once sadly called them.

Well when you think of Honduran food of course first comes to mind are 'Baleadas.' These thick flour tortillas folded over eggs, cheese, and meats like chicken or chorizo are indeed a tasty treat.  I odered two roasted chicken & chorizo baleadas here and enjoyed these filling concoctions very much.  You can eat-in here (minimal atmosphere) but most of their business is takeout. Cool that now tasty baleadas are to be found within easy reach of Center City!

It's hard to not find Clarkville with its large lettering on the side of its building.  I was walking by recently and also took note of the $2 a slice of pizza during lunch hours.  It's hard to rate an establishment on just a couple of different slices of pizza but for my experience Clarkville comes right down as average.  The pizzas were okay - tried the plain and the pepperoni.  Crust was a bit chewy if you like it that way.  Toppings are extra as one might expect.  The space looks fine although it was on the dark side when I was there as the lights were not turned on - I was the only customer. I'm hoping Clarkville shows more life and flair at dinnertime.

Tavern on the Hill (formerly Hill Tavern) has transformed itself over the years from an everyday drinking bar to more of a gastro-pub atmosphere.  Indeed its warm back dining room is replete with  a fireplace and the woody front bar looks more clubby than dive.  An appeal to a wider clientele has resulted and now this spot is a quite popular dining venue.  There's even music on Friday evenings.

The food to me however is more often only average or just a little bit above. I recently had the French onion soup which was tasty enough but def not hot enough.  The green salad with bleu cheese dressing was standard which was fine.  My main course was a beef & cheese sandwich that was decidedly not something memorable or I would order again.  Where was the cheese? The sweet potato fries lacked crispness and appeared to just have been heated up.  My friend however reported very much enjoying his filet mignon dinner.
Side note - there were no condiments on the table including no salt or pepper and I gave up trying to flag down our busy waitress to get some pepper or hot sauce.

Despite all this, I actually like the Tavern on the Hill because of its atmosphere and location.  Staff are welcoming  as well. And they def have some good beer choices!

The latest vegan (and supposedly more casual) eatery from the owners of Vedge is V Street in the Rittenhouse neighborhood. V Street is smaller in size than Vedge but in so many ways it seems like a fraternal twin...which is both good and not so good.  The food is excellent just like at Vedge.  I sat at the bar to try some of their bar food.  The carrots asado were tasty and the langos with smoked beets (which is the main reason I stopped by here) was also very well-made.  However both dishes are small and pricey just like at Vedge as well - the Langos is probably a quarter of the size one receives in Vienna or Budapest and is more than twice the price at nine dollars. (I guess beets are expensive!)  The five delicious carrots are eight dollars. When you add in a drink, you are over thirty dollars with tax and tip and you have only really had appetizers so you still have to eat a dinner. The bar service was okay but couldn't answer a question I had on one of the wine choices ... and they also left the candle directly in front of me unlit (it actually needed replacement) the whole time I was there.  It's a really small detail but at these prices, I guess I expected it to be lighted like the other candles at the bar.

Again, the food is very good here...I just need an expense account.  I look forward to entrepreneurs who can someday do vegan food this good for those of us on student or artist incomes!

Primo's is a well known Philly Hoagie chain.  I like Philly hoagies as much as the next guy but this week they were offering a special on their meatball sandwiches which I wanted to try.  I actually thought it was going to be a Meatball Hoagie but to be honest it was just a meatball sandwich without all the hoagie accoutrements.  No prob.  I just took it home and added lettuce and tomato and onions and peppers etc.  Anyway I like Primo's and the sandwich was good .... and the staff at the very attractive Chestnut Hill Primo's was as friendly as they always are!

I thought this looked authentic and amazing. I was wrong I ordered the #1 taco and enchilada I was less than impressed that my taco was dripping in red sauce how to pick it up and eat? The taco was also dry and had zero flavor I added hot sauce didn't do anything for it. My enchilada was tough and the cheese wasn't even melted...not gooey and yummy so for $9 with tip not at all worthwhile. 
Skip this place there are to many options out there.

First time in Philly and came straight here. I have always wanted to get a real philly cheese steak from Philly and let me just say this was by far the best philly I have ever had. I live in D.C. and we get a lot of food trucks who make "philly's" but they are nowhere near as good as this place. The only complaint is that they are a little small, so if you plan on eating there, you may have to wait for a table to open up to be able to sit down and eat. We were lucky enough to grab one and be able to sit down and enjoy it. The owner of this place was an absolutely hoot. He made some funny jokes to my husband about the amount of food we ordered and just made our first experience here a good one. We don't live in Philly, but whenever we go back, we will come here. I just hope they end up making their facility a bit bigger so there are more options to come in and sit down.
Really wish happy hour was left till 7! Will visit Stonewood now... 6 is a little early!

I've been here a few times. The food is good. I can recommend it to others. The service is excellent. But I have never found anything on the menu that they do better than anyone else.
For my last visit I got the spicy lunch burrito with beef. It had some nice tang. The best touch were the grilled onions. But it wasn't an especially good burrito. The chips and salsa were average. 
The other menu choices were limited. You can't order just a taco on the side, for instance. And they don't offer tamales. No jamaica either.

Please do not let the three stars fool you, the food was delicious and the wait staff was friendly. My review comes from the $$ price range thinking it would be only mildly pricier and then getting a sticker shock from the menu. I am thankful I came here at a time when I wasn't feeling particularly ravenous because the portion sizes in relation to the dollars are not worth it to me.

I am not a fine dining connoisseur, so maybe there is worth for Those Who Don't Mind Spending Their Dollars This Way, but as an Average Joe, I can't see myself coming back for anything less than a really special occasion...which frustrates me because so many things looked so good.

The egg rolls here are the best (and reasonably priced) but do not come if you are very hungry. The main course always takes longer to arrive than you might think, and this was a problem with me on more than one occasion.
Good neighborhood place.  Food and drinks are not amazing but are solid. Wings are good but I expected more from the Keilbasa cheesesteak, it was just okay.  Vibe and service are on point.

Burger Up was just OK. The burger did have the taste of good quality but lacked or had minimal seasoning. I don't know what size they serve but the bun overwhelmed the burger. The fries were served at room temp and were disappointing for being house-cut. The burger was not worth the $12 they charged.

Still one of my favorite breakfast spots.  Hot tea in big metal mugs, MAMMOTH biscuits with the butter on the table, macaroni and cheese that somehow still goes great with whatever you ordered for breakfast.  Come with cash, and be prepared for a wait.  It IS, however, worth the wait!

My sister and I returned tonight to give Sullivan's another go round, and we were so glad we had.  Our food was excellent as usual.  My sister loved her crab stuffed salmon and as always my filet was cooked to perfection.  What returned was the stellar service that I knew was the standard for  this restaurant.  Erin was fabulous!   We were able to enjoy each of our courses without feeling rushed. Our drinks were replenished without intrusion and her interaction with us was easy, friendly and genuine.  Thanks Sullivan's!!

Food was pretty good. But I really am annoyed by the fact that on "game nights" they do not adhere to their specials menu. All restaurants downtown still do specials on these nights; even the hole in the walls. I wasn't here for a game... and it was apparently mid game when we went. Do you really need to make that much more money?! Is your customer service worth it ??? To me that's ridiculous. No thanks. Will not come back.

Hate to do this. But if you want to last - the food needs to be stepped up a notch. The service and management staff were amazing. 

We had just been to tastings and had a meat / cheese tray a couple hours prior. So we did not start with an app. 

Husband got a Caesar salad. To me - it was extremely fishy tasting. I love anchovies - but every bite tasted like fish. 

The bread was hard and wasn't flavorful. When do you ever say that about bread? Or stop at just one? The olive oil dipping mixture was so so. 

Meal - we both ordered the filet. Loaded baked potato for the side. We typically wouldn't order a baked potato, but sounded good. Filets were perfect. Not overly seasoned. Cooked perfectly. Great flavor. The potato was cold. And the sides are odd. I know with there being a million steak houses you have to stick out. But if you're going to put sides on the side, put them all on the side. Butter was on the potato. And then the bacon and some mixture with  chives was in the side. Both were not tasty. The bacon i believe was smoked but tasted like bacon bits. Yuck. The chive mixture also was not good. The baked potato presentation by itself was nice. And the size was perfect. But again was cold. They brought another. This time no butter at all. With the same sides. I suggest different sides. More appealing presentation of them also. 

They were absolutely so very nice and offered us dessert. The molten cake with vanilla gelato was delicious. 

Our wine was delicious. But can't really mess that up ;)

Overall I wouldn't go back.  If it was for the staff / management only i would. But the food was nothing to talk about or worth the price.

As one of the newest dining options in the Spanish Springs area, Chin Chin Restaurant has an uphill climb. The decor is more polished than most strip-mall restaurants, lending an ambiance that says "date night" more than "bring the kids". They offer delivery service which might help them compete with numerous Asian options in the area, and their mix of Chinese, Thai and Hibachi dishes makes for interesting options.

After being seated, a serving of fried wonton strips was served with (canned) sweet and sour sauce and Chinese hot mustard. The hostess was friendly but we had a pretty severe communication gap with our server. Thankfully, the hostess came back and sorted things out.

My wife and I chose Combination Dinner C (for two or more, $15.99 per person). The meal is served with a choice of entree from a list of eleven options, steamed or fried rice, and one of several soups. The included appetizer plate featured two pieces each of crab rangoon, fried prawns, beef sticks and vegetable egg rolls.

My wife said her hot and sour soup was lacking in vinegar, I felt it needed more heat. My order of wonton soup was better, nothing special but acceptable. The appetizers were pretty good. The beef sticks were skewers of marinated, tender flank steak served with teriyaki sauce. Butterflied prawns were breaded and crispy, as were fried triangles of wonton wrapper and cheese. Unfortunately, the vegetables inside the egg rolls were undercooked and stringy, making it nearly impossible to bite through without leaving the contents all over the plate.

My wife's Hibachi Triple Delight entree was quite good, with a mix of veggies, chicken and scallop in a savory,  slightly-spicy sauce. The veggies were cooked with with just a bit of crunch, no complaints about the meat. Quite tender and tasty.

My choice of Black Pepper Delicacy was less successful. A shallow dish of diced bell pepper and onion in a dark gravy comprised the "black pepper sauce", perhaps so-named for its color. I certainly couldn't detect any peppercorn in this condiment served with battered shrimp, scallops, and "crab" (obviously surimi, aka, krab-with-a-K). The batter was similar to tempura, though lacking in crunch or flavor. I dunked the first couple pieces in gravy trying to appreciate it as-is, but eventually gave up and freed the seafood from its dense, spongy cocoon. Though I don't mind surimi per se, I'd really love it if all restaurants--I'm looking at you, AYCE sushi--would identify it as such instead of calling it crab. The surimi had become one with the batter, so that was that.

Our dining companions chose to order single entrees, which meant I got to try a couple more entrees. A dish of Singapore rice noodles was agreed to be everyone's favorite ($9.99), a bed of thin vermicelli supporting chicken, shrimp, bean sprouts, onion, and scallion in a spicy curry sauce redolent of Chinese Five Spice blend. An order of teriyaki New York strip steak rounded out the meal with chunks of medium rare beef and al dente veggies ($15.99).

Though our overall meal was pleasant, there were service snafus throughout. The wrong soup was delivered (then replaced) and everyone's entree arrived with considerable time gaps in between. Last to the table was a mistake plate of some chicken dish rather than the steak, so more time was lost waiting for its replacement. When the correct plate finally arrived the vegetables were nice and hot, but the beef was barely warm. There were plenty of good flavors to be enjoyed, but the staff have a lot to learn about timing. My order of hot sake ($5.99, lg) didn't arrive until after the appetizers and one of the entrees. Chin Chin has only been open a few weeks, so hopefully it'll find its path up that hill.

Not sure why the reviews are so high, maybe I went on an off night but there was nothing memorable about my experience. Lava rock is a good idea as long as the offerings are either filling or priced accordingly...not the case for the scallops or the filet. Goat cheese flat bread was just okay, still hungry we order their $15 cheese plate which we were told was filling. What was served was the most scarce and pathetic platter, it was promptly returned. I also found the server to be short and unfriendly.

Underwhelming, from the decor, service, and especially the food, everything is just blah, and over priced. I just don't think with all the interesting dining options out there that Malio's can compete. They need to revamp their menu and lower their prices.

Great food!  Love the salad bar.  The day I went was a little hectic being right after Christmas.  So the dining area was a bit dirty and looked like a tornado of people had been through it.  I will definitely go back to try some sandwiches!

I have to admit that I have NEVER had Indian food so I thought "hey why don't I stop in here for lunch?".  I was having a lonely lunch alone but the atmosphere was inviting, there was a Tv and the staff was very friendly.   I got a chilli chicken as a wrap.  I love how the wrap shell seemed like it was thin naan bread and was lightly toasted on a flat top.  I wanted an iced tea to drink, which they have over by the soda.  And to my surprise after I drank it, I think it was a chai tea but it was sooooo delicious!  I didn't know that's what I wanted, but it was and paired perfectly with the flavors from my food.  Everything is made fresh to order.  I watched them making blended beverages for others and they were so vibrantly colored and looked delicious.  I plan to go back to continue expanding my indian food palate.  It's located on Main Street in Carmel but more towards 31.  You can't see it from 31, but if you see "wild eggs" it's in that strip of businesses.

I gotta tell you the quality of meats they use is rather poor. The service is exceptional though. Went back here this past weekend. The salad bar got chintzier. Slim pickens! Their Sangria has gone downhill and really expensive! Yeah it's nice to get unlimited meat but you will pay a lot for it. You are better off going to a nice Steakhouse and getting an excellent steak for the price they charge you. Nearly $80 a head for a couple of drinks and food. Not worth it. Very disappointed. I prefer staying in Jersey and going to Newark!

We were pretty excited to try this place so when it opened we headed for breakfast. I got the eggs Benedict, someone else got a mushroom Swiss burger with an egg on top and a side of corned beef hash and the third person got a bowl of fruit.
Wait time was minimal. Friendly and well organized staff. Our bill totaled around $40 with tip and each of us thought it was nothing spectacular. 
Heard they are along the coast. Someone in our party recommends more vegan selections. 
Someone else felt the music/ restaurant was too loud.

Fancy attempt at Mexican food

The chips are crisp and the salsa is chunky. I would describe the salsa on the roasted tomato side, it looks kind of dark. I did not care for it much, but I am picky about Mexican.

The guacamole was fresh and not overpowering. I think it was a bit less doctored up then I prefer but it was still good.

The carne asada tacos lunch special I ordered was skimpy. The large plate arrived with two small flour tortillas with a little bit of Carne Asada chunks on each one. The plate also included a cabbage and pepper garnish as well as a bowl that had half black beans and half Spanish rice in it. The beans/rice tasted fresh but very boring, would not order on purpose.

They sell a starter which is a quesadilla with chorizo and potato in it and those are very tasty, but the portions are small.

The waitress was good and the service prompt. 

I could see how some people would really dig this place but it was just OK for me. If I am going to spend 20 bucks on mexican I would expect some beers with it, not an ice tea.

Miel.  I believe it's French for 'go to Hattie B's instead.'
The service was bad, but we were there for a party.  So, okay?  I'll let it pass, waiter I always had to remind twice that I asked for a drink.  Sigh.
But the food??? Ha!  
Sorry.  I've eaten French cuisine.  I've even dated a chef that has a restaurant in New Orleans that studied in France.  He would never go for this 'art food'.

I ordered the tortellini.  Ha!!???  Not only is it not tortellini.  It's ravioli.  And you get ONE.  ONE ravioli.  I came to that dinner hungry. You should've seen my face when they put the one piece of $26 pasta in front of me.  I bet I looked like Oliver, "Please sir, may I have some more?"  

And then I realized my error.  WTF is pasta doing on the menu at a French restaurant?

I guess that was my fault.

Well, my husband had the salmon.  Miel must also mean, "bland by design."  I've made salmon at HOME that had more personality than that thing.

To wrap it up, apparently Miel means 'honey' in French.  They just left of the rest: Honey better a eat a real meal before you come here because this is all art food.  Blech.
Didn't think the burgers were anything special and they were definitely on the pricey side. It's one of those place that you go to once in your lifetime and you don't really ever need to go back.

I went to this Bertucci's location recently for a family member's birthday.  

The bread came out warm, and the waitress was happy to bring me some butter to go along with it.  (Am I the only person alive who thinks olive oil is NOT the best way to dress my bread?)  

For apps, we ordered the Three Cheese Focaccia and the Tomato Bruschetta.  The Focaccia was basically a quesadilla with marinara, but good nonetheless, and the bruschetta tasted super fresh and yummy.  

Of the 6 of us, only my boyfriend ordered something other than pizza.  His Baked Tortellini and Chicken Gratinati came out bubbly hot, and judging by the fact that he used a piece of bread to sop up the sauce at the bottom of an empty dish, I'd say he liked it.

As for the pizzas, we ordered the Portofino, the Tucci, The Ultimate Bertucci (dun dun duuuuuuunnnnnnn!!!), and the Pucillo.  Check the website for toppings on those and others; there really is something for everyone.

I wouldn't consider myself a pizza snob.  I'll eat real pizza joint pizza, franchise pizza and even frozen pizza without having my arm twisted.  But I have to say, something about the irregular shape of the crust and the little bit of brick oven char on the Bertucci's pizzas does it for me every time.

Sad review. Stopped in on a business call and thought while here I would get a bite to eat. The young girl behind the counter was curt and rude ( I'm a senior and believe in manners). Needless to say I quickly changed my mind about giving them my business. We need some employee education in my opinion.

When we went to Firebirds for lunch, the place was almost full but we were were seated within minutes of our arrival. Quick as a wink, our server, Jennifer, appeared, to bring us our water,  take our orders then bring a little loaf of delicious Panella bread.

I ordered the cheeseburger and their cider slaw. Firebirds uses a Brioche bread rather than potato bread, but Brioche is what's commonly found.The meat could have not have been cooked any better. Those who dislike slaw are in for a surprise when they try Firebird's cider slaw. It's really good.

The price of my cheeseburger was a little high for most cheeseburgers, but was very reasonable for the one I had for lunch. Considering everything- food, service and price- Firebirds Grill rates an easy 4 stars.
This place needs to learn how to properly make an edible chicken wing.  They overcook them to the point that they are dry and hard as rocks. Can it really be that difficult?

This place was filled with snooty hipsters. The bartender was rude and inattentive and treated me and the person I was with like we were an afterthought. The only thing that was good was the baked beans.

I was here around lunch on a weekday, and the place was deafening. Ordered a salmon bagel sandwich, and it took about half an hour - and then it wasn't even assembled! I ordered it to go, so their theory was probably that it would get soggy - but come on. I paid twelve dollars for them to toast me a bagel and throw some smoked salmon in there. It was really good, though. I can't tell a lie.

We love Green Fork! They have a wide selection that will make everyone happy, from vegans to omnivores. Almost every menu item has vegan and gluten free options. I'm neither, but I usually get the tofu wrap or the quinoa scramble - they put this green dressing on both of them that I'm addicted to. Their pancakes are also phenomenal. I would say they need to work on their service, as it is very slow, but it's a lovely little place with a friendly neighborhood vibe.

I was looking for new places to go to brunch in my area and came across this place on Yelp. The reviews, menu and pictures look good so I decided to give it a shot. There was an art festival going on in the street outside when I visited so there was considerably more foot traffic than normal. We were still able to get a table within minutes of arriving at noon on a Saturday. The space is pretty small but welcoming. The service was veryyyy slow. We had to flag the waitress over to take our order then once she put it in it took about 30 minutes until we were served. Another table ordered right before us and it took them just as long to get their food so it seems like it's just the way the kitchen runs. We had the Greek Brekky & pancakes. The food was good but not exceptional. I enjoyed the tater tots the most. They were perfectly crispy. My eggs had no flair and didn't seem to have any cheese although it was supposed to come with feta. The pancakes were average. I wasn't terribly impressed by this place but it wasn't horrible...

I've been to Smashburger a couple times and seems like it's pretty consistent.  The only time I go crazy for burgers is in these types of burger joints or if a restaurant is really well known for them.  It's got a lot of varieties for burgers and lets you build your own, which is always cool for those who like to get creative.  For review purposes I stuck with the Classic Smash-- pretty standard burger and cheese with lettuce, tomato, and onion with ketchup and pickles.  All in all it's a decent burger, but I wasn't blown away by it.  The burger tasted like a more fresh version of Burger King.  As for the fries, they need to step their game up.  There was nothing exciting about these fries.  There was no seasoning besides salt and they were barely bigger than the width of a toothpick.  I loathe skinny fries!  If you're looking for a great burger in this area, I'd hit up Five Guys which is on the opposite side of the mall.

I was looking for a late dinner, a concept that is not very big in Tucson. Not many places are open late (until 2am on Saturdays) so at least Sushi Garden has that going for them. 

I was greeted by a very strong smell of Clorox that pretty much foreshadowed the meal that followed. I won't mince words the sushi wasn't good. I was craving  a fried roll so I ordered a Vegas roll and the roll tasted as it had been fried way before I ordered it. The batter was also very thin and didn't add much to the taste, which defeats the whole purpose of a fried roll. Even worse, the roll had a strong fishy smell. So gross. The two other rolls we had throughout the evening were just okay. 

Thinking that maybe the food would be better, we tried the chicken skewers. I was dead wrong. The chicken was so rubbery and had a very strange gamey taste. 

It's also annoying that their drink specials are more expensive that full-price drinks elsewhere. They do have 2 dollar sake which is nice.

It's a pet peeve of mine when a restaurant spends too much on interiors while ignoring the food quality. Sushi Garden falls under this category. Sushi Garden could benefit from focusing on their food rather than ritzy interiors. They are, after all, a food establishment.

This is our favorite Mexican Restaurant.  It always brings my husband and I to our fun vacations to Cancun, Mexico.  Their new decoration is so much better than their old X-Files theme.  The service is always excellent.  Never ending refills of beverages and salsa.  Ayayay, Miguel!

Favorites:

~Strawberry Margaritas.
~Chile Relleno.
~Carne Asada (Husband loves it.)
~Sopa Pilla (Warm sweet bread as dessert.)

Tips:

~They do NOT accept American Express. :-( 
~Gets busy on weekends and during dinner time.
~Get there early if you want a table by the window.
~Parking is not ideal.  Their parking is behind the restaurant without ample lighting and you have to go through an alley.  We usually park by the bank where all of the commercial buildings are located.  It is next to the restaurant.  It is a much safer.

Yes, still five stars for this place! Husband and I went there last night.  It was an excellent experience. Lovely presentation of entrees.

Favorites:

~ Waiter, Michael.
~Gulf Shrimp Cocktail (Five Huge Prawns) $12
~ Los Cabos Shrimp Scampi (Spicy. Husband loves it.) $23
~ Jumbo Prawns and Scallops Thermidor (Really Creamy Sauce) $24


Tips:

~Coconut prawns is no longer on their menu.
~They do NOT accept American Express. :-(
~No more table coffee peculator preparation.
~You have to go through their smoky casino to get to this restaurant.
~ It is fine dining but casual attire is acceptable.

My wife did take out here for the lunch special because I had to work.  My wife ordered the pepper steak and salt and pepper pork chop. I know we ordered something else, but I forgot what it was good.  Overall, they gave us a lot food for the price and filled me up.  Honey walnut shrimp was good and well as the salt and pepper shrimp. I would come back here for lunch.

We went here when it was packed so our wait time was 40 minutes.  Overall it was a great experience.  I order the dungeness crab salad which was awesome. They give you quite a bit, plus the avocado as well.  Vegetables were fresh as well. My wife ordered the sushi, I did not have the nigiri, but had the blta roll which I really liked quite a bit and the oceano roll which was good too.  We did not eat all you can eat though as I was full from yesterday's buffet.  Service was pretty good, I checkin and we got a free beer which was awesome.
We took some out of town relatives and were super disappointed. The bar was very, very slow and our order wasn't correct. The burgers were over cooked. It was disappointing for us and our guests.
Service was friendly, and the place is clean.  The pho broth had a really nice flavor, but even though I ordered a large I thought it was really skimpy on the noodles & toppings.

Stopped in after constantly passing Mixto on my walks home. I was surprised by how large and authentic looking the inside was.

We started with empanadas and trio ceviche. The empanadas were ok, nothing to rave about. The ceviche was great. Very fresh and plenty for two of us. We split a single size of the Paella, as suggested by our server. Seriously, he wasn't kidding. This was PLENTY. We actually didn't even finish. I thought it was a little dry and lacking some cuban flavors, but it was still tasty. 

Overall we were both extremely full. Service was wonderful. I'd come back just because of the service. I'd like to check out their happy hour.

I was taken to dinner here for my birthday by two wonderful friends, so I hate to not give a rave review. But I would have had a great time with them even if we went to McDonalds. 
We arrived before 7 p.m. and there was already house music blaring. Or at least we thought it was House until we realized the record had been skipping for hours and no one had noticed. The food was OK - spanakopita, hummus, dolmades - fair, I've had better and worse. The waitress told us we really had to try this cheese dip. It was like the leftover American Cheese stuck to my toaster, but flambed with a flair. 
We did not partake in the hookahs. I just dont see the appeal behind smoking tobacco out of these things. In fact, I dont think the contraption's creators had this in mind. As quoted from an interview in a college newspaper article I wrote many years back, "Bongs don't make potheads - potheads make bongs." But I digress...
For better varieties of Middle Eastern food I prefer South Street Souvlaki, Kanella, Effie's - even the Israeli falafal joints. I do think this place has potential - maybe they just need a kick in the dolmades.

I like it here.  There's something about Jose's that I find really relaxing and comforting.. maybe that's because I usually go on "off" times when it's not crowded.  Granted, I'm not a huge beer drinker, but they do have two of my favorites on tap (Framboise and Doc's) and the margaritas are pretty darn good too.  The chicken sandwich is awesome, and it's nice to have options as to what you'd like to have with it (fries, salad or chips and guac).  The salsa is always fresh and delicious, and Adam the bartender deserves a mention too.  Yes, the bathroom is a hike, but it's a really old building so there's probably not much they can do about it.

LOVED it.  The buccatini all' amtriciana is quite possibly one of the best things I've ever eaten.  The arancini made me swoon and the grilled smoked mozz with pickled veggies was heavenly.  The wine, ambiance and service rounded out the evening.  

Amis has a cozy setting that's quieter than Osteria yet more attainable than Vetri.  You can dress up or dress down, spend a lot or a little, but either way you go.. you'll have a fantastic time.

We found this place only with the help of Yelp. It is not easy to see as it sits off the road in a stop center. Look for the Yellow Sign.
We tried several if the dishes. We started with the Calamari...not the best ever but very good and crispy. We opted to share a bowl of the Crawfish Etouffee and Jambalaya. The Etouffee was very good. Lots of crawfish and the rice was perfect. The Roux could have used just a little more seasoning. The Jambalaya was insane! I have never had any better anywhere including in New Orleans. We also got a couple if pounds of the boiled crawfish with all the fixins. Great boil flavor and the mudbugs were perfectly cooked...firm and tasty.
We were so glad to find this little jewel of a place in the most unlikely of locations. If ever in the area or even far away, drive over and have the Jambalya! Call first to see if the bugs are fresh as they are better in season because you will want some of those as well!

Monday night  5:45  3 people for dinner
The service was very good, but our waiter OVERSOLD everything.  It was all so "fabulous...tasty...excellent...savory..the best..."  you get the picture.  It was exhausting just listening to him describe the menu items.
Started with a cheese plate..nice presentation, cheese was room temperature (which was good) and a good selection of cracker/breads to go with it.  To call that stuff bacon jam was a stretch.  There was not smoky or fatty flavor you would expect from something called "bacon jam".  It could have been fig jam or raisin jam and it would have tasted as described.
Also started with crab cakes---too much rosemary and not much crab.  Served with some sweet sauce and a vinegar slaw.  Not a winner at the table.
Had to have the fried green tomatoes---same sweet sauce as the crab cakes and thick slices of tomatoes that tasted raw and under-ripe. Swing and a miss.
Dinner entrees included:
Chicken fried chicken on a bed of yukon gold mashed potatoes and a  puddle of brown demi-glace.  I like my white peppery gravy on my chicken fried anything, so this was different but not good.  The chicken was huge, but not much flavor.  The potatoes were lukewarm at best.

The small filet was cooked perfectly and had a nice flavor.

The meatloaf was not nearly as tasty as it had been predicted to be.  The texture was rather strange, also. It was pasty and had the texture of liver spread.

Macaroni and cheese---not cheesy enough and the addition of ham didn't do it for us.

Brussel sprouts could have been cooked a little longer and seasoned with some of the missing bacon from the jam.

Dessert..hhhmm
The Elvis thing---imagine something like a pumpkin pie but made with bananas instead (not all the cinnamon, allspice  and sugar) baked in a crust that wasn't quite done. Slice it onto a plate with some good peanut butter ice cream and sprinkle some HARD pieces of peanut brittle.   You know you want to try it, don't you?  But I doubt you'll finish it.

The fried peach pie---deconstructed.  So on the plate you get some pieces of paper thin pie crust  (and those are quite good), An unpeeled peach that, I think, was poached and sliced, and then sprinkled with some sugar and cinnamon, and a scoop of yummy butter pecan ice cream. I was hoping for grill marks or anything to live up to the "fried" end of the bargain.

So, to sum it up,the atmosphere was nice,  the service was a little overzealous, the presentation of the food as it goes by to the other tables and the menu make your taste buds tingle, but the execution leaves you underwhelmed.

Great kitchen making hearty, fresh and flavorful vegetarian fare.  

I went here for a late lunch on a Sunday.  The waitstaff was friendly and prompt.  As a vegetarian, I really enjoyed having a whole menu to choose from, not just a few boring vegetarian dishes.  I'm not a big fake meat eater, but I've always wanted to try a Cuban sandwich so I got the veggie version- which was delicious.  We got fried beets with aioli to share, which were my favorite part- perfectly cooked and crispy.  My friend, a meat eater, got a sweet potato scramble with fried eggs that she really enjoyed.  

I would definitely come back to try dinner here and will certainly come back for lunch sometime!

Typical mall chain restaurant.  Home brew beer on tap was probably the only plus.  Burgers were large but sub par.  Not very flavorful or juicy.  Not bad in a pinch and out classes the fast food alternatives, but given a choice I would get my burger elsewhere.

Atmosphere: Halal Guys has a clean interior. The menu and the assembly/ordering area were very organized!

Service: We came later at night, but the staff was still friendly and energetic! Ordering doesn't take too long and is pretty simple.

Food: We ordered the combo platter (with chicken and beef gyro), and we weren't as impressed with the quality of the food. Compared to the original stands in New York City, the Halal Guys here is underwhelming. The food didn't feel as fresh or flavorful compared to the original experience. The spicy sauce is still good and hot though!

Overall: Given that we came a bit later at night, we didn't find the food to be as fresh or flavorful as the locations in New York. However, it is still a decent place to get halal food, but did not live up to the Halal Guys' name.

Soup left a bit to be desired. My main problem was that I ordered the Spinach Manicotti - the filling in the center of the pasta was ICE COLD. The rest wasn't that bad and the tomato gravy was on par, but overall I left feeling really underwhelmed.

This is an absolutely gorgeous restaurant. From the moment you enter, the foyer is pristine, beautiful flowers, and the paneling and seating in the restaurant is luxurious. The service is also impeccable, as expected from a place like this. 

I had the dry aged USDA prime NY Strip which was perfectly done to the medium rare that I love. Add on the sides of some creamed spinach and velvety smooth mashed potatoes and a rich strawberry cheesecake I was very happy. Definitely a gorgeous, delicious restaurant to dine at for special occasions. The price can add up pretty quickly though.

Four Rivers is probably one of the better Chinese restaurants in Philly. It also works like a Chinese restaurant anywhere else... if you don't see it on the menu, ask if they have ingredients, and then the chef will throw something you might like together. For example, I always ask them what type of fresh vegetables they have, and often just have the chef toss the veggies with some garlic and oil and spices and have it as a side dish.

I often come here for the dan dan noodles. I think they probably have the best dan dan noodles in town. It's spicy, sour, and chewy like they're supposed to be. 

Since Four Rivers is a Szechuan style restaurant, you can expect a lot of the food to be very spicy. Bring tissues and napkins as you will be sweating, your nose will be running, your eyes tearing, whether in happiness or in pain. 

The mapo tofu here is also done well, a little too well, and I prefer it to not be so spicy. Unfortunately even asking for less spicy here is a little too spicy for me... but hey, that's what you expect at a Szechuan restaurant right?

The scallion pancake here is traditional and very good. Try this place if you want something authentic, and again, if you don't see what you want, ask if they have it... who knows... you might end up getting what you want.

Made reservations for late on a sat evening. Menu had changed since the last time we had been there. Octopus appetizer was really tough. My ham was ok, too many cloves. Potatoes were undercooked and asparagus was bland and not prepared well. Dates steak had so much garlic there will be no vampires in south jersey for weeks. Catelli Duo is crossed off our list.  Service was pretty good.

The greet was ok host was friendly. I was Seated and took a few mins to be greeted when I was greeted my server took good care of me and made sure I still got the happy hour. Unfortunately my coupon did not have anything stating on having to purchase a different entree besides a kids and a salad item but all over sushi wasn't that great. My pear mojito was pretty good. But not really some where I would make time for in my dinner route. Good quality just not my cup of tea or roll of sushi.

Haven't got to visit my favorite taco place in a while. But looking for the most authentic ? This is my favorite because they really use cabbage instead of lettuce. I'm a spicy lover so I absolutely love the green sauce I have to bring a bottle home with me each visit. When it comes to beverage the pineapple water is one of the most refreshing things you will ever drink. Service isn't always excellent but the watering mouth always is!

Mexican cuisine at its finest and most authentic!  I dropped in for a super late lunch on a whim.  Was in the area and remembered that my friend Sigi has been here and given the place a decent review...so I figured, why not?   
When you enter the store you walk to the far rear left corner to find the restaurant.   It's a lot larger space than I imagined and very colorfully decorated.   Despite the fact it was 230p, there were several tables of patrons.  I took this as a sign the food was good!  I was seated promptly, and my waitress arrived in just a couple of minutes. I ordered water to drink as well as one of the daily specials (huevos con verde).   Upon being seated I was served with tortilla chips and two different salads, a roja and verde style. They were both very tasty and spicy hot just as I like them!  
My entree arrived in record time...seriously it took maybe five minutes!  The eggs were served with rice, refried beans and corn tortillas.  Again, spice level was hot, but I prefer this so it was a non-issue for me.  I expected the eggs to be served huevos rancheros style, but they were fried and sort of chopped up in the verde sauce. I enjoyed the dish, despite not being exactly what I expected.
CG also offers a full bar with seating, as well as a bar menu at your table, if you're interested.  The restaurant is very large and could hold a crowd if necessary.   
My waitress was very efficient and friendly (spoke English as well, so we had no communication issues).  Overall a good experience and I'd come back!

Oh, Chick -Fil-A. As a Georgia native of freaking course I love those waffle fries but then they had to ruin it with their bigotry. Welp. At least the people at this location are nice and helpful. They don't mind giving me strawberry jam or Polynesian sauce when necessary. They do have less pulp in the lemonade here than back home in Albany. I wonder why? I like it better with it. This location is always packed so don't come here in a rush thinking you'll be in and out. Parking is also kind of a hassle here and there is no room for overflow so you end up on Panda Express' grass.
I cannot really do a review. I only had a cappuccino.  It was not very good but much of the menu and other items look intriguing.  Nice atmosphere.
Wow. Smelled so good when walking in!  Had the salmon hash. Wonderful. Drank a toddy (strong coffee). Meal good. Clean. Nice atmosphere. Be back.

Nice!  Love the chef!  Enjoyed the fresh original approach. House smoked salmon. Very nice!  Had that with chefs choice sashimi. The fish was well prepared. One was slightly seared with a nice smoke. Another has a thin layer of green hot sauce (a fresh mixture) another had another drizzle on it. 

A very nice experience finished off with a variety of fresh fruit...plums, watermelon and more.

Friendly staff. Love the staff.  Clean. Ate too quick. They recommended the burger so I had the burger
avocado, salsa macha, roasted garlic aioli. It was good!  Cooked perfectly. Salsa macho added a different twist which was nice. A large burger served with home made potato chips. They were absolutely yummy!  Mmm. I want more!  Darn. Have to go back!

Nice variety in menu. The steak salad was so good!  Nice light flavorful dressing. Whew!  Yup. Pretty good!  Parking worked because I got there early. Otherwise...ouch!  

Full bar. Plus since they serve mules they offer ginger beer!  Their coffee is excellent.

Loved it!  However will this be a go to place?  Will this be a place I want to come back to all the time?  No!  Unless....I meet up with a group of people for to watch a sporting event...possibly, depends on parking. Who knows. Liked the food. 

Open modern atmosphere. Large and loud (noisy). Somewhat generic now a days. Friendly staff.  Indoor and outdoor setting. Indoor has high tops with stationary bolted down stools, half booths and tables. Outdoors is large and roomy with corn hole game etc. offers different seating arrangements plus the traditional. 

Menu has a nice sampling. Ordered the Green Chili Stew braised pork shoulder, northern bean, fried egg, cornbread. Excellent. (Fried egg edges were a little overdone). Excellent meal. Boasts a ton of flavor. Great spice level. Nice cornbread. Just marvelous. Nice portion. $16. Someone else ordered their fried chicken. Wow. Good stuff. A sweet glaze under the crust. Marvelous. Yum to both!  

Enjoyed the food!  Not too crazy about the space itself. Very clean. Bathrooms are set up nice. Despite the huge parking lot it was almost full and the restaurant was not full at all.

Food is good!  Our waitress did not know what she was doing, however someone must have spotted that and took over!

Started with pita and hummus while waiting for meal. Included with meal. 

Had a gyro plate. Gyro, quartered pita, rice and Greek salad. What can I say: a beautiful simple dish served fresh!  

Clean and simple atmosphere. Nothing romantic here. The set up reminds me of upgraded fast food. 

Yes I will return!

After reading the reviews I thought I'd try Dragos for their charbroiled oysters.  The location is great, and the ambiance is decent.

My first complaint is that when I showed up there were at least 2 hostest and 3 servers standing at the front, and nobody acknowledged me to seat me.

Service, mediocre, never refilled my water, didn't know the menu well,.

Ok, so I started with the charbroiled oysters, and I waited for them I watched them cook these oysters, and I got really excited to try them (flames flying around on the grill).  When they showed up they looked like they would be good, but sorely disappointed.  It just tasted like butter and garlic, and maybe paramsean?  What oyster????  

Next I had the bbq drum fish.  I was told that it was a spicy dry rub.  When it came out....the plate looked boring, and it was super bland.  I generally eat on the blander side, so it must have been super bland.

Salad it came with.....totally overdressed.

Maybe I'm spoiled with all the great and fresh restaurants I have in California, but this was not worth the money at all.

I celebrated my birthday with brunch at Brennan's. The atmosphere was beautiful and everyone was very friendly. The food was excellent- the baked apple is a must try. The eggs Hussard was great, although I didn't care for the English muffin, my husband really liked it. The eggs Cardinal were also delicious. We got a side of grits which were creamy and fantastic. The bananas foster prep and cook made for a fun show and a delicious dessert! As an added bonus, they also bring out cotton candy with a candle on top and a piece of cake hidden in the middle for birthdays. I also got a Brennan's apron to take home. Our only complaint was that the service was pretty slow at times. It was a great meal and experience, I definitely recommend it!

I was really excited to go to lunch here, as I have passed it a million times while out and about uptown. I was pretty disappointed when I left, and two stars is actually a pretty decent review after pit experience. My fiancé and I bought a groupon and when making a reservation made sure to note that we were using a groupon. We walked in to a near empty dining room- only one table was occupied- and told them we had a reservation. Which we realized at the end of the meal they never looked at in the computer, when they wouldn't let us use the groupon. 

The atmosphere was okay- small dining room, pleasant with a busy and smiley but slightly snippy waitress. We ordered- I got a soup and salad and he got the quiche of the day and a salad. The prices are totally outrageous. $29 for an omelet. $11 for soup. It's crazy! Also- The prices are way higher than on their website menu. So it was more than we had anticipated after looking at their website online. The food itself was just okay. Underseasoned, not quite hot just lukewarm. The salad dressing had no flavor. My fiancé said the quiche was mushy and had a strong and off putting shrimpy taste. Most certainly not worth the prices. 

At the end of the meal, we were told we could not use the grouping bc we did not order 2 entrees as the fine print stated. And that we should have told the waitress we had it so she could tell us how to order. My fiancé tried to explain that we put it in the reservation (we assumed they would look at the reservation in the computer when seating us). The waitress laughed in his face and said "Oh please! I'm not the one who took your reservation!" Wow. That wasn't at all what he was saying, if she had taken a moment to try and listen. We were stunned. In the end, she gave us the value we paid for it off of the meal. 

Bottom line- the food is mediocre, the service isn't great and the customer is most certainly the last priority at this restaurant. I will spend my money elsewhere in the future.

The food is amazing! It is some of the best Chinese food I have ever eaten. The only issue I had, and why it's not a five star review, is the waitress. She was really rude- sarcastic to the point of almost feeling abusive. She made fun of the food we ordered, called us names, wouldn't bring us refills. Another waiter helped us out because she couldn't be bothered. We were almost afraid to ask for anything! We will definitely go back for the wonderful food, but the waitress should probably be reminded that this is a customer service job.

Tried this place since it has a gluten free menu. Options were good.  Got a cider and the corned beef and cabbage. Disappointing.  Had to ask for mustard since what they usually use is not gf. But they had two other mustards available. The corned beef was dry and felt reheated. The cabbage was a bit undercooked. The carrots were fine, but the whole meal lacked seasoning.

The food was pretty good, but not the best. Drink selection is expansive. Wait staff is very friendly and offers suggestions. 


The only downer was that we went for lunch and there were crying children and a man threatening to slap his grandchild. NICE GUY.

It really kind of hurts thinking about a bad experience here. I'm vegan and not by choice. I'm allergic to most animals, bananas, several things some places put in salads, a huge chunk of preservatives, and twice as many fragrances and chemicals than that. So needless to say I feel l like a bother when I go out to eat. Yats is perfect though because the B and B which is the only thing on the menu I can eat is my ultimate indulgence. 
Anyways we ordered, the cashier told jokes, normal friendly Yats person. We cashed out sat down and waited. They brought food to our table and he started with what my friend ordered. So he gets his I get "Mine". From the jump I was confused because the color was wrong and I didn't see any beans, but it was spicy and sweet like my dish so I stopped picking at it. A few bites in I bite into what I realize is chicken. It's effect is only like kryptonite on me and can't actually kill me. But the shock of being poisoned I spit it out in a panic anyways. So I drink a ton of water, collect myself, and I go up to the counter and say "I don't think this one is mine." To which they all begin exclaiming that I made some mistake. And they call me by a name that isn't me, "Well what is your name." The cashier tells them it was under my friend's name. The order hadn't been sold yet. An honest mistake and an easy one to fix. 
So the guy brings me the correct dish, and takes out the other party's using their name this time. I begin eating my meal and it's the ecstasy I expect from them. The guy who brought us the order returns to the table and drops down a pile of napkins and says, "Here so you can get that chewed up ass piece of chicken." Yeah I'm alive thanks, and the food's great...... You on the other hand... So we won't be going back to this location. Which sucks because we moved and pass it daily on our way to work. I feel horrible about a low review for such delicious food but the experience was god awful. I'll be writing a review for the Fishers location which I used to frequent.
Was unimpressed with this location. Customer service leaves much to be desired. The food was ok but not worth returning for.  I would try the other location before this one.
Bland food..would not like to return! I don't have much to write about ambience and service as the most important part is the taste of the food which is not at all up to the mark!

A little tornado storm wasn't going to keep me from meeting up an old friend who just moved to Philadelphia!

Johnny Brenda's has been on my wanting-to-go list for awhile but I never trekked out to this neighborhood much since moving here myself. But that's all about to change now that more friends are moving into the area and my new home is also close by. 

Anyways...even during a storm, the bar was pretty full with what I assumed were locals. The staff were super friendly, the menu had great options without being too overwhelming, and prices were totally reasonable. It's a pretty sizeable bar but I didn't really look around much and sat at the bar the whole night. Maybe next time I'll peruse more. 

I had their mules and a fried chicken sandwich which were all yummy. 

They are also currently requiring proof of vaccination, fyi. Enjoy!

oh my! i'll have one of everything on the menu please...i mean, we almost kind of did. lol dim sum heaven. 

over the labor day weekend, i met up with some friends here. there's always a line to get a table but it moves pretty quickly. 

amongst the three of us, we shared a few things which i can't remember now but included some spicy pork soup, veggie, moon pie, and scallion pancakes. after the first round, we decided we all could eat more so we ended up ordering some crunchy something (but they messed up and gave us spicy pork soup again), some kind of mushroom thing, and some garlic pork noodles? 

if you're thinking how the heck did you finish all of that?! well...i'll tell you...we didn't! lol we almost did though. 

our server was very friendly and efficient. i'll def go back!

Memorial Day Monday at 1030AM.

Service was ok but , man, was the place filthy.  Everything about it.  Floors, tables, counters, bath rooms.  Get this taken care of quickly.

Decent enough place with good service. The steak was kind of tough for my liking, but the fried ice cream was the best I ever had. 
My sister and brother-in-law really like this place, so I'll probably return and try something other than the steak.

What I ordered wasn't very memorable, but what I DO remember is the guy at the cash register with a sneer on his face, giving me dirty looks. I was the only white male in there and I was the only one getting the dirty looks. Hmmm ... Coincidence? I think not.
  
I'll never spend another dime in this nasty place and I'm going to tell everybody I know how I was treated due to my race.

3/4/17: Had an overpriced, bland, bacon, egg and cheese on a poppy seed bagel. 
Will not return.

With so many farm to table establishments in Nashville, Sinema fell very short.  

The Good:  The greatest  attribute to this restaurant is it's interior, which is spectacular.  They've done a great job of making this a hip/swank place with old movies streaming on the walls, comfy couches upstairs and very cool lighting.  The drinks were very well done but took a while to make it to the tables.  When they arrived, they kept coming in different style of glasses - for the same drink.  Tall and skinny tube like glasses to short rocks glasses for the exact same drink.  Just think that's kind of odd.

The Bad:  How high brow are you to charge $3 for valet parking?  This is the only place in Nashville that I've ever seen that done.  $12 bucks for a bread basket?   How good is the bread?  Isn't bread one of the cheapest things in a restaurant?   The rest of the meal  (fish and chicken for the table) was over salted and underwhelming.  

The tables themselves felt cheap and more like something you'd find at Ashely Home Furnishings.  I'd expect more if dropping well over $200 on a meal for 4.

I say all of this with baited breath but I don't think I'd go back or recommend it to others.  There are much better places with better and well cooked choices than here.  

I'll take my $3 valet charge and apply it to an Uber ride to a different place next time.

Stopped in here on Saturday afternoon after a wedding up the street. We sat at the bar, had a couple drinks and ordered a Joey B's deluxe pizza. It was such a great pizza. Lots of bacon!!! And its good bacon too, not fatty or really greasy. Totally recommend it.
Delicious food,attentive service, fun atmosphere

What an amazing spot! For my birthday, my family planned to take me out for dinner and I chose 9IB.
I had no idea that they offered a free whisky shot anddd bread pudding to anyone there for their birthday. Such a treat!!
We had amazing waiter who got us our drinks, appetizers, and dinner lightning fast despite the place being packed. 
All 5 of us ordered fish and chips and my family, who had never been to 9IB, said it was the best fish and chips they'd ever had. 

I'll be back soon & highly recommend to anyone who asks for good food and atmosphere on Mass Ave.

We had the worst experience here. We love dogs but holy cow!! Dogs barking and fighting, took 10 minutes to get water, and food is just meh, nothing special. 

Our server could have cared less. A few people around us got up and left because of the situation.

Menu is very small. Would not be coming bacm

Avoid! Tourist Trap! We were in the neighborhood and starving. There was a long line and we decided to join the crowds and wait. It seemed like a visit here was something iconic that we should do. We were wrong! Skip this joint! 

Service was incredibly slow. Food was overpriced and mediocre. A stop here is a waste of time and money.

Besides a cozy and rustic atmosphere, all I can remember from my short visit here was the scone.

You bit into it and it instantly raped your mouth of all moisture making you feel like you just took a big hunk out of a chalk stick. The dryness and powdery residual dust from a scone gone very, very wrong lingered even after dowsing our mouths with water. 

No bueno. If you want to experience the above-mentioned without paying for a scone, just walk outside and lick the sidewalk. I'm talking a nice, tongue-rubbing against the gravely cement. Yummmm
Way over priced for what it is. Went there with my 3yr old grandson it was 21 bucks for a kids meal and an Italian grinder. Addios to jerseys.

Probably not the best time to go into it a Friday at happy hour. Got a table for 4 right by the bar. It was pretty loud just conversation wise. The food took 25 minutes to get and wasn't worth the wait. When the band started its over the top loud plus he wasn't very good. Over all to much commotion in the place.

Four stars for the pastries, three stars for the service. 

I've had a few things from La Boulangerie: the fruit tarte, the ham & cheese croissant and the chocolate almond croissant. The pastries are really reminiscent of what I had in Europe. Actually, the whole place is really reminiscent of the cafes in Europe. Everything I've had here has been excellent. The pastries aren't dry, and the crust and cream are fresh. I like that the almond chocolate croissant isn't too heavy on the chocolate. The fruit tart is always a hit at gatherings (I would know... I've been to about 4 potlucks/parties where someone has brought one) and loaded with gorgeous fresh fruits. Coffee is decent and they offer almond and soy milk. Prices are very reasonable ($20 for fruit tart, $3-4 for croissants) given the location, quality and ambiance of this place.  

Onto the service: hit or miss. I guess that can be said about a lot of places, so let me clarify. The workers are pretty cold, especially as the place starts to get really busy. But, there was one who was super sweet and even ducked out of the way so that I could get a good picture. Also, the signage is terrible and confusing with the double registers. There is a tiny sign by the register near the gelato that says to order at the other register - this sign is difficult to see. 

Bad service experiences aside, I would definitely return here (and plan to)!

Welcome to the Nashville tourist scene. If you looking for great food, look elswhere. Food here is just OK. But if you're looking for place to kick up your heels and make a fool of yourself, come on in !

I will admit I probably ordered the wrong thing, a personal pizza with a sweet red pepper base.  I was not a fan, and to me it almost tasted like they had put jam or something on it.  Hey you're probably not going to like everything, and there were other things on the menu that I probably would have tried.  What irritated me more than the food being kinda nasty to my palate was the fact the the server never asked if I liked it or not.  And considering how little I ate of it to me, it was pretty obvious.  I would have liked to have had the opportunity to order something different, but it wasn't offered.  I am down in St. Louis every month or two, but I definitely won't be going back to this place.

Parking lot that was so small that we were forced to use the valet.  There at 7:00 and only had a 10 min. wait.  No reservations for groups of less than 5. The faux $8 margaritas are a bit disturbing in a restaurant at this price point. For appetizers, we had the fried oysters chipolte,  crab cakes and the wild mushroom quesadilla. The oysters were large but the batter was way too thick and the flavor of the oysters was lost.  The crab cakes were way over fried, more like a hard croquette.  The quesadilla was fine but soggy on the underside due to the dipping sauce being sloshed over the plate. Two of us had the crab and shrimp stuffed snapper.  The fish was over cooked and smothered in sauce.  They should cut back on the sauce by at least 2/3s. Our third diner had the chihuahua combination which was good.  Bottom line is the food would have been better with less sauce and they need to get a full liquor license!

Pretty awesome spot! Enjoyed the chili, the brisket sandwich, French fries were crunchy, smoked chicken was flavorful and fried chicken sandwich was good too. Only complaint is I didn't like the bread the brisket sandwich was on, and brisket itself was on leaner side. Also moist towelettes after a messy meal like that would be really nice. Would come back again.

I suppose I am a gelato ignoramus, but I don't see what all the hype is about.  Maybe I didn't pick the right flavors or combination thereof.  Maybe I don't know how much air or cream or whatever is supposed to be in this stuff.  With that said, I did think the one chocolate flavor we had was outstanding and the others just OK.  But not nearly worth the price.  I feel wrong in thinking that some store brands, though obviously not nearly as fresh or natural, have better flavor than what I tried...  But, that's what I think.  Maybe I'll try it again sometime?

The reviews on Yelp said good things and then one of our friends who eats Vietnamese often recommended this place.  It was fairly crowded on a Saturday night and they have a ton of tables that are somewhat cramped.  Benefit of this is one always seems to be turning over so we were seated very quickly.  This is not particularly a place you go for ambiance, but it is clean and inviting nonetheless.  Mixed crowd inside.  Families, older couples, etc.  The service was quick at first and no-nonsense.  We each got a beer.  Only $3 for any beer including the well-known Asian imports like Tsing Tao, Singha, Sapporo, etc.  Huge menu!  Three of us shared a bunch of stuff: the vegetarian spring rolls, Pho with rib eye steak and "beef balls," Lemongrass tofu and BBQ shrimp over vermicelli.  I'm not a Vietnamese expert so I don't have much to compare with but I thought the food was excellent.  The Pho was great but I think the tofu was my favorite dish.  The most amazing part is that all of this with one beer each came to only about $33 or $11 each.  And we took a big box home too.  Only qualm was our friend ended up being in a bit of a hurry and we didn't see our server for awhile and it took a bit of time to track down the check.  Otherwise, very tasty, very affordable, very quick.  Four stars with a chance to move up to five.

After attending a Yelp event my husband and I ordered the chicken wings and fries. My husband really liked the chicken wings. They were a little too much tabasco flavored for me. I am not found of tabasco. 

There were a lot of wings and fries for a cheap price. The place was hopping. I have been here several times as it was a popular hang out when I went to UNR. 

Nice friendly place where there are usually lots of students from UNR. Servers are friendly. The food is inexpensive and tasty. Lots of different sub sandwiches to choose from along with pizza wings and other items.

I regret not writing a review for this place years ago! But better late than never right? 

First and Foremost the Location and parking: I'm not going to lie but it's HORRIBLE!!! Think Trader Joe's parking but 10x worse!! Come with patience. 

Pro Tip: Place your order on-line if you're pressed for time! 

Bonus Tip: Come 10 minutes before the noon lunch rush and you're guaranteed to find parking and there's no line! 

They have two lines, one specifically for on-line orders and the other for walk-ins. 

Portions are HUGE whether it's a sandwich or salad expect to get your money's worth and then some! It's no wonder why every location here in town is continuously busy. Aside from that the food is delicious!! Everything I've had is yummy. My favorites are the Buffalo chicken Sammie, garden salad with tuna, Mexican chicken Caesar salad, and the Asian chicken salad. 

Discount Tip: They take the Axxess card! Buy one get one Free. It applies to a sandwich or salad. Free drink everytime thereafter. 

Even though the location/parking here sucks, it's well worth the trouble!

This is my go to place when i'm craving sushi and teriyaki chicken. My usual order is the teriyaki chicken combo. This comes with charbroiled teriyaki chicken, 6 california rolls, salad, and rice. The salad dressing is very creamy and delicious! I wish they would bottle it up and sell it. If you call in a take-out order, my suggestion is to make sure you check your food order before you leave! I learned my lesson by not doing this, so i came home and i was ready to dive into my food when i discovered the pieces of chicken were cold and didn't look very appetizing. And to top it off they didn't give me any teriyaki sauce! I didn't have any on hand either so my meal was a disappointment to say the least. I'm still giving this place 4 stars because they do serve good food when you eat there, but just be aware you might not get the same freshness if you call in a take-out order.

Welcome back Corazon Cocina! I've missed you dearly. 

The food is just as amazing as I remember it to be and the presentation is just as beautiful. So glad you guys are keeping up with your unique style! Chef Ramon is a master at what he does.

All the tacos are served on a homemade corn tortilla. Not only are they delicious but they are the perfect size, thickness, and holds up very well when eating your taco. Never gets wimpy! 

Let's talk food! 

Here is what I ordered:

Chicken mole taco - The rich dark mole was slightly sweet, nutty and just a tad spicy. I added the peanuts from the salsa bar to give it that extra crunchy nutty flavor. Try it! 

Ensenada taco - Crispy beer battered cod served with cabbage, radish slices, and a mayo lime crema; which my son didn't want so it's not pictured. But he loved the fish tacos! I've had them before too and they are crunchy and yummy. 

Al Pastor taco - The meat was perfectly marinated and the pineapple pairs well giving it a nice sweet and salty taste. They don't skimp on the meat here! 

Quesadilla de Mercado - Not your average quesadilla and by far the best quesadilla I've ever had! Served on a blue corn tortilla with a nice thick slice of seared panela cheese and beautiful fresh market veggies. A true picture perfect masterpiece. The presentation was flawless! I shared half with my son and he was wowed by it too. 

Yes the food is on the pricey side but the quality, care, and effort put into making the food is well worth it to me and there is no other place in town that compares to Corazon! They truly are one of a kind and the food is made from the heart. 

I can't wait to go back and try more. Keep an eye out for the pulpo (octopus) taco when available! This will blow your socks off.

There's one thing I have noticed about some grocery stores since moving to Indianapolis: the produce section is disgusting. This is the third Wal-Mart I have been to that has fungusfied (yes I made that word up), produce! The green apples, lemons, and tomatoes were so disgusting. I can make comments on their fish tanks that are filled with dead fish, but let's just stick to the much needed veggies and fruits!

Okay, so for quite a while I stuck to my guns and simply avoided the Butler location of Metro Diner. After all, a well deserved 2-star experience left a bad taste in my mouth, quite literally, and even hearing from local ownership didn't really seem to sway me to return to this particular location despite my occasional patronage of other spots - especially Castleton and the Northwestside spot. 

However, the recent Thanksgiving holiday found me without a place to go and in my usual holiday funk. So, I joined a friend and we decided we weren't in the mood for Chinese and even Denny's didn't really hit the spot. He'd already checked and knew that Metro Diner was open until 2pm. 

So, Metro Diner it was. 

Now then, I must confess that when ownership or even management reaches out to me I usually am pretty good about giving a spot another try. However, this location has always felt a bit awkward to me. There's an attached parking garage, though the idea of paying for parking is unappealing. There's a side campus parking lot, though one never quite knows if an over-zealous officer will decide to ticket someone - or at least that's what always goes through my mind when I pull into one of those accessible spots. The truth is I've never quite understood the parking arrangement. 

As I noted in my previous review, this location does actually do access fairly well. There's the nearby accessible parking, and I never have received a ticket, along with the garage that also offers accessible parking. Since my first visit, Metro Diner has also arranged for you to be able to park for free for up to an hour. Metro Diner has a nice concrete ramp leading into the restaurant - definitely ADA compliant. The front door usually has staff nearby if you're struggling with the door and the general rule at Metro is that if they see you coming they're going to be at that door (and they usually see you). 

While dining out on a holiday can be a little hit-and-miss considering many employees would prefer to be at home, I didn't sense any disgruntled employees here. Our server, whose name I've since forgotten, shared very openly that he lived nearby and that his family gathering wasn't until 3pm anyway. So, he figured he could earn some money AND enjoy the holiday. It was a terrific attitude and it set the tone for a casual, warm holiday at Metro Diner.
