Unlike my previous visit, service was top notch from beginning to end. It was attentive, yet never intrusive and friendly in a sincere way. We were there from noon until a few minutes before they closed at 2pm and business was steady throughout. 

As I preferred a more traditional meal on this fine and festive holiday, I opted for their pot roast special. It was a healthy serving of pot roast, red-skinned mashed potatoes, and I had my usual unsweetened iced tea. At $11.99, it was a solid value and quite tasty. 

I will say I always find Metro's prices to be a touch high, though it may have felt a little more like sticker shock since I was also paying for my friend's dinner as a late birthday present. However, I will also note that for that price you tend to get bigger servings and higher quality food. 

Overall, there's definitely some redemption here and I can't help but think that my original experience was either a fluke or simply some bugs that hadn't been worked out of the system yet. I was definitely happy with this visit - grateful for a quality meal on a holiday, an enthusiastic employee to serve it, a warm and welcoming atmosphere, and to be able to up this rating and say that this location now pleases me as much as the other Metro spots. As this location is actually closest to my home, I look forward to returning.

Addendum: Approximately two weeks after this visit, a person attempted to use the same credit card I used here to make a substantial purchase. Fortunately, it was caught and denied by my credit card company. Quite simply, there were no other possibilities. Can I say 100%? Nope, but that's a little too scary and despite a better experience here on a return visit I simply can't take that risk. I won't be back.

I've returned six years later and had a much better time! Why? The patio was practically empty. And I hadn't been out to eat in two months. Yes, the patio is open and they're serving a limited menu (available on the website). 

My friend has a beer. I had a margarita. It definitely tasted premixed, but it was strawberry and I haven't had a marg in so long, so I can deal. 

I ordered chips and queso. Pretty good. Also ordered little pieces of heaven (or something like that): fried Monterey jack bites. These are smaller and gooier than mozzarella sticks and a big improvement upon those. 

My one complaint is the bugginess. Please get some citronella candles or other bug control for the patio.

Remember back to future 2 when biff owned a casino? Well this is that place. 
It's smoky, small and they charge you a fee to get in. Only thing they are missing would be hookers in the lobby. But I'm sure thats coming soon....

I would give it one star but I did see a great comedy show here so two stars is fair. Be prepared to leave with a sore throat and smelling like a Newport.

I haven't been to this one, just the ones in the mall. Usually the food was pretty good. I thought the meat was a little dry and my pita was just ok. On a good note, I think the food is very reasonably priced and they don't skimp on the amount. 

The Service was fantastic, hence the 3 stars. I'm willing to go back and try them again to see if they beat maybe just had and off day.  I like the people and hope for better experience next time.

My bf and I came here for date night because we found the deal on Groupon and thought it sounded good. Service was slow. We waited quite awhile for someone to take our order and then also waited a very long time to get our check. Other than the lacking service our experience was good. We split three sushi rolls, the tiger roll, west pine roll, and crunchy roll. They were all good. Didn't blow me away or anything but it was good solid sushi! I did like that everyone gets complimentary miso soup and salad. I haven't seen that at other sushi restaurants so that was nice. I would go back here as long as I get better service the next time around. The groupon deal is definitely the way to go if you're planning to go here for date night.

Not a big fan of Soulard!  But I do like this little establishment.  I've had only good late night's here and there has usually been a pretty dang good and authentic group/band, whatever you would call a couple guys playing Irish music.  The bar staff is pretty skilled and quick, the crowd a nice mix of younger to a bit older.  I like it.

I can count the number of two star reviews I've given on one hand. So bare with me on this one because it hurts to write this...

Before I was feeling my 3 star rating, now, based on a recent visit to celebrate a friend's birthday 2 stars almost seems generous for multiple reasons - 

1.) service - I understand that they have a certain way of seating people on the rooftop but when a birthday party crew enters eager with balloons and flowers to surprise a friend before they arrive and not one table is seated and said guests waited half an hour to be the first in the door - why must you rain so heavily on the parade by making them waiting until the birthday boy arrives to be seated? The way the entire situation was handled was extremely unfriendly and inflexible. To top it off, we were told birthday cakes are not allowed to be brought in - a-okay, I understand - "can I tuck it away somewhere so it doesn't melt before dinner is over?" Response: "hmm...I dunno...." (aka "I really don't want to go out of my way on ANYTHING here") 

2.) the food is meh. Big time meh. Uninspired and lacking one specific direction. Ya know, it's one of those places that seems to think they can pull off pizza, Asian noodle dishes, pub grub and a zillion other styles of food under one roof. 

3.) it's sad to see the extreme potential of the rooftop space being utilized by such a sub par eatery with unenthusiastic staff 

Quite the bummer experience.

I came here a few weeks ago and had great service. I was surprised by the wait on a Wednesday night but it went pretty quickly. The food was fresh and hot. As far as chains, Olive Garden is pretty reliable. Our server was great and I wish I could remember her name, she inspired me to update my Yelp review.

Waffle House has never let me down on food! I always order two scrambled eggs with cheese and the classic or chocolate waffle. Sometimes the cleanliness is hit to miss. Staff is attentive and welcoming. A diner experience with great food and fast service.

This place has cool cocktails. I love the soiled dove! There are lots of hip, fun and unique choices, and of course the bartenders can also make whatever you fancy. The beers on tap are nothing to write home about though. They could definitely use a better selection. 

The food is pretty good. I got the chopped chicken salad which had all of my favorite ingredients, but I didn't love the bbq ranch sauce that was on it. The pretzels and fondue are VERY excellent.

The ambiance of this place is strange. You would think it would be a good place to watch football on a Saturday evening (because of the amount of TVs, drinks and food) but it's not. It's packed with patrons who are there to party. We sat at the bar and the bar stools are the most uncomfortable seats. You can't move them so it was kind of a claustrophobic feeling. And it is LOUD. There was live music and the band was really good but no one was listening to them. Instead, everyone was just yelling trying to have conversations.

I have waited a while since Double Knot opened to get here and see what all the hype was about. I went on a Friday night with a group of 7. The decor was awesome and service was on point. We each ordered 4 items off the menu. The servings were good to be able to try a bunch of different things. Overall everybody enjoyed it but I am going with 3 stars because the food was very similar to sampan of course but sampan food I think is better. They also had items such as the edamame dumplings and fried rice that I also think are better at Budakkan. I am sure I will return but I just don't think it lives up to the hype.

My first bang bang shrimp tacos were on soft shell.  Since returning, I haven't seen it on the menu with anything but crispy wonton tacos that I did not like as much.

The happy hour (Mon-Thu) had a nice option of 2 of these crispy tacos for only $5 though, and that was just the right serving size as a starter for the meal.  I had the Cold Snap cocktail with orange and berries that comes in a glass made of solid ice!  That was really cool, turned some heads at the bar, and quite tasty.  I would also recommend the Dirty martini and the White Sangria.  Victor at the bar was great!

Bang Bang Shrimp Tacos, crispy wonton shell = 3/5
Bang Bang Shrimp Tacos, soft shell = 5/5
Cold Snap cocktail = 5/5 (glass made of ice)
Dirty Martini = 5/5 (blue cheese olive and provel-stuffed cherry pepper)
White Sangria = 4/5 (lightly sparkling)
Tilapia Imperial = 5/5 (lower cal-ish, nice serving size, potato au gratin was good)

I love the prix fixe meal here at dinner!  Better yet, on a nice night, sit outside on the patio.  For one set price, you can choose 3 courses.  You can mix up what you want for the other two courses.  It can be salad, appetizer, entree.  It can be appetizer, entree, dessert.  If there are at least two of you, I'd recommend this:

Complimentary bread
Two salads (or soup if you prefer)
1 Appetizer
2 Entrees
1 Dessert
That's 4 courses (not counting bread) for the price of two prix fixe meals!  It works out so well!
Then yeah, grab a bottle of wine while you're at it!

What I ate:
1) L'Escargots (4/5) - pretty good, not for everyone, if you don't like the texture of mushrooms, you're unlikely to like this
2) Salade César (5/5) - one of the better Caesar salads I've had
3) Poulet DeBergerac (5/5) - had no idea how good this was going to be, would definitely get it again
4) Steak Frites (4/5) - Yay, it comes with bearnaise sauce!
5) Chocolate Torte (2/5) - Decent, wayyyyy too rich, couldn't eat beyond a couple bites

There's an outdoor area but the sun beats down on it at midday, and there are no umbrellas or awnings, so even if the weather was nice, it seemed like you'd have the sun in your eyes too much.

They serve water out of what looks like wine bottles, which was a neat idea.  However, I kinda expected the water to be a little more ice cold than it was.

I like the color scheme - the white and farm house blue was a nice contrast with the ampersands on the coffee cups and employee shirts.

3 of my friends ordered the steak and eggs and liked it, and 1 friend ordered the grilled chicken sandwich and really liked it although he admits he was eyeballing the steak and eggs the whole time.  He said he was glad he really liked his chicken sandwich, or he would have been regretting not getting steak and eggs as well.

Under the "Sweet" section of the menu, you find the pancakes and French toast.  I tried the blueberry pancakes ($7.50) and bacon ($3) with a Diet Coke ($2) (see POSTED PHOTO).  You get 3 fairly thick pancakes with blueberry butter.  This was way too much blueberry - too many blueberries in the pancakes with blueberry butter was just too much.  It was way too sweet to me.  The bacon, however, was very nice cuts of bacon, but I think the bacon should come with the pancakes and not be offered only a la carte for $3 for 3 slices.

So on my experience alone, I would have given 2 stars, but since my friends really enjoyed their meals, I have upped it to 3 stars for now.  They have a Black Canyon Angus burger (what is Black Canyon Angus?) with cheddar on a brioche bun that looks tasty, so I hope to get to try that on the next visit, and maybe I can update my review to a stronger 3-star review or even a 4-star.

Breakfast - Their breakfast paninis are the best breakfast sandwich in town!  In the bakery, I love the plain bagel with plan or - Mmmmm - hazelnut cream cheese, the muffin tops, and the egg souffles.

For lunch or dinner, the seasonal Strawberry Poppyseed Salad is amazing for under 300 calories I think.  My favorite soups are the Chicken and Wild Rice, Baked Potato, or Broccoli Cheese.  I would NOT get the Lemon Chicken Orzo again; it's not as good as the one at Sweet Tomatoes and tastes more like a chicken noodle with a faint hint of lemon.  Finally, I regularly return to the Frontega Chicken hot panini, the Bacon Turkey Bravo, and the Sierra Turkey.  If I'm not getting soup, their white mac and cheese is rich and creamy.

Great food and a fun location.  You can sit in or outside in warm weather.  I LOVE the flaca bowl.  It has black beans, rice, chicken, salsa, cheese and avocado.  I am not a beer fan so I can not comment on any of their beers.  The staff is always friendly when we are in.  The place isn't the cleanest but it isn't bad enough to not make me want to eat here.  The parking can be a bitch if you are trying to go there when Victorian Square has an event happening.  If there is nothing going on then there is all sorts of parking available.  The fish and chips are great too.  My honey likes to eat their salads and he enjoys them.

Let me start by saying that this review is based on appetizers and drinks ONLY....

We came here after reading the Weekly Yelp and its positive reviews from my fellow Yelpers.  Most people who have lived in Reno and know the town will agree that East Fourth street has not had the most...ahem...good reputation for many years now.  It is refreshing to see such a beautiful building and a large crowd gathered on a Thursday night at this establishment.  Kudos to the owners for bringing such a great place with a welcoming vibe to east Fourth Street.   

The parking lot is narrow and long so you will have to make your way along the back to find a spot.  This isn't a complaint but merely an observation.  Once inside we were blown away by how packed it was.  Lots of guys in suits and lots of ladies sipping cocktails and enjoying themselves.  Honestly it felt like we were at Bricks or Roxys.  The place is beautiful as many of the other reviews have pointed out.  Warm brick accents and wood flooring throughout.  

We were asked if we had a reservation and we did not but were seated right away.  The hostess was friendly and did not give off that "ohhh you don't have a reservation..." vibe which was nice.  The room we were seated in was set up for a large party which always makes me shudder because I know that my nice, quiet evening will soon be cut short by a large group of loud, obnoxious folks.  Not the case here.  The service was attentive and quick and I think what kept the large group from getting out of hand was the fact that they had multiple servers tending to them and quite often.  Well done Depot.  

We ordered the Poutine and the cheese plate.  I had wine and my partner had beer.  The poutine was decent.  I wouldn't write home about it but I am a poutine SNOB and have had the bar set pretty darn high.  The cheese curds were very good but the gravy just was meh... The cheese plate was nice.  Don't ask me what kind of cheese was on it because the server didn't tell us.  She just put the plate down and walked away.  When I order a cheese plate I want to know what I am eating.  The cheeses that were presented were tasty but I have NO idea what they were.  When you go to Campo and order the cheese plate they tell you exactly what cheese you are presented with and what the accompaniments are.  

Anyhow, I do plan on returning based on others' experiences here.  We plan on having dinner and I hope to bump the Depot up a star or two.
The food was good and the employees were nice.  It didn't WOW me like Mid Town Eats did but still a great place for a good bite to eat at a reasonable price.

Most of the employees (checkers, baggers, and stockers) are very friendly, and this store does have a good selection of products (a natural section, a decent 'gourmet' section, okay wine/beer selection) for its size. But still, I've come to loathe this place for some of its employees and the prices.

Bad apples: one of the checkers (a white-haired woman in her 50s/60s) is consistently crabby and borderline insulting. Today she had an issue redeeming my Raley's custom coupons (the kind Raley's mails you when you have a 'club card'). She asked if the coupons were associated with a different card (they were not). After her audible frustration to her bagger ("I am NOT doing these anymore!") she manually deducted the coupons. I thanked her but she had to again assert that the problem was my fault ("I ONLY have this problem when the coupon is for a different account"). I would have gone to management to complain if my kid weren't with me.

Prices: ridiculously high on most things relative to Winco (for example) and even Whole Foods (for the natural stuff; as if it couldn't get higher - it can, try Raley's!). The bulk section was the source of my ire today; plain-old raw walnuts in a package were around 50 cents a pound (in the baking section), but in bulk they were 66 cents a pound. Shouldn't bulk be cheaper for the same product? It's little stuff like this all over the store that make me avoid making trips here. It's really only my "emergency store" due to its proximity to my house. I suspect that's the main reason most people shop here; it's close to lots of off-campus UNR students and retirees.

Stopped in for dinner while we were at the mall tonight. I haven't eaten at a CPK in years so wasn't sure what to expect. I was actually surprised at how good our experience was, only because another chain is the last thing I figured Franklin needs. Started with some yummy bread with dipping oil - always a win for us. For dinner I had the Shrimp Scampi Zucchini and it was so very good. It was light and lemony, with a good amount of shrimp. I could eat this all the time! My husband had the spicy chicken pizza. He's never met a pizza he didn't like lol, so he enjoyed his meal as well. Our server was on top of things and super friendly. It's a tad pricey for pizza considering the size. Overall, a great addition to the current mall food offerings!

I don't know, I wanted to love it... but I just didn't. I am surprised the ratings for this spot are so high! The pad kee mao was mediocre, as the shrimp was very overcooked as were the noodles. I ordered a 3 on the spicy scale and regretted it immediately - if you like it hot, get a 4. That was my fault though as I know I like it spicier than most Americans. Husband got the basil Thai stir fry which was also fine but nothing special. The dumplings were a tasty start. Not to be over critical of a a friendly, local place, but there is better Thai in Nashville.

Stopped by to try some burgers and fries for our Friday night dinner. No turkey burgers here but they do have chicken and vegan options which is great. We thought the burgers were pretty tasty although over cooked  vs. what was ordered. Loved the fries, very fresh. All and all a good experience if you are looking for a quick bite to eat!

I've been to the old location and new location several times over the years. The new place is definitely a huge upgrade over the Moana place. It is much bigger and nicer. Every time I think about the old place I think about the sketchy plastic chairs they had and how pissed I was if I had to sit in one instead of at one of the other tables. 

Anyway, the pizza is just ok. I usually order by the slice so I can't really say if they put more love into their full pizzas but I'd imagine they are the same. I know all pizza topped with cheese and meat is greasy but the pizza here seems exceptionally greasier. The employees are generally nice although I've had at least twice where either the guy taking my order or the guy taking my money have been a little rude. Maybe they were just frazzled or overwhelmed but it's not cool to take it out on the customer. 

Thanks to the good people of Yelp here in Reno, my eyes have been opened to so many other pizza places that are so much better.  I may return one day but it's not likely. And if I do I surely won't make a special trip.

Fun place to go grab a PBR and fireball shot for $5... Seriously, it's a real deal at this place. Perfect for pre gaming before the bars. Also, karaoke rooms you can rent out and have sushi delivered to your private room??? Sign me up motha' licka! 

Tip - the waiters always seem high and have zero idea what is on the menu. Other than the random stoner taking your order, cheap prices for a lot of food.

We were stuck in the Southwest terminal from 11am-7:30pm and chose here to have a "linner".   The tables are close, and it's very noisy,  but it's a restaurant in an airport, so what can you expect.   Service was quick and she was attentive the entire time.  We both got burgers, and ordered them with different toppings and she got it all straight without writing it down.   Food came hot and fresh, but the burger had no flavor.   Not sure what kind of beef it was, but I love burgers and this one was bland.   Even with condiments, the beef was bland.  

Could have gone to Burger King and spent much less money and would have been a bit better because I know what that tastes like.   

Sadly, we were disappointed.

We continue to enjoy this restaurant, and having outdoor seating makes it even better.    Service is always top notch.

This time I tried the chicken cheese steak, but it wasn't my favorite.    Great, fresh bread, good flavor, but not enough ingredients to bread ratio.  

Will be back to try more on this menu.

Yeap 3 stars!

Beautiful restaurant on Macdill Ave, loved the romantic feel inside, warm lighting, jaw dropping ceiling and much more. I had been here for lunch but not for dinner. I wish there was more parking available, they do have complimentary valet service which was a good touch. 

We were greeted and seated promptly. Ami was our amazing server. We started the night with couple of appetizers, crab cake beignets and cornbread. Crab cake beignets were great and nestled in different sauces. I wish the sauces were in a separate bowl, some of the sauces overpowered the subtleness of the crab. 
OMG cornbread! So freaking good and moist, buttery! Comes to the table in a cast iron pan, glistening from the butter and topped with a streusel. One of the best things we ate there! 

Next we ordered Cobb salad, it was good. Nothing out of the ordinary. As for entree, we opted for Braised Pork Shank, highly praised by our server. For $26, we were really hoping for a dynamite main meal but it wasn't meant to be. The pork was dry, which means it was overcooked plus we couldn't taste any truffle oil in the mashed potatoes. 

Overall, it was a good meal until we got our main entree.

Hmm.. i feel really bad leaving 2 stars here but the food wasn't good at all. 

We started with seafood pancake: very very doughy. Either there wasn't enough seafood in the pancake or they added too much rice flour. I didn't like it at all. 

I usually come here for Korean food but we opted for sushi. Bad idea, next time I'll stick with my favorites. We ordered the rolls that came highly recommended on Yelp. I couldn't eat more than 1 bite. Very disappointing since we spend over $50 for mediocre sushi. 

I really hope they were having a off nite because our meal wasn't good.

Great restaurant! Huge outdoor seating available. Hookah, belly dancing and so much more. Reservations are highly recommended. 

Pros: 
* drinks are amazing, must try the gin & tea cocktail. 
* babaganush (excuse my spelling) and feta-yogurt dips are great. 

Cons: 
*  pricier than most places  
* mixed grill meats weren't cooked very well, beef kefte was undercooked and pork and chicken kabobs were over. 
* the mixed grill came with fries as a side, i would never pick fries as a side at a Mediterranean restaurant. 

Overall, it was ok. I love Mediterranean food but this wasn't the best.

The original location, and still the best. Taco Bus is one of those quirky, yet quintessential Tampa eateries that you need to try at least once.

The original location of Taco Bus is a small cluster of buildings, picnic tables, and two school buses parked near the intersection of Nebraska and Hillsborough Avenues. You actually order your food at the side window of one of these school buses (the yellow one), and your meal is prepared in the kitchen which is contained within the other (white) bus which is parked at right angles.

Taco Bus nailed the whole food truck concept long before the trend became cool in Tampa. Those of us who've lived in Tampa for a number of years have fond memories of staggering up to the bus in the middle of the night, and ordering some very good Mexican street food. Over the years they have expanded from one bus to two, and added some additional seating, but this is still the same relaxed place to roll in, order some tacos, burritos, tostadas, tortas, quesadillas, and ensaladas with your choice of proteins and toppings. The menu is posted on a banner, alongside the yellow bus, so start over there, and then place your order with the ladies.

If you're eating in, then grab your drink cup and walk over by the other bus (the white one) where you'll find a Coke Freestyle machine. Sit outside at one of the covered picnic tables, or under the covered patio, or inside the little building which also houses the rest rooms. When your food is ready, they'll bring it out to your table. If you like your food spicy, be sure to ask your server for the homemade red and green salsas to punch up the flavor.

I generally get the two taco platter, and my favorite protein is the conchintina pibil which is a traditional Mexican slow-roasted pork dish, which involves marinating the meat in strongly acidic citrus juice, seasoning it with annatto seed which imparts a vivid burnt orange color. I also like the carne asada, chorizo, and shrimp. Taco Bus also offers a variety of chicken, pork, fish, and vegetarian fillings.

Order your food, then kick back and laugh about their motto of "Broken English, Perfectly Spoken" while you enjoy your meal.

Kona Grill is a very nice restaurant, sushi bar, and cocktail lounge located on Boy Scout Road across from International Plaza Mall. 

The menu features a diverse selection of appetizers, salads, sandwiches, chicken, seafood, steaks, pasta, and pizzas that incorporate over 40 signature sauces and dressings that are made from scratch. Kona Grill also offers a wide selection of award-winning sushi, sashimi, and creative rolls.

Kona Grill features a contemporary design with a very dramatic atmosphere with a main dining room, cocktail lounge, sushi bar, and private dining areas. Wait till you see the spectacular salt-water aquarium behind the hostess stand. It must be several hundred gallons and filled with a wide variety of colorful tropical fish.

I was there for sushi, and I thought their chefs had some creative options including a tuna sashimi flight for an appetizer with albacore tataki in a daikon garlic vinaigrette, jalapeno yellowtail sashimi with sliced jalapeno, cilantro, and ponzu sauce, and finally a seven spice ahi tuna with sumiso sauce over a cucumber salad.

For my rolls I ordered a Volcano Roll which was baked crab, whitefish, yamagobo, motoyaki sauce, sriracha and eel sauce. Also one of their house specials called a Checkerboard Roll which was a habanero tuna mix with avocado and asparagus, and topped with tuna, yellowtail, and a spicy motoyaki sauce.

My waitress was Christina and she was EXCELLENT with lots of helpful suggestions and recommendations. One of the best servers in town, IMHO.

I can't speak for their regular menu, but I was very pleased with the sushi.

One of my business partners wanted to host dinner at Charley's Steakhouse, which meant they were picking up the tab for all of us. Now Charley's isn't my top choice for Tampa steakhouses, but it's hard to argue with a free dinner.

Charley's has been family-owned and operated since the mid 1970's, and was founded by Charley Woodsby, co-founder of the Red Lobster chain. Charley and his son Ron now own the Talk of the Town restaurant group, and the steakhouse is the crown jewel of their chain.

Charley's serves only USDA prime and choice Angus steers, ages them for four to six weeks for tenderness and flavor, and then hand cuts the steaks daily to ensure consistent quality. The steaks are then flame-broiled over oak and orange woods in a custom-built pit. They claim that their secret is the pit which cooks all of the steaks, chicken, chops and fresh fish over a 1,200-degree fire. 

As you enter the lobby you'll see a refrigerated case spotlighting all of the different cuts of meat and seafood that are available for dinner. Our group gathered at the bar while we waited for the stragglers, and then we were off to our private dining area in one of the smaller rooms.

The service was fantastic, and the waiter that managed our group of 8 was quick to gather up our drink orders and then return to talk about the menu. He led us through a dizzying array of steaks, chops, wild game, seafood, and Chef's specials along with all of the different choices of sauces and sides. We shared some calamari with shrimp and scallop scampi for appetizers, before diving in to our main courses.

I ordered the T-bone for my dinner, and had plenty to take home for a second meal. The steak was cooked perfectly, and it had plenty of rich flavor. As a group we shared some creamed spinach, grilled asparagus, and smashed potatoes for sides, and there was plenty of that to take home as well.

I passed on ordering dessert, but watched while others tried to tackle slices of the carrot cake and Key Lime pie. I was content to sip a glass of port and let my dinner digest before it was time to pack up the leftovers and head for home.

What a great little find in the New Tampa / Tampa Palms area! Mr. Dunderbak's is located just north of Ehrlich Road / Bearss Avenue on Bruce B. Downs Blvd in the same little strip mall with Acronis Greek Taverna and Takara Sushi & Saki Bar.

The restaurant is a combination biergarten and European-style market with some mighty delicious German dishes. The official Bier Polizei and Beer Geeks are there to help you select from the 400 cans and bottles of beer in the chilled bier kellers, as well as the 50 or so draft beers, lagers, ales, stouts, etc.

The menu is a fabulous mixture of hearty pub grub sandwiches and very traditional German delicacies. I ordered the veal jagerschniztel which was a pounded and breaded veal cutlet, fried, and then smothered in a delicious brown mushroom and onion gravy. That came with two sides, and I selected sauerkraut and warm German potato salad.  What a delicious lunch!

My waitress recommended a pint of Einbeecker Schwarzbier which was a dark lager, and it perfectly balanced the spicy gravy.

After eating I wandered around inside to see the smaller party rooms / beer halls which would be perfect for hosting a Yelp event (hint, hint). The butcher's case in the back of the store offers homemade sausages, sandwiches, sides, desserts, cheeses, and a large variety of German favorites including spicy mustards and curry ketchup, wines, beers, chocolates, and more.

If you have an interest in home brewing, then Mr. Dunderbak's sells DIY brewing kits along with all of the proper glassware and beer steins.

Raise your glass and toast to Mr. Dunderbak's by saying, "eine zwei drei, hinunter die Luke!!!"

Ja, ja ist das gut!

Really awesome shop that reminds me of California. I had the Stoke's salad and it was rad. You can tell these people care about the food. 

NOT CHEAP, however.

I don't understand the hype over this place. The Cuban sandwich is marginal. The rest of the food is marginal. However I will say that due to the fact that this place is very busy, the food is very fresh. But I would never make a special trip to get a sandwich here.

These bagels are hard as fuck. I don't know if it's because they weren't fresh or that's just how they bagel here. But hard as fuck bagels are not my thing. Chewy soft bagels are my thing. They were also overcooked, or overbaked (not burned but overdone). They get 2 stars for the quality bacon and eggs tho.

I am not a big burger fan or snob. If you are picky about burgers, you may think this place is lame. Me, I was trying to avoid making my own turkey burger at home and so I picked one up from here to-go. I had been to this place previously about 2 years ago. I remember it as being just OK.

I think Burger 21 is better, but there is no Burger 21 in South Tampa.

Square One is a really tackily decorated restaurant in South Tampa, and they have burgers and other bad-for-you foods. 

My turkey burger was actually better than I expected. Really big, juicy, tasty. I also recommend the sweet potato fries.

I would not go out of my way to go here. But if you are looking for a decent turkey burger, try Square One.

Also I would say this place, although mediocre, is still better than that horrible BurgerFi on Howard.

South Tampa really lacks great burger joints. Sad. It's like the burger fad came and went and in the meantime completely avoided South Tampa.

A solid 4.5 stars.

Very romantic intimate setting...nice bar area. 

Hostess was nice...our waitress was very knowledgeable and attentive.

We started with some goat cheese (leonora), membrillo, and the chorizo pamplona. Excellent. Next we had the black cod, lamp brochetas and kobe beef canapes. Everything was good.

My wife's only complaint (and I agree) was that some dishes were a little heavy on the salt (the lamp brochetas and the sauce with the cod).

But yummy nonetheless!
Will be back!

Oh by the way...dress up...we were semi-dressed up,,,and we certainly cud've taken it up a notch..or 2...and not felt out-of-place.

Upon entering this place is LOUD. Seated promptly but no cushion in the seat. Menu is limited, mostly all day breakfast, sandwiches & burgers. Very few dinner entrees. Charleston Shrimp & Grits ($16.99) and chopped sirloin ($11.95) was average. Soup & salad is not included. No complaints with the food quality but portions are small. This is not really a diner with a huge menu selection, mostly limited comfort food. Competition is fierce. The Warminster West right down the street has fabulous saute dishes with soup & salad included. The Eagle Diner not much further has a full salad bar plus 3 different soups included with dinner. The Metro offers limited value. Give them a try and you decide.

I am not having much luck finding good Thai food here. Pad Thai is a very simple dish to make, and one I really enjoy when eating out. The pad Thai here was not good. The noodles were over cooked and something was just off about the dish. The only reason I gave this place three stars was because of the boba tea! Very yummy and really helped to wash out the odd taste I had in my mouth. Oh, and I'm not sure if this is always the case, but the restaurant had no running AC, so it was uncomfortably hot. My husband also mentioned that the restrooms were very dirty. I don't think we will be returning. Oh well... on to the next one.

This place was so good! I had the lemon grass chicken stir fry and my husband had the sweet and sour chicken. Meals come with either an egg roll or egg drop soup. We had one of each and both were delicious! I can't wait to go back and try the pad Thai!

I visited McKenzie's for lunch and my opinion of the place is favorable overall.

I had a wonderful sandwich of housemade lamb sausage and tzatziki sauce and it was great! The sauce was laid on thick, just the way I like it, and the sausage was like taking bites of a lamb chop. VERY flavorful, but there were some cartilage chunks that I had to spit out. Worth it though, since it was housemade. The chips that came with it were all right and the pickle was no good-- the brine was not at all good. I tried a bite of the chicken pita and it was really fresh and tasty (also with that tzatziki sauce). The service was overall friendly and knowledgeable, too.

Not great. 
Not Bad.
Great if you need a pick me up to walk back to your car. It was really dirty. But I am so having cabin fever this winter! Ahhh

This place is dangerous - you'll bust your budget as you keep picking things off the food and drink menus. We ate at the bar, and loved the experience. We tried the house pickles, 2 grilled skewers, salmon, and tonkatsu, and loved then all. We look forward to our next visit.

I've been here a couple of times and was never really impressed. The service is great, the atmosphere is nice, but the food is just terrible! Everything has always just been really tasteless and has always left me with an upset stomach, definitely not worth it. 

This last time we went, our table was next to the patio doors. My friend and I watched for over 20 minutes two girls, about 6-9 years old, tearing apart the patio, throwing the cushions over the glass, climbing and standing on tables, and kicking chairs over. Parents were nowhere to be seen outside, and staff did nothing to put an end to it, which I can understand, but I would think they would try to find a parent to stop their kids from destroying their patio. 

I just wasn't impressed. No desire to go back.

The spa was very relaxing. Parts of it was outdated but overall pretty nice. In one of the treatment rooms the light squeaked the entire time so that wasn't relaxing. The people at the spa are very nice and welcoming although-whoever answered the phone to book the appointment wasn't the friendliest(maybe she was having a rough day). I did the full day package for my birthday and it was the ultimate relaxation. I enjoyed the facial, the massage, lunch and the herbal wrap. However, I was highly disappointed because my salt scrub was not properly booked. They don't greed a later time of 5:30pm but that time wasn't feasible for me. The manager offered for me to come back in and have it done. The lady at the front desk said it'll be a "promo" and "free of charge" but that's not a favor for me as I already paid for the salt scrub and essentially didn't get what I paid for. Also, safety Harbor isn't close to me so the chances of me coming back is very slim. So, I guess that goes down the drain. Needless to say I'm not happy with that aspect of how things ended.

Better than Geno's. I tried both and found that I definitely enjoy Pat's steaks more.

The cheesesteak was just your average Philly cheesesteak that you could get from any food cart. The bread was correct (Philly bread that was so soft w/o falling apart), and the meat was properly chopped up into small pieces and fried w/ oil. It could be that this was the type of cheesesteak I was used to eat, but I felt that this cheesesteak worked better for me overall because the chopped up pieces of meat from Pat's melted and absorbed the cheese well, giving the entire sandwich a well rounded balance. Nothing special about the onions, and I did not get any other toppings. 

Overall, I think Pat's just packs a bit more flavor and a better texture, given how the meat is cooked. Neither side were particularly polite, although it was somewhat understandable given how long the lines were.

This has been me and Daddy's spot for my whole life. now it's mine and my husband's. This is where I come for some serious comfort food. I have never had a bad experience. Drive-thru or dine in, everything is made to order. Family owned. They're actually from Greece, regardless of who is in the kitchen. Homemade tea and lemonade. They have the meats! $.40 for extra tazikii. They do have TVs. Pepsi soda machine. 23 years in the neighborhood and they aren't going anywhere anytime soon.

Located right on Stearns Wharf, you'll find Longboards Grill which is located on top of another restaurant.  Longboards is a nice chill restaurant that is first come seating throughout.  If it's not too hot sit on the patio for a beautiful view of the ocean.  

We sat alongside the window by the bar (it was hot on the lanai) and we still got a beautiful view.  

So, when you seat yourself, a server will bring the menu to you.  I think the servers are a little slower and not as attentive as I would've liked them to be.  The reason why I say that is when we first sat outside on the patio, we got our menus then no one else approached us to take our order after 10 minutes so we made our way inside (also cause it's cooler).  
Seems that this is a popular place since it's the 1st restaurant on the pier.  

Food: 
New England Clam Chowder
Specialty Burger (I forgot the name-but it had bacon and it wasn't on the menu) with fries
Garlic Bread

The food is mediocre and nothing really stood out.  The fries were just alright too.  :(  

I would return for drinks in the future but would prefer to venture out to the other restaurants on Stearns Wharf for food.

I went here with an open mind and empty stomach -- hoping for a worth while evening. I was there due to an event that was scheduled that night, so one would think the restaurant would have planned ahead for such an occasion. Instead, when we arrived our event was "competing" with another. With such a small space around the bar, there was no reason two events should be coinciding. Though the food was good, it was limited. The beer was fantastic, but the lines were ridiculously long. See the issue here? A thorough organizational meeting is in order. 

If these quirks are worked on, I believe this place could flourish. Until then ... eh.

A group of us came here for a friend's birthday. They had all been there before me, but this was my first time.

Having never had Malaysian food before, I wasn't sure what to expect. To me, it tasted like a cross between Filipino food and Thai food-- right up my alley!

We had the famous pancake appetizer that was just delicious. Fiance likes bacon, so we decided to throw in some shrimp puffs (minced shrimp wrapped in bacon and fried), which were divine as well.

I was a little disappointed with the main entree I got though...beef rendang. I'm not sure if it was because I haven't been craving that much meat in a while (I've been on a chicken kick lately), but it was WAY too much meat! The first few bites were good, but after that...ahh!

The Malaysian iced tea was pretty good too.

I'd definitely go back and give a chicken dish a go though.

My first time here and I already love the place! We went on daiquiri Wednesday, which, to my surprise, also features a live reggae band. Uprising performed and they were amazingly talented, even serenading my friend for her birthday. 

On Wednesdays, the jerk chicken wings are only $1, and that dollar is totally worth it because the wings are huge. The spicy mac and cheese was good also, although a little too spicy for me. 

The bathrooms are clean and have some interesting art on the walls...you know, in case you ladies feel the need to brush up on your Pirate Code knowledge as you relieve yourselves, haha.

I was super happy with this place. The menu had so many yummies I could hardly decide. Ended up getting a ton of appetizers and they were all very good. The pulled pork sandwich is now my usual. This place is great for someone with the munchies as they have a lot of odd fried options. Great scenery and occasionally soft live music. Sit wherever and the staff will come to you, just be careful the birds dont swoop down and snatch your food.

I honestly didn't have the highest expectations but this place is amazing.
The vegan mac and cheese with coconut "bacon" and the tofu sesame noodles I got were surprisingly flavorful. 
This is the best spot in the bay area for locally made chia pudding. Really unique flavors. They have a few dishes being made to order on some days but its mostly grab and go from the fridge. Theres a ton of great options including salads, ready to heat meals and a selection of dry snacks. Well worth the visit and even though I don't live over here I'll definitely be back.

I've been here a handful of times, and have only been happy with one thing that I have gotten (garlic steak).  Burgers aren't as good as they are cracked up to be, and other pastas and such were similarly lackluster.  Each time the service was so-so.

The two young men sit in the Dennys, well after midnight. They talk wildly and scribble in their notepads. They are writing a script for a movie, which will blow everyones minds. Food and coffee get cold, victims of inspiration. The waitress doesnt even bother to see if they need anything anymore. They would go their separate ways, both on this night and in life.

 One, has a wife and young child to go home to. He has responsibilities that render the screenwriter dreams void. The other will follow his dream, take a few small rolls in movies and TV, work behind the scenes of a few productions and finally work making documentaries.

Nothing ever became of the script..., although the family man wouldnt be surprised to see it ( or the many others) pop up in some form someday. It was this memory that pleasantly crossed my mind as I sat in a Dennys recently. The family man being a few shades greyer and a few pounds heavier than he was back then.

I rarely go to Dennys. Its not a conscious decision, I just feel there are always better options. I had worked  8hrs straight through without a lunch, and I was starved and didnt feel like fast food. Not that Dennys is better than fast food, its just that I wanted to sit down and be waited on.

It wasnt crowded so I was sat immediately and was able to order and get my food quickly, which was what Id hoped. The food was decent. I got a bowl of soup, rolls and meatloaf dinner for under $10.  I felt it was a great deal. The chicken soup was just as good as ive had at Panera. The rolls were odd. Between the consistency and the sweet butter, they were closer to cinnamon buns (without the cinnamon). If you cant tell if i liked this or not, I couldnt either. I know my kids would have liked them. The meatloaf wasnt bad. It had to be the hardest, densest meatloaf ive ever had but it was tasty.

 Just a note about bands selling out. Was it really a good PR move, for bands like Plain White Tees and Hoobastank to have meals at Dennys named after them? Im sure all the elderly coulpes there for their senior menus really gave a crap about the "Plain White Milkshake"

But I digress. Basically, I got exactly what I came in for. A quick meal that stuck to the ribs. I also got to relive a good memory. Ill have to get in touch with my friend, the one who left to follow his dream. The one I lived vicariously through. Ive got some good new movie ideas and he just may be in the position now to get them green-lit.

Went to the White Bridge Rd. location and got 2 fish sandwiches, onion rings, seasoned fries and one sprite.  It cost over $18.00!!  The fish sandwich was quite possibly the worst fish sandwich I've ever had.  The fish was way overlooked.  Seemed like it was cooked with plastic on it.  Couldn't even bite through it.  Really gross and a gross waste of money.

I've been wanting to try this place and drove up 15 minutes before closing. Was told they are open but the chef has already put everything away. So I asked if they were open but not serving food and the girl said yeah sorry.  But she graciously told me I can come back tomorrow and get hot dogs for my kids for a buck. Thanks but I was looking for dinner and my kids are adults.  I went to chili's instead. Poor way to run a business.

I seem to be having the same issue with chain restaurants over and over again, due in part to receiving generous gift cards from family. With the price of a meal here and considering there are so many amazing local restaurants in Nashville I cannot fathom why this place is always so packed. It must be the way I cook but both dishes that my husband and I received literally tasted like they had been marinated in salt for days. We had one of the most attentive and overbearing servers I've ever encountered. Water was refilled every 2-3 minutes, chairs were pulled out for us, bread reappeared the second the basket was empty, etc. But when I received my dish and couldn't eat it, I pushed it to the side and shared my husbands. This gesture was ignored by my server, and 2 managers who walked by our table and admired our choices. 

I also feel it's worth saying how rude it is when a hostess goes to seat you and prefaces that you receiving a table is contingent on you finishing your meal by a certain time. I understand that you have reservations but all patrons should be valued.

Really 3.5 but I'm feeling generous. Nice place to meet up with friends before or after a movie. My friend and I met up on a early Sunday afternoon for lunch and ordered a simple meal of drinks and appetizers to share. They are fairly new, so they are still working out the kinks here. I got the calamari, which for just a tad under $10 was pretty pricy for the amount they served. I had to ask for lemon, which seems standard to serve with calamari everywhere else. The two different sauces served were okay, nothing too memorable - in fact, I barely touched either one. My friend's Caprese salad was lovely, nice thick slices of heirloom tomato with little ribbons of basil and thin slices of mozzarella.  

We had one very tiny glitch, which was a misunderstanding on the tip on final bill of $23.  The manager was able to fix it without too much fuss and we were grateful that it was sorted out without drama.

PRO TIP:  Let them know as soon as you sit down if you are headed to the movies so they know if you are concerned about timing. I noticed our waitress wrote down that we needed to leave by 1:15 which was very observant of her.

I'm kind of an Ikea addict.  I come here and walk out with things I don't really need - and that goes for basically any Ikea, no matter where it is in the world!  I've probably been in 10 different Ikeas all over America, and they're pretty much the same.  

I don't think I even own a piece of linen that isn't from Ikea.  

This location is in a pretty good area, but getting back to the main highway is a bit complicated if you are not from this area and don't know the side streets.

2.5
Wow! what a slippery scale of service and food. Having read the reviews of fellow Yelpers, I was looking forward to eating here, especially since I was "scouting" places for potential international dinners I host each month.

Perhaps this was an "off day" or slow-for-some-reason, because we neither had good service, nor great food. 

The eclectic combo of furniture in the gaily decorated interior reminded me of some of the charming restaurants I visited during the two years I lived in South America. (I know El Salvador is Central America...just sayin'.) But what followed in service and food was less than charming.

We each ordered two pupusas. My first was filled with a very traditional queso con loroco (cheese and savory flower of an edible herb, Fernaldia Pandurata). Good but not great. The second was filled with frijoles (beans) - standard and very run-of-the-mill, lacking seasoning. We topped both with the rustically presented in a mason jar, "curtido," a lightly fermented or pickled slaw made with cabbage, carrots, onions which helped. Off to a fair start.

Then came the first hiccup - no fried plantains! Everything else on the menu was available. This seemed an odd occurrence for a Latin restaurant.

Things fell apart a bit even more when I was served very dry, tough beef shanks on a base of lightly fried yuca (not quite raw, but not adequately done either), slaw and assorted raw veggies as garnish. And, oddly, when the server presented it, she simply stuck a fork in the top (see photo I posted). Sorry, I just didn't get this less than stellar dish and its ?casual? presentation.

I was hoping for a lot more, based on comments from friends and fellow Yelpers. But this visit did not live up to their accolades.

I would give this place 5 stars when they first open but it seems to get worst and worst. The prices haven't changed but the portions of our favorite Lox, gets smaller and smaller and 2 out of the last 3 times we went and ask for extra pickle, we got none or 1 out of 2 orders. So they were out of their everything bagel. My wife will not stand up for that and I won't either because of the punishment I'll receive for not bringing her back what she wanted. So...
-1 star for smaller portions.
-1 star for the wraith I'm going to receive from my wife for missing items.
Still the bagels are tasty and the cream cheese are to die for.

Wings are a nice size but it'd be a bit better if they were wetter. I have a lot of trouble with the fact that a skimpy order of onion rings were $5.00. We ordered 3 orders of 10 wings and got an order of 10 and 15. Maybe they were just a wee bit busy with it being Super bowl Sunday.

Came here Saturday night with some friends I haven't seen in a bit.  People do like coming here, and I think it's because it's Stephen Starr.  

The decor is nice and pleasing to the eye, the lighting is somewhat dark, good for ambiance.  The crowd is upscale chic, with a nice dearth of "frat" people (even with the close proximity of Drinkers!).  The music is quite low, so you can easily hear conversation.

We were in the roofdeck, and if you've been once, you've been a thousand times.  The type of crowd that comes in is not eclectic.  You will find good looking people dressed well.  The crowd is not diverse - that's usually a bad thing for me, but the crowd here is much more blase - they were much more into their own conversations than interested in the differences of the types of people.  That's refreshing.  I only notice the diversity if I feel out of place - this place doesn't make you feel that way (unless you're in sweats or dressed inappropriately).

All in all, I wouldn't complain coming here, and I might even be slightly excited, but it wouldn't be my first suggestion when going out.

An old fashioned steakhouse, right here in Indianapolis.  They only have the one real appetizer, the shrimp cocktail.  Get it.  Prepare yourself for the massive amount of horseradish.  I didn't think it was that bad, but my brother thinks that it is tear inducing.  Good nonetheless.

The ribeye was good and flavorful.  The outer ring was amazing, and I wish I could have 24oz of just that...alas, that isn't to be.  Great service.  Bearnaise sauce costs $4.  

Not complaining, but, if a steak is going to cost $45, I think a sauce should be free.  Loading up a baked potato costs extra, but that's because you are getting a good deal of bacon at least.  Overall, worth it for a once in awhile treat though.

Baldini's can't seem to shake the seedyness that has always seemed to be the underlying theme of the place. 

Over the last 15 years I don't think any casino has tried more restaurants, bars, and themes than this one. 

Currently the cafe is pretty decent, the walk up cafeteria is a good price but not great food, and the Occidental is nice. 

The smoking is still overwhelming and gets on your clothes more than most small casinos. 

The customer service varies widely from employee to employee.

Cute little upscale pita place with upscale prices. 

I had the lamb schwarma with lettuce, tomato, and the yogurt curry pour. It was very good...the meat was very juicy and all of the veggies were fresh. The sauce was excellent as well. The rest of the party tried the roasted turkey breast, which was described as being decent, and the curry chicken salad was deemed to be just  "so-so." 

The decor is what I would describe as being upscale industrial. Unfortunately the prices are too. For three pitas and drinks we were over $30. While the food (particularly mine) was really good and I would eat it again, maybe they should rename it Eat$-A-Pita.

Nothing says "clean" like watching your sandwich get made and the line working wipe the knife off on their apron. Look at the video: 01/29/2018 @ 11:54am. Disgusting! 

Not to mention, I wasn't greeted when I walked in the door and then waited at the "order here" register for at least 2 solid minutes before one of the employees broke away from their conversation with the other two employees by the front door. 

By the way, it wasn't busy. Literally me in line and two people in the dining room hanging out. 

Get it together Einstein's!

Had lunch here on a Wednesday.  Comfortable space, great decor.  No wait which was nice.

Service was impeccible.  Many return visits from my waitress, water always topped up.

I ordered the 1905 salad and chicken and yellow rice entree.  It came with cuban bread and butter.  The bread came out hot, it was great.  The salad was excellent.  The deessing was amazing.  I could have had just that for lunch.  Not so impressed with the chicken and yellow rice.  The rice was sticky, similar to korean rice not the light rice I am used to with this dish.  Not bad though.  The chicken was practically inedible though.  Very dry, there werwbparts I could not eat it was hard as a rock.  I expected a lively flavour too.  However it was very bland.  And a small piece of chicken at that.

I would return, but get the cuban sandwich.  I saw many of them come out and they looked really good.

Don't go here expecting the same product to be delivered the same way every time.  I visited a year ago and had some amazing breakfast tacos with crispy strips of bacon, fluffy scrambled eggs, shredded cheese, fresh pico, etc etc.  Returned this past Saturday and was sadly disappointed.  What I received was a dry omelet-type egg loaf with bits of bacon broken into it and cheese melted and dried on top, wrapped in a corn tortilla.  I sent it back and had it removed from my bill and was told by the waitress to show the picture next time and let them know that is what I want.  Seems odd that I would have to explain to them the preparation of the meal.  I ordered it and received it that way before and would think that is how it would always be prepared.

On the bright side, my daughter ordered the fish tacos and devoured them.  She said they were crisp and delicious.  Make sure you squeeze the fresh lime over it!

It has been a long time since I have visited this location. Ironically, I used to come here when I worked nearby. I usually go to the Severn location nowadays but decided to come here for soup. I was surprised at the change or updates done and hope the same will occur at their Severn location. 

I was greeted by several employees which I liked and who doesn't like learning some French words there. I ordered the potato soup as well as the paella. Soup was great along with the paella. If I am in the neighborhood I will visit again!

Now I know what all the hype of deli Towne is all about. This is a quality sandwich. They use super fresh ingredients and they stuff the Sammies full. They've got great, fresh made side selections and delicious baked goods to choose from. It's nice that it's in a gas station so you can one stop shop while you're there, since it does usually take a little bit of time to get your sandwich ready. But despite the wait, the staff are super friendly and helpful, and the food speaks for itself. Probably my new favorite sandwich spot.

When we first arrived, the staff didn't seem too happy to have to deal with our larger party, although we were very understanding and didn't rush them or treat them poorly at all. 

After we sat and got our orders in, the staff seemed to warm up and we were brought our sushi in quick succession. 

We know one of the sushi chefs here, so he brought us a couple special rolls, but overall, everything was very delicious. The fish was fresh and there were so many options to choose from. I really enjoyed their goyza as well. 

Overall, the initial feeling I got from the staff was weird, but they made up for it with their service afterwards and throughout.

The restaurant itself is very cute and clean with a sleek modern style and great views of the river. The staff is extremely friendly,  helpful, and efficient in making suggestions and making sure your order is 100% right. 

The food itself is okay. I got the Hawaiian salmon burger, which was way too saucy. I would have preferred it with either the BBQ glaze OR the ginger vinaigrette, both sauces was just way too much. The slaw on top was very crispy and had a good flavor while the pineapple complimented the salmon burger really nicely, but the sauces were just really overpowering. I made my burger a meal with half/half "fries" and onion rings. Their "fries" are more like chips, little crispy potato discs with soft insides, and while they were salted perfectly, I was lacking the crunchy soft combo of a traditional fry. The onion rings however were perfect, and their ranch dipping sauce wasn't made in house but was far superior of other fast food places. 

We also ordered a strawberry shake that was predominantly syrup, but had a good strawberry flavor when you weren't bombarded by sugary syrup. 

Overall, I would eat here again, but I might ask for sauces on the side in the future and I probably wouldn't order the fries plain again.

Wife and I went here for an early dinner tonight. She had a hamburger and sweet potato fries. She said burger had no flavor, very greasy  and it was served on two bun tops. I ordered the gumbo and the side salad. Gumbo was definitely not gumbo. No okra, It had what seemed to be left over brisket and pulled pork in it. I sent it back.

Our server (Did not get his name) was great and very attentive.  We ate inside which is still somewhat in the open and had quite a few flying insects, flies, bees.

We came here shortly after they opened here some years back. We only returned because of recommendations from a friend. Sorry we won't be returning.

Excellent twist on Mexican food. Favorite restaurant in this town
Crispy shrimp tacos or excellent.

First time trying the Sunrise Cafe. The portion size for breackfast was really good. My Carnitas Huevo Rancharo was a solid three. My wife had the Philly Cheese Steak and it was a 4 star. Presentation was good, sandwich had to much bread but the fries were awesome. We will be back to give it another shot and will update you then.
It wasn't a great sit down place to eat, the restaurant has old oil fragrant.

Always a great value when you order through the Dominoes App. They have coupons loaded into the menu, so you know you're always getting the best deal. I always get a gluten free pizza with light cheese, red sauce and veggies. The chicken & philly steak are really good toppings too!
The lobby is usually hot and it's pretty small, so we always order ahead. They always have the pizza ready when we schedule it, so that's super nice! The employees are pretty friendly and the pizza is always hot & fresh.
Delicious cinnamon rolls and cookies...all vegan.  Looking forward to trying their large lunch menu options

My wife and I stumbled into this place as we were looking for a new steak joint to try out for our anniversary. Without reservation, they were able to seat us promptly and started serving us swiftly. The overall atmosphere was elegant with very dim lights and full of guests. I found it a tad bit difficult to read the menu as it was fairly dim. Wait staff was very  attentive with providing service, as well as bussing dishware from the table.

For starters, my wife and I ordered the fried green tomatoes with crabmeat which was delicious. Nicely fried without the feeling of being too oily. Also ordered the onion rings to accommodate my steak, which was the Ribeye that was cooked perfectly. My wife ordered the shrimp and lobster pasta, which unusually was mildly sweet. We were unsure of it was supposed to be sweet, but we usually tend to not complain. For sides, we've ordered the potato au gratin and Freddie Mac and cheese which were both nicely prepared. Some of the potatoes were undercooked, but edible.

5 stars to overall atmosphere and making us feel welcomed. I would definitely come back in to try other dishes, perhaps a bigger steak!

I went here for a bridal shower so it's hard to say how the regular experience is. The room we were housed in was very hot and a bit stuffy and uncomfortable; it left my friend and I feeling drowsy by the time entrees came around. Considering, though, that it was such a huge party (probably 60 people at least) I was fairly impressed by the service: everyone was fed around the same time, waiters came by often to refill water and drinks, and all of the employees I met were friendly and polite, and very patient, especially with the chaotic scene before them.

The food, however, was just average. The bruschetta that was handed out as an appetizer was delicious--I would have been happier if I could've stuck with that. The caesar salad was gross. The dressing was watery and tasteless and it had ONE crouton buried underneath it. There was also the roughly grated Kraft-type Parmesan sprinkled on top. Very disappointing! I had chicken parm, which was soggy (I'll let this slide a bit because for so many dishes, I'm sure things had to sit out for a bit), but tasted good. The vegetables, unfortuantely, were a soggy inedible mess, and by that time, I was too full to even try the little bit of noodles on the side.

All in all, based just on the food, I can't say I would come back.

We usually go to the restaurant in Myrtle Beach and  a few years ago had decided not to go back since the food and drinks were really not that good and certainly not worth the usual long wait. However, this is Nashville and it was lunchtime and we were hungry and there was no wait. Glad we went. We got seated right away and had some delicious Landshark on draft which is always a good start! My daughter had Coconut shrimp which was delicious. I ordered the Fish Tacos. Our server recommended upgrading to Mahi Mahi which I did- great choice!

Were back in Nashville and came in again for brunch. We enjoyed a delicious meal. I had a Garden Omelet with grits. My husband had the special which was Berry French Toast. My daughter had Butter Pecan Pancakes. Everything was so delicious. Service and atmosphere is splendid. Thanks for a great meal.

This is one of those spots in the city where even if you only get a chance to eat there once, you'll never forget it. 

Firstly, the aesthetic of the interior is this cool modern play on traditional chinese culture. Their walls are covered with this graffiti style art, and there are lanterns and lights hung throughout. Just a ton of positive energy as you walk through the door. 

You can't go wrong with anything menu. Whether you are looking for dumplings or noodles, they have yummy options for both vegetarians and meat eaters. 

The dish that stole the show for us was their egg custard dessert. This is a MUST get.

While Passyunk is covered with all different types of restaurants and cuisine, you want to put this at the top of this list.

You just can't go wrong at Buddakan!

You walk in, and it is just this huge open room, with high ceilings (they need it to fit the 10ft. buddha statue - which is really cool.) Lots of tables and energy in the restaurant. 

Their menu is HUGE, and really fairly priced for their appetizers, dim sum, noodles, etc. The portions are great too, you'll likely have leftovers. Their main entrees a little pricey, but you can easily avoid them if you aren't looking to spend a ton of money and get a few smaller plates. The flavors though are poppin' on every meal.

Desserts and drinks are must gets - worth the indulgence. They have really cool Asian influences to them.

One of our go-to spots on Frenchmen St.  Awesome bands. I have never been here and NOT enjoyed the music. We have heard awesome Blues bands, Reggage Bands, R & B bands... you name it.  No cover ever. The drinks I am not impressed with. I prefer well crafted cocktails. They don't seem to have those here. Best bet order  a bottle of beer. The people watching is always great. I have never had any of the food offered in the back,  but have heard first hand that it is really good & affordable.

Last few weeks, one night a week, I have been eating Indian from Monsoon. I order take out for dinner, usually the Chicken Biryani, Chicken Tikka Masala, Samosas, and Paneer Tikka Masala. Last couple of weeks, Friday night (05/20/16) and Saturday night (05/14/16), the taste has been somewhat off. Did they get a new chef? I don't know. 
The samosas from the appetizer menu were just awful, and the green chutney they came with had a funky smell; not the way it used to be. The appearance and filling inside the samosas was totally different from what I had bought only a few weeks ago.
The tikka masala wasn't as smooth and creamy as the previous times either. It was a little greasier, and coarser in texture, and tasted slightly different from what it used to be. So, this was my favorite Indian restaurant in the area for the past few months, but I'm gonna have to take a break from this place for some time.
It is what it is. Not exactly fine dining but it'll do for a quick bite on a week night. Ok food and good service.

I went to Grimaldi's over on Campbell just north of Broadway with my son for lunch today and I normally would skip a review of chain pizza but Grimaldi's boasts a higher level or "gourmet" pizza with a wine list.  Overall it was a very HIGH/LOW experience and I can't see giving Grimaldi's  a 3rd star because Yelp says that 3 stars is A-OK and this place as a whole is not A-OK.Time to explain...

          I was so eager to try this place and we arrive at 2:30pm or so and upon arrival we are greeted warmly by who seemed to be the host (actually was the Manager, Mari),  were seated and soon after greeted by our server, Bryce.  There are only 3 other tables in the restaurant going at this time.  Bryce is the best part of our experience and gets 5 Stars for her service.  I told her that it was our first time there and that I had a free 18"pizza coupon.  Bryce energetically replied with, "That's Awesome!" which is the reply you are supposed to get instead of the eye roll and the sigh that a lot of young servers give instead.  Bryce is the same exact person I want to serve me at every restaurant I go to.  She is young, very pretty, very attentive, and knows the menu.  Bryce said she had been there a little over 3 years.  Grimaldi's has an enjoyable dining area, not that big but they also have patio dining.

     Looking at the menu I see the prices are a little high for pizza but manageable and they do have a wine list which most pizza places don't offer.  A large 18" is $16 and medium 16" for $14 with 2 and 4 dollar toppings.  So, we order a large pizza with half plain and half bacon.  First time at a pizza place and I always get a plain pie to see what they have to offer.  We order a 1 liter of SanPellegrino as our beverage for $6.

     So far everything is looking great and if I stopped right here we are looking at 4.5 star rating.  However, the problems start here.  The bottle of Pellegrino is brought to the table with nicely frosted glasses but unsealed.  I don't mean to sound picky but if you go to any restaurant and order a sealed product, that product should come to the table sealed and opened in front of you and Pellegrino is an easy screw cap so there are no bottle opener issues. The sparkling water (by no surprise) was missing the sparkle and we were not offered lime or lemon.  If you ever had Pellegrino then you know that this stuff really packs a punch on the effervescence and you gotta be tough to chug a bottle.

     The pizza comes very soon after and too soon really because I don't think the best pizza chef in the world could make a pizza in less than 10 minutes and have it be served barely above COLD!  Or barely warm. So was it a pre-made pizza that was reheated or just sat there when not busy?  Not sure but it came out way so fast to not be piping hot when served and having to wait a few minutes to eat it.  Also, why not serve Pellegrino opened table side.  Either it wasn't Pellegrino or refilled somehow which doesn't make sense because I think their largest bottle is a 1 liter.  It's hard to say because I don't remember having flat Pellegrino before.

     More on the pizza.  The crust is extremely thin, the thinnest I have ever had and it's not filling at all.  I was told that this is "Brooklyn Style" pizza and uh......dunno 'bout that.  I am from New Jersey and I have been to New York many times and never had a pizza like this before and my favorite food is......You guessed it, PIZZA.  I won't say the Brooklyn reference is wrong because like I said, first timer but those guys tossing pies in the New York and New Jersey locations of Grimaldi's would be offended by what I was served.

     The other hero of the day is Mari who was also great comes out with 2 500ml bottles of Pel and says sorry and takes it off the bill but the quality was the same.  Very nice of her to do but I mentioned it was flat and not opened table side and I get 2 more bottles not opened at the table?

     The sauce was sweet but OK. I like the slices of cheese instead of the shredded, nice touch.  I know it's Tucson, AZ but why was the dough dry but doughy with no "snap" to it at all. Reheated pizza slices still have the snap.  I also reviewed another pizza place and when you bite in to one of those slices you get that snap.  Not here I didn't for almost double the price and almost half of the food.  The plain cheese pizza tasted OK I guess and maybe would've been better if it was hot.  The bacon topped pizza tasted like bacon.  I know you can never have enough bacon because bacon is awesome but not here.  The pizza is so thin that the bacon took over and that's all what was tasted.

     In closing I want to say that Bryce offered us a whole fresh pizza AFTER my son and I ate.  Unbelievable and fabulous service to offer that.  I thanked her and declined the offer because her offering was enough for me and promised Bryce I would give them another shot and I will before my final verdict is given on Grimaldi's of Tucson

Used to love stopping here for lunch before flights but the service is so bad now.

Tottering older guy would NOT bring my drink. I put in my order, 14 minutes later he came back to ask me what I ordered. 

Then I got the wrong food!

Trying to make a plane here and this poor service is not acceptable

I like the cup for its fresh and satisfying meals with a welcoming indoor/outdoor and dog-friendly environment.  It seems to bask in a neighborly restaurant appeal.  However I've strolled there two Saturdays now with my dog for breakfast and told to wait for 20 minutes for a seat but I could seat myself immediately at the bar.  I say I can't do the bar as I'm with my dog.  I wait outside and the whole time there are several empty tables and I'm just waiting.  Twice I leave because there's only so long I'm going to wait for breakfast on a whim.  They've lost my business twice because they say they are too busy outside but not inside.  I don't get it.  Give me a coffee and let me wait while I'm being caffeinated.  Ive never been to a popular breakfast place that was too busy yet had empty tables.  I feel there's a disconnect between hostess and business manager.  Since when are empty tables good for business and not only was I discouraged twice, but less interested in repeating that experience a third time.

Soupy tacos. 

Maybe it was because I got the mushroom tacos? Either way, my friend's tacos were also soupy and it was a little weird. The salsa also wasn't spicy enough. 

However, the corn tortilla was delicious! I wouldn't recommend getting the mushroom tacos because you could definitely just make those on your own.

Great food, buzzing brunch place. The place was packed so we waited 40 min for a table but got to enjoy delicious bloody Mary's while we waited. The service was quick and efficient yet friendly and the food was very good. I had the florentine omellete, while my friend had the pulled pork eggs Benedict on a biscuit. We were all happy and will definitely visit again

I was looking at the other reviews and kept thinking to myself man this really is not a pizza place.  In fact I don't think I ever purchased a pizza from Balducci's.  To me it is a  restaurant.  I just went there for who knows how many times.  Could it have been 50?  I bet is has.  I had their Mayfair dressing on the salad.  It is so tasty for the those not from the Lou Mayfair is the St. Louis version of Cesar dressing.  Since I was very hungry on this visit I ordered the hamburger.  It came with Swiss cheese lettuce pickles can't remember if it had an onion or not.  The burger was cooked to order and came seasoned with a good amount of pepper.  I love pepper and the taste it imparts to a good burger.  The burger also had fries the curly type.  Not a curly fries kind of guy but they did taste very good.  On a side note the waitress did offer to exchange my fries for the salad for my side.  I said no I was err hungry.  Just great food.  Also at my table one person had the french dip and another had a pizza.  From looks only the dip seemed to be a better choice than the pizza.  So I guess in my mind this is not a pizza place but almost a full service restaurant.

Going back over the years I have had most of the pasta's and sandwiches and cannot remember a bad meal.

One caveat this place does get crowded for lunch and it is a tight fit.  i guess you can call it atmosphere.

I came here the day after Thanksgiving.  The high points was the toasted ravioli and the service.

I ordered the Osso Bucco  and was disappointed.  It is a pork shank which is fine with me.  The Osso Bucco was served with polenta and asparagus.  The shank while tender was very dry and had no flavor. If  it came with potatoes and a decent sauce it would have helped the dish.   But the sauce was almost dried on the plate.  Not making my list of places I really want to do over.  Way too many other places to try.

I went with International Supper Club to The Atomic Cowboy.  The service ISC demands is hard on any server and ours did a great job.  She accommodated with a smile and wonderful service.  The one thing I always learn from these events is to order what Mark P ordered.  As usual I did not.  I had the Mexican Spaghetti with two smallish chorizo meatballs.  What makes this dish Mexican is the cumin they put in the sauce.  It was a $15.00 dish but really was not a ton of food.  So value must be gathered in other dishes.  I would strongly suggest looking at the burritos.

We go here pretty regularly, like a couple times a month. The food is decent, but their wait times suck, & the customer service isn't great. They often ask me to pull into a parking space from the drive-thru because they don't have something ready; Tonight, I ordered 2 sandwiches, 2 fries, & a plain ham & cheese kids' meal for my picky 2 year old. (They charged me extra for the cheese. Not only did it come w/o cheese, it came WITH mayo, lettuce, & pickles - a fact I didn't realize until I got home & tried to feed it to him - yes, it was on my receipt "plain, no mayo"). They told me the fries had 1 minute & 58 seconds left, & asked me to pull forward - 7 minutes later they walked my meal out to my car; 1 large fries was hot, one was cold; the hot meatball sub must've been waiting on the counter while the fries finished, because it was lukewarm. When I got home, I tried to call to let them know about the error & give them a chance to make it right - no one answered the phone; I called twice.t

I decided I wanted an oyster poboy and French fries. I called Parasol's and ordered. I was told to wait 25 min to pick up my food. I arrived early and sat in my car for 15 min.
