When I went in, there was no one in the restaurant and no one in the bar. (I am not sure why it took 25 min.) I was shocked at the price...$22.50. I know the price of oysters is high right now, but WOW. The poboy was about 8 inches long with a sparse amount of oysters. I will not be going back.

Spent a Saturday night at Hippot for my nephews 21st birthday.   There were 8 of us and ordered just about everything on the menu.   The food was fresh, fun and pretty good.

Of all of the dishes we had there were none that were terrible nor fantastic but would certainly return.

Downside is bar selection.

Chile rellenos in the Tucson Area rated according to the Homeland Security Advisory System with three word descriptors.

Micha's: nice canned chile. Green

See photos.

Tried this place recently for the first time with my wife and a friend.  I hadn't heard much about it but was excited to give it a shot after looking over the menu.

It has a small dining area, and looks like there may be seating outside during the warmer months.  The menu is posted above the main counter where you place your order.  I went with the curried goat.  

The meat, served over rice like a true curry, was fall off the bone tender.  Literally, the bones were everywhere.  Whoops.  No big deal, but attention to detail!  Unless you're advertising a rack of goat.. sounds funny.. get those bones out of there!  The flavor was ok.  No part of it was overly flavorful, not even the presence of curry.  The rice was also overcooked.  Honestly, I'd like to give it another try but not sure if I will.  If I do I will update my review.

Service was great, but the food was not.  They actually put ham in their biscuits and gravy which myself and my wife were not a fan of.  I had the Mexican omelette which was not good.  I love spicy food but it was so hot I couldn't eat it and the chorizo sausage was ground up to where it was almost like it was ground beef.  Manager did stop by a few times, but it was so early when we got our food that we really didn't get a chance to any of it by then to give him feedback.  We paid $28.50 for food we didn't eat.  We did say something to the waitress because we didn't even eat half of the food.  Nothing was done to correct the mistake.  There are better places out there.  Next time I'll just go back to flap jacks. I am a little nervous about getting sick because another review mentioned sour sausage and after eating here me and my wife are starting to feel sick.

Friends moved to Jenkintown recently so we tried out this place for breakfast. Wait was a little long but there were 5 of us and it was Sunday morning. Small place, close tables. Service was friendly, I think it was the owner greeting people. The food was pretty good, I got the wag eggs Benedict. Came with thick toast, Canadian bacon and poached eggs. Good spot to soak up the drinks from the night before. Didn't get to eat them today but pumpkin pancakes sound delicious. Will try to get back here and try more things.

I have to be honest and say that the meal I ordered for brunch (corn beef hash) was pretty terrible. When the dish came out, it looked pretty in its individual cast iron skillet. The first bite, however, tasted of pure salt. I know corned beef is naturally salty but this was on another level. I could only take a few bites before my mouth was stinging from all the salt. That almost never happens because frankly, I devour food and I especially love salty food. I did take the almost untouched meal to go and did eventually eat if, after I threw in some potatoes and things to balance the saltiness. 

I was excited to try this place out and I think the regular dinner menu is likely better. A friend of mine says so, anyway. Unfortunately, the whole thing left a salty (pun intended) taste in my mouth and I doubt I'll return voluntarily.

This hotel is a paradox...beautiful visually but absolutely one of the worst run hotels I've ever visited. This was our 2nd visit. We were hoping the first visit was just an anomaly so we gave it another go this past weekend. What a nightmare! I'll never visit this hotel again. First, I checked in online. I figured that should help expedite the check-in process. NOPE! Then I had to wait in a line in the lobby where there was only one kiosk open for online check-ins...on Labor Day weekend. Smart right? This was an hour wait. There were only 8 parties in front of me. At this one kiosk were 3 hotel employees.....3....all with zero urgency. Then, we learned we had to wait in another line to get our Soundwaves passes...another hour lost. What the hotel doesn't realize is this is counter-intuitive to making money. If the guests are in lines all day, they're not spending more money at the hotel. Very stupid hotel managers. Then, upon check-in, we're told our room isn't ready yet. Now, check-in is at 3pm. However, we didn't get our room until 5:15. Again, really poor management. There were a number of other issues to note but my last rant has to do with dining. There are a number of restaurants inside the hotel. We made our way to the closest one first to have dinner. It had a 45 minute wait. We have 2 little kids. No way 45 minutes is going to cut it. So we walked to the next one. Same thing. And the next one...oh yeah...it was closed. They have monitors located around the hotel lobbies intending to show the wait times for the restaurants. There's only one problem. They only indicated if the restaurant was open or closed. When the property is so large that walking to all of the restaurants is a cumulative total of a mile and a half, the last thing you want to learn is that there are no sets available at any of the restaurants for a least 45-60 minutes. This hotel has no concept of crowd management. I overheard 2 other parties very upset of the long wait times, the constant lines everywhere and the poor signage leading to extensive walking. We won't be back.

Decent tex-mex food with a great margarita selection. They have some specials almost any day. The salsa that comes with chips & salsa is bangin! Their entree prices range from $10-20. I would suggest at least giving it a try.

There is a certain type of night that I go to PJs for- whenever I'm craving some wings and a beer! Keg and kitchen has better sized wings but PJs are consistent in quality. Decent array of sauces too. Check out the game and girls here!
"Steak fajitas.were mostly green and red peppers. sour cream looked like mayo. blaring music in background. won't go back."

This is my third or fourth trip to Hoshun and I have enjoyed the food there.  I wanted to go with hubby and two small kids for my birthday meal.  I was totally disappointed today.

I'll start with the good--the bartender in the back was friendly (according to hubby) and gave us a shirley temple for my son for free and big, strong drinks (bloody mary for me, vodka soda for hubby).

However, they have no clue how to cater to a family with kids.  We went at 5:30 p.m. on a Saturday, not exactly prime time.  The place was pretty much empty.  They sat us at a booth, which was fine, but difficult to maneuver my 9 month old in a booster seat with no straps.  They offered to move us, and I thought it would be fine.

My toddler is admittedly rambunctious; however, we asked if they had paper and crayons.  They did not.  No big deal, but when I gave my son the copy-paper sushi menu (we weren't having sushi) to draw on, our server insisted he give it back to her ("Can I have that back?" to a 3 year old--really?).  

The food was fine--it generally is.  We had the dinner combination platters--one General Tsao's and one sweet and sour chicken, both with brown rice.  The General Tsao's was spicy in a good way and the chicken in both dishes is good quality and large pieces.  There is not a ton of rice, but that's not just Hoshun; it's tough to get  a lot of rice anywhere.  The hot and sour soup was good with lots of mushrooms and tofu.  I had a crab and crawfish rangoon that was good and an egg roll that was so-so.

So, as we are paying and gathering up to go my son was trying to drink out of my hubby's vodka dredges and being in the huge booth, I couldn't reach him.  The server was back and overheard me asking him to not drink that.  She asked him to help her clean the table and asked for the glass.  Then she turned to me and (unkindly) said, "was that good enough?  You know, you really have to ask them to help you, it's really the only way to get them to do anything."  What, Ms. Surly 20-year old?  Now you're giving me parenting advice?

So, it's unlikely I'll be back unless it's for take-out.  The food is okay, but I'd rather go elsewhere with my business.
The cheese-steak was okay.  The onions they added were good but they were chintzy with the provolone.  The hot sauce was very hot.

We went o Agave Bar and Grill for the first time today, and I was very impressed.  Every aspect of the experience was top-notch.  I had the Carnitas, which is a slow-roasted pork dish.  The pork was very tender and full of flavor, with fresh corn tortillas.  Service was outstanding, and the interior was nicely decorated.  The decor blends well with the art gallery look & feel of the Main Street area.  My wife had the Tacos de Carne Asada, which I found to be authentic and reminiscent of the thousands of tacos I've had in Guadalajara.  Real Mexican tacos, of course, are pretty simple.  Small corn tortillas, chopped flank steak, chopped onions and cilantro - that's all you need.  We also had the fresh guacamole, along with the flautas.  I can't say enough about this place.  It was really wonderful and a pleasant surprise.

Let me get right to the point.  The food was about what I expected, which means, it was about a B+ grade.  There are tons of slightly higher-end Mexican restaurants around now, and the food quality at Verde was in line with my expectations.  Not great, but better than most of the competition out there.  I had two complaints though:

1)  Attention all restaurants, everywhere:  Appetizers and soups (especially soup) must come out BEFORE the main course, not at the same time.  BEFORE.  BEFORE.

2)  Good LORD it was noisy in there.  Come to this restaurant on a Friday night, and you will yell at your companions all night, or else your companion(s) won't hear you.  Yes, the restaurant must accept full responsibility for this, for two reasons:  A) You chose to put in that concrete floor, with no sound treatment on the walls.  B) You chose to blast loud music all night.  Yes, I understand that in every culinary school in the country, they're apparently teaching prospective restaurant owners that silence is bad, and that it implies your guests aren't enjoying themselves.  That's why every restaurant keeps amping-up the noise and the music, so as not to seem boring to the Millennials.  But, come on people - enough already.  Turn down the music and then buy some of those foam sound treatment panels that they sell to recording studios and High School band rooms.

Just start with any one of those two things, and I'll be back.  I can easily overlook the premature soup thing, since you just opened, and it will undoubtedly take time to get all the glitches ironed out.  No problem at all.  But, the 300-decible sound level I won't excuse.  I don't want to get too graphic here, but my ears felt better after a rock concert than they did Friday night when I got home.

I've been to Blaze several times in the last year and a half, and I'm definitely a fan of this new 'Subway' style format for pizza.  At Blaze, their ingredients are always fresh, and the service always seems to be pretty good.  

I do have one suggestion:  The area where you pickup your pizza is too small.  A backlog of people always forms around that area, blocking access to the fountain drink dispensers.  I don't know what can be done about it, but it does get pretty challenging at peak times of the day, like noon and 6pm.  

Other than that, I recommend the red spicy sauce on the Link-In.  It's outstanding.

So true to their nautical theme, they serve food reminiscent of an 18th century whaling ship. Go for the hardtack. 
An extra star for not being busy during dinner hours.

Thai is possibly my favorite cuisine. For some odd reason it's my comfort food. Pass me a Tom yum soup, spicy noodles, and I'm a happy soul. 
As I continue my search for good thai in the area I came across a little Thai kitchen.

Overall it's a good spot. Large portions, well priced and friendly staff. The food doesn't scream good though. It's okay... I wish their tom yum and pad Thai weren't so sweet. I need that savory flavor!

Im honestly a little embarrassed that Im leaving this review so lately. Here I am thinking I'm updating my review when reality I failed my yelp game . 

This relationship spans over 6 years. Lots of history between Gagan palace and I. This was one of my first south jersey gems when I moved down here. A little taste of soul filling Indian cuisine. Before their large space now, it was a fairly small restaurant seating maybe 20-30 people at best. Good times- cant say I've dined in since their expansion. 

Ive done so much takeout from here and have tried so many of their dishes. All so delicious. Literally everything so good. Over the years I have noticed some of there main street dishes like tikka masala have become less flavorful (knocking them down a star). I wish it tasted as authentic as it once did. Regardless still delicious and amazing staff.

We came in and looked at the buffet. It looked a little worn for a 2pm Sunday afternoon. So we decided to order from the menu. The cucumber salad wasn't anything we expected lettuce drenched in their version of tzatziki sauce. The saganaki came out and no fire at the table. I had the mixed grill and it was okay. Nothing spectacular and I've had some pretty amazing mixed grills at Argentinian and Brazilian restaurants so by that measure it didn't even come close. But the rest of our party seemed to enjoy their food. Yet they were doing a pretty brisk business with people coming in for takeout. Overall it wasn't too expensive for 4 adults and a child.

I don't know why all the low votes for this place. Then again it was my first time in a Steak and Shake. Loved the sit down service. Food was excellent. Service efficient. Shakes were to die for. It has been a long time since I've had a good banana milkshake. I will be back!

Im ganna start this review in a weird way but who cares...i just gotta start by saying that their cheese queso is some of the best queso ive ever tried. Came here for a quick lunch and had a nice time. Got the loaded tots to start and they were great. A little small but a very nice app with amazing queso lol. For lunch got the pulled pork sandwich which was average id say but got queso on the side for the fries which was a great call. 
Bar is cool and has a unique look with stickers and sharpie everywhere. They had some live music which was very loud so we sat in the back. Bartender was a little nasty but she was the only one bartending and had a pretty full lunch crowd. 
Overall a decent spot to stop for a bite to eat at a reasonable price.

I don't know if it was the peculiar smell (geriatric home??)  in here that turned me off or what, but I was not impressed with Millers. 
I was looking for something remotely healthy to order here and when I saw that their salads had more calories than a cheeseburger and french fries, guess what I went with? 
I always thought that one can't go wrong with a burger but I was wrong. Their cheesburger was flavorless, and served on a dried out kaiser roll and the food was luke warm. The french fries could've been better if they were hot, but they were sort of cold.  My friend ordered a salad which looked really good, but I'd have to save up my calories for a day if I wasn't trying to diet (siiiigh).
Aside from the odor of the restaurant, it appeared to be clean and the service was good which is why I would come back if I wanted a few drinks and fried food.

I wanted to give it a 2 1/2. This was our 1st visit. Heard it was this awesome place so we had to give it a try.  $63.68 lunch for 2 w/ tip (20%).  2-cokes, 1-diet, 2-baby lobster, 1-baby shrimp & 1-baby fish soft Taco.  4 baby soft taco's & 2-soft drinks for $64 bucks w/ complimentary chips & salsa.  The tortilla's were those baby ones. Notice I keep stressing the "baby" part.  The Lobsters were $7.95 each I believe.  It came w/ smothered onions.  Anything extra is a la carte. I added sour cream, guacamole, rice & beans & before I knew it I had a $13 taco.  The chips were very fresh & the salsa was tasty but came in this tiny little bowl. I think there is a "tiny" theme here.  If you wanted more salsa that would be extra so just wet the chip, no scooping or you'll run out on the 5th chip. The rice & beans came on the plate & the sour cream & guacamole came in those tiny bowls.  The tortilla's are so small that you can't put much on them so 1 sour & quac would have been enough for both of us to share.  If nothing extra was added the taco's were just ok.  There was a decent amount of fish, shrimp & lobster on the taco but again, they were baby ones so 4 pieces of shimp & your taco was loaded.  The server Mari was great. All in all the place was just ok.  The price was WAY to high for what we got.
The cruise was very nice and the lunch was excellent, well worth the two hour boat ride.  I took a ton of pictures of the port traffic and the shore.

Review is not for the food. Came here because reviews on here are pretty good. My server was very nice but didn't seem too efficient. Although the staff was inviting, the place was not in my opinion. Shades drawn and place rather dark. Not a warm feeling. It was more frustrating than anything just to get a cup of coffee. I decided not to start my day off being aggravated so opted to leave. Wish them well. Not my type of place. I wanted to like it. Oh well.

We stumbled upon this place on our way to somewhere else. So glad we did. Scored two bar seats and watched the wild card game. Rob was our bartender. He was awesome. Very pleasant, informative and attentive. Great beer selection too. Onion rings for $5 were a very pleasant surprise.  Fries pretty good too. Will def stop back here.

I was at the King of Prussia Mall on Sunday around 1pm, then I remember that the fyers were playing.  I went to the neareast bar I could find.  I ended up at the Rock Bottom Restaurant and brewery.  We were seated right away and near a big ass TV just as I requested.  
I order beer and a shrimp and crabcake mountain to start. I was a little disappointed with the mountain since it was more like a hill but it was tasty.  The I ordered a Blackn chicken sandawch with home made chips,, It hip tthe spot .  The waitress was very nice and on point with her service the manager was walking around making sure that everything was in order and at some point I noticed that he was also helping with food service which it saids a lot to me about how he care for the clientel. 
For game watching this place is the place to be, well when at the mall that is.  

I will def come back to this place.

It was a bit of a rough morning after the first night of a bachelor party I was down here for, so when a few of us rolled into this local cafe, I was mainly expecting to take down some food to help me fight through the hangover. It's got a very casual, local feel to the joint - you can pretty much sit where you want, whether it's at the assortment of tables inside or on the few that are out on the sidewalk corner. The breakfast menu is relatively standardized, though with a local flair to the items. I went with the scrambled eggs and citrus-poached salmon and was pleasantly surprised - it wasn't the freshest filet of salmon I've ever had, but the citrus flavor really tastes quite good, particularly in the morning paired with eggs. The scrambled eggs were also pretty well-executed - fluffy and slightly runny. I was also a fan of the $3 glass of OJ, which didn't look fresh-squeezed (at least since it came out of a carton), but it wasn't from concentrate, and nothing helps jump-start you like a good dose of Vitamin C.

The baked goods did look good, but I was in no mood to contemplate eating sweets in the shape I was in. However, this is a solid breakfast spot that has good prices and serves up American breakfasts with a strong local influence. I'd stop by for a casual breakfast again if I was in the area.

Had lunch here with Yoga group. Very nice place, everyone seemed to enjoy their food. Plus we had a FREE sampling of Pumpkin Spice Ale. All beers are brewed on site and free sample of any one. Lots of fun.

When you go to a restaurant for the first time, first impressions mean everything.  I knew that we would not be seated until the other couple that we were with arrived.  I had read someones post on that.  What I did not need was a hostess scolding me that we could not be seated, not one but both of them.  The entry area was hot as Hades, with floor fans blowing air, we told them that we had to be seated where it was cool and we were told that they would put us in the far area of the restaurant, which had a different name?  Five minutes later, the hostess seated us and still was not very pleasant.  The meal was very good, price very reasonable but they only had one waitress for the whole area and recall was not good at all.  Had to ask for tea and water on multiple occasions.  When I rate a restaurant, I start with the attitude that it is 5 star, things that happen during the evening can only lower the rating.  By the way, one of the servers spilled half the sauce from my dish onto my friend's wife's purse and leg; while bringing her plate to her and balancing mine, in the same hand.  Never took mine back to add sauce to it.  Also a large group at the bar was very noisy, right behind me,  The lack of lighting required us to use our phones to read the menu.

Not really what I would call thai, more of a Chinese reastaurant with some 'Thai' dishes. I'm a big fan of masaman and yellow curries yet their yellow curry was bland and pasty. Service was bad, had to get up to get my own silverware and boss man gave me a dirty look when I asked for napkins and begrudgingly handed me one napkin from the stack.

The toasted Ravioli, cheese garlic bread, and Caesar salad were all good. Haven't had tortellini in years and just remembered why. It's soooooo salty. I tried to eat as much as possible, but threw in the towel early which is very unusual for me not to finish my meal. The service was okay. Guess when you order cheese garlic bread you don't receive the complementary French bread which is no problem because we had plenty of food, but honestly think our waiter just forgot. My girlfriend got baked lasagna which she stated was mostly cheese and sauce over A noodle. The guys were both satisfied with their chicken Marsala and tutto mare. I was not  impressed and sadly would have preferred pasta house. Maybe I just got the wrong thing, but it took me 29 years to experience Italian food on the hill so I'm sure it will take about 29 more years to return.

This spot is hopping. This must be a local favorite. Call ahead for reservations even on weekdays. 

Everything we ordered was good. 

I ordered the bbq salmon. Salmon was perfectly cooked. The arugula with the white BBQ sauce was interesting. I'm not sure if I'd order it again. 

The salads were fresh and tasty.

The flourless chocolate tort was so indulgent with the coffee cream sauce. I'd highly recommend! 

They are so gluten free options. GF isn't indicated with a little asterisk.

I went here just before the 2020 Nyx parade began and wow I wasn't expecting much (given that I just bought for so I could use the bathroom) but this was still such a let down. I took two bites of the mac and cheese and threw it away because it literally wasn't worth the calories. It tasted like nothing. Easily the least cheesy mac and cheese I've ever had the misfortune of eating. The chicken sandwich was better but not by much. I got the wheat bun which promptly fell apart after I added the barbecue sauce to it. Thankfully the barbecue sauce was pretty good  but that sandwich would've been beyond bland without it so if you opt to get the smoked chicken sandwich definitely get sauce for it. Or, I'd recommend saving your time and going to a local fast food eatery which dare I say will have better quality food for the same price.

I wanted to give a 3.5. Food is hit or miss on flavor. The chicken satay had no flavor and the pho soup was not pho. The burgers, pad thai , and most of the sampler platter were tasty. I would come here again because hubs and I can do Asian food while the kids can get American food. Oh and a shout out to the amazing young white kid running the show. He was the waiter, bus boy, take out and counter person.

This is purely based off of their catering, but these guys are pretty good. We had a large event, over 200 people, and needed breakfast on short notice. The day before, we called and ordered, no issues. 
The pastries are top notch quality, especially for the price, and the fruit salad and cream cheese platters they gave us were displayed fancily. You also get way more than enough cream cheese for all the bagels, which is a rarity with other breakfast caterers, in our experience.
The only issue we had was that the delivery was a bit late, but maybe that was just the weather or traffic. Definitely recommend these guys for events and larger occasions.

Mediocre at best... Disappointing to say the least!  We stopped in for lunch mainly because it was the only place in the immediate area that was open for lunch on a Sunday.  We were hot, tired of walking and hungry so in we went.  The food was very expensive and of mediocre quality.  The Best part of the meal was the Top Shelf Margarita... the Zydeco Gumbo (a cup for $7.99) was ok, the Mardi Gras Shrimp appetizer was pretty lousy...miniscule size shrimp masked by enormous amounts of coating, the wings were not bad but $10 for 5 wings is a bit much. Side salad was just ok.  A tourist trap for sure...but at least we got in from out of the oppressive heat for an hour.  Looking forward to MUCH better meals in New Orleans...

This is a good restaurant for eating on the healthier side of things. I either start with the Chips and Guacamole or the Edamame, both are very good. For the main course I normally order the Waldorf Bowl with sticky rice, it comes with grilled chicken, strawberries, blue cheese, lettuce and candied pecans and topped with a strawberry sauce. Very nice flavors. Tuesday's they have a special menu for flats which are like mini tacos filled with all kind of different things and those are $2 on Tuesday's. Their specials are normally very good as well, they normally last a about a month before changing. They also have a very good mango green tea which is very flavorful, I normally just use 1 Splenda and it makes it perfect. Servers are really friendly but sometimes it is a little slow due to being a pretty popular place.

This was the first time I have visited and was very impressed. I came with my mom for lunch and we both went for the daily specials they had going. I got the Wagyu New York Strip on an open face bread with Brie Cheese and the flavors were impeccable. salted perfectly and beautiful marble pattern in the steak. This was the first Wagyu piece of meat I have ever tried and also the first New York Strip I have ever had and all I can say is, I can't wait to have more. Mom had the Grouper special which had lump crab on top which I didn't really notice the crab when we got the meal. Grouper was very tender but could have used a little more seasoning or lightly blackened maybe. But needless to say both were very good. I also checked in though yelp and got a free appetizer so I can't wait to come back to use the free appetizer and try something new.

I know nothing about indian food. I now know that Chicken Vindaloo is delicious.  The naan is also tasty. simple and tasty. actually that would be a good way to describe this place.  Simple and tasty.
Always a delay in service, food is OK, a lot of grease....true meaning of a "greasy spoon".  Avoid on Friday's and Saturday's if you are in a hurry bc the place gets very packed.
Always good even order carry out. Love the ambiance and feels like somewhere in Thailand. Good Thai in the are, never doubt the location and small place. Always take serious about their food.

The best thing about this place is the beer selection.  A good mix of Mexican and craft.   The food was okay.  Lots of rice, lots of beans, not a lot of flavor.  Chicken and chile burrito was small, pretty unremarkable.  I didn't feel like the food was fresh, partially based on the crunchy Mexican rice.  I know first hand how rice gets crunchy like that and it's because of time.  Doughnuts were nice looking, fresher than the burrito, but also okay.

I really had high hopes.

The food here just wasn't my style.

Since when does organic automatically mean "no meat"?!?!? Psssh.

I considered trying some of the food, but most was around $15 and when I saw the small portions on other tables, I opted to get tea instead.

The food was just too rich for my cheap pallet -- at least for the amount you get.

The tea was good, though. No complaints for that.

I ordered from Circles (via Caviar) last weekend, and while the food was fine (good even), I was really disappointed when I found a piece of chicken in the vegan green curry that I ordered.

I get a bit nervous ordering food if I can't speak to someone about what's in each of the dishes, so I called ahead before putting in my online order and was told that both dishes could be made vegan (using vegan fish sauce). I then made a note on both dishes when putting in the order online requesting that it be made vegan (no egg, fish sauce, or meat). The dishes were a tofu pad kee mow and a vegetable green curry, so except for the fish sauce both should naturally have been vegan. 

The pad kee mow was a bit oily for my taste but my sister liked it a lot, and the vegan green curry was very good. The big issue though was the piece of chicken. I had my bf investigate as he eats meat, and he confirmed that it was in fact chicken =/

The best Homestyle Italian in the city. meatballs are great, the veal is even better and the lasagna is the best. pizzas are fabulous. If you want real italian in New Orleans there is no better place. Plus for dessert walk up the street and get some Brocato's Gelato or canoli.

Great appetizer called Cho-Cho's that have put this west bank staple on the map. The other food though is just ok. I ordered the combination rice and it was a little burned and dry. The cho-cho's filled with shrimp and ham are exceptional and the dipping sauce its served with is great as well. I often stop and get some as a snack when on the wank. The service is ok at best with always some drama going on around the bar with the to-go orders.

The reason why you go here is of course for oysters but there are many places that serve the mollusks better around town. The oyster poboy is very good as well as the fried oysters, the rest of the menu is meh. As far as the char broiled oysters go, they are good but not great. If you want char broiled oyster and in Metairie why not go to the place that started it all, Drago's.

Went back to Bonefish to give is a second chance and this time was much better than the first. The service tonight was impeccable as they teamed us with a pro who had been with the company for years. We ordered the crab cakes as the appetizer and its the best thing on the menu by far. The entrees we had were the fish tacos and the fish and chips both were ok but neither outstanding. The macadamia nut brownie was definitely worth saving room for. Entree wise you have to bite the bullet and order a grilled fish dish here or get a salad with the grilled fish on top, its the best thing on their menu other than the crab cakes which I could order as an entree.

Half of us were served then had to wait 15 minutes for the rest of us to receive our super simple orders.  Staff had a small argument right in front of me about the cash drawer.  No highchair for baby.

The people work here are not stoked and the vibe permeates the place.

Steel cut oats were ok.  Sweet potato tacos and the #2 grilled cheese sandwich with cucumber, cheddar, avo, and chives were just ok, but close to bland.

Iced Americanos got mixed reviews from my group, but I thought they hit the spot.

Just go here for coffee.

I'm just not sold.

The drinks are tasty, but I don't find the food anymore authentic then some of the chain restaurants at half the price. They just have a nicer visual presentation.

I've dined outside during the summer. Part of my dining companion's food was missing, we didn't have utensils initially and the server seemed to not know the offerings (I believe he said he was a bartender). We thought one order was an entree, it looked more like an appetizer and I shared by food. 

I also did pick-up recently due to convenience, still just ok. Requested utensils.. it was pretty annoying that there were none in the bag and we were traveling.

Doubt I will be back for food, drinks maybe.

Basically like any standard Chipotle, but with frequent issues. 

The staff is always rude. Every single burrito I've ever ordered here has fallen apart. They just try to hide their mistake by adding foil to the destroyed burrito. 

Is it that hard to wrap them correctly?

Went here (for the deli / food, not the market) due to the high reviews on yelp with a semi-highi expectations. Unfortunately, I ordered the ravioli, and it was quite the average ravioli, while being expensive, and very little portions. The taste was alright, nothing special. If I ever come back I guess I will have to try a sandwich
Solid New York style pizza at reasonable prices. Will definitely become a regular here!

A friend recommended this place while I was in town, so I went with him to dinner.  The place is fairly small, but you can sell the delicious aromatics right when you walk through the door!  The place is well decorated, and the staff was nice, we had the following:

Dumplings:
Butternut squash with shiitake mushroom
Pumpkin
Pork
Chicken Marsala

All of the dumplings were delicious! Even the non meat ones!  I was very surprised since I am a really huge meat eater!

Sweet chili chicken wings - delicious and flavorful

Tonkotsu - not creamy like other tonkotsu I had, and the pork belly is pan fried instead of braised like other ramen.  However, the ramen is still delicious and flavorful. Noodles are house made too I believe, which is a plus.

I would probably come here again!

Been wanting to go here for quite some time now, we finally made it!  There was a wait, but so worth it!  The vibe was very lively, peoole is smiling and conversations everywhere, and the good energy from the workers were contagious!  While we were waiting, we went grab some drinks from the cooler:

- Peach Oolong Tea
- Raspberry Green Tea
- Vanilla Cold Brew

The teas were really good, and although the vanilla cold brew were also good, it was not strong enough for me.  I had ordered an americano when I was at the table, and it was on point!

We had order the following:

- Crab Daddy Biscuit - soft shell crab, Cajun gravy, sunny egg over biscuit - crab guts were nice and fat, well seasoned, just a little tad bit too salty, but overall very delicious

- Cat Daddy Biscuit - chicken, Cajun gravy, sunny egg over biscuit - also very delicious and filling

- Brisket Hash - slow roasted brisket, egg in hole, gluten friendly mornay - brisket was tender and delicious, but a bit heavy for morning time

- Shrimp and Grits - gulf shrimp, stone grits, nola bbq, grilled bread - good consistency on the grits, sweet, plumped shrimp and delicious sauce

- Bearcat Breakfast - two eggs, crisp potatoes, bacon & bison sausage, add pancakes - the potatoes were super bomb!! As was the bison sausage!!

Definitely a great spot to get some food, cannot wait to come back!

Amazing again! We went for their tasting menu last week and the theme was melon. The entire meal was so interesting, creative, and delicious. I felt like I was a judge on Iron Chef rating the secret ingredient. Perfect evening, yet again!

Ah, David's. My 2AM home away from home - perfect after a night out. It doesn't get much better than the salt and pepper chicken wings for a nice greasy indulgence. They also sell beer, so your fun doesn't have to end!

Unfortunately, I was disappointed with my meal from Mood last week. We ordered take out and the food was prepared very quickly, maybe 5 minutes max. We paid $35 for 2 entrees and one piece of garlic naan. 

The naan was probably the best part of the entire meal. The entrees were mostly rice, which was fluffy and delicious, but the actual dishes left much to be desired. The chicken in the vindaloo dish was extremely dry, and the sauce had very little flavor. It basically tasted like plain tomato sauce. The lamb and spinach dish also was quite dry, but at least had more flavor than the vindaloo dish.

After paying $35, we really hoped to have a meal that was more flavorful and impressive. I would love to give them another try because I see great reviews here, but I don't think that will be happening anytime soon.

We had a great meal here with awesome service. The burger was super flavorful and the lamb tacos were tasty and different from the typical gastropub offerings. I enjoyed some local beer, and we shared some exciting cocktails, as well. This place was packed on a cold, Sunday night. They must be doing something right! Would love to come back here next time I'm in Nashville.

For the man that wants a little extra with is beer and lunch. You will not find the most beautiful women in the downtown area. That alone is worth the trip. But they have a fantastic food menu to select from. And to all men they do have some of the coldest beer in town. And a large selection of Tv's to watch all of your sports needs

For a smoke Brisket. It was very dry, and not true smoke flavor
There potatoes salad needs to be improved
Along with Bake beans. 
You could better tasting items at the store
Would not recommend this for your BBQ fix.
No impressed with this location. Hardly anyone here and waitress got a capation and coke instead of a jack and coke.

What an incredibly "meh" dining experience. I'm a little nostalgic about Angeli (as lots of people are) because 10 years ago, this was where I shared my first meal with my partner. For years people have been telling me how horrible it's gotten so I've stayed away until now - but I get why it's earned such a bad rep. With over 1300 restaurants in the city, this place needs to do better if it's going to last. It's in an incredible location - it should be booming! I'm in a position that recommends restaurants to tourists daily and I can't, in good conscience, recommend this place at all for any purpose. Why would I when there's better pizza and pasta (all with a better atmosphere) within a short walking distance from several other places? It just doesn't make sense for me to recommend it  over LPK, Italian Barrel, Mona Lisa's, Turtle Bay, or even Frank's... Every one of those places (with their similar menu items) beats the food, service, and atmosphere at Angeli's and they're all within earshot. 

The one saving grace? The feta triangles were pretty good. The pizza and pasta were all just something to scarf down in order to move on to the next location of the evening - definitely not worth coming back to. 

Food (actual taste)- **
Service - ***  
Atmosphere - **
Price:Quality ratio - **

No liquor license yet here - BYOB.

Ok food, ok beer selection. I've been here a few times. The thing that kills this place is the service, the waiters seem like they just wander around and pick tables at will. This has occurred a number of times both in the bar area and the dining room

One night we sat down and waited a good 15 min for anyone to even notice us, we finally grabbed someone and she said "yea I guess I can take you"......gee thanks..

Yum on the food.  The place is small, but there's an upstairs (so i'm told).  We ordered delivery via Caviar, and it was reasonable delivery, but they charge a lot of gratuity/service charge for a to-go order that I couldn't adjust. 

I loved the food, but I've had better tasting Dan Dan noodles.  I would def order it again, but the price range for chinese food is a bit higher than I'd like.  I'm used to going to chinatown to get my food for much cheaper and it's still authentic.  

However, this place is a must and the food is great.  On par.  The must haveS:
Try the Dan Dan
Shrimp Lo Mein
Xa Jian Mein (they added shrimp in it - which I thought was weird)
Cucumbers -expensive, but good
Shredded cold potatoes - plentiful!
Green onion pancake - ok
Taiwanese Sausage w/ garlic - yum.  

It's in a great location, so just do it!

I mean seriously- great service! I really enjoyed the hostess as well as our server, you know, the guy with his sunglasses and Mohawk? Ya he's the bomb. My brother was about to try to steal him for his own restaurants if they were near his home. Lol. 

They helped accommodate our super larger group of 11.  They can take down reservations the same day. They'll take your phone number and try to call you when your seat is ready. Otherwise, it's a small spot. 

The food is served promptly and don't forget to enjoy some sake!  Some food items you can order:

-Of course, the potstickers were huge! 
-Mapo tofu was too sweet for my taste. 
-Duck noodle was my fav for sure served with mushrooms. 
-crab fried rice
-lamb veggie dish
-5 spice chicken wings, calamari and pork
-green beans with ground meat
-fried tofu
-Peking duck- yum!!
-plenty of beer options

We had literally as many dishes we could try on the menu and there was more. 

If you need to wait, go to the speakeasy across the way (lookup surplus supplies). They were also raving about Kwoks.

Beyond Bread.  I love you, I really do.
Your maya's market sandwich is one the best things I've eaten since I got to tucson.
My friend had your chocolate babka and we ate half of it before the meal.  

But, the other day I picked up a loaf of bread and instead of rustic, you gave me rye.  I bit into it and was sadly disappointed.  And unfortunately it didn't fit the purpose i had originally intended for it.
I will still be back, but i will be inspecting my loaves for correctness next time around.

The food was delicious! The drinks were good! The service was mediocre. 

Let's talk about the food first. Both cauliflower-bites were good. Enough sauce and the breading had a nice crunch. The salad was nice and crunchy, the Shanghai Power bow was delicious! The black grain and the shrimp were well cooked and juicy. I loved it! 

The sangria flight was a great choice. Out of all three drinks the beehive sangria was the best! I would recommend the full size version. 

We waited for over 15 minutes for someone to bring us water and take our order. We never got the complimentary bread and did not receive the silverware until after our food arrived. And after we asked for a to go box still waited longer for our check. The restaurant is not bust at all.

Nice place, good vegan food. Food has great quality ingredients and wonderful waitresses.  Long wait time however because it's soo popular and even longer wait time for food. Get  here early. Sometimes I think our food sits in the window too long and is not as hot as it should be. But we come because it's a nice vegan restaurant and nice ambiance. The drinks are nice too.
I ordered fried rice and sweet and sour chicken to go. It costs $50 and they legit gave me like 3 pieces of chicken. It's overpriced and seriously not that good. I don't understand the hype.

I ate here some time ago, I thought the food was okay when it was fresh, but upon eating the next day, only 1 star. I noticed it was extremely oily that actually defied explanation and then made my stomach hurt. 

I don't mind oil either, but something was off, maybe old oil, to much oil, not really sure, but it didn't become apparent until the next day, then I was just grossed out by the experience. 

I would try them again, so that's why the 3 stars for now. On the plus side the hot mustard was probably the king of hot mustards, I literally had to be super careful on not getting to much, and I did choke. I would give the hot mustard 5 stars. 

Value equation wise, I felt the place was pricey, but if I didn't have the terrible oily experience, I could have seen myself dining again as the flavors were elevated compared to most food in this town.

To start w/ I have eaten here multiple times, but I am done with them, today was the last draw. 

First I arrived for my lunch and there were plenty of tables available, only a couple were taken and the server (lady) sat me at a table that isn't balanced, so it moves everytime you touch it. I don't like to eat on ship, so I asked to be moved. I don't understand why that would be her first choice for me, and I sat at the table right next to my table that had all four feet touching the ground at the same time. 

Now the food is decent, sometimes 3 stars, sometimes 4 stars, today was 3 stars, but my, "Eek" is service and what is a terrible dining experience. The servers are total Nazis when it comes to giving the standards you come to expect w/ Mexican dining, sufficient tortillas, sour cream and guacamole, that are suppose to come w/ your meal. 

You are given you a baby to child size portion and if you want more they want to charge you. It's feels like a bait and switch, this comes w/ your meal, but you only give enough for a taste, not enough to satisfy your meal, unless you pay up.

The food isn't cheap here folks, if it was, I wouldn't mind, it's above average pricing, and they don't do lunch menu/specials. This place likes to serve everything extra big, so they charge you more, but you get a bigger burrito, or a large size of sizzling fajitas, but then they extremely short change you and give you smaller than a tablespoon of guacamole, or sour cream. 

Today my 2 very small ramekins were about 1/4 full of guacamole and 1/3 full of sour cream. "I asked if that was it, and just like the soup Nazi on Seinfeld, yes that's it, with a demeaning tone" like I should praise the lord I got any, although it says on the menu, served w/, like you actually get some. It's doesn't make sense, I have never seen a place that was so stingy w/ something some many places are proud to serve you, so you can enjoy your meal. It's like getting 4 large pieces of toast and 1 small pat of butter and 1 small jam packet. 

I don't like eating meals feeling they don't care how I feel eating there, and that's how I feel when I eat at Anna's. They don't care how I feel when I eat, unless I want to get shaken down for a few more bucks to get treated properly and get what should come w/ my meal. This is because they don't things right and DON'T give you the right portions to complement the prices you are paying their their food. My lunch today (Asada Chimichanga only) was $9.99 plus tax, so not cheap. 

Last time I was there, I got Fajitas and I got 2 small tortillas, and wasn't offered or allowed more, although my portion needed at least 4 of them. It was $12-$14  for the Fajitas, so not cheap. When I wanted more or anything, tortillas, guacamole, sour cream, it was an add on, what I received w/ my meal, was a similar serving size of guacamole and sour cream as today too. 

I eat down the street and get plenty of guacamole and sour cream included with my lunch special, and every other place in town is happy to hand you a sufficient amount of guacamole or sour cream, tortillas, etc. especially w/ Fajitas, it's standard to serve a hefty side of guac and sour cream w/ them. I don't get this place, and I don't care anymore, OVER ANNA'S!

There's way better places to eat where I enjoy my meal and my dining experience, and the business wants to me enjoy myself, and actually respects my wallet!

"Taste + Price + Quantity + Quality + Service (Acceptable varies according to the place) = Value or aka My Value Equation".

Went to Beefy's today, to get a burger and it was too busy for a lunch hour away from the office, we waited over 10 minutes and didn't even get our order in, sitting right in front of the cashier/server so we jetted, but I had a burger craving so my co-worker suggest Brasserie St. James (BSJ). 

We were almost half way through our hour, so I asked the hostess, where should be sit to get our order in the fastest and she recommended the bar. I have eaten here one time, I had the pork shoulder, it was okay, nothing special. Today I tried the At Water Burger. It's sounds really good on the menu, but didn't hit all the notes I was expecting. 

The avocado or guacamole on there was more of see but not taste, and the blue cheese was very strong, which is to be expected. It was an okay burger, fresh meat, cooked close to order (Medium) closer to medium well, but I notice fresh meat tends to do that. The burger was just okay, nothing exciting about it, tasty wise, topping balance, just okay. The fries were the same okay. The ketchup probably has sriracha and was interesting. 

The server was great, super fast taking our order and super fast on the food delivery, so BIG UPS for that. So without a drink and tipping 20%+ it was over $18, and to me at that price point it should be a WOW, that was the great fricking burger and fries EVER, and it was just okay, and something I wouldn't order especially at the the price point. 

I like the look of the place, and the service, but the food 2x for me now, hasn't delivered on the expectation or meeting My Value Equation!

"Taste + Price + Quantity + Quality + Service (Which Varies) = My Value Equation"

Last point, the faucets in the men's bathroom, need adjusting, the spray is so hard, it bounces off your hands no matter where you place them. It sprays onto your clothes. I cannot understand with all the thought they put into this place, somehow this was missed. I wear professional clothes and my sleeves were soaked washing my hands, not a good experience, especially when it looks like they would want to appeal to professionals.

My parents are visiting and they are staying at the Eldorado, so we wanted to grab an easy bite, and back in the day, I really liked Tivoli Gardens (Millies24 predecessor), so was excited to see what replaced it. We got right in, and the busser came by for our drink order. It was a little complicated, but no biggie. 

My dad decided on the 16oz T-Bone special for $15.99, my mom a patty melt, and myself chicken fajita's. It wasn't busy in the pace at 6:30PM, and we got our food in a reasonable amount of time. 

My dad's steak looked overcooked, so I asked him to cut it while the server was present and he was having problems, so the server left, then he finally cut in and it was well done not medium rare like he ordered. It was also very thin for a T-Bone. I mentioned he should send it back and the server already say it was my dad was cutting, and got another ordered, so I thought this was impressive. 

Mine came with corn tortilla not flour, we got that corrected. Mine was good, not a ton of chicken, about 7 to 8 strips, lots of peppers and onions, a small but fair amount of guacamole and sour cream, and very low grade beans (can) and overcooked crusty spanish rice that looked cooked maybe at lunch time and sitting in a warmer. 

My mom's burger looked okay, not great, not inedible, but the Coleslaw she got looked saggy and sad, and not fresh either, looked liked they had thousand island in it. 

My dad got his 2nd steak, it was cooked closer to medium rare, but the problem you have with very thin steaks, they never really cook right (looked raw in the middle), in this case, the steak was very gray on the outside with hardly any grill marks on the steak. I imagine the grill there is not very hot or the cooks don't know how to cook steak, but it just wasn't much better. I think the overcooked steak was probably the way to go here. 

Overall, I would give the chicken fajitas 3 stars, service 3.5 stars, and the rest of the food 2 stars. It's a place I would eat again if necessary, but wouldn't choose it again with other options available. Also see my review of Eldorado, the air quality is disgusting, which unfortunately houses this restaurant.

I haven't eaten here for a long spell, got Cashew Nut Chicken late last night. It was $9.10 out the door. 

The only part of my meal that had good flavor was the white rice. 

The Chicken was very slim and tasted terrible. Lots of over cooked and very soft vegetables. I would feel confident, this was not made fresh like I ordered and paid. The cashew nuts were very soft too and not abundant. 

Terrible taste, terrible meal, terrible value! 

Eww Me Thinks Not AGAIN!

I went to Super Taqueria on the recommendation of a coworker. I am always looking for a great breakfast spot, that is quick and easy, inexpensive and delicious, a real value! So I heard this was the place, big portion, small price, great taste. I was going to go there for lunch on a Tuesday, but at 1PM the parking lot was bare. I questioned the recommendation, as a place with food that good, and aggressively priced, should be busy. That day, however, I got scared and drove on, saying I would wait until I did breakfast, since that is what I was going on, I didn't want to tell my coworker it was disappointing, if lunch was not as good as breakfast. Thank god, I did, as you read on...So I woke up early on Saturday, August 15th and decided to give it a go. When I arrived no one was in there, but I moved ahead. The lady working the counter, probably was Mom could of cared less that I was there spending my money, but alas did take my order. I had a bad feeling, that somehow it wasn't clean, although on the surface it looked clean. They just didn't look like people who made sure to wash their hand before preparing my food, and they were up to many other tasks. You know when you walk in and the cook is busy managing his restaurant. I didn't specifically watch the cleanliness, I sat down and read my RNR. I then rec'd a breakfast burrito with Chorizo, which I promptly added on properly iced in a metal container Hot Sauce. I added ample HOT sauce, as I can stand the heat. I proceeded to eat a breakfast burritio that surpingsly had no beans or rice, but was mixed well with the egg and the burritio. I thought it a fair taste and went on my way. About 2 hours later, trouble hit. I had a movement that hurt. HURT BAD. It was the first of many. I know the old adam about food poisoning, but I am believer that our HIGHER faculties of self know things, and my body knew this food was NO GOOD. It quickly exited my body with lots of pain and blood, that I am still feeling as I write this review. Sad to say, I think the only thing missing here was an attention to washing THY hands, and I would not have had a problem. Do I feel like I could complain, not with the lack of the passion the mom or whoever took my order showed. I would surely pass on Super Taqueria, and I wish I could recommend my other place, but there really missed the mark as well  the last two times I ate there, I'll give you a hint though, it's on Virginia St and open 24hrs. My question, why is PASSION and ATTENTION TO DETAIL and CLEANLINESS missing? Are people that are taking our money, gambling with our Life and Health, that LAZY? That sad part is creating Food for others can be such a JOY. There are thousands of famous local restaurants from mudane to complex dining, everyday, showing people that PRIDE in FOOD, Quality of Taste, and Attention to Detail and Commitment to Service as what can take ordinary to EXTRAordinary!-TDSR, 2009

It's a little higher than 4 stars, but I can't give 5 stars unless, I am can completely feel comfortable that I would think my readers would agree. It's definitely 4 plus!

First, it's LOOKS GOOD, they did a great job creating a classic but nice atmosphere, as you know, most times I focus on the food, and price, but I do appreciate when a place is nice enough to take a date too, and this place makes that mark. 

Service, on point, quick and efficient, and who doesn't love some food given to you right away, and when you are a Dragon, you most definitely appreciate, not 1 but 2 different dips for your chips! I would give my first batch of chips 3, today, 3.5. 

I am not sure if the chips grew on me or what, but I appreciate the fact today, they really tasted good. They serve this bean dip (Si Amigos live again!) with the chips, then they give you salsa, but it's more like the sauce, with minimal chunks, but it's good. I enjoy both, and they serve a carafe of extra sauce/salsa. That's a great touch, and I appreciate variety and anticipation of enjoying a sauce/salsa, knowing they make sure you don't need to ask for more because if they did it right, you will be pouring more, as I did today! =)

Last I have tried two meals, and if you know me, I appreciate value, and Casa Grande delivers in 2 ways, first M-F has changing daily specials $6.95, and 2nd, they got an even better happy hour $4.95. The lunch special ends at 3, and Happy Hour starts at 3. I tried both Chili Verde lunch special - 4-5 stars, and today I tried Shredded Beef Flauta's (like a medium size triple Chimichangas cut in half w/ plenty of SOUR CREAM), 5 stars all the ways. 

I left FULL, could barely eat my last split Flauta. My only tip is they need to do 2 things: 1) serve extra napkins automatically, there's nothing worse than looking around for a napkin and every table is clean as doctor's office. 2) Anything that needs to be cut or can be cut to eat, needs a steak knife standard. 

I think Casa Grande fills a missing piece of classic and tasty Mexican fare with a date impressive atmosphere, and or if you are bargain hunter, you will find a home in  flexible in dining times/dishes - like me and not be disappointed =)

Adios Amigos!

Tried Flowing Tide today, had a late lunch, did the appetizers 2pm - 6pm for $6, got chicken wings, just nasty terrible tasting chicken, ordered nitro it wasn't, didn't matter, I couldn't eat the wings, service wasn't great either, I wanted to pay my check and leave, wasn't busy, waitress didn't come out for a few minutes after walking by and I had the black folder upright per correct procedure to show it's ready to pick up with my card sticking out, after minutes of wondering why she hadn't come over, I even stacked all my dishes up too, I finally took my CC out and just left cash so I could leave. I won't be back, it's just a disappointing place, it's below average and that's some people's speed, but not mine! Also I don't understand why there isn't a bathroom on the smoking side, pretty much negates the non-smoking side, when it's constantly being opened by smoking side people needing to use facilities. Lastly, the music was all messed up, I was hearing Michael Jackson, and the volume was going up and down, it's nuts! I feel bad if that happens often, as a worker there that sound system would make me insane, like it did for the few minutes I heard the terrible sound fluctations today! Fix the sound system unless you hate people and want them to suffer!

This review is for my experience on a weekday (Thurs) morning. The price is $14.99, but with a local club card you get 20%, so it came under $13. 

I was starving this morning, and hit up Atlantis, my favorite for breakfast buffets, but it's still under remodel. I was quite hungry and now I was buffet committed, and decided on the next most convenient option, The Island Buffet at the Peppermill, knowing too, you get local love (20% off at all restaurants)! 

I arrived and got seated quickly, the buffet was sparse on customers. I already knew I wanted a fresh cooked omelet to start. Due to my large appetite, I quickly filled up a plate while waiting for it to be prepared of bacon, corned beef hash, ham, home style potatoes, maple sausage, and another potato version. 

I got my omelet with the kitchen sink included, added some sour cream, and sat down. The omelet was okay, nothing special. I dug into my other dishes, the only ones that were decent were the bacon and ham. The rest fell flat, too salty, flavors were off, and just not satisfying.  

You know when you look at food in a buffet and it doesn't look appetizing, you think you know it's not going to deliver on taste, but you try it anyways, hoping that your wrong, that's how I felt there, and that's what I tasted on the dishes, so at this point I was over the cooked food. 

I perused around and decided on fresh cantaloupe and pineapple. These were both abundant and tasty. After that I hit up the salad bar, they had all the usuals, plus some other salads like you get in a supermarket deli, so I tried most of them. Nothing was fantastic, but more satisfying  than the cooked food. 

Overall, I wouldn't eat this breakfast again, unless I wanted fruit and salad for breakfast, bacon, and maybe an okay omelet. I have been here on Saturdays with the carving stations, and that provides a better taste and value.

Running errands stop by for breakfast, chorizo, and eggs, and a cheese quesadilla. 

The place has improved much. Music was on, Mexican, but just right. 

The food was very good. Of course, I got the green salsa (only one I have ever liked). I also tried the red one, very good as well. 

I even got a couple of SUPER HOT grilled Serranos! 

Will be back!

I ate here, used to love this spot under Binder, I would eat there 2-3 a week, he sold it, then it was sold again to the current owners. The last time I was there, it was GROSS. The food was probably the worst tasting food I have ever eaten, there's tons of crap on the walls about specials, and you better eat all the food, or they will charge you for the food you didn't eat, I mean JUST CORNY and feels super GHETTO! I have eaten tons of Indian food, and I was so hungry, I just thought maybe they put these signs up, because people didn't like real Indian food, or maybe it was spicy or, I wasn't really sure, but I wasn't worried about loading up my plate, as I can take spice, I like flavor, etc. I literally had to force the food down, and only becuase I was worried about having to pay more than the buffet price, because the food was disgusting. I asked for my Naan well done, they served me cold Naan. I couldn't wait to pay and get out of there. Binder if you are reading this, please, buy this place back and restore the glory that used to be, SS Super and Taste of India. That place was the best.

I don't like a super thick crust that is about about 5 stories tall, and all the pizza topping go to the center, and that's how they serve pizza here, so I am not reviewing that pizza, but I am reviewing my recent experience of a less than stellar Calzone 1 week ago. 

You know how they say when you are drinking mostly 2 or 3 star foods tastes like 4 or 5 star, we'll I wish this were the case, because what I got for $10 price ranges was mostly reheated chicken, a minimal appearance of artichoke hearts and mushrooms, but the bread was BIG as they do with their pizza. 

If you like bread than Pirate's is your place, I mean $10 for bread and some reheated chicken isn't my idea of anything stellar. You got to balance the toppings and fill the damn thing up! 

It looks like a ghost town in there, it really needs some help. 

The food was super slow to get too. 

It's not a place that I enjoy eating at, except the Mozzarella Sticks are THE BEST in TOWN, and I would give those 5 stars and recommend them HIGHLY. I wish I would have stuck my to plan and gotten those instead of that crappy calzone. I was super hungry and thought they would do a proper job, another $10 flushed way!

The food here is not that great save for the oysters. The charbroiled oysters are awesome! The oysters creole and the raw oysters are great here too. I have tried lots of their fried seafood and it is nothing to write home about. Their fried catfish platter is especially lacking. Taste like it isn't seasoned at all. Their lobsters are pretty darn good here though.

I like the ambiance here better than the one downtown plus Tommy is usually here. Ivana is wonderful and always a pleasure to see. If you ever have any issues go talk to Ivana. She is always here so you can't miss her.

There are better places in the city for seafood but none better for oysters than Drago's!
We waited to get a table.  Once seated we waited 15 ?minutes and no server.  We left.  Disappointed overall.

Dinner Saturday night....enjoyed the Indonesian rolls for an app.  Served with a basil avocado sauce, these rolls were tasty and somewhat filling. Ordered 2 entrees to split. Not gonna lie, I don't recall what was ordered nor what i was consuming. (I blame my dinner date) All I know is that it was meatless . The 2nd entree consisted of apples, mushrooms and chorizo.  We both loved this plate! 

The service was sub par. Our server loved being a carnivore enough to not try anything on the menu which was very helpful when deciding what to order. Sarcasm.

I will return to Mi Lah to try some more unidentifiable yet flavorsome cuisine.

Restaurant quality gourmet meatballs with a variety of meats and sauces served by business owner, Mike, who is a super nice and funny Philadelphia local. My wife and I have always loved food trucks, so we were excited when we stumbled upon Mama's Meatballs food truck at a Philadelphia craft show at Penn's Landing. My wife and I decided to try the original Mama's Ball (beef, pork, veal) slider. We were so impressed with the flavors and moistness of the ball as well as the accompanying marinara sauce that we got the Rocky Ball boa (sweet sausage), Rabe Father (turkey and broccoli rabe) and Dat zap Spicy Ball (spicy sausage and long hots). They were all fantastic, but the Rocky was off the charts, with the melted provolone inside the ball just putting it over the top. By the time we walked away, they had quite a crowd trying all the varieties. All were equally impressed. They will be in my neighborhood in June. Can't wait!

Good sports bar with a mixed age crowd. Open layout that had plenty of seating and a large center bar. Good crowd for March Madness but not crowded. Large selection of draught beers at reasonable prices. The bar offers good views of the many TVs with good friendly efficient service. I ordered grilled mahi mahi with mixed veggies and my wife the blackened chicken salad. She was very happy with the salad and I was a bit underwhelmed with the fish and vegetables. The fish had a decent grilled flavor but was lacking in freshness. The veggies were a bit soggy and seemed to be on par with a bag of steamers. The best part of my meal was the coleslaw. Overall, it was pretty much what I'd expect from this type (sports bar) of place. No regrets as we came for the game.

Five star desserts! We only come here for dessert. Brownie sundae and carrot cake are decadent. Coffee is ok. Usually head for the first come first serve high tops. Service is always five stars. Not sure about the food as we only dessert. :-)

Of course the stars don't represent the deliciousness of the food. Today I ordered lunch curbside. It was an expensive order, at least a$100.
Why I was upset, we ordered 2 famous fries with extra cheese. The containers were HALF full. 
HALF.  Because yes filling the containers full with fries will break the bank of a chain restaurant.
And I didn't get the extra cheese.


I will say, the young woman bringing our food curbside was exceptional. She gets 5 Stars.
This is your typical Burger King. Service was adequate and the food is a fast-food chain burger. But it seemed fresh.

Oh ooooh nooooo. Great basin dropped the ball.
They have held my attention for over 20 years (dagnabit!) with fantastic dishes like salmon fish and chips, which they no longer have. Great burgers!, Great beers! Great atmosphere and great service!

Alas, this was not the case during our last burger night.

Let's go back in time to 8-29-2017. Our burger night group decided on Great Basin Brewing (GBB). I was champing at the bit with mouth watering desire to sink my teeth into a really good burger!
Our friends (Angie and Bill) arrived first as we frantically fought traffic and road destruction trying to get to downtown Sparks. 
After being seated the waitress took my beer order (Cantaloupe Wit) and within a few minutes, my cantaloupey tasting beer was at the table an on my lips. Not my favorite beer but I had to try it!
I ordered the Black & Bleu burger as did my wifee. My dad ordered the patty melt with no special sauce. And, we all got garlic fries!
I didn't time it, but it felt like the burgers took just a bit longer to arrive than normal. Not a bad and that wasn't my complaint. 
When the burgers arrived, I noticed that my burger was smashed and like many burgers that are smashed, they appear like they are falling apart. After taking a bite of the cardboard burger, I realized it was dried out and was woefully disappointed. The garlic fries were crispy and soft inside. Just the way a great fry should be. But, compared to what they were, there was hardly any garlic on them! Very disappointing. 
I asked my dad how his patty melt was. His answer was not enthusiastic at all. He, instead of telling me showed me that the special sauce was put on his patty melt and oozing out the sides of the rye bread, despite the fact that he specifically asked to have it left off. Yes, I remember him stating that.

When the waitress did her satisfaction rounds and asked how things were. I didn't mention my burger but we did mention my dad's patty melt. 
Her answer shocked me after my dad told her there was special sauce on the patty melt. The waitress said that it's too late for her to open it up and scrape it off. WTF is that!?!? That was not what I wanted to hear and I almost got up but didn't. 
She followed up with asking if she could get him something else, to which my dad said no.
There was no more conversation about replacement meal, partial discount of the meal or even a full comp. 

What started out as a potentially five star rating, dropped to 4 with a dried out smashed burger and to a three star with the waitress's response.
Not only that, I'm sure it will be years before we step inside again.

Bottom Line
----------------

I was very disappointed. Though I will enjoy there beers, I doubt that I will patronize either of there locations for quite some time and it's a shame since I really enjoyed this place. 
Perhaps it was a bad waitress
Perhaps it was a bad cook
Perhaps it was a bad manager

Perhaps I'll go somewhere else for burger night

I was excited (and nervous) to check this place out!
Our friends invited us here and I am not a seafood, sushi, ramen fan, haha! I know!!!  So immediately my taste preference for American food really drew me to the Crispy Brussels and even the Potato Fries! I also really wanted to give it a shot too. I've never really had GOOD ramen or noodles etc.  So I compromised, with the Crispy Brussels and the Garlic Noodles.  The CB's were amazing. Each bite was a lottery, you didn't know if were going to get a crispy bite, a saturated bite, it was like each bite was different but good.  Sometimes they seemed a little too rich.  Garlic noodles everyone raved about.  As my first Garlic Noodles experience, it was just so-so.  I mean, maybe these were incredible comparatively speaking but since this isn't my jam, I don't know that I'm a good judge.  I **think** your entire party has to be there in order to sit down for a reservation or get on the wait list, which would be important to know.  We also tried the Warrior cold Sake, and it was decent.  The sparkling flavored drinks looked really good, I wish I would have tried one of those.  Probably the grapefruit ginger one, although the hibiscus cucumber sounded pretty good too!

PROS:
- Vibe with the moody lights, it's good
- They have a bar! It's pretty cute
- Patio lights, way cool
- The booth was so comfy
- I don't even remember if there was music on, but if so it wasn't overbearing so we didn't have to scream over it to have a conversation
- Our server was AWESOME, he was super helpful and really patient with me trying to find something I would like.

TIPS:
- There's a sign on the clear doors that say EXIT ONLY.  That doesn't mean the entrance is around the other side of the building first-timers! The entrance is the big wood door next to the clear one with the sign.
- Make a reservation, they are busy
- Parking can be sparse, so if someone is pulling out just take their spot (the first one you see)
- The tab can add up quickly so if that matters just be sure to pay attention (and if it doesn't matter, try ALL THE THINGS)!!

These burgers are delicious. Probably one of the best I've had in Philly. Also, the people who work here are really nice, though the waitress we had was perhaps a tad overenthusiastic. Better than apathetic, I suppose. 

And crayons + construction paper? Yes please.
9 years later. Ceviche is still amazing (yellowtail with passionfruit vinagrette, rainbow). Vaca frita is still delicious. The tres leches is to die for. That is all.

I did take out for 2. Almost $25 for a small dish of spaghetti w/meat sauce and chicken princess (some chicken tenders, a few asparagus and maybe a tablespoon of roasted peppers). A hard as a rock piece of garlic bread was in the bag. The chicken came with NOTHING. No salad, no soup, not even any pasta (the spaghetti included nada either). Just a few tenders swimming in some sauce. Neither one of us has a huge appetite, but we were still hungry an hour later. I don't live close and I sought this place out because of the great reviews. Very disappointed and felt like I was short changed because I did take out. The food itself was just okay and certainly not worth $25.

Nothing really special here, basically another production line tourist restaurant famous only by Man vs. Food, our raw oysters served with copious amounts of chipped shell, and at room temperature. Chargrilled Oysters cooked away to practically nothing, but it's a fantastic place if you're drunk, in your twenties, like it very loud, and don't mind being constantly bumped and jostled by extremely fast servers who do a semi-passable job at remembering what you ordered. See photos for more details.

Drago's was good, but if you're on tight time schedule and want to hit a lot of the NOLA restaurants, I wouldn't waste one of my precious meal slots here.  The food here is delicious, don't get me wrong, but it's nothing uniquely Louisianan.  

We had the raw and charboiled oysters.  They were HUGE, but not cleaned well.  So when you ate them you got a lot of debris in your mouth as well.  The oyster shooters were also missing cocktail sauce.  So oyster plus only vodka?  umm gross.

For the main course, I had their stuff lobster: "A 1 1/4 lb. whole Maine
lobster filled with a fresh crabmeat and shrimp dressing and topped with crabmeat au gratin."  Definitely came with a lot of lobster meat.  Very good and decently priced under $30 if I remember correctly.

The food there is amazing. However, the reasoning behind the three stars is the male owner that is such an aggressive, rude hobbit. Rather than greeting us at the door with a smile, he aggressively asks us how many people and screaming at his workers in front of the customers. 

Clearly, he's in this for only the money. 

If it were up to me, I wouldn't even bother going there but seeing how the workers there always greet us with a smile and asks professionally, I know my money is going to them, not him.

I was really surprised at how not in love with this place I was.  

I did really like the atmosphere, I really felt like I had been transported to France.  Our waitress seemed cold and uncaring and in a huge hurry, even though they didn't seem that busy.  

I had no idea what to order!  There were no pictures (lol yes I really said that)  but aside from that, because I CAN read... I felt the descriptions were not fantastic.  I ended up ordering food that was okay, but I could have cooked at home.

I was really glad that we topped off our breakfast date with 2 tarts to go, those were so yummy, they made it worth breaking my diet.

I was really hoping for a lunch menu when we got there, hopefully next time we will get there late enough for lunch.

This place could be highly rated EASILY only if places like this were FASTER!!! Hattie B's is always fast, Prince's is usually slow but they're worth the wait given their history and notoriety, Helen's needs to be just a little quicker, or higher more cooks. Great food though I will say that .

I guess for Philly this is a choice but having lived elsewhere the prices are high unless you plan on eating before or afterward.  The food we had was very good but my main complaint was the server who rattled off all the specials and the prices (seemed weird- it isn't a diner, AKA "Flo") and when one of our dishes arrived he announced, "here is your $25 platter".....never had that happen..anywhere.  Also when he picked up signed check he opened it up at the table and said oh that's ok.  Good food weird service!  I think they need to up the quantity or lower the prices and get some ideas from Japanese Sushi places in other cities.  If you want a taste it's ok but for dinner not my choice. First time-last time!  I'll keep on going to Center City (15th Street)-that's a real Japanese restaurant.

I am between 3 and 4 stars for Saturday brunch. 4-5 stars for food, 4-5 stars for ambience, and 4-5 stars for staff attitude but the service was still so bad! :(  They gave us one glass of water then came back for another. One cup of coffee then had to come back for another. One set of silverware--same story. Had to ask twice for milk and sugar and refills on coffee (never came).  The food took so long to come out. The staff apologized but we were hungry and here for a loooong time with periods in which no one seated had food. Music was also good, so clearly I'm feeling conflicted. I may try again for Sunday brunch (bc with the buffet, maybe the service won't be such a problem).

This place is an overpriced  joke. It's not even that busy and I stood at the bar for SIX minutes waiting to make a take out order. The older woman bartender with the messy hairdo and glasses looked at me and then looked away. While I continued to stand there for six minutes, not even being acknowledged. Absolutely atrocious service and extremely unacceptable. So I went to the Greek place next-door and they got my $50 order instead. 
Currants wanted $25 for salmon, which I was going to pay, but I'll take my business elsewhere.
Also, what is going on with the bathrooms? It looks like a homeless person lives in there. Ladies clothing hanging up all over the place. As well as toothbrushes, toothpaste, hair brushes and what not. Just looks like somebody's personal bathroom.

Won't return. Came with a group. Service is severely lacking. Called ahead, like over a week for the group. Came just for brunch. Was immediately told they were short servers and short in the kitchen ?  That's a "you" issue, and not an excuse. Regardless the place was not in any way busy.
