Was told we had to order breakfast or lunch. One or the other because the kitchen would have a hard time with timing orders. Well it's something-plenty of other places deal with so figure it out. 
Bloody Mary-meh and just bland. 
Frittata-awful, literally awful. Homefries? Nah they ran out and took it upon themselves to substitute fries. Whatever. Toast or biscuit? Just toast, ran out of biscuits. 

Will never return, god awful service and food.

Late lunch with grown kids - We should have   know when we walked into the large cavernous room that was at best 65 degrees on a 32 degree day that the food would be as chilly as the room.  Waiter was great - high energy and was accommodating in drinks, refills of chips and salsa and easily took our order.  What he couldn't help was the oddness of the food - the black beans were swimming in a salt water mix with a few onions, the fish tacos came with a vat of odd mayo and the refried beans were just...bland.  No taste.  Thankfully the chips and salsa were excellent and we ate with our coats on.   Maybe it's great in the summer with a margarita, but without flavor and some heat... will pass.

This was my second meal at JG. The first time my boyfriend and I went our food was exceptional. Soo exceptional that I still think about the roast chicken dish we had to this day. 

We loved it so much we decided to go back and take my boyfriend's parents. Our food was ok. Nothing was terrible but nothing stood out. 

I love Graces and I usually love everything he does. Our food last night really missed the mark. I'm not sure if I will be back with so many other great restaurants to try in Philly.

Unfortunately not a good experience again at Outback. We are normally Outback fans but this location cannot get it together. We headed to Outback on a Wednesday night. We were seated right away which was nice BUT things went downhill from there. We sat for the next fifteen-minutes with no waitress coming over. I headed over the the hostess stand and asked if they could send someone over. There were only a few other tables sat in the whole place and it was not busy. Five minutes later a manger headed over apologizing that our waiter was new and was nowhere to be found. They sent another waitress over which unfortunately did not go smooth at all. We did not enjoy the experience and service which is sad because we really do enjoy the food at Outback. We were comped for one of the dinners by the manager which was nice but it did seem other tables were getting comps and had complaints as well. No Bueno! Cheers!

3.5 more accurate 

The eggs in a box is good though unseasoned. Omelettes are very average. Absolutely Love the ambiance. Very sleek and modern. Clean and white with wood floors and wooden tables. 

2 entrees with 2 cups of coffee ran us $32 before tip. Considering the amount of food this felt pretty high. Would rather get something more filling, more flavorful, and cheaper from half and half. 

Pastry case looked good though we arrived later in the day so not a lot for our choosing. 

Will probably be back but not necessarily for brunch. Sandwiches look good and are on average $10.

I actually left and got a pancake from half and half after this lol.

This is my favorite bbq restaurant in St. Louis. I recommend the delicious and flavorful hush puppies which are served with a fantastic maple bitter. The macaroni and cheese is definitely not the type I would normally eat. -it has crackers on top- but it is so amazing. Their fries are also very very good. I've had the pulled chicken, pulled pork, and brisket sandwiches and each were very good. The burnt ends of the brisket can be a bit salty though 

I also love their apple whiskey cocktail

Ramen is pretty sub par here. There's a lot of room for improvement.  Anyone saying it's the best in the area is clearly NOT from the area! haha On the other hand, omurice was steamy and tasty which is a plus. It annoys me they only give u one menu per table so it takes forever for us to order. Overall the restaurant is expensive for a mediocre meal. On the plus side, there is no surcharge for tea which is essential for my Asian family lol could that justify the premium? ...Possibly~

Personally, I'd say skip but try it and judge for yourself~

Walked in and smelled that "ewwww-fish" scent.  Granted, this is a sushi place.  But you shouldn't be smelling fish when you walk in.  This was the first strike.

A few other tables were seated and orders taken before we even got water.  We waited close to 15 minutes just for the water.  And then once we got our water, it took awhile for them to come by for our order.  By that time, a few other orders were taken, and it took awhile for our order to be made.  Strike TWO.

The food quality was meh.  We ordered 6 rolls.
- Sunburst: our favorite.  VERY Good.
- Shrimp Tempura maki - good.
- Eagle: meh.
- Valentine: very nice presentation.  kinda dry.
- Blind date: not a date I'd write home about.
I can't remember what the last roll was.  nothing special about it.

We didn't order dessert.

For the two of us, the cost was $60 with tip.  We were full, but we didn't enjoy the experience.

Why the two stars?  Because I liked the interior and the menu.  And they did have nice presentation.

We were hoping to find more redeeming traits for this sushi digs close to home.  Alas, after much thought, the consensus is that we'd rather drive up to Shogun on Street Rd than come back here again.

Hungover? This is your spot.  Their breakfast burritos are SO good. I've had tacos and maybe a few other items but I always pick the burrito. My only complaint is that service is usually reallllly slow. The food is made to order, which I appreciate, but sometimes I wonder if any of the food could be prepped ahead of time.

Food was good, service was terrible. This was my first time at a pollo tropical in over 5 years. The food was good, hot and fresh. But the lady at the cash register was rude and nasty. She was unwilling to explain the menu to us or what sides came with the meal. When she spoke she mumbled so you couldn't hear anything she said. They have you sit down at this place and they bring your food out to you. The food came out very fast. The bathroom had water all over the floor and wet paper towels were all over the place. Not to mention the amount of kids running around like it was a daycare. Parents not picking up after their kids mess and the working staff also not cleaning anything up after people left.
Awesome paninis...I highly recommend the SanFran. They don't have tap water though (seems calculated).
Used to be really good.  We always loved thier burgers and fries but they changed something about both and we were not impressed last two visits. Prob won't return.

had a beef shawarma, and it's just not good. and I've had shawarmas before, I know what good taste like.

presentation is definitely very low. it's poorly wrapped so that it looked passable when they cut in half, but when you eat, everything breaks apart. there's definitely not enough meat to make up the 6.99+tax, with way too much lettuce and tomato and all. the bread is not fresh and is definitely taking over the whole thing. 

sorry to say this, but no I would not rec this place to anyone.

I've been enjoying the Reading Terminal since I was 17.  So I've been going there for great food for 31 years.  

Stopped in this past Saturday afternoon to get some lunch.  My boyfriend mentioned a Thai restaurant that he used to go to when he worked in the city.  He recommended the salmon dish which was soooo good!  

I stopped in a Moroccan shop and everything was so beautiful and made in Morocco.  Took me right back to being there when I was 19 and in the outdoor markets!

I grabbed some cookies too....and they were only $1 each because it was National Cookie Day!

The terminal has everything you want and some things you didn't even know you needed!

I really enjoy the show with the food at this type of restaurant. 

I highly recommend going any time except on holiday occasions.  Five of us went NYE - the food and service was good, but we were really rushed thru the meal. And the only menu option was a surf and turf meal for $75, no substitutions. It was a large amount of food crammed into an hour of time, it would have been fabulous to slow down the service and enjoy the meal more. There was a couple of dishes that did come out a little salty too.  

They did honor the free sake with Yelp check in, so kudos for that. Enjoy the hot moist towels before dinner. 

Recommend trying this spot on a regular night. Great for groups.
Call for reservations.  The bar is a little too noisy.   Signature pork chop had great flavor but a little dry and tough to cut.   The root veggie mash was real good
This is ranked among the best sushi I've ever had!  I don't remember the names but we had 8 rolls and they were all winners!

So I came back here wanting to try somewhere different for sushi outside of our usual spot, and that calls for an update. I originally wasn't too impressed with here when we came over 2 years ago, but we were pleased after last night. My wife and I got a craving for some late night sushi and called here. I selected 3 rolls after going over their online menu which had several choices. I will say that last time we came for lunch and the selection/options were different, which was mostly what I didn't like. I recall complaining about the lack of rolls without salmon, which wasn't an issue yesterday. We got the ring of fire, blazin, and candy cane rolls. They were all very good. The quality and freshness of the fish was very pleasing, and all of the combinations were tasty! What really blew me away was the customer service. The gentleman who took my order over the phone was VERY courteous, ensured he got everything correct, and was just as courteous in person. I also like their carryout, where they come to you and you don't have to get out of the car(it's in the back). All that said, I'm raising my opinion of this spot up one star and will gladly recommend here to others.

The service was great but the food was not good. the trout I got was smothered in an overpowering & greasy butter sauce that made the encrusted pecans & parmesan soggy and tasteless. My husband got chicken with goat cheese & steamed spinach - the spinach was steamed too much so it had lost the flavor and wasn't able to balance out the goat cheese - and the amount of goat cheese on the plate was too much so that it again overpowered the rest of the dish. It was a very disappointing meal.

I don't get it? Something here seems a little fishy. I love everything that Caplingers is about - local, scratch made, and great staff. They even gave out free samples in line! It gives them an extra star. 

We ordered dinner around 7:50 and didn't receive our food until 8:50. One hour. I know there is a sign that says that it takes time, but an hour is egregious. Nothing is good enough for an hour wait.

I ordered the Caplingers Special. I have no clue what fish it was, but that was my fault. I didn't ask. I'm a sucker for marketing. I chose blackened instead of fried because I am not always keen on fish batter. I regret this decision. It was ok... Not good. Not bad. But ok. 

My fried got the fried catfish. I tasted a piece and I thought the batter was super tasty and reminded me of fried chicken. I would totally get something fried next time I go. Does my doctor read my reviews? 

The key here is to order online and then show up for some eating.

This is my to-go place when I am in no mood to wait for brunch.  Abbaye has a delicious egg and cheese sandwich on biscuit or bagel, and consistently good service.  Sometimes I am turned off by the over fried breakfast potatoes, but that doesn't stop me from going back!  P.S. they have amazing nachos.

Ate here twice. Once to check,  the second to confirm. First time food was oily n bland. The sauces were delicious both the green n red one. I ate the torta and tacos al pastor. I'm not saying it was their food  but i had a stomach a few hours later. (Oh did i mention I don't want  cheese in my torta?idk how that got there) second time  tried tacos de carne asada n my fam tried their entrees that come with beans n rice. . Gotta say disappointed  at that too. That rice was plain as white rice. It's like they used two or three tomatoes to give it color n left it at that.  The chicken tasted weird or old too. Anyways if you're not sure about it. Buy a little bit of food first then after you eat that decide if you wanna take your chances.
Good little place. Stopping in for a cup of chowder. It was tasty & HOT in my mind that means fresh.  There were actually lots of clams in the cup of chowder.  The Dungeness crab Louie was great too.

1 OF 7 RESTAURANTS I HAD TO REVISIT BEFORE MOVING OUT OF THE QUARTER. Yep, after almost 20 years I'm happily headed back Uptown! So this final week I've decided to follow my cravings and begrudgingly Bistreaux is a "must do" for their:

TRUFFLE OIL MAC & CHEESE, it's simply the best i've ever had. 

BUT Bistreaux is consistently disappointing...

snarky service

overpriced

and word has it...

THEY'RE PAINTING OVER THE FOLLIES BERGÈRE MURAL!

BIBIMBAP is my favorite Korean food (and way fun word: bee-BEEM-bop!).  My partner's mother is Korean, and through her I was fortunate to experience, learn and prepare their centuries old cuisine.  Heck, we even make our own kimchi.  One of the best attributes of their dishes is that they ferment well as leftovers and then are excellent mixed: "bibimbap".  My chicken entrée at Maurepas was good bibimbap.  When eaten together the various components are actually more delicious and sumptuous than individually: sweet & sour vibrantly hued collards, salty pink charred Chisesi's ham, creamy grits to offset the veggies' tartness, crispy nutty golden chicken skin, rich almost slippery dark meat, all adhered by a thick gooey sunny-yellow poached egg.  And they were even better as leftovers!

AFFORDABLE: almost the entire menu is $12 or less.

KIMCHI: Did you know that Korea was one of the few Asian countries not to have an Avian flu epidemic & many credit that putrifying cabbage condiment for their immunity?

QUITE POSSIBLY THE WORST SHRIMP PO'BOY 
in New Orleans, and it's outrageously expensive!

$1 PER SHRIMP:
I only had six 30/40cts individually dotted across my half. Essentially they were garnish on a lettuce/mayo sandwich. I ended up tearing off 1/3 of the bread and squishing the shrimp together just to get a single layer.  

BREAD IS DOUGHY AND DRY 
- like eating a wash cloth. Their thin cut fries are overcooked and resemble the remnants that no one wants at the bottom of a fast food bag; the onion rings are institutional.

WAY BETTER SHRIMP PO'BOYS: 
1. Melba's - guarantees 22, 40ct shrimp on their $10 sandwich
2. Parkway - but of course
3. Slice - their BBQ shrimp sandwich is even better than their pizza
4. Milk Bar - the "Shrimply The Best" sautéed version is my favorite
5. Bank's Meat Market - the 32", $12.99 po'boy is becoming legendary

*** 2 stars and not 1 because it's a great space and good service.

WILL STILL REEK AFTER APRIL 22ND
This place reminds me of that bar in the Irish Channel where back-in-the-day the cops found a severed head in a crock pot. The very same bar that I had eaten Irish stew at a year earlier, choking down unfiltered cigarette flavored broth under a sickly yellow bulb. Pass all the ordinances you want, some places will never be smoke free.

BUT THE JAMBALAYA IS EXCEPTIONALLY GOOD
It's made with dirty rice and not tomato based, reminiscent of that found in the Texas Cajun communities around Port Neches/Groves. In fact if I Iived in the WHD I'd probably order it take-out weekly (1lb $8). But avoid the rest, the red beans are mushy and the gumbo's amber roux is way too light.

BETTER NEARBY INEXPENSIVE RESTAURANTS: Cochon Butcher, Wood Pizza, Carmo, Phil's Grill, La Casita.

OVERLY-FRIED, BLANDLY-BATTERED CHICKEN
was so unappetizing that I gave it away. For me the pictures say it all. Compare my photo for Brothers' Combo to that for Key's Fuel Mart's tenders, both posted here. It's no contest in my opinion..

$5.89 THREE PIECE MIX COMES WITH FRIES,
but they're mushy and rather institutional. To be fair however, that's true at most convenience stores.

BETTER FOOD MART FRIED CHICKEN: 
1. Manchu Food Store (dicey location so best to go in the daytime) is a tempura style crisp.
2. Key's Fuel Mart (but ask them to make it fresh and skip the sides) is a simply seasoned, lightly fried, flakey version.
3. Quarter Grocery (get a side of their awesome crawfish pies) is pretty basic but they have the best fries in the area, maybe even the city.

...this list is a work in progress. Any recommendations?

Korean karaoke comes to Philly!  I have only done a private room session here, with a group of about a dozen people, but the experience was hugely fun and one that none of us can stop talking about.

The menu is a fab "asian tapas" mix, a bit pricey, but really satisfying.  

The karaoke system itself is easy to use (once the crew sets things up for you), but the song selection is a bit bizarre, with many obvious choices inexplicably missing.  An improved song catalog would probably bring this review up to 5 stars.

In short, the ideal place to bring a mid-size group for an unforgettable bonding experience.

Would have been 3 stars, but I have to go to 4 for one reason:  the BURGER!  It was outrageously good, simply structured but excellent, excellent, excellent.  The best in Philly.

Despite an incredible burger (and the three others with me had nothing but good things to say about the food they ordered as well) and a vast beer selection, I really did not personally like the overly-large, overly-corporate and chain-like atmosphere.  Definitely reminiscent of places like Triumph and Iron Hill in that regard, and therefore attracting the same contingent of business-guy-types, tourists, etc.

I agree with many of the other reviewers - you come here for the patio. Eating outside is a very enjoyable experience here with some good margaritas, however the food is only fair, particularly for the prices. I've been here on a couple of occasions, eating both inside and out. If you are forced to eat inside I would say to save yourself $100 and make burritos at home. On the other hand, if you're lucky enough to get a nice summer night, go with some friends, splurge and get a couple of pitchers and some appetizers and enjoy the fountain and the lights on the patio.

We didn't love our food here but we did love our drinks. It's pricey so beware. We got four drinks (two margs and two sangrias), empanadas, and split a chicken entree. The drinks were amazing! The patio is fantastic, especially on a nice spring or summer night!

Wow. I have been sleeping on Bellagio -- I can't believe I'm just now discovering it. I decided to with my tried-and-true, the plain ole pepperoni. The crust was thin yet sturdy enough to support the cheese and pepperoni. It had just the right amount of chew. The cheese was golden and bubbly. The pepperoni coverage was decent, but I'm not one to want the entire pizza covered from crust to crust. They had just enough spice to not be lost among the cheese. The sauce was incredible with a very strong zingy tomato flavor.

The mozzarella sticks we ordered were pretty good -- a little smaller than I was anticipating with not a strong mozzarella flavor. But the side of marinara was delicious. It was chunky and rich with flavor notes similar to the sauce on the pizza.

Overall, Bellagio has earned a spot on my list of go-to pizza spots in Nashville. I can't wait to go back and explore more of the menu.

This place used to be swell...then it got busy and the service went to shit. Were seated by the host and had our drink orders taken by the host because a server never came to the table. Now, the manager has to do damage control and kiss everyone's ass because his staff is a joke. Don't come here. Ever.
Oh, and the guy playing guitar spent more
time talking to the barflies than actually playing music! That's it...I'm going to Hooters.

I stopped on the way home to pick up some loco moco and some kind of combo plate.  The food was decent, but I'm a tough critic when it comes to Hawaiian food because I live in Hawaii, so I've had better, but I do enjoy this Arizona Hawaiian food when I have the craving.  The service had a lot to be desired.  I ordered and waited, and then added a soda and a spam musubi to which the waitress seemed thoroughly annoyed about, what happened to upselling?  First she said she couldn't take cash for the extra's because they were counting the drawer???  I enjoyed the food, and I was debating between 2 kinds of chicken - the waitress did tell me she liked the Katsu better, which I did appreciate.  The macaroni salad was the best thing on my plate.  I told her the spam musubi was for later, but she still had it heated up, and didn't tell me.  I just stood there waiting instead of her telling me it would be a moment, to which I could have said don't bother heating it up, I don't plan to eat it now.  I will be back when I have the Hawaiian food craving though as it's the only Hawaiian near where I live.
In the last few months it is apparent that the new manager is implementing changes and the changes are improvements.

The food was acceptable but not great. I had the baked spaghetti. The serving was generous and the price was fair but I'm always bothered when I pay restaurant prices and then receive a product so basic that I could have made it at home as well or better. In the unlikely case that I return I'll try the pizza

The reason my return is unlikely is because of their payment policy. To begin with I have a problem with cash only brick and mortar establishments. It just indicates that there's something shady going on. I pay my taxes and I expect local business to pay theirs too. When it's cash only I suspect (with no foundation in fact) that not all of the sales are being reported. But at untouchables it goes one step further. Here, there is a credit card looking machine right next to the cash register. Only it's not a credit machine, it's an"ATM". So basically you eat dinner here, you done have enough cash to pay for it and they force you to use the credit machine only instead of a standard transaction it's an ATM complete with foreign transaction fee from your own bank as well as the convenience fee that the"ATM"charges. So the $10 dinner ends up costing$15 and the restaurant is actually the beneficiary of$3 of those extras. I know they're named after a crimeland story but the untouchables were supposed to be the good guys.

Dined in a little after 4pm on a Saturday. We were greeted by the hostesses who was very pleasant! Dining room had about 5 tables occupied.  We were sat by the hostess at a 2 top table (because it was just me and my boyfriend) it was very tight in the corner. Waiter asked if we would like to move to a booth, so we did! 
We were BOTH SO EXCITED for this place to open! Have been waitingggg to try it! 
Asked our server what was good, she said sriracha shrimp! Shrimp on pizza? 
WHY don't they have BBQ CHICKEN Pizza!!??

We were told we had to order the Large if we wanted to do half and half. Kind of annoying? And the only difference between a medium and a large is 2 slices! 

Asked about the root beer on draft, she just said wanna sample!? Agreed tried it and ordered it. Still not sure what kind, where's it's from, or who makes it? It was a very smooth, vanilla had a nice foam head! It was very good! I do recommend trying it!

Ordered a glass of root beer, a small Caesar salad, and a large half and half sriracha shrimp, and Thai 

Salad was good!  Pizza looked good, but was almost flavorless. It didn't have any flavor. Also didn't have any pizza sauce. It was so bland. We were so disappointed. 

We watched the table next to us order beer. Their server never came back by their table, someone else came dropped off the beer after the customer asked for it. Server came back but never apologize for not bringing her the beer she ordered. They actually ended up just walking out. 

There was what appeared to be 3 managers walking around. None of them ever walked up to any of the tables asking if food/service/drinks were good or bad? Or simply just stop but the tables and chat with the customers?
Wish them the best! But Im not sure that we will come back!

This place was just ok. Went for dinner since I was in the neighborhood. The food was pre portioned which I didn't care for. The grits were good, and the Mac and cheese were ok. We split wings which were ice cold, pulled chicken was fine, but looked like it had been sitting in a steamer for hours so I didn't eat too much and my husband had the pulled chicken wrap which he liked.   Doubt I'll be back. The sauces weren't great either.

The meat lovers stromboli was decent. The chicken parmegiana ziti was good. I dig the 50cent wing Wednesdays deal. And the pizza was... overall quality was... taste was... service was ok...but the wait for the food was a bit long.

Pro: Ok they have a good beer selection I'll give them that. Con: However, if your a fan of untraditional or less popular beer selections (like me) than be warned that they run out of beers on tap frequently. I have been denied many beers at this place under the excuse if "we ran out of that on tap" or "we don't carry that anymore". So although they CLAIM to have 75 beers on tap its really not completely kosher. Pro: The burgers and onion rings are great. Especially with whatever sauce they serve with the onion rings. It's sort of like Raisin Canes sauce...but better! Con: I'm not going to sugar coat it: the girls are just kinda stupid. I've never had one that could remember a basic food order. I don't know why they are all the same here. I can only assume that they are all hiring their equally less intelligent friends or something. It reminds me of Hooters how you usually get really shallow service there but since the girls are all somewhat "pretty ", and the clientele are mostly men, they just accept the subpar service as "just the way it is" there. And if your a woman who is simply passionate about good burgers and beer (like me), than you probably appreciate the whole "hooters-wanna-be" approach they are trying to go for, but not SO much so that you want to tolerate waiting an hour or two to see your server again. Anyways, my point is that if you want good burgers and beer (when they aren't out of it ), and you don't mind teaching the waitresses basic skills like how to read and write, than give it a go!

Ok the food seems good but the fruit flies are insane!  I have been here numerous time but no more.  The fruit flys are just everywhere!  I am afraid to even think of looking inside the liquor bottles.  I am sure they are loaded with dead flys.  Just flat out disgusting.
They're definitely improving.  Enjoy the trivia. Place seems pretty clean. People are nice.
Excellent food, outstanding service, and a great price. This place is a winner. I had lunch for the first time today and can't wait to have a reason to come back for breakfast.
The food here is excellent. A little pricey, but large portions make it an OK value. Service was adequate. I'd return.

Lunch at 11:15 on a Thursday. Glad we arrived early because it was getting busy by the time we left. Very good food with fast, friendly service. Would definitely return. Only downside is finding a place to park on California Ave.

It not bad for Chinese buffet. The service is great but it seem like they don't like to put Sashimi that much the chef wait for until it all gone then he will put the new one in. There place clean but sometime the restroom was so dirty [sometime].

So Michi Sushi is a good sushi place, but nothing fantastic. I actually prefer that their rolls do no have too much rice, but some people may be annoyed and want thicker rolls. There is a lunch special for 2 regular rolls for $8.95, but you only get 12 small rolls, so it's not necessarily a great deal. The sushi is nothing spectacular, but it is still pretty good especially for lunch. The restaurant itself is dimly lit but clean.
I really enjoyed the wings. They were tender and juicy with a densely crispy skin and well-seasoned dry rub.

This isn't a food review as much as a review of the service. We got to the restaurant at 7:40pm on a Thursday. Despite being listed as open until 8pm we were told they wouldn't be able to seat us because they were closed. The place was 75% full and a few tables were open. I insisted to no avail and left very disappointed in a less than great neighborhood with few walking options for other places, none of which did they offer as recommendations. This is bad business. When you say you close at 8pm, this is when you ought to close. I understand this is tecnically at the legal discretion of the restaurant, but I don't believe this is the right way to operate. I am very disappointed in this place. Big letdown.

Ordered the Bulgogi Beef bowl. The beef was pretty tender. The rice was good. There was a fair share of fresh veggies in the bowl. 

Overall, I think this was a solid Korean bowl.

I order from here at least once a week every week while at work. The specials menu is ridiculous. The pricing is so cheap, what you get tastes fantastic, and is usually a huge portion. The specials are usually around $8 each and they always make it worth while by adding a soda, soup, garlic knots, etc. They have the best salads around the area in my opinion. If you ever see the taco salad or Caribbean shrimp salad on the specials menu I would definitely recommend it. I am addicted to the Caribbean mango vinegarette too. I'm not sure if they make it themselves, but it compliments any salad they have on the menu. Their wings are also really great. They have a variety of flavors, including the work place favorite; sweet chilli. I would definitely say ordering from them is totally worth it. The girl who usually takes my order during the week (I think her name is Samantha) is such a sweet heart. She's always so polite and patient. The only con to this place is that when we order, something is usually missing. I can't be too mad about it though because they always come through and make it up to us which I definitely appreciate. I don't know where the break down is when it comes to missing items, but I hope they can work it out. I would definitely say if you haven't ordered from here and you've been ordering at Gaetanos or Sopranos, you need to make the switch and try this place.

Charles H. said it all. 

It's simple enough to understand. The food was not worth the hype. 

I'd rather go across the street to Felix where the line is short or non-existent and the oysters are large. Where I can order the same dish and get a larger version, cheaper.


And If this is not long enough, then please, go shove the other reviews up your ass., M.

Went back here and ordered from the traditional menu again. Girly ordered from the American one. We ordered two dishes that seemed similar to each other. 
The Traditional version was once again waaay better than the Americanized one.
Go...but order from the traditional menu.
Seriously.

From Love in the Park:
Ok..I thought the actual brick and mortar location was bad. And since they brought a dog into the the kitchen I was pretty much thinking that was as low as it could get.
Fast forward to Love in the Park. A 100 dollar a person event.
Santa Fe had a table and managed to get even grosser than the restaurant.
The redhead who was working the booth and the person who was with the woman who took her dog into the kitchen(I'm told it is the owner...eeew), were both smoking at the table where they were serving...at once point, she had her cigarette in her mouth while serving food. He smoked several times in less than an hour (I was with the band in the back so had a good(?) view).
Not ONCE did they stop and wash their hands...ever. It really made me sick. Even the band didn't want to eat anything they had and they were DRUNK as heck.
I can not imagine how they stay in business.
Oh..and when one guest was surprised they had opened back up after leaving Frenchman, it took all I had not to mention it wasn't worth going to with the terribly bland food and the animals in the kitchen.
Horrible.

Had a meeting a few blocks away this morning at 10am, but I ended up in the area at 8:30, scouting the business out (OCPD). Stopped here to get a cup of coffee and wait a bit. A decent little place, close to a lot of businesses.  Free Wifi with password (coffee beans).

Since most of NOLA doesn't really do breakfast, it must be nice to have a place close that you can get some morning grub. The prices seem to be decent for breakfast and like most "Coffee places"  the coffee prices are too expensive and this coffee is a bit bitter. Nothing 6 creamers can't help.

My over medium eggs were really close to correct. Better than most places.
The hash browns are NOT HASH BROWNS. I think New Orleans cooks need to look up hash browns so they don't keep mixing up home fries for them. They were good home fries, but they were not hash browns. 
The toast was thick cut and toasted so...yeah. Toast.
They has every assortment of jelly split up by type and all the condiments. So that's cool. 


I have to agree with the reviewer who mentioned that the waiter did not look happy...or even friendly. As a matter of fact, he didn't smile or say anything that wasn't the bare minimum for making the transaction happen. Even after tipping, he wasn't any more polite or friendly.

I would give this place a 3.5 if possible. It's better than just ok, but it's not fantastic.

The first time we went after the new people took it over, there was no one to be seen. Not just customers, but we couldn't find a worker. After waiting 10 minutes without seeing anyone, we slinked out thinking maybe they were closed and forgot to lock the door, but we checked...they were open. no idea where the people were.

The last two times we visited, they had a good amount of customers and WOW, servers and everything.

Free chips and salsa as most good places do, but be prepared for a different kind of salsa. It's warm and not overly-filled with cilantro (which makes me happy).

This is the place that The Girly gets her favorite Chimichanga from. They are crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside and unlike most places, not too salty.

I've had the chimichanga and the quesadilla myself and both were good. They are a bit skimpy on the guac but still pretty good good. 

The prices are about a buck or two per dish more than I like but I'm a cheap bastage so take that for what it's worth.

Recommended for those who like Mexican food but want to keep it kind of white-washed and safe. Still good, though. Just make sure you ask for a hot sauce or something.

Gave Stephen's a third try for Dining Under the Stars and I'm consistently disappointed. Extremely slow service, overpriced food, and to top it off the entrees come out cold! The biggest surprise was when the steak special was $50 a pop! I will try my best to not return.

Service is generally slow and always seem to get forgotten when it comes to drink refills. However the food is tasty and reasonably priced. They're pizza and Strombolis and large and yummy. I love the crust used in both and the marinara with the Stromboli is very good. The wings are large and crisp. The crab cake sandwich is very crabby with little filler but it is pretty small portion wise. I must say that chaps next door has one of the best crab cake ive ever had so that's generally my comparison. They usually have pretty good soups too - love the seafood chowder.

Only because I can not give zero.  Had the worst experience that I have had in years at any restaurant.  Booked a reservation with Open Table and then it was refused at the restaurant.  If you don't want to accept open table reservations, then don't use their system!  Walked in at reservation time and was told by hostess that we would have to wait for a table behind the people in line.  I said that I had a reservation for 4:15 for a party of three and was told again that these people have been waiting and regardless of my reservation, we would have to wait for 20 minutes.  Waited 20 minutes and finally asked for a manager.  First manager came and was going to seat us, then Jay shows up.  Jay was rude beyond belief.  He said that he did not care about open table and that we would not be seated.  All in all the absolute worst experience that I have ever had in NOLA.  Run, don't walk from this place!  I would go anywhere else but here in the future.  Jay absolutely ruined our day!  His rudeness and unwillingness to accommodate a customer will cause me and the rest of my party to never return here.  I would be embarrassed to have such an awful manager if I was an owner of this restaurant.

It was ok. I wasn't all that into the buffet. The food was bland, however,  it was fresh. I loved the history photos on their walls and I love the tile designs on the ceiling. Food was just ok and bland my waitress was normal. Very small inside so grab your seats when you can.

I can't tell you how happy I am to finally have a great Italian restaurant in the neighborhood! While I loved Fitler Dining Room, it was more of a once in a while restaurant for us. I can see Trattoria Carina popping up on the rotation far more often. 

The restaurant was buzzing on Saturday night - we lucked into one of the last open tables outside and it wasn't long before people were placed on a wait. At this time, reservations are not accepted. I kind of like it - there aren't many places that offer first come first served, so Carina is perfect for a night when you didn't plan ahead but still want a nice dinner.

There is a short list of cocktails and also red, white, rosé and sparkling wine, which you can get by the glass or bottle. The menu is broken into starters, salads, pastas, mains and sides. We wanted to try a little of everything so we ordered the meatballs, pumpkin salad, tagliatelle with bolognese, shells with crab, branzino and broccoli. 

I thought all of the food was nicely prepared and presented and tasted great. I love a good plate of pasta and neither of our pasta dishes let me down. The shells may have won out by a small margin - the tomato sauce was just spicy enough and I loved the toasted breadcrumbs for some texture. The branzino was perfectly cooked and I really enjoyed the citrusy tomato salad underneath. Also, those meatballs! If Carina ever opens for lunch, I really hope they put a meatball sandwich on the menu. 

I'm looking forward to many more meals at this neighborhood gem!

Crystal Lake, we need to talk. 

The last couple times I chalked it up to a bad day, a full moon, what have you.  Today was the last straw.  Lately I've developed feelings of anger and resentment towards you.  I'm angry because my omelets are never as good as they used to be and resentful because I know you are holding out, or worse, giving your best to someone else.  It's because of this that I am going to start seeing other diners.  

Ssshh, don't get upset.  I'll definitely be back for a quickie between the hours of 2 and 4 a.m. some night when I'm drunk and nothing else is open.

My friend has been raving about The Couch Tomato for ages, so we met there for lunch last week. I love the various salad offerings or the option to create-your-own. We placed our order at the counter then grabbed a table outside. 

I selected the salad with barbecue chicken, tomatoes, corn, black beans and cheddar. I got ranch dressing on the side. The salad was big, super-fresh, and really delicious. Since the chicken had a decent amount of sauce, I didn't need as much dressing, which I liked. My friend created his own salad but the toppings were a little skimpy, especially the quinoa - he ended up paying extra to get some more on the side. 

Overall, very solid spot for a healthy lunch and I've heard the pizza is delicious as well. I'll definitely return when I'm lunching in Manayunk!

We stopped into Talula's Daily a couple times over the weekend. The first time, we were looking for a quick breakfast. There were croissants stuffed with turkey and Swiss for under four dollars, so we opted for those along with a couple cups of La Colombe coffee. I asked for extra room in my cup after noticing that the coffee was filled to the brim. My boyfriend, unfortunately, did not. When he picked up his cup, it started to buckle causing hot coffee to spill all over his hands. So unless Talula's decides to upgrade their cups, do yourself a favor and ask for room so you don't suffer the same fate. 

Aside from that unfortunate mishap, I have mostly positive things to say about this place. The dining area is very cute, though shared tables are a concept that not everyone seems to grasp. Sharing is caring, folks!  

There's currently a check-in offer for a free cookie, which I am looking forward to claiming. The aforementioned turkey and Swiss croissants were quite delicious. A second visit yielded tomato focaccia that was absolutely fantastic. Their mushroom soup was too heavy for my taste, but if you love mushrooms and are looking for a soup that will stick to the ribs, you'll probably want to try it. 

I'd really love to check out one of the dinners sometime. Until I do, I'll be swinging by for more food to go or a quick bite in.

I looooove Plenty on East Passyunk Avenue, so I was absolutely stoked when their new location on Spruce Street finally opened last week. I parked the car illegally and stood watch while my partner in crime ran inside for breakfast sandwiches. 

My choice was the pancetta hash, with two fried eggs, pancetta, breakfast potatoes, and fontina. We got home and tore open our packages. Mine came in a cardboard to-go box, and when I opened the lid the first thing I noticed was the pool of egg yolk covering the entire bottom of the box, leaving the whole underside of my sandwich completely soaked and really messy. Meanwhile, the roll was really tough and also very large, and it overpowered (what was left of) the ingredients in the sandwich. If you do feel compelled to order the pancetta hash to go after reading this, be sure to order it with scrambled eggs. 

This was my first time ordering breakfast at Plenty; normally I have sandwiches and almost always the tasso ham panini, which is incredible. I'm looking forward to swinging by again soon, and hopefully updating my review once that happens.

2009 World Series, Game 1

For reasons still unknown to me (and against warnings from friends, family and spiritual advisors), I agreed to watch game one with a born and raised New Yorker, who had relocated to Philly in adulthood.  During discussions of where to watch the game, it was discovered that homeslice had never hung out in the Dirty Jerz, or more accurately, Southern New Jersey.  We agreed it was high time to pop that cherry, and I couldn't think of a more Jerztastic place to do it than Tom Fischer's.  

The bar was packed with Phils fans young and old at game time.  Our waitress got right on our drinks and kept them coming through the night.  I had always heard great things about the bar food and it was the perfect night for enjoying some greasy grub.  Everything we were looking at was priced around five or six bucks, so we ordered three things thinking they would be on the small side.  Looking back, I do wish our server would have said something like "FYI, our servings are pretty big here!" or "Save some food for everyone else, fatties!" but we got none of that.  What we did get was a huge basket of pizza fries, a heaping pile of nachos with hunks of breaded chicken, loads of cheese and diced green onions, accompanied by salsa and sour cream, and buffalo chicken tenders.

About those buffalo chicken tenders.  I am thrilled to report to all city dwellers that you can cancel your Philly Car Share reservations because there is no longer a need to trek all the way to Pic-a-lilli's in Shamong, NJ.  Just hop on PATCO and jump off in Collingswood.  Walk east on Atlantic until you are smack dab in front of Tom Fischer's.  No joke, I would not know the difference from TF's buffalo chicken tenders and the ones they serve at the Pic.  The sauce was tangy but not too hot and with a touch of sweetness.  I would imagine the wings are comparable but I'll have to check them out sometime in the future.  They also do takeout- happy football Sunday to me!

Our experience was pretty awesome (for me, anyway - the New Yorker was a little butthurt) through the game.  The service was good, food was great, game was awesome and the people-watching was hysterical.  Please refer to my "local photo" to see what I mean.  After the game, however, things took a turn for the dicey.  Without getting into details, let's just say that sometimes small towns bring out small minded individuals.  A slob on the opposite end of the bar made a very loud, obnoxious comment that would have been inappropriate in any setting.  It was an unfortunate way to end what had been a really fun night, otherwise.  I know it's not the bar's responsibility to censor clientele, but it does speak for the types of clientele they attract.

It's official: I love this spot. 

My very first experience with soup dumplings actually took place at Bing Bing on the tail end of a girls night out a couple months ago. I thought they were delicious, along with a few other things I was able to try (that bubble tea cocktail - love!), and I couldn't wait to go back. 

Saturday, my fiancé and I decided to swing by for Bing Bing's first lunch service. Apparently the masses had not yet been informed so we were seated right away. The servers were all so friendly and knowledgeable about the menu. They recommend ordering 2-3 plates per person. We ordered: kimchi pork soup dumplings, turnip cake, rice noodle rolls, pan fried bao (mushroom and cheddar), xo chicken wings. We were also treated to the green beans, which are really delicious. 

The soup dumplings were so awesome. I may need my own order next time. Though I certainly wouldn't have room for anything else - the food is very filling and we took enough home for a hefty snack. The bao are pretty large; I loved the taste of the mushroom and cheddar. The turnip cake is super unique and fun to eat. I'd probably pass on the rice noodle rolls in the future only because I enjoyed everything else so much more. Looking forward to my next visit!

Swift Half* and Whiskey Dix* had a baby, and its name is Gunners Run! 

My boyfriend and I stopped by last night to check the place out and grab a beer, and that was my first impression. The music had a hard rock tilt and the art was strange and edgy. We found two available seats at the bar and surveyed the crowd. It looked like everyone there had been at the Phillies game earlier in the day. We perused the menu. Short and not interesting enough to grab a snack (although what did go past looked good). We ordered our beers and watched the end of the Flyers game, which was conveniently showing on the TV in front of us. 

Then, a very drunk man tapped my boyfriend on the shoulder, which he ignored. The guy started giving me a weird look, which I also ignored. He moved past me, further down the bar, and as he started making his way back, he smacked my ass on his way by. 

Internal monologue: "OH NO HE DIDN'T!!!"

Ponytail swingin' and mouth a-movin', it's safe to say my Jersey was showing. My man stood up and things could have gotten very ugly, but I came to my senses and got the attention of a bartender. Within a few seconds, a bouncer made his way over and the situation was handled swiftly and quietly. The staff was extremely apologetic, and they bought us our next round, which was very sweet. 

I really don't know what the future holds for this place. I do miss my Swift Half and it felt weird being there for another business. I'd consider going back, but I wouldn't go out of my way, either. 


*RIP

This was our first stop for food while in New Orleans, and we liked it so much we went back for seconds a couple days later. First thing's first: this place is pretty divey inside. Don't let that scare you - the service is friendly (and so are the other customers) and the food is solid. 

There isn't much on tap but the five or six beers are mostly local and cover the bases. I had gumbo on my first visit while my fiancé had a shrimp po boy (which I ordered on my second visit). Both were very good. The gumbo had a slow burning heat - use caution before adding any hot sauce! The po boy was overflowing with fried shrimp and it was totally delicious. When the touristy spots have lines flowing down the street, hit up Cajun Mike's for your fix without the wait.

First things first: I love the feel and vibe of this chill neighborhood bar. I dig the constantly rotating beer list, and the bartenders have always been great and fun to chat with. 

However, I'm regretfully pulling stars after my recent dining experiences at Resurrection. Last time, a cheese plate was awesome but a risotto-style dish was a bit monotonous. Jalapeño-accented falafel bites were cute and tasty, but overpriced at eight bucks for five or so small pieces. 

Today I was excited to check out brunch. A chorizo and manchego omelet with a side of greens caught my eye right away. My request for egg whites was unfortunately denied. After looking over the menu some more, I decided to deal with the extra calories from whole eggs and I went with the omelet. At first glance, it was pretty and nicely sized. But once my fork cut through, the plate was swimming in butter. I had a few bites of egg and picked out the chorizo slices, but turned my focus to the side of greens and the heirloom tomato salad we ordered on the side. 

I want to love Resurrection and I want it to be my neighborhood bar of choice, but I never leave feeling truly satisfied... Unless it's fried chicken day.

On a recent cold and rainy night, I decided to go the delivery route for dinner. Yellowtail was new to me, so I checked out the reviews which were fairly positive. The delivery fee is $1 but the minimum order is just $10 so this worked out well. I ordered the three roll combo for $10.95 and my delivery arrived well within the promised time of 30-45 minutes. Probably less than that, actually. 

I ordered a tuna avocado roll, tuna cucumber roll and a California roll. I loved that the rolls weren't too weighed down with rice. Each bite was the perfect size and everything tasted great. I asked for extra wasabi and received enough for a family of four. I will definitely order from Yellowtail again.

Not a fan!!! We had our monthly book club brunch and meeting at this spot and I don't think I will return. First of all, the wait was ridiculously long and then you sit down to mediocre food. I was sooooo disappointed! Brunch is my favorite meal, so I was excited to try a place that everyone said was good. It was nothing special. My food was bland and generally unmemorable. I would not recommend this place to anyone.   I see people are all hyped about it, but if you are a real foodie like myself, you'll pass on this spot.

This place is good for a Panda. Food quality is consistant and staff is fast and friendly.
Outdoor seating is nice in the summer but a bit load with the road right there.
Walk in customers definitely take a back seat to drive through customers as they feed probably 3 drive through orders for every walk in. Needs to change for sure. It feels really rude.

Public House, is a decent spot in midtown to grab some food before you head out for drinks.
The service was good and the outdoor dining is great on a warm summer evening.
The only problem with Public House, is that it feels like it's trying too hard to make it's food standout.
The irish nachos and burger I had with pancetta in the patty were good. But there are items on the menu that feel forced. Like the egg rolls with kimchi in them or the weird, deconstructed rabbit, shepherds pie.
I would give Public House another try as it wasnt bad. But  we will probably wait till the menu changes a bit to go again.

Came up the stairs and immediately loved the decor! We went in for some drinks, so I haven't tried the food, but the waitress we had seated us then took quite a while to bring us the list of brews and was overall very inattentive, poured our drinks then never came back to check on us. The place seemed fine, except when we were leaving, I went to pay, and the minimum at the bar was $15 dollars to use a card. $10 I understand, but $15 dollars at a bar known for its beers? They have an ATM I think, but it still seemed an unreasonable minimum for this day and age.  Liked the atmosphere, but the service left much to be desired.

Having never visited Philly before I had to stop and try from both Geno's and Pat's.  I ordered the exact same at both--cheesesteak wit onions and cheese whiz.  Since I had already eaten my Pat's first and loving every bite (at Pat's with no evidence of me being there) I approached Geno's for an order to take back on the plane.  The woman behind the counter was rude and not pleasant at all.  The food was okay but the service at Pat's was overwhelmingly positive compared to this place.

I love the location- Bella Brava is at the best spot in DTSP. It offers cozy outdoor seating and very good wine.  I have been to BellaBrava many times and i have always been happy with the experience- food and service. 
Unfortunately, last Wednesday, that was not the case. We were promptly seated outside. We ordered our drinks and waters with lemon. All but the lemons made it to the table. Then we ordered half a chicken diablo and a skirt steak. While waiting we were offered a wonderful crusty tasty bread with butter. I believe the butter was infused with garlic and herbs. Delicious! A few minutes after placing the orders I realized we were not asked if we would have a soup or salad with our entrees. Before I had a chance to ask our waiter, our entrees were served with no soup or salad. After getting the entrees I asked about the soup/salad option. Our waiter didn't skip a beat- just asked politely-which one would you like? I'd have really preferred to have my salad before my entree. How can one not take the full order? Anyways, halfway through our meals I did get my salad and my companion got her soup. The salad was very good, nicely seasoned and fresh. The soup was ok-sausage and lentils. It was kinda heavy. The chicken was bland and dry. The steak was dry and chewy. The best part about both was the mascarpone mashed potato-rich and flavorful, and the consistency was right on point. 

On a side note- BellaBrava has happy hour specials before 7 pm on wine, beer and sangria. No food specials during happy hour. Overall, I think the price point is very reasonable considering the portions and the location. I just hope my next visit is more enjoyable.

Numex is a cute addition to the Grand Central scene. The decor is very cool, open and inviting. Service was good too. The food- very good flavors and generous portions. I opted for tacos- i picked 3 different proteins for each taco- very good! The meats were very well seasoned, fresh toppings, nice presentation. Numex offers an interesting desert-sopapilla- deep fried pastry with honey- delicious! 
My only disappointment was the jalapeño margarita. I am not sure why it is called jalapeño margarita since there was no hint of any spice or jalapeño. It tasted like a very sour lemonade. Would I come back again? - yes, but I'll stick with simpler drinks that are poured straight out of a bottle.

again, another Mass-Ave restaurant trading on its location rather than on putting good foods together.  Way over-rated.  Average at best.  How good could it be when most all the customers are drunk and have no sense of what is good, they only eat here because its right outside the bars, and happens to have another bar in it to keep the drinking going.

The newest Thai restaurant in Broad Ripple is a hit in my book! Although there are other Thai restaurants in the area, none seem to hit the mark for me. Chiang Mai is a hit from the decor to the food to the Thai Iced Coffee! On my first trip, I ordered the Pad Thai and Lava tempura. Lava tempura was basically tempura veggies with red curry powder added to the batter. The name Lava is a bit misleading because what you expect (or what I expected) was something spicy. It was not at all spicy and the curry flavor was very subtle. It did result is something I could not stop eating.

The Pad Thai was good. The flavors were on-point and the serving size is what you'd expect from Pad Thai. It could be a meal on it's own or shared between 2 people with something else to go along with it. I ordered it spicy and what I received wasn't what I would consider "spicy" so if you want something that's gonna light you up, opt for the extra spicy.

This is a lead-in: So, I recently visited my dentist, who is working out in Rhawnhurst and has been for the last umpteen years.

My family started going to him when I was just a kid, and we were still in North Philly. Now I have my own insurance and can choose my own dentist, but I still make a trip every six months - and maybe sooner if we've been bad - to see him. He's known me for at least 21 years. Ridiculous, right?

Part of the tradition of Vichet getting a tooth pulled/drilled/cybernetically enhanced is that I always pass by the Adams Avenue shopping plaza, a local Asian small-business dominated lot that is home to Cafe Saigon. And a Pho 75. And a Dunkin' Donuts. And an IHOP. More on those later. 

We'd usually get lunch at the Pho 75, then my mom would pick up some munchkins (really, mom? Right after getting a cavity filled?)  while my dad got us a couple of hoagies at Cafe Saigon.

Anyway, my point here is that, like my dentist, I've been coming to this place for Vietnamese hoagies for longer than I have a clear memory of anything. They're the perfect combination of meaty, crunchy, fresh, toasty and buttery. I want one right now. I kind of want one all the time. This is part of the reason my dentist has so much work to do.

All you need to know is that it's three for a regular, three-fitty for a barbecue beef.

What I like especially about the hoagies that this place slings is that they really load you up on the pickled carrot and daikon, and jalapenos slices. Also, if you do get the barbecue beef, they pile it on, and it's still tender and smokey from being cooked.

If you're ever out this way (I doubt you will be unless you live in the Northeast or have business there), try this place out. Cash only, but hey, it's only 3 bucks.

Pro-tip:
- The only thing I've ever tried at this place are the hoagies. Can't speak for any of their other stuff.

Two words: pitchers and karaoke.

McGillin's is a solid choice. And solid choices that let me make an ass of myself in front of an ale house's worth of people deserves no less than four stars.

Add the cheapest pitchers you can find in the area, along with some heart-destroying bar snacks, and baby, you've got yourself a Sunday evening.

For real though, karaoke here is hilariously awesome. People get into it and sing along and shit. Glad I finally made it out.
Really just 'meh' Mexican. Why are there no truly delicious Mexi restaurants in H-ville?
Excellent customer service and excellent brews. The only thing I'll say is that I wish we were able to customize the sampler flights. Other than that, we will be back.

My review of this Qdoba is pretty similar to the one in Audubon, so I'll just provide a summary: the chicken burrito with queso is very delicious! Generally I get it with the spicy habanero sauce (the hottest Qdoba offers).

I would give this location 5 stars, but when I went, they didn't offer a drink plus chips/salsa as the Audubon location does (maybe they do offer this now?). I went on Cinco de Mayo, and yes, there was a very, very long line, but I can't deduct any stars for that...the wait is to be expected.

By the way ,be sure to join the loyalty program and you can earn points towards a free entree! (Plus, you can get double points on Tuesday.)

This was my wife's first Time here. I have been before with our son. We were seated immediately for our lunch. We both ordered a beer to drink and we both ordered the beef bulgogi. I ordered mine spicy. The main dish comes with several sides including rice, potatoes, fish cakes, pickled ginger, kimchee, and a few others. You cook your own at your table which I fun and you can't say it wasn't cooked right. Service was great and they were always checking on us to see if we needed anything. I was surprised as my wife is not a fan of Asian food. But she liked this place and said she would like to go back. We had more food than we could eat and brought some home. Prices are reasonable for what you get. So, good food and great service. We will return.

We have been out of town for five months and this was one of our first stops upon our return. Very disappointing!  First, they made us sit outside even though we stated we did not want to and would wait for a table. They refused and said we had to go outside. First mistake. We had to get the server to clean the table as it was very dirty. They brought us water and took our order. We ordered our usual, gyro salad with extra gyro meat and two glasses of wine. Wine was delivered in a timely manner. The salad arrived and we had to ask for plates which they delivered to our table. So, the salad had almost no salad to it just gyro mead and a few pieces of tomato, cucumber, onion etc. very small for a dinner selection and the price. The additional gyro meat we ordered was served in a separate dish. Most of the gyro meat was well beyond over cooked and could not be eaten. We got a take home box for the additional meat and requested the check. Our server had to ask us which kind of wine we had!  A very disappointing welcome home dinner. We won't be going back anytime soon. Terrible food and service.

I have not changed my opinion of this establishment!  Our son came over and we decided to go to lunch. We offered several suggestions but he wanted to go here so he could date and go home after that.  First, you enter the place and if you are lucky someone will come and Take you to a table. They have no dedicated host/hostess. And there is little room. To stand around and wait for someone to seat you. Our son ordered ice tea and my wife and I both ordered a beer suggested by our server. Well, she returned with one full beer and less than half full. She said they ran out of what we ordered and wouldn't charge us for the half. No offer to order something different, just here it is!  I ordered the dip, my wife ordered the wings and our son ordered the Mac-n-cheese.  My dip came out with very over done fries and a small cup of catchup. The sandwich was so dry and the au-jus was so salty it was terrible. Our son ate most of his but said it wasn't very good. My had a difficult time with the wings that were served on top of potato chips.  She said they were very tough!  So I will leave the. Off my list. When are they going to figure out they are a bar and not a restaurant. My opinion, bad food, high prices, and bad service. But if you are into the bar scene, this is the place.

Family took me here for Father's Day. Needless to say, very crowded with a 35 minute wait. We expected it so no big deal. Got to our table and they got water over to us almost immediately. Our server, Matthew A was very good. Each of orders a steak with different options and a bottle of wine for mom and dad. Matthew brought over warm bread with butter for us to snack on.  Salads are part of the dinner and were more than adequate. The steaks were brought out and were very nice. Mine was cooked just like I like it. My son commented his was great. Moms as well. Two of us had baked potatoes with the works and son had Mac-n-cheese which he loved. All-n-all a very good dinner. I usually shy away from chain restaurants but this experience was great. We visited the Broadway location. I know they have another location here in town.

Steak 48 is Trash.....! (Looks around Nervously) Now before anyone comes for my head, 2 disclosures; this review has nothing to do with price. I honestly don't remember what I had to pay. I would feel the same way if the steak cost 20 dollars or 100 dollars. Second, I am in no way a chef or cook or claim to be, but what I have done is try multiple steakhouses and unfortunately the steak at steak 48 does not even begin to compare to some of the great steaksI have had in the past. I definitely run the risk of making this overly lengthy because of how much I have to say so I will try to make this as terse as possible.

Now, this is my second time trying this restaurant as I felt my first time must have been bad day for the chef, both times I ordered the same thing; The Bone in Ribeye, and both times I was equally as disappointed. The steak, I don't know..., just confused me. I honestly did not understand what I was eating,  any donut who enjoys steaks will attest, the main component adding to a great steak's appeal it is the hard sear on the outside and the medium rare center. If you cook your steak right, and leave it to rest enough you should achieve this perfect sear and have a warm center, creating a contrast in the texture; the hard outer sear, and a tender center. 

This ribeye had neither, though it was cooked to a perfect medium rare (visually), there was no sear on the outside  and the inside was oddly singeing hot, which still does not make any sense to me. I Imagine the steak was broiled in some form after it was cooked which will explain why the plate was scalding also, but this made for a really peculiar eating experience I truly truly did not care for. The steak was burning hot but still medium rare, it truly felt like someone chucked the steak into a microwave after it was cooked. The resulting offering was a flabby steak, red in the center but inedible because of how hot it was and the un-rendered fat.

All that aside, the appetizers and sides were, okay, I guess, but this is a steakhouse so who cares how good the appetizers are. My two stars are honestly for the service, despite the strict dress code and  spending minimum, this place is not pretentious or snobby at all, the staff are inviting and very welcoming, too bad the meal was not just as up to par.

I have been dying to try this place. Heard alot of great things from people who visited in other places on the East Coast. It shocked us that on a Sunday that they had happy hour. We were not expecting that but price was regular hour if you ask me. My french martini was $11 during hh. We got the crab cakes on happy hour menu for half the price. They were so GOOD. If I had to do it over again would just order a white wine and crab cakes. 

It took forever for our chicken, potatos and spinach to come out. Spinach was super good too. Customer service was good. Wasn't a wait on Sunday night and parking is pretty good and valet is also an option. 

Nice music and love the wine bottles as decor. 

Thinking of bringing my picky auntie here for her bday. If I am bringing her here, I must really think highly of this place.

We read all the other reviews and decided to try this restaurant since we live just around the corner.  We were there for happy hour.  The place was almost empty.  Two guys bowling and 1 lady sitting at the bar.  The other reviews said the mushrooms were great and they were.  But for $8 you only get 4.  I don't know if they were that good.  I ordered the Boyne Valley Pasties.  The menu said that it was corned beef, sauerkraut and Swiss cheese in a pastry shell.  If I had not read the menu, I would not have know what I was eating.  Everything was ground up together - like potted meat - with no flavor at all.  Ugh!  My friend had the Sausage Roll.  The menu said it was smoked sausage, onion & herbs wrapped in a pastry with rosemary gravy.  Again everything inside was ground up - like potted meat - and had no flavor at all.  The rosemary gravy was in a bowl and again it had no flavor.  The service was good, but we were the only ones eating.  The restaurant is upstairs but we found the elevator but that doesn't really matter because we will not be going back.

Since it's a chain restaurant it's hard to comment on the food because it's the same everywhere.  A place like this needs to make it alone on service.  This place clearly failed us...   Our waitress spent more this gabbing with other employees and rolling silverware.  It was 7pm and the place was busy, and our waitress is doing closing work?  She was so out if touch she filled our drink as we were walking out the door. Would not go back.

Cool ambiance without the pretension at similar places in other cities. My black walnut old fashioned was a tad on the sweet side though, lacking that bite that makes you feel like you're somewhere special.

This place has gone through a facelift since my last visit five years ago but, sadly, the food hasn't improved. I popped in again because Ming's--my go-to--was closed for vacation. My breakfast burrito was good enough, but the accompanying hash browns were the consistency of dry mashed potatoes--my only guess is that the has browns had been on the stove so long that they completely broke down into mush. It's a good thing there's hot sauce on the table, because it was needed to make the hash browns edible.

My breakfast partner had pancakes, which were fine . . . although he was disappointed to get pancake syrup in a small plastic container rather than real maple syrup to pour.

Service was lackadaisical at best. It started off well enough: we were dropped off at our table, drink and food orders taken relatively quickly. But then our server disappeared. We had track down an employee to ask for coffee refills. Food took quite some time to arrive at the table. 

I don't mind a leisurely-paced breakfast; however, this place gets so loud that it's hard not to get a headache, and it's impossible to have a conversation with the person sitting next to you without raising your own voice and adding to the general cacophony. It's a stressful atmosphere with all the ear-splitting noise, and it's made worse by the slow/non-existent service.

Customer service took a nose dive
I came to place an order, no one else was in line.
A gal was arranging plastic bags next to the register. She called another name presumably to assist. Over the next few minutes kept arranging bags, she hollered a name to the back.. a few minutes later another customer came in.. nothing. The phone rang and she promptly placed their order.. 10 minutes waiting and the phone person can be helped but not the person in front of you. This is god awful service, cant even call it service since you provided none. No matter how good their food was in the past customer service is all important. I walked out pissed. Well it saved me a certain stomach ache as that is always a certainty after eating there.. Lost a consistent past customer..
Very succulent . I am very hard to please with King cakes . However , Yesssss Honey Yesssss.

It was "meh."

Not bad. But not amazingly good either. Just in between I guess. Also I must caution all who read this review that I only ordered 1 thing from the menu so it's probably not the be all to end all review for Ginger. (Does anyone think of "ginger kids!" when they hear the name of this place? LOL! A bistro run by only redheads.....haha.)  I mainly just wanted to sample their sushi....I've heard mixed things about this place so yeah.

I got the Loop Trolly (?) Roll. Except instead of fried shrimp (tempura) on the inside I asked specifically for non fried shrimp since I'm trying to cut back the calories/fat a bit. 

I don't think the menu mentioned anywhere that the roll had carrots in it too (not just cucumbers) and that they were going to drizzle a gallon of spicy mayo and eel sauce on top either (so much for cutting calories, haha. I had to scrape it all off.) It said it was topped with masago but there was barely any masago on it at all...just lightly on the sides of the roll like the way some places do to their California Rolls.

Anyway. Those discrepancies aside, it wasn't bad. Although the rice was kinda...."gummy"? It seemed like they pushed the rice down too hard when they were rolling up the roll. But maybe I am just getting picky/technical now? LOL.

Flavors were good but nothing to write home about. Nothing that other places haven't done before. So yeah. I did note that it's fairly cheap and those weren't just the lunch prices (I asked.) 

Service was pretty speedy too. I'd go back but I wouldn't make it a point to. Just if I happened to be in the area and wanted some cheap Asian food. IMHO for sushi in the loop, Seki's is wayyy better for traditional sushi, and Blue Ocean is better for fusion (and all you can eat to boot!)

It's been such a long time. This eating establishment is a culinary staple in mexican cuisine so it has to be good. Right? Not necessarily. Last week I arrived at this location at 2:30 in the afternoon searching for good meal...cheap. Lunch ended at 2. So there went that idea.  (Why so early? Who eats dinner at 2pm?). No problemo. I'll order the pick 3 off of the dinner menu. Your choice of 3 tasty treats complete with rice and beans. While I waited for my dinner I munched on some light and airy tortilla chips dipped in a watery, tomato based salsa. They offer a meatier, chunky, hotter salsa that fares much better. Dinner arrives quickly and features a "mini" burrito, a cheese enchilada and a chicken tostada. The burrito was filled with tender beef chunks and still managed to be the smaller in size than the enchilada. Maybe it was an enchilada. Nope! The cheese enchilada didn't disappoint, but the sauce that covered the delicacy gave me terrible heartburn. The tostada was mess. Imagine a mountain of shredded lettuce covering salty chunk chicken over a soggy yellow corn tortilla (blame it on the refried bean spread). The side of red rice that accompanied the meal was ordinary while the refried beans were extraordinary. The beans and tortilla chips were the highlight of the meal. I hate constant complaining but the darn meal was $12.99. Surely, not worth it. Maybe this is the reason I stayed away so long.

The burgers were pretty good and I love the endless fries, but I have had two horrible experiences here, in terms of service.  The first time, I went with my dad at around 8:10, keep in mind they close at 9.  I asked for a refill of their endless fries and the lady said no.  When I asked why, she said it's almost closing time. I hate when places try to rush you out when it's near their closing time, but in this case they were going to be open another hour.  I asked to see if she could get me some again, this time she went back and returned with them.  She said I was lucky to get them.  Seriously??  I paid for them and as long as they are technically open they should give me what I order.  I want to like this place, as I have had decent experiences here, but those two horrible experiences make me eat at other burger places in Tucson.

Found this hidden spot and could not be happier ! Likely the best mexican food I've had.  The Rum Chata pina colados were AMAZING! Ice cold beer (literally ice on them) -the mexican rice is perfection , black beans are delicious -and the grande burrito is delicious.  Literally planning my next meal here for next week !
Thought I would give it a try, bad mistake, the food was not hot, luke warm, some item even cold, not fresh, so disappointing. Won't be back.  Oh and the bill for two was $30.

THIS McDONALD'S WILL GYP YOU FOR MONEY!

I ordered a Quarter Pounder and a Double Cheeseburger through the mobile app (I had a reward that I redeemed).  Went to the drive thru only to find out that I needed to pay twice even though the order was already paid for in the McDonald's app.  I explained to the manager that the order was already paid for; the manager claims that my card didn't go through even though it was in good standing.

Just what kind of restaurant is Caspers Company (the franchise owner of many McDonald's in the Tampa area including this one on West Kennedy Blvd.) is running?  Poor customer service and now into stealing customers money?  That is not right!

Just to let you know before you stop at this McDonald's.  Buyer beware!

Always heard about the Rivershack Tavern and one of the main things I always heard about was that it was a friendly place to go out and listen to good live music. So my wife and I decided to check it out one evening after a long day of running around doing errands. 

Well, from the moment we both walked in, the people there made us feel out of place. It was like a scene out of one of those movies where the needle scratches on the record and everyone looked at us like we were from the other side of the tracks or something. I've lived in New Orleans my whole life and I've never been somewhere where the locals look at me like I'm from Mars or something. (Not that there is anything wrong with Martians.) One gentleman grumbled under his breath right at the door and made some off color remark about my wife and I being there which I didn't really care for but for the sake not making a scene and giving the place a chance, we both ignored him. 

The bartender was really friendly and asked if we would like to see the bar menus which we did. The food there is reasonably priced and there is a lot to choose from. We both ordered burgers as well as two pints of Abita Amber. As we both drank our drinks and waited for our food, we turned around to watch the band play. Not sure what band they were but they seemed really good, it's just that no one was really interested in them. In some New Orleans bars, people move to the music. Even a nod of the head, at times. Not here. Everyone just kind of sat there in a trance just staring. Maybe because it was a Sunday night and people were dreading the upcoming Monday? Who knows. 

The food came out and it was fantastic. Burgers were cooked just right and seasoned to perfection. Our bartender even came to check if we were good which is definitely a plus. All in all, it was an alright experience, but I had kind of hoped the place would be rockin a little more than it was that night. Maybe we'll stop by again on a Friday or Saturday night.

I had a 50 minute drive home to ponder this review.  I wanted to be generous.  I was so hopeful when I walked into the place.  I thought I could find a way to rationalize a solid three star rating.  I just can't!

If it wasn't for a pretty cool ambiance and vibe, along with a stellar waitress (Sondra) this taco stand wouldn't even be worthy of the two stars I am giving it.

One of the guys I was with mentioned Cheap had some "Supper Club" promotion.  Apparently it's all you can eat and drink from a limited menu for $20.00.  You can't possibly go wrong with that, can you?  OOPS!  You can!!!

I am actually sitting here with the itemized bill in one hand, and the Cheap website page opened to the menu to figure out just what is was that I ate.

I started with the Spicy Tuna Roll ($6.00), and the Volcano Roll ($8.00).  The spicy tuna wasn't so spicy.  The volcano roll is served with "dynamite sauce".  The dynamite was a dud!  Sushi is one of those items where a mediocre product can be masqued by a well done plate presentation.
