You would certainly expect at least that in a hip and trendy place in one of Tampa's hip and trendy nightspots, wouldn't you?  Not here.  It's not that the presentation was bad.  It was perfectly average.  Even the wasabe paste was bland!  How does that happen?!  On a scale of 5, the sushi earned a solid 2.3.

Next up, Bandarillas ($8.00).  The menu describes them as, "Marinated Chicken Skewers, Grilled with Cannellini Beans".  Marinated in what?!  The chicken was rubbery and flavorless.  The beans were okay.  The plate earned a generous 1.9.

Then came the Patatas Bravas ($4.00).  They are, "Fried Potatoes, Aiolli and Spicy Brava Sauce".  There may have been brava sauce on the plate.  It wasn't spicy.  That was aiolli?!  I'm working out the frustration, and feeling a bit kinder.  Let's give tham a 2.1.

Along came the Sliders (2) w/Shoestring Fries ($6.95).  Is there possibly a more flavorless frozen beef patty served anywhere in North America?  Doubtful.  My friend never even touched his.  We both agreed the fries were decent.  The patties earned the dish a 0.8.

With maybe 35-40 minutes left in my two hour spree, Sondra asked if she could bring me anything else.  All I could say was, "I think I should stop now."

So you're reading this and wondering, "What the heck is he complaining about?  With drinks, he probably consumed $45-50.00 worth of stuff for $20.00".  I know!  It sounds crazy, doesn't it?  How is it possible to feel so bent out of shape for all that fare?

It's Cheap Magic!  I would have never dreamed it possible.....

Very busy for breakfast but the establishment is large and seems to get people in and out quickly. There is also a large sitting area inside while you wait for your table which is nice. 

My husband and I split a skillet and a full order of biscuits and gravy and it was more than enough food! 

We will definitely go back!
Excellent food, service, and ambiance. Friendly servers. New festive decor. Always a favorite local business.

I'm giving it 3 stars because i'm not really a crab fanatic, but I think it still is worth a visit.  

Firstly this place is impossible to find on a stand alone GPS.  If you are planning on using a Garmin or a TomTom don't.  I know of 2 other car loads that got lost using one, Google maps seems to get you here with relative ease.

Decor of the place is very fitting.  Left side of the store is more of a take out place where you can pick out your own crabs and place your order to go.  To the right side is a sit down restaurant, appropriately decorated with seashore paraphernalia tastefully placed.  The drinks served in mason jars, and tables fairly clean.  Came here for lunch on a sat was please that we got seated right away and food was served relatively quickly.  

Crabs were appetizing.  I tried the old bay one and friend got the garlic ones.  I think I'll try the garlic ones next time, since old bay is available on the table.  If you like the eggs in the shell, remember to request the female crabs.  They work with you to get it for you if they are available.  

 I think you should only go here to get the crabs,  the other dishes seemed to be lacking.  Someone at our table got a seafood pasta dish but stated that it was flavorless.  He tried adding, salt, oldbay, garlic sauce from the crabs but still dish never got any better.

It is what it is.  The food is above average.  I had the lobster ravioli and the appetizer special which was stuffed long hots which were both very good.  The service is cordial and our food came out in a timely manner.  The server didn't pour our wine but who really cares about that.  We will be back and I think it is a great addition to Havertown.

After living in San Diego for 7 year I feel that I know my Mexican food.  This place was great.  The fact that it is a BYOT is awesome since it saves money bringing your own tequila.  Food was excellent and service was attentive.  Last but not least, the margaritas were ginormous!  My fiance and I will definitely become regulars there.

The worst experience at a restaurant ever today. Literally maybe 5 tables taken at this place, super slow so we went - 4 adults and 2 children that didn't even sit with us just played at the playground. Took over 30 mins to get appetizers, didn't even get water asked for until 15 mins passed sitting outside on a hot day. Ordered drinks that we cancelled and they still brought out to us and charged us. Then because the kids drank water charged us 18% gratuity to the table because we had "6" people at our table (the two kids who were playing at the playground). Waitress was terrible and never checked on us - hour and a half to get 4 appetizers and 4 beers during happy hour when it's slow and then forced to give $15 tip - cannot believe we experienced what we did.

My group of 5 went to Buca yesterday evening as part of a birthday celebration. We had a lovely time! Our server was very attentive and we got very fast service. The atmosphere is intimate and the noise level is low, so it is easy to have a conversation at your table. This was our first time to visit this restaurant, so we were unsure what to expect.  We ordered a large chicken parmesan and a small rigatoni.  The amount of food we received was amazing! It was served hot and delicious! We couldn't even finish the rigatoni so we brought some home with us. For 5 people, our bill was very reasonable.  We are already talking about our next trip to Buca!

Complete scumbags. We bought gift certificates during the pandemic to help out small businesses like this stay alive. So when these gift certificates were getting ready to expire, I called the businesses to see if they would still honor them and everyone said yes. When I went in today to use it, the owner or manager said nope. Then as I was walking out and other customers saw what he did, he tried saying he will honor it. I still walked out in disbelieve. You try to help out and this is how they act. Never again will I come here. Zero integrity.

Love love love their breakfast!  My bf & I love this spot!! The wait to get a seat can sometimes take a while but food comes out quick. I had their cannoli french toast and it was AMAZING!!! Take out is good too, would highly recommend.

I visited again. I got four great beers on a flight for $10--Petrus Pale Ale, St. Feuillien Tripel, Liefmans Goudenband, and De Dolle Dulle Teve. Amazing!

And the garlic herb fries were delicious. The beer can chicken? Also good, but with a bun that couldn't handle it, it was just WAY too soggy. Could barely hold it. At three stars this hipster magnet stays.

Good food at great prices. Obviously, the biggest pull here is the $4 bargain breakfast: two eggs any style, potato latke or grits or homefries, with an orange slice, a heavy portion of bread, and coffee/tea. I always know someone there when I have go in.

Staff is efficient, friendly, and sweet. Incredibly busy on weekends.

The food was fine, but I was really turned off when I was watching a server making salad and she sneezed. She tried to cover her sneeze, but it looked as though that was not enough. She didn't change her gloves and continued to use her hands to make the salad. It was disgusting. I have three stars because their breakfast was nice.

Whats the attraction here?  Over-priced, average-at-best food, but quick service (hence the 2nd star).  Must be fir those who have no taste....both physically and euphemistically.  Won't be back.  Nashville is just down the road with over-priced, yet delicious, food.

Nothing special, wait was long.  Won't come back

Came here to celebrate a co-workers new job opportunity.  What was supposed to be a nice quick lunch turned out to be a long, dragged out meal.  The steam pots were a let down as the crab looked dried out.  I got a sampler with fried fish, calamari, and shrimp and it tasted like it was frozen.  The only thing good was the crab cakes with the sriracha sauce.

The waitress we had was super overwhelmed, she got our orders mixed up, she brought out incomplete orders, it took her forever to get us our to-go boxes.  It was just a mess.

We've been to Big Lug twice now and have really enjoyed our experiences. Our first visit was on a Saturday afternoon. It was only sparsely populated so we were able to get a seat at the bar. Bartenders were attentive and friendly. We struck up a conversation with one about their cocktails and the local spirits they use. We haven't tasted the cocktails yet but have had a chance to sample most of their current beers and haven't been disappointed. All were solid with no surprise stinkers in the group!

We had the cheese curds and the Nashville wings. The cheese curds were great and our very first experience with cheese curds at all since moving to Indy three months ago. Cheese? Good! Fried? Good! Dipping sauce? Good! Seemed like a win to us, but can't comment on how they compare to other local curds. We'll have to see in the future. As far as the wings, we found them to be meaty and juicy with secret heat (i.e. you finish a wing and then your mouth starts burning).

Our second stop in was around 9:30 on a Friday night. Much busier at that time so we checked out the upstairs, and despite the cold, the second floor porch overlooking the Monon (and Kroger as it were, but that's okay). It was fun to be outside for a little bit enjoying the crisp evening air and we know this is going to be an awesome summer spot once the warm weather comes around again. The upstairs bar cleared out by about 9:45/10 and we came inside to finish our beers.

We'll definitely be back to explore more of their menu as well as their new brews!

Waffles and wedges is a quaint spot that packs a pretty nice punch!

The good: the menu is filled with several favorite items as well as the option to build your own savory or sweet waffle. In my opinion, I think the best part of the waffle is the variety of things you can have with it. By itself, I thought the waffle was average but the honey drizzled chicken made it much better!

The bad: Cost ($9), which isn't really bad but the waffle isn't that big. The restaurant is really small with seating for about 6 inside with some outdoor seating making it a great place for togo brunch!

An ok place to get absolutely wrecked off cheap margaritas and InBev beers if you feel so inclined. The food is all mediocre, but most of it will sop up all the swill you put in your gut, so it serves its purpose I guess.  It's effective, if nothing else.  And making a bloomin' onion is crazy labor intensive at home, so I'd rather pay the $11 here than start a grease fire at my house.

The place is super-corporate with the ambiance and personality of an Excel spreadsheet. It is staffed almost entirely by local teens and most of them have never seen someone get incredibly overserved, so (again) if you want to get completely blotto at a chain steakhouse, this is your place.

Let's get straight to the point. The pizza pie is a very huge serving!! It is a thin crust. I ordered half margherita (with pepperoni) and half hot sausage! My favorite is the margherita: it's simple, cheesy, and a classic! Caesar salad: DELICIOUS, the sliced onions just added the magical touch to it! Downfall: menu changes up regularly, so if you have a favorite, fingers crossed that it will be there the next time you visit. Coming back to try the garlic knots and pasta!

My mother said, "something kind of rubs me the wrong way about this place". Me too...actually, a few things.

Here are some of those things:
-This seems like the kind of place that puts more attention into presentation than taste.  
-Likewise, there seemed to be more attention to lots of interesting garnishes for each dish, rather than on the quality and taste of the core component.
-I wonder if they pick their staff the same way: our servers played the parts of a cool, hipster staff more than they delivered knowledgeable and welcoming service.

Here are the specifics:
-duck breast was over-smoked, and therefore was kind of one-dimensional
-I order trout every time I am in the midwest, because it is always better here than on the east coast, but when I ordered it last night.  It had very little flavor, and I didn't like the cook on it...to heavily fried rather than having the nice roasted quality I am used to
-panna cotta was quite beautiful and had great flavor, but the custard--if that is the right term--was grainy.
-the busser tried to clear our plates multiple times before we had finished, and the third time, I just capitulated and let him despite the fact I still had a mouth full of food.  (Why was I still eating if the food wasn't that good?  I eat slowly and am never really full when I am not really enjoying my food.)
-our waiters response to the question, "what is the red ale like?" was, "it's a red ale."

Here's what I liked:
-every part of the succotash, though it is notable that we shared this as an app because there really weren't many other starters we were excited about
-the french onion soup.  lovely.
-the mosel riesling; can't remember the last time I had such a good glass of wine for $7...

...which brings me to value.  Portion sizes were fine, and the preps justified higher prices, but the taste of the meats did not.  Also, for $30 entrees, I expect my table to be crumbed after the entrees.

Decor was nice, but the light above our table flicker most of the meal, and it was too cold half of our meal and too warm the other half.

Too many issues to be any more generous than 2 stars.

Bad experience here.  The servers were not attentive, kitchen kept making mistakes, and the food was not that great.

Came with a big party on a Sunday for lunch.  Ordered the ahi tacos and a nikka cioppino.  Total came out to be about $35.  When I had ordered the ahi tacos, I specified for two sauces- a house one for one taco and a Chipotle for another taco.  I also got the side of salad with sesame dressing. When the tacos came out, I was missing the Chipotle sauce.  I was also missing the dressing for my salad.  Although there was quite a bit of fish in my tacos, the fish was unevenly cooked.  Some of the fish was perfectly seared, while other pieces were tough and overcooked.

My friend who got the seared ahi burger received his fish well done and it had to be sent back.  

The nikka cioppino came in a tomato broth and was delicious and flavorful.  It did have pieces of small licorice or something that tasted like that within the broth (which I wasn't so fond of).  While eating it, my friend who also ordered the same cioppino mentioned that hers was missing king crab legs and scallops in it.   I looked at mine and it didn't have either of those either.  We checked the chalk menu inside the restaurant and the printed menu, and sure enough- the cioppino was supposed to have those two seafood items.  We bring it up to the waiter.  A different worker comes out and explains that there was a problem with the distributor for the king crab legs and they sold out of scallops a couple of days ago (but that they had given us extra seafood to compensate for it).  Normally, this wouldn't be a big issue for me- but I feel like they handled it all wrong.   If someone orders something from your menu and you run out of certain items for that dish, shouldn't you inform the customer about the changes ahead of time??!? The explanation also sounded "fishy" (get it? :P) since my friend had ordered a fried cod/scallop appetizer and he received it.  

Any way, not the best experience and probably will not come back here if I can help it.

24-hours, and (now) non-smoking! (Thank you, smoking ban. I didn't need nicotine smoke with my eggs.) 

Surprisingly lower on the grease than I expected - hey, it's a diner. I always expected a bunch. 

A good standby for late, drunken nights. Bring your own DD. Also good after other late-night activities, such as flights and grad school group meetings.

Not sure why this place gets such great reviews. 

I didn't chose to go here but was brought with family. Normally these touristy, loud places do not appeal to me. We arrived by boat so we came through the area where they transfer fresh fish from their catch. I like the idea of eating actually freah, hardly transported fish. But that's about the only thing I liked. 

Our server was inattentive and only came to take our orders and deliver them. He never came by to check up and we had to signal him down not once, but three times to make comments about our orders. 

We ordered the full order of cold boiled shrimp  that were slightly mushy and came with only one small, half filled souffle cup of cocktail sauce. What are you supposed to do with that amount of of cocktail sauce, 5 people, and at least 20 shrimp? That was our first attempt to wave down our waiter to ask for more, who didn't come over until much later when we were more than half way done eating it (it wasn't just going to sit there) and graciously brought us another small half-filled souffle cup to torment us. By the way, the order came with ONE single packet for wet wipes for the entire table. 

We also ordered the "famous smoked fish spread" which seemed a lot like a pile of mediocre tuna fish with some celery. It was even served with pre packaged saltine crackers. It was offensive and I wish that I took a picture of it but I did not want to offend my family. 

I ordered the almond encrusted snapper salad over a small bed of salad mix, 5 halves of a strawberry, a light sprinkle of feta cheese, and 4 thin slivers of red onion. Not impressed. The only positive I have about that was the portion of fish, which was larger than I was expecting. 

Seafood quesadillas were below average. Not sure who in their right mind would order a quesadilla stuffed with seafood and cheese, but my parents did. Menu states it was served with sour cream and salsa, but instead it came with some wilted iceburg lettuce and tomato. Couldn't taste the tequila citrus marinade. The biggest flavor in the quesadilla was the cheese.

The plates that the food was served on were identical to my college's dining hall. Besides the awful tye-dye ones. Those my school did not have. 

I have never left a review like this before, but I was not impressed. 2 stars because it was at least edible and I didn't leave half way through. I'm not sure if we just had a really bad experience because the place was packed, or if everyone dining there just has low standards. 

We should have just ordered the fried fish tacos so we could have eaten them quickly and got out of there.

I had brunch on a Saturday afternoon in a party of eight. We'd made reservations beforehand, but they weren't too busy at the time. We were seated on the second floor, which, as many reviews describe, had a "classier" feel. 

I ordered the Chicken Curry Naan-wich (I love bready things and the naan caught my attention immediately). Overall, the food was fun, flavorful, and creative--I liked the fusions of different cuisines throughout the menu. However, among the dozen or so dishes our party ordered, there was a huge variation in portion size from The Big Bang to the Seared Tuna that couldn't really be predicted from the menu. 

The Naan-wich came with the Continental Salad (there was also a choice of fruit). The naan itself was heavenly--soft, warm, and a little buttery..The filling contained tender chunks of chicken and had a hint of sweetness that paired well with the naan. The salad was also good, and the amount of dressing (oil and vinegar) wasn't overpowering. I really appreciated the hardy amount of salad, and the sandwich is nice and filling. The Eggs Benedict with smoked salmon was okay, but the hollandaise sauce was overly greasy.

This is the only non-chain Mexican restaurant I've been to, and I love it. The furniture are painted with all sorts of fun and colorful designs, and it's a really laid-back place to eat. The staff are all really friendly, and they greet and thank you in Spanish. 

They give your table warm, slightly salted tortilla chips to start and a jar of salsa that you can pour into a little bowl. The salsa isn't spicy, which is good for me. Yum.

As for the food, I've only been for lunch, but I love ordering the lunch specials so I can have some of everything. I've tried almost everything on that menu, and you really can't go wrong. The list of specials seems to cover most of the possible combinations, and they're all a great, low price.

They were closed (to recover from a kitchen fire, I think) when I swung by a few months ago. I hope they're back open so I can go back soon!
I didn't think this place was good at all. The quality of the fish didn't seem sushi grade since it was rubbery

For years, I have listened to my parents rave about this place.  The Phoenix rolls were a reoccuring theme in these stories as I recall.  When I went as an adult, this place had a lot to live up to.  However, either my parents' memories were skewed with the passage of time, or this place has slipepd a little.  Their food is pretty good, but not out of this world amazing.  I have ordered a few thigns over the years, and even though I always get something different, I swear they bring out the same thing!  Anyway, the poopoo platter is delicious, and the phoenix rolls actually were pretty good.  Excellent service too.

We first word that comes to mind when I think about Ikea is clusterf$#k. Every time I'm here I feel like a lost child whose mother needs to be paged on the intercom, as I inevitably venture off the prescribed path and get terribly lost. 
Another gripe-they seriously need to get more cashiers. I spent 45 agonizing minutes in line whilst buying my sister furniture for her new apartment.  Then, when it was finally our turn, we find out that the piece we plucked from the self-serve warehouse was a three piece set, of which we only retrieved one piece.  Back in line we go.
I guess Ikea is cool if you like Swedish meatballs (I don't) or are good with a screwdriver (I'm not). I'd recommend them for odds and ends like cheap colanders or wall art, but as far as furniture goes, it's not my first choice,

Oh, how I love my Tria. There is little else I love in the world more than tasting different, unique wines. Tria affords a wonderful venue for this activity, and has a pretty romantic, trendy vibe. My man and I enjoyed a lovely evening here recently working out way down the wine list and sampling some delicious cheeses as well.  And possibly since everyone looks better in candlelight and after a few glasses of wine, we had a wonderful night and really enjoyed each other's company. 
The waitresses are always sweet, knowledgable, and willing to impart their well-informed suggestions. There's nothing not to love here my friends!

Crappiest diner I have ever went to in Philly.  I have been to a lot of diners in Philly.
Their menu sucks, their food is mediocre at best, and their service is awful.  My husband & I went once, and after ordering our sodas, our waitress sat at a booth with some lady & had a chat for about 20 minutes.  We left $5 on the table for our sodas and left.  Pretty ridiculous.
Travel a little further up Frankford Ave. and visit the Dining Car.

So I wasn't overly impressed with this spot, but not so disappointed that I wouldn't give them another try. Then again there is a wide berth for anyone willing to deliver tacos to my door in 20 minutes flat. 
The tamale I ordered was pretty good. The quesadilla was really the main offender as far as I'm concerned. It wasn't cheesy at all, just very chicken-y. I'd honestly rather have a quesadilla from Taco Bell. 
I also ordered a beef burrito and ate it the next day. That was fairly good and heated up well. Again, I just wish there was more cheese. 
Delivery was exceptionally fast and friendly. I will give this spot another chance...maybe I caught them on a night when they were running low on cheese.

I'm not sure I get all the Chipotle hype.  Especially this location.  It is extremely narrow and near impossible to find seating at lunchtime.  
The staff seem to be almost robotic...don't dare ask a question about rice when they shout "chicken, beef or pork."  It will completely throw off their groove, and you will be on the receiving end of a nasty little look.  I speak from experience.  
The ingredients are fresh, I guess.  But when they all mix up in your little bowl or burrito, they are indistinguishable from one another.  Nothing special here my friends.

Unbelievably amazing and creative sushi here my friends.  First things first-get a reservation. Even with a reservation we waited about 45 minutes, but it was well worth it.  The restaurant did give us our apps for free for waiting so long, which was a nice gesture.  This place is very tiny and fills up quite fast.  I love the open kitchen concept they have going on as it adds to the cozy atmosphere.  And don't forget it's a BYOB. 
The designer rolls are awesome.  I love fruit infused sushi and this spot has a lot of that going on. My favorite by far was the Kraken roll.  I forget all the components, but there were cherries in it and it was delish.  The Godzilla roll was fabulous as well.  Anyone who loves sushi needs to get here ASAP and taste all the awesome stuff they have going on here.

I normally don't trust any Uptown Vietnamese restaurants, but after reading the positive reviews about this place, I decided to give it a try, a lot of people liked it, so it can't be that bad, right? It was beyond bad!! I had the beef pho and it was literally just beef! No other kinds of meats were added. I've never had a bowl of pho that only has one kind of meat, except for chicken pho! The soup has no flavor whatsoever, even after adding all the sauces and herbs, it was like eating instant pho at home, so disappointed. I also ordered the soda lemonade, and it didn't taste anything like soda lemonade. I'm sure they have other dishes that are better, but if you're specializing in "pho" then at least make it edible. I walked out hungry after dining here and will never come back again.

I went here for NYE dinner and the place has great food but small portions. 

The food is latin-american inspired and has great options, however, I did feel they were a little limiting with their menu and the quantity is less than expected. The menu online was a little different (taco options were different) from what was provided at the restaurant so I was slightly disappointed. However, I was very pleased upon trying the buffalo cauliflower tacos and seitan tacos. Both were delicious. The cubano club was also very good and it was a good sized portion for  two.

Came in during 2nd street festival expecting a bit of a crowd. Happy to report it stayed on second street and didn't make its way down here. It's a great spot with indoor to outdoor space, liter and half liter drafts and games to boot! Definitely one of my fav spots to enjoy a summer night with friends.

The first thing I ordered was hot tea. When it arrived it was Jasmine, but certainly not hot. Barely warm might be a better description, which means by the end of my lunch it was totally cold.

After ordering my bún with charbroiled pork & spring roll, I was presented with chopsticks and  a small plate of spinach leaves drenched in the kind of "Oriental" dressing typically reserved for all-you-can-eat hibachi joints.  I guess this was some attempt at "salad", although I've eaten at my fair share of Vietnamese restaurants and never had it before.

The vermicelli in my cold noodle bowl were not the kind I usually see in this dish. They seemed more like angel hair pasta than rice vermicelli. So be it. But there was so much leaf lettuce in the bowl that I wound up picking a good two cups' worth out to get a good balance of greens to noodles.  

Maybe I shouldn't have wasted my time because the pork was overcooked & so chewy, I had a hard time eating it; the spring roll was "ok"; but there wasn't much cuc, pickled radish/carrot, bean sprouts, or mint in there to liven things up.  No cilantro. Watered down nc mm pha poured over top & mixed around didn't improve the flavours. 

BTW, this wasn't the first time I'd eaten at this restaurant. I was underwhelmed then, but wanted to give it another chance. Looks like I was right the first time.

Let me start this review by saying that we have followed Ho Ho Choy from their original location on Dale Mabry. Over the years the quality has steadily gone downhill. And even the dining room makeover at their current location doesn't help the results. 

Shrimp dumplings with chives & scallion pancakes both suffer from a lack of either herb.  The pancake is also small & rather greasy.

Sticky rice is a decent portion, but other than some diced mushrooms and a teaspoon of ground pork, has nothing in it. Where's the lap
cheong?

Sui mai has no seasoning & a weird texture.

Chicken feet just tasted boiled; didn't eat more than one.

Beef chow fun with black bean had a lackluster sauce and very little flavour. Apparently  three skinny strips of green pepper & a few bean sprouts were supposed to be "the vegetables" in this dish.

In short: tasteless dim sum & not worth the price.
Yummy!!! Simply awesome! Great food, awesome service!!! Arugula Salad oh my :)) hormone free wings!!! Dan Marino picked a winner!

The service has gone so down hill here since the return. 
Most of their regular bartenders and servers never came back. 
Seems the same with the food quality. 
Manager doesn't care or wear face covering correctly and doesn't care that service is slow and got the order wrong

When the right staff is on it's a five! 5 stsrz

When the cats away the mice SUCK!!!  3 statz

Typical of most the Beefs in Florida. 

Great beer selection!

I really want to love Kahootz. It's local, they have tons of beers on draft, the bread pudding is worth leaving my husband for. But twice now my steak has been overcooked! I thought maybe the first time was a fluke, but it happened again. I did say something the second time and they comped my steak. That was great. I just find overcooked steak an unforgivable sin in a steak house. I guess I'll stick with their brews and bread.

........ did not impress at all :-/

- Small portions - like really small
- Don't know what's Gluten Free, the server had no idea what I was talking about - scared
- Expensive - WHOA
- Food was so/so - came out luke warm - meh

So all in all, if you want to be over charged for small so/so food and drinks - this is your place.

There menu has huge!!! But the service was great, the food tasted good and we would definitely go back. The prices were excellent, it was like $30 for 3 of us to eat...nice! We had a couple traditional dishes and I had the seaweed/seafood soup and it was good, not the best I have ever had, but definitely good either way.

We have a friend who LOVES Waffles on Maple. When the one opened in Metairie, he was so excited. Like SO. EXCITED. So we gave it a try. We need to call him and find out what's going on in that head of his. Or maybe there's been a huge issue with the second location? 

We went to the counter and ordered. I'm always a little irritated when a counter service place asks for tip before you've even had any service, and the lowest grat offered on their Clover POS was 15%. To be clear, all they're doing is running food out, and we generally don't tip food runners. But okay. 

There issues with the POS system and the owner/manager had to get a little tutorial from the girl working the other station. But it took us a little time to order. We ordered a Bayou Crepe, a Hangover, and, since there was no signage in the bakery case, had to do a bit of pointing and "no, what's this one?" to figure out what was in there. (PS everything was banana nut bread.) We ordered a little banana nut flat cake thing (not a loaf) and took our number and went to our table. Asked for waters while we waited so felt better about that 15% tip. 

We were right by the door and ended up moving. It was clearly clean the patio day and mops and squeegees were coming in and going out. I love cleaning, but it was just a lot of traffic. 

Food came out fast, and as it turns out, too fast. My Bayou Crepe, a crepe filled with crab augratin, came out first and I let it hang for a minute while my husband's food came out. Coffees came out in paper cups. Husband's Hangover arrived, and this savory waffle topped with grits, scrambled eggs, and soy sausage looked gorgeous. The gentleman who had rung us up delivered the waffle and said "enjoy!" and we had to ask for the banana nut thing. So no one is expediting. But apparently, no one is actually cooking either. 

This food was microwaved. The crepe, despite the pan marks, was not crisp anywhere. Not on the pan marks, not on the edges. It was soggy, like a gas station burrito. The flavor of the filling was incredible, but the disappointment in the consistency wasn't something I could get past. My husband's waffle had crisp looking brown edges and they were just soggy too. We don't know if the food is cooked at the original location and then brought over just to be heated here (there is a Waffles on Maple van parked out front that would work great for this), but it's a shame.  The flavor in everything was quite good but there was no texture - it was just hot glop. And I don't mind a bowl of stew but not when I've ordered a waffle or a crepe. I also don't mind paying $40 for breakfast but that stings when it's not made fresh.  

The banana bread was no better. The walnuts tasted old and we didn't come close to finishing it. Cafe at lait was just non-chicory coffee with cream and the cappuccino was a latte. 

It was like eating in the airport. Everything sounds amazing, the place looks cool, but seating is tight, food is cooked off site and microwaved, and is overpriced for what you actually get. We won't be back, but are quite curious about the other location.

Oy, so: I didn't hate it, but I wanted so desperately for this to be better, because I remember LOVING Friday's as a kid - It was always my celebration spot of choice for good report cards, birthdays, etc. But alas, I guess I and my taste buds have grown up and TGIF I suppose hasn't kept pace. 

Went with a host of family members with varying levels of pickiness, so I will say in their favor that their menu is so extensive that there was certainly something for everyone. Started with the spinach-queso appetizer which was essentially undersalted cheese with an occasional spinach leaf that would surface after much digging (though it was served with a little dollop of some surprisingly good guac, which WASN'T EXTRA - take that, Chipotle!). Then four of us split two of the 2-for-1 meal options + a Caesar salad, so a pretty good deal financially: the ribs were tender and sweet, the salmon with its teriyaki glaze was fine, the sirloins weren't as bad as I expected, the broccoli was soggy but had a nice zing to it, the mashed potatoes were good, and the lemon soy Brussels sprouts were actually quite yummy (but cost extra, and their accompanying "crispy" croutons were soggy). I also ordered a cup of French onion soup, which was one of my faves from childhood, but it was horrendous - effectively lukewarm brown water, utterly tasteless, requiring maybe a solid minute of grinding away at the sea salt shaker before it became palatable - this was not the soup I remembered. The manager was kindly receptive to this criticism and graciously took it off our bill. 

Overall, everything was... fine. Shout out to our waitress though, who was warm, attentive, and had a remarkable memory!

I went during the week at an off time to avoid the wait.  I could see how annoying the line could get because of the way you order.  I thought it was more of a sit down restaurant but you order right when you get there.  It's also pretty expensive for a breakfast place.  I spent $27 on bonuts, the hash, a side of grits and coffee.  (Id rather go to Kitchen Notes spend $26 and get way more for my money) $3 for a coffee is a bit ridiculous when Starbucks is $1.50.  The hash was delicious and it went well with the sweet bonuts.  

Overall,  this won't be my new brunch place unless it's an off day and I'm wanting to splurge.

Great pizza! Thin crust, tasty cheese. Very limited toping selections, possibly because they're still fairly new. But really, who can beat a classic pepperoni pizza anyways, if it's done right? The pizzas are huge too, so if you're solo or not feeding a few folks you can order by the slice. The pizza here reminds me of Gulf Pizza in Algiers Point (which you should totally check out if you're a Pizza Delicious fan!)-- high quality toppings and cheese on a thin crust pizza.

Taco lunchbox - 2 tacos, a side (sweet chili potatoes) and a munchkin size donut. All for around $11-15, depending on the taco you choose. 
I chose the shrimp - a good amount of shrimp inside but there was only 1/6 of an avocado on each taco, so a little bummer there. 
A salsa & chips starter is only $2, which seems fair, considering most of the time chips & salsa are free; the salsa had zing and wasn't watery though, and none of the chips were stale. 
Overall, a pretty good meal! 
This is supposed to be the most famous taco place in Indiana. Don't go to California or Austin if you don't want your world rocked by tacos.

This place is really great.  The gentleman who greets you when you walk in he is just a pleasure I can't say enough about him.  He mentioned the CEO of the company was plating in the back and I spoke to him briefly and again an absolute nice guy to chat with.  The place is very informal nothing special but truly the experience was great.  The food was excellent and the only reason why I didn't say five stars is because I would've liked to of seen a little bit more chunks of bigger meat ... I would even pay a couple dollars more for it.  Other than that the food was delicious well priced excellent all-around.  I really can't say enough good things about this place.

I can't wait to come back.

Loved our server. Very laid back setting. I must say whoever has to clean thoose peanuts they allow you a to throw on the floor better get paid doubled definitely something fun they do for customers but what a mess!!!! Food is good. The loaded mashed potatoes are amazing definitely generous with the butter but whenever I come here I dont order very healthy. The steak is exactly what I expected when I ordered it juicy and delicious. I added on riblets to my meal for five dollars more and they were also great. I added a little extra bar b q sauce for extra flavor and devoured majority of my meal. I definitely recommend you sign up for there email club they are always having all kinds of specials and great deals and if you sign up they send coupons etc. I just got a 10off for my birthday from them. Also they have a kids eat free day. A bogo on fajitas once a week. There killer salad really is..
Country fried steak is good too. Give it a try you might be surprised. . ;)

My boyfriend loves this place. I think that the flavors are in their favor and I really enjoyed my bowl but from now on I will bring my own hot sauce. The only thing they lack is a great hot sauce other than that no complaints so BYOB on the hot sauce tip and prepare to sink your teeth into something mighty tasty.

If you don't mind waiting in a line that's 20 people long, this place might be for you.

If you like crispy pizza crust, this place might be for you.

If you like the layout of a Qdoba or Subway and having the ability to dress up your pizza exactly how you want it, this place might be for you.

If you like white pizza more than red pizza, this place might be for you (I think their white pizzas are better than the red).

If you're looking for a pie that's more artisan and less pizza-shoppy, this place might be for you.

My experience here was A-OK. The lines are ridiculous, but the staff move as fast as possible. The size of the pie is enough for one person to eat if you're pretty hungry, but most likely you're going to have a slice or two left over, which is actually a little annoying because it's not enough to save for another lunch.

I can't get on board with Tinto for two reasons -

1. I'm simply not a fan of tapas.

2. The first time I ever had octopus was here, and it was one of the most memorable experiences (in a bad way) I've ever had. The plate that came out was straight up tentacles, little suction cups and all. I'm not used to eating gummy legs unless they're fried, you can call me amateur, but it grossed me out right away. Anyway, when I clamped my teeth down for a chew the leg shot from one side of my mouth to the other. It was so hard and inflexible. I gave it another chance, chewed again, and the same thing happened. I could not make a dent in the thing. So I spit it out into my napkin (which I never do). A friend I was with advised me that the technique was to simply swallow and not chew...my theory is, if you have to swallow food like a pill, maybe it's just not edible.

Anyway, this was definitely a "meh" experience. The dessert was good. The food was too scarce. And the octopus was frightening.

Pass.

Nudy's is not a cafe, it's a diner. Now that that's out of the way...

I had the chance to dine here for brunch/lunch recently, and the most remarkable thing about the experience was how magically fast the food came out after we ordered. It felt like we blinked and our food was out in front of us - piping hot and delicious. We sat down at our table at 12:07 and were OUT of there by 1 pm. I wasn't trying to have such a speedy lunch, but that's just the way this joint operates. They want to turn the tables over on the weekends. 

The menu here is colossal. There's really no other way of describing it. Do you want dessert for breakfast? Peaches and cream with pancakes? French toasts of a thousand varieties? A shrimp entree, chicken fingers, or some crab Benedict? This place has it all, in typical diner fashion.

If you're needing a no-frills restaurant with a huge menu that will be guaranteed to please all, Nudy's may be right for you!

I am surprised with how awful our experience was.  We arrived at 5:48 pm on Saturday and were seated promptly.  By the time 6 pm rolled around, nobody had come to our table.  We decided we'd give them until 6:10 before we left.  at 6:05 a fairly large table was sat on the other side of the table.  I decided to keep an eye on them and see if their server went to their table.  They did - almost immediately.  While we still sat there with our menus and nothing else.  Our server finally came over to take our drink order at 6:09 (20 full minutes after getting to our table) - she was friendly enough but really had zero personality and seemed unaware that we had waited so long, although I had seen her walking around in the restaurant while we waited.  We placed all our orders.

I got the chicken sandwich with no onions, bf got the fried chicken meal, and the teenager got the half rack of ribs.  The 2 stars are for the chicken sandwhich and the ribs, which were fine.  oh!  and we got a cup of clam chowder which was pretty tasty.

The main issues were with the corn on the cob that comes with the fried chicken meal.  As soon as the plate was placed on the table, my boyfriend asked if he could have new corn.  I've included a picture to show the weird mushy brown corn that he was given.  She said ok and went back to the kitchen.  She didn't ask what was wrong, or offer any apologies.  It took quite a while for the replacement corn to arrive.  When our server brought it back, she said "here's some more corn for you" and left the bad corn on the table (we had removed it from his plate and put it on one of the side plates that we were given for some reason).  the new corn didn't have the same mushy brown spots, but he only had 2 bites of it.  It was cold and hard and unappetizing overall.    The server checked on us once, when she brought the replacement corn, but not again after that.

I did try to get the attention of the gentleman walking around in the button up shirt, because he appeared to be an authority figure, but I couldn't flag him down.

By the time we got the bill, we just wanted to get out of there.  

Prices are definitely not in line with what you get.  I wanted a drink, but the drink prices were really outrageous, so I stuck with a pop.  

I have no desire to return.

MOST of my food was amazing!!  The steak was cooked perfectly and wonderfully seasoned.

We started with escargot.  Which was cheesy and buttery.  Very tasty.

Then we both went for the sirloin.  As mentioned, it was a perfect medium rare.  I went with the Rice Pilaf for my side and definitely regretted that decision.  It was very dry and tasted way too earthy.  I'm saying that to be polite... it tasted like dirt.  So obviously I didn't eat any of that.  I'll go with potatoes next time.

We managed to save room for dessert at the end and went with the dessert trio, as it gave us a chance to try out a couple of things.  It included the raspberry creme brulee, the rum cake, and the chocolate souffle.  I'm a sucker for creme brulee and this was one of the best I've had.  Though all three were delicious and there was nothing I didn't like!!  I did find the souffle to be a little too sweet, but the rum cake balanced that out.

The service was friendly and efficient.

The ambiance and atmosphere in the lounge were very warm and inviting.

I ordered the veggie burger and was super pumped when our server (who was awesome, by the way) brought it out - It was huge, obviously handmade, and looked awesome.  The first few bites were pretty good (not incredibly flavorful, but good), but it was ice cold in the center.  The center 50% of it was cold enough to make me nervous about eating it.  
Luckily, my boyfriend and I had also ordered a basked of onion rings to share.  They were delicious with light, crunchy batter around hand-cut onions.  They were super greasy, buy we didn't mind- we were craving a little junk food :-)
I'd say 4 stars for service, 2.5 stars for food, 2 stars for beer selection, and 0 stars for decor/atmosphere.  I'm no math wizard, so I'm just gonna call it 2 stars overall.
It was better before from what I could see. They don't have the coco pops anymore, which was a disappointment. I still like the place.

I like this place and they have good food but service is awfully slow. Our server (with a costume for a fire-department woman) was also rude. I was surprised by that and wanted to leave a word with the manager but didn't get a chance.

The food was at best Medicare. The only thing that I enjoyed was the ambiance. The waitress was rude and lost one of our credit card and almost accused us of losing it until she found it and was barely apologetic, Also it was quite noisy.

Wanted to get an authentico cheesesteak in Philly. Thought this place fit the bill with its "high end" offerings of ribeye steak, but in the end it was pretty greasy and not cheesy enough. Not bad, just wouldn't go back especially since it's at a premium price point.

Went here with a group for a team dinner...nothing spectacular but A-OK, the pork chops and the meatloaf we both very good. Service was quick and friendly, the homebrewed beers were good, and the prices were very reasonable. Would go back.

Went thru the drive thru today and ordered lunch. I checked the bag before leaving and instead of the rice I ordered, there were French fries...ok, no big deal. I drive around and tell them that they made a mistake. English isn't the first language spoken here so she promptly blamed me, saying I did ask for fries. (I hate fries). Ok, she takes them back and to my amazement, opens the box and puts the fries that I had in my hands, back into the area with all the other fries!!!! 
I'm done!!!! I can never eat there again!!!!! I wonder what other things that should have been thrown away weren't and I may have eaten. 
Completely disgusting.

Three stars...not bad but certainly not deserving of more than three. I'm not sure I understand why people love it here so much. There isn't anything that struck me as bad necessarily. Maybe I just don't  understand the hype. The food is fine..Not good. Drinks are okay too. Nothing stands out to me as cool or unique or over the top good. 

Again, nothing wrong with an average bar. Just nothing special. I think the big draw this that there are not a lot of options in Des Peres.

3 Stars for donuts. 1 Star for service. 

My wife's boss brought some into the office one day. My wife loved the donut so much, she even brought one home for me. The plain glazed donut was very good. She then informed me it was one day old. It made me wonder what a fresh one would taste... 

Looking to fulfill a week long donut craving led us here. Though its across town from us, we hoped to satisfy craving. Our excitement peaked as we were greeted with the mouth watering smell of fried fat and sugar. For me, it went downhill from there. 

Have you ever gotten to know someone through the stories of a mutual friend but was disappointed when you actually met that person? Yeah. I met Doughboys today. Our server was a young, petite brunette with the scowl of Jillian Michaels from the Biggest Loser. She rushed our group of four. 

"What else?" she demanded, like the mean old lunch lady in grade school. 

"Whoa! Chill your donut hole!" I replied, in my head. She proceeds to ring us up and disregards the fourth person with us. She rolls her eyes and doesn't apologize.

Anyway, for my wife, the first bite of her glazed chocolate was what made her smile. I take a bite of my jalapeño and cheese croissant and was bummed when it didn't have the heat nor the crisp. The saving grace of this donut excursion was the second lady that helped us out. She gladly warmed up my croissant and even delivered it to the table. Thanks kind lady.

I'll be back for the big boy. Its about 6 inches in diameter and about the thickness of a small pillow.

After having lunch here, I remember why I haven't eaten here in a long time. After every meal I've had here, I always feel I overpaid for a sub par meal. 

They offer a lunch special menu for $7 something for a cup of soup, 2 entrees, rice, and a fried wonton. I had the basil pork and chicken with egg noodles and mixed veggies. Other offerings were chicken curry some veggie dish and something else not worth remembering. Eh. After enough hot sauce it actually tasted like something. The pork and chicken were both over cooked. I won't be back for a while...

I feel like Passariello's is missing the mark right now. They moved into Haddonfield's cutesy King Highway business district but lack character or charm. The environment is sterile and corporate...like they're hoping to franchise and go national or something.

Most importantly, the food is just plain mediocre. It's not your hometown pizza shop. You walk in, grab a swipe card, and walk station to station to select your meal.

All the food is on display and they cook it to order. I selected two slices of pizza, grabbed my mom a plain cheese slice, and then selected a couple desserts for us.

The checkout area looks like it would be self service, but it's not.

Both pizza slices I had were pretty bland. The four cheese tasted and looked like a plain white. Hardly caught any pronounced cheese notes. The chicken and broccoli alfredo was stacked high but the quality didn't match. My mom said the plain cheese slice was nothing to write home about as well.

For dessert, I was told the coconut snowball wasn't great at all. The chocolate lava cake was pretty decent warmed up though.

I feel like this would be a great place for group outings or kids birthday parties. They base their business model off sensory overload and flashiness. There are plenty of seats -- so much so that it looks like a cafeteria.

Staff members were friendly and answered all my questions. The food came out promptly. Nothing was downright poor, but it wasn't a meal to remember.

Also, Yelp, please update the business name. I tried to edit it but you guys didn't accept my changes. I doubt the 'a' in and is supposed to be capitalized...but the 'k' in kitchen likely should be.
This place used to be called "Franklin Mills" but they changed it's name to "Philadelphia Mills". There's definitely a modern take to it this time around and there are more stores here.

We used a Groupon for a return visit to Yemanja for the first time in over 10 years.  We are not experts on Brazilian food, I have only been in Brazil twice and ate more churrasco.  Our friends who lived there and co-workers from there, preferred Café Brazil.  

I like the atmosphere, very homey.  It was not busy at all for a Saturday night, but we were early by Brazilian standards.  Ms T and I started off with some decent Empanadas Camarao.  They were piping hot and had a creamy filling that had some tartness with the cream.  The shrimp were flavorful.

Ms T ordered the Xin Xim de Galinha.  This comprised two chicken breasts in a creamy coconut milk sauce with some shrimp thrown in.  It had a little chile heat and was excellent over the rice.  I had the Lombo Ipanema, which was pan seared slices of pork loin with pineapple.  It had a tangy rich pan sauce from the pork and fruit.  It was served with black beans over rice and some potato salad.  All were very good.  The pork was tender, moist and flavorful.  One slice was thinner and slightly over done, but all in all it was very good.  I love simple black beans and rice and these fit my taste.  I also liked the style of potato salad with mayo and whole grain mustard. (not sweet, no Miracle Whip).  Farofa was also part of the pork dish.  I have to admit I don't "get" farofa and don't usually eat much of it.  

Both were very large servings and we brought food home.  I would definitely go back and would take friends.  Both dishes would be re-orders but there are certainly more good things to try.  I will say the salad Ms T had and the carrot soup (of-the-day) I had were not anything special.  My soup was barely warm and pretty plain.  The main courses made up for it.  I also liked the iced tea which was smoky, somehow.

This was a return visit to Ocha.  We had a good "groupon" that needed to be used.  With just the two of us, we did not need to order a lot but in general it was very good, with one exception.

After a couple of trips to the West Coast (Seattle and Portland) we fell in love with the teriyaki that is everywhere out there.  We have been looking in St Louis for that style and have not found it.  Ms T is not a raw fish eater, so Ocha is a good choice because of the Thai offerings.  This time she tried the teriyaki chicken and found it to be the same as the previous two places (Fuji Sushi and Sushi House.  None of it is worth ordering.  Again, she had a dry piece of grilled chicken breast with some bottled teriyaki sauce on top.  Apparently the style of doing Teriyaki that is West Coast, has not translated to St Louis.  This is simply, not good.  So lesson learned, I think we are done trying.

We shared Thai Potstickers in Panang curry.  These were very good.  I liked that the Panang curry was not overly sweet.  I ordered an Angel Roll again as well as nigiri of yellowtail, tuna and sea bass.  They were out of sea bass, but all of the others were very good.  

I am not a reliable judge of sushi, but I like this place, although I doubt if I could distinguish it from others.  I recommend against the teriyaki.  I will stay with three stars until Ms T gets a Thai meal that she likes.

Ever since I saw the photo of sea bass in Sauce in September 2014 I have wanted to dine at Jax Café.  Finally, nearly a year later, Ms T and I joined the D's here for Saturday night dinner.  We were excited to dine here since we are fans of Sidney Street Café.  We took a good bottle of wine, corkage is $10.

Jax is a nice little place on a corner in the Benton Park neighborhood.  Parking can be a bit of a problem because it is street.  We were able to get within a couple of blocks.  We had reservations and were seated promptly.  Our wine was opened and we just ordered the Fried Asparagus as an appetizer since we had already had a nice starter at the D's house.  The asparagus was breaded and deep fried with some mozzarella and served with an aioli.  It was the best part of the meal after the wine.

Ms D and Ms T both ordered a Chicken Breast that was served over couscous.  The chicken was very plain, pretty much unseasoned, relatively tasteless and generally uninspired.  Ms D and I liked the couscous though, which included some cherry tomatoes and an occasional raisin.

I grew up eating fresh walleye from fishing trips to Minnesota.  I have always said that it is fish for people who don't like fish.  So I almost ordered it, but had my mind made up for the Teres Major.  Mr D did order the Walleye and was underwhelmed.  I was picturing a nice filet, paneed to a golden color.  He received three small cross-cut slices with skin on that just looked steamed to me.  when I saw it, I was glad I did not order it, however.......

My Teres Major was not really any better.  I am a fan of beef chuck; braised, roasted and ground for burgers and meat loaf.  It is about all I buy.  I was hungry for a steak and decided to try this trendy, cool steak, taken from the chuck and purported to be the second-most tender muscle on the beef.  It was cooked properly (medium rare).  It was not really tough, but certainly could not be called tender.  I had some difficulty cutting it and it was what I would call, solid.  Chuck, even the teres major, just does not work well as a steak no matter what the chefs are pushing.  The bigger issue was that this was unseasoned and the meat tasted sour.  I don't think they touted it as grass-fed, but I wondered.  It just was not well flavored.  It was served with baked beans, a huge serving of overly creative, ill-conceived baked beans, made of all things, with red kidney beans.  Nothing should be made with red kidney beans.  This was heavy, sweet and sour and loaded with onion and a few of those raisins again.  I barely touched the beans.  I really wanted the oyster mushroom Bordelaise and dirty mashed potatoes that they listed on the menu on-line.  (they don't maintain their menu up-to-date on their website).  The final accompaniment was some corn bread that I can safely say was the worst I have ever eaten.  It was somehow powdery-floury, like it was made from corn flour rather than corn meal and the flour was not all wetted.  This also did not get eaten.

All the way around the table, we were underwhelmed and even disappointed.  It is not often that all four of us get meals we would not order again, in a place like this.  When we walked in, I was expecting so much more from Jax.  I had visions of taking Bro J and TT there.  The menu reads much better than the food.  Our service was fine but the chef missed the mark both in concept and in execution.  Apparently this might be a better place for the Sunday brunch.

We made a second visit to Hendricks with our dining partners, the L's since it is on their side of the Big Muddy.  Hendricks continues to do a great business and may be the only barbecue game in the close local area.  They were busy and I recommend reservations for a Saturday.

We managed a free appetizer based on a Yelp instant coupon that came with check-in.  For this we tried shrimp and grits.  Having just returned from the North Carolina coast, I can't say that the shrimp had the most flavor, but I liked how they were prepared with a lot of coarse black pepper and a nice sauce over the top of some very cheesy and creamy grits.  I could see splitting this with Ms T again if we return.

The L's both ordered fried chicken and received huge portions along with two sides each.  The chicken looked nearly burned to me and the breast meat looked dry.  I'm not sure I would order fired chicken here based on the appearance of what they received.

I stuck with a Pick Two this time based on the Whole Shebang sampler from last time that allowed me to rule out turkey and sausage.  I also ruled out pulled pork since knew Ms T would get it.  I selected brisket and St Louis cut ribs.  I have to say the meats were fine but maybe not up to my original four stars.  The brisket was OK, a little dry and actually plenty salty.  This was pretty much the same as the previous visit.  The ribs were not as good.  I just had the impression that the meats were not particularly fresh on this night.  They did not taste stale, that is, old, but they were not wonderful.  Lately I have been having significantly better at Sugar Fire.

I still liked my collards.  I avoided the horrible pureed onion slaw having learned my lesson last time.  Ms T had more cheddar grits and baked beans.  Both were decent.  The potato salad is made with small cubes of potato.  I liked the mayo dressing for not being sweet or mustardy, but the potato was undercooked and nearly crunchy.  I know, everybody has their own preferences.

Bah. 

This place stinks. It's in a great location - huge space. The host was quick to seat me and friendly. The waiter was kind but didn't come around much. The salsa was sweet and the hot salsa was too spicy. I skipped their "famous" margarita and just went for dinner. For $8 I got an enchilada that was about 5 inches long - it was like a mini enchilada. The plate said it came with "lime vegetables" - they were sliced, raw carrots that tasted like nothing. The rice was bland and the beans were runny. Everything was wrong. I ate almost nothing on my plate and the waiter did not ask if anything was wrong. I could have told him - but judging by my friend's plate in not sure that anything else would have been much better. If I go back it would be to try a margarita.

Honestly this place is the best Dim Sum in town. I have yet to try anything I don't like.

Here are my faves: OG egg roll, shrimp shu mai, scallion pancake, soup dumplings, and pork bun. 

Honestly I personally challenge you to find a better pork bun than here. (Spoiler: you can't).

Everything is authentic.

Staff is very kind, and service is quick.

There is plenty of parking on Race street, or any other surrounding street.

I come here a few times a month and could eat here every day for the rest of my life

In search of good fish tacos, I was directed to Loco Pez by a talk thread.  I ended up bringing along the brother and his wifey to help me on my journey.

There were a few things that caught my eye on the menu, but I was here for tacos and so tacos are what I got.  I ordered 2 fish, 1 pork, and 1 steak.  The pork and steak were both ok.  The flavors were there, but both needed some sauce to help make them better.  He felt the same way about the tacos. The sauces were fun to mix and match. 

The fish tacos were good, but the piece of fish was so tiny, it was more cabbage than anything else.  Surprisingly, the waffle fries my brother ordered were really good.  I don't even like waffle fries.

Service was awesome.  Cash only...good thing we had that dinero.

I never had such a carnal experience eating vegetarian fare as I did when I devoured the Samantha's combo fare.  I arrived at the perfect time, with only 2 indecisive ladies in front of me.  My order was made with "a little spice", but it was enough to keep me grabbing for the water.  I didn' t know I was such a wuss.

I took my order to go, but not before grabbing a few of the pickeled veggies at the bar and squeezed my way through the line of people that was now out the door.

Back in the office, I had a fun time mixing all of the ingredients together for one bite and then some of the ingredients together for the next bite.  This platter is literally a control freak's dream.  The falafel was perfectly crispy and I never had such flavor.  The latke was huge and I kept telling myself that it was somewhat healthy as I could see and taste the flecks of veggies inside.  My favorite was the eggplant, which was so delicious and not mealy as eggplant can sometimes be.  

It came with a huge portion of veggies and hummus, which turned out to be too much for me to finish.

I have been trying to eat healthier and more vegetarian lately and so Mama's is going to stay at the top of my list.

I'm not sure why I have eaten here so often. At best it's good. It's never great , ever. And I'm talking like 25 years of eating here. We usually go before a show and I always leave and say we should have tried someplace else. The service is always good but it's very dated and not in a good way. You could do worse.
I only go if the wait at Vietnam is too long. It's good . Really but I like Its neighbor more. They are less expensive. The food is always ok.

Went for happy hour. They do not have happy hour. I'm sure they used to? Sat at a table near the bar. Service was very nice. The restaurant is pretty enough. We ended up having a light dinner. Two cocktails, 4 raw oysters, they were ok, fried calamari, it was not very crispy and Thai sweet chili sauce is boring. A salad which was ok. The small filet was cooked perfectly and was very good but looked so lonely in that large plate. The side of potato's gratin was the best thing. So I went for happy hour but I ended up paying $180 for two drinks and a light dinner. To be fair I left a giant tip . I can't wait not to return.
Hanks is a diner. It's ok. Years ago sometimes Andrew Wyeth would stop in to eat. He's dead so why bother?
I'm sorry to say I've been here so many times to keep trying this place and give it the benefit of the doubt. It tastes bland and it's way overpriced.
Just what palm harbor/Oldsmar needed....an awesome raw foods place. I had the "burger" and it was awesome. My friend got the "pizza" and it was amazing as well. Can't wait to go back and try more!

There were 4 in our party and overall, everyone was very happy with their food.  Our friends, who live in Philly and have been having a hard time finding a good Thai restaurant, said this was the best Thai they have found so far.

The service was friendly and attentive and our server even ran out to our car to give my friend her purse (she had left it in the restaurant).  We were really grateful.

The only criticism I have, and for me it's an important one, is that the pad thai was pretty dry.  There wasn't enough sauce or moisture to it.  The overall flavor was very good, but it just wasn't moist.  Otherwise, everyone was very happy with their appetizers and entrees.

 Not sure if I would visit again, only because pad thai is my favorite dish and it was disappointing at this restaurant (to me).

So, I ordered a pizza with a side of marinara and pepperoncini. They had no problem charging me extra for the sides. But they just didn't give me the sides. With receipt in hand, I went to the counter and was ignored for over 15min. I used to be a frequent customer. But I will never eat here again!

I feel this is my fault for going to a chain for steak, but everywhere else was packed. Came with my family for dinner the other night and we left disappointed.  We called ahead and the hostess assured me there was no wait at all, we walked in 10 minutes later and she informed us that there was now a 20-30 minute wait for a table....what? I ordered ribs which came out decent. My husband got the bone in rib eye which was cooked nicely but it was a little tough, especially for the cut he ordered. My uncle had the porterhouse which came out burnt the first time, when they sent out another, the meat came out tough and chewy. My mom had the lamb chops which were completely overdone and tough. She reordered it again and it still came out tough. The manager was nice about everything and tried to rectify the whole thing. He even gave us free dessert. The 2 stars is for the service but I give a 1 on the food. Poorly executed food that lacked flavor for the most part....my cousin had to ask for steak sauce for his steak....enough said there.

I don't even know where to begin to describe our experience at this restaurant.

I picked this restaurant because of the positive reviews and went there last night with out of town friends. I was EMBARRASSED that I recommended this restaurant to them. While I understand that Covid has affected the restaurant industry, we should not have experienced the following:

I made a reservation for 6:30. I kept calling to add one more person to the reservation and they didn't answer the phone each time I called so I left a message but they never checked their answering service. I got a text at 5:55 that my table was ready and it turned out that they thought the reservation was for 5:00. I wasn't even at the restaurant yet.

When we arrived and sat down we asked for water and were told they don't don't provide water to their guests. You have to purchase a bottle of water for $4. That's $24  for water for 6 people! I have never in my life had a restaurant flat out refuse to put tap water into a cup when they're serving people dinner. 

One person in our party only ordered an entree and asked that it not be served until after our appetizers and they brought it to him twice before everyone else's dinner was served. He sent it back each time. When we got to the entrees, his food wasn't hot and he asked if this was just the same food that had been sitting. He was told that they had boxed up the other entree for take out and this was a fresh one. But they didn't give us the other entree, so "boxed up for takeout" apparently means that after trying to serve him the food twice they boxed it up and sold it to someone else. 

The waitress' accent was very hard to understand and even harder through a mask. Her attitude was nonchalant and she did not seem to care about the issues we were experiencing.

My friend ordered a salad and didn't realize that it  came with her dinner so we asked the waitress if she would remove the charge and appropriate it as the salad that came with her dinner and she refused to do so. She said that she had already put the charge in the computer and it would be too much trouble to fix it.

The food was not very good. I have had much better and fresher tasting sushi. A lot of their rolls are made with chopped up fish instead of whole pieces which is cheaper for them but their prices don't reflect that. My son's chicken teriyaki was over cooked and the sauce was burned onto the bottom of the serving dish.

After I got home I felt very nauseous and since I hadn't eaten since breakfast I can only attribute that to the food.

When it was time to pay the bill, the waitress asked for the credit card without even bringing a check. I had to ask to see the check rather than just handing my card over for whatever they wanted to charge. 

It seems like everything this restaurant does is an attempt to save money or overcharge. They don't provide physical menus even if you ask for one, they charge for water, $1.50 for a little spicy sauce, using the chopped fish, refusing to count the salad as the salad that came with my friend's dinner, etc. 

All I can say is AVOID THIS RESTAURANT!!!!

Dave & Tony's is a place I passed often and thought about going in even less often. However, one day I decided to go someplace new and this was the spot I choose. I placed my order online and since it was my 1st order I got 15% off my order.

When I arrived about 20 mins later, I waited about 2 additional minutes for my food and my togo order was hot.

Fries: 3/5: For $2, you get a lot of fries. The right amount of crispness would have made them great fries but them being overly salted caused them to get knocked down some points.  

2/5  Slinger Burger: The portion size of the beef was about right for the price, Now the beef was sort of in the middle ( not dry but not juicy either).  I just couldn't get with "high quality beef " mixed with a diner spot dish (fried eggs and hormel chili).  This marriage of foods was not a match made in heaven. 

2.5 St Louis Burger:  "Provel makes it better,"  well in this case  the provel was just there as a after thought . I really didn't even notice it was there.

2.5/5 ..overall this is not a place I would have to go to get a burger but if I did it would be just for a plain burger because all the toppings and specialty burgers i had did absolutely nothing to make the burgers taste better or were great complements.

Meh. I live a stone's throw away (well not with my aim, but perhaps the aim of someone a little bit more athletic) and there is nothing really compelling about this place that makes me want to ever go there. I wish I felt differently because it is oh so convenient!

The food is decent. Service is good. I will try it out again but not really in a rush.

After my review, I received this "compliment" from the business owner:

For your review of: China Rose

Or maybe you should just go eat from a dumpster since all you ordered was fake garbage designed for fat and poor foreigners.


Soooo ordering off the lunch menu is "fake garbage?" Won't even mention the rest of that comment. All I can say is MingYang L, you need to look at the PICTURE of the reviewer before making blanket statements. 

And speaking from someone whose ethnicity is 100% Chinese, grew up in a traditional Chinese household AND lived in China for over two years, I KNOW the crap you serve isn't authentic. 

But to know it's described by its owners as "fake garbage...." 

Seriously, why eat here?? When there are GREAT restaurants (ok, not Chinese in New Orleans) who serve actual food for everyone- and not garbage.

Apparently a BBQ restaurant can survive on 2-3 stars, and I hope it can, and improve, but the comments on here could be very helpful if actually reviewed and put in place. I recently read a book Franklin's BBQ, that describes how difficult it is to run a BBQ restaurant. And I know some places in Central Texas, i.e. Kreutz Market, got away for years with having people wait in two lines, not having any decent sides, and just getting by on the meat. But that's not the kind of Place Johnnie Macks is trying to be, and so I have to review it on what I got.

I went on a Sunday about noon. My favorite BBQ joint only serves M-F lunch, so I went looking for another place and found Johnnie Mack's was open. There was one table occupied, and one guy waiting for take-out. The restaurant is a tad dark, and I ordered and then sat by a window. The table was clean. There is salt, pepper, and Tabasco sauce on the table, and that's it. 

The young guy taking the order was in his teens and was very pleasant and professional. I asked about sausage, not seeing it on the menu, and was told it was no longer sold. So I went with the 4 rib plate, which was very low priced - about $10.  And a can of soda, reasonable at 85 cents, but no cups or ice available. No napkins or sauces on the table reminded me that I was not in a very nice part of town, and they likely have had past problems with vagrants eating up the profits in sauce and napkins. The nearby McDonald's likewise operates on the conservative.

The ribs and the potato salad arrived first, and I was told that the mac and cheese would be right out. The ribs were four large spare ribs, cooked well, and like it or not, covered with sauce in the kitchen. To me, that would be okay if the sauce were cooked on the meat, but this was sauce applied just before the ribs came out. That sauce should be on the side. It was tasty enough, but nothing so good I would definitely want it in every bite. The four ribs were generously sized, and I almost couldn't eat them all.  The meat was tender and tasty.

Not to be gross, but I ended up burping up a rank smoked smell and taste for the rest of the day and well into the evening. I don't ever recall eating lunch, and later eating dinner, and then after that burping up the smell of lunch. Reading some other reviews about the wood or starter fluid (if they use it, which would surprise me) makes me think something was off for my meal. I doubt seriously that would happen to me again, but I am making note of it to see if it does.

The potato salad was okay. Mix mustard and mayo, and toss in the potatoes, maybe onion, and that's roughly what you have.

The mac and cheese was a disappointment, and I didn't eat it. I tried a bite, then another bite which came with a hunk of gristly pork that I had to spit out. I decided the flavor was off. I don't know what the wait was on it, either, as it came out lukewarm five minutes into my meal. The mac and cheese did not look like that pictured by other reviewers.

The attendant who took away my plate noticed I didn't eat it, and I told him I wasn't that hungry anyway. I was amazed at someone's noticing! Lately most waiters just take away the uneaten food without even noticing whether an item was clearly not enjoyed, which I find to be careless. So I give the young man points for taking note.

Most of these comments have been said before, and if this restaurant has such a line out the door at other times, I have to assume my experience is a bit of an outlier on the negative side. That said, comments like mine have appeared from several rational-sounding reviewers, and I hope they can help the restaurant improve and stay in business as we don't have many BBQ places locally. Here's hoping they get to consistent 4 and 5 stars in 2015.

A friend and I decided to give this place a shot, especially after seeing the brisket ramen on the menu. The visit was an overall nice experience, if not a bit disappointing.

The brisket ramen had a delicious flavor with the red chile broth, the matzo was perfect, but my brisket had a huge vein of fat in it and there were only two thin slices of it; for a steep $14+tax, I wasn't even full. 

Someone else has it right that this is a dive bar meets ramen joint, which should turn out to be a good, charming thing. However, you typically feel good for that value you get for your money at a dive bar, yet most ramen joints are inherently overpriced.

It's a cute place, but the room here is tight, with very few tables; so you are probably going to sit at the bar, squeezed shoulder-to-shoulder while feeling cramped in an awkward situation with others. At least our visit was not in the middle of a mad rush of diners, and we could relax.

Cheu is "A-OK" (3 stars) for an occasional treat, but it's a stretch to be a "huge fan".

Wawa continues its streak to open a number of new Center City locations, with this Midtown Village location being the latest here in October 2018.

This isn't the biggest Wawa in town, but it has the most modern design - with the greenish-glass tiled walls. It's a rather slender-width store, which may be challenging for the bustling lunch or dinner crowds this area tends to draw. The checkout area has a ton of registers, which should help during those busy times - it just depends how many employees will be in the store to assist at those times.

We will see how long the 24x7 hours stick, being just several blocks away from a Center City flagship Wawa that had to limit its hours due to in-store violence. And probably the worse design move: placing the restrooms just inside the entrance doors, which is just screaming to invite some of the rougher street crowds that hang out in this area.

However, here's to its success - I'm thrilled to have a location close to my workplace to get my Hoagiefest on whenever I want!

Went here with a ladies group for a holiday dinner and to watch the golf cart parade (which was rained out). It was a Friday and "Fish Fry" night. Should have ordered the fish.
