The white part tastes kind of like wedding cake, the pink is cherry and of course the chocolate!  It was delicious!  It was a near perfect dinner and we will definitely be going back. I didn't quite understand the TV's all over.  This place doesn't feel like a sports bar and I hate watching the cage fighting while I'm eating...all that blood and gross stuff!  But that's just me!  This place is off to a great start.  I hope they keepheading in the right direction!

Hands down the best Chinese food in Chinatown, Philly and South Jersey.  Everything is good.  I.e. Fried rice, salt and pepper shrimp or chicken, egg rolls, lo Mein Noodles, beef and broccoli, spare ribs, fun noodles.  Everything!!! However the service sucks!  They staff have been there so long they act indifferent bordering on rude.  They hardly pick up phone for orders, maybe they are just that busy.  I find myself just driving there and waiting 30 minutes for take out.  Parking is terrible.   That said the food is awesome and I put up with bad service and parking blocks away.  This is my favorite chinese food Restuarant ever.  I make special trips over bridge and whenever in city consider ordering.  Back in the day when David was there often they were 5 stars all the way.  Highly recommend just know what to expect when it comes to service.

Eh. Gave them a try on UberEats since I couldn't get ahold of my preferred sushi place and I was quite disappointed. The order was correct, the sushi just tasted somewhat stale and not fresh. Maybe I've become a bit of a sushi snob, but it tasted like it'd been sitting in a grocery store cooler for a day or two. 

I forgot to specify utensils which was my fault, but there wasn't even soy sauce in the package. I don't think I would order from here again.

I have been to West Side Gravy 4 times now, and really, really wanted to like this joint. I just do not. 

I don't understand cuisine in Collingswood. It has simply left me underwhelmed. If a few of these places (including West Side) were in the city, they would never have made it. 

The food is ok (probably 3 stars- good, but nothing to go gaga over) but the service sucks. Today we went for brunch, were the first ones there, the doors were locked (at 11 am!... I think it is supposed to open at 10?), the server who greeted us was surly, and there were no brunch menus. Instead, there were specials which had to be recited by the server. Can you say awkward? No, I dont want grilled cheese and tomato soup on Sunday morning, thank you. I want to sit down and look at a menu and decide what I want. That's how it is done. Or so I thought. 

And yes, the other times i have been there the service has been below par as well. I dont get it- here is this cute little shop, really cool decor, certainly acceptable menu items, and yet I feel like they are doing me a favor by serving me. 

Anyway, I know I am alone in not loving this place. It simply hasn't worked out for me.

I went here for dinner with a party of five for dinner.  The wait was about an hour but that's to be expected for a Saturday night.  The beer was pretty good although I only tried the Belgian blonde.  The food was pretty good but not great.  I was a little disappointed b/c they didn't offer fries or any fried food for that matter.  I finda felt they were trying too hard with the food and need to add some more "typical" bar food to the menu like a burger and fries.  Service was ok, no issues but not great.

This is THE PLACE to host a large dinner party! My first visit to Giorgio's was for a friend's birthday dinner last year. We had a reservation for 10 people and were seated and taken care of right away in the front room. My second visit was for a friend's going-away party, and that was for a party of 14. Most recently, I organized a birthday dinner for my best friend and needed a place that would accommodate a party of 25. Giorgio's was the only restaurant I called that 1) did not have a buyout fee 2) was willing to host such a large group and 3) did NOT require a pre-fixe! This was awesome for those who wanted to save some money and simply order off the menu vs. paying a fixed $40+tip+tax. Giorgio was so great on the phone and assured me that he would do all he could to arrange the tables in the back room to fit all 25 of us, which made my life SO much easier. The food was amazing as per usual, although it did take about 1.5 hours for it to come out so everyone was starved by 9:45 (but I supposed there was 25 of us...). If you like flavorful, meaty pasta, I highly suggest the rigatoni. The pork special of the night was also amazing, as was the seared ahi tuna! Also, it is BYOB and they're really great about offering to chill your cake/wine/beer beforehand if you like! Fun ambience (a bit loud) and wonderful family feel - nothing but praises for this place!

SEXY DATE NIGHT PLACE (not for me unfortunately). My best friend was visiting from out of town, so I wanted to take her somewhere special that I hadn't been to before either. I'd read that R2L had a great view of the city, so I thought it would be nice to show her that Philly could be beautiful too (haha). In my opentable reservation, I added an additional comment requesting a window seat for the occasion, and when we arrived for dinner, I was blown away. First off, the entrance to the place is through a hotel lobby in rittenhouse and up twenty some odd levels in an elevator. Talk about fancy. I felt like I should have been there with a boy rather than my best friend, but I wasn't complaining. I was also thankful that I had decided to dress a bit nicer that night because women were dressed to the nines. The interior was dark and sexy, the perfect date spot, and we were seated at an L shaped table facing a window with a great view of the city - it really was quite breathtaking. We ordered the lobster mac & cheese to share (talk about decadent), and I opted for the chicken. The lobster mac and cheese is really a must and definitely for sharing, even though the portion is enough for an entree, because it is super rich and creamy and delicious. We were in a bit of a rush all night because we had a party to get to, and the waiter was more than happy to expedite our food and bring everything out as soon as it was ready. Overall a really great restaurant, although next time I will probably go with a date ;)

I was here for a corporate event. The wings, cheese dip, etc. were all very meh. If someone had bought it from the frozen food aisle of Walmart and heated it up in a microwave the results would have been similar, or maybe even better.

Therein lies the issue with food at sports bars. It's a "sports bar". People go to there watch *sports* and to get drunk ("bar"). I don't know of something called a "sports restaurant".

And let's just say it: The patrons at sports bars like this tend to not care about the food *and* not able to distinguish good food from microwaved Walmart frozen food. Thus, the consistently mediocre food at pretty much all sports bars.

As someone who doesn't like beer I love that beer NV offers a Bloody Mary sampler! Every sample was delicious! 
However, the service was terrible. We were there right before the rush came in, but still waited 10 minutes to get the attention of the bartender. And when she did finally come to us she was very short. I can only image what service is like at rush hour.

I have been very pleased with this restaurant until last night The owners were not in had they been I don't think I'd had any problems. .I placed a 34.00 order was told by the older lady I couldn't get a drink because they were closing in 10 minutes, I advised her 
1. We have always been allowed to eat when their open
2. What Or How Am I Supposed To Eat Without A Drink Or Table Service Was Told That Was Our problem.
Another customer came in with food issue the same lady snapped at the customer saying they would add the toppings but refused to make the fish over the lady asked about customer service her responce was I'll give you your money back we close in 8 minutes
I tried to reach out to the owners today to no avail..even thou their banana pudding is very good I refuse to eat where I cannot get a drink or table service it's sad because before everyone was just so friendly. .when my girlfriend asked why we couldn't eat their she was told it's the the holidays to come back in January I just started laughing...

I've been to this McDonald's about a dozen times, mostly drive-thru but sometimes eat-in. It's a nice interior and the employees are friendly. Other than that one experience when they didn't include my Egg McMuffin Sandwich in my breakfast meal and maybe one other occasion, I've gotten the correct order and the food has been good.

Brought two friends here for lunch, and we all thought the food was delicious! Lucky for us, the place wasn't crowded when we arrived (around 11:30 am). The lunch specials all sounded delicious, but I had to go for the shrimp & grits and got to try the calamari as an appetizer. Both were fantastic.

The ambiance was so quirky, and I felt like I was taking a trip down to the Bayou. Can't wait to return!

Lunch at the buffet. Good variety but most dishes way too salty!  Good service, especially from the man behind the dessert counter. I was having a coughing fit from hay fever and he brought me a glass of icy water. Just what I needed.

We went in here last night with the intention of having a nice dinner but we found the place to be cold and noisy and having a very brief menu. We might have been able to find something on the menu to satisfy our hunger but the cold and the noise drove us away.

Had difficulty finding this place. at first thought it was at the tennis club across the street. (Looks like they also have an interesting restaurant to try next time. And you can sit out on the terrace and watch the tennis matches!)

Liked the ambiance of M3. We were hungry but not famished so did not order appetizers. My fellow diner ordered a chicken dish that was much more tasty than my salmon with quinoa. The salmon was a thin piece and very overcooked, therefore quite tasteless. The quinoa was apparently unseasoned as it even needed salt and I am not one to usually salt my meal. 

The service was pretty good, the meal came out very quickly.

I will give them one more chance to wow me! The prices are too steep to not be totally satisfied with your meal.

It's IHOP.  What are you supposed to say about an IHOP.  You know what it is, you know what it's about. You know what they serve.

What I am telling you about has to do with this particular IHOP.

It's so clean. I mean, eat your pancakes off the floor kind of clean.  The dining area. The bathroom. The waiting area.   All immaculate. 

The staff is great at 9 am or 9 pm, everyone is smiling.  Friendly.  Nice.  Polite.

So, why the three stars?

Because.  It's IHOP.

Denny's is a Denny's is a Denny's is a Denny's.

They are useless except for two things:

1) Really good breakfasts any morning you don't feel like cooking.
2) Really awesome breakfasts any time after midnight.

I couldn't tell you a single thing about any of Denny's regular food.  Not their burgers, not their salads or sandwiches.  I have no clue about their soup.  And while they look delish, I've never eaten one of their desserts.

However, I have their entire breakfast menu memorized and committed to heart.  Any Denny's you go to is going to have the same stuff.  There is really no difference between Denny's, nothing to make one stand out over the other in terms of food.   However, some have better cooks than others and some are definitely cleaner than others.  This Denny's is one of the clean ones.  

What always surprises me is when people rate a Denny's on Yelp, they act like they are tragically disappointed, like they were expecting to eat at the Four Seasons with white glove service and a Michelin rated chef.  It's DENNY'S, for heck's sake.  And, to take pot shots at what people are wearing, how their hair and make up looks and making fun of their profession...it's just tacky and classless.  You want to complain about food or service, knock yourself out.  But when you decide to utilize Yelp as your only way to have some passive aggressive fun at the expense of others, well, your opinion no longer matters.

All I know is that any time I have come to this Denny's location, the food is always hot.  The coffee is always hot.  The people are generally friendly, so long as they are not dealing with the antics of your random 17 year olds making a mess, hurling spitballs around at each other or carrying on like some newly freed chimps from the zoo.  

April H. was our server to our party of six and she was quite lovely.  We did have a dirty, stained mug which she promptly swapped out without having to be asked.  She brought more than adequate amounts of ketchup, creamers and syrup to the table.  We were being a big loud and rambunctious, hyped up from a concert my son had just performed in but she remained polite and even laughed with us.  All our food was very good, warm and satisfying as breakfast can be at 3 am.  

Three stars for this Denny's because it was, indeed, A-Ok.

Bleech! Sadly this location is very skimpy with ingredients.  Often food items are stale and often messy with slatherings of other food items mixed in.  There has been one young lady at Drive-Thru who was friendly and professional, but rest of staff has regularly been rude, slow, careless, and unprofessional.  How can a national chain allow for such sub-par service.  Go to the Taco Bell on W 86th by Traders Point or by the Pyramids - much better quality.

Our water tasted like straight up bleach... 

The new menu was very enticing, plenty of tasty sounding options. I had to get the Alfredo since it was eyeballing me. My husband ordered the lasagna bake and loved it. 

Service was okay, our waitress was friendly enough but very scatter-brained. And we were with my husband's boss and his wife but the host st us at a booth that was clearly for two people. I should have asked to be re-seated but I didn't want to make a fuss... blah. Felt like i was still on the airplane I had just gotten off of...
Awesome smoked half chicken good service local beer.  One of the best places in mooresville.

Two words:  GRILLED.  CHEESE. 

First off, the staff was extremely friendly.  I am pretty sure we had a casual conversation with at least half of them during our visit (even gave us pens and magnets!)

You can select from their signature sandwiches (even get it "crunchy" by adding potato chips) or make your own from the list of their ingredients! (This concept reminds me of s'Mack in NYC)

I got the grilled Mac and cheese with bacon and the DONUT with whipped peanut butter and bananas.  VERY GOOD.  The Mac and cheese was okay, I would have preferred it to be more cheesy.

My friend got the regular grilled cheese with bacon on the donut and a side of tomato soup.  The tomato soup was very good!

I would come back and look forward to trying their different concoctions!

Servers are dressed as they would be in any Brauhaus in Germany. Bar is decorated with old steins and animal heads. 

The food is typical German cuisine with American influence. Yes, they do have potato pancakes, Wiener Schnitzel, brats, knock worst, kielbasa, sauerbraten and smoked pork. However their crab cakes and burgers are a good choice as well.

Check out their menu http://www.ottosbrauhauspa.com/

Food is good, but I have had so much better. Prices are reasonable and service is attentive and festive.

Mike's is a friendly neighborhood sports bar and restaurant. They are so serious about their sports that the dining rooms have TVs in them, in fact they have twenty one TVs in the bar and restaurant. Can't miss the game! 

They have continually been voted best of Buck's County for their sports bar and their ribs. They also have a banquet room upstairs. Bar events, live bands, DJ's and happy hour. 

Their menu has so many offerings of appetizers, soups, salads, sandwiches and entrees. They do have great ribs and burgers and they prepare an awesome fish and chips using cod from the Cape! 

Appetizers are not very inventive and is typical bar grub, however their sandwiches and entrees are. "Homemade" food it is like Mom's meatloaf and real garlic mashed potatoes. Steaks, BBQ chicken and they are known for their crab cakes. Give them a try: 

Kids eat free Monday thru Friday, two kids per one adult meal. 

http://www.mikesyorkstreetbarandgrill.com/menu.php
Good chicken.  Was funny... the guy asked if we were Canadian since we were the only white people in there.  No, I just like Carribean food.

I bet their in-dining is fab. My order was to go. I called first to make sure their tortillas, both corn and flour were home made. Yes they assured me. I ordered 24 flour and 18 corn. Pretty obvious we were using them to make something special and not just wanting to chow them in the car. The flour did seem homemade but were folded in quarters! They were so dry and didn't roll easily. The corn were rolled up. Needless to say they all just fell apart. If the corn tortillas were homemade then I will stand on my head, spin in circles while twirling plates on my feet. So disappointed and those babies cost me a small fortune! Nearly $30.00. Cry.

I went here about a month after it opened and it still had some kinks to work out, but if you want some delicious ramen, I would definitely suggest trying this place out.

Cons: The place is small. There are very few places to sit, so no matter when you get there, you are probably going to have to wait. But there isn't actually anywhere for people to wait, so you just sort of gather in one of the corners and try to entertain yourself.

The place is also very sparsely decorated. I can understand going for a minimalist style but this place just feels a little bit empty.

The waitstaff is very friendly but when I went he was still struggling with English, so there was some difficulty with asking about menu items and ordering. It's not bad enough to be frustrating, but just be aware that you should be patient and as clear as possible.

Pros: Like I said, the wait staff is very friendly. Even though there were very few tables and plenty of people waiting to be seated, I didn't feel any sort of rush once I was able to sit down. They were happy to serve us as long as we wanted. Which is good because it was not a particularly fast service.

The daily tea was delicious when I went, and I think it's a great addition to the meal.

The ramen, of course, is what it's all about and I would give it a 4/5. The broth is delicious and one of the best I've had. Be aware though, when the menu says that the soup will come with pork, it means there will be a single slice of (very tasty) pork. If you want more, you should definitely order the extra pork to get (according to the menu, I can't verify this) an extra 3 slices. The egg is also tasty, but if you were hoping for soft boiled or at all runny yolk, look elsewhere.

Unfortunately I can't vouch for or critique any of the other menu items, as my party only ordered two bowls of soup, but if the rest of the food lives up to the ramen, I can't wait to try them out.

I have been to Ants Pants 4 or 5 times since moving into the Graduate Hospital neighborhood, and have nothing but positive things to say about it. The staff is wonderful, very friendly and accommodating. The food is well-priced and delicious; they have fun specials that change frequently, and I almost always recommend.

Beyond great food, the coffee is AWESOME. It's fresh, and better yet, bottomless! The only bad thing about the place is the long wait, but you can't really blame them for that. In the warmer months, when you can sit outside, they're able to seat more people and keep the waiting line moving.

If you're looking for a new brunch place, you really have to try Ants Pants!

I kid you not when I say I got the best bacon, egg & cheese on a bagel I've ever had in Philadelphia. Not that I'm ordering them often, since I don't love the bagels in Philly, but still. This thing was huge, delicious and under 4 bucks.

Will be coming here much more often, since it's a block from work. And the place is surprisingly clean and well-kept. Yay!

Hot dang.

My girlfriend and I are admitted pizzaholics. We decided to try this place last night after reading some reviews here.

Scrolling through the menu and I came across this gem... 'Mozzarella Cheese Stick Pizza,' say WHAT? We had to try it! We were here thinking we'd just get some mozzarella sticks laid on top of a cheese pizza. That would've been cool and all but what we got instead far exceeded our expectations. It was covered with tons of delicious, springy, real mozzarella, topped with marinara, parsley, and basil. I love simple and cheesy pizzas, and this one hit the bullseye. Even the crust was awesome -- A nice thinness to it but it's still substantial, foldable, and chewy.

Definitely give this spot a try. I'm only giving the place 4 out of 5 stars because we've only ordered from then once. We'll be ordering again, though, that's for sure. I foresee tons of other tasty pizzas and sandwiches in our future.

I overheard some people at work talking about this place, and that's all it took for me to bookmark the Sockeye Grill on Yelp.  When a dinner opportunity came up, my wife and I randomly chose it for an evening meal last week.

Let me start by saying there was nothing wrong with our meal, or our evening out.  I was pleasantly surprised by this restaurant, and the great atmosphere it provides.  It's hidden back away from the street, and with comfortable indoor seating and nice patio seating, it's just a really nice spot.  The service was good, and the prices reasonable.  The food was OK.  I ordered their salmon fish-and-chips, even though I was thinking that seems like a weird thing to cook.  But hey, we aren't at the "Cod Grill & Brewery", we are at the "Sockeye Grill & Brewery", and I always like to get a place's signature item whenever possible.  Well guess what...  Fried Salmon prepared with fish & chips is a bit odd.  It was fine, but I think I like something more traditional cod or halibut for fish & chips.  The chips were very ordinary, but I still enjoyed them smothered in malt vinegar like my ancestors in the old country like it. My wife ordered the Reuben sandwich, which is one of her standard favorites.  When she got it, she said is was ...ok..., but a bit bland.  She mentioned a couple of times that it was "dry".  I offered the dill sauce that came with my fish and chips (with me preferring the cocktail sauce anyway), and when she added that to the sandwich she said, "Yes, this is pretty good." (Sorry, forgot to get pictures). 

Now obviously the place is a micro-brew pub, but we are more into pub-food than the brew, and all I can say is that this place is just ok in the food department.  Certainly not bad, but not really good enough to be a dinner destination for me in the future.  I'm sure the place is fun to go to for big games or sporting events, or to have a few beers with friends, since the atmosphere and setup of the place seems great for that.  




[  A roman walks into a bar and holds up two fingers and says, "Five beers please."  ]

Having just moved from South Philadelphia to Collingswood, I have some pretty high standards when it comes to so-called gastropubs. 

Keg & Kitchen is within walking distance of our house and so we went last weekend. We sat at the very fun communal table (but had it all to ourselves) and had good service. Our waitress was a gal named Ryan and she knew exactly when to offer refills of our beers!

There's an excellent beer selection (great mix of local beers and imports) and the prices are great. You will definitely find something you like there.

I enjoyed my grilled cheese and my pretzel, but my husband found his fries with Welsh Rarebit sauce not so hot. There are a bunch of different things on the menu that I'm interested in trying (rare for a vegetarian to find!) so I'm looking forward to going back. I really wasn't sure what the menu would be like because it's not posted on their website (as of now) so the variety of vegetarian options was a pleasant surprise.

Oh and... if you're anything like me and my husband, we LOVE to look at couples who appear on dates and try to speculate whether it's a first date, a blind date, etc... this was a great place to do that!

I visited Birra a couple weekends ago on a double date, with much anticipation, and it did not disappoint. What a great addition to the neighborhood!!!

I had the truffle pizza, and it was truly delicious. I'm not sure why I was expecting the crust to be a little bit thinner than it was, but whatever, I loved the flavors! 

The beer was good (Peroni!) and the service friendly and patient, and surprisingly quick considering they make pizzas to order. The wait wasn't long at all, even though we got there during peak time on a Saturday evening- even if we had had to wait, I wouldn't have minded- the open kitchen was a lot of fun to watch.

Bathrooms were ridiculously nice, but the floors were slippery. I'm not sure why that was- maybe because it's so new? Just be careful.

Prices are a little bit steep in comparison to the rest of the neighborhood, but completely worth it. As they say, treat yo self.

I remember when the food was actually delicious there so I guess that means I'm aging myself. My parents came into town and wanted to sit near the water and chose Bahama breeze. I was hoping to be surprised but unfortunately the food was worse than I even expected. The calamari was rubbery and you could taste that it was frozen. And what was up with the dip? My mom ordered the lobster and shrimp quesadillas that barely had any seafood in it and had the overwhelming taste of onions. I tried to play it safe with the jerk chicken But couldn't believe it did not have any flavor. It's jerk chicken! And the salsa on the side tasted like it came out of a jar and was sickly sweet. The mashed potatoes had no taste. Everything was bland! You can tell that nothing is made fresh there anymore.

Would of been 4 stars if the service was better. Our server took over 30 minutes to take our order! I hadn't been to GrillSmith in years and decided to have lunch with a girlfriend who was visiting. After debating over Bahama Breeze and GrillSmith we opted for GrillSmith. The food was not terrible, but nothing special either. I had the Buffalo chicken sandwich and my friend ordered the fried fish, which looked pretty generic. Coleslaw was very bland and I got about 6 frenchfries with my sandwich. Not as good as I remembered, probably won't be going back again.

We've been to China Grand Buffet many many many times over the years.  And we like it well enough.  They have a significant assortment of Chinese food, some American things like French fries and tator tots, fresh fruit, desserts like almond cookies and little pieces of layered cakes and ice cream, and sushi.  They'll have protein like chicken, and you can get pineapple chicken, mandarin chicken, chicken and broccoli, peanut butter chicken .... there's probably more, but like I said - an assortment of items and an assortment within the categories of food.

Only a couple of things that bother me - that don't stop me from returning - is that the tables don't seem to get clean.  I have watched them wash the tables down after people leave and it doesn't appear to get a good washing.  And then when I have sat down at a table it has a stickiness to it.  Sometimes I wonder if there is a cleaning agent in the towel they are using or is it just water?

The other thing is that they have signs that say kids under 10 must be accompanied by an adult to the buffet.  And I have never seen it enforced and almost always see little kids there making a mess ... or taking something and putting it back!  Yikes.

It's a good value though because they have shrimp and crab and it's all you can eat.  I paid $23 for lunch for my son and I and that included sodas (not included in the price, and you do get free refills).

As buffers go this one is bad. 
Q: What's the fun part of a buffet? 
A: having a little of this and a little of that. 

The problem here is that everything pretty much taste the same. There's absolutely no flavor profile. Absolutely no spice level. It's all just a buffet.

So to end on a positive note, service is much better than the food they serve.

We were here for Memorial Day weekend and disappointed. Read all the great Yelp reviews and it was a let down. The kebab platters were all aveage - lacked marination. The hummus was meh !! All in all below average meal with sky high prices. Don't know how they have 4 stars.

The only reason that this place is getting decent reviews is because there are almost no Thai places in St Petersburg and Tampa. As a result, many of the customers probably do not know what actual Thai food is. For example, the Pad Thai was brought out immediately after we ordered it. This is because they had a batch of precooked noodles that they then mixed with a watery sauce. The taste was completely off. Then, there was their Chicken Satay. Satay is supposed to be grilled, skewered meat. Their version was basically pieces of breaded and fried chicken on skewers. Though the food is edible, it is not Thai food.

There are also a couple of other things to mention that may annoy some people. This place is only open air seating and as result there is no air conditioning. It was very hot on the day we went, but we endured it. The other thing is that all their food is served on paper plates with plastic utensils - not very impressive if one is looking for a nice date place.

Good museum featuring a lot of historical art. It reminded me of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC, except smaller. The collection is a wide variety of paintings, prints, sculptures, and photos of mainly European, Asian and American origin. There was a very cool armor room with armor from throughout history too. Every Wednesday evening is a free (pay whatever you want) night.

While I have been here several times, it appears that the quality varies. In fact, I dined here yesterday with and out of town friend and the chicken was undercooked and bleeding. Additionally, the staff does not present themselves in a professional manor. Finally, the place does not appear to be visible clean.

My recommendation is to go to the Food Assembly Hall at 5th & Broadway for either Prince's or Hattie Bs Hot Chicken. This place is not trying to build a reputation of quality and taste!!!

I had never been to this location and just stopped in for a quick burger to go. I ordered the 1/4lb I believe it was...it actually was very dry, not seasoned and bland. 
I just couldn't believe it, but maybe just an off day! Only one other customer in at 1pm when I stopped by. The woman at the counter was pleasant, took no time to get burger. I'll go back at a later date and have a redo, when I can sit inside and have aa shake as well.

So I went to the Dawg House Saloon on NYE for the Super T show thanks to some nice friends of mine.  It was a good time.

First, I think this place used to be something else but I cannot remember what exactly.  There's a patio out front, a big square bar when you walk in, a stage and dance floor in the back, and tables situated all around.  For NYE they had everything decorated and looking festive.  

As for the band, they were fun and the dance floor was big enough for everyone to shake their ass.  Sound was good I think - at that point the booze was taking over and it seemed fun to me.  Let's be honest, it all seemed fun to me.

They also have TVs and some people I know go there on Sundays to watch football and do their Sunday funday up right.  I think they also have some food to help you not have tooooo much fun.

Give it a try, it is new and if you like bars I can't imagine you won't like this!

I love a good sports bar and, while I am a Sam's devotee, my friends arranged a happy hour so that I could cheat on Sam with Jed.

Jed's place isn't in the most obvious location.  Right off of West End behind the Electronics Express.  I don't think Jed gets as many ladies to visit him as he might like because it is hard to see that he's there.  Poor Jed.

When you walk up you notice that Jed's place has a nice front patio.  Go in and find a nice sized room with TVs and tables.  Up the stairs to the left find more tables and seating around a raised bar and even more TVs.  Up more stairs you will find a huge patio, currently enclosed for the cold weather, with enough space to host the UT Alumni party.  Not bad Jed!

So I sat with my friends and excitedly perused the menu while drinking economically priced happy hour draft Miller Lite.  They have burgers, pizzas, wings, sides, other sandwiches, etc.  I also really liked the option that you could get menu items made smaller if asked - good for when you are trying to stop gorging yourself with huge menu portions.  They had any bar food you would like, plus, PLUS mac'n'cheese as a side option.  Don't mind if I dooooooo.

So I got the Boss burger that comes with a fried over easy egg on top.  Ah, reminds me of that time I was in Amsterdam and they brought me a burger with a fried egg.  I'd never seen such a thing and was intrigued...and excited...and, ultimately, pleased.  Plus I had the munchies something fierce.  I digress.  So this burger was a pleasing large size and the first bite makes the yolk run out pleasantly all over your hands and the plate below.  Nom!  However, I really wish the burger had been a bit more juicy and flavorful...and that they had asked me how I wanted it cooked.  Medium to medium rare thanks.  Anyway, still not bad.  The fries were not as crispy as I like them but had a nice seasoning on them.  At the risk of seeming gluttonous, I also ordered a side of mac'n'cheese because I believe I've found the holy grail of mac and cheese dishes (sadly in Dallas) and I'm always willing to give a place a chance to oust them.  This didn't but it did have a nice bread crumb topping and wasn't your standard cheese mix.  Not awesome but not bad.  A-OK perhaps?

The service.  Man.  The chick we had was pleasant and she managed to get everything right even though we had a ton of people there.  However, it seems perhaps they understaff because at times you are parched for your next beer or waiting to order food or waiting for your tab and your waitress is nowhere to be found.  I think perhaps more staff would help?  Not sure.

Overall, not bad.  They have trivia on Thursdays and apparently karaoke on Fridays.  I do love karaoke at random bars y'all so perhaps I'll give it a try.  Otherwise I will keep Jed in mind when Sam is boring me....but shhh don't tell Sam!

Well the service was good.  The food was OK.  But we will not be back!  

We started our visit off great.  We were greeted and seated right away.  Our drink order was taken and the drinks arrived quickly.  The food was OK and it came out pretty quick.  Our server remained on the ball the entire time.

Here is the problem.  They apparently went with an electronic jukebox system.  About in the middle of our meal the music came on so loud we could not even talk and hear each other.  The last thing in the world I want to hear during dinner is extremely loud music.  I enjoy conversation over dinner and with the music it was impossible.  With this system they now have we will not be returning.  It truly is that loud.
Decided to try this out for something different. It was ok nothing special but nothing bad. I would not go out of my way to come here. I got the peppercorn steak and shrimp rangoons.

The food here is just okay. What I would expect from a chain. I have only been coming here to utilize gift cards. 
Everytime I come, I am less and less impressed. The service is comical. Something is always wrong. It's inconsistent. 
Most recent and most notable, my boyfriend ordered a medium burger. The burger was bleeding. We politely asked the waitress if they could cook the burger a bit more. She claimed that is their "medium" and asked if they could bring it up to "well" for him. So what you're saying is there is no in between?! Total joke. So of course he keeps his burger that is still moo-ing. Who wants a well burger when you order medium?? 
The skillet cornbread is very dry. The only thing I enjoy is the shrimp and calamari. I don't see myself returning once the gift cards run dry.

I love love love Allways Cafe. I have been a customer for about eight years. Their food is incredibly fresh, healthy and wholesome. My favorites are the Sweet Potato Quesadilla, Jerk Chicken Salad, and the Falafel. The atmosphere is very warm and inviting. They sell a lot of local arts and crafts. I have to say I am disappointed that they have removed some really good items off of their menu! Their chocolate bombs are also delicious for dessert as well.

We frequent here as often as possible for their avocado egg roll appetizer - it is SO tasty. Their menu selection is large and can be overwhelming at times; it includes pizzas, pastas, sandwiches, steaks, seafoods, burgers, Asian and Mediterranean dishes, and so much more. We try to pick a different entree each time, and there have been a handful of times our meals were disappointing (especially for the average price of $15-$23 per entree). Most recently, we tried their Korean fried chicken dish and the pasta da Vinci. Both were delicious! Last time, we had the meatloaf and it was unfortunately dry and bland.

The service was friendly and quick, but I can not recommend this place. It was a bit cold and smelly, too noisy for a date, and the meat was ok, nothing extraordinary.

You really take advantage of the all-you-can-eat if you are with a group of friends, but even then, I am not sure the $27 per person plus tip are worth it.

Pass.  I had the tuna tacos, and the 2 little tacos you got were so overpowered by the hoisin sauce you couldn't taste anything else...and they salted the hell out if it.  The chips it came with were stale.  But hey, at least it was overpriced at 15 bucks!! For 7 bucks apiece we got ripped off by the smallest kids meals I've ever seen.  Waitress was good,  but the hostess was completely disinterested. PS-parking was ample.

Above average sushi, pretty good tempura (though a little greasy and some of it was overbattered).  The dinner bento box is a steal at $23.  It was a large meal and fresh.  Service was very good and attentive.  Fair price.

I've been - don't need to revisit. Not at all my scene - touristy, super duper loud, drunken frat/sorority/businessmen behaving 'crazy' vibe, mediocre pricey food. We were there between 6-8:30 on a Saturday night and there were a lot of open tables so maybe I'm not the only one thinking it's just a 1 visit kind of place. 

Server was very friendly and bravo to him for being able to YELL since the music is so flippin loud. Food - super limited options for those not wanting meat. Ordered a small pretzel with beer cheese (not impressed - Applebees is better), a huge plate of spatzle with swiss cheese and side salad (1 of the 2 vegetarian options) - good, but no one could possibly eat, or want to eat, that much spatzle and I would have preferred it without the swiss cheese. BF ordered the Chicken Schnitzel Salad from the 'Light Crispy and Healthy' salads section. There were 2 leafs of lettuce holding potato salad, a few veggies (tomato, cucumber), and breaded chicken cutlets - not at all a salad. Chicken cutlets were tender and good though. 

If you want to get sh*tface drunk and get a spanking in public or have someone play spoon drum on your butt while you stand on a table a la Coyote Ugly, this is your place.
Great food, but why does it smell like the sewer backed up? Gross!!!!  I don't know what is up it didn't used to be that way but now it's like a big turd smell!

I've been thinking about Watkins for many months now - and I keep meaning to check it out. Boy am I glad that I finally did! Located on a small tiny block in South Philly, Watkins Drinkery is an amazing dive / local spot with a WONDERFUL ambiance.  The crowd seems to be pretty local.  I only had beer, but their drink list was great and the food smelled amazing. I can't wait to go back and try it! The food tends to lean towards gamier meats - but they also had a really veg friendly menu, which was super nice to see.  The beer list was fantastic by my standards, and really well priced.  Happy hour drafts are a good deal! It's a little dark inside, and honestly I see it as a great place to go during the winter time to sit back, be cozy, and drink myself into a hole.  I'm a big fan, and can't wait to be a more frequent visitor.

Decided to try Pickles & Swiss today as we were in the downtown Santa Barbara mall and thinking a wrap would be a great and quick to go food to have after shopping. A little disappointed in our experience. Ordering was easy, staff friendly but just be aware of  the up sale aspect. We did go for the "yes we will add avocado", turns our added avocado is an extra $3.00 per wrap, what! That's an extra $6.00; this week you can get six large organic avocados at Bristle Farm for that price. To make it  bite even worse upon  arriving home and eating our wraps it was very difficult to find any avocado. Finally found some, but it was pathetic to say the least (see picture). Chicken wrap was just average in flavor, rather disappointing. Sadly I may not try Pickles & Swiss again. Maybe give them a chance trying a sandwich but no add ons for sure.

SURPRISE.... this restaurant isn't as great as everyone says it is. Housed in a stand alone building on 4th Street  this open design restaurant features pizza and novelle cuisine Italian fare.

Atmosphere       70   Absolutely horrible the music was devastating
Service               80   Probably the best thing offered 
Food                  75   The pizza was a tad above average
Value                 70    New York prices for an okay outing

An interesting menu and good reputation  (a Tampa Bay top 50 in 2016) probably make this a restaurant to visit. As for my wife and I there are two pizzerias in our neighborhood that challenge this eatery for half the price.

Ok, the way that the french fries were cooked the first time, must have been a lark.
Many of you have mentioned the spices on the fries.
I had a portion of french fries that were cooked to the point of being crunchy..
---------------------------------------------
Went back and ordered another burger and fries.
The burger was good.  Good like all the other places around here that buy 85% -92% lean- grass fed ground beef.
The burger was not dripping juicy like a fatty burger would drip.
But it was tasty.

The fries were not cooked to the point of being crunchy, so that was a lark.
The fries were cooked a little longer than other places, just enough to hold a crisp edge for a good 5 or so minutes.

If they could just cook those fries again, to the point of being crunchy....
well done - you'd be hot stuff.
As it is now, your fries are crispier than Gabby's..
Not as crispy as Five Guys.

Your burgers are cooked to order, which Gabby's does not, Dino's does not, and all the other places that will only cook to Medium - sighting the Gov't guidelines.
The buns are buttered and grilled...  5 stars - right there.
Burger is cooked to order..  but not overly juicy like an 85% lean burger would yield.
so...  4 stars there.
and french fries... not crispy like my first encounter with you.
Not outstanding like the first time....  4 stars.

I would return.
You're in the neighborhood, and I want you to survive..

Now, we had a different kind of experience here, the other night.
Our waitress was very intent on having extensive conversations with every single table....
Bree was totally into social mode and not into servicing mode...

We ordered pretty simply..  One roadhouse burger and one roadhouse salad... that was it.
it shouldn't have taken 25 minutes to cook one burger and pile salad ingredients onto a plate.

Our food was good. The salad was  a good enough portion that we could share it and not feel amiss with lack of ingredients.  Burger was ordered Medium and it came out Medium-well.
We were not about to send it back..  We probably never would have seen it, again.

I will try this place again, but I have a feeling I will have a much, much, much better experience
sitting at the bar, next time....
and yes, I will give this place another chance, as I've never had really bad experiences at this franchise..

It's just that good help must be really difficult to come by.

I had the opportunity to try their GF Vegan chocolate chip cookies.
They fell apart in my hands and I actually had to finish eating the cookies with a spoon.

Perhaps if they use coconut flour, the cookies would be more firm and will hold up to holding in the hands.......

Other than that, the taste was good.

Great margaritas.
good service.
clean establishment.
space enough between tables.
indoor and outdoor seating.
good locale.

food: I wasn't impressed with my taco choices.  I got the Korean BBQ, and the special country fried chicken and gravy.
Neither jumped out at me and made me happy.  Very little substance in the taco.. (tiny quantity), and no real pizzazz as far as cilantro, shredded cabbage, whatever...  very dull, in fact.   Salsa was mediocre, as well..

So - food 3.
Everything else 4-5.

I would go back for a pitcher of margaritas, but I'd probably bring my own salsa.

I went to Sparkroot on a Sunday night and I had the 4. fontina, portabellas, arugula with a side of kale chips. The sandwich was great, it was a bit of a wait but the cashier did warn us about that before placing our order, which I appreciated. The kale chips were also crispy and delicious so if you like veggies go ahead and get them.

Also the wine list, although brief, was great because all glasses were $5, simplifies and lets you pick whatever sounds the best to you. I had the Velvet Devil and it was quite tasty. All in all I'm going to have to try this place again for coffee in the near future.

Amy and I have been dining at Houston's since High School. Many of our early dates consisted of dinner at Houston's and flirting. We have always loved the field green salad with buttermilk garlic dressing. Amy is a fan of the Fried Chicken Fingers with Honey Mustard. I love the shoestring crispy fries and their iron skillet beans. We have tried everything on the menu over the years and have never been disappointed. It is consistent service and consistent food quality in a great environment. It gives a local feel considering it is a small chain.

My 5 stars are based on BBQ for the New Orleans Metro area. The Joint is hands down the best. Why? First they actually smoke the meat and get a nice bark. They know what they are doing and take pride in it. I am a fan of their ribs. They do them dry with a nice rub. They come out with a nice smoke ring and bark. The flavor is full and they are always good. BBQ is tough to keep consistency but the ribs are always good-great. I am also a fan of the Brisket. It is never to fatty or to dry. When it comes to sides I like the Mac and Cheese, Potato Salad and Green Salad with Smoked Dressing. I typically finish off the joint with a piece of Peanut Butter Pie. This is quality BBQ in a non-BBQ city. I know that you will come with your bias based on your favorite BBQ (Texas, Memphis, Kansas City, Carolina and more). If you give it a try it will be the best you have in NOLA and a good change of pace to your first BBQ love.

I need to remind myself that all the gambling machines and cigarette smoke does not make this place comparable to vegas. Dorothy and Toto, we're definitely not in Wynn or Bellagio.

We stopped in for the Sunday Brunch (which included champagne). The food was acceptable. Many of the items were hit or miss. Maybe because I was really craving veggies and decent Asian food... but I found the sauteed veggies absolutely divine. Oh yeah the crab legs were pretty good. The omelettes were fantastic... made to order!!

So disappointing. It's kind of a bummer when you go to a place and are told that you can't order anything eatable, despite the menu listing several options, because "the kitchen is closed"...2 hours before the establishment even closes. :( Then, my beverage selection was also not available. The seating to the 2nd level was barricaded to prevent people from going up there because it looked as if staff had cleaned it and didn't want anyone to dirty it before they closed...2 hours later. Staff were minimally friendly and seemed uninterested in being helpful.

This once rough and tumble bar got a facelift a few years back.  I can only review them for lunch or a late afternoon cocktail and snack.  

The bar is huge. There are booths and tables for dinning.   In the cooler months they open the front windows for a great breeze and people watching.   Parking downtown can be a problem, not to worry they have a parking lot!  

So how's the food?  Very good.  I highly recommend the tots -- just like they served at hot lunch in elementary school but elevated to pub grub cuisine via preparing them with nacho topping.    Japanese wings with wasabi ranch dipping sauce -- the spicy wings are lollipopped making them perfect for immersing into the dip.  

Plus the DAILY SPECIALS - Dine-In Only for food and drinks are the best deal in downtown....
 
BURGER MONDAY
$9 all burgers & $3.50 Racer 5 IPA

TAHOE TUESDAY
$3.50 Tahoe Mountain and Tahoe Beer and 1/2 off Large Pizzas

WING WEDNESDAY
Starting at 4 PM - 30¢ Wings & $2.75 Coors LT Draft

THIRSTY THURSDAY
$3.50 Corona &Well Drinks + $7 Fish Tacos

THE WEEKEND
Friday, Saturday, Sunday
$12 any Medium Pizza

THREE AFTER TEN
Friday and Saturday after 10pm
$3 Well Drinks

It's been quite a while since I've done the college bar thing and quite frankly I wouldn't bother with a review because we've all been there (speaking of the environment) But my friend had a bday party in the private room downstairs. 

First I appreciated that because we were on a guest list I didn't have to pay a cover, get frisked or have my handbag rummaged through. I was however scared to death to descend the the very steep staircase that led to the private room teetering on my heels. I held the railing for dear life.

Once downstairs I have to say that I was sorely disappointed with the space. There was absolutely nothing special about it. Just a hodgepodge of tables and chairs, some random booth seats and a bar. No decor, nothing that gave you the specialness of being in a private space. Me and my party pal felt like we had just been shoved into someone's basement. 

Also I was so damn hot I couldn't stay down there. Unlike upstairs where the parameters are all open windows, the basement was cave like. My gf and I made our way back up stairs and nabbed two seats at the bar where we remained for the rest of the night.   Yikes Copa, you can do better.

Long over due review, but what can I say about this Chick-fil-A??? It's pretty big, they have a play area for kids and I always want it on Sunday of course. 

I'm really writing this to advise others to use extreme caution in the parking lot. The adjacency to Wawa along with the strip of stores in back of it means cars are coming from every direction. Leaving the Wawa, trying to get in line for the Chick-fil-A drive thru, or simply trying to get pass cars idling in the back up can be challenging.

Service is meh but something I'm willing to sacrifice for the authentic dimsum experience. They come around with carts of hot foods and you can pick which foods you want. Unfortunately many of the workers don't speak English. I recommend the egg custard tarts for dessert!

The interior of this place is very pretty and theres such a huge variety of yummy looking desserts. However everything is a bit pricey. $4-5 for a brownie or cookie.  My friends and I ordered savory crepes each. I normally like my food with little to no salt but the chicken and pesto crepe was very bland. I wish there was hot sauce or a little more pesto. 

On the upside there was a free cupcake coupon on yell we could use. Unfortunately they dont sell cupcakes anymore and just gave us cider apple donuts. At least they were free!

We went for restaurant week and paid $35 each. I believe it's usually around $70. It's completely worth it for restaurant week! There's a green and red token card that you can flip to indicate if you're ready for more meat or not. They come around with a variety of different meats that they slice for you. The salad bar wasn't that special. There was just a lot of cheese spreads. They also give you some side dishes. My favorite was the mash potatoes.

I'm usually here when we go out on the town for drinks.  They occasionally have dj's with some interesting (in a more odd way) music.  I like their garlic knots but I had once ordered them to find out they ran out (aren't they just dough, oil, garlic, herbs? Can't make more?). Someone on yelp noted that the crust/dough is like paper, and I can agree with that as far as taste goes,  but it's all in the toppings you pick (artichoke, prosciutto, pine nuts, roasted garlic, tomatoes, more gourmet toppings than the typical pizza place). They also have a vegan personal pizza option. They have a bottomless mimosa special (hit and miss though) for brunch on weekends and a bloody mary bar too. The beer selection is pretty good.  The decor is nice and they sell some local art like most Reno local businesses.  The seating is mostly half booths along with walls and some couch seating and a little bit of bar seating. Also to go means your slice on a paper plate with foil (of course a box if you have a whole pizza). Can get busy on the weekends for late night, but worth it!

What a great gem of an Italian restaurant! This very unassuming place was fantastic. Service was a bit slow, but for a Sunday afternoon the place was packed. The shrimp scampi appitizer was wonderful and the leftover scampi sauce was perfect for dipping the hot fresh bread in. The lasagna was delivered to me by the owner who explained it was his mom's recipe. It was delicious. We also had the tomato pie which was tasty as well. And lastly we had the gnocci and shrimp in a blush sauce that the chef said was his favorite! I can see why. Prices are great for the portions.

This was my first time at top golf. We went with a group for a party. The golf part was a lot of fun. You have different games to play with everyone and it was all computer controlled. The balls have chips in them so it can tell where you hit it and keeps score. Pretty amazing technically. Drinks were very good, regular soft drinks, and superb adult beverages. the food was good. A nice selection of bar type appetizers and sandwiches. The place overall is huge and they have the usual gift shop type items. If you have never done it, it is neat for a new thing to do.

Sakana is small high end sushi place located in Montecito, the land of million dollar houses.  The decor is minimalistic and pristine white which becomes a canvas for the extravagant rolls beautifully decorated in a plethora of colorful sauces.  The seafood used was high quality and very fresh, and of course the high price tag reflected that.  I am glad I went and I was kicking myself for not bringing my camera.  Overall, I prefer Ahi or Arigato over Sakana because the latter went overboard with flavor combinations, therefore, was not as successful in introduce nontraditional flavors to sushi.  The same half a dozen sauces range from chocolate to red to orange to yellow to green were liberally applied to every plate like a Jackson Pollock painting.  It was just too much and overshadowed the delicate flavor of the seafood.

The menu at 4 eggs and pizza is all over the place, pizza, burger, Vietnamese, European although I had a feeling that their specialty was probably Vietnamese and French.  I got a bowl of pho for dine in and a banh mi togo.  The pho tai nam exceeded my expectation.  There are only a handful of restaurants here that serve pho, and the bowl I had at 4 eggs and pizza was probably the cleanest and most aromatic tasting one.  I also didn't get the thirsty feeling from too much MSG and salt.  What stand out for me besides the broth was the high quality meat.  Nam is cooked beef and tai is the rare beef placed on top of the noodles and cooked by the hot broth. Both meats were tender and trimmed free of gristle.  The banh mi was also tasty filled with tender marinated pork, crunchy pickled radish and carrots, herbaceous cilantro, however it was pretty small for $10.  The price was comparatively high, typical of downtown Santa Barbara, but a good bowl of pho can take all day to make, so still worth the price in my opinion.  I look forward to try the European food to get a better feel for the restaurant, but do go here for the excellent pho tai nam.

This was my first time trying hot pot so I didn't know what to expect. I ordered the sizzling plate and my friend ordered the hot pot and our plan was to share them both. My sizzling plate came out in a reasonable time so we started eating that. It was exactly what I expected and really aesthetically pleasing and delicious. 

We realized that about 15 minutes had passed and there was no sign of the hot pot. At this point we already finished the sizzling plate. Our plan was to share and eat them together, but it would have been really awkward if we weren't planning on sharing and I had finished my meal before hers came out.

None of the servers had checked on us during that time and we had to flag one down (the table button didn't seem to do anything) to ask for a status update on the hot pot. The server didn't say anything to us like "let me check" and just went straight to the back to ask someone. The hot pot arrived about 10 minutes later. We had to remind the servers to bring us water half way through the meal and then flag then down to fill them up again. We also had to ask for the sauces.

I thought the flavor was good (again, without anything to compare it to) and enjoyed it once it finally did come out.

It wasn't until we were home that we saw a Yelp photo of the menu and my friend realized that we were totally scammed on the hot pot. The ingredients that were supposed to come with it were not inside and instead it was meat, fungus, lotus root, and mainly cabbage. This was really disappointing to find out after the fact.

It was a busy night and there seemed to be a lot of servers. They were certainly hustling around and showing a sense of urgency but seemingly with no direction. Maybe there was no manager that night? I'm not sure how there could be that many people working and passing by our table but NO ONE noticed our empty water glasses or thought to check on why one of us had food and the other was sitting there for 15 min without any food in front of her.

I'm pretty disappointed in my experience here aside from the sizzling plate and would probably rather try somewhere else for hot pot.

The food was decent, and this place would have some serious potential if management could get their employees to 1. actually prioritize customer service and 2. put the correct ingredients in the bowl. 

Not to mention the prices are on the higher end (~$16/entree). Really not worth it.
very good chinese food clean & very friendly staff great place to eat at if ur looking for a good chinese restaurant

My first love at Illinois St Food Emporium will always be the iced sugar cookie.  At $2 a piece they are well worth it.

IFSE is a bit old school diner, a bit neighborhood secret, a bit sassy restaurant.  You order at the counter and they bring it to you.  Menu boards abound with breakfast, lunch and (somewhat recently) a new dinner offering.

I recently went for brunch and grabbed an omelet.  This thing was HUGE and it was served with potatoes (meh) with peppers and some toast.  I couldn't finish the omelet.

DO NOT PASS UP THE BAKERY COUNTER.  You will be a sad panda if you do.

Oh, and if it's snowing, your coffee is free.

They have some pre-made items available in their freezers, too.  You can take home desserts, breads and even entrees. 

ISFE feels like a place with history and meaning in Indianapolis.  Go check it out for yourself!

The location is one of the few spots in Tampa where you can dine on the water & the views are spectacular to say the least.  The food quality, however, doesn't stand up to the prices & that's one of my main reasons for only 3 stars.  We had their signature Calamari Fries and Conch Beignets for appetizers.  The Calamari looked amazing, big & thick like steak cut fries, but when I bit into them, they weren't piping hot and the breading was a little soft & damp.   The beignets were good.  There was a haddock special, which was a nice piece, but not remarkable, and my blackened grouper was served a little tough.

On another note, I had my sister in town, so we had 6 of us including our 9, 11, & 14 year olds.  We sat at a table in the corner, & the restaurant is a little loud, so everyone had to speak up.  A table of 4 adults sat near us halfway through dinner & one of them had the nerve to shush my 9 year old.  For LAUGHING.  (Our kids usually get compliments for their behavior in nice, expensive restaurants)  Not Oystercatchers fault, but what a bunch of pretentious twits.  

Our waiter was OUTSTANDING.

Firm believer in second chances and was severely let down. Tried the ribs this time and got the half rack. The ribs were probably 80% bone. Very tough and very dry. Didn't even want to finish the half rack and it was pricy at $20. The collard greens side was alright but the cured bacon in it was so tough you couldn't chew it. Drinks were ok, service was plenty fine. My friends said the brisket was average. There are better BBQ joints around with better prices.

Worst experience I have ever had here.  Terrible service.  Pizza took so long I had to ask for it to go.  No communication about the delay.  No apology other than to acknowledge yes, it was a long wait.  This place is losing my business.
They do appear to be trying harder, but it seems like every time I get lunch here they mess up my order.

We have been watching this business prep for opening with great expectations and our expectations were met!

My wife and I scooted down on opening day to see just what they had to offer.  We went in about 10:45 so had to order off the breakfast menu (served until 11:30).  My wife ordered the Liege Benedict and I ordered the traditional Benedict.  Both were excellent.  Instead of a poached egg, they were served over easy insuring a good runny yolk to mix with the hollandaise.  However I would have to say that my wife's was the stand out between the two.  It was served on a special waffle and had regular bacon instead of the "standard" Canadian Bacon.  This is what I would consider a "signature item", something that will make you consider this place over others.  Mine was quality. I personally would have liked a smaller more standard english muffin, but the ham eggs and hollandaise were perfect.
  The potatoes were temptingly tasty causing me to have a bit or two extra when I shouldn't have.
  We intentionally lingered for about 10 minutes over our Hub sourced coffee so we could get a shot at the soups, Gino the Soup man soups if you are already familiar with them.   Today was Coconut, Corn and Sweet Potato Chowder and the "every day" Tomato soup selection.  If you can't decide you can get a sampler for $6 for both soups!  Both were very good.  The CCSPC was very unique and the tomato wasn't a bisque style which was a nice change from what normally see.  I did add in some of the "fire oil" that was on the table.  Great addition to the tomato soup.  Really made it pop but not overwhelm the dish.
  The atmosphere is light and open.  Not your normal Midtown feel, but a refreshing change.  Lots of Ambient light.  Lot's of four seater tables and two seater tables.  Just two booths and even a few bar height tables too.  
  We enjoyed the coffee, and they were nice enough to bring some soy creamer for my wife, but don't know if this is a regular thing, so don't hold them to this nicety.

The rest of the menu was full of important words like local, organic, vegan, gluten free, raw and even paleo!  And from what I saw, this is no "vegetarian snob shop" but a real restaurant approach to good food and reasonable prices.  

The only negative that I perceived was the late start time for lunch.  My wife disagrees with me that 11:30 is too late to start serving lunch, but I think 11:00 might be a better time to be ready to serve the lunch menu.

The service was great, especially considering this was the first real day of business.  They may have had some soft openings I didn't know about, but for a first real day, I was very impressed.  Many of the places around town could learn how to open a business from Great Full Gardens.

A few additional notes.
Coke products...but also some Oogave soda products as well.  Gonna have to try these next time.
Gluten Free isn't just lip service here...they understand the allergy side of gluten free.
Kids menu is available too.

Ka
Boom!!  Head splodes!!

Yep.  This was a mind blowing meal.  We walked in for a late lunch early dinner after Moo Dang made our dinner choice for us by not being open on Mondays.  They had a happy hour special on of 30% off apps and drinks.  We ordered everything off the small plates menu, plus the Shao Kao Meatballs and the Momma Lin's Fried Taiwanese Bacon.  It was all great!

My favorite was the fried pork filet.  Just perfectly cooked and spiced.  Loved the Guay-Ah Pork.  This place SEEMS authentic, but what would I know about authentic.  Authentic or not...this place IS really good so far.  The service we had was very attentive, but that was because we came between lunch and dinner.  So if you want very good personal service, go for a dunch!

The place really hasn't changed much since it's Sushi bar days.  But why change something that looked so nice anyway?

I did mention that I didn't really think the name equals the food.  But one of the staff explained to me that the name was a word play and they were trying to avoid all of the standard Asian cliches.  They succeeded there!  But really after having the meal I had, they could call the place poo poo platter palace for all I care.  The food was excellent as was the service.

Food is not worth the prices or any other visit. Service is okay. The space itself is nice, spacious, and clean.
Autumn Betty was just meh. You can taste the goat cheese or the truffle pecorino or the thyme or the walnut oil. All you can taste is the heap of mushrooms on this pizza. Too many mushroom that aren't even seasoned or cooked well. Okay for one slice, but hard to eat a whole pie of mushrooms.
Love and mercy pizza was also meh. Unmemorable. Soggy center. 
14 1/2 was good. I liked the spicy soppresetto. Best pizza out of the three, but NOT great pizza by any means.
Chicken and waffles is a total rip off. The chicken is okay. The waffle is dry and bland. It's a big plate of mediocre $20 chicken and waffles. Not worth it.
The eggs in purgatory was fine. They completely overlooked it the first time so we had to send it back.
The crostanza was probably the best thing. It was a nice little fig, ricotta pizza.
Somehow I asked for OJ and got a screwdriver. I don't even know how you mess that up.
Overall, I would never come back. With such prices you would expect really good food, this is mediocre at best.
If you want pizza, go to Zavino or nomad Roman!

Food is good, service could be way better.
Getting a large table on a Saturday night was pretty easy.
Most apps (not the fries) came it quickly. Though we never got played or utensils until all the appetizers came and sat a bit.
Mac and cheese was creamy and really good. I liked the pickled jalapeños.
The pickled veggies are awesome.
Salt and vinegar chicken wings were unique and surprisingly great. Peanut wing's were just okay.
When the entrees were set down, I asked if we could cancel the fries and the waiter unapologetically said the fries were ready. We asked for two order of fries when we first sat down, along with all the other appetizers. While they said the fries were coming, they didn't come until the entrees and all the entrees had fries. Why even bother ordering them as appetizers.
Burgers are pretty solid (though rare turned into medium so why even ask for how you want it cooked).
Grilled cheese and tomato soup was good as well.  Very filling.
Cleared all our plates except for the plates we obviously wanted to box up, yet still had to ask for boxes at the very end. Had to ask for water refills multiple times.
All the food was good. The service is inattentive and annoyingly bad.

Route 6 was okay, but there was nothing spectacular that blew my mind.
Service was just okay--pretty standard, nothing special.
The fried lobster tails were okay. The breading/seasoning was sort of bland. You get three tails and a great sauce. $22 full price...I would never pay that, but luckily it was half off month.
Lobster rolls were good. Lightly tossed in Mayo. Nice lemony finish. However, the lobster was somewhat overcooked and chewy. Fries were sort of standard. Worth $12 (because it was half off), but I wouldn't go back to pay full price when I could just go to Luke's Lobster which is amazinggg.
The decor inside is reminscent of a beach house which is cute. Location is sort of strange, as there isn't too much north of city hall.
Good place to try while on promotion. November is semi-half off lobster month.

Pastrami & hash sandwich was amazing. Lots of big flavors. Lovely oozey egg on top. Get it.
I've read tons of great about the duck meatball sandwich, but after the Pastrami & hash, I was underwhelmed. Still a good sandwich, but not great or memorable. 
The red eye Danish was interesting. Kinda strange mix of ham and cheese croissant with some sort of espresso gravy in the middle. It worked, but not sure if it'd get it again.
Service was just okay. The decor inside is quiet cozy and inviting.
I think the food and portions are good and I would return to try oner things.

Bon Chon is okay. Service was friendly and the decor is pretty clean and modern. The soy garlic wings taste good, but they are very salty. The hot wings have a medium heat. The wings are nice and crunchy. I love the pickled radish side that come with the wings. The bugolgi bibimbap is pretty standard and tasted good. I like that it comes in a hotpot.
The food cam pretty quickly and the service was attentive. I'm not dying to go back, but it was all pretty good.

This unassuming bar is on the far end of 7th ave in ybor. It's the kind of place you go regularly with friends to shoot the s**t. 

The drinks are pretty tasty. It's exactly what you'd expect at happy hour prices but it gets you where you need to be.

I had the shrimp option on the happy hour menu. I believe it was a taco but I had it put on a salad instead. I've been thinking about this salad all week. It's incredibly delicious and the shrimp was seasoned very well. It also wasn't rubbery, that's always good. 

The waitstaff was always there right when I needed them but not in a badgering way (thank goodness) and they have great suggestions.

This restaurant is located right on Clearwater beach with direct access to the water. Seated outside you have a direct view of the water and good people watching. They have fans that blow a cool mist, so it feels good out there. 

I'd suggest sitting more inward if possible just in case it starts to rain, you're pretty shielded from the rain. Which is what happened to us, luckily we were inward so it was relaxing with our meal.

I ordered a rum runner in the souvenir cup. That drink put me on my butt! It was great and strong. 

Ordered the seafood ceviche, crab fries, and fried shrimp. 

The seafood ceviche was perfect. It was perfectly citrusy and packed with different seafood and veggies. There weren't many chips and it's $3 for another scoop of chips so I just ate the rest with a spoon. The crab fries were disappointing. The fries were over seasoned and the crab was dry so I couldn't finish it. The fried shrimp was decent. 

The waitstaff was friendly and when it started to rain they helped the guests in the beach relocate indoors.
awesome chinese food for the price you pay, love the lowmein and chicken corn soup...reminds me of Indo-chinese joints in Mumbai!

We tried out the Rotisserie Buffet for lunch on our way home after a weekend in Reno. This Buffet is located within the Nugget Casino where we were staying. 

Lunch was $11.99, all you can eat. Selection for lunch was not great, I found myself picking at the food on my plate and didn't really find anything appetizing. Although it was cheap, I'd save my money next time and try out some of the other buffets in Reno.

4.5 stars!

We came around 6ish, because we knew there would be a line.  However, the line wasn't too long and it moved rather quickly.  We waited for maybe 20 minutes?

We were a party of 4 and the tables were definitely waaaay too small for all we wanted to eat.  We had to really clear out some of the food fast before new ones could be brought on (okay and perhaps we were also hungry so we ate like beasts too...)

We ordered:
Chargrilled oysters (different from Deanie's on the previous night, but just as delicious!)
3 dozen raw oysters
New Orleans medley (jamabalaya, gumbo, andouille sausage and rice & beans, portion is for 1)
Crawfish etouffee (DEEEEELISH!!!)
Boo fries (french fries with gravy and cheese)  TIP:  Get the gravy on the side so that it doesn't make your fries soggy!!

I have to say, the food here is simply out of this world.  The ONLY complaint I have is with regards to the seating.  We were right smack in the middle and the table was so small we barely had any room to move around.

Acme has a very sports bar feel to it... so don't expect any sort of "ambiance" but DO expect good food at a reasonable price!!!

They have a 15 dozen oyster challenge -- if you can complete it within X amount of time, your name goes on the board.  More than that, you get to go on the Wall of Fame category.

Our bill came out to be 120 after drinks, tax and tip.

There are lines at all hours of the day, and they don't take reservations.  By the time we left, there was a line about 30+ people long.  So just go a bit earlier than you'd like to eat and you'll be set.

DEFINITELY recommended!!!!
Pizza was okay, but this place is way over-priced. Three sodas, an order of wings & a 2 topping pizza ... $33. For that kind of $$$, the toppings should've been caviar and truffles.

I tried to go there at 8 AM to get a box of donuts for work. Key word: tried.

I'm pretty sure there is only one person working in the entire place. I sat in the drive-through for five minutes with no movement then backed out, parked, and went inside. There were a couple people in line so I waited in line for a few minutes and then left once I realized it was going to take a long time just to buy a box of pre-made donuts.

Maybe I will go there on a day off, when I have all day.

The hot and sour soup was delicious with fresh vegetables and a nice broth. The general tso chicken was okay and orange beef was my least favorite.

They do deliver, so it's a nice option for Chinese delivery.

Love the new remodel!!! It's like a Techy looking qdoba now, love it!!! 

Food was ok, the staff seemed pretty young, a young lady the made the order was pleasant, quesadilla cheese wasn't fully melted. 

Gentleman that rang me up was a whole nother story, rude, disrespectful, nonsense of customer service. 

Eating in was pretty uncomfortable, not sure how to explain, females would get much better attention I guess is best way to put it.

I was excited to come here and try Ethiopian food, unfortunately I was not impressed by the food. I got the zibzib tibs which was basically pieces of beef with onions and peppers served with enjera. Enjera is a thin pancake that is extremely sour. As my friend described it, it taste the a spoiled dosa. The meat itself was very dry. I can't comment too much on the flavor because the sourness of the enjera was so overwhelming that I couldn't taste anything else. The cafe itself is a cozy place and they do serve wraps/burgers/salad for those not interested in Ethiopian food.

We had dropped our car off at the shop to get it looked at and decided we would walk around the area to find somewhere to eat. My wife remembered Costa Vida and has been wanting to try it so off we went.

The set-up is similar to Chipotle and Qdoba. You walk in and decide on what you want (burrito, bowl, etc. They'll then take you down the line as you decide on your meats, beans, veggies, and other toppings. You pay at the end and enjoy your meal.

I'll start with the good; the customer service was good and the restaurant was clean. No issues there. The food, however, was just ok. Nothing special. Chipotle's food is eons above and even Qdoba (which I'm also not a fan of) is better in my opinion.

I was happy when I discovered this place a few years ago. Food was nothing special, but it was generally good and a decent value. I have made the trek down there several times, and either I have come to realize that food is really barely average or the quality has declined. I tend to think the latter. The restaurant was almost empty at 12:30 on Sunday.

Went primarily for the AYCE fried chicken. My wife ordered fried shrimp. We were asked if we would like a roll. Two small rolls were brought out in a basket. The waitress never asked if we wanted more bread; she just took the basket away...before the rest of the meal was served. When the food came out, the garlic mashed potatoes were barely warm. There were two small pieces of chicken (a wing and a rib breast) that tasted as if it was cooked several hours earlier...dried out and not very tasty, yet greasy. A good restaurant would cook fried chicken to order unless it was turning very quickly. My wife's side order of fried corn on the cob was maybe 2" long...about a third of an ear. I was asked if I wanted more chicken and two more pieces were brought out. That was all I could eat...less-than-fresh yet greasy chicken. 

Bottom line is that the quality and value just isn't there. I will never return.

Many times I yelp I wish there were a half star option. This is one of those times. The Mildred's menu, decor, food, and drink selection definitely deserve a 4. But the service--both when busy as well as when woefully slow--leaves much to be desired.

The first time I came was for happy hour. And what a deal. Excellent food and drinks at reasonable prices. Everyone must know this because it was packed. I chalked up the laughably slow, and I-couldn't-give-shit-about-you service to the volume. Though while there was no time to serve us there was plenty to consort with fellow staff.

Despite that the chicken and biscuits was amazing, the drinks were good and strong and I didn't yelp, determined to give it another shot when they could redeem themselves.

I did this for Saturday brunch. We were literally two of six people there. Despite that, service was still slow and unengaged. Example: my friend ordered tea. It took 10 minutes.
