When he server brought it, he poured it, already steeped. Which explains why it took that long. He did not, however, leave the teapot (tea was $4 for one small cup) or bring sugar or cream. Nor did he offer any. Nor did he come back.

Considering we were one of three tables, our food took a really long time. But we kind of expected that at this point. What I did get, though, a pasta with kielbasa dish, was plentiful and delicious, as well as reasonably-priced. 

Overall I really like the food, so If it's close and convenient for you, it could be worth checking out, but be sure to budget plenty of time if you go.

Best happy hour around (with douchiest crowd.)  Amazing after-work deals, value, food and drink specials-all $4! Edamame dumplings are excellent, even though concept may have been stolen from Buddakan, they're tender, juicy, and a touch of truffle makes them decadent. The enormous bowl of fried rice-with fried egg-will fill you up. Brussels sprouts are not healthy in the least but they're super flavorful and taste better that way. Only downside is the throngs of people who also love happy hour here. Tip: try for seats at the kitchen bar where you can watch the chefs and avoid crowds. Back bar is also a bit better than front.

I don't know why a business has posted hours, you arrive at their posted opening hour, and the doors are locked...!? They are inside, but you get no acknowledgement. Llike a, 'We'll be ready for you in a minute. Sorry for the wait.' Nothing. Like, they want you to leave so they can arrange tables and umbrellas etc unhindered. We waited 'til 11:07 and then walked across the river to their competitor.  Watched them slowly arrange their furniture and watched other people walk in and right out. Something is wrong with that. 

Last trip, last month, we were annoyed also. Service and portions were lacking. So.. paired with the facts that the fish pieces in their fish and chips have shrunken dramatically, they bring a thimble of catsup/ tartar sauce upon request so that you have to beg/ bother them for more, the service is disjointed, slow, we won't go back. 
 Sad. Wish the truck was still parked on Moana and Meadowood. They WERE the best in town.

Just wanted to add that the lunch buffet?  Awesome.  Pure awesome.  A group of four of us went yesterday.  The buffet was $15 and included a variety of Indian delights plus rice and naan.  And on top of all of that greatness?  Our server was pretty cool (for a Bengals fan).  He was on top of it - waters always full, attentive, etc.  Another great experience at Veda.

Our household loves Mission BBQ- both for their mission and their BBQ.  Their donations warm my heart. And it's really good BBQ, especially for a chain.  

My go-to is the salmon - it's perfectly cooked and seasoned so well. I love it with a bit of the MD/Old Bay BBQ sauce, although all of their sauces are so good you really can't go wrong.  I'm pretty simple so I pair my salmon with either their delicious mac and cheese or good ole' fries, but we are also fans of their green beans and bacon.  Pair all of this with their corn bread?  You won't be upset. 

We have also used them for catering - our large family often comes in to celebrate our twins and their birthday.  We did their pick up packs and it was perfect- very well packaged, more than enough food, and everything was organized and tasted great.  On top of that they threw in utensils and plates so I didn't have to do dishes at the end of the night.

I stopped in on a Sunday afternoon with my son to grab a tea latte and treat him to a macaron (which was FREE w/the Yelp check-in offer!).

Here's what I loved:
-The lavendar fog tea latte was delicious. It was served at just the right temperature and was flavorful but not overpowering. The cashier let me know it was one of the most popular tea lattes, and I can see why! I'd get this again, without a doubt. 
-Macarons are $2 on Mondays!
-The macaron was generous in size. It was a 3-biter, not one that could be popped and devoured in one bite. :)

Here's what I would love to see:
-The seating situation and the shopping section are merged together in a way that makes it hard to find a spot to sit where you're away from a lot of stuff. I don't know how else to say this. There was a baby shower happening on the upper level, and there were a few tables and chairs where guests were seated on the lower level, but the arrangement was not at all inviting. We ended up sitting at a table near the trash can so my son could eat his macaron. 
-The plate the macaron was served on was wet, and the water dissolved almost half of the macaron (b/c its kind of spongey). Luckily, my son is 5 and so if I pretended it was SO COOL that the water was eating his cookie, he thought it was, but in truth I was a little disappointed that it was served to us that way. 

I've heard that there is a Hoi TEA Toi TEA in the Fashion Mall, which was great to know, as I really enjoyed the tea latte but not so much the setting it was served in. I'll be back for a lavendar fog latte -- to go. :)

My first time eating out  Indian and this place gave me a descent introduction.  Had the lunch buffet ($12.99)  and there is a decent variety.  The food was very good and powerfully tasty.   I came late in the buffet, so there wasn't a lot left.  I enjoyed everything I tasted.  I was happy to see that it isn't strictly vegetarian.  I saw chicken, goat, fish...

The one drawback was that the rice dishes has large chunks of cinnamon sticks in it.  I bit into a cardamon pod and it was very unpleasant.  I am new to Indian cuisine and maybe this is customary, but some people who don't chew their food well may choke on this.

Meh. I came here with my mother & her lover at what was probably an awkward time between lunch and dinner, so the menu was limited. We had appetizers that weren't anything to write home about, including shrimp and the pimiento cheese; the cheese is allegedly restaurant-made, but I couldn't distinguish it from the type one might pick up at a grocery store. It was fine, sure, but nothing spectacular. They did have an acceptable selection of NA beers, which won them some extra points from me. Our server was attentive but tried to upsell us three different times... I get that that's part of the job, but at some point it was a little too much and a little too insincere. There was some kind of construction going on next door (we sat outside in the BEAUTIFUL patio space - points for ambiance) that was loud and made it difficult for us to engage in lazy conversation. For the price, I was unimpressed, but maybe we just came at the wrong time.

Came to Fork for the 4th stop of Cosmo-Con, a UYE/Cosmo tour of Boise Bars in search of the ultimate cosmopolitan.  I phoned Fork a day or so prior with the final head count for our reservations.  We had 15 confirm.  I made the reservations for 7:45pm, 15 minutes earlier than the expected arrive time of our crew (as I like to get there a bit early and make sure everything is prepared and ready to go).  I also phoned the day of the event to confirm and warn that our group would be needing separate checks.  I arrived at 7:45pm and unfortunately, they were not ready for us.  I was assured that the party that was currently occupying our space would be just another 5 or 10 minutes.  45 minutes later we were finally seated.  We ended up with a party of 17--so that meant 17 people lingering on their stairway for 30 minutes (the extra 2 people were not the issue as our table accommodated 15 and we squeezed the last 2 in).  There also was a few snafus with our checks (a drink I hadn't ordered made it's way to mine--and then after getting that removed, a drink I HAD ordered wound up on another yelper's check...oy).   

So, clearly, handling reservations and a large party in general, on a busy Friday night, is not their forte.

What they did right:

After we'd been waiting a while, they mixed cosmos for each of us and brought them to us on the stairs.  When we were finally seated, they brought us several platters of appetizers to enjoy on the house.  All the appetizers were quite good (one to note was the asparagus fries--yum!).  The cosmo itself wasn't a winner (our party gave Fork's Cosmo 2 stars of 5--personally, I gave it 3 stars of 5--but I had a sip of several others and their mixing was very inconsistent--some had lots of vodka, some too much lime, others tasted like mostly cranberry--weird but we've run into this issue at a few places, when ordering 15 cosmos at once, it seems to cause difficulty in dimensions).  

However, Fork has a great lineup of specialty cocktails to choose from.  I thoroughly enjoy their 3 in the Chamber and their A Thyme for Bourbon--both well mixed and well presented.  I also enjoyed a piece of their butter cake, which is haaaauuuuge.  My people, share it.  Firstly, because it is so ample that it is PLENTY for two people.  Secondly, because, it is butter drenched, sugar laden, and  ice cream topped--do you REALLY want to enter into the eye of this caloric sh*t storm alone?  No.  Of course not.  You must bring others down with you.

I loved Fork before this visit and I'm sure I'll love them again.  But, standing on the stairs with 16 people as we waited...and waited...and waited, I definitely wasn't feeling the love. 

Bottom line:  Maybe not the best place to bring an overly large party.  And, skip their cosmos, but don't fret, they'll have another cocktail you'll enjoy.  Of that, I'm certain.

I got to say, there is really no redeeming factor that keeps me coming back to Michael's other than their killer soft cheddar cheeseburger. The atmosphere is just all right, everything else on the menu sounds just all right, the service is just all right, even the steak fries that come with the burger are just all right. I'm willing to ignore all of that just to sink my teeth into 10 oz of juicy, charbroiled deliciousness.

Here's a word of advice. Once I got the smaller 5 oz version just so I wouldn't be so stuffed. Big mistake! It was too small to really taste all the elements that make the burger great. Go for the big boy!

The service was poor, to be kind.  The service took away my friends 3-year old's lunch before he was even done with it and without even asking.  Don't take food away without asking, especially from a little kid who is slow to eat (kids sometimes pick their food and take a long time).  We didn't notice right away since she grabbed it out so fast, then when we asked for it back she said it was already gone and didn't even offer him some more fries or anything to make up for it.  Just not cool.  

Other than that, they were out of just about everything.  Now, I get things may have been busy the night before, but plan better.  Heck, they didn't even have bloody Mary's.  How does a bar and grill run out of that mix?  

I don't think I would go back.

This small beach restaurant is located in the Bilmar Beach resort and Treasure Island. As you walk through the hotel,  towards the back of the building, it faces the beach. You can sit inside or outside. The outside has a covered plastic that they roll up when the weather is nice. It was nice the day we went there. They also had some nice live music with one-man with a guitar.

It was close to lunchtime and there wasn't a lot of people in the restaurant (either inside or outside). It took a while for anyone to greet us, but once we got a server, he was extremely nice and good at attending to our table. The kitchen was very slow in getting the food prepared. Also since it was after Breakfast stopped being served, they only had two breakfast items available with the lunch menu. 

We ordered a Walnut apple salad with shrimp, chicken wings, and 2 egg sandwiches (One with potatoes and one with a side of fruit). Both the salad and the chicken wings were good, but the egg sandwiches were just OK.

All in all, it's an OK restaurant, but it is on the beach. (Also not sure where to park. We parked in the lot out front, but when we returned to the car, there was a note stating we couldn't park there? Overall mediocre experience.

Went with a larger party on a Friday night. There was supposed to be 12 of us, but the table was only set for 10. Since I was one of the early ones to get there, I asked the server several times how she was going to solve this problem. She stated that she would wait to see if everybody showed up...Very interesting? It ended up being 11 of us, so we grabbed a chair to add to the end of the table and opened up the extension ourselves. The service was the less than expected (although It wasn't very busy).

I haven't been here in over a year, so I was excited to try something new. I ended up ordering the seafood platter grilled. It was just OK, nothing spectacular (especially for $28). I also ordered the gumbo soup. Amazing spicy flavor with lots of seafood! 

I also tasted the fried soft crab plate, it was good. But a little thick on the breading. My friends tried the Pad Thai, the Chicken Amazing, and the Shrimp Shi with mediocre results. 

Overall, I was less than pleased with this latest experience. Will be sometime before I go back.

Um...wow. Stick to the Mexican food on menu and you'll probably be fine. The ice cream is crap, as is the other in-Mexican food. You'll find much better Mexican on Cherokee. And what's up with that decor? Lol!

Tasty gyros but waaay too much tzatziki sauce smeared on mine, and only on the top of the pita.  Once I scooped off about half and spread it around, it was much better.  I enjoyed the soft pita and velvety hummus.

Overall. I found this place to be very underwhelming. Our server, some emo guy, was brutal. He was rude to other people at my table. I get that we came in rather late but he could have treated us the same as if we came at a regular hour. The beers were great. We all enjoyed our beers and undoubtedly they are the best part about the place. I'm not crazy about drinking in a basement, but the room was decent. They didn't have anything on the tvs. The potstickers were tasty. The wings were bland, but that's mostly par for the city. There are better places in the area to go. Woodwork, tres carnales, and craft are better in my opinion. I would try them again if my friends wanted to go again. I would probably go earlier and hopefully get a better server. Overall. Meh. But has potential.

I am having me some bad luck trying to get the full on experience with this little restaurant.  I went here yesterday for breakfast and did not realize that they are closed on Mondays.  Then today (Tuesday), I arrived here at about 7 minutes before closing time.  Hmmmm..

But.. I am so appreciative of the staff working today.  I had been thinking about begneits for about 2 weeks since it came up in a class I attended.  Never had one in my life but was on a pursuit to figure out what it was.  The staff had just turned off their fryer, but turned it back on just to cook my order and I really appreciate it.  This what I call A++ customer service and if I could give higher than 5 stars, these folks would get it.

The atmosphere - cozy little cafe.  The people so nice and accomodating!

Can't wait to come back and get the full on Creme Cafe experience.  What a gret bunch of people.

And the begneit was so good, warm with powdered sugar, a friend donut.  Mmm... mmm

I had heard that this was a family owned business but was disappointed as it has the appearance of a chain restaurant.  Came here for an early dinner and was surprised that we were one of 2 families here to eat.  The pizza is rather bland, nothing really stands out, not even the crust.  Also had the fried calamari, but I have had better elsewhere.  I was disappointed, but will probably give them another try and have some dinner.  Maybe spaghetti or another Italian dish
The come back to life soup was amazing with lots of seafood.  Large portions with all food items. Chile rellanos were also large. Great service and great value.

Tampa has been spoiled with all the amazing Steak Houses. We are a city of carnivores! Compared to some of the other steak houses in Tampa, LongHorn seems less then impressive for a steak, but for the price, it's hard to beat. They have a lot of different options and even enough choices for those who do not choose to eat beef. Everything I have tried here has been pretty good.

The parking at his location isn't so great but there is usually some nearby parking in the walmart parking lot directly behind the restaurant. 
 
When you are in the mood for a steakhouse but don't want to spend a fortune, LongHorn is a good choice.

They nailed it. Tibbys satisfies all of your New Orleans cravings. 
We went in on a Friday night and we're told it would be an hour wait for a table for 4, to our pleasant surprise, it only took about 35 minutes to get a table.
We started with Hurricanes which is how we start every visit to NOLA. Although it wasnt quite Pat O' Briens, it was probably the best hurricane I have had in Tampa. We then ordered appetizers. We devoured a generous portion of "Maws fries" which is French fries covered in roast beef and debris. For anyone who has never been to the deli called Mother's in NOLA, debris is the gravy a drippings left in the pan from cooking roast beef. They were soooo good and I would come back to tibbys just for Maws fries. We also ordered boudin balls, which I was slightly disappointed in. They were made up of mostly rice but they did have good flavor so we still ate them all.
After eating those fries I wanted more debris, so my husband and I split a "12 napkin sandwich" which is a roast beef and debris sandwich. We ordered it plan so there wouldn't be any pesky lettuce and tomatoes keeping me from the full flavor of the debris.  Again, I didn't look up until it was gone. I was very full at this point but I had already ordered a cup of sausage jambalaya, so I had to try it. The sausage was perfectly spiced and there was a generous amount of sausage mixed in the rice which gave it some kick. Again, very good. 
The service is still slightly slow but being we were there the first week they opened, we understood that they were still getting used to things. 
Tibbys did a great job remodeling the building, you don't even recognize that this used to be a different restaurant. There is a lot of recognizable new Orleans memorabilia hanging on the walls and from the ceiling
 All they are missing is the live trombone player.

This was the most expensive dining experience I've had in STL so far. Sadly to say its the least memorable. I'll comment on what I do remember: 

We had a table to 8 for my partners birthday. I ordered two bottles of wine for the table. Yet for some reason our server took what seemed like forever to bring out the wine glasses and even longer to get them poured. Meanwhile drinks people had ordered from the bar were also backed up someplace. No water had hit the table either. 

Once the beverage comfortableness passed several people ordered appetizers. I tried the Escargot and while I could understand how it was well received by others at the table it didn't wow me in any way. 

I had the Smoked Tomato Bisque. It paled in comparison to very similar soup anyone can get at the fast casual chain La Madeleine (they also sell it canned at Sams Club) It was virtually flavorless and one of the girls at the table simply didn't choose to have hers after tasting it. 

I also tried what I can only describe as cold mashed potato soup. It too lacked and was passed around for people to try. Nobody wanted it. 

The birthday girl had the Arugula Salad. It was good, but again no wow factor. 

I had several more selections from the Prix Fixe menu. I believe there was a crepe. I opted for the 4th course of a Creme Brulee however it was not brought out at the end of the meal. 

Everything I ordered lacked flavor. Most everything needed salt. 

We were there on Saturday June 25th at 7pm Not long enough ago for me to have forgotten something great. 

Someone had brought a bottle of White Port Wine to share with everyone after dinner. It was nice that they were able to accommodate us with this. However more than half the bottle was full on the table when we left. We came back after one drink downstairs and nobody could account for where it had gone.

As I was focused on the birthday girl and her experience I didn't review the bill when it arrived. I have no idea if I was billed for the Creme Brulee I have no idea if there was a cork fee.

I've tried 4 different calzones here now. The two I've ordered for myself sounded good on paper but didn't hit the spot for me. I've nearly completely forgotten what I ordered they were so forgettable. Something with meat balls and something else with Mac n cheese.  

My partner ordered the other two and hers were actually pretty good. She got some kind of thanksgiving dinner calzone that disappeared before I could sample it a second time. She also tried the fig calzone. Both much better than what I ordered. 

I don't really see myself going back. So 3 stars. 

Service was great though! We also liked the alternative selection of soda.

This place is "all the rave on the north side" as I tell anyone who hasn't been there before. 

Honestly in my opinion its an upscale glorified chinese buffet. On the weekends the parking is usually hard, & its pure pandemonium trying to get through the other diners trying to fix your plate in the buffet lines. 

The food IS good! The plates are bigger than the average buffet plates. They also offer things that you don't get at your everyday chinese buffet. They have sushi, & you actually see the chefs rolling it. There is a chocolate fountain that you can dip wafers, marshmallows, fruit, whatever you want into. I had fried crab legs once when I went for lunch. They do have american food on the buffet as well. 

I would recommend you go at lunch & save yourself some money the only difference is a few items of food.

*Also as a note to the sushi lovers they do have sushi on the lunch menu.
Mediocre, bland, not clean, and greasy.  I won't come back, no reason to. Many better options for tacos.

Still cannot understand why this spot ceased being a Starbucks, as it was always packed and some of us know it was often the place you could find Derek Jeter just hanging out enjoying his coffee and how people in Tampa pretty much leave professional athletes alone.

While I knew the olive oil store idea was doomed, putting a Taps in this spot seemed like a better idea...and then I read all the Yelp reviews.

Ouch.

Still, we had just left The Pub, Doc B's does not open for another six weeks, our girl Lindsey was not working at Bar Louie and I would not be caught dead in Blue Martini...so we figured one drink at Taps would not kill us.

Our service was excellent from a polite young man named Parvez and my friend's cosmo was "kickass." The interior seems odd to me, and the bar has very limited seating. At least come 10pm there were actually some people in here since when I first walked by at 730pm, there were as many people inside as when it was that olive oil store.

Not sure how Taps is going to do against Bar Louie and Blue Martini or if they will just feed off one another. Especially because Taps is expensive like those other places and obviously does not have the regular business that Louie and Martini have enjoyed from years of being anchor spots of Bay Street.

Absolutely stunned they dropped the queso from the updated menu.

They no longer have it and a seasonal menu right now features a buffalo chicken dip that just is not the same quality.

As the new manager of the store explained to me, not enough people ordered the queso and they dropped it because they were throwing so much of it out. 

Oh, the new manager here seems like a good guy. He actually followed up with me on why my recent takeout order took way too long and spoke to me at length about the menu and some other things.

Now that 2016 has arrived, I'll look forward to the new calendar of "Dress to Impress" dates and the themes that go along with them. It is like Halloween for women at least once a month.

For those of you who have kids, call ahead to make sure you don't bring the children out on these particular days. Those shorts the girls usually wear may not cover much, but the Dress to Impress themed outfits generally cover even less. 

Maybe they should call it "Less to Impress?"

I've been waiting for months to write about people who work the counter at restaurants who simply DO NOT PAY ATTENTION to the customer.

Today is that day.

This was my first trip to Hank's. And it will be my last. 

I walked in and ordered a bowl of Brunswick Stew for takeout.

That's it. Pretty simple. I'm a TV/Radio broadcaster and speak rather clearly.

For some reason, it took way too long to get my order. That's odd on its own when it is literally a bowl of soup and there's nobody else behind me.

What did I open when I got home? Gumbo. 

Gumbo was also on my receipt. This means the cashier was absolutely not paying attention.

I do not eat gumbo and there are ingredients in it to which I'm allergic.

Nice job, Hank's! What the hell are you doing?

I will be immediately returning to your store with this receipt, the gumbo untouched and a firm request for a refund.

No. I don't want any food from you, not your Brunswick Stew or anything else for my troubles. Save that free food for your next Yelp Elite event when the freeloaders show up and give you five stars because they didn't pay for anything. All I want is my money back for wasting my time coming into your store. 

Let this be a lesson to cashiers who are not paying attention to the customers. We're are simply tired of you not listening to us. Please pay attention or find a job where you do not have to interact with people.

We've been getting dinner from Three Coins for about a year now.

However, we always order takeout.

Why? Here's just one example:

As we walked in to pay for and pick up our order last night, all we saw was an enormous pair of exposed butt cheeks straddling a seat at the counter.

The large female customer was sporting a green thong bikini. No cover-up.

Honestly, a rental car doesn't see this much ass.

How we did not lose our respective appetites after that disgusting image was only due to the quality of the food we receive at Three Coins.

We regularly enjoy their fluffy pancakes (since breakfast is served all day), the country fried steak and tasty sandwiches like the Happy Waitress.

Sure, it is a diner and it is Seminole Heights. 

Still, this is not Caliente and select customers should show more common sense when dining in here. 

That said, common sense is clearly not that common these days.

Don't you despise when you enjoy a favorite item on a menu, crave it and come back for it only to discover it has been discontinued?

That was the story of our night here.

We have been frequenting Tijuana Flats locations more often specifically for the Philly Cheesesteak Flautas because they have a surprising amount of delicious flavor in a rather large portion.

And tonight we learned they are gone.

If it had not been for a quality manager and two good employees at this clean and fairly new location being so nice and discussing the menu change with us, we would have simply left and gotten our dinner somewhere else.

Sure, this happens all the time at various restaurants. There are reasons for it, but it still does not change the fact that we as customers are disappointed.

Put it this way: I like Tijuana Flats. But I loved that menu item. 

The alternate items (tacos) we ordered were fine. They were prepared well, served quickly and had fresh ingredients.

Still, we did not get what we came for and are not sure when we'll be back now that we can no longer get it.

It is coming up on half a year since the first Duffy's opened in Tampa, so I wanted to update my review as I visit there quite often.

First, this just might be the best frequent customer/rewards program available for people who dine out on a regular basis. 

Many casual restaurants have these programs and they simply are not worth the constant emails and carrying the card around with the name of the business.

Duffy's version of such a program is excellent. 

In less than six months, I've accumulated well over $100 in rewards through either regular visits, promotions or even the company throwing an extra perk or two on my account for something they felt they could or should have done better.

While I wish the bar was bigger (But that's the previous tenant Macaroni Grill's fault), Lexie and Samantha are always who we want to see behind it whenever we visit. They hustle, they're friendly and they remember regular customers. And while I'm not a fan of men working the bar at a place like this, Desmond is rock solid back there as well.

Nazzi, Guy and the managers are always visibly making sure things are going the right way or if any customer has an issue.

Not sure yet if there are plans for a second Duffy's in the Tampa Bay Area, but I certainly enjoy earning and using all my rewards at this location.

I've lived across the street from this California Pizza Kitchen for a decade and never went in this store until recently.

Do not have a reason. Just kind of forget that it is there since it is completely isolated from the other food options at International and not something you notice when driving Boy Scout Blvd in either direction.

I initially entered my online order here via Yelp, but decided to check something else before finalizing it and making payment. 

Sure enough, if I simply went online via the CPK website and ordered there, my order would cost me less money...so keep that in mind.

My order included a flatbread, entree and side and it was waiting for me at the designated time to pick it up. The employee who handled my order was a wonderfully nice woman who made sure I had everything I paid for and all the other things that usually come with takeout.

The flatbread was A-OK as they say here on Yelp to indicate a three star experience. I've had better, but it got the job done.

My piadina was memorable and ordering the full size version gave me enough for a second meal a couple days later. As a short rib apologist, my eyes are often drawn to this menu item and my appetite was not disappointed at all.

The baked potato soup also got the job done and I appreciate Nueske brand bacon being featured on menu items as well.

While I agree with others that CPK is priced a touch high for a casual dining experience, the variety of items is also more creative than other casual spots offering pizza, pasta and more.

It had been a few years since I visited this spot on Kennedy, so this was my first trip to the new location right down the street.

However, I am a fan of salads sometimes instead of a sandwich and thought I would try their Cuban in salad form.

The new location is quite nice and an upgrade from the previous tiny spot next to Smoothie King. 

It was a late Saturday afternoon and there was only one employee working at all. I give him credit for getting everything done, as he knew what he was doing and did not have any help. He said it had been slow all afternoon, but I was one of about four people who came in at roughly the same time.

My wait was a bit too long, despite his efforts. If I had known it would take that long, I would not have stopped in the first place and would have gone to Lenny's right down the street. 

The finished product was good. Plenty of meat, cheese and other ingredients and very filling for one person. A salad this size needs more than one packet of salad dressing, as this is a common mistake made by many places...except PDQ which always gives you two or three.

Oh, I also added an order of stuffed potato balls. You receive four for $2.49, but they are rather small. Not something I would order again, because it just was not worth it.  

If I know I can get in and out of here for that same Cuban salad in less time, I would make another visit to The Floridian.

Well, that did not take long at all.

I was back in LDH looking for bagels and the owners identified me almost immediately based on my review a week ago.

When I told them the appeal of the PayDay candy bar in that it is the one candy bar we golfers can stash in our golf bag that will not melt in the Florida heat, Katie immediately went to work behind the counter.

I'm a man of my word. So LDH's fourth star has been achieved.

Check the enclosed photo for the custom made and personally inspired PayDay donuts.

Feel free to ask for my PayDay donut on any future visit.

I typically prefer Humble Pie, Sauce or Piazza Gavi for a similar cost. However, I decided to order Papa John's because I'd received a coupon on 08/08/2019.  I mentioned it to my teenaged nephew, who got excited saying he loves their pizza, so I decided to place an order!  The coupon did not list an expiration date, and this is a franchise, it was good at the Swan location only.  I called on Saturday 08/10/2019, the person who answered informed me that the coupon expired. He couldn't honor it and had no explanation as to why I received it only days before.  I would have dismissed the idea, but I didn't want to disappoint my nephew.  I hung up the call and went to the website hoping my coupon would work there.  Nope.  It said to enter my zip code and it would list the locations closest to me.  Their website was problematic ... it jumps to delivery, and I wanted to save $3 and pick it up ... it was hard to figure out how to change that ... also, I'd selected a $12 special for an XL with 2 toppings.  That was confusing how to get the normal charges removed to save an additional $4.  It had selected the location for me, so I wasn't paying close attention - I ended up with the franchise on 22nd.  I live near Sabino Canyon, about a 6 mile drive. The website didn't honor the coupon either.  I'll continue my review for the 22nd location separately.  I did want to mention on THIS location as they mailed a coupon then didn't honor it.

In my attempt to give Ting Wong, my one-time favorite Chinatown restaurant, one last try I attempted to go there for lunch this week only to find that they were closed "for renovations."  No surprise, my experience there had been decidedly unsatisfactory ever since they changed ownership several months ago.  A local resident who witnessed my confusion stopped to assist me.  After a brief discussion he pointed down the block to another establishment, Wong Wong, he suggested I should try.  I figured, why not, he lives here so he should know the good spots. Wrong!  Wong Wong must be his brother's place because my experience there was worse than my first choice.  I had to wait five minutes before anyone even acknowledged me. Finally someone looked at me and pointed to one of the empty tables where I was to sit. After that table was cleaned I did sit and perused the extensive menu. Actually there were two of them, the regular one and another for the lunch specials. I decided on #5 from the regular menu, noodle soup with soy chicken. Big mistake. While the broth had decent flavor and there was an abundance of okay noodles, the chicken was more bone than meat. I had to actually search through the soup to find something to chew on. I was hungry so I did finish the soup, but it didn't get any better. When the bill (written in Chinese) came it was higher than I expected so I questioned my server about it. She took it away somewhere and came back and explained, "she made mistake" and provided a corrected check. I felt it still was too high but I was in no mood to quible, so I paid the check with an adequate tip and left the premises. Though rather small, the overall atmosphere is pleasantly decorated and well lighted.

We tried this place twice and we really wanted to like it, but just couldn't.  The food was average, the service was decent, but it was just a little too greasy, a little over priced, and nothing on the menu you can't get anywhere else.  

Yes, it does have free ice cream.

I had a great first time visit at OPA! Be sure to start off with the Opa Flaming Saganaki. You won't regret it.
Huge menu that can cater to anyone's taste. I got the chicken breast platter and it came with pita bread, grilled chicken strips, traditional sauce, feta, tomato and lettuce, potato, rice pilaf, green beans, and a Greek salad. What a deal. I didn't like that the chicken strips were very long and my pita slices were too small, so I had trouble cutting the chicken and fitting all the toppings. It was a bit of a hassle so I started to eat the ingredients separately and I was making a mess. I wish I would had gotten it in a wrap so it was already together. Also with all that on one plate (salad comes first though) the juice from the tomato was seeping under the pita making it soggy and I didn't notice. Wish it was diced tomatoes so I could have easily put in on the pita bread instead of having to cut a big slice of tomato. I was a fan of the potatoes, but I didn't care for the green beans.
As for the whole experience, I could tell that the waitresses didn't seem excited to be there. The service was alright but the waitresses weren't very friendly and happy. Even when someone ordered a flaming cheese appetizer they would say opaaaaaaa with no excitement. The dining area looks really nice especially with the murals of Greece architecture but the chairs seem to be old as the material is ripping and pealing. It was also quite noisy in there.
So overall I was going to give 3 stars but because of the awesome appetizer I decided to up it. Definitely give this place a shot!

I was very impressed of the speed going through the drive-thru! We ordered two concrete mixers and an order of cheese curds, yet everything was ready once we paid at the window. The only issue I had was that I ordered a chocolate concrete mixer with brownie pieces, and my ordered was repeated back to me twice, yet I ended up with a chocolate and Reese's concrete mixer. Don't know what happened there. It was very delicious though!

What a great foodie find, (and in the most seemingly random plaza of all places)! But don't let the location fool you. This place is pretty legit. 

The seating for this place makes it seem very authentic. It's small, close knit, and quaint which really gives it that homey authentic Italian feel. The menu also reflects that, along with the ever vastly large rotating house specials. Between that and the regular menu, I could not make up my mind to decide what I wanted to eat. But that was no problem since there was no rush or pressure from the staff to. I believe the waiter came back three times because I was being so indecisive. Not once did I feel pressured or pushed into making a decision. In addition to their patience the staff here is wonderfully friendly. I got a visit from practically the whole staff! 

I began with the caprese salad which was wonderfully fresh, with the most creamy mozzarella. They then recommended I choose the lobster ravioli, my date choose the seafood pasta. While the ravioli was tasty and filing, unfortunately there wasn't a lot of lobster within the ravioli filing. No bueno, which is typically while I steer clear of ordering seafood at most restaurants. I should've known! My dates seafood pasta featured plenty of seafood-so at least they delivered there. For dessert we shared the tiramisu and had two cappuccinos. No complaints there! Soft, airy, and mildly sweet. If I'm in the neighborhood I wouldn't mind returning, but just not for the lobster-less ravioli.

Ordered from here 2 days in a row, and glad I didn't post my original review before getting our 2nd order today, because it's definitely much different from last night's. I gave 2 stars because I am combining my positive experience from yesterday with my negative experience from today. Below is the review I wrote last night, and then the review from today's order...

"I can't figure out why the reviews on Grubhhub and Yelp aren't better!? Ordered from them for the first time...

- order of several items was correct (seems there is generally at least one thing wrong when you order delivery!)
- delivery person was friendly
- food arrived quicker than expected
- lots of condiments and extras with the order, to make sure we weren't short on anything (huge stack of saran-wrapped nice napkins, silverware, yummy bread knots that apparently came with the meal, plenty of butter for them, and finally - a place that gives you enough salad dressing for the whole salad!) 
- they also have a huge menu with some unique items that cannot be found at similar style restaurants (bacon wrapped meatloaf stuffed with prosciutto, sun dried tomato risotto balls stuffed with mozzarella)."

Review from today...

- Confirmed 3 times that the vegetables would be on the side and packaged separately from the meatloaf. Despite that, they still came mixed in with the meatloaf. I am a vegetarian and was going to have the vegetables as part of my meal, but couldn't because they were mixed in with the other meal. Very disappointing after confirming multiple times on the phone when placing the order. 
- no silverware
- no napkins
- no little rolls (instead just a piece of bread)
- no butter to go with the bread

A shame, because the food was good and I had high hopes after our first experience.

We get the Chicken Family platter, lettuce wrap and spicy tuna Roll, our food was great no complaints.

Service was Horrible since waitress Gwynn came to the table and ask for our drinks without introduce herself, she wasn't happy with us maybe because we're a family of hispanics, she never smile or offer any appetizer, she never came back to see if everything was ok, we have to share our lemonades and left without getting any dessert just because the terrible service. I found her name on our check  #20036 total was $80 dollars and I still tip her $20. I could spend more on drinks appetizers and dessert if she just have this thing call Customer Service, all my reviews are 5 stars I Don't waste my time on write if something was bad, I just gave the place another opportunity but this time I feel like I just spend my time and money on any fast food or gas station place. We never ever coming back to see long faces on our table
I just had Mama's cabbage salad, so good!  Our server at the bar was great, best server experience we've had yet, cordial, attentive and professional.

Service is pretty awesome here and the live band made our experience totally worth it.  My friends and I came by on a Sunday afternoon.  They had pre-fixed menu going on for about $39 per person.  Samantha was our server that day.  

My friends and I all ordered different things.  I stuck with:

Turtle soup for appetizer
Shrimp & grits for my main course
Bread pudding souffle for dessert

I also got to try all of my friend's dishes which were the shrimp & lobster fritatta, pecan encrusted fish and steak & potato.  

We started with the garlic toast and my turtle soup came out shortly after.  My soup was rich in flavor but a little too salty for my preference.  The shrimp & grits was a rather light dish.  Shrimp was cooked perfectly and paired great with the grits.  I think next time I'll order the steak & potato as my dish because I think I would've been more satisfied with that dish.  

The bread pudding was a great ending to our lovely meal.  I also tried my friend's banana split.  You can't go wrong with either dessert. 

The ambiance, entertainment and great food made our experience here really memorable.  If you're ever in the area, be sure to stop by this restaurant.

Pub and Sub is one of my favorite places to go during the summer.  I don't usually like to go other than in the summer because it's so dark inside.  But sitting out front or in the backyard is the perfect way to spend a Sunday afternoon during the summer.  
Pitchers are usually pretty cheap, but prices went up since the last time I was there.  The Sub sandwiches are HUGE, a half sandwich is what you would expect to get if you ordered a full sandwich.  The pizza is pretty greasy, but I think that's what makes it so good!  And the garlic fires are delicious too!
Pub and Sub can get kind of busy sometimes, especially during the semester (since it's only a couple of blocks away from campus and it's the middle of a residential area with a lot of students.)

I agree with Erin about the lack of meat and cheese on the sandwich (I was the friend that went with her).  But the sandwich was fantastic regardless.  I'm sure there are still some kinks being worked out since they just opened.

I went back a couple of days later to check out the butcher selection and was throughouly impressed.  They have everything that I could ever want.  AND (this was a huge plus for me) they de-boned and trimmed a leg of lamb for me.  They have a huge beef selection, gigantic lobsters, pork, fresh fish, chicken, etc, etc.  While I agree that the prices are not exactly competitive with grocery stores, I will pay the extra money to get a less common cut of meat.

The people are super friendly and even when I went in there to get my lamb and there was a ton of people in there I was served within a minute or two.  And I do think that some of the stuff they have in there is not necessarily what you can find in a grocery store... Maybe Whole Foods, but then again, I have never looked for Black Truffles at Whole Foods but happened to notice them here.

I'm kind of torn between 2 and 3 stars...

The first time I tried to eat here we received HORRIBLE service, well, not at first, but here's what happened:
We were seated in a pretty reasonable time frame, our waiter took our drink orders, brought our drinks and told us about the specials.  We asked for some more time to look at the menu and then everything went downhill.  I have no idea what happened to our first waiter, but all of a sudden there was a new waiter in the area.  A couple more tables were seated after us and they received their drinks but we still hadn't been asked for our food order (our menus were closed and we kept trying to make eye contact with the waiter.)  Then all of the tables that had been seated after us had been asked for their food order and we were still sitting there waiting....  We finally just got up and left without paying for our drinks.  I was pretty disappointed because I was looking forward to trying this place but pretty much made the decision to never go back.

Well, I ended up going back with my family.  My brother talked me into it since one of his friends is a waiter.  We waited at the front for several minutes without ever being asked if we had reservations.  Drinks came out one at a time instead of all at once and took forever to get there.  Bread came from a different person every time so you never knew who to ask for some more.  We wanted to order an appetizer right when we ordered our first drinks but that didn't happen so we didn't end up orderding our appetizer until we ordered our entrees.  Luckily the appetizer came out well in advance to the the entrees.  We got the fried calamari (fritto misto) which was ok but nothing spectacular.  Between the four of us we got: Duck Ragout, Chicken Piccata, Seafood Pasta, and Cioppino.  All were great, except the seafood pasta could have used a little bit more flavor in the white sauce.  Dessert choices are pretty typical of what you would expect to see in an Italian restaurant - gelato, tiramisu, cannolis.  Again, nothing I was wowed about.  Service got better as the place cleared out, but I am still left with a bitter taste only because I expected so much more.

I really love Kokopelli's Sushi, but over the years it has changed a lot.  When I first came to Reno, Kokopellis took up the whole seating area, but it slowly changed to just the back seating area.  So beware - if you are seated in a certain area you have to get up to order sushi and they won't bring it out to your table.
They have a large selection of rolls, and I have never been disappointed with the quality of the food.  However, they do close around 9pm, so it's not good for a late night dinner.
I have only had one bad server there several months ago.  Our waitresses seated us, but didn't give us menus right away.  When she finally walked by our way again, we had to ask for her to bring the menus, which took several more minutes.  She didn't bring a pen with her, so luckily I had one otherwise we would have had to wait even longer.  Our waitress never came back to get our order, so the hostess finally took it and our drink order.  The hostess was also the one who brought us our food and drinks.  I don't know what was wrong with this waitress, but it was some of the worst service I had ever had, and was thankful that the hostess was so helpful.

The food is still stellar. But now I have a serious bone to pick the IndeBlue...  About a month ago, we stopped by for takeout and asked whether they deliver to Cherry Hill. We were told that no they do not, but since our house is less than .5 miles from Haddonfield (which they do offer delivery to), we should just give your street address and say Haddonfield. So we did just that when we placed an order. Half an hour later we go called back and reprimanded for this with a promise that they will never again deliver to us. Considering it was a weeknight and we ordered $70 worth of food, seriously?? Also, if anything, why not simply say that when we placed an order, rather than wait half an hour to call us back (and then have us wait another 40 minutes or so for the food)...

Maybe I've been to PJs too many times, but lately it does not feel the same. It feels like a chain (which it actually is now) though it used to be more of a local bar/tavern setting.
Still, it's not a bad place... with limited but good menu and an average selection of beer...

New Orleans, Louisiana ---

"The Avenue Pub" is an easy "ain't coming back here again bar!" ...

Their bartender is the winner of the "Run-A-Way Bill" "Worst Bartender of NOLA" award winner ...

Never made eye contact or listened to a word I said ...

I ordered a $10 "Duval" beer and requested the bottle cap, but in the trash it went 

then I said keep a $1, which she did not & I held it out for her and she walked away ... the other bartender walked across the bar and took it from me 

watched & listened to her deal with other customers ... very angry person 

I thought she just hated guys, but I was wrong ... she doesn't like ANY customer! 

No reason to visit this bar with so many other choices (pARTy Tip ... "Half Moon" bar) ...

"Run-A-Way Bill" was here! (but will NOT be again)   

day 038 DUSA 2017" (Discover USA) 

day 091 "666 Bars of 2017" bar 185

#RunAwayBill #DUSA2017  #666BarsUSA 

04.01.17

I like this place and have a true love for Bao buns! I think I ordered everything on the menu out of excitement to try this place. So let's start 
Hot Dumpling bowl- delicious and spicy but needed some kind of dipping sauce 
Juicy pork bun- delicious and flavorful but definitely need a sauce to dip. That goes for the beef bao too. Seared or steamed. 
Pork and shrimp dumplings- delicious! Ginger packed came with dipping sauce 
Small seafood soup- wowzers! So jammed packed full of flavors! Like whoa! No seasoning needed, the scallops and shrimp went great with the soup. 
Last but least
I had the pork belly bowl I guess that's what's it's called. It was very disappointing. Lacked of flavor completely and the pork belly was dry. I had high hopes for this item and it was a let down, I took it home and tried to give it another try and nope it threw it away. I would not recommend. I will be back to see if they have sauces for my bao besides chili paste
This was an okay place that is somewhat healthy but the prices are high for the amount of food. The meat, veggie, and sides are a good combination and the ambiance is nice.
hoenstly the live music is not very good and you cant really dance cause there are too many pepole around. they  also do not give free chasers which is a reall bummer.

Chicken shawarma , but kind of pricey for the atmosphere of Cleo's. I understand it that the previous location was smaller, but this is still in a convenience store. The chicken is good, hot off the spit. And the salad is good as well and convenient obviously now right on canal. I think I would love to re review this place but it's a nice grab something to eat after or before you study sort of place

When I was in Philly, and dinnertime was near and I had no plans, or time to trudge to target; I was surrounded by so many restaurants, and many great choices I could easily walk to. One of my favorites was Harp & Crown- Hopefully one day I'll move back to Philly and Ill be able to update this review to (one of my favorite is Harp & Crown).

Why go to Harp & Crown? Obvious reasons: 
- It's Michael Schulson's (Duh!)
- Gorgeous interior.
- Underground bowling alley. (Yes, exactly!)
- Accommodate big parties.
- Delicious food: Try the pizza with unusual ingredients (Smoked octopus. Anyone?) Also, try the Skirt Steak and the roasted olives- you'll love them.

Five Yelps

One recent evening, I was hitting up couple of breweries in Jersey with Kathleen D and Mariella S. And after few (many?) brews, we finally decided to get some food in our bellies. Kathleen suggested going to Treno, and since she always rave about how good their pizzas are, we agreed.
I had the Kennett Square pizza. A wood-fired, mushroom pizza, loaded with bechamel, cheese, and few kinds of herb sautéed mushroom: Crimini, oyster mushroom, and shitake. Rich and delicious. 
Another good reason to head over Treno, is the Italian Budino. Smooth, creamy and rich chocolate mouse, paired with salted caramel and accented by cookie crumb. Oh, it was heavenly.

Great pizza spot, but personally I wouldn't cross the bridge regularly to get my pizza fix, just because we have tons of pizzerias in Philly. However, If I ever again in Jersey, I'll definitely eat here again.

Four Yelps

Fast Facts:
- Casual breakfast spot for early risers, other than Cafe du Monde. 
- Cafe Au Lait ($2.75) wasn't the greatest. 
- I wasn't very happy with my breakfast. I ordered the egg breakfast on a croissant( $6.50) with hash brown( +$1.50). The croissant was not flaky nor fluffy, instead it was gluey, heavy, and too sweet for my taste. 
- The lady behind the counter, wasn't overly friendly, or smiley. 

Two and Half Yelps

Hi Yelpers,

I have two questions for you: 
1) Would you like some delicious breakfast-or brunch-or lunch?

2) Do you want to know what to eat for breakfast, like a king?


If you answered yes to either question, then don't miss Fitzwater Cafe.  A BYOB cafe that serves breakfast and lunch. 
Can't go on weekday? Try going for a weekend brunch. I went on a Sunday with my friend, Rena, and we had a fantastic experience. Our friendly server Nicole, brought us some water and complimentary cappuccino ( only during Octobor'15).Then I had the Wild Mushrooms Omelette with caramelized onion, spinach and feta cheese. It was delicious and very flavorful. Also, we both shared some thick-cut creme brûlée French toast, and I could not be more pleased.

"All happiness depends on a leisurely breakfast." So, are you in?
Sincerely, 

Your Philadelphia Yelp member,
Sari A

Four Yelps
P.S: It is cash only!

My girlfriend and I always pass by Palace Cafe and always wanted to try it. Crazy how living here my entire life, I never went here before. Finally, for our 7 year anniversary, we decided to give it a shot! I was always hyped for this place when I tell her about it. It was during Jazz Fest, so parking was a bit annoying with some walk, but nothing too bad.

Walking into Palace Cafe, I can already feel like I was going to like it. Inside is nice, well decorated, and the staff very courteous. I told the hostess it was my first time and she told us we were gonna get the best seats in the house. She seated us by the window so that we could get a whole view of canal. Great seats, that's a plus! 

My girlfriend and I ordered the Cafe Eggs Benedict and the Grillades and Grits with the Banana Foster for desert. My Grillades and Grits were not bad at all, but definitely not memorable. The Eggs Benedict was the real problem. It came out cold, a bit under warm. I asked my server if he could get us a new one because it was cold. He took the plate and a new one literally came out in 3 minutes.. kind of fast huh? We tasted and tried to see if it was hot, it was only lukewarm. We decided not to bother them again because we felt it wouldn't change. All in all, the entrees were a bit disappointing. 

We were hoping the saving factor for this review was the banana foster. The way the server made it for us tableside was nice. He explained a bit about it and served it to us shortly. The banana foster was nice and all, but nothing crazy to say that it was "original here" or "Our famous", because it was honestly still a bit forgettable. Oh and I must mention.. even though it tasted okay, the presentation SUCKED. Just look at my photos, it looks like a hot soupy mess. Yeaaah.. very off putting.

Regardless of our first experience, we felt it could be better and would be better in the future. Maybe it was a bad day, but I'll eventually give this place another shot. Overall disappointed, but the atmosphere, service, and the making of the tableside banana foster saved it from being 1 stars.

I went here again recently to give this place a shot. I gave it 2 stars before and I'm gonna stick with it again for this review. I've tasted a lot of ramen, and this ramen is not that bad, but certainly nothing memorable. Better than Little Tokyo, but nothing like Kin. My previous review, the "too spicy" Ramen was WAY TOO spicy. Living in New Orleans, I've eaten my fair share of spicy foods and my tolerance is pretty good. This time, I decided to stick with the regular ramen and asked for spice on the side. After adding my own appropriate amount, the ramen was much more enjoyable the first time, however, the servers weren't too attentive to us. After receiving the check, I noticed they charged me extra for the spice on the side. That doesn't make sense at all because the "too spicy" ramen is the same price as the regular ramen. That kind of threw me off which attributed to the same 2 Star rating. Again, nothing that would bring me back here, especially since the ramen is nearly $14.

I liked Spice Box. It didn't really wow me with the flavors, and I just didn't seem to get a lot of food. I kinda felt like I was left wanting. I've tried the mango lassi, and the was pretty delicious, so maybe I'll go back for that at some point.

The VEGAN carrot cake was delicious. The icing was super tasty and made the cake nice and sweet. The cake tasted very fresh and the icing on top was put on in a very professional manner. 

However, I was not a big fan of the pulled seitan, the seitan was cooked great and the chipotle slaw was tasty, but... it was WAYYY to salty. The sandwich came with chips and salsa which was nice. 

I did also try a bit of the buffalo wrap and it was very tasty. I definitely recommend getting the buffalo wrap over the pulled seitan. 

In general, if you are a vegan or are interested in trying VEGAN dishes, Three Carrots is a place you must try. 

The location of Three Carrots offers many other small restaurants, so if you are scared to try a Vegan dish, you have back up options. But cmon, just try some vegan food, I promise you'll be amazed by the flavor.

Could I be more disappointed? I don't think so. We chose this restaurant for our group for New Year's Eve dinner. Needless to say there are many good options for dinner on NYE, but one of our group loved the chile relleno served here. Upon arrival at 7, we were greeted by...no one. The employees were standing around and not one person greeted us. Although we made our reservation months ahead, we were seated at a mediocre table with an excellent view of the kitchen. (See photo.) The place was slow, yet we were not given any of the nicer available tables. We should have seen the writing on the wall and left, but we really wanted to eat there. A mistake...the food was sub-par, even the highly anticipated chile relleno was a sloppy mess. Although there was a special menu posted online, our pleasant waiter knew nothing of it, and no special menu was produced. In hindsight, it's as if the restaurant is closing soon, so all of the employees have the attitude of the Honeybadger if you know what I mean. Horrible.

I would love to give a place in my adjacent neighborhood the glowiest of stars.  This is a new establishment and I am always itching to try new places local. 

A Friday night during Lent (Good Friday) seemed to be the best time to check out a seafood establishment.  It's cozy, in two small dining rooms of tables and booths with a bar.  It was not packed but full.  It looks like they upgraded it with new fixtures from the former pub (19th Hole, I think) and it seemed clean.  

The menu is laid out in a placemat which kind of has a down-the-shore feel and the murals on the wall are bright, nautical and cheery. Our waitress was attentive and gave great service.  There was gentleman that checked on our service, as well, prior to food delivery.  (Owner?)  The menu was straightforward and didn't really give descriptions of the dishes.  The prices were reasonable for seafood  'delivered fresh daily' as noted on the menu.

I ordered snow crab legs but the specials did sound delicious - crab ravioli in a blush sauce with sun-dried tomatoes, etc.  But I was fixated on Snow Crab - kind of a Lenten tradition on a Friday with me and the boyfriend.  He ordered the same thing but his was a trio with mussels and shrimp.

The food came out quickly but to my demise, it was in a pool of salted butter.  I immediately thought I was at Red Lobster (if that is your thing).  Of course, I did not exactly specify steamed with butter on the side, but what a mess!  Slippery and crab don't mix so it took forever to eat.  I don't really eat that much salt  frequently but I felt a lot bloated and smelled like a garlic butter that no wet-nap or hand soap could penetrate effectively.  The crabs themselves seemed fresh and large but were tainted by that presentation. 

My boyfriend's dish was similar - the shrimp and mussels were tough and the corn-on-the-cob was mush, likely due to the butter content. 

I am sure since this place is new, they have some kinks to work out with regard to the menu, etc.   There is always room for improvement and I look forward to hearing more positive reviews so that I am tempted to revisit.   It certainly is cheaper than Red Lobster but the dishes and prices are not unique enough to set it apart.

Great wings, shrimp, and nachos. I haven't ever tried anything here that I did not like. It is typical bar food but it is always fresh and well prepared.  We came here today to watch the game because buffalo wild wings was too busy and we did not feel like waiting. The entire restaurant was full but not packed like the aforementioned. The bartenders were attentive but not over bearing. I like being left alone which is why I love sitting at the bar. Give it a try you won't regret it. Also, my fiance noted they had 'all the games on'.
Friendly staff but my family was served a SOUR and SPOILED pancake. It was disgusting and the place was filthy as well.
No thank you.  We tried this place. Order a large gourmet pizza two drinks and a desert; price: nearly 50 dollars. wow.  There are way better pizza places in nashville that have better prices.

The restaurant had great food, a cute outdoor seating area, and excellent service. The hotel and room itself however, left much to be desired. It looked more like a motel and I recall very lumpy pillows.

Brunch Buffet is pricey but has a large selection.  If the weathers nice make sure to sit on the deck along the river.

There's a sushi bar on the first floor.  I wouldn't go here looking for top notch sushi.

On the weekends this place gets packed.  They have live music downstairs and if the upstairs room is not rented there's a DJ and another bar.  I didn't find out about the upstairs bar for several years.   Its a nice option if the band isn't that good or if you feel like dancing.

My wife and I had lunch here on a Sunday in November.  Each of us had a burger and we shared sweet potato fries and a Kale smoothie.  The burgers were bland and cooked well done.  The fries were barely warm.  We did enjoy the smoothie.      I was really underwhelmed and would not try their burgers again. I may stop back to try one of their salads

After a long day of shopping or people watching the Rock Bottom is a great spot to unwind at the King of Prussia Mall.  Usually bars / restaurants located in shopping malls are there for convenience and don't pay much attention to quality.  The Rock Bottom doesn't fit the mold.  The restaurant space large with booths and tables scattered all over.  The bar area is large and has a plethora of TV's.  

I stopped for an early dinner with my girlfriend the day after Christmas.  Although the mall was more packed then a keg party in my Fraternity basement the restaurant wasn't too busy.

We grabbed (2) seats at the bar and took a look at the menu.  I had been craving a beer all day so I tried one of the home made unfiltered Belgian White's. My beer hit the spot and was full of flavor.  My girlfriend ordered a turkey sandwich and I picked the 2am burger.  The burger came with bacon, cheese, fried egg and a hash brown all piled together.  It was the perfect ending to a long day of shopping.  The turkey sandwich was packed with turkey and my girlfriend said she would order it again if we came back.

This is the only fast food restaurants I know of in the Philadelphia area that is completely vegan.  Heck, it's one of the few vegetarian ones.  That's what makes it special.  The food isn't mind blowing, but it's pretty tasty, fresh, and fast.  I like this second location much better than the original in center city because there are a lot more tables to dine in at.  Also, parking is pretty easy to find and in some cases free.  

I really enjoy the buffalo "chicken" nuggets with sweet potato fries.  The texture to me is better than actual chicken in my opinion, and the buffalo sauce has a nice little kick to it.  My favorite part is the black bean cilantro sauce that comes with the fries.  It's creamy and super flavorful.  If you love cilantro, it's a must!

The bistro bella sandwich is another item I see myself ordering again soon.  The marinated mushroom is topped with salty olive spread along with artichokes and onions.  It's fresh and not heavy at all.

My only complaint is that the prices are a bit steep.  If you get a sandwich, fries and a drink, you'll easily be around $15 a person pre-tax, which is a lot for fast food.  However, when I'm craving this type of food, it's a price I'm willing to pay.  I would visit more often though if the prices got knocked down a bit.  

Stay away from most of the drinks.  Last time I ordered the green tea, it was good, but the small cup wasn't anywhere near full and it cost $2.50.  The lemonade with carrot and ginger is very bland, and also not worth the $3.

My first meal here five years ago was spectacular, but every one since then has been a let down. The quality varies and the prices are way too high for the quality. I've had over cooked lobster and gritty shellfish. The atmosphere is nice and service is generally good though, with the exception of my last visit.

Most recently I was in the neighborhood at lunch time. I thought I would revisit that wonderful lunch from years ago. Maybe fried seafood is just what they excel at, I thought. The place wasn't too crowded, which was a bit surprising. I had my choice of seats and chose to sit at the bar. I ordered the fried seafood platter. It arrived quicker than I would have thought in less than ten minutes, but since the place wasn't crowded, I figured that was why. 

My food was only slightly warmer than room temperature. The fries tasted good and fresh cut although they weren't piping hot. The seafood made me sad. The shrimp was rubbery and overcooked, the scallops had a nice texture, but they were a little undercooked and had some raw batter inside, and the worst was the oysters. They were so gritty and rubbery, they weren't even edible. The batter was so flavorless too. For a place that is named after its oysters, gritty, tough oysters were the most puzzling and disappointing part. After tax and tip, I spent over $22 on seafood that I mostly couldn't eat. I wanted to say something because it was so bad, but after the sever brought the food, it was next to impossible to track him down. I tried for ten minutes and then gave up because I was starving and had an appointment to get to. 

At least the fries tasted good and the hostess was friendly. I don't see myself hurrying back here anytime soon when there are better options.

This place is always crowded, but I've never had to wait too long to get a table.  The decor is little strange and mismatched.  There are random items hanging on the walls and it's really dark in the dining area.  I don't really get it, but that's okay.  I come there for the food.  

     I'd been here once before for dinner and had the chicken entree with the mashed potatoes.  It wasn't bad, but was rather bland and not worth the price.  I wanted to give it another go though.  I started off with the mojito martini that has the right amount of sweetness and minty fresh goodness. I had the fried tilapia sandwich. The portion was generous.  The fish was breaded and crispy on the outside and flaky inside, but I think it could have used some more spices in the breading.  The toast it was on was rather plain.  I felt like the whole sandwich was lacking something.  The fries were hot and crisp and appeared to be fresh cut. Some people around us had wings that smelled and looked really good.  Maybe I'll try those next time.

This is the best escargot I've had in Philadelphia.

Yeah, they have other menu items, I guess.

This is where James Bond would meet up with a lovely lady to get a drink(and later be trapped because she is working for the villain anyways).

It has a great view and great ambiance at a price you'd expect. It isn't ideal for Sips or happy hour events because it gets too packed. It is a solid choice for late night after the large crowds have moved on.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this place is Casino Royale(the Daniel Craig one)

I've got to hand it to Makiman for some efficient service.  

I drink a lot of water with dinner.  I might as well be trying to drown my food just to make sure the animal aspects of it won't come back to life and try to do some damage to my internal organs as a last act of vengeance(and I do realize this makes even less sense in the context of seafood but bear with me).  Even at my ridiculous water-consumption rate, the server never let the glass get any less than half full.  She did an amazing job.

The sushi was really delicious and very reasonably priced.  Tack this fact onto the fact that it is a BYO and you've got a winning combo.

Their rainbow roll is very tasty.  The shrimp tempura maki is easily on par with Center City establishments.  The Cap'n Crunch roll was...silly.  In all honesty, it did not blow me away.  The salmon and tuna sushi were rockin'.

I tried the green tea tempura ice cream and I've got to say, they overdid the strawberries on top.  It was a little overwhelming.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this establishment is Iron Man.

Great burger, although somewhat pricey ($6.75 for a single cheese burger).  The group of workers were all very friendly and the dining room was large.  Lost points due to the fact they have limited parking and did not have onion rings available, even though it was 11:45 am.  Also, the overwhelming reference to marijuana use posted throughout the place - as well as the shirts the staff wear - sends a wrong message to kids.  I will be back and hopefully try some rings (my grandchildren will not be with me).

It's a mixed review. I can't totally give it the stars it deserves based on this trip. 

The apps were killer! 
The humus was insane!

The bartender... Was terrible. 
Couldn't make me one of the simplest drinks. 
Returned the 1st one, and the 2nd and just had beer. At least they can't mess that up. 

I'd like to return to try the entrées. Everything that passed by me looked amazing. Maybe one day I'll go back, but not for a cocktail.

When have shorts and f'n Hawaiian shirts been considered casual dress?!?!! 

I was excited to try somewhere new. Sorta dressy but not really.  Jeans and a collared shirt? I can do that. 

Dudes wearing short ass shorts and Hawaiian shorts? Are you kidding me?!!!!

I normally don't care about something like this but I chose this place because it was a little more upscale than chili's! What the actual f?

The vibe? Besides Richard wearing shorts, it was really cool. I'd come back. 

Food? Amazing. Had the sea bass. It was killer!!!

Drinks?  Ehhh. So so. The one thing going for this place in the drink category is that they are not expensive. I could swear the first old fashioned that came out was NOT smoked and sat at the bar for a while. Still....not terrible.  Eventually I had a decent smoked old fashioned after switching up the whiskey. I love redemption, but it wasn't working here. 

To wrap it up, I'll be back. 
I'm pissed there is a dress code that is not at all enforced.  
The food was great. Can't wait to try more!

To the guy in shorts, get the F out!

1/5 for the food
5/5 for the always friendly staff

I'm pretty sure I got food poisoning here and can no longer bring myself to go back. I loved the idea of having a diner so close to home but the food was just never good anytime we went. It just always seemed like shortcuts were taken everywhere no matter if it was, breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Once there was water leaking from the ceiling onto our table.

It's a shame because the folks that seem to run the place always seemed so nice. I would always see them go out of their way to talk to their regulars and see how they are doing. This is the only reason for the extra star. 

I'd have to say that this was the worst food I've had in Pennsburg hands down on multiple occasions and for that reason I cannot give it another chance or recommend to anyone.

Finally! A good Mexican place in the Haddonwoods! 

Yes, it's Americanized and hipster, but that's okay as long as the concept is done well, and it is here.

The Mexican Street corn (off the cob and in a bowl - get over it) is HUHMAZING.

I had the spicy crispy chicken and veggie tacos and both were solid.

Good chips and guacamole.  Good margaritas (many with interesting and fresh twists).

Big high ceilings, nice bar area, good natural lighting, reclaimed wood everywhere, and a nice covered back patio where you can see the trees in bloom and watch the Patco speed by.

What more could you want?

We've been to multiple Sabrina's locations but this one in the CWood has to be the nicest (beautiful building with super high ceilings - so downside it can get pretty loud) and the food here is just better and more consistent than the ones across the river. They are currently doing a Game of Thrones themed brunch menu and Cersei's Iron Fleet (bacon, egg, fried green tomato, and greens with a slammin' dressing on a croissant) is HUMAZING! The fried chicken and waffles is also top notch (especially with that specially seasoned butter). The service can be hit or miss depending on how busy it is but we've had some great servers and some just ok ones. It's nice they have the app so you can see the wait time before walking downtown.

... let me start with, we have a lot of pizza shops around the only thing making this one different is the pool tables ... with that being said I thought it would be a dope little spot to come especially when they had cheap wings.... I should have stayed home. I ordered buffalo wings 2 extra blue cheeses asked for them to double the cook time because I hate slimy wet wings... Sis taking the order says "ok" which means it'll get done right? WRONG after getting my order I looked and instantly knew these aren't "cooked hard" "well done" "a lil crunch to it" i said "hey can they drop these again, they're nottt well done" she goes to say "well are you going to try them first" that was the only strike I needed to snap.. I can clearly see the juices still simmering begging to be cooked longer don't tell me you cooked them double the time !! And she just says well they drop the wings all at the same time then add the sauce .... I didn't even hear the rest, ......mam what does that have to do with me when you said "ok" that meant I am paying for what I asked for! ... it was just excuses, give me a refund I'll go down the street. 

‍‍They could have dropped new wings only put my batch in .. and then followed through with adding the sauce or whatever it is she was saying... (please excuse my grammar)

The courtyard is a cute hideaway for a first date. The tables are small which makes it intimate. But, beware they may be shaky due to the pavement. 

Dinner started off with the charcuterie plate. I can't say I enjoyed it that much. I loved the pecans but that's about it. It just wasn't my cuts of meat and cheese. I don't know if it's a seasonal thing or its always the same items.

My friend and I shared an entree and ordered about three apps/sides to share. We had way to much food and no appetite. Maybe we were too busy catching up?

Entree was pork ? See, I didn't really care for it so I don't remember anything about it. 

I remember the crab gratin. That was delicious. We had the fried green tomato, I liked that as well. Lastly, was the gritcake. Which I could have passed on. 

The menu looked very promising and for the most part I enjoyed the meal. I didn't have anything epic. But I just think it was due to my choice of dishes. 

We had two cocktails and the bill totaled to around 70-80$. 

Service was slow, super slow. We didn't care. Too busy talking. 

1 star for ambience
1 star for a variety 
1 star for crab gratin

Five stars because their peanut butter burger will change your life. That is the end of this review. 

You're welcome.

I thought the food was great.. the reason i am giving it such a low rating is that it is WAY expensive!!!!! My lunch was $25.00. YEP! Because I had a beet burger and three spring rolls.. and a wee glass of kombucha. I like this place a lot but will NEVER support this sort of extreme menu pricing.

Yelpers often come to me for advice on tacos, where to find them, the good and the places to avoid.

Pros: The cocktails were well-mixed the day we went. Try the Mexican Mule - which comes with jalapeno infused Altos tequila. It's a pretty awesome kick! The decor is cool. Service is a little shaky, but nobody has ever been an outright jerk... if you can call that a "plus". 

Cons: Everything else...

Full disclosure, I have tried this place more than once and each time tried something different on the menu. Nothing is authentic, at all - well, as authentic as Mexican Food in America can be.

The most awful of offenses was that I ordered tacos and they put COLESLAW from a tub on them. (It tasted identical to the stuff you get in the tubs at Schnucks for a backyard barbecue). You don't put REGULAR cole slaw in a taco...???
