When you go to a legit Mexican restaurant where they serve good tacos and they say "slaw" - they DO NOT MEAN the creamy cole slaw that you eat as a side at picnics - that is not what goes in Mexican tacos! Disgusting.

The fish and shrimp were both "fried" and it was painstakingly obvious that they were pulled from a frozen bag and tasted, also,  very much like something I would give to the kids on the weekend when I am feeling like a lazy Mom... You will have a VERY hard time finding any tacos that are grilled, as opposed to fried, unless you just get the Tacos Pastor... Other than that... Gross. I had to SOAK them in Cholula just to eat them and at one point I was letting the slaw drop out of the taco because I would have rather just have had frozen convenience food shrimp and fish and bare taco than any of that... 

Who made this menu? Who was responsible for these tacos? Who EVER thought that these were acceptable?  Perhaps, they need to talk to the Tilford family who own Mission Taco ---- or Fuzzy's Taco Shop..... or Vallesana on Cherokee???? Somebody has to help them...

Who decided that Mexican restaurants charge you for the salsa bar? 

The most validating thing about my adverse feelings was when I returned to SLU and spoke to various people about my experience they all threw their hands up and said "Oh no we do NOT eat there! That place is gross - how has it taken you so long to figure that out..."

As an elite Yelper, I try to give places multiple changes to disappoint me... three times and you got this review.

Please rethink your menu, rethink your tacos, especially --- they are awful.

Didn't live up to the hype. :( Certainly good food, especially the creme brûlée, but I wouldn't pay that much for what we got again. Also, I hate horseradish, so their cocktail sauce was repulsive to me.

This was an okay spot, the ambiance is nice food was bland. I had the special, blackened catfish with
Crab cake on top and the bbq shrimp as an appetizer. Nothing special here. Maybe go for the drinks or perhaps a bowl of gumbo.

Stopped in here for a birthday. Lots of seafood selection. I was craving some fried shrimp so ordered that up and it was pretty tasty, lots of flavor. I wish there were twice as many shrimp but not bad. Side of fries and coleslaw also solid. Though the cold bread and butter on the table was a bit rough. I also tried out the seafood bisque and it was tasty but very peppery. Also the pumpkin cheesecake was great though I'm not sure if they make in house. Overall not bad, stick with the fried seafood and desserts.

Well, yes, Panera is a cruel place to be for someone who can't eat gluten. But it's a nice space to hang out, study, whatever. Gluten-free options include tomato soup (w/o croutons) and many of the salads, so it is actually possible to eat here. As soon as they hear the magic word "allergy," they are very understanding about having the food prep people change gloves and use separate utensils for the salad. Pretty awesome! Comfy and plentiful seating, the faux fireplaces are always a nice cozy touch, but the muzak is awwwwwfullllllll. Maybe that's the secret weapon to make sure you don't stay there for 5 hours.

We came here to watch the Cubs championship game after a nearby bar filled up. We were able to find seats and a table, and the bar was busy but not uncomfortably packed. We had to order drinks and food at the bar- there were no waiters/waitresses- and the bartenders seemed a bit overwhelmed. It would often take us several minutes to order and get a drink, even with an open tab. We ordered food- fried pickles, a corn dog, mozzarella sticks, that sort of food- and it seriously took forever to get to us. It looked like there were just 2 guys back in the kitchen, and they were pushing out food pretty slowly. But the food was tasty once we got it. But the beer and food was affordable, the crowd was somewhat douchey but somehow still friendly (although maybe that was a product of a shared love of the Cubs), and they had a big screen TV for us to watch the game on in the back room. There was also a pool table and a shuffleboard table that nobody was using. Overall, nothing life changing, but I'm glad we found this place to watch the game at!

The pizza is awesome and are definitely worth the trip and the price.  the trio fries are also awesome. 

I always enjoy their beers and have spent way too much money there drinking them.  the rye ipa is a solid beer.  

the only downsides are that prices can add up quick if you have a few beers and pizza.  Their happy hour is from 4-6 so its hard to actually be there for it considering the location, and I'm pretty sure its a 1 or 2 off of one particular beer, not everything.  The place also doesnt have a tv, which might make alot of hipsters happy, but it would be nice to be able to watch a phils game or something while there.
Very disappointed!! I gave up after waiting over 45 minutes for a to go order. Staff seemed friendly enough just not at all prepared for a lunch rush or a grand opening.

Every time we come here and things seem to be getting better and back to the way they were.

Despite the lightning game we were seated quickly and our server David promptly brought us waters and took our order.

Our food arrived at the table quite fast and was the best its ever been.

After previously posting many negative reviews I am proud to report that new management has definitely turn this place around for the better.

Keep up the good work Hablo Taco !!

Old, worn down, dirty and not well cared for restaurant that I have wanted to try for a while. Multiple wait staff in the foyer, yet strangely slow service. I had go up front  to ask for our check at the end of the meal. 

I had a mediocre ceviche and my son had an octopus dish that he enjoyed.  Neither dish was good enough to warrant a return after I attempted to use the bathroom on the way out. The stench of raw sewage was like hitting a brick wall. It was terrifying considering that it was next to the kitchen.

The food is nothing to rave about. I have tried a few different menus items and all come close to that of something frozen and reheated. The star of the show (and only reason I keep going back) is the patio seating. I love the fire outside and the corn hole. Nice place to relax and have a drink after a long day at work.

We came to celebrate my birthday with a sip and dinner.  We waited for 2.5 hours and the hostess told us it would be 10 more minutes.  1 hour later we were finally seated, however experienced a poor attitude from the hostess.  There was also a lady serving wine samples in the waiting area.  She was very rude and condescending.  Yes, we just experience the wine tasting (where we received great service from julio) but we had just waited an additional hour to be seated and were chastised and denied a sample. Not sure if I'll come back.....    And I love this place!

Stopped in while we were out and about the 'burg this past Friday. Been waiting for them to open. We were not disappointed.  Felt like having pizza with friends with the staff being so friendly. We just had a small pie and regretted not getting a bigger one as soon as we took the first bite.  Fresh flavors on top and incredible bread made for an awesome pizza.  We can't wait to get back for more!

Nice outside seating. Quick service and a pretty diverse menu. We started with Grouper egg rolls. This were ok but didn't seem to have a lot of grouper in them. The we shared a bowl of she crab soup which was really good. The bowl was a lot so we had left overs but it re heated well. I got the grouper Ruben which had great flavors but again lite on fish. Debbie got lobster tacos which were tasty but guess what?  Lite on lobster!  It is a great place across from the beach to sit and chill but they really could put more fish in their entres!

Stopped in for lunch while in Ybor.  Very impressive menu and drink list.  The beer cheese was amazing along with the bread for dipping makes for a great start.  Moved on the the Jambalaya that was spot on.  Lots of shrimp with rice and a really tasty red sauce.  I added some tabasco to kick it up.  Wife had the mac n cheese with andouille sausage.  She could not get enough of either they were so good.  Really looking forward to going back and trying the other things on the menu.  The service was top notch as well.

Forget this place! Drive the extra five minutes to Mid-City's Little Tokyo for Japanese food! Not only is the food way better, but I feel like they double the size of your portions for about the same price!

Sorry Lakeview! I like to stick to my neighborhood, but The Pearl just doesn't cut it like other sushi restaurants in the city.
I got an Iced Coffee here with cream and sugar- not impressed. I'm not really a hot coffee drinker but maybe their hot drinks are better. I can only speak for the Iced coffee.

meh! good for beer but forget the food...................

nothing more then a high priced tavern.

i came here with my boyfriend for what I wanted to be a nice, romantic, traditional creole dinner. What I got instead was an overpriced meal that was very clearly meant for the tourist crowd.  I'll agree with reviewer Eileen Z that this place is a lot of hype and doesn't quite deliver at the end of the day.

I'll start with the good: the food is very good.  I got the gumbo and the blackened drum and both were delicious; perfectly cooked and very savory.  The dinner portions were also big, so even though you're paying a lot, at least you're getting a lot of food on the plate.  The breads in the breadbasket (aside from the molasses muffins) were also very good.  They give you four types and they're all very savory.

What I didn't like, and what killed it for me, was the service and the atmosphere.  I found the service to be too draggy in the parts where it should have been quick, and too quick in the parts where it should have been paced.  It took forever for us to finally place our orders.  When we did place them, our food came out very quick.  Then when it came time to pay, it took forever to get the check and get our cards back.  Additionally, our server was not satisfactory.  He not only spilled water all over the table and nearly all over my boyfriend, but he also didn't know the different items on the wine list, insisting that I order the more expensive pinot gris as opposed to the pinot grigio (he later acknowledged his mistake but I found something else to order at that time).  I also felt that he was rushing us at times.

Finally, I appreciate the fact that K-Paul's doesn't discriminate, but when you're paying over $30 for an entree, you expect the restaurant and atmosphere to have a certain level of class.  The party that was seated a couple of tables over from us was not only dressed inappropriately for such a nice restaurant (seriously, leave your 12 pairs of beads at home buddy), but was very loud and frankly, didn't know how to act appropriately in a nice restaurant (the guy would get up and bang on the table while still semi-drunk).  Fine if you're at Applebee's.  Not okay at an upscale restaurant.

I probably should have gone of one of John Besh's restaurant's instead.

Not bad but not good either. Pork ribs tasted great but they were too fatty and I encountered some gristle. Not a fan of that. Lo mein was mostly noodles, barely any vegetables, and minimal chicken. Pork fried rice tasted hood but there was very little pork. The Crab Rangoon were great though. 

I'll probably try them again.

My weekly visit to Ybor for lunch with my wife is always a surprise as she selcts the place to eat. We walk a few blocks, I smell BBQ and we're at New World Brewery, a first for me.  I see the board. "BBQ Buffet @ $6.50lb!"  As I live a healthy lifestyle, I usually do a sample platter approach to buffets, keep my portion control intact, and get to enjoy the choices put out there.

I pretty much sampled what I thought would be different. I left the mashed potatoes and a couple of other sides that I wasn't in the mood for.
 
I did try the Curry Potato Salad which I will definitely hit next time! The Macaroni Salad was nice as were the collards greens! The cole slaw was vinegar based and that's not my preference. The Jambalaya in a white gravy? This is a New World interpretation. I'm a purist so this is more a chowder. 

Now the BBQ! The smoker is outside in the courtyard. You cant help but smell it as soon as you're half block away. I chose the pulled pork and sausage. There's a lot of good smokey flavor in both. The sausage was quite mild. The pork was righteous! Four sauces are available, Texas Smoke,  Carolina Gold, Mississippi Honey, & Kansan City Classic! I liked the Texas & Honey mixed. Thatr's the fun of having choices of sauces. I lived in NC BBQ Country so the Gold was initially not what I was expecting. It did grow on me and, in the end, I liked it!

Apple Cobbler was the single dessert offering. A warm crisp light crust, filling not too sweet with nice sized apple slices provided a perfect ending to a surprising BBQ lunch buffet. For my accompanying beverage, Clay, our bartender and server recommended Stiegl Radler, a beer with fresh soda mix of grapefruit, light for the summer. He also added ice to a glass as this poured from a can. He was most helpful and made us feel at home. A great lunch! Gonna have to come back in the evening with some Yelp peeps...BRENT! :-P

Gigi and I have frequently visited "the dill!" I lean towards breakfast when we come here. I can always depend on finding an early morning crave satisfied. G loves their Chicken Soup and occasionally hits their burgers anytime of day! IF I decide to get a deli sandwich, I can guarantee I'm bringing half home 'cause their sandwiches are HUGE! Oh, the menu is huge as well. I do enjoy visiting the bakery next door after eating so I can take a dessert home.. and trust me ... you can find it! It does get crowded at times but if you want to eat here bad enough, embrace patience! Enjoy.

We just ate here again this week and WOW we were not disappointed!

The server, Ryan was super and one of the best servers we've had in a long time. He described the food perfectly and was on top of everything. He works Sunday, Tuesday and Wednesday (we asked as we only want him to wait on us from now on) so ask to sit in his section!

I had the tomato basil soup of the day and it was very tasty. My boyfriend had the appetizer of the day which was grilled shrimp with grilled romaine lettuce and this was so frickin good that we made it at home the next day!  We both had the gnocchi and it is still the best gnocchi I've ever tasted. I also ordered the special of the day - red risotto as a side dish and it too was very good.

I highly recommend you try this and I doubt anyone could ever be disappointed - it is just that good.

After stopping in one day for lunch and the place is empty, that should have been our first clue to turn around and leave.

We were told this restaurant has been open for 2 years but I cannot imagine it being open for much longer.  I can't believe that Chopped got booted out of this location for this crappy place.

My husband and I both got terrible upset stomachs after eating here and we ate 2 very different items.  He got a shrimp burrito and I had a cheese quesadilla.  Both were tasteless and the cheese wasn't even melted on my quesadilla.

Love this new market downtown! A great vibe with a killer salad bar. The bakery section offers vegan doughnuts, brownies and cookies - a big plus! There is a huge patio to enjoy your coffee and doughnut or eat your salad.  This store reminds me of a mini-version of Whole Foods.  They have fresh flowers too!

Marco Polo is a restaurant that I always pass by when driving around the neighborhood, but for some reason I never went in to get any food.  One day while I was craving Italian I decided to get some Marco Polos for lunch since its only a mile away and not 10 like the Olive Garden. (I actually like Olive Garden, so for those seeking true italian food and etc, you're looking at wrong yelper) 

The service was really quick and my food was ready in about 10 minutes from when I ordered. Just like the guy that took my order said!

I ordered the bruschetta, the fried calamari, and the Farfalle Marco Polo which is basically bowtie pasta tossed with smoked salmon and baby scampi in a  pink cognac cream sauce. The fried calamari was average but you can't really go wrong with fried calamari, I would have appreciated tartar sauce instead of the marinara that it came with but its fine. The bruschetta was also average, it wasn't bad but the flavors were kinda weak for me to rank it above average. The Farfalle Marco Polo which sounds great on the menu was disappointing and underwhelming. You would think a dish named after the restaurant would have more of an impact instead of being bland as it was. You could have substituted the pink cognac cream sauce with hot water and salt and I wouldn't have noticed a difference. 

I prob won't be going back for a while unless Im seriously craving Italian and can't wait 20-30 minutes for Olive Garden.  Like the previous yelpers mentioned maybe the quality has deteriorated since Chef Lo left, its unfortunate I didn't have a chance to try his cooking when he was there.

IEnjoyed dinner tonight and used a Olive Garden Gift card!!!  (Special tip) 

We sat in the bar at the bar and the service was very slow. We had to ask for second round of drinks, cleared our own table and had to ask for the dessert menu.  Next time we will sit at a table. 

Pork chop and mashed app was Lobster Flatbread were yummy. New Old Fashion was

Had a great experience at the Liter House. Delicious meal and hearty bloody! Was a unplanned stop on the way to the winter market located in the same location. The service was exceptional and the menu interesting. They use local ingredients and from the menu support local most of the time.

Since I am not a vegan,  the meal was tasty and very filling.  I will probably give it another shot. 

Service was very good,  but remember it's a small place and it gets a little crowded.

I'm still surprised there are only like 5 places in the whole city to get hookah, but I guess it's not that high in demand.

Kind of a wannabe-classy establishment, with music that's blaring loud on a Wednesday night and super dark to hide the chips in the odd Roman bath-type walls and floors theme they've got going on.  It's kinda charming in a dirty city way, though.

Overall, the meal and hookah was a pleasant experience.  Hummus was pretty basic, but it definitely wasn't enough for the heaping pile of pita bread, which could have been much softer.  Fried calamari was good, nothing special, but the hidden fried pieces of jalapeno peppers left a bad taste on my palate. The lamb kibobs over rice with some type of yogurt sauce was actually pretty excellent, so I was pleased with that.  Boyfriend's whiskey sour drankkk was done right, so that's a plus.

Got the mango hookah and went through a couple coals.  Pretty nice, though I'd like to try the other flavors they had, specifically Fuzzy Lemonade.  Sounds intriguing.

Overall, I'd go back, but I'd still prefer Fez, where you can unwind and relax on the plush couches and throw pillows, rather than sit upright in an uncomfortable chair on a hard marble table.

P.S.-  Music playlist was my style, but expect to hear a lot of Reggaeton and Usher club hits, as opposed to the usual Bollywood-type stuff.

We'll be back if they ever start carrying gluten free crust again. Place is truly great, but on our last visit several months back we were struck to hear the owner explaining to a server at the bar what he thinks of gluten free, after she had just explained to us they don't have gluten free anymore. We were told to call beforehand to see if they have gluten free. After 2 or 3 calls now and hearing, no sorry, we've given up. Otherwise excellent pizza if no one in your party has to do GF for health reasons.

Ok breakfast but nothing remarkable.  Sat on the patio which was nice.  Kinda weirded out when they sat a party with two hounds that were professional beggars. My first and second breakfast haunts for Sunday mornings remain Ruth's and Rosie's.

Where the heck has Half Liter been hiding this whole time? Or maybe I should say: Where the heck have I been? Because apparently, lots of people have been to Half Liter, and lots of people love it. Though I'm late to the game, I'm glad I discovered this restaurant, and I'm sure I'll be back many times.

One important thing to know, right from the start, is that Half Liter is an offshoot of Liter House. They both occupy the same building, but they are on different sides. One side is the barbecue section (Half Liter), where it's a little more laid back and you order at the counter. This is where most of the families were (and where my family decided to go). On the other side is Liter House, where they serve German-style food, and it's a more traditional restaurant. 

We decided to visit Half Liter, the barbecue side, and the thing over on this side is that you find your own table, write down orders for alcoholic drinks and clip them to a stand at your table, and then order your food at the counter. This ordering system wasn't my favorite, because someone came to take my beer order as my husband was at the counter ordering food, so the server had to coordinate with the person taking my husband's order to make sure my drink was included on the tab. If that sounds confusing, it is, and like I said, it's not my favorite, but the food makes up for the convoluted ordering system.

The food! Specifically: the ribs! I could eat multiple racks of Half Liter's fall-off-the-bone ribs all day long. They were the best thing that we ordered, and I see myself coming back for future orders of ribs. They were smoky, slightly sticky and tender -- all of the things you want from ribs.

We also got the Eddie's Melt, which is smoked pork, collard greens, pimento cheese and caramelized onions. So much meat! If you're looking for a substantial sandwich with a lot of meat in it, get this one. It was delicious. 

We had kids with us, so we also ordered off the kids menu. The kids cheeseburger was fine: The server specifically made a point to tell us that it's not anything special -- just a burger between a bun that they keep warmed in a warming tray. But kids don't care. My kids didn't care. As long as it looks like a burger and it doesn't have anything spicy on it or anything extra, then they are happy. It wasn't the best kids cheeseburger, but it did the job.

This restaurant can get loud from all the people talking and enjoying their meals, but Half Liter keeps the music at a decent level, which I appreciate! (As I get older and more of a curmudgeon, there's nothing that ruins a dining experience faster than overly loud music.) The service is also very fast and not overly obtrusive.

I thought I'd just pop into Joella's for a quick lunch. No -- there's no popping to be done here, nor is anything quick. You need to block out at least 45 minutes to an hour when you visit, because it takes an absurd amount of time to get your food. From the time I ordered my lunch special to the time they put it down on my table, 30 minutes had passed. Thirty minutes for a fast-casual meal during the work week! I should have read the other reviews before I visited, as other people have had a similar experience.

I had ordered my meal to dine in, but by the time I actually got my food, I had to throw it into a to-go container and run out the door because I had an appointment to get to. I had no idea it would take that long to get my food, otherwise I would have went somewhere else for lunch. This is why I'm telling you (nay, warning you): If you want to have an enjoyable visit to Joella's, you need to go into this place knowing that it's going to take a long time. 

The lunch special is chicken strips, a side and a drink. I got the mashed potatoes and gravy and a lemonade. From what I tasted of my food as I was eating it in my car as I was driving, it tasted really good. It's a shame I couldn't have enjoyed my meal while sitting at a table like a normal person. I dunked my chicken strips into the mashed potatoes like a dipping sauce because I had no other way of eating it, but it actually turned out to be a good decision because the chicken strips and mashed potatoes go really well together.

I'm not even exaggerating a little bit when I say that these are the best donuts in Indianapolis. 

You see, I am a donut fiend, and I try every donut when possible. I've eaten a lot of donuts in Indy. Pana Donuts are it. These are the donuts. It sucks that they are so far away, though -- past Beech Grove and almost to Southport. But, I will drive to Pana to get their donuts, because they are worth the drive. 

My go-to donut when I'm trying a new donut joint is the glazed twist. It's a simple donut, but it's easy to get it wrong. Pana got it so right. It was fluffy, soft and fresh (even though we visited in the afternoon!), glazed and chewy yet had a slight give at the ends. It was a perfect glazed twist. I don't even know what else to say to you guys except you need to go to Pana and get some donuts.

So, I got a glazed twist, and my husband got a Boston eclair that he said was "beautiful." Who even says that about donuts? My kids got a strawberry iced sprinkle donut and a vanilla iced sprinkle donut. Now, my kids love donuts but they almost never finish their donuts. But these donuts? They ate them all. 

Pana labels all their donuts in the display case, so you know what they all are and can easily order what you want. I don't know why more donut places don't do this. All the donuts are arranged neatly and everything is visually pleasing. It's just a great donut shop all around, and I think other people agree because at least 10 people came in and ordered during the short time we were there.

So my only complaint about Prohibition Taproom is I once came in on a Monday around 9 or 10 and someone gave my group a hard time about sitting at a table because they need to save them for there dinner crowd.  What dinner crowd do you have that late on a Monday?  That defiantly rub me the wrong way a little but other than that I've had good experience here.  They have a fabulous beer list although a few times I've wanted what's up next.  Those list always get me.
late night drunken people food. oh and it actually tastes good too. lol

Remoulade was respectable but pretty small. Caesar Salad was fine.  Chicken not over done.  Fried fish dinner reported to be fair by colleague.  Gumbo was good, meaty and roux was solid.  Service - really really nice servers.  All engaged talking with patrons almost to the deficit of prompt customer service. Respectable
Great pizza and beer selection- large parties welcome- not too crowded or loud either!

My experience at Honey was not up to par for a handful of reasons. I can speak more to the experience than the food, since the menu isn't always the same. 
It began with an error on my husband's part. When he called to place a reservation, he failed to mention that it was our wedding anniversary. Upon arrival, we were seated in the center area, where there were families with children eating. I asked if we could be moved to the (empty) private table. We were told that that table was unavailable. I mentioned it was our wedding anniversary and the hostess said she would, "see what she could do." She did end up moving us. Amazing how it magically became available.
Anyhow.. We ordered a variety of things-- chips, wagyu beef cheek potato skins, seafood shells, and bread and butter. The chips were divine. Very flavorful and crisp. The potato skins, while not my favorite, were my husband's dream come true. The seafood shells were subpar. Very fishy flavor (which I totally understand is the intention), but it ended up tasting more like tuna casserole. The delicious seafood additions could not properly shine through. The bread and butter had a topping (veggie.. fruit.. root???) that my husband refused to it. It did leave a bit of a weird aftertaste.
We noticed the table behind us kept getting "complimentary" items. We got one... A bite of bread with some spread on top. 
We ended up ordering a dessert and two cappuccinos. The dessert was good.. chocolate hazelnut something. The cappuccinos were terrible. I left mine untouched and my husband tried to slug his down.
After spending well over $100, we hit up McDonald's and Starbucks. We needed to fill our bellies and get our caffeine fix. 
Unique experience? Sure. 
Worth a second trip? Unfortunately not.

An actual text conversation surrounding my recent trip to the Institute went as follows:

Me: I'm heading to the Institute before the concert

Friend: The Institute? 

Me: Ohh, yeah...it's a bar, haha. 

We definitely had some good chuckles about my plans to visit the Institute. Luckily, it's a bar and not someplace where people seek mental help. Although, I can't help but think about those scenes from TV shows and movies where patrons gush their personal details to a bartender over a stiff beverage. 

In any event, this establishment couldn't be any more chill. From the bar cat to the classic graffiti in the single stall bathroom, it was your quintessential, local watering hole. 

The draft beer selection was just okay. They have 16 lines, with 13 in use during my visit. Nothing really stood out so I opted to go the can route. Interestingly, they don't have bottles, just cans. The can list was solid but nothing too crazy. It reminded me of the cans available in the new Whole Foods.

The service was a little Jekyll and Hyde. The bartender was nice and helpful. The server was a little gruff. 

While I didn't eat anything, the mac and cheese at the table next to me had me immediately grabbing the menu. Their comfort food selection could be worth a trip back at some point when in the area.  

In the words of George Constanza, "I got it from the Institute. The Institute!"

I spent a lot of time here during the Santa Barbara Film Festival, and I thought this place was amazing. They served the tastiest ahi tuna appetizers and teriyaki salmon bites, along with some solid beer options. Unfortunately, when I returned for lunch, I discovered all that shit was just catered, and their actual meal was completely disappointing. 

Bummer.

Two stars because the host was very nice and sweet. The server started nice, but when we were almost done and we reminded her that she didn't bring the OJ her answer was "that's it?" Unacceptable answer, I get that part of the human condition is forgetting things still you need to apologize. Also that is why I don't write her name, she was doing great except for that. To the kitchen I order potatoes not the scrubs of your flat, let me know when you change that and then I will came back.

I had never been to Philadelphia before but the first thing I asked my Lyft driver picking me up from the train station was where is the best cheesesteak in town. Max's was the first thing that came out of his mind. He warned me the neighborhood was a bit intimidating to white people, but I gave it a shot and was so glad I did! Yes, he was right, the neighborhood is a bit in the Hood but I had a great experience. I was the only white guy there but everyone was very nice and helped me order one of the best cheesesteaks I've ever had. Seriously, it was the best! Bread, steak, cheese, the peppers, the soginess..., it was amazing! Took it to the bar attached next door and enjoyed it all to myself. Really was worth every penny and next time I go to Philly, I will head back up to Max's for a great cheese steak!

I had the veal picatta. It was a VERY small serving. Cost extra to have vegetables instead of pasta. My meal was outstanding but expensive. $20 for a lunch. Our server was attentive till we got our food, then we never saw him again. We had to ask another waitress to send him over so that we could pay our bill.

The hotel seemed fine to me for the money, even with the resort fees.  It's only 20 mins to downtown.  I do think that some of the valets need more training though.  Some of the them couldn't answer basic questions like "where is the spa entrance" (which is basically right there near the front of the hotel but has quirky access point).  Still, the valets were speedy and otherwise very friendly.

Came to Adele's with a group of 10 people around 11AM on a Saturday. We didn't make a reservation so we wanted to get there when the place opened to see if we would be able to get a table. We didn't wait long to be seated and was initially had a table inside, but we asked if we could sit outside. The staff was very accommodating and had no issues with that. 

Our server was very knowledgeable with the menu and checked up on us often. She provided us additionally information on where to eat or get coffee around Nashville. She also was able to do split checks for our group which was amazing. 

I ordered the pork belly sandwich which comes with a side salad and their kale salad. Both items were delicious. The kale salad looks pretty simple, but it has tons of amazing flavors! I also never had pork belly in a sandwich like Adele's had it, but I am so glad I ordered it. The price for the amount of food was perfect.

I would def come back here and suggest everyone giving this place a try.

I think it's nice that they bring out complimentary muffins; however, I felt as if they tasted a little stale. We ordered the mussels, chicken wings, and the coconut shrimp to start off. The mussels were definitely over cooked to the point where I was not able to chew it any longer. The chicken wings had a distinct taste to them, which were not that great. The coconut shrimp on the other hand were tasty but not fantastic. As an entree, I had the onion crusted salmon with the mashed potatoes and fries. The salmon was cooked to my liking but could have been seasoned a tad bit better. The mashed potatoes were your typical mashed potatoes. The fried were the worst! Not only were they soggy but they were extremely greasy as well. I recommend this place to those who like bar style foods. If you're coming for drinks then I think this place best suits you. If you're coming to dine with friends or family, I don't recommend this place. Will I return? Most likely not, unless I get invited to come here.

Went to Terri's because its a nice place plus has fabulous coffee, its hard to find an eatery that has great coffee, we ordered coffee and lunch, for me a burger and hash browns, wife ordered eggs and hash browns. Something was wrong with my burger didn't taste good, I ate a few bites then went back to coffee. I asked my wife how her food was her eggs good but hash browns weren't crispy as requested not cooked long enough, we realized the food we ordered likely stocked frozen, my burger patty cooked around the edges but pink in the middle next time I'll emphasis 'well done'. You know most folk that come in this place aren't in a rush, Terri's a happy scene and l don't want to complain and send food back because of a dumb hamburger everybody's working hard I know. I'll go back because the coffee is fantastic but might order food not stored frozen like eggs, bacon, muffins, hot oatmeal. It's hard to find a restaurant that serves great coffee and I'll go back, and if the situation is for the guys in the back having to rush then getting the grill hotter might work since things they cook for breakfast and lunch could handle a really hot grill they promise good breakfast, sandwiches, salads, waffles, you know the basics its not French cuisine but if there is a decision needed between waiting longer for an order OR getting food out fast we'll nurse our great coffee and happily wait for it!

Sad as this used to be one of our regular "go-to" places. On last visit, it seemed to be going downhill and after last night, I think it has jumped the proverbial shark. Service was bad at best..sat at the bar where after waiting for at least 15 minutes just to order a drink - all while watching the bartender pace frantically back and forth without ever really getting much done - we then watched while he made drinks with wash water literally dripping from his hands and sweat dripping from his face. Areas behind the bar looked in desperate need of a good cleaning, ick! The one star is for the cabrales cigars which were as good as ever.

This spot is new. It's on what I feel is a desolate corner of Old City. And the food isn't stop the world good. It isn't bad, but it isn't "wow, so glad I came HERE!" Good. But let's talk about Ducky Spots. Duck as in when you can go to a nice spot and dodge the people you normally run into. That's what I took away from the Tuna Bar. It's open enough (outside seating on Race Street!) and dimly lit enough inside that a first or second date here doesn't run the risk of bumping into your whole crew. That's worth something in a city this small. Capable kitchen, friendly staff. Everything is just fine. Now, next up is their happy hour which from the looks of the menu might be the best deal (versus regular priced menu) in Old City. We'll see.

Came in to try this place out for the first time on a Saturday night. The bar area was packed so I had to sit in the dining area. They have 120 taps of beer! 

I tried the broiled lump crab cakes and they were delicious! 

Jordan was our server and she was knowledgeable and helped us through the menu.

I'm not a big fan of Mac n cheese but decided to try the buffalo Mac because the only place I have had Mac and cheese is at the District Tap so I wanted to compare and I think honestly the Mac n cheese at the District Tap tastes better.

Came in to try this place out for the first time on a Saturday night. The bar area was packed so I had to sit in the dining area. They have 120 taps of beer! 

I tried the broiled lump crab cakes and they were delicious! 

Jordan was our server and she was knowledgeable and helped us through the menu.

I'm not a big fan of Mac n cheese but decided to try the buffalo Mac because the only place I have had Mac and cheese is at the District Tap so I wanted to compare and I think honestly the Mac n cheese at the District Tap tastes better.

I had a cup of chili because I was told by the server it had MORE meat than beans.... I found that not to be true..didn't even finish it. 

I didn't think I could go wrong with salmon with mixed greens salad. The dressing was too tangy and tart. 

Women's bathroom smelled.. almost as if sewage backed up in the floor drains...

My favorite was the biscuits and graveyard!! The gravy sauce wasn't too salty.. had nice flavor without tasting like too much flour and the biscuits were soft and melt in you're mouth! 

I also ordered the granola with yogurt parfait. The taste and creaminess of the yogurt was spot on but it had way too much granola in it. 

It is a very small place but we got sat right away. I was bummed they offered no bloody Mary's or mimosas for brunch.

I'm all about their Tuesday Tacos, but the past few visits here have been pretty disappointing.  The tomato basil soup contained so much cream that it would have been better as a pasta sauce, while forgetting to ask for my dressing on the side, the Caesar salad came overly drenched. Too much mayo and over-buttered bread...this "light" lunch  left me realizing that there are much better ways to spend $20 in Boise.

I was excited to hear about another Greek place in town, but this place is just okay in my book. Not a whole lot of variety, as the menu seems more fitting for pub grub. Prices are a little high for what you get, but I will say that most of the food I've had here tasted fresh and made to order. This is not a good choice if you're craving falafel though, and the spanakopita was pretty much what you get in the frozen food isle.

My husband are in search for the BEST pizza place in the valley.  We tried Lucky 13 last week and it was good but not as amazing as people had built it up to be.  It was just normal pizza with creative names and topping combinations.
Great local place.  It's best to call ahead your order during lunch rush.  Everything is made fresh daily!
I really like this Market. They have a variety of different Cultures. You Name they got it! STOP BY AND CHECK IT OUT!

Came in at 9pm on a Thursday and the place was still pretty full. The place is HUGE - 7,000sq ft was what the hostess told me. There's some really good bread that I wish was served warm, but still good.

Shrimp cocktail - delicious. The horseradish cocktail is not as potent as Harry and izzy's, which I can enjoy more. It still clears the sinus.
Navy bean soup - was okay, but then again I'm not a huge bean person. I liked the sausage bits in there.
Bone-in filet - COLD. They brought it out and it was almost colder than room temp. We had to ask the server to reheat it for us. Didn't get a single apology. Whatever. The steak itself had no flavor. We added salt and it was delicious and super super tender. I wish the steak was brought out warmer.. 

Nice ambience, okay service, mediocre food. I might lean more towards Harry and izzy's or capital grille.

My wife and and I came here on a rainy Friday evening. It was too humid to sit outside but the exterior decor was pretty cool.

It's modern southern food but not pretentious.

We had the shrimp and grits, Mac-n-cheese, chicken pot pie, and a chocolate tort with raspberry goat cheese. 

Great ambiance, service, and food.

I stopped in to the Sycamore on Thursday for the wife's B-day dinner.  We both agreed it was one of the most fabulous dinners we have experienced in many years.  Certainly the best new American meal we have ever eaten.

Lansdowne is an unusual place for a fine restaurant.  No one thinks of it as a restaurant town.  It was the glowing reviews on Yelp that finally put Sycamore on my radar.

We were seated right on time for a 7:00 reservation.  The room was slightly less than half full.  The décor is rustic, warm, and casual.  The wait staff was in jeans.  

Sycamore is BYOB but they have a "Cocktail Mixer Menu."  You bring the liquor and they make wonderful drinks sized for two ($8).  Check the web site for the selection.  We tried the La Paloma and the Indian Ocean and they were both wonderful.  

To begin our meal we tried the Farmer's Plate.  This is a selection of three cheeses and two meats accompanied by an amazing selection of .accoutrements.  You can select the meats and cheeses yourself from a short list.  This is not to be missed!  When ours arrived the beautiful presentation and our moans of pleasure caused two other tables to order it immediately.  

We ordered delicious Spaghetti alla Carbonara as an appetizer and prepared for the entrees.

The entrees are limited at the Sycamore and change frequently.  It's important to check the website.  The wife enjoyed Seared Duck Magret and I devoured Red Wine Braised Beef Short Ribs.  This is new American cuisine at its finest!  We finished the meal with the wife's favorite desert; Tiramisu.

Our evening included mixers for four drinks, Farmer's Plate, one appetizer, two entrees and one desert.  We were pleasantly satiated and the tab was a very reasonable $108. 
 
We will definitely be back!

"New" like hell!

These folks have been around for over twenty years.  Whatever you call them they serve up some tasty food.  I'm working just down the street right now so I gave them a try.  I try not to review a pizza joint unless I've visited at least twice and that was the case here.

They are located just a few feet from the intersection of Lancaster and Wayne Aves.  Directly in front of them are a few parking species marked "ten minute pickup parking" with no meters and that's nice.

Each time I visited the place was spotless.  This is a take-out only family-run place with just a few chairs for sitting while you wait for your order.

Day#1
Of course I was going to try the pizza. Its Greek pizza here so all you Italian pizza snobs can stop rolling your eyes and making those funny snorting noises!  I ordered two slices with sausage and they made it fresh.  They happened to make it from a small pie and when they do that they double your order so I was given four small slices.  The crust was cooked perfectly and there was plenty of topping.  The cheese was particularly tasty.  This is a thin crust pizza joint.  My "4" small slices and a 20 oz. soda cost me $8 and change and it was an excellent lunch.

Day#2
This time I tried an Italian Grinder.  It was fresh and tasty and most importantly hot all the way through.  I hate when you order a grinder and they are cold in the middle!  The tab was $7.53 and once again an excellent lunch.

On each visit I'm betting the Greek lady that cashed me out was the mother of this family.  She was excellent and really makes you feel welcome.  For a "New" place they seriously have their act together!

Identity crisis!

I roll in for lunch today and sit at the large full bar.  Ten feet away is the hostess podium with a giant bowl of lollipops for what I assume are the kids.  Yup, here they come now, ready to run around and cause a ruckus.  My very friendly bartender reals off the specials and each dish has so many ingredients it screams gastro pub. But wait, the place is super casual with very casual furnishings.  There is no way it feels like a gastro pub.  What is this place?

So I order a Braised brisket Sandwich for $9.75.  It arrives quickly and the toasted soft roll is to die for.  The brisket, not so much.  It's over cooked and a little tough and fatty.  The entire plate was quite small including a tiny cup of coleslaw and a few chips.  Maybe I shouldn't bitch so much for $9.75.  It may have had "smoky sautéed onions" on it but there was no way in hell it was anything but a three star casual sandwich. 
 
This place is surrounded by serious upscale restaurants.  It's likely a good choice for an economical lunch in the area. I'm not ready to give up on them yet.  I'll try them again and hopefully I won't step on any rug rats!

These folks really push the envelope, in a good way, when it comes to delis.  This is a family owned place that has been around for years.  The lovely wife and I have been visiting them just about forever.

We stopped in yesterday for breakfast.  I tried the breakfast platter that included three eggs, my choice of meat (sausage), a mountain of hash browns, toast, and unlimited coffee for $4.99.  OMG, how would I pay the mortgage!  I really appreciated that it wasn't greasy because I really hate that. They have a bigger platter that includes the same stuff plus pancakes or French toast for $6.99.  After eating that it would be kind of embarrassing if I had to waddle out to my car.

This place is not just for breakfast.  These folks have a beer license and have cooler after cooler of beer including many great microbrews.  But wait; it gets even better.  They have six beers on tap.  A deli with draft beers in Havertown; who would have thunk it!  I could have a Magic Hat with my super large hoagie.  What's not to love?

If you are anywhere near Havertown I think it would be a mistake not to give these folks a shot.

Very pleasant. I had a fried ham Po-Boy, and it was good, but really needed a lot more ham on it. The bread was fantastic. We ordered cheese fries and they were good, but seemed like they had very little cheese on them. We also ordered potato salad. It was good, but very generic. It was a great base to build off if you wanted to make it distinctive with some bacon or Creole seasoning. I would go back, but not my favorite place.

Ohhh Man-O-Manakeesh --

I want to love you and you leave me disappointed!

I want to first say that the intention to be amazing is there; the problem in the execution is the reason for 3 stars.

Put order in for a spicy fish wrap;  15 min later,  am told they don't have it.  Asked for a suggested replacment.  Talked into the freshly made kefta wrap.  A half  hr or more goes by and check on my order -- never put in.  Given complimentary baklava for the error (which was very amazing,  though wayyy too sweet for my liking and I gave it to a couple sitting nearby who appreciated it!).   This was a lovely gesture and I was now beyond famished.

Kefta wrap arrives 20 min later.    So I have literally spent over an hr awaiting food!  The bread is too die for.   Can't say I was a fan of the kefta.  An acquired taste, me thinks. 

I am willing to return and give them another chance to wow me like many of the other Yelpers have experienced.

Am always thrilled to find a new Pho place and often I can exclaim I have not met a Pho I didn't become enamored with (unless it is too greasy or too salty).

This was a pretty satisfying bowl,  I must say so !   I got the Pho Do Bien (seafood).  Noodles were just the right softness,  good broth,  excellent octopus (tender with just the right bite),  large flavorful shrimp.  The fish cakes were not the best I've had,  yet fine.  I could have done without the mushy imitation crab in it (hence the 4 stars vs. 5).

Service was expedient and efficient!

Lovely atmosphere and enjoyed watching pre-season football on the big screen.

Excellent cafe su da (Vietnamese Iced Coffee).

Great addition to diversifying the culinary palette of the burbs when one doesn't feel like making the trek to the usual Pho spots in N.E. Or S. Philly!

The atmosphere at Aksum was great... the food, not so much. I ordered the grilled seitan, which came with wild mushroom faro, peppers, and avocado. I was very disappointed by the sparse amount of seitan that was actually in the dish; most of my plate was faro. The rest of the dish was pretty bland, and I definitely did not feel full after I finished eating. My friend ended up ordering an extra soup halfway through his dinner because he was still hungry too.

The restaurant also somehow messed up our reservation. My friend had originally made a reservation for 6pm, but they called her saying to come at 6:30 instead... but then at 8:30, our (rather large) group was rushed out in order to accommodate another big party. Um, okay, thanks...

One thing I will say though is that their menu is very vegetarian/vegan-friendly. Other than that, there wasn't anything I particularly liked about Aksum that makes me want to return.

This is no doubt a local favorite.  I unfortunately am a huge Mexican food fan and have had way better.  It has made me wonder based on the reviews if people who frequent here have ever ventured out and tried different Mexican places, say in the city which isn't too far and offers a several locales which would trump this easy.  The food is okay.  It's not bad but not anything worth mentioning.  I also find that I would expect a little more food for what you pay, not that its pricey just would expect a better food to dollar ratio.  It was really disappointing because it's in a great location.  On the upside, it's one of two spots open late night after bars let out in Conshy.

Texas Roadhouse has always been a safe bet for a good steak and comforting sides.  At least that was always true at the Shiloh, IL location.  We have eaten at the Edwardsville location twice.  Both times were for dinner after 7.  The first time my hubby and I ordered a medium well filet and a medium rare sirloin respectively.  We got a medium rare filet and a medium sirloin.  The filet was sent back for a better cook and I did not mind my medium sirloin.  The mashed potatoes were good as were the rolls (always).  The second time we met another couple here.  The cooks were correct on the steaks but the flavor was not there.  Someone forgot to season the steaks and the potatoes were lukewarm.  We have since learned that there are many restaurant options in the area and it is unlikely we will be back.

The staff does not know how to take an order and communicate that order to the kitchen. You will be waiting for over an hour for your meal to show up, and that is ONLY if you mention to the staff "Where is my food, been over an hour?" 

I am not sure if its a joke? Do they realize that when you pay for food, you actually expect to GET THE FOOD? Do they eat the food in the kitchen? Do they let out a huge laugh that people are waiting  for 1 -2 hours? Pathetic. They are a joke and the pizza is not good.

Never a long wait. I've tried the lamb and beef tibs with injera. I also had the okra wot. So good!! Everything I tried has been delicious. Friends that I bring have all complained about customer service. Mostly about how the staff does not explain the menu to new comers. Not everyone is familiar with this type of food. The first time i was here, I felt the same way. This could make some people feel out of place. But im used to their 'mediocre/minimum' service now. For that reason I mostly order to go!
I've always enjoyed their food. Been coming here since the grand opening. And remained loyal ever since. The portions are generous and there's never a wait.

They really need to be more careful and thorough about reading orders. I've been a vegetarian for almost ten years. I ordered a burger that came with bacon and subbed the patty for an impossible burger. I even put a bunch of asterisks by the 'no Bacon' part when ordering online because for some Reason people always seem to never listen when I say that. But of course, the burger had bacon on it. I was so disappointed because after waiting so long for the food I couldn't even eat it. Pork is such a harsh meat to accidentally put in someone's food; a lot of people don't eat it for religious reasons or allergies and even the juices can make someone sick if they've never eaten pork before as their body isn't used to it. I had to throw it away, and I didn't have time to drive over there to get it replaced. Extremely disappointed.

We were directed here by someone at another brewery. That, for me, is a good sell. I was told that it may be too crowded, and to go to some other place if it was. But there was a spot right there on the patio. I was mainly looking for beer, but we were hungry.
Parking was a bit atrocious, but it's more the neighborhood than anything. It was also very difficult to get in to the area. We ended up only about a block away though, in a free spot.
The patio is nice enough, but features cheap lawn furniture. I'm not looking for white table cloths, but when my chair is from Wal-Mart and cost less than half what I'm paying for my meal, it's annoying. But I'm glad we were outside because of what the inside looked like: dank is the word I'd use. Everything was dark, musty and kind of strange. If they were going for the British pub look, they didn't succeed. The size of the bar really disappointed me: it's supposed to be a brewpub, so why have a bar that's only 5' or so long?
And that should have signaled to me, right there, that this is the sort of brewpub that focuses on food, not beer, because that seems to be the case. The beer wasn't awful, but everything was very safe, and a lot of it just wasn't very good. I was impressed that they did nitro/cask pours, but they were served cold.
I was told later, by a local bartender who also spoke highly of this place, that their beer is supposed to be more English style. That actually redeems the beer in my mind a little, because it makes sense why some of them tasted as they did. But they're still not good.
The food also was not good. I mean, it wasn't bad, where I'd throw it down and say "This is awful" and refuse to eat it, but it was just so mediocre. I got the sausage sandwich, which was served with sauerkraut from the can on a slightly stale roll. And the sausage was undercooked. I got the mashed potatoes for a side, which were good, but were topped with a watery gravy that looked, had the consistency of, and tasted more like sweet coffee than anything.
My companion got the vegetarian sloppy joe, which was more like vegetarian chili than anything. She got a side of the vegetables, which were undercooked.
The service was relatively slow throughout the meal but the girl was nice, until I asked about a charge at the end of the meal. Both of our standard sides had been fries, but we both decided to change. I noticed (the list of sides along with their prices are at the bottom of the menu) that my mashed potatoes with gravy were $0.25 more than the standard fries, while my companion's veggies were the same price. On the ticket, instead of being upcharged $0.25, I was charged the full $1.75. The server said that this was how it was and it was more a fluke that my companion wasn't charged than me being charged. My whole thing: if you're going to charge the full price for a side substitution, then give me the other side. It's just fair. But we protested and she huffed off, not to return for about 10 minutes after that.
I was also irked by the sampler price: $1.25 each, which added up to $10. $10 for eight samples? That seems high, and it would have been nice to know that beforehand.
We could have gotten away with "That place kind of sucked" and left it there, but the issue with the ticket, and the fact that I had been deliberately led here by others left me feeling so slighted that I started saying "I should say something to the manager." I'm not the type to usually talk to the manager. In fact, I've done it all of twice in my recent memory: once here and once at the worst Boston Market I'd ever encountered in suburban Atlanta, where I told the guy that his franchise should be taken away and that he should be ashamed of his operation. Here, I just mentioned that it was a bad experience all around and that he should consider worked on the sampler pricing, because $10 is absurd for the quality of that beer. I had already paid, and wanted nothing but to give them feedback that I hoped would help them.
Will it? Probably not, because this place is so busy that they don't really need me and they don't need my feedback. I'm sure I was written off as just a self-righteous asshole. I would offer this to readers though: there are four brewpubs in the Broad Ripple area so, if you're looking to patronize one for dinner, your options are not limited and are much better elsewhere.
1*, but 2* when I realized that the beer was supposed to be English style. It would have helped to have known that, just as it would have helped to have known beforehand the sampler pricing. A sign outside saying "This is going to suck" also would have been helpful, but not necessary.

Stopped in here on my way back into town from San Manuel.  A riding buddy had suggested it and had been here several times.  I got the world famous pulled pork sandwich with beans as my side.  The food was very good and the service was great.  They had a 3 BBQ sauces - a mild, their house special (a little spicy) and a southern mustard.  The only thing I was a little disappointed in was the warm apple cinnamon crisp.  They used apple pie filling, which was not bad, but it was the fried tortilla shell that disappointed me.  I was expected more a traditional apple crisp.  I will swing by again some day when I am in the area, but next time I will try something else for dessert.

Been to the original a few times and really enjoyed it.  Thought I would be getting the same experience here, but that was not the case. I opted for a build your own burger rather than one of the canned favorites.  Like others have said the burger was dry and no flavor despite their menu saying their burgers are seasoned.  This was a bit of a letdown given the juicy burgers I had gotten on 4th ave.  It was a bit of a slow night and service was on point.  The place looks great and there are plenty of seating options - Bar, Booths or Tables.

Red Robin - Where the food is just OK, the service is really bad and the management customer service is nice.  My daughter and I arrived early to beat the crowds and hopefully have a decent meal with decent service.  We beat the crowds since it wasn't even half full yet.  We ordered our drinks and the short stack of onion rings (6 rings).  My drink came out quickly, but since my daughter ordered one of the Cream Sodas and it took longer for her to receive hers.  After about 10 minutes after my daughter received her drink her burger showed up.  She had ordered the Pigout Tavern Double Burger with their in house made chips.  10 minutes later the manager came by and told us that there was something wrong and that she would pay for the onion tower short stack.  At which point she asked what I had ordered. Wait a minute, you mean to tell me that I placed my order 20 minutes ago and our onion rings 30 minutes ago and you just now tell me something was wrong.  I reminded her that I had ordered the Guacamole Bacon Burger with Chipotle Aioli for my side salad.  Well my burger finally showed up but instead of a container full of Chipotle Aioli, there was hardly any, maybe a quarter full (and that is stretching it).  I was well into my burger when our appetizer finally showed up and my daughter was almost done with hers.  They were very hot, but super greasy. The onion rings came with full containers of ranch dressing and their Camp-Fire Mayo dipping sauces.  Kind of what I was expecting with the Chipotle Aioli.  Maybe the Chipotle Aioli is made of gold and the 50 cent up charge for the Chipotle Aioli only gives you so much.  

Bottomless sides means bottomless fries.  As I mentioned before I had a side salad and my daughter had the chips.  We got more fries.  But how can I get more fries, if I didn't want fries.  What about more chips? Or a refill on my salad with some more of that rare Chipotle Aioli.  Sodas were supposed to be unlimited as well, but we were limited to one each.

So, overall the food was just ok.  The burgers only ok and the guacamole was spread so thin that I hardly noticed it was there.  The chips were very dark (almost burnt) and had no flavor.  I guess if you wanted you could have paid for some dipping sauce, but we saw how well that work with the Chipotle Aioli.

It was nice the manager covered our onion rings, but there were other issue here that they need to take care of.  Maybe they were a bit short staffed tonight, but when you watch her punch in the order at the table on a little handheld device, how do you lose two thirds of our order?  I think after this experience we will pass on going back again.

In the past we have experienced problems at this Dairy Queen - Whether it is with ordering, paying or getting our food there always seemed to be an issue.  The last few time we have gone, they have been much better, we get the food that we ordered, in the size we requested.

I would have given 4 stars if not for them downsizing the salads! I get the strawberry fields salad every time I come here. The dollop of honey pecan salad and the sesame dressing make the salad out of this world. It's my favorite salad of all time. But recently I've noticed that the boxes the salads come in are smaller than before, but I am still paying a good 13 bucks for it, which is quite expensive for a salad, especially when it depends on who makes it. There's a guy there that NEVER fill up the box. Aside from this slight annoyance, it's still my favorite salad and I have no choice but to go back when I crave it!

My work always cater from here and the food is always fresh and delicious! The roasted veggies side is awesome, packed with flavor. Chicken or beef rollups are yummy and fun to eat. The protein plate is a great healthier option.

Their chocolate chips cookies are awesome, packed with huge chunks of chocolate! yum!

This place definitely has two things going for it; foozball and darts. Even adults need to play! The jukebox is fairly eclectic, you'll hear all kinds of music ranging from U2 to NIN to Snoop to Johnny Cash. Like that. It gets way too smoky for my taste in there, little hard to breathe honestly. And I wish they sold something other than beer; I tried to order hard liquor and was surprised to find out they don't carry that license. Otherwise, I do like the people that come through. It's laid-back, no pretentions, just a good time. They would have all my stars but for the smokiness and lack of liquor!

Dreadful food. Tables have been dirty both times I've eaten there and the whole restaurant smells like a giant, 500-year-old ashtray. All the trucks and tooboxes in the parkinglot should have been a clue. (My dad has a truck and a toolbox, and I love him; but I don't let him choose restaurants. It's just common sense, people!) 

It's like Shoney's and Der Weinerschnitzel did it in a bathroom stall, and then popped out a really fugly baby.

However, the people that own it are super nice, and straight guys have to have somewhere to eat. The world can't be all cloth napkins and wine spritzers. But I really wish they had warned me first.

Despite living on the East side for nearly 20 years, this was only perhaps my fourth visit to Eclectic Cafe. It's a cozy little restaurant tucked into an aging strip mall on one of the busiest intersections in town. The inside is painted in warm colors and features beautiful paintings which appeared to be by local artists.

The menu is extensive and has many, many dishes that would be good choices. I quickly chose the Francisco's Enchilada Salad, as I have never had anything called an enchilada salad before. It arrived almost immediately -- less than five minutes after I ordered it. This would usually be a good thing during my lunch hour, but it did not bode well for the quality of the food.

The salad was large, fresh, and beautiful, with bright green slices of avocado, crumbles of queso fresco, chicken soaked in red guajillo sauce, tiny halved jalapeños, and topped with crisp tortilla strips. The salad was accompanied by a jar of red salsa that was just piquant enough, without overwhelming the flavor of the dish. Underneath the salad, I found a pair of corn tortillas soaked in the delicious guajillo sauce.

The only real fault with the dish was the chicken, which was slightly dry and slightly tough. When the plate arrived so quickly, my first thought was "How did they have time to grill the chicken?" They didn't; it was pre-cooked. And for this, it suffered. Some of the tomatoes were also under-ripe and had hard, flavorless white centers. Every other aspect of the salad was perfect.

Eclectic Cafe's menu is huge and many of their items are unique, at least in my experience. The fast service got me back to work with 20 minutes to spare in my lunch hour and while this would usually be a benefit, I would have waited that extra 20 minutes if it had meant better chicken. Still, I would be happy to return to Eclectic and sample more of their local delights.
Quality of the food is good, but the quanitity is not so good. I feel like the prices are a bit too high for what you get.

Time to write a new review.  Food average, the shitty bartendress I complained about a few years back is gone, FINALLY.  Jeez, did she have pictures of the owner involved in something that might be embarrassing?  Was in there the first weekend of January 2013, and the little blonde bimbo airhead twit  "look at me I'm so cute" cheerleader tending bar charged me $6.50 or a 12-oz bottle of Budweiser's finest ROLLING ROCK.  No shit,  $6.50 for a fucking Rock.  Whoops?  Did I just say that?  Goddam right I did.  wouldn't mind paying that for a good micro brew, but Rock?  We used Rock to mop the floor of the Rathskeller at Penn State.  But try ordering a draft and see how much head you get on top of your beer. I'm done with this place FOR GOOD.  And that's a real shame because it's the closest bar to my house.  I'm pretty screwed I guess, because when I go the other way, I pass the Pineville Tavern and that's no prom winner, either.   This new owner at the "Wyck" seems to have a real knack for picking lousy bartenders. When they have a good one, it is REALLY rare.  So if you're looking for good service and a bartender that can think, even when the bar is crowded, go somewhere else.  I do it all the time now!!  Screw the Candlewyck.
Greatest tuna hoagie ever.  Probably have other good sandwiches, but the tuna is the only thing I had.  Doesn't get any better.

Came here on a Monday night around 5 PM, it was pretty packed and we had to wait around 15 minutes. We grabbed the flaming volcano drink for two which was great. Then had shrimp & scallops for the hibachi which was good, they had a great sauce to go with it. The views to this place really make it great!

Best BBQ in the sourounding area by far. This place has some of the best homemade pies and desserts ever! But hurry cause they sell out fast. Also on certain days they havelivemusivand the restaurant is on Percy preist lake.

Pretty decent.  I called to make a reservation and they said none were available.  I got on open table and made one for the exact time I had just asked about.  It was barren when I got there at 11am for brunch so I was a little confused. I was not crazy about their drinks(bad bloody mary tasted like V8 and straight vodka & a overwhelmingly strong chocolate martini).  Food was good.  I would recommend the crab cakes.  Nothing to really rave about...

The closest to our newest residence we frequently order on Saturdays after ive been out late Friday nites. This seasons is hit or miss; depending on whose working your pizza will be perfection or a disaster. Last nites pizza was probably one of the better ones we've had. Thin crust cheese is our staple and they also offer gluten free and whole wheat crusts. The signature salad is also a go to for me cranberries, gorgonzola and mesceulen greens it comes with balsamic raspberry vinaigrette but I usually substitute the house dressing. 
This location has a full bar and HH specials. We've never actually dined in but the girls who take to go orders are pretty friendly and efficient. 
Its not the best pizza ive ever had but its way better than any chain

This place is on my way to work depending on which way I go. Never considered it for lunch but im an e club member and they sent a coupon for 3.00 off a sandwich. I forgot lunch today so I gave it a whirl. Tuna on whole wheat wrap with chips for 6.55 (pre coupon) the tuna could have used some salt and pepper ( no not the rap group) but it was pretty large for its size and I was only able to eat half .
They have a couple different options for lunch bagel pizza, sandwiches on your choice of bread, bagel or whole wheat wrap along with some salads and soups. Moderately priced between 5-8 I think this place is pretty good for an on the go meal. Not many tables since there was some sort of geriatric convention in the dining room. 
Breakfast is always good when I bop in here. I think its worth a lunch stop im intrigued by the pizza bagels.

Sooo.... my husband and I have been eating Mungos for years at all locations. When they recently moved to Collinsville we were extremely happy as we live in Collinsville.
We have frequented the restaurant a few times and besides the loudness of the place I would recommend. Food is always amazing... but what I WOULD NOT recommend is getting it to go. After working all day and just wanting to relax we have ordered to go quite a few times. Food is always good but you DO NOT get what you pay for. Salads are our favorite and for $10.00 you would think you would get a decent size. That was the case at first but tonight did me in. After seeing the size get smaller and smaller each time I have now come to realize I am not going to eat there any longer. At first you did get a large portion and considering you are paying for lettuce, cheese and dressing you should. The same is for the pasta dishes. Less and less each time we order. They are at least half the size they were when they opened and the same price. I want to support small businesses but they are making it hard when the ones who support you are taking advantage of your hard earned dollars. Extremely DISAPPOINTED and will not be back.  
Collinsville Resident

Friends from Levittown brought us here for lunch and we really enjoyed it. The inside is colorful with fun chairs and a great atmosphere. The service was friendly and the menu is expansive. The prices are really reasonable for the portion sizes and we all left very happy! Try the white queso dip - it's amazing!!!

Cute shop in the area. I tried the special of 5 dumplings for one price. This special already includes 5 'favorite' dumplings so you can't modify the order. The dumplings were smaller than I expected but they were crispy and warm. From the flavors, the cheesesteak was the best one. I had the spinach and ricotta one, and it tasted like the inside mixture was still cold so it was a weird experience to bite through the crispy outside to the cold filling. I'll try out the dessert ones next time bc they seem more promising.

I'll put the TLDR first: MEH. Mostly basic menu, bad food and okay service. And too expensive for food that was not fresh. Now on to the details.

I was really looking forward for this place to open. They did a lot of work in the building formally called the schoolhouse. They built a huge deck out front, and added lots of wood and TVs inside. Its pretty nice and does have a New England feel. Now, I realize this is a Boston themed restaurant, but the Red Sox and Patriots stuff was too much. You're in FL now, so maybe some support for OUR teams too would be nice. I'm not letting let bias my review.

We started with a beer. Decent beers, moderately priced ($4-$6) and a full cocktail list. Our server gave us the wrong beers. I know you're new, but something like getting the right drink doesn't take months of on the job training. 

On to the food. They were out of lobster so we couldn't try the bisque. We decided to start with the "stuffies". The clams were chewy and inedible. Gross really. The rest of the menu was extremely basic bar food. They had a few special seafood dishes, but not enough to stand out. For our entrees, I got a buffalo chicken wrap, and my boyfriend got the fisherman's seafood platter.  My wrap was just a notch above the mcdonalds snack wrap: dry and boring. The fries were good. The $20 seafood platter wasn't much better. The claims were horrible. They were so chewy they tasted frozen, or not cooked right. There was also only 2 shrimp on the plate.  I don't mind spending money on quality food. But if I can go to the grocery store and buy frozen claim strips and popcorn shrimp and be more satisfied than with a restaurant meal, we have a problem. 

I left $70 poorer, and dissatisfied. I feel like the mistakes were too much that I can't chalk them up to this place being new. I won't be coming back. Do yourself a favor and choose one of the many BETTER pubs within a 10 minute drive. I give this place less than a year.

EDIT: this might be a case of yelp being dishonest. Some of the poor reviews are not "recommended" meaning they don't show up in the ratings. It's mostly people with one review, but how come the positive ratings from 1 review people show up? It's fishy to say the least. I'm Hoping my review continues to show up. This place is NOT a 4.5 star. The real rating with all averages to about a 2.5/3.

Cafe Beignet may not be as well known as the More Famous Beignet Place, but it's a locals favorite with multiple locations in the city. This one is located right next to the police station on Royal because cops like beignets in NOLA, I guess? In any case, it's certainly convenient for a quick, reasonably priced breakfast. 

The space is super cute with a frescoed barrel ceiling and inviting pastry case. You're probably here for beignets (3/$3.99) and they're really good - served hot & fresh. They're a little crisp outside with a soft, slightly chewy interior. 

We also had omelettes ($9-10) which aren't huge but are very nicely made and tasty. They come with delicious grilled French bread and grits, which you should just throw into the trash because they're congealed, unseasoned and straight gross. Everything else is good though. 

You'll order at the counter and food will be brought out. We found that service was quick and pleasant, and we would definitely come back!

In the context of hotel restaurants, 211 is probably 4 stars.

In the context of the "real world" i.e. a restaurant you'd actually "want" to eat at: 2 stars.

Average: 3 stars

Our service was really good - attentive and proactive. The prices are high, but that's to be expected for a hotel. The food was definitely ok for a hotel but nothing special when there's 20+ choices just a few blocks away.

Nice day in Tampa? Walk a few blocks.
Raining like the devil? 211 is just fine.

I was pretty impressed with Meril - in general the food was really good, and a good value besides. I had dinner with a group of 8, and thought they handled a larger party well despite being packed with other larger groups. 

We had a reservation but still had to wait close up 30 minutes which wasn't great. I did like their wine list - lots to pick from including one of my favorite Cremants, St Hilaire. The bartender overcharged me though ($15 vs the $14 menu price) and I didn't realize it til later. Sad face. 

We started with a bunch of things: deviled eggs (yum), cornbread, shrimp tacos and fried biscuits - all excellent except for the biscuit things which ended up like hush puppies, kind of dry and boring. They'll definitely size appetizers to suit the size of your party which is really nice. 

For my main I had their meatballs ($11) which are nice and light and served with a slightly spicy tomato sauce. Again, lots of sides for the table - tasty Brussels sprouts, patatas bravas that tasted like Spain and outstanding curry cauliflower. At the end of the day, I found that the veggie dishes were the most delicious and memorable so it's a good place to check out if you're with meatless eaters. 

Service was really on top of our tables many requests. Considering the location, and the high quality, the prices are a very good value. Would recommend and definitely would me back.

Came here for lunch with my Dad. As I've done so many times in the past, tried to order a lunch combo on the weekend even though it's only a weekday promotion. You'd think I would learn, but you'd also think that Applebee's would NOT HAND OUT THAT MENU INSERT ON THE WEEKENDS. It's just annoying, but I'm not saying I'm not at fault.

Ended up ordering the chicken fajita rollup in a snap decision. The same thing I always get. It tasted the same as always. The service was fine, not exactly friendly, best described as matter-of-fact.

All told, same ol' Applebee's. To paraphrase Ron Burgundy "we've been going to the same party for 12 years and in no way is that depressing"

Pretty solid.  Like many, heard about this place on Triple D and let's face it, we all need to ingest a healthy amount of grease from time to time.

Went with the Home Run Chili Cheeseburger and a side of onion rings.  The onion rings were fantastic, hot and greasy and they didn't fall apart when I took a bite.  They tasted great in the chili from the burger.

As for the burger itself, quite good.  I added jalapenos and that was a nice touch.  The chili is right up there with my mom's - and that's high praise.  The burger itself was tasty and greasy (notice a pattern?) - just the kind you want.  I had delusions of eating it with my hands but those were quickly dispelled after I got it.  Definitely a fork-and-knife burger.
