I'll definitely be back - I want to try the Clemente as my decision came down to the wire.  Danny's doesn't seem to be hurting so I should have plenty of time for a return trip.

Food: 2.5
Decor: 2
Ambiance: 3
Service: 3.5
Value: 2.5

I've heard good things about this place, but honestly this doesn't particularly seem like a standout in Chinatown considering how many options you have within a few blocks. Prices were average, as was the food. This place has a liquor license, if that is what you are looking for.
The food was decent but a little overpriced. It's a nice location but maybe not the spot for a foodie- that said some of the fusion options are worth a look.

My first experience at Casa Tina was not the greatest. My friends talked this place up and said they loved it. The service was good considering it was probably one of their busiest nights of the year due to the St. Patrick's Day block party. 

I ordered a taco salad which was nothing like I expected. This was NOT the first time I've eaten a taco salad. In fact I've probably had 100 of them, if not more, in my lifetime. The shell was flat and buried on the bottom of salad. The chicken was grilled not shredded. If I wanted a grilled chicken salad I would have ordered one somewhere else. The tomatoes were not ripe. Very disappointing. Even my friend that had been coming here for a long time didn't eat her salad as we ordered the same. When I questioned the waitress she said I could have requested shredded chicken. Sorry, but shredded chicken is standard on a taco salad and I should not have had to request it.

I will say however, the queso fundido with chorizo was delicious! This was the highlight of my meal, the appetizer. The shots were also on point and my Corona Light was cold.

They were using a special menu, according to my friends, which didn't offer all the usual selections. Which I could understand seeing how busy they were. One of my friends told me it also seemed like the prices were higher than usual. Not cool!

When I'm back in the area I may give this place another try. We shall see.

This place smells like pee the food was horrible. He appetizer was good and the service was great he was on top of everything. But the quality of the food was horrible not his fault. We will never be back I would recommend going to the the local Irish pub in town the caladaugh. It's about the same price and the quality of the food is way better. Trust me when I tell you don't waste your time at the Coachman

I have been to Bhan Thai twice and both times the food was very, very good. I was just here last Saturday and I really like this place.

The restaurant is bright and welcoming. It is not a large place, Bhan Thai probably holds about 20-30 people. 

We had Tom Yum soup with shrimp and that was very good, maybe just slightly under spiced. The Pad Thai was excellent and fresh, the Masaman curry was super flavorful and contained Avocado, nice touch. We had a noodle dish with beef that was great and and seafood dish. We also had daily special appetizer, a fried noodle with tofu and shrimp that was fantastic. Each dish was fresh, had tons of flavors and was just really, really good.

The staff was friendly and the prices were typical. We are definitely going back. The only negative for me is I wish it was a bit closer to Cherry Hill.

I have been to BBP in University City and I was very happy that one opened  in Cherry Hill. I also would write that BBP consistently is among the better burgers I've  had from a chain. The burger comes out exactly as ordered but is slightly on the small side. I  think the bun could be a little better at BBP, it is nothing special.

I have had a few burgers at BBP but right now my favorite is the Buffalo Style...crunchified. It has the prefect amount of hot sauce and cheese. The other burgers I have tried at BBP have all been good also.  What BPP excels at is their toppings. The are fairly unique and the flavors work together well. The milk shakes are pretty darn good too. 

The place is clean and hip.The staff at BBP are always super friendly and helpful.

Prohibition Taproom is from the  owners of Café Lift and Bufad. The space is open and clean and outfitted with retro-funky black leather barstools, filament bulb lighting fixtures and nice vintage jukebox. The menu includes a solid tap list of domestic microbrews and hundreds of bottles, along with some really solid and diverse comfort bar foods.

We started with the crab fritters. These were similar to a crab hushpuppy and not greasy at all. There are not too many foods much better then Crab and fried bread! I had the Burger which is 100% grass fed local beef, butchered & ground at Kensington Quarters topped with a 6yr. Rustic cheddar, lettuce, & onion stout jam on a Snowflake bun. This cheese and bun were excellent and the burger was juicy. My daughter had the  Kielbasa & Pierogies - House smoked Polish sausage served with our potato pierogies, sauerkraut, and hot mustard. That was really good also. For dessert we had the the Pumpkin Tres Leches. The sauce and brittle were fantastic.

Callowhill is really changing and becoming a cool and funky neighborhood.

Food is good but service is bad to the point of being hostile.  I am handicapped and tried to reserve a booth.  Was told they don't reserve booths for anyone.  So, I went at 6:00 and all booths were empty.  I asked for a booth and maitr d said "We don't reserve booths for anyone."  I replied that I want a booth since no one was sitting in any of them. He said he would have to "check".  We were baffled and told him so.  He finally seated us but let us know he didnt like it.   Bizarre.  Knowing their policy, we tried to eat again last week (mistake) and come in at 6:00 p m.  This time we were told very flatly that we could come in at 6:00 but we would be forced to leave no later than 8:00 p m--guess they would call NOPD.  While their food is good, I would never go to any restaurant and be treated like that.  They are obviously doing too well from tourist business.  Unless you are prepared to be treated like this, don't go there.  I sure won't and I am certain they don't care.

Very disappointed . It's a chain style restaurant . Our apps n main course were served together , food was cold and dryer out like I got a returned food , waitress was nice but the feel I got was they were trying to close up and get out

Slow as molasses in January and it's April 28th.  We arrived at 1:30 pm with only two people in front of us and it took 33 mins to get a Ruben & a salad.  Zero urgency and it was "okay".  Not sure we'll go back.   Had higher hopes.

Horrible service, pretty good sushi. Unfortunately, it's not good enough to come back and deal with the service that we had this last experience. Our waitress was very rude and made us feel rushed to finish our meal. Happy hour is nice but apparently you can't mix and match the beers, they bring the same two out at a time, and you have to wait for your server to come back around again and open the second one for you (which will take a while.) Will not be coming back unfortunately. It's a shame due to the amazing quality of the sushi and presentation being absolutely beautiful.

Went here for cheesesteaks on a recommendation from a friend.   Opted for the "Giant Half Pound Cheesesteak for 10.99."  Our fearless leader tried the "Pepper & Thyme crusted filet mignon sandwich for $14.99".
 First appearance when they brought out the platters was "WOW"!  I keep it simple with fried onions and ketchup.  They say half pound of meat and I'm thinking it was more.  Some places advertise with words like "jumbo" or "big" and "giant" and inevitably disappoint.  Not this place!  Picture tell the story better than I can describe.   The cheesesteak was a mix of ribeye and brisket chopped well with the cheese melted in nicely.  There was a hint of smokiness from the brisket.  The final product was moist and tender on a butter toasted Liscio roll.  The whole thing worked well together.   The filet cheesesteak was very good but I wasn't a fan of either the seasoning or the arugula.  The meat was tender and would have been great with simple salt and pepper.  Nothing wrong with it just a personal preference.  In addition order Red neck egg rolls (love the name).  It was filled with pulled pork and cole slaw.  Served with cue sauce which later found out is barbecue sauce and Japanese mayo.  Nice taste to it with just a little heat.  Excellent condiment for the egg rolls and probably will slather it on my left over cheesesteak today.
We got talking to The manager and Tiffany who cooked this amazing food for us.  They encouraged us to try their barbecue food next time, but as we explained we were on a cheesesteak adventure.   The next thing the manager did was life altering.  She brought us each a piece of candied bacon to try. OMG!  Thank God I have to cross the bridge to get to this place because this bacon could become addicting!  Pricing was fair for what we got

Late night hunt for po'boys led us to Le Bayou. I have to admit, drinks were on point, but the shrimp po'boy missed the mark for me. Massive bread with super, hard, crunchy parts coupled with softer, overly chewy sides and topped with a skimpy amount of shrimp with no sauce. I did request remoulade sauce, which was provided upon request. Service was ok, but I will attribute the perceived shortcomings to the lateness of the evening. I was a little disappointed, but I got full.

Wings are great. I can't find a better wing place in Westchase. Aesthetic Upgrades are long overdue.Another recommendation is to expand the beer menu and to trim the long winded entree and appetizer portion of the menu. Tampa bay brewing company is down the street but their beer is nowhere to be found on the menu.

Pretty good. The food was good. I felt like they should give eating plates along with the serving dishes that the food is on. I was kind of confused as to weather it was just meant for us to eat off the dishes the food was served on or not. One dish was quite large or one portion & the other dish was a salad & served in on a tall dish that was quite awkward to eat from. We also had an appetizer that we shared & had to ask for plates for it. We sat at the plant wall at the front of the restaurant, which is beautiful but the plants hung down kind of low & tickled my hair the whole time. The  atmosphere is nice. Service was okay, they were busy, so, it was fine, not overly attentive, but friendly.  I was really disappointed that they had no non-alcoholic mocktails on their menu.

Not my favorite breakfast place.  I can't really put my finger on why I don't love it, I guess I just find the food to be average, slightly bland.  Cute little gift shop, but it doesn't make up for "just ok" food.

It's a rainy Sunday morning and my family (party of 6) met at Southwest Diner for brunch. We had to wait about 30-40 minutes. They squeezed the 6 of us around a table for 4. This one has been on my list for a while so I was looking forward to trying it. 

I ordered the Enchiladas Platter (Stacked corn tortillas with cheese and chile sauce. Served with rice and beans) and was given the choice of red chile, green chile, or Christmas style (both.) Was there any other option? Of course I went with Christmas style. This was a delicious and flavorful plate of food. Everything on the plate was well spiced and the cheese was smooth and creamy. I didn't love the rice. My brother ordered the Carne Adovada (Red chile braised local pork shoulder, 2 eggs, home fries and tortillas.) I thought the pork shoulder was well seasoned, tender, and delicious. I would order it myself. My boyfriend ordered the Jonathan's Famous Fiery Scramble (Spicy, cheesy, scrambled eggs with sausage, home fries and biscuit.) He requested light spice and felt the food was still spicy but very much enjoyed his meal. Other orders were one of the egg combos, a breakfast sandwich, and the buttermilk cornmeal pancakes. The portions are generous, the prices are reasonable, and the service is friendly.

My issues were the long wait time and the fact that they squeezed our party of 6 around a table for 4. The host even commented that we were all very tall. I'm not tall (5'6"). I'm the short one but the rest of the party is 6'4", 6'2", and 3 women at 5'10". Also the place is crowded and loud. I'm sure this is a much different scene during the week and I wouldn't hesitate to give it another try then but as far as weekends are concerned I'm out.

My boyfriend and I walked over to Bar Louie on a Tuesday night after we had been to a Yelp Event at Scapegoat a few doors away. Turns out Tuesday night is $1 burger night. Score! Who knew? I ordered a burger with blue cheese crumbles. He ordered a burger with cheddar cheese, tomato, etc. We got an order of tater tots to share. We each had a beer. Our bill was like $22 and the burgers and tots were great! These weren't tiny sliders either. They were quite a nice size. Thumbs up Bar Louie! I'm not rushing here any other night but if it's Tuesday then yes, I'm there!

It had been a couple of years since I had been to Soco's Gyros. I was in the neighborhood on a weekday so I stopped in for lunch. Their gyro meat is spiced right and they do a nice job crisping the slices on a flat top before they serve it to you. The pita bread was fresh and just a little toasty. All in all a good gyro but slightly expensive considering there is no table service, nothing comes with it, and it's a little on the small side. I'd go back but I'm not in a rush.

I had previously been to the Salt + Smoke in U City once. We got a to-go order from the Hampton location on a Monday night. Our order included the Burnt End Toasted Ravs, a Falafel Burger, a Prime Brisket Sandwich, and a Caesar Salad (no croutons) with Brisket on it. We got a variety of BBQ sauces in our bag. The service was friendly and speedy and the order was nicely packed. The vegetarian felt like the Falafel Burger was adequate. The Brisket Sandwich was good except that the "burnt end mayo" included with it was pretty gross. We had to reread the menu while we were looking at all of the food to figure out what it even was. My Caesar Salad was adequate. The lettuce was leafy and the brisket was a little bit tough. I'm not sure why they cube it instead of slicing it? I eat a lot of BBQ and I'd consider this one to be just average or slightly below. So much good BBQ in town now that I wouldn't rush back to this one. Side note though: the Burnt End Toasted Ravs are totally awesome. They are fresh and different and the white BBQ dipping sauce complements them perfectly. If I had to go back I'd order a whole order of these for myself and call it a day.

Canyon Café is one of those places I've eaten at many times so I'm surprised I've never reviewed it before. I was there on Tuesday night with a party of three. We sat at the bar for a few minutes to wait for our table on the patio. We ordered a guacamole appetizer and two drinks. It was happy hour. We only sat for a few minutes before the table was ready so we paid the bartender and headed out to the patio. We carried chips, salsa, guacamole, and drinks with us. The bus boy brought us a new basket of chips but no new salsa. We had to ask the waiter later for salsa and waters which I feel should have been obvious. My two dinner dates both ordered fajitas and I ordered the Pecan-Crusted Crab Cake (sweet potato, poblano peppers, charred corn and pecan-panko crust, tossed greens, papaya fruit salsa, sweet potatoes strings, snakebite beans, southwest remoulade sauce.) I've eaten this dish numerous times. It's good and it was good the other night. It wasn't amazing but it was good. All in all if you're looking for real Mexican go somewhere else. This is watered down but it's a nice setting with a great patio. The service isn't what it should be for a restaurant at Frontenac.

I had lunch with my Dad at Byrd & Barrel on a Wednesday.  It's a cute place and the food was great.  We shared the poutine (tater tots, smoked chicken, cheese curds, & chicken gravy). Um, so delicious.  I love tater tots and these were clearly handmade and the best ones I had ever had.  It was crispy, cheesey, creamy, and salty all at the same time.  What could be better?  It would have been better had I snapped a picture but we started demolishing it too quickly...  We both ordered the Mother Clucker Sandwich (fried chicken, caramelized onion, provel cheese, hot pepper jelly, red hot riplets, sesame bun).  The chicken was crispy and hot but still moist on the inside.  The caramelized onion added just the right amount of sweetness, the provel cheese was mild and didn't compete with any of the other flavors going on, the hot pepper jelly again added a bit of spice and sweetness and finally the red hot riplets were the perfect saltiness, spice, and crunch.  I ditched the sesame bun but it was great.  I can't wait to go back and try more of the menu!

Drove about 30 minutes to try this place out so I was hoping for the best. 

Walked in...yep...TONS of frog decorations. I was thinking to myself, it must be nice to be so enthralled with something that whenever you see that thing at a craft show or store, you just buy it and put it in your restaurant!

So, now for the experience. The place was VERY busy for Sunday brunch at 11:00am. However, we only waited about 25 minutes and were shocked at how the zipped people in. It must be a big deal here in Florida, but we had coffee in our cups before we even met our waiter. So, perks for the fast coffee service (and he came around every so often to refill too). It took a little while for the server to great us the first time, but once he did, the service was very good and quick. 

I had french toast and home fries. The french toast was on the better end of the spectrum as far as french toast goes. Thick and fluffy and a rectangle instead of a square. Oh, and they gave me like 6 or 7 pieces....it was A LOT of french toast. And did I mention that the home fries are TO DIE FOR? I didn't? Well, they're to die for! Some kind of spice on them that made them extra delicious. 

My friend ordered some kind of crazy egg dish with peppers and cheese and a whole bunch of stuff, and she was enjoyed it way much. She was also VERY impressed with the home fries. 

Only flaw was that the coffee was on the weaker side.

The place is right across the street from the water, but there's a giant apartment, hotel, or condo complex blocking the view of the water, but it's there and you can kind of see it, plus, you get to see some crazy big beach front homes as you're driving up to the restaurant. Small parking lot in front and a bigger one in the back. Casual attire, and, yes, there are a handful of "regulars" that are probably at The Frog Pond regularly, but I think it's mostly first timers or people staying in the area, so don't be intimidated if the staff doesn't know you ;). 

So, for my first Tampa brunch experience, it twas pretty good.

I don't know how this place has a four star rating.  If you want standard-fare, low quality breakfast (overly processed, frozen food with little to no fresh options), this is the place for you.  We live in Yardley, and against my husband's better judgement, I insisted we give this place a try.  I ordered the grilled veggie wrap--I think the veggies were frozen.

I know Chickie & Pete's is a Philly staple, but the breakfast service a terminal C is poor at best.  Everything comes with their cheese sauce, no options = no sale for me.

I opted for their Bloody Mary.  This was no better being weak and watery. A sure miss.  Even after a generous shot of Frank's Hot Sauce it only made it the "meh" level.  

They can do better.  At least they are consistent with their competition ... All of which is mediocre.

Excellent atmosphere. Great, affordable wedge salad with nice bleu cheese. Hubbz and I split the quinoa and roasted veg bowl with added blackened chicken.,seriously the best thing I've all week. I could eat this all the time - the dressing and roasted veggies were amazing. Order this!

The cocktails and chips and salsa were delicious and a great start to the meal. Unfortunately, the tacos were pretty underwhelming. We tried 6 different tacos and none of them had any flavor. They were pretty spicy, which I enjoyed, but very flavorless. The food itself was expensive for what it was, and I more than likely won't be going back - even for the delicious cocktail

I usually love Redstone and have always went to the location in Plymouth Meeting with great experiences each time. After COVID hit, I tried the location in Marlton expecting the same experience. Unfortunately that was not the case. 

I ordered one of my favorite dishes the Cedar Plank Salmon which came out burnt on the outside with burnt lemon wedges as garnish. So bad I had to flip the lemons over to salvage the pic. Before I ordered I asked for it to be cooked medium medium rare like it usually is at Plymouth Meeting, and it seemed almost purposely the server brought out this burnt salmon. Why be so malicious towards customers? 

I love the garlic aioli that used to come with it but its not available right now with the new post COVID menu. This is something I feel the server could have mentioned to me while ordering as I mentioned I come  here often so I didn't read in detail the description. I usually dip my salmon and asparagus in the aioli and it's my favorite part of the dish. 

The Cornbread still taste good but for some reason I don't remember it having actual Corn  pieces in it...? Maybe I forgot, but I could do without the corn inside. 

I also ordered my usual buffalo shrimp which was $17.50 and I only received 4 pieces instead of the usual full order of 6. There is also no option for a half order of 3 neither anymore. The new limited COVID menu is frustrating to any long time goers because the menu isn't huge to begin with and there also no weekly specials. I think I'll just go back once their menu is back to normal. Biggest plus is my Redstone Manhattan  still taste pretty good just a little stronger than usual and it's already a strong drink. 


The server was very indifferent throughout the entire meal, and did not act like he cared about us enjoying ourselves at all. He actually brought down the mood it was so bad. I didn't even want anything else to eat. We left without dessert. I don't want to feel I have to fight to be treated right at any restaurant. Will never return to this location.

--approximately 6:15 Tuesday, 12/114/21

I called because I couldn't find where on the website to order the mini burgers. I was told I had to order online. 

Said I couldn't, so the girl (honey,sweetie,baby, were her favorite words) said to hold on a minute, and she would take my order. 

I drove from Cleary and Airline on hold, and hung up when I got to the drive up window. 

Placed my order, paid, and gave a tip. 

I waited 35 minutes, and never got food. So I rolled over the bell, and the same girl came out to take my order. I told her I was still waiting for my order.  

She went to the other side of the restaurant and came back a few minutes later with my food. I asked if was still hot. She said, yeah, we had to wait for the chili. She also gave me 6 glazed donuts--complimentary. (Thanks!)

I drove off and realized I did not get my drinks. 
I got home 6 minutes later, and the burgers and fries and even the chili were all cold. 

Heated up the chili--is that barbecue sauce I taste in the chili!?!? - YUCK!
Really?  

So so disappointed for $24 worth of cold food. 

Yelp makes me give one star, so that's what I gave, even though I didn't want to!
One word: totchos ... not for every day, but kind of genius. Bartender has a parietal eye, I swear.

I've been to the Flying Saucer in Memphis numerous times and since they've opened one here in STL I've been pestering my co-workers that we have to go there for lunch.  Finally we made a visit and we were all highly disappointed.

It's a seat yourself place and even though the inside is decorated with plenty of things to keep your attention, I choose a table for our group outside.  I should have known by the fact that all the empty tables had not been bussed that it was a bad idea.  I chose the table with the least amount of left over cups/plates/napkins thinking somebody would come over to wipe it up fairly shortly.  However we sat there for a good 10 minutes before seeing anybody who worked there bring out a pizza to the table next to us.  She stopped and asked if anybody had been by to take our drink order.  She politely took our drink order and also our appetizer order and walked away.

After that a blonde girl came by and asked if our drink order was taken, we told her yes and then she disappeared.  Our appetizers ended up coming out 15 minutes later by the same girl who took our drink & appetizer order but we still hadn't gotten our drinks.  Finally the blonde girl came back with drinks and began to walk away but I was able to ask her for plates, napkins and for our table wiped off.  She looked stunned and confused as to why I was asking.  She came back carrying the plates pressed up against her body while juggling 2 drinks for another table and the whole time I'm thinking awesome my plate that I'm going to eat off of was just pushed against your t-shirt and god only knows where that's been.

After she half-assed cleaned our table, she asked if we were ready to order or need a few more minutes.  By now we've been there a good 25 minutes, so I'm pretty sure we've been able to look over the menu and if you don't know what you want pick something now because who knows when she'll be back.

Our food came out quickly by yet another server/food runner/whoever.  Food was pretty good - I had the Turkey Meltdown with the side salad.  Good size portions for the price.  Also our table got the Rocket Tots as an appetizer and I'd definitely pass on them in the future, nothing special.

After our meal, our waitress finally showed up again and asked if we were ready for the check.  One of us asked for a to-go box, which she of course forgot. I was definitely glad to pay for my meal and get the heck out of there.

The couple seated at the table next to us had to get up to track down the waitress several times.  Once to get the other part of their order because apparently they ordered more than just pizza, another time to get silverware after the lady had asked the waitress when she brought the second dish, another time to get drink refills and then finally to get their check and a to-go box.  During our table's time there, the only time the waitress came to their table was to drop off the second meal.

All in all service was horrible.  It completely ruined my experience of the STL Flying Saucer.  I would have been more forgiving if there was a rush and the place was busy, but after the couple left next to us there was only our table of 3 and another larger table, who had ordered before us.

They definitely need to get their service in check, hopefully they have their A-Team servers working on during Cardinal's games and leave the C squad for the weekday lunch crowd.  May or may not be back in the future, I might just make the drive to Memphis or KC if I'm ever craving Flying Saucer.

Food was delicious but our overall experience was disappointing. We had to wait 45 minutes upon our arrival for our table- even though we made reservations!! We requested a booth, they sat us a table. We were never offered bread. 

At the conclusion of our night we were left waiting 40 minutes for our car to be retrieved from valet. They locked us out! Lucky for us, the valet knocked on the door and someone graciously let us in the wait for our car. I won't be going back!

I felt like the original owners are gone?
The food was barely warm, portions on street tacos terribly small, no more sopapillas to end the meal with 'on the house' & only 1 bathroom in working order.
Plus, the tables were dirty.

This is going to be the first review heavily influenced by the server.  As a former waiter, I tend to give a lot of leeway for poor service.  The server may just be having a bad day or be inexperienced at the job.  I don't like rating an entire business because of one person.

In this case, the service was so poor and the server so unapologetic that it soured the whole experience.  

She was rude, short-tempered, forgetful, and extremely slow.  She forgot to place our order, was incapable of getting the correct drinks, barely checked on the table and was extremely, extremely, extremely slow.  

She also added drinks to the various bills at the table, and was unable to properly divide the bill, even though we told her several times we needed separate bills.  Finally, she refused to correct the extra drinks on the bill and made excuses about where the manager was.  We finally just paid for the extra beers as we just wanted to leave.  

I do believe she did all this on purpose as well. I was able to watch the other tables she waited on and those that arrived after us had drinks and food well ahead of us.  She was very attentive and prompt with the other tables as well.

The only reason this isn't a one star review is that Kilroy's itself was nice and seems to be a great place to watch a sporting event.  Soooooo many TV's!  

I just can't bring myself to recommend the place to anyone.

The space is great-bright, modern, and airy. The food is not so great. I got the grilled fish sandwich with a house salad. The fish which was flounder that day was tasteless. It was like the chef did not season the fish at all. The filet contained so many bones it made it impossible to eat. The salad dressing was unbalanced with way too much vinegar.  The fries were a welcome distraction to my disappointing main course. Hoped it would be better.

Soooo very pissed. Ordered a pasta with grilled chicken to go and they brought my order out WITHOUT THE CHICKEN. And of course I didn't notice til I was home and they were closed. What a waste of money. Who orders noodles only?

Update.....the following day I asked for someone to get back to me.....days later and no one has spoken with me yet. I'm a college student so funds are tight which is why I make a big deal out of lost money

I can't say I ever chewed on leather before but I imagine it would be similar to what Pat's Steaks uses for their meat. I can't give them 1 star because that is what I would give Geno's, their neighbor. My vote would be for either Jim's or Steve's.

Meh... 
Burger Republic was a real let down for us. 
Positives:
The atmosphere was nice and the selection of beer on tap is awesome.The crab dip was decent and the tater tots were very good but what was supposed to be the shinning star, the burger, was a total let down. 

Negatives:
The burger meat was dry and tasteless. The toppings sounded better on the menu than they actually delivered. Neither of us finished our burgers which says a lot. I've had better burgers at home and at Red Robin. We both thought the burgers were overpriced for what we got. 

So disappointed! We won't be back..

Sunday is not the night to visit Petite Valentien. Very poor experience this past Sunday. Took house guests for prix fixe. Chef substitutes not prepared to cook tasty food or turn food out in timely manner. We were there three hours. The waiter did apologize and comped one glass of wine, referring to a "snafu" in the kitchen. The Tomato Provencal was fine.  Pissaladiere inedible. Of the 3 mains offerred, only the Steak was adequate. Lamb Confit was refrigerator cold, bad greasy taste. Seabass was overcooked served room temperature.  Vegetables served with the fish were tasty, but would have been better warm.
I had the espresso and biscotti dessert, which was quite good. Others had the creme brulee and said it was good.
After having had many previous meals that were quite good, it was certainly a dissapointment to share this bad experience with guests celebrating an anniversary.

This Sunday (around 12:45 p.m.) we decided to try Shlomo and Vito's.  We were going to one of our "regular" restaurants for a lunch, but decided to try something new.  We won't be going back.   

The staff was friendly enough; that wasn't the issue.  It was the food, drinks and cleanliness of the establishment that turned us off to a return visit.   Our visit:  We arrived and were seated immediately.  The restaurant was less that 20 percent full.  I ordered Iced Tea and the Met Salad.  I asked for grilled chicken on the salad instead of friend chicken and was told that was "no problem"---only to learn when the bill arrived that this $12.95 salad had a $2.00 additional charge ($14.95) for simply changing the chicken from fried to grilled.   The salad, while edible, was definitely not worth $14.95.    

My iced tea was so weak that I thought it was water (you couldn't tell through the red plastic glasses).  When I told the waitress, she said that "everyone complains about our iced tea"  I asked if it was brewed tea and she said that it was.  I sent it back and replaced it with a diet Pepsi.   Seriously, how can a DELI not have decent iced tea and instead has tea that "everyone complains about" per the waitress.

Two strikes.  

My lunch companion order the bagel and lox (for $15.75) and said that it was unremarkable.  In fact, the lox had brown edges that had to be trimmed before he could eat it.  He said it was the worst bag and lox he can ever remember having.

Three strikes and I'm not done...

I used the Men's room and was disgusted at how filthy it was.  It had clearly not been cleaned in a while.  The window on the door to the mens room was covered with "crud" ---finger prints, and other sticky residue.  The floor was dirty and clearly hadn't been washed in a while.  And the area above the urinal was disgusting as well.   I believe that the state of the restrooms in a restaurant says a lot about how the kitchen is most likely maintained.   I would urge the Pima County Health Department to make a surprise inspection, because I bet the Kitchen would not pass muster if the cleanliness of the rest of the establishment is any indicator.    Also, the menu's we were given were sticky---clearly they are not cleaned between patrons.  (Can you say GERMS???)

Bottom line:  We left after paying a $35.00 bill vowing to never return and feeling that we had experienced one of the worst dining experiences ever in Tucson.   We dine out at least three times per week so have a significant base of comparison.

Hopefully, the management will take my criticisms to heart and clean up the establishment; clean menus before re-using, make Iced Tea that doesn't taste like water and tell customers when there is a charge for a substation of grilled chicken instead of fried.

Had one danish and it was decent, but it was pretty crowded on a Sunday afternoon. For only two of us, The receptionist told us to wait would be an hour and a half. That seems incredible and difficult to even estimate, especially because it was a very large place with lots of seating.  Hence, only three stars. Seems like they have to work things out and/or higher better staff.  Good luck.

This place was highly recommended by a local friend. And by highly recommended, I mean, enthusiasm coupled with sparkling eyes and a really painful slap on my shoulder (I had a bruise the day after!). That enthusiasm for anything gets me equally enthused so of course we simply had to go!

The good thing about Gene's is that they are open 24 hours, so I imagine they are a godsend after a long night of partying and/or drinking. Also, it feels very much a neighborhood joint so you don't have to deal with "those tacky tourists" much. 

Now, I don't eat red meat so that makes Gene's menu very, very limited for me.  Everybody raves about the hot sausage (beef, said the guy in the counter) poboy, but I could only have the ham and cheese poboy (I know! I know! Who in their right mind does that? Well I was hungry at 3 in the morning!). Well it is nothing special, I can assure you. However, the bread is really very good. I kept imagining how good a poboy would it have been had I been able to choose shrimp or oysters instead (no seafood poboys at Gene's).

But what made me rate this establishment from "Meh" to "A-OK" is the experience. First off, the guy behind the counter was really very pleasant and kept chatting with us. He even gave me advice on how I can speed and not get a ticket ("Just bawl your eyes out, baby!").  There were a few Belgians who came in while we were waiting who looked frankly bewildered that the place their concierge raved about was *this* place and looked suspicious of the clientele. Not that I could blame them -- a number of drunks were at Gene's. In the space of 20-25 minutes, overall rambunctiousness (paired with conversations ranging from freaking hilarious to quite philosophical to nearly violent outbursts) ruled the place. It was an interesting way to end the evening.

So go for the experience, if not for the poboy.

Slim Goodie's strives to be a classic old style diner, and it largely achieves that goal.  The coffee is strong and served in proper diner mug.  Eggs in abundance, both traditional forms and some creative iron-skillet dishes.  

The Orleans Slammer is an iron pan full of bacon, beans, and eggs, prepared as you like it.  In my case, the over-easy egg had stayed on the grill too long and the yolk was cooked through.  That was a disappointment, as I was looking at this dish as a kind of huevos rancheros.  The cheese fries had a lighter dusting of cheese than what's typical. That's good for your calorie count but not exactly why one is ordering cheese fries in the first place.  

The coffee,  good, strong, and dark, was refilled quickly until the burgeoning crowd demanded too much of the server both in terms of both time and ability to get to our table. Crowds are a problem here.  On most weekends you can expect to wait, and then once in the restaurant the place is buzzing with people.  That gives it a lively atmosphere, but also means that carafe of coffee is less likely to come your way when you want it--and when you're at a diner on Saturday morning, you really want it.

It's easy enough to scope out the crowd situation from the street, though.  If there are legions of pale-looking people milling around the sidewalk, keep driving or stay on the bus.

The check took a long time to arrive, all while we endured the haunting stares of hungry people outside on the sidewalk (truly, a first world problem).  Another long time passed as we waited to get change back, as it's cash only here.  New Orleans, of course, is not known for its punctuality, but when a meal is finished and it's time to settle up, but even the least punctual New Orleanian wants to squirm with an empty coffee cup while a line of hungry people glowers.  

This all sounds harsh, but consider it counterpoint to the obvious and sustained popularity of Slim Goodies.  The large menu offers a lot of choices beyond just a plain omelette or eggs and toast.  Go, but try to pick a less busy time.

I love the ambiance of the Rathskeller. The building is beautiful, and the place settings are elegant. I have been many times because my parents are big fans, and every now and then a friend suggests it.

I like the starter pretzels with hot mustard. I like their jagerschnitzel. I like their beer. I guess I like everything, but I just don't *love* it. It is not something that I crave or visit on my own account. I just don't find German food all that exciting, but I will eat here if it is the chosen place without complaint.

The best part of the experience is the hot mustard. When eaten, it somehow manages to shoot straight up your nose and into your brain :)

This place is fine for post drinking grub - I think it might rank as a two star place should you eat here sober.  However, I have been slightly intoxicated every time I've dined here, and the food managed to hit the spot each time.

We came for devour downtown to Barcelona Tapas! It was $35 for two people and we got 6 tapas to share. It was such a great deal and you won't leave hungry.

For the majority of the courses, you could choose from serval tapas, but for one of the courses there was only one option. We were more than okay with that because it was a fan favorite, goat cheese in marinara sauce.

One word... Phenomenal!!!

You haven't tried this place you HAVE TO!! 

Great sandwich, great chick parm, great meatballs and sauce! 

Top it all off with an espresso & Canoli.

After some of the glowing reviews, I decided to get this place a whirl.  To begin, their guacamole was pretty good, and the homemade chips complimented it fairly well.  However, the two entrees (fajitas and flautas) were disappointing.  Both entrees lacked flavor and portion size.  I may try this place again, and if warranted, adjust my reading accordingly.
I thought it was good. The sauce was fantastic. But I got pepperoni on it, if there was 8 pcs I would be surprised. I would go back.
I really enjoy coming here for lunch. The food is always real good and the place is clean and the staff is very nice. There lunch specials are fantastic

Wow what a disappointment! I don't know what happened to this place but it's definitely gone downhill. 

Just came back from a dinner with friends and probably had the worst pizza I've ever had in my life!  We ordered a Margarita pizza, the first one was totally burnt. I understand that with a wood-burning oven there can be a little Char, but this was far beyond a little char-- it was black & burnt over most of the pizza. 

The waiter must have known it was a Turd because he just dropped it and ran.  Of course, we had no plans to eat it and immediately requested a replacement.   Sadly, the second pizza that came out wasn't much better and the quantity and quality of toppings were a joke.

My friends ordered one of the basic pizzas with cheese, sausage and mushrooms; perhaps the kitchen was short on ingredients because again there was hardly any toppings on this pizza. 

Let me be clear, I'm Italian, I'm not expecting the American Pizza loaded with toppings when I go to a place that boasts an Italian style pizza. I get what an Italian pizza is and THIS wasn't it.

The salad that we had, the featured special, was the only redeeming quality of the evening and that's what earned a 2 star review. 

Get it together Napolese-- I want to support my neighborhood eateries, but not if you're not going to offer a good product.

I love the idea of supporting a local neighborhood bar but with all the choices in SOBro MJ's needs to step it up.  The food is mostly average some things are good, but the service is consistently poor.  

I went there with a group of friends this past Saturday night after the SJofA French Market Festival--it was late and we were hankering for pizza.  The pizzas were good but the service was terrible.  We had to chase down the waitress for everything.  The patio was pretty deserted and it didn't look like the inside was all that busy either so I don't know why she was inattentive.  We ended up just doing  self service getting our own silverware, plates, napkins, peppers and parm, etc...

This is a tough call. The theming is there, but it seems to have worn off over time. Likely, when PF Changs first opened, the novelty of the theming was attractive to people. There are times when they have the most perfect broccoli, but other times it is overcooked. Recently, they added dessert shooters--cheap dessert "shots"--but these are fairly disappointing.

This review is based only on the apple dumpling. I had no idea what to expect. Upon eating this dumpling I found it to be the singular, best apple dessert that I have ever eaten, perhaps the greatest dessert ever. It's unbelievably perfect in every respect. I just lowered my stars to 4 since I had lunch. A sloppy joe. It wasn't bad but nothing great. I think I would come here just for the apple dumpling.

Food is good however, tonight was not a good night for us at this restaurant. I walked up to the hostess station and stated I had a party of 3. The first thing she said was do you have reservations? I said no and she proceeded to seat me at a table in the middle of the restaurant. However, there was an open booth right next to me so I asked if I could sit there and she said no it's reserved. My husband proceeds to walk in about 5 minutes after me and he over hears her asking a party of 4 if they have reservations and they state "no" and she proceeds to seat them at the booth I asked for, which is quite rude. Either the reservation cancelled or she outright lied. Either way the booth should have been offered to us. Shame on her for being so rude.

I've eaten here 6 times. There are enough reviews so I just want to say a few things about this place. 

I have never experienced this cuisine elevated to this level. It reminds me of what Rick Bayless did for Mexican food in Chicago. I have no doubt there will be chefs trying this in other cities soon. It's groundbreaking and deserves its accolades. 

A great restaurant is about consistency, service and attention to detail. I've had 6 excellent meals. I've seen lots of interesting menu changes and tried many of these. You can read reviews that talk about them specifically. I've never ordered a dish I didn't care for. 

A couple tips. My wife and I like to get 3/$15 from the center of the menu, 1 hummus and something from the left. You'll leave stuffed. We also like doing 5/$23 and getting a hummus. I've enjoyed the mazoh ball soup. 

I can't recommend BRG restaurants though and the ending to chef Shaya.

I have to echo comments regarding the value here.  There are hundreds of restaurants in this town where you can get a great meal and for a fraction of the price.  The portions are too small and the prices are too high.  I ordered the shrimp remoulade and the snapper over shrimp etouffee and rice.  There were 4 shrimp over a single fried green tomato and some frisee.  Why not 2 slices of tomato?  How much could this cost?  A 5th shrimp would have been nice too.  I loved the dressing, however, and even though I am not a fan of this particular green it was a delicious dish.  The food isn't haute cuisine where you get 8 very small courses of unbelievable food so show us some hospitality and feed us.

 I also ordered the snapper over about 2 tablespoons of shrimp étouffée and about the same amount of rice.  The plate pointed to how small the portion was.  The dish was nice, not seasoned very well, but the fish was fresh and although a little tough around the edges I enjoyed it.  I would go back if someone else was paying but otherwise would definitely pass given so many opportunities for a better meal.  

They gave us a Christmas Eve gift of a oven mitt and a bag of the biscuit mix that stated it needed to be refrigerated.  I didn't know that we were the only people in the restaurant that were traveling and couldn't accommodate it.  I guess it's the thought that counts.  Hmmmm.

I've eaten here for the lunch buffet several times and have never been disappointed.  There's always plenty of vegetarian options.  I've had better and worse.  They're consistent.  The tandoor chicken was not warm on the buffet and some fresh pakora would be nice.  The food is a little richer than I would prefer overall from dish to dish.  The spice level is good.  I like the view from the dining room.  The service is ok.  It's really 3.5 stars overall.

they have really good chips and salsa but i think a lot of people are fooled into thinking they have good food for some reason. Don't get me wrong. it's OK but I limit to visits to playa azul to paid lunches and per diems.

playa has exceptional salads, however. they use quality ingredients but I can't help to think I'm paying way too much for mexican food when there is so many better options for the same price points.

The service, the iced tea, and the fact you can eat al fresco is good, but overall I do not think the presentation and the food is anything to brag about for the price you pay

The Mildred is thisclose to being a 5-star neighbourhood establishment, but a few little missteps lead me to a 4-star assessment.

I had been to the previous restaurant in the space, and it was much cozier this time around, although I find the window next to our seat to be strange. It was a window to the entryway and it was slightly higher than our heads, and every time people were in the vestibule waiting we felt like we were in an aquarium.

However! Last-minute tables were to be had at 7:30 on a Friday evening, and people need to get on this band wagon. The food here is excellent. My BFF and I started with cocktails- she went with the cucumber elderflower and gin cocktail and I requested a gin sour. Hers was tasty, very much cucumber, and mine was good as well although slightly too tart. They were not lacking for gin, though, and when I got home after having two of them I was pretty drunk.

House-baked bread and butter came to the table pretty quickly, and it was good bread, but the butter was too cold and they never brought out more bread after we finished the first two pieces. The water sitch is my other beef: they offer sparkling or still from bottles they carry around, and the water was room temp. If there isn't ice, the water should at least be cold. It made me drink more cocktails, which was likely not a coincidence.

We decided to share everything, so we got the chicken and biscuits, the potato tortellini in a Madeira mushroom sauce, and the vertical roasted chicken, then two desserts to share. The chicken and biscuits is phenomenal and I'd come back over and over again just for that. Savory, warm, and comforting. The biscuits were a little twee, however. The highlight of the pasta was the mushrooms and sauce, but the pasta itself was very good even though it could have used maybe 30 seconds more cooking time. It was like an Italian version of a pierogie.The roasted chicken was insanely moist and tender and all the veggies with it were spot-on.

For dessert we shared the plum clafoutis and the chocolate peanut butter mousse thing. They were both decadent and heavenly. The plum clafoutis would make the world's greatest brunch dish, hot out of the oven with sweet whipped cream.

The total for 4 cocktails, 3 dishes, and 2 desserts was $120 including tip. Not bad at all! We could easily have saved $20 by getting one drink each, but it was a girl's night so who wants to do that? Service was great, the server was new but capable and friendly and didn't rush us out when we lingered over our last cocktails.

I hadn't been to the Khyber since it was still the Khyber, you know, that awesomely grungy and bare-bones music venue where everyone's friend's band played at one time or another.

The Khyber Pass Pub, however, is a delightful revamp of a space that probably wasn't pulling in enough revenue to support the costs on such a prime location. B and I met up with some fellow Yelpers for an excellent UYE. It was vegan-themed but B and I went for the awesome BBQ I'd been hearing about.

The draft list was impressive but I was disappointed by their lack of regular IPAs. There were Double IPAs and Imperial IPAs, but I had just come from the gym and wasn't feeling such a heavy beverage. I went with a Jack's Cider and it was perfect, nice and light and refreshing. Bottle list was limited.

For food I chose the 1/2 smoked chicken with debris fries and coleslaw on the side. For gluten-intolerant folks, be warned that the gravy is most likely thickened with flour since I'm not feeling well today, but I didn't ask because I wanted to eat them anyways. Didn't have any of the coleslaw since I can't eat cabbage either, but it looked better than the average. The chicken, however, was beyond delicious. I think I liked it better than Percy Street's, the smokiness had a better flavour somehow and wasn't as overpowering. I think it was the hickory? It went great with my BYO homemade BBQ sauce that I make sans onion and garlic. Yes, I brought a small tupperware of BBQ sauce to the restaurant. Don't judge me.

There was so much food I ended up bringing a whole chicken breast home. Atmosphere is very basic, service did an excellent job handling a large and ever-changing group, doling out separate checks without complaint and they even comped my second drink when it took a long time to arrive. I hadn't noticed because I was having a great time socializing, but I was pleased to get a free drink! Volume was super loud but that could have been because we had so many people in our group. Prices were incredibly reasonable - my enormous entree was only $18 and the ciders were like $5 I think. 

I'll definitely be back for those fries again, stomach troubles be damned.

Place is awesome, have been there three or four times and everything is trendy and excellent, very clean, staff is very attentive, food is very unique, try the Dr Pepper ribs, if you like meat you will not be disappointed.
They also have a great wine selection to go with what ever it if you would like to eat
It's a dive big time but it fits right in on the beach and if you want the best Grouper Sandwich around this is the place!
This is my new sushi option now , every thing we ordered was excellent and will definitely be back.

Out of all the casinos in Reno, I think Eldorado is the worst in terms of air quality. The casino level is full of smokers. It was really hard to not cough. I didn't like being in the casino so I left. I prefer Circus Circus and Silver Legacy over Eldorado

Not bad.  The service was pretty good... of course I haven't seen this place too busy (maybe I just go at the wrong times).  The food is pretty good too.... you can't go wrong with a smoked salmon blt.

Gosh...I wish it was good. The exterior looked so cute and promising. Ordered double tacos with chicken. Bit into it, and was immediately put off by unfresh, stale taste...with bland sauce. And the trash was SO full, just over filled. 
It is literally receiving additional star for the decor of actual bus Incorporated on the storefront.

Let me preface this by saying I'm of Cuban descent and recently moved to the area from south Florida ... excited to see a Cuban restaurant in the area so we stop in for lunch.  Aside from eating, we were looking for fresh mariquitas to take my mother-in-law in the panhandle. Since we hadn't seen it on their online menu, I ask the waitress (in Spanish)  if they have mariquitas ... she stares at me ... turns out Jennifer doesn't speak Spanish nor does the restaurant make plantain chips... *record scratch* I'm taken aback but decide to give it a shot anyway. 

I ordered the half Cuban sandwich with fried plantains and my husband had the half pork sandwich with black beans and rice. Surprisingly,  both had great taste, plantains seemed to be freshly fried and the pork was nicely seasoned. 

Although Jennifer didn't speak Spanish, she was very sweet, attentive and went out of her way to try to get us the mariquitas we were looking for (she came out with bags of Chifles mariquitas, which the kitchen uses ... not what we were looking for but they get points for at least using Chifles brand).

Desserts were ok.  On the Cuban side, they had flan and cheese flan (which I had - it was very yummy).  The other desserts (carrot cake, chocolate cake and a peanut butter and chocolate dessert, which my husband loved) aren't Cuban.  Seems although the restaurant owners are Cuban, none of the cooks are. 

I was a bit disappointed that their menu didn't include the variety I'm used to back in SoFla but we enjoyed what we ordered. I was also surprised that a loaf of Cuban bread goes for $9 - really really steep - that better be some dang good bread for n that price. 

Overall, are they what I expected from an authentic Cuban restaurant?  Not entirely. I'm used to a loud busy eatery with certain staples.  Would we return?  Sure, we'd like to sample other dishes. 

With regards to covid, the servers wore masks and tables seemed to be socially distanced.

Pretty cool bar just off of bourbon street.  They have a few different rooms such as their main bar (which was dead), the back patio (which was bumping with drunkards soaking up the sun), and your dimly lit piano bar which had two ladies bumping requested tunes.  

Do order their Hurricane here.  It will knock your socks off.
Don't order anything else besides that or beer.  I ordered an old-fashioned (wtf was I thinking?) and the bartender threw some crap together that reminded me of college.  He even used his bare hands to rip the orange meat off an orange slice just for the peel.  I just hoped he washed his hands ...

Anyways, the dueling pianos was a blast.  The crowd was mixed, including your bachelorette party, older seniors slamming down a few hurricanes, drunk frat boys pounding beers, and your standard 30's people like my wife and I.  However, everyone was having a super fun time which was awesome.

Bathrooms are really dingy but what do you expect?

4 stars!
Their pasta with pesto & shrimp was super scrumptious & satisfying. The bread was warm and with lots of butter was heavenly. Will definitely come back.

Basically i'll go here for cocktails and guac but food at lolita across the street is much better.  Its so don't forget the tequila but I thought the maragitas here were much better than el vez.  Actually probably one of my favorite maragitas I've had.  El vez average trendy bar rita.

I tend to treat this like the pubs I frequented when I visited England--a nice diversion on a weekend afternoon.  The drinks are well made, the draught choices are plentiful, and the decor has that Irish feel.  Yeah, it's really that "out-of-the-box-kit Irish feel" but whatever.
The food is decent, but nothing exceptional.  Think pub grub from somewhere that hasn't been pointedly noted as having great food.  Fair enough but it won't blow you away.
There's the occasional music--always free.  I believe there's even impromptu gatherings of musicians that occasional happen during the day.  Always fun to walk in on something like that.
Good place to enjoy a pint on the front patio where you can watch people go by.  Great place to grab a pint for that football match (English or American) as well.
Crowds can get a little more hectic in the evenings as it is close to campus.  
Service is ok, but highly dependent on how crowded the place is.  If it's crowded, just expect to get less attention.
See you there for the next Manchester United match with a pint of bitter!

The food here is tasty, but the service is a bit strange.  I arrived with a  group of 8.  Although the dining room was empty, we were seated in the bar at a small, low table.  It was very difficult to comfortably enjoy our food in that seating.

In our lifetimes, there have been many raging food debates; Goobers or Raisinets? Pizza Hut or Dominos? Cool Ranch or Nacho Cheese Doritos? (the correct answers are Goobers/Pizza Hut and Cool Ranch, by the way) And now we can add, "Chipotle or Pancheros" to that mighty list. Well, being well versed in both, and having been to both recently, I'm ready to make MY ruling: Pancheros by a nose.

While at the Moorestown mall yesterday, my GF was going on about how STARVING she was, and suggested a burrito. She wanted to head down the street a little to go to Pancheros, but on our way out, we walked right past Chipotle and I suggest we try there, since she had never been. She was game, and we were off. Let me preface this by saying that BOTH are EXTREMELY good, and you will NOT be disappointed in either burrito. But when both dishes are so evenly matched, it comes down to the details and that is where Chipotle falls behind. 

First thing I noticed (because the misses wanted queso dip) was the lack of said dip at Chipotle. You can only get chips and salsa or chips and guac. No queso was a bit disappointing. 

Secondly, Pancheros gets an extra point for making your tortilla right in front of you. Chipotles tortilla was just as fresh (tasting) but it was just cool to see the dough ball get flattened and turned into your tortilla right in front of you.

Finally, a little detail that actually makes a BIG difference is at Pancheros, after everything is added to your burrito, they mix it all up before wrapping. At Chipotle, they just scoop it on and wrap, which leads to your ingredients being in sections. There were many bites of my Chipotle burrito that were nothing but rice and other bites that had NO rice. 

Both places are made to order with fresh, tasty ingredients but if you are ever in the fantastic position of being able to choose between the two, I say hit Pancheros.

Hmmmm. As a CONCEPT, Top Golf is 5 stars. It's like a driving range/arcade/bar/grill hybrid, that actually really works. It's like Augusta National had a threesome with Dave and Busters and PJ Whelihans. Its like a bowling alley, but with golf. Its a good idea. The execution however, leaves a little to be desired.

I'm not sure if they just haven't worked out the kinks at THIS location, but we went last night, and had an ok time. First, the place is beautiful; bright, clean, spacious. There were greeters at the door and a nice glass waterfall that you see in restaurants that are trying too hard. To the right is a HUGE bar. We are asked to check in and then led to a "bay" where we sit down and look things over. 

We are on the second level, and in front of us are multiple colored sarlac pits where you basically try to play darts with golf balls. Its visually very pleasing. And, they have clubs, so all you really need to bring to Top Golf is your wallet. NOW, full disclosure, our night was a little bit different because we were with an employee, but all that really affected was the price. 

The first thing I noticed that was off about Top Golf is the staggering, overarching presence of danger. This is a place that combines a game dominated by frat bro douches, gives them metal clubs, liquors them up and tells them to swing said clubs in mind bendingly close proximity to each other. Yeah, theres a red line that you're not supposed to cross, but the penalty for doing so might just be a fractured skull. And thats the danger on just one side of the mat; on the other, is a precarious drop if you happen to cross the YELLOW line, and fall off the ledge. (There ARE nets, BUT....) There are kids running around, rouge golf balls rolling down the corridors behind you....its just RIFE with potential for injury. The insurance premiums on this place must be ASTRONOMICAL.

Issue #2 is that its overly futuristic. Everything is controlled on your little ipad thing, which, predictably, was wonky throughout. It took about 25 minutes for the guy giving us the schpiel to get everything started. I started to wonder halfway through if this guy even worked there, as he didn't seem to know much about how any of this stuff worked, and the guy we were with that DID work there, said he had never seen this guy in his life. There was massive confusion about which "card" was supposed to be used, and theres a different card for that, and that card is not for that...etc, etc. (One of the cards in question is a membership card that you have to sign up for. $5). Cardgate sorted out, we couldn't get the tv to work correctly. Some channels weren't listed, sound didn't work. A literal third of the tv screen was for the Top Golf logo, incase you forgot where you were at any given moment. I was ignoring the tv anyway, because I came to Top Golf, but a few of the group wanted to see the Sixers game. It never came to fruition.

Issue #2A was with the scoring. The balls have microchips in them, so they know where they go and dole out points appropriately. Except when they don't. Multiple times someone would sink a shot, only to have the ball register a 0. Again, it wasn't like it was the Olympics, so I didn't care about the score, but it did kinda dampen the competitive vibe.

Issue #4 is more of a Top Golf issue, as in one THEY should be concerned about. All the food choices are messy ass finger foods. Now, that's to be expected in a bar/driving range mashup, but are they not concerned with greasy grips or just gunk and food laden clubs? I had a burger that had an over easy egg on it. I was COVERED in yolk by the time it was my turn to whack balls. I had to run to the bathroom and scrub down, but I could EASILY see some teenage slob just grab the club and let er rip, thereby covering the clubs in schmaltz for the next guy. Maybe they routinely wipe the clubs down or something. Eh. 

As far as gameplay, it was fun, but staggeringly easy. I'm not a terrible golfer, but I'm also not a chimp with a stick, so it was barely a challenge to hit a target. I'm SURE its designed this way so that all skill levels can play, but it was actually hard to NOT hit some target. It got to a point where I didn't even aim, I just tried to hit it as far as I could, knowing that it was most likely going in anyway. We even played a chipping game where you had to aim, but again, the targets are so big if you get it in the right DIRECTION, you're most likely going to score. So, its definitely more for an "all-play," family, goof of time, than actual skill or practice. I'm sure there is some game mode that is actually pretty hard though, I just didn't experience it last night. 

Overall though, it was fun, and I'm sure I'll be back. I am a member now, after all. This would be a really good date spot, fellas.....

Pass the Baba ghanouj!

Went here recently and had a fantastic lunch of chicken schwerma and the aforementioned Baba ghanouj. My coworkers all got different dishes, with one literally getting a sampling of like 6 different bites. EVERYTHING got rave reviews. We left satisfied, and FULL.

This was my second time to Al-Sham. The first time I went, I noticed that the wait was a bit long for my chicken and rice platter. This time seemed to be a little bit quicker, but I was also in much less of a hurry. The staff were very nice and the price was fair. We have been planning a return trip, and when we do, I will definitely update my review.

We had a great dinner today at Stella in great part due to our server  Max. The table bread was delicious. We had the Spaghetti Pie and Gnocchi for appetizers and the salmon as our entree. All the food was tremendous. We sat inside in a booth which was comfortable. Unfortunately Our drinks were so so. Don't expect a heavy pour here.

After hearing so many good things about this brunch spot, my girlfriends and I finally got the chance to check it out. We got there around 11am and the wait was about 15 minutes. It's very packed inside. We ordered shrimp & grit benedict, red velvet pancake, kitchen sink and creme brulee french toast. The shrimp & grit benedict and red velvet pancake were my favorite. The pancakes were moist and not too sweet. The kid version was big enough for one adult. The only pitfall is that you can only get the kid version if you order a regular size dish. But it's a good option for a group to share. 

Cannot wait to go back there to eat more delicious food!

Came Easter Monday for breakfast - veggie omelet for me, Farmers omelet for breakfast-mate.  Still great portion w optional side of potatoes, tomatoes, fruit or multigrain toast. Housemade ketchup is not overly sweet.  Always a great breakfast.   

Suggestion:   Would make huevos rancheros an everyday breakfast.   People who work miss out on Highlevel's interpretation as it is served Min to Fri and does not include holiday Mon or fri either.

Times on this site and their own website incorrect.  Opens 1030 mon to fri
930 amSaturday 
930am Sunday.

Wanted to post an update as we came back to Byrd and barrel for lunch with coworkers a couple weeks back.  It wasn't nearly as busy as my last visit during dinner which helped mitigate any chaos. I will say the staff were friendly, helpful and very in control this time vs last.

I had the mother clucker as I wanted to try something new and it was really very exceptional.  My colleagues tried the nuggets and the poutine and they were each very happy with their selections.  That being said, we will definitely be back again for lunch sometime soon!

I think over the years, Rigazzi's has gotten worse.  The food is sloppy, the decor is, of course, nothing to write home about.  It used to be the main attraction for me was the "fishbowls" of beer, but I've outgrown that.  I guess the main reason for visiting this place is because it's on The Hill and is sort of an "institution."  I think it's burned down a few times and I've always wondered if that was for the insurance? Who knows....who cares?

Went to dinner here with a large group of friends, as we were in town for a football game.  The space was pretty nice, and the location was great.  I started off with the baked oysters with garlic butter.  No butter, no garlic and bland.  The oysters didn't smell fresh either.  They were not good at all.  They barely put anything on them.  I've had some of the best baked oysters on the planet and these were awful.  I ordered a calzone with pit ham and mushrooms.   It looked great, and was good, with the exception it was made incorrectly without pit ham and had no ricotta cheese.  I was dining with a large group so I couldn't hold everyone else up for a remake.  The beer was ok, but I'm not a huge craft beer guy.  The server was nice but appeared to be inexperienced and overwhelmed.  The next time I visit Tampa I'll pass on TBBC.

Juan's Flying Burrito (Mid-City) is located in a busy section of N. Carrollton Avenue. This location is full of people (lunch at noon on Saturday), so we sat at the bar, instead of waiting for a table. I ordered the chicken enchiladas ($8.95), and my companion ordered the Flying Burrito (beef, chicken, and shrimp) enchiladas ($10.95). Both meals came with Mexican rice and black beans. We both agreed that the food was good, and we would return. Check it out! RJT
Food was ok. But the place was filthy. I was disturbed by how dirty the place is. Ever hear of a vacuum?

I'm glad I tried Fette Sau, as I've heard several good things about it, but I don't think I'll seek this place out again. 

For a place as popular as this, I was a little irked by how inefficient the ordering process was. From what I could see, there was only one person cutting/weighing the meats so the line moved very slowly. They also ran out of some cuts of meats very early in the night - they were already out of the pork belly, shrimp, and a couple other things at 7 PM on a Saturday. 

As for the food, it was hit or miss. The beef rib was tender, melt-in-your-mouth amazing (although very fatty). The short ribs were decent, I've had better and I've had worse. I was a little disappointed by the selection of sauces though. Because the meats are smoked, you add your own sauce, but there was only 1 sweet, 1 spicy (this one had a weird aftertaste), and vinegar available as options. I definitely expected a few more sauces. 

For sides, I also sampled the mac and cheese (deliciously creamy), sweet potato (forgettable), collard greens (just okay - wish they cut the pieces smaller). The burnt end beans were good, but overly salty. 

I will say it's a cool atmosphere, especially the outdoor patio area, and in a good location right next to Frankford Hall. 

I do also want to mention that I could not believe how expensive my meal was for the amount of food I ordered. I got one large portion of the burnt end baked beans, one beef rib, and two of the regular ribs... and the total came out to $27. I was shocked. Definitely be prepared to drop some $$$.

Service was the star of the show here and unfortunately the food took the backseat. I came for the first time for Indy taco week. I thought it was such a great deal, $5 for tacos. Since you only got 2/per order we each ordered tacos but also a starter. I left full but underwhelmed. The yuca fries were good and I suggest the aioli but I was not a fan of the egg rolls. The tacos were also very skimpy on the filling and the taste just wasn't there for anyone in our group. Also I thought the drinks were pricey for what they were. I paid $8 and didn't think it tasted all that great. Service was good though, they were attentive but I wouldn't recommend as a place to go back to. Even with the $5 taco deal I somehow spent $25 per person and it was not a $25 meal

I've been here a few times and each time it gets less appealing. It's quite disappointing, I wanted to really like this place! The first time, I got the Italian sandwich, which was piled high and delicious. I was convinced I'd go again, and the second time returned and got an Italian sandwich and a cup of soup. It was severely lacking the same taste as the first time (which happened to be opening weekend) and the soup was incredibly watery and under seasoned. I had convinced myself that it was just a fluke, with how good the first one had been. Returned and got a different sandwich (vegetarian), took a handful of bites and decided that I wouldn't be back. Some bites were warm, some were cold, and some were a mix of both. There are so many other sandwich places in Indy, and all of them are a much better choice.

I use to love Chubby's but as of 2/15/17 they have changed. Cheesesteaks are now more money if you sit down compared to ordering to go. NO MORE FREE REFILLS on soda or juices. NO MORE FREE REFILLS on pickles, hot peppers, or sweet peppers. You have to ask for them and they will give you one container full. In addition, you now have to ask for a key to use the restroom; which could be a little disgusting as to hold a key when everyone doesn't wash their hands. Ewwwwww. Not really sure if I'll be back as I was a frequent customer on Thursday nights. May have to visit Mama's on Belmont Ave.

Sometimes this papa johns location can be the worst. They tell you 15 mins and you get there after 15 mins and they tell you another 15 mins.. really??? Can I get some free wings, bread sticks and sticky buns? WTH?

3.5 stars actually. Food is delicious, but service can sometimes be slow. Drink specials are A+, and the bartenders are always nice even when busy.

WiFi doesn't work here though, don't even bother giving them your social media info to log on cause you'll just get kicked right off three time in a row before asking the host what's up and watching him chuckle and him tell you their WiFi is horrible. For a place that does a lot of lunch business with the local workforce, that's disappointing enough to dock a half star in my book.
Over priced and they lost the personal feel. They became to much of a franchise. Had back to back bad experiences there this year. Please has gone down hill.

Being a true Southerner I have had the pleasure of enjoying lots of really good fried chicken in my life. Willie Mae's greatly exceeded my expectations. I can't say it's the best fried chicken I've ever had but I honestly don't remember having any that was better. Their red beans and rice was really good too, as was the fried okra and freshly squeezed lemonade. Bread pudding was amazing. Service was wonderful, both friendly and attentive.

I'm really glad Renata's is in the neighborhood. They offer indoor and outdoor seating, have good service, the food is great, and always presented nicely. Today I ordered an iced coffee and a short stack of lemon poppyseed pancakes. The coffee was served in a mason jar with sugar coating the rim, and the pancakes came with ricotta and lemon poppyseed topping. Next time I would order the ricotta on the side, because they also spread it between the pancakes and it was A LOT. 

Today I was seated immediately, but whenever I walk by Renata's on the weekend there's usually a line. I'd suggest the earlier the better. It's a great place to eat, right off the 34 trolley, and a short walk to Clark Park. Not a bad way to star the morning!

I came here very excited to try out Branzino. As soon as I walked in, it was a very nice quiet place with an interesting menu. The restaurant had a great ambiance. Reserved a table for 4 on a friday night at 8:30 and were seated immediately. The problem was that we were placed in the corner and none of the staff I guess really saw us. Had a glass of wine and were waiting to order. When our waiter finally got to us it was already 20 mins into our night. He tells us the specials and one of us decided to order the pork chop special. About 10 minutes later he comes back to tell us that the pork chop has been changed to veal. So my friend asked for the menu again (ultimately he decides to go along with it). It takes him another 15 mins to bring out bread. And another 20 to get out the appetizers. And around another 30 minutes for the entrees.

Food: 3/5
Calamari Stufato- Found it to be drowned in sauce, barely any calamari, didn't notice a single golden raisin in it
Roasted shrimp- Came with 3 large prawns which were great, the oyster mushroom was I little overcooked

Capesante: The cauliflower was cold, and the scallops were inconsistent. I found 2 of the scallops burnt and did not bother mentioning to the restaurant considering it would be another 30 minute wait. The others had a nice color to them but as soon as you bite into them, you can tell that the scallops had been sitting in the window for quite some time.

The food definitely could have been better, tiny portions were given, and not enough balance in their dishes.

Service:  2/5
I thought the service was abysmal and I wanted to not leave a tip but I caved and still gave the restaurant more than they deserved. 

Atmosphere: 5/5
Great lighting, love the decorations and how everything is set in the restaurant. 

I was really looking forward to Branzino since I have heard great things but they definitely fell far from expectations. Would I dine here again? Probably not, and I would not recommend this restaurant to anyone. The atmosphere can only get you so far. If I was in the restaurant right now, I'd get up and go across the street for Italian cuisine or walk a couple blocks and find somewhere else.

I enjoy Holy Hog.  I do not eat BBQ often, but sometimes I just get a hankering.  Cue Holy Hog.

I do enjoy the sides a bit more at Holy Hog than the meats.  The jalapeno mac n' cheese is ridiculously good.  The meat I had last time (brisket) was a bit dry.  I like the BBQ sauces that they offer, especially the sweeter sauce.

I appreciate the ordering system (counter style).  I also appreciate the craft beer selection - beer and BBQ is a pretty good combo!

All in all, I like Holy Hog - not my favorite, but when I need some delicious mac n' cheese it is a great go to.

We made a reservation for 7pm and arrived promptly at 7. We were told our table wasn't ready and would be in about 15 minutes. I was annoyed but understood that it would be ready soon. By 7:30, there was still no sign of our table. I inquired and they said they had overbooked and didn't have a table for us now. Meanwhile we weren't the only table waiting to be seated and were squished in the entry way, dodging all the takeout customers picking up. By 7:40, I went up to check again. They said another minute and it would be ready. I proceeded to ask what the point was for having a reservation if we had to wait 40 minutes. Time I'll never get back. We were fuming at this point! 

Once seated, we were offered appetizers on the house which was a great gesture because our night was off to a terrible start here. We opted for the calamari and the tasting board.
