The calamari seemed previously frozen and fried really quick and the portion was small. Wouldn't order that again. The tasting board was delicious with a nice mix of cheeses, spreads and toppings. The bread they bring to the table is really delicious. 

Main orders for our table included: the fish special of the night, mahi mahi with mashed potatoes and asparagus, the chicken parm, lemon and pepper linguine, and the Torino sandwich with fries. 

The fish was good but I didn't like the mashed potatoes as they were really bland. The asparagus was way too thick. The fish portion was a bit small and I didn't like the dark meat on the fish. The lemon and pepper linguine was very good and flavorful. The chicken parm was also good but we've had better. The sandwich was enjoyed. 

We got tiramisu for dessert which was pretty good. Overall, the food was decent. I've had better Italian but everyone mostly enjoyed what they got. We had a great waitress. However, we ate so late due to having to wait over 40 mins for our table. It definitely but a damper on our night and a bad impression on our entire party as this was our first time here. Plus it took an eternity to get our check and for them to collect it again. I can't say we will be back.

Awesome beer selection. I hit up the Foodery whenever I want to try some new beers. A little pricey, but that's what one should expect when purchasing singled-out microbrews. Another big plus is that the Foodery has baller sandwiches. The Diablo (buffalo chicken, jack cheese, avocado, green peppers, and chipotle mayo) is awesome. I definitely recommend the Foodery if you're looking to try out some new brands/types of beer. Glad this place exists and is so close to my house!

CHEERS!

Since I'm waiting for Costco to open, I decided to try a Latte.. I am not a crepe person, so I just got a plain Latte.

Smooth, tasty, and less than the other main coffee places!

Next time I'll bring the hubby!

My mother and I went for our "Girl's Night Out". The restaurant was almost completely empty at 6pm, but the menu looked promising, so we decided to order. My green tea (iced) was quite good and the appetizers of Edamame and Rice Balls were tasty, although the rice balls fell apart after a few minutes (I had hoped to take one for lunch the next day, but no luck). My mother got Udon and I got Ramen- both were inedible due to their saltiness. I got the Ramen with pork, but the pork was horribly overcooked and flavorless. My Mother's Udon came with Shrimp Tempura that smelled like it had gone bad- neither of us were able to eat more than a bite or two. When we told our waitress about the food, she apologized but did nothing to remedy the situation. Nothing was removed from our bill and the cooks/owners (all of whom were there) said nothing to us as we paid and left. We will not be back.

Tried their charbroiled oysters, acme special po boy sandwich, acme medley special and pecan cobbler. Pecan cobbler was delicious. Long lines if you want a table so I recommend sitting at the bar for faster service.

Was very busy when we were here today for lunch. We had to wait a good 15-20 minutes to place our order.  There were 7 of us together including 3 kids. I ordered the chicken Caesar salad with no dressing. I honestly hate dressing on my salads because it always comes smothered in it.  Well, apparently that is not possible.  I know I should have complained, but it was so crowded and the line was so long, I just accepted it. But it was smothered. Yuck. I only ate the chicken and a little of the lettuce.
Meh. I've eaten here a few times and each time has been progressively worse. The only thing I like about the place at this point is the fries.

Been here many times, always a good time.  Close ride, open late on friday and saturday nights and they take credit cards.  
Good quality cheesesteak, hand cut fries and an ok bottled beer selection to boot.
One of my favorite night time spots.

Have stopped in here a few times now and actually pleasantly surprised how I've enjoyed my meals here. I usually go for the hamburgers and they've been all quite good. Inside you will find lots of tables and TV's and the place tends to be on the louder side. Service has always been good and we can easily bring the kids here. We like to stop in here for dinner before seeing a show.

The short story is that the food and drinks here were excellent, but unfortunately on our visit, the overall experience was marred by poor service. Because the manager proactively came to me during dinner and promised to "make it right", which he did with the bill, I'm still giving it 4 stars. 

My wife and I came here after a matinee show at the theater and this was also a slightly early Valentine's celebration since our visit was the weekend before Valentines. Everything started off wonderful and our waiter even gave my wife a gluten free menu once we told him she was GF. We also asked for his recommendation on drinks and he recommended the Berries & Bubbles cocktail. I would highly recommend this cocktail-great drink and a fantastic presentation! My wife ordered the Crisp Wedge of Iceberg as an appetizer, which came out pretty quickly and was delicious! Then it started to go downhill....

About 45 minutes or so go by and we noticed that we still hadn't received our entrees yet people around us who were seated after us were starting to get theirs. Then a food runner comes out to us to deliver us a second Crisp Wedge of Iceberg salad. We were like, thanks, but we've already had ours. At that point, I thought oh boy, I bet they haven't even started our entrees yet. It was close to another 30 mins before our steaks came out and my side but not hers. My filet was to have the Maytag Blue Cheese Crust, which is clearly did not. So back to the kitchen it went and I was just left with my side of Black Truffle Mac & Cheese. As I didn't want it to get cold, I proceeded to eat that. Unfortunately, I finished my side before my filet came back and my wife's side never came out until AFTER she finished her steak. While the food was excellent, we would have liked to have eaten our entrees together along with our sides. This was around the point the manager came over and apologized and offered to "make it right". We both ordered dessert. I had the Baked Alaska, which was HUGE but good. My wife just had sorbet, which was also a very large portion. 

I would return to give them another try as we did really enjoy the food and drinks. Hopefully the server would be much better. Something was going on that night as others around us were having some issues as well, but ours seemed to be the worst.

I had a really great time at Penang! I got the curry noodle and they were very tasty, I think the spice level was just right and not too much. Portion sizes are fair and enough.  Service was good and I will definitely return soon!
We went in for drinks and karaoke.  They were completely out of tequila which is crazy.. we ordered 3 vodka drinks and the total was $32 before tip. Way over priced for Tito's vodka.

Food: 4/5 stars
Service: 2/5 stars
Overall Score: 3/5 stars

I had my first experience with Triumph Grill on NYE at 6:30 pm for dinner. I had a reservation and my bf and I were seated quickly upon arriving. The place wasn't busy at all, yet in the dining area where we were seated there were three other tables of diners, and only one waitress. She was stretched but was definitely eager in helping the other tables ahead of ours. We waited for some time to be greeted, but she did stop while passing by to say that she would be right with us. After a while longer, she came back and took our drink orders. After having received our drinks for a few minutes, she passed our table and asked "how is everything?" That's strange in that "everything" was literally just cocktails. We understood that she was wrapping things up with two of the other tables (giving checks and such) so we let it go. 

After a while longer, she came back to take our food orders. I ordered the cajun shrimp pasta and the boo ordered a sirloin with NO ONIONS. She wrote it down and rushed off. A different staff member brought our dishes, and what was there sitting on top of the boo's steak? FRIED ONIONS. We weren't impressed at all. After a few minutes, our waitress came back with an almost exact replica of his steak, saying "you were brought the wrong steak. this is your steak," and swapped it out. Mind you, THE ONIONS WERE STILL THERE! He stopped her and expressed his concern about the steak. She INTERRUPTED him saying "that's just for decoration, there are other onions that weren't put on your steak." WTF?! No apology, blaming decoration, and interrupting with an irritated tone of voice. No bueno.

After she ran off, the table of two sitting close to us asked us if our food was cold? We replied that it wasn't cold. They told us that their soups and entrees were served to them cold. I explained that we were not impressed with our service so far, and they stated that they've had good experiences here in the past which is why they decided to come here for NYE but that their experience this evening was awful. When the waitress returned to their table, I heard the women complain about the temperature of their food. The waitress INTERRUPTED them saying "we have a cold kitchen. We don't have a hot kitchen." ARE YOU SERIOUS RIGHT NOW?! Like really?! I've never heard of a restaurant give that excuse for why the food is coming out cold! Never. Ever.

Although my pasta was good, I've received the same quality for about $8-$10 less elsewhere. The boo thought his steak was okay and finished it. I should also mention that I had the Paris Manhattan cocktail, and it was good. Our bill for two entrees and two cocktails came to $77. I inquired if the two chocolate desserts (cake and flourless torte) came with ice cream, and was told "i can add ice cream for an additional charge." I passed. I wasn't in the mood to be served by that woman any longer that night, or to give this restaurant any more of my time or money for the evening, so we left, somewhat disatissfied and turned off. 

Based on this experience, I probably won't return here, as it was nothing really to write home about. Cool ambiance (dim lighting), cool motorcycle museums (from looking through closed glass doors), interesting selection of music although a bit out of place with the atmosphere of the restaurant ("Baby Got Back" was played among other random assortment of 80s/90s pop and hip-hop music), but not enough to overcome average/decent food and terrible service.

The food is excellent! But the long wait is what has kept me from coming back. Don't get me wrong, the food is worth the hour-long wait (and yes it really was an hour during lunch time on a Friday), but who has time for that? It would be great if the restaurant dining area was larger to accomodate the large amount of guests. I think this would shorten the length of time it takes to get inside the restaurant.

Visited: Saturday - Dec 20, 2014 - 10:30 AM

I ordered the western crepe, fresh fruit, and black coffee.

Good, good, and good

Service, good.

We good?

Good!

Sunday - April 28, 2013 - 10:30 AM

I'm an evolving carnivore.  Non-meat options are gradually finding their way into my diet.  I've always enjoyed fruits and vegetables but, meat has always been a staple.

 I've heard mainly positive remarks and the promise of a Sunny Sunday prompted this suburbanite to venture into the city. HipCityVeg is a small store within a minute walk from Rittenhouse Square.

I was immediately greeted by a cheerful 20 something that eagerly described some of the customer favorites.  She recommended the $9.00 Udon Noodle Salad (Chinese black bean dressing, sprouts, arugula, carrots, cabbage, daikon, peanuts, & spicy glazed "chick'n").  My eyes transfixed to an oddly written drink - The $4.50 Groothie (green smoothie with organic apples, organic leafy greens, bananas, & seasonal fruit).  I ordered same.

The Udon Noodle Salad was very good but, was suspicious of the so-called chick'n.  Why?  It tasted like grilled chicken but, in fact, is soy and organic grains cooked on a hot stove.  The Groothie was refreshing and flavorful.  

I won't wait for another Sunny Sunday to enjoy HipCityVeg.

After over a good year of living in Fishtown, or going there pretty often, i FINALLY stopped in Sulimay's. I love it's local vibe, you can tell this place has been around forever and has faithful clientele. It's cozy and has a real "home" feel to it. The staff is superbly nice and attentive. We got an entire pitcher of coffee to ourselves, our food came out pretty fast, the food was pretty darn cheap. 

And it breaks my heart to say this, because I hyped Sulimay's up so much to myself, and they really seem like sweet people who work here and made us feel right at home, but I just wasn't crazy about the food. I can scarf down an entire plate of eggs, homefries and toast no problem even if I end up feeling sick after (i love love LOVE breakfast food), but I just couldn't even eat half of it. The eggs were spongy, the feta in my omelette tasted off, and the potatoes were nothing to write home about and were on the cold side. 

The service was so nice though that I still enjoyed it. We had a waitress and a woman who may be the owner came by several times and was sweet as pie. Also, apparently their pancakes are made to order, so I think I will come back some time to try something else on their menu. I'm always one for second chances.

I usually like to visit Zea when I'm in whatever city. This one was located in a mall. I ordered grilled chicken breast it was dry and cold, the corn grits were ok and so was the broccoli. The best thing was the spinach salad. Can't say I will be back... it's way better options in NOLA

Excellent brunch. Cool looking restaurant. Kind of a southern, rustic thing going on. I have enjoyed all of our meals every time we've been here. Apple fritters are delicious and a huge serving. Definitely share those around your table. The baked eggs are excellent. So many different flavors and textures and my eggs were cooked perfectly. The southern style Benny- deliciousness on top of a sweet cornbread waffle. Had the chance to try their new enchilada dish on our last visit. YUM. So many flavors...I love flavors!

Service is always excellent. Definitely get there early if you can, Sunday brunch starts filling up fast about 11:30AM.

Love the location and the covered outdoor seating. Great place to eat and watch all of the activity going by. Food is okay. The hubby loves it more than I do. Parking can be hard to find sometimes, depending on what time/day you get here.

Empanada - beef filling is tasty and well seasoned. Pastry is not greasy and fried perfectly. Pork tamale - it was alright, a little dry and I had to use a lot of hot sauce for flavor. Beans and rice are good. Well seasoned and not bland. I think they make their tortilla chips in house? That's pretty cool. Huge burritos! And their hot sauces are okay.

Service is consistently good and food is alright. A nice place to meet up with friends or to grab a quick bite.

Had higher expectations. Been here a few times now. Dinner a couple of times, food was not memorable and service was ok. Think I've had the French dip and pulled pork sandwiches. More recently, I came in for lunch. Seated pretty quickly. Our server was ok. Not friendly and didn't look like she wanted to be there. Food took a long time to arrive. I ordered the crab bisque and a side of sweet potato fries. Bisque was lukewarm and did not taste good. Sweet potato fries were soggy and not hot. Server error or kitchen? Not sure, but lunch was not good. 

This place seems like it's always packed though. Great location? Maybe they have awesome happy hour/drink specials? It is a nice restaurant with lots of seating. The bar area looks nice and there are tons of TVs around to watch games on.

Was not blown away by the Thai food we ordered. Maybe the sushi is good, but we didn't order any rolls. The chicken wings were ok, kinda bland. The pad woon sen with tofu I had as my entree was ok. I've never ordered this before from any Thai restaurants so I don't have anything to compare it too. The pad Thai my sister ordered was too sweet though, for my taste and what I'm used to. But this seems the norm for most of the pad thai dishes I've tried in the area.

Service was ok and the lady was nice enough. Not sure we will be back though, at least for the Thai. The sushi pics look good enough to warrant another visit maybe for sushi. It's located right off Park Blvd in a small strip mall so not hard to find.

Would have given another half star but alas, no halves allowed.  Simple menu with simple selections.  I opted for the vegetarian and was amazed at how quick it was made.  Thought the veggies tasted fresher than it's competition, you know..the place that Jared goes to.  The sub is 8" and comes with avocado, provolone, cucumber, lettuce and tomatoes.  Pretty tasty and cheerfully inexpensive.  After checking out the nutrition info online, realized it's not exactly healthy veggie sandwich at a whopping 673 calories, but most of that comes from the bread and mayo, glad I got very light mayo.  You can also get unwrapped which would be wrapped in lettuce but is same price either way.  

Will be back when I need the convenience of a place to get sandwhich on the go.

I wanted to go 4 stars here but I think a solid 3 or 3.5 stars is more appropriate.  

My Mom loves to order from here when she's down in the Reading Terminal Market.  In fact I think she might order from here every time she's in the neighborhood.  We were down in the city for the Philadelphia Flower Show, and no show is complete without a trip to the Reading Terminal Market.  We had some lunch at a different destination and then decided to get some to go from the Little Thai Market.

It's a small shop in the center somewhat typically with a long line as mentioned.  Here's my ten cents:

Salmon Curry - Tons of Salmon.  You definitely get a very large portion for $6.50.  As mentioned in other reviews it is heated up in the microwave, not the worst thing in the world but not great when I want fresh.  To their credit it is very fresh just in a reheated kind of way.  The curry sauce is thin and I wanted more of it to really give a punch of flavor.  The broccoli is totally crisp and fresh.

Chicken with Basil - Again, thin sauce and not as flavorful as I would like.  You get a ton of chicken and veggies over rice and its yummy.  

Chicken Coconut Soup - Now this is what I would come here for!  The chicken is plentiful with veggies and some mushrooms and then ladled over the protein and veggies comes the coconut broth with great depth of flavor.  Now this is  the soup dejour.

I would come back for the soup every time and the other dishes are okay, just don't have enough Thai kick for me.

No worries, I will be back on my next visit.

YES! Finally a place that has specials on FourSquare. Your first check-in per day gets you a free pint of any beer on tap except Golden Monkey. Came here on halloween and they had the kracken and some flavored O vodka on promo. Neat place, but not enough seatings for people. The courtyard is pretty cool to watch games on the jumbotron and hang out. 

I think I'll need to come back at some point for some food. Saw a few dining tables on the side.

I've tried this place a few more times. Not a fan of anything else- soup, noodles, etc. Their dumplings came out soggy and the dough was overcooked and mushy. They came in a plate that had tons of water in it still adding to the mushy factor. Their bun is good but the ratio of filling to dough is once again, and still sad. Tea eggs are a must. Their sriracha has been updated and nomore moldy bottles exist in the place.

Went in yesterday and had their bbq chik'n sandwich. It was pretty tiny for the price but definitely enjoyable. they skimped a bit on the bbq sauce but no harm, no foul. My friend ordered their portobello mushroom hoagie. The owner came around to ask us how it was. He said he always enjoys this place but gave constructive criticism that there wasn't a lot of portobello slices. The owner continued to say that its supposed to have 5 strips and she'll let the back know. When the sandwich was closed, you could barely see the ingredients in it at all. His sandwich was mostly bread.  5 SKINNY strips clearly isn't enough. They should focus on how to make it filling and tasty rather than simply counting the pieces. she walked away without any real care it appeared. A dinged star for that. otherwise, i love their new menu and am so happy for their vegan options in tucson! the rest of the experience was enjoyable and tasty.

Top 5 Steak in Reno!  The Ribeye is just plain amazing.  I am typically not a ribeye kinda person but I gotta hand it to them on this steak.  Appetizers are yummy as well as the salads.  You can go upstairs to the martini bar and enjoy a great martini or you can sample some Port with a cigar.  They have a cigar stand across from the upstairs entrance to the martini bar.  I strongly suggest this restaurant to anyone that wants a great steak or a killer martini...Or BOTH!

My wife and I went to check out Freddy's to see how it compared the the other recent  (and not so recent) burger additions to Tucson. With Five Guys, Culver's, In-N-Out in the neighborhood it seems like it would be a tough market. 

The setting is a little softer than the others. Lower lighting, and an atmosphere that seemed to encourage sitting a little longer. We ordered our food, got our drinks and sat down. My wife was up getting condiments when our number was called and I was answering a phone call with our food on the table when an older gentleman (my guess is early eighties) walked up to our table and asked how the fries were and proceeded to grab a handfull from my wife's basket.  I was almost too stunned to respond and my wife walked up just then and asked him what he was doing. He just walked off like nothing had happened. I am taking notes on what kinds of things I can get away with once i get a little older - my daughters tell me it isn't that far away.

Anyway... I admit the fries do look tasty, and actually were pretty good. They are the shoestring type and were done just right. The steakburgers were good, though I prefer a juicier, thicker burger. The buns were very nice. We will give this another try. I want to try their cheese steak next time.

I didn't try the custard to that will have to wait for the next trip also.

One of the better dine-in non-corporate Italian restaurants in the city, and certainly the better of the two Pizza Perfects.  I personally enjoy the calzones, but the pizza is great.

Most of the items, especially the pastas, are pretty traditional, and there is a screened-in dining area out front that isn't bad.  Pizza Perfect is basically a locally owned, classier and tastier Fazoli's.  Most items are really cheesy, but I like it that way.  Prices are moderate, but your wait time can sometimes get a little lengthy in the evenings.  Nevertheless, the staff is quick and friendly, and this is as good a place as any on 21st to grab a quick but tasty dinner.

This is a lively little joint.  Lipstick Lounge is renowned for the crazy karaoke performances that go down there--some of these people are genuine karaoke stars.  It's a pretty cool (relatively small) bar, and while it's billed as a lesbian hot spot, they welcome people of all sorts. 

Lipstick Lounge tends to get extremely busy on the weekends, and they often charge a cover.  I'm not really a fan of places that make you pay just to show up, but the vibe is pretty good and the dancing is a blast.  As Liz H. mentioned, they have free pool upstairs, so I suppose that makes up for having to pay a cover.

With all the lovely little neighborhood bars on the East Side, you may wonder what is so unique about Lipstick Lounge.  Well, I can't think of anywhere else in my neck of the woods with karaoke, and it's kind of one of those party-centric bars where everyone's always having a good time.  Drink selection is average at typical prices, and the staff is very nice.  Worth checking out.

To start this, I should be clear.  I came here to the little jazz room, and had no food.  
That being said, it was a solid 4 store establishment.  They gave my friend and I a table and were pretty quick to serve us drinks.  They had some nice jazz playing.  
The ambiance was great - the drinks a little pricey, but given the nice music and fancier establishment - I didn't think it was overpriced.

Sadly the awesome service by both bartender and table server, great food and drink as well as delicious desserts couldn't overcome our massive disappointment in our tiny table that was literally on top of another set of diners.  The restaurant wasn't full, yet the hostesses insisted on seating the other couple right on top of us.  The tables were so close...how close were they?  So close that I didn't get up to use the restroom as I was afraid I'd knock over their wine.  We heard every word of their intimate discussion and honestly were embarrassed we did.  Enjoy the food photos as we'll never take any again!  I refuse to spend that much and be that uncomfortable again.  Ironically when they initially sat us I specifically said "please tell me no one is sitting there (pointing to the very close table next to us) anytime soon!"  No less than five minutes later they sat them.  The couple also complained about the close proximity but to no avail.  Considering the restaurant's size, you would think they could make diners more comfortable.  Left a very poor taste in our mouths to say the least!

I'm a byo-aholic, and went here to celebrate a friend's engagement. It is located on South Street, but don't let that scare you as South Street has a reality check on Broad Street, so you're safe from Flash mobs, and cheesy tshirt stores and Duck Tours.

Pumpkin is a big name in that neighborhood, with a Cafe and a to-go store all in Grad-ho.

The space is small, but this cute spot is great for a special occasion. To be honest, none of the food really stood out or was very memorable, but the cozy, candle lit atomsphere was very comfortable and would tempt me to come back.

Been here only twice, which is sad since I lived a block away from this restaurant for two years.

Went for dinner and lunch, and there was a definite business crowd for lunch and a dressier crowd for dinner. Food is amazing, but parking is tight. Great selection for a special occasion, or birthday dinner.

Please just refrain from the "Halloween" jokes as there was a mob hit in the bar area in the 90's...

Open on holidays, friendly workers, good/large portion food items all make this spot a nice place on Magazine Street.

FYI breakfast menu ends at 2pm. Shoestring fries are on the flimsier side but they're still good.

Lemon meringue tart is a bit dense but delicious.

This place is the worst. The design of the building is atrocious, you're like a rat in their ridiculous maze. It's like a damn theme park - once you're in you gotta walk all the way through the entire thing. Coming to the store for one item in particular? Forget it, put on your walking shoes because you're going to see every bit of merchandise they have in stock while you walk 2 miles to the never ending lines at the very end (which takes another 20 minutes). The worst part is every single worker I stopped to ask for help was rude and made it seem like I was totally bothering them. I guess I'd be mad too if I had to dress like that and work here.

Service was decent and our drinks were fine and that's where it ended. The food is right out of your grocers microwave dinner section. It was the stuff of nightmares. It's a shame that a decent chain is turned to this crap. Avoid at all costs.

The food was good, but the place is really overpriced.  It's decorated in a way that really doesn't do it for me, and seems to really be catered towards your mom and dad's type of crowd.  I was there for lunch, and even the lunch offerings are pricey.  $12 sandwiches?  Come on!   But the burger was good and the fries were good too, but their prices are just ridiculous.  You do get a good amount of food though.  

If you're having a lunch meeting in the burbs and it's on expense account, go for it.  That's right, it seems much more of a business meeting lunch place than a place for young people to get some grub and brew.

Used the new click thru seating. Arrived ten minutes ahead of the scheduled time. TOTALLY USELESS. Arrived to find we would still have a half hour wait. All it appears to be is marketing ploy to get your personal information. So now we stand here in a restaurant that twenty minutes ago had no wait according to their website, waiting with two young kids and no place to sit or stand out of the way waiting for a table that has no shorter wait than others waling in the door behind us. Worthless.
After we were seated and ordered, I was told the special I oredered (prime rib and lobster tail) was no longer being offered and would be $5 additional. Waitress could not offer any explanantion as to what changed between the time I ordered and when she came back to inform us.Not Happy at all with this visit. Got the New England clam chowder as my choice for the other side. It would jave been excellent if it didn't have so much pepper in it. Also got the cheese fries appetizer but there wasn't enough bacon on it.

I have been to the Broadripple location a few times but this is the first time I visited the Carmel location. The interior is huge and absolutely gorgeous. The Christmas decorations were clean and stylish. I can't  tell you how many people I saw taking pictures outside the shop. It is absolutely lovely. But I was disappointed. We had lunch and I ordered the half and half - a chicken croissant sandwich and the lemon Caesar salad.
The chicken croissant was fine although a bit overloaded with mayonaise and I did enjoy the grapes in it,  but it was small and the caesar salad was disappointing.  I did not see an anchovy and the salad dressing was bland and there was no lemon it in.  For $18, i expected a lot more. The lavender hot tea was also sad. I was surprised to find the top of the tea covered in lavender leaves that I apparently was supposed to eat. One of the people in our party only wanted cake and she was finally given a cake menu after we had all ordered and received lunch. We had to wave a waitress down to get her cake so she was not just sitting there drinking her tea which she wanted with the cake. (Tea was finished before she received the cake.)
 Earl's Chocolate Court Cake was rich and delicious. However, $14 for a piece of cake is pretty rich. If I return, it would definitely be for the baked goods - I would not bother with the food.
Nice little family own shop but to tell you the truth the sandwiches were just OK.  I think it is a bit overrated.

Food here is ok but the service is terrible. In my opinion, if you want to charge $22 for a bowl of pasta, the ambience and service provided to customers should match that premium. This place falls significantly short. Not really sure where the hype comes from because after 1 visit I can't justify coming back

I really like the idea of the restaurant... Feels like  a big warehouse with food and drink being served informally. Great for groups and definitely a cool addition to the other bars/restaurants in northern libs. 

The food is only ok, I had the following: ribs, brisket, pickles, Mac and cheese, and beans. Eh, nothing really stood out to me.

Wokworks is only okay in my book. I've come here twice and got two different combinations and found both to be mediocre. Growing up with authentic and delicious asian food, maybe I'm biased and prefer the more traditional dishes. 

Anyhow, to enhance the dining experience, Wokworks should really consider  using different take out plates/bowls, instead of the doggy box they currently use. the doggy boxes are really difficult to eat out of.

We have been to Edleys at this location many times but probably will never return. We ordered our usual 2 pork sandwiches & a basket of fries. We were very disappointed at the small amount of pulled pork on our sandwiches - to the point that it was such a thin sandwich you couldn't taste much other than the bread. The pulled pork that was actually present on the sandwich was cold and dry. The "double" portion of fries that we always split was about half of what we usually receive. There are TONS of BBQ restaurants in Nashville so we won't be returning to this one that disappointed us in all these listed areas - not to mention, the prices had increased!

A super solid Mexican option in downtown Tampa. The tortilla chips are homemade which is always a SUPER plus. They have a nice crunch and, the salsa is on point with just enough cilantro and lemon in it. The house margaritas were also pretty good and taste like they were handmade without the store bought mix overwhelming the flavor. We ordered Tacos and Enchiladas, my tacos were very good. The shrimp tacos might have been my favorite followed by the carnitas and chicken. Great flavor, nice use of queso fresco, red onions, and sauce. One complaint is that my homemade tortillas were falling apart and could not hold the flavor overload. Maybe a double corn tortilla would to the trick? Great visit, will be back.

Reviews are spot on for Chuy's. So glad we gave it a try. The best part for us was the jalapeño and cilantro margarita's. They were outstanding. Fresh and not near as sweet as regular margaritas. But they are pricey...$9 a pop. That price will keep us from coming regularly for a drink. The food is also very good. Fresh, well prepared and plated nicer than most mexican restaurants. It is worth the prices. We have already recommended to friends and will come again when the budget allows.

Another WaWa with all the custom-made sandwiches, pre-made food items, huge coffee and soda bars....as well as really cheap gasoline.  This morning regular with $3.39, lowest on the North side of Tampa.   Location is convenient in and out on the corner of Fowler and 30th St/Bruce B. Downs.

Deservedly busy at the pumps.

Have eaten there several times since it opened.  Delighted to support a local restaurant now earning national acclaim, and surprisingly on N. Nebraska Avenue, which had a rep for a rougher menu.   Lots of fine dishes, with constant rotation of menu.  Some basic variations keep repeating due to popularity, such as poutine (Montreal-style frites/fries with gravy/sauce and curds/cheese).  

 As noted by others, portions are modest and prices are above average....but reasonable considering the creativity and focus on using fresh, seasonal, local-origin ingredients.   The choices of beers/wines also invite experimentation.   Dining space is limited, as is the  parking, but since seating is also limited, there is less competition for parking.

Finally got to try one of the few delis in the area, a chain at that.   Perhaps not the best in town or comparable to NYC or Miami Beach, but they offer a nice menu of Jewish deli standards.   Tried the pastrami and corned beef sandwiches, matozoh ball and dill tomato soups.  Excellent soups and nice meats, if not as generously stacked as other delis.  Atmosphere, service and prices were good. Would be glad to try more some other time.

A very spiffy, upscale mostly-sushi place we would normally not go to, but they nicely sent us a $10 coupon that allowed us to have drinks, edame, avacado egg rolls, and dim  less than $25   All were very good and particularly enjoyed the lemon-butter with red pepper sauce on the edame.

The setting is very modern/sleek in a building identical to the neighboring Tejas de Brazil.  Prices are a bit high but many real deals on drinks and apps during their long happy hours and weekends......and even better with coupons.

I remember and enjoyed the prior location on N. Dale Mabry, and have tried this one near USF a few times.   On most visits it seemed clean, orderly and "slicker" than most Asian restaurants, particularly the "Mom & Pop" standard-menu  storefront operations.  Since I like Viet food, my comparison dishes are pho and spring rolls. Both are very good here, and you get plenty of garnishes/sauces, including Thai basic, nuoc mam, hoisin & Sriracha.   Egg rolls are also fine as well as bun sandwiches and prices.   Noted several reviewer comments on cleanliness, so I will be more alert in future, but know that all restaurants get written up by inspectors....it it their job.  But repeated "critical" violations and yuck-factor failings like visible insects cause me to look elsewhere.

Still need to sample some other Viet restaurants recommended by Yelpers, but Pho Quyen will be used as a comparison benchmark.

Another local favorite we finally visited.  We also love Bella's for Italian food, but now regard Bellini's as comparable.  And it is among the classiest interiors in any restaurant in Tampa....with high ceilings/windows, elegant furnishings and art, an open bar with linear kitchen and huge ceramic pizza oven and a  secluded nook upstairs for more romantic dining. 

We took advantage of the extended happy hour special prices, with $2 martinis and half-price entrees.  Best duck with non-sweet cherry sauce I can ever recall having and we both enjoyed a fine eggplant/cheese app.  My wife liked and shared the fresh grouper with pistashios. We passed on desserts but they looked great. 

Service was highly professional and high-class without snootiness.  Also learned that the same owners also run Green Iguana and the new Chophouse at the entrance of Centro Ybor.  Based on the quality here, the Chophouse has now been added to our list of destination eateries.

This review is by a vegetarian.

There are three vegetarian options:  a couple of pastas and an eggplant dish.  I got the eggplant.  It isn't exactly what I'd call "eggplant parmagiana" -- it's more akin to a stuffed eggplant, stuffed with ricotta cheese.  It was okay.  The eggplant wasn't crispy, as I would have imagined, and there wasn't sufficent sauce to balance the richness of the ricotta.  I would not order it again, despite that it came highly, highly recommended by one of the wait-staff, who proclaimed that the eggplant was the best dish on the menu, meat or vegetarian.  (If that's true, there is a problem).  The simple side of pasta that came with the eggplant, however, was quite nice.

The garlic bread that came with the meal was meh-ish.  The house salad, also simple, was good and not over-dressed.

Service was outstanding.  I came on the later-side, and opted to sit in the lounge area instead of the dining room.  Both are very nice; the lounge is a bit more casual.  The server did an outstanding job of tending to all patrons, maintaining a fantastically positive attitude overall, and being just plain friendly.

I'd go back (in theory), but if I did, I wouldn't get the same thing.  I get the sense that Reno is not a culinary town, and so decent places may be lauded as brilliant when compared to the local competition.  Back in the Bay Area, I wouldn't give this place a second look.

It's a Joe's crab shack... As far as I can tell they're all the same. 

They do have some fun specials. Food and drink are practically free during $2 Tuesday
The wild boar was just regular pork (wild boar should have a pleasant chew to it). Everyone else's food looked like it was what they ordered though.

Had ate a few in the shop. They were great. My brother had a glazed didn't mention anything about it. I bought a couple for my son and roommate. Tore it open and seen it was still raw. Disappointed to say the least.

Okay....the food is good.  It's not spectacular.  Also, charging +$14 for something like Chicken Tiki Marsala.....well.....

Okay, if it was more than rice, chicken, and sauce I would be okay.  It is good food.  It isn't as great of an up-sell constantly on the phone, please stop.  

I like it.  I like the place, food, and people.  I don't like being gouged because of location.   I'm seriously 1/2 and 1/2 on it because of the cost vs. the food price point.  It is tough for me to accept the $14+tip meal for CTM.

Food was mediocre. Was craving meat hummus- but realized there was only vegetarian. So I ordered the mushroom hummus. Everything tasted similar. The colors were an ugly shade of brown & black. 
The pita bread had no life and freshness either. I didn't even bother to try the salad. 

Most dishes come with a pita bread (whole wheat or white) + a salad.

The staff inside was friendly though- hence the one star. They had a little place to sit outdoors as well. The entire kitchen is visible from an outside window & the payment counter.

I surely will not be coming back.
Just an update: I did receive the $11.00 refund on my credit card. I still stand by my review though. There is a lot of room for improvement at this chain restaurant!

I stopped in around noon on a Tuesday and sat at the bar, seeing if anything changed since Otts sold it. The friendly bartender, Erica, greeted me with a smile. They had 2 IPA's on tap and I picked Flying Fish. It was an unbelievable $4 for a pint of this goodness. The lunch special was also a bargain, a Road House burger, 1/2 lb of beef, chili, cheese and 2 whopping onion rings. It was delicious and cooked perfectly. It came with soup or salad and fries. I picked buffalo wing soup which was packed with chicken, and got the fries burn. They were perfect. The bar patrons at the time appeared friendly too, which is why I sit at the bar.  I will be back.

We usually get China King if we are feeling like loading up on Chinese takeout, but over the years it's kind of gone downhill. We heard about this place and decided to give it a try. We ordered out on a Sunday around 8:15pm. An order of bourbon chicken combo, general Tso combo and an 8 piece order of crab rangoon. They told us it would be 15 minutes and we arrived about ten minutes after ordering and it was ready. 

I had never been in the area before, it looks a little rundown. The restaurant didn't have any customers in it when I entered to get the to go order. They have a LOT of handwritten signs that tell the different rules of the restaurant that doesn't make it feel very welcoming. The total for our meal was $21.33. We came home and busted it open. The bourbon chicken is a non breaded chicken, it had somewhat of a sweet/spicy sauce on it. It didn't taste like bourbon. The chicken was good though. The general Tso's had a LOT of sauce on it. The chicken in the bottom was covered, soaking in it. Maybe next time we will ask for the sauce on the side. 

The crab rangoon wasn't good. It was hard to bite into the wonton and the filling tasted like runny cream cheese. I wouldn't recommend getting them. The peas in the rice were a little on the firm side. I think that must be a Chinese restaurant issue around here though.

Who would've know that a little market would have such a great restaurant inside?! We were in the area & found this place on Yelp! because of the great reviews. You enter the market & make your way to the right of the store. That is where you'll find a little alcove with the restaurant. The hostess stand is the same as the register area, so if there's someone being rung up, just wait behind them to be seated.

The dining area isn't that big, I'd say they have about 14 tables maybe. The menu is very straight forward, even if you're not familiar with the cuisine. Each item has an actual picture, not a stock photo from some website. They've also got pictures of the entrees on the wall around the restaurant. Whoever did the photos did a good job too, they're great. They've also got letters & numbers to go with each item if you're not too sure of the pronunciation & don't wanna look like a fool lol. 

We ordered an order of spring rolls & crab wontons. It didn't take but 5 minutes for us to get them. The spring rolls were good, had a lot of fennel flavor in them. They had shrimp & pork and paired with peanut sauce. I think they were probably pre-made and refrigerated because they were quite chilled. The crab wontons were hot and full of cream cheese and crab, I really enjoyed them and the sweat and sour sauce. The sweet and sour sauce has some heat to it, which I liked.   

I've got a bad habit of ordering pad Thai at a new place, I'm not sure if its because I'm trying to be safe or maybe because it's how I compare it to other places. Maybe both. My boyfriend and I decided that we'd each get a different dish and then split them so we could try each others. We got the pad Thai with chicken ($6.50) and we were going to order the Dry Sukiyaki (stir fry vermicelli noodle w/ Napa cabbage, celery, eggs, shrimp, beef, cilantro, green onions and house sauce $7.50) but our server said that we shouldn't get it. Well he didn't say that we shouldn't get it but he said that it was an acquired taste and if we hadn't had it before then we probably shouldn't order it. I like when servers give feedback about dishes, but I don't like when you feel like you cannot make a selection because the server thinks you won't like it. We ordered the pad Malaysian, as a suggestion from our server. 

I wonder if it has to do with the message at the bottom on the menu that says "Also know your entree before ordering and will not be refunded after it is placed. Please communicate with your server." Next time I will order the dry sukiyaki. Our food didn't take but about 15 minutes for it to arrive to the table. Both dishes looked great and I was looking forward to trying both.

The pad thai was good, it tasted like a lot that I've had around town before. Our server didn't ask how hot I wanted it, so I take it that it was cooked normal, probably without much heat. The noodles weren't gummy which is good. It had a LOT of onions on it, I'd probably prefer a little less onion. On the pad Malaysian (stir fry flat thick rice noodle in spicy house sauce, eggs, Chinese sausages, spouts, w/ choice of chicken, beef or pork, $8) I really enjoyed the noodles and the little sausage pieces in it. The sausage reminded me of breakfast sausage. If I had to chose between the two, I'd pick the pad Malaysian.

Overall I was really impressed with the little restaurants food. The unassuming location has a real gem inside. The staff working here is friendly and attentive. FYI they keep the checks up front so when you're ready to leave just head up to the cashier.

Best pizza in town. Try the Chile Verde pizza or the el diablo fuego.
This are the best, the only reason why they don't get a 5th star is because they charge you for little things like delivery, extra crushed peppers and ranch.
The pizza is well with it.

The experience was okay.... But I will start off with the fact that we had a table of 14 due to a birthday. But I saw the waiter literally twice once for drinks and once for my food order. I ran out of my water the first 20 mins I was there and then 20 mins later I had to ask someone else to refill my cup. My plate was fairly good I had the tacos al pastor I won't complain about my tacos the guacamole was awful, and the retried beans were awful. The chips were fresh and the salsa tasted like it was held in a plastic container for a long time. That pretty much sums it up for my review and my experience there. I probably won't ever go back, oh and on weds they have a live band playing I don't know what time it starts but it ends @10 I believe so make sure u get there before 7 if u want a table.

Barely  OK.  The food is sub par, not much flavor, portions are small, salads are chewy, not fresh over dressed.  The gyro meat was chunky, usually sliced, and was a small portion. Nothing included a la carte, thus is the last time  we visit.  Parking is inconvenient, staff doesn't care.

Food is OK, prices are cheap.  

THE SERVICE IS TERRIBLE, makes you lose your appetite.

Rick's continues to frustrate. 2 stars due to repeated service/timing issues. Great setting on the water and the decor at Christmas is beautiful. The food is almost always very good. On the other hand, I am not sure how many more times I can take the poor service or slow kitchen. Went Friday night after the rush. Things started well with drinks and salad received promptly. Then the evening took a bad turn. Nearly an hour later we had not received our entrees. A very passive manager delivered the food, without much of an apology or explanation. To his credit, he did substantially reduce the tab - but it was not about the money. The good feeling of the evening was ruined and we didn't even feel like eating by the time the food arrived. I don't know why it took so long to cook scallops and the fish special, but this type of delay has happened to me several times. I usually forget about the bad experience after a few months and am lured back - only to experience it again. Don't get me wrong - I have had several very good experiences with both the food and service. However the success rate seems to be running at 50% for me. I really want this place to succeed because there are so few good alternatives in the area. I'll have to let the memory fade until the deck re-opens in the Spring.

We have dined in and picked up from Altamura.  I'll tell you our dine in experience first. 

7 o'clock reservation on a Thursday night, because neither of us felt like cooking.  So we find ourselves promptly and politely seated immediately.  Nice break from the weekday grind.  Our appetizers and salad courses came quick.  In fact, my salad came so quick, I asked the waiter to bring it back in 5 minutes while we finished our apps.  So finish the first two courses by 7:20 pm.  1 hour later, no entrees.  Me and Shari V are catching up and carrying on, but now we are getting hungry.  So I ask the waitress to check on the food.  She says it'll be one minute.  Great.  Who can complain about 60 seconds.  20 minutes later, I ask the waitress to get the manager.  I ask the manager about our entrees.  She explains that they are catering a party upstairs (as if that matters to me) and that our entrees should be out in 15 minutes.  I told them to forget it and bring us the bill.  A restaurant can screw up in all kinds of ways - bad food, rude waitstaff, mix up an order.  But wasting our time is the cardinal sin.  2 hours later, $60 spent, and we left Altamura hungry.  I was bummed.  Shari V was furious.

I convinced Shari V to retry Altamura for pickup.  She was skeptical but agreed if she didn't have anything to do with the process.  I reordered the Spiedini Mozzarella which is like a delicious gourmet cheese stick.  Fired gooey cheese seasoned with capers. Our entrees were the spaghetti & meatballs for Shari V and the King Crab pasta for me.  I thought both pasta dishes were ok, 3/5.  I liked them but didn't love either.  Shari V's spaghetti was bland (she says lacked depth).  The king crab pasta was overcooked big time.  Made for a soggy dish.  

Hard to be objective with Altamura, but I'd give them a 3/5 for food, and a 2/5 for service.  We were so put out with our in-house dining experience.  We will not be repeating.

Shari V's quote:  "Don't bother reviewing them.  Altamura won't be around next year."

We came in a cold cold day. There were about 3 other tables occupied. It was our first time there and didn't know how their system was. We kinda stood there for a few seconds when we walked in. We walked to the counter and the menu was off to the side on a chalkboard. There weren't many options. I got my usual two eggs and potatoes with a side of bacon. When I can't decide, it's my go to. My friend ordered pull pork. That was my second choice. We picked a table and waited. The same guy who took out order brought out our coffees. Shortly after, out food came out. It looked good. The portions aren't as big but at the end we didn't leave hungry so that's ok. I love potatoes. These did  not disappoint. It was crispy and not greasy. My friend enjoyed his dish. I had a taste and the flavors were good. I noticed they had a bunch of take out deliveries. Not a bad place for a quick bite.

I knew better. I was hungry. It was close. Counter was dirty. Rice was gone. They made new, soggy, gloppy rice that had a perfume flavor. Slop in a bowl. Queso was actually disgusting to even look at. Up early for antacid. #neveragain

Probably my favorite buffet in the downtown area. It can get crowded on the weekends, so bring your patience. I like to end my meal with gelato for dessert, and none of the other buffets offer this...

I have only tried their sushi and must say it's mediocre. I find $1 up charge for brown rice per roll of sushi highly overpriced. I'm used to paying 50cents maximum! $1 gets me 1/4 bag if brown rice!!!! 

Service has never been their strength. I go to this place only because there's nothing else healthy to eat nearby. 

But then again, it's not like Delaware is the foodie central.

For me it is all about the chicken livers with three types of gravy, cannot speak for anything else on the menu.  This sets me up nicely for a camping trip down the Natchez Trace.  All our visitors from overseas love to make a pit-stop here.  A little shopping for jellies and bacon and a little liver eating! Ah lurve the South.

Within walking distance to trivia night on Tuesday.  Usually pretty low key and the questions are quite hard.  Staff friendly, drinks terrible, weak as can be.  food, standard fried fodder.  Joined some gal pals last night after 9.00pm (Sat) and paid the $5 cover to hear karaoke.  Karaoke has gone to the dogs, no one is bad anymore, the true spirit is lost forever. Clearly full of regulars having a good time, nothing wrong with that.

The day after superbowl we stopped in to watch a soccer match.  We were the only people in there which allowed Pablo to have his match on every screen, and jump around and shout at his team.  Food was awful, the service was great.

Deep sigh... A-Ok for the alcohol, we were lured in by Anchor old Foghorn on Tap, it's been 10 years since it was in Nashville.  The Tap menu is certainly interesting as are the cocktails, I had the shochu/ginger/pineapple tonic which at happy hour prices was $5.  So small I got two sips and that was it, tasty but no VFM. The menu cocktails were up to $12.  Pab's Foghorm was $6.  The place feels like Tavern or one of those M street vibes except everyone is wearing deer hunter bandanas,  we edged in with edamame, soo over salted, shishito peppers, a massive portion but not as good as the other places in town, a little more sauce needed.  We then had some happy hour rice thing, deep fried with tuna on top, words fail me on this one - I could not eat it.  Why did we not have ramen or yakitori , well because gut instinct said no, the choices did not seem appealing.
All in all a little expensive, the vibe not for us, food mediocre.  Sure it brings something different to the east side and the place was packed.

This place is terrible. First the pizza is very greasy. Second, their delivery drivers are as lazy as they come and they aren't afraid to admit it. I live in a secure building and I ordered about 4 different times. Each time I gave the code to dial so I can let them into the building. Each time they call me saying they are at the back door and that I need to come out to get it because it's easier for them. I didn't realize the customer needed to make sure the driver is convinced.  Called each time to complain and the lady on the phone said it wouldn't happen again but it did each time. They don't really care about their customers. I would not order from this place unless you like terrible customer service and dripping greasy pizza.

After my visit this weekend I must say the reviews delivered. The woman that owns this place is terrible!! I called ahead on a friday afternoon,  she answered the phone,  Yes? I asked may I place an order she nonchalantly says,  no I'm actually not opening this weekend Ok and hangs up the phone lol. Me being the curious cat I am,  I call again next sunday. She answers the phone,  Debreaux's, I ask to place an order for the chicken platter, she says, Which part?? I say well what do you have( mind you I don't have a menu) instead of giving a suggestion. She says "you know what parts!" lol, I'm actually tickled by her attitude but any normal person would've ended the conversation for that reply. So I say I'll have wings with mac and cheese and greens. This was about 4:40pm. I arrive to her store at 5:30 to give her some time. It's about 6 hungry people waiting. I can tell by their expressions my food is most likely not ready. I approach the extremely high counter and tell her I've called ahead for the wing platter. She's says Ok it'll be a minute, wow it's only been an hour wth! After sitting inside the store with no tv or radio with the hungry crew for twenty mins I decide to wait in my car. At this point I wanted to drive off to any other restaurant on city av but again the curiosity n me says stay. Finally, about 6:45, 7pm!! Smh she comes from behind the counter and shows me my platter inside. I can't lie it looks amazing and the portions are cool. My wings were fried a tad too hard for me. The Mac and cheese was one of the best I've had in philly, very nice flavor. The greens were good also reminded me of my family down south cooking. However, later that night the greens gave me quite a trip to the restroom that night. I also came to the conclusion calling ahead means nothing. I believe she doesn't actually put the order in until u arrive due to prank callers. However, you'll still be waiting another hour or more! entirely too long. The owner is not friendly, no smiles, small talk and it appears she does everything alone, go figure...  

If your still interested, just go and place your order in person and have at least two hours to waste. And please don't expect the service to be good as your meal.

I also must add this place is a little over priced 16, 17 bucks just for four wings and two sides is a little steep. Not incl the bad atmosphere, attitude, sells NO beverages, and extremely long wait. The bare minimum you can do is be kind to people contributing to your business. Positivity goes a long way ;)

Mixed review here....
Hostesses: rude, unprofessional, condescending 
Waitress: very friendly, talkative, and friendly
Raw oysters: the best I've ever had!
I'll have to come back again to gave a better review. Maybe I'll just bypass the hostesses and head right to the bar in front of the excellent gentlemen opening up oysters non-stop.

In Tampa, my go to Korean restaurant will always be Sa Ri One. However, the 2nd best Korean restaurant in town and one that is not that far behind is this place. While Sa Ri One focuses just on Korean food, at Matoi, you can get sushi and various other Japanese dishes as well! How do you beat that proposition?? When I went this time, decided to go for a splurge and get both a sushi roll and a curry combo. I got the Matoi Roll, which was really delicious. I love the combination of the fried white fish on the inside and the raw salmon on top of the roll. It made for a fantastic contrast. The curry combo though...My goodness...I was not expecting such a huge portion! A full on katsu chicken with 2 shrimp tempura, a side salad, and a heaping portion of rice. The curry was nice and thick with a really nice kick of heat. I'm telling you, go in really hungry or on an empty stomach because this dish will leave you feeling absolutely stuffed! The chicken and shrimp were fried perfectly, nice and crispy on the outside while staying tender on the inside. The salad they give you is a good way to temper the heat of the curry if you start feeling overwhelmed by it. All in all, I'm glad I came back to this place after such a long time. It was a fantastic meal and reminded me that Sa Ri One best stay on their toes because this place is not far behind :)

It is unfortunate for a follow up review I have only give this place 2 stars. I understand that we are in a Pandemic. I understand that things may be a bit slower due to a mix of takeout orders and drive thru orders. But I think it is inexcusable to have to wait over an hour for your food when everything is pretty much deep fried. What happened to the fast in fast food?? I decided to swing by to try the new Chicken Sandwich that just came out. In terms of the sandwich itself, pretty solid. Chicken had a nice crispy crust. Inside was nice and moist. The addition of fresh jalapeños and the spicy sauce adds a good kick to really wake up your taste buds. 

But while the sandwich was solid, the service left me far from jolly. I truly think the terrible service I experienced that day was a lack of preparation and management. You go in and there was mass confusion as to who ordered what and what orders have been completed. No one was properly expediting orders or calling out what was needed. This combined with a huge backlog of takeout orders was completely sinking the restaurant that day. Word of advice, you really have to get more organized. If fast food is no longer "fast" and customers are waiting 45 minutes to an hour for their order, you just missed the point.

A Tampa standout in the local ramen scene, Ichicoro is expanding and that is great news for all Ramen lovers. Opening up in the Armature Works, think of this place as the lite version of Ichicoro. This place may be small but it was buzzing during Saturday around lunch time. Although this place is known for their ramen, don't pass up the rice bowls. Today, I decided to try out their Karaage Rice Bowl. Those tender prices of Japanese fried chicken, man, they blow all other types of fried chicken nuggets out of the water. Crispy but not greasy and flavorful but not overly salty, they provide such a good textural contrast to the rice it's sitting on. Top it off with some spicy mayo, fresh green onions, and house made pickled cucumbers and daikon radish, this is the perfect combination of flavors and textures. I just wish there was more seating and a shorter line. But you know what they say, if you want good food, follow the place with the longest line. Following your nose is a good alternative too haha

After seeing reviews of the newly opened Hainanese chicken rice restaurant on Yelp, I was excited to check out Cily Chicken Rice. 

I grew up eating Hainanese chicken rice, so I am going to be biased of course, and had high expectations going in. 

I am used to Hainanese chicken being poached in stock with ginger and scallions, which would make the chicken flavorful. Cily's boiled chicken tasted pretty bland. The sauces that were provided did compliment the chicken nicely though. I also liked that the chicken was served warm, unlike Penang's. 

The fried chicken, on the other hand was delicious. I would recommend this over the boiled chicken.

As for the chicken rice, it wasn't seasoned and could use more chicken fat. Our set for two also came with two bowls of broth, with generous pieces of radish in it, which I enjoyed.

I'll let you in on a little secret... Bayona's 23rd Anniversary, 3-course $23 lunch, with .23 there martini (gin, vodka, manhattan or lemon drop) is the best deal in town!  

The food & service is off-the-charts amazing anytime, but this deal is almost too good to be true. Start off with a Bayona salad, followed by your choice of four solid entrees and a bowl of ice cream, all for $23. Can't beat it!

Not what it used to be.  Mediocre food at quality food prices.  The heavenly hash is not bad, but very small serving for the price.  Fried chicken is alright, but doesn't hold a candle to Willie Mae's.  Mac & Cheese is so-so.  Drinks are good.  Service is okay.  I'd stop in for a drink, but skip the menu.

Rib Room hasn't been on my radar, but had the chance to dine here this evening with out-of-town friends who are staying at the Omni.  The dining room is classy, with white tablecloths, luxurious woodwork, etc.  We were seated promptly for our 7pm reservations.  The service was satisfactory, but nothing special, and not what you'd expect for fine dining in the French Quarter.  

We enjoyed some great wines and complimentary humus appetizers while perusing the menu.  Started with turtle soup, which was very good.  A few of the others had the gumbo, which they described as "bland", and in need of hot sauce.  The entrees were hit & miss, as well.  The filet of beef was perfect, but the sides were mediocre, at best.  Same with the catch of the day, fresh grouper.  

I wish I could tell you that the dessert was the high point of the meal, but sadly, not the case.  In fact, we all agreed that the bread pudding was perhaps the worst we'd had.  Very dry and... tough.  Seriously, how could bread pudding be tough?

Honestly, 3-stars, may be a bit generous, given the fact they they missed the mark in so many areas, especially at the menu pricing, which is on par with the finest restaurants in the Quarter

Okay people, I like your reviews and after stopping here myself I have to add WOW....AWEOSME DONUTS!!! But I will go one step further and say that what really made the trip worthwile was the fact that when I mentioned how fresh they were the counter lady showed off the window where I could watch them make the donuts. WOW, what an operation. I could not stop watching the assembly line and the glaze pouring over the fresh glazed donuts!!! I took a picture or two and will add them. Bring your kids here......they will thank you and get all bugged eyed like I did !!!!!!!

Great place to get Latin food in the area.

The Argentinian Empanadas are terrific - succulent seasoned beef, punctuated with olives and wrapped in a crispy yet chewy dough package. Enjoy with their spicy salsa verde.

The portions are huge and very reasonably priced. I love the Columbian styled bacon - a huge hunk of pork belly fried and made all crispy.
 
Will be back to try more items from the menu.

The best part is the customer service and genuine gratitude that is conveyed by this family run business.

Spread the word!!

Went for a weekend breakfast, which was a buffet and included:

- Made to order omelets from the kitchen
- Made to order pancakes and crepes from the kitchen
- Sausage
- Fried Plantains
- Huevos Rancheros
- Scrambled Eggs
- French Toasts
- Fresh fruit
- much more

And all this for just $6.95 !!

Best deal and great service.

Just meh.  Went for lunch yesterday with some friends.  Ordered apps and lunch and took advantage of the 2-4-1 sangrias. The appetizer (coconut shrimp)  came at the same time as our food.  When our food was delivered, I was asked if I wanted another sangria special.  I said yes...it was never received.  When she did finally come back to the table, my husband ordered a soda and she asked everyone except me if they needed another drink.  We at our food and I never did receive another drink. Not even a water.  Paid our bill and pretty much vowed to not eat there again. 

3 stars is because she didn't charge for the app (but never apologized that it came out with the food ) and the parking was free because we were eating lunch there.  Let's not even mention a lady throwing up in the restaurant and watching the multiple employees all ignore the throw up with nobody taking immediate action to clean it.

I am being hopeful by giving them 3 stars.  I ordered a philly cheesesteak (my husband asked why I would order one in Florida) LOL.  It wasn't the worse I've had.  Maybe like a regular corner store cheesesteak, not something you'd wait in line for.  It was dry and gristly(sp).  But ok, nonetheless.  The onion rings on the other hand were awesomeness!  I am always happy to get real onion rings.  The delvery guy was nice.  

That's all I got! next time I'll have the pizza.

I liked it.  The menu was nice, kind of chic.  It seems like a nice place for business or college students and somewhere in between.  We had a large family group that ranged in ages and there was something for everyone.  Service was nice and the food was good.

Made the mistake of returning. I've only met friendly people since moving to Tucson, but this establishment is successful at finding the least friendly staff. The door guys (especially the $ guy with the fan robbing me of my $3) went out of their way to remind me why I don't want to spend my money here--RUDE! Bartenders could give a crap. This is the WORST gay bar I've ever been to ( been out for 30 yrs and traveled the world) IBTs makes Council Blufffs, IA look like  the Castro. Owner/ management should be ashamed to represent our community...CLEAN YOUR BATHROOMS!!! On a positive note, the entertainment is really good....I just feel sorry for those talented performers.

Been here only once and not a huge fan so I've never been back. When we went, service was not great and the food was not that great. I actually don't even remember what I ordered which tells you how memorable it was! Others seem to enjoy it but it's not my cup of tea so it's not on my list of places I'd choose is trying to select a place to dine.

Well come here for lunch and didn't get what I ordered. Ordered a to go kids nugget meal with tots but when I get back to work I have 2 nuggets and tots. Disappointed because it's not what I ordered. And I tend to like the nuggets better.  And went inside instead of drive thru since it's typically faster however today was sooooo slow. Waited so long and they weren't that busy.  Still good and quality food just wasn't what I ordered.

We were  in the area for movie day and needed a lunch location in between movies. Found Racks on Yelp. Mixed reviews so I had to find out for myself. 

Walked right in no wait , no hostess just a very friendly server. Today was game day for football playoffs and they are ready with TVs everywhere including a very large screen. 

We ordered wings to start. The wing sauce was very good however I like my wings Cooked more. We also ordered several sandwiches. Cheese steaks and roast beef. Good sandwiches, good fries ok onion rings. Good spot to watch a game .

This is the only bbq restaurant in the area. They have a large craft beer selection that keeps us coming back. They have a newer menu and offer specials. It was a nice night so we decided to eat outside. The outside patio adds a lot to the restaurant. 

The server was fast but a little forgetful. We ordered the sausage wrapped in bacon with a whisky sauce. Not a favorite with the table. Ordered the ribeye special steak $. 36.00. Asked for medium rare. It came well done not a drop of pink to be found. What a waste of a good steak. Also order a rack of ribs. They were over cook too. 

Suggestion to the owner. The better bbq restaurants put their award winning sauces out on the table so you can apply some when the ribs are dry. Good thing they sell quality bear

Driving by noticed the sign saying buy one gift card at normal price buy a second for 1/2 price. Told the hostess I wanted$ 200 worth. Was told sorry they should have taken the sign down. Standing there holding $200 to spend I was told sorry and was not offered any options. We were planning to stay for dinner. We decided not to stay. You not only lose $ 200 in gift cards you list $100 dinner tab. Might be awhile before we return.

Love Thai food. Finding a Thai restaurant in pitman is a good surprise . It is a very small yet comfortable restaurant. Maybe they will grow into a larger space. There is no hostess you walk in an find a table. You will not wait long for a server to welcome you and offer you options like Thai tea or Thai coffee. We tried both and they were good.

Now it is Thai burger. You have to try the spicy Thai burger it is a very good burger cook the way you like it. However don't miss out on the soups or the curry dishes. 

Tonight we tried the pumpkin curry. It was spicy and good. Had to try the drunken noodles with pork. Again a very good dish. G ordered the Thai spicy burger med rare. Came cooked perfect. The chef should moonlight at the barnsboro on burger night and give them some burger

If you haven't been to Pitman in a while then you wouldn't know that Thai burger reopened today in what was Jim and Mikes. It still says Jim and Mikes above the door. The people are the same the food is the same. The wait tonight was long and they did warn us it would be an hour after we sat down. I suggest you bring a bottle of wine and order an appetizer as soon as you sit down. The was ad promised the dinner was worth the wait.

We had great expectations for Miel Patisserie.  Our hotel staff raved about the delicious pastries, hinted at the Le Bec Fin connection and urged us to go.  The exact words: "They will blow your mind!"

Well, we went...but our minds remain intact.

SERVICE: Service was slow, but once we got attention, the staff was patient in explaining the pastries.  It would have been very helpful to have prices and labels for the many pastries for decision making purposes.  The café ran out of ice for our Miel Iced Tea ($2), but the staff managed to convince us that we were, in fact, better off without ice because our tea would not get watered down

CROISSANT: We tried the Chocolate & Almond Croissant ($2.75), which was everything a sweet croissant should be.  Flakey and buttery with plenty of filling.  As a bonus, the croissant was enormous and easily shareable (unless you are a butter-holic...in which case, you should get your own).  Had we stuck to the croissants, this would have been a 4 star review

PASTRIES: Unfortunately, we could not resist the adorable pastries and scooped up a key lime square and a small cheesecake.  The key lime square was passable although otherwise unremarkable.  The little dome of cheesecake was adorable, but the crust lacked any distinction and there was a strange layer of gelatin coating on top of the cheesecake.  We concluded that this addition was meant to create a nice shine and uniform texture on top of the cheesecake, but it really subtracted from the texture

And now for the vilest transgression of all...

The MACARONS ($1.25 each) were incredibly stale.  After hearing the unusually low price, I opted to get one of each, but I should have known better.  These were practically inedible.  In fact, the chocolate was about the consistency of chewed gum and we threw it away after a single small nibble.  Robert Bennet must be incredibly disappointed in the low macaron standards of the new owners!  If you go, make sure to check if they were baked fresh that day!  Otherwise, skip the macarons and stick with the croissants!

PARTING THOUGHT: Rittenhouse Square is a great place to sit in the sunshine and enjoy your croissants.  There is ample bench seating and an endless parade of strutting puppies

I was worried that it'd be impossible to find a table here on Saturday at 9am, but we were able to stake our claim on a table inside within 10 minutes of arriving! Parking is easy and free on the weekend. 
I ordered the Sante Fe crepe and will definitely be getting the same thing next time I come. I was pleasantly surprised that all the crepe arrived at the same time for all 6 of our group--and it came out quickly! The Santa Fe crepe comes stuffed with chorizo, avocado, salsa, cheese, and is garnished with some tangy hot sauce and creamy goodness. I ate half and took home the other half because it was so filling--and it tasted even better when I reheated it/ate it later! As others have mentioned, it's a great place to people-watch, it's quiet enough to hold a conversation with people at our table, and makes delicious coffee and crepes.

I don't see why this place is highly rated. I really didn't like it.
I checked it out one day because it is close to where I live. 

The customer service wasn't very good. The clerk seemed rather anti-social and not very talkative. I had to tell him 2 times what I wanted to eat before he heard me.

I ordered the burger which had hickory sauce and onions. Without the hickory sauce the burger would have lacked any flavor what so ever. I think that is why they doused it in sauce. The texture of the patties also threw me off. The fries were nothing special either. All the food here is frozen and NOT fresh.

This place had some entertainment value They had some video poker machines and a few arcade games. However the jukebox only had southern mullet music on it. I am not really that big of a fan of The Doobie brothers, Molly Hatchet, or Ram Jam.

In short there are way better burger joints in town!

The beer selection here is legit. It almost feels like a bruincafe in Holland. Happy hour was really busy and they had some pretty decent deals. Our dinner was really good and the cheese plate was a wonderful value for everything you got.

Meh. 

The Greek salad was an extreme disappointment considering it was 6 + dollars. It was small but more importantly, really bad. It seemed to be a random assortment of pizza toppings thrown together. It was 80% spinach, 10% feta and the rest very small amounts of onion and literally 3 small pieces of warm iceberg lettuce. My advice, do not offer something on your menu if you're not going to do it right. The small Greek pizza was pretty good but the thin crust we ordered was actually quite doughy, which we both were surprised by. Honestly, I do not plan on going back.

Yum yum yum! 

This place is so delicious and caters to my vegetarian diet, which makes me super happy! 10/10 would recommend!

After having my first visit to a Chipotle in L.A. while visiting family, I was anxious to try this local store to see how it compared to the fresh flavors I found in first experience out west and subsequent visits to other stores around the country.  Not too much to say about the interior of this location, as like most fast food places, they stick to the formula, and it's pleasant.  Order taking was very prompt, and the food prep/delivery was lightning fast in spite of the fairly busy crowd.   I've tried several different dishes, but my favorite burrito is the barbacoa, which is braised and shredded beef shoulder flavored with fresh garlic, chipotle chili adobo, toasted cumin, fresh oregano, and S&P.

The food was good, but not as flavorful as what I found in L.A.  Still fresher and better than most any fast food place, though, so a good alternative when you want a quick meal.   

After followup visits to several Chipotle's in different cities around the country, I can't help comparing it to the ~10 Qdoba's I've eaten at from FL to NC and the midwest.   The formula is obviously the same, but I've found I prefer Qdoba's flavors.  I know Chipotle's commitment to organic and local ingredients, and their preference for meats raised without antibiotics or hormones.   So I always anticipate Chipotle should wow me with significantly better flavors, but inevitably, I still end up tilting to Qdoba for my preference.  The only thing I can attribute that preference to would be the seasonings they use, both which kind and freshness.   Add in that Qdoba has queso, and it's always been Qdoba for the win.

I'd still choose a Chipotle in a side-by-side choice with any burger joint, so they definitely succeed in that regard.

Sierra Gold is in my neighborhood. which means I can bike or take a long walk if needed to get home after Happy Hour or a late night!

They have a great Happy Hour $2.00 draifts, wine and well as well as a few items like spinach dip for $5.99.
