Breakfast is great here also.  The scrambler is great, I think it was $5.99 and I had really thick sourdough toast with it that was delicious.

About slipped on ice in parking lot..mentioned and young guy shrugged.. clean dining area.. very slow getting pizza to me and noone else here ... i got home and surprise no salad.. called restaurant was told they would remove the charge for the salad... charge still on card.  Next calling corporate

I gotta say, I was real skeptical when I first look at the menu for this place. The menu is diverse ranging from sushi to Italian to Tex Mex. No one speciality, so i questioned  if like most restaurants that has varied cuisine, would the dishes be average at best? But food was good! Been here twice  once with a large party of 9 and last time with my boyfriend . I would rate food and ambience a 4 but drinks a 3. The lure Does not take reservations unless you are a large party, a party of 9 or more I believe. Their tapas portion sizes are large compared to most tapas restaurants, but I'm not complaining!

The server who brought us our food told us my boyfriend and I ordered the three best things on the menu which were the fig and the pig flatbread, the Kenny and the Kevin small plates. I certainly agreee! My friends ordered some sushi and she said they were ok. I'm pretty particular about sushi so I wouldn't order sushi unless we are at a sushi restaurant. I've ordered the mojito and the margarita and I found them to be ok.  The Buddha was a lil too sweet/ syrupy for me. For  9/10 dollars a pop, they  should be better than average. I can tell that the bartenders aren't mixologist like at some restaurants where they are carefully measuring and pouring to exact amounts to make the perfect cocktail. With such an expanse cocktail menu I expected the drinks to be good.  

 Fig and the pig flatbread =5, amazing! Better than the one i had at On Swan in Hyde park. Perfect balance of sweet and savory. Has become my favorite flatbread combo.
Lava drops= 3.5-- my least favorite thing I've tried. I saw how yelpers were raving about these, but I should have known I wouldn't enjoy them due to cream cheese. I usually always stay clear of sushi with cream cheese. I think that when used, cream cheese is too heavy and overpower the fish and whole entire dish

 Joey meatballs= 4, good huge meatballs.I would prefer for the balls to be a lil smaller so that they  melt in your mouth buttery soft texture, but they were still pretty moist and the sauce was good too.

The Kenny scallops =5. Bronzed n  smoky yet not overcooked scallops on top of a sweet potatoe mash. If you like sweet potatoes you'll love the light cinnamon yet not too sweet taste of the mash.

The Kevin redfish is a 5. Red fish was fresh and blackened well without being too salty. The Gouda grits peppers and black eyed peas come together in a perfect bite. My boyfriend hates bell peppers and he even joked he liked them in this dish.

The pasta dish with mushrooms, sundried tomatoes, and olive oil based sauce =4. Light and simple. 

Ordered the gnocchi special with fried shrimp, pine nuts and sundried tomatoes which was a large portion and the gnocchi was good. I felt though, as we continue to finish the dish, the olive oil sauce made the dish too heavy and greasy. Id give it a 4 rating.

Well, I don't mean to be rude in any way. This place had a friendly server, fairly quick service, and lots of great outdoor seating if I'd wanted to sit there. I got a large jerk chicken platter, which was covered in a delicious, almost teriyaki-ish sauce and came with plantains (mmmmmm, plantains),

But in all honesty, I've become a regular customer at Gigi & Big R's, in University City or by 30th Street Station. If you've ever eaten there, you'll probably understand why I'm bringing them up. Their menu is very similar, but their meals are bigger, cheaper, and fall-off-the-bone tender. If you're on South Street and you have a craving for spicy food, Jamaican Jerk Hut will do - but I'd recommend you man up and take a walk to try the real deal.

I've been here several times and it is hit or miss. It is a good spot to grab a quick cup of coffee or enjoy the cozy loft seating on the second floor on a winter day or outside seating on a spring day but there are better options in the area. It's worth mentioning they also have a full bar with a well curated selection of beers and wines, although not the best ambience for a drink.

Pros: full menu (breakfast and lunch), serves alcohol, cool inside space w loft
Cons: pricey ($11-$14 sandwiches, $4.55 latte), food OK, charge extra for almond/soy milk, service can be slow, no wifi on weekends, upstairs gets really hot in the winter

As far as sushi is concerned... I've had better.

As far as tempura is concerned... I've had better.

As far as service... meh, they were friendly.

I had the bento box today for lunch - it came with a lot of food - tempura, two pieces of chicken katsu, six pieces of California rolls, mussels, and some rice (along with your standard miso soup and salad). 

The mussels were GROSS... they looked really old. The California rolls were your standard grocery store looking rolls and the chicken was a bit dry.

We also shared a KC roll... that's like your standard "white boy" roll - deep fried with tempura. They said it was spicy... but it wasn't at all. Oh well.

Can anyone recommend good sushi here in Boise???

As far as dive bars go, this is one of the bests especially in Manayunk (where dive bars are seriously lacking). It's a small corner place that could use more seats, but it's always fun. There are darts and games, good selection of craft beer, and a great menu. The food is delicious and far exceeds the environment it's served in. My friends and I have had soups and sandwiches, which were all good! 

They also have a lot of events with breweries and Di Bruno Bros. Classy ass place!

It gets one more star in the summer when you can sit outside.  This bar is smokey and the crowd can be trashy.  Personally I think the food is terrible, but they serve it late so sometimes it is convenient.  If you do go, go when it is warm out, but don't expect too much of a view, as the "patio" is basically a walkway between other stores.

I was underwhelmed by the donuts which may be due to the hype of this bakery.

I will admit they have some less common flavors (e.g. maple+bacon) than the typical Krispy Kreme however the quality was about the same and didn't give me the "wow" factor. The bakery closes early since Reading Terminal Market closes early. Having arrived during rush hour probably wasn't the smartest idea as tourists and locals alike wanted to grab something prior to closing--this was close to 5 pm on a Friday. The line extended around the corner and took about 10-15 minutes to finally reach the counter. All in all, it's worth visiting for your first time but debatable if you want to return.

Stopped in for take out.

The music was too loud to hear one of the order takers questions, each had to be repeated. But all in all the process went fine, in other words they did not leave anything out as they do each time in the Sparks store.

The food was kind of ok. Cole slaw was actually quite good as were their version of mashed potato. The chicken on the other hand was quite dry which is odd since I am sure it is fresh. The rolls were nice little hockey pucks.

The building is as others; clean and colourful. Parking is easy as getting in and out.

I have been planning on going here or some time now.

The reason being, I went to one in Las Vegas a few times driving through on the way to Phoenix. 

What really impressed me was the macaroni salad, it was amazing. So I was hoping to find the same here. I did not find the amazing taste here, it was very much ordinary, and that was disappointing. It was not bad, just eh.

I had planned on getting a meal for lunch. I had looked on line to see what is on offer. When I got there the meal I wanted was two dollars more than advertised on line. So I passed this time around.

This place was packed with folks eating and ordering.

The counter folks were friendly and quick, I will try it out further at some point in time.

The seafood grits are the truth, jumbo shrimp, lump crabmeat, lobster and 3 cheeses. The portion was just right. They serve breakfast all day long and they also offer a lunch menu. It's a little out of the way however it's worth the effort to find
No impress at all customer service good food delicious but slow to come and portions are very small
Well known for its burgers, but divey with spotty service.  A good place for a burger before or after a Ray's game.

Having been to many mojito bars in the South America, Miami & NYC metro area - this was a watered down version of the decent ones.

Here's the good: the decor is really cute, you can bring your dog in, they have a band playing and the Mojitos don't have too much mint, that way your not picking it out of your teeth the rest of the day.

The not so good: we ordered food and it was served on a tiny desert plate but cost a full meal's price. The band that plays there plays Jazz, yes I know it's New Orleans but this is a MOJITO bar! I would not return.

Went here with a friend on a whim. Wonderful, large portions... Not too expensive either. Three stars because American food isn't really my thing and I wasn't WOWED per say... but a good experience overall.
I love La Tolteca and the food is always great no matter which location. Convenient place within a shopping center. Staff is (mostly) friendly, but they could try harder.

This place is no different from any other Vietnamese restaurant I've been to. Everyone brags about how tasty the broth is compared to other. I don't taste the difference. Fact, I can taste more MSG and a little pricy compared to others. I walked out of that place extremely thirsty. Servicer are coherent. I asked for no onions and peanuts with my order. I brought it to their attention, they appologizes but, they didn't care to replace my order nor compensate me in anyway. Took a sip of my soup paid them plus 20% tip and walked out.   Not my favorite.

Dinner was $80 worth of disappointment.  Why disappointed?  Well, not much food for $80 not including tips.  Glad we had cash otherwise we had to pay $4 ATM fee (on top of the pricey food) like other reviews indicated.  Portion was small and food was nothing to WOW for.  Can go to other small (hole in the wall) places to eat with the same amount of food that satisfies our taste bud for a cheaper price.

CASH ONLY.....

Place consists of 5 tables that seat 3 in the front & approx. 9 tables that seat 4 in the back.

To make a long story short.  2 adults, 3 kids (15, 13, 11) sat at 2 different tables since they were packed.  We ordered only food and had water all around:
  - 2 cups gumbo ($10 total) [ 1 for ea table ]
  - 2 dozen charbroil oysters (~$32 total, but overcooked & dry, no dipping 
          cheese butter left for bread) [ 1 for ea table ]
  - hubby ordered 1 fish plate & 1 cheese fries
  - I ordered soft shell crab dinner (market price ~$16) 
         [Was told plate consist of 1 big crab, fries, & toast but crab was not so big].

You can give it a try to experience the high priced seafood that doesn't satisfies the taste bud.

3/20/2014

I'll start off by saying the store is decorated really nicely and has a beach vibe. 

The iced coffee on the other hand, I found was too expensive for what you get. I got a large iced vanilla latte with soy milk, which is what I usually get at Starbucks. I was almost going to get a medium here but I really like iced coffee and thought the medium was a little too small for me so I upgraded to a large. Well, my total for my one iced coffee was $7 and some change. 
Which is more than what I spend at Starbucks for a Venti iced vanilla latte w soy and the ventis are bigger than this stores larges. Ok, moving on from the price, they literally gave like one small scoop of ice which melted pretty quickly, my friend and I were going to ask for more ice but decided not to. The taste was mediocre at best, I prefer Starbucks or Frothy monkey. My friend and I also became quite sick from the coffee, not sure if there were 3 or 4 espresso shots in their large (I should have asked) but if there was 4 that would probably explain why we felt so sick and jittery after. 
All in all, the price wasn't worth the taste, the small scoop of ice or the effects that happened after we consumed the coffees. But this was just my experience, I'm sure other people will like their coffee, I just didn't.

This is a classic Jewish deli that appears to be family run.  I have been here twice and both times was satisfied but underwhelmed.  The portion sizes are very generous - consistent with a Jewish delicatessen - but on both occasions I ordered soup and on both occasions the soup was lukewarm. As a former New Yorker I am fond of Jewish delis and there are not too many of them that I have come across in the Philly area. Thus, Moish and Itzy's is definitely a good option if you have a hankering for some pickles and pastrami but if you are looking for a five star experience you may want to get yourself to the lower east side in NYC.
What a gem of a place in the francisville neighborhood! I had a skim chai latte and a sucre crepe. The staff was very friendly and the downstairs dining area was very welcoming. We will be back.

Just got back from a sad scene at Backyard Bowls. In the 20 minutes it took it get my one small bowl I observed a few items the Owners wouldn't be stoked about. Don't get me wrong, I love the bowls and smoothies but this was my worst experience. 

 A measuring cup was inadvertently knocked to the ground. A blender gal picked it up and put it back on the counter- next employee comes by and uses the very same measuring cup to scoop granola for a bowl, NASTY. 

The gal cutting fresh strawberries was more concerned in keeping tabs on employees and their whereabouts instead of minding her business. She walked towards the back and walked back to the cutting station wiping her nose, and yup continued cutting strawberries, SERIOUSLY? 

She then went on to shout a name followed by "whatever it is" because she didn't know how to pronounce the name? YIKES.  

Seven people behind the bar and eight or less waiting customers? One bowl should be 5-6 minutes tops. Implementing a dress code wouldn't be bad either. One of the girls had seriously small shorts on. To the Owners get this crew back on track.

La Casa Catracha is a fairly new Honduran restaurant located by the NW corner of Dale Mabry and Kennedy. It's nice to have a place like this in this part of town. I ordered the carne asada which comes with 3 sides. I wanted an authentic Honduran meal so, with a little help from the owner, I selected the black beans, Honduran cheese and tajada de guineo verde (fried green plantain). The tajada de guineo verde was a very good choice. A little sweet, a little salty. Somewhat soft, somewhat crispy. If you want something different than your typical maduros or French fries, this is a good choice. The Honduran cheese was something I could do without. I'd probably go for something else next time. The black beans were fine. Next time I'll get the refried beans. I enjoyed the carne asada. Good flavor, cooked well. 

The service was friendly though a little spotty. The atmosphere could use some improvement. But I came for the food and it was good so I was happy. I'll definitely return, especially since the location is very central.

Sad that Drama Burger closed but happy Caffeine, a Lithuanian coffee chain, took over this spot as I've been a regular at their downtown Cass St location since Day 1. Their new location on Kennedy takes Caffeine to another level - dedicated parking lot, drive-thru window and larger space. This afforded them the ability to roast their own beans (from Honduras, El Salvador, Ethiopia and Kenya).

As far as the coffee, I basically order from the Iced Coffees side of the menu. My favorite drinks at Caffeine are, in order:  Late Latte on Ice (which has butterscotch flavor), Aero Cappuccino (light, creamy, frothy), Iced Latte with added housemade mint syrup and the Orange Cold Brew (cold brew muddled with oranges and brown sugar).  For the coffee purists, they have a slow bar featuring Chemex, V60 and Aeropress. For the non-coffee drinkers, they have a few teas to choose from (matcha latte!). 

The food is top notch for a coffee shop. Chef Freddie (former Drama chef) knows his way around the kitchen. Everything I've tried has been A+. They have everything from biscuits to oatmeal to salads to paninis and more. The prices are great too. And just like their downtown location, they take great pride in customer service.  Perfect place to work/study or just hang out for a couple hours.

I have gone to Cracker Barrel a couple of times over the last year or so.  I wanted to make sure that I gave them a fair review instead of a review based off of one experience only. I wish Yelp had half stars because I would give 2 1/2 stars. Each and every time that I have visited this restaurant my food has been messed up in some way.  The last time I came in I ordered a grilled cheese and the cheese wasn't melted. I let the waitress know that the grilled cheese needed to be remade. She was apologetic and took my plate back to the kitchen.  She returned to the table with my food less than a minute later.  It appeared that the cook simply put the grilled cheese in the microwave to melt the cheese.  It was disgusting! The waitress offered to take it back again and have them remake it but at this point, I was done.  I asked her to just take it off of my check. Once my husband finished eating our check arrived.  The waitress took off the grilled cheese but still charged for a side of fries. I was confused! So, I called her back over to inquire about the charge.  She told me that she ONLY removed the grilled cheese! WTF!?! I didn't even eat the fries. It was crazy.  

So, why a 2 star review??? Because I love the country store that is attached to the restaurant! I have found some of the coolest things there. Most recently I found Dia de Muertos salt & pepper shakers. They are so adorable.    Thankfully I don't have to eat there in order to shop there.

The three of us were seated before 6 pm on a Monday evening.  The waitress, 'Din' was curt and very unfriendly.  Our son ordered a steak, my husband ordered a chicken fried steak, and I ordered a hot and sour soup, with an extra bowl and an extra plate (so my husband and I could share).  The hot and sour soup was delivered quickly, and was pretty good, although it was slopped all over the rim and was difficult to share as there was only a soup spoon.  Thirty minutes later, our food had not arrived.  The restaurant was not busy or crowded, but we never saw the angry, hostile Din again.  A waiter came by and asked if we were enjoying our dinner!  HA!!!!  He immediately rescued our lukewarm food, minus the sides of toast.  He said Din never said she was leaving!  I finally hailed him againto ask for our bread, which arrived as 'dessert' because we were finished with dinner.  Our water was never refilled, and we were never offered dessert.  I gave the waiter a $10 tip, because it wasn't his fault, but we paid our full price of $48 for a REALLY CRAPPY EXPERIENCE!!!!!  I think it would have been good if the service was not so disgraceful.  I filled out a 'comments'card but I saw the cashier toss it between some boxes on the counter, so I doubt any manager will ever see it.

Let's start by saying I'm from New York, so I know how an authentic NY hot pastrami or corned beef on rye should taste. It tasted okay, but definitely not New York by a stretch. The meat needs to have all that spicy goodness that covers the outside of the brisket. Its got to have a few of those fatty juicy flavor pockets. This had neither. It was pretty lean, so it's wasn't brisket, so my best guess is bottom round and probably steamed in some way. We ordered the giant one, which was $13.99 and came with thick sliced pickles, and we were sharing it, so they were nice enough to plate as such in the kitchen. I guess I wasn't paying attention to the menu, because the regular sandwich came with a choice of about 6 sides and was $2 less, and from the looks of what was being served around us, wasn't too much smaller that what we ordered. Anyway, we enjoyed the sandwich, and the order taker, which is at the counter, was very friendly and welcoming. Btw, you order at the counter, get a number, find a seat, and your food is delivered to your table.
All the food was very average.  Fried food was not drained well.  Might be better with a few beers and a game on TV.
The food is very good. The buffalo chicken egg rolls are my favorite. The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is that the drinks aren't that good. Tacos taste great but are tiny!

I was highly disappointed with my experience at my favorite chain in the whole wide world. I have been to many red robins over the years and always loved it. I'm not sure if the cook was having a bad day or what. 

I ordered the chophouse burger, which I usually get either that or the whiskey river burger. I ordered my burger medium well and added on bacon. It was supposed to be peppered bacon. I get my burger and tasted a piece of the bacon, and it was burnt. As you can see in the photo it was black. The waitress said she would get me a new burger, I just asked could the bacon be brought out. The bacon was regular bacon with a crap load of black pepper on it. I assumed it would be a gourmet peppered bacon. 

So I wait maybe ten minutes for new bacon to put on my burger. As I start eating my burger, there is an overwhelming taste of burnt. I know the burgers are fire grilled but this was too much. I looked on the burger and the outside crust was black all around. I can only imagine what a well done would have tasted like.

Cuban Breezes is a well oiled machine. Service and food are always consistent, and the prices are very reasonable. They're one of the only Cuban restaurants that are actually open past 5 p.m. around my neighborhood. They have a decent Cuban sandwich, definitely not the best I've had, but not the worst. The thing that makes them though is their maduros, yucca fries, and incredible Havana sauce. If they bottled and sold the Havana sauce, I'd probably purchase it. Also, if you're an FSU fan, this place is decked out in Noles gear.

Purchased recently and received barely any sauce on cheese pizza. Called and spoke with manager and was told would deliver a new order. After arriving the new order was more burnt than the original and still no sauce :( manager didn't seem concerned with customer satisfaction. Will not be back.

LOVE THIS PLACE. Love the atmosphere, the service is always great and the food is just GOOD. Tried the burger and the piccolo boca along with the meat and cheese board and the Joker Got Away cocktail. Finished with the lemon blueberry mousse and the green apple crostada. All great choices. The burger is just awesome, cooked perfectly and topped wonderfully. The piccolo boca flavors were so great. Loved the meat cheese board spread, and the desserts were so good and so different. Our server took very good care of us. Last night's visit was our second and we'll be back for more in the future.
Good food and great beer.  $2 pints on Sunday... You can't beat that.   Great vegetarian options.

Decided to add the Tenderloin Room to the rotation in my quest to find the best steak in St Louis.  Came away with a nice dinner but not the best I'd ever had.

Arrived at 6:30 for an early-ish dinner.  Had reservations but didn't need them, the place was deserted.  (On a side note, *every* other nice restaurant I've been to has confirmed the reservation by email or phone call the day before.. not the Tenderloin Room)  Seated at a table that wouldn't have been my first choice, since it was on the aisle and right inside the front door.  The waiter came and introduced himself, seemed very charming.  However, I was a little disappointed that upon seeing 4 adults clearly dressed up he didn't ask if it was a special occasion (which it was, my birthday).  I paid attention to the next few people seated after us and EVERY single one of them was asked if they were celebrating anything.  I guess we just didn't rate!  We didn't feel right just volunteering the information because then it looks like you're fishing for free dessert.. and I should *not* have to ask at a place like this.
  
Started with the smoked salmon and bacon wrapped tenderloin tips. Delicious, both of them.  The waiter was kind enough to split up the appetizer so we could each try some.

Disappointed with the rest of the menu.  Online they advertise a *crab* stuffed filet.  Upon arriving we found out that it was a shrimp stuffed filet.  We were told that our steaks were served with a twice baked potato and green beans.  Period.  I don't care for green beans, so I asked if there were any other choices.  "Oh, of course.. we can do spinach or broiled tomato".  WTF!?  Why can't you just tell me that or put it on your menu?  Apparently you can also get a baked potato (as seen on another diner's plate.. but for some reason you have to know to ask?!  Ridiculous.  

Of the four of us, 3 had the filet and I had the tenderloin.  We all agreed that on the inside the steaks were tender, well cooked and delicious.  However, three of us had charred edges on steaks - like they'd been left too close to the flame on one side.  I don't like scraping burnt bits off of my expensive steak.

Dessert was phenomenal.  Bananas Foster and Cherries Jubilee made tableside and were delicious.  Cheesecake was good, but the raspberry sauce is literally out of a bottle.  Lame.

Overall, the atmosphere of the restaurant is cool but the overall experience just can't compare to somewhere like Morton's or Ruth's Chris.  I don't know if it was our age (well below the average for the restaurant, but we're not college kids and were extremely well dressed) or what.. but I just felt like we were doing way too much work between the lack of acknowledging our special occasion and the lack of detail on the menu.  My search for the ultimate steak continues!

These days, I don't go out/stay out super late ('tis true) so when I do, it's usually for a special occasion or one of those awesome impromptu nights when you're out with friends and just say: why not? This past weekend was one of those events and with 2nd Saturday going on downtown, it was that much sweeter. The scene upstairs had a DJ with a diverse crowd dancing (music was okay--but maybe they rotate DJs frequently?). And downstairs, there was a big screen playing Mean Girls (haha) and had more of a chill, laid back vibe.

I like places that have a variety of spaces within the general space itself and to me, Playground seemed to be one of the major spots downtown. Good times!

Food is above average but service is "stuck up" without much reason.  Been here a few times and have experience decent service but on one occasion the waiter was not attentive at all after we said we bought our own wine (they serve wine but allow you to BYOB if you choose).  Either the waiter thought the check would be less so his tip would be as well or he is just arrogant but he made us feel very unwelcome.

While I want all to understand that more than 90% of my reviews are Highly positive, I have to give this one a very less than positive review.  The ONLY reason I've been there several times is because my girlfriend is Filipina.  She loves fish and loves the whole fish on the plate with bones, eyes, etc.  Disgusting to we Americans.  
Although we've eaten there multiple times, I'd never go back if it weren't for her.  Their food is less than good, their wine selection is less than good and I hope to never be coerced to go back there again.  Stay away.

Only gave them a 1 star because 0 stars wasn't an option.  It was my first (and last) time there.  A group of us went for lunch that took forever considering the place was empty.  Our waitress was less than pleasant or fast.  I ordered the Cobb Salad.  For $10 it came with very little dry/overcooked chicken, one small sliver of egg, a little bacon sprinkled ontop of a small bed of lettuce.  No flavor at all.  Someone else had the fish taco's that were bland and tasted fishy.  Another in the group had Buffalo Ckn Sandwich.  Taste was good, but chicken was dry and overcooked.  She asked for Ranch several times and finally got it when she only had a couple bites of her food left.  She was charged for the ranch.

Upon cashing out, we had a CL Deal worth 30.00.  We paid our bill and someone elses bill which would have totaled about 36.00.  The waitress only gave us credit for 25.00 of our CL Dean and took the rest as cash.  So we lost out on 5.00 of our benefit and she made no effort to make things right.

I will never go back to this place, or their other location.
I haven't been back to this place for a while.....but this place is still pretty good!  I would recommend this place to any pho lover!!! :)

Decided to stop in and give this place a try. Curiosity has been satisfied, but that's about it. Service was rude and food was only okay. I place as much importance on the service as I do the food. Best thing about the visit was the cold Coors Light. I won't return to a restaurant whose servers make me, the customer, feel as though I'm bothering them to provide my service/product. Won't return.

Ordered a fish hoagie (Muslim). First time ordering from here, it was a mess, there was sauce everywhere, too much fish in a very little bread loaf.. Too be honest I couldn't even taste the fish, it was just sauce and more sauce, too messy. However it was decently flavored and even tho I looked like a fool eating it, I did it anyway.  Only if they can get the ratio of fish and bread right, it might actually be ok. Not to mention everyone doesn't like a hoagie loaded with sauce...

Just started eating here more regularly. The 3-6 sliders are a really good deal and tasty. My husband likes the long sahm silver and I am a fan of the pork tenderloin. Service is usually nice and fast. Beer is pricy but really where is it not these days?

Delicious. A bit pricey but you do get a ton of food. 
We got the fried chicken and chicken and shrimp combo. My husband says their cocktail sauce was the best he has had.
Sides were all delicious. Served in large quantities for sharing.
Our server Camey was superb.

I've been here twice now, and my second visit was so tepid and unimpressive, it seemed like it was time for a review.

A friend insisted on having a Friday lunch here, so I agreed to meet her, hoping this visit would be better than my last meal here. It wasn't.

We had a table outside so that was a positive start. The house cocktail menu looked imaginative albeit over priced. I ordered a Brass Monkey because it sounded refreshing, but it was far too sweet, not very cold and served in a coupe glass (which I HATE), garnished with a tired looking bit of orange peel. If I had been smart, I'd have gotten a Tanqueray and tonic or a Campari and soda. Hell, even a Lillet would have been a better choice. So the bad drink was poor judgement on my part. 

We both like seafood so we started with the ceviche of the day. It was 2 types of fish, neither one a type we'd ever heard of, and it was a goopy mess. The ceviche had more radishes in it than fish, it was too sour rather than refreshingly citric, the fish tasted alright but was cut sloppily. We both just got tired of all the radishes and other extraneous vegetable chunks dripping their vinegar off our forks as we tried to spear a bit of the fish. It came with tortilla chips, was unattractive and poorly executed on all levels. We didn't finish it. 

The waiter recommended the crab cake so I ordered that. My companion has a lot of neurotic food issues (and to my mind should just plain NOT eat out) so she got a fish dish that came with spaghetti. My crab cake was okay, not exceptional, not awful. It did not taste extremely fresh, but it was not fishy and did not make me sick so score 2 for that. The other diner spent the better part of the meal scraping the sauce off her fish, then scraping the coating off it as well, then picking all the black olives out of her pasta. I don't know if she ate anything other than the bread and some of the spaghetti. She did not comment on her meal other than to complain about level of spice and I know better than to ask how her food is. This woman thinks a sprinkle of Lawry's Seasoned Salt is on the level of consuming 75 Thai bird chiles so I ignore what she has to say the majority of the time.

No one asked if we wanted a second cocktail. I would have gone for one but I was not going to chase after it. I think service that is that indifferent causes a restaurant to lose a lot of revenue. Tipsy diners always order more even if they don't eat it all and thus tend to have a bigger tab.

I passed on dessert, as did she, but had a nice grappa which was the only part of the meal that I can say I enjoyed. No one bothered to ask if we wanted tea or coffee. 

For a very sub par meal with cursory service, we spent close to $100, not including tip. On the plus side, I am now totally convinced I will never eat here again for any reason, even if the meal was free.

I like coming here on the weekends for a quick egg breakfast. Pancakes and waffles are okay. Take out is also pretty good. Steak sandwiches, hoagies, burgers have been a frequent occurrence for my family over the years. Good onion rings! Sometimes the fries could be more crisp we think. It's not open too late but it's nice to stop in if you live in the area for breakfast or lunch.
Terrible coffee. I had the Red Eye which tasted like burnt charcoal. My wife describes her Raspberry Mocha Vanilla Hot Latte as undrinkably sweet. Nice service though.

'Heaven. I'm in heaven.' Hyde Park Burger. Wow. Buttery brioche toasted bun. SRF Wagyu beef patty cooked perfectly medium. Swiss cheese. Tomato. Lettuce. It's not a fancy burger but it was absolutely perfect. Fries were great. Soft in the center but had a nice fry on the outside-perfect with a little ranch to dip it in. 

Also tried one of the chicken kabobs with peanut sauce. Wow. I'm pretty sure I can honestly say I've never had a chicken kabob that was so juicy. Kudos!! Lunch was great!!

Santuccis isn't just a pizza place, it's a Philly staple. My mom grew up with it, I grew up with it, and I'm sure my future non existent children will grow up with it. Pizza pie is their thing and they do it best. They are expensive but it's worth the extra price for the quality. And nothing is better than having leftover cold Santuccis pizza for breakfast. Their cheesesteaks are also pretty darn good.

Awesome food and a pretty killer happy hour! We stopped in for happy hour and grabbed some dollar tacos, a couple appetizers and a few margaritas. I have to say the tacos were impressive alone, I had a ton of steak on my tacos I had it spilling all over my plate when I took a bite. I had a mini carne asada platter left over when I was done. We got shredded beef taquitos which were cooked perfectly and delicious. And we also got some bean dip to go with our chips and salsa which was interesting because they layered the beans in on top of salsa verde which is the way I personally do it at home. Finally the margaritas were pretty hefty for being the cheap happy hour specials. Two of them was a perfect way to unwind after work. I highly recommend. I'll definitely be back for sure!

I came to this place after being recommended many times. It was pretty much what I expected especially walking inside and seen the Decore and getting that whole authentic Mexican vibe. But I did not expect was a staff and I could care less if I was there. But I try to ignore that and prepare myself for an amazing meal. Once to me OK my whole thought about the place changed. The food was great. One of the best I've ever had in regards to Mexican cuisine. And the portion size was great. For this reason alone I am giving four stars. If their staffs attitude was better this place could easily be a five. And the sad part is that out of all the people Who have reviewed this place the majority of the people who get four or less are all complaining about the same thing, the staff's attitude. Unfortunately since this is been going on for months based on reviews it seems like management doesn't care. I would still recommend this place to people but I would warn them to be prepared to be treated like they don't matter.

I visited Treno with three friends on a Monday night around 6:30. I was seated as I waited for my friends to arrive (I almost always arrive first +2 points for seating partial parties!) While the menu was OK, there weren't as many options as I would have hoped for. Obviously one goes here for pizza, they have brick oven and wood fired varieties. I instead opted for the grilled ceasar salad which if you look at the photo was not what I was expecting. It was a half stalk of romaine lettuce with dressing and chicken on top. That being said, though I wasn't expecting that type of presentation the salad was did pleasurably satisfy my hunger. My friends split the fried calamari which they thought was good. I had a few pieces and it still doesn't compare to my favorite calamari ever (Cucina Forte, South Philly). My other friend ordered the beet salad and a Margherita pizza was ordered to split. 

Our server Sean?Shawn?Shaun? was really attentive and friendly. While it was nice to sit outside on the patio and enjoy the summer evening, we all endured quite a few mosquito bites. I'm not sure if they can control that at all, but perhaps get an exterminator out to spray? Otherwise, bring bug spray if you plan to sit outside.

They have some great vegan options here (vegetarian but you can ask to remove the cheese/dairy). Service was always lackluster but there was fun games to play here so the occasional trip here was alright. We usually ordered to go from here.

Before we hit up our dinner spot we decided to stop in and check out Chilly Water. First, I LOVE the location. The building that it's part of is modern and trendy. 

We walked inside and walked to the bar to check out the beers on tap. We were told that we needed to have a seat at a table and a waitress would be with us. OK.... I don't think I've ever been turned down at a bar. Apparently they will only serve you if you are sitting at the bar. So we sit at a table. And we sit... And we sit... Finally someone shows us the menu, which was already on our table and the beer list and leaves. Apparently she wasn't our waitress. Finally our waitress comes and we order. (They were not very busy)  I got a flight and my husband got the IPA. Good stuff! I also really like the pale ale. 

I would come back, but there are other breweries that I get better service.  First impressions are key, and they didn't hit it out of the park.
Went for lunch yesterday.  Yummy and unique selections.  Good service.  I would return.

I wanted to love this place. I am from Boston originally and my two best friends growing up were Italian. 

I didn't love it. I did like it alright. 

Their pizza has a crisp homemade crust, but they dump about half a pound more cheese than need be and it turns into a cheese grease explosion. 

The chicken parm was above average as are their cannolis. 

On a side note, they are one of the few places in town that serve Moretti beer which is an Italian beer I love. That definitely scored some points for me. 

Staff was helpful and very friendly.

After a long, hard day, this was a nice new (to me) sit down restaurant to try. While I would not consider anything on the menu healthy, everything I had was tasty and had a true Southern cooking flavor to it. Plus the server was very good at his job. 

The servings are huge, so come with an appetite. I enjoyed the Fisherman's Platter (fried bone-in catfish, shrimp, and clams) with fries, apples, and hush puppies. My boyfriend had the country fried steak with gravy, mashed potatoes, and green beans. While I liked my fries, I wish I had gotten mashed potatoes--they were quite good, and I liked the gravy. The cornbread was great; light and fluffy, and made even more tasty by the addition of honey on the side.

We really wanted to try a dessert, but there was so much food that we were too full by the end of our meal and ended up splitting my fried apples.

I liked this place a lot, and will definitely be eating here again (after some exercise to work off that big meal)!
Table stinks like it was wiped with sour rag. Somebody somewhere is smoking I suspect in back. Take a pass

My first trek out to the GenCon food trucks brought me to The NY Slice truck, parked just outside the convention center on Capital Ave.  Eager for a quick lunch, a stromboli sounded fantastic and my stomach was grumbling in agreement.

What I got, however?  Oooof.

The stromboli from NY Slice was decently sized--probably about 8" long--but was shaped more like a calzone (in a crescent, as opposed to the long straight stromboli).  That, I could forgive, but a solid third of my stromboli was utterly inedible; the dough was overdone and charred in places, to the point where I simply couldn't tear the crust with my teeth, much less chew or swallow it.  The filling was mediocre at best--simply pepperoni and cheese, with none of the other decadence that you'd typically get in a calzone or stromboli.  

That half-moon of disappointment cost me $12, with a bag of plain Lays chips and a can of Coke.

One lone bright spot from NY Slice was their cannoli which was not only tasty, but also drew heads.  No less than three separate people asked me, "Where did you get that cannoli?!" as I sat, trying desperately to choke down some of my stromboli.  

It's a crowded food truck market in Indy, but I can't recommend NY Slice.  Try Twisted Sicilian or Hot Box instead, if you're craving some Italian flavor.

Oh Katie's... you are what my summertime dreams are made of! You and your adorable picnic benches outside, your hand crafted cocktails, your inventive & oh-so-fresh salads and pizzas...

Mother nature was in an incredible mood yesterday so my roommate & I decided to head to Katie's for a quick dinner. The front patio was pretty open so we grabbed seats there and I loved all of my surroundings... gorgeous plants and flowers, tables full of happy people, a hilarious situation at the table next to ours involving two year old twin girls who weren't in the mood to sit and eat. It was just so refreshing to see a good mix of people who were just out enjoying the weather! These recent 100 degree temps are for the birds...

Their watermelon cocktail was on special yesterday, so I ordered one and it was the most perfect drink for a summer day. I wasn't too hungry for pizza this time (shame, I know) so I had the fried artichoke salad with mixed baby greens, asparagus, pistachios & goat cheese. I definitely categorize it in the "OMG" category... take a look at the photo. Usually when I get salads I'm left hungry and wanting more, but not this time.

There's not one thing about Katie's I don't like, and I can't wait to come back for brunch to get the egg & speck pizza again! So glad to live just a few blocks away.

I recently met my mom at the Crossing for lunch, and we had a pretty nice time! It was definitely more A-OK than great, but I would definitely go back to try more.

Our service was really on point and everyone was so friendly - a definite plus. We had coffee right away and took our time looking through the menu. There's a lot to choose from between the starters, salads, pastas, sandwiches, and the bigger entrees.

We ended up going with the taglioni pasta with wild mushrooms (to share), and were happily surprised when they split it up for us ahead of time. The pasta was okay, but there was so much salt that it was hard to eat (and even left my mouth stinging a little bit.) It would have been great otherwise. The caesar salad I had on the side, however, was wonderful.

I like the environment at the Crossing for lunch so I'll definitely come back to try something else... the tilapia was looking pretty tempting.

I'll update once I try more!

Ohhhh how I LOVE having this place in my neighborhood! Seedz is a very welcome addition to Demun, and I've been there at least a half a dozen times already.

I make juice a lot at home, but it takes a long time and I'm usually out of produce (you go through it so fast!) Clean up is also the worst. I love that I can swing by this place and get a heaping cup of juice before I hit the road. They always have a couple you can choose from, but I typically just ask the owners to make me something green. They throw in a bunch of different things and I've never been disappointed. If you want something more specific, I'm sure they'll be happy to oblige. 

I've only tried one thing from the food menu, and that was the raw pad thai... I can promise you that I'll be back for that one. Everything on the menu looks so good and is so unbelievably healthy. The interior of Seedz is pretty cute too, with a clean, quiet feel... I'm sure I'll meet one of my friends for lunch there soon. They also serve wine in the evening which could be fun.

Sure, you're going to pay more than you would most places around, but you're getting fresh, organic products. When I'm on the go, I'm more than happy to do that. So glad to have Seedz in the neighborhood and I hope they have a ton of success so they stay for a while!

Tucked away in a partially defunct strip mall, between Pinch a Penny and an empty Winn Dixie, is Bj's Asian Fusion.  You can't miss it because of the blinding LED lights that surround the windows and door.  Once inside, it smells great and the place is very neat, a wall booth and tables w/chairs line one wall, the center is filled with tables and chairs and the other wall is filled with booths. Plenty of seating for everyone, and of course there is the ever popular take out. Mind you, this is not your everyday Asian take out. 

The menu is THICK.. there is Chinese, Thai, Japanese and Sushi on the menu, and plenty to choose from, you can't possibly leave here with an empty belly. If you do, you must not have eaten for a week! 

We started with an appetizer, this was a mistake, we had no idea how big the portions were, so... in the future we won't do this. We started with the Thai spring rolls, they were very fresh and very tasty, but their peanut sauce was a bit too sweet for me.  Since I ordered the hibachi dinner, I also got a salad and soup with my meal, I HAD NO IDEA there was going to be so much!  The won ton soup was DELICIOUS, the Salad was good, but there was way too much dressing (One of the reason for not 5 stars), the Hibachi style steak and shrimp was good, but the the steak was over cooked, to the point of being dry and tough.   The husbeast had one of the chef's specialties, the Dragon and Phoenix (?) The way he ate it, I can honestly say he LOVED it.  

All in all it was absolutely delicious, we will certainly come back.

Not our first choice for dinner on this Saturday night, but since our first choice was SUPER busy, we decided to give this place a go.  There were 2 couples inside, one sitting and eating, the other waiting for their order to go. 

We walked in, and took a moment to familiarize ourselves with the menu. I asked what was good, and got the standard answer of "everything" and then I was told what was popular, such as their Pulled Pork, pulled chicken and their greens.  Taking those things into consideration, I ordered the Pulled pork diner - 2 sides being the cole slaw and potato salad. The husbeast had the Pulled beef with Cole Slaw and french fries and my friend who was joining us had the sausage dinner with 2 sides of their greens. 

Since it wasn't busy, we had the undivided attention, which pretty much included table service and everything. We asked for our sauce on the side, and it was given. There is no .. choice of sauces, it is only Daddy Mack's sauce, which is light, kind of sweet, with no tang. It's good but it's not Spectacular, and they will sell a 32ox bottle to you for $6.99. 

The food was tasty, well the meat was. The Pulled Pork was tender, a bit on the dry side. The beef was flavorful and the smoked sausage was standard Keilbasa. As for the sides.. The fries were hands down the best thing we sampled. The cole slaw and potato salad were institutional - i'm not even kidding. They were store bought and getting close to ending their cycle of freshness. And the greens were Ok. 

I'd come back, but not often.

Came here after getting a massage from a friend, and we were a bit more than a half hour before they closed.  We were worried because a lot of places don't give you good service when you come in that late, but we got AMAZING service from Ashley. She was perfection. 

Our food was delicious from the bang bang shrimp to the scallops and shrimp that my friend had. My pork was also tender and tasty.  This location is a bit hidden, but it's certainly worth visiting.

I want to give this a higher rating because the food was DAMN good.  

Right on the water at the start of the Sponge Docks, ShrimpWrecked is a new addition to the area.  I'd just come back from the hospital - yay foot injury, and I was hungry. So we opted to get food here. First issue, parking is confusing. But once we figured it out, it was easy. 

We made our way to the back of the bar area, to sit out side, because it was a lovely day to be outside and nearly sunset, the perfect time to be on the water.  The hostess sat us and we were given menus. Once that was given, our WAIT-ress, came over and asked us for our drink orders, we placed them, and they came over quickly.. I was ready to order my app, but in a quick second she was GONE. 

We waited... we waited... we waited.  In 10 or so minutes she came back and asked if we wanted to place our orders with the preface that there was a 20-30 minute wait in the kitchen. She just wanted us to know. No worries. We placed our order for a soup and salad, an App of the buffalo shrimp, the coconut shrimp and the crawfish platter.   And she was off. 

Around us, I noticed that other people weren't having the wait times we were, or the others in our section. One table was especially techy about the waitress, I'm not sure specifically about what the issue was, but they had the manager come over and I did over hear them talking about how the waitress wasn't around.  Our drinks went empty.  Finally our salad and soup came out. We enjoyed them. 

And we waited some more. The live music was awesome. I'm not sure who was playing on Sunday afternoon, but he was really REALLY good. 

When the food was delivered, it was hot and fresh. The coconut shrim was as good as the other people have claimed. The buffalo shrimp was hot and spicy, there could have been more celery offered with it.  The crawfish were.. interesting, more like fried clams than crawfish, but what do i know? I've never eaten them before. 

We waited again.. I asked for a refill on our drinks from another waitress.. I asked for a box, when I asked for our box, I had to ask for our check AFTER she dropped the box off. I'm not sure if Lola was having an off day or what, but she certainly brought down my rating due to the lack of service we were having.

Had a lovely lunch here with a friend of mine. I wasn't aware this location existed. 

It was clean, the lines were populated well and filled with all the usual good things. Including my favorite, Pickled beets. 

The people were friendly, the soups were good and they had Gluten friendly pumpkin muffins. Not as good as their Gluten Friendly Coconut muffins but they'll do.

A newly remodeled McDonalds with twin drive-thrus for fast service, I fully approve.  We stopped here to get drinks after driving across the bay. The store appeared clean and neat from the outside, and most certainly could tell that though it was a busy store from the location, it was kept up on the outside. 

Service was quick, and polite. I like when I encounter that at a MickeyD's

I wasn't sure what to expect, but the parking lot was full so that's got to be a good sign, right?

When we stepped in, we found out you put your order in first, before you sit down. Given that they were so busy, and it was an hour before closing, their ordering board said they were out of a few things. That's ok. We could work around that. 

We placed our orders, I got a pulled pork combo, and my husband ordered a ribs combo, both of us would get our meat plus 2 sides for $11 or $13 with cornbread.  Not a bad price really, just a bit over average.  Once our order was placed, we walked into the small seating area and waited.  .. And waited.. And waited. As I mentioned it was packed in the parking lot, and so it was packed inside.  When we sat, they were calling #96, our ticket was #107 so we knew we'd be waiting for a while. 

Time passed slowly, the husband and I chatting quietly, taking a look at the people around us plates, when I noticed one lady had just gotten her hush puppies, she must have had about 10 on her plate. I told her how good they looked and she offered me one. I politely declined, but I really thought that was nice.   

As we were waiting, the woman who took our order came around to several of the waiting orders and told them that they were out of ribs.  She finally came to us and told the husband that they were out of ribs and would he rather a different meat. He chose brisket, he was fine with that.   When it was time to pick up our plate we were doubly surprised! The serving size of the sides were huge (Unless you got the onion rings, you only get 4) and he got Ribs. Apparently they found the last order of them.  This kind of made the lady who was sitting near us upset as she too, had ordered ribs and ended up getting prime rib. She was not a happy camper. 

The food itself was good. There were 3 different sauces offered. One was very sweet, with a hint of Maple. The next one was kind of sweet but much more smoky and the last was smoky with a lot of heat. I liked the smoky one and the Hubby prefers the hot one.  The pulled pork was well smoked and very flavourful, the potato salad had a *special ingredient* that added some zip to it and made it unforgettable. While the fried okra that the husband had was very tasty as was the coleslaw.  

What I was really surprised to see was that you couldn't get either Coke Or Pepsi there, but rather Kodiak soda, I've never heard of this brand but people seemed to like it. They also had unsweetened flavoured teas to try. 

We will certainly try this place again when there isn't a groupon out, and have a better chance of trying everything we really want to.  I guess you can't fault a place for being popular, and having to turn customers away by telling them "I'm sorry, we've run out of food!"

3.5 stars. Fish is fresh and rolls are well prepared. Servers are friendly. I am a sushi purist so a menu with a large amount of over busy, heavily sauced rolls is kind of annoying. If you are confident in the quality of your fish why smother it in sauces??

Wow, well this is disappointing. We love this place or rather we used to love this place. Ordered delivery last night and we were both really disappointed. The portion sizes have been literally cut in half. Seriously, in half. I requested that the feta spread on my sandwich be omitted but no such luck. In addition to the portion sizes being significantly reduced, the actual ingredients were sparser than usual. Needless to say we were not pleased and will probably not order from here again.
Better than the guy across the street. Higher quality meet, better bread fresher veggies and not quite as greasy. The kings are very long, it's expensive and, yes, it's a total tourist trap.

The daily specials are the deal as it also comes with a drink for  $8.99.

Fresh made flour and corn wraps cooked right there. Go down the line selecting your sauces and toppings.

Covid standards adhered here.

Friendly service.

Clean dine in area.

Best birria in Reno! Lean, soft pieces of meat in a delightful broth. Served in tacos or soup style. Soup style is packed with meat. Reminds me of goulash suppe!

Friend had the 7 Seas soup. It's packed with almost every type of seafood item. When done, he  proclaimed he felt like he ate a whole aquarium! Lol! It's a big bowl.

They have soups, the cauldrons and a full bar. Small outdoor patio, too.

Again, get the BIRRIA!

Flap Jack Pancake House is a nice place to come and grab some breakfast that tastes like it was made at home (in a good way). I ordered the skillet and thought it was very good. It needed a little salt, but I would rather have to add than have it be too salty. I did not really like the coffee, but everything else was good.

I think what most impressed me about Flap Jacks was the service. Our coffee was always full, we were seated right away, the hostess and waitress were very friendly, and our food came out quickly. There wasn't a wait or a line for anything (I'm always a fan of that!). Very nice.

It's certainly not haute cuisine but they do a pretty good job of making traditional food with nice flavor and spice.  Jambalaya was the best I've had at a restaurant so far - still not as good as I can make at home but not an easy dish to do well in a restaurant environment.  If you go, get the multi-course meal which for around $30 is a good deal including salad or a spicy crawfish enchilada to start and bread pudding for dessert.  Certainly, K-Paul's won't wow the foodie but they have good food which can be reasonably priced (in the 3-course meal) and a very nice wine list by the glass (the bottles are overpriced but you will probably be able to find something you like).  Not my favorite ever, and I probably won't be back given the other great restaurant options in NOLA, but a solid restaurant choice if you don't want to leave the French Quarter or have a particular affinity for Paul Prudhome and/or his large contributions to the NOLA food community.  K-Paul's was an even better deal with a $60 Groupon for $30 - although you can't apply it to the 3-course menu so make sure that at least one person orders off the more pricey part of the menu.

Having been to Peche twice in the first 2 weeks after opening, and a couple times since then I have to say that Peche somehow knocked it out of the park from day 1.  Best catfish ever (the smothered catfish entree).  Fish stew and crawfish spring onion gratinee were excellent along with fish dishes from the raw bar.  The fish entree specials have been very good but maybe underwhelmed a little with subtle flavor compared to much on the table which had very big flavors (including too much pepper on the ground shrimp & noodles).  Everything has been fresh, well cooked, and generally had nice flavor.  Service has been great and the only recommendation I would have for Peche is to serve bread - especially with all these great sauces you really need some great, fresh bread to be paired either with some nice salted butter or to sop up the sauces.

The wine list is medium-sized but well chosen and some great choices by the glass.  Cocktails are nice and there is a huge 3-sided bar in the front that seats about 15 as well as a raw bar in the back by the kitchen that seats probably 6 or 7.  The building exterior and upstairs is still under construction but the interior is done nicely (and surprisingly quickly - a couple weeks before opening there weren't even floors) in a minimalist warehouse feel.  Upscale food with great flavor in a nice but fairly casual environment. Another absolute hit by the Link Restaurant Group to join 3 of my favorites Herbsaint, Cochon, and Butcher.  Bravo.

Ok today is Saturday around 2:00 pm my little Brother is out here from New Jersey where the bakeries are amazing and today he is going back home . Well I wanted him to try the carrot cake from here I order whole cakes  every holiday and I come in quite often . Anyways I wanted to take some home and wanted him to try but unfortunately the cashier said they were no longer cutting slices of carrot cake for the day , I thought this was a joke ! There was a whole cake in the case just sitting there for sale but I could not buy a slice . So it's like going to the bakery and not being able  to buy what you would like ! So why be open ! If u can't sell it ! I guess this company dosent care or need my money they are just to big ! And to top it off every time I go in they never thanked me for coming in and they're never appreciative!

So where does a tourist staying in Algiers go for dinner on a wet miserable Mardi Gras night when you've come home across the river for the night? The Dry Dock is the only game in town.

It's a fun, lively place, obviously a neighborhood hangout where everybody knows each other. The drag on the rating was the food and service, even though I'll make allowance for the fact it was Mardi Gras. The waitress was rather curt most of the time, although she did soften a little once to say it had been a very long day, and it appeared she was working the whole restaurant. Another woman, maybe a manager, came by a few times and was more gracious.

The shrimp po' boy is not on my list of great ones-the shrimp weren't crisp, and there weren't a whole lot of them there. My friend's roast beef looked much better-more meat and plenty of gravy, and she said it was good. The fries were pre-made, but perfectly acceptable. The high point of the evening was the King Cake shots, obviously made with Rum Chata, and completely delicious! That, and a Quentin Tarentino siting-he was sitting right behind us.

I have loved Dim Sum throughout my childhood and continues to be one of my all-time favorite meals. So when I moved to Tampa almost 2 years ago I went on a search to find the city's best Dim Sum... sadly, it's not here. After reading great reviews, I decided to give it a try and to say that I was unimpressed is a huge understatement. I even ate here twice to be sure.

The best thing about the restaurant was not the food. The decor was classy, the atmosphere was welcoming, and service was good, but the focus should most certainly be the food. The food was bland and seemed to be the furthest thing from fresh. It was an absolute disappointment. Not to mention that they only had 2 carts, which is no where near sufficient for the kind of spread a proper Dim Sum restaurant should have. In a nutshell- it's over-priced and poor quality with a lacking menu.

They say "Third time's a charm" but I'll never know because I don't intend on wasting my time or money on another disappointing meal. If I'm going to waste my time and money, I'd rather do it driving around the entire Tampa Bay area to find a better Dim Sum place.

I loved the atmosphere, but I couldn't figure out why the lines were so long. Chipotle has better burritos, and they're the same price. The orchata is bad, worse I've ever had.
However, they have a fantastic homeade pineapple salsa that is AMAZING!
Overal, next time I would go here, I would just get chips and salsa.

It always makes me happy to see vegan and vegetarian menu items! Ate there with a bunch of people before seeing a show at the Sanger. Everyone seemed to really enjoy their meal. I had the Roasted Cauliflower Sandwich. Great flavor but as often an issue with vegan/vegetarian sandwiches the texture was mushy making it less enjoyable to me. And they've got wine in a can!

And so begins my search for Thai food in Philly, and this was not a bad place to start. 

The menu is a mix of Thai and Malayasian food, as the name would suggest, and has a few familiar favorites if you're not up for trying one of the spicier dishes. We had the tofu triangles appetizer (delish!), chicken pad thai (very good, a lil spicy), and pineapple fried rice served IN a pineapple (also very good, and not too greasy). The staff was very friendly and attentive. We came here before seeing a show at the Walnut St Theater, which worked out really well, and they have a discount deal with members of the theater.

I thought that this would be a great experience but the wait was outrageous. The staff was great and the tacos on taco Tuesday were also delicious. The hostess seated several groups ahead of us and when we questioned it the Rum House said "oh well". They have too much business to be concerned about service but eventually that will catch up to them. There are way too many options in the Garden District to put up with it.

Tonight was my first time to Grbic. It's a little off the beaten path, so I'd never heard of it. If it weren't for Sarah coordinating a little ISC action, I don't know that I would've tried it. 

Tonight I started out with their house Pinot Noir. It was yummy and did the trick. Best part, it was only $6. 

Before our meals, Julia R and I shared the Grbic salad - it was a bed of chopped feta, tomatoes, and lettuce tossed in their house made Greek dressing. Refreshing and delicious. 

Chicken cordon blue and the chicken roulden were our meal choices and they were both great choices. Chicken was tender and all white meat. The skin was perfectly cooked. On the roulden, there was melted feta and spinach stuffing and in the cordon blue creamy cheeses and ham. They were both delicious. 

We were too full for dessert, but they had some tasty options I look forward to saving room for next time I'm in!
Two locations. We visited the original location and the food was what you would expect from any breakfast diner establishment.

I was really underwhelmed with this place. It's a lot of show and not much else. It's decorated very nicely and it is huge. It's certainly not as hipster as Chipotle or annoying as Moe's (WELCOME TO MOE'S!!), but there's really nothing awesome about it that would keep me coming back.

The chicken was meh at best. It reminded me exactly of the chicken at Moe's. Yes, you do get chips with your meal, but you can count them on two hands. It's strange, they give you unlimited salsa, but the chips they have a stranglehold on.

As I walked out of there, I knew what this place reminded me of. A Tex-mex kinda place you'd eat at in an airport in some random city between flights.

The Habenero Salsa was awesome and hot and if anything brings me back, it'll be that.

Oh, and for the price they charged - it wasn't even close to worth it!

I wanted to finish up the last weekend of Tampa Bay Burger Week strong, so we bounced around today and tried a few burgers. This one was from Stellas in Gulfport. This one was an angus beef patty piled high with Stella's famous fried green tomatoes, bacon, and lettuce, topped with goat cheese and house-made chipotle spicy mayo. It included hand-cut french fries. I ordered this burger medium rare, but it came out closer to well, but trust me when I say it did not hurt the flavor. It really was an amazing combo of flavors that truly worked. The goat chesese, bacon, and fried green tomatoes truly complimented eachother. The service was great and everyone there was incredibly friendly. They really are quite welcoming there. Overall, it was a great experience and I would highly recommend Stellas. They mentioned that this burger was really well received and that they were considering adding it to their regular menu. It would be a great addition.

I want to love this place, because they usually do have the best chicken tikka masala. But for some reason, they can't keep orders straight. If one person orders mild, and the other spicy, both orders are made spicy, or they are reversed. I don't know how this happens, but it happens often. Please read orders twice before making them.

so disappointed in your sales manager Kim  I guess she doesn't work weekend, or check her voicemail even though your staff swears she does.  BTW, whoever answer the phone on the weekend is very rude, try retraining her to be more courteous and human.  I understand that I called late on a Friday and then AGAIN on Saturday afternoon for a Monday evening reservation.  But I would think you would want a party of 15 and the revenue it would generate.  Must be nice to be doing so well you can ignore the customer.  Thank goodness there are so many other restaurants King of Prussia who want my business.

I'm sorry I let you down world. The last time I was here I must have been either 1. drunk (it is BYOB after all) or 2. clouded by nostalgia and the yearning for Korean food. 

Came back here tonight with a fellow former Korean English Teacher and we were determined to have a reunion worthy of our blackoutkorea days (google it). We stopped by the Wine and Spirits conveniently located a block away and picked up the small green bottle that was a staple of many a dinner back in the day. I downplayed it a bit because, I know this isn't the best Korean, and we've obviously had better (lately every time I go to NYC I magically end up in Koreatown before doing anything). Nevertheless, we couldn't help but get super pumped about the vaccums that come down and up at the click of a button. But that's where our excitement dwindled. 

The service was lacking, but, lets be honest, who goes to an Asian restaurant for stellar service? We went with the Bulgogi Set for 2 (around $40, comes with veggie pancake, rice, and tofu soup). Turns out the tofu soup never came (when I asked he said it was a choice of veggie pancake or soup, and I guess he chose for us). The Bulgogi was not that tender or flavorful, and the banchan were tiny and boring (steamed broc, mashed potatoes, and bean sprouts). The veggie pancake was fine, nothing special. The price was reasonable, but more than you'd pay in Chinatown for way better Asian food.

Will have to be REALLY craving Korean BBQ to come back...might be worth just waiting to be in NYC or trekking out to the northeast.

It's like subway - you go in and basically just ask for what you want on your taco. Everything tasted very bland. I got six tacos and the only one that I enjoyed was the chicken taco. I got pork, beef, chorizo and chicken. Regret going to this place for sure.

Just wanted to adjust my review based on the fact that the owners take lots of pride into their restaurant. I spoke with the owner Pike and he was really apologetic and willing to do what he can to make sure I was a satisfied customer. 

Wish I could have take him up on his offer!

Food was just eh. I was hoping for better so I could come back for brunch. 

Ambiance is awesome though! It's tucked away right on the Cumberland river so it's pretty cool to be at a waterfront restaurant in Nashville. 

Next time I come I'll just do drinks.

The line was long, but the cashiers had everyone moving very quickly, and were friendly and helpful.  
I got a grilled cheese and a bowl of tomato soup.  Both were just....ok.   The tomato soup was just slightly hot, but I didn't mind that.  The grilled cheese was incredibly mediocre.  When I get a grilled cheese, it's to indulge in gooeyness and butter and all things that I know I shouldn't eat, but do when I yearn for comfort food.  This grilled cheese had none of what I was looking for.  It didn't have that oozing out of the side, butter all over the bread making it crisp goodness that I like in a grilled cheese.  It felt like everything was portion-controlled, and designed to maximize profit in the kitchen, and not customer satisfaction.

Despite that, I still wanted to take one home, and was told that my name would be called.  I waited forever, and my name wasn't called.  I peered into the kitchen, and was asked if I had a to go order.   When I said that I did, they got it from some sort of warmer holding station.  So...why take a name if you don't call it.

I can't say I won't be back, because I probably will, although I won't be back as frequently as I would be if they really did serve those gooey messy grilled cheese that I long for.

I ate pizza from here once.

ONCE.

Watch a new movie in a theater with reclining La-Z-Boy type chairs and grub on Italian food?  Yes please!

Stopped in on their official opening day with La Chica to catch The Internship, which was pretty funny, and to get some grub.  First off, the place is extremely nice.  It's been a long time since I've seen a movie in this location, and I don't remember exactly what the old Cobb theater that was here looked like, but it was nothing like this.  What the Villagio folks did here is just beyond comprehension.  The décor is just great. 

To drink, we ordered a bottle of wine.  To eat, we summoned some nachos and a CHICKEN PARM PANINI (see Gigi S's pic).  Damn was it good.  I've eaten a lot of chicken parm from a lot of different places, and this one was up there with the best.  So good, in fact, that their Italian restaurant in Lutz is now on my radar.  If they make a sammich this damn good, I can't imagine what their full menu is like.

Service was good.  Everyone was very friendly.

My only complaints, well more like suggestions... They should have music and info running on the big screen prior to the movie.  You could hear a pin drop in there, which made it odd as all the couples in there were trying to eat and talk without everyone else being in their business.  It was just awkward.  Also, some napkins and eating utensils would have been nice with my meal.

This diner is legit!

I've been looking for the Pinellas county equivalent to Pop 'n Son's since La Chica and I moved to Dunedin and I've found it.  Sure, there is no smart-ass Patsy running around with her Tennessee accent, but Papa's makes up for it with their expansive freaking menu. It goes way beyond breakfast, folks. Sandwiches, burgers, seafood, pasta dinners, steaks, chicken parm--you name it. 

I went with the Pancakes Supreme. 3 pancakes, sausage, bacon, ham and eggs for $9.50. First of all, no one needs 3 damn pancakes, ever. So leaving hungry ain't an option, especially since they're really good. Hands down, best I've had in Pinellas thus far. Bacon is the real deal too. Thick, meaty, center-cut, crunchy and fresh. I actually subbed out the ham for double bacon, but considering how toothsome everything was, it might have been a mistake. 

I am an instant fan, and am chuffed to bits to have discovered this diner.

meh The ex works right next door, so I met up with her for lunch one day about a year ago and I wasn't impressed.  Actually, I take that back; it WAS impressive how much they charged us for a salad, a sandwich and two sodas ($37).  The portions were no larger than what I'd make at home, and nothing about the flavor makes me yearn to go back.

Meet up with a bunch of friend's here for a birthday celebration last night, and it's a pretty cool looking place.  The atmosphere, décor, sunlight lounge with the live music was all very nice.  La Chica and I weren't hungry, so we only ordered some appetizers.  I order the mozzarella boccanccini and La Chica got the steak tartar.  Both had excellent presentation (see pics), but neither were "OMG" good.  They were just average in taste with the steak tartar being slightly better.  We also summoned some white sangria, which was surprisingly cinnamon-free.  A lot of places like to load up their white sangria with that stuff, and it's just not necessary at all, so props to Timpano for that.  But three SMALL glasses of their white sangria will set you back $28, and then throw in the two appetizers and all of a sudden you're spending nearly $50.  A bit steep for food hovering around average in taste.  And that doesn't even include any entrees! 

We had a party of 22, and I asked several people around the table how their food was, and these were their responses: "good," "ok," or "had better."  No one was impressed with anything other than the atmosphere and service.  

Honestly, I don't see ever returning to Timpano.  It would probably cost me and the chica $80 to eat dinner here, and I just don't bank hard enough to blow that much money and HOPE that the food is better than "good," "ok," or "had better."

We formed a gaggle and hit up Kona during the summertime storms this past Sunday to take advantage of the happy hour deals at and around the bar.  Tons of items for $6 and awesome drink specials.  The AVOCADO EGGROLLS and ROASTED CORN and GOAT CHEESE FLATBREADS were the best items we ordered, hands down.  Very tasty!  Lots of people at our table ordered up various sushi rolls, but no one was really amazed.  I personally ordered the gyoza, which places seem content with calling "potstickers," and they were terrible.  I can't even begin to explain all of the flaws, so I won't.  Just don't order them if you're into a traditional type gyoza because you'll be pissed.  

I would definitely go back because there really were a ton of discounted items to choose from, and as Art F. stated below, happy hour is all day, everyday, so long as you're around the bar, either inside or out.

Unless requested, I probably won't go back this pizza/Greek joint.  Nothing was "wrong," per se, but life is too short for average pizza. The look, feel and taste of this pizza was a little too Chuck-e-Cheese-ish for my liking.  For the same price, one can travel a quarter mile north or south down the road and get a better pie for the same price.  Granted, Gondolier's menu is expansive as hell and they offer up a ton of options from Greek to pizza to burgers, but I went there for pizza and it fell short of my expectations--Grande cheese or not.

So we were at The Patio and ran into one of the owners and noticed he was wearing an Outpost shirt.  We asked about it, and he said he had a stake The Outpost as well.  Then, he whipped out his cell phone and showed us a live video stream of what was going on over there, so we decided to hit it up after leaving The Patio.

We weren't really hungry, so we just ordered a Tampa Cheesesteak, which was just a cheesesteak, but served on Cuban bread.  We had them quarter it for us so we could just sample it, and it was damn good.  Why hasn't anyone thought of serving a cheesesteak on Cuban bread sooner?  It came with a side of fries, which were probably some of the most crispy fries I've ever eaten.  Delicious.

We also got some Korean BBQ chicken wings.  They were excellent in taste, but could have been a little crispier.  Maybe coat them in whatever those fries were coated in.

Only downer was that they didn't have a full liquor bar, beer and wine only.

Will definitely go back though.  I'm interested in the Cuban burger, which is basically a Cuban sammich with all the traditional fixins, plus a freaking burger patty.  I gotta have it.

Been here twice, and wasn't wowed either time. The breakfast was... well... BREAKFAST. I mean, it's kind of hard to screw up breakfast. Personally, I set the bar high because I like my own morning cooking the best, so I only get out to a restaurant on lazy Sundays. And when I do, I'm not usually swept off of my feet, so take my 2 stars with a grain of salt.

Pancakes are the exception to the 'breakfast is breakfast' rule. Cracker Barrel... Horrible pancakes. IHOP... Decent pancakes. Pop N Son's... Absolutely amazing pancakes.

Anywho, back to Nicki's...

The service was good both times I visited and the prices were reasonable.

Not too much else to say. It's not like they have some mind-blowing menu items that are unique to the establishment.
