Slyce's pies are not half bad for beach pizza, which has a terrible reputation for being hum-drum.  Do they use the best ingredients, freshest toppings and have a crazy innovative menu?  Not really.  Do they cook their pizzas on a screen, depriving them of that desirable crunchy crust?  Yes.  But they deliver directly to the beach, folks.  And on a hot, beer-laden day under the sun, that is all that really matters.

This past Independence Day weekend, we ordered a cheese pie, as well as a Hawaiian.  The Hawaiian has never been one of my faves, but they did throw macadamia nuts on theirs, which added a welcomed crunchy texture.  Still though, I preferred the plain cheese pizza.  I really like to keep it simple.  When adding melted cheese to cooked tomatoes and dough, there really isn't much of a need to do anything else.

Though I wasn't completely wowed, I would most definitely order from them again.

I've been to a lot of Capogiro and it's true that they are all different, this little gem included. In all of its South Philly charm, it's basically a house with a storefront and counter. My visit had some of my favorite Capogiro flavors, and sitting in the creaky house made the atmosphere for me. I ultimately decided on cappuccino and burnt sugar, but the selection was pretty great and hard to choose from! I'd hate to see what the place looks like when it's crowded since there isn't a lot of space to manage a lot of people.

I've been here a few times for family gatherings, and the most recent was during this pandemic! Our table of 8 dined indoors in a nearly empty dining room, which is a little weird considering this place is usually filled to the brim in different public health times. We wore masks when not at the table, though I felt a little weird not wearing a mask when giving my order to the waitstaff.

A family favorite is definitely the seafood tower! It's so much food all served cold, but it's so worth the price. The filet mignon is cooked perfectly no matter what temperature you get, the side portions are huge so plan on sharing, and do not leave without getting the creme brulee! I'm serious. Listen I know you're like "But I'm so full" but I cannot tell you the last time I had such a good creme brulee. But you might have to dine in for that so maybe wait a little.

I probably won't be back here until after the pandemic is over, but any way to help out this amazing business so that we can make sure that happens would be great!

Everything here was insanely delicious. Point blank period. How haven't I heard more people rave about this place?

The entrance is a little dinky but the actual dining room is adequately elegant for the neighborhood and the chairs were pretty comfortable. The service staff were great, and I don't think I ever had an empty water glass. There's nothing like eating dinner and you haven't had water in a half hour and the waiter is MIA so good work 

We ordered the chicken 65 to start, which has to be the some of the best fried chicken I've ever had. It was the perfect level of spice and it came with some fun sauces, but eating it plain was plenty. I got some lamb dish and my boyfriend got some salmon dish that of course I can't remember now, but they were both delicious and I would eat them both again in a heartbeat.

Our dessert may have been the Karma Delight? It was fried bread with banana and ice cream, and if you can't figure out that that was good, then obviously you're on the keto diet.

In all seriousness, this was one of the better places I've been to in the past few months and how there isn't more buzz about this place is beyond me.

We use to love this place. I'm so so upset to say that they have gone to shit. The service has gotten so much worse and it wasn't great to start. Now they have become so nasty about the food. Many people have food allergies. I asked to have one vegetable taken out and the kitchen acted as if I was asking for the moon. I also asked for some sautéed onions. That is also IMPOSSIBLE according to them. These are the exact onions that they have prepped to go under the chicken on a hot plate. I was happy to pay the up-charge but they refused. They told me it is to much work. Please tell me how cooking off some onions is to much work for a restaurant??

Sliced pork was lacking flavor, smoked sausage tasted like an Erhlich's polish or something from Winn-Dixie.  Only one sauce on the table, might as well have been any generic bottled sauce off the shelf.  

Mac+Cheese just okay, hush puppies the same.  

Friendly service.

Ugh. I ordered the jambalaya and wife the spicy chicken sandwich.  Just like on triple D's.
I also ordered the charbroiled oysters too. 

Maybe the hype from the show gave over the top expectations but the food was just ok. My wife said the chicken sandwich was ok and she might like the chickfila spicy sandwich better. I tasted it and in fact she might be right. Just kind of bland spicy taste. 
Oysters were good but it was missing something. I love oysters from Drago in New Orleans and these weren't quite charbroiled as I like and greens that were on it was over powering the taste of oysters. Just not my thing and little disappointed. 

That being said, I'm not saying you should go. Just didn't meet the hype of Triple D's show. Hence 3 stars. 

Service was good and like the atmosphere.

I used to visit SATCO more regularly when I lived in Nashville, but now that I live in Franklin, I don't go out of my way to eat here unless meeting up with a friend. Decent food at a decent price. A great place to hang on the patio on a nice day.

Pro's: Large patio, good location, ability to customize your order (i.e. "build your own taco" with the sheets where you circle the meat and toppings you want), line moves fairly quickly.

Con's: Food can be hit or miss

I'm not a big fan of hot dogs, so when my wife suggested it, I was a little bummed out, but I need to make her happy...LOL. Surprisingly, it was delicious and filling. I wanted to order the Cincinnati skyline, but since my wife was ordering it, she told me to order something else. So, I order the surf and turf dog...again to make her happy. Oh, the things I do for her.

Philly Surf N Turf - Fried fish with a hot dog. Huge and extremly filling. Fish was large and flaky, but lacked a lil bit of flavor.

Cincinnati Skyline - I wish I stuck with my gut and ordered this. Packed with tons of flavor. I'm not huge on scallions, but this hotdog did it well. The melted cheese with the gooey chili was great! 

Fries - really good and tasted fresh. I tried it with siracha ketchup. Nothing special regarding the sauce. I make this at home.

Overall: I would definately be back even though I'm not a hot dog kind of guy. Price isn't bad for how filled you get from one dog.

If you want chinese and ok with searching around forever for parking, this is your spot! Food always comes out hot and delicious. Customer service is hit or miss. I don't really expect amazing customer service at places like this though.

My favorite items here are:
Salt and pepper chicken wings - so crispy, yet so moist.

Sizzling Pepper Steak - This can be a hit or miss. Seasoning is always spot on, but sometimes the meat they give can be very fatty. If you really like peppers and onions, they also give you tons of it. My wife eats the veggies and I eat the meat. :-)

Salt and pepper pork chops - deep fried pork chops in the same seasoning as the wings. What can go wrong?

Beef chow fun w/gravy - Flat noodles in a brown gravy sauce with veggies. So good! I like the gravy one because it isn't as greasy as the normal beef chow fun which is stir fried.

They also have a bar if you want to drink. Not exactly sure how well the prices are for the alcohol (I've never had it before), but if you are in need of a drink, you can get one.

Overall: I keep coming back because they are fast and good. Come here. You won't be dissappointed.
The burgers are good, but does not live up to those standards. The atmosphere is basically a family setting, where you just find a seat. It is a good place for a quick lunch or hang out with friends.

I hit this place up for lunch every once in a while. The food is good but a touch overpriced for the lunchtime crown in Center City East. The salads as enormous and the ALT (Avocado Lettuce and Tomato) sandwich is great. It's the perfect amount of food. I have not been here for dinner or drinks but their fresh blackberry lemonade is the perfect blend of tart and tangy to wet your whistle.

It's really loud in this place during lunch - not the type of place where you want to have a good conversation. 

They have pretty good Matzo Ball Soup, but cross the street if you want the best.  ;)

Acropolis is really just... Average. I sometimes think most people go for the gimmicks - dancers on the weekend, the Greek dance the waitstaff does (plus the occasional drunk customer), and napkin confetti. They're not usually busy during the day from my past experiences, but it still can have a bit of a wait for food.

I used to swing by on certain nights when a friend of mine was dancing, but after she left the area I really didn't have a reason. After the dirty dining shitshow a while back I actively avoided it. I found myself there recently though. 

I had a waitress who was nice, but not especially good. It took a while to get things (including change for a dollar to feed the meter) and she wasn't really good at thinking outside the box with my lunch mate's request. As with all of my previous experiences, my lunch (a salad) was average. Nothing really stood out, but I was hungry and I could put it in my facehole. 

I find it interesting that people always seem to send tourists/out of towers here. I'm not really sure I would consider it "one of those places" but maybe it's the superfluous crap that draws them in (or gives people a reason to suggest it).
Delicious meal - I had the short rib fettuccini. Nice atmosphere. Brought over a bottle from the Chadds Ford Winery since it's BYOB. Good service. I liked the lights they had outside of the building.

Wow. Incredible experience. Delicious food, service that wowed, and a broad selection of tasty wines. I had this dish I can't name with chicken and crab. Wow. I can't wait to come back. Everything about this experience was amazing!!

I stopped by and picked the 10 piece meal this Saturday night for my husband and I. Friendly staff, but yucky food! The chicken tenders tasted like they had soap in them, the rice tasted bad! The biscuit was okay,  but never again,  I rather go to KFC!

Do NOT eat here !   Go to Tony's a block away.   Everything was burnt. Overdone. No taste. Poor quality and misrepresented USDA rating.   This place fraudulently advertises that certain steaks are USDA prime and did not provide a bone in filet that was usda prime.  Terribly prepared.  Terrible taste.  Dry. Poor quality 

The Managment does not want anyone to know the truth of their poor standards    

Don't be fooled by this restaurant.  In the past it may hsve been good  Not any more !  Stay away

I think this location just needs more time to pull it together. My order was missing one shake and the other was the wrong flavor. It was very busy and i never got the shake corrected. It was a little chaotic. The cheese fries were delicious. The burgers were a little under seasoned and a very small trace of the shack sauce. Maybe try it again in a few months.

The entire time while I was eating the sandwich, I kept thinking to myself, "I don't understand what all the hype is about with this muffuletta!" It was premade ready, cold, and although the olive salad was good, it was a bit too salty. This is definitely not a place you should go for an absolute "must try". Not to mention, with that price, I would prefer a poboy.

What's a butter burger?? I made it my mission to find out.  

Visited on 6-17-17 around 12PM. $22.21 got us a kids meal, a single butter burger combo, a mushroom and Swiss burger, a small drink, a turtle sundae, and a single scoop of chocolate custard. 

The employees here are extremely friendly. Like scary friendly. Like they're hostages and you're a crazed maniac and they're trying not to piss you off and get shot in the face.  

I got the  $6.59 single butter burger basket which came with fries and a drink.  The burger had onions even tho I asked for no onions but it wasn't a big deal...I just picked them off. The meat patty was thick and juicy and had so much beefy flavor! It tastes like the most delicious organic grass-fed beef you've ever had. I give this burger two thumbs up. They have crinkle fries too which are my all time favorite!

The custard was chocolatey and silky and luxurious. I found myself wanting to lick the container when it was all gone. 

I gotta say I think I prefer Freddy's but I did enjoy my first trip to a Culver's and I'll be back!

This was our third time attempting to eat here and this time we actually got food. Wish I could say third time's a charm. 

The first time we came they told us it would be a 30 minute wait. After an hour we gave up and left. The second time we sat at the table for 23 minutes and a server never came so we got up and left. Our most recent trip on 4-21-19 at 1PM we succeeded in getting served food.  $44.38 got us two adult entrees and a kid's meal. Our server Robert was pleasant and efficient. 

I had the $18.90 lobster tail which came with two sides. I chose broccoli and added a side salad for a $2 up-charge. The salad was a little sloppy looking and the dressing was tossed very lazily. Some lettuce was naked and some was drenched. An easy fix but noteworthy. The lobster tail was fantastic- really big, tender, juicy, and perfectly cooked. The broccoli was completely raw which was disappointing. It was literally about half a head of raw broccoli thrown onto the plate. I didn't complain because I mean....I eat raw broccoli and like it...just wasn't expecting it I guess. 

There will not be a 4th attempt. Not worth it.

Visited on 5/26/17 around 7PM.  When you enter the restaurant you choose whether you'd like to be seated at a regular table and have items brought to you or you can sit around a communal hibachi table.  Either way, it was $17.95 per adult.  My-- two-year-old was free.  There is a "no waste" policy....you'll get charged extra for anything you leave on your plate but you're allowed to take it with you.  

The restaurant itself was pretty nice....it had traditional Japanese decor and was fairly clean.  I like their yellow swirly tables and they had nice restrooms.  Well....the girls room anyhow...I'm not allowed in the boy's room.  

They have tons of items on the menu ranging from cooked foods to sushi to soups and desserts.  Here's a list of what I tried: 

*Edamame- Pods were on the smallish side but they were fresh and bright green.  The pods were perfectly steamed and nicely salted.  I enjoyed these. 

*Crab rangoons- These were the "purse" variety where the filling is placed inside the wonton wrapper and the edges are folded up.  The wrapper was very thin and crispy.  The filling was tasty and smooth and savory.  Be sure to get an order of these if you go.  
 
*Chicken in garlic sauce- This menu item should be called "huge slices of bell pepper and some tiny chunks of chicken".  The chicken was like what you'd find in a Lean Cuisine...mushy and I wonder what part of the chicken it came from.  The sauce had good flavor, however, and the bell peppers were still nice and crunchy...I like it when they are lightly sauteed like that. 

*Singapore noodles- Probably my favorite thing I ate there.  The noodles were plentiful and well seasoned...with just a hint of curry and chock full of tasty veggies.  I wish I had a bowl of this right now.  

*fruit cup sushi- By far the weirdest concoction I've ever seen at a sushi joint.  It was chopped mangoes and strawberries on a bed of sushi rice wrapped in nori.  I could not stomach eating fruit and seaweed together so I tore it off and the result was much like Thai mango sticky rice.  It was not torturous but I would not order it again.  I really only ordered it out of curiosity.  

*Coconut shrimp- By the menu description I expected the big butterfly type shrimp with hunks of coconut in the batter but they were more asian style...small shrimp with the tails removed then dunked in batter, deep fried, and then smothered in sweet mayo.  I really wish the mayo had been on the side cuz' I hate mayo.  I didn't want to get charged extra so I choked it down.  *shivers* 

*Vanilla ice cream- must have been good because my mini-me devoured it and didn't even offer me a bite.  The fried dough balls were fresh and coated in sugar although tiny in comparison to the kind you usually find at chinese buffets.  

Next time I'd definitely try the hibachi side...I loves me some onion volcanoes.  I think this would be a great value if you were into sushi as well.

I like this place for date nights, they don't have high chairs so it's a great excuse to get a babysitter and enjoy alone time with my husband. I also took some friend here who were visiting from out of town and they loved it. 
Having been there a few ties now I've pretty much ate my way through the entire menu and I would recommend the chicken rotissarie. It comes with spicy potatoes and yummy salsas to try. This is a sharing platter but if you are feeling hungry get a couple of sides too. The cauliflower is so goooood. Usually I hate the stuff but here it is cooked to perfection with loads of garlic and cilantro. 
Always get the churros. They will offer dessert after your meal, even if you are full, get them to share. It's only three donut sticks of delight. Yum.

There is an enormous selection of omelettes - veggie, seafood, just about any meat; "country style" with home fries rolled in; pancakes, waffles, French toast; healthy choices; dieters specials; oh yeah, Potato Pancakes - awesome!!!
If you don't see it, ask for it!  Enjoy!

A-OK about sums it up for Maggie's.  Which is fine for a bar.  I have not eaten here yet.  I have only been here a few late Thursday nights in a row for some drinks with a couple friends and we like it.  Good prices for draft beers.  40+ beers on tap, plus a full fridge of bottles.  Also bottles on ice.  Kitchen is open til midnight. On a weeknight! I have seen other people at the bar order food and it looks good.  Open Mic til 1am.  Real musicians (guitars) playing til 1am.  So far, it's been crowded until closing. Mixed young and old crowd, me being among the old.  Bartenders are attentive and friendly.  It IS very tight around the bar and I haven't decided if this is good or bad yet.  Men's room has a trough urinal, which I don't like, usually filled with ice.  I understand they have recently made the inside larger and are putting an outside deck on the roof overlooking the Delaware River. Could be nice in the warmer months.  I may change my review if I ever get to eat here.

We arrived on a red eye flight and our room wasn't ready so the concierge at the Sofitel suggested we try Marathon for breakfast while we waited. 

We both had the Benedict with ham. I subbed the home fries for a fruit bowl ($1.50 upcharge). It was well done.

Coffee was freshly brewed and flavorful.

Average food quality, only thing famous about this is that it was showcased on You've gotta eat here. It was very busy when we were there, Parking is not that best especially if you are trying to avoid getting a ticket. Our favourite part was the cinnamon bun as that is all that my boyfriend remembers about his visit.

The food here is less than good. The beef sticks were so chewy and spiced with very weird spice that was inedible. The general tsos chicken sauce seemed like it came out of a jar and they mixed it with sweet and sour. It also had the same odd taste that the beef sticks had. I gave it two stars vs one because they were friendly and it was clean

Tsuki Sushi operates both as a restaurant but probably is best known as a delivery service (you can order through multiple outlets such as GrubHub, Yelp, etc.). As you can probably see, reviews vary from both the delivery and dine-in standpoint. I will weigh in on both below.

Delivery (Ordered through GrubHub):
I am very impressed with the GrubHub delivery option that Tsuki Sushi has to offer. The pricing as well and the quality of the food is very competitive with other sushi joints across the neighborhood. I challenge you to find a 3 roll special for the price that Tsuki offers that ALSO has a good fish:rice ratio. Delivery is relatively prompt. I have ordered Tuski over 20 times and they have arrived before the estimated GrubHub time by up to half an hour for a great majority of orders. They have only been late once. (Note: I live in the graduate hospital area.) The sushi arrives fresh and is tasty. As other reviewers note, not all of the deliverymen speak English well, but enough to communicate directions and receive your order without any issues. 

Dine In:
My 2 dine-in experiences with Tsuki were also quite good. I went on weekend evenings both days and there were probably 1-2 other tables occupied when I arrived. Note that the restaurant is small, totaling probably fewer than 10 tables overall. The staff is polite and the sushi just as fresh and tasty as the delivery option. The only thing I will say is that do not be surprised that your sushi takes longer than you would expect for an "empty" restaurant. It is likely that your dine-in order is queued with all of the take out orders.

Overall, Tsuki Sushi offers quality sushi in the low-mid price range. If you are looking for exceptional cuts of fish or are a sushi connoisseur, you will probably be disappointed. However, if you're the average person looking to satisfy a sushi fix, I highly suggest you try this restaurant.
Damn this place is pretty run down...it smelled pretty musty too. I wish I could say something nice about this place. I guess the ushers were nice?

Here's the thing...I want so badly to give this place 5 stars. I would give it 4.5 if I could but you know how that is. I love the food, I loved the drinks when I drank and I love the staff. The thing is the first time I came here I was an out of towner. I was an out of stater to be honest. I think maybe it showed and the girl working there didn't seem so friendly. We talked a little bit but something seemed off. I had the bacon Mac and cheese and some good beers so the food and drink were 5 stars I was just a little annoyed by the service. Well a month later I moved to philly and came back. I got the same girl as a bartender and put my best foot forward to be friendly and it paid off. Probably also helped that I was now a "local." Every time I've gone since no matter who's working I have a great time! The draft selection is pretty nice and the can/bottle selection is pretty extensive. I had the shrimp etouffe and it was AMAZING. I will admit the menu is sort of small but it works for me. I love this place and my stomach is growing just thinking about that etouffe!

The Hooters Restaurant in Fairview Heights has set a new low, and after reaching rock bottom, has begun to dig. How hard is it to cook an unbreaded, well done chicken wing? Apparently for the kitchen staff at the Fairview Heights Hooters, it's an insurmountable task. For the third time in as many visits, they have failed to cook my requested dish of chicken wings the way I requested them to be cooked. One would think that Hooters could manage to cook an order of their SIGNATURE DISH properly, but that would not be the case. Each time I have visited Hooters, I have ordered the same thing--unbreaded well-done wings. Each time the same thing has happened--the first order of wings (after a 20 minute wait) comes out with breading, and then the second time (after sending the first order back because I ordered them naked since I don't like greasy fried breading) after I make the identical order, I receive unbreaded and UNDERCOOKED wings. Each time I waited FORTY MINUTES and left without getting anything to eat. I cannot put into words how incompetent the waitstaff or the kitchen or both has to be in order to screw up the IDENTICAL order TWICE IN A ROW on the same visit and have this happen on THREE SEPARATE VISITS IN A ROW. I have never seen such incompetence at any restaurant IN MY LIFE and for this to happen REPEATEDLY on THREE SEPARATE VISITS is simply beyond the pale. Chicken wings are Hooter's SIGNATURE DISH. If they can do nothing else, they SHOULD be able to manage to cook a batch of unbreaded well-done wings yet they have failed to do this SIX CONSECUTIVE TIMES. It's not a complicated thing and if they can't master something this simple, then they should really close the restaurant and try something they could succeed at doing--such as playing with their lower lips or walking and chewing gum at the same time. I will NEVER go back to Hooters again--I don't know if their wings are good or bad because I've never gotten to eat any of them. So, to the siliconed and nubile waitstaff I offer this advice: Write down the order and to the imbecile in the do-rag I advise him to READ the order. This could possibly result in my actually getting something to eat although I'm not holding my breath.

Always reliable when I'm on the road, this one makes a good breakfast and the bacon is great. I don't like the sausage as much here because to me it's like a ground ham patty. I'll take Jimmy Dean's sausage.  The Sunday fried chicken is delicious and the turnip greens, green beans and corn are great along with the cornbread and biscuits. Cracker Barrel is reliable and solid country fare.
Fat Salmon is ok sushi.  Its run of the mill.  Not bad, not great, just kinda there.

We ordered the Ma Po tofu and Water Boiled Fish. The Ma Po  tofu had an odd taste and it was so spicy my tongue was tingling. I have had spicy food but this was too spicy. The dish was so red and oily I could not eat it. The water boiled fish came in a large bowl and the sauce was the same. If I scrapped off the chili and ate it with a lot of rice it was tolerable. We didn't take the left overs and left most of the food. The restaurant was clean and well lit and the service was good. Not my type of food but there were many other dishes on the menu.

We went on more than a few recommendations so we were disappointed when most of our fish was overcooked.  We ordered the octopus, shrimp, and smelts.  It was really unfortunate because the hummus was wonderful and the service was fantastic.  Its so cozy in there and they don't rush you even though there is generally a wait.  It may have been an off night but there are really too many other places to try so we most likely won't go back.

I have to admit that I pulled my hat brim low over my eyes as I entered the Factory to pick up a white chocolate raspberry truffle cheesecake as my contribution to Thanksgiving this year. A Thanksgiving with no dishes, sleeping late, and satisfaction from the "wow" factor all played into my decision. I ordered the night before, but still waited about 15 minutes for the cake which was, by the way, delicious. Be prepared for sticker shock, though. A 10" will set you back $50. The cheesecakes are shipped frozen, and oddly pre-sliced with wax paper between each slice. Not that I would have tried to pass off the cake as homemade, but the stiff paper garnish sticking up not only threatens a paper cut, but also screams "I am glopped out from a big metal robot machine in an uncaring, impersonal mass production facility." Who am I to sling a hammer at Big Brother, when everyone at dinner sang its processed praises?

Hipster heaven,  music hotspot, gallery, bakery, coffee bar, cocktail den...Passe manages to wear its many hats with cool flair. My bloody mary was more like a salad and sported a huge pickle generously sprinkled with the house spice and fat with jalapeno stuffed olives. The beer list was apparently compiled by a trappist physicist. Towheaded toddlers were wrestling quietly in front of the quaint little stage where Tom Wahlbank was crooning free (!) blues to a packed house of ducktailed scenesters, conversed boarders, natty grad students, and European tourists. The service is swift and seamlessly invisible as the staff maneuvers the tight rooms to drop off begs and acon, fresh salads, smoothies, Mexican ice water, etc. People watching here is like a mash-up of Truffault, Monty Python, and the Harlem Shake. A Stetson-wearing craggy Clint Eastwood-like cowboy strolled in wearing a rodeo duster, spurs jangling, just as we were leaving. Next time, I'm sampling the mythical grilled PBJ.

I want to love this cozy little kitsch Midtown cottage. Polish food is simple by nature, hearty and fresh with a focus on potatoes, apples, and sausage, etc. I probably should have ordered pierogies, but my kielbasa was dry and lukewarm. It needs to pop when opened. Mine sighed.The fries were blanched and undercooked, sparse to the point that I pictured myself in a kulak (Polish work farm). The vodka with apple juice was sweet and mild. I've been here a few times over the years, but next time it's pierogies only.

The B-Line is A-List all the way. It ranks at the top of my Fourth Avenue dining choices because of the catfish burrito. The white, flaky saltiness of the fish is offset by sweet red cabbage. Flavor fest! I believe that restaurants with menus written in colored chalk are somehow healthier than restaurants with printed menus. The flexibility of chalk menus means that the cooks can take advantage of fresh ingredients as they become available instead of working slavishly to make an offering work when it's out of season. The barstools along the front window offer prime Fourth Ave menagerie viewing, the service is efficient and friendly, and vegetarian choices are plentiful. I nipped a star only because I would like to see B-Line stay open later!

I heard Bob Dobb's had gotten a little facelift, and we checked it out for happy hour this week. Besides the lack of restroom poetry, it was the same diehard U of A fringe old school hangout. We might or might not have brought a sharpie. I love that these guys welcome pooches, and the food is always tasty although greasy. My partner gave our server a twenty to settle up, though, and she never came back. We asked another server, and she said our total was $21.87. The other server had just taken off with our cash, and the second one didn't seem at all surprised. She had already charged our card with the full total again, and had to reverse the charge. Hmmm, a little shady.

Imperial Inn?  Try Indifferent Inn!  Went for Dim Sum for lunch.  Big mistake.  Maybe the carts circulate more on busy Sundays, but during the week the place was more than half empty, the carts were sparse and the staff took to covering the carts with towels to keep the tepid dim sum....well...even more tepid.

The service was awful.  I asked three times for vinegar for dipping before receiving a plate placed on the table with extreme annoyance.  The shumai were gummy and luke warm at best.

The entire experience was awful.
Not anything to write home about. Chips and salsa was just salsa you get thick and chunky at a store. Salad was nothing exciting.

Got there just in time for HH on a Thursday  and ordered my favorite, which is pretty much any white wine and the bartender told me they were completely out of all of their white wine...WTH?? I was so annoyed that I wanted to leave but my husband wanted to stay so he just ordered a beer and we ordered dinner. We were seated outside (our preference), the food was good, I got the Southern Fried chicken sandwich,  he got the meatloaf. Our waiter didn't hover but checked on us from time to time which was good. If I hadn't wanted a glass of white wine during my visit I would have given them 4 stars but since I did want a glass of white wine and they had none, they get 3 stars.

I was sold after hearing they give you a glass of wine on Wednesdays. This place is awesome...the variety, the atmosphere, the staff, the free glass of wine, and oh the yuumy pizza...I'll definitely be returning!

Jack's always seems to rock. The staff is always kind and considerate. Food is good to go.

From the simple breakfast oatmeal to the breakfast burrito choices (5 total) all yummy! Plenty of egg choices any way you like. All the side choices too have you covered.

Lox, lite cream cheese, toasted onion bagel, lots of fresh squeezed lemon juice, thin sliced red onion. cYaL8R. All perfect.

The lox are the very best: Cambridge House of SB. The finest smoked salmon on the West Coast. An old family smoking recipe-method from jolly old England. Fit for the Royal Family. Yes true. As you can see we do endorse the lox here. Plus you can grab a package of lox to take home if you like. Why not! Grab a cheese with jalapeño bagel, or any of the greats, multi-grain power, egg, plain, poppy seed, bialy, they have them all, fresh every morning to go as needed. Get there early, they do run out. The cinnamon raisin if a big fave at our table breaking bagels.

Lunch... two giant menu pages of lunch offerings. Sandwiches, paninis, wraps, salads, soups, burgers, yes beer and wine! Good Peet's coffee choices too!

The tables out front and the patio fill up fast, go early no waiting. Otherwise you may have to hang out for a bit.

On the patio, dog friendly is real nice, great for our Little Pup Lionel, he gets to have a breakfast bonus snack at times. They do serve the best water in Carpinteria for our furry friends as needed.

They cater as well! As partially listed above, the bagel choices are the bomb, off the chain, killer bagels. Bagelwiches to boot. If you love bagels you know Jack's.

They do not serve dinner, they close at 3pm. The mini location on Milpas has plenty of bagels as well.

Ya gotta love Jack's for keeping great bagels, breakfast and lunch alive in Carp and SB. Enjoy. Splurge! :~*}

Good food, delicious coffee...but the staff could use more training....they seemed young and out of their league when it came to dealing with crowds, plus a smile couldn't hurt, most of the staff looked miserable!  Poor service can really ruin a meal, no matter how good the food is!  Its just too bad that that management of this establishment doesn't get it!

Very disappointing...
The service was surly, the food was meh and the margarita was nothing special. I was expecting more from this resort restaurant. We'll never eat here again, nor will we recommend it to our friends.

Ok, did my usual stop after dropping the kids at wrestling. I usually get hummus from the Costco near them and get fries to dip as a snack for the two little ones. I decided to get some fresh hummus  and pita. 

The hummus and Pita was good. The fries on the other hand were definite double dipped (in oil). It is a real pet peeve of mine that food places cook too many fries, they sit in the heat lamp or basket, then 2 or 3 hours later, I order fries and they dunk The old fries in hot oil to "refresh" them. Yes, it saves the owner from tossing them and wasting, but @ $4.50 for fries, I would like the courtesy of consistent and fresh fries. I went back and the worker was happy to exchange them. 

I really like this place and won't let it stop me from our weekly snack run, but now I have to specifically ask for fresh. It was inconvenient to have to return and wait. I shouldn't have to do that. 

Finally take a look at the pics and you can see the bad fries buried under a layer of some less older-yet still old fries. I added a pic of the replacement fried. Perfect!

Every meal that I have at the demun oyster bar is a great experience-From the ambience, warmth, and fabulous staff, to the exceptional attention to every detail, with cuisine that is extremely fresh and delicious!  The oyster stew has become one of my standards on every visit and the pasta with seafood is phenomenal!  This restaurant and bar has become one of my favorites and gets regular visits... There's no where in St. Louis where you can get fresher oysters or better seafood!!!!

This is one of my favorite places to go after a long day for a relaxing and delicious meal!  The owner takes great pride and he's warm and engaging.  The atmosphere is lively and very comfortable; The food is always delicious!  Whether you order ribs or street tacos, or something else from the menu, everything is prepared with great love and attention to detail.  The food is just so very tasty and there's a great selection of beers and other drink options.
The combination platter allows you to try the street tacos, the ribs, and a side, and it's a great option for a first visit!!
Everything is prepared beautifully and you will be sure to return for great food and an atmosphere that is so very comfortable and relaxing!!

Go for the tots, stay for the drinks!  The tots melt in your mouth and the burgers come with butter lettuce.  Yeah, you heard that right, butter.  Oh and the drinks, don't get me started.  Strong and tasty, no matter what you order, it's sure to satisfy your thirst.  Best time to go is mid-afternoon; otherwise, you could end up waiting for an eternity.

Hands down, best happy hour in the city.  Why?  It's seriously a no-brainer.  First of all, they have the best food specials in town, for a happy hour.  Four dollars will get you a gigantic bowl of shrimp fried rice.  Two dollars actually goes rather far here, and I usually stuff my face with a gourmet hot dog or Kobe beef slider.  I can also drink my face off with glasses of house red at $4 a pop.  I always leave here feeling slightly tipsy and full, but not the type of full that makes me want to go home and take a nap.  Oh and they have happy hour on Saturday too.  #winning!

I've stopped in a couple times for bagels and coffee. This place is always busy and it seems they have a newish system for managing orders in that they give you a card and call your card when your order is ready. A good idea, however, please check your order before you leave. I got all the way home to find out they only gave me one bagel instead of the two I paid for. We went back and they gave us the bagel, but it was an inconvenience.

Service is no frills, which is par for the course in Philly. The bagels are good and they have a variety of cream cheese flavors. I don't go out of my way to go here, but it's a nice option when I'm hungry and in the immediate area.

If I lived in this neighborhood, I'd be here every day.  The beer selection is overwhelming, which is a good thing if you're a beer connoisseur.  I liked how they had all the seasonal beers in their own section.  Looking at all of the pumpkin beer options at once is easier than trying to locate them separately.  

Aside from the generous spiked soda section, they have a plethora of sandwich and panini options.  One sandwich filled me right up and it was tasty and made right on the spot.  

The space actually looks deceiving from the outside, as it's rather large inside.  A back room for sitting/doing work, an upstairs for chilling/eating or you can sit by the front window and watch passersby on Girard Ave.  

Great addition to an area of the city that is still up-and-coming.  I really hope Rybrew is here to stay.

This is one of those places that really makes you wish that 0 stars (or even negative stars) was an option.  Of all the Steak 'n Shake locations I've visited over the years on multiple states, this location was THE absolute worst service of any of them.  A group of 11 us walked in at around 9:25 this evening, and when we saw the look of derision on the shift manager's face, that should have been the first sign that it would've been best to turn around and walk out.  There were 3 people seated in the restaurant, but yet every other table was dirty.  We were told that they would seat us when they cleaned off some tables.  The second sign that this place was bad was when they didn't bother to use the usual plastic bin to bus the tables.  Nope, that would have been far too pedestrian.  Instead, two of the employees (there were many others who were standing around, which will be discussed in sign three) thought it would be far more efficient to carry two or three glasses at a time.   While these two employees are moving at a snail's pace, the shift manager and what appeared to be a cook stood in the cash register area chatting something about Murfreesboro as the shift manager continued to look totally disgusted by our presence.  We were all a bit perplexed as to why the shift manager didn't seem motivated enough to go out and help her staff clean off the numerous dirty tables in the dining room or why she didn't see fit to tell the other employees (who were standing around and talking about some cute boy while watching the other two bus the tables two or three glasses at a time) to get busy and help.   After standing there for 20+ minutes, our group decided to take our business elsewhere, and only after we began walking out did anyone bother to speak to us.  Needless to say, we kept on walking and are very happy that we did.

I used to love going to this place, however it has recently been degraded to a low quality sushi buffet. Their sushi selection is quite limited and doesn't offer any of the higher quality special rolls such as Dragon or Spider. The restaurant does offer shabu shabu and some hot soups. The highlight would be their nigirizushi and sashimi. Although not the freshest, these two items make the meal tolerable. They also got rid of their froyo machine and replaced it with ice cream.

came here for a girls night with some BYOB wine and sushi!

super cute restaurant and very attentive servers. made a reservation through opentable and was seated right away. 

we started with some shishito peppers, vegetable dumplings and edamame beans. shishito peppers were very plentiful and vegetable dumplings were cooked well!

we got 5 rolls to split, philly roll, school of rock, incredible hulk, fiddler and another roll i don't remember BUT all of them were amazing! such beautiful presentation, great flavors and fresh fish. my personal favorite was the school of rock roll.

i'll definitely come back here, loved the rolls and the fact it was BYOB!

came here for lunch and had a great meal!

it was a little bit empty but it's also a HUGE restaurant. as time went on, more patrons came in.

we started with the butternut squash soup, which didn't look like it sounded but it was yummy! it was a clear broth with vegetables and some chicken. i would have preferred some tom yum but it was still yummy

then we ordered the roti which isn't on the lunch menu but it's so delicious it's a must! they gave a decent quantity of roti with curry which i appreciated. perfect portion for 2 people

my friend and i split the shrimp pad see ew and the red curry. both were cooked very well and had great flavors. i wanted a little bit more for the price (especially the curry) but they are lunch portions so i would hope the dinner is bigger.

all in all, the service was great and the food was delicious! i'll def be back to try out their HH specials

Ordered pick up and was pleasantly surprised.

I read a review on here that they had the best cheeseburger and I'll have to disagree. The burger was really dry and thick but not enough cheese to meat ratio.

The wings, onion rings and fries were good but they forgot my mozzarella sticks! Fortunately I live close so I came by to pick up my sticks but nothing worse than being charged for something you didn't receive.

E Mei to me is a cheaper but same quality version as Han Dynasty.

I haven't tried Dan Dan yet but this place to me was decent. Price and portion match and one thing about Han Dynasty that I dislike is how salty the food is. I understand how it's difficult to have something heavily seasoned and spicy without salt but to me, Han Dynasty is super heavy on the salt.

I asked E Mei to lightly salt my dishes and I'm glad I did!

The Dan Dan noodles here are quite spicy. They didn't really ask me about the spice level I wanted for these. The noodles I wasn't a fan of; super thin and definitely not hand made. I won't be ordering these again.

The spicy hot fish hot pot was my favorite. The fish was well seasoned, not big pieces but enough for 2 people. I also enjoyed the amount of bean sprouts that were in the dish but I didn't really care for the glass noodles.

The dry hot pot chicken was also good, little pieces but seasoned and fried very well.  

The mapo tofu was OK, i like my soft tofu to be way more fresh but it was still delicious and i asked them not to make this that spicy which i enjoyed since all of our dishes were very spicy.

All in all, I like this place way better than Han Dynasty; lower prices, less salty and same quality as Han
I wanted to confirm that I have found good pizza and this is a fair review of the establishment based on their pizza. I never returned to try other things on the menu.

Okay food. Terrible customer service. Brought my family in who are visiting and it was embarrassing how rude the lady was behind the register. From what I was able to gather, everyone looked like they hated their job. What happened to good customer service?! I think I'll go elsewhere next time.

I've given this two stars because the food is edible and it was all cooked properly, although it's not a pleasant experience and not somewhere I would return.

Bright interior space and freshly painted walls give a great impression when you first walk in...unfortunatley, that's the last good experience you'll have

The staff is clueless and walking around frantically, but no one knows what anyone is doing.  There were 3 (THREE) hostesses working, all arguing about what table number a party was just seated at and trying to figure out their request to change tables...and too busy to help us immediately.  Once we got their attention,  we asked for a booth, and asked to wait "about 5 minutes", until they could figure out the current table problem.  With less than 1/4 of the restaurant and bar area filled, there should have been no delay and no reason ONE of the THREE hostesses couldn't help us.  A few minutes later we were told there were no booths available...and then we were led past 6 open booths to be seated at a 4-top table.  Maybe they were reserved, but we were there for about 90 minutes total and not a single other table was sat meaning that all 6 booths sat empty (plus 1 more from a table that finished and was reset).

Our waitress started off friendly, but was overly chatty, spending more time asking our friends son about school, what he liked, what grade (he's 14, not exactly a young child), favorite subject, etc, etc.  It was like having dinner with my great aunt.  She then spent 3+ minutes going over the Pellagrino flavored selections on the menu and how we are supposed to drink it properly...you'd think it was some crazy new drink we'd never seen before (maybe Downington is that rural that's it's new for them?)

The wine is served in a cheap tumbler like water glass...very European if you're drinking table wine in Rome, but a little low rent when you're drinking a $14 glass of wine.

To finish off our great service, the food came out and each course was served to the wrong person, and right after our apps were served, the same server placed another tables entrees down on our table.

The Calamari was actually good, we were told it was made fresh and the breading was light and not at all oily.  Unfortunatley, the little bit of calamari we found on the plate was heavily overshadowed by the fried yellow pepper rings  (which we initially ate mistaking them for calamari rings!).

Pear salad was good, but not great.  The pears were kind of bland and it was a little light on the cheese, but the overall portion size was good.

Spaghetti and meatballs tasted like store-bought boxed spaghetti with a watery and bland tomato sauce....how do you open an italian place without eing able to make a red sauce???  I shouldn't be seeing chunks of red separating and leaving a bowl of water for the pasta to sit in.  Simple execution aside, there was no flavor at all to it...pretty much a watery and bland red soup the pasta sat in.  The are three large meatballs, but they are under seasoned as well.

Gnocci with braised short rib was a little on the sweet side, served in a brown sauce.  The gnocci tasted fresh made, but the sauce was a little overpowering, although it was one dimensional.

Three of us ordered pasta and we had to ask for a grated cheese.  The large hunk of cheese was grated with a corse grater leaving too large of chunks of cheese on top of our dish.  After maybe a 1/2 tablespoon of cheese, the waitress started commenting on the "mole hill" of cheese and how we were using too much of it, etc....I'm sure she was just trying to be funny, but after spending as much time talking to her as we had each other, we were pretty sick of her commentary.

Dessert was served in small glass cups with 4-5 mousse-like options, you basically pick the glass(es) you want, no other options.  If you've eaten at the owners Harvest restaurants, you'll recognize the process.

Initially, this is a really cool space, but the execution is so far off, it's not worth your time.  Maybe after they get the staff properly trained and settled, the service issues will be taken care of, although I'm more concerned with the failures in the kitchen department and highly unlikely to ever return for a second chance

Went here late night with some co workers after a busy day.  after 10 pm. 

1. Waiter was annoyed that we ordered a bunch of appetizers and only 2 small entrees.   ok, he didnt say anything, but he made a face, and walked away.  (our bill came out to 33 bucks for 4 people).  he did not smile once during the whole time we gave our order.  

2. The roti with the chicken curry (2 orders) came out, food was good, but one person in our dining party asked from some sriracha, and the same waiter who was annoyed with our small order rolled his eyes as if the sriracha request was a major imposition, but he brought it over. 

3. When i ordered our food, i asked for the peanut pancake dessert at the time of ordering, because I know it takes a long time. 

4. our waiter disappears after another waiter delivers our entrees , and never came back to our table. 

5. as we were done with our apps and main course, i asked, where our peanut pancake was.  everyone looked confused , and they told me it was never entered on the initial order.   So, i told them to forget about it.  I didnt want to wait another 15 minutes.  If you are annoyed that our order was small, then you forget to put a dessert on the order? thats not my problem.  if you want more revenue for your company, then don't forget to put the whole order in. then you will get more tips

i think it would have added another 7 bucks to the bill...

Then while other customers are walking out our waiter was all of a sudden friendly and cheery to others? 

Dude, either learn how to smile and suck it up, or get another job, preferably not in the hospitality industry,  


in any case, probably wont go back and spend my hard earned money here, when there are other places in Ctown where the waiters want to work hard and care about customers...

Disclaimer: I am writing this in the heat of the moment but I would advise NOT placing an order for pick up here. I waited for over 30 minutes at this location while watching other customers come in, place their order, be rung up, served and leave the whole time I waited. This was beyond frustrating. 

Xoxo,

Is this thing on?

Being from Texas I am picky (finicky) when I judge BBQ.  I have been so disappointed across the country I quit trying and usually just eat other foods.  Reviews convinced me to try a dpretty impressed.  Had Brisket and wasn't offered regular or lean (was given lean).  I would have chosen other but it was decent in comparison to TX BBQ.   Mac was very good and fries would have been awesome if fresh vs  warmer warmth fries.  Even the side of coconut pie very good.    Prices were very reasonable and I would definitely eat here again next time I am in the area.  Great job and patriotic
Pizza is average. Service is sad. Way too expensive. And I was told 20 minutes and it took 30. And the cooks would rather watch TV.

We live in the 'hood and have eaten here 3 or 4 times/month for several years.

Looks to me that there may be an orchestrated campaign against Sun Ray.

First off, the large parking lot is right across the street, not a block away.
Second, we have never had a disaster meal here.  Worst we have experienced was an almost well-done cheesburger.

Sun Ray is almost always open, has no really greasy food, and has a wide-ranging menu. 

My biggest complaint is that they quit carrying Coors Light beer.  And, some of their best food offerings aren't on the menu.  Just ask.

Place & restrooms are clean.  Waitstaff is stable and friendly.  Owner is frequently there and has been very nice to us.  "Alexis", the dinner-time manager is great.

They have nice steaks under $30, full sushi menu, good specials, neat sides, full bar.  Some of their seafood is sorta California-style, but good.

Not a tourist place; most customers live nearby and frequent this eclectic eatery.

I say try Sun Ray, it won't disappoint.

Rick

WARNING !

The food is still good and the prices are right; BUT, the counter service has declined to the point that I'm not going back.  

The rudeness of the order-taker is now astronomical and he never gets the orders right any more.  

And worse, I  was threatened by a rude customer yesterday !

This is just too unpleasant to endure, no matter how good the food is !

Caveat Diner !

Rick

We have been trying to eat here since the place opened.  Finally got there today, for lunch..

Nice building, grounds, parking.

I had shrimp-lump crab "stack" salad; very good.  wife had a  broiled catfish item. 

BUT, they have no COORS LIGHT BEER !

Some menu items are REAL Cajun style.  Nice building, easy parking, inviting bar.  Scenery outside the rear glass wall is of a typical South Louisiana swamp-side pond, with the usual animal denizens:  gators, snakes frogs, mosquitos, & snakes

Definitely a nice place to visit and dine.

BUT, no COORS LIGHT BEER !

Rick

I went on a cold, winter's night- Saturday at 5pm. Me and my friend were seated right away and the service was great. The beer selection was fine. I had the sweet chicken wings which were great! The sauces are interesting - at the table in giant plastic squeeze containers, labeled with sharpies. Paper towel rolls on the tables, servers wearing cute aprons. It's a greasy, sticky BBQ place. I've been there with big groups before and we also get a spot, so that's a plus.

We had takeout tonight. My wife had tacos which were cold. I had steak fajitas, we were told fajitas were on a special menu only kept at the register. They made it, it came like the tacos. The wraps were,  just like it came out of a plastic package. meat was almost unrecognizable as fajita meat.  This location is nothing like the original. We will not be going back but I going to ask for a refund.

The food at Three Kings is good.  If you are looking for good pub food, Three Kings is a very good option. The wings were delicious, although they were breaded, which isn't my favorite.  The burger was cooked fantastically and very tasty.  They have a good selection of beers too and they are pretty affordably priced.

The downside, it took forever.  Our server was so hard to find, it was like he was playing a game of hide-and-seek with us and he was a really good hider. 

The band was really loud and not very good. It made it really hard to carry on a conversation.  We should have sat in the back, but I like the atmosphere in the bar area a lot better.

We have not returned for a couple years now. Last we went the decor and carpet were old and tired. The owner was pushy and impatient. We have found other more agreeable Thai places around the Southside and city. The spice level is too much here and they seemed challenged to get the right desired intensity for the customer. One big turnoff for our very last visit was the disgust of the owner when we wanted to share our entree and not over-eat post appetizers. Argh! The customer comes first, I thought.

Food was good, portions large, staff great! I'll be back. I had the Red Velvet french toast - was like dessert for breakfast (just what I like). In the end, the price was even more what I liked. Went on a Saturday around 11a. It was pretty packed but there wasn't much of a wait and the food didn't take forever to come.

I have been here a few times. They recently (2018) cut the portions in half and it is not enough food to buy one entree. One entree is around 12 bucks or so. So the cost to eat here just doubled to 20+ just for the food part of the meal.

I just went to eat here for lunch and i ordered a chicken sandwich with fries and an iced tea. (last time i got the fried fish)

the sandwich was good except the amount of chicken was only enough for about 2/3 of the bun.  Very small like something a 75 pound model would eat. you could easily eat the chicken in 2 bites.

The fries were cold and stale as if they had been cooked 2 hours prior, maybe longer. I normally cant avoid fries, but i actually did not eat them.  This is a very rare occurrence and ruined the overall meal.

After the waitress/bartender gave me my food, i had to ask for silverware and a napkin. she looked at me kinda strangely. i had to use the knife to cut off most of the bread out because i didn't order a bread sandwich. 

She then proceeded to disappear for about 30 minutes. (i never actually saw her again or any waitress for that matter). I DID NOT receive one single refill on my iced tea the entire 45 minutes to an hour i was there. my tea sat empty for at least 30 minutes. there was also a piece of hair in my water.

when i was tired of sitting there staring at the table i decided to stand up and wait for my check. after about 20 minutes of waiting for my check i went into the kitchen and asked one of the cooks if they could check me out. i could have walked out and not paid easily.  This is probably the most appealing part of this place. (chance of not having to pay)

i proceeded to leave $0 for a tip, which IS SOMETHING I HAVE NEVER DONE IN MY LIFE. this is officially the first time i wrote $0 on the tip line. i am so happy i did and wish i could have wrote a negative number for how terribly bad this bia was serving me.

i would only recommend this place to a desperate house wife that likes to drink wine and has a lot of money. also, if you have a hipster hair styleand a lot of money you might also like this place. everyone there had a hipster hair style.

TLDR: UNLESS YOU ARE A DESPERATE HOUSEWIFE DO NOT, I REPEAT, DO NOT GO TO THIS PLACE. IT IS AN ABSOLUTE DISASTER AND YOU WILL NOT BE HAPPY WHEN YOU LEAVE.

Great place to eat drink and be merry. Staff is friendly. Mizzou bar. However, the food has yet to impress me. I must have been here 15 times and have yet to truly enjoy a meal. Pretty sad. Probably bad management. Not all managers know good food.

Came here on Sunday 3/2/14 during Mardi Gras parades. Even though it looked packed walking in we were immediately seated. The water was really nice. We ordered the Cajun platter for two (2), shrimp bisque and some Crawfish Étouffée. I'm kinda whimsy when it comes to spicy food and this night it got me. 1/2 way trough the meal I started to get heartburn while Dave mauled through it like a bobcat on a rabbit. My New Orleans Mojito was a bit too sweet for me to even finish. We ordered dessert, the bread pudding with ice cream a la mode. IT WAS AWESOME!!

PROS:
-Quick seating on Saturday night during Mardi Gras
-Live music
-Mixed drinks
-Family friendly
-Dance floor 
-Band playing some southern tunes with the fiddle
-tasty desserts that u can see on a tray
-Breading pudding with a side if ice cream is fricken fantastic

CONS:
-All the mixed drinks were sweet so not to everyone's liking
-Super loud environment 
-Though the music is nice there is no way I could hear it everyday.
-Heavy greasy and fried meals, couldn't handle it

I got the strips combo and although it was on the dry side- there was lots of kick.  As for the fixins, the fries were awesome and the Cole slaw was the best I ever had.  They were down for chicken.  If I would have gotten the regular fried chicken I'm sure it would have been awesome.

I passed here every day for years and didn't even know it existed!!  Was only after some friends insisted on the location that lived in the neighborhood was I aware.  It doesn't help that they operated WITHOUT A SIGN & black windows for 30 years?!?!  Went here with a group and got the moo-shoo pork.  They nailed it!  Plum sauce, thin pancakes, ample pork & extra anything was awesome.  But everything was exceptional.  No place better around there.

Now if I can only find fish tacos like they make in Ensenada!, I'd be thrilled....

It's just okay.... nothing special. 

Customer Service 
Taste of Food 
Atmosphere 

We ordered a Italian beef and hamburger meals along with a bowl of chili. We waited for awhile for our meals. Based on other reviews, I was expected. :( The fries were cold but the rest of foods were okay.  It was better than Berger king but I don't think I will visit again.

3.5 stars bc their food is inconsistent since the lockdown started! I love Chabaa Thai I used to order or get food regularly before the lockdown but the couple of times I've ordered takeout from here since the lockdown the food has been inconsistent! I've noticed inconsistency in the taste of the curry - probably left over curry from the previous day! I will be going back again but won't be ordering takeout or delivery till the restaraunt opens up to its regular hours again

After many years of going here was extremely disappointed in the service and hostesses this time.  Will not return at this point it was so bad.  Too bad because this used to be a decent place with great people.  Apparently they've been replaced by the unpleasant unthinking drones they now have at the front and as managers.  

I am sure they will say I was rude but I don't call leaving after 30 minutes with no check in rude.  

Thankfully there's lots of other places to go within steps of here.

The Sail Pavilion is a great place to bring out of town guests so they can get the whole casual, hanging out in Florida next to the water vibe.  The tables are placed all around the center bar. Even though the restaurant is entirely outside, they do have overhead air units blowing cool air downwards.  That, combined with the breeze from the bay, made for a very comfortable temperature even in the middle of summer.

Service was good - the waiter was on the ball and very friendly. My sandwich was just okay. I thought the chicken in my chicken sandwich was small, bland, and dry.  For $12, I expected better than that - and the bag of plain potato chips that accompanied it.  The peach tea cocktail I had, however, was delicious.  With so many great restaurants in the area, I think next time I'll eat elsewhere, and go there just for cocktails.

Wow, do I love this place.  Nothing much to look at on the inside or out, but the deliciousness of the food makes up for lack of ambiance.

Their burgers are crazy good. They have about 13 different varieties of burger offerings, plus they run specials all the time. They also offer steak and cheese sandwiches, chicken sandwiches, and salads (but why bother with a salad at an amazing burger joint?). 

Side orders of onion thangs, and loaded french fries are wonderful - but every burger order includes a side of french fries, so I rarely order another side item.

They also offer ice cream, milkshakes, and usually have an assortment of cakes for dessert.

Service is super friendly, and the food comes out surprisingly speedy, which is great because they do not accept phone orders. I wish they were open later hours, but consider myself lucky the few times I have made it in time after work. You are crazy if you go to a nearby fast-food restaurant; the food is way better here, and cheaper, too.

I have walked into Piquant many times to buy a treat from their bakery, but this was the first time I've actually come here for sit down meal.  Their baked goods, including their unique cronuts, are outstanding, and I highly recommend them.

We came on a Sunday, pre-movie, and since the wait time was only ten minutes for brunch, we decided to wait. I love that they take your cell number so they can text you when you're table is ready.

We were led to a small table in the back, and were greeted very quickly by our upbeat server. It's wonderful that they offer soy milk options, however, my soy latte was probably the worst-looking latte I have ever seen in my life.  No foam, no design, no nothing - and it supposedly was made seconds before she ran it out.   It was lukewarm at best-plus, it took longer than my BF's bloody mary to come out.  Weird.

For my meal I had the Roasted Vegetable Tartine.  It was one piece of challah, with petite diced roasted vegetables on top, Gruyère cheese, and a fried egg.  That was it. No sides, no garnish. So, while the flavor was delicious, I felt it was way too small of a portion for the price.  Thank goodness I planned on eating popcorn at the movie, or I would have had to order another entrée!

I'm sure I will be back for some bakery treats, but not for brunch anytime soon.

One of my top two favorite Chinese restaurants in Tampa. The restaurant is large with plenty of tables, and plenty of space to accommodate large parties. Some round tables have a lazy susan in the center to make sharing easy. Servers are always efficient.

I love that you can go here any day of the week and have a dim sum meal from their dim sum menu. No waiting for a cart to make laps around the restaurant, leaving you stuck with what everybody else doesn't want.

My favorite items to order here are steamed dumplings, Singapore style rice noodles, salt and pepper tofu, and chicken noodle soup. But really, everything I've tried is great.

One caveat though - we brought some non-adventurous eaters here, and we could tell they were a bit thrown off/horrified by the dead ducks dangling in the windows, and the fish tanks all along the wall chock full of fresh seafood to eat. Fortunately, they both managed to scarf down the 'safe' beef with broccoli, so all was well.

To be perfectly honest, I loved just about everything about this place.  You walk in, and the woman who takes the order was very friendly, polite, and helpful. She handed me their menu brochure, because the display board doesn't show all the offerings. She also gave me suggestions. I love when people offer recommendations when I go to a place for the first time!

I went with her suggestion of the Xtreme Sope, which was a flat tortilla shell topped with pulled pork, black beans, cabbage, pico, sour cream, guacamole, and cheese.  Wow was this awesome!  No matter what else you get - get one of these.  She recommend the pulled pork, and that too was spot on.

I also got two of their tacos to try.  One Xtreme taco with chicken, and one buffalo shrimp taco.  The chicken taco was basic but good, and I loved the buffalo shrimp taco; it was super spicy, but in the best possible way.  The food took about fifteen minutes to prepare - I could see they were preparing a lot of to-go/delivery service orders.

They have a separate dining area if you choose to eat in, which is only a few tables, but it's away from the take out window, so it would be a good option.  They have two sauces, green and red, hot and hotter, available to help yourself. 

The only thing I didn't love was the parking.  When I went in, I was the only customer, yet there was only one oddly angled parking spot available.  When I left, I saw that parking is available along the nearby fence, but it is still not very many spaces.  Plus, getting in and out of their place via Waters Ave can be a tricky situation, as the section is a feeder to I275. Nevertheless, it is worth the risk to have some mighty fine Mexican food.

This place is really par. Nothing that really stands out on the menu or is unique/special. Sushi is tightly portioned. The rest of the menu is generic. There are better restaurants in the area with sushi/korean/japanese. Strongly advise you to skip coming here.
Updated Review: Showed up at 9pm and it was closed. Was supposed to be open for another hour. No sign or indication as to why. I was furious.

Ordered Wings. Half Nashville Hot and Half Cherry Chipotle. Got Half Cherry Chipotle and half UNDRESSED WINGS. Look at my picture for proof. Once again, BJ's is a far cry from what they were. Will not return, not even if co-workers come back.

Yard House was making waves on my yelp feed, it was added to my "gotta try if i'm in the area". I don't hang out in the area, but had some errands and my friend worked down the street, making it the perfect opportunity to try. It was MLK monday and the place was packed (12:30pm). Luckily the crowd comprised of large groups. The bar is seat yourself, so i scored 2 seats. About 20 minutes later, there were no more seats at the bar. 

I was a bit skeptical of getting in and out in a timely manner considering the kitchen was in the middle of lunch rush. We ordered 2 shortys--i liked my Philly Wheat WIt and my friend liked his Neshaminy Jawn---we kept it real philly! I think the shortys are a good marketing tool (ploy even?). It was a pricey pour ($4-5) considering the size but not a deal breaker--i would go for a pint if you know how a certain beer tastes. Our bartender was nice and efficient.

The menu is diverse and offered a variety of continental dishes, american, southern, asian-inspired, mexican/tex-mex inspired. Again, i was a bit skeptical of the menu delivery good flavors being so large. I ended up with the chicken enchilada stack and my friend got the spicy jambalya (small, with brown rice). 

The food did take awhile, but not that long considering how many diners were in the restaurant. Again, i expected to wait so it wasn't horrible. I will say, the kitchen seemed to push food out fairly well but mostly because the dishes were typical lunch/american stuff like sandwiches and fries---quick orders. 

My friend said his dish was warm, probably waiting under a heat lamp while my dish was being made---my dish was nice and hot. I thought the chicken enchilada was pretty good. The small jambalya only had 1 shrimp which was disappointing. We both finished/cleaned the plate. The portion was not "diner style" huge, but not "high end" tiny, just in between. 

We both enjoyed the food and atmosphere. The music was on the louder side, which I assume made the crowd speak at a louder volume (including myself), but good vibes all around. Will definitely make an effort to stop by here more for happy hour. 

I couldn't help but mentally compare it to Iron Hill brewery. I think Yards House is MUCH better.

I give this restaurant three stars because of the portion-size compared to price and the overall vibe of the place. 

The food itself was great. I went with a larger group and everyone was happy with the quality. 

It's a BYOB so that helps a bit on price, but for the amount of food you get, I think it's a little hard to justify the price. Plus, they don't do much to make you feel like you're eating in a truly upscale restaurant. It's a bit bare, with not much on the walls, it's pretty boring actually. 

The service was fine, nothing incredible but they did their job. 

I can't say I'm dying to go back, or that I would tell someone to run here tomorrow, but if you're in Yardley and looking for something different, it's worth a shot.

After having been to Dandelion many times since its opening, I think it's safe to say this pub does it right. It's not a pub to go for a drink in if you're not dressed at least somewhat nice, so it can't exactly be considered super authentic, but it's Steven Starr and it's the experience that matters and you will get on here. 

The dark and homey decor throughout, with the fireplace being my favorite set the scene for an English menu filled with lots of classics like tandoori chicken, fish and chips, and bangers and mash, while also throwing in lots of other dishes and plates to try from meat and cheese plates to deviled eggs and foie gras. I enjoy their dinner menu the best, while I do love a good brunch, but the brunch menu was a bit simple and with a restaurant like this I was hoping it would be more creative like dinner.

Definitely a place to add to your list in Philadelphia though.

I think I had a one or two day span between my visit to Jones and then to El Vez. I think I'm Stephen Starred-out for the time being.

I've been ogling this place for so long. I think it was the funky seating that did it for me whenever I passed by. And the allure of kitschy (sp?) decorations with multicolored lights.

Holy moly, that was a lot of guacamole! My friend and I could not finish that bowl and we both went in with large appetites! At least we can say it was worth the $12. The chips are fresh and hot for the most part. Sadly, we had a guacamole craving the other Friday night from drinking but dinner hours end at midnight, so note well if you need to satisfy such cravings.

Hmm let's see. It took me a while to figure out what my friend ordered. Ok, here we go. He ordered the huarache de vegetal, which was basically a black bean corn cake on top of a lot of stuff (looking such things up on wikipedia)..nopales (from prickly pears), chayote (gourd), and poblano pepper. It was a large amount, probably adding to why we didn't finish our guacamole. I ordered the mahi mahi tacos. They were just enough to fill me up without making me feel huge and I enjoyed the flavors in the remoulade. Too full for dessert and went on day I needed to study a lot so no drinking, though from what I saw, the drinks looked delicious.

Will definitely be back, even if it is just for guacamole and drinks. Groups love coming here. In fact, I think a whole high school class ~20-30 people came. So apparently highly recommended by many. I guess I don't blame them.

Recently went here for the BBQ of course. 

First, let me say...the customer service was stellar. It was young lady who helped us (unfortunately I can't think of her name) and she was awesome. 

Now, on to the food. Maybe we came on an off day but I just think that it was subpar at best. Nothing we ordered came out hot...which can be typical for BBQ but not even the baked beans or corn was hot. The BBQ chicken was also very, very dry. So dry it was obvious just from looking at it. 

In total, we had ribs, pulled pork, brisket, and chicken at the table. The best thing on the table were the ribs. I believe had they been hotter and had the cut of the ribs be a little cleaner I would've enjoyed them more. 

I wouldn't be opposed to trying it again, just on the hope that they were having an off day the day I came.

My husband and I had lunch here last week. We were so disappointed!
It started with having to order at the counter, and no real place to stand if there's a line at the counter. When it was our turn, the order-taker drifted away without acknowledging us, so we were left wondering if/when he would return. I strongly dislike ordering at a counter. It makes me feel like I'm at a McDonalds.
Once we were seated, the next unpleasantness is the NOISE. This little house is all hard surfaces, so it was really loud. 
We ordered Suppli because Calafuria posted a picture and description on their FB page. It's deep-fried tomato risotto with a heart of melted mozzarella. The whole thing was absolutely flavorless, even the cheese. No hint of salt or seasoning anywhere.
Which led to not finding any salt on the table. It's fine if the chef wishes to leave out salt, but at least make it available to diners,without having to ask for it. Salt and pepper should be on every table.
We both had eggplant Parmesan, also lacking in flavor, but slightly better than the suppli. Again, the cheese lacked flavor, and nothing tasted like it had any seasoning. The eggplant did have a nice texture. I asked for some Parmesan which I carefully sprinkled over the dish, and I treasured each little nugget of flavor because it's the first I'd tasted at this meal.
The service was good.
I doubt we'll be back.

Brand new sushi/ramen restaurant in South Philly, right off of Washington Ave. Street parking was pretty easy. The staff was friendly and the interior is nice. From photos and reviews, my expectations were high..

The food and quality was mediocre. Prices were a bit expensive for the portion. 

The beef ribs were good, very flavorful. I would go for more of the uni scallop dish! The uni sushi was okay, could've been better and it was weird that it came with avocado. The otoro sushi was not good, it did not taste like what it's suppose to be. The fried oyster roll was good and interesting. Our sushi bowl (Big bang,$29?) was okay. The fish was good but the rice was too sticky and packed that it was hard to eat. We also ordered the King crab milky ramen ($18). The ramen itself was good but broth was bland..

3.5 stars ~

Got a deal on Groupon for two people that includes drinks and desserts. The environment is definitely very different from Fogo and Chima, it's not fancy at all. It's a small local business in the Northeast area. I like how there's street parking in the front of the restaurant and a private parking lot behind the restaurant. You save money on parking verses parking in the center city.

Food: The meat is very flavorful and delicious. The salad bar was good, not a huge selection but it had lots of Brazilian sides. They don't have a huge selection on drinks either but hey, it's included in my deal so can't complain. I got the flan for dessert and it was so good!
Service: The waiters and staff was amazing. They're all super friendly and attentive.

Definitely recommend this place and will come back. Make sure you check Groupon for the dinner, drinks and dessert deal. It's worth your money.

I've biked past this place a bunch of times, all on my way to other eating establishments :-X!

I was finally led here the other day, and it's pretty good! They have really interesting menu items (banana walnut crepes!) as well as your standard cafe fare. 

My only gripe is that the portions are kind of small for what you're paying. I got a tuna melt that came with a side salad for $8, and it was only one slice of bread cut in half and like 6 pieces lettuce. And radishes. Who even likes radishes?

Regardless, I want to come back to try some of their other choices. Maybe when I get a real job.

My dad wanted to eat French food for dinner.  I was a bit hesitant after looking at the menu since I have tooo many dietary restrictions.  But, I decided to take a risk.  Boy was I glad in taking that risk.  The staff accommodated me.  I got the Escallop du Porc, & it was delish!  The potatoes came out crisp & very flavorful.  The entire dish wasn't salty.  The pork was awesome.  Great presentation.  Perfect amount of seasonings & great flavor without the butter!  The whole wheat bread that they brought out as a sort of an appetizer was quite doughy.  Thanks, Cafe Provencal for making my taste buds happy & for making my tummy calm!

I love federal donuts! And this place def makes them well! Why 3 stars? This location has SLOW service.
