Not because they're understaffed, not because they're busy, but because there is no oversight of the employees. While one worker was making donuts, refilling items, and taking orders, the other girl was chatting it up and flirting with one single customer. We were first in line when we entered, yet had to wait 25 minutes for our donuts because one worker was trying to get those digits while on the job. I would hate if she were my co-worker, and the other worker was obviously unhappy doing the job of 2 people.

Wooooooow I'm in so much shock at how terribly-made the food here is yet how people still eat here! 
Yes it's authentic, but just because you have no competition doesn't mean you can disgrace Japanese cuisine. 

We arrived 6, didn't get to order until 6:15 because of the 3 whole people ahead of us, and didn't get our food until 6:50. The portions were so TINY I was done eating by 6:59, which is surprising considering how tough and hard to chew their katsu (chicken jerky) was. No joke, I've had katsu probably at 50+ different locations and this one here  is hands down, no debate, the WORST I've ever had. It's on par with public school lunch cafeteria food.

Okinomoyaki was decently flavored, but filling was mostly batter and for $12, there should be more than 2 pieces of meat that are 1 cm big. 

This was probably the worst tasting meals I've had in the past few years, but I can't get myself to give them 1 star bc they are nice, and the store has some items that are not available in regular grocery stores.

Came here with a party of 4 and we weren't sure what to order, so we pretty much ordered everything!
Mofongo comes with these pieces of pork skin, which makes everything taste even better, but when added with gravy, comes out to perfection. 
Tostones with garlic was better than without garlic.
 The beef was pretty bland and nothing special. 
The pernil (pork) was a little on the saltier side, but complements well with the rice and beans. 

Now, another thing to note is the PRICE! My gluttonous group definitely over-ordered (ended up feeding all 4 of us almost to the point of death, with enough leftovers for 4 extra meals) and each of us paid $18. Okay, that might sound like a lot, but we also ordered a ~$5 colada drink. So fine, take away the drink, come with a big group and order family-style, and you're probably paying ~$6.00 per head for a delicious meal!

I was excited for Roxborough to finally get some new places to eat, but this place was so disappointing! I'm really surprised by the high reviews! Portions are so tiny that it would take 2 platters to fill up an average person. Also, maybe because it's new (we went the week it opened) and they haven't ironed out the kinks, but they switched our orders up with another customer's and didn't even apologize. I love Mediterranean food, but this may be the most disappointing. I'm being generous with my rating too with hopes they will stay open and get better.

We arrived at 5 with a reservation, were seated immediately, but service was awkward and slow. We couldn't flag our server down to order or get utensils (we only got 1 tea cup) until 40 minutes later. Food is average, but I guess there is not much competition out here. Parking is easy, and BYOB, which are the only redeeming factors of this place.

Mediocre food at a mediocre chain, except this is the fourth iron hill I've been to and has the worst service. I've been a server myself and something here is super disorgsnized. After we sat, no one gave us menus for 20 minutes. Finally after someone came and took our order, another server came 2 minutes later and handed us menus again. We asked for water, and she came with 3 for the 4 of us. 

Your basic place when you want a basic hangout.

A much needed Asian drinks/cafe in the West Philly area. During my first visit here, I spent about 6 minutes looking at their menu because of all their food items available as well! Even though I was taking so long, the staff was super nice and patient. The only con is this place is super small - probably can only sit about 10 people. Overall definitely a place to go when Chinatown is out of the way.

First...... I MUST AGREE with the other reviewers - this place is NOISY. Did I mention this place was NOISY?? Fortunately we were seated in the back of the restaurant away from the bar where is was SUPER NOISY.   The food was hit or miss. sister had shrimp on a roll - which was TOO "bready", Buffalo Wings were not Hot (spicy) and were undercooked (pink chicken is NOT GOOD) . Onion soup was "ok".  Fortunately - i OUT ORDERED everyone...... I started with their Clams Casino special App & it was VERY TASTY -- I could have eaten a dozen for dinner - who needs an entree?   Seriously - if you go there & the clams are on special GET THEM.  I had the turkey reuben for dinner & it was oh so VERY GOOD. The side of veggies (my choice) were lame but the sandwich was awesome. I had 1/2 for dinner & 1/2 for lunch the next day. yum.....
I'm guessing we won't be going back mostly b/c of the noise & b/c only 1 out of 4 dinners was really any good......

SO IMPRESSED. We ordered all of our groceries for the week through Mercato.com (website that lets you order delivery or pick up from three of Indy's local markets: Turchetti's, Wildwood and Goose). We ordered several meats, vegetables, fruits, sauces and a delicious smashburger and fries from Turchetti's. It was similarly-priced to a normal grocery haul and we chose to pick it up curbside. When we arrived at Turchetti's, we called them and they came outside immediately with our order, properly labeled and divided by refrigerated items, produce and ready-to-eat meals. Their team is SO wonderful and professional. They were in high spirits and you can tip them at @Turchettis-Delicatessen Venmo (this is being written during quarantine time and they're using it to pay employees). There was even a handwritten thank you note in our bag which was such a sweet touch. Their meats are incredible and they're stocked with everything - get good food to cook while you're stuck at home!

Step into this funky, bright, fiesta-filled spot for a fun night out. The decor is colorful, with loads of twinkle lights that set an incredible ambiance. 

When to come: evenings for drinks and a night out. 

When I wouldn't recommend coming: for lunch or a nice dinner. 

I came at lunch time and although there weren't many tables, our server didn't notice us for about twenty minutes. We tried three different kinds of tacos and they were all dripping in grease. It was a little too much. I really want to love this place and know that the experience will probably be different if I come again and just focus on drinks and possibly some rad margaritas.

Who knew they have great quesadillas? We were on Mass Ave on a Friday night and every place was crazy-busy. However, we were able to walk right in here and order instantly. There were even some available tables and the servers were friendly and got our order quickly. 

The food came out fast too and our portions were large and worth the money. I got the chicken quesadilla and it had corn and beans and onions and cheese in it. Super delicious.

 I loved the speediness of this place because on the weekends, Mass Ave restaurants can take hours to get sat. They also had a fun, seasonal & spiked drink menu.

This CFA is SO disappointing. They will try to rip you off in any way possible - filling the fries half way, barely adding any cheese sauce, giving fried batter instead of chicken tenders, & the list goes on. Complaints get you no where and no one seems to care about the customer. Sad.

I stopped in for lunch today because I've always loved their donuts & figured I'd give their chicken a try. The staff was friendly and there was no line so I placed my order quickly -- 3-piece chicken with soy garlic sauce, fries, and and a strawberry lavender donut.

The donut was warm and tasty as usual. The chicken was terrible. It looked nothing like the photos on Yelp or on their website. Every piece was overcooked. There was no crunch to the chicken and no soy garlic flavor. Every bite was bitter and the burnt taste was overwhelming. I threw 2 of the 3 pieces away. A true waste of money for one of the most unsatisfying meals I've had in a while.

The fries were tasty but considering my chicken was the primary component of my lunch, I have to give this location 2 stars. I don't know what was up with my chicken but at $10 for 3 pieces, I can't imagine returning to give it another try.

My sister and I are new to Indy and love exploring new eateries! We have tried a few breakfast/brunch places and Taste is probably on the top of our list at this moment. We had such a great first impression from the moment we walked in. The restaurant is very nice and modern... Service was pretty good... I think they need more staffs to great and take orders, however the one girl that was there was quite pleasant!!! We ordered their truffle egg toast (pretty amazing) their special quiche (creamy and tasty) but my favorite had to be the truffle frites with the amazing aioli sauce!!! Yum yum yum!! Must have again and again!! Overall, this was a wonderful experience and we will definitely be back!

Ended up here on Friday for a friend's birthday.  It is a very nice location and there was plenty of seating.  We hit the bar and got two bottles of Miller Lite for $4.50 a piece.  The "nightclub" thing needs to take a break though...they set up a projector so they can play music videos (I didn't even know they still made those anymore...MTV doesn't play videos..) and people can dance in front of it.
If I was there for a meal and they set that shiz up, I'd be out of there!

I really enjoy Caribou despite them having a very lame Nicoise salad.  I love the atmosphere and the drinks are always creative and/or classic.  They made me a Kir Royale!  Watch out though, if you drink like a fish, it will definitely put a dent in your wallet.

Calypso specializes in vegetarian/healthy food, but of course I usually opt for the least of these.  The black bean + chicken nachos are spectacular! I would trade some prized possessions to get the recipe to that barbecue-y salsa-ish sauce.   
Parking around lunch is terrible, so get there early. Parking at the Elliston location is awful, too. Annoying.  
The service is usually pretty fast during their busy times, but that's about all that can be said for it - not outstanding, but they can get you in & out on your lunch hour for sure. 
The atmosphere is... different... very casual, to put it nicely. 

All negative aspects considered, for the price and quality of the food, you can't beat it.

Ok, here's the deal, I feel like I need to review this location since I previously mildly bashed the Sylvan Park location... This location is wayyyyyyyy better. 

Most of my qualms with the Sylvan Park location have to do with atmosphere, layout, service... none of which are a problem here.  I did not realize the locations were so different until I got into a semi-argument over whether Local Taco was awful or awesome.... I was familiar with Sylvan Park, he was familiar with Brentwood. We were both confused by the others' opinion of the place. 

This location actually seats and serves you - you don't have to stand in line to order and then go back to the register for every drink refill. The restaurant is much bigger, not at all cramped like Sylvan Park, and it's much, much nicer, too.  

No difference in the food, which is what really matters, I guess - it's just as good.  I still recommend the guac and the queso, I could just eat those as my entire meal.

I tried the "Tequila Mockingbird" cocktail... (get it? get it??) It has tequila, st. germain,  cranberry and orange juice. YUM. 

I'm a fan of Local Taco's food, but from now on I'll probably only be eating it in Brentwood.
The pasta is okay but I've had better. The staff is friendly. It depends on what you want to eat

This location is always a hit or miss. Today they get a 4 because my wings were actually pretty good and my husband just always likes Pizza Hut pizza. The employees are nice. If you haven't been here in awhile, they no longer have their buffet.

It's been my recent go-to for breakfast po'boys but today I made the terrible mistake of ordering my breakfast online. I placed the online order at 9:30am, planned pick up around 9:45am. When I arrived, the restaurant had not even checked for online orders. They placed my order at that time but then I waited 30 minutes to get my breakfast because the cook didn't know about online orders. Almost a dozen customers had ordered and left by the time I got my food. Please don't set up online ordering if you can't deliver the expected result, which is speed and efficiency. From beginning to end, it took 45 min to get my food which is not the way I want to start my Sunday. They did apologize for the delay but that doesn't change the time wasted and lost. I like Melba's food but in a city where there's plenty of delicious po'boys, I don't know if I'm inclined to return.

Woops has a lot of charm and tasty sweet treats! When you walk inside, you feel like you were transported to a small, hip bakery in a big city. The decor is stylish and the macarons are pretty! The prices seem high for Tucson (but then again macarons are generally pricy). The staff are kind and space is clean.

"Long John Silver's meets White Castle" 

The owner is personable and genuine. I enjoyed chatting with him and hope to return. My dad and I ordered the BFF - steamed burger for me, fish for both of us. The food was hot and came out pretty quickly. The patty was thick and juicy with a generous amount of cheese. The fish (cod) was fried just right. Well seasoned fries and hush puppies included too. Very reasonable prices! 

The location is a little odd and it seems like a hole in the wall place. I went a few days after opening, so the decor, bathroom, and interior structure looked like they were still being worked on.

First time here for an afternoon snack. The surf special is a good deal because you can pick one hand roll, one roll, and nigiri (2 pieces) for $12.99 during lunch. We ate mid afternoon and we were one of 2 groups dining in, so it was pretty empty.  Technically lunch ends at 2:30 but they charged us lunch prices anyways. The yellowtail nigiri tasted velvety and it was a decent sized fish. The IOU roll was creamy. I wouldn't order it again because the sauce was strange. You couldn't really taste the salmon. The Leona hand roll (spicy tuna) was massive! They put so much fish in it. The spiciness was hotter than most other spicy tuna I've had in Tucson. It had a little too much heat for me. The hand roll was tightly wrapped and it was filling. I would go back if I'm in the area. I'd also potentially go back for all you can eat for lunch (good prices). Not the best sushi in Tucson, but it was ok.

This is one of my favorite go to sushi restaurants in Tucson. When people ask me for sushi recs, I always include this one. I always order the exact same sushi boat special. It's about $14 and it comes with nigiri, sashimi, seaweed salad, and a roll (I pay $1 extra to upgrade from California roll to spicy tuna roll). This boat special almost fills me up. Sachiko is pretty full every time I eat here, and I don't usually have to wait for a table. The complimentary miso soup is very hot and is a nice way to start the meal. I think it's funny that they handwrite all of their specials on printer paper and tape them all over the walls.

Was advised to try this place for the beef and broccoli and I was very disappointed.  The meat was very chewy and lacked flavor.  Ordered the large entree with no rice. 11 dollars.  I would never try anything else from here. Wasn't impressed.

Went in last week before a game.  Could not get a server.  Ok fine made my way to a bar.... 10 minutes later finally got two beers.  Attempted to go outside to the street party and was stopped at door.  Beer bought inside could not go outside.  I was like ok!?!?!?   Stood near door to drink beer, as I was standing there a beer cart was being pushed outside, with the same exact product I was drinking.  So I attempted to follow him out, I was stopped again.  I asked what is the difference between what I had in my hand and what just went outside? I was told no drinks were allowed outside that were bought inside.  I then asked to talk to a manager/supervisor and was bluntly told there were none available.   Yeah real fan friendly.  If I never walk in the place again it would not hurt my feelings.

I visited Open Society shortly after its opening for coffee & pastries and fell in love. So last weekend I set out to try Open Society's new brunch with high expectations. These were fully met. The menu is small but varied and a step fancier and "foodier" than basic brunch offerings. Portion sizes were quite large, especially considering the fair meal prices. The building is a new rehab and I'd describe the ambiance as modern, clean, and upscale hipster. The front patio is cute, though the neighborhood doesn't offer much in the way of scenery. I'd definitely recommend brunching here and look forward to my next visit. I'll leave it at that and let my photos do the talking...

I walked into Milktooth and the first thing I saw was a young man in a yellow cardigan and a feather earring freshly squeezing orange juice... and I knew I was in a magical place.  The atmosphere is super hipster, but there were all kinds of folks dining while we were there.  The restaurant is small but open and great for people watching.  The decor is delightful!- silverware is piled into an old coffee can and there are simple fresh flowers on each table.  

Oh yeah...the FOOD.  The menu is creative and unique.  I love this because I always feel like I could make other brunch places' offerings very easily at home. (Milktooth will take your run-of-the-mill hashbrowns and raise you a crispy potato latke topped with harrisa ketchup and aioli...)  I ordered the cornmeal pancake with fruit, cream, & cinnamon sugar- it satisfied my sweet tooth without being overly rich or heavy.  I paired it with the ricotta whey grits- they were perfectly (very simply) seasoned and very creamy.  Personally, I'm glad that Milktooth's portions aren't huge. I loved being able to select and try more than one menu item for my meal! Sweet + Savory = Success!  This morning I just had the bottomless drip coffee, which my server graciously filled 3 or 4 times.  Next time I'll try something fancier and maybe one of the pastries I was eyeing at the coffee bar.  Or the sorghum glazed bacon.  Or the lamb patty melt.  Or the uova al forno.  Time for more Milktooth!

Came here on a late night food coma after walking a dozen blocks and drinking beforehand with a friend.  The pizzas in the glass cases looked not that great and probably had been sitting there for a little.

However, the one cheese pizza had just come out of the oven, and we each had decided on one of those slices.  The crust was super-thin and crispy with some char, and the cheese was great.  What I didn't like was the sauce.  Dare I say that it almost tasted like restaurant canned sauce from a distributer?  Wasn't that great for me, but it's pizza real late at night, and you really cannot go wrong.

Slice also offers a Yelp check-in special of a can of soda with the purchase of 2 slices or salads.  

TV had the Flyers playoff game on, and my friend and I had some good conversation.

Cheap way to go on a Friday night!

I first tried pho at the Vietpho in Shoppers Square and kept hearing about this place so I gave it a try.  I've only eaten here twice and both times the service was very bad.  I came back the second time thinking maybe they were having an off day but apparently not.

  Basically my experience went like this: After an afternoon of shooting candids downtown, I walked into a mostly empty restaurant. 3 people in the place, including the server, who upon seeing me... almost immediately walked in back and did not return for about 5 min.

  As I was starting to debate leaving, he came back out and hurried me to a table, handed me a menu and was gone again.  Ok, maybe a bad day?  I let it go, but after about another 5 min and no drink order, I was starting to get frustrated.

  Then something funny happened; a group of 5 people, obviously casino workers, happened into the place and holy crap, this guy came alive.  He rushed out to seat them, making small talk, suggestions on the menu and taking -their- drink order.  Not mine tho, I had to wave him over.  Finally, after these folks got their drink order, he came over to get mine and my lunch order. No small talk or suggestions by the way.

  My food did come out fast, and around the time as the other table and the vermicelli was adequate but forgettable.  Never saw the server again till I paid, where I gave the cashier a $10 tip, left a dime on the table and left.  And I won't be back.

Ok, so I like wings. The best finger food there is(sorry sushi) and have ate at and reviewed just about every place in town that is worth reviewing but every time I get caught up in a conversation about it, people bring this place up as the best. Even to the point of being dismissive of my opinion since I had not.

  I really wanted to knock this one out in 2020 but being an "essential worker" has made it hard to do anything this season, but I digress.

  I went here on a Saturday night a couple weeks back and it was lightly seated, with delivery drivers seeming to make most of their business. They have a good selection of hard spirits and beer behind the bar. Limited seating in an already somewhat cozy space.

  I ended up taking to the kitchen manager before I ordered to find out how the wings were cooked.  Mainly because I prefer a fried chicken wing to a baked one.  Its a texture thing.

  They actually par bake the chicken beforehand and finish it in the fryer.  I imagine this is because the wings themselves are very meaty. Like twice the size of a normal buffalo wing.  If you tried to deep fry something big and meaty, you tend to overcook the outside and leave the inside a little rare.

  The result is chicken that has a more roasted texture, rather than crispy fried. Think a rotisserie chicken.  Juicy and flavorful. No, It doesn't have very crispy skin but it's still very good.  It is also served fast, probably less than 7 min.  

  Then there is the toppings, which consisted of peppers, garlic and parm.  Perfectly accented th chicken without overpowering it or making me want to scrape off the detritus before I dipped it in the house made ranch. Which, by the way, is the best ranch I've had.

  So yes, Noble Pie knocks it out of the park with their wings.  Not something I will seek out when I am wanting traditional style but definitely something I will suggest to anyone wanting a nice, juicy and meaty wing.  Of which there are plenty.

Decent place to have a meal or hang out with friends, I think. I normally am not a fan of chain restaurant cocktails as they tend to just be full of sugary mixers, but I gave the spicy margarita a try and was pleasantly surprised. I think the strawberry was unnecessary, but it was still a good drink. They have plenty of good local drafts to offer. 

Our server Lance was very nice and funny! I was unsure what to order because most of the options seemed underwhelming (standard sports bar fare though). I settled on the Nacho Mama's pizza, and I'm glad I did! It also would make a yummy cold midnight snack with the leftovers! That pizza has refried beans in lieu of sauce, cheese, jalapenos, and a sour cream drizzle. It's like nachos on a pizza! It was very good! The crust was soft but also had a nice crust on the outside. I definitely recommend eating it with a fork as the bottom crust doesn't really stay firm under all those toppings. 

My husband had the boneless wings and said they were better than BW3's. I haven't been impressed with B-dubs lately so take that for what it's worth. They definitely looked good although I didn't try them - the chicken was tender and didn't look processed much. 

There are plenty of TVs around to watch whatever sports are in season. The garage bar is completely separated from the rest of the establishment, but it's a nice feature I think. There is a separate bar in the other area, but then there is a separate dining area if you don't wish to sit in the bar.

I decided to try the Friday night fish fry. 
Not at all impressed with quality of food. 
The outside of the fish was hard/tough and extremely greasy.  After I removed the inedible outside it revealed a three-inch square piece of very very overcooked fish
The bread was soaked with butter or grease. 
The tartar sauce was too heavy. 
This slaw was okay and the french fries were edible. 
I then asked for the so-called "grilled" fish and the waitress brought me some boiled rubber overcooked fish. 
My girlfriend and I each got a fish dinner I agreed to only pay for one of him. 
The food was greasy and overcooked. I won't be going back to Kappys.

Great atmosphere and ambiance and the beers were amazing. While we didn't eat anything definitely the best beers top to bottom in the country. Looking forward to the Spring and drinking in their huge outside space.

The Seminole location has a lot of growing up to be like the Blind Pass location. They revamped the outside/ inside of the building which is nice but lacks being unique. 
They have way cool art at the Blind Pass one by Artist & Designer Lauren Smith. I have purchased 2 pieces of her art there and one from a  local brewery she has her art in too. This location has a great vibe! and funny menu board sayings when entering.

My first visit shortly after they opened was not anything I would write about so I didn't. I gave it a couple more chances before the April 3 rd Grand opening.  I have been disappointed. Service is slow( even when not busy) drinks from the bar take awhile unless your sitting at the bar. 
I did have a great server ( Megan from Ohio) who genuinely cared about my 1st experience and was top notch in exceeding our needs. 
I'd love to see Megan at the Blind Pass location as that's where I'll dine from now even tho it's a lot further away. This may be an occasional happy hour spot but that's all for me. 
I hope they can make this a unique Seminole spot because it has so much potential.

We had high hopes for this place but we found the burgers just average. Here you can custom order your burgers with whatever you want on it. I had a pretty standard burger with swiss, lettuce, ketchup, mustard, mayo and to add a bit of a twist-roasted corn. The buns were average-a little too big for my liking. The taste of the burger was pretty good but again, nothing too special. Not sure if we'll be back for a second round. There are so many other better options out there.

I know a new restaurant has issues which is why I don't understand why there was no management of any kind here helping staff. There were 4 customers here and good was crawling along. If they want to survive management needs to pay closer attention during this opening. First impressions are lasting ones

you would think that visiting mc donalds during the lunch rush would mean fresh fries and double cheese burgers that have either spent enough time under the warmer to slightly melt the cheese or (if you're lucky) have been made with freshly grilled meat to melt the cheese.

today (at a relatively busy 12:30pm), i received neither.  my fries were the "sitting out for a few hours" kind (with no salt?), and the double cheese burger was downright cold. cheese, meat, everything.  really disappointing.

Saturday morning brunch at Gloria's! 

By the time we finished our walk at Oxbow Nature Study trails, we were starving for some delicious food! And I've been wanting to try Gloria's being that I was a fan of Oxbow Cafe. And we were not disappointed at all! Love their outside dining patio also!

I had the BLT and had the side of fresh fruit instead of the french fries ($8.99) and an Iced Chai Tea ($3.75). Perfect! Bella had a few sides - 1 over well egg ($1.50), 2 slices of buttered toast ($1.99) and 4 slices of bacon ($4.00) and a horchata ($3.50) ... her basic deliciousness!

We love that artsy area and we'll definitely be back! If you haven't tried it, give it a shot... everyone was very friendly, great service and excellent food choices!

Chifa is good...not amazing, but still a solid restaurant.  I went with a group of people tonight for restaurant week and we ordered almost one of everything. 

A quick run down of some of the food:
Ceviches - we had 4 different ones.  All were pretty good and refreshing except for the one with the pineapple...that one was just OK.   Also, the ceviches all tasted kind of similar.

Short Ribs - Ok

Pork Bun - these were delicious and juicy

Mushroom - with tofu and topped with puff pastry - this was OK

Shrimp Noodle - Good, but kind of creamy and heavy

Beef Noodle - did not like this...the meat tasted "gamey"

Chaufa - One of the best dishes of the night.. it was a "kicked up" version of fried rice

Crab Empanada - Another winner...crispy and delicious

Crab Curry - OK..tasted like typical curry

we had a few other dishes as well but nothing that was memorable.  Overall the place was a big OK.  The decor is nice and the service was good, but other than that, I think I might just go back to Amada.

Ok Yelpers, I'm very disappointed in you.

That's right, I'm calling you out.  In a review about a business that I think you've been treating unfairly.  I notice that ABP has gotten abysmal ratings, and I think that it's a little undeserved.  You can't give them one star because you wish you could order off of the McD's dollar menu instead of getting a pastry.  That's a gripe about Vanderbilt's decision to put in ABP and take out McDonald's, and does not belong in a review of the restaurant.  ::end soapbox::

ABP is a nice, newly renovated space that serves some tasty food.  Yes, their sandwiches can be a little pricey, but I think that they are more unique than say, a Subway sandwich, and I've so far been impressed with their freshness and quality.  If you want a Subway sandwich, there's a Subway within a five minute walk.  In two different directions.  They've got a variety of healthy and not-so-healthy snacks, a nice coffee-bar, including espresso beverages, and I really enjoy that they provide the nutritional information so that you can make an informed decision about what you're purchasing.  I've also had really pleasant interactions with the employees as I'm checking out my food.

Rooftop Bar review:

In the grand tradition of Joe Edward's establishments, this place only hires dour, slow, and rude staff.

From the impatient/snarky door person who lets you go upstairs, to the snail-like service at the bar, there'll be no mistaking you're at one of Joe's places. 

I really can't stress how terrible the service is. When you've got a full bar, you can stop doing those super awesome bottle flippy/catchy tricks. Last time I was there they charged me $50 for 2 beers and then tried to argue with me about it. They mixed up my tab with someone else.

Buttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttttt, I do love the rooftop atmosphere.

This place has pizza. It is good. 

We tried The Blues pizza-prime rib, bacon, gruyere, bleu cheese and red onions. I wanted to bathe in it.

Service was friendly and the food came out quickly even though they were hella packed.

Everything was mediocre from check in, to service,
to food....way over priced for basic stuff and nothing was really even good

We went here after a bust of a dinner at another spot. This food was exactly the pub food we were looking for.  Service was great even though it was only two people and busy. Only downside was there was one girl who worked there and was having a shift drink who was so loud that you could literally not hear anything else. Not the bartender, not my husband, no one. It was ridiculous and the story she was telling blew so it was all just annoying.

First of all, I don't like panda express to begin with. I just have a picky husband and sometimes I give in. That being said, I don't know why we keep coming back to this location. EVERY time we're here, they're out of half their food and backed up on their orders (express?) , and EVERY time the workers are rude as f***. This time was no exception, other than a lady named JOJO being exceptionally rude. I actually think I may have never seen someone talk to customers the way she talked to us and every other customer. The eye rolling and passive aggressive sarcastic attitude she gave us? I always feels petty complaining about workers attitudes, but trust me she was acting like a straight up b**** to everyone. If we weren't exhausted and starving, we would've walked right out after dealing with her at the register. The cooks and other server were hard at work trying to catch up, but she was like hey instead of contributing I'm gonna ruin everyone's day with s***** attitude.

Roadhouse is fine but waiting almost 2 hours after calling ahead is a terrible experience, especially for a restaurant like this. If this problem is typical, I recommend taking reservations. 
The food is fine, nothing to write home about but not bad and the prices are alright. The service is good but it all goes back to the original wait time which put a huge damper on the night and guaranteed me to not return unless absolutely necessary on a Monday afternoon or some other time I don't have to worry about wasting 2 hours of my life

Unacceptable service , tired of having to explain to manager how their employees should be doing their jobs . McDonald's is not what it used to be. Missed food or inaccurate menu item during my last 3 visits. close to where I live so I always keep giving them chances , but honestly not worth the time or effort anymore .

Ate here last night with three friends and the husband and for the most part really enjoyed it. 

Pimento cheese spread with house made pickles and little buttery crackers (also house made) was delicious and served with country ham. Always a plus in my book.

The other appetizers were corn and crab fritters (um....could we have some crab please? The crab was just a whiff) and pigs in a blanket. The problem with those was there was too much blanket (very tasty) and not enough pig. Seems pretty simple.

The main courses we had were pork chop with collards and black eyed peas (which my friend liked), lamb pot pie, which was delicious but could've used a little more seasoning....the crust, however was fantastic. 

Finally the odd man out of the entrees. It was listed as "roast chicken." In my book that usually means a few pieces of chicken roasted with crispy skin on...or some variation on that.  This was listed as "Roast Chicken rice + pan gravy + mushrooms + buttered white bread." It had all of those things, but it was actually shredded chicken in what amounted to a risotto. That's not roast chicken in my book. It was tasty (if again under seasoned) but really not what was advertised.

I'd definitely go back for the baked goods, the sesame crusted bread served with the pot pie was really nice as were the house made crackers.

When naf naf first opened I couldn't get enough of it. It seems to have gone downhill since then. They no longer are serving fresh pitas, they're out of a bag. I believe they're making them ahead of time and bagging them up, just not the same as fresh. They used to cut the pita across the top and put everything in and it would stay together "nicely". Now it just falls apart and is a bit more difficult to eat. It tastes good but just isn't what it once was unfortunately.

Just ate here....not my cup of tea. First of all they put two paper  thin burgers on one bun. I am a thick pattie person. Then the "shakes" were too thick and did not really taste like ice cream. The French fries were the hit here. Hand cut fried just right. I will probably  not eat here again, unless the only choice  is McDonald's or burger king. Much rather Tru burger, five guys or Ruth Chris.

The food here was okay. The grits while cooked well, had a funny after taste that I couldn't  quite place. The biscuits are divine! The crispy  potatoes were great, eggs cooked correctly. My wife enjoyed her yogurt with granola. The service, however was mediocre...I don't know if it was just our person, or in general....and it was little things, like he brought the coffee, but we asked for sugar and cream, he wiped off the table next to us then spoke with another table before finally coming back with our request. Then when our food arrived, I asked for salt and pepper and again he went off to do other things....eventually we asked someone else and got it. Also, if you like coffee refills, forget that....you have to pay for every cup...he should have said something or the restaurant should specify  on the menu...no refills....AND they don't even fill the cup...it's about a half cup that you get for $3

I'm pretty stingy with the 5 stars, so my 4 stars means pretty damn good and you should definately check it out. 
My husband and I have become fans of Sahm's n Sahm's endeavors (i.e. Big Lug) for their consistent quality of food across the board at each locations. 
We have made this location a regular spot due to its location close to my husband's workplace. He loves the Sirloin steak that comes on a sizzling iron plate. Never strays. I seem to have found my favorite with the Bistro Burger. I can't quite remember the name of another sandwich I had, it was a special of the day but know I was very happy with it.
I am not one of those reviewers who has the ability to paint a picture of tastes with words. What I can do is share that this food will make you smile. Read the menu, does something sound interesting? combining flavors and items that intrigue you? Then order it, you won't be disappointed! Feel free to order how you want it. This is no chain where shit comes pre mixed or frozen all together so they just heat it up to serve.
This location is mainly a bar (they do allow kids) with a stage as they frequently have bands. No frills. Service is good, lots of selection for beers, and drinks are strong. 
Summary : if it's a Sahm's, you should eat there.

Biking around downtown, the smell of this place caught my nose. My friend talked me out of eating the PB&J I packed for lunch and to eat here. I like it. I don't love it. The lunch special prices are really good, the gyros meat is soft, flavorful and too greasy. The tatziki sauce was not over powering garlicky or cucumbery  (trademark pending on that word). I would prefer regular fries with a squeeze of lemon ad greek seasoning as opposed to the coated fries they serve. I really liked the baba gnoush (sp?) even though it was on the smoker side. Falafel are fried crispy almost burnt but good flavor. The hummus wax smooth but maybe a bit too much lemon.
Service was good, seated right away, plenty of attention and refills, she just wasn't super friendly, but I'm fine if your good at your job and not rude.

Local hole in the wall type bar. Not the new hipster trying to make Fountain Square something it's not kind of place. I usually sit outside and enjoy a few beverages after work. Very decent prices and friendly service. Inside looks to be able to accommodate a decent crowd and it's clean. I have tried the fries, very good, nice n crispy not too greasy. Special always seem reasonably priced n usually spark my interest but I'm trying to keep the spending down at the moment.

So I've been here many, many times! I've been wavering between a score of 3 and 4 stars because I really enjoy it here.

What I like the most about Julio's is the open atmosphere when the front windows are open. In the summer it is one of the busiest patios, but it is worth the wait! If you can, definitely make a reservation because this is a happening spot every night of the week in the summer. It's a great place to enjoy some drinks, Mexican grub, with in your face views of Whyte ave and some great people watching! Oh, and complementary chips and salsa when you're seated - how can you resist! The decor here is also great and it has an awesome vibe. Every server I've had has been funny and attentive. 

The bar here is AMAZING. If you want to have drinks on Whyte, come here! They have excellent margaritas, beers, and liquors. My personal favorite is the bulldog, a margarita with a corona in it! I'm kind of getting thirsty for one right now... 

The only reason I didn't give it 4 stars is because the food, while good, isn't anything out of the ordinary, but it's definitely still good.

Come down to Julio's, have a (few) drinks, and you'll have a great time!
Somebody told me they are open until 4 a.m.  How's that for value!

Tasty gyros and great steak fries served fast with a bottomless soft drink.  Quick in and out to satisfy my monthly crave.  Would be even better if feta chesse was standard on the sandwich.  The olive and cheese plate appetizer is a meal in itself with warm pita and garden ripe tomatos and peppers.  Delicious, cheap and fast.  Worth the weight when you're hungry and a great ethnic vibe plus hot waitresses.  Yum!

The best cheesesteak in Philly. This place hits every element out of the park. Steak is tasty, cheese is sharp, and the bread is surprisingly the star of the show.

A few quick notes, Angelo's is cash only, but they do have an ATM inside. When I went on a Friday afternoon, the place was absolutely packed; they did manage to get our food out to us quickly. A few tables outside the store, and some standing room inside the store to eat, but expect it to be jammed. The girl taking our orders was very friendly, and helpful, recommending I get Cooper Sharp, over American Cheese, which turned out to be the right suggestion. 

The cheesesteak with onions and Cooper Sharp cheese is the way to go. Let's start with the surprising star of the cheesesteak, the bread. We're talking about an Italian roll freshly baked in-house. It's seeded, fresh, and used perfectly. Probably the most overlooked element to any cheesesteak, Angelo's nails it. You get this perfect crunch with every bite, and I cannot even begin to tell you how good a fresh baked Italian roll is. To talk about the cheese, go with the Cooper Sharp. It's basically a sharper American, and having tasted them both side by side, the Cooper Sharp adds the perfect balance of flavor. The steak it good quality, cut into ribbons, but not really chopped up too much. I will say, the only real knock on the cheesesteak is I wish there was a tiny more steak on the sandwich, as I did get a few bites with just bread (not that I'm complaining, but is wonderful). The meat is very tasty, and more ribboned, not chopped finely. Also, when you get onions here, you can taste them. Not finely chopped, so you really get the crunch of the onion. In terms of competitors, I think John's Roast Pork cheesesteak is close to it, but the fresh Italian roll, and Cooper Sharp cheese puts this over the edge.

I also had cheese fries while I was here, honestly, they were whatever. Just average, out of a bag fries with some cheese wiz on them. Not that there is anything wrong with that, it's a classic, but nothing special about the cheese fries. Price is $11 for a cheesesteak, which I think is a bit on the higher end for Philly cheesesteaks, but totally worth it.

Food (A-) Pricing (C) Atmosphere (B), Service (B+)

Not as bad as this 2 stars indicates, but get's less desirable each time. The last 3 times I have ordered dinner here the order was wrong. I usually order right before work so no time to take it back and go inside to get it right. The late night drive thru is pretty good. They should do hamburgers 24-7 not a breakfast type. I do but prefer burgers

This is a review of the bar.

This place was a real life saver during Endymion in that it was a good place to grab drinks and use the restroom. The bar itself is pretty much as divey as it gets, but the drinks are priced well and the bartenders were pretty friendly. If you're in the mood for food, there is a fully functioning diner in the back complete with all day breakfast and places to sit. I'm not going to lie- the food smelled and looked amazing and if I hadn't been at a parade I would have taken the time to sit down and have something to eat. I will definitely return and try the food.

I am so bummed. I've been waiting for ages to try this place and I was left with one big disappointment.

Okay, so I was here with my dad on a Friday for lunch. We got here at about 1 and we were seated immediately- great! I was here for the restaurant week lunch special, but I think they might do the $20/3 course special all the time, I'm not sure.

For my three courses I decided on the thin cut fried pickles, the shrimp and grits and the bread pudding. The thin cut fried pickles were great! Lightly battered and not heavy or overly filling. This was a great starter. The shrimp and grits were okay. The grits were decent, but not the best I have ever had and on the somewhat bland side. The shrimp are tail-on, but they were cooked nicely and were a good size and juicy.

My main reason for the 3 stars is the fact that they were out of bread pudding and we weren't informed until the end of our meal. The reason we decided to even have lunch here was because we wanted the bread pudding. Honestly, I feel like they should have either put two bread puddings aside at the beginning of the meal when we ordered, or they should have come out and said that they were out of bread pudding. I just felt like I had been kind of tricked and I don't like that feeling. And how do you run out of bread pudding two hours into lunch? Instead of bread pudding we were given chocolate torte and it was okay, but I wasn't in the mood for chocolate at all.

Anyway, the owner was super sweet and the service was good. I just don't know if I'll be back or not.

If anyone ever questions my dedication to good food, I will probably just tell them about the time I got in line at 10:30am for grilled cheese. Hey, I was 6th in line and I got to order as soon as they opened, so who's the fool now? I was here for The Big Cheezy grand opening and you really haven't questioned your life until you have rushed over to a grilled cheese restaurant at 10:30am so that you can eat delicious grilled cheese and then get back to work.

The line moved quickly and when it was my turn to order I got the crawgator, which is alligator and crawfish sausage with cheddar and pepperjack cheese, onions and peppers. I don't think I had ever had this sandwich before and it was SO GOOD! If it's your first time and you are looking for something really cheesy, I would go with this one. It's all packed between two buttery slices of sour dough bread and it's just perfect. For my side I got the bacon mac and cheese, which was beyond rich and delicious. I was happy they had "to go" boxes, because there was no way I could have finished all of this in one sitting.

The service was fast and the food was delicious. Also, they are connected to Henry's bar, if you happen to be in the mood for a cocktail with your cheese. I'll be back.

Bellocq is one of the fancy cocktail bars the New Orleans is known for. I am not really a huge cocktail person, but I can appreciate a well crafted drink.

Bellocq has an extensive menu of drinks that they can make for you, that are sure to appeal to all tastes.

Oddly enough, I think that the best thing about this place is the atmosphere. It's really dimly lit, which I love. I really dig cozy places like this. It also has a lot of sofas and benches for group sitting, which adds to the tranquility of the entire place. 

If you are in the mood for a little something to eat, they have a small menu of little tapas that you can munch on.

I knocked off a two stars because the staff seemed overwhelmed by the large crowd and there was limited seating at 9 pm.

I'm pretty amazed. I had never heard of this place when a friend suggested that we get dinner here.

Walking in, the restaurant is small but nice. We were here during the week, so there was no huge crowd and there were a few empty tables. We sat down and the waitress was quick to come over, bring us a bread basket and take our beverage order.

Looking over the menu, everything sounded delicious. I decided to go with the Penne Alla Vodka which is penne pasta, mixed with a delicious cream sauce and huge pieces of crab. It was delicious and creamy and I was delighted that there was plenty of crab. The dish had a lot of flavor and wasn't overly filling.

My only complaint was that service was pretty slow.  Considering it was a week night and there weren't a lot of people in the place, it took a while to get our food. We weren't in a rush, but from the time we sat down until the time we left, two hours had passed. It took about 45 minutes to get our entrees, even though we didn't order anything crazy complicated. It's not the end of the world, but just be aware of this if you are looking to grab dinner and you are on a schedule that you have to keep.

I would return to this cozy little French Quarter restaurant and would recommend it for a date.

This Pho Bang is good. Really good. As much as I liked this one, I really miss the one on Manhattan, but I digress.

I went in and got my usual beef brisket and rare flank Pho. It was really good and had a lot of flavor. Honestly, if you read my review for the other Pho Bang, it was pretty much exactly like that. Oh! And I also really love their pork Spring rolls!

For whatever reason, this Pho Bang was really packed when I went in and it took a little while for me to be seated. That's not a huge deal, as I wasn't in any kind of major rush. I am hoping that the Pho Bang on Manhattan reopens soon (their sign says that they are TEMPORARILY closed),  but in the meantime this one will have to do.

It was the second Friday of Lent, and when my dad suggested we have lunch somewhere, I was a good Catholic and suggested a seafood restaurant. Not that Station 6 doesn't have meat, but a good rule of thumb is stick to what the place specializes in.

We were here a little after the lunch rush and were seated inside immediately. They also have lovely outdoor seating, but it was fairly warm on this day, so I chose to sit in the a.c. Looking over the menu, everything looked incredible. I had heard raves about quite a few dishes here, and I decided to go with the trout almondine.

The trout was perfectly prepared and was topped with a nice butter sauce. It also came with a side of new potatoes and asparagus, which I only ever enjoy in restaurants, so I consider that a treat. My photo doesn't do this dish justice at all: the fish was tender, juicy and full of flavor. The potatoes and asparagus were nice and buttery and all of the flavors of the food blended together wonderfully. The portion was light and great for lunch.

My one complaint is the wait time for the food. Usually when I go to a restaurant for lunch I expected to be in and out within about 45 minutes, max. Well, from the time we ordered to the time the food hit the table, 30 minutes had passed. I guess that one could argue it's because the meal was made-to-order and it takes time, but with only a few other people eating I was kind of baffled why it took so long. It's not a a big deal, but it's worth noting if you have a limited lunch hour.

The service here was excellent, I enjoyed the atmosphere and the food was delectable. I'll be back.

We were craving good gumbo and did a yelp search for the area we were in and tried Gallier's.  This place is a bit off the beaten path, not in the Quarter price trap, but a short walk across Canal.

Gallier's gumbo is big on flavor with smokey undertones; and the serving size was big for $11.  It was probably about a 12/14 ounce bowl.  It's a dark, very thin roux, which isn't bad, but definitely a bit more soupy texture.  There was plenty of sausage and chicken in every spoonful.  We ordered our gumbo New Orleans style, which is with potato salad (on the side) for an extra $2 each.  I was skeptical about gumbo and potato salad but some of my employees had previously encouraged me to try it--I must say that the combination was magical.  The potato salad was southern, a bit sweeter but offered a great balance with the savory gumbo.  Served with buttery garlic bread.

We also tried the chargrilled oysters, $13 for half dozen.  Heavy on the cheese compared to other restaurants, like a sharp cheddar vs. mild Parmesan.  Not ideal for me, so I'd pass next time and stick with only the gumbo.

Parking is a bear, so walk over after you've had enough of Bourbon Street.

I didn't go to the store but had an apple fritter from this place.  It was super fresh and flavorful (not boring) but not very apple-y.   Nonetheless it was tasty.   I would buy them again even if just looking for a good donut.

Four stars from me as I would come here again.   We stopped in here after a shopping event in the mall.  Service was great and the atmosphere was quite nice for a mall restaurant- you actually get some natural light!    We scored a table near the window so that made the experience much more pleasant.  

We split two appetizers - the calamari which we chose to have Thai style and the tuna.   These were two generous portions.  The calamari were a bit overdone but the sweet and spicy chili sauce was good and was set off with small pieces of pineapple and peanuts.   The shashimi was dressed with black and white sesame seeds, wasabi swooshes, and a seaweed salad.  All good.

For entrees, we had the fish and chips, the fish sandwich, and the crab cake sandwich.   The crab cake was all crab but could have used a bit more seasoning and a smaller bun..   The fried fish was also good and crispy with a thin coating.   These were served with a generous portion of fries and Cole slaw.

We were too full for desert even though we left plenty of fries behind.  I would definitely return.

Ate here earlier today. The service was awful. The waitress behaved as if anything else was more important than actually taking care of our table. The food was bland and completely forgettable. I will never eat here again

I had a burger with bacon and cheese. It had no flavor. The french fries were slightly under done.

Not so bodacious. I ordered the pork ribs here for dinner, with a side of beans and coleslaw.  The pork ribs were overcooked, and too hard to chew some of the outside parts of the ribs.  The parts that were not overcooked were nice and soft, but it was hard to sort through the meat that way.  The bbq sauce was okay, but nothing to write home about.  I did not like the coleslaw at all.  It was sort of warm, and had a kind of old taste, and was very bland.  The beans were okay.  The fries were so-so... a little soggy.  My friend had the pulled pork sandwich but said it was so awful he actually had to send it back and order something else.  Having lived in the deep south for many years, I wasn't expecting perfect bbq here in Santa Barbara, but even so, I would not recommend this place for bbq ribs.
Great selection but the lines at checkout can get crazy. Parts of the store could use more cleaning.

I kinda like this spot....it's like a cool hood bar without being in the hood.   


-cool bartenders
-food looks tasty (I'm going to come back to try those buffalo shrimp-love those!)
-cool/non-pretentious crowd

I'd say come here to pre-game with a group of friends or stay the whole night and get trashed and still have a lil money in the bank to go to brunch the next day and cure that hangover :-)

Inconsistent food and poor service. I understand Vietnamese and the lady told the server to tell customers they didn't have the food if what they ordered wasn't what the chefs knew how to make. Also the chefs are white americans. authentic viet food is not made by white Americans.

This is up there on worst places I've ever eaten. Location, service and all that is fine..... but the ACTUAL FOOD was completely a waste. I felt like Chef Ramsey would come in and flip out on the chef for how bland the food was. Worst Filet l ever got but then again.... l shouldn't have gone to a place that wasn't a steakhouse for a Filet to begin w so that's my fault. 

Anyway.... take the money you would spend here and just hit up Applebees or something.

I visited this location a week ago. I have experienced very slow service here before, but try to be patient and understanding. My most recent experience makes me not want to return to this location. 
I ordered online and opted to pick up in the drive thru. There were three cars ahead of me when I arrived. It seemed to be taking a very long time for those ahead of me to receive their orders. When I pulled up to the window, the employee did not realize my order was the one placed online. She promptly gave me my drink, but then I waited longer for my food. Honestly she seemed quite overwhelmed. I must have waited 25 minutes from the time I arrived until receiving my food.
As I drove away, I double checked my order and was missing the Mexican Pizza. I was not going to wait in the ever growing drive thru line again, so I decided to go inside. There were a few people inside that seemed to be waiting for their food and were beginning to get agitated. The cashier working that day had no sense of urgency and was not rude, but not pleasant either. I explained that I was missing the Mexican Pizza, and thankfully they had it ready. The woman from the drive thru gave it to me with sincere apologies. 
I know businesses get busy. Things happen and the restaurant is understaffed or having other issues. I get it and can be understanding. However, there always seems to be an issue here. One night they were out of all beef...ground beef and steak. Another time they ran out of mild sauce. How does that happen? Poor management most likely. The wait is always longer than it should be, and honestly the food at this location is not as good as at other locations. I will probably think twice before coming here again. The Taco Bell on Disc Drive is much better.

I've eaten here before and enjoyed the food (though I found it all a bit overly salty), but this review is strictly about their hospitality, or lack thereof, with an experience I had last night.

A group of two friends and I called around 8:45 p.m. because we know their kitchen closes at 10. We asked how long the list was and if we would be able to get a table if we came right away. The hostess who answered said, "There are only seven people on the list right now," so we told her we would be coming down in 10 or 15 minutes. "Great, see you then," she said.

So, we rushed down there by car, and when we arrived ten minutes later around 8:55 and asked the hostess to please put our name on the list, she told us they could no longer seat any more walk-ins and we would have to try our luck sitting at the bar, which was completely full. We explained that we just called 10 minutes ago and someone (apparently this same hostess) encouraged us to come in. "I'm sorry," she said, "There's just nothing I can do at this point. We can't seat anyone else."

My problem is definitely not that they don't seat walk-ins after a certain time, as that's totally understandable for a busy restaurant. My problem is that the hostess should have communicated to us over the phone that there would be a risk of this happening if we drove there. Instead, she never mentioned there would be a possibility of them filling up and encouraged us to come down. So, obviously this qualifies as extremely poor customer service, and we were all understandably upset. Fortunately, we went around the corner to Peche, got our name on the list with a fairly lengthy wait but had a really great experience there.

Our glasses smelled like dishwater, it was cold, and my friend kept making out with her ancient boyfriend.  And someone played one hundred thousand country songs on the jukebox.

The next time I go, I hope the glasses don't have that stench...because that's worth TWO WHOLE STARS.  The beer selection was decent, and I like its history.  I wish bars didn't blast air conditioning, but I understand it's because the waiters are moving around and would be hot otherwise.

But ugh, those glasses.  =(

We first tried out this restaurant several years ago and had a pleasant experience; pretty good Greek food and great service. But we tried it again this week and were disappointed - this place has definitely gone downhill. The food was not very good (one of us liked his meal but the rest of us were underwhelmed at best - fish not cooked properly, mushy vegetables that seemed to come out of a can, etc., etc. The service was subpar as well. Worst of all, they blasted disco-type music throughout the night - the music was so loud that we had to scream just to hear each other across the table. We won't be coming back.

Decent sushi, shakes, and hamburgers, poor service. The mix of foods may sound weird, but it actually does cater well to a group of people who want different types of foods for lunch or dinner. The spiked shakes are super yummy. The biggest issue I've had is the slow service. Furthermore, I've come several times when they've been out of house wines and forgotten to bring out appetizers. Hopefully they improve as they become a more seasoned business.
Great burgers and service. Tina was amazing. The reason for the 4 was the menus smelled funny like they were wiped off with a sour towel. The smell instantly dissipated when the menus were removed.

Zia's is good and would probably get 3.5 stars in my book if I could. I would not rate this as high as Trattoria Marcella, but it is still pretty solid.

Enjoyed the house salad to start. The toasted ravs were ok, but not great. (We tried both kinds)

My wife's entree was tortellini with cream sauce -- very good! I had their veal saltinbocco and it was good. I can't recall what my in-laws ordered, but they seemed to like it.

We went here for a birthday dinner recently on a weekday night. When we arrived, it wasn't super crowded, so we were sat immediately. This is a nice little restaurant in the Hill neighborhood, and has a family feel to it. 

The food is primarily Italian, but also has sandwiches, and pizzas. We ordered a few chicken marsala and spedini dishes, along with a cannelloni and pizza. The food was all really good, but was strange as they came out separately, and one person had to wait a few extra minutes for theirs. Not a big deal though. 

Their service was good, and they made sure our drinks were refilled all the time. We also got a free dessert for the birthday girl, which was very nice of them. 

If you are looking for a nice, cozy place in the Hill, Guido's would be a good selection, and the prices are very reasonable. Only docking 1 star because the floor was really slick, not sure what from, but our chair kept sliding around while we were eating. Other than that, the food and service were 5 stars.

There aren't that many indian places in New Orleans unfortunately....well at least I haven't found that many. 

Nirvana does the job for me. It's not the most fantastic excellent indian food but every time I've gone there it's been pretty good. It's enough to make me happy and come back. Lunch buffet everyday except sunday. Dinner buffet thurs and sat night. Their buffet is always good and I've been there on days when they don't have it and ordered from their menu and had just as much of an enjoyable experience.

I know some people have had bad experiences...but I recommend

My friend who is of Sicilian heritage went with me to Ancora. Of course, he knew that any pizza he had in the U.S. would not come close to what he had had in Italy. However, he said that Ancora is the closest to what he had in Italy and therefore, the most authentic pizza place in the city. 

I've read Ancora's pizza rules on their website and their goal is to produce a product that contains simple and fresh ingredients. The toppings on a pizza are unimportant if the dough and sauce are not done correctly and Ancora does both very well. Their dough is very simple, no oil or added ingredients. Just flour and water mainly. Their sauce is also well done as it does not overwhelm the pizza. All their pizzas have very few ingredients, not ten things thrown on top like some places.  It is a little pricey compared to other pizza places but I look forward to going back

Came here to Bar Volver for a couple weeks ago for Restaurant Week and was sorely disappointed in the experience. From start to finish, I was there for 2 hours and my companions longer than that. By the time I left, we were still waiting for the dessert which I left there.

The issue wasn't the food (I ordered the kale salad and fried chicken) which were delicious. My cocktails were also very enjoyable. The problem was mostly our server. Everything took an inordinate amount of time between getting our cocktails and food ordered. I asked her twice for ice and after a half hour asked another server for the 3rd time. She never gave me silverware or a plate which took me a while to get her attention to get. 

Additionally, it took a while in between courses to get the food which added to the 2-2.5 hour meal. 

While everyone (including the server) were friendly, the slowness of everything would deter me from going back.

This is the 4th time I have eaten here. Food was just as bad as the last couple of times. Came for fathers day. 7 adults and 4 kids. Not a single person liked their food. I wish we had gone somewhere else. I do not know how they are still in business. Would not recommend for my dog. 0 stars

First, let's start with the atmosphere. They don't hide it, it's in a church, right in the main area. It's really cool, however the couple of times I've been there others in the group were a little creeped out, but hey what can you do it's a cool idea. The beer is great, I really enjoy their Confessional IPA, and their oktoberfest was great as well. Their food is unique, however not for everyone. I had the bison meatloaf with the mashed potatoes and gravy, which came additionally with a side of fries. I thought the food was good, but really was here more for the beer.

Been here twice gotten the same this fries and the shroom burger.  Very disappointed with this place! 
I'm a vegetarian and I've tried a lot of veggies burgers in the past.  This one is 6.25 ish for a rather tiny fried ball of grease on a soggy potato bun. When I bit into the grease ball my mouth was scaled with liquid gross cheese. The fries look like they came from sysco frozen and refried.  I only got half through my meal before I was grossed out and left.  For a dollar more I could of gone to hip city and gotten a burger that tastes good and is adult portioned.

So... I was super excited to have Deanie's in my neighborhood Uptown. Though I was disappointed that this location also follows the "No reservations" policy of their other restaurants, my guest and I decided to wait it out. 

It was a Monday night and the hostess checked us in by name and indicated there was about a 20 minute wait. The hostess also indicated that there were two (2) available seats at the bar, since a couple had just left. My guest and I headed to take advantage of the bar seating, since no one ahead of us was interested. We approached the bar area, only to be rudely stopped by Chandra Chifici, Owner, Deanie's Uptown. She flippantly remarked that we needed to first sign in with the hostess instead of heading to the bar. When I indicated that we'd already signed in and the hostess subsequently directed us to the available bar seating, she completely ignored me and escorted us back to the front. She refused to seat us and instead chose the next folks on the list (who did not want bar seating). She also never apologized for the misunderstanding. Rude and unacceptable. 

Despite the rude behavior of Owner Chandra Chifici, we waited patiently to be seated...wherever we were told.

Once seated at a table, I ordered a dozen oysters on the half shell and my guest ordered the pick 3 combo fried seafood dinner with fries. Sadly, the oysters were haphazardly shucked and there was an unusually large amount of broken shells in eat bite. I was constantly picking out small pieces of shell with each oyster. As one who eats a LOT of oysters on the half shell, this was so disappointing, especially for a seafood restaurant. Note: I did not eat any of the fried seafood but my guest commented that it was "just ok."

The restaurant was relatively disheveled and the staff was slow to turn tables after guests left. This was seemingly a large contribution to the delay in seating new guests. 

When I went to use the ladies room, I was unpleasantly surprised. It was absolutely disgusting. Paper everywhere, a VERY soiled toilet, dirty sink, and filthy floor...badly in need of bleach. Since this restaurant is relatively new (only opened a few months), then it is inconceivable why the ladies restroom was in such a poor state. 

Additionally, if Owner Chandra Chifici expects to have long-term success Uptown, then she must change her tune. Even the greatest restaurant will fail with poor customer service from management. In truth, Owner Chandra Chifici would GREATLY benefit from customer service refresher training and better manners...

With so many other delicious dining options Uptown, there's absolutely no reason to be treated rudely at this New Deanie's location. No thank you, Chandra Chifici.

As another storied addition to the Vetri empire, Pizzeria Vetri slings out pies on par with the city's other Neopolitan haunts. The topping selections here lean a little more conservatively than do the options at other pizza spots, but there's nonetheless something for any palette. A good chunk of the menu is vegetarian-friendly, including the delicious melanzane pie with tender, rich roasted eggplant, creamy straciatella cheese, and tangy chunks of San Marzano tomato. The more carnivorous crudo pizza also tasted excellent and brought gossamer thin sheets of prosciutto cotto (more tender than its dry cured cousin) paired nicely with funky yet smooth buffalo mozzarella. The crusts struck the appropriate balance between thin crispiness and glutinous stretch, each bite offered pleasant chewiness, a good punch of fermented flavor, and a nice bit of char.

The rotollo lived up to the considerable hype; the combination of nutty pistachio pesto, porky mortadella, and cheese harmonized rather well and made for a delicious snack. The canned beer program at Pizzeria Vetri is similarly impressive, and the draft beer list is rather small but well-selected. One major pet peeve I have with the space is its communal seating. I understand the purpose is to promote conviviality among patrons, but I'd rather enjoy my pizza in relative privacy than bump elbows and make friends (as curmudgeonly as that sounds). Truth be told, the pies here aren't leaps and bounds ahead of other Neopolitan live pie joints, and that speaks more to the quality of our gourmet pizza scene than Pizzeria Vetri's pies. Vetri's new place is thus a solid addition to any pizza rotation. These are five star pies, but minus one for the seating.

The food quality and selection has gone down a notch, so Grand China Buffet loses a star.

The other positives about Grand China Buffet I outlined in my past review still stand: very quick turnover, decent variety, surprising cleanliness, and unparalleled people watching. Not everything is good, but there are enough good things on the buffet line to keep me coming back roughly monthly. Worth the $12 to gorge yourself on seafood, the Mongolian Grill station, and some of the more authentic Chinese stuff.

I absolutely love Bahama Breeze! Every time I go there I know I am guaranteed to have a yummy meal with an island feel. This island feel here will have to do until my trip to the Caribbean in a few months! Anyway, this time I ordered the Key West Tacos with a side of yellow rice and black beans. The fish in these tacos is mahi mahi with tomato salsa, slaw, and a side of guacamole. It was very tasty, and one of the lower calorie choices on the menu. I will have to return one night when they have live music going on
We went their for breakfast and while the seating area is quite nice the food was hugely disappointing. The egg dishes we ordered were bone dry and bland. There is better in Santa Barbara.

Cute lil açaí bowl joint. I love all the different sized portions you can order. 

We got a lil baby açaí bowl and pitaya bowl. They were the perfect pick me up before brunch. Packed with fiber to get your engine revving!

Honestly I am not a big fan of açaí bowls, I prefer parfaits

If you think you are big and bad you can try to tackle an entree item solo. For the rest of us mere mortals bring a buddy to tag team these massive sandwiches. 

Everything here is oversized. Even the cups of water are wider and larger than your standard restaurant cups. 

The potato pancakes were the best part of the meal and sadly the smallest part of the meal. I've never had such a tasty little latke in my life! Highly recommended. 

The pastrami Rueben can handily feed two growing children and the chocolate bobka French toast is the size of a loaf of bread which can feed two as well. 

The cheese is melted on the Rueben and slides out easily so be sure to grip the sandwich firmly. 

The chocolate bobka has raisins in it which I was fine with but I know it was definitely a surprise. 

The serve produces free chocolate chip cookies when they bring your check. I had zero desire for any additional food. My girlfriend said the cookies were harder than they looked. 

The food here is good but the huge portions are what make this place memorable.  I will probably never go back to The Rooster, the size of their sandwiches are pathetic. I guess size does matter.

Don't get me wrong. I want to love it because its proximity. I want to make it my home base, but they have too many flaws. Despite it being open from early to late (7-11pm i think), the beer is hella expensive (even the wooter beer). Can you get a Kensinger or something that is cheap and local? The sandwiches are pretty good but they could be bigger in size. Staff is overall nice (family run) and it is super convenient. Maybe I won't be a baby and start making adult money to afford philly beer prices...smh

Amazing bbq and what a nice little spot right on Alt 19. I walked over for a bite to eat after having a beer at de Bine Brewing Co and was pleasantly surprised. The owner is super nice and made sure I got exactly what I wanted which was some pulled pork and a couple sides. So I literally got a bowl layered with baked beans, pulled pork, macaroni & cheese and topped with coleslaw-genius! It was more than enough food and so good! Have to try this spot out, it's delicious!

Recently had lunch here and overall it was pretty good but not great although this definitely go back for another try. First I'll start by saying inside is not very kid friendly with lots of high top tables and oversized shareable booths which I like the idea  but I'm sure the next person isn't necessarily gonna want to share a seat next to a two year old. So anyways we sat outside. Lots of fans to keep you cool but talk about the most uncomfortable chairs ever! 

Now onto the food, we started with two appetizers a tamale with pork and the egg rolls. Both were delicious but I'd say the egg rolls were the better of the two. For my entree I had beef brisket with potato salad and the gouda mac n cheese. The brisket was not very warm and on the chewy side so I didn't eat any but the sides were amazing, especially the mac n cheese! My husband had chicken and pork with fries and green beans. The fries were extremely soggy and greasy but the chicken and beans were good. We both drank sweat tea which was good and our server kept our drinks full. She was very attentive and did a great job. Overall it was a decent lunch and I'd give it another try but prob go when it's less busy so we could get a table inside.

We stopped in for lunch yesterday. It was beautiful outside so we took a table outside. Our server was very friendly and attentive. My husband ordered the fish spread to start which was a little too fishy for me but he enjoyed it, we shared the brewers choice pizza but we weren't all that impressed- it was greasy and fell apart so it was hard to eat. Our daughter had the grilled chicken kids meal which was great and she enjoyed. The beer is always wonderful and as I said the service was great so I'm sure we will be back and hopefully have better luck next time with the food.

Our new favorite spot! The table side guacamole is a must! My husband had the shrimp and grits as an appetizer and it was probably the best he has ever had. I had buffalo chicken sliders and they were delicious as was my husbands meatloaf. Our server was very friendly and on top of things. Looking forward to going back!

The Izzy's steaks were just overloaded with way too many peppercorns. Their regular steaks were much better. The French onion soup was delicious!  They served some really good pizzas. The biggest problem was that the service was TERRIBLE!! It took forever to get our food. We had to ask several times for our checks and then instead of separating our checks out, we got the exact same checks. Someone was definitely not paying attention! A regular customer said this was not what this restaurant is normally like but we were just in town for a few days.

We stopped here for lunch after running errands all morning.  We were seated promptly, but unfortunately the seat was wet.  Apparently someone had wiped it off but didn't dry it.  Oh well, I won't melt.  Jenee was our waitress and she did a wonderful job.

We decided to do the half and half (I think they called it the duo).  We each got half of a salad (me a Caesar, him a super spinach + quinoa).  We both decided on the oven roasted turkey with brie sandwich.  Both our salads were good but each of us agreed that we could have used just a bit more dressing.  The sandwich was delicious but I agreed with our waitress who said she thought it would be better if it had cranberry chutney on it.  All in all, it was a good lunch and fueled us for the rest of our day.

Would I come back here?  Yes I would because it's a great place to grab lunch.

Good location for a Hooters. Parking is a challenge, but no more so than most places in downtown. Service was just OK, no real complaint, but nothing to rave about on a slow night. Food is decent, as it is at most Hooters - again, nothing to rave about. We had a group of 6 adults and 5 children, everyone was well fed. Biggest complaint...automatic 18% gratuity added to the check for any party over 6. We normally tip 20%-25%, but since they added the 18%, we left it at that. I guess I understand that they do this because some groups under-tip, but somehow rubs me the wrong way....what if service had been really poor? I have to believe that this policy costs the servers more tip money, than if they just left tips up to the patrons...

LOVE the food here. It's fantastic, but I took off 2 stars for service. I have several issues with this place in regards to service. I've never seen an employee over maybe say 18 there.
