That being said the service really hasn't been that good the last several times I've been there. They struggle with consistent portions and they just seem to be constantly in the weeds. The person that cashes me out is always nice, but they need a manager on duty more consistently. I also think that their guac is too expensive. I'm good with an upcharge but I think it's like 1.50 extra. I can make my own bowl of guac for 2.00.

I came here to celebrate a friend's birthday. We sat at the bar and ordered food and drinks. I ordered the copa lemonade which was delicious! They put vodka in it and ask you if you want the house vodka, absolut, grey goose, or ciroc. They bartender mentioned that most people love the peach ciroc that they add to it, so I chose the ciroc. Mind you, the copa lemonade is only 7.50. She didn't tell me that it would be five dollars extra to add the ciroc to my drink, so when I got my check I was unpleasantly surprised.  No wonder she was selling the ciroc so hard. On top of that, she added the 18% gratuity even though there were only three of us and we all got separate checks. This place has a fun atmosphere, but I don't like when bartenders try to trick you into spending more money. I'll definitely keep my eyes open if I ever find myself here again.

This is a review for the dessert I tried at Chaatable. The dessert, FULL ON FALOODA, needs to be removed from the menu. I can't believe a well-known chef has something that bad on their menu. I'm a lover of international cuisines, I love Persian rose-flavored vermicelli ice cream, I've enjoyed Chinese ice w/ custard/oatmeal/syrup, etc. But the Full On Falooda is terribly chewy vermicelli noodles topped with a creamy mixture that turns the dish into a gel-fest. You can't even get noodles up to your mouth on a utensil because it's all the consistency of slime with vermicelli in it....so the noodles hang down in the slime. The small bit of ice cream in the middle of the dessert was tasty. It would be best just to serve that....instead of the concoction. 
.
So obviously I don't recommend the Full On Falooda. Stay away from that one. I haven't had any of the other desserts.

Nothing hits you like a little age discrimination when you first walk in. Let me get this out of the way, I have dined here many times before and never once had a problem. Now lets jump to the past Saturday night. I take my wife out to Valentines Weekend Dinner and get 5 PM reservations. We walk in and there is no greeting at all, just 2 ladies staring at us like we had no business in there. We tell them we have reservations and they proceed to sit us. Our waitress comes and is the most ignorant waitress I have ever had in my life, no welcome nothing just here is your menu and walk away. (She was the sweetest to the old couple next to us even saying happy valentines day to them.) Anyway, we order one filet and one strip steak cooked medium. The food comes out 5 minutes later with hardly any grill marks and so rare I actually had to send the food back. (This is the first time, as I never once sent something back) Never one apology for the way undercooked steak or anything. Get it back to an actual cooked rare steak which I ate. My wife's filet was also incredibly rare. The service here was the worst I have ever experienced in my life. They rushed us out of there since we were home not even an hour after arriving. The two stars are for the food which was good except the cold stale champagne cake. I will never go back here and give my business to other local establishments that know how to treat their customer and cook an actual steak to the temperature you desire.

What a delightful surprise...really good barbecue in Nashville! We went on the strength of Yelp reviews and were not led astray. The scent of smoke wafted its way into the car as we parked, which is always a good sign. This is a humble, family owned restaurant, and you will get multiple greetings when you walk through the door. I love that. We were invited to seat ourselves, and I chose the back room, as I heard the unmistakable sound of a guitar and country crooning...another delightful surprise; music with our dinner. I didn't have a huge appetite on my visit, but had enough to order the pulled pork plate with 2 sides and a corn cake...I went with their vinegar slaw and turnip greens. Hubby had the ribs, so I got to sample those too. The pulled pork was great; it had a pervasive smokiness and a nice meaty flavor. Sauces come table side, and their mild, which has a distinct vinegar note, was a perfect accompaniment. The sides were tasty also. I liked the ribs, but the pulled pork was the winner here for me. I will most definitely return for more delicious 'que!

In my humble opinion, New Orleans is one of the top 3 dining cities in the United States, and John Besh is arguably the best chef in town (granted, he has some strong competition in Donald Link and Susan Spicer). Whatever issues I may have once had with this restaurant have dissolved completely, and I joyfully and enthusiastically pronounce my love for this wonderful little bit of heaven on earth. When we arrived for our latest evening of indulgence, we discovered that the menu had been changed and some of our old favorites were missing. My husband's mood downshifted from expectant to irritated very quickly, but he need not have worried; the items we chose were sufficiently delicious to turn things around. We started with our usual 2 dozen P&J oysters, which were better than they usually are here. I usually get a French 75 and/or a bourbon old fashioned here, and they're still some of the best cocktails in town. We had a little glitch with my husband's drink, which at first had no vodka in it and then, after being doctored up by the bartender, had way too much vodka in it. He switched beverages and all was well. 
So one change in the menu was to add shrimp and grits (Shrimp En Cocotte), and, as this is one of my favorite dishes, I chose it. Good move. Their's may well be the best executed of this Southern standard that I've ever had; creamy and spicy roasted jalapeño cheese grits with smoky Andouille and green onion sausage, redolent of that full shrimp flavor that lets you know they've infused the dish with some stock, and sizable Gulf shrimp. Perfection. Really, if they never added another dish to this menu, I could be happy with this one forever. We didn't save room for dessert, but that didn't stop us from ordering one to share. If the Chocolate Bourbon Pecan Tart with Coconut Sorbet is still on the menu when you read this, get it. Coffee as always is great here too.

Decent diner I stopped in for lunch while out on the road yesterday during client visits. The place itself looks like it used to be an old ski chalet / ski shop that was transformed into a 50's style diner. Large mural of rock and rollers on the wall, pictures of old time movie stars and rock stars hanging around, guitars pinned up, large flat screens around, etc. Actually, a very clean and nice setup here.

The menu was huge, but was what is expected of diner fare. Had a grilled chicken Greek salad wrap with fries. Not bad, but the fries were a bit under cooked. Wrap was tasty enough. There is even a salad bar here if you choose that or get it with your meal. Outside seating too for when the weather is nice.

Service was attentive and pleasant. Not your standard diner set-up but worth a try if in  the area.

For what you're going to pay, this place will probably set you back a little more than you'd want, but generally good food and good beer. Their stout is absolutely perfect, and their burgers are good. I tend to shy away from the entrees because of the price, but I hear that they're not bad. 

However, the atmosphere in here is what turns me off the most. The bar area can feel a little unwelcome to strangers, especially if you aren't dressed well.

Every few months I get the urge for a really good bowl of Matzo ball soup. In between I get the urge for borscht, great sandwiches, dill pickles and Dr. Brown's Cream Soda. Rachael's provides me with all of these needs.

A great little Jewish deli on 19th and Sansom, Rachael's has been churning out quality eats for more years than I have been old enough to say "Rueben on Rye". During holidays they provide specialties like kugel (yummm) and  unleavened treats. I am personally not Jewish but really look forward to the holidays just for the food!

Service is pretty fast and between their large windows on the corner and the characters in the dining room it's a fun spot.

I come here may be once a month , I just love eating wings and Buffalo Wild Wings happened to have the best wing  flavors out there with a big variety , service is okay , prices are okay . If u love wings and sports then this is the spot but if u sent I will recommend another restaurant .

A great new place for delicious Hawaii-inspired cuisine. It's exciting to see an accomplished young chef open a delicious new local spot. 

Aloha Ansley is in a newly renovated building along West Bay Drive. The storefront is brightly painted in a Hawaiian theme. The colorful theme carries through inside, with a hanging surfboard and Hawaiian music in the background. There are about 10 high top tables for dine-in. 

You order at the counter from the menu board; each entree is prepared fresh.  We tried the Volcano Flow Salad and the Maui Poke.

The salad is a tasty combo of mixed greens, diced tomatoes & peppers, dressed with black bean corn salsa, a dollop of guacamole and served with a side of homemade Hawaiian BBQ dressing. The dressing, with a ginger base, is excellent and enhances the combination of flavors without overpowering.  We chose BBQ chicken for a little extra protein.  This adds a big portion of shredded chicken, lightly flavored with Hawaiian BBQ seasonings.   A really good salad! 

We also tried the Maui Poke bowl. This is made up of a generous portion of imported-from-Hawaii Big Eye tuna, diced & house-marinated.  The tuna is served with diced tomatoes, mixed greens and pickled cucumbers, then garnished with sliced avocado and black sesame seeds. All of this is added to a bed of sticky coconut jasmine rice.  One of the better Poke bowls I've had - no frills but super fresh ingredients and the right proportions make this one shine. 

Honorable mention for using all biodegradable plates, bowls & forks.  Dinner for two with soft drinks is $24.

There are a few other mouthwatering options on the menu. I'll definitely be back. Recommended!

Were early and on our way to see the "Star War Movies" at the Sparks Legends Mall. We decided to get a drink and waste a half hour or so. We went to O'Cleary's  and we all had coffeed alcoholic drinks. I saw the bartender pouring the drinks in the coffee. No measurement, just perhaps judgement. Worst drinks we ever had. One ordered a decfaf drink and it was absolutely cold. The drink went to the micro wave oven and brought back without refreshing the drink. My Baileys and coffee tasted more like water. No attention to detail. Don't know how much longer they will stay in business when the employees are running away the clients. So much potential with the right management in place.

Have you ever wanted to pay high-end fine dining prices for thoroughly mediocre food? Do you have a desperate hankering for gristly steaks, sad wilted salads, and $12 cocktails so bizarrely balanced they ought to be performing at Cirque du Soleil? Good news, Moshulu's got you covered!

This place is a tourist trap, plain and simple. I'm not unsympathetic to the limitations of (what I presume is) an onboard kitchen, and Moshulu does deserve some credit for holding down the fort back when the waterfront was all but abandoned. And, sure, the view of twinkling lights across the Delaware River is quite romantic, and I've never had a server that was anything but nice.

But good lord, the food is terrible. And at those prices, that's unforgivable. I have to assume Moshulu gets by with an out-of-town crowd that comes for the novelty of sitting on a boat and watching the bridges sparkle in the sunset, and if that's what you want, you will get it. What you *won't* get, despite paying prices that rival or exceed those of any other restaurant in town, is a meal actually worth eating.

You deserve better, and your special occasions do too. My advice is to give this place a pass.

Really the only decent food option at MSY.  I've eaten here a couple of times

- The alligator sausage is very good
- The chicken livers are decent
- The okra is a little too soggy
- The red beans and rice are a little bland
- The bottles of Louisiana hot sauce are a godsend
- The service is very friendly

I thought I might suffer on my flight the first time after eating here, but no issues.

I really enjoyed my Terakawa ramen. Broth was excellent and I really enjoyed the mushrooms. All of the little add ins in the shakers created a very tasty and filling experience. Interior is standard, but clean and cute. This is also BY FAR the largest and most spacious ramen joint I will probably ever dine in. Thumbs up for bathrooms (weighs heavily in my book.) Not quite as memorable as Minka in NYC, but I would definitely return here anytime and highly recommend it.

We went first thing in the morning, and it was just OK. The owner seemed really nice, though, and was able to accommodate our dietary needs (we're on a strange diet right now), so we'll be back to give it another try.

I always enjoy the food and drinks at CPK. I think it's a solid place for lunch or dinner but it is definately overpriced. The lunch specials are probably the main selling point for me to go back, the pricing is fair for the amount of food that you get. We came here for dinner last night because it was conveniently close to the movie theater and were very impressed with the food. The Mac and cheese bites were amazing and my boyfriend was still talking about the delicious crispy chicken sandwich after the movie. I also had the appleberry sangria which was presented beautifully and was yummy! In wouldn't go out of my way to come here again but if go back if it was convenient.
Decent food and service - nothing terribly special though. As others have pointed out, pretty small tables and cramped layout overall. Bacon is very good,and coffee is decent as well.

Got their Hakka style tofu. It's too expensive for $18. It's tofu and pork belly chop. I don't think tofu and few piece of pork should be this expensive. And the rice that come with the meal is overnight rice.
Wow.  How do you screw up a finner salad.  Managers response to wilted brown lettuce.   "Thats how it all is" 46.00 for two sad dinners.  We could have had a good meal for that.  This location sucks.

Meh. I really wish there was a good Mexican place in the Far Northeast. Blah. This is everything it appears. Mexican that has been watered down to a sad shadow of a cliche and haven of Corona sponsorship. Literally you will trip over all the propaganda and branding.

I wasn't blown away by this place, but then I didn't get the infamous char-grilled pork sandwich. The food is good especially for the price. i will definitely hit it up again when I am in the area to give more of their menu a try.

I like this place! I had never tried it and just happened to be driving by and wanting to pick up a quick dinner. The location on Hampton was clean and the staff was friendly. This is a delivery or carry out location only and offered no inside dining. But, that said, the pizza was good. I tried the thin crust but intend to try their other options on future visits.

Have to say today's special salad with dried fruit was not very good. I have enjoyed previous meals here, so hope it was a fluke. Unfortunately this time the lettuce didn't seem fresh and the chicken I had them add to the salad....well....I am not entirely sure what was wrong with it.

I had the grilled 3 cheese and truffle sandwich and tomato bisque. (Although,I would be hard pressed to say there was any truffle in it.) Basically, this is one of those places where the food is good but you are really just over paying for presentation. I don't mind paying for quality, but there really isn't a pretzel worth $8. I mean let's be real, they are made with flour and salt not imported magic dust from Narnia.

 The outside seating is nice and offers a clear view of people driving by, because you are literally on the side of the street. Their beer selection is vast and the staff was friendly. Would I go back? Yeah possibly if I was already drunk and feeling pretentious. Otherwise, I would go to one of the many other options in the area.

I ate at Milk and Honey during a recent visit to Nashville. Our server had told us how they bake the breads fresh everyday and recommended we order something that was on bread. I ordered the Farmhouse Biscuit and I really enjoyed the biscuit itself. I'm not a biscuit lover usually but it was tasty. The rest of the items on the biscuit were okay. I was a little underwhelmed and felt it was missing something. My husband ordered the Prosciutto Egg & Smoked Mozz sandwich. He liked the bread it was on and that was about it. He didn't expect the prosciutto to be cooked and it was tough to bite through. I thought the restaurant itself was cute and had a good vibe. Our service was fine too. The ladies restroom needed some attention but being the 4th of July they might have been busier than normal. I just wanted to like my experience more.

So I really want to rate this place a 5 star, I think I will once I get to try their dinner.  Ok first things first, this restaurant is called Girard (per giant yellow sign).  Brasserie and bruncherie seem to be subtitles (nowhere to be seen in the front door aside from being on the menu).  Not a big deal, just technicalities. 

I came in for brunch with my boyfriend and sat outside.  I kind of got a diner vibe once I walked in the restaurant, however, make no mistake, the food was far from diner quality.  We started with the tomato gazpacho (morr puree than creamy but certainly was filled with flavor).  I normally dislike puree soup but this was really good. I had the smoked duck benedict with hollandaise sauce on the side while my bf had the country style breakfast with bacon, charred grapefruit. Ok, so I was actually expecting a thicker piece of duck than sliced beef like duck. However, it was overall very good without being too salty which is normally the reason why I don't like smoked salmon on my benedict.  Glad I got to try the duck version benedict.  My boyfriend really enjoyed the hike fries which were a fusion of being a chip but filled with potato filling. 
We ended our meal with the banana granola coffee cake, served warm and moist. No complaints there. The granola were toasty and crunchy, loved it. 
Oh for our drinks. We had the ice cafe Brulee (I thought was a little disappointing because it tasted like a cold brew) and coconut Chai lemonade (one word, INTERESTING but not my cup of tea).  Overall, a very enjoyable meal outdoors because the building was on the side where it was shaded so not too hot on summer days. 
I'd definitely come back for their dinner menu and review again. But I'd really give this a 4.5 star for brunch in fishtown.

It is a nice place if you are looking for something different out of the main hub of restaurant around king of Prussia mall area. 
Be Advise, go there only if you have time if you are looking for a quick meal forget about it. Especially around lunch time its more than an hour dining in or even take out might take 30-45min depending on there mood. 

Best is order food, call them and go run 5 miles around valley forge park and come back. Then your order is all set to go.
FYI, every time you call and order they will tell you 20min i am not lying here.
This is how regular customer gets treated and how normal business is over there. I ordered a grilled veg Sandwich. Went there after 20 min and had to wait another 25 mins as they where busy . Not house full but few tables and most where done eating. I got my To go order after 40 mins . I told the server who was bringing my food Hey it's been 40 mins since I ordered. The guy tells me, "I did not take your order, so stop yelling." Wow I was like what. Yelling is something but I was just Complaining. I was complaining because I paid for it. Customer has the right to complain as I paid for the food at it is taking 40 mins to make it. I asked him if he works there. He said yes but he was again quick to point out he did not take the order. What is it got to do with him taking the order. He is not making the food. Seems like who takes the order makes the food in this place. 
Ofcourse, sometime kitchen gets busy. But you want to be nice to your customer. "Hey we are late this time." Be honest about it. Can I give you a soda it's on us. Or maybe some fries or something. You want to keep your Customer happy. But Hell No, don't complain don't yell kinda attitude does not help in these situations. I guess you don't care if Customers comes back or not. Best of luck .

I guess that I had forgotten my previous review/ experience with Carl's Deli. With places like Pickle's around, how does this place have such high ratings? Sure, they serve Boar's Head meats and other comparable fine deli brands, but the food was ridiculous!

I have never had a true reuben from NY, but I hope to God it isn't served with microwaved meats on soggy bread. After waiting in a huge line to order, and paying $8 for a reuben, I was so livid with the quality of my food, that I left it on the table and literally walked out of the restaurant and down the street. It was probably not my finest moment, but really? 

I will never be back!

Dinner  Jan 26
  In the past year I have ate at 2 outstanding British Pubs/Restaurants in Knoxville and Dania Beach, so I feel I can judge this establishment on its merits as an English eatery.  Not to mention that on all 3 dining occasions I was fortunate enough to have a friend with me who just happens to of been born in England and is pretty knowledgeable of the cuisine there.
   What was really good:
    1) the Vindaloo w/lamb was as good as any in London.  "Brilliant dish" was what my English friend said.  But this dish was way too hot and spicy for me!
    2) chips and curry - was spot on.
    3) peas with the fish and chips were very authentically English
    4) the bar maid was fun and very engaging..and really knew her baseball!
   What was okay to not so okay:
    1) the fish was just normal, nice light crust, but small and kinda bland
    2) the chips with the fish were terrible, which was weird as the chips with the curry was incredible - not consistent.
    3) bangers and mash - really liked the gravy, but the potatoes were cold and very lumpy.  And I was very disappointed in the bangers ( sausage ) they were pretty normal and flavorless  For reference, the Crown and Goose in Knoxville actually makes their own English sausage.
    4) great outdoor patio for drinking/dining, but was surprised inside there was no dartboard.
   We made a special trip to eat there and I dont know if I would Would I go back again without trying other places 1st.

Dinner Oct 6
  Let me start by saying that the management did a wonderful job in addressing all our concerns and issues with our dinner.  They really went above and beyond to make sure we were satisfied. So even though we had some issues, I would return to this restaurant again as I really believe we just caught them on a really bad night.
  If you are the owner and you are reading this, please note that I eat out all over the country and have had maybe 1 or 2 managers as genuine and attentive as yours was on this night.  I wish I remembered his name, he really went out of his way to save the day!

Probably the worst PJ's locations in the south Jersey area. I've been here for Tuesday half off wing night probably more than 30 times in my life dating back to high school.

The wings -- delicious (sometimes there's not enough sauce). The service -- a nightmare. 

I stopped coming here after countless occasions of having to wait a ridiculous amount of time just for a table and for the food and the terrible service. Instead I choose to go to Tuesday wing night at other PJ's locations that have a much friendlier staff with better & faster service. 

It's not that I don't like PJ's, just not this location.

This is the second Chinese restaurant that I tried in Tucson, Not voluntarily but friend of my like the place, so I was just tag alone (with open mind).

Now... you guys nervous?  Wondering.."OMG what he's going say about this place?" Well~ weak-hearted people shall skip this one..nah  just kidding!!

My problem with the Chinese restaurants in general are they put WAAAAYY too much sweet and sour sauce on everything....Just in case anyone of you guys care to know...the only sweet and sour dish I had when I was kid was Sweet and sour fish. 

The artificial coloring on the pork we had... just.....sigh!!! I can see why people likes PF Chang or Olive garden, not that those food were bad,,,but if you respect your palate or passionate about food..you adventure out.

Started with the hot and sour soup...it taste OK but the ingredients were like 4 out of 10 to the original...  

Sweet & sour pork...this is the dish that makes me rather eat Arby's

Schezuan style pork (its not on the menu..I had asked the waitress changed from eggplant to this)...its a totally different dish. Although I am not complaining here since its Cantonese chef cooking back there.. you just don't asked Mexican chef make Sushi (don't want to point finger, it happened)..it just not fair.   

I had asked the seasonal veggie dish and they did a decent job which is the only dish I can shut up and eat.

Snow-peas and shrimps was the other dish my friend ordered...I didn't even try it...don't ask me why but looks pretty good.

Service was good that always can add another star.

The reason why we have Chinese restaurants like Guilin are something we can extend this review to social studies so I rather stop here and off my soap box!!

I am just a foodie after all!

I tried it for take-out, tried it as a sit-down tonight.  Disappointing on both counts. I had both sushi and chinese food.  Basic rolls, like California and eel/avacado were bad supermarket grade.  Seriously, if you are a sushi restaurant, you should at least be able to create a moist, flavorful roll.  Dry and tasted pre-made or left over.  For special rolls that are $12, they should be able to get it right.   

Brown rice extra money.  Bland chinese food.    

Waited in line behind party of 6 in cold doorway although restaurant was empty.  I saw someone setting up a table, but there were plenty set up already. No reason.  Going next time to Chesnut Hill for sit down, even if it's further.

Let there be no doubt, the cheesecake is AWESOME!   I got a burger, and the meat was first class.  When you can get service, it's very friendly and proactive.

But their other food spotty and not always outstanding, their food differs somewhat from their menu, their staff disappears at times, and sometimes the little things don't come up to snuff.

When we got the bread, it was not even warm.  I thought you're supposed to get warm bread at a place like this.  I was thirsty, so I went through my tea quickly, and since the staff disappeared for long stretches of time, it was empty for long stretches before and during the meal.  My burger had not only that weird special sauce, but also mayo on the other side of the patty.  I'll cop to probably missing the special sauce on the menu, but not the mayo.  They're so unnecessary, because it was such tasty meat.

But the cheesecake was awesome.  This is a place where you're going to pay a pretty penny, and it is not up to the pricing.  We went because we had a gift card, and the price plus the fact that some important pieces were missing.

This place is all right.  I went in at about six pm, and left with two big loaves of bread, plus a cuppa joe for about $6.  Sometimes I'm looking for a deal, and when bread comes cheap and is tasty, I can make it on that.  If you don't mind that the bread is 12 hours old, that's the best time to get it, since it's 2 for 1.

The coffee is all right.  A little bitter.  But they guy behind the counter was very nice and had a good sense of humor.  So this place is good people.

The food was great. And the service was good. I was happy to see that they have healthy food options and vegan choices as well.. and It was a nice family oriented atmosphere. I will definitely visit again.

Wow!! What changed?? I called for curbside pick up which they advertise for, have signs out in front of their shop,& cones for "contactless curbside pick up" and they arnt doing it anymore. So I placed a phone order to   Pick it up in the drive through and he said I still had to come inside. I don't want to, nor can I come inside!! So disappointed. Not willing to work with people at all. The drive through took 20 minutes to get through with the most unfriendly workers. Wow!!! On top of everything else they gave me the wrong order.

OK. This place is in a gas station.  But the food in the gas station is no joke. The Indian food is fantastic from what I have tried and the gyros are really good too. Cooked to order.  They also have burritos, tacos, pizza and a few more things. This is all at reasonable prices and good food portions per serving.

Meh. I gotta stop getting coffee from this place. I always think it's going to be better than it is. The medium roast consistently tastes burnt and bitter. 

That vegan chicken salad sandwich, though-- totally delicious. It's worth coming here at mid-day in summer for an iced tea and lunch, but the breakfast, and the coffee, are pretty lackluster.

Three stars 'cause it nearly always seems like they're playing my iTunes library through the speakers.

Recently moved to Nashville from NY and had high hopes that this place would fill my craving for Korean food but left disappointed.  Food isn't the worst I've had but dishes are cheaply made and no where close to being authentic Korean nor do they use all the ingredients that are typical in Korean food.

I really enjoy the concept of creating your own entree and that is exactly what you get at Pho Xua Vietnamese Noodle & Tea House. It's located in a small shopping center with plenty of parking for those of you like myself that are easily stressed out by having to street park. My fiance and I arrived here after work one day for dinner and it was only us and two other tables being served. I was starving and just went with the beef pho--didn't add any additional toppings though you do have the option to do so. Compared to other pho I've had, this pho was a smaller portion that I was used to. My fiance went with the standard lemongrass banh mi which I took a bite of and thought it was delicious. We ordered the crispy spring rolls, but shrimp summer rolls came out instead. We didn't mind, but are looking forward to trying the crispy spring rolls next time.

I loved the building, loved the restaurant and the shop and the garden. The food was good but I was hungry, and it just wasn't enough. Service was good and while I did not have a mixed drink.......they had some really interesting options!

I'm glad the wonderful taste of locally roasted kahwa espresso has expanded to South Tampa. Plus, they have almond, soy, and regular varieties of milk for your cappuccino and latte needs. I will just stick to my double espresso, thanks!

Once you try this, you'll never be tempted to visit a chain named after celestial objects and cash.

What is my recipe for an awesome and tasty evening? Here we go...


First, head to Cristino's and enjoy the friendly service.

Next, simply order my favorite pie, Bianca with capers, mushrooms, and roasted peppers. 

If you bring a wonderful guest like I did, order another pizza. Why not?

Wait patiently and enjoy the atmosphere. If you sit outside, mind the occasional fly :-(

Now comes the best part. Eat slowly and savor. 

Finally, for the finishing touch, enjoy some smooth, cold, and refreshing gelato!

Voilà. The recipe to a wonderful pizza evening is complete! Feel free to customize to your taste.

Please go there if you want to spend $50 on salad and rice, with occasional - every 20 minutes or so- meat service that's extremely salty. No host at the front desk for about 5 minutes on a Saturday night, busiest time. She wanted to talk to the other people behind us before seating us even though we had a reservation. No drink service for about another 20 minutes after we were seated. Server dropped a huge piece of meat on the floor while serving our table, did not even bother to pick it up. It took me 3 attempts with other servers to get it picked up. Please spend you $50 somewhere else. I used to like this place, and come quiet often.
I love the food but the 8 dollar mushrooms is a little overboard. But the steak and fish on a half shell were so good I don't mind being robbed, does that make sense.

I was glad when Frenchy's took over Outpost, not that I'm Frenchy's hugest fan, but anything was an improvement to Island Outpost. We first stopped in right after they changed hands. Frenchy's was operating it but the menu was still the same and they hadn't done the overhaul. We weren't to impressed, but once we learned they would be redoing the place and eventually updating the menu we vowed to try it again.

Well we finally got around to trying it again this past weekend. We had a 45 minute wait, which is a little long for May, but what can you do there were a lot of big parties taking up all the tables. Hubby got a drink from the bar, eventually, while I grabbed a spot to sit and wait. 

We had eaten at Rockaway not to long ago and I left a little underwhelmed. My grouper wasn't the best and it didn't leave me wanting more Frenchy's. But we had vowed to return to this new location. At Outpost we started with the fish spread. It was good. It was fish spread. Our food came out very quickly after we got the appetizer. Would have preferred a little more time, but not a big deal. My husband ordered the Fire Island Grouper Sandwich (I think that's the name, something with fire in it) and I opted for the chicken salad pita for a change of pace and because I have a friend who goes to Frenchy's specifically for this. I figured it was worth a shot. The pita was big and served with delicious fruit. My hubby and I were joking because when this place was Island Outpost I ordered a salad with tropical fruit on top which ended up being a can of dole fruit - yuck. Frenchy's gave me FRESH kiwi, strawberries, banana, cantelope and honeydew (which wasn't quite ripe) I took half of the pita home and had dinner the next night. My husband let me try a bite of his sandwich and it was really delicious. The fish was perfect. Super fresh and much better than my Rockaway experience. It left me wanting to come back.

Our server was great. Very friendly - wish I remembered his name. Anyways, we really enjoyed our meal and are looking forward to returning. Hopefully with a little bit shorter of a wait.

Just read about this place today and decided to run for a burger tonight as I heard theirs were pretty good.
I had the El Guapo Burger, the wife had the Blue Cheese burger (We forget the name of it.)

Both burgers were pretty good, though I think there is room for improvement.
They advertise right on the menu that nothing is ever frozen, if their beef is that good, give me a choice of how I want it cooked.
My burger was so well done it had lost all its flavor so all I got to taste were the toppings.
It also struck me as not having any seasoning on the meat, but that may have just been overwhelmed by how well done it was.
The service was great, and very friendly and helpful.
The atmosphere was pretty low key for Manayunk.
The beer selection was very good, and the bar was stocked with quite a variety of bottles.

I'd go back, but I don't know if I'd have another burger.

3.5...Food is great. Service is lacking, and no happy hour? What gives? I love the downtown location, so I was pumped when I saw they were putting one in Oro Valley, which is close to my home. It seems to be pretty busy, like COVID has not had a negative affect on their business. The food is great, especially the nachos al pastor. That's my go-to. Tacos are yummy as well.

There are a couple tables inside, and there really isn't much square footage. A handful of people were at tables on the patio. I was more comfortable to take my food to go both times I've visited. Not as comfortable of a place to hang out.

I wish this location had the happy hour specials that Congress has. They don't seem to offer any specials here, and the service is short and a little stingy. I was asked if I wanted guac on my nachos and said "yes." I don't remember there being an upcharge for that before, but it was $3.29, which wasn't mentioned. Another visit my husband asked if he could get some pico de gallo on his tacos, and the guy refused and said he could only do Street or Gringo style. It's a little bit of pico, dude. Relax.

I'd been wanting to try this place since reading about it in Tucson Foodie. I met my friends for dinner here on a Friday before it got too packed. We ordered their special, which was BBQ beef nachos; an order of Rollies tacos with beef; and the cochi-style tots. It was a decent amount for the three gals; we were full but not stuffed to the gills. The BBQ beef nachos were so delicious; I hope they put that on the menu permanently. The tots were also amazing, and we liked the tacos as well. We also got concha and cochito ice cream sandwiches to share, because why not?!

I liked it here. I'd return and try some other things. Their tortas looked pretty good too. This spot is very laid back. It was cool and comfortable when we went, but I'd imagine once summer hits, it may not be too pleasant to eat out here. The service was pretty friendly. 

It would be nice (and the restaurant could save quite a bit on cost) if they put in a soda fountain. Their beverage offerings include canned/bottled soda (both Mexican like Jarritos and some standard RC, Sprite, etc.) and bottled water. The only thing to drink without sugar is Diet Pepsi or water. My boyfriend is a Type-1 diabetic, so I take notice of these things. Anyhow, not many drink choices for the health-conscious.

We came early for dinner (around 5:30), and I was able to find a spot in the small parking lot, but it was extremely tight getting out, so be mindful of that.

Excellent mixed drinks, service, staff, atmosphere, but my only drawback which is my opinion is the food variety. 

This was our first real speak-easy that we've been to and it was a blast. Just showing up you'd never know it was there. The atmosphere is definitely what you'd think a speak-easy place would be like. We really enjoyed the secluded booths that they seat you in. 

The food was awesome and I like the fact that it's tapas style which is small portions. It gives you more options to order more and try other things. My only draw back was the fact the food was very out there in my opinion. I like trying new and different food but I always like to order something that i know for a fact I will like. Looking at the menu it was hard for me to find something i know id like for sure. We ordered the waygu beef tartare, octo tacos, trio burger. & house salads. Honestly most of it was good but I definitely wasn't sure about most of it. I feel like the options on the menu is kind of small as well. This is just my personal opinion on it. 

All in all it was a great experience and I will definitely be coming back again. The wife and I enjoyed it and I'm sure you will too.

You can't throw a stone in NOLA without hitting a John Besh restaurant. Borne is a reason why. A wonderful restaurant and atmosphere. Love the oyster shell columns. The food was wonderful and the drink selection is nice.

So I came upon this place as part of a thrillist top 10 burgers of NOLA list. Got atomic burger, dressed, fries with truffle mayo and garlic aioli dipping sausces( on a side note truffle mayo was awesome, used leftovers on a ham and cheese sandwich. The burger was awesome, great fresh party, seasoned well, which made it highly irresistible. Good thick cut pickles and melted cheese, completed a great burger, wife raved about it too.

This place sucks. The wings are the smallest I've ever had, more like chicken toes. I ordered a chicken panini and when I got home discovered I was given a Cuban panini. I also ordered the buffalo chicken wrap, it was awful. The chicken was rubber. I'm usually not much of a picky eater but I took two Bites and threw the rest out. I will not be a returning customer.

This is my standard go-to Vietnamese restaurant. Good pho and good bun. I used to get my Taro boba tea here until Bing Boba Tea opened up next door. Good food, good prices, super convenient.  Service is not always the best but is normally pretty speedy so not too bad.

Stick to the Chinese/Cooked dishes and you will have a better experience (in my opinion).  Mandy, the server, is just lovely and treats my elderly parents - who are dine-in regulars - like royalty.  She even knows what they usually order.  (Creatures of habit).

The "special" house wonton soup is truly delicious and the meaty spare-ribs are so much better than "that other place" in Doylestown.

I like to get the Chicken with string beans, light on the sauce (to cut the grease factor). My parents love (but I am not a big fan) the Honey Walnut shrimp. It is fried so too rich for me.  If you like fried shrimp and sweet sauces you might like this.

The dining room at lunch on weekends is always nearly empty.
Take-out does a decent business.

Give Jade Island a try - it's really quite good.
For Chinese.

OMG - Thank the LORD I did not go to use the bathroom at LP's until AFTER we had already eaten (and enjoyed) or dinner.

To get to the bathroom you walk through the kitchen and it is so GROSS.  I could not even go in there.  The stentch of the "disinfectant" mixed with urine was too much to bear.

Before this, however I should mention that I had eaten at LP's about 3 prior times and all were fine.  The food was decent, cheap, typical diner grub.  I was even impressed that the iceberg-based tossed salad was fresh and crisp.

Nice servers, too.

But that bathroom downgraded a 3 star experience to a disgusting big fat ZERO.

3 star service (Danny is terrific but the food came out rather slowly and we were on lunch break)
4 star food - upscale "gastropub" type bar food.

I had been wanting to try Roots, and my group of 5 coworkers came for lunch - we only had an hour and lunch took easily 85 minutes.  Next time we will advise the staff that we are on a tighter time frame.

3 of the crew had burgers and they looked terrific with any toppings you could want - cheddar, bacon, fried (a little over cooked for my liking) egg.

I had the $10 lunch special of French Onion Soup ($6 on its own!) and a 1/2 sandwich (I chose the Chicken, Avocado and Pork Belly panini - yes, please!).  Both were scrumptious - albeit caloric.  Best of all?  The French Onion was not overly salted.  It was perfect.

I will return - but not on a day when I have a 1 PM meeting!
Great selection of beers - and a full bar ('natch!)

After a 6 year hiatus (I was not working in Philly) I am back and I guess I did not read my own review because I needed some sushi (sashimi, actually) and for $9.99 I got 2 pieces each of Salmon (not that great), tuna (good) and Yellowtail (surprisingly good and not fishy tasting).  I also got a $2.99 side of cucumber salad.

I may be back - especially when I am in the Comcast Center, as Sook Hee's has sadly, closed.

Pretty Mediocre.  The family stopped in here while house hunting in this area. Clean but GRAY and cafeteria-like dining area.  DD had a meatball sub (my meatballs are better - these were bready and tasteless), DH had a cheesesteak which he hated and I actually like my (Kronos pre-packed, obviously frozen) Gyro sandwich on Pita.

The gents behind the counter were friendly and very nice.
I was leaning toward 3 stars until I tasted DD's sub.  Blech!

Bathroom was clean and decent.

The place needs a facelift for the dining room and a re-vamp of the "classic" Greek-owned Pizzeria menu.

I wish I could have liked it better - but we will NOT be back.

Very disappointed in the flavorless, dry black quinoa salad that set me back $10 for lunch.  Also had an OK $3.00 Arnold Palmer.  The quinoa salad at Pure Fare (and even the frozen Quinoa Bowls I get at Whole Foods) are far superior and cheaper.

Not a fan of this place any more.
Over-priced and not that good.

I should have stuck with the green submarine (glad it's still on the menu).
Skip this place and go elsewhere for a better lunch for less money.

This places ROCKS!!!  (And I don't really like falafel - there's is great.).

I usually get a fresh-baked whole wheat pita and a few slices of the most YUMMY friend eggplant.

The hummus is smooth and flavorful - not overpowering.
I hate tahini - so none of thast por moi, but bring on those valuable veggies.  Crisp and fresh always.

And hot young men are often manning the counter.  A-men to that!

The side bar with olives and delctable fried (a bit oily) cauliflower [and I am not normally a fan of the 'flwoer] is wonderful, too,.

Great latkes.
Great pita
Spectacular Sandwiches - and don't miss that eggplant.

This is middle-eastern/kosher paradise for vegans, veggies & carnevores alike.
Just  OK.  Good baked good.  Mediocre produce.  Sorry - but the peaches were sold out and the green pepper was old.  Not impressed, Tabora!

Our party of 9 (6 kids, 3 adults) received great service from Nicole - and ordered a wide variety of pizza, sandwiches, pasta and salads.  Food was very good - my 12 year old enjoyed an enormous plate of penne a la vodka.

Linguine with *white) clam sauce is a classic preparation with plenty of garlic and red pepper flakes.  Whole baby clams were plentiful and tasty.  Caprese salad was solid. Pizza was average in my opinion - but nothing bad about it - just a plain cheese pie for some of the kids.

All in all - a good experience.

I am not much of a fast food eater - and I don't touch hot dogs, but on a whim I ordered a (nearly $10) patty melt here - a calorie bomb for sure - but it was tasty.  Just too greasy for me.

I skipped any fried sides and dared not order a (1000 calorie) shake.

I think my cholesterol quotient for 2021 has been achieved.

It's not bad - but nothing much to write home about.  Brunch is probably the saving grace and they are accomodating - somewhat- to my 3 year old daughter.  Not a fave for me - but OK for a brunch.

Oh, and it's moderately priced - so it's not horrible.

Average food and average service.  A neighborhood place but not a neighborhood RAVE nor FAVE.  (I almost gave 2 stars - but our burgers were quite tasty.)

It's kinda "meh"/"blah" on the decor too.  A bit shabby.

The space is lovely, the copper tables, the tablescape and seat cushions are awesome. You can tell they spent quite a bit on the interior. The food is decently priced, I think their lunch items and pricing is best so I plan to go back for lunch. The coffee is meh, but comes in a cool cup, so if you hold your nose and drink it you'll be fine. The food is ok, I had the chicken kebab dinner and it was lacking in flavor and I used all of the yogurt topping to try and make it more flavorful and less dry. I was expecting more flavor for sure, not semi-bland food in this lovely space. All four of us were underwhelmed and hope to try it again and see if anything changes. Again, worth a try but I think your money would go further on the lunch menu and if you don't like it you'll be less disappointed that you only spent a few bucks rather than a lot more.

Before you get to the menu, you gotta walk thru the venue! It's
LOUD, even when few folk are there (as on this Sat, at noon). I've been to Brit pubs in Manchester, Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Oban, Greenock and Glasgow. Brit food and kitch décor do not a pub make. Yes, some pubs can be rowdy when football is on the telly. But the essence of a 'public house' in the UK is a place for family, food, conversation, and drink during the day. This Florida iteration is more milennial mosh pit noise-wise, than a pub to nosh in. Sorry, mates.
Wtf is this crap. Seriously bad service. Bad food. Too much grease. I'd rather eat my own vomit.

I have been to this location several times.  Lunch, dinner and late night appetizers.  Wait time is very short and we are usually seated right away.  Wait staff isn't really friendly, just OK.  Food, well it's a chain restaurant.  It's ok.  Their salads are probably my favorite.

It's nice they allow the 2 for $20 special as takeout (I believe it is 2 for $22 now).  And last time we did take out she showed us each order so we were assured it was correct (I thought that was a nice gesture).

The restaurant is always clean.  Parking is always available.  No major issues, just nothing to rave about as far as customer service and food is concerned.
Eh... forgot my bacon on my breakfast sandwich although the coffee is excellent, service is rough. Not a lot of options on the menu it's just basic food you could make at home. Nothing special.
New place for us. Enjoyed our meal. Food delivered very fast. Had lobster roll and lobster pasta. Will like to try the #2 combo on next visit.

I've visited this place three times so far which is a good indicator of how I feel about it. The spring rolls are excellent as are the eggrolls. The Vietnamese chicken salad is super and they offer a generous portion of fish sauce for the salad. I had a beef rice noodle bowl during one visit that was wonderfully seasoned. This place is a bit pricey but not out of line. Totally worth a visit to get your Thai fix.

Really decent Mexican food served with a side of attitude - which is funny because their food is anything but consistent. Depends on who the cooks are at the time you go there. I've had really excellent food to just okay food at the downtown location. That said, the food is pretty damn authentic. The salsas are fantastic. I like this place enough to return on a regular basis despite the moody-and-dripping-with-attitude cashiers.

Yes, I'm writing an update to reiterate what a good find Country Pizza Italian Grill was and its consistency - in product, service, and price.  I came for the lunch buffet, which is an excellent value, but see that the standard menu offers so many choices, including pizza for take out,

I helped myself to three or four plates from the buffet - 1) salad plate, 2) pasta and other stuff plate, and 3) pizza plate.  Everything was very good.  I liked that the salad bar offers feta cubes, one of my favorite types of cheese.  I liked that the pasta choices included large stuffed shells.  And I liked that the pizza area offers around four different varieties, though I limited myself to two of them this time.

A few other kudos are in order.  I had forgotten that a small cup of soup was also included.  On the particular day I went in, it was turkey avgolemono (that's Greek for lemon flavored) and it was very tasty.  Then, there are little baklava triangles in the salad bar area that are obviously intended to be dessert fare.  I can slam dunk those little baklava triangles down the hatch the way someone laying on the couch who watches soaps and Oprah can slam dunk those Oreos.  And, obviously, from avgolemono soup and baklava, this is an Italian pizza-pasta place with some Greek staples, all of which I love.

Country Pizza Italian Grill's lunch buffet is also offered 7 days a week!  It's not just a Monday through Friday thing.  I paid $8.99.  (From looking around and listening to some people talk, it's obvious it has local "regulars," which is a good sign.) The service by the friendly young lady, the tidiness and air conditioned comfort of the interior, and the amply sized parking lot were also pluses.  It's not fine dining, so don't be complaining given the respectable value.

Just find Country Pizza Italian Grill, which is on the frontage road to crazy US 19, Pinellas County's half baked attempt at a north-south freeway.  It's also technically in Largo, which abuts Clearwater.  And be sure to make some time for snooze time afterwards and to plan on a light dinner.

Ella's is great, the vibe is fun, the place used to use great ingredients, and there is wonderful live music on the weekend HOWEVER I went a couple months ago on SUnday so I could get some good southern cooking, mind you there are TONS of places that have great BBQ around the bay I chose Ellas because of their amazing fried pickles. I ordered my favorite dish excited and willing to WAIT AN HOUR for an appetizer at the bar but instead I got these disgusting yellow soggy pickles underneath a ton of yucky sticky batter. EWWW!! I asked to speak with the head of the house and a woman politely explained to me they could not afford to use pickles they brine themselves (why not just raise the damn price?!). So instead they buy those nasty soggy mass produced non-perishable yellow pickles. Wtf I thought this place was different than the rest of the local businesses that sell out for a higher profit.
We stopped here for a quick bite while at the mall, we got the appetizer sampler tray. The food was good, but over the moon great but it met the need. I would visit again.

Our 2nd visit here for breakfast, both times I forgot to take a picture .  Ample menu selection with good portions. The breakfast is pretty good, home fries could use some seasoning - very bland...other than that the food was good,   The service is very attentive. Good spot to get an inexpensive breakfast.

I found this gem last Sunday when I was walking around the Rittenhouse area with an old friend. I am dying to go back because it's already one of my favorite wine spots! On Sunday's, they have a "Sunday School" menu where they have a wine, cheese, and dessert suggestion for the day. The prices are very cheap because they want you to try and discover new tastes. For a wine lover, this is my dream. I tried an excellent white wine for $6. I forgot what the cheese was called, but it was very creamy and buttery. We also ordered the Brie and goat cheese. They provide plenty of bread and honey and other dipping sauces. We sat outside, and it was quite lovely. I am planning on coming back super soon!

I've been coming to this place for a while now and lately things keep getting messed up and then tonight I found a sticker on the pear in my sandwich! The same sandwich they didn't hold the spread on like I asked.
I like the thick bacon here.also I think this place has one of the best cheesesteaks on Philly. Bit pricey though.

THEY GAVE ME A  BIB! That was awesome. I wore a really pretty dress here and it was hilarious. 

I should always wear a bib when I eat anyways, because I always end up getting something on my clothes. I thought the food was pretty good and the service was decent. The BBQ shrimp was HUGE!

Overall, great experience. You should try it!

BAD EXPERIENCE!

First time I've had a bad experience here. I usually try not to let little things bug me, but when it's one thing after another, sometimes I just can't handle it anymore!

So we (mom, dad, and I) came here the day before last and the wait was CRAZY! We were looking forward to eating here, but our stomachs were telling us to try again later. We come back yesterday and I really wish we hadn't come at all. 

We were seated rudely. The old ladies at the front are not so nice.

It's going to be tough to get me back in here. I wish I hadn't had such a crappy experience.

Let me say this - I came here without ever having read the reviews. I am stunned by the amount of people that did not like it or have a bad experience. 

I've come by twice, in a hurry, on my way to work or something. Anyways, the girl at the register just straight up told me, "I'm sorry, but it's my second day and I apologize in advance if i"m repetitive." 

I was thankful for her honesty. She did ask me repeatedly what I wanted, but it's better that then get the wrong order. 

I asked for two bagels toasted with spread - I think I paid around $7 but I didn't get a drink or anything. I took it to go, obviously since I was in a rush. And it also did not take that long. I had people in line beding me and there was one person ahead of me.

I would recommend it... yet I do agree about the atmosphere... it's so not NOLA. We're used to comfortable and home-y settings and warm atmospheres. This place does give off a very "corporate" and franchise-y feel. Something we don't welcome very much in NOLA.

Scarpetta will be excellent... in a few months. Unfortunately, what could have been an amazing experience was ruined by cold food and arrogant service. The entire meal was rushed - 5 pasta dishes and 2 entrees within 35 minutes.  In terms of service, not once were we asked how our meal was, not once did we feel as though we were taken care of.  First course arrived before cocktails. The food was great, albeit all was cold/room temperature.  Due to a new restaurant, it felt as though dishes were pre-prepared and placed under a heat lamp to pump out of the kitchen.  Multiple times with food on the plate, we were asked if they could take the dish away.  While the servers may have been trying to tend to the table, it was entirely too rushed and we felt as though they were trying to turn the table over quickly.  3 stars is because the flavors were definitely on point.  However, when you spend higher end prices ($100/person), you should at least expect people to be NICE (you opened five days ago, why so jaded?) and food to be served hot.
The price point is amazing. The size of the plates are just right! We had the squash dumplings, brisket slider, collard greens, and hot chicken - all worth trying. Loved the Mobile Mule cocktail.

Ferg's Live is in a great spot located right across from Amalie Arena. It is sure to do well with the consistent flow of traffic from Amalie's events. 

The decor is sports-themed and very creative from the wall of floor-to-ceiling hockey sticks to the "Balls to the Wall." 

There is live music and the acts perform from a stage located from above and there is lots of seating throughout the bar. However, there is not much shade outside and it can get very hot and humid, welcome to Florida!

I didn't get a change to try the food but plan on going back and trying the food soon.

Neighborhood bar that would be great to lounge in with more than adequate seating. Bartenders are a bit standoffish and would rather you order your drink at the bar than having to come out from behind the bar to serve you. 

We went in to watch the hockey game after an event. It was fairly slow but we were ignored. There is no food served here but I saw people bringing food in. Not sure if I would come back to a bar where the bartenders think they are all that and ignore you. There are plenty of other bars in the area that have much more interaction and are much more lively.

Not a bad Dairy Queen...the price at dq is pretty outrageous but at this location the problem is the speed.  I've been here a few times and it seems more times than not it takes forever.  We just ordered ice cream cones and waited 12 minutes.  Maybe I'm impatient but I'm watching everyone else wait too and they aren't happy at all.  I wonder if they know culverts is next door?  The cashier told us they were short 4 people tonight.  You would think the manager/owner would step in and assist.  Guess not...

I like dq although it's overpriced so we will probably be back.  Maybe a new location is wise...

Just left this place after attempting a late lunch/early dinner with the wife .. Wife ordered eggplant parm I ordered veal parm. Can't get anymore simple and straightforward than that , or so I thought .

My veal comes to the table and I cut into it and it feels tough and rubbery , I take a bit and it feels like chewing rubber bands . The sauce my spaghetti is in isliterally floating in water like they didn't drain the pasta at all. 

I also ordered a side of meatballs and to my dismay they were ice cold and also swimming in water/sauce ..wife's eggplant was edible but the eggplant themselves had no breading on them from sitting in the " sauce " 

I am not the type of person to send food back or even complain, but this was so inedible that I couldn't even suffer through it . The waitress was awesome and attentive and very sympathetic . I felt bad for her to be honest as none of this was her fault. 

The food was taken off my bill as I only took two bites ( it was that bad) and I left the waitress a very nice tip as i felt bad for sending food back . I honestly don't know how this place is in business . And after reading the good reviews on here i really wonder if the ppl in this area are just used to below average food..

I live right down the road and would never try place again . Olive Garden is horrible , but at least they don't insult u by claiming they are authentic ..

Nice way to  answer for wifey day is cold crafted pints and sports. 24 taps always changing the rotation , great decor with the flat screens, crafts posted up everywhere. 

Nice big sports bar with plenty of seating with flat screens everywhere so you can't miss a beat . A huge wooden bar that has a great shine where the beverages have that perfect slide when coming down your way. Great vantage points also if you decide to sit at the bar. Plenty of seats that outline the bar, that gives an great view of their taps, along with liquors. These guys did it right I must say, I enjoyed myself, a great rebuttal to wifey day. ( score 1 for the good guy )


I love samples by the way, sampled several delicious crafts, they also do a beer sampler , 4 selections of 6 oz glasses  for 8.99 I believe it was. This is a great spot  for the beer aficionado with all great crafts to peruse. 

The food all looked so good, best sellers are their burgers. Specialty gourmet burgers to their signature selections. Wow, I had the big mans cheeseburger, cooked to a medium. Talk about delicious, with the homemade chips and side order of fries to add. Every inch of my plate was covered , so you know I was happy about this. My wife went with a specialty bison cheese burger cooked to a medium, that also looked like something I would sink my teeth into. 

Great music pumping out, 90's alternative, from Sound Garden to Pearl Jam, from the touch screen juke box hanging along the wall. Our bartender was Rebecca who was nothing but great, attentive, offering her insights of what the best are. Apparently she makes a great Mojito seeing this is what my wife was drinking. 

side note **  Rebecca knows how to make a great snake bite , I was impressed that she got it right.

Great spot to be at, watch a game, enjoy the food, the crafts, and other drinks. I'll surely be back again to frequent this joint when in town. Besides I saw what their wings look like from a patron sitting across from me. They looked great , a mouth watering scent coming from his dish.

A landmark you might say that has been in debate for the "Best Cheese steak " in Philly. Chubby's is certainly up there in ranks , but with the competition out there to be number one is fierce. 

These guys have been around for a while now with a competitor across the street no less who also has been around  making a phenomenal cheese steak in DaLessandros. 

The differences from these two are:

First- you can enjoy a frosty pint / mug , bottled beer, or you can go with something stronger like liquor  with your cheese steak.
 
Second - The fried long hots in oil types of  hot peppers and pickles bar they offer you if you want to take your steak to a different level.

Third- they accept credit cards, and at times are open later than the rival across the way.

A great  high calorie induced, greasy flavored  by this I mean a marinate from the whole day types of grease on the grill is what I am screaming! If you are a person who doesn't like a good flavorful cheese steak with all the add-ons and is worried about the grease factor, DON'T GO IN !  

OK so picture this  you walk in , mind you it is not a big place , counter seating and with booths along the side wall. People ordering, the smell hitting your senses of Philly goodness, the onions being fried, the pounds of meat on the grill, whiz being kept warm for that next piece of bread or fries. Wow doesn't that sound delicious, you can always go to the gym the next day if you feel guilty, and besides you shouldn't if you already committed by walking in the joint.

My perfect Cheese steak I had made was with raw and fried onions, bacon,  extra cheese (Whiz ) with the  hots and pickles on a side cup  was being prepared for me to devour.  Sometimes I would go with American cheese just for the hell of it  . I know blasphemy ! How dare I !! I do dare even with American cheese this is good, hell do a duo of Whiz and American.

The staff is friendly , and patient when it comes to the people leaving the bar scene. Now go inside, sit down , get you sides of pickles and hot to sweet peppers on stand by with a frosty pint and get ready and enjoy!!

Yelp keeps removing my review, but I am describing an actual customer interaction.

Green Eggs Cafe regularly allows it's waiting patrons to block the sidewalk, and that's not cool and that's not neighborly. 

And every time I have asked the host, hostess or manager to control their crowd i get some condesending bs answer along the lines of " you can just cross the street" or "there's nothing we can do" or "don't you have anything better to do?"

It is a sidewalk, not your private waiting area, and I shall continue to barge my way thru and call you out on your boorish behavior, you arrogant, inept, unneighborly, sidewalk-blocking waffle-slapping bastards.

Seriously, if Woody's can keep their sidewalk traversable, so can you.
Green Eggs Cafe of 13th St--acn you please stop blocking the sidewalk?

2.5 stars because the beer, chicken fingers, French fries and mussels are good. However, the burgers and most of the food items are not good. This place has a VERY long wait to be seated, they do not utilize the space and the food is not worth the wait. If u want beer this place is great. If you want great chicken fingers- come here.

The food is generally just not good- I've been here too many times and the food has gotten worse each time. However the chicken fingers are amazing. The chicken fingers are worth a 20- 30 min wait. And you can get lost in the awesome BEER selection. You can NOT get alcohol and wine here. (I've never asked for wine so I may be wrong but I've never seen anyone drink any here). I've been to the place at least 20 times And it is definitely getting worse each time. But it could be great if they got a new chef and utilized the space. 

I really want to like this place but tonight might have been my last visit. I shared Ahi tuna w noodles and it was covered in pink peppercorns and it is not nice getting multiple of those in your mouth. I can't get the awful peppercorn taste out of my mouth. We had to send back Mac and cheese bc it was fishy and watery. Further, the waitress even agreed that they always take back the ahi Tuna dish w a lot of left over peppercorns. Maybe the manAgement should do something about that- it's gross to have a mouth full of pink peppercorns and it is pointless to have a garnish that is hardly edible. 

Finally, DON'T GeT a burger here- horrible. They can't cook a burger medium rare and it is chewy. Very disappointed w the food here.

Final opinion: come here for beer, chicken fingers, mussels and French fries- NOTHINg ELSE!!! And be ready to wait at least an hour for a seat. 

And if I was repetitive, it was bc of the beer!!!

Our server Jessica was very nice and accommodating. Great Latte and mimosa. The food over all was good but pricey. We were initially interested in ordering the Eggs Benedict but asked to sample the hollandaise which all 3 of us rejected as too citrusy. .. (Chef Lucs)....When Chef Luc visited our table at the end of our meal to apologize for the slow kitchen, he asked how we enjoyed our meal. We expressed our preference for a more traditional hollandaise sauce at which point he apparently took great offense and bluntly informed us "that when we opened our own restaurant we could make it however we wanted." Evidently he really didn't want any negative feedback. He then proceeded to huff back to the kitchen. We were in total shock. And this is also one of the owners. So needless to say we probably won't return.

I come here for ONE thing because its so delicious! The coconut curry with shrimp, which is also offered with chicken or tofu. I know I'm not the only one that loves it because last time I went nearly every table had it. They've definitely struck gold with this dish. I love the portion size because you can certainly get at least 2 meals out of it.  If not familiar with this dish its very similar to Thai rice dishes. If not familiar with that either, its basically just a party in your mouth. It's sweet and savory, its everything you want and more. They also have some great appetizers. The spring rolls are pretty standard. The calamari is really fresh and tasty.

The service is always really attentive and nice. You will never thirst because they are so on top of their refill game. They have indoor and outdoor seating and they've done a really good job of shielding the outdoor seating area from the ugly street that it sits on. They also have fans and heaters to offset whatever weather mother nature is throwing at us that day. Lastly, they do take reservations which is nice for larger parties, but not necessary for tables of 4 or less in my opinion.

This place is NOT a good option for dinner... or anything other than beignets and sweet tea.

We stopped in here last night after doing some shopping at the Legends.

Restaurant was deserted at dinner hour - only 4 other tables had patrons.

Service was still slow. Getting water refills was tedious and required multiple reminders.

The food - I cringe thinking back on it to write about it.

'Not full order' of Beer Battered shrimp - not full = 6 shrimp. Beer battered = all batter no shrimp. Sub'd for fried okra instead of hush puppies - Okra was cold. I ate one and pushed the rest aside.

Fiance's dish - Shrimp fettuccine - sauce was flavorful but not overpowering. Shrimp were well cooked. Great dish. Took the leftover home but they tasted horrible reheated. 

Dessert:
1 order of regular beignets (4 average sized beignets)
1 order of stuffed beignets (1 large home run pie shaped beignet stuffed with a thick hot fudge type sauce). 

Both were FAR, FAR better than the food... and the service.

Despite being my closest access to beignets I will NEVER dine here again.

This is the reason why groupon sucks!! Cannot use more than 1 groupon per table and every person in the group has to order a drink.. FYI drinks here are $2.89. So it's really not a discount. Service here is so S. L. O. W!!! Took 15 minutes b4 we got our drinks and another 10-15 b4 we actually put the order. Food came out another 15 mins and 3 of us waited another 15 mins because .. I think they forgot one of our orders.. Food is ok but, not worth the wait and the groupon really wasn't worth it
Great food and even better service. Thanks Jenny. Feel like I need to be rolled out the door every time I eat here. Place was pretty packed and for good reason.

No no no yo ! 

Music way too loud . confusing seating and service arramgement and ARROGANT staff/owners

Mikey will never return

Came for brunch. Ambiance is beautiful. The decor was open and lighting was good. There was a cool live band playing. The restaurant was 3 weeks into their opening. Staff was friendly & accommodating.

The food was good but nothing exciting or exceptional. I had the pancakes with a side of bacon & tried the potatoes. The pancakes were served with fresh berries. The berries were sweet & in season, a definite plus. The pancakes were good but not very memorable. The potatoes were good but not served with any type of peppers or onions, which is how I prefer them served.

The pleasant surprise was the live band playing during brunch. There was a live band playing jazz music during brunch. The music provided a great addition to this experience.

Came for lunch and was actually impressed & surprised. I expected a casual hot dog shop but found a full blown restaurant with games and a fully stocked bar. The place was decorated with various travel memorabilia from around the globe. As someone that loves to travel, this was right up my alley. There were retro airline signs from around the world....

The menu was quite impressive. I enjoyed viewing the combination of ingredients they used to depict flavors from around the country and the globe. I actually compared some of the ingredients used from various countries and found it to be authentic to the region. I ordered the Poi boy Maui but changed it up a bit, as that is what I like to do :). I had the teriyaki sauce but instead of the pineapple relish, I had the cherry pepper relish. Can you say Delicious! I love spicy so this was right up my alley. The sausage was great and the pork belly was perfectly seasoned and juicy, an added bonus to the sausage. The honey dijon mustard gave the perfect hint of sweetness to balance the spiciness of the pepper relish.

While hot dogs & sausages are not a regular thing on my diet... this was quite an exception! This place is definitely somewhere to come again.

Not much to say. Pizza was dry, bad and flavorless! Service didn't help either. I ordered a create my own vegan pizza with garlic knots and they only gave me the garlic knots. It's partial my fault. I just assumed they put everything in one box lol. I went home to discover they forgot the pizza. The cashier was apologetic however it still sucked! I was mad that I even went back for that nasty pizza that they could've kept! Smh

This place is good, BUT NOT GOOD ENOUGH for an hour+ wait, especially when those willing to wait can't even get a coffee on the house (we're talking cheap drip folks, not gourmet brew)! That said, we waited..

I'm a sucker for cornbread so I went with the special this month - they described it as a kind of southwestern eggs benedict with pork belly..but it was just two fried eggs on thin cornbread with a few pieces of pork belly and jalapeños. It was very tasty but it was definitely NOT a "Benedict" in any sense of the word or what we're all used to. My wife did the corned beef has, which again had good flavor but did not look very "hash" like. Her dish was really wet - from the soggy hash browns (not browned) to the runny egg it melded into something she couldn't finish. I tasted it a couple times, and although tasty for me, it was very sloppy. 

What's with cooks not knowing how to make eggs over MEDIUM?? This is a standard thing in cooking schools - a fried egg / sunny side up is just that, not flipped and cooked in one side and runny. Over easy is flipped and cooked quickly on the top side - still runny. Over MEDIUM should not be runny at all, but ooze slightly, and over hard is just that - fully cooked yoke. Apparently the cooks here don't know the difference..

The regular coffee was no better than Macdonald's, and the mimosa just so-so. Atmosphere was energized - like I said there was an hour wait to get in and folks were definitely taking their time at their tables.  

I really really love breakfast / brunch food, and this place delivered a solid 3star performance. Prices are decent. Food was decent for a fast casual place. Wait an hour knowing what I know now? NEVER AGAIN

Solid retro old school vibe I really like. We popped in for lunch after flying back into STL and had a great midday meal. Very sharp servers in the lower dimly lit (in a good way) lower dining room made for a great first impression. I love good calamari, and they did t disappoint - perfectly lightly fried with jalapeños and a couple different dipping sauces. We also did a seafood trio which was excellent.

The one disappointment was the Gorgonzola steak salad.....sounded so good on the menu... WHY CHAR (and wilt) THE LETTUCE!? It doesn't make for a pleasant texture or taste. 

Overall though I'm glad I finally made it in and now know they're a solid seafood option for lunch and dinner.

Very solid 4 STARS.

I wasn't expecting much the first time I went, but after eating there a couple times I think it'll be my new go-to place for sit down casual sushi. There is a lot of room so it's a good last minute place to go out with a group, and it's BYOB.

The 3 roll special is great - they give you a lot of choices, and the rolls are larger and more filling than other sushi places nearby. The spicy white tuna roll with apple is really tasty, although they do stuff their spicy rolls with panko so you don't really appreciate the fish as much. On the other hand, there's a good portion of salmon in the salmon avocado roll, and both times I've had it, it's been very fresh and sweet. 

Generous, fresh pieces of sashimi in the sushi bar entrees. The specialty rolls are pricey but good - I especially liked the green tea roll. 

They have impeccable plating, and everything is rolled perfectly...but it also means the food takes a long time to come out, so don't expect a quick dinner if you're dining in.

I really enjoyed having lunch at the Sparks Squeeze In. The atmosphere was fun and homey. The kids had a great time with the buckets of McDonald's toys and matchbox cars. They also enjoyed coloring befor their perfectly prepared food arrived. Everyone in our party was more than satisfied with their food. The only drawback that I had was that the menu is gigantic. Other than that, this is a great place to eat.

I wish I could give 3.5 stars. 

The real draw for me on a Tuesday night is $2 pints. Great opportunity to try beers I'm usually to nervous to pay full price for. I think of it as beer tasting. 
While enjoying various beers I tried their burgers. They're good cooked to order good sized burgers. The fries are just..... Ok. Go for the onion rings or something else. 

The biggest negative is the noise level. Tuesday night I guess is karaoke night. It gets loud in there. Hard to have a conversation with your dinner mates in this restaurant. Otherwise the food is good. And so is cheap beer.

I have been here several times and usually the food is good. But my rating is due to the quality of service I received last time I went there with my girlfriend. She was pretty tired from a whole day of work. It was busy and the line was long so she sat at a table while I stood in line. But the manager came over and told her she couldn't sit until she had ordered. We just left. There are plenty of great and friendly places to eat in Tucson. This is not one of them.

It is just too much of everything. If you want the good, ORIGINAL take no names cookie, find the original owners in the back of the reading terminal market.  I can't go back here because the challah french toast so overwhelmed me that I almost lost it.

Poor service & understaffed on 12/27/12. Waitress had Dirty blue apron , which was not appealing for our appetite nor was her charming personality ! No hostess to great people ( see in photo section )
