Always love this restaurant but expect to pay $100 person with all said and done. One thing that makes me mad is the palm keeps forgetting to check me in on open table?! Twice in a row...

I have been to this place 4 times in 4 months...and I think this one definitely deserves a review.
Huge quantity entree - very much sufficient to share between the two and if you had few appetizers can do a take away too.
Scallion Pancakes - My all time fav. I can just go on eating this....
Spicy cucumber/Chicken in Chilly Oil - I don't eat too spicy food...so not a big fan of it but my husband and friends enjoyed every bite of it.
For Entrees we ordered multiple dishes:
Dry Pot Style with Tofu/Garlic Sauce Style Chicken - Very good to taste. Though a little dry so I prefer ordering fried rice or some gravy rather than eating this with plain rice.
Three Cup Chicken - Good to taste but I found it too much salt in it. So did not enjoy it as much.
Double cooked style Fish - It is very difficult for me to like some fish. But this one was just awesome. I think this is one of the only place in Philly so far where I liked Fish and I will go again to eat it.
If you are trying to book online..you may see the slots are full but worth making a call to book. Also, we have walked in couple of times and have got the table in 15-20mins. The only thing that has stayed constant is that the Staff is not very cheerful, I always feel they are tired and exhausted and waiting for it to get over soon. Otherwise its all good.

Food OK. Service, wanting. Atmosphere is all right -- if you like dining on an airport tarmac. (Noise level would deafen the deaf!). Prices just about right. Though I didn't appreciate the sparkling water scam: Small bottles ONLY, so you have to buy multiple bottles so as to jack up the overall price. Go late when the crowds thing. Jeez, we were there for 5:30 opening (our dinner companions are Americans transplanted from the Midwest, you see), and the place was already jammed. -- Hotspur for The PJ.

Weird, but my sushi didn't really taste the freshest. The price was to be expected for a sushi place, but the rice was hard, and the spicy tuna roll was not very spicy. pretty fast and nice service though.

Mondays all-you-can-eat-buffet = hurtin' and lovin' it! Honestly, if it's your first time going why not go for the Monday buffet? You can try out everything and see what you like and then come later. Apparently this place gets crazy but it was not very packed when I got there plus they had homemade sweet tea that made me miss the South. The black in me loves this place.

Also, I called because I'm getting their food for my Super Bowl Party and they were like super friendly and helpful. Adore them.

Trying not to be a hater, but really the "Meh. I've experienced better" hits it RIGHT on the mark. Mostly I liked the super chill server who came by and chatted with us. I think trendy bowling places that are expensive and serve expensive but greasy food go against what bowling is all about. Gimme the inexpensive and fast, and it'll feel like what a bowling alley should feel like. I mean, if you had to pay $40 for a philly cheesesteak you'd cry foul, right? It just feels wrong. No matter how much low-lighting and trendy couches you add. 

I even like North Bowl better. Mostly because it feels less like Corporate America there. Whatever that means.

I walk by this truck to classes from work all the time. It whispers my name. After a the fourth time of buying macaroons from here, I started buying them for friends instead of the usual birthday cupcakes. As Thank Yous. To bring to a baby shower. And the list goes on and on. They're assembled right in front of you. They always have the standard 3 flavors (Milk & Honey, Chocolate Ganache,  and Tiramisu) then depending on the day of the week they rotate in other flavors. 

It may not be may favorite place to get macaroons in the city, but they are delicious AND conveniently located way too close to me.

So I've hear of this sang kee biz for a while since apparently they're famed for the roast duck -- but i heard it's the one at reading terminal. Anyhoo, we went for UC Dining Days and you can definitely get a good deal/price on days that are not UC Dining Days. Take this review with a pinch of salt (MSG?) though, because I plan on going back and figuring out the rating for real.

Here's why this place was good:
Affordable and fast

Here's why this place was okay:
Appetizer of juicy buns was in fact not juicy. I've had waaaay better. The pork was tasty but they should have just called them pork dumplings.
My friend got their tofu curry ... and there was no tofu. We sent it back after much confusion on their behalf.

And in general the waitress wasn't really on point. So, in summary if you're in the area this is definitely a good place for lunch or what not. I'd definitely go back, maybe for dim sum and see how it goes!

Above average (by an inch) Japanese food in CC. It's close to my office so it's convenient at the moment. Special rolls are great, everything is pretty authentic. Atmosphere is cozy and the service is pretty prompt and efficient.

Bottom line: efficiency + consistency + convenience = 4 stars.

It's so really hard to give  a full review of a Restaurant when you just dine at the Happy Hour.  Albeit,  we did order one of their lip smacking items from the list. of sandwiches.   We got the trip tip roast sandwich on a warm crusty ciabatta bread oozing  with carmelized onions.  It comes with either soup of the day, chips or salad.  We chose the salad with fresh greens, gooey good tasting pecans in a light vinegarette dressing. Very fresh and yummy.  They kindly split the sandwich for us.  Also ordered the toasted ravioli with a pretty decent tomato sauce. This was from the Happy Hour menu.   The ambiance is very chic and tasteful.  It was a Saturday night at about 6.00PM and with the hot summer ascending upon us desert rats the place was pretty quiet.  The snow birds have once again went to cooler places.  They were having a local band perform at 10.00PM when the young un's start to arrive. When us from the older group are soundly asleep.

I love wandering around AJ's checking out all the high end gourmet food.  It's so close to my house which makes it a great thing to do on a boring Sunday afternoon.    Of course, you can't do a full shopping here because you will pay through the roof.  However, they do have some descent sales on certain items.  We just love meandering through all the selections of fruit and veggies. fish department, as well as meats.   When we get to the fish department.  Outside of it they display tuna salad, whitefish salads, cajun trout salad with little crackers for sampling.   Yummo, I have to taste them all.  So far so good.  It hasn't cost a cent.  Then we get to the Pizza.  Being a definite maven on Pizza, theirs is top notch.  All freshly made in wood fired ovens by the slice.  It is the best bargain around.  The slice is humongous like two slices.  The other day they had a chicken with ranch dressing pizza.  I usually wouldn't get a bastardized version of pizza.  Being the purest that I am.  The other pizza wasn't in the oven yet, so I relented and got the last slice of the chicken one.   Wow!! That so so awesome.  So far the bill is $2.99. Not a bad deal for AJ's Fine Foods. 
Then hubby being the beer aficionado buys a couple of bottles of the singles they sell to take home.   A pretty good selection I might add.  We took our pizza and dined out in the glorious outdoor  setting  overlooking the city lights of Tucson.  What a romantic way to spend an evening.

After much interest, I finally had a chance to visit Azian. 

I was actually excited. It sat in my bookmark feed on Yelp for a couple of months. I opted to go one weekend day when I had some free time and so happened to be in the neighborhood during the lunch hour. 

It's been established that this is the previous location for Sushi Garden. Once inside, it looks utterly different. The bar is still toward the front and the sushi bar and line toward the east, but the decor and mood are so different. 

First off, I arrive and am immediately greeted by two staff members. It was very light for traffic -- only two other tables seated with one person at the bar. I found that the server was very attentive and was ready to take my order at the right time. 

I did take a look at the lunch buffet, but opted against it. I wanted to see what they had to offer for sushi. I went with the $1 option. Sushi at $1?! Pretty sweet. 

As I sat waiting for my order, I observed the space. 

The decor is a dark grey with silver tones throughout. It reminds me of 1980s era lounge bars. Not sure why. I wasn't anywhere near the drinking age in the 1980s and, thus, would never have been in a bar. Anyway, the carpet has been removed (thank goodness!) to give way to nice flooring. Also, a few television sets are installed set to sports and entertainment shows. 

FYI: They have a kid's menu for those 12 and under. But it's pricey: $9. 

But, in all, I'm feeling pretty good at this moment at the restaurant. 

Soon, my sushi arrives. I went with the nigiri. First thing I notice is that the sushi look like they are wearing mini skirts. The fish was that tiny, so tiny that looking from above, you could see much of the sushi rice. 

Whatever, I thought. 

All told, I went with the mackerel, red snapper, salmon, spicy scallops, tuna, yellowtail, conch and white tuna. What I noticed right away is that the fish tasted fresh, but that it did not have that much flavor. Mackerel and salmon, in particular, tend to be luscious oily cuts. But these were somewhat dry. It was strange. 

It was like a miniature, light (read: lite) version of real sushi. 

I did try a roll: the popcorn lobster roll, which is basically a California roll with nuggets of lobster and what is called "yummy sauce". Seriously, that's what it's called. It's printed like that right on the menu. 

But I didn't like it at all. I could see the lobster. I could see it right there teeming with this thick, orange-color sauce. The sauce did it in. It was way too heavy -- like a slice of melted cheddar cheese. 

The total cost was about $16. Honestly, I left wishing I'd just paid the full price of sushi. I wonder if, because of the $1 pricetag, they go skimpy. I would rather cut a check for quality than to skimp on the price for what amounted to substandard sushi. 

So, all that to say that I will be going back at some point, but most likely to try out the dinner menu.

After some errands in Center City, I came to Elixir after reading good reviews for a place to get caffeinated and make a dent in the pile of studying I had to do.

I have nothing but positive things to say! I loved the decor and the atmosphere. There aren't tons and tons of places to sit and do work but there was never more than one or two people waiting for a seat at a time, and the wait wasn't long for anyone. I ended up asking someone if I could sit at their small table with them and it was plenty of space, so if you're okay with sitting near someone than this is a great place to do work.

Because I stayed so long studying, I ended up getting a few things (also because I felt bad staying for hours and not getting more than one thing!) The latte was good but standard. I had a peanut butter banana chocolate donut which was delicious. And then I had a plain black coffee which you could tell was actually GOOD coffee. 

I'll definitely be back when I want to get off campus!

I give this place a 4 star because there food is so good. I got there shrimp tacos and it was super flavorful and it was a delicious. Our server is SO SWEET. but the bartender while we were waiting was super rude and unwelcoming. Almost turned our group of 4 off to this place but again the food and our actual server redeemed the experience. 10/10 food and drink! Minus bartender.

Awesome dim sum. Came here yesterday for the first time and I'm so glad we did. After 3 years of being back East, we finally gave in and drove to Philly for delicious dim sum. My hubs and I are big dim sum fans and I'm surprised it took us this long to go. We were pleasantly surprised with Joy Tsin.

We came right on time. Shortly after we arrived (around 11A), it was PACKED with a line out the door. So be sure to get here early.

We sampled Shu Mai, Fried Tarot, Shrimp Balls, Sesame Balls, Pork Ribs, and so much more. My favorites were the Fried Tarot and the rice steamed in a banana leaf with a variety of meat. Oh MY GOD. So good. I could've had 3 of them (well, not really, but you can imagine).

The servers are very attentive and the food is fresh. The seafood dumpling tasted like it'd been in a heater for a bit but other than that, all of the pieces were delicious.

Awful. Awful. Awful. I came here with co-workers for a Happy Hour event and we were beyond disappointed. We arrived at 5:50 and went over to our reserved area. We were the first ones to arrive. We ordered a pitcher of margaritas at 5:57 (still the only ones there). We received our margarita pitcher at 6:25. Are you kidding? The service was GOD AWFUL. The server felt it was necessary to serve the folks who came long after we'd arrived. She put the pitcher down and returned 10 minutes later with glasses. The margaritas were awful - pure sugary mix. Where was the tequila? We paid our bill and left, not finishing our drinks. On the way out, we passed someone who'd ordered tacos. The meat in the tacos was oily ground beef. EW. I won't be back.

Pretty good! I can't give this place a full review just yet as I only sampled some guac, salad, and margaritas.

Get here early or make a reservation. A typical wait on a Thursday night at 6:45P is 45 minutes.

In any case.... I tried the pomegranate and pineapple margaritas. SUPER YUMMY. this is the first time in a long time I didn't feel sick to my stomach after drinking a margarita. I think it was due to the fact that they use lime juice and purees vs. sweet and sour mix.

The Mexican Chopped Salad was super yummy. Light and fresh. The guac with goat cheese and pistachios was SO GOOD it was addicting.

Mm.
Excellent service and way too many beers to choose. Huge menu and everything we got was delicious.

Let's just say I totally outdid myself at Texas de Brazil.  Upon arrival you are first tempted with a lobster bisque that is "buffet style"...a trick to get you to the table of many treats! Once there, I found that they had a cured ham selection, some mozzarella, some sundried tomatoes, pepercini, and other items that was hard to say to no to; we are there for the meat right??! 
Anyway, a plate later I realize my date has been sampling the tasty steak while I was having fun with all of the other non-steak options! 
The meat was nice and salty, tender, and I must admit fun to have people coming to your table with spears and knives...I only had the steak, I was not interested in the pork or chicken.  
We also had the flan for dessert, this was the consistency of a NY style cheesecake...but was AWESOME! We will definitely be going back!
We had a doz of raw oysters, shrimp crab egg roils, and Cajun crab pasta! Everything was delicious! Friendly service! Will definitely come back!

I don't love this hotel. I stayed here once and it was during Street Vibrations, which if you know anything about Street Vibrations it makes downtown Reno an expensive and obnoxious place to stay. I stayed at Circus Circus because the rooms weren't insanely expensive.

Regular week days here are very inexpensive. I would say it's one of the better casinos to bring kids to but it is very outdated. I don't trust the carpet in the rooms, it's red and I have no idea what is in it. Circus Circus is pretty easy to get lost in, but the monorail is pretty neat.

Great food. Service is hit and miss...1st time was good...2nd time 4 people was 2.5 hours for brunch...Sat outside but inside looked really nice. Brunch cocktails were good and strong.
The sweet potato fries were nice as to was the chilli checicken Colorado sandwich.
Will try the next door same owner i think...bbq place next as got 15% off with the receipt frm whinnes

I really should name this review "Stephen Starr underwhelms again". I went here for restaurant week with a good friend. This restaurant itself aesthetically is gorgeous. Most of his restaurants are. Maybe interior design is more his style, because the food is always underwhelming to me at all his places I've been too. Now idk if it's because other hype them so much I have high expectations, but it was basic at best. I went for a bento box which was served with mediocre dumplings, pretty good soup and a tiny portion of average sliced pork which vegetables. Presentation was really nice, which is even worse because the food looked better than it tasted. Drinks were decent and the dessert was very good. If you go I recommend the doughnuts, they were they best part of the meal easily. The gentleman who served me was very quick and pleasant as well. I went to cross it off my bucket list, idk if I would revisit however.

Ordered through Caviar so I can't really comment on anything other than the food. 

Veggie mix platter came with a little bit of everything. Would we order it again? Probably not. I found it to be overpriced. It pretty much was two salads stuffed into a box with little sides of hummus and Baba ghanouj. I will admit that everything tasted pretty good, I wasn't craving it the next day or anything but I was thoroughly happy while I was eating. The falafel were crispy and well put together. Not the best but not the worst. 

Gyro sandwich... half of it was ice cold while other half hot? I threw it in the fridge and heated it up the next day. I'm not crazy for the Lebanese bread, it's really thin and bland. I didn't have my glasses on. I thought my napkin next to me was another slice of bread, that's how thin and flimsy it is. 

We had free delivery, so with tip and the two food orders.. everything came out to almost $40. Not worth it. I wouldn't order the veggie mix platter again. $19 is just way too much for what you actually get. 

I don't think I would order from here again.

I have been here 3 times now and each time I have had great service. My husband and I love their ice cream. The Oreo explosion cone thingy is his fav and I get the Butterfinger Blast. Omggg it's so good. I also get the Diet Cherry frozen limeade, which I found out it's actually not diet because the frozen base actually has sugar in it. I wish they would have shared that with me the first 2 times I ordered it.

I came here mainly based on proximity and the desire to get something quick and casual. My friends who are locals recommended The Godfather, but we ultimately selected the Grandma with garlic. 

When I entered the shop I noticed a nice assortment of enticing slices, and my friend said it was a great place to grab a few.  I think that will be my strategy on my next visit. I did like our choice, and it was a huge box filling pie. I think it's best to reheat this at home and if that's your intention just ask them not to slice it. The fresh mozzarella was plentiful and a good ratio to the sauce that while being robust, was also just a tad too sweet for me. But overall I did find it to be an above average pie, I'd like to explore more. 3.5 Yelps
Somehow this carmalitas is not as good as the one up the street on east bay. Not quite as fresh and just seems dark in there.

Located in an older strip mall on West Main, Pueblo Real is nondescript and easy to miss, but you can't judge this book by its cover. Having been here many times, I can attest to its overall quality and dependability.

In terms of food, they offer all of the usual suspects, but their preparation, seasoning, and sauces are a cut above most other places in the Nashville area. The house tomato salsa is above average, and they have a few off-the-menu salsas that you can ask for, of which, my favorite is their fiery habanero. Holy cow, this stuff is good, and highly addictive to the heat-seeking palate. Their red and green burrito sauces are also notably better than any I've had in town.

A few menu items really stand out. My absolute favorite is their chile Colorado, probably my favorite Mexican entree in town. The beef tips are served in the most delicious spicy, tomatillo sauce. It's rich, smoky, savory, spicy, and tangy all at once. I would pay big bucks for the recipe. Another favorite of mine is their large Texas chimichanga, which I recommend with steak instead of the chicken listed on the menu. Speaking of Texas, my girlfriend hails from the Lone Star State, and for what it's worth, she considers Pueblo Real the most legit Mexican restaurant in the area. Her favorite dish is the enchiladas Suizas.

Prices are generally on par with other Mexican restaurants, if not a tad cheaper, but food quality and portion size make Pueblo Real a better value and more desirable destination in my book. Oh, and their lunch menu prices are outstanding.

The employees here are super friendly, including owners Jesus and José. The atmosphere is fun, and the noise level can be on the loud side during busier shifts, including 1/2 off margaritas night (Tuesday), trivia night (Wednesday), and weekends. The custom Pueblo Real seats and booths are visually a little much, and they really cram in as many seats as possible, at the slight expense of the customer's comfort. Minor criticisms aside, Pueblo Real is a reliable winner in my book. If you're in the Franklin area, try immediately. If you're in Nashville, seriously consider making the trip out here.

While this place does have tasty dishes, the value isn't great and the service and ambiance can be a bit lacking. I've been here a number of times for corporate events and dining out in University city, and my reaction is consistently the same.

Pros: This place has a combination of traditional Mexican fare as well as American standards, giving plenty of options to the guest. 

Cons: The way the menu works is rather confusing, I find that when I need to order for myself, and food is not simply provided in a banquet style, I never know how much food to order, and leave hungry or annoyed at the wait staff for allowing me to order too much (presumably to add to their tip). Additionally, it does not make sense to have a family style menu that features tacos. They come in orders of three, which is NEVER the right amount for any party really ever. What I would advise the restaurant do is allow orders of tacos to be served in multiples of three if they'd like, or preferably to allow mix and match tacos that can be ordered alone or in any quantity you so desire. Lastly, this restaurant does a poor job of describing what their traditional Mexican fare actually is, leaving diners who are not used to traditional Mexican aimless and virtually confined to the tex-mex style.

Overall: This restaurant is decidedly elevated Mexican fare, however, it is not a great value, and the menu is very difficult to navigate.

I've always had mixed feelings about Jones, but my last trip put me over the edge. I like the American-themed menu, but the food just never lives up to its description. A few trips ago I tried the mac & cheese as an appetizer and was very impressed. I did think $8.50 was a little steep for a small dish of just plain noodles and cheese, but I enjoyed it so I didn't have any complaints. Over the weekend I had a mac craving and thought Jones would be the perfect destination. However, this time around the dish tasted completely sour. It was like they were trying to throw in too many flavors, and just ruined it. It's rare when I don't finished a plate of mac & cheese, but this was almost inedible. During that same trip my boyfriend ordered the matzo ball soup. Again, almost $8 for one matzo ball, and it wasn't even hot. This could have been an off day, but I've never been impressed with any of the dishes here. The entrees are similarly just so-so- they sound great but have the quality of diner food. As for the drinks, I'd pass on ordering these completely. They are small and way overpriced for the quality. 

It's a shame because I only live a few blocks away, but I don't think I'll be returning.

As of this review Seasons Pizza states on its website that it was voted the #1 pizza in Delaware from 2002 to 2005 according to News Journal readers. Well, I never tried Seasons Pizza until 2009 so I can only assume that the quality must have dropped precipitously since that last award in 2005. I'm not a pizza snob by any stretch of the imagination, but I can't imagine how Seasons Pizza could win any awards, at least not with the pizza they currently foist on their patrons.

My biggest problem with their pizza is the crust. I've tried Seasons pizza in its regular and thin crust variations, but the crust never seems right. I can't put my finger on what the problem is, but it just doesn't work as pizza crust. I prefer the crust found in most frozen pizzas to that of Seasons. The crust is the foundation of any pizza, and if the crust is no good then it's game over for the pizza.

I've tried a few other selections from Seasons' menu - calzones, salads, chicken wings. Everything was adequate, but unremarkable. In the end, if you can't get halfway decent pizza at a pizza joint, what's the point?

(In the spirit of full disclosure, I've only tried Seasons' takeout service. I've never eaten in the restaurant.)

Every time I pass by Cheddar's it's always packed! I had to check it out myself. I believe I went on a Sunday and yes, it was packed for lunch time. The service was good and the server's attitude was excellent!

The food isn't the type of food I really enjoy, heavy and fried food.. average American food. The flavors isn't that bad, but I did find the pasta to be too salty. The onion rings were highly suggested and I don't even like onion rings, but these were so light and crispy! Delicious and they are also super cheap for such a large pile.

The Shepard's pie was average and the Cajun pasta was pretty good, but too salty for me. The serving was a large size.

I must have to say! The drinks were pretty cheap! If I were to return I would definitely go for the drinks and appetizers.

I'm really surprised how beautiful the interior is when I walked in. It was not what I was expecting from a traditional Vietnamese restaurant and I'm very pleased. The service was also on track and my cup was always filled. 

The food was also pretty good. I had nothing negative to say and actually will come here more often because its clean and also not crazy rushed like other places near by.

They also have nice lunch specials if you're on a budget!

This is a wonderful hidden gem in Santa Barbara!  Wonderful Italian food, great service, and intimate cafe seating!  You will not be disappointed!  We took my mom here for her birthday and we were treated to an amazing slow lunch that made us all feel like we were back in Italy. They didn't rush us, we enjoyed every minute of it!  Thank you!

This place is great!!  After searching locally for an Axxess deal for lunch I stumbled upon this hidden gem in Old Town Goleta. What a delicious lunch. The dining room was cozy, the fireplace added a perfect amount of warmth and charm. The service was polite and friendly and very attentive. The food was delicious and the serve yourself salsa bar was perfect and had several selections. I would highly recommend this place. I will be back again soon!

The Hubs and I stopped in for lunch recently. We were sat quickly by the bartender who was also our waitress.
I had the Warm Spinach Salad with grilled chicken. Delicious! Loved the warm goat cheese. So good.
Hubs had Macadamia Nut Chicken Salad sandwich which he would have preferred without fries since he is watching his fried food intake, but those fries did look good!
Efficient lunch service. Will try again for dinner some time.

The service gets worse with each visit. 
Today we waited ten minutes before I finally approached the hostess to let her know we had no server. 
It was yet another ten minutes of waiting before a server finally approached us. 
Had there been a spot at the bar we would have moved there. 
We were seconds from walking out the door. 
We eat here a lot and this is not the first time we have encountered poor service. Poor service use to be hit and miss. It has now become the expected.
My husband and I love the food and the beer at Carolina Blue. Unfortunately, the food and the service are too inconsistent. We have been regulars here for many many months, but today was our last visit.
I hope someone wakes up and does some server training to save this spot.

E & E has been one of my favorite spots on the Bluff in the past. Revisited with the family on Wednesday and was not even remotely impressed with my meal; Chicken Margherita. For a side I had whipped sweet potatoes which were nothing special and some broccoli. 

I must admit that I am somewhat finicky about chicken and would not order a chicken dish from E & E again. I suppose I have always ordered seafood items previously.

Two at our table ordered the special salmon with sun-dried tomatoes, basil and a beuree blanc sauce. It looked good and they seemed to enjoy it. A fourth had the Chicken Caesar Salad which she enjoyed.

We did enjoy a gorgeous day with outside seating and a great server (Liz?). I will return again, but stay away from the chicken.

Just awful, from when I ordered to when I ate. Firstly, I ordered online and (thought) I paid online, which apparently I didn't... my order was $17 and I didn't have any cash on me, so I tried to use my card, and the lady informed me that the min credit card purchase was $20. I said fine... I don't have cash. I got out my wallet and she proceeded to look over at my wallet and I had to show her I didn't have cash. Absolutely absurd. Then, I leave, and go back to school, and find that they didn't even get my order right. I ordered Sesame Chicken, which isn't supposed to be spicy, and they gave me General Tso's Chicken, which is most certainly spicy, enough so that I couldn't even eat it. Then the crab Rangoons I got were tasteless, at best, which a weird lukewarm filling that tastes like I'm chewing on cotton. I mean c'mon. Avoid this place like the plague, there's plenty of other Chinese takeout places near here. $17 wasted.

New Orleans Food & Spirits is a pretty good restaurant. I have never been completely disappointed with this restaurant. 

I am a fan of their voodoo rolls and baked fish entrees. I believe their voodoo rolls are a favorite in general--creamy and filled with crawfish. They are worth the try!

I also love their baked fish entrees. I have always received fresh-tasting fish that was cooked to my liking. My favorite is the Redfish Pontchartrian. I could honestly eat it without the pasta and with a vegetable instead, but I still love this dish. 

Their chargrilled oysters are okay--I am a bigger fan of Acme's oysters and the oysters from Legacy Kitchen. My bigger pet peeve with NOFS is their uniformed taste in sauces. In other words, their white pasta sauces all taste the same. It also taste like the same base or sauce they use in other items, such as the crawfish corn soup.

Nonetheless, I find that the employees have great   customer service skills. A little slow from time to time, but I believe that happens when they get busy.

This is one of the spots that one cannot truly appreciate until you walk through the doors. And, if you really want to see the charm of this space, make sure to have a meal in the upstairs dining room.

I've walked by 417 Union more times than I care to admit without ever having entered the premises. Slap my feet with disdain.

The ambiance reminds me of classy with a mix of classic. I was surprised that it was rather quiet in the upstairs dining room. Since I turn up on the loud side, I was concerned I was going to destroy the room with volume. However, after the lunch crowd filtered in, I found that I was no more a nuisance than any other patron. 

I was promptly greeted upon entering the establishment. I also suggested a specific type of table and was kindly guided to my preference. The crowd is more of the decision making business crowd. A well-dressed crowd filled the seats. In some way, I felt as though I fell back into time where everyone dressed and felt important. It was a gentle reminder of how former generations appreciate feeling classy while enjoying well-prepared dishes.

I had the grilled catfish sandwich with a side of mac and cheese. If you know my reviews, you know that cheese is a staple. The sandwich came with a bun that was lightly toasted on the inside which was a perfect compliment to the lightly grilled catfish. The Cajun tarter was delightful and a nice twist from what could be expected from a remoulade sauce. The mac and cheese was perfect. The macaroni was al dente and not the overly Southern meat and three soft version. The cheese was a well-crafted thick style that was rich and held the macaroni together just right. 

My lunch friend has the Strawberry Caesar salad. It looked wonderfully fresh considering it is on the cusp of spring. 

The staff was fairly attentive. But, as anyone knows, lunch crowds are the toughest. They come in in a hurry and leave before the serve anticipates. 

I'm looking forward to frequent trips here. I also believe this would be an excellent place for a date and a nice dinner out downtown. The prices are reasonable. The high ceilings have that feel of a Victorian. But, this is a building amongst others in a downtown environment. With a few more trips, I'll update this review and hope future experiences will increase the starage (new word).

Having been here many times prior to big events in the Country music world, I dig the crowd and flavors this place offers. 

First, the bar area is usually bustling with a star studded cast during big nights: Country Music Award, concerts, or simply weekend nights. They make an excellent martini and at the price of $10-15 each, you'll be sure to move on after a few. 

Second, the food here is on par with an over excessive Americanized serving portion. This, helps justify the cost of the meal. Having been to much more expensive places and received half the serving, I feel the over all portions to price ratio are acceptable on any budget. 

Third, the staff here are knowledgeable about both the menu and the clientele. Engage them in conversation and they have amazing and fascinating stories to tell. 

Fourth, if you live in Nashville, bring your our Tupperware. There is definitely food to be brought home. 

Lastly, get the chocolate cake for desert! One piece here could feed four! 

Oh, and watch out, this is a tourist destination. That means there is a 25% liquor tax on all adult beverages! 

I have enjoyed my drinks, meals and conversations here. Not to mention the star gazing on a good night. This would be a great night out for a date or wanting to impress someone.

It's good, not great. Brisket is thin sliced. More like a cheese steak or a French dip cut. Just not what I expect on a Texas brisket sandwich. Spicy BBQ sauce didn't really have a stand out flavor. Like I said, it was good. I'd eat here again, but won't rush back.

Good food, service was okay. The online menu IS different that what they actually serve.  It is probably important to note that both our meals were the saltiest we've had since visiting New Orleans 5 days ago.  That could be a definite plus for some though.

I was in Indianapolis for a hot second, but had to try out this place. I had the fortune to talking to one of the assistant Brewers and had a lengthy conversation that made me feel at home. I had tried the sweet water Pilsner which was a solid selection. Didn't have food but the menu looked tempting. I will definitely have to come back for food to give it a better rating.

Don't go here for dinner. 

I'm not even sure where to start, but I left completely offended by this meal. I would NEVER recommend this restaurant to anyone. From the uncomfortable service to the poorly executed food, to the odd ambiance, it was simply a bad experience. 

We ordered the kanella platter, I ordered the manouri cheese ravioli and my husband ordered the fish dish accompanied by chickpeas etc. Maybe 15 minutes later a small plate which we later learned was the "platter" was set down on our table. Four cherry tomatoes, a small bunch of greek salad and two falafels on a bed of sauce. This was simple food, the beet falafel was decent, everything else was your basic stuff, that we make at home on a regular Wednesday. Then, came our entrees. It's not a good sign when you have to look for ingredients. As I looked at my husband's dish, I was having a hard time locating the fish; it was small even fine dining standards. (And kanella is not fine dining). To add insult to injury - the chickpeas and other accoutrements were overly salty. Then, my ravioli. What can one say about this poorly executed dish? How hard IS it to cook four ravioli to be al dente? And, I'd love to tell you that the mint pesto was delicious but all I could taste was salt. And then were the sad zucchini blossoms, which had been so unfortunately misused - they had simply smushed them into the pesto, so they were soggy, and inedible. Really? $22 for undercooked pasta in salt sauce with soggy elephant ears? Nope, no thank you. To be clear -it's not about paying for food - but if you are going to charge that much, then it better be excellent, or maybe even good, but it can't, it simply can't, be that bad. 

Then there was the very inconsistent service; one person came to take our order and read us the specials. A second guy sort of waited on our table, and re-read the specials even though we said we had already heard them, and a third person came to deal with our check, mainly because of the look on my face after I had been served the entree.

All in all so incredibly disappointing.

A little packed a lunch good variety of pizza options. If you have a vegan/veg friend this would be a good choice also have gluten free stuff. Me being a meat eater without sprue I'll still go back. But I've had better pizza in tampa before. The server/cashier was pleasant and the two person crew managed to handle a flood of macdill folks arriving at the same time.

This place is always packed for some reason.  I really can't figure it out.  We tried going there for happy hour once and ended up leaving because it was so crowded.  There are a ton of televisions so it's good from watching sports.  We've been here a few times and the service is ok.  Food is typical bar food quality, nothing to write home about.  But the biggest complaint that I have heard from friends whenever we go is that the drinks are watered down.  We ordered a pitcher of margaritas because it was a special, and it was a complete joke.  Tasted like something you would get from Applebee's.  We ordered mixed drinks, and again, there was almost no alcohol.   They ended up making us new drinks, but it's still very underhanded.  Stick to beer if you plan on going.  Although, there are so many better bars in the area.

This is the third time I have come here and still no bagel dogs - the excuse is they are in high demand and I should call ahead and order! Seriously how about you plan effectively and know that you have a hot selling item and make more! Store was dirty today and service lacking.

First of all, let me say that my only problem with this place is the attitutde of the manager or who-ever he is.  I was willing to overlook it during Jazz Fest when I went in with 5 people and we took a seat to get out of the way of the crowd while one of our group ordered.  The manager came up and asked us not to take a table until we got our food.  I understood his point and we got up, but since there was really no place to stand we were in the way of everyone one (we had two kids with us which didn't help), and immediately a woman from 4 spots behind us in line sat down and started texting while her husband waited in line to order.  The manager said NOTHING to her.  So he is inflicting his control issues on us but evidently not on anyone else.  I figured they were busy and anyone can have a bad day.  But yesterday this guy was extremely rude again.  We asked what kind of bread they had because we couldn't remember the name of the one we liked.  The woman helping us named two kinds but it wasn't one of them so we asked "is that all you have?"  The manger pipes in "Well it IS late in the day!" in a really obnoxious manner.  We responded that we weren't really talking to him.  Turned out they did have the kind we wanted and the woman got it for us.  The women who work there are very very nice and I LOVE their cupcakes, pastries, iced coffee (and their grilled cheese is AMAZING).  But this guy needs to go on vacation or something or find a job where he doesn't intereact with the public.   His personality would be better suited to debt collection or something where he can let his general bad attitude work for him.    I live in the neighborhood and since the long, hot summer is upon us and tourists will be in smaller supply, I would think that this guy would be a little more courteous to his local clientel.

CBW: For when you're just not down with bar food today.  While the wraps, and even the salads, may not be shining examples of nutrition, they are far better for you than the alternatives offered up by the local competition (Chuy's, Laclede's, McDonald's, etc).  The food is tasty and away from the ordinary, the parking is plentiful, and the service is solid.
Good food, good service, huge space!  I've been here a few times, and I apologize for my brevity, but those three factors remain the only and unchanged meat of my review.

Another casual food restaurant but it seems they have higher food quality standards than most of the chain restaurants. I was with a group of 5 and we were seated soon as we walked in. Their portion size is large and the food tasted good, nobody complained.  I had the chicken breast sandwich with hot sauce. The breast was juicy and cooked right and the sweet potato fries were perfect. I will be back.

Pizzamazing!! Whaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa! What a cool event. When we got there we received a ticket for a Lagunitas, then another ticket for cocktail of your choice AND a raffle ticket. The place was packed... Should have got there earlier, to grab a seat. This event was more like a social than a sit down dinner :) loves the change with this!! lol!  
Wild garlic had plenty of staff to accommodate the group and the locals that were coming in as well.  In addition to all the crazy good company we had CRAZY GOOD FOOD!! knock your socks off!! Best pizza I ever had! 

The owner spoke to us about the beginnings of wild garlic and blind onion, his multiple set backs with water damage, attempted suicide by car in the window and of course the fire!! Wow!! His successes and the wonderful accomplishment of adding another location! After all this business has been through!! The Yelp staff is always accommodating, friendly and FUN! GREAT JOB!

For stars for effort! This place is up off of pyramid highway in sparks.. It's up in the Walmart shopping center. The location has been open since December 2015.... Who knew? Parking is super easy and there is lots of space. 
When you walk in it's very clean and free of any one particular food odor. There were about 15 people inside already and more just pouring in. 

You are greeted immediately by the owner or one of his extremely nice staff.  We were seated right away and offered to get a drink order done. They have a nice big menu with Mexican and American food to offer. Half of my group got breakfast and half of my group got lunch.  The food came out within 10 minutes and everything is piping hot.
I ended up ordering the chicken Caesar wrap with french fries. My french fries were super hot and sprinkled with some amazing seasoning. The French fry is a combination between a regular french fry and a steak fry. Super delicious and super hot. My chicken Caesar wrap it's self was perfectly balanced with sauce to lettuce to meat. It wasn't too dry or too wet... It was just right. However, the texture of the chicken was a little chewy and a little gummy and it was waaay over seasoned with garlic. I was able to pick the chicken out and eat around it just the same. 
I wasn't going to say anything because every single person at the table was happy with their meal and everything looks fantastic! However when the owner came over to ask if I wanted a box, I told him no. He seemed concerned on why and inquired if everything was ok?  I explain the situation above. He insisted on removing it from the bill and comped my entire meal! I ask him not to do that because I was happy to pay for it, totally 100% out of my normal character, but he insisted and said it was the right thing to do!NOW THAT IS WHAT I CALL SERVICE! 

When it came time for us to pay the bill, my iced tea, side of ranch ( I don't know if they charge for that... And it was super good ) and my meal were completely removed. I asked to at least pay for the iced tea, he insisted on removing  the entire thing, apologized and apologized. He told me " we are better than that! Please come back to let us show you". 

Because of his outstanding customer service I WILL BE BACK to try the shrimp enchiladas that my girlfriend said were phenomenal and or the taco salad that equal.

WATER SPRINGS!! you should teach some of the other places in town ... How to treat a customer :) outstanding job! I will be back with friends!  Thank you for getting giving me the opportunity to do that :) GREAT JOB!

Late lunch on a Friday. At the bar. Ambiance rocks. 

Saw Teelings Irish Whisky on menu. Two kinds. Finally get to try it. Nope, neither in stock. Strike one.

Order black and tan and get a black. No process used to assure separation. Strike two.

Order tater skins. Bartender hung out on other side of bar with either daughter or friend and ignored my side of the bar. 30 minutes to get my food in a largely empty space. Strike three.

Skins were good so add one star back on. 

Lots of great spots to hit so likely not back here unless Dexys Midnight Runners are playing. ;0)

The food was ok, but it didn't make up for the rest.  They had a huge wait but everyone waiting was just crowded in the entrance so it was pretty uncomfortable.  The service was ok, everything was overpriced, they were out of the one thing I really wanted (potato pancakes), and I was just overall not impressed.

We were very mixed. The lower review is because Travis thought his burger was overcooked and dry and that it wasn't worth the hype (or the wait in line).

Nick loved it and has returned twice. 5 stars from him. The pide is amazing. Probably the best to start with if you haven't been there before. I got it with impossible burger and would do the same if I got it again. But my new go-to is the #4 lahmacun for the spice. It's SO good.

The 1/2 Cevapi is a good option for a cheaper lunch that will still fill you up.

Also, they have a great veggie sandwich (#7 Patlidzan with wood fired eggplant, bunches of veggies, and apricot-pomegranate molasses. But you can also get anything veggie or vegan if you ask at the counter.

I came across this place with a friend while looking for a quick place to eat around Rittenhouse last weekend. After having a phenomenal crepe in New Orleans a few weeks ago, I was super excited to have another one as I had been craving them! We were seated instantly.. the place was pretty dead. The service was great and extremely attentive. The issue is the food and pricing. I wanted a savory crepe and decided to go with the "La Norvegienne" which was smoked salmon, brie, zucchini, and basil. Sounded amazing and I was really looking forward to it. My friend ordered one of the chicken savory crepes. 

Our food came out quickly. The first thing I noticed was that my crepe was about half the size of my friends! I instantly was disappointed. Not only was my crepe pretty small, but it wasn't even very good. The smoked salmon was not what I am used to and it was more of a fishy and unseasoned flavor.. not the salty, smooth taste that I was expecting. The rest of the crepe was just not that great and fell flat. I finished it in about 5 minutes because of the sheer lack of food! My friend wasn't very impresed with hers either, though at least hers was more filling. For my crepe, water, tax, and tip, I paid 18 bucks.. and I was starving when I left. Do yourself a favor and spend your money elsewhere!

Been here a few times. I don't know why I'm being generous & giving 2 stars but the waiter was nice & location super convenient since some of us were meeting after our movies. The last couple times the food was mediocre. 
Biggest downfall - Everything was DIRTY ! The floors were sticky everywhere, but especially in the bathroom! Our feet were seriously sticking to the floors. Eww! 
Our wines glasses , 2 of us ordered wine - dirty! You could feel it on the outside & visibly dirty. We "washed " the area we would be drinking from before putting it to our mouths. In hindsight probably should've asked for another but it took us so long to get our drinks, guess we were anxious.  
The plates at the salad bar - dirty! I went through the small piles that were left, every single one had to be wiped off before you could use it. 
The salad bar - dirty & a mess! Needed to be cleaned up & wiped down desperately. Also so many of the selections were bottom of the barrel just floating in ice & needed to be freshened up. It was 530 on a Sunday & pretty busy so a time when things should've been stocked. 
Very disappointed! This is in a perfect location for us, especially being regular movie-goers & I love a good salad bar but after this experience I wouldn't recommend coming here. Hopefully things improve. 
Please step it up !!!

3 stars for fresh ingredients but not enough of them. I could never find the bacon in my pizza and sausage was scarce.  They do not use herbs in this place and charged me fifty cents for the basil I asked to add to my pizza!!!

Back when the location was Tazia (http://www.yelp.com/biz/tazia-restaurant-philadelphia) I thought it was perfect as an off Asian sports bar with solid drink specials and a late night happy hour. But at the same time I also felt that  their were a few key flaws in execution that prevented it from being a winner. While Bar Ly just falls short on some of things as well, it does offer some serious upgrades that makes it worth visiting during either their exceptional Happy Hour or the day of a big game.

One of the things that didn't sell me on Tazia was its lack of an interesting drink menu. But Bar Ly significantly improved upon that by bringing in 40 taps that ranges from basics like Yuengling & Blue Moon to Heavy Hitters from Ommegang and Stones, and upping the ante with a pretty impressive signature martini list. The fact that a few of these are put up on the special Happy Hour menu that happens 7 days a week for a regular and occasional late night option is pretty awesome. It also helps that their made by some pretty impressive bartenders (including a Trocadero veteran).

The Tazia menu was fairly uninspiring Americanized Asian fare with a few basic bar food options like chicken wings. While the Bar Ly menu doesn't stray too far from from that path, offerings like the chicken gizzards or bacon wrapped quail eggs skewers, and banh mi are pretty inspiring. But things like their sushi and duck dumplings left much to be desired.

The creepy randomness of the bathrooms being in a bizarre hallway that's completely separate from the bar is weird. but other than that and the few aforementioned fronts, Bar Ly is a pretty solid bar overall, and perhaps the Philly best in the sports bar category.

The Khyber - Otherwise known as one of those places that I can't help but be conflicted reviewing. So I may as well explain why.

In a rare time there comes a place that maintains same ownership, and may very well maintain the same name that decides to pull the 180 degree and initiate some serious changes, only to go for the 360 degree. During that time you may find yourself hating the significant changes, yet can't help but like what it has become in the process.

I'd be the first to jump up and decree that to the Khyber, if it didn't prove to be such a confusing bastard in the process, that still manages to be one in certain ways.

If you look at the confusing path (http://www.philebrity.com/2010/07/29/city-paper-makes-cover-story-sized-bed-that-khyber-owner-is-not-completely-full-of-shit/), you'll find a story that flip flops throughout many situations. From selling the business, to not at all. From getting rid of the live music that it was known for to not at all; to doing so after all(while building a stage upstairs, but that's another story). From deciding to go Japanese Izakaya and do something that no place in Philly has done; to going southern BBQ and doing something that a number of places have done. In a nutshell, I don't even know where to make head or tails of that (and I appreciate you if you tried to read beyond the well place link that backs it up!)

But besides that I also feel that their giving up on live music was more or less a colossal cop out. Sure, it was at a time where places like Johnny Brenda's, Kung Fu Necktie, etc.; were delivering better shows. But rather than put the $$$$$ towards re-branding, you could have probably put significantly less towards looking into what you were doing differently, and fix it! while the other places had revamped sound systems, yours was more or less the same old 'ish. While other places maintained different bookers that maintained in different ways (house bookers, R5 Productions, websites, Flash Mob Productions, etc.!), Khyber more or less maintained just one that eventually got out of touch towards the end. Remedy both, and maintain what they had going on upstairs on certain days, and the product may have been fixed for significantly less. 

But I've knocked the Khyber for long enough. Because despite all the angst I feel toward it sometimes, it still maintains a lot of things that I love about it! The Khyber has always been a beer lovers paradise, and the new selection that it brings in only cements the fact that it may very well always be one. It also earns a gold star for staying true to the classic Happy Hour that it used to have! the food (especially what ever chilli you'll find them serving) is always impressive. As are the special events that they host!

Another wild card that is still as yet more of an undetermined, is the Khyber's upstairs area. Other than adding a few tables; and a stage which may or may not be necessary considering how they ostracized themselves from live music; upstairs has been more or less kept the same (they even kept the notorious bathroom - http://www.yelp.com/topic/philadelphia-the-worst-bathroom-in-philly#4qA-E0qL4ynFhI_eF5f81g). I can't say whether its a good thing or bad thing yet, because the Khyber hasn't really done a good job of promoting upstairs compared to how they used to, and have already lost things like a solid karaoke night in the process.

But if The Khyber managed to apply  the necessary tweaks to upstairs (whether it be as an extension of the restaurant, or especially a secondary club/music venue option), while being able to maintain the quality that their dishing out downstairs; then it could very well be on the FULL CIRCLE towards perfection. Therefore this review will hopefully be continued in admiration.

Ishkabibble's hands down makes some of the best fries in Philadelphia, and it has all kinds of varieties of them. But beyond that it really doesn't offer a whole lot of variety. add on the fact that it's a very compact outdoor eatery on crowded South Street, and you end up having so many places nearby that end up standing out a whole lot more.
as said above the fries are beyond worth it though, and the staff are very friendly and fast. And I'm going to have to try the Gremlin as soon as possible now.

Dear Benna's -

How I wish I knew about you sooner than Saturday morning (your coffee did a good job of bringing me back to life). You might just be everything I've wanted in a coffee house. People i know and haven't seen in age's happily sitting and drinking caffeinated goods, tasty baked goods for reasonable prices, and all kinds of interesting art and free publications to look at. I think I'm in love (and not just with your cute baristas).

Seriously though I randomly walked by Benna's while leaving my cousin's house and it's a cool little inviting joint. I'm not sure if it offers free wi-fi, and I can't tell you if it has any free trade coffee varieties. But I can tell you that it's a nice laid back spot that even welcomes your dog. and it's outdoor seating was a good reminder that Spring is almost in the air!

Climb aboard the Phooooo Train! With the Pho train you pretty much get what you pay for. The Pho definitely isn't the best that you'll find. But it's inexpensive enough to make it just above sub par. and you can't go wrong with the fact that it hooks up cheap drinks with frilly umbrellas (or can you?).

It does dish out an interesting assortment of milkshakes (jackfruit!). And it hooks up a great assortment of soups and pad Thai's. But there are just factors like service, and consistent quality that makes it just fall short of being one of the the better Pho institutions of Philly.

McThrill doesn't always drink fancy cocktails, but when he does he orders one called a Lady Boss because Bourbon (https://www.askideas.com/media/48/I-Dont-Always-Drink-Bourbon-For-Breakfast-But-When-I-Do-I-Go-Swimming-With-My-Bow-Tie-On-Funny-Swimming-Meme-Picture.jpg)!

On the scale of lady bosses, Philly's best named bar EVER was an Arianna Huffington - liberal with its use of quality alcohol, purposeful with the fresh ingredients found within the cocktails, and creative with its overall presentation!

Despite it being within a couple blocks of the 13th & South area that I've known for decades, Writers Block Rehab is one of those spots that I wouldn't have come across if it weren't for my drinking partner suggesting it out of the blue for a happy hour. And it led me to a spot that's essentially a speakeasy within plain site since its on a perfectly random side street, but towers over a parking lot on 13th and Spruce and has signage that flashes different colors. And inside leads to a 3 floor library themed cocktail bar that's complete with crossword and book themed murals, and "chandeliers" made out of multiple globes.

The entire list of cocktails are twists on old classics that utilize locally sourced herbs and plants - so a martini gains arugula, and a pisco sour gains tumeric. A potentially valid argument could be that it makes this hip cocktail bar come across as being a hip juice bar. But at least the end result tastes delicious, costs the same price as the juice, and has booze in it, so that at least makes for an upgrade. In addition to the Lady Boss, I also had an incredible whiskey drink that utilized Earl Grey and ginger (The Belvedere?) that I really wish I could remember the name of, and would easily if they maintained some sort of menu that could be accessed online (hopefully this changes!). but if you don't do cocktails they also have an alright beer list, wines, and some light bites (at least from what I saw on their Facebook).

At the end of our happy hour rendezvous we were presented with paperback copy of A Street Car Named Desire (movie cover edition with a shirtless Marlon Brando on the cover for the ladies!), in lieu of the standard check holder. And even though an awkward pickup exchange managed to toss my credit card card underneath my chair when I dropped it, it was extra quirky touches which embraced their theme like that which I loved overall. And not just because it also managed to uncover a random Found letter that I'll likely be sending somewhere (http://foundmagazine.com/). So with things like that I'll definitely be back!

Words can not summarize how excited I was to finally dine at Sulimay's. So I may as well explain why with the perfect video series example -

http://youtu.be/SfgjHXF1MuE

Being a Philly music nerd I can't help but mark whenever Woodshop Films delivers another episode of Breakfast at Sulimay's. So seeing the table where it all happened seriously made me feel giddy inside!

But outside of the Youtube series, Sulimay's dishes out a slight step above your typical diner fare, without doing it on the 24/7 time slot. along with your bacon, eggs, and bottomless coffee you can savor options like seasonal fruit pancakes.

Although always friendly, service can be slow at sporadic moments. And its definitely far from the first destination whenever I'm Fishtown bound. But if you're looking for the perfect inexpensive breakfast spot that can also deliver on neighborhood nostalgia, then Sulimay's is truly priceless!

It took me awhile to come here based on the so many mixed things that I've heard. But we stopped in here after my birthday arts crawl based on the soul fact that my two incredible friends from Alabama wanted to pick me up a birthday round there. and by now you all know McThrill rule #347 - http://www.yelp.com/biz/mexican-post-philadelphia-2#hrid:B0Xyx41uJbg_Vc3JEYUSKg.

My expectations dimmed when I saw that it looked to be filled with a crowd that I don't typically relate with. And I had a hard time figuring out what was up with the surfboard table that we were seated by (and since it was on wheels I had the fight back the urge to ride it). I could also dock off some stars due to the calamari being pretty bland, and the bar deciding to randomly crank up and play some annoying DJ music over the speakers in our chill conversation room at an inconsistent point. And although I didn't go myself, I heard some real horror stories about the bathroom.

But overall there were some very good things about the place that needed to be noted and respected. Even though our group grew from a 6 people to 10 after we were seated (What can I say, McThrill knows people :D) our server hardly missed a beat and made sure that we had everything within a reasonable amount of time. And the best thing about here was easily the beer. The Irish Red was smooth and full flavored in all the right places. and My friends were really enjoying the Scotch Ale that had a 9% alcohol content. So for things like that Triumph Brewing Co. and I can be friends.

I like this location a lot more then the 1511 Locust Street location. Very spacious mixed crowd where you can see everyone at the bar and plenty of TV's. The menu is very large and they even offer Califlower (instead of macoroni) N' homemade Fondue cheese as a option for those being carb conscious.

I went with the Oysters that normally are not brought in to the establisment until after 4pm but lucked out as they had these early in the day. The Oysters were quite small and not worth the price but I appreciate this bar offers them as a food option.

French Onion Soup - Pretty banging cheese. I have had better French Onion Soups but enjoyed the soup and at $8 a cup that is the max I am willing to pay.

My overall impression of this Misconduct Tavern is it is a great bar to bring friends from out of town if you want to relax and enjoy yourself spending time catching up with a great variety of food options. That being said...it is slightly overpriced but directly adjacent from The Sterling (an extremely nice apartment complex) and if you have money to rent from The Sterling I do not think you will balk at the price points. I hope this bar is around a long time as I do enjoy it however.

There other location is much more dimly lit and too crowded. Only benefit of the locust location is there are many bars you can pop in and out after visiting the locust Misconduct Tavern. The one on JFK is pretty isolated but a few minutes walk and your be back to the bar scene of the city in no time.

As always people SYOY!!

Welcome to Uzbakistan! 

The review for this place centers around the grilled trout. This fish has the perfect grill lines which I had delivered. The item comes with choice of side which I selected the vegetables. When I tell you I tore this fish apart like a crazed possum I kid you not! Spectacular all the way around from fish eye to fish tail! Now the fish does have a lot of bones in it but that comes with the deal when ordering trout. I would definitely try this place again as I am used to going to my usual spots for take out in this area and the menu is filled with many different options from Uzbakistan.

Overall I'd say this place is pretty good until it comes to slicing my pizza. I don't understand why it's sliced in 4 big slices. I usually have to remind people that the paper says 6 or 8 slices. Tonight I was hoping for six evenly sliced pieces, but I got 4 small and 2 big. One time they gave me the wrong pizza. Fortunately I look at it before I leave. But the flavor, size of pizza and toppings are good.

I love Chipotle-this location just seems to often be out of things. I don't like having a 10 minute wait for veggies and meat to be ready. Isn't that something that they can plan ahead for? Parking is also a rough time. They have a couple designated spots, but they are already taken 90% of the time, so it can be hard to find somewhere in busy Broad Ripple to park, which takes 15 minutes when all I wanted was carry-out. I wish they had a drive-through or delivery! Food is good, though!

I thought this place was very overrated. Service was forgettable. Atmosphere was cute, but not incredible. I thought my burger and fries were way overpriced for the quality. The menu claimed my burger had all sorts of toppings and flavors included, but I didn't taste many of them. I hate it when you have to order sides separate from the burger. I'd like to see more boozy shake combos in the future. It was also dead on a Sunday night when I visited, as a disclaimer, so maybe this place is more exciting when it's hopping?

Go for the margarita flights, but that's about it. This restaurant is located in a strip mall in Greenwood. Pretty standard stuff. Nothing bad, nothing that good. Pretty much the definition of average. I definitely won't be making a special trip to return, but I also won't complain too loudly if a friend wants to meet up there.

There is so much to like at Crispy Bird: the adorable interior, incredible biscuits, Instagram-worthy desserts, and creative cocktail menu. I've had a full meal here twice now and walked away with the same feeling both times: 1. It's way overpriced and 2. The chicken is the most boring thing on the menu. The chicken is bland and uninteresting, but it seems odd to stop in and just order sides and desserts since there are no other entree items. The sides are great, but they are small and the bill really adds up if you try a couple of different ones. I really appreciate that the beer and wine list has been specifically designed to pair well with everything on the menu, but it still seems odd to order a nice bottle of wine to pair with this blah chicken. I heard they made some changes, but my second visit was months after my first visit and I didn't notice or taste anything different. I hope they can make some adjustments since I'd really like this place to be awesome.

My patience has worn thin.  I think I'm done with Toto's for good.  I went in for a simple slice of pizza the other night and I waited for 15 minutes for the counter person to figure out the register. It looked like a cave woman  seeing fire for the first time. I just left.

How the mighty have fallen. Stein and Vine was a rare treat hidden in a nondescript strip mall in Bloomingdale. We have gone many times over the years, but it seems like it's growth and success has taken its toll on the things that made it great. Sadly, our most recent visit may possibly be our last. 

The biggest culprit here is the food. Many items are missing from the menu, which I appreciate could be caused by supply issues, but even the popular Pig wings were nowhere to be found. The chili was served at a temperature just a hair over lukewarm. I decided to get the filet mignon cheese steak, which was served on rock hard, day old bread, with the meat having a slightly off putting organ taste, think liver.

You would think if the menu was limited that you would be able to focus much higher the food quality, but this was not the case.

It's time for S & V to get back to its roots.

Great addition to the food scene in the South Shore area. Second time visiting Tuk Tuk and I'm still impressed. Last order was for the green curry with shrimp, and my wife ordered the shrimp pad thai. The green curry came out with the right mix of spice, and a good complement of protein. Everything tasted fresh and was prepared perfectly. The same held true for the pad thai. A wonderful balance of vegetables and shrimp, plus well prepared with the sauce. Not at all greasy, as can often happen.

We'll be back for more, including the boba teas. Get the thai tea, it's great!

i am completely baffled how this place could get anything more than 1 star...to see how it's rated so highly confuses me. this review is based solely off of the food. portions were small and the food we got was dare I say...worse than take out. The design of the place is nice and looks like a fine dining establishment...they should've spent more time on making the food taste better instead. 

What we ordered:

Firecracker chicken wings - burnt till a crisp and had no flavoring
curry tofu dish- tofu was burnt and hard
Xiao long bao-good, respectful flavor and may have been best out of all
Crab wontons-equivalent of a Chinese takeout place
General triple delight-equivalent or maybe worse than Chinese take out. sauce was average brown sauce with no uniqueness 
Honey walnut shrimp-tasted average and u got 8 shrimp for 20 bucks or so...close to 2.50 a shrimp, outrageous. 
Mongolian beef-again, equivalent of Chinese take out

All in all, we spent around 170 and got food that tasted like i could've got the whole thing for that'd the price at a local joint and would've tasted better...

Very disappointed. Ordered Take away. The garlic chicken was uncooked. The meat pieces were just raw.. Chunks of Zucchini and whole baby corn.. No salt no spices. Looks like the chef dumped the ingredients into the wok, gave it shake and put it in the to go container. The salt and pepper tofu was more of salt than pepper. A few of the tofu chunks were still raw. The only saving grace was the fried rice which was sufficient for two. Thank god we didnt have to go to bed with an empty stomach. After reading all the reviews in Yelp, very sad to have such a bad experience.

I come to this location often because they're open late (even on weekdays) and they have lots of vegetarian options. Yard house in my opinion is a bit overpriced but I do not mind because the food usually is worth the extra money. They are getting 2 stars because today I ordered their Gardein buffalo wings and my wings have NO SAUCE. I should mention it was takeout so I didn't get to look at the food before I went home. I am very disappointed because I have ordered this before and I was expecting the same delicious $11 wings.

Lola, what happened to you? I was there last night with a group of seven for Yelp Eats Out and I was totally disappointed in you.  As we were leaving we discussed our # of stars and our consensus was 3. As I sit down to write this review, I could not bring myself to give you a 3. There is an old saying, "if it's not broken, don't fix it", Lola you are broken, now fix it.

I'm a simple man when it comes to drinks, give me vodka and I'm happy. However to night you were out of many call brands and finally had to go with a flavored one. That was okay, but how can you be out of three name brand vodkas at the same time?

My meal started out with envy, the Polenta Fries looked way better then my Calamari.  The Calamari was served cold, not luke warm, but cold. It was also flavorless. The sauce provided for dipping had a nice kick to it, just wish my Calamari was warm. 

My main entree was the Cajun Chicken breast.  The Chicken breast was sliced into four slices that were seasoned/blackened very well. The meat was also moist and tender. However, the red beans and rice were a sad mess. Those reading this review, look at the picture I posted and ask yourself, would you serve this to a guest? I've had better red beans and rice at a chain chicken joint.

Now for the Blueberry Bread Pudding, it was a total disappointment. 
I have never experienced a drier bread pudding then yours. We were actually thumping the top of it with our spoons and it sounded as if we were knocking on the front door of a friends house. As Miss Stephanie said, "even more blueberry sauce could not help this pudding". 

Lola, what happened? My first review was a 5 and now you are getting a 2 and a place on my No-No List. I can understand one out of my three items being off, but tonight you struck out.

I'll end on a positive note, our server was cute and charming.

Oh, Happy Day! I love it when I get to raise a restaurant up a star, especially when I have had to remove a star in the past. Originally I had given Salt+Smoke 5 Stars and then had to drop them down to 3. They have gotten back into my good graces and I'm raising them up to 4.

Dining with a friend, we started off with two appetizers; Burnt Ends Toasted Ravs and Fried Pickles. I can now say, I've had the Ravs, but I will tell you I will not order them again. They were okay, but not worth repeating. The fried pickles on the other hand are always worth repeating, I can order them every time I come and never get tired of them. 

Being at a BBQ Bourbon place, I had to have a Manhattan. Normally I do my Manhattans up, but today I did it on the rocks. It was a nice blend of 4 Roses Small Batch, Cocchi Vermouth di Torino and Angostura Bitters. I was in heaven after a long day at work. 

I was motivated to come back for the brisket. It still impresses me that you get to select how you want it; lean, fat or burnt ends. I also like that they let you mix it up, I choose lean and burnt ends. The lean is always tender as can be, melts in your mouth and the burnt ends gives me that crusty crunch coating to the tender meat.

For sides you can never go wrong with their garlic and herb fries, or the white cheddar mac-n-cheese. On my last visit, I let our server pick my two sides. I know that is a dangerous thing to do, but I put my trust in her. I allowed her to bring me her two favorite sides and one of them I would have never ordered on my own. She brought me; Creamed Corn which turned out to be a delightful surprise. I would have liked it a little thicker, but the flavor was still a good accompaniment to the brisket. The second side was; Sweet Pepper Potato Salad. Which was rich and creamy with an extra tang from the sweet peppers. 

I'm glad Salt+Smoke made The STL 100 and I will be back for more of that delicious brisket. 

When: April 7, 2016
Why: Dinner & STL 100

I have a new addiction, or perhaps I should say, "love". I am totally hooked on their Steamed Bun with the Togarashi Spiced Catfish with Shishito Pepper and Cherry Tomato Remoulade. As stated in previous review, it is better then any Po' Boy with Catfish that I had down in New Orleans. The crispy catfish is also superior to my current fried catfish fix here in the city. I just don't know how I'm going to break-up with my previous love, because I'm hooked on Kounter Kulture's.

Also, the Baby Romaine Salad - I can eat this every day and not tire of it. The soft cooked egg, white anchovies and their House Miso Dressing makes for a perfect evening meal. All I have to do is uncork a bottle of white wine and I am a happy diner in my own home. 

I wish all carry out restaurant offered the same top notch professional service that they offer here. They are always professional and as attentive as if you were dining in. They truly make you feel welcomed and understand their menu and offerings. 

I promise to try the Rice Bowl or Gyudon on a future visit. 

When: Septembe 22, 2016
Why: In love with their Catfish and Baby Romaine Salad

It's amazing how a year and a pandemic can change things. My most recent visit wasn't what it use to be. I truly was disappointed. 

A friend and I were out running errands on a Wednesday in December and stopped by for lunch. We were seated on the back patio. I stopped to use the bathroom before joining my friend on the patio. When I entered the patio, I was hit in the face with a strong odor. The bathroom I just used smelled better then the patio. I have a sensitive nose. It didn't seem to bother my friend, so I kept it to myself, but it did effect my experience. 

We each had a draft beer to accompany our sandwiches. I had the Cheesy Bacon Burger and my friend had the Buffalo Chicken Sandwich. Both of our sammies came with a side of fries. Both of us enjoy crinkle fries, so we were pleased that is the type Seamus serves and their position is always generous. 

My friend was pleased with her Buffalo Chicken, but my burger was not up to the level I am use to getting at Seamus. The grade of beef seemed to be different and my burger was over cooked. I also could not get beyond the odor, I should have spoken up and moved inside. 

In closing, I'll say the customer service wasn't what it normally is, but it was obvious they were short staffed, so I will not judge them on that. 

I haven't given up on Seamus, I'll still go back and hope for a better outcome.

Sorry, Rooster you are still on my Terrible Two's List.   The food this morning was Denny's and IHOP quality. One item had to be sent back and one item  was so bad we totally had it removed from our bill and our total bill was $70 with tip for two people. 

We arrived at the perfect time, approximately 8:30 AM, just ahead of all the Bears fans, so were seated immediately. When our server arrived, we quickly ordered a Bloody Boleyn, which is typical Bloody Mary with a champagne float on top and a MiMo which is a Mimosa layered with pomegranate juice. Both were majorly good. 
The champagne float, gave the Bloody Mary a little extra kick and flavor. 

The Biscuits and Gravy with Sausage was a vast improvement over our last visit. Enjoying today's biscuits, we realized the last time they must of made a mistake and served us the vegetarian version. This time, there was plenty of sausage floating in the thick creamy gravy. The biscuit was also an improvement, so they can go on my Biscuits and Gravy list.

Our main breakfast dishes were the Scramble with Goat Cheese, Spinach and Red Onion and the Savory Crepe, Sirloin #3. I had the Scramble. It was scrambled eggs served on top of breakfast potatoes with the before mentioned ingredients. Without the Tomato Jam that was served on the side, this dish would have been rather bland.
It was the jam, that added the pizazz. The OD (other diner) had Savory Crepe - Smoked Sirloin #3. It was a crepe filled with mushrooms, caramelized onions, asiago and of course tender sirloin. I got a bite and the horseradish sauce I dipped it had a nice bite and I am not a fan of horseradish. 

We also ordered three side dishes. The side of bacon was plentiful, done well and totally worth the $2. However, the other two sides were misses.
