A side of breakfast potatoes were so COLD, that we had to send them back to the kitchen. As out potatoes were going back to the kitchen, we noticed the side salad was sad and I mean real sad. The mixed greens were so wilted, that if they were at my house I would have thrown them out. Not here, they plate it and send it out to a customer. 
When our server returned with our potatoes, we just had her take the salad back and remove it from our bill. Their breakfast potatoes were a little greasy and were heavily seasoned in chili powder giving them a red tint. 

Our second round of drinks, OD stayed with the MiMo and I tried their regular House Bloody Mary. My second one was not as good as the first. Without the float of champagne, this drink seemed extremely weak. Their glasses for Bloody Mary's is large, so I think they need a little more vodka in MHO. So it is not worthy of my Bloody Mary list. 

Gwendolyn our server needs to make a career change, she is not cut out to be a server in a high volume restaurant. She was not personable, nor attentive. Could it have been that I was wearing orange and it was the Sunday the Rams were playing the Bears. If so, you still need to provide superior service to tourist. The hostess and host seating guest were not much better. 

 I'm still not impressed. Rooster I think you are on my Terrible Two's list permanently.

Like their sign says, "Where the beer and the bison burgers roam".  TS, knows how to serve up a ice cold beer and they truly know how to grill a bison burger. I've had bison at several bars here in the Lou and Trainwreck does it best. They understand the importance of making a bison burger rare to medium rare. Nothing ruins a burger quicker then over cooking it and so many other bars cook them like a regular burger. 
Their long, crispy, slender seasoned fries are the perfect accompaniment to these burgers. 

I wish they offered their chicken wings during lunch, but due to their popularity and the small kitchen they do not offer them during lunch. If you want to experience the wings, be sure to arrive after 2:30PM.  However, for those who have ice tea at lunch time, they offer all three of the major artificial sweeteners in addition to the real thing. 

When you dine at Trainwreck Saloon, be sure to sign up for Telugo. It is a virtual punch card for your smart phone.  After you have paid your bill, they'll scan the QR Bar Code at the bar and after 10 scans, your 11th lunch is free.

I have been converted. Before last night when I attended the International Supper Club, I would have told you I do not like Indian food. I quickly learned  that it wasn't that I didn't like Indian cuisine, I was just eating at the wrong places. 

I will admit the service started out slow, the waiter would take half of our drink order and disappear. Then reappear with the first round and finish taking the rest of the orders.  Perhaps a dozen Yelpers could be intimidating. 

Once he started to take the food orders, a spark appeared in his personality. He truly seemed to enjoy talking about the entrees and the spice levels of each dish. He issued warnings to some diners and those who did not listen to his wisdom, had beads of sweat building up on their upper lip and forehead. 

My entree was Chicken Palak, which was chicken (given) and spinach with Indian seasonings. I was a wimp and choose my spice level as a 2 1/2. For my reentry in to Indian cuisine that was, but next time I'll be able to kick it up a notch.  The entree and rice are served in separate bowls, (almost family style) which made it easy to share samplings of other diners choices. 

Portions were large enough for take home and the other half enjoyed my experience when he got home from work. 

The ambiance is simple and casual which makes for a very relaxed dining experience. 

Thanks Saffron for introducing me to good Indian cuisine.

My bosses 14 year old son knows that I Yelp and the last time he was visiting the office, he informed me I had to try Bonefish Grill. This young foodie told me, Bonefish Grill is his favorite restaurant. With a recommendation from my bosses son, I had to give it a try.

I arrived at peak lunch time and the dining room was full. The hostess informed me I could sit at one of the communal tables in the bar and order from the same menu. I selected one that was empty, so I didn't have to share my space. My server arrived quickly and cheerfully welcomed me. I already had skimmed the drink menu and knew I wanted a Fat Tire. Their selection of beers is small, but they had an impressive martini menu. I'm going to have to return for Happy Hour to enjoy a martini. 

Wanting a quick lunch, I opted for the Fish-n-Chips and they did not disappoint. The fish was done Tempura style and the fries were crispy. I am not a fan of tartar sauce and I surprised myself by trying and actually liking theirs. I also liked that they serve ketchup in little cups, its' one of my little quirks. 

I never got to  snap a photo of their offerings of sweetness, but they have them all and deserve a spot on my Rainbow of Sweetness list. I thought it would be awkward to ask the people next to me enjoying ice tea to snap a photo of the sugar. 

With us in the peak of Lent season, Bonefish Grill is going to be a great place to grab your fish on Friday.

Booze, this review is just about the cocktails we enjoyed while sitting at the bar. It was a day of shopping and bar hopping and we finished our day at Gamlin Whiskey House. We were pleasantly greeted by our bartender. As we enjoyed our cocktails his attitude got cocky, as if he were the Bees Knees.

Speaking of Bees Knees, that was one of the drinks we enjoyed and I must agree with Erin G. this is one of the best cocktails I have ever had. It's  a sweet blend of Knob Creek Rye and Ginger Ale that is served on honey laced ice. OMG, this drink is perfect for winter or summer. I can enjoy it pool side or fire side. 

However, the other drink we ordered was a major disappointment. Big Bacon Daddy, did not live up to its' description in their cocktail menu. The menu boosted bold flavors of bacon infused rye, the sweetness of maple syrup & the complexity of pomegranate shaken and served with a bacon strip garnish. This may sound good, but we found it rather blah. It was so blah, we didn't even finish it. You know a cocktail is bad when a seasoned Yelper doesn't finish their cocktail. 

Some day I'll stop by for another cocktail, but I will not be in a hurry.

Sometimes when you visit a neighborhood restaurant on the frequent, you forget to update your  reviews. I had no idea that I had not updated my opinion of Adam's since my initial review. With Adam's being on Ian Froeb's Top 100 STL Restaurants for 2016, it is time to update my review. 

Numerous times when I have come for lunch, I have selected their signature smoked salami as one of my meats when doing the Pick 2 Plate. It has always been a perfect companion for my other two favorites beef brisket or turkey breast. Today I went with Ian's "Must Order" and enjoyed the Salami Sandwich (6 oz). 

As I order my sandwich, the cashier recommended adding brown mustard as my condiment. Being a fan of brown instead of yellow mustard, I grabbed a couple of packets to try on my sammie. For some he may be right, but not for me. I agree whole heartedly with Ian, give me a dab of Cranberry Cayenne Sauce (my favorite) and that sandwich is a winner.  I am not a fan of white bread, but it was fresh and soft. What I think would make this sandwich go over the top is a hearty beefsteak rye. I think next time I'll get mine to go and rebuild it at home. 

My two sides always seem to be the same, or at least one of them does. I love their pit beans, I think they're most likely one of the best if not the best in the local BBQ joints. Their overly creamy and sweet cole slaw has grown on me and slowly has won me over. I normally prefer an oil & vinegar cole slaw, but this one has it's merits. 

Some would say, the staff is overly friendly. I say it is southern down-home hospitality. They just want everyone to feel welcomed and they treat everyone as if they were from the immediate neighborhood. That is why Adam's is in the Top 100 Restaurants in STL - it has good food and good service. 

When: March 16, 2016
Why: Lunch & STL Top 100

I give it a solid "Meh." 

We got the Desano, which I would assume is their signature offering. It was fresh, but the flavor was just ok. I definitely could not taste any higher quality ingredients than what you would get anywhere else. The most frustrating part was that it pretty much had no cheese on it and was rather expensive for what we got. 

I can't figure out what all the hype is about for this place. ‍

8 adults...10 kids ranging in age from 3 to 14. 6 large pizzas. $155. 
Good time!
Big place. Nice atmosphere.
Pizza is thick and delicious.
Fine dinning...not at all.
Great value for big group...you bet,

Aren't stars hard to use for reviews? Seems like it is always difficult to be fair. We loved our food at OM during lunch today. Panang curry and Tikki Masala chicken. The curry sauces were delectable and complex, lots of chicken, wonderful brown rice, and great service in a pleasant atmosphere. Thankfully they had the large screen TV turned off so we could enjoy each other without that blaring away.

The lunch menu is very interesting with nice variety, and reasonable prices considering the quality of food if our dishes are any indication.

However, at $13 a dish (our lunch was not off the lunch special menu,) with no salad, no sides, just a helping of rice and a bowl of curry, we felt it was just a bit steep. Drinks also are high: $3 for tea? But sitting next to an overpriced steak house and Chinese restaurant in the foothills, perhaps it is to be expected.

Anyway, we will return to try out their lunch specials!
This is as good as it gets for gelato, sorbetto, etc outside of Italy.  Their service can be slow and indifferent for coffee etc..but damn the cold goods rock.

First time dinner this past Monday 7pm, not crowded.

Walked by this place many times, touristy look and name so I passed it by.  But I had seen TV ads with huge salad plates, glanced at the door menu and saw "Strawberry Fields" salad.  Better than Wendy's I'll bet, I'm in!

Ordered at the bar, quick response from the bartender was "we're out of salads".  I was sure I didn't hear that right, so I asked him to repeat it.  He mumbled something about "forgot to order (something)".  Oh well, I'll leave it to you, the reader, to assess the gravity or novelty of that.

Other annoyances:  Thin fried catfish was 2 parts breading, one part fish, don't see the appeal.  Beers served in dumbell-style mugs, don't know why anyone still does that.  Maniac staff member standing two feet from me smashing ice for five minutes for a drink and shaking the bar.

One star for having the hockey game on TV.

Upon my return because of our initial amazing experience here, I noticed a few things had changed, unfortunately, not for the better.
There was one server for the entire restaurant.  Granted, they were not terribly busy, but it might have been one of the reasons why we had minimal interaction with our server.
We ordered an appetizer - Mantoo - it was not even warm.

Thank goodness our entrees were hot.

And, just also wanted to note that the decor has changed some since my last visit - looks much better....the private room no longer has pizza pans on the wall!  :)

I've been to this steakhouse three times now. I think the food here is good and the presentation of food is good. Depending on your seating and who cooks your food will determine how much of a good time you'll have.
My biggest critique is that they could remove at least a couple chairs per table so you can have some more elbow room. The last time I went which was this last Friday evening, I felt cold and smushed together. I had to scoot my chair each time the servers came by with drinks. 
Also, the amount of food you get is determined by how many people sit at the table and what they order, since the cooks only come out with a set portion of rice and noodles and vegetables. I'm not sure if that applies to the chicken.
The servers and cooks are all friendly. It's a great first time experience for anyone though!

I took my parents here for their anniversary dinner and it was a bit of a disappointment. The service was good and we were seated immediately when we arrived to the restaurant. My parents and I ordered some pasta dishes and a salad and were underwhelmed. I though the dishes could have been hotter since they were served at room temperature and the portion sizes were small compared to how much we were paying for them.

I've been going to this Corona location for about 2 years now pretty consistently on a bi-weekly basis. When I got there this past Saturday for lunch there was 1 table clean in the restaurant which I happily took. I know this place is alway busy for lunch but it was about 2pm. Right away I saw that there was 2 waitress and only 1 cook in the kitchen. We waited about 5 minutes before our drink order was taken and we also ordered the queso dip. The waitress was not only serving and taking orders but was also helping prep food. Also the server was taking money and also grabong the chips with her bare hands. This is when I ask myself where is the manager or owner this place is locally ran and there was zero management. Well after our chips and queso where finished finally our server comes back and we ordered some tacos. Guests were getting up cleaning there own tables it was a complete mess. Finally at about 2:40 manager finally arrives. Things really don't get any better the servers were too far in the weeds to have a big impact plus he doesn't get very physical. My food was wrong I had asked for 3 tacos with flour tortillas I got 2 and my wife asked for 2 tacos with corn tortillas and she got 3. We couldn't tell the server fast enough because she threw the food at us so quick and ran off. I did ask for another flour tortilla which she forgot about and brought the check before I was done. I did eventually get the tortilla. The server says after she comes back with the bill once she charged my card "I forgot to ask I you want any dessert". Really! I want to know what has happened to this place? Guess I'll be trying out the Harahan local next.
The food was good, it was fresh and it was delicious. The overall service was marginal at best!

This is currently the best option for a quick burrito in CC/RH, but there isn't much competition (not 1 but 2 qdoba's, really?)

The salad option is nice for when you're craving the spicy beef but need to cut calories somewhere. Serving beer and margarita's is a no-brainer, and the happy hour is a nice touch, even if I don't really see myself coming out anytime soon.

And unfortunately (for me) I agree with Monica, the original seams to be better. Maybe it's a grass is greener scenario, or maybe my fond memories have whitewashed any shortfalls. Overall a solid 3, but it's not going to blow you away. If you've got the time or motivation Bella Vista really isn't all that far...

Formerly known as Tokyo Bistro, Sushi Brothers has evolved through the years both on the menu and the decor.  If you're one of those sushi people who don't really eat sushi but the Amerikanized rolls, this is the review for you because I eat RAW FISH.  In fact I always order the Seafood Martini.  This tasty treat is tuna, salmon, white fish atop "crab salad" served in, what else, a martini glass!  Perfection!  

The reason why I give it an "A-OK" is two fold.  The first is because they have two GIANT screen TVs in a small dining room.  Why do restaurant's feel the need to have TVs on?!  People are suppose to be dining and interacting with people.  Not watching mindless garbage.  The second reason is because the wait staff rushes you even if they aren't busy.  Don't understand why this happens.  

Alas, takeout is really quick.  I live in the neighborhood and often take advantage of this.  I can eat my sushi, watch what I want to watch and take my sweet a** time doing it.

Wayyyyyy overrated.  I drove pretty far out of the way to try this place, and it let me down.

The atmosphere is fine enough.  It's just what you'd imagine when you think of a fairly-fancy Indian place.  The food was a let down, though.  I had the mixed vegetable curry.  (It was the non-creamy style, which I like.)  I wish I had something enlightening to say, but I don't -- I just didn't think it was all that great.  When I tasted my friend's meal, I knew my meal wasn't a lemon.  In fact, the sample I had (sadly, I can't remember the name of the dish) was worse than my meal.

I'd go to GtI if I lived nearby, but it's not worth traveling for.

I wasn't very impressed. This place felt like a Cracker Barrel that started selling Cuban food.

Vegetarian Note: They don't have any vegetarian entrees, but I kind of expected that--it seems like very few Cuban places do.

Ahh, Restaurant Week, the double-edged sword. I talk myself out of going to "expensive" restaurants all the time for fear of having a disappointing experience. Sometimes those fears are unfounded, all too often they are not. 

The evening started out with so much promise. From the valet out front to the honest to god Maitre D' just inside, the place just screams "old-school" class. Frank Sinatra would have felt at home seated in a high-backed leather chair at a white linen covered table in one of their cozy oak-paneled private rooms. 

The service was top notch. Our waiter, Pee Wee, who'd been at working at the establishment "off and on" since 1978, was absolutely perfect. He read my wife and I completely, provided helpful suggestions, and came by only and always when needed. We weren't looked down upon or ignored because we were ordering off the "special" menu. 

When it comes to the food I have just two words for you: Meat. Glue. 

I am not a butcher, a chemist, or an adhesives expert, but I've worked in enough steakhouses and have seen my fair share of meat glue steaks. Go ahead and open a new browser tab and Google that if you have to/dare. It's a dirty little secret of the meat industry akin to the pink slime found in ground beef. Maybe Jimmy Kelly's chef doesn't know that he's being sold frankenfilet, or he does and doesn't care; I'm not sure which bothers me more. I halfway considered asking for steak sauce.

It didn't end there. Our baked potatoes were served still in tinfoil, and the toppings (for which we were charged an additional fee...seriously?) came in paper ramekins, a la McDonald's ketchup. The salads were bagged iceberg and the house Gorgonzola dressing was reminiscent of Kraft, or maybe, if I'm being generous, Wishbone. The corn cakes all the other reviewers rave about? Burnt. A truly disappointing meal. 

The only thing we enjoyed beyond the atmosphere, the service, and the drinks were the mushrooms and the two cobblers: blackberry and apple walnut. You're safe ordering those I'm sure --the rest? Well, you're on your own. 

In short, if you go, get something bone-in (harder to fake with meat glue), skip the potato, and soak up the classy atmosphere, the good service, and plenty of tasty tasty liquor. It will make the bill easier to stomach, especially if you're paying full price.

Eh...I just don't get it! 
I've oficially now had Pat's, Geno's and Jim's all once now...yes..I know there are more..BUT
Pat's=Geno's and Geno's = Pat's
Same greasy, too soft bun with loads of cheese...
I was slightly day drinking at the Italian market festival and decided I'll give Pat's a go since I haven't had it yet (the line was much shorter than Geno's), my neighbor's daughter wanted fries, and I needed to walk past to get to the auto shop.

Super quick service I ordered, and my sandwich was already waiting for me while I paid!
I get the novelty of just meat cheese and onions and "ordering properly" but some customization would be nice. However I did order my sandwich "togo" but it wasn't wrapped or in a bag...once I saw some people with bags I decided to go back..get a bag and some extra papers and wrap up my own sandwich. 

And whats with the separate windows for the sandwich, fries and a drink? Are these two separate lines? Do you have to pay separately? So confused..

Honestly...I think I can make a better cheesesteak with some steak-ums, provolone and a crusty roll.

What to say???  Four of us had a very good meal and a very good night celebrating my wife. Service was good except for the random disappearing acts (which they accommodated for by giving drinks on the house ) 
The full dinner took three hours. Again, we were celebrating so I appreciate not being rushed but... 
cocktails were good, steaks were good, dessert was good too! They allow substitution fir sides on your main courses which was great.
The other clientele seemed like Ladue regulars  and it stayed busy.they even had a musician in the bar area after dinner hours.
All in all a great night.

I feel like I may not be the right person for an opinion on BBQ. Every time I go to a new joint, especially one of the acclaimed, I feel a bit disappointed. As with the others, nothing was wrong with the food or anything else at Beast Craft. I just feel like I had it too primed to be fantastic and it was not. 
I had the burnt ends with smoky bacon Mac and cheese and kielbasa sausage as my sides. I also tasted the candies bacon. Fortunately/unfortunately, the best part was the Mac and cheese (Best m/c I have had at a BBQ joint!)
It's good enough to go again but way out of my way as I live in St. Louis city.

We went to Central Table Friday evening and decided to try the sushi.  After living in San Diego for almost ten years and having some of the best and freshest sushi I never have great expectations for St. Louis sushi.  My wife had the albacore and I had half a dozen oysters.  We also ordered the Forest Park roll and the Spicy scallop roll.  
The oysters were great.  Definitely go with the west coast oysters.  They are bigger, more plump, and tastier.  My wife's albacore was melt in your mouth good.  The rolls were just as tasty.  The Forest Park roll was absolutely wonderful.  
The service was good and they serve Six Row beer.  I'm trying to expand my beer choices so I tried the whale ale which was very good.  
Everything was good except the bill.  It was pricy for how much food you get.  Overall, it was a good meal and we would probably go back for that Forest Park roll.

Such a cool spot to chill at. Iv had about half of the drinks on the menus and my favorite by far is the grapefruit gimlet! Now this is my second time here and we didn't eat the first time so this time I got the goat cheese balls. Super sense. Not bad but may have been better if it wasn't colder than room temp when it got to my table.

Great deal! Way larger variety than koizi. Huge selection for sushi. Not the best but the price itself makes it yummy. The green tea ice cream is the best way to end your meal. The soup and says I suggest you just skip.
Won't be back.., not worth the price they charge. I'd rather eat and pay this price for a normal buffet!

This would have been at least 4 stars but it was literally 1 hour and 10 minutes from the time we ordered until we received our dinner. I would have thought maybe they're slammed in the kitchen, but it really wasn't that busy, and there was a chef looking person standing around socializing with the other employees, so I imagine the kitchen wasn't busy.  I don't expect the food to be immediately, that's an unreasonable amount of time.  The busser was great, our waiter was ok but offered no apology for how long things were taking. The food was good but not as good as normal. It was a very disappointing night.  I made the reservation through open table which was canceled by the restaurant so I won't get the points for that...not really a big deal but just the principle...we probably won't be back for a while.  I would have just sent them an e-mail about this instead of posting here, but I could not locate an e-mail on their website, so here it is.

2 Stars too many for this location. Weve tried supporting them for years since we live around the corner but nothing seems to change, or better yet improve. The food is mediocre and never consistent. Wings are either soggy or under-cooked and burgers are way too pricey for the quality. So if the food isnt worth the money then why bother?

So lets examine the staff. Again, no changes here either (in years) as the attitude of not caring translates throughout the experience. Occasionally you will get a server who is friendly but Rare. Weve even tried ordering for carry out thinking at least we can just eat the food but still have to deal with someone taking an order who has no clue about the menu (not sure how thats possible) and then pickup from the bar. Bar tenders usually dont care to help once they realize your not ordering drinks. 

Salad mix is awful and dry with only brown iceburg centers. 

Overall a poor experience and should only be seen as a bar! Thats a place for drinking and adults but wouldn't recommend for kids.

I like this place...good food, nice employees, but slow service. I will definitely continue coming because the food is good, the place is clean, and location is centrally located. 
The pancakes are a solid choice but only order a half stack unless you are sharing. The egg dishes are my favorite-no surprise, the restaurant is WILD EGGS. The drinks... alcoholic and non alcoholic are fresh and sweet. 
This place is A-OK.

Maybe I missed something or this place just isn't my cup of tea. And from everyone else's reviews you can tell they are appealing to many. I've gone twice for lunch and unless it's someone else's choice I probably won't be returning.
The location is wonderful. The food and service is just okay for me. 
I have had the hash browns, applewood bacon, and silver dollar blueberry pancake stack.

When the best thing at a family steakhouse is the baked potato, I can't find much good to say. My $21 rib eye was about 1/4 inch thick & at that size, medium rare would be impossible. Thus the medium well steak I was served. I chose not to complain, because I hate to wait for a replacement while my table mates finish their meals. My broccoli was perfectly cooked but cold. The potato was very good & it was hot.

Service was mediocre. I absolutely hate being served tea or coffee with no sugar or sweetener on the table & then have to track down the server. If the restaurant is so afraid of people stealing that stuff, then the sweetener container MUST be brought with the drinks. 

I am disappointed. It has been several years since my last trip to Outback & I remember that meal was just ok. Today we thought we'd give it another chance. I won't be back.

The restaurant is on a historic wooden sailboat, and the interior is decorated in a very classic way. I recommend trying to get a table with a window or sit on deck to enjoy the views and watch the boats on the Delaware. Unfortunately, the weather was rainy so we sat inside. Service was decent. The waiter was helpful in answering questions about the menu but became MIA later in the night as we were finishing up dinner. The food was OK and a bit disappointing for the price (Over $100/person all in). I got the lobster bisque which received great reviews on Yelp. It was OK and seemed to have too much cream which took away from the lobster taste. For a main course I had the swordfish on a recommendation from the waiter and positive Yelp reviews. Once again it was mediocre and I really didn't like the green sauce it came with. My girlfriend had the steak tartare and crab cake. She said the beef tartare tasted funny and she ended up with food poisoning from it. I would recommend staying far away from this appetizer!The crab cake was mostly filler and mediocre. I recommend passing on this restaurant except for drinks on the top deck during nice weather.

I am woo'd. Honestly, I don't know why I waited so long. I picked a weekend, drove into the city, cautiously navigated the side roads and found a right out front parking spot.

They had maybe two customers inside so my order came quick. The owner was there, in a really good mood, friendly as all heck.

I wanted to stick to the basics so I did the 3 piece with biscuit & honey butter. I had high expectations. I've had amazing fried chicken before and I was just fingers crossed on my first bite.

Looks alone, gorgeous fried chicken. The color, the specks of seasoning, the crisp and crunch of the skin, the juicy meat. Honestly, you taste the love put in this dang chicken. 

Don't even get me started on how much I loved the honey butter on that biscuit.. because I would have gone back and asked for a tub of it. 

Overall, I'm going back and getting more and I'm already sure I'll be woo'd all over again.

Excellent job Love & Honey Fried Chicken.

So this review has a disclaimer. The food was innovative, diverse, and delicious. The Workshop Eatery lost two stars because I had perhaps the rudest, arrogant server that I have had in the last 15 years. Right away when she came to our table I could see by her expression that wasn't enthused to serve us. We had to ask for a drink menu. I ordered a smoked grapefruit jalapeño margarita and my friend ordered sangria. Both were good. Then we asked the server  that us three would like to split some meals to try a bit of each and what would she recommend. She murmured that some of the specials were good and when I asked her to describe them, she said "They are written on the board." Then, when my friend asked how big the portions were because we were wondering how many to split,  she said, "For some they feed one." I have no idea if she was referring to our weight, or whether she didn't want to go on and describe them, but this was incredibly rude. And your job is to sell us the food, and deliver it in a pleasant manner. She did neither of these things.   So I will describe what we ordered on the menu - ARANCINI - Creamy risotto balls, lightly breaded, crispy. These were tasty. They switch daily and I have no idea what was in these because our server didn't tell us. They were executed properly. Crispy on the outside, creamy on the inside, full of flavour.  We also ordered the crispy brussel sprouts, token steak dish, some special that now I can't remember, and two desserts. The brussel sprouts were the best that I have tasted in the city. Crispy, full of flavour and accompanied by a Sriracha sour cream. Lovely, beautiful dish. Steak was properly cooked and had more of those brussel sprouts and chirozo tater tots. Really great meal that was well balanced. However, part of our food experience was taken away from our server, we had to ask for water, we had to ask for a dessert menu, and she did not really ask us how our food was. In fact, we had to ask a server from another table to fill our glasses and ask for our bill. Will I be back? Unsure.  I am sure that if I get this server again she will spit in my food because I gave her a 1% tip. I have never ever done that and I hope that I never will do that again. So go there, but if you see a female server with a really short brown haired boyish cut, perhaps asked for a different table.

This is the first time in a long time that we did not have a good experience.  The service was poor and didn't get what I ordered. We were disappointed,  because usually Gold Ranch is one of our go to places. They followed the COVID-19 guidelines. The servers wore masks and gloves. The patrons are required to wear masks to enter the establishment.

I would say 3 1/2 stars. My friends and I wanted Mexican but I didn't want to go to Las Margaritas and tried to find something not too far away but new to try. We went around 7 on a Sunday night and the main dining room seemed to be closed for the night so we sat at a high top table in the bar area. That was not a big deal however service was incredibly slow & when our waiter took our drink order he completely skipped my friends. Please keep in mind there were only 4 of us. The bar area wasn't packed but it seemed to take forever to get our meals and he completely disappeared after he dropped off the check. We seriously waited over 10 minutes for him to come back to the table. 

Once we were sat someone came out and put chips and salsa on the table. I loved this plus we all were starving! We ordered queso to go with our chips and it came out in a metal dish that they toasted in the oven. I have never seen this before and it was delicious and I would definitely order that again. I loved that they had a monthly specials menu,along with the regular menu. I decided I wanted something on the healthier side after all those chips and queso, so I ordered the grilled shrimp tacos. They were very good, I thought the shrimp were on the smaller side but none the less I really enjoyed my meal. My hubby ordered the shark meat quesadilla, he was happy with it but there was no way I was trying it. My meal came with the choice of one side and I chose the Mexican rice, i really did not like and would recommend staying away from it. It was made with brown rice and it didn't seem like it was cooked all the way. 

I love that they offer flights of tequila and think this would be a great place to come and catch up with an friend and do a flight or two... obviously you will need a uber.

I got to spend a rare Sunday morning with my brother for brunch. We decided to go somewhere different and this was the perfect option this morning. Parking wasn't terrible but there is no parking lot, only street parking. They do have outside tables but the wind was terrible so we had to wait about 15 minutes for a table but it seemed to go by quickly. They only have tables no booths. 

We were greeted right away and a nice big mug of fresh hot coffee while we looked at the menu. They serve both breakfast and lunch options ALL day long. So you don't have to rush to get breakfast. I love that idea! I also love that they are trying for minimal waste and conservation. I wish more places cared about the environment! 

There were so many delicious choices but I decided  to order from their specials menu & got the Spicy Bacon Avocado Benedict. It was delicious! They didn't overkill it with the hollandaise sauce and it comes with a side, you can choose from fresh fruit, rosemary potatoes or pepper and onion potatoes. I went with the pepper and onion potatoes, I'm glad I did. They had huge pieces of them with the potatoes. They weren't drenched in oil either. Please keep in mind that there see no subsections on the specials menu, it comes as is.   

My brother ordered from the regular menu, the "kitchen sink" it had a little bit of everything in it and he was pleased with his meal.   

I would highly recommend this place and I will definitely be back to try something else!

We waited a good 40 minutes before being seated and it definitely wasn't worth the wait. We got our food relatively quick and it was just ok. The front part of the restaurant is just a bar area and in the back is the dining room. When we were seated there were at least 5 open tables so it was unclear why it took so long to get seated. We saw our waitress twice, for orders and when the food was ready. I've been there twice now and wasn't blown away either time.

Well, this place is a Louisiana institution. Chef Paul Prudhomme was responsible (and also to blame) for the cajun blackened craze that swept the country in the 80's and 90's. I was surprised they are still so packed...we couldn't get any reservations the entire Memorial Day weekend. It was only by coming back on Memorial Day itself that we were able to score one. It was actually very nice inside, with a casual feel. Our server was nice enough I suppose, but not particularly warm and friendly. We were seated in the back, with a clear view of the kitchen. Now I know it would be too much to expect to see Chef Prudhomme still tooling away back there, but I couldn't help but be a little disappointed that the Executive Chef was off that night as well.

The food was a bit of a letdown...the blackened drum (I guess they don't use redfish anymore) was tasty but kind of one-note, especially for such a huge slab of fish. It was a bit overdone, and was swimming in so much butter (and I am usually a big fan of the stuff) without any acid to cut through the fat that I felt like I needed an angioplasty after dinner. The jambalaya was another huge portion of pretty much the same taste...slightly overdone chicken, sausage, and ham. For the prices, I guess I expected a little more refinement...in essence, you are paying fine dining prices for casual/rustic food.  

The kicker was the huge cockroach lying dead on its back next to our table...no one ever bothered to get rid of it throughout our meal...not exactly an appetite enhancer. Well, I suppose we had to visit this place and now we have.

Fado is a great place to start the night when you are with a small group.  It is an Irish Pub the way an Irish pub should be done.  Great atmosphere, friendly bartenders and servers, and plenty of alcoves (you use this word?) to tuck your small group into for some privacy.  A number of Irish beers on tap and a good selection of Irish whiskey.  

I have ordered food in the past and it was less impressive than the bar itself.  The food was overpriced and not too flavorful.  Lately, my routine when I am in this area is to get dinner elsewhere and stop here for the first round.

Very good food, the place was empty when we visited.  Service was quick enough, and they provided some recommendations.

I started with the Laotian onion soup.  Very tasty, with a lot of vegetables, I would order this again.  I also tasted the tulip dumpling, which wasn't exactly what I expected, but the flavor and sauce that went with it were both good.

For my meal I had the Hor Mok Laos with salmon.  This is a fish stew, and was very flavorful without smelling too heavily of fish.  While the broth/sauce was thin, adding the rice made it almost a solid.  Very tasty, I'd order this again.

All B-Dubs are the same; cold beer, good wings and tons of TV's. If you are looking for a spot to watch some sporting events, this is the place. There are TV's everywhere, and I mean everywhere. I've counted more than 40 before. Wings are tasty and beer is cold!

Yet again, another great restaurant in Germantown! Went here for lunch today and was seated immediately.Staff was very polite and it had a great atmosphere. Reminded me of a really old library. 

One thing that was strange, is that there were baby pictures everywhere. Small one, huge one and everything in between. Not sure the reasoning behind this, but if babies scare you, don't go here. 

I ordered  that Black Bean and Corn Filled Ravioli. It was topped with a roasted red pepper sauce and Parmesan cheese. The portion size was large for lunch, but I continued to eat until nothing was left on the plate. I guess I must have really hated it. My girlfriend ordered the chicken and vegetable soup that was pretty good.

Since their lunch was that good, I really want to go back and try their dinner. I will keep you posted when I make it back.

Stopped by for brunch. Got the mushroom crepe and a cheesesteak. Cheesesteak is not your typical philly cheesesteak but instead a fancy version with brie and larger chunks of meat. All around average food, service, decor.

Came here a few weeks after they just opened. The staff are friendly, but the food took a while to come out - maybe because the place was packed with a ton of people. The Pork Osso Buco (on the bone) is delicious but their burger just seemed like an average burger. I would come back again for the pork bone.

The farther you get from the City, the harder it is to find a good chinese takeout. I've tried two of the stereotypical American-Chinese dishes for lunch: Sesame Chicken, and the Garlic Chicken. On the plus side, I thoroughly enjoy their Wonton Soup that comes with a lunch order. Most takeout places have a relatively clear bland broth, but the soup broth here has substance. On the down side, the wontons are mostly skin with a pea-size amount of meat.

The sesame chicken here is made with higher quality ingredients than you would expect. It seems to be made with breast meat, while most take outs use cheaper thigh meat. In a sense that's a positive, but the distinct taste of sesame chicken is all about the dark thigh meat. The pieces of chicken are large and crispy, while I am more accustomed to smaller bite size pieces.

The garlic chicken is the bigger disappointment. The sauce is not at all spicy, and it pretty much comes with just broccoli with a sprinkle of other vegetables for some variety.

Came for some brunch and ice cream afterwards. Couldn't resist ordering a burger since it is voted "best burger." Sticking with the breakfast theme, I got the Wake Up Burger with an egg. Very good burger, but I wouldn't call it the best. Enjoyed the ice cream as well. Only downside is service a bit lackluster, slow and made two errors with our order. Also, as other reviewers have said, ithe setup is a bit weird that you can look at all the ice cream displayed inside but you have to order it outside.

First off, love the area.  Nice outdoor seating. Other good options around as well. We ate inside because it was a bit warm. 

It was Saturday - I was hoping for the lunch menu but was not advised by the website that only the brunch menu would be available. Needless to say, I had my heart set on some dishes on the lunch menu so was I a tad bit disappointed from the get-go.

So, the brunch menu explicated one beer on draft for $5 (Cigar City Guayabera) which I ordered and was informed by my server that it was a typo. It's not a typo, they were clearly just out of it. I was informed that the special option was Pacifico, no thank you.  So I ordered another beer from the (oral) list that the server provided. There was no written beer menu. So I was a bit surprised to find on my bill that the three beers cost me nearly $50, $16 dollars each! The food was excellent but the menu doesn't really explain what you're getting.   

Would I go back? Sure, but for dinner next time!

Wing Wah is our Chinese take out "du jour." Are there better Chinese restaurants in the Philadelphia area? Sure, but around Wayne and Berwyn, I know of none better than Wing Wah. 

The food is always fresh, hot, and flavorful. It offers the standard Americanized version of Chinese cuisine, all prepared well. While I wish it offered more authentic fare as I can find in Chinatown area of Philly, it suffices for those those nights when no one wants to cook or go out for dinner. 

And the proprietoress is always welcoming and friendly.

When you don't want to drive into the city for great Vietnamese food, this place will suffice. The food just doesn't measure up to those in Philly. 

As it's at just beyond the Main Line, don't expect the bargain prices you'll see downtown. The limeade is great , however!

This is a neat spot that has a nice menu. I had wing (5) and magna fries(cheese fries). A bit pricey for what you get in my opinion. The wife had a burger that was OK as were my wings. The food is nothing special to be honest, the atmosphere is kinda cool but dated. Service was a little slow but there's plenty to look at if you're into racing etc. there are some games(video, claw machine etc.) for you to play with while you're here. 
They have some great events, bike night and such which are fun to attend.
Overall, I'm glad I finally visited after driving by a thousand times but it probably won't be a regular spot.

Nice place, nice atmosphere and I've enjoyed both visits. I will definitely be back for the brisket as it was AH-mazing both times, the ribs not so much. The brisket was extremely juicy and tender, portion was good and flavor was terrific, the sausage is juicy but not in that fatty greasy way some places have. I like my sausage a bit on the cooked side and rely on the sauce because I hate the fat dripping from it. The pulled pork is moist and tender and has a good flavor with a touch of sweet. My oldest daughter ordered the brisket mac-N-cheese on our fist visit and they NAILED it! They have four sauces, regular and spicy that are really good and we all know how important the sauce is when it comes to a good BBQ place. NOW, the Carolina sauce I can't speak on cause I can't even..... 
STRAWBERRY JALAPEÑO BBQ sauce is a thang!!! I was hooked on strawberry jalapeño jam a few year ago and was so excited to try a BBQ sauce like that and I was NOT disappointed. This alone is a reason to come, try or return. Just wow! 
The ribs, tough, good flavor but so tough I couldn't yank the meat off the bone with my teeth. I usually only pay to have ribs after I've had brisket at a place because it typically tells the tell if the ribs are going to be worth the money. 
Service has been good both times but I could have had two beers with my Q if the server came by a little sooner, haha! 
The prices are pretty standard given the location and who comes to the beach expecting a cheap dinner. 

I am pretty excited to find a place with good sauce since my last favorite BBQ place changed their recipe. 

Four stars not five because of the tough ribs and the sticky sauce bottles. 

We will be back soon!
OK indian, the bangain barthan wasn't the best i've had. Not sure if it was fresh eggplant or what it was. Breads were ok. The paneer with chili sauce was also a little overly seasoned. Ok i guess.

Great location and institution in SB, though the clam chowder was a bit of a letdown. Really thick...way too much flour and not fully cooked through. No real clam taste unfortunately.

Had also the swordfish which was a great looking piece of fish and perfectly cooked. Great tasting...simple and fresh.

Not a big fan to tell you the truth - food is mediocre bar food, beer choices are mediocre, and the clientele is a mix of crusty older locals and college students. Nothing really special nor any real character to speak of. Heavy duty cigarette smokers. Really just a rung up the ladder from dive bar.

As Kim said, perhaps the only plus is that they have a parking lot.

Pretty awesome beer selection. Waitstaff was extremely helpful in trying to help you pick a beer.  Will say that two that I tried to order were out of stock. :(  But like I said the waitress was very helpful in recommending something similar. Not really the best place for a vegetarian, but they do have a couple of appetizers that are pretty good if you just want to order a few of those. I had the cheese plate, the pretzel and the potato pancakes.  All were very good.

I stopped in today for a Blackened Chicken Sandwich only to find that...they sort of don't have it anymore. They have revamped their entire menu. Now it's all "Build Your Own Burger" for $3.89 and pay 3 more bucks to make it a combo! 

I had to go through each confusing little category to try and replicate my fave sandwich there. 

The cashier was helpful but this is not my idea of fun. Fortunately, I came armed with a coupon. Otherwise, there was no way I was paying 7 bucks for a fast food combo. 

This could have been a glorious opportunity for BYB to bring back their beloved waffle fries. No such luck.

In spite of the fact that it was bustling, my food came right out. It was pretty good and almost like the blackened chicken sandwich of my memories but not quite. 

They've started getting a little too big for their britches here! They've lost their identity and are now just serving over-priced fast food.

Don't. Just don't. Please don't. Come. Here. Even if it was the apocalypse and zombies outside threatening your life. Don't. 

First,  the parking lot is a complete and total damn zoo! Between no parking and having to walk across the lot to the store, a number of panhandlers begging you for all your hard earned money and cars blocking entrances, it's a mess. 

The store is cramped and thrown together. Produce section is filled with rotten fruits and vegetables. Don't even think you'll get a good piece of meat here because it's all picked over. Saw open packages as if someone took a bite. Sticky floors and awful customer service. Ugh..

I am just not there with all the other reviews. I have been here once for dinner and then did takeout. And it makes me sad because this is not how I remember other Sahm's and this location is a death trap, so it has to be good to survive. I had the salmon with broccoli and buffalo cauliflower for sides. The broccoli was like it was just nuked for 3 minutes. But ok, it's broccoli. The buffalo cauliflower was so salty it was inedible. Hubby liked his salad. Takeout on Friday, I had the pork chop with mushrooms. First, the pork chop was dry and 2) there were only about 5 mushrooms (exaggeration) and I thought there might be a sauce, but no. My baked potato suffered in the drive home. My side was chili which I just ate and it was passable. Nothing here is remarkable but it's so close I'd love to see it succeed.

I had the Batali but asked that for it on wheat. They had a semolina wheat bread. The sandwich was delicious. Tried the beef tortilla soup, was good but not outstanding. Need to try more sandwiches. This place is a keeper. Bought some Tasso ham to take home. Wanted to try some "rubbed" wings I saw in the case. Will be back now that I notice there is plenty of parking across the street.

Made a reservation through Open Table because my mother in law wanted to come here her 71st Birthday. I let them know in the reservation that it was her Birthday and we wanted to sit outside. When I got there I realized that outside is first come first serve which was fine because it was windy and looked like it was going to rain. I arrived earlier at 1:40 my reservations were for 2. But I checked in and was immediately taken to a table, I asked to wait for my in laws but she was like iI will seat you and then you can come back up here and wait for them. So she brought me to a table not really a great spot especially for a Birthday reservation. I flagged down my husband as he was parking the car and had dropped me off upfront in case it rained. He hated the table but went back upfront and waited for my mom and dad. The waitress brought everything over I told her I was still waiting on the rest of my party she explained the specials and tried to get me to order a drink but I wanted to wait. My In laws are conservative so they wouldn't let my husband ask for another table. The waitress was rushing us and did not know the menu as she was asked about a sauce and when we googled it after she left because her description was vague and didn't make sense I realized she tried to BS her way very badly she could of just said I will go and ask. She was not pleasant and seemed annoyed which when your there to celebrate a Birthday that's not the mood you want!! The food I thought was nothing special could have went to Chilis and got the same food. But my mother in law is obsessed with Key Lime Pie so I know that's why she chose this place because she loves theirs so much. No one acknowledge her Birthday, not even the waitress even though she had a Happy Birthday balloon so it was obvious. Would only go back to drink outside because the water views are amazing but I doubt I will be back unless my mother in law wants their Key Lime Pie again and invites us to go and I love her so I won't complain and that would be the only reason! Shari your email address is not correct!

Was here over the holiday break.  Food was ok.  Service was sloooow and they were packed.  Not a bad bar but my friends said they were begging for drinks and they were sitting at it.

They gave us a beeper to alert us when our table was ready and it didn't go off so they asked us to close out at the bar and wait at the front until they could get a table.  They were fast about that part but what's up with the buzzer not working?  Maybe time to invest in texting like other up and coming restaurants.

I'd go back, but hesitantly, until they fix their issues.  Maybe it was just the holidays.  If I go back maybe I'll update this review.

Lots of different food choices, the very left of the restaurant had your typical Americanized Chinese food and the very right had sushi! Don't get too excited though, the sushi was okay. Here's a short pros and cons list. 

Pros:
- Decor, they did a really good job decorating the restaurant
- Food choices, there are tons and tons of options for a pretty good price
- $8.29 for adults for lunch! that's pretty cheap for that many options

Cons:
- Food quality was a little above normal Asian buffets

I usually try to stay away from buffets, but this one was okay. Usually they are overpriced and the food quality is absolutely terrible. If someone invited and insisted I go again, I wouldn't fight them.
I really enjoyed the fish taco and chicken enchilada. We tried the salsa trio which was pretty good, too. The margarita was average.

Full disclosure: I used to make my living as a food writer/critic for a city magazine (different city).

Because of this, my friends hate to go out to eat with me (funny, when the tab was paid for by my company, they loved it); I am constantly underwhelmed. 

So its of no surprise that my friends were frustrated with me on a random Saturday night, looking for a "decent" restaurant on the Hill. We actually attempted to eat at Cunetto's, but after being told there was a 2 hour wait (at 8:00pm!), we promptly left (note: I still have yet to eat at Cunetto's, so I know nothing of the food, but the smell in the restaurant was terrible.). 

We drove around the neighborhood, looking for anything that looked promising, and that's when we drove by Anthonino's.

"Stop." 
"Why?"
"Here, we're eating here."
"It looks like a mom and pop dive bar."
"Its perfect." 

Anthonino's looks like a place that serves good food. There's nothing fancy about the place--after all, cooks aren't interior designers--its just a giant room where people eat and drink. I'll take good food over ambiance any day.

Now, I must admit, I had my doubts when they dropped the menus on the table and I saw "Greek and Italian Food." Its normally never a good sign when a restaurant attempts two different cultures (Ever eaten sushi at a Chinese restaurant? I rest my case). But Anthonino's did a very decent job. 

Their calamari was the best I've had in St. Louis (on a follow up visit, it didn't taste as fresh, but was still better than the other sad examples of calamari I've had in this town), and the pasta dish I had, while not necessarily "authentic," was delicious. Also, Anthonino's is the first place where I've actually enjoyed the toasted ravioli (every other time I've had St. Louis' famed toasted ravioli, it tasted like standard fried bar food). It was homemade! (I later learned, from a place down the street. Mama Something...)

The only problem I had was with the service. Our waitress literally came to our table a total of four times (greeting, drink order, food order and check--she didn't actually bring us anything). She didn't ask how anything was, nor did she bus our table as plates continued to pile up. My friends say its because I have a "look," about me that makes people in the service industry think "oh crap, not 'this guy,'" but I also have crappy friends, so, whatever. 

The other thing, as noted in a prior review, is that there are a TON of kids here. I'm the type of person that likes to drink away stress, so a few Peronis, and I didn't even notice them; I suggest you do the same. 

Also, on the aforementioned second visit, a busy Friday night, I found the service to be excellent. But then again, maybe it was due to my successful attempt at appearing "lookless."

West End Grill is a new favorite of mine, albeit a confusing one. I've been here a few times in the last two weeks, and every time I'm left with the same confused feeling. Luckily, their food is, overall, very good, and ridiculously cheap. The lady and I went there this past Friday, and for appetizer, salad, entrees, two cocktails and a bottle of wine, it was only $80--there are very few places in this city that you can get food that decent for that little. 

Anyway, to the confusion. 

The place overall has a very warm vibe. Lots of blacks and dark woods, balloon-like Riedel glasses, the word "Culture" in their tag line, and... paper napkins? Seriously, I understand what you're going for--you want to be classy, but not snooty; special, but approachable--that's great, and kudos to you for basically pulling it off, but it's off-putting to me to see not only a paper napkin on my table, but a stark white paper napkin amongst all that dark "Culture." It made me want to order a No. 6, super-sized. 

The service is weird because everyone is very friendly and charismatic, leaving you feeling like you've had the best service in the world. But then you notice that your water glass hasn't been filled in 30 minutes. And the last time, you had to ask, too. And you had to ask twice for a cocktail. And there's only four tables in the entire restaurant, so busyness isn't the reason. Overall, the service just isn't there. It's like they hired great people, but sub-par servers/bartenders. The only problem is, I don't know which I'd rather have if I had to choose: good person/bad server, or bad person/good server. The answer seems obvious, until you realize that you're not picking out a friend, you're wanting a good time, and you're willing to pay for it. 

I've literally tried over twelve dishes in the last two weeks (don't ask, but I told you it's one of my new faves) and there seems to be a weird pattern at West End Grill--the entrees are solid, but the sides are uninspired/unimpressive. The only exception was the bad ass brussels sprouts that accompanied the Salmon. It's not that they were bad, it's just that I expected more skill and thought in their pairings--especially after seeing exactly what they could do with their entrees. And speaking of which, West End Grill knows how to do fish. Their Salmon is awesome, and their Trout is solid. Also, I agree with everyone else on here that said the PPB&J is baller, because it is. Congratulations, you're all geniuses. 

Overall, West End is a really good restaurant that has ridiculously low prices. There are some problems with it, but nothing that can't be overlooked by one more bottle of wine. Excuse me, I said one more bottle of wine. 

God damn it.

I'm not sure if I should be doing this, but here goes. 

I can't speak to Won Ton King's standard menu, but what I can attest to is WTK's weekend "brunch." There's only three places (to my knowledge) that serve dim sum in St. Louis (no, that shitty excuse for a restaurant, Fu Manchu, doesn't count), and Won Ton King is by far the best. How can I tell? The fact that the place is packed out the door with Asians from 11-1 on Saturday and Sunday. Oh, and also the fact that WTK are the only ones who truly care if they serve good food. Taste the dumplings here, and then go down the street to another dim sum joint, Lulu's, and tell me its better. Once you do, I'll either call you a liar or declare your palate ignorant. Possibly both. 

Anyway, the reason why I'm uneasy in telling the STL Yelp community about this place, is because I don't need yet another of my favorite places to be overrun. Plus, if word gets out that I let the white people in the door, the other Asians will kill me... 

So if you're white, and you go, don't say hi to me when you see me (I'm there nearly every Sunday). Just sit down and casually order a shumai steamer to be sent to my table, gratis.
Highly mediocre.  I saw on channel two news they had a great menu and lots of desserts, but - unfortunately - I did not find this to be the case in person.

I was served bleach water with ice here. My boyfriend drank It . The staff didn't seem to care. Never heard back from anybody on staff including the owner. Sucks because the food there is actually good. I don't know if It was a black thing or a gay thing...maybe both.

Pizza OK for the price, seemed salty and one visit crust was burnt, next visit not cooked enough. Also had the grilled chicken salad, OK. Decent size. Don't go out too often for lunch and not sure why we come here. The food is OK. Had wine but have not seen any entertainment. Like I said, we come for lunch mostly. What is probably the best is the cheesy bread. Add pepperoni and it is better than the pizza. Go figure.  Parking is sparse at best. Servers are friendly and the atmosphere is fun. Wish there was better food for the payoff of trying to get out to lunch. Wish the Pizza was better too. Try the cheesy bread and salad.

We were excited to try this new seafood spot, but left the experience pretty disappointed. 

We chose the hush puppies for an app, then got chicken for the kids and seafood for each of our entrees. Hush puppies were *so* good, the rest of the food was meh. I'm not big on seafood, so my friend shrimp was fine - not terrible, not great. My boyfriend opted for one of the big combos, and he was pretty disappointed with the quality of the seafood, noting there wasn't a ton of meat in the crab and the crawfish were almost mushy. 

Honestly though what really brought my experience down was the service! Our server didn't check on us throughout our time there, and at one point we were trying to flag her down while she and the other servers were sitting on their phones in a corner booth. Each server only had one table, so we were bummed it wasn't a better experience!

Added a star back for hush puppies and the cute atmosphere.

I was getting my car windows tinted nearby...so I started walking to see what was around.    I saw the sign for Firstwatch, and thought..."I will just get a cup of coffee and read".    I walked in and was greeted promptly, and then seated.   I started looking at the menu...and WOW...what a varied selection that are solidly grounded in sustainable ingredients.   I got the TRI-ATHLETE     (Egg white omelet with house- roasted Crimini mushrooms, onions, tomatoes and green chilies. Served with house-made pico de gallo, whole grain artisan toast, all-natural house preserves and fresh fruit).     OMG it was delicious!    The green chilies added zip yet were not blazing hot (I added hot sauce).The toast was a perfect compliment to the perfectly cooked egg white omelette, and it had texture and tasted like fresh baked bread!   I really did not have high expectations, because to make a flavorful egg WHITE omelette...takes finesse.  Well done!   The fruit was ripe and delicious, and the coffee was superb.    I had a great waiter....(Sisco)...he was attentive without being annoying.    Well done sir..   WELL DONE FIRST WATCH.

I was in town visiting some friends, and my bestie took me here the night I arrived.   I should say I lived in Tucson for 33 plus years.....so I am pretty picky.    She swore the tortilla soup was amazing....and I admit it was GOOD!   I would have given three stars....but I just could not ignore the service.
The service was HORRIBLE!     The place was not that busy, yet there were four or five people STANDING waiting to order....as the people behind the counter just walked by. (and walked by)......and walked by. 
I thought it was just us, but the people waiting in line with us,  were all talking about the fact no one seemed to care to take orders.
We were there on a Friday night at around  9pm....and there were enough people there to certainly make it worth their while tip wise.   There are way to many places in Tucson that serve REAL Mexican food....for a chain like Chuy's to have staff that openly were bothered to wait on customers.   My buddy said "I don't understand, on Sundays these girls are nice".    Ahh....Sunday football?     How about Saturday though Friday's?   Come on Chuy's.....pay attention.

Met a few friends here for lunch on Sunday, and I must admit...it was a tasty burger!   The potato salad was AMAZING, with a unique flavor that really complimented the burger.    The "Dirty Sanchez" is a spicy burger and yes I did get the added ghost pepper sauce!    The burger was perfectly cooked, and I took the leftovers home.   Attentive service, and a good solid burger make this place a thumbs up!

I like Buca.  I do.  Just not this Buca.

I usually frequent the Buca located downtown, but happened to be up in the area with a gift card burning a hole in my wallet.  This is your standard Buca with tons of decorations all over the walls and kitchy seating areas.  We arrived for dinner quite early (in my book) around 5:00 PM.  The place was already pretty full and getting fuller.  

Our waitress was so friendly and so nice.  Lisa?  Liesa?  Something like that.  Very bubbly, but honestly she was swamped.  We sat down and didn't see her for about 10 minutes.  Then ordered garlic bread and it didn't come out for 20 minutes.  Dinner was 20 more minutes.  All in all, we spent most of our time sitting asking "where is our waitress?"  It wasn't because she was flaky, but honestly seemed to be overworked or something.  

A dinner shouldn't take 90 minutes, and that's how long the two of us were there.  I'll be sticking to my downtown location from now on.

This place just opened so I am given the benefit of the doubt. This place could be a hit or miss. Keep in mind they just opened so there is room for improvement. I believe pricing is a little high for the quality and quantity of  the food. I started off with the octopus thinking was going to be enough since I wasn't too hungry, which I must say it was tasty but very small divided into 2 little tentacles. I have visited some of the most upscales Greek and Italian restaurants and for that price or a little more you get at least a whole tentacle. Has to ask for a side of mashed potatoes which surprisedly was a great portion. Their pasta is also a very small portion keep it in mind it was $22 with just a marsalla sauce in it with no meat. Their mezcal drink was good but I don't think will be something I will ask again. They won't carry agave for their drinks. Their vibe was good but too clubby for what I heard from other tables. It's definitely not kid friendly as they don't cater a kids menu. FYI: kids love pasta and $22 for a kid is too much. Everything was good but quite frankly not Master chef good. Don't take me wrong I won't mind paying for great food but coming here hungry will drain your bank account. I don't think having a Master Chef behind your name justifies high pricing and small portions. Even yout bread is divided in 3 small pieces. The server was awesome. I might give them another try after a few months, let's see.

Decided to try this place  because it seems to be the only decent looking one in Clearwater Beach and did not want a burger, crappy sea food or wings. My 3 star goes to service because it was very good but as far of the food it was ok but not great. Upscale pricing at a poor execution. My friend ordered the veal she ate it but wasn't her favorite then I ordered the shrimp pasta and was ok a lil greasy for my taste. Pasta was good though felt like home made but server was honest to confirm wasn't home made. Their bread and sampling tray was ok but some better than others. I wil probably stop by again for some drinks and to sit outside but food needs to improvement.

3.5

I left here thinking I would have rather had drinks. This isn't a slight. I came during a work lunch and getting happy on frozen Pimms Cups isn't the way to go in to the second half of a work day. But I'd heard so much about them and, I'm guessing, they're relatively quick to make so both elements would have lent themselves to a good experience. But, alas, I ate here. It wasn't bad but it wasn't all that memorable. And, as I've written before, in a town like New Orleans, you have to serve memorable (hopefully in a good way) food. There's too much competition to do otherwise.

The first thing I noticed upon walking in was the brick walls. The second thing I noticed was the soundtrack. It's a good thing the walls were attractive and the tunes were bumping because I had ample time to take both in. As is mentioned in other reviews, time management issues in the kitchen is a thing here. Thankfully, before too painful of a wait, the first round of appetizers came out. Even though I hadn't gone in on the ordering, I made sure to help myself to some food.* The poutine was as good as you might imagine a French Canadian dish to be in a Cajun American city. So, good. The mac & cheese was a bit on the underwhelming side. The elbow mac was coupled with three cheeses but the consistency was more liquid than stretchy. I found it a touch off-putting. Despite my hunger, I didn't eat more than a bite. So, by the time my lunch made its way to me (I was the last served at the table), I was ready to do some damage. The chicken pesto sandwich was substantial but, ultimately, bland (chicken, pesto, minor greenery). And, dry. And, in the first world, there are few things worse than a hunk of dry chicken... especially if you're from Kentucky like I am. My side of chips were more of a forget-me-not than anything else. I appreciated the homemade quality but, it's New Orleans. Gimme some Zapp's and keep it moving.

I think I might have preferred a liquid lunch.

*A) It's how I do. B) I was looking out for all involved. No one wants to see me when hangry.

I brought my boyfriend and his mom to Kitchen 519 for Mother's Day brunch yesterday after reading the great reviews on Yelp. They called me on Saturday to confirm my reservation and mentioned that they were booked up for the day and could not accommodate any time changes. Good to know!

The decor of the place is eclectic with a vintage flair- a pleasant surprise, being that the outside of the restaurant is pretty plain and industrial-looking. The kitchen is located right by the hostess stand, and since there was no wall separating it from the entry way, you could see, hear, and smell everything that was going on. Unfortunately that meant I could hear loud inappropriate conversations being had between the staff members as I waited for my boyfriend and his mom to arrive. It was a little awkward to say the least. 

When we were seated, our waiter promptly took our drink orders and went over the menu. We all ordered coffee (which tasted burnt in my opinion) and put and order of the garlic fries in. When they came out, I was excited to see that they came with 3 dipping sauces. I'm a sucker for that kind of thing! The fries were crispy and tender, nicely seasoned, and the sauces were all delicious (however, the 2 aioli sauces tasted very similar). For entrees, we ordered the crab cake Benedict, stuffed burger, and bananas foster French toast. The kitchen was nice enough to accommodate my boyfriends mom's request of a lettuce wrap instead of a bun. All of the food tasted great. 

Our waiter was very nice, but a little awkward at times. Overall, I am excited to come back and give this place a try for dinner!

Delicious texture of meat with American cheese melted in nicely. Soft yummy bread. Decent beer selection. Onions didn't have any flavor though. And the bf said his was a little dry. Quick service. Steady stream of customers.  Limited but comfy outdoor tables. Street parking wasn't bad for prime dinner hour (but it was a Wednesday).  Word to the wise - the hot cherry peppers are no joke!

These people are heaven sent, and so is the cheese. I got some special creation with pulled pork, pineapple and the ooziest, gooiest cheese I've ever experienced on a grilled cheese. The dill potato chips and side of kale fennel slaw rounded it out nicely. This would be 5 star if not for the prices, but $14 for a glorified grilled cheese, slaw & a drink is a wee bit steep. But the amazing service and delectable food ensures that I will be back many, many times.

This location just can't get it right! Just got take out to take to my friends office on Kennedy 2 min from here. First they left me on hold for 5 min before I could order ok fine. Then I get there and have to wait. She brings my food in 5-10 min. I got next door basically and everything is cold even pizza and fried mozzarella!  Not sure what the wait was for. The pizza had hardly any cheese. Very disappointing would have been good if the put some on. The mozzarella sticks were over cooked and exploded so the cheese leaked out. Chicken Bryan was good my friend said but cold. For a50.00 lunch this was TERRIBLE a total waste !!!! I guess the carrollwood location is the only one that is descent. Very disappointing because I live in south Tampa and this location is much closer!!!

TGI Friday's is the typical, chain restaurant food. Nothing too special but I did love their $5 blood orange cooler cocktail. Delicious! They have everyday drink specials. We went for their $10 Endless Apps and it's not worth it unless you're starving and can get the same dish numerous times. We got the Sriracha Chicken Potato Skins. They were okay. I actually enjoyed my $4 wedge salad more. Also, the server should've asked if we wanted another app when we were finished with the first one. Instead we had to flag her down to order, and then it took awhile... so by the time the second app came out, we were full and ready to leave.

But the server we had that night was good. She was awesome and even gave us a take out box for the app we didn't finish.

I'd rather go to Applebee's.

This pizza place was recommended by the hotel personnel. When he said his family always orders and it's the best in town. I just had to try. 
They did not disappoint. Pizza crust was soft and the crust had flavor on the bbq chicken pizza was so good just the pizza sauce was just the right tangy We also got chicken wing plain and ranch dipping sauce. I was disappointed on the size of the wings but it was well seasoned even without ranch dip it was very good. 
They also impressed me by verifying my order with a call back since i was staying in a hotel near by. 
The pizza was promised 45 min but to my surprise it even came earlier.

I really wanted to like this place, but honestly it was very average. First of all, the door was broken and we literally we getting up to let people in so they didn't walk away, and no employee came to fix it. The employees also seemed to not enjoy their jobs very much and were not helpful at all. The prices were normal compared to other local places. The birria tacos were pretty good, but the juice you dip it in was very watered down. The elote was good, but I think they could come up with another way to serve it with the meal, instead of out of an ice cream cup! (But if that's what they were going for than it works.) It was very heavy Mayo compared to others I've had. they did have a great menu with a lot of options!! The chicken tacos were great and had lots of flavor but the carne asada came out and was only meat and I had to put stuff on it from the toppings bar so it wasn't so plain. They also had a lot of ice cream options, but were out of a lot of things they had posted on their menu. I'm wouldn't refer this place, but I definitely would if they changed up a few things that really pulled the restaurant together!

the new menu is fantastic.  the bbq'd pork fries are loaded with pulled pork and definitely large enough to share.  the happy hour is great for food and drink.  the pizzas are 2 for 1 and delicious.  well drinks and beers are only $3.    I will definitely be back again and that grilled cheese burger looks amazing.

 the main reason for the 3 stars is that the service always tends to be very slow and not friendly.  the servers give off the impression of not caring about your meal experience and will rarely come by your table for drink refills or ask about how your food is.

I'm here on a business trip and had this bookmarked. It just so happened to be 2 blocks away from where I had my meeting so I decided to come and give it a try. Parking is non existent so I parked in the little parking garage right next to the store it says free valet for Asian supermarket shopping. I'll get back to that later.

I was contemplating between sliced beef or brisket and after she told me the brisket had more tendon and was fattier I opted for the slice beef hand drawn noodle instead. Overall noodles were fresh and they were tasty. The broth was good but it wasn't mind blowing either. I would give it a solid 7/10. So if you're in the mood for a nice bowl of hearty Chinese soup come on in and give it a try.

Now back to the parking... I tried to finesse the Asian lady in the supermarket to validate my parking and she wasn't having it. She told me only if I spend $60 lol. So basically do not try to park there and get away with it. It cost me $11.00 to park but I'll charge that to the company so I didn't feel as bad. So unless you want to pay $20 for a bowl of soup try to find parking!
Portions seem to be smaller.  New plates?  Quality and service still good.

Good food but unrderstaffed on a recent weekend visit.  Enjoyed grilled romaine and two fish entrees.  The bread Is a disappointment.  With local bakeries in the area they could do better.

Had to ask several times for water refill.

The check process is a hassle.  Have to do it on phone while waitress waits.  For those of us that need glasses keep them handy.  Also the receipt is either emailed or sent via text. 


Patio needs to have some gardening done.

Okay. So you walk in. The place appears to be nice. Then you start to look around. Deflated balloons on the ceiling chairs scattered all over the place and not tucked in. Oh well. You sit down. Ask for a cocktail recommendation. The server has none. Out of the hummus you want. Order the cheese plate. Get drinks. Drinks are decent. Fresh. Good. Server drops cheese plate. Gives no description on the cheese or accompaniments. Doesn't refill water. Mediocre vibe. Mediocre food. Shit service. Drinks decent.

I've been to Square One twice now.  The first time was over a year ago.  On that occasion I was one of the two patrons in the bar and the bartender still found a way to completely ignore me for 20 minutes at a time.  That time was lunch and this time we went for dinner.  I was anticipating trying the Single Malt Scotch Ale which was in cask the last time was there.  So we ordered drinks first.  I ordered the Scotch Ale and my wife ordered the 4 beer sampler (Maple Stout, Irish Stout, Spicy Blonde, and Scotch Ale).  We also both ordered waters and it took two attempts and about 20 minutes before we got them.  And there was no apology when she forgot the first time.  Boy was the Scotch Ale disappointing.  Scotch Ale is my favorite beer style, and I don't even know why they called it one.  It tasted as much like a Budweiser as it did the better Scotch Ales I've had.  It was bland and boring.  I tried my all the beers my wife got and they were okay, but nothing special.  Ironically the spicy blonde was probably the best even though it was my least favorite style.  The food was actually pretty good.  Wife got the Fish and chips and I got the Lamb Burger.  The food is the reason it got two starts instead of one.  But I never go to a microbrewery for the food.  And while the food is good it's not close to good enough to make up for bad beer or bad service, let alone both.
