I had read that the peanut butter semifreddo was like eating a frozen Snickers bar. In actuality, I would've preferred an actual frozen Snickers bar. The dessert was overrated and not worth the $9 we paid. 

The brussel sprouts were the highlight of the night. They were tender and flavorful as always. I'd prefer some bacon fat like Ruth's Chris version, but they were still good. 

Our server was friendly and fast and provided great service throughout dinner; there were no disappearing acts the later it got. 

Ambiance is always nice and tonight was no different. We stepped in for a bite to eat before heading to the Saenger. Between 5:45 and 7:00 pm on a Wednesday, the restaurant was pleasantly quiet. Borgne can be obnoxiously loud at lunch time, so this was a nice change of pace. 

Three stars for food and one star for ambiance and service.

Impeccable service and fabulous cuisine greeted us at Eddie Merlot's. From the minute you get out to of your car, you are treated like royalty. The staff is friendly, knowledgable and attentive.
Fresh flowers were at the hostess table. The dining rooms are elegant and decorated with art. We chose to sit in the lounge which is a little cozier, but also lovely. 
We shared the calamari with martinis for appetizers. The calamari came breaded in a edible rice/sesame seed bowl and was served with three delicious sauces. I couldn't stop snacking on the bowl. But the sauces stole the show.  The martinis were nice and cold, and a generous pour. 
For dinner we ordered the grilled shrimp with rice ($29) Sides are a la carte and shareable. We shared the truffle fries and creamed spinach. The shrimp were huge, meaty and cooked to perfection - tender and flavorful. The rice and spinach did not disappoint. Yummy. Only one minor complaint was with the fries. We did not taste the truffle in the fries and the fries were limp. I paired my shrimp with a Chardonnay which was also a generous pour. 
Our server and the manager checked on us frequently. It was a beautiful experience and we will definitely return

Jackie's sets a new standard for how I will rate breakfast in the future. WOW is all I can say. Stopped today for the first time ever to have breakfast with a colleague. The cafe is small and quaint with local artworks on the walls. The dining room is super clean. The small coffee bar is help yourself. 
We both ordered omelettes for $10.50, selecting among any three gourmet items. I chose smoked salmon, asparagus and avocado. The omelette was huge and fluffy with generous portions salmon, asparagus and avocado. Delicious. The omelet included artisan bread toasted and a cup of mixed fruit. The fruit was mostly honeydew melon and grapes-very fresh. 
The service was friendly and attentive. The food came quickly. 
They offer a tempting selection of fresh cakes and pies - maybe next time!  The chocolate torte looked scrumptious. The carrot cake had at least 5 layers. 
There is a lovely outdoor seating area but loud with traffic from 421.  There is plenty of parking.
They have a popular catering service as well.

Purportedly the owner is from New York and brought the pizza style here with him. This may be true, but if so, I assert that he left New York because nobody there made crust thick enough for him. It's New York *style*, but if you're dreaming of a taste of home, this isn't it.

Authenticity points for making me wait ten minutes for my garlic knots even though my pie was ready. Very New York.

We have been wanting to try O+O for a while. We loved the story behind the restaurant and believed the experience would be fantastic. However, I guess we ordered mostly the wrong items. Oysters Rockefeller tasted pre cooked. Not hot on presentation and very dry. The crab dip was room temperature and smelled fishy. We didn't finish that. The shrimp and grits was the only item that appeared fresh cooked. Super hot and perfectly cooked shrimp. The grits were creamy and delicious. After the appetizer experience we decided not to order an entree.  That plus one glass of wine, with tip, was $75. The atmosphere and service was really good. Unfortunately we won't be back.

Low prices and good selection of produce. Prickly pears, dragon fruit, Thai chilies, escarole... it's more than just carrots and onions here. Though they have many types onions too. 

Many things are bagged in quantity, so you might need to share with friends if you don't need 2 large heads of cabbage. But the prices are so good you can afford to share. 

The deli sells hoagies that are nearly 2 feet long for just $7.99. And they're good.

This place stays busy, so give yourself time to wait in line. Better yet, bring a friend to wait for hoagie while you grab the produce. The line to pay moves quickly.

Good cocktails.  Stopped in at the bar for drinks only. The woman behind the bar did a good job of handling the crowd.  We all enjoyed our drinks, and the food looked good.

If atmosphere is what you want, Sampan is pretty and stylish. So were most of the patrons here on a Friday night.

Oprah claims that their mac and cheese is the best in America.  I stopped by to find out.  I ordered a small side of mac and cheese.  It cost $5!  For that price, it BETTER be the best in the country!  That's all I had, and it was pretty darn good.  Other people walking by stopped to ask me how it was (maybe they looked at the price first and decided to let me take the chance).  I have to admit that it is probably some of the best traditional mac and cheese I've had--and I have eaten A LOT of Southern food, especially mac and cheese.  I'll go back to try the other food.  The fried chicken and greens looked great.  But I still think my own mac and cheese is the best.  I also think that it is ridiculous to charge a lot of money for a dish that was created as a cheap meal.  (No, that's not really a review of Delilah's, but it had to be said.)

Place seems to be going down hill. The BBQ doesn't taste as fresh anymore, the quantities have been reduced and the kimchi and sides are such plain Ol dry. So Sad because this place used to be pretty good.

Tried out the University Location this time...wait was around 15mins on a Saturday Night..which is not bad all..the Interior and Location is much more vibrant and livelier than the old City location...we had the usual dishes as always...Tripe Appetizer, Crispy Cucumbers, Dan Dan Noodles and we also tried a daily special this time...which as a whole bass with sauce...yummy...had to walk back 15 blocks to digest our food..well worth it...

This place is the epitome  of overpriced tourist place. I've been there 10-15 times over the years and have seen their prices keep going up and their portion size getting skimpier.  I'm not even sure how yelp has it set at two $$ signs. Easily a three, easily. $17 for poached egg on toast, no sauce, literally a poached egg, $ 20for a spicy chicken omelet. (See menu scans) 


I'm a foodie, I eat out a lot, and I am far from cheap. As a foodie who eats out a lot, I know how this stuff works. I don't mind being charged a premium for food that blows my socks off, but this does not do this. Nothing rubs me worse than a restaurant that is obviously gauging their customers. Another place that's guilty of this is Anderson's on State. 

If you go, no you'll most likely be paying at LEAST $20 per person, and thats just coffee and bread.
Went here on Friday night.  The place was packed.  We had a great server.  We ordered a Cesar salad which was good and split the lasagna.  It was just okay.  Nothing to write home about.

This place was awesome! I loved the old school interior look and the flash cards in the table to make the wait interesting. I ordered the Chicago style pizza  and was happy I did. It was everything I expected, and the cheese was practically melting into your mouth. The service was on point as well, and overall I had a great experience.

Needed a nice place to study and this definitely wasn't it. My qualifications for a fantastic place to study includes 6 things: drinks other than coffee, food options, acceptable wifi, appropriate amount of outlets, clean environment, and clean bathrooms. This place hit 4 out of 6. I'm not a coffee person so I typically order some type of iced tea. Usually, iced green tea tastes great wherever I'm at. For some reason, their iced green tea was just not acceptable. I had to force myself to drink at least half so I could get my money's worth. I just couldn't get myself to drink the entire thing though. They offer food which is a plus and there were ample amounts of outlets. As for the cleanliness, it was not up to par for me. Tables were dirty, trash and crumbs were on the floor, and the bathroom was nasty. I went on a Saturday morning and they were packed, so they're doing something right that I'm just not seeing.
Great tacos at great prices. Easy location, parking is a bit of an issue. Great beer selection! Will be back.

We ordered take out tonight after returning from the shore. We had it delivered and quoted 30 minutes. The order arrived an hour later, no biggie for a Friday night.

We ordered a large plain, steak Stromboli and a small white pizza. They offer a coupon on the menu but the girl said it wasn't valid on a Friday night. We also ordered boneless wing and fries. The wings were terrible, dry and chewy. They also only sent literally 2 pieces of celery. The fries were good but the bag was not even half full. For the prices they are skimpy with the portions. The large pizza was very good. It had the perfect amount of sauce and cheese, I enjoyed the thick crust. The white pizza was good. The ricotta was fresh but the tomatoes weren't great. They were very chewy. The best by far was the Stromboli, it was packed with meat and delicious.

Overall it was just okay and far from gourmet. The pizza is good and the Stromboli was good. If we ordered again we would just stick with that.

First let me say we really wanted to like this place. Before we stopped in I read some reviews. I should have listened to the other elites. Upon entering the place was dead! At noon on a Thursday, that was strange. The floors were also very sticky, first thing I noticed walking in. The guy taking orders was very nice. He went through the menu and ordering process because it was our first time there. 

Now for the food. We started with the chips and queso with a side of salsa. The chips were stale and in pieces, we've had better out of a bag. The salsa was ok but was not fresh as stated, it was from a jar. The queso was the worst and tasted like it came from a can. My wife ordered a fajita salad with chicken. The salad was bare bones and lame. The fajita vegetables were raw, who does that? Raw onions and green peppers. They only offer 2 types of salad dressing. The chicken was seasoned well but there wasn't much of it. I went with the 2 tacos and added and extra. All 3 were steak with everything. The shells I swear we're out of a box. The steak was seasoned well but again there wasn't much meat and it was extremely thin. The tacos were edible but not great. I could have made better at home. Paid $3.00 for guacamole and never received. They also make you pay for water. They do have fountain machines, they usually have a water feature. We were told only bottles were available. As a previous person said, there aren't any trashcans in the joint....

I would not go back at all. The food was mediocre at best and it's very expensive. $33.00 for a bad lunch, we could have went to Chipotle for a much better lunch. 1 star for customer service.

Every so often we go to Red Robin when we run out of close options to eat while running errands. I for one am not a fan of most chain restaurants. We stopped Sunday around noon and it was packed! Our server was Matt and he was aces. He was on top of refills and just pleasant.

I ordered the blt, it was just okay. The bun wasn't toasted. The bacon was scarce and it was dry. The fries were good as always. The wife had the veggie burger and she seemed to enjoy it for the most part. She skipped the bun but the burger itself was a bit dry. Her side salad was nice and fresh with a large variety of dressing.

Overall it was a decent quick meal. I wouldn't go out of my way to return. Solid 3 stars.

i really wanted to not like Woksabi, since i learned that it's owned by the same people that own Chow's across the way.  I'm pretty sure that Chow's is the devil, but that's a story for another review.

I walked in expecting Woksabi to be rude, overpriced and have "eh" food, just like Chow's.  The servers are nice.  The prices are pretty good for amount and quality of food that you get.  The selection of sushi rolls is outstanding.  If it's not busy, they'll consider doing custom rolls for you.  Combine all of that with a clean, bright, modern looking space, and i am, depsite my desire to hate them, sold.  it's one of my favorite sushi restaurants at the moment.

i recommend sitting at the sushi bar if you want to watch masters at work, or just don't know what you want.  you get to see all of the plates going out; which if you're hungry is exquiste torture.

Had lunch here a few days ago, I heard rave reviews from lots of people so I'm a Philly guy and cheese steak guy of course. so I indulged. Honestly I was extremely disappointed with the cheesesteak, not meat at all one slab of beef on a roll. But Steve's had no flavor either, the rolls were borderline stale. Sorry that doesn't cut it. To me it was below standards, maybe I'm biased growing up in Roxborough with Delasanndro's, Barry's and Mama's on Belmont Ave.  The only redeeming factor was that the French fries were good.

Great beer selection (IN BOTTLES ONLY) The drafts are terribly overpriced and they don't list the size. I ordered an American Pale ale and got a 10oz pour in a Duvel glass. Seriously.  for $6.50 I said something and was assured it was the correct pour. 

It's a dirty move. http://honestpintproject.org/

First trip here was 4 star. Drinks were yummy and we met with some friends for a nightcap so the ambiance was perfect.

This time around, drinks were completely lame (where is the espresso in this thing?) and the staff could have not made less of an effort to realize we existed, let alone thank us for our business. Boo!

Consistency is something we look for and it looks like it's been all over the place for the other reviewers as well.

Updating this to 3 stars. On 3 separate occasions we have ordered a pitcher of margaritas that have had little to no alcohol in it. For a point of reference I drank 2/3 glasses out of the pitcher and felt less of an effect than half of a beer. I let this go once thinking it was a one off problem but it's consistent. 

Stop stealing from people and give them what they pay for when it comes to drinks.

After three meals I'm left wishing that Ginza has better food. The BYOB option is a plus. The service is adequate, however (again) it comes back to the food. I'm specifically talking about the sushi here as I haven't had any hot items other than the average miso soup. The sushi rice was over cooked, gummy and excessively sweet on each of my visits. This doesn't set up the fish for success. The other major problem I have is the overwhelming size of the sliced fish itself. Once placed atop the rice the shear mass of the nigiri "bite" makes it nearly impossible to eat in one piece. I found the same to be true with the sashimi as the pieces were really large and thick making it very difficult to swallow. Lastly, I don't understand why there was jarred pickle relish on top of the salmon nigiri? Shit out to a hot dog maybe? Strange. All in all I think I've eaten my last Ginza meal. Try for yourself though as it may be your style.

This is my favorite incarnation from the Cheu crew as of now.  Cheu Fishtown is a bit larger than the original midtown location so it's less cramped and more comfortable.  The cocktails and service are very good.  The talk of the town here is the brisket/ matzo ball ramen.  The broth is thick and rich and porky in all the best ways.  It's certainly a more original and inventive take on ramen but it hits all the notes and then some.  The black garlic wings are also a must order.  Dollar for dollar Cheu will give you appropriate value for your $.

It's great to have a place that serves breakfast late specially on weekend mornings. We came noonish on a Saturday and ordered takeout because most seats were occupied. Our 3-plate order took about 30 minutes. Hmm. I ordered a blackboard special - chorizo shrimp hash and I thoroughly enjoyed it - nice balance of veggies and protein. Mrs. got Molly's Kale salad with chicken which was "ok" - the breast was cut into medallions and were a tad dry. Sis got the Falafel burger which looked crunchy but was not so much. If we go back, we'll probably stick with breakfast.

I'm from Texas, and I lived in Austin for a few years. I never went to Hopdoddy when I lived there, because the line just seemed kind of ridiculous to me. Recently, after a movie at the Belcourt, a friend and I got burgers at Hopdoddy. It was all right. We got the same burger - something classic and traditional, maybe just a cheeseburger? - and they were cooked to very different temperatures. My friend's burger was quite pink, mine was definitely medium. The burgers were okay. The fries were okay (weirdly undersalted). The system is weird. We walked to the register, where they didn't have menus. Then as we waited to place our orders, someone came by and give us a table menu. As a first time Hopdoddy-er, it was a little confusing to figure out the system. All in all, it was all right. An a-okay burger if you're hungry in Hillsboro Village.

I stopped by 615 Chutney for takeout for dinner tonight, and it was a really great experience. What I loved about the meal was that the restaurant specializes in South Indian cuisine, including dishes from the Chettinad region and the southern state of Tamil Nadu. Because they specialize in the cuisine of this region, the menu offered a lot of dishes I'd never had before. I had a hard time narrowing down what to order, so I just ordered A LOT and figured we'd eat it over a few days! Worth it. 

So what did we eat? From the starters section of the menu, we tried Egg Podimas (shredded hard-boiled egg tossed with veggies and Southern Indian spices) and Kyma Idli (shredded rice cakes grilled in South Indian spices and house-made masala with choice of protein - we chose lamb). The Egg Podimas was good - a sort of South Indian flavored egg salad since it was hard-boiled eggs rather than scrambled (which I found some recipes for online). The Kyma Idli was delish - well flavored and a good texture. I loved it.

From the mains, we tried the Chettinad egg curry (hard-boiled eggs in a Chettinad curry tomatoes and onions), Kothu Parotta (shredded parotta/paratha cooked in spices with your choice of protein - for this dish I chose paneer), and pepper chicken curry (boneless chicken cooked in South Indian black pepper sauce). All three were really good. It was the first time I've ever had hard-boiled eggs in curry - yum! The chicken was tender and delicious. But the Kothu Parotta was my favorite. 

Both the Kyma Idli and Kothu Parotta reminded me of an Ethiopian dish I love - firfir (leftover injera cooked in a Berbere-spiced sauce). The idli and the parotta cooked down in their respective sauces to make for interestingly textured and very tasty dishes. 

I also ordered a dosa, but sadly the filling/paste for the dosa didn't make it into my to go bag. I look forward to trying it for real next time (it was the Nethili - anchovy - curry dosa, which sounds so interesting!). For dessert, we tried the Ras Malai (soft cheesecake patties soaked in milk flavored with cardamom), which was a good way to end a spicy meal! 

Despite trying so many dishes, there are a lot more dishes I'd love to try! They also offer dishes that are more familiar offerings from Indian restaurants if you want a familiar/already loved dish (Paneer Tikka Masala, Butter Chicken, saag, Kurma, Vindaloo, Biryani, Chana Masala, Pakora, Samosas, dosas, and more). They have the dishes you already love and maybe some you haven't had the chance to experience yet (at least that was the case for us)! When ordering, they offer several spice levels for their dishes. We went with Spicy for our dishes and they were! 

I ordered online on their website. They texted me to confirm my order and then texted me when the order was ready. They have curbside if you prefer (I think you just call them when you're outside), but I just popped in to get my order after they texted it was ready. Their lobby area is pretty spacious, and no one else was inside waiting for their meal when I went in. It looked like they did offer dine in, but the few tables are really far apart and it wasn't busy inside. 

The menu is varied and exciting and the food is delicious. Other than forgetting a couple of items I ordered (the anchovy paste for the dosa and a drink I ordered), the meal was near perfect. And it's understand that certain items sometimes get forgotten with takeout and given how much food I ordered! I'll happily go back and get an absurdly large order of food again!

So, I know that Dino's has been around a while and is a Nashville tradition. But, geez, is it grungy and gross. I don't expect dive bars to be squeaky clean, but Dino's was a little bit grosser than I'm cool with. We enjoyed a few pitchers of beer outside with a few friends, because inside was packed. Outside was very smoky and packed with hipsters. The door to the outside and the bathrooms were gross. Definitely a hole in the wall. Not a place that I'd recommend. But maybe go once and check it off your Nashville bucket list?

We were visiting St. Louis last weekend, and we were just wandering around the Central West End when I noticed Yellowbelly! I had read some reviews of it on Yelp, and I was excited to try it. We were just hungry enough to stop in for a late afternoon snack! We ordered two cocktails: a Negroni for him and a Crop Circles for me. My husband enjoyed his classic Negroni. I LOVED my drinks: macchu pisco, ancho reyes, curacao, sweet corn, coconut, and lime. It was refreshing and light and delicious! We shared the sea biscuits with cheddar and uni butter - the biscuits were delicious and buttery and flaky, and the uni butter was rich and delicious! I also got four of the "oysters and pearls": oysters with frozen little balls of baja cocktail sauce. They were excellent, and the presentation was pretty great. The service was great (we sat at the bar), and the restaurant is beautiful! Based on our afternoon snack, I'd definitely stop by for a full meal at Yellowbelly!

My friend and I went to Tansuo for their very first brunch (on Mother's Day). I should say that the ambiance and the decor are top-notch - gorgeous, dark, moody. But I was a little underwhelmed by the food and drinks. If you're going to go high-end, everything really needs to be perfect - otherwise, you just feel like you overpaid. 

For my brunch cocktail, I had the Jade Emperor (green tomato juice, scallion, garlic, ginger, bird's eye chilies), which was more interesting than successful (the texture was a little off-putting).

For food we tried some Chinese pancakes, which were underwhelming. We also had a chicken entree that was tasty, but not quite as outstanding as the price tag made me expect. 

Tansuo is new, and their brunch was brand new, so I'd definitely give it another chance. Maybe we ordered the wrong thing, but my first impression was that Tansuo is style over substance.

Went to Red lobster on a Friday, not to packed. Was seated as soon as possible. With some good bread as starters. Great service. Nice waiter. Fast with bringing me my drinks. And placing my order.. I got a combination. Surprisingly I got alot of food on my plate and can't be beat for the price. And get a side salad with. All the food came out nice and hot, done perfect. 

For dessert I had cheesecake... It was good but I feel like the peice of cheese cake could have been bigger. But that won't defined me by how good everything esle was. 

I look forward to coming back hear in near future....

I've always enjoyed Mayfair Diner... And there food. But sometimes when things change u have to move on. And that's what happen this morning. The service was good. And so was my breakfast... But after I got my bill and went to pay I notice for the first time there was a sign that said minimum payment $10 for credit and debit cards. So I hand the lady my card and the bill, she says we don't take credit cards or debit cards under $10. She tried telling me that the credit card companies charge me a fee. Yes interest fee, What she didn't want to tell me was they charge them the fees that's why they have the minimum of $10. But in the long run places with the minimum payment. Will lose and gain. With me they will lose. I will find another Diner to go that dont have the minimum. Especially when my bill was only off by $1.50 of the minimum. It's more of an inconvenience for people sometimes, especially when it's not mandatory. it's if the merchants want to add the minimum on. Place should mabe have a minimum under $10 charge 50 cents to a $1 on the bill. Make much more sence.

Ikea is a great spot for so many things. You can spend hours in hear. And get so much for cheap. They have much more to choose from then on the website. After you look around a d find what you need. Most of the big items you have to walk downstairs and get in the warehouse. 

It's very easy to get lost in hear. So loom at the maps thru the store. It's beats target, Walmart or really for that matter any other store...

We just had dinner using UberEats delivery was good 45 Minutes . We ordered Goat Saag, mild Chicken Tikka Masala mild and Garlic Naan. Both dinner were way to hot to enjoy and they did not give us any rice. Never had Indian food without rice. Will not order from them again.
If you like heaps of seafood, done right, with lots of with-its, come here.  Service is a secondary consideration, though.  Very secondary.

Had late lunch (closer to happy hour). Parking and sitting were no issue.  I had the spicy katsu ramen. It was very tasty.  The spice level was akin (bad analogy) to a sour pickle. Broth was thick and rich, not quite creamy. The soft boiled egg (1/2) was among the best I've had.  Noodles were chewy and "al dente". Filling.  A very limited menu - basically ramen and add-ons.

Good food, but the service is not very good! Tried it twice with my grandpa and both times the food was great, but the service sucked! Had to ask multiple times for milk for my coffee, always waiting for a refill, forgot to bring our biscuit. Wish they would step up the service game!

Parking is sometimes a problem here. Interesting donuts in terms of flavor and creativity. The taste was standard, nothing special but just what you would expect a typical donut to taste like. Maybe because I'm so attached to Krispy Kreme's specific texture, it's hard to try new things. However, this place definitely deserves another visit so we can try several of the other flavors.

Was pleasantly surprised by this place. I'm usually not a cold dessert person, especially during cold weather. However, I'm glad I came by this place and tried it out because it was worth it! I like the naughty/nice concept, although it's kind of funny that they ask for ID for the alcoholic ones. I like that they have interesting/unique flavors. The only con so far is that there is not enough space to sit (one table). Will definitely try again hopefully.

Very disappointed for my first visit here.  Had a large party.  Food took forever to come out from the kitchen and it was only between two different sandwiches.  I was done eating when the last person received their meal.  My burger was medium rare which wasn't cooked enough for me and the bun was so hard I could not eat it.  The seasoned fries and side salad were good though.  I will give this place another try however won't recommend larger parties to this restaurant.  Our server was very nice and continued to check on us while the food  was being brought out.  Sad that my first experience wasn't better.

This was more like a 3-1/2 star place. We pulled into an empty parking lot except for 2 other cars. Neon sign says open 24 hours but all the handmade signs say otherwise... Inside it's smaller than you'd expect and the decor could use a good scrub and some modernizing. This was my first visit here. The menu prices posted online are old, but the prices are okay-ish. We got breakfast for dinner: ham and cheese omelette with pancakes and a side of hash browns (extra crispy), potato pancakes with applesauce--classic diner food. The omelette is really a scramble, the pancakes (3!) were tasty and fluffy, potato pancakes were fine, and the hash browns were good and crispy! (I actually asked for biscuits instead of pancakes but I liked that I got the pancakes because they were really good.) The applesauce was very disappointing. No real finesse with the food, but it came out quickly! The food was solid and the service was fine. We'll be back, and maybe we'll try something that isn't breakfast.

Stopped in here to pick up our stuff for the Onesie Crawl and we decided to have drinks and food.  I ordered the Shrooms from the Starters & Appetizer section.  I was so excited about the stuffing ingredients and the sauce, that I missed that they were deep fried.  Kind'a kills any special flavoring going on, once you deep fry something.  It was fine, but not great.  So, it's more of a bar than a restaurant?  Asked about any specialty drinks they had...  Nope.  Asked about any ciders, and all they had was the Stella Artois Cidre on tap.  The server wasn't rude, just didn't seem like she cared at all.  NOT impressed.
Food is OK service is slow and kids eat free on Tuesday nights. Best part is they have iPads for kids to play games for free

We arrived about half an hour early at the restaurant.  We didn't encounter the traffic we had feared.  The restaurant accommodated us being early, mainly as the table was ready and unoccupied.  One advantage of getting an early reservation.

It is a comfortable old neighborhood restaurant.  You know you are coming here for the food, not the decor.  Although the plates on the wall do present a different touch, especially after hearing the story behind them.  The owner's names on the bathroom doors signs add a comical touch.  

My wife started with the Lobster & Brie Cheesecake with Lemon Aioli.  It was so good, she was reluctant to even let me have a taste.  After the taste, I agreed with her.  I started with Jenny's Salad; the Blue Cheese, apples, and spiced pecans definitely give it a different style and flavor.  I liked it.  

It was one of those rare nights where both of us decided to leave our comfort zones and try something different.  And we had decided upon the same entree, the Coconut Curry Thai hot pot.  As soft shell crabs were on the menu, we replaced the flounder with a fried crab.  I can't complain about the portion or the amount of seafood (shrimp, crab meat, and calamari) in the sauce.

The meal was interesting.  There was some herb or spice in the sauce that was a little off-putting.  I couldn't quite pin it down, but it just wasn't to my taste.  That's the price I pay to explore different foods.  You win some and you lose some.  Next time I'll stick with the short ribs.  They looked awesome as the plate passed by the table.

They had a nice wine list considering the size of the restaurant.  Some French, Spanish, and Italian to consider along with the usual Californian products.  Also offered an interesting selection of seasonal cocktails.  Wait staff was good.  Never did have to ask for drink refills, even though I had a bottle of wine on the table.

My kids (7 and 4) were pumped to go to Main Event on a day off school. Seems like everyone else had that same idea. It was a hot when we showed up and the line was out the door. We waited in line for 10-15 minutes. Eventually I realized that since we were only there to play arcade games we could purchase a card from a machine and didn't have to stand in line. Better signage or a person directing traffic, especially when the line is out the door, might be helpful. 

Once inside, things moved much quicker. We bought our card (I paid 35 dollars for the two kids to share). The kids wanted to race and there were lots of options so that they weren't standing around waiting a long time to play. After multiple car and motorcycle races we ventured to other parts of the arcade. There were VR games, shooting games, carnival like games, basketball shooting and bowling. There were also tons of claw grabbing prize games (too many as my kids wanted to do all of them). 

We had one issue, a game malfunctioned without my kids or I even realizing it, and an employee jumped right in and corrected it.

Main Event is a fine way to spend a hot afternoon indoors. It is a bit pricey but seems comparable to other venues that do these same types of activities. I hope to come back with some adults and try some of the other things they have to offer.

Malvern Buttery is conveniently located on the main stretch of Malvern, just blocks from the train station. The decor is clean and rustic, with plentiful seating and an open kitchen that constantly replenishes the buffet-style display of food.

At first, I was confused by the honor system payment scheme - the customer chooses their food, then pays at the end, after having eaten. It's an idea that definitely encourages the friendly community feel of the place, and an idea that could only ever work on the Main Line. 

All the food I tried was great, though the items certainly added up quickly! After much deliberation (everything, especially the pastries, looked great!), I got the pulled pork sandwiches, a chicken pot pie, a canelé, and a flat white. The coffee was excellent and the chicken pot pie, though lukewarm, was flaky and flavorful. I would have liked to see more reasonably priced vegetable side options - the salads were all priced as full meal portions and there were no other plain vegetable sides (e.g. green beans or brussels sprouts) available. 

Malvern Buttery is deservedly super popular, attracting families, students, and local workers alike. We arrived right before the lunch rush, so the buffet bar was well-stocked, but when the crowd came, we did notice that all the buffet items got snatched up quickly and quite a line formed to pay and order coffee. All in all, Malvern Buttery is a really great lunch/coffee option in Malvern, and I'd definitely stop by again next time I'm in the area.

I'll get my complaints in first: 
My burger which ordered medium rare was actually probably still breathing.  Yuck. 
Other than that the sweet potato fries were tasty.
The best and only redeeming part of this place was the milkshake. The Black & White is what I will hands down recommend to anybody.

I may just come back for the milkshake.

Hrm....

The pretzels were ok, the service was ok, I didn't fall in love with the American cheese sauce. 

Sometimes cheese sauce can taste a bit....hard to describe. Almost like it wasn't vegetarian. Almost gamy or something. I did not like. Good thing I had also snagged some mustard.

The pretzels were okay. I prefer a good, fresh one from Target actually. Of all places. 

The fountain Coke was not carbonated enough. That stinks because it's 100% fact that good fountain Coke is practically the best thing ever. 

I will probably try it again. I would like to try the jalapeno sauce or the cheddar sauce. 
Also the pretzel nibs looked good. 

I guess the overall underwhelming experience is why the place is called Pretzel Boys and not Pretzel Men. 

Mmmmmmm....pretzel men.

Down a star. 

Had the cheddar sauce this time and I hated it as much as I hated the American cheese sauce the first time. I make much better cheddar cheese sauce at home and, while I don't hold places up to my own homemade standards, I do expect it to at least be somewhat enjoyable. Let's face it: at no other time do I prefer mustard over cheese. No. Other. Time.  

Quick rundown: 
lackluster service
mediocre pretzels
awful cheese sauce
2 stars 

Pretzel Boys: hit me up for my cheese sauce recipe. I will sell it to you. It's worth it, I swear.

We have lived close to this place for about 2 years and only this past weekend got around to trying it out. 
Pizza, salad, beer, wine. 
Lit candle on table. Had to move that out of the reach of my monkey-armed 14 month old son. (Seriously, the kid looks like he has normal arms but when he wants something, they can expand like Plex's arms on Yo Gabba Gabba) 
They bring out bread, it's warm. That's nice. I like bread. I like warm bread even more. 
MMMMmmmm bread. Not even the best bread I have ever had. But good. 
And warm. 
And my wine was decent. Cold. Clean glass. 
Same thing, the beer. Cold, clean, good. 
Alcohol a little premium-priced here but whatever. 
Then salads. 
They're ok. Not much cheese on them. What can I say? Much like I like bread, I like cheese. Except I love cheese way more. So, could have used more cheese. And maybe a little less sugar in the dressing. But, really, for all my complaining, I enjoyed it still. 
Service was perfectly fine. 
Pizza came out: black olives, StL style. 
Pretty decent pie. I have had better (Hi, Stefanina's!) and I have had much, much worse (Eff you, Imo's!) and this hit the spot pretty well. 
Owner (Mike Nicoletti) came out and introduced himself and shook our hands. How lovely! 
Waiter commented on cuteness of my kid - automatically increasing his tip. 
We left, satisfied. Mr Nicoletti once again chatted with us as we left. Seems like a very nice guy. 
We'll probably be back.

The customer  service here is not good at all the problem is there is way to many young high school kids working here . I pulled up to the window in the drive thru and the very young lady just stood there looking at me she didn't say hello or anything she could at least repeated my total she didn't do anything but look at me as if I was annoying her . With that being said my cookies were very good and fresh

We arrived about 7PM on our way through to Sarasota.  This was the worst experience at a Cracker Barrel EVER! 

First off, we were waiting to be seated as a line accumulated behind us. The restaurant wasn't really busy at all. It was nearly empty. When the manager / hostess finally came up to seat us she thought we were a large party. I said no, we have just been waiting awhile. She stated she was dealing with a complaint. She then sat us at a table very near the door to the kitchen. The server saw us but no one came out. 10 minutes later the hostess came over and asked if anyone had been at our table yet. We said no, she asked our drink order. We were actually just saying we picked the wrong place and were going to leave. She grabbed our drinks and said she would have the server come over to take our order. It was 7 minutes before she came. At this point I was actually timing things. It was that bad.

 When she finally took our order we had 2 chicken fried chicken dinners and a biscuits and gravy breakfast. Nothing that should have taken 27 minutes to come out!!! Then, it was obvious it had been sitting in the window awhile. The chicken was hot in the center but everything else was very mildly warm. I am sure it never would have passed health code inspection. Our server did not bring out our dinner someone else did. She did stop by to drop off the check immediately after we got our food. She never returned. Luckily there were others to refill our drink once but aside from that, we were on our own. 

We actually considered breaking something to get someone over there to refill our drinks. The hostess who I believe was also the manager on duty was fully aware of the situation but only said I hope it gets better now. Oh, I hope your cracker barrel experience improves....

Upon checkout, she said how was everything? I said terrible, server was awful and food was cold. She said oh thats surprising, we did get busy earlier so maybe everyone is just tired now.....REALLY? Then go home don't try and destroy our dinner because your too tired or lazy to do your job! This place was a joke!

We ordered broccoli cheese soup in a bread bowl, tomato bisque in a bread bowl, a Cuban sandwich and a pulled chicken panini. Everything was delicious. Normally we would never eat that whole bread bowl but it was so good we couldn't stop eating it. The sandwiches were a standard size, nothing skimped at all. We had leftovers for the next day. It all still tasted great then as well. We did not try the drinks but everything we tried was delicious. We will definitely be back.

Decent food but its family owned and you cannot get service to save your life in here. It is good for large crowds I would think because they seem to cater to kids ball teams etc. As a family outing for dinner, there are too many other choices in the area to try and beg for service here. Maybe take out would be better.

A little pricey for BBQ but it is great food. The portions are pretty small for the price but I still love the pretzel bread bowl. The sausage sandwich is awesome too. I really enjoy smoked food so we do come here on occasion.

We normally love this place. Last night though, we ordered a Greek chopped salad & 2 gyros. We ordered spicy tzazki and feta cheese on the gyros. First off, the chopped salad was so soggy, we could barely eat it. There's at least an inch of water in the bottom of the bowl. Then, the gyros have more tzazki than meat! It's literally not even edible. Our bill was $45. This is the worst Greek food ever! 
See pics...

Least impressive of the three lunch sandwich purchases today. The pork was a bit dry, accompanied by juice but not juicy. Heavy garlic, bread standard. It was not at all warm when we unwrapped it. We posted one person in the long line while someone else ran for muffuletta. I'd grab Tony Luke's pork again if given the choice.

Loco Pez was solid. I went there for a solo brunch on a Saturday and found the AC cranking (awesome), the bartender squawking (bearable, sort of charming I guess), and the food good. Huevos rancheros was $11, and while I didn't have a drink the Bloody Mary's next to me looked delicious and were $2 off, making them only $5 each. I had heard rave reviews and to be honest, was happy but not blown away by the food itself. I think the whole package is what you come for -- well priced drinks, solid food, nice decor, fun atmosphere -- NOT authentic, unbeatable Mexican cuisine. And I'm okay with that. I'll be back.

I liked it.  I didn't go ga-ga over it, but I liked it.

The portions of pasta are large, and should be for the price, so consider sharing.  I thoroughly enjoyed my Bucatini All'Amatriciana---very spicy in the best possible way.  I enjoyed the hollowed-noodle bucatini for a change of pace. Loved the mixed greens salad, a fairly common (these days) combo of pears, walnut and goat cheese.

Friend C ordered teh Strozzzpreti---Pastaria's Bolognese.  It was a little weird---too rich and bacony for my taste.  My friend enjoyed hers, with leftovers to spare that she gobbled up in the car after an evening at the Thaxton Speakeasy (apparently moonshine stimulates the appetitie!)


 Friend L ordered the Bucatini and concurred with my opinion.  She also tried the Shaved Kale salad.  She liked---I thought it was a bit wet.  I wouldn't be tempted to order it.

Friend J love, love, loved her pistachio ravioli---which is probably the thing to order since it's not so comon.

We shared some Risotto Balls----everyone enjoyed, some to a great degree than others.

The wait staff was friendly and attentive.  I loved the decor and will probably go to the restaurant again, as I think it's right up my husband's alley.

However, I wish there were a few more non-pasta choices (I know, I know, it's called Pastaria).

I just felt that 22 bucks for pasta and salad was a little off balance.


I'll keep ya posted.

One of my favorite places to get Pho. I stopped going here only because I started eating Pho Ga only, and I prefer the chicken and the broth at Pho 75. However, their beef pho is amazing and this used to be my go to spot. 

The servers are nice, attentive and the restaurant is much more spacious / family style seating compared to something like Pho 75. They also have many more options for appetizers and entrees, as Pho 75 only focuses on Pho only.

Solid choice

Maybe my last order 2 years ago was sub-par.. I don't know. But I ventured back craving a chicken cheesesteak as I've stopped eating beef recently. 
This time I got the chicken cheesesteak with spinach provolone and special sauce. It tastes great with or without the sauce -- but I like that the sauce is really sour and spicy to give it nice contrast. Like other yelpers have said -- it's huge chunks of fresh chicken breast -- don't expect the usual minced up / cut up meat that normally represents a cheesesteak. I will say that, I do sometimes crave that cut up minced up because it's less dry and absorbs cheese much better. But this is a great alternative

I also go the shrimp and chicken cheesesteak one time which was also great.

Carrot cake continues to be $1.50 and deliciously diabetic.

The first time I tried MOD pizza was at a different location for a Yelp Event. We had a great time, I was really impressed with the pizza dough, the flavors, price and service, and couldn't wait to be back!

Unfortunately, yesterday I was disappointed. When we arrived, the lady did ask us if we've been before or if we needed help, a great start to the service. 

When we were ready, I saw her write my name " tiffany" on it, write that I wanted to add chicken + mushrooms to the Dillon James and 1/2 jalapeno on our Ella pizza. The wait was much longer than we anticipated, I suppose we had thought it might have been closer to 3-5 minutes but it was much closer to 10 minutes. Then when we got it, the two orders said " Irene". We went back, they said it was the right pizza, but they switched up the names by accident, no big deal. Went back to our table, noticed it wasn't our pizza bc mushrooms + chicken were missing. We went back, we hate wasting food so we just had them add it on and bake it in the oven ( so you can see the picture, the mushrooms are severely undercooked). 

I'm sure the pizza is still just as good as last time -- but the confusion, mix up, raw mushrooms made for an unpleasant experience.

Get the special rolls. They're fantastic!

The prices are amazing. Every roll is priced between $9.50 - $11.50. 

FOOD: 
We ordered Agedashi Tofu $6 - delicious. The sauce with the tempura sauce was perfect. The batter was light, but not perfect (hence the 4 star review). 
We ordered 4 rolls, miso soup, and the tofu between the 3 of us and it was the perfect amount of food. 
We ordered the Fancy Sushi, Rock n Roll, Miss Sake Bomb, and Lost Rainbow. My favorites were Fancy sushi and Lost Rainbow, but all were good. We cleaned our plate :)

AMBIANCE: loved it. I love the dim lighting with the blue/neon back light, the modern decor and hanging lights. No complaints at all.

SERVICE: attentive. The male server was very nice, never overbearing but always there when we needed some more water :)

WILL RETURN!

Came here a couple weeks back with my girlfriend and then again this past week for restaurant week with my dad. Very tasty Italian spot in a city that has no shortage on good Italian. 

For restaurant week, we ordered the caesar salad, shrimp scampi, Sunday gravy, orecchiette with sausage, chicken parm, and stuffed long hot. Insane amount of food for two people, but I am not complaining. The Sunday gravy and chicken parm were both generous portions. They even offered a complimentary dessert, but we turned it down only because we simply could not eat anything else. My favorite was probably the orecchiette with sausage. Our waiter informed us afterwards that they do not alter the portions much for restaurant week and I believe it. 

The restaurant itself is big. However, that being said, both times I was seated at a table that was almost uncomfortably too small (especially for restaurant week). Not a huge deal but figured it would be worth mentioning since a lot of the reviews talk about the spacious restaurant room. I thought the atmosphere was very cool and people are right when they say the restaurant room itself is massive - I did not know what to expect when we were told the restaurant was downstairs. 

Will definitely be back. Not sure if it did enough to differentiate itself from other Italian spots in the city, but make no mistake it was very good classical Italian cuisine.

I had a bad experience my first visit, but went back and sat at the bar and had a fantastic time. The bartenders were wonderful and the service/food was great. I love the dark lighting and tropical ambiance inside.

man i really like thier approach to indian food. The corn and curry soup was a winner, the naan was outstanding, and the little pastries filled with yogurt were differnt and very tasty.
We had the goat with rice and spiced lamb. both were execllent. This place fills up fast - we arrived at 5 and were like 2 of 10 in the place. By the time our appetizes came it was packed and people were waiting. 

great ambiance, up scale indian dining experience. better than most in the area. return trip in order.

Solid choice for breakfast at the airport. The pork roll Sandwich is a phila exclusive and well worth ordering. We also had the Montecristo - which is an usual combination with maple syrup for dunking - actually a really good sandwich. A variety of bloody Mary options are available - rounding out the menu for those of us that are headed out on vacation. 

All in all- not bad. Not at all

Here during festival - the oyster sandwich for $12 was lackluster. Way to much mustard- all you could taste- even overwhelmed the bacon. They need to rethink that. The rubarb cocktail was pretty good- a keeper . 

Server good-  if overwhelmed.

Bartender and manager on duty were nice and friendly.  Food was prepared and delivered for takeout in a timely manner. The food was just bad....we ordered...

the pork wontons - overcooked and no flavor including salt

Crab puffs - no better than frozen food aisle crab puffs

Sesame chicken - tasteless and soggy

Shrimp pad Thai - was the only decent dish we had once we add Chile paste and a squeeze of lime.

There are way better LOCAL Asian businesses to support in Tucson than here.

I've been to a few Ale Houses in my day and this one is pretty good. Located right near the Willow Grove turnpike exit (NOT where the pin sent me!) and the Home Depot. Big parking lot.

Inside was a bit noisy but the place is clean and welcoming with a large number of tables and booths. I took a stool at the bar, where I asked the bartender for a recommendation on beer. He knew his stuff and I was impressed. I had a great Belgian import with a good kick to it.

For a late snack, I chose the potstickers which seemed to be the least fried/greasy option on the nibbles menu. Yes, they also have huge salads and sandwiches and burgers and wings. Six stuffed dumplings on a bed of lettuce with a lot of sauce drizzled over it. They were okay - I wouldn't have 'em again.

A decent place to have an after work beer or a full meal. Open until late hours!
As McD's go, this one is good. The parking lot was well marked, there was no trash to be seen, the drive-thru line moved quickly, my order was taken and delivered accurately. I'd say "A-OK."

Einstein's has some breakfast competition here with a *$ across the street and a DD a few storefronts away. But they seem to be rocking it with good service and decent bagels. I had the sliced salmon on a toasted everything bagel and it was top notch. It's not the greatest bagel in the world, but it was as good as any Einstein that I've ever had.

Refillable coffee? And it's good coffee? Yes, please!

The first four times I ate here the food was great! I enjoyed everything that I had tried. I even told friends to eat there. The last time I went it was at 5pm when the place was empty. There were no customers and every table was dirty. There were flies flying all around the place, and I happened to look at the service area to the left of the bar. The floor was covered in dirty cardboard with black smears all over it! Yuck! 

I have a friend who went there to do some after hours work and he told me that what he saw in the service area and kitchen was disgusting! 

I would check their rating with the health department before you eat there again. I will never go back again!

The food was good but I'm not returning until the menus are updated. Most of the menu items listed are incomplete in my opinion. And while the rolls list the ingredients contained on the inside, the outside could be a surprise. My rating is fair for the overall taste but also for my expectations (based on the menu alone) not being met. What I mean is that, a menu should tell you what your meal contains and if it doesn't, you can't expect that the consumer will be happy. I don't like ordering something and getting something unexpected.

For example, we ordered a couple of rolls based on the ingredients listed: cotton candy and vegas. And while they list the main ingredients, you don't know what the sauce or toppings are. So, if you're avoiding something for I don't know, allergy reasons, you may be surprised so ask in advance. 

Interesting and innovative rolls but deceiving to a degree.

I am a little torn as to how I should rate my first Pi experience. My friends constantly rave about this place so figured I should give it a whirl. My perspective is slightly biased considering the only other Chicago-style pizza I've eaten came from...well, Chicago. That being said - it was a decent pie. The crust was delicious but thought the toppings could've been a tad more flavorful. They did have a delicious beer (unfortunately by Schlafly) that I enjoyed (Kolsch). 

The service was average. It was relatively packed for a weeknight. 
Yelp only has whole number rating systems...otherwise I would give Pi a 3.5 versus 3. However, I will be returning to try the other specialty pizza (again nameless) and give Pi another opportunity to satisfy me to the fullest extent.

Service is avg, it's a chain so nothing special. Ribs were ok had a half of rack. I only go for when children eat free tuesdays. So three adults 3 children eat free. It's fine when you want something quick.

Went before going to see philly pops. Had shrimp cocktail which is shrimp cocktail nothing diffrent. Friend had the wedge that was very good. Had the bone porter house medium. Came out little rare. It.was still tasty, friend had Brazilian lobster, 108 bucks lol. It was a 20 Oz nice size but to me lobster is lobster. Had the king crab gnocchi which ok, potatoes au gratin was good asparagus was fresh. 
Service was a little slow, but it was really crowded. I sort of like the capital grill better still. I most likely would not go out of my way to come back here.

It was crazy noisy as well
Meh. Overpriced gringo food for rich white folks who don't want to venture out of their beloved Foothills for some real Mexican food. Location is beautiful, happy hour is a decent deal but...meh.

I love this place. We've gone there for Christmas some years when we didn't have plans. They have great breakfast, great green chile burgers, and even Mexican food that is pretty good. Lots of homestyle comfort food, too. I was pretty disappointed the one time recently that I tried one of their pies - canned peaches, boo.
Definitely better Chinese/Japanese places in the area. The food here isn't anything special and the service is terrible. Won't be back.

Bourbon, BBQ, Beans, and a Bacon Brownie. Moving to Philadelphia from Texas had some drawbacks...I missed great but inexpensive Mexican food and BBQ. Well now I just miss the Mexican food. 

Fette Sau would be right at home in the Texas Hill country. Perfect ambiance, great smells emanating from the pit, and a friendly staff. Having a new BBQ pit is a lot like having sex for the 1st time. It's good, kind of awkward getting used to, but definitely gets better with time. The best pits in Texas have been seasoned for over 50 years and you can taste the history in every smoke ring on the brisket...low and slow is the only way (also like sex). Fette Sau is very good but will only get better. The sauces on the table will accommodate any taste from Texas, Memphis, Kansas City and Carolina style BBQ. And the links pay homage to Philly being more of a spicy Italian sort compared to the traditional southern sausage.

Two things go well with BBQ...whiskey and beer. Fette Sau hits the mark on both. A vast whiskey selection (I had a nice Rye straight up), and a decent beer selection. They even have little vials of water with droppers in them to "open up" the whiskey. I felt right at home listening to the great music and getting my hands good and greasy. Well done!

Albeit the beer and fries are all right, I always wondered why I've never seen anyone in here...although the bartender behind the bar who finds it a terrible inconvenience to acknowledge you even though you are the only person here...or maybe it's because you have a half dozen better places to eat or drink within a hundred yards. I think that places like this rely heavily on the naïve tourist who wanders in now and then and could care less about repeat business from the locals.  This place reminds me of Eulogy a few blocks away...I think that they utilize the same customer service training regiment for their bartenders.

Amazing architecture and layout. Service is what you would expect at a place that is over $100.00 per person for cocktails, apps, main, sides, and desert. 

My critique starts with the horrible music. I think they have on some waitstaffs iPod on shuffle with a mish-mash of pop music. If you are going to play loud music in an establishment like this, may I suggest classical, or anything from the rat pack or better still a live pianist on a grand piano. Next comes the cold bread and the less than stellar tuna tartare that was fresh over two days ago.

The steak was perfectly cooked and well rested and the wedge was spot on. Unfortunately I probably will not return as I think Barclays Prime attention to every detail blows away Del Frisco's.

Service was nice. The wait staff were all kind. It's just unfortunate that food was unsanitary. I ordered their popular crispy chicken appetizer and found strands of hair in my chicken. At first I thought it was chicken hair and was not going to say anything. But after closer observation it was actually human hair. So I pointed it out to our waitress and she apologized and brought it back to the kitchen for a new one. We waited about 5 minutes and they brought it out, so obviously I look it over again and THE HAIR WAS STILL THERE. I don't think they even switched out my dish but just brought the same thing out again. Long story short they took the meal off my check and apologized for it but I don't think I will return again.

This place only takes cash and they have a weird setting inside! It's super hot and stuffy. There are products stacked around everywhere making it look like they tried to make a small warehouse into a "cafe" by putting a few ugly chairs and tables around. I'm not asking for a place to be pretentious or anything but maybe if they could make it seem like they are trying to be somewhat presentable. Went there to study with my buddy once and I felt like a kid again having to do my homework in the back of a sweatshop.

Great for a lazy night when you don't want to make dinner but also have a great cheap Chinese food. This is the place for that! We call in and by the time we get there the food is done, the staff is sweet and friendly and will give you your food just the way you order it.

The Basics: Haiku is a sushi spot located in downtown Tampa. There is indoor dining as well as an outdoor patio. There is a hip bar/club vibe to this restaurant and it seems like they are looking to be a fun bar with good food as opposed to a spot you go just to enjoy a great meal.

Things I like: The food was overall very good. I enjoyed everything we ordered. I particularly liked the Steamed Pork Gyoza, Pork Sticky Ribs, and the Torch Hamachi Roll. The sushi rolls we ordered were very good, but there is more of an emphasis on creating creative sushi rolls here than having quality fish available. The menu doesn't really emphasize any Sashimi/ Nigiri (says available upon request), which would better showcase the quality of the fish used. 

Things I didn't like: I wanted more of a quiet dinner environment and that is not what you find here. The patio music was extremely loud at 5pm on a Friday evening. This is something I never normally care about, but I couldn't hear those at my table. I asked if the volume could possibly be lowered and the waiter said that they would not do it. I would have liked to see much more care placed on the comfort of their guests. Additionally, the sushi rolls were creative, but the quality was not at a level where I would be excited to return to the restaurant. 

Overall, Haiku emphasizes having a fun bar environment more than the quality of their food. This is a nice place to hang out with friends, but I wouldn't come here just for the food. There is better sushi available in Tampa at a better price as well.

Don't get the steaks.. Two prime rib specials and they were both overcooked.  One party complained about the overcooked steak and was offered a filet cut replacement which was again overcooked.  I didn't want another steak.. took one for the team ..the waitress was fine and the joint was jumping.. but just don't order a steak!

Walked in and female host was rude immediately. Refused to sit my group of 8. Place was extremely empty. We asked to sit outside and she said she couldn't do that but she could sit us inside. She was unprofessional and rude. Bad employee. I've been here 100 times. Won't be back, I'll take my group of 8 elsewhere happily. 

Let me know when she's no longer working there. I'll start coming back. What a joke. Rude lady.

On a sunday Morning this place got packed very quickly. I felt my veggie wedgies dish was very bland. The wedges were a bit under cooked, but at the most flavor. The avocado was not that fresh, there was  minimal cheese, i asked for an over easy egg to add on and it was sunny side that was kinda raw. Barely any flavor to this dish, i had to throw on salt and some other sauces. Over all, i was just not that impressed. I tried a piece of my friends waffle with chicken and hot sauce, it was okay but felt drowned in hot sauce. Cute spot tho, it might be better for sweets.

This was my first time visiting Koizi. We have lived in Tampa for almost 9 years and just recently heard about their endless hibachi & sushi. They do take reservations, 1-2 days in advance. This could help you avoid a long wait. We went for lunch on a Saturday, and there was a 45 minute wait for a table. They have a special lunch menu with limited items, but very large selection. My husband and I tried a little bit of everything. The sushi just didn't do it for me. I only tried 2 of them before I gave up. The dancing crab roll was recommended, and it was just ok. I wasn't really expecting the WOW factor due to it being endless, which to me means a little bit of lower quality. I also tried the crazy salmon roll, which tasted like tuna fish. I only finished it because I didn't want to get charged for leftovers. We split the coconut chicken, which was heavily breaded and topped with a coconut sauce. I think from the small plate they brought out there was honestly 1 large piece of chicken, and the rest was fried batter. The Mongolian beef was flavorful, spicy, but drenched in sauce. We swear there was a whole onion included on the plate. The portions of the hibachi were the perfect serving, so you didn't over eat, and leave too much behind. For a $11 per person, endless lunch, this wasn't terrible. Will I be back soon? Not in too much of a rush, but would eat there again. Don't expect fast service. If you order hibachi items, they take about 15-20 min to come out. Sushi was averaging about 10 minutes, even though it was already pre-made. I felt like I did a lot of waiting around.

This place was formerly called "Gott Gormet" & I'm not sure if they are affiliated or not but seems like they just changed the name to draw interest... I ordered a sandwich as a hangover remedy once from Gott Gormet (through Nola food delivery)- it was fine.  We made the mistake of going here on a Friday night recently. It was empty. This place should not even be open for dinner. It's a sandwich or maybe breakfast place. They advertised breakfast anytime but we were unable to order breakfast that night for some reason. Due to the lack of appealing items on the menu, everyone ordered the shrimp & grits which were not inedible but they also were not worth the calories! I ordered the Mac and cheese & it was the same. Overall, I would not recommend this place at all, but if I had to, I would say lunch or breakfast (not dinner!!).

The specialty Dosa brunch seems to be their forte but having experienced only their weekday lunch I will comment on that only.

They pretty much use the same curry in everything, and it isn't noteworthy or even payment worthy, though certainly edible. You can get better food at most Indian restaurants.

The service is attentive, ambience is so-so.

If I crave Dosa and can get myself out of the house on a warm summer Saturday, I might go try it, but not the regular fare again.

Ordered a cheese pizza with five toppings, all meat. Fair, no complaints, except it arrived past 4 PM whereas we were settled in by 3 PM. The server could not explain clearly what The Bucket was, specifically if the five rums were blended or separate. Avoid, it's just a bucket of ice and juice from a box. The beer sampler was terrible as well.

I have been coming here since I moved to Nashville over 8 years ago, and it still continues to be a thing that I crave more often than I care to admit. Make sure you order the app sampler, that comes with a salsa (go for the red!), guac, queso, and all the chips your heart desires for $10. Can't go wrong with any of their margaritas, but I like the house El Vez. I have neverrrrr put a sad taco in my mouth here. Are they authentic mexican tacos? Nope. I wouldn't even call them Tex-Mex. Think more along the lines of what kind of tacos you want to see when you eat non hispanic food. I always get the glorious, double decker, taco royale and the spicy crunchy asian-y general homeboy. Yesterday I went a bit crazy and got the gyro taco and mannnn was I happy. Leave in an almost coma or you're not doing it right. Also, try to come on a weeknight. Even with all the taco spots in Nashville, this place is consistently packed on weekends. That alone should tell you that this place is delicious. I will always be back!

Came today with out of town friends - was pleasantly surprised to learn that Party Fowl has a brunch menu. There wasn't a wait on a Sunday early afternoon so we were seated right away.

***TIP*** if you check in on Yelp, you get a free app with purchase of two entrees Monday-Thursday 


Our server, J, was very attentive to our needs and was awesome!! She was very quick to refill our drinks and was very friendly.

Our group got the chicken tenders with fries - we all picked varying spice flavors and loved our food! My boyfriend loved the boozy slushee that he ordered - he got the cherry limeade flavor. 

Pros:
Lots of seating, minimal wait time
Great brunch and traditional hot chicken options 
Great service 
Good drink selections (beers, cocktails, slushies) 
Parking available across the street and at restaurant

Oh brother, why is it so hard to find good Mexican food and good customer service?  Service was slow, but there was only one gal trying to serve all of the tables in the bar,  if they would simply increase their happy hour wait staff, problem solved! My first taste test was the guacamole, fail.  So bland.  My quesadilla was fine but our friends were disappointed in their meals.  We aren't a tough crowd to please, but we won't be back.

The food is disgusting and the restaurant part smells like a stale cigarette because they have a bar next door where they allow smoking. The whole area is just run down. I had a pulled pork sandwich. Almost immediately after finishing my stomach started churning and later I threw it up. The people working there go next door to smoke... Do you even wash your hands afterward?! YUCK. The ice cream machine is always "broken" or "temporarily unavailable for cleaning."
What's not to love about The Joint? Nothing. It's great. Fast, friendly, and no reservation needed in the middle of covid. Hard to find these days. Thank you to the staff for a wonderful experience.

We don't usually get dessert with dinner and wine, but here, it's a MUST, and I'm talking about the Belgium waffle dessert! They make it fluffy, so it's not as thick and filling as a regular Belgium waffle, but has the same great taste topped with delicious ice cream! 

The menu does not have descriptions, so definitely ask the wait staff about anything you want! Our waitress was extremely knowledgeable and explained several of the appetizers and entrees to us in order to make a decision. The extensive wine list is also in Italian, and I usually drink Napa Valley Cabernets, so the waitress recommended one of the best wines I've ever had! 

They serve a variety of salad, pasta, seafood, and meat entrees along with a large selection of bruschetta, meat, and cheese appetizers. 

Appetizer must: Sal's famous meatballs with tomato covered potato. You get three juicy meatballs with a little potato underneath them, and the flavors were impeccable!

We were looking for pasta and had the ricotta and tonnarelli dishes. Both were outstanding. While other reviews mentioned "generous" portions, I would categorize them as below average for what we usually receive at high-end Italian restaurants. We both finished our plates and could have eaten more, whereas usually I cannot finish an entire pasta entree. This was even after consuming one appetizer, fresh bread (provided to all patrons but with no dipping oil), and our complimentary side (described below).

The service was top notch! Besides our waitress being attentive and knowledgeable with everything, we were offered a complimentary side that we shared while waiting for our meals because the chef was not happy with how the entrees resulted. Therefore, he started over while we enjoyed the side. We greatly appreciated this level of service! 

I'm surprised it's rated $$$ because most entrees were $16-20 a piece minus a few exceptions. We got a bottle of wine, two entrees, one appetizer, and one dessert for $115 plus tip! The ambiance was upscale, yet we saw people wearing anything from t-shirts and flip flops to dressy. 

They have $18 valet that is the best option unless you want to park and walk quite a bit. They had outdoor tables, but we opted for inside as outside seating is on the sidewalk by where everyone arrives, walks by, and valet.

We enjoyed our date night and would definitely go back as we are huge fans of the Vetri restaurants!

This was my second time at Barbuzzo, and probably my last.  The place was pretty crowded, but all the servers seemed to be handling it well... except for mine.  It took at least 15 minutes for drink orders, and then another 10 minutes to get said drinks.  The wine selections looked promising, but none of the wines I had matched the tasting notes very well, and all of them seemed really one dimensional.

Once ordered, though, the food came out in a reasonable amount of time. Unfortunately, it wasn't very good... I'm not very sensitive to saltiness, but three out of our four dishes seemed to think salt was a substitute for actual developed flavor.  The chickpeas and shishitos were drenched in a salty spice rub, and the chickpeas were still in their shells - "like edamame," the server said.  Too bad that chickpeas are too mushy to eat like a soybean - they don't pop out of the shell and into your mouth so much as get mangled in the process.

I also had the gnocchi with corn, wood mushrooms, baby tomatoes, and truffle butter.  Again, the gnocchi themselves were flat, as were the tomatoes.  The corn had flavor, but it just tasted like corn... and some of the wood mushrooms were tough and inedible.  The truffle butter itself had absolutely no truffle flavor, but again, was over-salted.

It's a shame - the menu looks great, but the execution just isn't there.

Small, loud, dirty, and rude. My $ 13 ham and cheese sandwich was greasy, and the batter on the accompanying fried pickles was so salty they were inedible. 

Besides the lack luster cuisine, the waitress went from slightly aloof to downright rude when we asked for the check. She kept walking past us and ignoring us..... After 15 minutes, my card in my hand in the air, she put threw check down when I wasn't looking. She then resumed her walking-by-and-ignoring thing, so we went to the bar and paid. 

I have no need to go back to this place- I got the full tour on my first visit,and that was quite enough.

Maybe it was because it was restaurant week.... but they flipped our table faster than McDonald's, despite the server's assertion that the table was ours for the rest of the night.

The good: service was extremely friendly.

The not-so good: we had our appetizers and entrees within 18 minutes of sitting down, and were handed the check within 40 minutes.  The tables around us were served at a similar lightning-fast pace.

The food was just OK - there was no complexity of flavor to anything from the prosciutto-wrapped-gorgonzola-stuffed dates to the strip steak.  While nothing was over-salted, the only source of flavor was salt.

The noise level in the restaurant was deafening, and we were practically on top of the table next to us. Maybe it was just because it was restaurant week, but given the noise level and the mediocre food, I'm not sure I'd be back.

Service just depends on your luck of the draw. We have had some really good night's and some really bad nights. Food is good, but is a bit pricey when we get down to the fact we are talking about burgers.

Been here 4 times now, so some what qualified to give a review.

Pros: top notch beer selection, nice TVs

Cons: Only go here for Blues, Cards, or MU. Otherwise it's not a true sports bar because they prefer old music to the actual games on the sound system. Never really liked the food, but most food is subpar in St. Charles county. The last time I got sick from the food so I won't be back.

I've been here several times for lunch, and the service definitely needs to be improved. It's ridiculously SLOOOOW.  I came here with seven others today. Luckily, we were able to seat right away. 

PROS - Really like their burgers, sweet potato fries, and quesadillas. 

CONS - There was one hostess/server/food runner for the whole restaurant. Ya heard me. ONE! Then it took 12 minutes to get our drinks (for 8 people), and a total of 30 minutes to get our food! Yikes!

My advice - Come here when you're not in a rush! Food is decent.

Updating my review after coming back here a couple of times and absolutely hating it. First off, their brunch deal is a joke! I think it's $36 for 6 mimosas, an entree, and game time. The mimosas were disgusting. All orange juice. My boyfriend even got a double screw driver and it was so bad. Even outside of brunch, their drink cocktails are gross! And they're pricey. The food was fine, but afterwards my whole party felt sick - don't know if the food upset our tummy or the straight OJ we drank. 

The service was terrible. Our waitress straight up forgot we existed. I don't like it here. I've tried to many times. It could be SO good. There's so much potential, but I do not recommend and won't be back.

Have been coming here for years. Delightful lunch place frequented by locals, but travelers are most welcome. Home-made desserts and history all over the walls. The former chef is now the owner. The menu is a chalkboard on the wall. Offers views of the river. Come early. There's usually a wait at lunch time.

My husband just called to order me dinner as I was just finishing up a 12hr shift at the hospital. At 9:05pm he was told they had shut off the grill. He asked if 10pm was their closing time. Yes. So no, 10pm is not your closing time if the grill is off. We'll go elsewhere from now on.

Still hungry from the burger place, I stopped to get some T-ravs on the way home. Phoned the order in. The waiter told me 25 minute wait. Place was packed with several people sitting outside. Fun, upbeat atmosphere with not-so-bright Edison lighting and a Cardinals game on the tv over the bar. 10 toasted ravioli set me back about $10. They were lukewarm at best, but I might have been a little late. Good flavor, soft, not crispy, not a lot of meat. Came with bread, no butter. Kind of a strange place for a sit down, fancier Italian restaurant to be in a strip mall. They seem to have a good fan base. Wouldn't mind coming back for a date night some time.

Disappointing. No samosas and a relatively small selection. The rice was old and dry. I tried an assortment. Nothing was particularly good and nothing was particularly bad -- except for the butter chicken. That pink mess tasted like generic meat butter soup rather than an actual dish. 

The naan was good, if you're ok with grease. Yes, naan is fried, but does it have to be so oily? No.

Pretty bad service today. Not half full, servers chatting with each other. Several tables not happy. 

We waited forever for a table, got our drinks quickly, then was basically ignored by server. 20 minutes to order??? That's baloney....and definitely not the good  service we've had before. Very disappointing.

Nice little cafe, tucked away in a corner at the Eldorado.  I have eaten here twice in the past couple weeks and service was quick and the food was very good.  Because it is in a corner and dimly lit, it wasn't too busy, and it was nice to get away from the hustle and bustle of the casino and other folks heading to the Buffet.  

I had the french dip both times and both times it was great. The french fries were crispy and well drained--no extra oil clogging them up!

A nice place to stop and take a quick breather.

i'd give it 2 1/2 stars. but not 3. having worked at a starr rest, maybe i'm just bitter. but, i just dont think the food tastes good. i'm not a fan of any of his places.  i tend to find them too gimmicky and over priced. jones is just mediocre. its pretty. but i see no reason to eat here.

I've been meaning to brunch at Delicia for the last 3 years and now I'm so disappointed it took me this long! The Bloody Mary's are made in house and are delicious, they have a chili salt rim that really adds to it! I got the chorizo hash and would definitely recommend it, although I do wish there was slightly more chorizo in it to balance out the sweetness of the plantains. 

The restaurant is beautiful and the staff was fantastic. Will definitely be making this one of my go-to brunch spots!
