A coworker recommended this place so I decided to place a to-go order. The caprese salad is unlike one I've had before and it is  orgasmic (and that's just the salad!). Wish I had bought the full size. Also tried the truffle mac and cheese (another party in my mouth) and the Athens (greek) pizza. I have a friend that makes an amazing greek pizza but this one comes in at a close second. And they deliver. Yes, that includes booze. Too bad I'm working!

I hadn't been to Tarpon Springs in more than a decade but I was looking forward to getting back up there for some good Greek food following a local show. Unfortunately, the local show ended at 10:30p and everything in T.S. closes between 9 and 10p, even on a Saturday night! As we cruised down the sponge docks slowly looking for signs of life within restaurants, I spotted Hellas Bakery, brightly lit with workers behind the counter. We parked and ran in, through the bakery into the adjoining restaurant where a hostess still stood behind her podium. She regretfully informed us however that the restaurant was closed and only the bakery remained open. Sadly, we wandered back outside where we stood on the sidewalk, contemplating our options: bar food or Awful Waffle. Things were looking bleak until the Manager (or perhaps he was the owner?) came outside and explained to us that although the kitchen was shut down and most of the food put away, if we wanted simple items such as salads or gyros, they would accommodate us. So he escorted us into the empty restaurant and told us to take our time. Our waiter, who I expected would be irritated at having to stay later to wait on us, was VERY gracious and also let us know that we shouldn't feel hurried to eat our food. My friends had gyros which they said were quite good. I was perfectly happy with a generous plate of marinated feta, olives, and warm, crusty bread. And the home-made Greek dressing on my salad was the best I've ever had! Ever! We left happy and full and I have every intention of returning to Hellas to enjoy a cooked meal the next time I make it up to Tarpon. Hopefully sooner than 10 years later. To Hellas, thank you again for feeding us after you were closed! Now THAT'S hospitality!

I went here with my sister based on the reviews. I hang out in Gulfport almost every Wed night and like to grab a chicken quesadilla and irish coffee at O'Maddys before swing dancing but this was the first time coming around for breakfast. I love the area! We went on a Thursday morning at 8:30am so we were the only ones there but even so, I expected it could be a wait for the food. Still, I would have preferred to get our drinks (iced Thai coffee) as soon as they were ready but the they waited until our food was ready before delivering any of it to our table outside, which was about 15 minutes. 
Again based on reviews, we ordered the Lisa bowl (can't go wrong with goat cheese), a breakfast wrap and the dish with rice, chai tea, honey, avocado and toasted coconut. Yes, the servings were small by  gorging American standards but the portions were reasonable. We didnt walk away full but still satisfied. And yes, everything was very fresh and tasty.  The Lisa Bowl was good but not mindblowing and after a bite of my sister's breakfast wrap, found myself wishing I had ordered that instead. However the rice dish was delightful! And it looks very simple to make so I may try my hand at it (by boiling rice in chai tea, drizzling it with honey and topping with avocado and toasted coconut). 
The coffee was a disappointment though, which I did not expect. I too have a freezer full of coffee ice cubes because I like iced coffee that is not "watered down" by regular ice cubes. So in that respect, Tea and Me is doing it right but my iced Thai coffee was luke warm, with coffee cubes melting in what was obviously fresh brewed HOT coffee. I have a cold brew system at home so I expected that a place that knows enough to ice coffee cubes would also cold brew (or brew and chill) their coffee for cold orders. 
There is wi-fi and a seating area outside so you can sip and work (or study) but no view to speak of since this spot is not along the water. 
Overall it's the sort of place that I would frequent if I lived in the neighborhood but not go out of my way for.

I'm a fan of my own homemade cold brew and healthy breakfast but when I ran short on time this morning I decided to give this place a try based on reviews. And I agree with all of them! The staff is friendly and efficient even in that limited space. The coffee is better than I expected. my order was complicated and I changed my mind twice and they still got it right haha! And the avocado toast was flavorful. I choked a bit when the bill was over $15 plus the tip pushing it to $17. Not some place I could afford more than once a week but for a treat, absolutely.

Hall & Oats, The Hooters and Elton John singing "Philadelphia Freedom" (or phreedom) are all part of The Local atmosphere. Situated in the center of terminal F you will find this cafe/restaurant. Order from an iPad [what happened to service with a smile] and hope to get your water glass refilled and a request, if you need anything such as an extra napkin or ketchup. I had the veggie burger and it was hot and tasted good. Optional sides were available for an upcharge so I stuck with the fries that came with the meal, since I paid $1 for a slice of cheese to be added to the burger. Not bad but not much service included in the service charge.

I have been here only once but will most probably never go back. I ordered the lunch special with two sliders and fries. The sliders were dry and the patties got lost in the bun. The fries were very greasy and did not taste right. The order arrived very late and looking at the kitchen area, it seemed like nobody in the kitchen area knew what they were doing. This is despite the fact that there were customers on only a few tables. I don't want to imagine the wait and the chaos in the kitchen if they had to prepare many orders. I am not sure how this place will survive in a location where there are are other restaurants that excel at service and food offering. 

One thing I liked was the outside seating at the entrance and open seating in the upstairs. The other positive was that the owner of the place came and asked us about feedback on our experience but unfortunately he seemed uninterested in what we had to say about our experience. As we were pointing to the things that we did not like, he kept saying .."but otherwise everything was good?" .. he just did not want to accept that we were not happy. He pointed to the fact that they just opened the place and it was their first week and they are figuring out how to run the place smooth etc. which made me feel worse because i felt like a test subject.

It's an odd building that's kind of withdrawn from the street, and the entrance on the side doesn't really look like one. Inside, it's nice enough, and their music selection was easier on my ears than a lot of Indian places.

The dosa I came for was not bad, but if I'm being honest, my AirBnb host made me a better one. The potato masala inside was piping hot, but the sambar on the side for dipping was quite cold, not a good thing on a frigid night, and the vadai I ordered when my first choice appetizer was unavailable were a bit dry and didn't seem fresh.

The lunch buffet was a rather different experience. Nothing South Indian in that, it was small and fairly basic, but my chickpeas and spinach pakoras were quite tasty. I still have yet to order some of the more interesting dinner items.

Given that this is about the only place I could find that even offers South Indian (along with their more common North Indian curries), I let them off easy. It wasn't disastrous, but I could have reasonably hoped for better.

The place is small, with sketches all over the walls (hence the name). That makes for an interesting ambiance, but If you love burgers then this place is like heaven! Choose from a sirloin beef, American Kobe, turkey, or vegan burger. Then choose your toppings, state your preferred temperature, order a side of hand cut fries with a shake, and you are all set. You will receive a perfectly cooked to order juicy burger that will put a smile on your face. The American Kobe cooked medium rare with cheddar cheese is my personal favorite. If I lived in Fishtown I would be a regular here.

The new High Street is more of a to go café than a restaurant. I went there for lunch with a friend and we sat at one of only two tables inside, after placing our orders. There are a couple more tables outside. I ordered the Turkey Goddess, a turkey sandwich with b&g pepper aioli, lettuce, tomato, on a sesame bun. The aioli was outstanding and elevated the sandwich well beyond the normal dry turkey sandwich. It was sooo delicious! I'll definitely go back to order it again, as it's my new favorite turkey sandwich. I also added a slice of cake, which was so unmemorable that I can't remember what kind of cake I had. I forgot to take pictures.

I can't give the new High Street 5 stars because it's not the same overall 5 star experience of the previous restaurant. But the turkey goddess is a 5 star sandwich.

This Cosi has gone downhill in recent months. It seems they put less chicken in the buffalo bleu than they used to and it can be cold instead of room temperature. They put less dressing on it too. What was one of my favorite lunch sandwiches is now just... average.  The chips are stale half the time. I'm going to have to cut this location out of my lunch rotation.

Gabi was my choice for center city restaurant week,  fall of 2021. This French restaurant had a 3 course menu that represents a good deal despite the increase to $40 for restaurant week menus. I started off with the French onion soup. There was a bit of a chill in the air the night I went,  so this hot,  tasty,  cheesy bowl of soup really hit the spot. My entree was the steak frites. The steak was a perfectly cooked medium. So tender and so juicy! With a peppercorn sauce that made it even better. The fries were fresh and cooked to the perfect crispness. I don't think I have had the dish done any better. My dessert was a chocolate cake with  some kind of coffee icing. A unique icing choice, but it worked to provide a nice sweet ending to my meal. My friend insisted I try her eclaire. It was awful! Rock hard and tasteless. I would think it must taste better fresh, but this one was not fresh and I wish I hadn't tried it. 

I like the decor at Gabi. My meal was awesome, but I can't pretend I didn't try the eclair.  Service was also spotty. Everyone was very nice but we were forgotten about a couple of times when we needed something. Gabi has the potential to be a 5 star dining destination, but it's not quite there yet.

I've been here a couple times and it's above average but nothing to rave about. It's a good low key sports bar/restaurant. The meatloaf was pretty good but the chicken pot pie was delicious! Not enough food for me, but an appetizer will take care of that next time. It's an easy place to meet visitors to Tampa since it's right off the interstate.

One we couldn't find the place right away.  And 2nd we had to ask someone where it was since there was no visible sign.  

I ordered the half sandwich and soup combo.  The half was as big as a regular sandwich.  The bread bowl soup was pretty good had broccoli and cheddar, I must say some of the best tasting soup I had in a long time.

It was pretty dark in the place, but I could tell they must do pretty good since the place was pack.

Our meal came out pretty fast although I read in the menu that sometimes your wait time can be longer than expected.

OMG MY favorite somen aka Ramen as some people call it.  I usually get the homemade noodle with the beef slices.  I am crazy I love to eat with a bowl of rice, thats just the filipino in me...LOL  

Everytime I go there hasn't been a line but I can see how they can be crowded at times.

Really slow and unorganized service, was not busy at all.. Waited 35 minutes to get a coke, 45 min for an appetizer which were spring rolls... food comes out 3 min after the spring rolls which made no sense at all. Orange chicken was crunchy on the outside and chewy on the inside definitely frozen and way too sweet/too much sauce. Don't recommend to anyone who is hungry

Just walking in makes you feel nostalgic. The bakery area is pretty small but to watch the action on that morning with all of the locals and the workers was a sight to see. 

We had guava turnovers, rainbow cookies, and good old standard Cuban toast with butter. Rainbow cookies were dreadful as we figured they would be. Dry as a brick, lacking apricot jam, and just the wrong overall tonality of food coloring. Ok, with that out of the way let's move on to the excellence which were the guava turnovers. The guava preserves in this turnover were unlike any other I've had. The standard guava pastries have that generic Goya style guava pastry which- I won't lie- does the trick- however at La Segunda we're talking about something else here. It was just different- like more velvety and carried with itself more viscosity. It was awesome to say the least. The Cuban toast- as simple as it may be- was purely bliss. The bread was toasted perfectly and the butter slathered on was the right amount. Yeah- it's as simple as can be, however simplicity still has its place is my heart considering how complex and at times fraudulent the culinary world has become today.

Will we back- c'mon now.
Good, well thought out menu but more expensive than I will pay for JUST good sushi. Best choice however within the USF proximity.

There's much hype for banana leaf and so we decided to try it out. "F"! Ok, not a "F" but a C-, maybe? The food lacked the overall spice expected from Malaysian food. 

Most likely won't go again but on a side note the presentation of the food was nice, the quarters itself were clean, and the people were extremely friendly and nice. I want this place to do well for itself just for those reasons alone.

Are you kidding me? A pizza chain THIS good? Yes, indeed. It was by far the best 
pizza I've had to date in this area of (Horsham, Willow Grove, Northeast Philadelphia). 

We had half an eggplant and half a spicy sausage, hot pepper, and caramelized onion cheese and sauce pie.

The dough was burnt but still pliable. It was perfectly burnt. The toppings were also nicely charred, especially the eggplant and the hot peppers. The sauce was naturally sweet (no sugar added) and the cheese was bubbly, gooey, and stretchy. Again. perfect.

We also had their coal fired rosemary chicken wings. Charred as well but perfectly done.

As far as I'm concerned, if you're in the area and in the mood for pizza- you should ride on over to Anthony's. Any other pizza joint around here would be wasting your time, and even worse, your hard earned cash.
Great cheesesteak and cheese fries. Service was pretty friendly and fast. Would have liked the fries a bit crispier.

Food quality has evened out, and is decent. Not "real" but still, not bad. You get a decent bang for your buck for portion size.
Only two issues I've encountered recently: the cashier described the spam burger special to me incorrectly - she told me it was a burger with an egg and grilled spam.
It ended up that it was two inch or more thick slices of grilled spam with a fried egg in between. As it was a to go order, I didn't realize this until I had gotten to work. Ultimately it ended up being a real pain to eat, as spam isn't the most compressible substance out there.
What really annoyed me was that I ordered a spam musubi with the spam burger. I walked out with my order, then looked and realized that I didn't have the musubi. I went back inside to ask for it, and waited for a few minutes, then the chefs told the servers that they were out.

I guess the cooks saw it on the ticket, knowing that I had paid (as you pay when you order), and just decided to leave it out and not mention it? Unhappy about that.

When they have them, though, get the musubi - cold, nicely vinegared rice, generally a nice side dish. Perhaps not with a giant spam sandwich, but with a burger or a salad, sure!

Went in today for lunch and ordered the "Best." I took my sandwich home to eat and when I opened it up there were only two small slices of pepperoncini peppers and a few slices of meat. When I started eating the sandwich I noticed that the bread tasted different, and there wasn't much spread or oil. 

The service was fine, but I wasn't a fan of the sandwich. I'll stick to eating sandwiches at Tino's on Carrillo Street.

Ginger Bistro is yet another subpar Asian restaurant in the University City loop.  The food and atmosphere are not great.  We tried a cross section of food including sushi, beef bulgolgi, and chicken curry.  The sushi did not taste fresh and the two meat dishes were over priced and over cooked.  

The menu is a mish mash of Korean, Thai, Japanese, Taiwanese, Mongolian, etc.  I hate it when a restaurant tries to do all of these things together.  The result is usually alot of choices with subpar flavor, quality, and authenticity.  

Our waiter was very sweet, but the service was slow and sloppy.  He spilled the curry before setting the bowl down on the table, with curry dripping over the sides.  of the bowl.  When cleaning the table at the end of our dinner service, he asked my dining partner to hold the dirty dishes while he stacked them in her hands.  It seemed like there wasn't much in the way of management or supervision.  Plenty of cameras installed, but no teachers/managers/quality control.  I won't be back.

Neveria La Vallesana is an extremely casual taqueria (authentic taco stand) located on Cherokee Street in the somewhat dodgy, but rapidly improving Benton Park neighborhood.  In the summer, this place is the bustling restaurant on the street. The newly renovated, covered patio is almost as popular as their delicious tacos, tortas, and quesadillas.   When I get a craving for authentic Mexican food from Neveria La Vallesana, it's bad. 
 
Highlights:
- The food is above average in taste and quality of ingredients.  Everything is made from scratch.
- Very Authentic.
- Cheap
- Nice outdoor seating area in the warm weather months
- Excellent Tortas (Mexican sandwiches on fresh baked bread with avocado, onions, and slow stewed meat) - YUM
- Excellent Tacos (soft corn tacos filled with a variety of tender, slow cooked meat options)-To die for!
- Great Quesadilla (filled with pork and pineapple, refried beans, etc.) - Yummy BARGAIN!

Drawbacks:
- The restaurant building is small and not ideal for dining in.
- The neighborhood is eclectic and interesting, but it is a bit dodgy.
- The staff is all Hispanic, so language can be a barrier when ordering.

The King and I might be the longest running Thai Restaurant in St Louis and they are still open!!  They deserve kudos for that!!  They had a face lift a few years ago and it's a little easier to get comfy.  Prices are a little high and the food is pretty Americanized and not spicy.  If you are new to Thai food, this might be a good way to ease your way in.  If you are an experienced Thai foodie, this might be a little underwhelming.  Very busy, not many Thai folks eating here.  Great location, pleasant decor.  Most of the servers are super young.  Service is hit or miss.  If you are taking a group of finicky waters out to dinner, this is likely to be a people pleaser.

Kabul Express is a tiny Afghan restaurant located off the beaten track,  a 1/2 block from Broadway in Lemay.  There only 8-12 seats inside and a table outside, but they made rom for a sofa .  The owner is very friendly.  I had the lamb curry special.  The lamb was very tender and it was spices perfectly.  My dining mate had falafel and samosas, both vegan and the owner surprised him with a complimentary salad.  Everything was good.  My only complaint be that they only have bottled water.  A restaurant that I will visit again!

Yum.  I  just love Thai food and I think Thai Basil Cafe does a decent job of it.  Service is friendly, with a small language barrier.  Water is never empty.  The ambiance is so-so.  They made a fair attempt to decorate, but the workmanship is shotty and the ugly white counter and an uglier refrigerator in the main room dampers whatever ambiance they attempted to create.

The Thai sweet tea is delish and only $1.50.  They have lots of Pad stir fries, curries, and of course , my fav Tom Kha soup.  Tom Kha soup (a spicy coconut cream soup with chicken, lemon grass, galanga, Thai peppers, mushrooms, Thai basil, etc.) is one of those things I must have at least once every six weeks and I have resorted to making it myself because so many of the local restaurants charge so much for it!  You can get a small bowl here for $4.50, which is reasonable.

Still, the menu prices are slightly high (I'm spoiled by the prices at Thai House and Thips Thai - both in Illinois).  Overall, it was a nice experience.  I had a great meal and was very satisfied.

So this place only gets 3 stars.  The place isn't that big and they have lots of high top tables for two. Very uncomfortable when you have to sit for a long time due to slow service. 

We started with green fried tomatoes with goat cheese. Unfortunately there was so much cheese, you could not really taste the tomato or barely see it. 

The BLT with avocado was good but the fries were just warm and finally cold by the time I was half way thru the sandwich. 

Nice looking place inside, needs work either in the kitchen or the servers or probably both.

Someone save me from myself.

711 Bourbon Heat is the perfect example of a bar I should never visit. Imagine loads of tourists and westbankers gyrating to ridiculous music. Then add in smoke, lasers and stairs. Thats right, I said stairs. 

If for some reason you like the atmosphere described above, you are forced to navigate a stairwell that is usually filled with strangers making out. Besides the make out folks, the stairs are rather steep which makes me worry the drunk behind me will fall and create a domino effect of death.

Despite all of this, I have been forced to come here on several occasions against my will. I even asked the staff to call the police, but they just laughed.

If you see me here, rescue me. I will be your best friend.
The best of the 'gay' cuisine. Better than average diner grub and, if Miss Earl is working, the best floor show in town.

LOVE this place. We had my mom's 55th surprise party brunch here and it was amazing. The food is great, service is friendly, and you can't beat the view. It's pricey, so it's a special occasion type place, but worth it! Their Sunday brunch is great, as well as their lunch options. Haven't been for dinner, but would like to. Also heard they have a great happy hour I'm hoping to try. Overall, a great gem you should definitely try!

When I first stepped into the door I thought, oh no, it's a trap!!! What may first appear to be a fast food Asian restaurant is much more. You order at the counter and go sit down. The food is brought to you quickly, while you wait they give you a few chips with duck sauce (You will need to excuse my ignorance on the task style of chips and sauce, but they are good). My wife ordered the pad tai, I got the king pow chicken. The food is much better than a panda express would give you. My wife did not like the pad tai though because it was heavily soy sauce dependent, which is not what you are expecting with pad tai. My kung pow chicken was good, no complaints. 

The food is not high quality but definitely good enough to go back for lunch in the future. For the prices and category this restaurant fits in, a 3.5-4 star rating is appropriate.

Hands down.. The BEST sushi EVER!!! I always thought I had to head over to NYC for some good sushi, but now, all I have to do is cross the Ben Franklin.. and tada~!!! The best part? It's run by real Japanese ppl, not some Viet or Chinese ppl...  The sushi just melts in your mouth.. it's a decent size, you won't feel ripped off and although there was a bit of a wait for the food to be served, it was all worth it~!!! I'd definitely come back again and again...and again.

Service sucked...

Was here after the marathon... They weren't even that busy. Not sure why the chose to have only one bartender there if its the day of the marathon.. She barely looked at us, and had to flag her down to get our FIRST drink and our food.. When the food decided to arrive, we were given no utensils or plates.. We had to literally reach behind the bar to grab plastic utensils!!!  WTH...

Food was delicious! Service was great... Our waitress greeted us with such a warm smile and was very thorough with the menu... She easily talked us into starting with the warm yummy monkey bread!!! Took me awhile to decide what I should get since alot of things on the menu sounded so good... I opt'd to go with the chicken and waffle (if you want to substitute the chicken, white or dark meat, it costs a lil more), hubby got the meatloaf.... The gravy for the chicken was a little bit salty, but other than that, it was delicious!!! Hubby said the meatloaf tasted just like a homemade dish he had at his friends house years ago. Comfort food.. Nice... Everything was amazing. The waitress even said she was glad we finished our food =)

Seating was a lil uncomfortable.. My hubby and I are not big ppl, but we prefer to have more space, a lil roomier.. to be comfy... The two seaters are tight. I'm not being greedy, but next time, i might just ask them for a bigger booth.. 

We'll come back to try their other dishes....

A little better than the last time I was here, but definitely not the good too for Chinese food. 

The store inside is super clean and our food was very fresh. I highly suggest ordering it online and just walking in and picking it up. The chicken egg rolls are worth a try! 

Shout out to the friendly staff.

This is one of my good go-to places for ramen if I'm around the Meridian area. Definitely a solid option for lunch and when it's pretty cold outside. My favorite is their spicy miso ramen with extra pork topping. Don't forget to grab some boba to add to your meal. Overall, service is efficient and friendly staff.

Six slices of self-satisfaction? 
1200 calories of self-depricating pretension? 
Yuppies coming to be at a Starr restaurant, eating pizza with FORK AND KNIFE and sipping on a glass of wine. WTF. 

The only reason I'm giving this spot a 3 instead of a 2 is that it adds a nice crowd to the corner of 2nd and Lombard (way better than Cosi used to). 

Just as I expect from a Starr restaurant, it's made to seem better than it really is. 

I've been a couple of times when I was at Head House and in the mood for pizza and each time the experience was okay. The first time I went, the waitress actually said "The chef recommends...", you've got to be f'ing kidding me, the "pizza chef?" I worked at pizza hut as a teenager and made the pizzas, was I a chef? Oh, I wasn't because Steven Starr wasn't paying me to be awesome. 

All kidding aside, if you're in the area, it's not a bad spot to stop but don't expect the best.

I enjoyed Tango. The decor was nice. We sat in a booth by the window and was cozy and enjoyable watching the trains pass. 
The food was good and well prepared. Service was good. I'd go again.

I used to eat so much fried chicken that 3 years ago I made a new year's resolution to limit it to twice a month, kinda of a running thing I've kept.

After all the hype I heard about this place ("best fried chicken in STL", "won over my health conscious sister", "cured my cancer [but gave me diabetes]") I came in with some heavy expectations. 

Chicken was woefully underseasoned.  A shame because the skin had a nice crispness and the meat was moist and juicy.  Getting the classic 1/2 chicken plate, I thought the mayonnaise-less cole slaw was a nice surprise, but the fries tasted (and looked) like freezer section ore ida fries.

Still, it filled me up and at $7.35 it's value is hard to beat, but I don't think I'll use up my twice a month allowance on Hodak's very often.

Less then expected even for fast food. I ordered blizzards and food for me and my group, watched several people walk out with blizzards while we did not have ours yet. Finally called me for our food and no blizzards had to remind the person what they were and the sizes and wait for them to be made to find maybe 2 pieces of cookie dough in my cookie dough blizzard, and unfortunately as the person tried the upside down "trick" with the blizzard one literally leaked all over. The fries were old and burgers dry as can be. Constant line in the place even though they seemed to have plenty of staff, the term quantity not quality applies here as most of the staff seemed to care less that you were a customer in the establishment. Such a shame for this location as my family enjoys most Dairy Queen locations.

Food is very, very good.  

Called shortly after opening, to place a to-go order.  Pleasant call, I was told 10 minutes.  
Upon arrival, exactly 10 minutes later, my order had not even been started!

Ridiculous and unacceptable.

Came to dinner here with my partner, my brother, and his friend. At first the place felt like a warehouse with some dining chairs and red drapery, but we were seated by the windows in the corner and it seemed less open. I was pleasantly surprised by the food options...we got the cheese fries poutine and we each ordered a different steak. They refer themselves as a cuban steak house...if they mean they are in Ybor City...thats the only Cuban inspiration I saw in the meal. Also being that its in Ybor, I probably will not drive there to go back.

Here's the thing about Southgate:  I didn't think it was Korean enough!  Let me explain.  

The wings are excellent.  Can't complain about perfectly fried (multiple times) jumbo wings with good sauces.  I preferred the spicy version better, but it's up to your tastebuds on this one.  For some reason I thought that there would be some mind boggling Korean flavor burst that I've never had before, but to my slight disappointment, they were just really good wings.

As for the burger, which was just named a Philly's Best, I had a similar problem.  It was cooked perfectly and had nice flavor, but I was expecting some Korean fireworks.  I liked it better with some extra pickles.  Same thing goes for the fries: good, but not what I was expecting.

Service was perfect.  They were attentive, well spaced and very friendly.  I like the space, and there was a nice local vibe going on.  It's a place I would drop in on again if I were in the area, but not one that I would walk all the way across the city for, like I did tonight.

So, it appears Michael Schulson realized that the Sampan menu and formula is a huge moneymaker.  Double Knot is an extension of Sampan (literally, you can walk back and forth between the restaurants).  The happy hour menus are identical at both spaces and they share a kitchen downstairs.  The idea of prepared food, coffee and things in the morning, combined with great food in the evening will clearly be a success.  The classy, rustic, reclaimed space at Double Knot is great, and I don't mind a change of atmosphere to eat Sampan's food.  

The problem, like most reviews have noted, is the service.  I can understand some opening week issues, but there are more problems than that.  When you walk in, there's an open space in front of the bar (where you'd think there would be a host, like Sampan).  We stood with three other couples for about five minutes before a bartender told us the tables are first come, first serve, or to go to the host stand in the back for dinner tables (really awkward).  There were no napkins or utensils on the tables, and each couple around us had to ask for plates, water and place settings.  The sushi was served without chop sticks, soy sauce or plates.  The food runners have no idea where to deliver the food.  They kept trying to randomly deliver food to the tables, and it got so ridiculous that we and the couple next to us just started accepting the random food.

Service issues aside, the food is great, the space is beautiful, and it's an awesome happy hour.    Hopefully they'll settle into a groove and work out the kinks.  We'll give it another try.

We stopped in for happy hour on a slushy day a few weeks ago and ran into a packed, muggy, odd crowd in this tight subterranean bar.  I like the space and the idea, but it seems a little mashed up with the arcade games on one side and club vibe on the other with an oddly placed side bar.

I thought the beer prices were about a dollar more than other similar bars and I was not thrilled with the bartenders pushy attitude and horrible pours (pet peeve when 3oz of beer is missing out of a pint glass...kind of negates the happy hour discount).  We were also looking to try some food, but there was none on the happy hour menu, and the prices appeared extremely high for the food we saw around us. 

There's a ton of competition in a three block radius that we like better, so U-bahn won't be on our rotation for now.

We've been to Zento twice, and while I enjoy the atmosphere and the sushi, something is missing.  The rolls are very good, the crab soup is lovely, and the Love roll is unique and tasty.  

It's been a popular spot for a long time, but it seems a little tired and worn out.  Also, the new $45 minimum for credit cards is just wacky.  They announce it at the hostess stand, and we saw two couples turn around and walk out over it...not the best idea for business.

Compared to its peers like Doma, Umai Umai, Roe, etc, it's a bit pricey.  The folks over at Roe are super friendly, and you can throw in a Thai appetizer to mix in with the Sushi.

Sinking my teeth into those succulent fish tacos immediately transports me to a West coast beachfront bistro on a beautiful, breezy, ocean-spray summer afternoon. Delicious.

Nothing else is even worth talking about.

Alley Taps is located in Printers Alley but on the East side of Church around the corner from the Courtyard Marriott.  

Just opened a few months back and the inside is very nicely refurbished - a stage to the left, long L shaped bar along the wall and a front room that has cozy leather furniture. 

Entertainment is no cover, 7 days a week and a bit different vibe than Broadway - more of a jazz blues vibe that is nice.   Note the bands work for tips only so keep that in mind and feed their jar accordingly.  

Full bar, limited local beer ... but our favorite West Coast IPA was on draft which was a plus.  Full bar, 2 for 1 happy hour 3-7pm was a perk.  

Plenty of servers behind the bar kept drinks flowing so that was appreciated. 

The total area is engulfed by the music so that could be good or bad - for us we couldn't chat or talk to bartender as we sat at the bar.  The Mgt may want to consider a bit of volume control.  

The menu is limited and very much bar food. We ordered a pretzel that was over micro waved and not very good.  I would not recommend coming in hungry unless things change (or your drunk and have to  eat).  

Overall nice place, good music, decent happy hour.

Typical experience for this place. Slow service. Slow to order. Slow to get your food. Slow to get your check. The buffalo chicken wrap lost its taste. Food is just "ok". You only really come for a unique beer.

We stopped by last night and ordered the masaman curry and the spicy lo mein.  The curry was bright with flavors, creamy and full of potatoes, tofu, pineapples, and peanuts.  For $6.50 the portion size makes for 2-3 meals.  The lo mein failed, very uninspired and greasy.

large portions
cheap prices
quick meal

3.5 stars

I'm obsessed with Jimmy John's. It never changes, it's always the same great subs and I could probably eat them everyday. The bread is phenomenal and I just can't get enough. The only reason this location is getting 4/5 stars is because they don't deliver to my apt which is literally 5 mins away (petty I know), and because when I had to go pick up my sub the guys in there had personalities similar to a rock. No greeting, when I ordered they didn't ask if I wanted a drink, chips, which ingredients, etc. If I had been a new customer I would have been totally turned off by their lack of customer service. Looked like they didn't want to be there at all.

Really super disappointed! My friends suggested SQWIRES because they've been before for happy hour and had a great experience. However, when we arrived the happy hour had already ended (although, the website my friend checked said we still had an hour left?). 

The waitress came around pretty fast to take our order and then we didn't see her again for 30-40 mins. Our food came out probably an hour after we placed our order. 

I ordered the Spinach salad and it wasnt anything extraordinary. My salad had so much potential (because I loved all the ingredients); however, when everything came together it was a mess. Definitely would not recommend the salad.  My friends ordered the Chicken pot pie (which is huge, and can be shared) and the mushroom goat cheese flatbread. Everyone felt that their dishes were too salty. 

Don't think I'll be back! The one thing I did like was the interior decor and the ample parking- but besides that, nothing really stood out.

I literally lived across the street from this place and didn't try it out until right before I moved out of STL! 

I really enjoyed the Block! From my experience the items that are a little cheaper tend to be much tastier! I went with a big group after my graduation and the people in my party who ordered the specials and the bigger plates/entrees seemed not to be satisfied with their meal (i.e., someone ordered the steak and didn't love it, someone else ordered the fish special and was not thrilled)... but everyone who ordered the sandwiches/burgers really seemed to love it. All the drinks and cocktails were delicious. 

Items I really love: the bacon jam, and the brussels sprout! Also the burger and pulled pork sandwiches are delicious here! 

I was a little nervous because I had a large group and they dont take reservations! But I just called in ahead of time to check and they said they would work it out. I appreciated how accommodating they were! Everyone who works here is so friendly and helpful. My only complaint is that the service is EXTREMELY slow and the wait staff seems super disorganized. For instance, one time I went there there were 3 different waiters who tried to serve us (even after we explained someone else was already helping us). 

It is a good thing I didn't try this place out until I was about to move out of STL because it is a little pricey. Overall, I'd recommend it to others!

I have to say that I love the decor. I was here with a friend for happy hour. I wasn't fond of the food we ordered. Not for my palate. It was pretty to look at and more of what my friend likes- pate , cheese bread kind of thing. I guess was craving pulled pork and some soup dumplings. Service was great and I would have to come back to try out the full menu.

I came here with my boyfriend on a Tuesday afternoon before heading to tennis nearby. Immediately I was impress by the whole space, decor and atmosphere. It was very spacious and well decorated. The space were divided into different areas: dining, bar, lounge, private room and outdoors. Each section was just lovely and I wanted to try out each area but ended up in the dining room area with a view of the outside space. 

When it came to ordering food, I had a hard time choosing what to do order since the menu was quite diverse and had many tempting options. I read reviews before coming here so I chose the dumpling sampler and ordered calamari because I really like squid. My boyfriend likes eggplants and so he ordered that. The food definitely score a lot of points on presentation. My favorite dumpling was the lamb. As for the calamari, It was ok. I just didn't like the sauce and prefer the sauce that came with the crab cake poppers instead. The eggplant was not the best I had but I like the change from the ones from Chinatown where they were drenched in oil and sauce. I feel that Empress Garden in Chinatown Philly has the best flavor for eggplants. For dessert I chose the crème brulee because I love crème brulee. Overall, the food was ok, some were a bit on the salty side for me. 

It was a pleasant experience. I would definitely come back to try our other food on the menu and different space areas. Also it was nice to know they offer complimentary valet.  And I heard about the shop at the Reading Terminal. I will definitely go there to try out the dumplings.

Food: 2 Stars
Service: 3 Stars

I'm not sure how this place has survived so long... They had a leaking ceiling and we were seated not too far from it. Tables were dirty, ledges had dust. It was just gross. Our server seemed uninterested/tired. 

Our food was nothing extraordinary- overcooked seafood and sides. The only thing I enjoyed were their corn muffins.

Food: 5 Stars
Service: 5 Stars

The Sushi Burrito has FINALLY arrived in STL and it's everything I hoped it would be! 
A small restaurant along Vandeventer, Blk Mkt Eats sits near the SLU campus which makes it a perfect spot for students who are craving something fresh and full of bold flavors. The menu consists of 7 mouthwatering options which you can make into a sushi burrito or a bowl. They also offer 3 types of sushi nachos (which I'll have to come back for). So what did we have?

-OG Fire Sushi Burrito. Spicy salmon or tuna, Persian cucumbers, avocado, crispy shallots, tempura crunch, masago, jalapeno, OG Fire sauce. Like heat? Ask for extra jalapenos.
-Seoul Delicious Sushi Burrito. Grilled chicken, kimchi slaw, bibb lettuce, BLK MKT pickles, carrots, crispy shallots, gochujang mayo. 
-Shake Poke Bowl. Hawaiian-inspired tuna poke, Persian cucumbers, avocado, green cabbage, sesame seeds, crispy shallots, tempura crunch, alaea sea salt, unagi sauce. Super generous with ingredients as we were able to get a little bit of everything in EACH bite. This was probably my favorite!
-Tofu Nugs. Seasoned and fried tofu with your choice of OG Fire or a soy based sweet sauce. Beautiful crunch on the outside, soft tofu on the inside. I preferred it with the soy based sauce although to be completely honest, I would just eat these as is.... All day. Every day. 

A couple of things to make note of: 
1.) Finding a place to park is a bit tricky in this area. You may have to walk a little bit to get to the restaurant. 
2.) This is a TINY TINY restaurant, not ideal for big groups. I would advice that you call ahead and place your order for carry-out.

Now go check this place out!

I'm not sure why I've never written a review here.. but if you're dreaming of something "different" visually and off the beaten food & ambience path... this is for you! Just a note.. always good idea to make a reservation if you're wanting to guarantee no wait!

Been here twice in the last couple weeks... both times happened to have Zach as our server.  He was quick and efficient with good knowledge of the specials. 

So.. table side guacamole.. just can't go wrong and they give you spicy options since made right there. The firebread... just delicious with it's herby, buttery taste. 

Both times someone had the ribeye special  which you can add on the hot rock. Yes, sizzling hot rock that continues to cook the steak very quickly (so if you want on the rare side - watch carefully!). Regardless the presentation is fun and in my humble opinion everyone should experience at least once! 

When I was listening to the halibut special.. you kind of wonder how all those "tastes" as he's describing what it is are going to be -but all are umami together and not enough to go crazy over but delicious nonetheless (like carmelized shallot sauce, safron carrots or some exotic sounding puree of potatoes).

The drinks are served with cool (literally!) Ice cup. Then... dessert! The icecream lollipop tree. I thought it was odd it served with honey- but try it  - it does "make it!". The smores.. well.. way different than any smores (served on a shortbread cookie & brownie and with candied bacon. 

Michael (red shirt) nice fella. 

All in all a very fun place! You need to check out the restrooms (Yes.. even they're very interesting to see!) Enjoy!

I used to really really like going to this Hardees. I liked Hardees breakfast menu a lot.  I even came here and spent close to $30 on breakfast items for St. Patrick's day.  All of that came crashing down one Saturday afternoon when the window checker never gave my debit card back to me (as I was distracted in my vehicle) and bought $140 worth of gas.  Thankfully my bank was able to stop any further transactions before they started buying flat screens at Best Buy. I won't risk using the drive thru here again.

Their food is okay and some is interesting... but why is it so expensive?  I swear I could order anything on their menu and a drink somewhere else at the same price and still pay Market Pub House more.  Maybe it's related to paying for extras, i.e. I order a different sauce (because I can't eat ranch) and my server charges me.  I can't really explain it.  

Also, of the 5 times I've been here, I've had the same server 3 of those times. I now feel like I have to avoid her like the plague because I really get this feeling that she hates me.

They do have decent happy hour and late night specials.  Sadly, I don't care for the atmosphere enough to be there at either of those times.

Great for Take-Out (they deliver, but we usually pick up).  There is a big crowd, sitting by the fish tank waiting for their orders on Friday night.  For some reason, the food's not as delicious when we eat at the restaurant. 
Possibly the take-out container is a secret ingredient.  We ask for extra spicy on everything, even the Lo Mein, and it always has that heat we crave.  Ba-Dar is a great basic, neighborhood Chinese fix.

The 'I love Christmas Movie' this year, 2020 was horrible. A complete waste of time and money.
Waited for 1.5 hour just to go inside and them
it was all props! Had to be escorted throughout whole thing. At times some lights and props didn't work. 
In past ICE was good. 
What a bummer!
Crowded as always. This is the second attempt trying to get table because I failed for the first time. The burger is big! I couldn't finish it but it's so goodddddd. Prefer fried than onion ring.

Good taste, very good price, perfect location very close to campus, tried burger last time and love it too but was too hungry couldn't take any photograph! 

Ps. They serve my fav fries here. It's so good.

So I absolutely loved this lace when I first started going! The bagels are amazing and just very unique in texture. However I came here on a Saturday, checked the time, it said they closed at 5. I got there at 340-something long before that. When I walked in immediately I felt unwelcomed. Everyone stared at me and barely acknowledged me. I got my order taken finally by someone half-heartedly of course. I asked for a hot chocolate and she says "we don't have it. We close in 10 minutes not at 5 so we cleaned them all." Uhhh okay...the door and all social media's say 5 pm not 4. 

So I leave and go eat in my car since I was starving but CLEARLY not welcome inside. 

I watch a family walk in. A few seconds later. Then they all come out with hot drinks...

So I couldn't get a hot drink but they could? 

I was forgiving about the attitude because yes it's Saturday you wanna go home, but I'm not going to tolerate being lied to. 

And I hope the owner knows their laziness and attitude is causing them sales. 

And it doesn't take much to change your times on social media and take a sharpie and mark out the 5.

The chicken tacos are dreadful. Huge chunks of chicken in a tomatoey sauce like a stew. And zero toppings- make your own. So tortilla and stew-like chicken with pico and a handful of cilantro- that's it.  No thanks. Kale salad on point, as usual. Casa Perfecta margarita is also solid. Stick with quesadillas, salad or chimichanga. Tacos need tweeking.

The drag queen brunch has been on my list of places to go for years now. Finally made it over the holidays. I'm sad to say that I wasn't impressed. One drag queen in multiple outfits and average food. Sorry Susy, I don't think I will be back. 

If I were to go back, I would get the chicken and waffles. I had a bite of my friends chicken and it was pretty good.
Decent little pub in Dunedin. The service was good, the drinks were strong, and there was plenty of seating. Nice little stop for a pint or two.

I kept my comments to myself, as I came here with a group for lunch who thought it was absolutely amazing. Let's just say this place to me is one of those places who puts a lot of money into the restaurant and ambiance. Definitely, this restaurant comes off as a higher price, higher class sort of restaurant. The food? Um. I've had better.

These types of restaurants I'm always sort of wary when stepping in. You know, the type of restaurant where if you look out of place, you'll be stared at? This is what this restaurant reminded me of. So let's see, what did I order?

I ordered the BBQ Chicken Tacos. And what I received were just about 3 tacos, a bowl of beans, and a lot of disappointment. It just didn't fulfill me, as far as the amount and the price. It didn't justify it. The taste was alright, but I could've definitely have found better tacos around Tucson. Maybe there were better dishes that I didn't order, but hey as I said this restaurant wasn't really my typical scene.

Overall, the service was not too bad. The food was disappointing, but the service made this place a 3 star for me instead of any higher. I wish Yelp had .5's, because it would have gotten a 2.5, but I round.

In brief, food, 4, service, 2, average, 3.

We were dining here for breakfast on a Saturday morning.  The hostess---well, she was less than helpful.  She said she'd check to see if a table was clean, came back so I'll check something else, then came back and grabbed menus and walked off.  Were we supposed to follow?  We weren't quite sure what was going on, especially since a couple of other folks were waiting.  On a hunch, we followed her and were seated without a word---rather disconcerting from the start.

Our server, while friendly, was obviously overworked.  There was a pretty extended wait to get water, then our drinks, but I will say the food was served in a timely matter, after a pretty good wait to even order.

I had one of their skillets, and it was quite tasty.

I'd consider returning based on the food, but the service makes me hesitant.

I'm a little torn on what rating to give this....I'd feel very comfortable with a 3.5, but since that's probably never going to happen, I'll go with a 4.

It's a  locally owned business, not a chain, so that gives them a point in my favor.

Tucked in a small strip mall setting,  near 116th and Rangeline, it's surprisingly easy to miss if you're not looking for it.  You go in, order at a counter, and they bring you your food.

The servers/counter people are friendly and eager to help you.  It's obvious that they have a lot of regulars at lunch that they know by name.

For my lunch, I chose the special...a slice of pizza, a salad, and a drink for 6.49.  I think this was a bargain!

The salad was nothing special, lettuce and tomato, but I'll say it was fresh.  Nothing worse than getting wilted salad, and that sure didn't happen here.

They had several options for their pizza, so I chose sausage, the safe choice.  It was a very generous slice of pizza, and I would say it was above average.  Not the best in town, but a cut above many others around.

My buddy ordered breadsticks and we split the order, and I'll say those were just about the best darn breadsticks I've ever had.  Simply amazing.

All in all, a quite positive.  I'll be back.

Big promise. Big wait. Poor execution.
Basically left hungry. The donuts were brown on the outside but raw in the middle. The steak was bloody. The eggs and the potatoes were soaked in blood. We did not ask about rare. In fact we were not asked if we had any preference. I assumed it will be medium.

The ambiance was great. The drink and the staff were nice. Not worth the $40.
took out the veggie dumpling soup. nice flavors, a bit heavy on the sesame oil. the dumplings were disintegrating by the time we opened the container at home.

Everytime I go to Philly I can't resist Elfreth's Alley and when the weather gets too hot or I'm tired of walking around, I always stop in here and have a chai. The only unfortunate thing for me is that the chai is made from a powder concentrate. Still, it tastes great, and I love getting to relax in the big comfy chair in the back.

In the interest of getting straight to the point, here's what I had and loved, and wouldn't order again:

1. Steak tartare with oyster aioli
2. Crab claws with Thai chili (nice, big claws but might not get this again)
3. Smoked tuna dip (definitely wouldn't get again)
4. Fried bread (our server recommended this and it was our favorite thing we had)
5. Shrimp with pea cake
6. Hanger steak 
7. Capellini with crab and jalapeño (definitely wouldn't get again)
8. Creamed corn side

The 'never get again' items were pretty bland, especially when put up against such flavorful dishes like the steak tartare and the shrimp dish. The rest was pretty good, but for some odd reason the fried bread was the star of the party. It was sorta salty, sorta sweet, sorta pretzel-y, and bready, too. We should've just let our waiter picked the whole menu!

This was a generic "authentic" Mexican place. I wasn't fond of the salsa but the food was decent. The Pancho Villa had good chicken but the shrimp had no flavor whatsoever. Hubby said the Burrito Mexico was ok but I forgot to grab a bite to see for myself. 

What really irked me about this place is that somehow, someway, after the food and drinks were ordered and delivered, I got completely ignored. Waiters all looked to my husband and even the manager walking by addressed my husband and only him and then walked on. Hubby says it just happened that he was the one making eye contact with people but it's never been that bad anywhere else. By the end, hubby was laughing and asking me how I enjoyed experiencing the 1950s. Well they may have paid attention to him but I made it a point to pay the check at the end, even when they put it next to him and didn't even bother trying to put it in the middle of the damn table like most places do. Hell no I won't be back.

Liked: 
- Pancho Villa 

Ok: 
- Salsa

Im really bummed about my first and only Shoefly experience. Ambiance was cool and I love the area however my food was sub par. I ordered a medium well burger and definitely got a medium. Added bacon for $3 and it was totally burnt and hard. Fries were limp and seemingly hardly cooked though they had good flavor. When I told my waitress after eating 1/4 of the burger and picking off a bunch of bacon she just said they could "put it back on for me"...No I'm sorry or compensation even just deducting the bacon or something. $35 for a bummer meal. Ill pass next time.

This place is in a nice quiet location, but the coffee is slightly darkened water the "3 Egg" omelet is a perfect square shaped 1/4" tall thing with about as much taste as McDonald's, the fried potatoes were cold and barely browned and the toast was the smallest piece of bread I have ever seen.  The butter was not butter and the only jelly was Grape flavored.  Based on the photographs and news articles laminated under the yellowed polyurethane the place had its heyday in the early to mid-80s and is still living on its laurels.  Avoid it, most hotels have better food and if you're a local and cook this bad then you aren't looking at Yelp anyway!

It is clean and friendly and small town friendly, but really some gas stations are that too.  I am rating this because the food is really that lacking.
Tourist/mall German...much better at other places in town....Beer and Onion soup were standouts...wife's Reuben was 95% kraut..no meat...not horrible but one and dobe

Ok - second attempt - this time lunch. My friend wanted to give this place a try. 11:45 and over an hour wait. Tables open everywhere. Needless to say if you only get an hour for lunch, stay away. We had much better luck at Cheddars next door. Won't be going here ever again. Predict this place is going the way of the DoDo - and Buca - straight for extinction.

Hubby had the smoked meatloaf, sauce is what makes the meatloaf!! Thought the mashed potatoes were very good.  I had the boss which was quite tasty, very unique cheese sauce.  Jalapeño creamed corned was my highlight, it was delicious!!  Service was lacking though which is why I only gave 3 stars.  Ordered right away but didn't get waters until someone else asked if we had been helped and then she went to get the waters.  I noticed that our server also didn't remember extras that another table had asked for so overall service seemed marginal.

New location, and management.  How can it go wrong?  I'm sure everything have improved here.
This is my dim sum experience here.
Service:  no manager in sight.  If you need something, you gotta flag down the dim sum cart ladies.  Foods:  most dim sum dishes are doable, but the Cheung Fun failed.  It's soggy.  Price:  very expensive.  $5-7 per a dish.  My advice is for you to ask the cart lady is the dish you want is small, medium, or large.  That's the only way you'll know how much it really cost.  When I was growing up in NYC, dim sum is comfort foods for us Cantonese.
It's like going to a diner for pancakes.  In other words, for the amount of money you spent here is equivalent to gourmet cuisines.
$9 for a bowl of noodle with a small piece of meat thinly sliced.  Overpriced!  The question is why Asian foods here are more expensive than NY, and CA?
Love the cozy vibe of the house, but it can be chaotic in here. Staff is friendly. The patio is often packed, noisy, hot and too sunny. I like the side screened room, but it is freezing in there.

City Pizza is my favorite corner pizza place in the neighborhood. Their prices are reasonable and their food is always delicious. They don't steer away from their original menu and never offer anything different so it is always steady. We order from there once a week and on a busy night the wait can be an hour but they will warn you on the phone. They rarely go over that time frame, even on a busy Friday night. If you order delivery the drivers are always extremely friendly and pleasant! There is parking right across the street under 95 so that is not an issue if you are going to pick up food. They sell pizza by the slices and have a lot of 20oz soda options that you don't typically see which is pretty awesome. I love that they sell cream soda and vanilla coke! 

The only downfall is the staff who answers the phone because they are always young and seem to have an attitude. I know some people that specifically don't order from there because of the service when trying to order food.

This place is really disappointing. The bar is laid out beautifully location is great dining room is so-so. I have been there 20 to 25 times and the food was never properly cooked. So I only go there for the bar now but it's always always dirty even after we ask the bartender to wipe it down it is done with a dirty rag. This should be rule number one because it's in tolerable when your arms and elbows stick to the bar every single time I go in there so I just stopped going.

2.5 delivery review
Ha don't eye on this spot for a few months and finally pulled the trigger. The reviews are amazing and so our the pictures but our delivery was disappointing. 

Two steaks quasadillas, two chicken tacos and steak nachos. Tacos were bland. The quasadillas were basic with only steak and a cheese that was very hard and not tasty. Mediocre dipping sauces, one red and one green. The nachos were decent but not great. $35 seemed a little steep given the absence of quality and taste.

First time last time.

Most inefficient seating process ever...Tons of empty tables and told 45 min to an hour wait. During my visit here people were growing extremely frustrated that dirty dishes were sitting on tables and people were waiting forever to get a table. Notice all of the empty tables and a full wait section....Both outside and inside took forever to seat.

Wanted to like this place, but concerned with how long fish stayed out of the cooler - sitting at the bar it was too obvious. Overly soft fish texture noted.
Petit Chirashi -  funky taste.
The food worries me.
The people and decor were very nice.
Nevertheless i am unlikely to go back with a nervous first impression.

Courteous hosting, available parking across the street on University, and a nice ambiance set the stage for a very pleasant evening with great food.
Zuppa de Pesce was the real deal with chunks of fish along with the shellfish. Shrimp Papardelle
very nice. Bread - meh. Overall experience still great and planning to return!
The food may be a bit questionable (although not terrible), but where else are you going to get piping hot Chinese food at 3am on a weeknight?

It seems almost cruel to rate P.F. Chang's on its food when its so clearly designed to be an "eating experience."   So before I say anything about the food I'll say the service was attentive and very good, the decor was lovely, and the place was bustling.  
But the food...now again, its my own fault for visiting.  But what's a downtown business traveler to do?
The egg drop soup tasted canned and was unfortunately more like chicken soup than anything else.  My dumplings didn't hold together.  The outer wrapping was rubbery and cold, burned in places and gummy in others.  The inner dumpling was ok, but just ok.
My Buddhist delight was full of broccoli, which made me happy but the sauce was heavy and had a not so pleasant aftertaste.
The free fortune cookies had a good fortune for me, which was nice.
Overall, though, given the cost, I would have been happier at the food court.
The decor of the place reminds me on an old bbq place. The food was alright. Service was nothing special. The beer was pretty good, but that's about the only really good thing.

Tru Burger is a decent burger joint, comparable to a "Dat Dog" for, well, burgers. The simple fact of the matter is that Tru Burger is simply "okay". Nothing really stands out about the food, and for being on the prime location of Oak and Carrollton, one might as well walk a few feet down to Mellow Mushroom or Lebanon Cafe for a much better meal.

I thought this place was just ok. I got a shop kitchen burger and have had much better before and for paying $16 for a burger including the tax and tip I would have expected better.

Food: OK
Portion Size: average
Service: Great
Environment: Amazing

Tfiii this place is as nasty as old harrys toes! Horrible place to eat and is very rotten Beoble. Z place is vetty dirty and no real mookhan toookhan chain food! Your bring shame to my family for serving Zeess foood ,

Limited review since I only tried their pizza, which was dry and tasteless. Toppings were hard and dry, and the crust had the consistency of Saltine crackers. Easily the worst pizza that I've had in years. Gas station reheated, microwave pizza would have been better. Ambience was pleasant and service was good - 1 star for each.

As long as I am in the mood to write about breakfast, I can't overlook my neighborhood staple.  A little place on the main drag in Spring House, Rich has been here for years.  And one thing that can be certain, the food is the freshest and the coffee the most flavorful.  

If you are lucky enough to get Patty as your waitperson, you will have the best server there as well as the nicest.  The others definitely have attitude, one always hurried, another always talking to patrons and ignoring their tables, etc.

The eggs are the freshest possible, the omelets are average at best.  The bacon is very very good if cooked correctly, depends upon the cook of the day, but the serving is big and the bacon tasty, so I risk the prep.

The bagels are as good as can be outside of NYC, but the other breads, ehhh, not so much.  Homefries are only good when requested well done, and that is only for the top layer, the rest of the potatoes sit, alone, abandoned on the plate, swept to an early grave.

Not the most comfortable seating, hard Formica, but then again, it's breakfast, and it'll wake your ass up!

I felt like a fat fucking hog when I left the Parc Bistro last night, my stomach was hanging down to my knees.   So all of you pigs who need mass quantities of food, you'll like this place.

A beautiful 80 degree evening in Skippack, a lovely night to sit outside so I returned to the Parc Bistro after a couple years as I know they have seating outside, and NOT on top of a parking lot nor on the street.  The ambiance was wonderful. 

The service from both Greg and Jay was excellent, attentive, fast with the wine and brew refills (Bells Two Hearted IPA on tap, yum), and pleasant.

The mussels appetizer was more than enough to share for 2, probably good enough for 3.  It was steamed in Weyerbacher Merry Monks Belgian Ale, with honey goat cheese, green onions and fried shoestring potato on top streaked with bourbon mayo.  This was so friggin good, so decadent and soooo filling, I didn't need the bread (focaccia with olive oil and red pepper puree)  nor the dinner that followed, but I ate it all anyway.

I ordered the veal meatloaf for the entree, served with yukon mashed, a wonderful mushroom ragu, and the best tomato marmalade you will ever put in your mouth..  And I did, every friggin bite.  My friend had the soft shell crab special of the evening, served with risotto.  This again was a very large serving, and my friend, unlike me, could not finish...closet eater!!  ;-)

No room for dessert.  Sorry.  Maybe next time the mussels and dessert would be sufficient.  What the fuck was I thinking.!!

Service was 5 stars, the mussels were as good as Eulogies in town, or Martine's in New Hope.  The entrees were almost 4 star worthy.  A solid 4 star place in Skippack, about time.

My first time here. I wasn't in the mood to try Mexican food but I'm glad I stopped by because the food was great!! The chicken was seasoned really well. The nachos had a great combination of flavors and were very tasty. My friend enjoyed the beef fajitas. I only wish they gave more chips and salsa or that they provided the chips and salsa complimentary at the beginning. Price was pretty reasonable. Overall worth a visit!

We've heard so many good things about Downey's we decided to go there for my birthday dinner after the Symphony, and it certainly did NOT disappoint.  In fact it could nit have been more perfect; sweet little window table for two, and food that was over the top fabulous. I had the sea bass which was cooked to perfection, and came with an incredible sauce.  My husband had the fillet which was equally wonderful.  The servers were exceptional; professional, friendly and helpful with no hovering.  Downey's will be top on the list for our frequent visits while attending concerts and theater.  SO happy we discovered this lovely Chef owned, intimate spot so close to everything!

I'm not sure what all the hype is over this All That Jazz. It was ok to me but not as great as I was expecting.  It seemed to have a lot more sauce than shrimp and ham.  It could be that I was just spoiled by the huge, lower priced, overstuffed shrimp po-boy that I got in Slidell on the way into town that blew this sandwich away.  
As I type this the next morning, I'm eating my daughters leftover half of her fried chicken po-boy and I find it better than the All That Jazz.

This is not good Szechuan. Or even Asian. If you want the best go to han dynasty and ignore this part of the menu. Don't even think about. 
Ordered mini wontons in CHILI oil. Not sure where the chili part was, because it was swimming in what tasted exactly like a salty dumpling sauce dip of soy sauce and garlic. The wonton was gummy and the pork inside was bland and unseasoned. 
Dan Dan noodles were close to cold, too pasty from too much sesame paste and not slick. Again, where was any chili oil? I felt like I was eating peanut butter smothered noodles. 
The double cooked fish was Not crispy. Soggy pieces of thick fillet and overly salted dressing. 
The tropical mango chicken actually was enjoyable after everything else, despite the mango being crunchy and not close to ripened. 
Next the service sucked. We were never checked back on once the food arrived, and had empty water glasses the whole dinner despite asking for more water. We got one glass of water filled at the check. Why not both???

Good beer, good location, and good service. Not the best value though. My burger and duck tacos were decent but I thought on the smaller side for portions and lacking in any excellent tastes or seasonings. Also there were no accompaniments on the plate or bread served or anything.
the food is awesome with a capital "A" but the two hour wait is ridiculously long. if i were to ever go there again and the wait was anywhere close to two hours, id go somewhere else.

OMG GOOD!!! I built my own with two cheeses, turkey and ham. It was great! That, along with a bottled water and Waffle Fries, did I mention they have waffle fries???, was $14. A bit high, but the quality was there. I can't wait to share this gem with the rest of the family

Who doesn't love a nice winter's blizzard? Mint Oreo and Turtle Blizzards are my go-to's. The drive thru at this location is tight and tends to block traffic. They have a sign posted on the window that says this location does not participate in the blizzard flip promotion. I asked for brownies bites to be added which they forgot but the blizzard was still delicious without it. Prices were  decent. A little over $9 for two small blizzards.

I have seen and heard about this place for a while, and was in the area and met up for breakfast with my friend. We went during the weekday and it was surprisingly pretty busy so I can imagine how busy it gets during the weekend.

We were immeditely greeted when we walked in the door and soon after seated. The staff were all very nice and my interactions with them were very professional. 

We sat at a booth and were immediately greeted by our waitress. She took our drink orders and quickly delivered or drinks. She continued to be prompt throughout the while dining experience. I ordered a poached egg (I forgot which one) and it was very tasty. 

Overall, the atmosphere and service were excellent and the breakfast was good.

I love this place.  Sandwiches are huge and pretty cheap, bread bowls tasty, and good service,

Ambience:  2.5 stars.  A bit of a dive, but you are on 4th!  It can get a bit tight in here, and you may have to wait outside--and that sucks when it is hot out there! The booths are not super comfy.

Food:  4 stars.  Diverse, creative sandwiches for every kind of taste.  Soups are good, but the bread bowls make them great!  Standard bar fare appetizers.  Mmmmmmm...  Grilled peanut butter and jelly....

Service:  4 stars.  Our server was prompt and attentive despite a fairly busy Saturday lunch service.

Family:  4 stars.  Plenty of options for the kids!

Definitely recommend this place.

Growing up in Bensalem there were three pizzeria's who's names are still around Tony's, Old Roman and Diana's.  Although the ownership has changed hands the food is still decent.  

I haven't been there in years, but I recently stopped in to grab a quite dinner.  The last owner was an Italian gentleman from Sicily who I heard passed away.  The newer operators seem like a nice family.  They were friendly and busy.  The inside hasn't changed at all, the floors and tables were clean with about a dozen tables that seat four.  The bathrooms were clean as well.

After perusing the menu and checking out the pizza slices they had sitting out I decided to go with a Buffalo Chicken Panini.  It came out after about 10 minutes and was not pressed as well as I would have liked.  It was a leaker of a sandwich, but the chicken seemed nicely seasoned.  It could have used more Buffalo sauce because it lacked the kick I was hoping for.  It was a big sandwich and with a bottle of water and side of fries came to $10.  

A good place if your in the area and just looking for a decent simple bite to eat.

Have stopped by here once or twice a year for quite a few years and the consistency and experience is still the same.  Perfect. The ambiance is just right, German beer hall feel, Bundesliga playing on TV's above the bar, long tables and proper glassware for each Brewery/Beer Style. The back room is spacious, a little loud, but very homey.  

Their German beer menu is unmatched.  They have breweries on tap that I am told are exclusive to them in this area and their bottle list is extensive.  The variety of German beer styles compliments the menu so well.  For example Aecht Schlenkerla makes the best smoke beers in the world, (you can find them on tap and in bottles here) pair so well with the 9 different wurst offerings.  

The house made Laugenbrezel (Pretzel) is a must starter, my wife orders Kartoffelpuffer aka potato pancakes every time we come and she loves them.  On this trip I went with the Wurstplatte which comes with two sausages from their list of 9!  I chose the Weibwurst (mild pork&veal) and the Feuerwurst (very spicy pork) with a double serving of potato salad.  The sausages are big portion wise and very fresh.  Feuerwurst was very spicy, but not enough to take away the pork flavor and had a nice snap when you broke through the casing.  Weibwurst may not look appealing because of its white appearance, but it was mild, juicy and tender.  Potato salad, served cold was delicious.  

I finished my evening with a bottle of Weihenstephaner Korbinian, a full bodied doppelbock with nice fruity flavors of figs and plums and left a happy man.  
Love this place!

In the mood for some fresh bread?  Check this place out. I bought a loaf of rosemary olive oil bread and enjoyed any sandwiches on it. 

I froze half of it and wasn't impressed with it after thawing and toasting in the oven. Maybe I did something wrong, but it felt gummy and chewy.

The hubby and I stopped in last night for the hubby to enjoy a guiness. The inside is pretty small, but was full of regulars and locals. The servers were extremely friendly and efficient. 

We sat back and enjoyed some live Irish jigs and a black/tan and a guiness. The table next to us ordered the pretzel sticks and beer cheese dip appetizer. After they arrived at the table, we had to order them too. 

They were good, but the cheese dip was lacking that bite I was expecting. It was full of real cheddar cheese, but lacking the "beer" flavor. They weren't bad, but not as good as I was expecting them to be. 

I would definitely come back to check it out again.

I invited a few friends to try the new place in town. I am a big fan of steakhouses and frequent Bob's, Jeff Ruby's and Bourbon. The happy hour was enjoyable and they had Justin by the glass for $10 which was appealing to me. The setting is modern but lacking in my opinion. We were seated I immediately ordered a dozen oysters and a salad. I was told that we had to place our orders all at one time which immediately interrupted my idea of a dining experience. The order of oysters I placed never made it to the table. The filet I ordered medium temperature came out well done and after a quick apology, another filet was quickly delivered. It had been fired on high temperature and was well done around the edges and raw in the center. They encourage sauces with their steaks and there is a reason why. The $20 baked potato I ordered was very lack luster and the other sides seemed like glorified canned foods. Nothing was impressive with the exception of the wine by the glass list...hence the upgrade to 2 stars. This place serves smoke and mirrors. I would definitely spend my money elsewhere.

I would say that I probably spend more time than I should at Scotty's. It's a great place to go watch sports, as there are TV's in just about every direction you could look. The booths even have their own personal TV's at one end, if turning your head just sounds like way too much work. It does get very full for large sporting events, so you might want to get in early for big games. For certain games, they will put the volume on over the speakers so you can hear what is going on. At all other times, they have a good selection of music playing throughout. The noise level is high compared to some other restaurants, but not enough that you can't have a conversation with anyone at your table. There is a bar area, an area for families, and outdoor seating available. I have come with some very large groups and they haven't had any problem getting together enough room for us all.

Most of the time I just find a seat at the bar, and the service has always been great. The bartenders make sure your glass is always full, and usually have a good recommendation or two if you are looking for something new in regards to food or drink. In my experience, I would put the bartenders as more sociable with the patrons than most comparable places, which I prefer over ones that seem to be there solely to take your order. The list of beers that they keep on tap includes a good variety of microbrews both brewed nationally and locally, and has something for everybody with around 30 beers on tap, with more selections available in bottles. They do a pretty good job of changing up what they have to offer, so there is usually something new to try and they offer samples of anything if you are wary about ordering something new. There are drink specials on most days that are as good as or better than most other places I have been to. They are also able to fill growlers here with beer from 3 Wise Men if you need beer to go.

Make sure to come hungry, because the food is always great with large enough servings to take lunch home with you for the next day. The burgers are really good and they offer some interesting combinations of toppings, but the wings are the best I have had in Indy.  If you make it in late at night like I usually do, they offer almost all of their appetizers at reduced prices.  I have also ordered food for takeout online a couple of times, and the process has gone smoothly for me with it waiting to be picked up when I arrived.

I set expectations very high for any place calling themselves a draft house. Fortunately, Ralston's does a pretty good job of delivering when it comes to beer.

I stopped in around 11:00 at night on Sunday of Labor Day weekend. Ralston's was only one of a few places that still looked like it had a decent crowd, and I pulled up a seat at the bar. The atmosphere is relaxed and it looks really nice inside. It's more upscale than a typical sports bar, but you won't feel out of place going in to get a beer and watch the game on one of their TV's. The patio was full when I got there, and it looks like a great place to sit and enjoy the weather while doing some people watching on Mass Ave. The beer list is pretty extensive and has quite a few offerings that aren't typically served elsewhere in Indy, but you can still get local offerings if you prefer.
