I don't know that I would say their beer offerings compete with some of the other well know beer venues in Indy as far as variety and tap rotation goes, but you can be pretty sure you are going to find at least a few on the list that you haven't tried before. The prices are on par with what you would expect, as you will spend $5-$6 on a draft of varying sizes depending on your selection.

If I was just going to rate them based on beer, location, and the atmosphere of the place I would not hesitate to give them 4 stars. The only reason this is a 3 star for me is because of the service. There was only 1 bartender that night, and he was working pretty hard trying to take care of both the bar and fill orders coming in from the wait staff. I assume that this was more related to somebody significantly misjudging that they wouldn't have a bigger crowd than usual with most people getting the holiday off on Monday, but it kind of ruined my experience. I'll definitely be back because they had a lot of other things going for them and I would like to try their food, so hopefully my service woes were just due to coming in on the wrong day. I look forward to pulling up a chair and catching a game here over some good beers, but I certainly hope they are better prepared when the major sports season gets into full swing.

I think this place gets somewhat unfairly judged because it is a chain restaurant and that usually doesn't fly on Yelp, but there is a good reason it exists in so many cities and does well in that many locations. They certainly appeal to a lot of people, and it is a place that the standard crowd is going to enjoy dinner and a beer at. Their menu is certainly not the lowest common denominator of ridiculous bar food creations that some chains hang their hat on, but they have a menu that is appealing to the masses and the things I have had from here are good. 

This restaurant is located right in the downtown area, and is really convenient if you are downtown or at the convention center for a conference or event. They have a large bar area with lots of seating at the U-shaped bar, and plenty of tables in the rest of the separated bar space. There is another larger dining area on the other side, and a large room in the back that can be rented for private events. There is even a small outdoor area in front that is nice in the warmer months. The place does get busy, especially when there is a large event in the area. They get a large Colts crowd on game days, and fill up any time there is something on Georgia St. or at the convention center, and a lot of times they will do fun things to celebrate the event that is taking place. There are plenty of TVs around to see any sports games you want to see, but not quite as overkill as your typical sports bar will have. The setting is a little on the dark side and they have a lot of wood and brick. If you have a large group, this is a good place to look as they have lots of larger tables.

The menu runs the gamut with the typical things you see expect to see at American restaurants. It has lots of appetizers, salads, burgers, sandwiches, and a variety of main dishes that have some nicer options. They have some unique twists on a few standard dishes, and have options for vegetarians as well as gluten free dishes. I'm a big fan of their mac and cheese when I am in the mood to splurge on calories. 

Their beer is definitely one of their strong points. They have a standard lineup or 6 options that cover most of the major varieties. They do a really good job with these and they are all great for the style. None are that unique, but they are perfect for the standard everyday offering. Their seasonals are where they really excel. They are always unique and delicious, and I think this place is underrated as a brewery.  The issue, and the reason I'm not here as much as I might stop by otherwise, is that their seasonals usually only exist one or two at a time, and don't rotate all that quickly. If you like to see new things often at a brewery, this one probably won't deliver on that front. They do serve beer in to-go cups, so you can order a beer at the bar and walk right out with a plastic pint of beer to enjoy while walking around if you don't want to miss out on any action around town. 

Overall, they have a crowd-pleasing American style menu with a lot of options to likely have something everyone will enjoy. The place itself is nice, and they have a lot of space. I don't recall service ever being bad, but they have done well a couple times. Their beer is what sets them apart from similar establishments, and makes this a place I would recommend if you are looking for this style of dining.

OK, where did this place come from? I have lived in Indianapolis off and on my entire life. I have never seen this place! What a nice place to be and enjoy a great cocktail!  The pours are generous, unfortunately the price tag mimics the pour, ha!  The atmosphere is warm, perhaps a little stuffy, but you would expect that being above St. Elmo's. The live music last night was nice, and just loud enough that you could hear it without your conversation being drowned out.  As I said, I'm not sure how I missed this place as often as I am downtown, but I am sure to return again.

I was hanging with my beautiful lady friend and we decided to treat ourselves to some pizza and wings.  We ordered a white pizza and ten hot buffalo wings.  The food came fairly quickly and as we were about to jump right into the joys of delivery pizza we noticed that there were two pizza boxes, despite the fact we only ordered one pizza.  It became evident that the delivery driver who appeared friendly yet spacey, had given up someone else's order in addition to our own.  We called him and he came back for the extra pizza.  Their interpretation of our order was confusing but tasty nonetheless.  The white pizza was a regular pizza with no sauce, cheese, and sliced tomatoes on top.  The buffalo wings were full-on pieces of fried chicken.  We got the hot and they definitely weren't spicy at all, although they had a good flavor and there was way more of them than we had anticipated.  I am always disappointed by the lack of sauciness on my wings, as I am a Sauce Boss but I was able to add my own sauce and I enjoyed them a lot.  Pete, your pizza is a little confusing but I enjoyed your savory offerings regardless.

Sometimes while I eat lunch I entertain myself by reading Yelp reviews of polarizing places - Port of Call is one of them. It has a wonderfully divey, New-Orleans-y atmosphere, and is so unique. It definitely gets a lot of hype, and locals constantly recommend it.  I am a local, and I've been a handful of times.  It's always fun, and the drinks are strong and large, but is it some of the best food in New Orleans? No.  I don't like burgers so I have only eaten the steaks, which in my opinion are overpriced and bland.  And yes the bacon that comes on the baked potatoes is a little weird.  It's a great place to pop in for a strong drink and some basic food, but I would never wait in line for it, and there's usually a line.  Just my 2 cents!

I decided to check out this place with my family tonight. I will start by saying I love creole / Cajun style food so I was excited to give it a try. 
My fiancé and my mother do not like creole/spice but they love Italian and this place advertises themselves as also an Italian fusion so we should be good, right? 
So we get seated and I will say the host and waitress where very friendly.  Our water was filled and my beer was brought right away. We started looking at the menu and the selection was very small if you are looking for an Italian or Italian "fusion" meal. 
So we all made up our mind and yes it took a little time for my mom and fiancé to make up their mind, maybe 15 minutes and both decided on the chicken parm which I will get back to. 
I started out with the gumbo. It came out fairly quickly as you would expect for a soup. I took a big spoonful of it and was super let down, it was almost flavorless with a very small amount of meat.i had to put a bit of salt into it just to give it something.
About 40 minutes passed between my soup and when our meals arrived, there was only 2 other tables in the dinning room at this time , however probably a dozen or so at the bar.. Not to busy to excuse this long wait. 
As I said 2 in my party ordered the chicken parm and it came over pasta that was cooked well however it was just a butterflied lightly breaded breast with a super thin, light tomato sauce that was very acidic and with virtually no seasoning and what looked like a light sprinkle of powdered parmasian cheese. Very flavorless and over priced for the dish.
 My father got the crab cake meal and he had said that his crab cakes contained a good amount of actual real crabmeat , they tasted as though they were made with stove top stuffing.. So needless to say he wasn't overly thrilled with his meal either. 
Now I got the popcorn crawfish poboy and it was stuffed with crawfish. The crawfish was battered and fried beautifully but had no seasoning as with everything else. 
We were all let down by the long wait for the meal , super disappointed by the food itself and not happy with the prices they charged for the sub par meals. The only nice thing was the friendly service! I would not recommend the food but its a nice place to go and have a few drinks at the bar.

i had the pork belly. the pork was undercooked, which caused negative digestive consequences for the subsequent 24 hours. even had the meat been cooked proper, the sandwich was quite good, but not $11 good: it's small for an $11 poboy. as it goes for so many NOLA eateries, for $8, i'd come back, and for $7, i'd be raving from the tops of buildings and dragging in everyone i know.

Went here for a friend's birthday. There were about 10 of us. The birthday girl sent back her entree because it was too salty, said it was inedible. 
The portions are very small. I get you're supposed to get a four course meal but it's so expensive that you'd be paying $100 plus if you did that! For one person! 
The pompano was excellent and so was the quail salad! I tried my friend's pasta dish after they brought it back and it was very delicious. Desserts were okay. Nothing to rave about. 
If you come here and want to leave full, you're going to be spending lots and lots of moola!

I went to this placed based on the reviews I read on Yelp hoping  to find another one of those great little neighborhood places that most people don't know about like Macaroni's in NE Philly on old welsh rd, wow! What a dissapointment. Where do I start, the parking was awful! But, to be expected given the location, the place looked dirty and cramped but I can get past all of that if the food is good,  unfortunately that wasn't the case. The service was bad I felt rushed the whole time I was there. Yhey didn't take a drink orderwhen half way through our meal my date asked for a soda the waiter brought over a dirty glass and a can and just left it on the table. The meals we ordered had no presentation and were not tasty at all, I am a person who eats out 3-4 times a week and have no problem trying new places or traveling to find good food. I was horribly disappointed with everything from the service to the quality  and taste of the food, I don't know if it was a bad night or what. Obviously alot of people like this place,look at the reviews it gets! I just don't understand how. I had a awful experience in every way and would never recommend in any way.SORRY!

This was our second time coming for the lunch prix fixe. First off, they would not honor our living social deal (which was fine). The more egregious error(s) had to do with the fact that there were lobster shells in the lobster risotto ... the stuffed chicken was well overdone ... and the breadsticks were stale. The salads were pretty good and the gelato was excellent! I will be willing to give Bliss another chance since the first time around, the dining experience was much better. But hopefully we won't run into this problem again. Service was very good.

I use to love Moreno but after my experience today, I can say I'm highly disappointed to what they have become. I've been going to them for 8 years now. I went in today, had to wait for the employees to stop talking before they would help me, I even said I'm ready and they continued to ignore me. I was standing right in front of them both and they didn't care. But that's not why I'm giving it one star, I'm giving it one star because the prices have grown to be absolutely insane! I just spent $50 on 2 yellow rice and chicken dinners a loaf of bread and 4 pastries. That's ridiculous! The dinners are not even enough to have left overs. I don't live close but I still try to go a lot but unfortunately this was my last time until they get some things straight. There's absolutely no need for their food to be as expensive as it is. I live in west Tampa, over here you get FRESH hot out of the oven cuba bread loads that are so huge they could feed literally about 25-35 people for the same exact price. This tiny little "loaf" you get from them only feeds about 4-6 people. Ridiculous! I do fee like the pastries are pretty good prices for the size and quality however the food is mediocre for the price. This is not the morenos I know. One lady even had the cashier stop while she was already ringing me up to go help another person but then just left me there and didn't say sorry or excuse me or anything. THATS PRETTY DAMN RUDE! Needless to say we will not be going back, I know my review may not matter to them but people will see it and once they get the same service they will stop going too. I just can't get over the prices for food. Over here I can get a chicken and yellow rice dinner split it between 2 people and STILL have left overs the next day. For $7-10. Get over your self Moreno because you have a LONG way to go before your food meets those prices expectations.

Ever since I'd heard the buzz about the Pimm's Cup Daiquiris I've been dying to try this spot. Finally made it in while some friends were visiting this week and it was ALL it was cracked up to be and more....Happy Hour (4-7) you get $2 off each daiquiri!!

We tried a few appetizers- the chicken wings topped with a pepper jelly glaze (a little too sweet for me, but GOOD), the crab & tomato salad with fresh mozzarella (MY jam) and the artichoke dip with tortilla chips (good and cheesey!).

The server and the bartender that night were both great and clearly worked well together to make sure everything was flowing nicely. Can't wait to come back!

Covid19 Update:  Still one of my favorite places to get a delicious, and relatively healthy meal, in Mid-City, but right now take-out is your only option. Last week I used the Yelp app to order some takeout, then we grabbed a few things in their little grocery store and took our lunch to City Park and enjoyed salad and hummus underneath an ancient oak in the shade.  

The grocery store was stocked with all of the usual items. And, because it is a tiny corner store, it wasn't packed with a bunch of people trying to get in my space.  I bought some spices and a few cans of stuffed grape leaves to add to my pantry while maintaining a safe distance.

Yuck.  Not good at all.  I've had better at a football game... and that's really saying something about how bad the food is at this joint.   The bread was stale.  The meat, bland.  The staff was rude.  I changed my drink order from diet coke to Pepsi and you would have thought I was asking her to paint me a Monet  with her toes... she got all flustered and angry.... "lets start this all over".  Seriously?  Start it all over because I changed the only drink I ordered from Diet Coke to Pepsi?  I was ordering two orders of fries and one drink.  I agree with other people who have posted about the offensive signs.  This is America and I am guessing we should order in English if we want them to understand what we want... but have they not heard of tourists?  Does money not speak every language?  I would never go back to this place... save yourself some time and go across the street to Pats.

Great service by Stevie.  The fried mushrooms  were amazing as was the duck.  Yum yum!  First time back here since Covid and it's still the same food quality and service level.  Glad to know this is still a top notch foodie destination!

I went to Jones a couple times for dinner years ago and wasn't a big fan. I went back last night and I'm sad to say, my opinion has not changed one bit. It's just MEH. Not good, not bad. 

My group ordered the Zucchini Frites for an appetizer which came with lemon aioli and marinara. They were about average, nothing different from the Zucchini Fries I've had before. I did like the lemon aioli so props to that. 

For my entree I got the ALT which was avocado, lettuce, tomato, and mozzarella on multigrain toast with that same lemon aioli which came with the Zucchini Fries. Right when I placed my order, our friendly waitress was quick to tell me it was a great choice. I was happy to know I had made a solid decision. The vegetables were fresh, the bread was well toasted, and I appreciated that it came with the aioli, but still, the sandwich was nothing special. I couldn't help but think it tasted the same as a sandwich I could have gotten at a chain restaurant or cafe (I'm talking to you, Panera).

My boyfriend got the Slow Braised Beef Brisket and wasn't thoroughly impressed with his entree either. I didn't try it, but it was really lacking in presentation in my opinion. :(

Overall although the ambience is great, the food is underwhelming and not worth the price.

The coronet is a wonderful addition to the 4th Avenue area.  I came with a group of friends in the early evening.  My experience here was a revelation in some aspects.  Everyone seemed to be very happy with their drinks.  The soup of the day was a chilled cream of celery and it was simply fantastic, and I am a person who never eats cold soup.  Rather than ordering individual entrees, we ordered all four of the sharable platters:  the steelhead, the pate de Campagne, the cheese plate, and the beets with minted chevre.  When they came out, my first impression was that they were all so charmingly presented.  Every platter had so much going on, with little bits of this and that, all meant to be eaten on toasted crackers.  Yum!!!!  I'm only sorry that I didn't take pictures for posting.

As delightful as my experience was here, there are a couple things that stopped me from giving this place a 5 star rating.  One, I thought the prices were a little high.  Two, and this is the most important, I would enjoy the place more if they had more offerings on their menu.

Even with that said, I would very much love to come back for brunch.

Pretty cool spot.  We got seated right away during dinner time without a wait.  The staff was very nice and friendly.  Food came out in a boil bag.  It was nice, hot, and steamy.  my spice level was a level medium.  It wasn't too spicy and just perfect for me.  I tried some of my partner's hot level, and it wasn't too hot to the extreme.  I liked it.  The seafood was cooked perfect.  It wasn't undercooked or overcooked.  The seasoning was also inside the seafood where you could taste it.  You know at some places you just taste the outside and the inside has no flavor.  We did the Mr. And Mrs. crab seasoning and it wasn't bad at all.

Made reservations and came to Dinardo's before walking to a performance at the Arden Theatre.  Walked in a bit just before 6:00 PM and were seated at once, not before engaging the bartender in conversation that resulted in a delicious Mojito.  We advised the Maitre D' that we had an 8 PM theatre function and they took pains to ensure we walked out on time.  

After a delicious plate of Calamari, I enjoyed a broiled seafood melange and my partner had the surf and turf.  Both were absolutely awesome.  We washed it down with a superb Pinor Noir.

Casual, pleasant, with good food and superb service.

I'm saddened by the decline of customer support at the Paneras I've been to.  This particular place could be a gold mine for the company and an oasis of good food and outstanding customer service for the consumer.  But it falls flat. From the lack of dairy alternatives to the fact that if you want breakfast, they tell YOU when you can have egg dishes, not the other way around.  Seriously, how difficult is it to crack a couple of eggs in a greased pan?  Sooooo... I order an egg souffle which I could have used as a hockey puck.  

Somehow I regretted my decision that day not to have my usual breakfast at Starbucks....

Just the salad bar catapults it into the three-stars.  Not many places have those anymore and I'm a salad freak.  Then there was the meat.  My partner had a juicy steak cooked just as he asked, and I had the salmon, also as rare as I wanted it.  Excellent beer selection and good service.  Yes, it IS a chain for suburban sprawl malls, that takes it down a notch.  But for a decently priced, good dinner, you can't go wrong at this place.

More of a bar than a restaurant.  Food was plentiful but not super tasty.  Oddly bland for a creole restaurant.  Our server was that shining star.   Really great guy who tried very hard to make sure we had a good experience.

I walk in, and they're playing the greatest hits of De La Soul throughout lunch. They could have been serving Big Macs and that gets you four stars alone. 

I order a grilled cheese sandwich, and it comes with apple, plums, and bacon on some delicious bread with tortilla chips. And it is sublime. The cheese is perfectly melted, and the goodies inside are covered in wonderful gooey dairy greatness. 

I order a cafe con leche while getting some work done on my laptop. It is flawlessly prepared by a lovely server, and I'm a coffee snob. And if I didn't get buried in work stuff, I was jonesing for one of those half-price martinis they serve on Thursdays.

Wonderful atmosphere (the skatepark staff makes it friendly and fun), great food, delicious coffee, a full bar, and lots of different options. This place is a total home run, and a can't miss for anyone in Ybor.

So when you have to go speak somewhere downtown at 8 am when you're used to rolling out of the rack about 9:30 every morning, the first thing you think is "yikes, that's early and that sucks." But when the second thought is "at least I'll be done in time to get to Daily Eats for breakfast," that should give you some indication of how good this place is.

I got the carnivore omelet. I always get the carnivore omelet. Everything else on the menu could be written in sanskrit and it wouldn't make a difference to my dining experience. Ham, sausage, cheese, bacon, and brought to your table quickly always by a waitress that's attentive without being pushy. But what makes it a 5 star experience is the home fries that are marinated in pure joy and love. They are quite amazing, and for some reason much tastier than the ones you get everywhere else on planet earth, and yes I just argued that they they are the world's greatest home fries. 

Oh, and now they serve Coke Zero. Awesomeness unlocked!

It's been about five years since the last time I've eaten at Domaine Hudson.  They have new management and have remodeled since the last time I visited, but some things remain the same.  

The service and food are still good.  Our water glasses stayed filled and our server was very attentive.  The owner walked around introducing himself to every table, asked if everything was okay, and engaged in small conversation.   

We started our night with home made charcuterie.  There were several meats.  The waiter did mislabel one of the meats as Spanish Prosciutto..huh?  I thought that would be called Serrano ham and besides the meat looked and tasted like salami.   

Besides that, the dishes I ordered looked and tasted great.  I loved the scallops.  They tasted buttery on the outside (I guess from being basted in butter) and creamy on the inside.  They were cooked to perfection.  The lobster risotto is a great dish also! It has taken me a while to write this review so I forget the special that we ordered but that was good.  

They have a nice selection of wines by the glass.  They sell full or half plates.  The half plates have a reduced price and allows one to try many dishes.  

If you are celebrating a special occasion and looking for somewhere to go in Wilmington for fine dinning, this place is worth checking out.

Revolution Taco is a fun and trendy taco joint in the Rittenhouse neighborhood. I ordered takeout from here on Grubhub during the pandemic, so I'm not sure how the dine-in experience would normally be. But the food was scrumptious and delicious. The food is more on the side of Americanized tacos as opposed to traditional Mexican cuisine, but it still hit the spot. I ordered their classic beef tacos - but this isn't your Old El Paso family taco night with just ground beef and shredded lettuce. The tacos were stuffed with various fillings and made for a satisfying lunch.

Overall a great taco eatery I'd gladly visit again.

United By Blue is a nice coffee shop near Penn campus with a welcoming ambiance and decent food and drink, though above-average prices. It's a good place to come for a breakfast or coffee catch-up with a friend or to get some work done. There's lots of space for spreading out or finding your nook. Overall a nice campus café.

Cool place to hang out at and watch a game.  My friends and I stopped by here before we were going to head back to L.A. after a great weekend in SB.  The Lakers were playing so we wanted to watch the game first.  The service was good and also the food. They also have a good selection of beers on tab.  We also ordered a bottle of their house cab and it was nice. It was only $18 for the bottle. We munched on a some fries and a pizza.  It would have been a better experience if the Lakers would have won the game.  But no stars were removed because of that. The kamakaze shots were pretty good too!  Good way to enjoy a Sunday afternoon in Downtown SB.  Peace out Yelpers!

TwinOak would probably be in the running for a 5-star review based on the food and beer selection, however the service was sub par both times I have dined there. 

I was not in the mood for pizza (but the bites that I sampled from others was great), so I opted for their mac and cheese app and a house salad. Salad was fresh and very good for being just a salad, but the mac and cheese with gorgonzola and bacon was AH-mazing. They have regular mac and cheese as well as a daily mac and cheese special, which was the said app that I loved. I highly recommend it if available.

The beer selection was great for such a small place and being a "pizza" place. I loved the local brewery support and I really enjoyed the Unicorn Killer brew.

Unfortunately based on the two times I have visited TwinOak, the service was pretty awful. They just don't really seem to give a damn about your experience and are unfriendly and not on top of their game. 

Amp up your service TwinOak and we will be best friends! Oh and I can't wait to drink on the patio when it's not blazing hot outside!

It's full of old timers, but First watch is not messing around when it comes to great breakfast and lunch! 

This review is based on the lunch menu only... 

We came here for a quick lunch and got exactly what we were looking for. Service was fast, efficient and professional. I had the Monterey club sandwich, which was great, and I could not believe it came with a small salad and their fantastic potatoes. What a deal for under $8! 

First watch is nothing fancy to look at, but it definitely beats Denny's, IHop and the rest of the brunch serving bunch. It's clean, organized, and has amazing food, what more could you ask for? I'll be back to try their breakfast very soon!

It's not bad pho, but I wouldn't pay $11 for it. The wraps were also quite good.... and I wouldn't pay $12 for it. Mostly because I've had better and for much cheaper, such as in Philadelphia and New York City.

I haven't had L&L BBQ in a while, but I was craving it so we went there for lunch. I noticed new people so I asked if it was under new ownership and she said yes, a guy named Rob Chadwick. Sad to see the other owners not there, but who knows what happened to them so I ordered the seafood combo plate which comes with fish, shrimp and a choice of BBQ chicken, beef or kal-bi. And was then told they ran out of fish yesterday.  Ok so if they ran out yesterday why didn't they have any today. I understand certain owners like to stay with certain vendors but hey shit happens and shit gets run out. So go to the regular store and buy more. Right? Maybe, maybe not. I was just very saddened by that so I got a different plate. It was good. They didn't give the same amount of macaroni but that's ok. A lot of meat. So I guess my only complaint is don't run out of the main seafood item. Don't have a choice on going elsewhere because they are now the only Hawaiian BBQ place here in reno and sparks.

One more thing they also ran out of buns so my husband didn't get to order what he wanted to order either. Not a very good impression on being the new owner.

Ok time to update!

I don't know why I gave them 4 stars before. 

I've been here maybe a handful of times whenever I'm in the Sparks galleria area. And I have never been disappointed. Even the service is great. The little Asian girl that greets you is the nicest person ever. 

I got the BBQ pork with rice and it comes with fresh sliced cucumbers and pickled cabbage, bell pepper and carrots. 

That on its own is so yummy when you eat it with a bite of the rice and pork. I'm not sure if everyone knows that's the reason why it comes with all that. Because they want you to eat the rice and pork or whatever meat and take a fresh bite of the veggie. 

Not trying to toot my own horn, but Asian people are food geniuses. 

It reminds me of my own culture. Why do you think with our food they give you a little bowl of rice with your main dish, meat, fish whatever tofu. And then all those little crunchy veggie goodies on the side. It's a condiment, that compliments the food your eating. Hello kimchi!!! It goes great with everything. So the cucumber and pickled veggies are like the kimchi for us. 

Anyway. Also got the pork egg rolls. Not sure if it had pork inside of it, but it was still good. Husband got the noodle wonton soup. Very good and flavorful even when I can barely taste because I'm so sick. 

I've tried their tapioca drinks also and I loved all the ones I've tasted. The honeydew is my favorite. I definitely love this place and will be coming more often.

Great all around!!! The food was phenomenal and the service was second to none.  When we first showed up I instantly thought there was no way we were going to get seated right away and would have at least a hour wait because the parking lot was packed.  

This place isn't cheap so if you are trying to go out for a quick bite to eat with the family this is not your place.  If you are going out for a special day with your family this is a great place to go.  They have a decent sized kids menu and the kids food is great.  We went for a later dinner and I think the waitress could tell our kids were ready for their food.  As a result of that the kids food came out in less that 10 minutes and was delicious.  

To top it all off this place has the best military discount I have ever seen.  If you are in the military and show your ID card you get 15% off.

Having grown up in Mexico I found some of the food lacking. Definitely do not get the  tortilla soup. The chicken was either undercooked or heavily processed. It was like rubber, the mystery meat in the Campbell's can is better. The fish tacos were good but deep fried, not authentic by any means. The chicken tacos were good and a little more traditional, though the tortillas are better on 8th st. The arrachera was tasteless and did not have the traditional sides. The guacamole was good but very to much lemon the chips were good and the tortilla helping was generous. The servers were very nice though the food came out slowly. The margaritas are very strong and the churro ice cream and mango sorbet were good, though not home made.  The prices were very very fair, so if you want a decent Mexican that is going towards authentic and you are in the neighborhood, then stop by. Otherwise find out where the taco truck is stopping next and head there.

Sadly to say that I only gave them 2 stars because I liked their ice tea and friendly staff. The spring rolls were bland and chewy, sad to repeat that the Cheesecake Factory still has the best Vietnamese spring rolls, they also have the best peanut sauce! I had the faux pho, bland, no flavor. The stir fry is poor, too little sauce and too much rice. However they get crowded at lunch, mostly USF students with the munchies.

Like all good things, it always comes to an end. 500 Degrees "end" is now. 

During the summer, I tried the "mini Rouge burger" for the first time with some co-workers. Although not entirely like the Rouge, the 500 Degrees burger was the next best thing. I deemed it one of the best, if not the best fast food burger I have ever tried; better than Five Guys and even better than In-N-Out. If I wrote the review back then, it would probably be 4/5.

But, that was then. What happened? Did they change chefs/owners/something? I ordered the Classic Combo with truffle fries and the strawberry milkshake, while my lady got the burger of the week with the fried egg. We waited anxiously around 10 minutes and our number was called. We prepare to unravel the anticipated greatness to come, and BAM. Did I just get Punk'd? 

Everyone take a look at the photos that other Yelpers have submitted. Beautiful little thing, isn't it? This night, not so much! My burger was sloppily put together. The bun was squished and not at all like the glossy and puffy bun I remembered. Bad start so far, and it does not get better since they messed up my order and replaced my mushrooms with cooked red onions. After removing that, I took a huge bite to feed my burning appetite. Meh. I ordered medium rare and it came out medium to medium well. I remember the burger oozing its glorious juices all over my arm after the first bite. This was just a disgrace.

Her burger was not much better either. The burger was also put together like the McDonald's down the street from me, nasty. The egg had already popped and left a watery mess. She didn't even finish the burger. That doesn't make me feel too proud after talking up the 500 Degrees burger for so long.

The "truffle" fries barely tasted like truffles. It actually tasted normal, but was decent. It could have been a bit crunchier, since I hate limp fries. 

The milkshake was the highlight of our meal, but then again, who messes up a milkshake? 

Yes, this was a long review for a horrible experience. Yes, I am a little harsh on a relatively positive establishment. But hey, it must have been a bad night or something for this place to completely change from my last experience. I will not return. I ask for a favor to the next person who read this review and tried the burger. Take a picture for me, and let me know if it was just a bad night for them/me.

I love a good dive bar but you know what I love even more? I dive bar with great food! 

I am not sure when it happen, I've eaten here before  but never had it been as good as it was the other day.

My girlfriend and I were on our way to the Women's March a few blocks away and were craving Pho so it  was a logical stop.

We sat at the bar where the friendly bartender took our order which included the following:

Pork Egg Rolls (fried) - Tasty and full of pork. I do however wish they would add a few leaves of lettuces cilantro and cucumbers.

Banh Bao - Fluffy steamed balls of flavorful house BBQ pork that will have you stuffing your mouth as fast as you can.

Tempura Battered Shrimp Banh Mi - my new favorite Banh Mi in the city. Big shrimp wonderfully battered and fried topped with an amazing mayo sauce that fuses it all into one amazing bite.

GF had the Chicken Pho which came out piping hot with all the accoutrements and pack with flavor.

All in all it was a great meal in my favorite dive bar of dive bars.

Ps. Bartenders has great taste in music.

This place used to be so good but the past two weeks I've gotten cilantro in food when I say no cilantro but what printed this review was the beef and eggs that are norm my fave tasted off then I found a cooked maggot! I guess I'll take my $50 per order else where!

Famous 4th Street Cookie Company does have really good cookies. My two favorites are the chocolate dipped chocolate chip cookie and the classic black and white. It also located in the Reading Terminal, which makes it an easier destination since there are many other great spots to visit there.

The two details that lose a star for me are they're not on LevelUp. (Most places in the market do you this handy app). The other point of confusion is their pricing is based on weight. And because these cookies weigh more than I guesstimated, I was surprised by the total bill.

I was pretty disappointed.  The food lacked good flavor.  They serve can soda instead of fountain.  Atmosphere was very outdated and gloomy.  WAY overpriced for what you get.  They bulk up your meals with tons of vegetables so you barely get any meat.  The spicy crab salad was pretty delicious though the crab was skimpy.

"We all need to make time for a burger every once and a while." 

Punch Burger is a burger joint that I will always make time for. They deliver on their burgers! In between fast food and a full-service restaurant, you can enjoy seating inside or on the patio and drink a beer, eat a burger and waffle fries. 

My favorite is the Thai burger. Who would of thought peanut butter on a burger could be so good?! I had my doubts. However, my first bite was light and refreshing. They pair a reasonable dollop of peanut butter with a crunchy slaw and juice patty. Nicely done Punch Burger!

The food was really good but the customer service was so rude. So we ordered table side guac and it was good but the server just had a horrible attitude. We asked for extra chips and we were waiting so long for them that my friend had to finish her drink for the other waiter to notice that we needed some chips. We ordered veggie fajitas and they were really good but we got it to go because we were waiting so long but it was alright.  After we received our checks he asked to see our IDs which was very suspicious to us because he only asked us and no one else in the restaurant so I'm my overall experience was very disappointing.

Was my friends birthday and he was looking forward to eating some seafood. As soon as you walked in you can smell the fish. The whole restaurant had a fish smell. We all got salads and it had peas in it. I have never gotten a salad that had peas in it. I ordered the chicken Parmesan. My friend's husband ordered a platter and my girlfriend ordered the crab cakes. She said the crab cakes were really good. It was more crab than breading. My chicken was very greasy and oily. My friends husband's was also greasy and oily. You can see it pooled on the bottom of out plates. Either the oil was old or it was up to temperature. One of those two. Our waitress was great though.

Awesome decor, Decent food. A little costly given the portion sizes. 

Service is definitely lacking and staff clearly prefers that you dine out since your food is brought out to go.

I also had to ask for napkins.

A lot of love went into the design of the location but they were out of hats and most shirt sizes. Basically a lamb baphomet logo and a mostly black motif. 

I managed to get some stickers however. Just ask!

My mom really has been wanting to try this Outback and I have been there in the past with a lackluster experience.  She wanted to go so I tried to keep an open mind. The food has been consistently good in my last couple experiences.

The host- not terribly welcoming, or friendly in my opinion , but we didn't wait- so that's a plus. 
Zee was our server. She was very attentive and friendly. Although she wasn't able to get to our table immediately she did acknowledge us in a timely matter and I always appreciate that. Mom and I both ordered the bourbon bacon salmon. I got the seasonal veggies and a baked potato and mom had baked potato (loaded) with a salad. When we placed our order my mom wanted to order the pasta w chicken and shrimp for my dad- "to go".  The one thing that's ridiculous is we got her salad and bread before she even got her wine. Not Zee's fault- maybe just a slow bar? I find that's a universal truth of every outback I have visited. 

Our entrees were delicious. Salmon was flaky and tender and came w one strip of bacon. My mom felt the menu picture showed a lot more bacon- I hadn't noticed. The baked potato was fluffy and served how we requested. Our server checked back with us promptly- thanks Zee! For dessert we got a large chocolate thunder from "down under" to share and it was delicious! We got our check, and Zee forgot to order the "to go" food. Not a big deal though. It really didn't take long and she took responsibility and ordered the food and rushed it for us, although we weren't in a rush. She was just so pleasant it really was not an issue. My mom left a very generous 20$ on 80$ because we liked Zee so much. 

Why three stars? One word- bathrooms. Garbage overflowing and trash on the floor, the sinks were gross and wet. And no toilet paper in the stall I chose (of course!) Also garbage in the stalls. Keep in mind I was there at around 4:15 and the restaurant wasn't busy. There's no excuse for this. None.

Don't really understand the hype unless the location in Chicago is significantly better than the on in Fishers. We arrived at 11:30am on a Tuesday, so we were expecting a lunch crowd but nothing like this. It took us about 40 minutes to order and get our food, then you have to battle it out for a table. And after all the hype and waiting, the food was nothing special. The chili cheese dog lacked flavor, chili was blah which is crucial. My wife got the Italian beef sandwich with peppers, it was okay at best, much rather get a French dip at Arby's though. The chocolate shake was the best part of my dining experience. Don't get me wrong, I'm glad I tried the place but I don't think I'll be back.

Surprisingly great experience at Olive Garden. The meals are usually so-so. But possibly due to changes with Covid, things have changed. 

Everything was great, especially going here on a Friday night. When you arrive, you get added to a list, and wait in your vehicle until your table is ready and you receive a text. 

The breadsticks tasted fresh and were very flavorful. The salad is always on point and wasn't disappointed there either. 

The one downside was the old fashioned. A true old fashioned should only use the orange peel as a garnish, but this one had the orange muddled into the drink, with the slice in the drink. 

But the shrimp scampi over angel hair pasta was fantastic. The garlic olive oil sauce was delicious, light, and very flavorful. I would definitely recommend it if you're an angel hair fan!

So I originally gave Pod a 2 star review because I think it is below average for the quality of food. But, let me qualify that, if Wharton/Penn Law/ [insert your favorite corporate account] is paying, then its actually a pretty good restaurant.  ok granted free food is generally always (more) delicious but truthfully the food isn't all that bad. It is pricey and not the best value for Philadelphia dining, but certain items are actually pretty good! For example, the crab spring rolls are delicate and savory, a real treat, but for $16 (or $14), I can eat better food in philly.  Also, who pays that much for salted edamame beans? 

I had the lunch sushi combo which was very average sushi and not that expensive because it was on the lunch menu.  The appetizers are much more creative and inventive. If I wasn't paying, I'd give Pod a solid 3.5 stars. But since recruiting season is over (just kidding!),  Pod isn't a place I'll likely come back to. I'd rather save my money and try out buddakhan, sampan, or morimotos

Stopped by just for dessert. The hostess was helpful and friendly.

We were seated at the chef's bar area. I really just wanted to try the banana cake and unfortunately, it was disappointing. It tasted like something that was just sitting around for days -- not fresh at all. The fudge sauce was overpowering and detracted from the dish as a whole.

I'm not sure if the savory foods would have been better, but I would not venture back to try it.

We could also see into the kitchen and it seemed a bit like a McDonald's kitchen -- sad and cold. Maybe it was because the restaurant was pretty empty so it was kind of slow, but it didn't turn me on to the food.

Amazing food ... but is it worth the price? 

My friend recommended this place because they serve authentic Vietnamese dishes that's usually harder to find in other Viet restaurants. I looked at the pictures and was so excited about the water fern dumplings (I've seen them before but can never find a place that serves them). I didn't even bother checking the price because all the food looks so good. We ended up paying about $80 for 3 dishes... 

We got the Shaken Beef and Soft shell crab. (After devouring the water fern dumplings) The shaken beef was amazing - so juicy and tender, and it's served with this lemon-y dipping sauce. Its very peppery. The soft shells crabs were delicious too but they only had 5 pieces of very small sized crab along with some vegetables. After our meal we were still hungry. 

The food is delicious, but the quantity is little for the price. They labeled their entrees "to share" so I assumed it would be big portions. We also had to pay extra $3 for the white rice because their entrees don't come with rice. 

Overall I was very impressed with the food and their menu. I don't think I'll come back because it is a bit overpriced in my opinion.

Must try restaurant in Philadelphia!

Wow amazing! I had the most wonderful experience here... we made a reservation for the indoor seating and the interior of this place is so dreamy! They are also known for their garden seating outdoors because of the cute greenery surround it but it was too cold outside we wanted an indoor seating. 

My boyfriend surprised me with a reservation for our anniversary. This place is fantastic for dates! It's so romantic with the candles & dim lighting. We ordered the cheese board as appetizer. It came with 6 different types of cheese and nuts/jams that compliments them. You also get a bowl of chips/bread on the side. They also have a sheet of paper describing what cheeses are presented. We had so much fun sampling the cheese and reading about the flavors. That was an experience itself. 

For the the main entree we got the seared scallop & shrimp lemon risotto (rainbow cauliflower & jalapeño sides) and the smoked pork belly in onion-lemongrass soubise (apple & cabbage sides). Both dishes were amazing and came with amazing side vegetables. The flavor pairings are so unique ... definitely the best risotto dish I've eaten. The couple sitting next to us also seems to agree. 

We ended our meal with a key lime soufflé cake. We've had soufflé before but not sure what a soufflé cake is ... it tasted like a castella cake. Came with creamy graham ice cream on the side and the flavor pairing again was just amazing!! Sweet, tangy, but you can also taste some salty pebbles in each bite. 

They put so much thought into the menu. This is one of the best restaurant I have been to!! Funny story, the waitress randomly brought out two bite-size pieces of chocolate cake at the end along with a candles since she thought we were celebrating my birthday. That was so sweet of her ... even though we were here for our anniversary. But this just goes to show this place goes above & beyond with their customer care!!

If you're in Philadelphia, definitely make this place a restaurant bucket list!

My second visit was horrible. We sat down and waited 20mins before the waitress acknowledged us. We gave her our drink order and appetizer (raw oysters). 10mins later I notice our drinks on the bar are ready. Another 10mins go by and we finally received them. The waitress then brought us menus again and we told her we already ordered. I explained to her we were in a slight hurry so I asked for the check. I paid and she said the oysters would be out in a second. After waiting another 10mins still no oysters. We left! Hope someone got to enjoy our appetizer. 50+ mins of poor service. Appeared to have one waitress at 4pm on a Sunday...can't say it was all her fault. I give it 2 stars becaus the drinks were good atleast.

When you walk in you will be immediately captivated by the ahhhhmazing mural on the far wall. It's an artistic expression of some of our city's awesomeness. I won't spoil it with specifics you'll have to visit Tavolo V for details. Scott & Selena were just lovely servers! They were super super hospitable, accommodating and gave great recommendations. Actually Scott wasn't my server, Selena was my assigned waitress but they apparently work as a team here...I love it! 
 
I started with the roasted cauliflower...to die for! Perfect texture & taste. Next up, Salmon special with Parmesan crusted tomato, arugula pesto & a crab chutney (devoured). Lastly, my sister and I shared the Coconut Gelato & Tiramisu (both of which we took a single bite and left u finished). Neither was bad I think we just weren't in the mood for dessert after all. 

Other amenities:
*Both street & secured parking available
*Patio 
*Full Bar
*TV
*Exposed brick 
*Linen napkins 
*Tea lights  
*Beautiful wood detailing 
*Partially open kitchen 
*Groovy background music 
*Prime location 
*Me....I'll be a regular going forward

~Christy

Awesome bar! 

Awesome seafood dishes especially the mussels!

Awesome servers; very pleasant, prompt & full of personality!

Awesome desserts!

Off the Central West End's beaten path!

Don't leave without trying the mussels!

Thank me later!

I've only been here once, and I'm thinking upon further examination this place could be a 4.  However, I'll go off my one lunch visit.  The inside of the place is kinda of neat, certainly bright and open during the day.  Had the ribs, which were good.  The server was attentive and the rest of the menu looks inviting.  Next time I'll venture upstairs to the bar area.  Good less crowded option in the Rittenhouse area.

I've been here twice now for brunch.  It's. ... nice.   Nothing spectacular, but when you think of some of the other places in Manayunk, I'd actually consider bringing my parents here.  And there's something to say about that. 

The food is solid.  Pet peeve #1, any bunch dish involving eggs and cheese in a skillet should come with toast.  It didn't... I was charged $1.50 for toast.   Also,  pet peeve #2, this place does NOT need valet parking.  They literally take your keys (and $10) and park on the street 50 feet away.  Maybe reserve those spots for patrons instead. 

Solid Manayunk option for a nice meal.

We made a 9:30 reservation. When we checked in, we said we'd wait at to bar and get a drink since the table wasn't ready. By 10:15, we asked the status of our table. "We moved you to the bar in out system". How about you consult us?!?! We wanted a table and waited for one, not to sit at the bar. Sincd they didn't have one, We ordered drinks and patiently waited. What a waste. Pretentious staff. The bartender suggested we go to dinner across the street. Ultimately her recommendation was spot on. Only positive was a lively scene.

I've had the exact same experience here twice - years apart from each other so I can't help but assume that it's the norm.
We were seated immediately, and that was the end of the prompt service.  The server continued to be pleasant to deal with just scarce.
It was late in the afternoon on a Saturday and there was 1 other table in the place.  This seemed promising as I was starving.  Ok, who isn't starving right before sushi?  It took about 30 minutes for our first order to come up.  There were just 2 of us, we didn't order insane amounts of sushi.  Maybe 5 long rolls?  1 other table..5 rolls..30 minutes.. 
The sushi was tasty, but nothing special. It could have been fresher.  I feel like they pile on the sauces and accouterments to hide sub-par fish.  A really good sushi doesn't need all that jazz.  Ok, we put in an order for 1 more roll and waited. With food in our bellies the wait wasn't as painful as the first round.  The wait for the check was definitely annoying though.  Granted a few more tables had come in since we arrived but all in all I really think they need to work on their customer service.  The sushi was good but it doesn't compensate for waiting that long, not when other places serve better and treat you better.

Ordered 25 steak burritos for pickup at 6:45 AM Monday morning on Thursday of last week. I even talked to the manager, Karina. 

Guess what? I arrived early at 6:25 AM and am advised by Karina that "I forgot." 

Forgot? I cannot even explain how angry I was. These breakfast burritos were for a recognition event to thank our landscape crew. They are on the clock by 7 AM and I needed to have their breakfast delivered hot and ready to start their day. 

OK, so the burritos were ready 10 minutes after the time they were promised. I was also promised a 10% discount when I ordered and I suggested because they forgot my order and I was running behind now that Karina should give an additional discount. She graciously applied another $10 off. 

When the burritos were delivered I finally got an apology and a sorry for the wait. Im glad I arrived 20 minutes early instead of at the designated pickup time of 6:45 AM, the time my burritos were supposed to be ready.  And Thankfully the landscape crew supervisor was understanding of the late breakfast delivery for his crew. Three Stars today, as while I appreciate the service recovery effort,  it's no excuse for forgetting my order.

PS The crew said the steak burritos were great.

I loved, loved, loved Sacred Pepper...the decor, the ambiance, the service....THEEEE FOOOOOODDD! We started with shisito peppers...tempura style served with a flavorful Asian inspired dipping sauce.  I love shisito peppers and these were AH-MAZING - the best I've ever had! The crab and corn chowder was rich and creamy...it was a little thinner than some chowders, but still delicious! We ended with a pasta dish with spicy sausage. I enjoyed every.single.bite. I cannot wait to come back!
Eh, all diners kinda suck. This is kinda sucky for a diner but I'll give it the benefit of the being "A-OK" - good coffee and now open 24hrs again. So, that's a plus.

I had heard a lot about this place and probably would have been on my perpetual to-try list until the other evening when my girlfriend and I were redirected here from a failed dining attempt at For Pete's Sake. Their friendly bartender informed me that their kitchen closed at 11pm that evening and kindly directed us here.

We were particularly pleased. It was late night on a Tuesday and the bartender was pretty helpful at informing us of their specials and offering up some suggestions. We shared a massive 9oz. burger topped with pork belly, caramelized onions and provolone. It was on special and proved to be quite delicious.

All in all, I'll gladly return to this place to check out their other offerings. The staff was friendly and the atmosphere seemed pretty chill & laid back. It also looked like they had a pretty good draft and bottle selection.

Extremely slow service, but the food was good. We were seated in an almost empty restaurant. Our server took our drink order, brought us our drinks, and then disappeared. After waiting over 15 minutes and nobody coming by again, my husband went looking for someone to give our order to. After the order was placed, it was 40 minutes before we received our food. Again, the place was not terribly busy. We ate our meal, which was pretty good, but took entirely too long to get to us. Our server dropped off the check and walked off. It was over 20 minutes before she came back to get our payment. 

A few tables around us eventually had people, and they all became frustrated as well. They also were seated and then forgotten about. And it wasn't just our server who was slow, another one was as well. Perhaps it's a training/management issue. If we visit a Joe's Crab Shack in the future, it will definitely be a different location, this one simply isn't worth the wasted time.

Came here for a late lunch on a beautiful Sunday with my girlfriend and our dog. The hostess and waitress were awesome! Food was good. We got the burger and falafel sandwich. I was surprised falafel sandwich didn't come with a side like a salad or fries considering that it was $14. But that's okay, next time I'll try something else. Overall it's a great spot for lunch.

Went in to pick up some cookies, pizzelles, and cannolis. Place was packed when we got there around 2:00. No cannolis were found, and employees were too harried to ask. Lots of Italian foods along with items from Springfield Pasta since SP sells their cookies; tit for tat. I know their cookies are delicious. They were not inexpensive, but they're only five minutes from Collegeville Diner, so while we were in the neighborhood....

I've been to this place so many times, and every time is basically a coin flip. Both the food and the service are so inconsistent that you have no idea if it will be a wonderful experience or a terrible experience, regardless of how many times you have been. 

The most consistently good things I have had are the pulled pork sandwich (a special that is offered pretty frequently) and the pulled pork pizza (a regular menu item). The shrimp and pepper pizza was great the one time I tried it. The fish tacos are sometimes amazingly good and sometimes surprisingly mediocre. The cioppino isn't very good (I don't think they even offer it anymore), the sandwiches aren't very good, but the burger is usually pretty tasty. The fries have improved and are usually pretty good.

The service is just as inconsistent as the food. Sometimes it is perfect, sometimes no one bothers to check up on you and you end up having a two hour lunch, anxious to get back to work. To improve your chances, try to sit in Esther's section, as she is by far the best of the waitstaff. If it is busy, don't sit inside unless you want to yell across the table for your entire conversation, as it gets unimaginably loud inside.

A Good Meal with a 60's Atmosphere
Located in the Sands hotel this diner is a throwback to the old school 50's-60's, thick shakes, great french fries, burgers and a lot more. They have a very large traditional menu with what you would expect. They also serve up a pretty good breakfast and I would recommend the breakfast burrito. Look for their daily specials because you will get a good meal at a great price. Not fine dining but a great place for a casual meal with a 60's atmosphere. Great, friendly service and reasonable prices.

They have an extensive menu with a lot of interesting Italian dishes. The service has always been great with a knowledgeable friendly wait staff. They also have a nice selection of wines. Six of us went to dinner; the calamari fritti was excellent, The mushroom ravioli was cooked perfectly but was lacking in flavor and the chicken parm was full of flavor but the chicken was over cooked. The linguini and clams was really good full of flavor and the clams and pasta were cooked perfectly. The lasagna was the hit of the night, excellent

Last time I was here, it was for a wedding in the same building and I did not even remember being here. When we tried it again for drinks before dinner, i vaguely recognized the bar, and remembered the many different types of brews served here. 

Very nice place, seemed somewhat understaffed. Very friendly hostess and waitress though

I like Sub Zero... They just suck on weekend nights.  We visited at about 10pm on a Saturday for a late dinner after a concert.  There was a short wait, which was fine.  But it seemed to take forever to get one of the 5 bartender's attention.  After we ordered a few drinks, our table was ready.  The music was so loud, the bartender couldn't communicate with us effectively and screwed up our tab.  He fixed it, but we had to wait a while. 

For dinner, we ordered a few appetizers and some rolls.  Everything came out all at once.  Service simply sucks on the weekend.  The food is still good, but the experience is so much better when they're not trying to cater to the wanna-be crowd.  

Sub Zero, I love you... when you are not distracted.

JP's has always been a favorite of mine.  They're walking distance from all of the major sports venues so it makes a great place to drink before or after the games.  Also, the place is big so you never feel crowded.  The bar food is good.  Hand cut fries, a decent burger, and many other options.  They have a plenty of bar games and it's the only place downtown I know of  with pool tables.  Although they close them later in the evening to keep the drunks from destroying them.

This place has already accurately been described by many other Yelpers. A great place to meet Cardinal fans. Expensive beers. Old building (which can stink at times). Many different bars and rooms. Extremely convenient to the stadium. 

I usually skip this place because it's too busy and overpriced. However, the group I was with outvoted me. I didn't know they had $2 pizza's. I don't know if it was a daily special or not. But $2 for a pizza after a Cards game was a blessing.

I ordered the New Year's Resolution... it's basically a guilt free burrito filled with tofu and veggies.  While it wasn't popping with flavor, it was still good.  However, I regret not ordering tacos, or at least something with beef or pork.  The space is nice.  The service was good.

This is a diluted version of PF Chang's.  They offer just a handful of menu options.  We tried the Lo Mein and an order of the lettuce wraps.  The wraps were similar to Chang's with plenty of flavor and sauce running down your forearm.  The noodles were good too... however after a few bites, you realize that they're loaded with oil.  Don't fool yourself into thinking these dishes are healthy.

Very good, upscale American food.  This place is a MUST TRY for a romantic date.  The dining room is dimly lit with mini streetlights and candles on each table.  

The food is good.  However, I still prefer Niche and Acero for upscale American.  But again, this place is more romantic than either of those two.

I tried the tuna and pork dish.  It was a bit strange... three little stacks of pulled pork, a fried green tomato, with cooked tuna on top.  It was an interseting mix but not my fav.  The other dish on the table was the duck.  I thought it was better.

Salads were small but very yummy.

Service exceptional.  We started with dessert then entrees, then salads.  This is my preferred way to eat to ensure I have room for dessert.  The server took it in stride.

As the meal was concluding, I noticed that the servers and managers gathered around a large round bar table to finish their turn-in, have a glass of wine, and share experiences about the night.  This is usually done behind the curtain, but I kind of liked it at a table.  You could see the comradarie and as I left every one of them smiled and thanked me for the business.  Very Anthony Bordainesque.
I was hoping for more in the way of food. I'm big on Italian and it was just average. I wouldn't go back to eat, except for possibly dessert on the cute romantic patio in the back. Friendly service.

Had dinner here with a friend, service was great but the food was lousy. Both of us had a chicken dish and both were way overcooked.
And then there was the mystery carrots, absolutely horrible and inedible! Ridiculous for the price. Would not return again and would not recommend.

I mentioned in another review that Chris and I watched an episode of Aziz Ansari's "Master of None" where Aziz's character takes a date to Nashville and they go to a sadly fictional BBQ joint. Well apparently, the joint in the episode was based on Martin's. Chris and I finally made it to Martin's before a preseason Predators game to try that white sauce that Aziz's character was raving on so much about. Unfortunately when we got there, it was busy. That was to be expected as there was the Predators game, but we were able to get to very cramped seats at the upstairs bar. It was uncomfortable and I was pretty much pressed against a pillar, but I'll endure for BBQ. 

Chris told me that it is a must to get chicken to go with the white sauce, so I did that. I don't know. I don't care for eating chicken with bones. I'm not really sure what my hang up is, I just don't enjoy it. Having said that, the chicken was good for the most part. Could've used more seasoning or something, though. The white sauce was good, but I would've liked more. I didn't feel I had quite enough.

Chris had a brisket sandwich. Usually when I get BBQ I get brisket. I tasted his and immediately wish I'd gotten brisket as well. Delicious.

I really wish they had corn on the cob on the menu. I'm getting annoyed that I'm going to so many BBQ restaurants that don't have corn on the cob.

Filthy. Needs to be cleaned! The inside bar was nasty. The bartender spent most of his time talking with other employees on the other end of the bar. The bar top had spills and was sticky. It clearly hadn't been cleaned in a day or two. The bar manager sat next to us to speak with a beer rep and placed her arm in a pile of crumbs from the previous patron. She didn't seem to mind one bit the bar wasnt clean. We walked outside and I peeked in the shed that had supplies and that was also disgusting. This place needs to be inspected. Lord knows what the kitchen looks like. A bunch of kids running a place that could be a gold mine!

We went there for the first time last Friday. We will DEFINITELY be back!  Its  a very nice restaurant inside and out. But you don't need to have a suit and tie, which is always a plus for me.  The chips and salsa were very good and tasted fresh; a nice change from the canned salsa most places give you now. I had the salmon and shrimp. They were both cooked perfectly, very moist and tender. My wife has the chicken Parmesan. I think that was the BEST chicken Parmesan I have ever tasted!  Both portions were huge and very filling. I think there were 3 or 4 chicken breasts with my wife's meal. 
We would have given them 5 stars had it not been for 2 minor details. We were sat right next to the exit for the kitchen, so we heard "corner!" all through the meal as the servers walked in and out. We also had to ask 3 or 4 times for a glass of water before we got it. Other then that it was a great meal and next time we will just be sure to ask not to be seated near the kitchen.

Maybe the mistake was going on a weekend. I might try again on a weeknight. I had high hopes, but this is a very crowded event. Very very crowded and everything has a long line. Everyone was just standing around in line. People didn't even know why they were in line. 
First it took 25 minutes to get into the Tarkington garage. It was very poorly designed and very small. Large trucks and SUVs have a hard time getting in and out of spaces. We should have parked across at the other garage and walked. It only took 20 to get out. Maybe they need people directing traffic in the garage. 
My goal was to find the baked cheese and hot wine. Both lines were huge. This was about 2:30 in the afternoon. We gauged both lines to just be too long. I did wait for about 20 min and we weren't even moving. I gave up and we did a lap around. It was hard to get to most of the booths with the lines. I do want to go back to at least get a 2017 ornament.  
The food booths seemed to be the busiest. I would have liked to see more local artists and crafts. Some of the German things were cool, but expensive. 
I doubt we will skate. It's too bad you can't reserve a time. You just have to show up and wait for a spot. Seems pretty chaotic. 
If you go be prepared to wait and wait, then wait some more. It's very crowded and I saw no seats or benches. There were a few high tables. And some firepits, but they blocked traffic and were hard to get around. It's just too small of a space. The rink takes up 90% and the other 20% is 40 huts. Very close and crammed together huts.

I am a huge fan of Neopolitan style, wood fired pizzas and as much as I've wanted to love TGP, it has not measured up to any of my expectations. The menu reads mouth wateringly but the food never seems to make it to the table with the same gusto. I've tried several different house pizzas and the toppings are consistently flavorful but we all know that pizza, especially wood fired pizzas are all about the crust, and that is where this place fall apart. Every pie I've had here has been horrendously soggy and limp. With the telltale char marks and bubbles on the underside it really disappointing to bite in and be underwhelmed by too little chew and absolutely no crispness. 

Compounding the meh crust is the apathetic and personality-less service. I've yet to meet the owner or any of the kitchen staff so this may not be unilateral but none of the servers seem to give two craps about their jobs or your satisfaction. 

For my money the move to satisfy my pizza jones in this area is to skip The Good Pie and head west on Delmar just east of old bonhomme and visit the guys at La Pizza. All around better option.

I am a big fan of Blackfish and have been hoping to make the trip over to Chestnut Hill to try the sister restaurant.  It was a quiet Wednesday night and actually had the restaurant to myself into 6:30 p.m.  The format had just switched to a tasting menu.  I started with the crab beignets and were a  bit greasy.  For the appetizer, I went with the roasted eggplant which was very tasty and large enough to be an entire course.  I finished with a delicious filet of salmon.  I was too filled at that point to have dessert.  My only issue with Black Fish is the noise level and the lack of space between tables.  Mica has addressed those issues and also has outdoor seating in the summer.

We were very happy with our experiences at G BBQ.  I was worried since there was only two other groups at 7 p.m. on a Friday night.  The ribs (which I always find the most hit/miss BBQ food) were fantastic.  The chicken was a little dry but good.  The potato salad was pretty good.  The cole slaw was the only true disappointment with no vinegar taste.  Excellent beer selection.  We plan on returning again.

I only had an appetizer but it was almost 15$$ and was very small. It was the ahi tuna app and the fish was very good and super spicy with this excellent rub on it! The host named Brandon was extremely nice and the atmosphere seems fun to watch a game but over prices

Very cool atmosphere. Great cocktail list inspired by famous people. I had the smoke and mirrors drink with mezcal. I have never had smokey tequila before but I really enjoyed it. The service was good and it was a beautiful night and they have outdoor seating so we got to sit outside. Def will go back!

We go to Olive Garden on a semi regular basis. I personally feel the quality has gone down as well as the service. This past weekend my husband got the steak and ordered it medium and it came out well done and dry. When he slathers A-One all over a steak there is a problem! Our waiter never asked us how our food was. I only ate a few bites of mine. It had a terrible taste. I had gotten the mozzarella chicken. It had way too much oil on the plate as did my husbands. The waiter again did not ask me if there was an issue. My brother got a chicken dish that came with risotto and the risotto was so bland. An Italian place should know how to cook risotto. I wish they would work on quality so we could start going more like we used to.

I really liked Benchmark after my first time there, but since-- things have progressively gotten worse and I'm not quite sure if it's because the food is actually not as good as it was the first time I ate there, or if it's the service that is influencing my opinion of the food. Went there last week and sat at a table for 22 minutes before deciding to leave. It's one thing to be busy, but a completely different thing to avoid eye contact with a customer. I saw two other tables get served (we had been there at least 5 minutes before the other customers were) before anyone even came in to greet us (we actually left before anyone came by). It was super disappointing and I'm doubtful I'll head back anytime soon. I've been there a total of 4-5 times and it's been worse on every occasion. 

P.s. The one good/standout point: I love the complimentary garbanzo bowl. 

My advice, go across the street to Sama Sama, or head a few blocks down to Eureka.

we went for the tachos and we were not disappointed!  tater tot nachos covered in nacho cheese, poblano sauce, and a bit of sour cream are not to be taken for granted - they were amazing!  the tots were perfectly cooked - crispy on the outside, soft on the inside..we wished we ordered more than just one order!  The bar itself is a little gloomy and I don't think the bartender was super excited 2 girls a little tipsy from wine tasting down the street strolled in, but we got decent drinks, were able to grab a table, and dug into the tachos...have I mentioned how amazing the tachos are?!?

On our visit here, we ordered their delicious blackberry fruit juices.  My husband and I both got the Papusa platters.  The beans were room temperature and so was the salad.  The papusas were very good.  They give you 3 to an order.  They were pretty good.  It's hard to find a good place that makes good papusas.  Our waiter was almost stalking, as he sat up top and looked down at us the entire time.  I guess he was bored since it was a strange hour, around 3pm.  Cash only!  That's crazy!  It's 2016 people.

Easy review. Great place to take kids for event dining. I wouldn't go there on my own or with adults only. Food is fine, desserts are awesome and the presentations are fun and add to the frivolous nature of the restaurant.

My husband and I had dinner there again this evening, and they didn't disappoint. The service was great, as was the food. We had the crab stuffed onion rings which were delicious. I had crab stuffed shrimp, he had lasagna. Both were excellent!

This restaurant is my favorite Chinese restaurant in Philadelphia. The service is great and very attentive. My family and I go there quite often so we have tried a variety of things on the menu. WE LOVE THE DUCK! The noodle dishes are fantastic as well. Just thinking about it makes me want to go there now.

I am giving Brasserie by Niche a solid 4 stars.  I had an extremely tasty meal here and would absolutely come back.  It definitely has a different vibe than the previous restaurant in this location (Chez Leon) and I have come up with a few pros and cons.

The pros are the great service and excellent food--the gnocchi Parisienne melted in my mouth and the prune clafoutis was delightful.  I think the only 2 entrees that were priced higher than $20 were beef. Other than that, all entrees were priced under $20 and they have a 3 course meal that costs $30.  

The biggest con to me was the fact that they restaurant seemed EXTREMELY high-staffed and, as a result, I think I counted about 11 staff sort of hovering around.  I know this is a new and hoppin restaurant, but it seemed like way too many people given the size of the space.  

My only other qualm with Brasserie that, believe me, wouldn't keep me from coming back, but just annoyed me were the red and white checkered table cloths.  They seem more like the stereotypical decor for an Italian restaurant, not French Brasserie.  

Finally, and not to end on a negative note, I'll say that Brasserie by Niche is a must try and I'll definitely be back for another special occasion.

I finally got the whisky sour I've been looking for. The place looks great and they have the worlds heaviest bar chairs lol. They got a heavy selection of whisky for your enjoyment. Now the menu looks like it has a great selection and I opted for the hot fried chicken strips. My cousin got the shrimp & grits....both kind "meh". So we move on to other foods. They said the steak is legit, so my other cousin got that and I got the short rib sliders..."meh", again. The whole food selection we got was meh actually. I'll come back for the brunch and a whisky sour with less ice. The waitress was 5 star but she's leaving for Ga.....so " meh", again! LOL

Everything was great!  To be honest, I was a bit skeptical about coming here at first because I've seen a bunch of Mr. Ed's around the city and it just seemed like another typical seafood chain, but I was pleasantly surprised!  The food and our server were wonderful.  Everything on the menu looked absolutely delicious, I wanted to try everything!  As an appetizer we got the crawfish spinach & artichoke dip which came with garlic bread and oh my gosh!!! SO GOOD!!  For my meal I got the crab cake pasta, which tasted just as good as the crawfish spinach & artichoke dip.  I also had some of my sister's seafood avocado salad, which I was greatly intrigued by as I've never heard of putting crab on a salad before.  It was amazing and the crab was such a nice touch to the salad.  For dessert we got the brownie a la mode, which was delicious except the brownie was a bit dry.  Other than that, I would definitely come back to Mr. Ed's, especially to try the oysters which I unfortunately did not get to try this time.

My first experience here was stellar. The service was prompt, the sushi was delicious, I thought I would become a regular. My second visit didn't meet the same expectations. My third visit was the worst of them all and I won't be back for a fourth.

I decided to give Tokyo sushi another chance after Valentine's Day. I figured the apathetic service was due to the volume of customers they had on that special day. WRONG. Today's service was 10x worse than the last time. 

We arrived around 1:35 in the afternoon -- the bar was full, but the tables were nearly empty. We were quickly seated and given menus. We wrote down a few appetizers and rolls on the sheet of paper and stuck it at the end of the table and waited.... and waited some more... and our waitress finally grabbed it 10ish minutes later.

Our mussels came out first (which never seem to disappoint), then our pot stickers a few minutes later. We started to receive our rolls one at a time in 10 minute increments. I have no idea why they serve sushi this way. Sharing one roll at a time with your starving 6 foot something boyfriend isn't fun. We received our third roll and was told this was the last roll on our list which was a lie. My boyfriend and I looked at each other confused. We were missing our yakitan and two other rolls. The guy who delivered the sushi was gone before we could say anything.
