We didn't get another sheet until another 15 minutes when the waitress walked by and we had to say "excuse me" to ask for a refill on our waters and a new order sheet.

We filled out the order sheet and placed it at the front of the table. I swear it must have sat there for nearly 20 more minutes. This was turning into the longest sushi date I had ever been on. When the waitress took the sheet I had asked if she could add some regular mussels to our order. She nodded and walked away. We received our rolls again, one by one, but no mussels. We see our waitress go to the table next to ours with an order of mussels and they had said "oh, we already got our order a while ago." And she turned around and took them back to the kitchen.

I asked a different waitress if she could check on our mussels. She asked if I wanted "regular or baked" and I replied with regular. 10 minutes later she comes back with BAKED mussels. 

I just don't get what's so hard about your job. I have never had such slow, crappy service in my entire LIFE. We didn't even get out of there until nearly 4PM. We spent maybe 30 minutes actually eating and probably two hours waiting for our rolls to be delivered. Big difference from my first visit to my last visit.

Really disappointed with this casino, the $10 parking fee is absurd as well as the excuse their representative keeps giving. The idea that we must pay for decent lighting as well as feeling safe on their property is ridiculous. With all the money they make it should be a given. There are other great casinos I have visited in other states and none of them has made this change. Everyone should boycott this place for a week and let them realize they should place more value in their customers. If not they will see it reflect in the tips!!!!!

I keep coming back for the Tuna Poke; rice, raw tuna, jicama, in a sauce that has a kick to it.
I should try other dishes.

Definitely prefer this over Taco Bus.  Great price.  3 1/2 stars - going with my guts here.  Definitely go back if I ever want a taco.

Excellent tacos. Got 1 fish (one big piece of battered deep fried fish) , 1 steak, and 1 pork.  True, no salsa needed.

Wasn't that impressed with the taco salad though. The shell was too oily, and the content was way below average.

Music was way too loud.
Terribly inefficient and terrible customer service from the very beginning of my order. Won't be going back anytime soon
I would have given it a three if others had not told me how great it was. Glorified bar food at best.

Very good quick, cheap Thai food. There are only four stools by the window for restaurant dining. I ordered the drunken noodles and they did not disappoint. Very large portion, nicely spiced with the right amount of vegetables.

I'm sure it is a BYOB, just don't tell them.

Please see other restaurants in the area...I've tried this establishment twice now...the first I thought it was a bad day and they were short staffed...2nd time...not any better at all! The fish I ordered was raw it took the server 7-8 minutes to check to see that I had not eaten any of it...I ordered the chicken corn chowder to start don't bother it's like dishwater with corn and no chicken and came out cold- sorry to say we were looking for a great place near home to come and hang with a good atmosphere and food...for us it's not here.

So I stopped here to try the ph and bánh mì while I was on a quest to try out all of the best of those offerings in town back when this place was Dai Viet.

I can say that while I was the only person there, had to seat myself, and it seemed a bit on the grungy side, that the food was right on the mark.

The sandwich clearly had a fresh roll, the meat was very savory and juicy, and the produce was very fresh.  When I got my ph, it was piping hot and very well done.  The basil and sprouts were beautiful and looked like they belonged in a glossy magazine.  Broth was very rich and really fufilling.

I had a great impression upon my arrival at Birra; great staff, awesome pizza oven with chefs making your food right in the open, and pretty decent menu.

We got the three little pigs pizza, which has pancetta, porchetta, and all the goods I'd love on a pizza. I was extremely excited to hear that they house make they meats themselves. However, the pizza was just okay--nothing too amazing. In fact, I think it was a bit overcooked.

I was informed by the waitress about the truffle pizza, with an egg on top--which just happens to be one of my favorite pizzas EVER. So I knew I HAD to go back for it.

The truffle pizza made me go back to Birra, and unfortunately it will probably be the reason I wouldn't go back to Birra. There was an uncomfortable amount of oil on top of the pizza that was literally dripping off each slice, the truffle flavor was very minimum, and the egg was surprisingly a fried egg dropped on the pizza (I had the impression that the egg would have been cooked on the pizza, while in the oven).

I had much higher expectations and they were definitely not met.

Having touched on the negative aspects of Birra, I can't forget the wonderful service that we received every time; the staff has been consistently nice and make us feel really welcomed.

Metropolitan Grill is a very average restaurant.  I've had meals that were above average, and meals that were so below average that they were comped by a manager.

I'll start with the best thing about Metropolitan Grill:  their complimentary zucchini and sourdough bread!  I can eat that stuff all day, it's so good!  The zucchini bread is rich and sweet, but not too too sweet.  The sourdough bread is crunchy but soft on the inside.  I don't like the butter they serve with it, it's usually oversalted, but neither of the breads need it anyway.  They taste great on their own!

Now, let me get to the worst:  the service.  Since the most recent reviewer of Metropolitan Grill had the nerve to say that people who think the service is bad are "1) rude, or 2) lousy tippers", I want to address how invalid of a statement that is.  I take offense to it.  I am never, ever rude to staff anywhere.  I am universally considered to be overly nice to everyone I meet (I don't think you can be too nice, but others disagree with me).  I also tip no less than 15% (unless someone is downright mean to me), I commonly tip 20%, and have given up to 50% (and not on $3 checks, on regular restaurant meals for 2).  This person's review is useless due to the off base  generalizations he makes about other's reviews.

So when I say the service at Metropolitan Grill stinks, it certainly does indeed stink, and it has nothing to do with me.  It usually takes us 5-10 minutes (sometimes more) to be greeted by a waiter.  I've gone entire meals without a drink refill.  You can look into the back server station and see them all huddled there, often goofing off, quite often.  I've seen them hitting each other with towels before.  All while I was waiting for an iced tea refill.  Not good.  The staff has never been rude, though, they're just not attentive.

The food is inconsistent.  I like inconsistencies because that means the food is actually being prepared by the chef and they're probably original recipes, not canned or frozen goods.  However, when the food goes from being super delicious one visit, and disgusting to the point of being sent back to the kitchen the next, there's something wrong.  This happened with the Four Cheese Mac and Cheese that I ordered on our last visit.  I've had it in the past, and it was seriously the best mac and cheese ever!  It was rich, and creamy, and had some heat to it from the chiles.  The next visit it was just ok, and this last visit it was so bland and the breadcrumb crumble on top was so burned, that I had to send it back.  The manager had it remade for me, and not surprisingly, it still tasted bland and bad because the cheese sauce is pre-made.  But he comped the meal without being asked. 

My husband likes their french dip sandwich.  He says the meat is tasty and the bread is soft and fresh.  The fries are ok, nothing great, but not too bad.

I like their weekly special three-course meal.  You get a salad, whatever their entree special is, and whatever their dessert of the week is, all for $16.95.  (TIP: Make sure you ask your waiter about it and what the dishes are because some don't remember to tell you.)  It's a really good deal, and the special actually rotates, which is nice.  It adds a little variety to the menu. 

Their dessert menu is great, too.  The desserts aren't knock your socks off, but they're sized and priced right.  They're not giant, but for me and my husband, still shareable.  And they're only a couple of bucks.  They're a great way to end a meal with a little bit of sweets!  My favorite is the brownie with ice cream on top.  The brownie is rich and moist.  They put a lot of chocolate and caramel syrup on the dish, too, adding a little extra flavor to the whole thing.

The restaurant itself is kinda boring.  The decor doesn't say much.  It's ok though, but not a place I would go to for a special dinner.  

The prices are reasonable.  The portions are reasonable.  Overall, Metropolitan Grill is a restaurant I will return to.

Let me start out by saying that I'm not much of a burger person.  You wouldn't know that at all if you saw my plate after a meal at Diablo Burger.  I actually finish the entire thing here, because it is actually really good!

My main issue with restaurant burgers is that the meat is usually low quality.  I can't stand getting a bite with gristle.  On the contrary, Diablo Burger uses really high quality meat.  It is locally raised, grass-fed beef from their own trust in AZ, and it is unlike any beef you'll get at most places.  Just from the texture of the burger itself, you can tell how different it is.  It's more lean, but not tough or chewy to eat.  The meat is also darker and richer in color.  I order my burger slightly more well than they recommend (medium-well vs medium), which they always overcook closer to well, but it's still juicy and moist.  Grass-fed beef is more difficult to cook, so I sorta understand that they can't get it to medium-well consistently, even though I would like it.  But I'd rather have it more overcooked than under, especially since the beef is still juicy and tasty.  And no gristle!

The Blutarsky is my favorite burger.  Their guacamole is insanely flavorful and makes the burger even more juicy and yummy.  They put a good portion of it on the burger.  It adds a nice creaminess to it.  The English Muffin doesn't really do it for me, but it's ok.  I think a kickass bun would be better.  English Muffins can be a little dry and boring.  It works well enough, though.

Their fries are tasty, but too thin for me.  I like a bit more potato in the bite and less fried crunch.  Still, they're way better than most places.

I think it's ridiculous that they don't have a soda fountain.  Right, ok, they don't want to serve the corn syrup/artificial drinks.  I get it, but I don't care for it.  I don't want to drink sugary Mexican Cokes or beer, and I'd like to have something fizzy instead of just water.  Sucks for me at Diablo Burger.

I also don't really like the community seating, but we go at times when it doesn't matter.  I wouldn't enjoy eating elbow to elbow with a stranger though if that turned out to be necessary.  The seating itself looks like it would be uncomfortable (no back support for those of us with bad backs), but it's surprisingly ok and reasonably comfortable.  The rest of the restaurant decor is kinda boring, but clean.

The service is a little awkward and not highly attentive, but then again when you're just given a carafe of water that you serve yourself out of, there's not much for them to do.  They don't really talk much though, which is a little bit odd.  It adds to the boring feeling of the entire atmosphere.

The prices are slightly high, but not so bad, in my opinion.  The food is fresh.  You have to be willing to pay more if you want fresh food, otherwise establishments will cut corners so they can make a profit.  That's not what most of us want, and if you do, just go to Chili's.

Diablo Burger isn't perfect, but they're really good.  All of my gripes are minor.  My true testament to how good their food is is that me, the not-a-burger-fan, finishes the entire Diablo burger.  They're good, go give them a try!

Went after getting my ashes on Ash Wednesday because I was STARVING from the day before. I got their shrimp plate which was served with french fries or potato salad and a piece of buttered french bread.
My total came up to be around $10.xx 
Maybe it was because I was starving, but I thought the food was pretty decent this time around. I had a good bit of shrimp left over as well that was still tasty the next day...

I've eaten here a couple of times.  We've tried quite a few items on the menu now, from the various burgers, chicken tenders, chili cheese fries, onion rings, and of course the frozen custard.  

The burgers are very similar to steak and shake but very inconsistent on the meat.  They aren't shaped patties, more like flat pieces of meat that fall apart and a double is about the size of a 1/3 pound burger if I'm being generous.  I tried the sourdough melt and sent it back to have it remade since it wasn't sourdough bread.  They just use white bread toasted and call it sourdough.  The second time I just ate it even though it was still white bread, it wasn't worth trying again to have them realize it wasn't sourdough bread.  

They bring the food to your table which is a nice touch.  Chili cheese fries get extremely soggy quick, but the chili has a nice flavor to it.  The custard is very thick, definitely around dairy queen thickness and has a pretty decent flavor.  I've tried a couple of them and they were ok, nothing special.  

They have walleye which I haven't tried yet but have missed it, I had it up north.  Hoping it will be good, but we'll see on another trip.  

I don't go out of my way to go here, but it's better than having to take the kids to McDonalds.

Haven't been here in years due to poor service .  Food has always been good .  Was a customer for years before the bad service few years back . Husband wanted to try it again . We seat at the first table closest to the TV in the bar . It seats 4 , we are a party of 2 . Place was steady but 8 other tables were empty . The older lady that came and gave us the menu , asked how many in our party . When we said 2 . She said just 2 ? Then looked around the room and back at our table .  Made a face . Not a good way to start :( .  Bus person , with European accent, continue to bring a salsa and chips and did a good job. The salsa is good. The salsa isn't chunky  and slight spice.  I ordered the # 20 and it's good folks . It's steak and enchilada.  Be ready for the $20 price .  But it's a big thick steak and it was very good. The cheese and enchilada was also good. The beans and cheese or just normal. My husband ordered a cheese enchilada and ground beef taco. He enjoyed both of those.he commented several times on my steak on  how good it was.  I did think of ordering  a shrimp enchilada, but they have it as market price. The shrimp cocktail also at market price. So I didn't order either.  I have never been to a Mexican restaurant that had market price on their seafood . but all in all we had a good meal and OK service.

jukebox... check
23oz LITs... check
creepers... check
too close for comfort with strangers... check check check

due to my deep love for conversations with strange strangers, this place gets 4 stars.

overpriced gyoza, although tasty.
my real disgust with this place came from my experience i had with the alaskan roll. i had not noticed it was listed as being made with boiled salmon. i received what looked like cat food. recognizing that the mistake was mine, as it was apparently listed on the menu with an asterisk, i did try one piece and did not make a fuss. it was so bad that i would have spit it out had it not been a rude thing to do. 

once they checked on our table and i mentioned my error for ordering this item, and that i was not going to be eating the remainder of the roll, the server tried to remedy the situation by knocking off a buck or two from the roll price, since i only ate one piece. he did however make it clear that it would be difficult to remove it from the bill completely as the owner was around, and the owner would say that since i had eaten a piece, i could not have hated it. so i suppose i should have spit it out onto the plate to the dismay of my friends.

note that i did not ask for it to be removed from the bill, nor did i expect it, but i know i'll never come back.

i want to review once more after having tried one of the wraps. went on a weekday night around 530pm, found parking easily on the street and ordered a shake with peanut butter, banana, soy milk, and chocolate (the macho?). i enjoyed it but it would probably not go out of my way for it again.

gets cool points for atmosphere. they ended up dropping a big projection screen around 7 to show "So I Married an Axe Murderer", which was weird but someone else might love that.
$3 for an 8oz. orange juice? Peace. Sayonara!

Had 2 eggs with sausage and bacon, hash browns and biscuit and gravy.  The only part of the meal that was enjoyable was the hash browns.  White country gravy was disgusting, tasted like sour cream or curdled milk.  Scrambled eggs had hard chunks in it and the sausage was barely cooked.  When the waitress asked it I would like a box for the uneaten biscuits and gravy I said " no thanks, the gravy had a funny taste."  Her response was "oh".  When asked at the cashier ( after waiting 5 minutes for someone to take my money) if everything was ok I responded " it was ok.  Your gravy tastes very odd to me like sour cream or curdled milk". Her response " haven't you had our gravy before? ". I told her no and her response was also oh.   No one offered to replace the uneaten biscuits and gravy with toast, pancakes, English muffin...nothing.  Seemed like thy didn't care at all.  First and definitely last time we will ever go and I will be passing my experience on to all I know. 
Cute interior but if your looking for a good breakfast with employees who care....SKIP Jethros.

Lots of options but ultimately not superior to other doughnuts I've had.  The customer service wasn't great.  The line moved surprisingly slowly for a doughnut place and then it took us awhile to get our order rung up.

We tried a few different varieties of the doughnuts.  All fine, not spectacular or special.  Probably better than Dunkin Donuts but more inconvenient.  I don't think I could say definitively better than Krispy Kreme although I do prefer local places.

My extended family tried Newk's for lunch on a Sunday. We were afraid it might be really busy as it is sometimes when we drive past, but this time it was not. I found ordering to be a bit difficult, although this was my first time eating here. I'm not sure what we would have done if the line were long - it is hard to tell where to stand in line when waiting to order and the menu is on a big board that is to one side perpendicular to the place to put in your order. Luckily the guy taking my order was very friendly and helpful. I ended up getting The Q sandwich with Newk's "white barbecue" sauce - it is made from horseradish sauce. The sandwich was hot and fresh, but I found it to be bland and uninspiring. My daughter ordered a salad which came in a HUGE bowl. Both she and my mother in law had to take home leftovers. My wife ordered the pizza margherite and enjoyed it. My son ordered Mac and cheese, which he picked out about 1/5 of it that was too burned and crunchy for him to eat. We did not try any of the unique drinks like tea. We didn't think the round table was as much as it is cracked up to be in all the in store advertisements for it - kids liked the crackers though while waiting for food to come, which took forever. For the price, I would not recommend Newk's. I would say you should go to Panera Bread or McAlisters Deli instead, where they both have unique menu items that rotate with fresh varieties and don't cost as much as Newk's and the service is faster. The food was okay, but with a lot of other choices for similar deli like food in Greenwood, I do not plan to come back.

Good food. Good service. They have about 10 beers on tap (mostly A-B products) if you're a beer drinker. If you order chicken-fried steak, go with the half-portion. The full portion is too big, plus it comes with two sides and a biscuit. Enormous!

54th Street isn't really a destination restaurant. However, it's next to Ronnie's 20 so it's a perfect place to get some food or drinks before or after a movie.

The main idea behind Rebar is that you can pour yourself beer by the ounce. Not to sound like Trump, but this system has to be rigged. I went to a tap, poured the tap, immediately released the tap, and was charged for three ounces. Without getting into specifics, there's no way this could be accurate.

I ordered their signature burger (full half pound of house blended angus beef, whipped chevre cheese, bacon jam, pickled yellow tomato & grilled red onion on a brioche bun). The burger itself was OUTSTANDING, but the cheese (half goat-half cream) wasn't my speed...a bit frou-frou. You throw some sharp cheddar on this bad boy and IT'S ON! Maybe I should have gone for the angus sliders where I could have had the amazing beef without the nonsense on top. The fries were amazing, but the "toppings" could use some work. The curry ketchup was really good, but the bloody mary ketchup and RB sauce were gross.

The staff was SO SO nice. Great service. The manager was straight cuteness. Looking into her eyes was like taking a vacation on the coast. What's the etiquette on asking out a bar manager? Impossible, right? She must get hit on everyday?

The steak is okay. I give it a 1 because it's not worth the price. Very expensive. You can find a much better steak at other restaurants in town. Plus, my experience was dampened by some annoying couple trying to sell me real estate as I ate at the bar.

It will be interesting to see how this place does because it offers so much. Latitude 39 is a bowling alley, arcade, bar, restaurant, comedy club and live music venue. From a brand identity standpoint, I would imagine it would be difficult to be "all things to all people" and to do all of those things well.

Anyway, I came here to eat dinner because I had never been here before. The bar was dead on Sunday afternoon, which was surprising because all of the other bars in the area were crowded due to the Manning vs. Manning (Broncos-Giants) game.  I liked the layout of the bar, although it was a little dark for the afternoon. It is far enough way from the bowling alley and arcade that you don't hear the noise accompanying those areas. On the second floor, there is a nice room with its own bar for private banquets. The bar had about 8 beers on tap. The bartender was nice and he handled requests quickly.

I ordered a cheeseburger and a side of fruit (they offer many side options other than fries). The food was good, although it was a dollar or two more than other sports bars in the area. I heard that Wednesday night is their most popular night because of their 39 cent Coors Light special.

On an outing checking out the tourist traps at the port we decided to try Fusion. This location has had countless series of new restaurants, all of which failed miserably. We were one of three tables for lunch, a good indication of their impending doom, our service was awful. The view would have been phenomenal had the cruise ship not been in port, but I used my imagination. 

I ordered the chicken bahi sandwish with the salad and my date had the burger. I can't say much for the burger, my bite was boorish. my sandwich, the flavor explosions were terrible...chicken, soggy bread, cilantro,jalapenos and sriracha. Sounded fantastic but what a soggy mess. My first bite the sandwich about fell into my lap. I was forced to pick apart the good stuff and trash the rest... It's a sandwich i shouldn't have to use fork and knife. The salad was meh, some fancy lettuce and that's all that I remember. Basically I'll be giving the next inevitable place a try in a year.

The restaurant is in distress and failing.  It was a 35 minute wait and half of the restaurant was empty.  The service was horrible.  The server was so bad we were waiving him down for drinks etc.  I will never walk back in this restaurant. I will be surprised if it's in business by 2020. I talked to the manager and he clearly was in panic mode. Stay away-really bad experience.  The manager was JD Harris and he was notified and nothing was done to address a belligerent server named Jordan.  He even refused to serve me a beer.  I had had one drink.  I am a HR executive and have never ever seen such poor management.i will call their CEO office Monday !

So I rarely come to south philly, let alone get a cheesesteak but I'm here late at night and my friend is craving some cheesesteaks. Now the place is quite attractive with the neon lights so Geno's looks good at first sight. The menu is limited and the prices are high. $10 for a sandwich is not worth it but again my friend is hungry. So we ordered  standard cheesesteaks with whiz and provolone. Orders came out quick so big props to them. Now the size of the cheesesteak is small, two strips of meat, and a sprinkle of cheese. Bummer. As I took my first bite, the bread was oh so delicious. Everything is else was nothing to talk about. So 1 star for service and 1 star for the bread. Overally there are a whole lot of places better than this, seriously.

An okay place to pop into for a drink. We made the mistake of not coming here Thurs-Sat when they have a DJ upstairs. Apparently the DJ that comes in on those nights plays a healthy mix of 90s hip-hop. That is what we were really coming here for, however, we came on a Sunday evening and alas no DJ and just an okay jazz band performing downstairs.

Plenty of place to spread out. There's also an outdoor area which I suppose they use when it's crowded. Bathrooms are clean but there is an attendant so be sure to bring cash. I saw her side-eye a lady who didn't have her wallet on her and therefore did not leave her a tip. Although this place IMO doesn't need an attendant and it kind of makes you feel obligated to bring cash with you.

My friends and I recently came here for the Pennsylvania Bacon Festival.  First of all, the festival was completely disorganized but this review is for the venue.

The venue is nice and rather large.  The festival was held in the parking lot but the inside was still open.  Inside there are a few bars all facing one another.  Some have seating at tables, others only have seating at the bar.  Absolut has their own little section of the place, as well as Chickie & Pete's.  There are two restaurants that also include an outdoor deck area which looks like it would be nice on a warm day.  The restrooms are VERY clean and I loved the mirrors/sinks but the hand dryers are in the back....Shouldn't they be on the way out?

Overall, it's a decent venue to visit if you recently attended a game or an event.

I am such a huge fan of Korean food so I was thrilled to learn that a spot like Bab Cafe existed in Reno. Their name is taken from bibimbap, the popular Korean mixed rice dish. Although there's likely other spots in Reno that serve Korean comfort food like this, this spot in particular is known for being veggie/vegan friendly and I was ready.

We ordered to-go two different bowls: classic and fresh. The classic contains rice, veggies, and all the standards of a bibimbap. For my "fresh" tofu bowl ($10), it substituted some of those veggies for fresh greens and brown rice. Although it's "fresh," they do use pan-fried tofu so be careful if you are trying to avoid too much oil or anything deep-fried. It wasn't heavy at all.

I absolutely loved my tofu bowl with their gochujang sauce (vegan friendly). It was something I could likely make at home myself but having it prepared for me at a restaurant with the sauce was deelish. They give you a lot of food too for the price so I was super satisfied.

The staff here were extremely nice and accommodating. They really respect your dietary restrictions, letting us know what was made in the soup, which sauces were vegan, and asked us if we could bag my vegan meal with the one with meat. It's small things like this that can really make a difference in your experience.

Limited parking is available on the street but you're likely able to find a hotel nearby where you can use their parking for free to grab the food.

I use to love this Chinese restaurant.  The food is still good and I like the fact you can place your online now but the delivery time is way to long.  A lot of the time we will just pick it up on the way home but sometimes we are exhausted and just want to get home.  We just ordered from here about a week ago and it took over an hour and a half to be delivered.  I called after waiting for an hour and the lady said he was on his way.  I am about 2 miles driving distance from their location.  I placed the order around 5:15 pm and they finally delivered it at 7:00 pm.  If I wasnt so hungry and hadn't used my cc online I would have refused the order.  But I did learn a lesson I will no longer be adding my tip to my online order because I did I give this guy $4.00 for a tip.

Looks like TheStranger2 is out on a limb again.  This must be another case of Boise Weekly  readers flooding the ballot for Boise's Best Burger. So here it goes...   We were downtown at The Grove Christmas Tree Festival. My GF suggested The Bittercreek Ale House.  No, I hadn't been there before, but it's burgers were always rated as one of the top in Boise. We ordered the fried cheese nuggets, which were good.  "Way big enough for two people," our waitress said, about The Huntsman Burger.  So ok we decided to split one.  For $14.50 I was certain she was right.   Well...I was wrong.  So was our waitress.  We looked at the $14.50 burger, then looked at each other in amazement. So what I gather from this, it must be the exotic cheese?  The select bacon?  The designer onions?  The designer special sauce?  Which adds the extra $6.00 to this $8.50 burger?   We split it.  And had two very small portions. The flavor was good, but not outstanding.  Far below Main Street Burger, Big Juds, Westside Drive-in or Highlands Hollow hamburgers for half the price. Even The Habit, Five Guys or Smashburger (which I'm not a fan of any) out paces Bittercreek's Huntsman burger. Heck for $14.00 Big Daddy's BBQ's Big Haus Burger is three times as big and three time more tasty.  In the Boise Burger Wars, The Bittercreek Alehouse gets blown out of the water and doesn't even break the top ten.  Very over rated and very over priced.

Decent patio with comfy chairs. That's the end of positivity in this review. I asked for a dry martini and she asked details about a dirty martini. The skinny bitch cocktail came in a fake glass (read plastic) highball glass. Dans could not be bothered to come back to the table more than every 20 min. It took 20 minutes to get a requested water refill. Goat cheese artichoke I'd fried (not stated) and bland. We asked for one check and got two. WTF.

Good country grub at a very "hot" stop in Nashville. Plan on spending over an hour to wait.  The food is good and the prices are reasonable. I guess it's the type of place you have to go to once.  Everything we tried was really good, just not great.  I had far better meals during my trip.
It's good. It's fun. Just not worth the wait.

The food and drinks are good.  The service is an absolute dumpster fire.  Wait staff mostly ignored us for much of the night and then lied to us about their liquor license to kick us out before the Monday night football game had ended.  Too bad for them.  I'm never returning to a place that employs such rude staff.

I normally love BWW, went there last night to meet my sister and mom.  It took us a little bit to get beers, after we got beers we couldn't get the bartenders attention to order food.  I order the small wings, they came out over sauces and the boat them came is was covered with wing sauce.  I had one bit and sent them back, after the 20 minute or so wait, they were at best luke warm.  I rarely send food back, but I couldn't eat them.  The replacement wings came and they were completely over sauces.  I didn't bother to send them back, although I should have.  Very disappointed.

My experience was the opposite of some other reviewers. The young woman serving was pleasant and helpful. But the food was not to my liking.

I asked if there were any choices that would avoid a lot of fat. She said that the beef is boiled so that would be a bad choice. And the chicken meat is from a fatty part of the chicken.

So, I opted for the vegan version. The vegan "chicken" managed to have the flavor and consistency of chicken fat! The only way I could eat it was to remind myself that it is really just tofu with that horrid texture.

The vegetables were mostly just overcooked cabbage. No broccoli or any other tasty vegetables. Under that was white rice.

If you are desperate for food in Isla Vista you might be OK eating here. Right now many of the restaurants are closed so I was desperate for something new.

I will add that as I was leaving a young man sat with his butt on the table where I had just been eating. I seriously doubt that there was anyone to wipe the table down after he left. I did not count that in my rating, but it was a bit unsettling.

Food was adequate. Service was subpar.
I asked for a salad with no onion and added chicken for maybe five bucks more. Salad had onion mixed in.  I hate hate hate raw onion so I waited for creepy server to come back around which took forever. My husband finished his grouper sandwich, my son finished his dinner too. Still I'm waiting. I eat some bread and a few chunks of chicken from the salad while I wait.
Server finally comes round and ARGUES with me about the onion on the salad. I show him onion. He then gets snarky with me and says "I guess you liked the chicken ok."
So he takes the salad off the bill but STILL CHARGES FOR THE CHICKEN.
I left hungry and I hate that server.

Service:
Low vibe servers are Sitting at the bar staring into space. Servers need a gallon of espresso just to get them to function normally. Had to ask other servers to get my server. There were 3 servers and 2 small parties dining for lunch. 
Food:
Took 20 minutes to come out. I thought that it was going to be great food, since it took awhile to get to the table. Wrong. The food was lightly warmed, tasted bland and was tossed down on the table. People are nOt pleasant here
OMG!!!!

I just went to Bourbon Blue for New Years Eve 2010. My boyfriend and I had six guests from out of town staying with us and we were looking for a good deal for New Years Eve in Manayunk. We paid $60 pp for a ticket that included 4 hours open bar, and a $20 gift card to use in the future. Overall their New Years Eve party was good. Downstairs got a little crowded (since I don't think they had a DJ upstairs until later in the night). The bartenders were a little strict about drink limits but seemed to relax as the night went on. If we went back next year I would buy one of the cheaper New Years tickets. Everyone else seemed to get exactly the same thing that we did at the higher ticket price (with the exception of the gift cards). 

Brunch - We went back a couple days later for brunch to use our $20 gift cards and everyone was pleased with the food. I had the Eggs Benedict with the crab cake and I will definitely be back to have that again!

Delicious, cheap, and making my mouth water just thinking of it!! 

I will literally drive from Manayunk to Center City at rush hour to pick up spicy noodles with chicken for dinner. All entrees are under $6.

This place is a shit hole and always has been. Security staff are a bunch of dicks, and actually l told me and some friends they didn't want our business because they where to lazy to check an ID. If I don't want a player's card I shouldn't have to get 1 correct? I was just DD'ing for friends and that's the only reason I visited this turd, but I will sure as hell never visit them again. I will also make sure that I let everyone know that casino staff said, and I quote, "they don't want customers money". I only wish I could remember your staffers name so you could give him a employee of the month award.

I know this Green Eggs is the new one on the block, but I just didn't love the service or the food during my most recent meal here.

The location of this place is prime, if you're walking around Center City and I'm sure that drives the foot traffic.  We stopped in on a Friday just around lunch time.  I was feeling more like lunch than breakfast so I went with the veggie burger.  When it arrived, it definitely hit one of my burger pet peeves in that the pattie was way smaller than the bun.  I ended up having to rip off a good portion of it just to make it a worthwhile sandwich.  My partner in crime got the vegan french toast and I noticed a distinct saltiness to it which i wasn't sure was intentional or not.  Either way, I wasn't thrilled.

I found the service to be a touch lackluster as compared to other establishments in the neighborhood.  We found ourselves a few times really hunting for our waitress just for a refill on water.  My coffee was pretty decent which bumps up the star rating a little bit in my mind.

I'm familiar with the other locations and those haven't disappointed.  Perhaps this location just needs a little time to get seasoned.

I've been to Triumph several times and it's a really decent go to place when you find yourself in Olde City.  The thing I like about Triumph is that it's decently stylish and they are making their own beer right there.  You gotta love that.  It also smells very clean when you walk in.  They must keep those fermenters very sanitized.

When I lived in Jersey (which I feel like was eons ago) I used to go to the Triumph in Princeton alot.  Similar food but a very different layout/feel to it.  I like the one in Olde City because it just works well for the space.  I like their hummus platter and their tuna tartare.  Actually their tuna tartare was awesome.  I could have eaten way more of it.

The beers are very hit or miss in my opinion.  I did enjoy their pumpkin ale this weekend and their dry irish stout is one of the best in my opinion.  Very roasty and not heavy.  Mid range ABV, making it a nice session beer.  I don't like their lagers normally so I avoid them.  I've also found their IPAs to use hops that I am not fond of.  Still, this doesn't stop me from coming back.

I'm happy triumph is there as a destination in Olde City.  It has consistency and it's a great spot for weekend lunch.  I'm not sure I would pick it as a dinner destination, but I like how it's always in the back of my mind if I'm in the neighborhood.

I will be contacting the manager in the morning as I cannot remember the last time I had such horrible service.  We paid for a $25 entree, half of which our waiter accidentally pitched in the trash, refused to give us more, and wouldn't take anything off our bill.  Absurd.  

They told us they served until 10:30, so we ordered dinner at 10 pm.  They put so much pressure on us to leave at 10:25 that we just asked them to box my husband's half eaten meal to finish at home.  (My risotto looked like a plate of vegetarian vomit and didn't taste much better so I skipped on the take out.)  My husband was brought a box with his buffolo medallions.  The waiter had thrown out the other half of his meal - a huge mound of greens and black eyed peas.  We asked if they could give us some other sides since we paid for a full meal and they threw out more than half.  The waiter said no, all the food was put away.  I asked him to take something off the bill.  He said he could take a $2 substitution charge off the bill but he couldn't take anything else off because he already ran the bill.  No logic here.  Why can you take off $2 but nothing more?

We live in the neighborhood.  My husband has eaten here many times and had good service.  Clearly this waiter just wanted to get the hell out at the end of his shift.  I understand completely.  I would too.  So either don't seat us and say kitchen is closed, seat us at the bar, or at least refund some of our money when you throw our food in the trash by accident.  I think a $25 gift certificate is in order.

I am honestly very surprised on how much I liked this place.  My only complaint, or more so a recommendation, would be to get televisions installed outside.  I went during Sunday football but my kids were whining and cranky so I did what any good parent does and sat outside with them.  Unfortunately there were not TV's outside so I had to stream on my phone.  Get televisions outside and my rating will go up!  Food was good and better than your average bar pizza and price was reasonable with plenty of alcoholic beverages to choose from.

I lunched here once before and it was memorable for all the wrong reasons. It was pretty much a swing and a mess with the food and service.

I'm glad I gave them another shot because my previous one star experience was eclipsed by a delightful lunch I just had. I got the burger special which was perfectly cooked and tasted delicious without a lot of extra goofy shit on it. The brioche bun was a real treat. I got side salad instead of FFs & it was colossal! A little overdressed but very good. And finally the Service which was truly impeccable. The hostess the waitress and the busboy were all efficient and really friendly.

This score (three stars)  is a composite of my previous experience and this one which was easily 4very solid enthusiastic stars. 

A good tip for anyone having lunch on a weekday: come at 1:30 or 145. A little bit after the rush and easy to get a table.

#fatjared say...might not have been an order that was usual, but everything should be done well. Below average experience for me overall.

Yelp really makes having certain criteria to stick with easy. 5 stars is the best, so that's perfect, 1 star is the lowest, so nothing good can be said about it, and 3 stars is average.

When I think about my time at 55 South, it was below average for a few reasons. 

First, the seating we had was not well thought out. It is right by the door, looking out the window, and that falls on the bartender. It was not her fault in my opinion because that should be a normal waiter, She had to walk all the way out of her normal area to come to us, and never got notified we were seated. So it took a solid 15 min for us to even get water. 

We stopped in at brunch, and obviously on Sunday in downtown Franklin it was packed. wait was only 20 min, but we were hungry. The menu options are not bad, but there are very minimal good options if you want to stay somewhat healthy.

My wife ordered the hot chicken sandwich, and I got oysters and deviled eggs. BIG issue with the oysters. They were not cut off the scallop yet, so it was tough to get them out of the shell. poor execution. The sandwich looked super simple and had no uniqueness. Wife only ate half. The eggs were decent, but again nothing special. We had potatoes as a side, some story.

This place is more of a bar type atmosphere, and for a brunch spot I know there are better options in Franklin. Will definitely try somewhere else next time! Below average for me overall.

I had to lower my rating because I gave them a 2nd chance for my mom's birthday in March. Our meal was nothing like when we went the first time, for my birthday in January. The staff seemed distracted doting on the regulars and my food was so bad I didn't even eat more than two bites; it just tasted like salt. I couldn't even bring it up to the staff because, as I said, they didn't seem to really be interested and for $120 that's not acceptable. 

I contacted the manager Judy, whom I took care of me for my birthday and she apologized and sent me a $50 gift card. 

P.S. I gave Harry's Hospitality Group one last chance at their Seafood Grill (which I'm left a rating.) But for the amount of money one pays at these places, it shouldn't be "hit or miss."

Food is great. The staff, not the brightest. I spent $200 on NYE. They passed out tiaras and party hats to the whole restaurant, staff included, somehow missed us, which would have been fine, but after asking 3 different staff members (who were wearing tiara's) how I could get one for my girlfriend, they couldn't figure it out. Sometimes it's not just about a paper tiara.

The hard rock now charges $10 to park.  The entire front of the hotel and casino lot is blocked off so your only option is valet or the parking garage.  The Harvest is at the complete other end of the parking garage so you get to walk through all the smoke and smell great.  If you're going just to eat, don't.  I may be he only one.  Lol.  We went for a work lunch because they have a variety of food so we thought it would be great for everyone.  The escalator was also broken.  So after you pay to park, walk across the entire casino through the smoke, up a huge flight of stairs, now you arrive. 

The cost of the lunch Buffett is $20 plus tip. You do save $5 by having a players card.  However, we all forgot to bring ours to work today.  We also didn't want to spend another half an hour going back to the casino to get one.  I'm not sure why they don't just make the price $15.  We were planning on paying $20 it just seems odd.  Once you pay you wait to be seated.  Once we were seated we waited about 5 minutes for drinks.  Another waitress besides the our assigned one ended up getting them.  We actually saw her more than ours. Once seated the staff was very good.  They all seemed to watch any table they walked  by and was very attentive.  The season there is great.  They also have room for larger groups.  The staff at the food stations were mostly pleasant and wanted and offered help.

The food stations were great. There seemed to be something for everyone. I had the pasta you could create yourself it was delicious.  I nibbled on a few things that weren't as great.  The homemade crepe for dessert was the best!  They had almost anything you could think of for other desserts including hand dip ice cream and made to order Belgian waffles.  

Everyone found something they really liked and no one left hungry.  I would call that a good lunch!  
We then get to go back through all the smoke back to the parking the garage. The down escalator was working.  If I was already playing at the casino or staying at the hotel I would consider going back but never to just The Harvest.

I think I may be the only one but there was nothing great about this place to me.  Everything was could have been so much better.  
The service was friendly and awesome if you could catch them!  but notNo refills, No How was your food, No Can I get you anything else.  If you wanted something you really had to ask loudly.
The food had potential but was served cold.  The menu sounds amazing and the tacos were tasteful but would have been much better if the meat had a nice temperature.  It tasted like the meats were cooked ahead of time and stored for the evening.  I do not prefer that.  It took away from all of the other ingredients of the taco.  They are also stuffed with cabbage and I love cabbage but too much.
The SoHo margarita was strong but also very bland.    It tasted like a watered down tequila shot.  The mugs were unique for the margarita to be served in.  
The room was nice and fun.  The sound carries so it is really loud if busy.  The chairs were not comfortable.  The parking is non existent.  
I really wanted to love this place and couldnt.    

I do love their response to reviews and the shout out to make it up.  Thank you.

Stopped in for the first time Saturday night. We got there a little after 5pm and it filled up fast. The service was great, Chef mathew came out and spoke to each table through out the time we were there. I had the grilled shrimp and roasted tomato risoto, partner had chicken pot pie. They were both amazing and the wine list was good. I ordered a large seafood gumbo to go. I think they gave me a small by mistake because when I dumped it out of the conatiner at home it was about a 1/2 cup. For $18, it was not worth it. But overall, the experience was very good and I can't wait to go back and try some other menu items.

I am trying to do my part to get businesses back on their feet after their long shutdown by getting carryout as often as possible or as tonight, dining on the patio. I'm still a little uncomfortable with being in close contact or going inside but...I stopped for dinner here on my way to work and sat outside. I ordered the Cesar salad and chicken parm. I normally love their Cesar but tonight it was way over dressed and the parm shavings were chewy like they were from the rind but it was still one of the best cesar salads around. The chicken parm though was awful. The texture was rubbery and tough like it had been frozen. The pasta and sauce was very good so that saved the day. But I made an excuse to leave and have my meal boxed because I knew I could not eat the chicken and with what these places have been through, I didn't want to add to their stress. I do have to call out bad food though for my reviews and this was bad.

I was very disappointed that they did not serve Burek (meat pie wrapped in filo dough). My Bosnian employees brought them to work luncheons and they were delicious. What I found very interesting was all the Schnitzel they had, there were 4 different schnitzels, I felt like i was in Germany. The Grbic platter I had was really good though, it had a massive amount of 4 different meats with some bell peppers, onions and cauliflower. I expected some rice or potato's but there was none. I would have preferred half the meat and a scoop of rice to round it out. The place was almost empty when we arrived but they seated us just across from the bar right next to the main aisle where everyone walks. I didn't care for that at all. It was a little cold inside but the décor was nice. Overall I good but nothing special.

Very tasty, perfectly cooked, well seasoned local beef though a tad small. Two of us ordered 1 burger each, split a beet salad (1 tiny quartered beet) , upgraded the fries for a buck, one of us iced tea, other water. Tax n tip=$37.00, a tad steep for lunch and I was still hungry.  I'm not trying to bash them too hard, I like the concept and I hope they do well just a bit pricey for what you get (or don't get).

I heard a lot about this place from people living in New Orleans and finally decided to check it out. I had a party of 3 and we ordered the assorted bread basket and taj platter as appetizers followed by 3 entrees - Lamb Biryani, Goa Jhinga and Malai Kebab. We were ready to feast.

Off the bat I'll admit as others have pointed out that the service isn't great. But that never really seems to bother me. They took our order, delivered our food hot and ready and kept our water glasses full. 

The appetizers were a little disappointing - the naan wasn't anything special and I honestly couldn't tell any of the 3 varieties apart. But they were quick to give us more dipping sauces without us even asking which was nice. The Taj platter was also meh - it had a few pieces of what essentially were chicken tenders and a few pieces of what appeared to be chicken vindaloo wings. I assumed it would have more variety but that's on me for not checking what was in it with the waiter.

The entrees however were incredible. The Lamb Biryani was delicious and used cinnamon really well. The Goa Jhinga had just the right level of spice that played really well with the coconut milk. And the Malai Kebab were cooked perfectly and came with a delicious yogurt sauce. They also come out sizzling on a hot plate which is a very fun, almost party trick.

Overall I'd skip the appetizers here but if I lived nearby I'm sure I'd be back often for dinner. I'll have to come out and try the lunch buffet sometime.
Food was excellent, but the server MCCoy was the best part of our experience. He was engaged, attentive and took our annoying orders with grace and ease. 6/5

Due to a rough yesterday and testing and X-rays today, I appreciated my brothers invitation to go out for pizza. Our only issue was deciding where to go. I recommended the Ale as we have lovingly called it for many, many years.  Several of us would go there after work when it was on 86th st. It was more personable then in my opinion. Since they moved here it's much bigger and the waiters and waitresses are running around like crazy.  We ate outside and it was so loud with people talking that it was extremely difficult for us to talk to one another.  Now, how was the pizza? Let me just say it was; SUPERCALIFRAGILISTICEXPIALIDOCIOUS! We ordered one large, thin crust, deluxe and one small, thin crust, pepperoni. One thing I can't understand, (being in a powerchair), if you go inside, all of the tables are the very high pub tables with the very high pub chairs. How does that accommodate anyone like me?? I couldn't get on one of those pub stools no matter how hard I tried. There were empty tables inside, however we had to wait for seating outside thanks to impossible seating for me inside. I can't speak on the other food, but I can highly recommend the pizza. The thin crust crust is slightly crispy and holds up well under whatever toppings you put on. They put on real cheese here!! Good old hot, gooey, stringy, delicious cheese. Throw in there some sausage, green peppers, mushrooms, onion, mmmm! Give the Ale a try

The food here is outstanding! We had the slow roasted beef sandwich today and there was a huge amount of real roast beef on it. It also had delicious Chipotle cheese and maybe it was voodeax sauce? All I know is I was going to eat half and save half for dinner, but it was so delicious I ate the whole thing! We had cornbread for our side. I adore the cornbread there. It's a little sweet and a little spicy. There is two sm/med pieces. I did save one to enjoy later. Tony snarfed all of it!

this place just doesn't feel right.
while you can't go wrong with a pizza or the family size salad to share with the table (the chicken is really yummy), the pasta was downright gross. too pricey for what it is.

If you're a native Hoosier, skip this review.  If you're from outside the area, like me, I can tell you that the locals rave about this place, but it was anything but special.  A 50s-themed restaurant that is family friendly, it's not in the best section of the Circle City or the best native food I've had.  Their signature is the pork tenderloin sandwich.  I found it incredibly dry and flavorless.  The kids meals come in interesting hot rod boxes, but you'll get more food for the dollar off the normal menu.

5 stars for the food. Delicious flavors and a changing seasonal menu was what brought me here twice. Fun and confusing decor inside but a great conversation piece. Pretty big with multiple rooms so seating is not usually an issue except for brunch on weekends (like everywhere else). 

Only thing I would improve upon is service. While they are super friendly, the wait times to be served and for the food to come to your table can be extensive. 

Overall, great food.. Not good if you're on time crunch.

This is my second time coming here. This time I had the grouper grilled with twice baked potato. I had the chicken noodle soup which was mostly noodles, but it had good flavor. It needed to have a better balance between noodles, carrots, chicken and I didn't see the celery. Our waitress said it's made different each time. Chefs...it needs to have a balance. The rolls are not fresh. I think they were either frozen or bagged in. They were warm so great job on doing that. We had the fried pickles which were fresh and came with a nice dipping sauce. I had the Grilled Grouper and twiced baked potato. The fish was a little over cooked, but better than it being raw. The interior needs a severe make over. Gordon Ramsay should come do a make over on his show 24'hours to hell and back. They make some of their desserts in house. I wanted to try the German chocolate cake and carrot cake, but don't need the extra calories at the moment. They have a wide range of food. From sandwiches, burgers, salads, soups, fish.and steaks. It's good food and fresh just not...oh wow it's great. It's close to home as well. The waitress and staff are very, very, nice. Great service!!

Heard about this place for over a year. If you like Greek food then this is a very good place. The outside of the restaurant is not eye appealing. There combo meal is very well priced. You can get the Greek salad instead of fries. The soda machine is self served and you get free refills. Now the good part....the gyro sandwich..AMAZING!! Filled with lots of fresh meat, and yes it's the real deal. They have the lamb meat on the tall secure. They slice it, grill it, wrapped in the large pita with tomatoes, and onions. Served with the creamy cucumber tzatziki sauce. I will definitely go back when in the area. Delicious....I wish more of my friends like Greek food. The reason for the four stars is the salad had alot of wilted lettuce. I said something when they asked how my meal was, and they said; "oh sorry about that"...

The best I can say for this place is the location is excellent! It is right on the corner with a beautiful view of the cathedral.  Service was decent.  However, the food was ... OK.  We both ordered benedicts, and though filling enough, it was unsatisfying in terms of quality both in taste(vinegary !?) and texture(soggy?).

I just stopped by Pionic Pizza and Pasta to pick up a hot dish for dinner. I've never been to this place but I thought I'd give it a try. The idea is pizza pasta or salad and you pick the fresh items you like. I love this idea. You can control what you eat, be bad be good but it really seems healthy either way. The staff was very sweet and attentive. They helped me decide what to put on my pasta and I chose Alfredo sauce chicken and basil. The noodles were pre cooked but they fire it in a pizza oven. The noodles weren't over cooked and the sauce was not too salty. It was really yummy. Thank you guys for a delicious dinner. See you next time! Lara

I got an Irish CHANEL STOUT 4/5: Prob. one of my fav. because it reminded me of a Milk Stout. It's the right amount of sweetness without it being overpowering - def. better than a Guinness. Pricey & was still $7 w/HH special - appreciated that I could take it To Go - loove open carry policy in downtown New Orleans.

DIRTY MARTINI 4/5: A double shot of vodka & with a lemon twist, which gave it a nice fruitiness.

I specifically came & made a reservation for dinner - wanted to start with raw oysters for Happy Hour, but they didn't deliver at all because they were all out. The manager apologized - really, really disappointed, so I decided to leave ASAP to another restaurant as a result.

Our waitress corrected our bill after a misunderstanding & appreciated that! 

This is 3.5/5, but I'll let it slide and select 4/5.

As soon as you park your car, it's hard to take your eyes off all of the beautiful, exotic cars that flood the parking lot. If you're coming here to eat, it's not unusual to see lots of profesionals.

I'd rate my experience 3.5, so I'm rounding up to 4 stars.   

To start off, the Point Judith Calamari is a good appetizer. The calamari was perfectly prepared and a little Asian sauce complimented the taste. It came with a Sweet Chili Sauce and Candied Cashews as well as bean sprouts, thinly spliced carrot strips, and sprinkled with sesame seeds. It was yummy tasting, crispy, crunchy, lightly fried with a golden crust...just the way it should be made!

For lunch, I decided on the Chilean Sea Bass and it was supposed to be made with with glazed carrots (didn't have a glaze on it and tasted plain), mashed potatoes, and champagne truffle sauce (the flavor was not evident at all). The best part about the sea bass was the authentic flavors; it was very simple and tasted really good. The fish was not dry at all and if you are someone who doesn't want their fish drenched in a sauce due to not being able to taste it, this would be a good dish to try. I do think the idea was to keep it basic and let the natural flavor of the fish take over. I think it was cooked in pepper and salt. At least that's what I tasted and unfortunately I couldn't taste the champagne truffle sauce or else it was very, very light. The carrots and peas were chopped and lightly sautéed, leaving a crunchy bite, but nothing about it left me wanting to take another bite. If I wanted to have carrots cooked that way, I'd simply cook at home instead of going out. I think the star of the dish was the fish, but it does have a somewhat strong fish flavor if you don't eat fish often. The sides that came with the fish did fall short on presentation and taste, so that was disappointing. If you want to enhance your taste buds and can't do that when you alternate between a bite of sea bass and your sides, don't be disappointed. Let's be frank, the sides are so ordinary and boring that I had to add salt and pepper to enhance it. I will say this, the sea bass is positively delicious and mild enough that other people who are not fans of fish would learn to appreciate it, even if they do not like seafood. The way the dish was presented, it's main focus was on the sea bass and the sides didn't get much attention at all. I guess what I'm trying to say is that a lunch dish for $29 should be better composed than what was showcased, but don't let it stop you from coming back to try other dishes. I do need to come during Happy Hour Mon. - Fri. from 4:00pm - 6:00 pm where you get 1/2 off selected appetizers. $8 cucumber gimlet, strawberry smash and pine fin cocktails.

GREEDY - I have to downgrade after I found a spot to park along with many other cars by the bridge where they're doing construction & got ticketed because I was parking in the opposite direction- I was supposed to face the other way instead. I am going to dispute the ticket because there's no sign about that & many others were also ticketed. Can you tell - I'm so mad! Armature already charges $10 to park but no - that's not enough. They want to charge people $30 because our cars aren't faced a certain direction...UGH! There's no oncoming traffic...it's not a busy parking lot compared to the main road so this is disgusting to do this to people IMO.

I try to support local businesses and I don't like this. I already spent $14/glass of wine, $6/coffee and an inedible Chicken Bowl...I feel like I wasted spending $60/night - factoring in my $30/ticket.

GROVE MULE (4/5 - 2 oz. pour): Mules are even more fun to drink for a hot day! 

SOLIDAGO (5/5 - 2 oz. pour): It's their variation of an Old Fashion although sweeter and I loved every ounce or the sips I sneaked from my hubs.

HOT WINGS ARE A GIRLS BEST FRIEND (5/5): David prepared them for us & they're baked beforehand and dropped in the fryer for 6 min. for a crispy exterior w/Bourbon BBQ sauce that is sweet.

LOVE GALORE (4.5/5): They are pretty big - could've been better hot vs. warm upon delivery w/a dash of sweet pepper jelly (no heat or spice, even though the menu states it).

Can we talk about the gorgeous mural they have in the back of the restaurant? I really loved it and it's moments like these that helps me to alleviate anxiety & makes me feel soo happy to have discovered this restaurant with help from other Yelpers & the importance of supporting local restaurants (Love the decor - I want to sit on the pretty & comforting looking blue suede couches w/a front seat view of the mural)!

There's also a club next door. I love Happy Hour, which starts @$7 & includes small bites & cocktails on Wed. - Fri. From 3-7pm!

My only recommendation is to amp up the heat on dishes that are considered spicy. 

Overall 4 - 4.5/5! Service is on the slower side - make a Yelp reservation beforehand & I always opt to site in the bar area because I love watching them cook in the open kitchen & chit chatting with the chefs (David & Chris did a phenomenal job whipping out dishes as fast as possible)! Thank you for making my stomach happy!

Went with a friend for his free play after spending some time at the Eldorado.  He didn't get lucky today though, but it's nice that you can stay indoors from the Circus Circus through the Silver Legacy to the Eldorado.  Marilyn at the player's club was extremely rude.  It was past 11 when we left and we were surprised to see so many children out with their families at that time.  Even the face-painting booth was still open.  Looked at some of the menu offerings at several eateries (some still open) and they looked yummy.  Glad I'm not a gambler- for money.  We will have to do this again!

If this is New York style pizza I must say I won't have to worry about eating pizza in NY if I should ever go there.  The crust was rock hard and soaked with grease and liquids from the meats and peppercini's (whole, not sliced).  The calzone wasn't much better, having little filling and even the pastries were sub-par in my estimation.  Sorry, we won't be going back.

Ate at Jane 4/17/19 for Anniversary.  My impression was they were one server short, as we had three different servers, including the person working the front desk. This was OK except for confusion about drink order. After 25 minutes, drinks hadn't come but entree was served. At that point a pre-dinner drink was not necessary, so I changed it to a glass of Pinot Noir, which went well with the NY Steak special, which was very good. I ordered rare and so it was. Spouse had the Anaheim chicken - excellent. Both dishes came with scalloped potatoes - excellent.  Veggies were properly done, but spouse just doesn't care for beets - should have asked for substitute. Our bad. 

After learning of the drink mix-up, staff was very apologetic, effusive even. 'Comped' our drinks and provided free coconut cake. We left happy and will return.

Have eaten here many times. Last night, four of us ate at The Nugget. Quality and quantity remained good. I had Angel's Pork Chop. Excellent. Another the Meat Loaf sandwich, with onion ring, also excellent (and a real value at $9.95), another Fish and Chips; good, but batter average, not a hearty, crisp beer-batter. Fourth person had a basic hamburger - very good. All in all, a good place for fair value.

I usually love El Vez. But I currently have food poisoning, and the only possible culprit is from their guacamole. We thought it tasted a little fishy and off, but weren't too concerned about it. Several hours later, complete food poisoning. So yeah, I'll be getting my guac elsewhere from now on.

I wanted a true Nashville experience so my friend directed me to Edley's in East Nashville and an experience it was. It's in East Nashville off of a main road and is MASSIVE. There are two large dining areas with a bar and plenty of seating from tables to booths. You order up front and really anything you get is amazing. I ordered "the best sandwich in Nashville" called the Tuk Special and it was divine. It's pork, spicy pimento cheese, fried egg, pickles and sauces. It came with two sides, which may have changed my life. The mac and cheese is very cheesy and the banana pudding is surprisingly out of this world.

If you want a cheaper, true Nashville experience, come here and leave content with BBQ in your belly.

YUM! We got delivery so i cant give TOO detailed of a review, but as far as delivery goes they are great. I LOVE that you can order online. LOVE IT! Service was really fast too, a major plus. We got a medium mushroom pizza and it was super good! Id eat here again. It didnt floor me, but its a decent pie with fast service and online ordering.

Fun espresso and coffee spot with good music along the lines of progressive beats.  It's smaller on the inside but quaint with an industrial/minimalist decor and seating, but you can definitely enjoy some time with a friend inside or out no problem.  Outside seating is a little more intimate, however.

Multiple (5?) types of espresso are available, which is something I've seen only at a handful of other places (Plenty), and I really appreciate as a lover of espresso.

While writing this review a cold nose belonging to a cute pup greeted me - they're dog friendly inside the place!

Coffee is SMOOTH!  No harsh 'S*bucks' afterburn in my chest, just flavor with just enough bitter finish, but not gross.

Definitely more coffee/espresso than breakfast, which I absolutely appreciate - focus on the good stuff!

The big hug of a coffee shop the big name places just simply can't offer!  Great wrap around couch in the back area for relaxing or doing work, cozy intimate tables, as well as a coffee bar at the window for people watching.  Pretty big area inside for your average coffee joint.  Artwork is presented all over the walls that is for sale - have to appreciate the support of those starving artists.  I feel like I've missed out with all the times I could've worked from here before... It's the perfect coffee shop - their house espresso is rich and not too bitter - soft and frothy.  The house coffee tastes great as well.  Soft Latin music is playing in the background... Just a nice relaxing spot.  Thanks for providing a great alternative to the pushy lines of the others!

I ordered $50 of food from here on UberEats. The restaurant accepted my order, then apparently CLOSED for the night. It took an entire hour and 4 different couriers for me to be notified of this. Why would you accept my order if you're closing for the night? That makes zero sense. I would honestly love to know the answer to this. In that time I could have ordered from some place else, and then ordered from you guys the next day.

Instead.....I'll just not be ordering from you guys again b/c who knows if I'll actually get my food?

I'm so glad I found this place. They do scallop nigiri the way I like it. Huge fricking scallops. That's my favorite. And pretty much everything they do here is done just a little bit differently, and it's always really delicious. Easily one of my favorite sushi places.

All the staff are super friendly too!

And they deliver!

Slow to greet, sat at table for 15 mins before flagging someone down. 

Menu is extremely limited. Looked like reheat and serve only. Hardly any seafood of note. 

Food was delivered to our table one plate at a time, final plate was 15 mins past the first plate for chicken fingers of all things.  Made for awkward eating/dining experience

My Mahi was inedible due to some crazy concoction using jalapeños on it that were extremely hot. Sent it back, just cancelled it altogether and ate later. 

Be aware of the "vegetable of the day".  We all received a plate FULL of long-cut, cooked carrots!?  Odd and Gross.  No veggie medley. Clearly the food buyers are struggling. 

Food quality in general was poor.  Tables around us seemed to have a similar experience. 

Prove doesn't match the quality of food or service. Steer clear. Major issues with the staff, menu, and kitchen.

So disappointed with Yeast Nashville. 

Arrived at 830am on Saturday to find that they were completely out of stock on the kolaches, which is what the place is known for (only ones available were Tex-Czech meat filled).  I asked about availability and was told it'd be over 30 minutes.  Settled for a breakfast taco instead.  When I was checking out, the same woman who told me that there were no kolaches left SOLD 2 cream cheese kolaches to the person behind me in line!

Totally unacceptable customer service.  They have lost my business and don't recommend that you waste your time with a visit here.

Want to be close enough to smell the action without being in the Fieldhouse? This is the spot for you! Having the Eastern Conference finals going on just around the corner had a spillover effect of energy and traffic. 

This is a great place to watch the game and eat some decent chow, have a beer or a dessert. 

Lots of outdoor seating too--though for the sportsters, the tv's are not outside, fyi. 

Great place to go for people watching and for being part of the crowd. 

Great energy to the place. Love the staff!

**AMENDING MY REVIEW DUE TO NEW OWNERSHIP 10/30/12**

Formerly my favorite restaurant in Indianapolis, the old owners are gone and the new cooks--whether they are using the prior owners' recipes or not--are not up to par. 

Food that was once juicy, tantalizing, flavorful are now watered down, recycled too often/long in the buffet slots and lacks the flavors that once lured me there and had me sending tons of people their way. They used to have the best, creamiest hummus in town--no longer.  They used to have an eggplant dish that would convert non-eggplant eaters into advocates--that's gone, too. 

They even replaced the awesome exotic iced tea with one of those crap Lipton machines. 

The only reason they get to even keep 2 stars (down from 5) is that the at least have yet to screw up the rice pudding and coconut  cake. 

Go downtown to somewhere like Bosphorous instead. This place lost all its special with the old owners. 

So sad, since I am passionate about quality international food. Boo. :(

Other than the odd/ awkward entry point (no host stand? No official 'hi, we've walked in the FRONT door of an eating establishment" type of clue...) I loved the space. The pub faire tasted authentic. I lived in England for a year, so I can be pretty picky, but the Shepherd's Pie here was AWESOME! I wish they would have served it with a small helping of chips like they do in England. Who doesn't want potatoes with their potatoes, I ask you? Not this kid. I could dip french fries (chips in this instance) into a baked potato smotherd in mashed potatoes with a raw potato appetizer. I guess that's the Irish in me. Love it. My fellow diners seemed equally impressed. Way to go! Oh, and they have Boddingtons. Now I am getting home sick for London. Thanks a lot, Red Lion Grog House! I'll have to be back soon.

Not as good as others raving about it. 

The pho and frankly everything else is sub par. I think people appreciate it being a more american style restaurant to feel like it's cleaner than a small Vienamese store like Saigon Deli but honestly the small stores are what the real gem is at. Good thing about Thinh An though is that it opens for dinner too and it has a food section where you can get some ready to eat/to-go Vienamese food.

Been here two or three times.  Always hope for the best but am never impressed.  Really doesn't measure up to Chopolte or Qdoba in any way shape or form.  Wish it did cuz it's close to home.  Menu is kind of boring.  Nothing jumps out at you at all.  I do like the mango salsa, but the salsa bar is even pretty boring.  I don't know what it is about this place.  It also doesn't seem super clean which may make the food seem less fresh, although they claim no freezers, no can openers.  If that's true that's awesome, but something has to change here to make me want to go back.  I really want this place to improve and I wish I could have given a better review and rating.

First of all, we walk in and it's 81 degrees. We sat right in front of the thermostat. Also a great first impression an employee was verbally arguing with a customer. Customer was trying to tell them they got something wrong and they were trying to argue back.  also had to split our group up seating wise which is fine but a table became available next to one of the tables we were dining at and when we asked if we could have the other group move, they were not thrilled. So then they take our papers. And then they start bringing rolls which have tons of rice - which is okay if you like rice - and we haven't even gotten our soy sauce bowls or drinks. Finally they get our drink orders but as they are serving our food they missed half of our appetizers. We reminded them three times before we gave up. We also had an 8 year old with us and we orders chicken and rice for her. We were eating for 30 (being generous) minutes before reminding them again about her food. She looked like she was about to cry watching us eat and not having her food. They did finally get her food when the rest of us were done. There was also something very sharp in my nigiri fish. I understand fish have bones but  I have NEVER had a bone in any of my sushi and I have sushi twice a week at TOKYO SUSHI. I am a huge sushi fanatic and I tried this place for the first time and was nothing but disappointed. The service was lacking, the food was ehhh... too much rice and not creative menu. NO MOCHIES? Hot and musty restaurant that made you loose your appetite and made the ice in your drink melt within minutes. The servers were just not happy at all or even attentive in the slightest and we were there for a birthday. Many other places are cheaper with better quality and service and like I said I am a sushi fanatic I go twice a week. The service was inconsistent with the food they brought out of order and took too much time. They even asked us if we still wanted our appetizers while taking our dessert menus??? Don't think I'll ever come back, should have never strayed from Tokyo Sushi.

I stopped in for some eats before a big court case. I ordered the muffaletta sandwich and fresh chips.

The sandwich was tasty, and portions were hefty. They forgot to bring my chips and instead brought their signature slaw...which I did not care for. I asked about the chips again and they still forgot. I had to eat fast since I was on a time restraint, but I never did see my chips. I have to say...that was kinda crappy.

Maybe I will give them another shot, but probably not. Sad to say.

Was quite surprised to find the place relatively empty during the lunch hour . . .if you're tired of fighting lunch time crowds, this looks like a good option.  Two of us shared a huge boat full of a few rolls, shashimi and nigiri, soup, salad and I think it could have fed 3 or 4.  We left stuffed and a few pieces remained on the boat.  We did substitute the fake krab cali rolls, but if you like your Krab with a "K" stick with the original.

I've only been for lunch a couple of times, but as a self proclaimed tequilla snob, I'll have to do another review when I am able to go "agave" while I'm there.  Both visits have been enjoyable from a food and service point of view.  Very nice and personable waitresses and have had great meals.  Their posole is definitley a good choice (maybe not as a complete meal) and their guac is great as well.  Great addition to the area.

Before I got officially diagnosed with a gluten allergy I RAN here.

SIMPLE LITTLE PLACE
With just a few hastily added tables and mostly unadorned walls, this place feels pretty new and pretty temporary. Currently the menu is written on poster boards in a regular black sharpie and a handful of Banh Mi variations as well as a score of Boba types are offered. In locations like this I prefer to grab-n-go rather than dine in so that's what I've done.

GREAT BANH MI DECENT BOBA
