MmMmMm the Bread is excellently crispy and flaky--you won't be able to eat that cleanly--and perfectly cradles the goodies inside. So far whether it's the special or the Pork the flavors inside make me imagine I've stepped into a family's kitchen and this is what they've prepared for me. 

Unfortunately the Boba drinks are more on the powder/flavor icy side--never as good as using brewed Tea bases or flavors from the real Fruit. And so far my slushies haven't been blended very well with larger ice chunks floating around.

GREAT PRICES ON THE GO
The Banh Mi prices are similar to other places who serve it in the area. I'll definitely return again when I'm craving some except maybe I'll skip the Boba.

LOCATION LOCATION LOCATION
No matter where you sit you are guaranteed a fabulous view of the waterfront. The restaurant is perched partially over the water and the seating further away from the shore is elevated allowing an unobstructed view. Our server also made sure we knew that any fish we were going to eat was still alive and swimming earlier that day--a perk from their relationships with those who fished the nearby waters. The would make a great date place because the environment itself would give enough things to talk about but families would also enjoy here because it's not very stuffy and dim.

FOOD PAIRED WITH SERVICE
My Thai Coconut Red Curry on the market fish was very mild in all spices. This allowed the subtle bay flavor of the Fish itself to not get drowned in what are typically strong spices. The presentation of using a whole fish UPRIGHT was also very pretty. We also had a dish containing a Cedar Planked Salmon. Tuna Medallion Skewer, and a Grouper Cake--each time the Fish flavor wasn't drowned out but wasn't boring bland either. The server was very attentive and made additional comments about everything without being annoying.

CONVENIENT AND UNIQUE YET ...
Perhaps it's because of our visit during dinner on a weeknight, or maybe even the choices of the Sushi chefs were questionable, but most of the choices on the conveyor belt were not appealing visually. Out of 23 plates my group ate, only three of those came from the belt (all Seaweed Salads) the rest were ordered directly from the servers.
 
THE FOOD WAS JUST OKAY
Some of our orders included Octopus Takoyaki, Salmon Nigiri, Seafood Udon Soup, Chicken Kara Age... honestly none of them impressed me. The Takoyaki relied heavily on sauces- the sauces could've been covering anything and it would've tasted the same. The Salmon Nigiri and Udon Soup were good- at least they didn't over season either of those; the original flavors still showed but were very toned down. Even the Sushi Roll plates we ordered were lacking in flavor.

AND IT ADDS UP
Even though each plate costs $3.50/ea or less, it adds up (Ex: each Sushi plate typically contains only four pieces). Then consider that much of the food had a quasi 'left out' taste. It was a good experience and the servers were friendly, but probably not an experience we would repeat.

A Groupon first lured us here (make sure you mention it prior to seating--they'll love you more) and the food will lure us back.

FOOD
Sounds crazy, but the food tasted like some Thai Grandma was in the kitchen cooking it specifically for me (while her son makes the plate look pretty) The proteins were cooked well and not overwhelmed by any of the seasoning. Vegetables tasted fresh. Thai food done wrong can easily get drowned in strong spices, but this place keeps afloat.

SERVICE
What? An Asian restaurant with Asian servers who actually show personality? There was a lot of smiles... however... THEY ARE SO SO SO SLOW. Timing was totally off despite having all servers' hands on deck. It was slow service before a server initially helped us, slow to filling water glasses, slow to bringing food out and getting the bill.

ATMOSPHERE
Prices are similar to other Thai restaurants. While decorated, this place doesn't look like an elaborate Thai temple... so you don't have to whisper all night and doesn't have a very "date night" atmosphere (at least during busy nights)

This Gameworks is great! The Indy 500 allows you to connect with five other people in game control cars that shake and move when you do in the game. An announcer even keeps you into the game, while cameras focus on your face. There is a restaurant inside as well as two bars with a ton of televisions nearby and seats to relax in. The arcade features some of the best arcade games such as House of the Dead, Dance Dance Revolution, and the classic Air Hockey. If you just want an appetizer then they have those as well, and they are fantastic!

This Red Lobster had some pretty good service, and though the wait was monstrous, I did have a party of thirteen with me for a friends birthday. The waitresses and waiters worked very well together to make sure we always had food by our sides, whether it was unlimited garlic breads, salad, or our main course. The workers were very friendly to our many concerns, and my only complain has to be that when they brought us new drinks and new breads they were not picking up the empty baskets and cups which led to some clutter, besides that the food was great and the service too.

Thai Thani has really gone downhill over the years. My last Chicken Pad Thai there was completely dry and flavorless. I like the waiters and bartenders there, but my experience with their dishes has not been great in quite some time.

Sally O' Neal's Pizza had a booth at the Straz Center's Taste the Best of Tampa Bay and was one of the most popular booths at the event and at an event with over 30 quality, popular local restaurants, for a pizza parlor to get the thunder says a ton about their pizza. It was delicious - I have not had a pizza like that before in Tampa. The ingredients all taste very fresh (apparently they get most of their produce from local farmer's markets) and Sally's has apparently been in town since 1985 - pre-dating my birth by 4 years. I can definitely see myself stopping at Sally's for a pizza after a night in SoHo - I wish there was one closer to home so I could have it more regularly.

After we finished tasting all the booths we decided we wanted another delicious taste of Sally O' Neal's and alas every pizza (there was a ton) was devoured by the hungry crowds. I will be making a trip in the future! :)

I used to pop in here almost every day for breakfast or lunch during one summer where I worked just next door. There's always a line in the morning and at lunchtime from all the university staff and students in the area, but the service is swift and the food is pretty tolerable. Prices aren't horrible, either, for being in University City.

Favorite drink from here has always been the Wawa Green Iced Tea... could drink that in the half-gallons it came in! Mac and beef is always a good option, and the thick homestyle chicken noodle was good, too.

The hot sandwiches under the heat lamps... avoid those. Get your sandwiches freshly done. I liked the ability to order your custom sandwiches and soups, etc. at the touch screens. And they're fairly generous with portions.  Fresh Philly soft pretzels in the morning, too.

Delicious buffet, and at $8-9 (lunch/dinner), it's hard to beat for a price. Come for their staples, including chicken tikka masala, basmati rice, naan, fried chicken, salad, mutter paneer and more... they have a split of their menu between the vegetarian and non-vegetarian options at the front so you can tell what's what.

The buffet comes with tea/coffee afterwards and a choice of dessert - I always enjoyed the gulab jamun, which was a honeyed milk dessert... so hard to find the same thing anywhere else!

They do rush you through eating and clearing your table if it's busy, though.

One of my favorite places to dine near-campus.

Our hunger knows no bounds. Thus, we sometimes discover unpleasantries when crossing over to unknown territory.

Our waitress- the sweetest ever. And tough, like a big sis. She worked hard, and got it all done with perfection and friendliness. I felt comfortable telling her anything.

The coffee- excellent. The food- well, mine- not so excellent. Everything I had was undercooked. My eggs, turkey bacon, and blueberry pancakes were possible carriers of bacteria. I told our waitress that my pancakes were raw in the middle, and I got a whole new meal. However, I could only eat my new, improved pancakes by the time that my first meal was replaced, mainly due to the fact that while you are trying to analyze if your food is dangerous, you are eating it because consumption fuels your gray matter, and because magical thinking is largely depended on within our society. 

Anyway, the blueberries in my pancakes were fresh.

The atmosphere is cool. The food is way over-priced and very disappointing. All of our entrees looked like appetizers or tapas sized plates. Especially, the scallops and risotto. This dish came with only 2 scallops and when we asked about it, the restaurant explained it was the type of scallop which was why they only serve 2 as an entree. If you would like a beautiful scallop dish, "Sidney Street Cafe" or "Oceano" will serve you 4-5 scallops of the same type with amazing sides. Our mussel appetizer was also just okay as a 1/4 of the mussels were unable to be eaten or bad (did not open when cooked). The wait staff was great...the interior is cool...the food is super average and super over-priced.

I was not impressed. The sushi was small and it didn't taste fresh. I heard amazing reviews about this place and was pretty disappointed. The Sushi was comparable to Publix sushi. I would recommend if you're not looking for something expensive or fancy. But you get what you paid for.

We were here for a special birthday celebration.  The view is most certainly stunning and worth a visit.  Otherwise, the food is very overrated, and the service was poor.  

The food was average... nothing terribly inventive, and nothing particularly mind blowing.  The steak was average, and although presentation of the dishes was creative, the meals themselves were not.  Lots of root vegetables, and heavy sauces.

The service was really what pushed this review down into the 3 star range.  When spending $500 on a dinner, I expect much better service.  We did not receive drink refills, and it took entirely too long for us to receive coffee and dessert.  From the time we ordered the final course until it was finally delivered, it was at least 20 minutes.  The server brought only 3 of 4 desserts, and never remember to come out with the 4th.  When we asked for coffee refills, we waited 10 more minutes until we finally just gave up and left.  As we were leaving, the hostess offered to validate our parking, and then when we left the building, we learned the building doesn't actually validate.

I would not return to this restaurant.  I do suggest going once for the view, and perhaps to have a drink, but dinner was a long, overpriced, overrated experience.

I wanted to love this place.  I have heard a lot about this restaurant.  First I tried it with a friend.  Then I went with my husband.  It's very cute inside.  Service is excellent and so are the drinks.  The food didn't blow me away - everything was definitely good, but nothing stood out.  I thought a few of the dishes had too many competing flavors.

Sweetie pies is a grotesquely overpriced, overrated restaurant serving less than mediocre food. Do not waste your time or your money by visiting this restaurant. I'm not sure where all of these high rated reviews are coming from but I don't feel like they're genuine, with the prices that they charge I'm sure they can pay for good reviews. Of course I'm not saying that they do that. That's just one explanation I don't know why anyone would give this place more than two stars.

I would say they have absolutely the best Chai Latte in the city!  I quite like the atmosphere very trendy and always busy often with university students and also often Remedy has some great art work from local artists on their wall to check out or purchase.  

I have eaten a few times and have yet to have something bad, mind you I haven't been too adventurous.  I did try their Masala Dhosa and it was delicious, I had the veggie one and am glad I opted for it as my friend had the chicken and found it to be too filling with the meat.  But I guess if you have a large appetite that would be perfect.  I have also had their breakfast sandwiches a few times and love them, I don't know what sauce they use but it is very tasty!

I don't think a lot of people think of desert when they go to remedy but I have to say they have some of the best cakes and pies I've had and it is always a plus when you can order by the slice.  A personal favorite is the Kitty Lime Pie, I'm not sure why Kitty is in the name but it's what drew me to it and holy pie batman it was amazing!!!

Po'Boy missing lettuce and tomatoes from my blackened catfish.  The "French" bread was very stale.  At least the fries were good.  Liked the margarita ($3.50) and Dos Equis ($3.00) specials on Tuesday night.  

The worst part was all the smoking.  I just smelled disgusting on the way home.  It was nice enough where people who liked to smoke, should've just sat outside.

Say "yes" to the breadsticks.   They're awesome.  My friends always love the fried pickles, but I think they can be a bit greasy.  

The back patio is a nice place to stop if you need to take a break from a bike ride on the Cultural Trail.

Received better service from the bus boy.  Never mind the food, we felt completely ignored my our server.  She didn't even bother to come by and check until it was too late.  I ordered the Ultmate Feast...no crackers for the crab?

Is it just me or is this place just a tad bit overrated?  I've been here several times and can't believe I haven't written a review yet.  

I enjoy the food, especially the tacos.  Don't forget the guacamole, queso w/ chorizo, and the salsas!  I'd definitely recommend coming on weeknight, so it's not so packed.  My friends swear by the margaritas, both regular and spicy.  However, I'm just not a fan.  These margaritas are tart!  Not a bad thing, just a preference.  At least they use large ice cubes, which I give them props for.  However, I usually just go with a beer or sangria instead.

Cash only
Great service at the counter 
The PEPPERS at the counter are fabulous!!  (Really! I thought this was the best part of the sandwich)

I ordered the Mushroom Cheesesteak as-is with the standard American cheese but I wish I had gone with the Cheese Whiz.  

It wasn't quite what I was expecting for my first cheesesteak in Philly.  I tried a few others later in the day and was still impressed with competition.

Quattro Forgmaggio.  That's all you need to know if you love bacon.  The ricotta is really good and is not to be missed.  Never in a million years They also have a pretty decent drink menu with $5 glasses of a variety of house wines.

The name can be deceiving, but make no mistake, SugarFire is in this place!  The menu here was specifically designed for the boathouse and is completely different from any other SugarFire location.  This is also a sit down restaurant complete with appetizers, entrees and desserts.  My visit was on a Tuesday afternoon around 1p with a group of 7 and we waited over an hour for a seat....on a Tuesday!  They offer bar seating, but you can't order from the same menu and it's very limited.  
The location is also primo because of the waterfront setting and outside seating availability.  Would be awesome to sit outside on a fall day.
Today's special for me was the Turkey Club, primarily because I love SugarFire's smoked turkey and I knew this would be good and it was!  The bacon was crispy and the turkey was piled high.  I was really starving, which was the only reason I was able to eat the whole sandwich, it was huge!  There were a ton of other options on the menu that I'd love to try, so I'll definitely come back, but hopefully I won't have wait as long.

Just OK. Definitely not in my top 10 choices for Mexican in StL. Had had this place on my bookmarks for awhile decided to pop in on a Sunday afternoon. Arrived at Noon, no wait and promptly seated. It definitely was full by 12:30p which gave me high hopes that were quickly deflated. Started with a Anejo Old Fashioned and Flautas. The drink was too sweet, so much so that I didn't finish it... me not finish a cocktail!!! Flautas were a bit on the dry side, perhaps some queso would help here and flavor wasn't standout. Shrimp Poblano lacked seasoning overall. The beans were pretty good in taste. I pulled the stuffing out of the pepper and ate it with the rice which wasn't so bad, but overall I left here not satisfied with my lunch. Service was friendly, no issues on that front Oh well, win some, lose some.

So, the outside patio is what attracted me to stop here.  The space is huge!  Very open and spacious. I like the set-up of the park style long picnic tables they chose the use.  It provides the feel of family style fun.  There is a self-guided tour of the brewery that you can take.  If you aren't into beer, they do have a few wines to choose from.  For eats...well, the menu is quite eclectic.  You won't see any typical bar food here.  I wanted to try something so I settled on the pomme frites with bacon gravy.  It wasn't bad...it wasn't awesome...it was ok.  Too much gravy on the fries for me.  Again, I loved the patio, that is the draw for me here.  Would go back to enjoy a beer.

From an Italian gal who only eats my grandmothers red gravy this is my only exception.   Everything is authentic. Sweet homemade marinara and everything is covered in cheese.  House special pizza is the way to go. Anything on the menu is awesome. But for dessert walk (almost) next door to the italian bakery.

This location brings me so much nostalgia. Its where I first tried and fell in love with Thai food when it was Siamese Restaurant over 20 years ago. Siamese went down hill over the years and couldnt keep up with new competitors. So here we are at Thai Zaap. I visited twice and Im sad to say today was probably our last.  The soups are just ok. The pork shumai was the frozen kind and horrendous. I couldnt bring myself to eat them even dipped in the goopy sauce. Maybe they were frozen a little too long plus it looked more like a dumpling than shumai. The pad thai is mostly tangy and not the best either. I do enjoy their pineapple curry but this time it only had 3-4 tiny pieces of meat.  
The atmosphere is sterile with electric yellow walls. Maybe if they had booths and a milder paint color it would be better.  
The typos on the menu are comical. Appetizers are spelled differently twice and both wrong. Seadfood,Pine Apple are just a couple others I noticed. 
They continue to run coupons on Local Flavor so I would suggest going that route if you want to give them a try.

For the quesadilla, they melt mozzarella cheese then add your fillings vs the burrito has no melted cheese and thats the main difference and maybe the addition of beans in the burrito.  We first fell in love with felipes when they had a booth at the audubon zoo one weekend.  But our visits never stood up to our first experience.   I find it rather bland. And of course you can douse it in hot sauce but whatever. The dessert menu says all homemade, well Ive made better flan out of a jello box then the crap they are selling.   The best things on the menu is the white queso and the flavored tea and milk.
Meh. The service was great but the food was just ok in my book. Not bad, but nothing special either. It all just seemed very bland. I would return if necessary but not seek it out.

A little dingy but the food is excellent and a nice change of pace from the usual pub food found in old city. The staff is very casual, but adjust your expectations and you will have a great time! Brunch until 4pm on Sunday.

With the great Pacific Ocean at our doorstep you use farmed Basa from Thailand for your fried fish?!

Makes me wonder where your other stuff comes from.

I came here by word of mouth. I'm not a phan of Pho but that is what I should have ordered. My buddy was raving about it. I had a 8" combo pizza for $11.99 and I didn't feel like it was a deal. Hot and fresh toppings but nothing out of the ordinary. So four stars for the pho and the fact that a friendly local and his lovely wife are running a good business.

we sat down and had no issue getting a table for lunch, got some waters and ordered. we got the bison nachos..... which had the most minimal amount of cheese and chili literally they put half a scoop it felt like (this costed 12.50) then we got bowls of chili and salads which were fine... the chili was eh but all of the food came out in less than 20 minutes of us ordering and by the time we're were ready for the check the waitress couldn't be found for 15 mins and when she came we asked her for to go bowls and that also took another 10 mins and then when we gave her the card she didn't come back.... at all. she sent the hostess who also took 5-10 mins. worst service and food is overpriced for the low quality you get..

Cute stand, good food, but you lost your stars when you hired that rude waiter. Note to the owner: he was the one with the bigger beard who was on duty the afternoon of July 29, 2017, mouthing off at customers. Give this punk his walking papers and maybe I'll come back.

*** Make reservations, this place is very popular and it gets very packed*** we waited an hour when we were told it was going to be 30 minutes. I don't suggest taking the first table you see as you walk in because it's too close to the door in the waiting area and people will hover around you and stare at you while you eat. This table should be a two person high-rise table.

Just okay. Still searching for worthwhile Chinese food in the area. This place is serviceable but nothing more. Prices are a bit high, even for the Newtown/Yardley area. I am basing this on take-out only. People seem to like the lunch buffet, so perhaps I should give that a try.

Came here for brunch for a friends birthday. It was nice that it was all you can drink $10 mimosas, however a little bit disappointing that it ended at noon. I ordered and eggs Benedict for $14 and find it odd that it did not come with a side item. It was nice that there was plenty of space to mingle about, and the DJ was also good.

This Outback isn't in the best location and figuring out the parking lot is awful but the hubby and I frequent this one when we want tasty food and to go out for a good time. I'm a big fan of the skinny margaritas and of course the bloomin' onion is the best. 

You don't go to Outback to be blown away by it's culinary masterpieces. You go for fun, tasty comfort food, and drinks. I always know that I'll have a good time!

Brisket is the only thing worth mentioning. Smoky tender beef. Pulled pork tasted like it was boiled;gross, fed it to my dogs. Collards were not washed thoroughly, sand in each bite, threw it in the garbage. But worst of all was the greeting, or lack thereof, I received when I entered this casual establishment. I offered a 'Hi' to the man in the dirty tshirt & 'where do I order?' I politely inquired. 'I'm waiting for you. ' he gruffly replied. Alrighty then. $45 later all but brisket SUCKEd!

Came here on a whim for a dinner date with some friends. Food was pretty good, but the restaurant was so hot that day, no AC and no air flow, and with 2 kids under 3yrs old, not a good combination. We ordered the triple dip to share and would have prefered pita bread over pita chips, but the tatzika dip was my fav of the 3. I ordered the chicken swarma which I really enjoyed. Their rice pilaf was really good. Other complaint is that our waiter seemed a bit overwhelmed, he also forgot to put in our friend's entree order. I would like to come back again and hopefully be able to edit my review.

I had their food here before.  Food is good but the service straight SUCKS!  Never had to wait to have a server ask to start with my drink. To top it off, I got there and the waitress asked me if I was waiting to be seated...I mean really?!?!?!  Then we had to sit ourselves and had to wait some more. Never was acknowledged nor was I asked for something to drink. Straight walked out in front of their faces!

I usually like The Havit but today they were horrible. Buzzer never went off and found my food sitting on the counter getting cold and being fondled by other patrons. Had to get an order to go and waited 25 minutes for a fried chicken sandwich. When i got home it turned out to be grilled cue the Joe Pesci drive through scene. When the habit is good, they are awesome. When they are bad it's a complete shit show

So I feel a bit apprehensive regarding this review. Pat O'Brien's is a staple of New Orleans. The drinks and staff were very good - I definitely recommend visiting here. However, we sat in the patio (note: there is outdoor heating) and unfortunately we saw a rat. The rat ran across the patio and spent most of its time hiding within the foliage - the rat kept to itself and didn't bother guests but I want to highlight it as I know some people may be affected. We did finish our drinks but made sure to move away from the foliage. So overall a decent place but maybe not for everyone! Also, may be worth getting a seat inside instead of the patio and maybe worth considering whether you want to order food here! Still gave it a 3/5 as everything was good apart from the rat incident!
The website says they are open until 9 pm however it is a Friday night at 8:30 and the place is already dark.  What gives!?!

Quaint establishment in Skippack. Came in around 10a with 2 friends and the hostess immediately guided us to our table. Each person in my party ordered the shrimp and grits. Very flavorful. I also thought the mismatched dishes are a cute touch. Our server, Kate, was friendly and attentive. This place has been added to my list of Montco bfast/brunch spots.

I have to say that my most recent visit here left me disappointed. Overall the food was still really good, but the service was lacking. A while after being seated the server said she was going to get us some bread. I was excited to tell our friends from out of town how much I loved the focaccia bread here. We had been bragging about the food at Liberty all day. Well the bread was a HUGE disappointment. It was very dry. I would have preferred that the server forget the bread like they had other things. Surprisingly for a night that was not very busy the service was slow. We had to ask multiple times for our water to be refilled, the server forgot the espresso that my husband had ordered, and brought one our friends the wrong soup. When our food was finally ready they brought out the gnocchi to a couple of us who had ordered it, brought our friend's sandwich, and then we waited well over 5 minutes for my husband's fish to be brought out. By the time we all had our meals those who's had come out first were cold. Luckily the food still tasted great.

I came here with some of my work biddies for brunch. One of them is a straight up knows-everything-about-Philly-food-scene broad so I let her make the decisions. She chose this place. 

We made a reservation for 12:30 on a Sunday. I was the first to arrive (not fashionably late enough I guess) and held down the fort while I waited for our table. Apparently the hostess told me to follow her upstairs but I'm literally so retarded I didn't hear her say that, so I continued to wait downstairs. Thank goodness one of my friends arrived and we waited together. 

We were shortly brought upstairs and seated. Hostess warned us that they suddenly became super busy and that it would take a minute (5 min) for our server to arrive. It actually took much longer and I told a bus boy or some shit to get the waitress over. She arrived and apologized for the wait, mentioning that it was her first day. 

My friend was very keen on the Gallo Pinto, the Costa Rican one (eggs, rice/beans, peppers, lizano sauce, fried cheese, avocado, plantains, meat). She said it's the rice in the middle of it that's the shit. I was also intrigued by this "lizano sauce". Like what the fuck is that shit? I'm picturing a light green color. It also has fried cheese. Fried cheese? Are you fucking kidding me?

Anyways they gave a whole bunch of things that intrigued me. A whole bunch of platters with like eggs, and meat in some form, and like rice in some form with various other things like beans and guac and platanos ("I'm just flying up some platanos right now"). 

I was also torn between that and the mexican (refried black beans, pico de gallo, eggs, queso fresco, tomatillo sauce, chorizo, home fries and avocado). I ultimately went with this one for onion reasons, but my two friends ordered the cuban one so I figured I would be able to have a taste.

When the waitress finally came over, mah gurl and I ordered bloody marys (ugh, classic). They gave us this delicious like fried or some shit bread slices and it was SO good. I couldn't resist having like...three.  

I ordered the mexican without meat and when it came, it classically had meat in it. This has been happening to me excessively lately. I didn't realize after taking a bite. I told them and they quickly came out with another one. It was pretty good! Unfortunately that's when the bloody mary and the mango mimosas I ordered afterwards had kicked in thoroughly so I can't provide more specifics than that. 

Bloody mary as one of the better ones that I've had in my life at restaurants. The mimosas were also super good, they come in a variety of flavors.

Ultimately the food was good and the offerings are unique. Sure, they have classics like omelettes and pancakes and shit but I look forward to coming back and trying some of their other shit.

Looks can be deceiving!

Croissants are supposed to be flaky, buttery goodness. A perfect croissant is not gummy or squishy, the pastry should be filled with air so you can see the folds inside. These were not the words I would use to describe the croissants I bought. Fool me once, shame on you! Can't fool me twice!

The pastries and bread looked good but they are all an illusion. I bought a few croissants and they were all doughy, oily and undercooked. This can make people sick. It should not be sold.

To all of those out there that read reviews to find out the truth..PLEASE know that I speak nothing but the truth. Michelangelo's pizza is by far the worst in Nashville. I ordered a large Pizza ( pepperoni, mushroom ,extra cheese) and what I was delivered was appalling. It was almost burnt, the topping slid RIGHT off the top of the pizza leaving sorry prepare dough...the taste was horrible. The customer service was also terrible. I called and ordered my pizza and the woman on line didn't take my phone number or apartment number...i called back and she was like " yea ok, we'll get it to you". I will never order from here again.

Horrible food. Poor quality of service. Horrible management. Cooks get orders wrong. Dirt bag hangout. Skimpy portions on some meals others are ok. Not worth going - terrible experience every time I give it a try. The quality of the meat is not very good, some of the Mexican dishes are completely flavorless, and the place seems dirty.  Seems like they cut corners a lot and the cooks do not seem sanitary.

3.5 Stars. 

I'd first heard of this place from Tony Bruno on ESPN Radio. After hearing all his comments about the broccoli rabe and reading all the reviews, I was primed to eat here.

They actually have two Tony Luke's, one's a sit outside/order at a window type deal and the other is what looks like a sit down restaurant across the street. I came around noon and ordered from the sidewalk/order at the window joint. 

I got the roast pork italian, which has sharp provolone and your choice of spinach or broccoli rabe(I got the rabe). I also got an order of fries.  The sandwich came out relatively fast along with the fries. There was a mixup on my soda, but I got it, so no harm no foul.  I sat down at one of the aluminium tables next to the order window with my sandwich. The roast pork sandwich was so so good. The combination of the provolone and the broccoli rabe really complimented the tender pork slices.  My mouth is starting to water again just reading about it. The fries were not too bad and there were plenty of them. I"m not sure whether they were breaded or it was the potatoes they used, but it seemed a little different.  Next time I think I'll get the onion rings. 

I did have one beef with Tony Luke's. I wasn't happy however with the cleanliness of the eating area and on top of that there were multiple flies buzzing around. I know that you can't completely wipe out mother nature, but I can't help but think if they'd cleaned the place and took out the garbage more often that maybe there wouldn't have been so many flies.

Overall I enjoyed the food. I'll come back and take the sandwiches back home.

Oh yeah, there is plenty of parking next to the building.

I venture into new Mexican places with a degree of trepidation, since most people know diddly about good Mexican food. But since there hasn't been any Mexican joint worth speaking of west of the Schuykill, I was eager to try it.

The chips and salsa were pretty decent. The salsa was more like the El Jarocho red salsa crema, flavorful and spicy without being too hot. The guacamole we ordered was also pretty decent. I was annoyed at having to pay for chips and salsa, but at least it wasn't too expensive. I would like to have gotten more than a small side sauce container full of sauce though.

My g/f got a vegetarian torta and I got enchiladas verdes with chicken. The chicken was pretty moist and of decent quality. The verdes sauce however was pretty lifeless. I couldn't taste the tang of the tomatillos, nor much cilantro, garlic, or onion for that matter. There wasn't an aluminum  or metal tang to the sauce, so it probably wasn't made from canned tomatillos. It was probably just a sauce kept in the refrigerator a little too long. My g/f's torta was full of vegetables and queso fresco cheese. She liked it, though I wasn't that impressed from the bite or two that I had. 

The churros were hot and seemed like they had been made recently. Delicious. The sopapilla like tortilla with cinnamon and sugar was also decent, though a little overpowdered with sugar and cinnamon. 

The atmosphere was pretty warm and inviting. There were a couple of tables to sit if you wanted to to dine in, though I could imagine it getting packed r.eal quickly on a weekend night.

The service was pretty good overall and the owner was pretty nice. He apologized for not having horchata, but said that they would have it soon.

Overall I wasn't that impressed, but I think maybe it was just an off night for them based on the previous reviews and the smells emanating from the other peoples plates. The tacos that the two drunk guys behind me had smelled delicious. I'll probably be back to give it another go.

I'm going to focus on what's most important in a restaurant here:

1. The Food
-PYT is a burger joint or at least says its a burger joint. I like burgers, so much so that I gained the moniker I currently use.  So I came here last night and had the BBQ Bacon Bleu burger.  Bacon, blue cheese, and BBQ. Sounds good, right? I thought so when I ordered it.  The burger came out within a reasonable time frame with onion straws on top and onion rings(I asked to have a substitute for the fries, since my Yelp friend Christopher R said the onion rings were good). The burger itself was neither real big circumference wise, but it was fairly thick. The hamburger bun(I never get why East Coasters say roll for everything) had a lot of sesame seeds on it. The burger was fairly juicy upon first bite. However, it was less medium and more medium rare which was annoying, but not unexpected. Few places seem to do medium right.  The blue cheese was piled up in the center of the burger and was pretty strong. I almost didn't realize what it was when I first got it. I'm not sure whether they crumbled blue cheese in the middle and let it melt or they used pasteurized blue cheese spread. It just looked a little strange. And it tasted a little strange The bacon was very crispy, kudos for that. I realized later that I didn't taste any BBQ, so I"m wondering where that came in. There certainly wasn't any sauce and the burger didn't taste like it had been on an outdoor grill.

The onion rings were a disappointment. The breading was light and crisp but the onions themselves were soggy.

My chocolate shake was decent but nothing memorable. It tasted like mediocre store bought ice cream(And it kinda tasted like vanilla ice cream with chocolate syrup, though I could be wrong).

2. The service-From the time I opened the door I was greeted and seated immediately.  My server came within the first 5 minutes(which is the longest I'll wait for service, knowing that places with shitty service start out by taking forever to get to you). She was nice, attentive, helped me with my order and got me my check pretty fast.  Exactly what you want from a waitress.

Based on my food experience, I"m not sure I'd come back. I definitely have had better burgers for 12 bucks(Yes that did include onion rings, so its not so bad, but still its a burger place. You think they'd kill every burger they made).  I kinda wished I'd gotten the cheesesteak pretzel burger but I went for something a little more normal.

Service was really good. However I will add I went early on a Thursday evening. So I have no idea how service holds up at more popular/frequented times.

Stopped in to watch a game. The place has a huge beer selection and the staff was great super friendly. I ordered some wings and chips and salsa. The wings were ok the dry rub was a little weird tasting but they were cooked perfectly. Pass on the dip it was lukewarm and just no taste; however the diablo salsa was really good. This is a nice bar to drop in watch and game then move on. If you stop in I would just pass on the food...if you are eating something amazing.

Finally did the cheese steak thing! I have to say, only in comparison to Geno's, that Pat's won, flavor wise. Very disappointed in the quality and quality of the food. The roll was cold and the small amount of meat on it was Luke warm and bland. Sent to "next window" for fries and a drink, fries were cold and nasty! Atmosphere was not friendly, (they had an outside worker begging for tips,even if he did nothing for you and rude customers butting into your private conversations )but I guess that's Philly. Seagrave's and Italian Kitchen, you have no worries from losing this South Jersey girl! Same price for twice the size, three times the meat and it tastes great! 
So if you want great cheese steak come to Salem County, NJ!

Decor was neat but that's about it.

Sushi was so-so. It wasn't over priced just didn't taste as good as I would've liked. Kinda tasted like fast food sushi :/ It also took forever to get our food but the workers gave us 2 free beers bc of it, which was nice. The workers were really nice.

The place was clean and they have all the condiments out for you to get. 

Based on the food I wouldn't go back.

Made a lunch reservation on Opentable the night before! We ordered a pizza and pasta to share, and still had two pieces of pizza leftover afterwards! The pasta was good but extremelllyyyy rich with the burrata and sauce; the pizza was also wood fired (quite charred in a good way) and rich, so maybe order a light appetizer and entree to split!

i love this place :) whenever I'm craving pho I come since the prices are decent and it's close enough to campus to walk! The owners are super nice, the portion is just large enough for me to finish, and the flavor of the pho is good (not the best I've ever had but not bad at all)! Prices of pho range from $8.25-$9.25 I believe.

Closed on Mondays and take cash only!

I can't say enough bad things about this subway. I used to go here 2-3 times a week until the good employees left and they put a bunch of stupid high school rejects in place. They can't get a order correctly made. Not in person, not online and when you bring it to staffs attention they get all huffy and tell you take your business elsewhere. I did and recommend you do to. Only people who say nice things about this shop come in when older guy is working or are one of these je idiots friends

How did I get here?  What in my right mind would make me want to eat at Tsunami?  A dark and dank place, covered in Wild West upholstery in the Tyrone Mall area of Da Pete.

While sitting in a saddle covered booth, next to one lone and overworked sushi "chef", aloof servers, water from the deepest sulfurous well, chewing on mayo covered salmon, my rolls falling apart (disintegrating wet rice) before my eyes, and cheap meat burning on teppanyaki flames around me--- I was seriously wondering the same thing.  

I will continue the pilgrimage to find decent sushi in Tampa Bay, even if that means that I have to brave battlegrounds of Japanese Steakhouses like Tsunami.

The goods news is:  I don't have to return, ever.
Too noisy, not worth the wait, mediocre food, expensive, long wait for food to come out. Soggy zingers. Tried it 3 times now, won't be back

A busy diner where  some guys looking like wiseguys stood in front, they sit you right away, and throw a plate of slop at you.  Almost stereotypical diner.  

OK, maybe I am exagerrating.  Plates are huge.  Nothing healthy to speak of.  It is the quintissential greasy spoon type place.

Bugs.... Oh my!  I went to Lola's a couple of months ago for a birthday party.  I've put off writing a review because I hate to publish bad reviews. But, as I thought about it more, I came to the conclusion that I should write an honest review.

Since it was a birthday party, there were several people at the table.  It was my first time meeting some of them. I noticed a big issue with my water, but initially didn't say anything. I didn't want to make a scene and ruin the guy's birthday party. I looked around the table and saw that other people had this issue as well. I finally spoke up. There were roach legs floating in our waters. I brought it to the attention of our waitress. The only thing she did about it was get us new waters. She didn't even apologize. 

I have to be real here. This is New Orleans. There are roaches everywhere in this city. It is what it is. You get used to it. Don't think its something specific to New Orleans now. I've lived in other coastal Southern cities where there were issues with roaches. The problem in this situation is that the waitress did nothing about it other than bring more waters. She didn't even apologize. It would have made the situation better if she had done something about it. Maybe a complimentary appetizer, complimentary dessert, or comp the entire meal. Just do something. 

I ordered the Combination Paellas. The food was actually good. 

As I said before, I actually feel bad about writing this, but it's the truth. The waitress should have done more.

I find myself really disappointed... Everyone knows and loves it this place, but I'm starting to feel that it's just an overpriced name. Today I brought 2 coworkers here for pannini's because they're from out of town and have heard the name... We just finished lunch and I find myself feeling foolish. I asked the guy making panini's if they really press them down well and if they have decent amount of meat... He truly  misguided me. Not only were the sandwiches cold with only a few press lines on it, but there was two thin slices of prosciutto.. Two little slices and the sandwich was worth $9? Come on Di Bruno's, step your panini game up!!

I started my cheesesteak experience at Pat's and Geno's and am glad I made my way over to Jim's (don't worry, not all on the same day!).  This location is not very convenient to the city (located in the middle of a West Philly neighborhood), but the cheesesteak was great!  I will probably check out the other location next time and hope for equally good food, but more convenience.

The staff was really nice - I had a few out-of-towners with me and the chef very nicely and calmly explained the options and ordering process.  I got the cheesesteak with provolone, onions, sweet peppers, and spicy peppers - yum.  The meat was the most moist of all the cheesesteaks I've had.

Two advantages over the other places I've tried: 1) there is indoor seating at a counter (although it's very limited) and 2) the spicy peppers and other condiments were inside rather than sitting out at the curbside in the hot sun.  Not super cheap at ~$7/cheesesteak, but I think that's the going rate and you definitely get better quality here.

Bowing to my sushi craving, I decided to try out Sushiwa.  Tucked in a strip mall, the ambiance is casual, but pleasant.  I started off with an order of Edamame and was disappointed to find it overcooked and a little too soft.  I also ordered the Salmon Avocado Roll (in which the salmon was several small pieces, rather than one nice cut of fish) and the Spicy Tuna Roll (good flavor, but not too spicy).  Overall, the meal would be fine if you need a sushi fix in the area, but it's not going to be amazing.

We started girls' night with a round of Mango Shakes and agreed to all go for the dinner buffet.  At $11.95/person, this was a good deal since a single dish was $9-12.  Now a Tuesday night buffet on the edge of University City made me a little nervous, but I was very pleased that all the food was fresh.  The standouts were the Chicken Tikka and the Vegetable Samosas, but the other selections were good as well.  The waitstaff was also really nice and attentive and did not rush us at all.

awww hay hub bub!   i work in this building so when i saw this place opened i got super excited.  

they already know my order every morning and have the soy milk ready.  sometimes i walk in and they are playing city & color or brand new and i just love love love that. 

the atmosphere is great, the stumptown coffee is great, the people who work there are great, the chemex options are great. 

they have fair trade options available and you can even get a banana if you forgot your breakfast in the morning. 

hey hub bub - start stocking some of ed's tofu vegan sandwiches in the to-go case so then i'd never have to go anywhere else during my work day :)

i think i'm missing something - when i went in here i didnt see any vegan well... anything. 

 maybe i came on an off day?  in the sandwich case there was a ton of non-veg salads and sandwiches - but i didnt see anything vegan that was pre-made and ready to go. 

i did have a smoothie and that was delish.  i dont know if this place is for me though.

ok so i was here friday night with 8 people.  our server was very nice!  this is a typical burger place so vegans get ready for something pretty boring. 

1) the veggie burger and bun are both not vegan.  they use goldfish crackers in the veggie burger for some reason. 
2) the grilled veggie sandwich with hummus IS vegan - just say no cheese. 
3) you can also customize a vegan salad if you wanted to be healthy. 

they have a great happy hour and w/ $4 glasses of cabernet i was happy.  it can get a lil rowdy and loud here though so if you're looking for a place to have an actual conversation, maybe this shouldn't be top of the list- but its more than suitable for bar/happyhour/ish!

Tequilas is a bit hit or miss.  

The decor is interesting for an upscale Mexican spot to say the least, and you will either like it or hate it.  I didn't enjoy getting seated in the weirdly lit bar area with people bumping into our chairs from time to time.  The chandelier has to go.

As for the service, I found it a bit odd that the waiter wouldn't take an appetizer order and insisted that he takes the meal and appetizers orders together.  That's the first time I've ever heard such a thing.

As for the food, it was decent overall... but pricey.  My friend had the grouper and the wife had the cochinita pibil and those were the highlight dishes in my mind.  The bacon guac was excellent too.  I ordered bacon wrapped shrimp with rice for my meal.  The shrimp just came out way too salty for my liking.  

As for the drinks, they were pretty strong and tasty.  I would say this is an area where they shine.

I'd probably stick with El Vez if I happen to be in that area, but this isn't a bad alternative.

Not the best bagels I've ever had, but certainly above average for the South Jersey area.

They have a good variety of bagel options and they appear to be made fresh daily.  They also do catering, which I've used before.  Pretty inexpensive.

Overall, not a bad bagel, but I think the in-house breakfast sandwiches leave something to be desired.  The bacon tastes a bit weird and the sausage isn't great either.  I think if they stepped up the meats, it could be a lot better.

Regardless, it doesn't seem to be hurting business as it's always packed.

So bland and so boring. I really wanted so much more from this place. It is in such a convenient location and such a great building but the food is absolutely boring. Three of us ate here and with no alcohol and it was 55.00. Crazy considering the only thing we could agree on being good was a cup of tortilla soup and that was three dollars and something with possibly 4 bites and it was gone. We had a variety of food. Fajitas (steak and chorizo), quesadillas beef, tortilla soup, chicken enchilada,  chicken soft taco, beef hard taco, and table side fresh guacamole.

Tried this place out after looking at the reviews. Online it says they close at 9, but I called to make sure and they said 8. I got there at 7:30, but the servers were still very cheery and friendly, not to mention, a big group came outside from the inside bar. They seemed like regulars and more people showed up at 8, so I think the hours vary based on if anyone is around. 

I ate by myself outside, and ordered a to go for my husband. I splurged on the ribeye ($25) because it looked good on the menu and on here. Asked for it to be medium rare, and it came out medium well, in part, the steak was  fairly thin, so I'm sure its hard to cook rare. It was very reminiscent of when I worked at Jerry's as a teen, and the Sysco steaks the line cooks would make for me in style, taste and texture, but wasn't tender at all, and had no flavor. I asked a server for Heinz, but she never returned. I did mention that I was unhappy with the steak, but I wasn't looking for comps because I was still going to eat it. But the server did take off my $7 bloody mary which was unexpected and nice. 

I got the special salad, of the sesame crusted halibut for Cory to go, and he said the fish was excellent, and a good sized portion, even though there was too much salad for the meat. But overall, he said his was great. 

As others said, this feels very much like a neighborhood hang out for regulars, and I wouldn't not come back, I just will avoid some items. Breakfast sounds fun as well.

I'm dating a liar, so I'm sorry, Jose, if we inflated your confidence a bit. Turns out Cory wasn't quite as big of a fan as I was, but I'm the yelper so my opinion is the only one that matters.... hasn't anyone seen our Southpark episode?

Now, I came alone one day after work and had a good experience, although I didn't stuff my face so I felt like I couldn't give an accurate review yet. I was the only customer for a long time so I talked with the owner Tony a lot, and that was really one of the major selling points in my first visit. I did try the saba, it is house cured, but I'm just too American in my tastes and still have a hard time eating this one because the fishy flavor is so potent. I liked Tony for the fact he didn't have any sort of grudge or "holier than though" attitude about the American palette for sushi and he seems just excited to be operating this business. He is from Korea and has cooked and been a sushi chef for about 15 years, all over the world and somehow landed here.  

Anyways fast forward, Cory is in town and is letting me pick the sushi place. The entire menu is included here at lunch, it's one of my favorite things I look for in our local sushi restaurants now. I start with mussels, there are 3 kinds, regular, one baked with the white sauce, and deep fried, I did baked. Then we started on the rolls. Both visits it wasn't busy so Tony and Jose said they don't mind making half rolls when it is slow. Jose was our chef today and I noticed he is looking at the menu a lot, and asking the other chef (who isnt Tony) lots of questions. Turns out it was his first day and had just started 3 hours ago. You could tell he wasn't a new to sushi chef, he has worked at 3 other places in Reno. Him and I talk about the reno sushi scene and eventually he asks if I am a chef (HA!), which little did he known is like the best compliment I've received in months... I told him I just sushi too much!

We tried a lot of rolls, I actually like the deep fried rolls here because they are so crunchy. The Panko has jalapeño and I added lemon inside, it was almost popper like. I loved my Lemon Time roll, that's where I discovered they do a lemon sauce, which isn't on many other places menus. Cory had the Yosemite, the menu doesn't say it's topped with mango sauce, maybe it was an Jose improvisation. I liked it, but I only had a couple bites, it was too much for him, a couple drizzles would have been better, but it was pretty covered. Cory ordered the Cacti roll too, with deep fried jalepeno slices, also one I enjoyed, but didn't eat a lot of. Cory would have liked it more as probably a 1/2 roll. Lastly I did the Zodiac, I like bbq tuna, but Cory apparently doesn't (again, liar), only thing I would change is the crunch, I like crunch in my rolls. 

We left and I was beyond happy, I feel like the rolls are different than what else is offered around town. Granted I can't comment on nigiri as much, as I didn't order it here. There are a variety of sauces, which I am in love with the lemon sauce. Cory got to the car and felt it was just okay, which bummed me out, because I thought we had a new favorite, but I guess it's just mine :)

Johnny Brenda's puts the fish in Fishtown. On a cool summer night, we celebrated the coming of fall by starting with an autumn beer. After reading the shared outdoor menu, I went with the Fishtown Stew. With a higher than average price tag for this local hangout, my expectations were high. 

Worth every dollar-Steamed clams, mussels, scallops and shrimp over a bed of linguini topped with a fresh tomato sauce. We nearly licked the plate. 

When out to you next visit, go for the gusto and order an exceptional beer and a unique item on the menu- you won't regret it and lifes too short to not enjoy it!

After the duck neck binge, I didn't feel like eating leftovers from lunch or getting a full dinner so we went on a quest for ice cream.  It's dairy protein so don't judge.  We hadn't been here in quite a while so we stopped in aiming to order just shakes.  Much to my surprise and delight, I saw the 2 magic words: funnel cake.  If you know me, you should know that I have an incredible weakness for fried, crispy batter covered in powdered sugar, especially when there aren't any seagulls to fight me for it.  So there you are.  I got the funnel cake, although my expectations were somewhat abated since this isn't exactly the shore.  It was actually pretty decent, though, and they made it fresh.  The presentation and swirling technique could use some work but fried batter/dough is delicious in any form.  Apparently, Tuesdays are $3.00 shake nights so we also got a mint chocolate chip shake, which was cold, creamy, and delicious.  Yeah...today was definitely not health-conscious day but live and let live, right?  Diets can wait, especially when there are funnel cake, ice cream, and duck to be consumed.  A nice, local business with friendly service and freshly-prepared treats.  They also have a huge sandwich menu so I will be in to try that in the near future.

Fantastic Sunday brunch with a buffet and entree, along with dessert.  We came to celebrate a friend's birthday, and our server brought her a small cupcake and chocolate-covered strawberry plate, as well.  The ambiance is beautiful and it's a great location for a date or a catch-up brunch with friends.  

Some highlights from the $35 brunch:

1. Crabcake benedict: Fantastic crabcake with plenty of lump crabmeat and perfectly cooked poached eggs.  Definitely my favorite entree on the menu.
2. Barramundi with couscous: Decent but not as amazing as the crabcake.
3. Salad Bar:
     a. Shrimp cocktail: Huge and perfectly seasoned shrimp.  Definitely recommend.
     b.Charcuterie and cheese boards: Great serrano ham and brie.
     c. Mussels in garlic white wine sauce: Tender but tiny although the broth was very  flavorful
     d. Smoked salmon: Tender and flavorful.  Pair it with the cream cheese.
7. Dessert table: Try the bread pudding, chocolate chip cookie cake, tiramisu cup, fruit tart, and mini banana nut muffins

A tip: save room for dessert!  A great brunch option in Center City, for sure.  If you only want the salad and dessert buffets, it is $25.

The banh mi special is good, with a good blend of meats, but not the best in the area.  You have to go to South Philly for that.  However, the service is friendly and it is convenient for a cheap, quick lunch if you work near Chinatown.  It's more expensive than other places but if you disregard the price comparisons, then it is a good value.

This is halfway between a cafeteria and a sit-down restaurant.  There is decent seating and your food is brought out to your table but you order and pay at the counter.  There should probably be a sign stipulating that all orders are taken at the register otherwise they might wonder why there are customers sitting at tables looking around with confused looks.

Foodwise, this was just okay.  I got the chicken taouk platter, which came with salad, rice, pita, grilled vegetables, and 1 kebab for ~$13, including tax.  The chicken was adequately spiced but could have used a bit more sauce.  The rice was topped with some almonds, and was pretty good.  Salad was very bland and tasted like it had merely been spritzed with a tiny amount of lemon juice and olive oil and a scattering of spices - definitely could have used more of actual dressing.  The pita was...well, a pita, although I think that it would have gone nicely with some hummus.  The portion size is pretty small, and probably wouldn't have filled anyone besides me up.  Maybe if they added a kebab?

The restaurant itself is very clean, with an open kitchen, and the overall experience was adequate for a quick, inexpensive lunch place.  It's good for those of you searching for a traditional, middle eastern lunch without any twists.

Okay, so the sushi here is just okay but the teriyaki bowls are pretty good and reasonably priced!  My spicy chicken teriyaki bowl came with perfectly cooked sticky rice, plenty of flavorful, tender chicken sauteed with onions in a sweet and savory sauce, a side of shredded Asian slaw, and a small bowl of miso soup.  The portion was also pretty generous, given the very reasonable $8.50 price tag.  I was quite happy with the meal and loved that the chicken and rice weren't at all dry, which is often at other places.  Will definitely be back to try the other bowl options.

So excited to have this place here in New Orleans! First time I had it, was of course in the famous NYC of the famous food carts. 53rd and 6th to be exact--no where else! You pretty much had to have it every night you were there, haha. 

Walking into New Orleans's The Halal Guys (it's a very casual restaurant-y place-not food cart), everyone was super friendly and excited to serve us. Small combo platter (gyro and chicken) was about $8 and regular sized platter was like $9 I think. Regular combo platter is the way to go. And of course EXTRA EXTRA white sauce. You seriously can't have too much of that white sauce.  Soooo good. Oh--and the hot sauce. If you like spicy, you need it in your life. Ask for a couple extra hot sauce packets to go too.. The food was good--not the NYC 53rd and 6th good, but I was extremely satisfied with our meal. My husband and I shared one platter and we inhaled it so fast we wanted another. Overall, We were very pleased and will definitely come back for more!

Has a very good look, even the high tech ordering system is cool but let me just say that the price is down right shocking.  The food was fairly good but every little add on cost this much or that much and before you know it, you have a 11 dollar salad.  Yes the fruits and veggies were fresh but the chicken and things didn't live up to the same quality of the veggies and fruit.  While I was there (30 minutes or so) I saw staff dump two different orders into the trash because they were prepared wrong, either adding something that wasn't to be in the mix or preparing it the wrong way.  If they are able to get this wastefulness down is prices would come down as well.  I'm going to give it some time, but I could see myself coming back to give it another try.

This is always super packed around the times of the year where it makes sense to go.  The restaurants are good but they aren't anything to write home about.  I will return because it is a cool little touristy spot to take friends and family that are in town.  Most items in the shops are fair to slightly expensive vs other options but all things considered, that isn't that bad!  It's free to walk around but remember, shop local.

My first experience with Halal Guys outside of NYC was at the Yelp Halloween event. I waited til I had the chance to stop in before writing a review and finally made that happen on Saturday night. I ordered a regular combo platter and skipped the salad. They don't let you add your own sauce so I got mine with white sauce and asked for just a little bit of red. They asked if I wanted a strip of it so I guess that is how they're measuring the red sauce? Either way, it was just as hot as I remembered. Having done my time waiting in line at 53rd and 6th, it's hard NOT to compare this location to the original. My bf and I agreed that while we didn't think the platters were quite as good, we definitely don't hate having a Halal Guys in Philly. It's in a convenient enough location so I'm sure we'll make our way back here to get our chicken and rice fix.

First time back at Burgerhaus since 2016 - took a while to get seated but once we did the service was quick and satisfactory. I went for the Mediterranean portobello burger for a change of pace since I'd had a regular burger before. It was decent, not anything to write home about, I thought the onions weren't well cooked and the burger lacked substance. I will probably go back for one of their regular beef burgers next time. The fries were great, always very well made. The drink I got was a cyan mojito - on the plus side it's always nice to find mojitos on cocktail menus so I'm glad of that but it was a Strong mojito so I had to wait for ice to dilute a little before I could enjoy it. Good ambience on the patio, perfect for a night breezy canal dinner.

I have wanted to try Sabrina's Cafe for a really long time but have always been turned off by what I hear about the wait time. But finally, one late Sunday morning I decided to go for it. 

So yes there was a wait once I got there even after using the online waitlist. Yes Sabrina's is small, tight and loud. Which I kind of guessed for such a popular place and from reading other reviews.

The servers were friendly, we had extremely fast service. We ordered the tuna blt and the spinach omelette. My boyfriend thought his spinach omelette was just okay. A little to fluffy. Like an airy omelette. He liked the famous breakfast potatoes a lot. He was kind of thrown off about his toast just being plain. With no offer of butter for it. I kind of understood. My tuna blt was just okay. I wished that the bread didn't fall apart and the big no flavor tomato slices were cut thinner. I took them off. I enjoyed my sweet potato fries, partially because the sprinkled powdered sugar on them. 

Our bill can to a little over $30. I'm not sure it was worth it. I can't say I'd be in a rush to go back but I would to maybe try some of the other offerings. Maybe when there is a chance of being less crowded...and when I don't have to pay for parking, lol.

I've had the Reuben and the Mom's Sandwich (all in + banana peppers), and both were great. Prices were fair, and their's good space outside for seating if you want to eat at the deli. Large selection of chips and drinks for sides, and some standard deli pasta salads as well. 

Typically a little bit of a line during lunch on the week, certainly a place thats in my rotation.

I honestly love Bertucci's and feel kind of horrible that I do, because I try to avoid chains. (Also it horrifies me to think that the chefs are dirty... ew)
Their rolls are so good and addictive- to me this is the number 1 reason to even go there. Everything else I could make at home or get somewhere else but those rolls... I'm gonna drool just thinking about them.
I also like Bertucci's because you can design your own pizza with a lot of different veggies which is great for the vegetarians. But the service is not consistent and the bathrooms are almost always gross.

I've been enjoying Madhuban's lunch buffet for several years - however, in the past several months I have seen a steady decline in the quality of food available at the lunch buffet which quite honestly saddens me.

The chicken in several of the dishes appears to not have been cooked in the sauces.  Lately the chicken has been dry and without flavor except for the sauce that it sits in. Most recently I started noticing the sauces were not as thick, almost as if they have been watered down.  

I hope the quality turns back around, until it does I will have to fulfill my weekly craving of Indian food elsewhere.

I really want to give this place a good rating, but I just can't.  The staff was very nice and the place is clean and comfortable.  The food just wasn't that great.  Here's the good.... two people in our group liked their hamburgers and one had wings that he liked.  Here's the not so good... They definitely need a new bar tender.  None of our drinks were very good.  How hard is it to make a margarita?  Really bad!  We tried the biscuits and they were warm on the outside and ice cold inside.  I think they were warmed up in a microwave.  I was really looking forward to trying the brisket and they were out!  How can you have a BBQ place with no brisket?  I had a BLT instead with coleslaw; the bacon was burnt and they coleslaw had no flavor at all.  The manager came by and noticed the burnt bacon on my plate and gave us a couple of dollars off our bill.  I thought that was really nice.  Overall I don't think we'll be back.  Super disappointed. :(

We usually go to the one in Springfield and or Broomall Panera. We had to pick up something at Lowe's so we decided to stop in (for an over priced meal). We always say we will never go back but we keep going I guess we are gluttons for punishment! I ordered the turkey chili which was petty good I must admit and my usual Smokehouse Turkey Panini. My wife ordered the spinach power salad and the Vegetarian creamy tomato soup both she said were good! We were surprised we were not asked for bread or chips with our soups as we usually but was asked for a bakery up grade. I will say the place was dirty we has to clean off our own tables as the was trash and crumbs from prior customers on ALL the tables! All in all we said our usual we will not come back! But I am sure we will found ourself back at a Panera bread soon!

We arrived at Agave and were seated outside with a closed umbrella at the table. The waiter never said anything about it initially and it was impossible to see the other person across from me. I asked the waiter if he could raise it up. He then gave us a long speech about all the things that could happen if the wind took the umbrella such as it hitting a car, hitting another person, damaging property etc. Not understanding why he was telling us this we asked " So what you're saying is, if we open the umbrella we are responsible if any of those things happen?" He said yes and we just asked him to take it out completely feeling irritated that he didn't just say that in the first place. (Mind you there were about 6 other tables with umbrellas already open). 

The De La Casa Margarita is awful. It tastes like a straight mix. I asked the waiter if he could change it to The Skinny Margarita that the other person got and he said "Yes, I will dump a little of this out and put some of that mix in it"....Not what I asked. Still tasted bad.

I ordered the combo plate with two ground beef enchiladas, and they we're extremely soggy and the meat had no taste. My friend ordered the fish tacos and it was a tortilla full of fish....nothing else. 

Will not go back and recommend people not to go.

We went there for lunch. It was just ok no wow factor. For the money better food and service is at other restaurants  we had to ask for everything. My ckn alfredo was sliced thin and not much flavor.
We will not go back. I was not impressed.

I don't think I have ever given only two stars to a restaurant on Yelp. Unfortunately I made a mistake in not checking the dates of people's posts that this place was so awesome. Won't do that again. Pretty much all the reviews are 1 and 2 years old and not only are items that people Rave about no longer on the menu but what is still on the menu is questionable. I was greeted walking in with the sight of the waitress eating. Even after she saw me she took another bite before addressing me. During my meal, which took forever even though I was the only one there, I witnessed the chef eating behind the counter right where he was making the food. I got the salmon omelette with toasted bagel and cream cheese. I asked for my home fries well done with onions as I always do. The bagel could not have been considered toasted, the cream cheese schmear was on The Omelette not the bagel, there was a minimal amount of salmon in the omelette and the potatoes were far from well done and had about four small pieces of onions. The waitress was very sweet but checked on me once during the meal and never again. I had to holler out for her and still it was the chef that heard me and told her to come over to my table. Also, placr could use a good cleaning and watch put fpr the extension cords everywhere. Sorely disappointed and will not be back.

I'll start with the good:

Crust was nice and crunchy.

The amount of cheese was pretty decent and didn't overwhelm the pizza. 

The so-so:

My pepperoni slice was just a cheese slice with a couple pepperoni thrown on top so they weren't really baked in. I guess that's okay? 

Not so good:

Most of the staff walked around behind the counter in full view of customers without masks. Mask use is very lax here. 

Overall, the pizza was okay, but the mask usage is probably going to keep me from re-visiting.
Silly thing duplicated my review :(
Food is not as good as it was before remodeling. Sorry but tried twice and it was just ok. Used to be the best in the area.

Woof.  Tiki is a total flop.

I've been in search of new tiki bar since the Upstairs Bar closed down, and Tiki is in a convenient location in Midtown Village, so I checked it out with a friend when we needed a spot to catch up and hang out.

We ordered the Scallion Pancakes and Dumplings as a snack, and the bartender pulled them out of frozen packages and cooked them like that. So basically, I just paid money for like, microwaveable food.  They also served them in like, take out paper containers you'd get at a fair and with take out packets of soy sauce and duck sauce which we just sadly squirted out on top of our food.  I was embarrassed for them, to be honest.

The drinks were really uninteresting - I ordered the Riki Tiki Tavi because it seemed palatable out of most of the drinks and it was dull.  Tasted like somewhat bitter soda water with a dash of citrus and some alcohol.  Yikes.  I honestly could have mixed something very similar during my college days.  

On top of all of that, the smell? The bar smelled like a mix of skunk, sweat, and gas.  

Our bartender was sweet, but I'm truly sorry, nothing can truly save this place or the experience.

BOTTOM LINE: SKIP THIS PLACE. Midtown is FULL of gems, and this is unfortunately the dud in the midst.  The food and drinks weren't even worth taking photos of, I was so, so disappointed.

My friend and I came here for girls night. The restaurant is beautifully decorated a lot of areas to take nice pictures. Our waiter was Ray and he was amazing! He constantly checked up on us and gave us amazing suggestions. For appetizers, we got the Pork Gyoza which was delicious, the Pork Bao Buns which were alright (I wouldn't get it again) and the Braised Pork Belly which was my friends favorite. For drinks we got Dragon's Breath, Sake Sangria, Namaste and Jelly Roll. All of the drinks were delicious and worth it! For entrees, we got the Wood Fired Lobster Uramaki Roll & OMG THIS IS THE BEST SUSHI I'VE EVER HAD!! If you go, you definitely have to get this. You won't be disappointed!! My friend had the Pork Belly Fried Rice which was also really good. For dessert, our waiter suggested the Matcha Tres Leches, I'm not a fan of tres leches cake but this was sooo good!!

I came here with my family for my birthday and I am so glad we did! My parents always rave about Gratzzi and I have been wanting to try it for a while now. When we first got there it seemed pretty busy but they sat us down right away. Our server was great the whole time! When we sat at our table we got some bread with Parmesan cheese and it was so good! We ordered Calamari Fritti for our appetizer and it was delicious specially with the marinara sauce. My mom and I got the Italian Wedding Soup and it was so tasty, the meatballs in the soup were so good! For our entrees my mom got the Chicken Parmigiana, my dad got the Rustica pizza, my brother got the Spaghettini Meatballs but he switched the sauce to the spicy marinara and I got the Cavatelli Bada Bing with chicken. Everyone loved their food and was happy with it but I have to say out of everybody's mine was the best! The way that they cook the Cavatelli Bada Bing pasta in front of you and then put it in the parmesan cheese wheel was just so impressive! It was definitely worthy of a birthday meal! My pasta was so freaking delicious that my brother got one to go! They give you pretty big portions, everyone except for me had a to go box. For dessert, I got the crème brûlée and I thought it was amazing! Our experience here was great! Just typing this review is making my mouth water and makes me want to go back to get more!!

Mediocre steak house, but OK for the price.  My son had roasted chicken which looked a bit over cooked.  The chunky garlic mashed potatoes had some grit in the texture. Not sure what that was. I had the 6 oz filet Mignon which was just OK. A bit thin for me.  I wasn't so happy that they charged you extra for a sauce over it like Bearnaise or Mushrooms. I had the creamed spinach for a side dish could've used more spinach and less cream and butter. Didn't taste healthy at all.   I don't think they serve dessert at all since they rushed us out after dinner.   I looked at the menu on the way out and didn't see any listed.
I love the old diner atmosphere here. Fun retro flare.   Great shakes in many flavors. Burgers, chicken and salads are all good here.  I never have room for dessert though.
A bit overpriced (tapas are very minimal), but the food is good.  The mojito we got was very bad, not at all mixed well, but the white sangria was delicious.  Overall an average experience.

If I find myself in Fennario's, it's not for the ambiance. Or the coffee.
 
If I have to enter into Fennario's...which entails parting a sea of chain-smoking, skinny-jeaned, tousled, dirty-looking young things of indeterminate age huddled outside the entrance, it's because a friend of mine's band has a gig or someone has an art show on the 2nd floor. As their live music acts go, some are interesting, most not. (I'll remain mum on which category said friend's performance falls under)

The interior of the place has an unkempt, derelict look about it, and more often than not one of West Chester's resident bums is spotted reclining in his own pungency near the back. I'm assuming the baristas have control over the music, because the music choices are really schizo: one occasion you'll hear (and appreciate) the low-key drawl and hum of an indie rap song quietly mingling with the dankness of the cafe...or on another occasion, you'll be assaulted by a blaring cacophonous techno mix of, say, Barbie Girl, that drowns out any and every rational thought. 
The coffee is meh. Lattes, etc, all meh. Not great but not awful. Apparently they have milkshakes/ice cream but I can't say I've ever partaken. 
Invariably I'll have some gig that I feel impelled by the deep bonds of friendship to go to and I'll find myself back here. But I don't have to like it.

I stumbled across this Collegeville gem when a nearby mexican place wasn't quite open and I was starving. We walked in and the people behind the counter were very friendly. They welcomed us and pointed out the specials of the day. I immediately saw the any panini special and knew that was what I wanted. I looked at the panini menu and ordered the Americano panini. Turkey, avocado, bacon and american cheese with a sundried tomato aioli, how can you go wrong. My fiance ordered a slice of the taco pizza. We took our seats and our food arrived quickly. Everything was hot, tasty, delicious. I ate until I could eat no more. We have some leftovers and I told the woman who handed me the box, that I had never been there, but loved the food. I literally went back days later. 

FYI, this place is BYOB. It's a small place, family friendly, and prices are great. I can't wait to go back.

I was really hoping to have a great lunch today after my Farmer's Market visit, but was very disappointed.  We waited too long for our drinks, but our server did apologize and said the bartender was behind on his orders. Okay, fine.  Had to wait again for her to take our orders, had to ask for chips/salsa, and ask for our water to be refilled.  Then we waited at least 30 minutes for our food! I actually had to flag the server down and ask her to check on our orders.  Funny, that she immediately went into the kitchen and someone else brought out our food right away!  Sadly,  the food was just lukewarm though.  I could hardly find the fish on my 3 little street tacos.  For $14, I definitely did not get my money's worth either in food or service.  Nice decor though! Definitely won't return.
Are you low on Salt? This is the place for you. Or just go to the feed store and get a Salt lick. .. cheaper and tastes the same.

I LOVE me some empanadas... so I knew when I was gonna be in town for an event, (I live in South Jersey) I for sure wanted to stop by this place!
