In the downtown Main Street area, parking can be a little confusing. They have a tiny parking lot in front of their place, and if you find one, you're super lucky! But there are tons of street parking all around the area within a short walking distance. Metered and free parking all around.

The shop is small, more of a takeout place than a sit in place. Lots of options on their menu. Go early to ensure they have all the flavors available because if they run out, they're done for the day. You can also call your order in to make the process even faster. There were a few girls working the front, very friendly and took the time to give me their recommendations along with dip options. Asked me if I needed the empanadas heated up. Service was nice and quick even with a shop full of customers!

Empanadas
I went with the dozen order which came with 4 dip choices. I went with 2 Korean Beefs, 2 BA Beef, 2 Sausage, 2 Chimi Cauliflower , 2 BBQ Chicken and 2 Honey Mustard Chicken. All of them were AMAZING!! Dough was nice and flaky.. but not too flaky where it falls apart so easily. It held together nicely and the flavor combinations were so yummy. I didn't even need the dipping sauces, but they were a great addition to them.

I will definitely come back if I'm ever back in town because the town itself is a cute little area to explore.. but this place is a definite must if you're in the area!
Stopped down in Ybor City on a rainy Saturday.  The food was good.  The deviled crab is good, but use the hot sauce to make it better.  Service was attentive.

Not as impressive as the first time. Not sure if the oven needed cleaned or what, but after eating our pizza and breadsticks, our hands were black. Plates were black as well. Also, it was kind of unsettling to see people working directly over food with nothing covering their head. One of the guys had very thick hair that he kept shaking as he was putting stuff on our pizza.

$2.50 classic margaritas (strawberry costs $3.50) during happy hour are the bomb dot com! Absolutely delicious and had me dancing in my seat :p 

Simply put, I'm just not a big fan of the food here. I came here for dinner with family and friends and everyone left food on their plates...not normally atypical but then again no to-go boxes were needed either :/ Meat was just not tender and food was somewhat bland.

Service is also hit or miss and the place can get pretty raucous, which is cool for happy hour but not for a nice dinner with parents or a business dinner. This is a happy hour only spot for me.

I really wanted to give Eggshell five starts. The decor is adorable, there's a GORGEOUS espresso machine sitting on the counter, and the menu has some good items. The cup of African coffee for $3 was lukewarm, the brioche with poached egg was supposed to come with asparagus ($9) - which, it technically did, but...it looked like sprinkled little pieces of slivered green onions. I doubt it was even half of an asparagus spear. They did not have fresh ground pepper. The piece of brioche itself was very good though. I like the concept of this place, and I will be back - I would like to improve the star rating...
Would not return. Burger and chicken too heavily spiced and charred.  Fried overly salted.  I actually wanted a side salad instead but the waiter never asked me which side I wanted.

Food is overpriced and mediocre. Walk a few blocks to the 80 Dunkins nearby and experience better tasting food at a fraction of the cost. I got a bacon egg and cheese on a bagel for $5, which was close to eating a sponge with some meat on top. It also took at least 10 minutes to be made. Not worth it. If you're looking for a solid sandwich (breakfast or lunch), might I suggest walking into 3 Parkway (building that says DREXEL on top) and ordering a made-to order sandwich from Cherry Cafe for about $3 in less than 5 minutes, MUCH tastier and quicker.

I liked the iced coffee at Capriccio, for $2 it wasn't bad. 1 star for the iced coffee, 1 star for the good customer service. 

Lost 3 stars for taste, price, and wait.

I don't know why I order the pull pork it's always tough and chewy but there's really nothing else on the menu that appeals to me but my husband like the gator and he enjoys it 
But you'll never be hungry Harry's minus the gator 
Also u should do Texas toast not just plain bread

What happened to you guys? Your place has REALLY tanked! We ordered "mild" and it burned our throats! That never happened before. Very disappointing. And your website says it has FOUR locations, yet there are links to only three!

Never again. Too bad.
Slowest service ever! Even the cable tv was slow why have on the news if it keeps glitching!! It took 15min for our easy breakfast order!

Possibly the worst hamburger I've ever had. I ordered a medium Jack Daniels burger. It was cooked well-done and was dry and basically flavorless. The fries were warm, but not fresh out of the fryer hot. Two stars because the toppings on the burger were nice and very fresh and the server was adequate. I'd give that hamburger negative stars if I could.

Wasn't my first time here, but I wasn't Yelping prior to today! Made a quick stop before jumping on 95 to go to the shore. I ordered egg whites, cheese, and turkey bacon on rye toast. It hit the spot. The bagels are good, but I used to be a bagel baker, so I'm over them. If you like bagels, you'll dig this place. It is poppin in here every time I go, but it's good. I've never had issues with the service or my order. I'll be back eventually. Can't say much about the coffee since I get it at Wawa or Dunkin instead.

Ive only been here a few times and everytime I eat here I always always always leave with food for the next day. The prices are cheap, nd a plate of food can literally feed 2 ppl. Im giving it 3 stars instead of 5 because their pernil was lacking in pretty much everything. My sister in law makes to die for pernil and tierras is nothing compared to hers. Also, another reviewer mentioned the tres leche cake. Sorry but Ive had better. Besides those 2 glitches on the menu, I would come back to try their other specialties

I have to say, I still like the original location, but do respect the new location. I like that you can watch your food being made and I like the lay out. I like I just enjoy the quaintness of the original location. The food is just as great. And I liked the happy hour.

So this is on our 2 week restaurant rotation now. We're in love with the salt and pepper porkchops and our son has to have his own order of salt and pepper tofu...he's almost 2 lol. The decor is chic and hip and for now it is a byob spot which works coz it's cheaper than buying a bottle at a restaurant anyways. We gotten a lot of the items on the menu and nothing has yet to disappoint! =)

You would never know this place even existed unless you went into the plaza and drove all the way to the end. It's pretty big inside. They have a full bar and the bartenders are always so nice. We came towards the end of the night looking for a nightcap and the wine place next door 'closed earlier than stated'. It was nice to walk in and get instantly greeted. The bar end was full and there were a few people out by the outside seating area. Everyone is nice and it seems like a total local bar because everyone knew each other. On to the food. By the looks of the reviews the food is good and made from scratch. I guess we were at a disadvantage because we came so late and wanted something to eat. We ordered the salsa & guac (which i thought would be safe) but when she brought it out it didn't look too appealing and the taste was right there with the looks. Someone asked about what else they were serving and she said ya no don't get anything now just get a drink. So maybe we'll go earlier and try out the food end coz the bar end is great!

I love that El Rey still feels like the old Midtown diner, only cleaner. I went for lunch once and though they do serve a reasonably priced brunch i wasn't so impressed. I do however, LOVE the happy hour! $1 tacos and $3 margaritas....perfect
Eh. Not great. Not terrible. Didn't leave much of an impression at all. Drinks are okay. Food is okay. Bartenders are kind of douchey and a little too cool for school.

Why 3 stars? Because this was a neat experience, but just not worth the bill.

   ---   ---   ---

Maybe I'm a tough critic because the only other Brazilian Steakhouse I've been to is supposedly one of the best in the country - Chama Gaucha in Houston. I don't remember how much my meal was there, but everything was so delicious, that I would have had no issue paying any amount of money for it. 

Bull Grill was a step down from that, for me. And there's nothing wrong with not being as good as one of Yelp's Top 100 restaurants in the country, but here's my beef (no pun intended.)

-The meat was generally solid, but not spectacular.

-The salad bar was very underwhelming (again, compared to a place with 3-4x the selection.)

-The cost was $120 for two people after tax/tip for two dinners and sodas.

Both my fiance and I walked out with the same opinion - a fun experience that's definitely different from the norm... but $120? Phew. To be honest, I would not return at kind of price point.

I don't enjoy giving negative, or in this case, a "meh" review for a local business that is obviously pouring their heart and soul into a business. At the same time, I also want to be honest in giving my opinion. 

I will say this - everyone working here during our visit could not have been nicer. Service was incredibly prompt and always with a smile. We appreciated that very much.

I had time to swing down here for breakfast recently. I'm glad I did. 

I loved the breakfast sandwich. They gave me the most bacon I've ever seen on a sandwich. I almost thought of taking some off it was so much (emphasis on almost). 

I also tried the steel cut oatmeal. I enjoyed the choices of toppings they give you, up to three. 

I like the fact that I can go to a place that has a counter and get a little more creative of a menu like this. That's a good combo in my world. 

It's worthy of your time.

OK, I get it now.  This place really isn't one of the good branches of the Ruby Tuesday chain.  

So tonight, we came here because we had a gift card.  Like I said previously, I generally do well with Ruby Tuesdays.  The one I go to in Malvern near work has generally treated me well.  I usually appreciate the salad bar.  Some items on the menu can be pretty good, especially the appetizers and burgers.  Like a lot of chains, if you go into the entree world, it's hit or miss.  

Before I go anywhere, let me state that none of this review is indicative of the level of service by our waiter, Brian.  He was very good.  I made it a point to name him because I know that everything else isn't his fault.  

Now, on to the grievances.  

So, my first mistake was coming in here expecting to get something I wanted as a paying customer.  Case in point... order the Chicken Trio, and ask them to substitute the rice pilaf for another side such as mashed cauliflower.  You see, this particular item on the menu is stated that it is served with rice pilaf on the menu.  If you get the salad bar with it, you do not get another choice of side.  Apparently the three pieces of chicken must be served on a bed of rice pilaf.  This is a rule.  Don't question it.  It has been deemed so by the corporate suits who own the Ruby Tuesday empire!

You see, in my naive head, being the paying customer, it seems to me that you can just serve the chicken on the plate without the rice, and put some cauliflower on the side or in a separate dish.  Well, my server was nice enough to ask the kitchen if they would do it at least.  But he seemed mildly unsure if they would accommodate the request.  

I never managed a restaurant in my life.  But I have to imagine some requests, if simple, should be honored.  It's not like I was asking them for a more expensive side.  It's not like I was asking them to change the flavoring radically.  It's not like I'm Meg Ryan ordering dinner in When Harry Met Sally here.  I just wanted cauliflower instead of rice.  

The server came back out, and he told me the kitchen couldn't do it.  Apparently he told me they said it has to be served over a bed of rice pilaf.  He asked if I wanted to order a completely different entree instead.  

Well, since I really wanted the variety of chicken, and I just didn't feel like making a scene, I took the rice.  You see, perhaps I could have asked for a manager, but sometimes you just don't want to fight the battle in the restaurant.  Because in the end I have a simple credo.

Always Yelp about it later... that's the best ammunition!

So anyway, I imagine the conversation in the kitchen went like this...

SERVER: Hey, a customer wants the Chicken Trio with cauliflower instead of rice.  Can you do that for him?  

20 YEAR OLD COOK WHO ISN'T TRAINED WELL: W-w-w-w-w-whaaattt???  Ummmm, I don't know how to do that.  The menu says rice pilaf.  I can't ignore the menu.  The menu says so.  Can't go against the menu.  

SERVER: So you're going to send me back out there to tell the customer no, then?

COOK: *head explodes from the pressure*

I mean, if you're Georges Perrier, and you have lived your whole life learning about food and you win major awards in France for doing so, then you get to tell me how you will serve your dish.  Otherwise, give me my damn cauliflower and hush.  

So anyway, now that my rant is done... that Chicken Trio does indeed come on a bed of rice pilaf, a HUUGGGEEE bed of rice, with three pieces of chicken the size of two of my fingers each.  

You know, I really think they could have just moved the damn chicken over, saved the rice, and thrown some cauliflower on there.  It's not like real estate on the plate was at a premium.  These weren't large chicken pieces here.  

I know... I'm ranting.  And there are far greater injustices in the world.  But for some reason, this kind of soured me.  

Oh by the way, the dish I got wasn't too bad in the end.  But my wife's dish... for 12 bucks she gets a scrawny cajun chicken breast, three overcooked shrimp on a wood skewer, and sliced tomatoes.  The tomatoes were bigger than the other two items on the plate combined.  The flavoring on her chicken tasted bitter.  She couldn't even get the shrimp off of the skewer, it was stuck on there since it was so overcooked.  Literally, she tried to pull the shrimp off and the stick broke from the pressure.  The tomatoes were the only good thing on her dish.  Bottom line... one dish failed out of two.  

I just have to say this to the Ruby's kitchen... if you had just given me the cauliflower like I asked, I'd have kept this place at three stars and not updated my review.  But you compelled me to mock you after this experience tonight.  This failure is on the kitchen staff.  They just didn't know what they were doing tonight.  

Next time I get a gift card for Ruby's, I'll just drive to Malvern to use it.

This Whiz Wit is a pretty special sandwich. It's packed with flavor. The truffle whiz is pretty amazing and makes the sandwich. Very tender and juicy beef. 

In my city cheesesteak top 10 it's probably 4th. I gotta give a little more props to the places that do amazing sandwiches without kicking the cheese up a notch.

So what's my top 10 cheesesteaks in the city? I thought you'd never ask. 

1. Angelo's 
2. John's 
3. Dalessandro's
4. Woodrow's
5. Philip's 
6. Tony Luke's 
7. Max's 
8. Joe's
9. Jim's 
10. Steve's 

Honorable mentions: Gooey Louie's, Ishkabibble's, Pat's

I love Jewish delis.  It's just a thing with me.  I am not a member of the tribe, but I've always appreciated the food and the culture.  

This place has been on my radar to try for a while.  Got my chance for lunch yesterday.  Apparently I was fortunate to come at a down time after 1 because it wasn't terribly busy.  According to the waitress, they were packed a half hour prior.  So I was able to get lightning fast service.  

I, like many others, have my yardsticks that I measure Jewish delis by.  I have standard things I like to try.   For me, it's about the matzoh ball soup and the knish.  The sandwiches are important as well, but those two dishes in particular will make or break a place for me.  

So here's my verdict...

Matzoh ball soup... not every place makes this with carrots, chicken, and celery.  This place does.  And I appreciate that.  For $3.39 it was a decent size bowl.  Not the biggest ever, but not a skimp.  Win.  

Potato knish.... now, I'll admit that I'm not a knish expert.  I just know what I like in them.  I've had knishes that had a touch of seasoning in the filling, maybe a dash of black pepper, that worked very well.  This had no seasoning whatsoever.  It was a little bland, and was mildly greasy on the outside.  And, due to microwaving I am sure, the outside was overly hot (to the point of tongue burning), while farther inside it was more cool.  Also, at $4.25, it was just not big enough.  Sorry, I have to fail this one.  

Turkey special... I've had this sandwich at several places in the local region.  it's just a combo I like.  The turkey was a generous pile, tasted fresh enough, with good flavoring in the cole slaw and dressing, and soft rye bread.  At $7.99 it was a good enough size. I've had better turkey specials that actually came with a side order unlike this one, but this was a fine sandwich.  Call this a win. 

I sampled the pickle bar.  I'm not a pickle guy.  But I give a plus for offering the bar.  

I almost hate giving it three stars because everyone who served me there was so nice and friendly.  Really, kudos on the service.  It couldn't have been better.  

Food quality, though, two of the three items were good enough to satisfy.  Judging by other experiences documented here on Yelp, I'd say this place is good enough to give a try.  But I have to call my experience as I see it.

I needed a Monday afternoon lunch. This place worked in a pinch for me. 

Positives here are that they give you a lot got your money. A BLT club with fries gives a sizable sandwich with a mound of fries. A slice of pizza was huge. The tossed salad with chicken came with plenty of it. 

Food flavor wise, nothing stood out as special. In fact, the huge slice of pizza completely lacked flavor. But the cheesesteak I tried held up ok. 

That defines this place perfectly. It's just ok. It's not special.

It's a nice enough place.  I stopped in last night for a beer, and what I hoped would be some good food.  I liked the atmosphere, and the place is spacious.  

But... if you're just one person on your own on a Saturday night in early November around 8pm, you will be told that you can't be seated to get something to eat.  The reason they will give is that they need the tables for the big college football game (apparently the owner is a huge Alabama fan, and it was LSU-Bama night), and they will need the tables for anyone coming over from Eastern State Penitentary.  You will then be told that you have to fight it out for a spot at the bar which no one appears to be ready to leave.  

This will make me, a potential paying customer, go somewhere else and not spend money here, probably ever again.  I understand the need for tables, but they had at least 16 spots open with small tables put together at the time I asked.  You mean to tell me you couldn't have broken one of those tables off for a half hour to seat me?  

Sorry, guys.  That's lame.

If you don't like Hope's Cookies, then you really don't like cookies.  

In fact, I'd also bet that if you don't like Hope's Cookies, then you actually don't like puppies, flowers, cute babies, sunsets, or even America.  This would make you just a miserable person in general and probably a hermit.  

I stopped over there for dessert after having some Peace A Pizza right next to it.  I figured I'd get a couple of cookies.  I left with a dozen.  

So many flavors, and most of them are excellent.  But let's just say that if I died after having a White Russian cookie, I'd consider that a worthy last bite of food on this Earth to have.  

And if you disagree, go join Al Qaida or something, you Commie sumbitch!

To be fair, I tried them in their first week. So take that for what you will. 

And I liked everything I ate. 

Between the Dan Dan noodles, the soup dumplings, and the Sichuan dumplings, it's a case of everything tasting pretty good. 

But in each case I can tell you that I've had better elsewhere.

I'm always looking for cheesesteak places to add to my list of places I've been in the city. Someone on Twitter said I should try Abner's. I've always seen it but never thought to come in. 

Today I did. And I'm here to say it's decent. 

It's not great. It doesn't make my top 10 of the city. 

The good... I liked the flavor of the meat. That stood out for some reason. The roll was ok. Not crusty enough for my taste. But not bad. 

The eh... not enough cheese. It was all at the bottom of the roll too. 

They did give my son a huge chicken finger platter with fries for $7.95. Can't complain there. And he didn't. 

It's a good enough place. But I won't be driving in from Delco for it. If you live in this area it will do nicely.

First off, this address is incorrect at the time of this review. This location is in Paoli, not Flourtown. Looks like the zip code got transposed by a couple numbers. Changes have been submitted. 

So, I decided to compare this place to some of the local pizza offerings.  They seem to have enough menu choices and the slices were nicely displayed for choosing. I tried a sausage slice, a buffalo chicken slice, and a piece of the pepperoni stromboli. The slices had a decent amount of toppings and were nice and foldable. I'd eat them again. The stromboli actually tasted better without the cup of sauce they gave me. That sauce was cold and lacked flavor.  I don't know if that sausage slice was made with the same sauce, but I'm going to assume not. 

If you asked me to compare, I'd come here before I went to Bravo or Nino's nearby. I'd probably choose Venice over them. I'd go to Anthony's before all of them. 

They're friendly enough when they serve you, and the slice prices were reasonable enough. They deserve a shot at your business.

Really, we all know this place will never be like the original, or like the South Street location.  Don't even bother trying to compare.  

But, last time I decided to give them a try for the heck of it, they made a pretty decent chicken cheesesteak with real chicken chunks, and lots of them.  I was satisfied.  

Just don't expect much.  It's a pretty good cheesesteak.  It won't change your life.

I have loved this Maggiano's for well over a decade. I have held several banquets and family gatherings at this location; which has brought in thousands of dollars in revenue.

I had a banquet there today, and I was more than disappointed in the food. I used to love the salmon and spinach, the chicken cannoli, fried mozzarella, fried zucchini and baked ziti. I was thoroughly disappointed. You spend $3000 for food that is ill-seasoned at best.

A few people thought the food was good, but I know how the food USED TO BE, and today's entrees were a poor version. The ziti was dry, with limited sauce and meat. The fried mozzarella had an aftertaste. the chicken cannoli's pasta was overcooked, over-cheesed, and 'under-chickened (very little chicken in the dish)! While the salmon and spinach dish was void of the light lemon taste with the delightful spinach. Instead, it was season-less, with a heavy 'in the way,' greasy sauce.

The shining Stars were our OUTSTANDING servers, Brian K. & Brendan! B&B are a team. I wondered how would banquet management put 2 servers in a banquet of 40 people...yet, other banquets had more servers. #questionable. Brian K. & Brendan were so inundated, that our guest never received the beverages on the banquet menu.

25% chance that I will have another event at Maggiano's.

#whereistheoldmaggianos

Certainly this location remains a Philadelphia staple. One in which has seen it's up and downs
in terms of food, service, quality, and atmosphere. I was there for a catered business business luncheon and the food was mediocre at best. 

One highlight was that parking is free during the lunch hours, which was awesome. During the afternoon Dave and Buster's is almost desolate, however as the evening progressed it was great, active noise which is what it should sound like. 

This is the optimum place for folks who love to play games, and for families with children. However, I would recommend that children come before 6pm. There is a policy for children after a certain hour, so check before you go.
Go here every year for fish sandwich during Lent. Last two years (carry out) have been disappointing. Too much breading. Maybe just not as good as eating inside which we always enjoyed.

One of your employees needs to be a little bit more educated and less MOODY with the people that pay their per hour salary. The attitude, the looks of your kitchen staff specially a white guy,bald with red facial hair...thanks for the attitude dude...thanks

Blake may be a Marylander, but this fellow Maryland native was very disappointed in his crab cakes. First, no option to get broiled, only fried, which was my first sign that something may be amiss. Then, it comes out as deep fried ball, but then I immediately notice the orange tinged end of the backfin lump (where the joint of the backfin is in the crab), which is a tell tale sign that this is NOT Maryland blue crab meat (see pic) and likely imported Asian swimming blue crab (similar but.not.the.same.). But I dig in, and the crab cake interior was mushy and kinda gooey, not firm, and the usual sweet crab meat flavor with subtle hints of old bay seasoning and brackish water - was completely missing. Lastly, the price - yes, you get what you pay for, and a really good super high quality jumbo lump Maryland crab cake with little filler will set you back at least $20, for one.  So,  if the price is too good to be true, there's a reason why...  then take that as your cue to run far fast. I was really looking forward to enjoying a Maryland crab cake here in Florida, but alas... I'm still on the hunt.

We drove by and my husband's eyes were riveted to the sign, "thin crust" mmm!  Could not spot the place though.  Drove by again and still couldn't see it.  So I checked Yelp and learned it was behind the B & N.  Also snapped a picture for my friend Jules.  

They make their pizzas in a unique long shape which is easy to slice and display.  They have a vegan pizza with Daiya cheese!!!  Clean, spare, modern decor in the vibe of Chipotle.  There are five of these, four of which are in PA (Wayne, Doylestown, Newtown besides this one), one in CA.  

Eight meat pies, fifteen veggie, and four cheese.  Swap out any cheese for Daiya -- they are happy to do it, thank you!  Three thin crusts, all organic, include a white, wheat, and gluten free.  They also have cool toppings like chick peas, butternut squash, all sorts of greens, artichokes, kalamata olives, pear slices, black beans, and about 30 other things.  Large is $18.50; medium is $15.50, a dollar extra for glutenfree. Salads are $5-6.

Local organic sources; I have to ask more about this.  Kid-friendly too, great to see kids not eating total junk, and very sweet enthusiastic staff.  Order by the slice or the pie.  BYOB, and there is a wine store right over by Trader Joe's.  Wish we had one in our town.

I love dogs and was charmed by the dog paintings and sculptures everywhere. We also appreciated the large parking lot. This is a nice bar to visit after a film at the local Bryn Mawr theater, a really wonderful one. Cocktail and wine lists were excellent. Staff at every turn were very friendly, even when they seemed to be overwhelmingly busy.

Note to vegans: As for the vegetarian menu, most of which heavy on eggs, cream, and cheese, you have to request the vegan customization if it is marked as being possible (with 3 stars).  Some items, however, seemed vegan according to their ingredients but weren't marked as "can be vegan." Why not just make the vegetarian items vegan, using nut creams and cheeses? Vegetarians will eat these, I believe. 

Yes, I could have asked more questions, but who wants to bother busy servers and bartenders? The only vegan dessert, of about 8, was sorbet. So I would not make this place my choice for an upscale dinner, but it is OK for snacks.

Our server gave us olive oil for the tasty bread, and our tofu entree with citrus and broccoli ($19) was delicious.

It is 10%-off if you order food at the bar.

With nearly 200 reviews here, why do you need mine?  People here have covered the vegan fare, and this place shows that vegan food can be offered among many meat dishes, pleasing everyone even when you are with a diverse group.  

While there is not a huge array of vegan, we can order straight off the menu and can't get to everything in one night, which is always a plus.  We were stuffed splitting the Korean BBQ seitan tacos, spring rolls with a cherry compote, and the wings with tasty creamy sauces, which my husband raved and raved about.  Next time I will try the Stuffed Tofu, filled with nuts and fruit.

He wished there were more actual Belgians on draft instead of just Belgian-style.  I am not as into Belgian beer and was happy with my Sierra Nevada rye ale.  

We have come for lunch but wish we could make the brunch sometime to try the vegan creamed dried beef on toast, something I never thought I'd be eating again.  It's so cool that they make savory comfort dishes with lots of flavor and spice.  

We had a long wait late on a Friday night which was expected, but the hostess remembered us and took care of us in the time quoted   Nice that the outdoor seating is non-smoking.  

Overall, it is a colorful, comfy space with two personalities, a bright front dining room and a wood paneled old-timey dark bar.  This is an easy walkable location to enjoy a late snack and drink after events at the Free Library or the art museum.  (Leave a half hour for parking however; no garages!)  Great library lecture recently by Tavis Smiley and Dr. Cornel West on their anti-poverty tour.  The library gets such good authors, especially on the topic of social justice (Amy Goodman, Peter Singer, Jonathan Safran Foer, and on and on).  Maybe Tavis and Dr. West can come to the poorest city in the country, Reading, PA.

Welp, apparently portions have now decreased while prices have risen. The Palermo Chicken was always my go-to before. It was large, juicy, and came with a good side of elbow pasta. Tonight my dish was flat, a tad dry and actually the kicker for me was a side of ten little individual elbow pastas on the side...It's like they counted them? Maybe they ran out? It was only 8pm. Who knows. But for $17.00, I better not have to scarf-down sides of bread in order to not still be hungry after dinner. Not in this town.

I choose to give this place 2 stars instead of 1 simply because I feel bad for the servers who must have to deal with what must be a never-ending list of complaints about nearly everything on the menu.  They are courteous and friendly despite working in a glorified dive.

Now, I have been a regular customer there for years and, in the end, it pains me to say anything negative about the place, but I have gotten tired of being served rancid chicken and, just tonight, the most foul coleslaw l have ever had.  The second it hit my mouth, I spit it right back out.  It was that bad.

They have a habit of getting orders wrong in the back (not the server who took the order correctly) and then to be served bad food on top of it is more than I can handle. 

I have sworn this place off forever.  But if they can improve the food quality substantially, I will reconsider.  Until then, South Street Diner is out.

I order from this location about once or twice per week. Today I ordered online and then called the store to politely ask for extra cinnamon sugar on the bread. The manager CJ rudely told me that I ordered $1.99 worth of cinnamon bread and I would get $1.99 worth of cinnamon and hung up on me! I called back to complain about being hung up on and CJ informed me this location is a franchise and he doesn't care what I think or say! This is not the first time i've had rude customer service from this location, but it will be the last time! Beware of this store!

This place was pretty good! Fried ravioli was good for an app. Pizza was great too, gave it 4 stars because it was a tad on the burnt side. Our server was great and very knowledgable of the menu. Will definitely be back!

Oh, sorry to disagree with the most recent reviews. This restaurant was formerly Ben Kay, where they made their own ginger dressing, served the best hamachi kama (yellowtail collar), and were the first Japanese restaurant to open an adjunct Japanese grocery in Nashville. It used to be the only place you could find fairly fresh udon and Poke sticks without trekking to K&S, which always smelled bad and had no personnel who spoke English. (Not that that's a criticism, because it is an Asian grocery, but it makes it difficult to find anything if you can't read Japanese, Chinese, or Korean signs.) 
AT any rate, Ben Kay went a bit downhill, and at some point was renamed Sonobana and I assume taken over by new owners. The staff are still friendly, the shop is still there, but the food is increasingly poor. The basics - tuna, salmon - are tired. The rice is below par; maybe its Nishiki or another good brand, but it's often dried out. The menu is enormous - it would be better if they'd concentrate on half the dishes and do them twice as well. The saddest is their salad and dressing, which tastes nothing like the previous.
Which brings me to my biggest beef about Japanese restaurants in Nashville. Why not spend the extra couple of cents a salad, and use something other than iceberg lettuce? Maybe drain the bowls so there's not a huge collection of water at the bottom? 
Oh well. There is a reason most of the reviews here date from a few years ago. This is no longer a good restaurant. More's the pity, because it's the only one in the neighborhood outside of a Sushi Train, which just opened.

Basically the only drive through and most accessible Starbucks around the airport in Tampa. The drive through lines can be pretty long because the only other drive through is miles away. However, you'll be lucky to get through the line within 20 minutes with a correct order. I don't mind going inside and I often study there about 3 times a week. The store is clean and well kept but the staff is slacking. I'm pretty sure this is a training store because half of the people wear white shirts and half wear black (?). They are also reviewing information at tables most of the time. This is pretty ridiculous that they have this kind of responsibility when they can't get simple things right. Today the man who served me looked at me and said NAME before I was even done completing my order. It seemed to me that everything I said to him was a bother. Last time I went inside and waited 20 minutes for my order when people behind me in line got theirs first. A man next to me was also waiting and only had an iced coffee. Another gentleman burst out in anger and stormed off. When I politely inquired about my beverage the woman said that it was coffee for dummies and the tickets print out once they are sent. Somehow that doesn't make sense and maybe this store should check up on its technology and serving staff.

If your going to make reservations at this place ; 

DONT !!

a member of a member from a members only party made a 200 deposit for reserve the top floor of the building for about 30-40 people . When arrival tables were 65% full on top , all booths and some tables were with random people . Reservations were a little after 715 so they had plenty of time to clear space up . Horrible just plain horrible for the familys trying to squeeze in ...


Service was good for what was happening i feel like thats why they got a star ; but for some it was not good at all for the fact the two main people didnt ever get served their food after a hour so they cancelled the order !

Food was good thats why they got another star . I ordered the burger which was nice and juicy bomb azs fries and beer cold as can be . 

Didnt take pictures to busy playing pokemon go.. sorry

I remember when they finished building this Outlet Mall, I still lived in the area and I've been a few times over the years. Usually I go shopping like this with someone, mom, sister, daughter- it's just more fun shopping with someone. I've been to various "Premium Outlets" across numerous states- this one is right off I75, one of the things they go for is being right off an interstate. That means traffic in this area is crazy, and even more crazy during holidays and rush hour. Covid killed a few businesses at this location and a few still haven't reopened, but the majority of the Outlet stores are alive and well. This time, I shopped with my sister- which was super fun. I shopped some of her favorite stores, but my reason for wanting to come was the Sperry Shoes Outlet Store. Everything else was just icing on the cake. Getting name brand at a discount is always good, and even the normal discounts have additional sales too. Not that name brand always equates to quality, but some cases- yes. My shopping spree started at At Home (I actually went back to get something I debated on in store), Sperry Outlet, Banana Republic, Tommy Hilfiger, Direct Tools, Finish Line & Vera Bradley. I may have missed a store- but that is what I can remember off hand. My sister and I made various purchases across numerous stores and went across the street for lunch. We passed the running children's train ride as we were walking between stores and there was medium foot traffic for a Thursday late morning. We hit sales- that's what you do especially when you are shopping outlets. As stated in other reviews- the Tampa Premium Outlet isn't actually in Tampa, but north of the city... I guess Lutz Premium Outlet wouldn't draw people in the same way? LOL Where's Lutz? Happy Shopping!

Updated-
Went back for another breakfast and have had several lunches and had a great experience!  I believe the original experience was due to the new location and taking time to get it up.

Took my kids for breakfast, Benedict came out cold. I sent it back politely and they brought out another one...cold. Like barley room temperature. I ate 2 bites of cold potatoes and by that time kids were done and I was starving. No one apologized or said anything...They charged me for it anyway, along with $3 for a cup of coffee when they give it away free up front by the waiting area. Really like First Watch, this location is terrible.

It took me a while to try Harper's Garden but it was a solid choice. Unfortunately my visit was this winter and not during the warm months when I could enjoy the outdoor dining and garden. Still, I enjoyed the indoor atmosphere and the food.
While this place was busy, I dined late one evening and didn't feel hurried or rushed at all. 

The burrata dish was delicious and definitely worth trying. The salads were good and my buffalo ricotta flatbread was good as well. I definitely see why this place has been so popular since it's opening. I would love  to come back and dine outdoors.

Stumbled upon this place while in the area and what a pleasant find. This spot is quaint and casual but also nice enough for a more fancy date night or gathering. The service was friendly and helpful.

This is not quite traditional Mexican food , the food is more modern but there are some traditional offerings. I got the vegetarian cauliflower tacos and a side of sweet plantains. The tacos were fresh and had great flavor. 

Worth a visit if you are looking for a fresh take on Mexican dining. The also have tables outside if you like dining outdoors.

I visited Time during restaurant week and had a fun Tuesday night! They have a few extras added to their restaurant week menu courses like  Hors d'oeuvres and a risotto. This makes you feel like you are getting a lot for your $35.

I had a carb filled night with the vegetarian options available but all were pretty tasty. Started with the
 hors d'oeuvres, then chose bruschetta for the first course. The risotto was next followed by the second course of bucatini pasta. I ended with bread pudding for dessert. 

It was open mic night so we stayed a while after dinner to listen to the live music. The house band played through our meal. This is a fun and relaxing, casual atmosphere. Very dark and of course loud so be prepared if you plan to visit.

At the height of the Omicron surge, Wendy's DOES NOT REQUIRE THEIR FOOD HANDLER EMPLOYEES TO WEAR MASKS! This is the height of corporate irresponsibility and lack of caring for their customers as well as their employees. Not going there any time soon and suggest you consider this wreckless no-health policy before you take a bite. If they can't be bothered, then neither can I.

I chose this spot because I wanted to try something new for my birthday. It was easy enough to make a reservation on a Friday night, and the restaurant was pleasantly busy (not packed, but not questionably empty either). One interesting observation--there were many more white-haired people in this restaurant than what's typical for BR.

I ordered the famed fried chicken, which was good enough. It was fried crispy and had been dipped in a great batter. The mashed potatoes and mushroom gravy were to die for...definitely cleaned those off my plate. The green beans were nicely cooked and pleasantly garlicky. I had plenty for leftovers. I thought the price was reasonable for the food and the area. In general, though, everything was too salty. At one point it felt like my lips were burning with every bite.

I would come back to give 10-01 another chance. I like the idea of upscale comfort food (I can only eat so much gluten-free roasted bone marrow with kale). It sounds like they are under new management and have plans to change the menu around. Perhaps we'll come back when it's warmer to sit on that great patio!

We made it in for the famed lunch buffet! While I'm typically not into buffet style anything, I make an exception for ethnic food because it helps me get out of my comfort zone. I'm happy to have tried some Thai food outside of my tried-and-true faves!

The set up is that the buffet is $9.99, and the normal menu (which has basically the same stuff as the buffet) has dishes that are about $9.99 and include some accoutrements (soup perhaps?). It's clearly a better deal to go for the buffet. The food was great, however, I'm not so sure that $9.99 is actually that much of a "deal". I do think it was worth that much, but I'm not sure it was a bargain in a city full of lunch specials. The service was average. It was packed on a Friday afternoon!

The buffet had some fresh fruit and salad (that I basically skipped...I was there for the noodle-y carbs and fried stuff). I had:
-Veggie spring rolls: a favorite! Lots of sauce choices available for dipping, too.
-Tofu Pad Thai: above average for sure
-Pork Pad See Ew: the only thing I didn't particularly care for
-Spicy Basil Fried Rice with Chicken: definitely spicy! But I went back for seconds ;)
-Green Curry: the first time for me, and I was pleasantly surprised at how tasty it was since I'm typically not a big curry fan
-Orange Chicken: really crunchy (yum) and not overly orange-y, just the way I like it
-Fried Banana with Coconut and Honey: just as delicious as it sounds.

We went to Cafe Ponte for lunch & ate outdoors.  What a beautiful restaurant.  The waitress was from Romania & was a delight.  The service was perfect & the food was truly outstanding.  Everyone at our table loved their meal.  I ordered Chicken Pad Thai....medium spice.  The flavor & spice were right on.  This dish was so well done.  Instead of the food swimming in peanut sauce, only a light amount of sauce was used.  This allowed all the other natural flavors to be tasted, & the flavors were blended perfectly.  I thoroughly enjoyed my meal.  Cafe Ponte is a little pricey, but the ambiance & food quality were worth it.

I was not impressed at all by the food at this restaurant.  The employees were friendly & did a great job, but the food was really lacking for the price.  Despite my opinion, the restaurant had no shortage of what appeared to be retired snowbirds pouring in.  I ordered the smoky brisket sandwich.  It cost $12.50.  There was no smoky flavor at all...I'm talking zero.  The brisket meat was just ok.  Some barbecue sauce would have spruced it up, but instead it was covered in melted cheese.  I don't know what kind of cheese it was, but sadly it reminded me of Velveeta.  I've said it before about Downtown Dunedin restaurants:  they are overpriced because of what I call the "Dunedin effect".  That means if it's in Dunedin, automatically everything has about a $3-$5 premium added to it.  That would be more acceptable if the food were of better quality.

I love pizza & I recognize there are many types of pizza across the country.  My favorite type is NYC style.  However I've tried many pizzas that aren't NYC style, & they can still be excellent.  What's funny is that Grimaldi's Pizza originated in Brooklyn, yet it doesn't match what I envision for a true New York style pizza.  Despite that fact, the pizza at Grimaldi's is excellent!  I think what makes it great is the flavor of their tomato sauce.  I've been to Grimaldi's many times, & unfortunately they are not consistent with how much sauce they use on a pizza.  When they are liberal with the sauce, the pizza gets 5-stars.  About half the time though they are a little skimpy, so they rate as 4-stars.  I usually get a pepperoni topping & their pepperoni is extra delicious.  It's small diameter, slightly spiced, & very flavorful.  The pizza is cooked in a coal brick oven.  If the pizza gets overlooked by even a little, it can take on a burned carbon flavor which is not good.  That happens here maybe 1 out of 6 times I've been there.  In summary, if they are liberal with the sauce, & the pizza is not overcooked, you will absolutely love the pizza.  Otherwise it becomes slightly disappointing.  The good thing is the majority of the time they are on their 'A Game'.

This place was a bit of a let down. First of all, I could have given this place 3 or 4 stars if either the portions changed or the prices did, because The taste of the food was actually quite good and the service wasn't half bad. 
I went there tonight with my boyfriend and I ordered the "flip signature burger" and he ordered the "Texas big burger". His tasted very good, but the patty itself was no bigger than a McDonald's burger. Mine was embarrassingly bad. The burger was super thin as was the ONE slab of ribeye steak slapped on top with some peppers. I can't believe this was considered their "signature" burger. It was so boring and flavorless and it was a whopping $9.95. Each fountain soda was $2.25, a complete rip off considering how cheap fountain soda actually is for a restaurant to serve. Also, the burgers aren't served in plates or baskets, but simply in a piece of wax paper more suitable for a take out order. 
We heard from someone that the milkshakes  here were no doubt the only thing they do right, and I wouldn't say the mint chocolate chip we got for dessert was disappointing, but it was nothing special. It tasted like something any other burger place could make. 
The atmosphere here was......confusing. It's a very big open room with retro style couches, booths, black tables and chairs, and colorful painted walls and one TV. The kitchen was expansive with 3 grills and 4 fryers!! ( all very very clean and new, obvious that they honestly don't get the use and abuse a busy grill should get!!) The place seemed quiet and çempty, with only a couple other customers. The overall theme seemed to be a half-assed attempt to copy a 1950's style milkshake joint, but falls drastically short. Also, what the hell is with the arcade games scattered randomly around the dining room?! I found them childish, tacky, and distracting. 

I may return only to try another menu item, but I doubt it.

Food was OK, definitely overpriced for what you get. Had French toast, corned beef hash and the chorizo rancheros.  Eh. Personally wouldn't recommend. 
Gave 3 stars because our service was great!

Sadly this was my first meal following months of quarantine. Although the accommodations made for COVID-19 were on point the food left much to be desired. 

We got two orders of pork soup dumplings, a caterpillar bread, and dan dan noodles to share. The soup dumplings were the best of the trio and had a lot of soup in each dumping. The vinegar and ginger sauce on the side could have come with a few more slices of ginger and although the soup was plenty it did not have a rich pork flavor. These came 4 for $9 when other places in Philly will give you 6 or 8 soup dumplings for the same price.

The caterpillar bread was disappointing for the price, $10 for a bit of pulled pork in bread with honey drizzled on the plate. The dan dan noodles were okay but the beef was a bit salty for my taste and the noodles were too hard/chewy. 

Overall if you are looking for dim sum there are a lot better places to go in Philly that have more variety, better prices and more traditional dishes done right.

Had breakfast here. It was OK. Actually, the food was pretty bland. I had an omelet and home fries. No taste. Service was fine, and seats at 7:30 on a Friday morning were plentiful, but it was basically just food.

I had heard quite a bit about Marché . I was truly looking forward to the experience. My friend had came up from Memphis on a whim, and we had a couple of dining excursion with this being the finale of his visit. 

Sunday brunch was already set in our minds to be a bit of a crazy, so the 1 hour and 15 minute wait came as no surprise. We expected it and this by no means is something to complain about when you know it is going to be that way. Consider this - East Nashville, Instagrammable dining experience both in atmosphere with food and dining room, plus everyone knowing Marché's reputation. If you don't expect a wait when coming here and then complain about it on Yelp; your Yelp review provides very little validity in my book. 

Speaking about Sunday brunch - the hostesses who were handling the seating were exceptionally nice and very great at what the did. I appreciated them not being stuffy and like we owed them something. So often, you will find yourself in a position where you are going to the hostess stand and them having some sort of pretentious attitude like we as the diners owe them something. Example - Husk. Marché didn't have this and I am grateful for it.

The kind customer service flowed over to our server, Dylan. Dylan was a super sweet guy who throughout the dining experience ensured that we were content. Except... I wasn't content. 

When the food arrived, my food came out cold. The grits had already coagulated. They had clearly been out for awhile and the eggs and turkey sausage were no better and also cold. To make matters worse, I found a hair in my food towards the end of the meal in my scrambled eggs. That was the icing on the cake. I didn't mention it to Dylan because at that point I could tell he already felt bad about the cold food which he offered to return. I declined and I just wanted to eat since we did wait for that hour and 15 minutes. I was hungry! 

At the end of the meal, he mentioned he took off my breakfast saying that was not the standard of the restaurant. I truly appreciated him in doing so. He mentioned that day must have been an off day since someone else had said that their food was cold, too, so this was not an isolated incident.

My friend enjoyed his meal. He got the omelette and we split their mediocre french toast. I wasn't blown away by it. It didn't have flavor and the syrup didn't add substance to it.

Conclusion - food sucked on this particular day and service and ambiance were amazing. Wish the food could have highlighted the experience as well.

I've always been a fan of Five Guys burgers so this really isn't a review on their food necessarily since they seem to be pretty consistent across the board when it comes to quality, taste, and size. Rather this is more of a review of this specific location which seems to be more or less a bit depressing when visiting.

The interior, though similar with any other Five Guys locations, is sparse, less clean, and not as inviting as other locations (lighting maybe?). Also, the service here was not so great to barely passable. I could imagine myself being served at McDonald's or Wendy's.

Though I drove out 20 mins to come here, I'd probably opt to go to another Five Guys a bit further away for a better Five Guys dining experience.

Here's how this place breaks down on my top ten burger list:
1. Burger Bar, Las Vegas (NV)
2. Healthy Junk, Anaheim (CA)
3. GBurger, La Habra (CA)
4. Left Coast Artisan Burgers, Seoul (KR)
5. Abbey's Burger Bistro, Baltimore (MD)
6. Shake Shack, NYC (NY) / Five Guys (VA)
7. Gourmet Burger Kitchen, London (UK)
8. Burger's Priest, Toronto (CANADA)
9. Root Down DIA, Denver (CO)
10. In-N-Out, California (CA)

Food: B+
Service: C-
Atmosphere: D

Parking: Large shared lot
Price: $
Wait: 5 mins after ordering

Ok, I've lived in China for 12 years and I go back there pretty regularly so I think I have a little bit of sway when I say this place is pretty decent when it comes to Chinese food. And trust me, 99.5% of all of the Chinese restaurants I've been to in America is absolute shit. And I'm not even counting the Panda Expresses or the all-you-can-eat buffet garbage because that's not even Chinese. I don't know what that is.

Anyhow, my cousin was raving about this place and quite honestly, I DID NOT want to go here. I don't care how many people loved this place, I felt as if I could never find good Chinese food in America. But I've got to admit, I was pleasantly surprised and impressed.

Granted, not everything was good here but their Peking Duck was pretty spot on. With the spring onions, the dipping sauce and duck flavoring. Their lobster was just ok.

Most of their servers speak horrible English so they're going to have a hard time understanding what you're ordering. I should've done the ordering instead of my cousin since I speak Mandarin but considering I really wasn't stoked on eating the food from here, I thought I'd let him get upset about it. Lol. I'm such an asshole.

Ok, so this place is really crowded and even though there's a parking lot, we found trouble finding a spot to park in.

Parking: Lot but always full
Price: I don't know, my cousin paid but it's definitely more than your average "Chinese" place
Wait: 15 mins

This is a family owned, family operated business, and you've really gotta hand it to them. You can tell there's a piece of their heart in there. 
Chapati's environment is very bright and charming. Lots of seating options available. There's a chalk menu on the wall or smaller ones you can take to the table with you to decide. And the decision making is tough because the entire menu looks amazing. 
I love love love how many vegetarian options they have, and they've truly mastered the cuisine. The presentation of the food was lovely too! My only minor complaint is that my food wasn't hot when I received it, though we were one of the last orders of the night. 
But that definitely wouldn't stop me from returning! There isn't a better Indian or Pakistani restaurant in Indianapolis than this one.

Every time we go to this location the food is mediocre. Not sure if they keep leftover rice but the rice is always dried out and food overcooked. The drive to the north west location is well worth it.

Tony Luke's was recommended by a local person on our flight and said it was pretty tasty. This was our first time trying a true cheesesteak so we didn't know what to expect. 

Overall, I can say it was tasteful. Was it the best this whole trip? Probably not. 

Came on a Saturday and people traffic want too bad. They had a good line flowing through. Seating is limited so you risk not being able to sit down. Now since Covid is lingering, I'd like to say I didn't see them cleaning their tables so there is some risk there. I always carry wet ones and I've always done it, do it till this day. So we cleaned it down. 

Hubby had the cheesesteak hoagie and I had the regular one with provolone cheese. Has lots of onions but it was pretty cheesy so we liked that. Meat wasn't too bad and they provide pickles and pickled peppers. Delicious! Overall, good bread, good amount of cheese, and meat had flavor. I love salsa so that's all I needed. Lol! I wasn't disappointed but shop around to see what other spots offer cause for sure each place we went to, made them a tiny bit different. 

Enjoy!

The atmosphere is fun and relaxing. I showed earlier than my party and sat outside and listen to the live music. Sitting by the water and enjoying a cocktail and the music was terrific. We sat inside as there is not a full menu on the patio which was a bummer. I ordered the grilled chicken with cilantro crema which was excellent. The side salad was fresh and not loaded with dressing.  Drinks were never empty. The only reason for the 4 is a personal pet peeve of mine,every time the server came to the table she called us honey, sweetheart, dear. That personally drives me crazy. Other than that all was great.

This is the best coffee in St. Louis. Better than the other Kaldi's too. The Clayton Kaldi's is cozy, the staff is friendly, and the baristas have mad skills.

This would be five stars but the wi-fi was cut to only one hour. I would be here a least once a week working if it weren't for that.

I came here Saturday around 12pm after looking on here for something to eat while I was out running errands. After seeing they have açaí bowls (my current obsession), I wanted to try it. I have mixed feelings. My açaí bowl was good. But, it was made from the same frozen açaí packs I buy at target (I could see him make it), and for some reason I thought it would be made from something special/better. Also, it took a minute. The guy making it was struggling with getting the blender to work. I do wish the bowl had more granola and that they had honey, but overall it was okay. Serving is larger than what I've gotten at other places, for about the same price which is nice. I wouldn't go out of my way to go here, but would stop by if I was in the area.

I've been here just once, for lunch recently, and will start out by saying that my three-star rating is somewhat generous. Granted, the place was virtually empty (it was a Monday), which should have caused me to rethink my decision to eat there. On to the meal: the salad with "grilled" peaches was a flaccid, bland young-romaine mix, prewashed and shaken straight from the bag no doubt. The peaches were tart slivers, not the succulent grilled halves or quarters I had envisioned. The dressing did taste of tarragon, which was pleasant, but it lacked the requisite tang of a vinaigrette. I ate the pieces of ricotta salata and the peaches, leaving most of the greens. The server took the dish away without comment. My main dish, a burger, was more medium than rare, as I had ordered it, and the beef had a slightly gamy "off" flavor. It was accompanied by a little heap of fries that were limp with oil. The brioche bun was a nice touch. I ate about half of the burger and, other than offering to wrap it up for me, the server did not ask if I was satisfied or why I had left so much on the plate.

I decided that it would be unwise to order dessert. 

In closing, the place is not especially alluring in its décor and the service was not attentive. There's an open kitchen and I had expected to feel the charge of culinary creativity emanating from it, but the mood was relatively flat. 

Lots of work needed here.

My husband and I live close and noticed this place on a walk, so we walked here and tried breakfast.  The place is clean and the menu features a lot of standard breakfast fare.  I ordered eggs, toast, and bacon with coffee and he ordered six egg whites and four pieces of toast.  The coffee is Kaldis, so it was great.  

Food came up fairly quickly, and both orders were correct.  My eggs were scrambled very hard (fully brown and crusty) in spots and my husbands meal was $13 for just egg whites and toast.  It's a decent and convenient breakfast place, but nothing special.  We will probably come back, but definitely will not special order next time.
Nothing special here. I actually enjoyed eating tacos at their Cantina much more. The margaritas are premixed, not good. Prices are reasonable though.
Really good gelato. The sugar waffle cone makes it even better. Haven't tried their pops yet but they seem to have some really interesting flavor combinations.

Service was good but a bit slow.  It's dark inside.  I didn't go for the lunch special because I find the menu too limiting.  I had the noodle won ton soup.  Broth was pretty good.  Unfortunately there were only 2 wonton's in it.  Veggies were still crunchy and good, I would like a little more of it.  Overall a decent bowl of noodle soup.  Good for a not so quick lunch.

First time I visited this shop. All of the staff was very friendly and helpful. I decided on the turkey BLT and a cup of chicken enchilada soup. Soup was very good. Turkey BLT had large chunks of meats, and a bit too much mayo to my liking. Easy fix for next time. While I was looking for a place to sit to enjoy my lunch, I saw a few dirty tables. It was cleaned up by the time I finished my meal. I noticed they also offer smoothies. I will revisit and try other menu items in the future.

I've been going to Bagel Fair since my days as a NCHS panther. They've been around for decades! I remember when they were cash only. Now they take cards and even Apple Pay which I appreciate given the current pandemic. They've kept up with the times and continue to put out simple yet fresh quality products. They're also inexpensive. I don't have a favorite bagel or schmear. I tend to try a different combo each time, but I always get it heated. They also offer drink options in a refrigerated case by the counter.  I haven't tried the sandwiches or coffee but they are also offered on their menu. Place is bright and clean and staff is friendly.

To be honest, I have absolutely no idea why this place is packed whenever I walk by it. That's not to say that Kildare's is *bad*...it just set my expectations up for something and seemingly failed on all levels. I wanted, wanted, WANTED to like this place, to find an Irish pub to drink at, but I have been disappointed every single time I've left.  As a disclaimer, I've never experienced what it's like as a club, but I have tried...it's just that every time I've tried things have fallen apart. This is a running theme whenever I visit.

The food is overpriced but entirely average. For those calling it a gastropub, I sincerely hope that you broaden your horizons because for the most part it is cut and dry bar food except for the few "Celtic Cuisine" dishes. Now, there's nothing wrong with that, except for two things: A) They are overpriced and B) they taste entirely average.

Probably the best part is the beer selection, and its correctly served Guinness is a saving grace, but I invariably seem to look over my bill and realize I've been overcharged, and on one occasion, that I had been served the wrong beer. They try way too hard to be an Irish pub, instead of BEING an Irish pub (as a note, manydiners don't like a bagpiper blasting away right behind him while drinking).

I don't know why I keep giving them additional chances, but I have to get my head examined as to why, especially with the superior bars in the immediate area.

I know it will be shocking to everyone that there is such a negative review but it's just the fact that I've had much better gelato before.

First off props to the staff, always patient. Second off props to the atmosphere the spinning display case of gelato is waayy flashy. Third off props to the location that sums up the two stars.

But when it comes to eating gelato I really think that the flavors are important and it may evidently just be me that feel this way (considering everyone else's review) but I just didn't like the flavors that they have here. I also thought the texture of the sorbettos were a bit off-putting, kind of like licking flavor infused sand off a spoon. As for the cream based flavors I found that their texture was nice and creamy but again besides the sea salt caramel the actual taste of the gelato was not appealing to me.

I'm excited that Nashville is getting more Italian restaurants, especially those that make homemade pasta, so cheers to Pastaria for that. The modern, airy vibe is interesting, and the service was great. I also like that they serve half carafes of wine, so you can get about 3 glasses for a decent price ($16).

My favorite part of the meal was my salad -- I enjoyed the Chopped Salad with the abundant green olives, garbanzos, pistachios, cheese, and the house-made pepperoni. At first it seemed pretty dry, but the flavors and the oil from the olives made up for it. 

What is going on with the burned pizza crust, though? I ordered the Holmes, which was dotted with black spots on the dough -- all along the edges and on the bottom. Now, I like a good browning of pizza cheese that enhances the flavor of the pizza, but the blackened crust interfered with the flavor, and I noticed that other pizzas served around the restaurant looked just like this, so it wasn't a mistake made with my pizza alone. 

Other thoughts: roasted broccoli was tasty, though salty and a bit overcooked. Cacio de Pepe - peppery and dry. I liked the flavor, but I was scraping the bowl to get at the minimal cheese sauce. It was more like peppery buttered noodles. 

Would l go back? Maybe I'd try it again, ordering different dishes. Maybe not.
Yes this place is still gross.Going to call corporate tomorrow.I only come here because my 85 yr old neighbor can eat this pizza.I should say she can gum it no teeth ya know .
What a great atmosphere with comfy, laid-back couches. Great beer selection (love the Double-Chocolate Stout). Excellent fire-sales. Great pretzels!

Hosted an alumni event here and the staff were more than happy to help us with everything.  The food was prepared brilliantly.  Definitely gave you the high-end feel with the imported cheese and hummus.  The buffalo chicken spring rolls were amazing!  Loved the wine specials and the atmosphere was great and sophisticated.  If you're looking for a great place to enjoy a few drinks and not be at the obnoxious "bar scene" this is the right spot for you to enjoy!

High-end casual dining that will only break the bank if you let it, Garces Trading Co. is perfect for a classy date night out. 

Garces Trading Co. strikes that perfect balance between offering an upscale dinner experience without a whiff of pretentiousness or entree prices that makes your wallet cry out in terror. A Jose Garces creation influenced by his travels through Western Europe, you see the French, Spanish, and Italian influences throughout the entire menu and even in the classy yet congenial wine bar feel of the place. 

My girlfriend and I came for dinner during the week, and although we made reservations ahead of time, you can usually just show up and get a table. After weighing the Chef's Tasting ($40-55 per person), my girlfriend and I began with Charcuterie & Cheese board, selecting the $15 option to pick three cheeses/meats - Country Pâte, and two cheeses, one goat cheese and the other a blue cheese blend of goat and cow milk. I loved the blue cheese served with local honey the best, followed by the goat cheese with sweet mashed figs, and the Country Pâte with its own sauce to compliment. If you like fancy meats and cheese, it's a must order. We also got the marinated olives ($5) topped with Thyme and, strangely, orange shavings, which I wasn't a fan of at all. 

For our main course we ordered the Pan Roasted Scallops ($24) and the Salmon Nicoise ($18). The salmon was a bit too overcooked for my taste and cooked inconsistently, although even with these nit picks it was still very favorable. The scallops was the better of the two dishes. Yes you only get three half dollar size pan seared scallops, but it's surprisingly filling with the savory pine nuts and scallop jus (a thin gravy or sauce made from meat juices). These were perfectly prepared, and the rich and flavorful jus really added to the dish. We paired both dishes with the Pinot Grigio, Al Verdi, Molise, Italy 2014.

All in all, we really enjoyed our dinner, and the bill only came to a little over $100 for all that great food. Fans of good western European food and/or wine will find a lot to like at Garces Trading Co.

Good and massive pizza, Concord Pike Steak Shop gives you maximum pizza for your buck.

Concord Pike Steak Shop is your traditional neighborhood pizzeria, with absolutely gigantic pizzas. We ordered takeout on our way back home, and the pizza was delicious - thin crispy crust, sizes as big as your head, fresh toppings, etc. A 20" is a very reasonable $15 ($12 on Saturday). There's not too much to write about, just go ahead and order the pizza already!

Pretty average bar with a good number of beers on tap, ideal for a quick happy hour.

I don't have too much to say about Founding Fathers Sports Bar & Grill. It's a very nice spacious bar with lots of TV and your typical sports bar menu. Several beers on tap and prices for drafts are between $5.50-6.50. Service will vary entirely on which bartender you receive - we had a very nice and outgoing one for a while, then one that avoided eye contact when I tried to flag him/her down (the bar wasn't even that busy). As such, a pretty average bar experience was downgraded.

Good food and brews right in downtown New Hope, Triumph Brewing Company won't disappoint. 

Another day, another microbrewery. Fortunately, Triumph Brewing Company is one of the better ones, with good beer and some really great food options in an interesting space. Parking is in a pay lot out back and the brewery features two levels with pool tables and small stage for live entertainment. They have a wide selection of beer, from Saison to Amber Ale to Stouts to hand-pumped English IPAs. I'm not a beer guy, but from my tasting all the beers were very well crafted and offered dome interesting flavors that your Untapped user will add with pleasure (although one didn't stand out as truly exceptional).

Triumph's Food was definitely a highlight. My fiancee and I ordered the Porchetta sandwich ($13 - roasted pork belly, Calkins Creamery vampire slayer cheese, formisano farms, broccoli rabe, thyme, and lemon caper aioli) and the Veggie sandwich ($12 - organic black quinoa, pickled phillips farm beet, blue moon acres micro green, pickled onion, cherry grove farm herdsman cheese, and ciabatta). I loved the pork belly sandwich, with succulent pulled pork and that beautifully creamy vampire slayer cheese (someone is a Buffy fan), and anything gets better with broccoli rabe. With vegetarian sandwiches fresh ingredients are key, and they pass the test with flying colors in the veggie sandwich, especially with the pickled beets and onion. 

Overall, the beer was only good but the food was excellent. I still think there's a lot to like with the beer, with some interesting flavors and creations, but the highlight of the visit was definitely the food. Even if you aren't a big beer fan, there's a lot to like at Triumph Brewing Company.

Marathons in the city of Philadelphia are a thing and this one is very adequate. I was thinking if this were a diner, I would rate a four star. But alas, it's not... so the bathroom matters (it was pretty dirty) , the stuff on the floor matters (trash, bits of food) but the food is definitely decent. I had the crispy sesame chicken salad and it was good. The salads here are always good and they do have breakfast items (a few) that they serve all day. (But see? It's not a diner) I had a cocktail, my kid had two Shirley Temples (she also ordered the pirogies  and said they were good) If you're out late, don't have reservations, want something akin to a diner but isn't a diner, this is a decent place to stop. Serves a good purpose in this city.

The first time I came I got pho with just noodles and broth and the veggie spring rolls. I've been to many Vietnamese restaurants and I would have to say the quality of the food is pretty good. I was also interested to see that they had a Chinese menu which I thought was interesting. 

The second time I came here my friends actually ordered from the Chinese menu and I got crab wontons and pho with veggies and vegetable broth. I actually was not a fan of the veggie broth and prefer the chicken so I know now for next time! 

The service sometimes is slow and it's hard to get refills on water or a to go box but other than that it's a pretty good place.

I finally found a restaurant that makes the "holy grail" of comfort foods: The Monte Cristo! It was crafted to perfection.

It seems like the service issues from opening have been worked out (it was notably good).The interior is very nice, and the prices are very good. All of our food was outstanding in both quality and taste. The Monte Cristo was, without exaggeration, the best one I have had in 20+ years.

The only issue I observed is that the stone flooring in the entire area near the kitchen is greasy, almost slimy, from all the foot traffic in and out.

I was a bit put off by the mere 3-star "OK" rating, but I think that should start trending upwards. My first time at Cheddars, but not my last!

Food, drink, service...this place has it all. I literally can't think of a negative factor. So five stars it is.

I admit, though, the Cheesecake Factory style "yellow pages menu" did induce a groan or two. 

The highlight of the visit was the deep dish pizza. This is one of VERY FEW places in St Pete that offers a deep dish option and it is a home run. Light, flaky deep dish crust and top quality cheese and toppings make all the difference. The pizza was so good, I'd probably give this place five stars just for that factor.

Also, the service was stellar...unheard of for Pinellas Park.

My husband and I went to this restaurant last night and it was awful!  The "fresh" guacamole for $5.99 was not only not fresh but they only gave us about three teaspoons of it. The Queso Fundido is a cheese dip that was basically chorizo with a little bit of cheese.  We then ordered the chicken and shrimp fajita combination for $13.99.  The food looked and tasted like it was all packaged.  We got three shrimp in this and they were tiny.  We will never go back to this restaurant.  We will be surprised if it is still open a year from now.

The only reason that I gave it one star is because our server was very nice!

There aren't many Korean restaurants in St Pete, but this place still not near the top tier.  The restaurant is clean, nice vibe and great service.  However,  I have mixed feeling with the dishes I ordered.  The bibimbap costs more, but the portion is bigger  with good ingredientes.  The seafood pancake is a disappointment with the high price, small portion and no much seafood.  Also,  if one table doesn't BBQ correctly, the whole place will be full of smoke as there is no exhaust for individual BBQ tables.

This place is on the steady decline, the last 4 times I've been here the food has been gross.  This most recent time I ordered a BLT, and got left over bacon bits fried hard with extra fat drippings bathing in a mayo soak and some shitty pieces of lettuce. They couldn't even cut through the entire sandwich so I was left holding half the BLT on one side and a whole on the other. What kind of attention to detail is required for a place out of a gas station.  I really wanted to like this place, but the quality control is absolute horseshit.

Solid lunch option in the CWE.  Chips and salsa are great and my barbacoa burrito was good.  The big disappointment was my husband's chili verde, which was really bland.  We will definitely be back, but will order differently next time.

As many other reviewers have noted, this place is adorable!  Connected to a garden store, there's plenty to keep you entertained if you have to wait for a table.  When we showed up for Sunday brunch, we were seated right away in their outdoor garden.  I ordered a mimosa that was great--garnished with fresh berries and served in a stemless champagne flute.  For brunch, the hubs and I split the egg scramble special (great, but needed a little salt) and the french toast (our waiter recommended that we swap the maple syrup it comes with for the blackberry compote that came with the pancakes, which was an amesome idea!)  I will definitely be back!

The 3 stars are for the doughnuts. They are the weirdest consistency doughnuts I have ever had, and I've had a lot of different ones. They're more like bread than they are actual doughnuts and therefore not for me. Plus the dough could be a little sweeter. Just weird. 

The sliders on the other hand were absolutely delicious (FIVE STARS!). I'll go back for the sliders and atmosphere but definitely NOT for the doughnuts.
Fine Dining for sushi , I'll take it! The Sashimi melts in your mouth. My favorite is the salmon sashimi.. excellent texture.

The hoagies were horrible here. When I ordered my hoagie and took it home, it was the wrong one and I had already driven home with it and couldn't go back since I don't live close to this location. 

Only come here a handful of times and wouldn't come back, because each time the hoagies just been eh. 

I have other Wawa locations that make the hoagies and sandwiches with care and like the people who made them, actually like making the food.

Came here on Friday night with my boo to celebrate  getting a new job. When I made a reservation I initially had planned to go to crafty crab but guess got confused and made reservations for here instead and ended up at the Crack Crab instead- huge mix up on my part. Well we arrived and the place was small, it seemed more like a place you'd pick up food or do take out versus dine in. We had the reservation, but it was silly cause the place was empty and I guess you really didn't need one. We were seated quickly and got drinks. 

We started with some corn nuggets- which was a special for the day- for a $1.99 you got about 12 of these fried balls that had corn inside of them. I liked them but my boo didn't care for them. We also had a free appetizer with Yelp check in which was sweet! We got the spring rolls- they were okay. 

When looking at the menu they had a nice variety of things but I guess in comparison to the crafty crabs menu that I had looked at and thought I was at- the menu was lacking and I wasn't sure what I'd order. I ended up getting the fried fish which the waiter told me was cod. 

This seafood place has Asian fusion also and sells hibachi which is kinda interesting. The fried fish came out and it was inside a little boat- it was a cute presentation. The fried fish was inexpensive and actually tasted pretty good. I was happy with my selection.
