The main entrance was starting to get crowded and we were asked after a bit by a manager type person if we wanted to sit near the bar at some first come first serve high top tables (roughly four of them).  We were good with that as it shortened our wait time.  Our server greeted us in a timely manner and seemed very capable.  We ordered a dip appetizer (artichoke spinach I think) which was so-so.  Our main entrees were not memorable at all - couldn't tell you what I had or any of my companions........but what ensued after that was much more memorable.  The tables we were sitting at since they did not require a reservation were being hawked by people actually milling about to get the table almost before you got up.  The table in back of us was grabbed by two older ladies and it was promised by a server to some people at the bar.  Words were exchanged but the ladies stayed put even after being counseled by the server.  My husband (just before paying the bill) went over to the family at the bar and told him we were leaving.  They were very grateful and assumed our table at the utter annoyance of the lady that was at my elbow waiting for a table there to open up......!  Why would you have tables designated this way at peak times? Won't be returning........

Let's talk about Happy Hour.

Crawfish has not one, but two of them! Lunch and dinner! And the deals, well they're out of control good, especially if you love Asian food like me!

Let's start with lunch. They've got like 5-6 dishes that are all $5 at lunch! Crazy right? I've enjoyed the congee (Chinese rice porridge served with ginger, pork and preserved egg), the Vietnamese style egg rolls (not exactly like the Viet imperial rolls in town, but packed with filling, perfectly fried, and served with a sweet dipping sauce), the salmon carpaccio (perfectly seated with a light delicate soy dressing) and the ahi poke! All of them are amazing!

At dinner the deals get even better! Chicken wings, oysters, whole fried flounder and more all for under $10!!! I can't wait to get in here to try these!

But seriously, any hour that involves eating is a happy one, but one that allows for an epic meal for $10, well that holds a special place in my heart!

I want to see all of our local businesses succeed, so I don't like to write negative reviews, but my hope is that the ownership will take notice, make corrections, and bring this spot back to what it used to be. This would have easily been a 4 star review if the management had chosen to handle the situation that occurred appropriately. 

That night we ordered 4 burgers, and when the food arrived, one was cold, the medium burger was pink, and my medium rare was grey. I showed the waitress and she politely offered to make another one, and when the new burger came, it was also overcooked. I showed her again, said it tasted great and that I would happily eat it, and she said she would mention something to the manager.  

When the manager came to the table, he pulled out his phone and showed me a picture of the first burger I sent back! After sitting, it was now pink from juices that had begun to run through it. He said "You're the Facebook photo of the night with this one! We can't just go around serving raw meat, so I don't know what you expect." I didn't know how to respond, and the entire party was shocked. We quickly finished our food, paid our bill, and vowed never to return. 

As the GM of a restaurant, I know these situations can be tough. I wasn't upset when the food came out wrong the second time, and I wasn't expecting anything for free. I understand kitchens have off nights and that the servers are not at fault, but I also know that all it takes is polite service to make these situations better. Had the manager handled himself differently, I'd be sharing a very different experience with you and our friends, one that would make guests want to come try Clary's.

Is it the best kept lunch secret in Reno? Methinks it to be! 

Oceano is well known for sushi, but it's actually a fantastic all around seafood restaurant. I'm guilty of having never explored that side of the menu, but on my last visit I hit the jackpot! 

On nearly the last page of the a la carte menu is a small box with a pinkish hue, and in it you'll find a fantastic menu of seafood lunch specials that are absolutely incredible values! 

At our table the Small Shrimp Pan Roast with half Pacifica Sandwich (crab and shrimp salad with melted cheese)  and fries ($12) was a popular choice. I opted for the Chef's Mixed Grill which consisted of three pieces of fresh fish, a large prawn, lemon buerre blanc and lemon couscous ($15)! Both dishes were beyond satisfying and felt like the best value I've found in quite some time.

Oceano keeps giving me reasons to love it. Now I just need to give it the amount of attention it deserves!

I had the pleasure recently of having breakfast at Toast Uptown.  Toast is located on Laurel Street at the old Laurel Street bakery location.

Toast is less than a year old, and word has is definitely out on how good it is.  I knew to arrive early, or I'd have a wait in front of me.  We arrived at 9:30 and immediately found 2 seats at the bar.  The regular tables were all full, one with a party of 12 (tables pushed together).  None of the tables outside were occupied because it was still a little chilly outside.

The atmosphere at Toast is bright and cheerful, albeit small.  You're in pretty close quarters with everyone around you, but I'm fine with that.  My only complaint was that it was VERY LOUD.  They've put foam under the chairs and tables, but it didn't seem to be helping much.  Once the large party left, it got considerably better.

I find the prices at Toast to be extremely reasonable for what you get, with entrees ranging from $10-$14, and smaller side items (like toast topped with prosciutto, honey, and ricotta, or an order of ableskivers) going for $5-$8.  

For my entrée, I had the croque madame.  It was huge and delicious, and was served with a light side salad.  My BF had the hangar steak topped with tarragon aioli, served with roasted potatoes and sunny side up eggs.  His meal was also fantastic.

I was really dying to try some of the ableskivers with lemon curd dip, but their portions are huge and there was just no way.  

By the time we left 45 minutes later, there were 15 people outside waiting, and all outside tables were full.

I highly recommend Toast, but you might want to go before 10 if you don't want to wait.

After asking for recommendations from friends on where to get some great gumbo, I was pointed in the direction of Avery's.  I live in Mid City, so I gladly took the suggestion.

Avery's is a cute little lunch place on Tulane Avenue near the courthouse.  The atmosphere is cute and bright.

I cannot say enough good things about the service.  The staff is some of the friendliest I've ever come across.

Now onto the food...

I ordered the chicken and sausage gumbo and some onion rings.  The gumbo was full of meat and pretty tasty.  I prefer a thicker and darker gumbo, so I felt myself still wanting for something this gumbo didn't deliver.  But I could definitely see how many, many people would find it to be exceptional.  

I didn't like the onion rings at all.  I didn't realize the batter was going to be tempura.  I found that type of batter to just not work on onion rings.  They were VERY greasy.  On the plus side, they came with a really tasty horseradish type dip.

I would really like to try some other dishes at Avery's, especially the buffalo shrimp po-boy, which seems to get a lot of love on here.

Waffles on Maple was terrible. Seriously. The service was absolutely awful, and the prices are ridiculous! A blueberry waffle, a crabmeat crepe that was made with imitation crab, side salad, and a frozen coffee (The coffee was actually delicious,  but it was 6 ounces of frozen coffee, and 6 ounces of whipped cream in a 12 ounce cup that they charged five dollars for). All said and done...36 after tax and tip. Never again.

I love pizza. Actually, not just love, I loooooove pizza! I'm pretty easy to please and usually think ok pizza is still good because it's pizza  

I'd put New York Pizza right about in the middle of the spectrum. The pizza was good, but nothing about it wowed me. 

Our server was friendly, you can order by the slice, and the prices ate reasonable. 

But my favorites are still Mid City Pizza and Dolce Vita.

Everyone in Philadelphia was ordering a cheesesteak on Sunday. I waited in line to place my order and then waited while it was prepared. Total time was 45 minutes but that isn't Carmen's fault. Howwever, when the line stopped so the cooktop could be cleaned there is an issue. I like how they hand out playing cards to identify your order.

My sandwich was correct and very good: steak with provolone, onions and peppers. My friend's was not: he ordered steak, provolone, onions and mushrooms. What he received: steak, whiz, and onions. Clearly the wrong sandwich but with line and the cook time delay, he didn't mess with it. I am sure Carmen's would have mde it right. (There was also a price difference.)

Reading Station has everything and like most central markets costs more but you will get a good meal.

The other day, I had really good omakase from a different restaurant and someone recommended this place to me. Wow, I cannot believe I'm just now finding out about this gem! I got the nigiri deluxe to go. Every single piece was so beautifully made. The flavors were so well balanced. Everything literally melted in your mouth. My mom is afraid of the thought of eating raw fish, so I let her try this and she was like, "omg this is so good! It doesn't taste fishy at all!" Now, this is actually the best nigiri I've ever had. :happy dance: I cannot wait to have the true experience of dining here one day. Unfortunately, due to the virus, there are no dine-in available.

Great first impression even though it's only carry out still. The service was top-notch. The quality is outstanding. Our family had two cheese breads and two pizzas. 

If Dominos is your dream, you will not be satisfied with PPP. If you crave quality, give the quality ingredients and wood-fired pizza a fair shot.

This is your shot, Goodlettsville. We've got ourselves another legit contender for outstanding pizza. (LHP is great too, but it is a different style of pizza altogether). And when PPP's full menu debuts, we are going to have even more to talk about. 

Make Goodlettsville a food destination. A few solid additions like this, and a cozy pub would do wonders for our bellies and souls. 

#shoneysisfoodblight #reduceourfastfoodoptionsbyfiveandourhotelsbys

Decent food. Good service.

My half sandwich (steak) was good. My bisque was a little shallow but had some good creaminess.

My wife enjoyed the Cobb salad.

Really happy with both locations of The Stillery. Similar vibe and service at both. It's the only place I recommend eating "on" Broadway...and I like this option that is easier for us locals to get to.

Pretty much a Quarter rat I've walked by Envie hundreds of times.  I always thought it looked like a great place to perch and people watch, but I never seemed to be on coffee mode at the time I strolled by.  

Recently on a cool evening we found ourselves heading out of the Quarter to the Marigny and my friend wanted a hot coffee. I wasn't in a coffee mood, but OK. 

Envie was as usual filled with people worth conversing with...."wow, how many tats do you have? Why are you wearing black socks with boaters and shorts? Man what shade of purple is that in your hair - its exactly what I'm looking for...." and that's only the folks actually in Envie. The passersby are really what NOLA is all about all the different people melding together in joy. 

Back to the coffee. My friend is busily ordering a basic flavored coffee drink ...When lo and behold my eyes please don't deceive me..... A FULL BAR! Not a coffee bar...we are talking ALCOHOL (which is what I was already consuming and therefore in no dang coffee mood). 

What was that? Did New Orleans just experience an earthquake? Nope, my friend says, that's you trembling in delight (I think my knees may have been knocking loud enough to be heard).... Now would you like to order something? Yes, yes I think I would.

Good Coffee
Great people watching
Brilliant extended drink menu

And super dog friendly... just no dogs in the hall please - their rule not mine!

Obviously I wouldn't expect much from Olive Garden, and besides their breadsticks being 5 star (duh) everything else is just gross.  When I was little I really liked it here, key word being "little." Now, this place is nothing but a huge waste of calories on pasta that was probably frozen then microwaved.

But we went for the buy one take one and that is a good deal in terms of price but all the food and options are kinda gross. I ordered the fettuccine alfredo and my fiancé got the smoked mozzarella chicken pasta. We split both entrees. The alfredo did taste like my childhood (kids meals at Olive Garden lol) but it's pretty gross. And the chicken pasta was so bad tasting. Our take one meals weren't much to look at either.

The service here was terrible. At 8:45pm we were told we were going to wait 5 min (no biggie) but it turned into 20!!! No apologies and we actually had to ask the manager if he knew if we were being seated. And the girl at the front was rude to us. Our waiter was almost overkill on the service. He asked us about adding on everything that could cost extra (bottled water vs tap) and then literally gave us two breadsticks and seemed really annoyed when we asked for more...it's unlimited for a reason, we could have as much as we want! Honestly
I don't think I'll be returning to Olive Garden for anything but a craving for a breadstick

Came here for a quick dinner tonight, overall it was decent.  We got the 2 for $25 entree plus one appetizer to share deal! What we weren't thrilled about was that things like flavored iced tea are not free refills. 

Our appetizer was the spinach artichoke dip, and it was pretty good. It was a little greasy but overall not bad! We actually both got the same appetizer, Bourbon Street chicken and shrimp. The waiter had told us how amazing it was and I'll be honest I was a tad underwhelmed. My boyfriend on the other hand, LOVED IT! I thought the chicken was a little too garlicky, like going to leave a gross taste in your mouth gross. But the potatoes were good, and the chicken was well cooked. Also points for being one of the lower calorie options that was still very filling!! 

Our waiter was super nice though! Applebees is applebees, it's average but occasionally it'll do and will be a decent meal!!

The Coconut Downtown is set back on Virginia, behind the monument (next to the Poke Bowl & La Familia).  Like every one else, they are experiencing a staffing problem, but even with that the service was pretty quick and friendly.  Although we were able to walk, there is usually plenty of parking on the side streets.

They have a Happy Hour every day from 4 to 6 PM, with $4 appetizers and drinks.  Check their Happy Hour menu on the window.

We went for dinner before heading down the street to the Bruka Theater.  Pad Thai still one of my favorites.  Order your food to the degree of spiciness 1-5 ... I'm a 2 and it had a bite.  There dumplings a fantastic and my daugther loves their Spicy Papaya Salad.  Lots to choose from.

If you love Thai, definitely give this place a try.

It's hard to find really great international cuisine in Santa Barbara. In the land crazed by California-farm-fresh food and sun drenched neo-Americana bistros, our little community sometimes forgets about the bold flavors of India, exotic heat of South East Asia, and comforting richness of Middle Eastern spices. Tamira won't disappoint. The traditional Indian flavors and extensive menu will take you out of California and transport you to the heart of India. The simple, straightforward ambiance lets the food speak for itself. Each dish is prepared with care and authenticity that are sure to please. Whether you're in the mood for chicken makhani or vegetarian dahl, there is truly something for everyone. Tamira is the perfect place to gather your friends, but the ambiance is a little bare bones and the staff and service can be a little brusque.

With a name like Scarlett Begonia, you may be expecting a quaint cafe reminiscent of your favorite memories from The Secret Garden. On that front, you won't be disappointed. Tucked into a leafy corner off state street, the outdoor seating area feels like you just stepped out of town and into your fantasies of being a "lady who lunches." This is one of the few restaurants in Santa Barbara where brunch is a destination, so get yourself up and at 'em and over to Scarlett. That said, the menu is a little expensive for dressed up breakfast cocktails and fancy pancakes, but brunch with your girlfriends is priceless, right?

Not spectacular, but very good.  A small, focused, approachable menu priced fairly cheap made by the top chef team in Philly.  There's a definite beer focus here too.  Certainly nothing wrong with that.

My girlfriend and I decided to skip the pizza and try some of the limited other options.  She had two rotolos which were really nice.  Flakey, gooey, nutty, cheesy.  Two was enough for her, but she is admittedly quite tiny so if you're a big larger like me and want to make a meal of these 3 would probably be a safer bet.

I had the calzone which was freakin' massive but I finished the whole thing thankyouverymuch.  Not that I should be proud of that but I was.  Gloating my gluttony until I noticed the two boys next to me housing a stupid Nutella pizza for dessert.  Fabulous.

This is a pretty good spot for tacos. They have some unusual varieties and specials. Very casual.

Avoid the horchata, it's from a mix and not homemade. NG. I assume the other beverages are of similar low quality. 

The interior is basic and the location is in a strip mall. Service is adequate. The salsa they serve with the complimentary chips is VERY hot.

This is a good cute place for Peruvian food in Tampa. You can get classic dishes like beef or chicken over french fries, ceviche, and more exitic fare such as hearts. Don't break em, eat em! 

The restaurant is cute and casual. We had friendly service when we went. You can also get a purole corn drink although zi dont think it's made in house. The Inca indigenous peoples, other tribes, the Spanish and the coast inform the cuisine. Enjoy a taste of Peru!!!

Three of us went here for lunch and the first impression is pretty cool.  Large place with very high ceilings, I am sure the building is architecturally significant.

The service was good, efficient and the food came out in a reasonable amount of time.  We had the tomato soup which was ok, a little "textured" as opposed to perfectly smooth.  Cheese was sprinkled in it, I think I would rather have my cheese in my grilled cheese sandwich but ok, not bad.  Microgreens sprinkled on top were ok but didn't add much and were slightly wilted.

Chicken sliders with pickles and a South Carolina mustard sauce were also ok, but again, not memorable.  Just good.

The butter lettuce salad with apples and figs and nuts and etc. etc. was well-thought but unfortunately drowning in dressing so the lettuce was wilted and mostly a mess.  I added shrimp on top for more protein and they were pretty good, they were actually still warm since they had just been cooked.  All in all an ok experience but no dish stood out enough for any of us to order it again.

Tio Flores is a reliably nice neighborhood restaurant and bar. They have great drink options from beers to a variety of margaritas and delicious cocktails. The draft beers come in a glass that I think is smaller than a pint, which make their can and bottles are also a comparable option.

I've enjoyed what food I've tried, but my friend and I agree the lentil cauliflower tacos were really good and perhaps more unique, that you wouldn't get at regular Mexican restaurants. The nachos and guac are great sharing options and very tasty as well.

The food may be more expensive than a Mexican taqueria but it's still great and they have yummy drinks, a trendy atmosphere, and friendly service on top of that so it's also a nice place to hang out.

I loved the dark izakaya style downstairs. It's very intimate and the cocktails and food are amazing. I sat at the bar and my friend and I got the monkey fist (sake spiced pina colada flavored) and bemini twist (sochu with fresh fruit juices), both were excellent.

We ordered the bacon wrapped mushroom skewer, spicy scallop sushi, miso soup, and tempura cheese curds. All were super good, and came quickly.

I love the atmosphere and the menu. The bartender was super friendly and it was a treat to chat with him and hear more about the drinks, which we got to watch him make, and about the food.

Busy diner like restaurant that has by far the best chicken and waffles ever.  The rest of there breakfast menu is pretty basic and could be had anywhere but I would certainly trek out to West Philly again for the chicken and waffle dish.  A warning about their staff though is that the younger ones seem to really not care.  The young woman we had needed to be reminded of drinks we had ordered and begged for coffee refills. I even had to wait for a check with piled up dirty dishes in front me for 15 minutes.  Thank goodness their food was good because the service I received certainly wouldn't bring me back.

My family threw a great Birthday party for me.  It was great to have a private room and gather all around a big table!  This wasn't my most recent Birthday but I don't think it has changed much.  All the food was very good but nothing was extremely outstanding.  The ambience made up for it!  Should be 3.5.  The next one was at Maggianos--Buca was much better!

We think the food is OK with reference to most of their sandwiches.   We are not beer drinkers but all the reviews indicate that they have a great selection.  I have to take them down a star because we go to hear live music close to home and they will "no longer" be having any!!  bleh  Guess it's just the Ale that has good food, great drinks and live music.

This is a place with a great idea, and if you show up at off hours, it's actually pretty darned fast.  Portion size is good, although they give way too much rice (I'd prefer more of the greens).

I had the karaange chicken bowl.  I didn't like that they used dark meat (and/or I wish there was an option to request all white meat).  Also, the sauce made the chicken soggy quickly.  The rice was fine, and the greens on the side were refreshing.

My husband had the pork belly with the Chicago Lee sauce.  He thought his dish was awesome.  I was blown away by the amount of meat he got, in fact, given how fatty pork belly is, I was a little alarmed that he ate everything.

My husband also tried the pineapple soda, and he said it tasted better than he expected.

If this place was a little more convenient, I might show up more often.

Good British pub food. 

Their chicken wings are excellent. Very tender. I wish there was more of a curry flavor, maybe next time I'll try the buffalo chicken. But the way they cooked the meat was perfection.

Everything we tried here was great. The Philly cheese steak was good, so were the fries. I loved the ploughman's board, although there was a lack of pickle. And the meat wasn't great. Oh, but the cheese!  And the scotch egg!  I wish I could just get the scotch egg by itself. It was crispy on the outside, and the sausage and egg just melted in my mouth. 

I'm too stuffed for words. But it was worth it.

I went to Cassis with my sister in law for a girls night out.  I loved the space, and our waiter bordered on obsequious, he was so attentive.

I had the Menage a Tini, and it was really tasty.  I believe it had elderberry vodka, champagne and a couple other things.  It tasted vaguely of lychee.

We both had the baby spinach salad.  That was so good, I wish I could eat it every day.  Baby spinach, goat cheese, fresh strawberries, beets, and candied walnuts.  

For entrees, my sister in law had the scallops, which I thought were good but not stellar (slight fishy taste, I think).  She really liked them.  I had the special roast chicken with rosemary jus.  The french fries weren't perfectly crispy, and neither was the chicken skin.  But the jus was very good.

We were stuffed, so we didn't try the dessert.  I'll have to go back.

Previously, I asserted that the best fried chicken in Tampa is at Love's Artifact Cafe.  I wish to change that.  Alez makes the best fried chicken.

I stopped in for lunch, and for less than $9, I got four perfectly crispy, spicy chicken drumsticks, a huge portion of rice and beans, a couple fried plantains, and seriously tasty pikliz.  OMG.  Add the pikliz to the rice and beans for a little heaven.  I really want to return to try the oxtail, goat and fried pork, but I don't know if I'll be able to resist the fried chicken!

The staff is very attentive and friendly.  The location isn't the best, but once you're inside, it's clean and nice.

We came here for our anniversary.  We had been to a bunch of fancy restaurants lately, and we wanted something a little simpler.  This place was the perfect choice.

It's a quiet, local restaurant in south Tampa.  The waitstaff all seem to be either family or friends.  They were attentive and jovial.

The wine list was reasonable.  I wish they listed the vintage year, though.

We had the prosciutto with melon to start.  The chef sent out some bruschetta as a sort of amuse bouche.  Then I had the osso buco, and my husband had the veal saltimbucco.  Both were wonderful, tender meat prepared well.

I wish I had had room for dessert!

Couldn't wait to try this place out for an actual sit down meal as I had stopped in numerous times in the past for gifts. We booked a reservation online ahead of time, however they couldn't accommodate our party because they had another, larger party coming in after us. Squeezing is into a small table really didn't work so we went somewhere else.

Can't believe it took me this long to check this place out as it is right around the corner from my apartment. Big mistake on my part, I've been missing out.

Although the prices lean toward the expensive site, it was well worth the dining experience. The bar is a great place to post up before eating, lots of high quality drafts on tap with enough variety for ones mood. Interesting variety of people, all ages likely just representing the locals. As for the meal, we had some mussels which were average. Not as much flavor as I had hoped but still enjoyable with no signs of sand (my ultimate pet peeve)

Now for the burger which gets its own paragraph. This was the juiciest piece of meat I have ever tasted in burger form. This special blend they bring in is no joke. I opted for cheese but next time might keep it au natural. The ultimate compliment I can give is I did not ask for ketchup which is unheard of. The fries were tasty also, perfectly seasoned. Go treat yourself asap.

I waited for Broad Street Diner to open for months.  Its location is incredible, and is extraordinarily convenient for an early Sunday hangover brunch.  Well, I ate there today and it was...horrible.  The waitress started our meal from hell by spilling coffee on my friend. Granted, it was a quarter of a cup, and we willingly forgave her mishap.  We both ordered scrambled eggs, hash browns and bacon--pretty hard to mess up.  They did. The eggs were the consistency of wet pudding, the hash browns fresh out of the freezer, and the bacon, pure fat.  Even worse, the plates were overpriced by at least 4 dollars.  Will I go back? Not until they get their act together.

Great food when you do not have other options late on a Sunday night. We went with very little expectations and were not disappointed at all. The pita bread was good, pizza was excellent and the veggie crepes were delicious. I may or not visit this place on a normal day but when you do not have options, not bad to try it.

I got the cheesesteak.  I liked Abner's. The Goldberg kid doesn't know what he is talking about. The best cheesesteaks are in University City!  big place.  Great ladies running the grill.  nice big meaty cheesesteak.

I'll begin my review by saying, no, this isn't a place I'd need to come back to. 

For starters, they do have a great location, I love the decor, and after looking the menu over, the prices are decent too! But that's all I can come up with for the glaring positives. 
The service was lacking in every way. I did not feel welcomed into the establishment upon entering, and once seated, my waitress showed us just how unenthusiastic to serve us she was. Not cool, at all.

The food was bland and basic. I ordered the chicken and waffles. There wasn't a single bit of crunch or flavor to either my chicken or waffle, such a let down, as I was really banking on the positive reviews from other Yelpers. Maybe other dishes are yummy, but I definitely wouldn't recommend the chicken and waffles meal.

After seeing that they were 4 stars, i thought it was a safe bet. Boy was I wrong. first off, on a busy sunday night there were only 2 servers working and the one lady walked by us several times. i physically had to get up and get us menus. my boyfriend's long island was just ok, my tom collins was ok, the food was not good. being that its a 'hockey bar' we were excited as we're both blackhawks fans, but seriously, on the night that peyton manning is going to break a record for most touchdowns and make history, they put on a rerun of the walking dead instead of football and no sound? just loud hipster music. sports fans beware, this place is a hipster bar masquerading as a sports bar. wont be back!

The famous NOLA hurricane cocktail was a ton of syrup and pineapple juice masking the rum and who knows what else. It was strong but wish it tasted more special. Downstairs had a cute live jazz band. We wandered upstairs for the dancing space and balcony but sadly it seemed like there was just an ipod playlist being blasted without much thought for the crowd.

I loved the view from the balcony but it was really crowded so we couldn't hang out too comfortably here for long. It was really spacious upstairs indoors which was nice and comfier with a full efficient bar :)

I've got nothing against this place.  They've never given me a reason to be bitter.  The food is below average and they post multiple (poorly) hand written signs everywhere (i.e. no free refills) which are kind of annoying.  
But what really earns them my first one star rating is the abundance of people that appear to be homeless.  I'm giving the other patrons the benefit of the doubt because I don't know their situation or their story.  All I know is there are dirty people that sit in the booths drinking 40s for what appears to be most of the day.  Lastly, no smoking means lots right outside!  Expect pictures to be posted soon.

Lastly, shame on Best House for putting a coupon in the University City Newspaper that expired six months before the newspaper was printed.

There is nothing bad you can say about this place. Great southern country cooking done buffet style. And it's not your typical mass produced favor less food. Everything taste good and is made from scratch.

Some of the best fried chicken ever!.  Come hungry because they have a ton of food options; grits, black eyed peas, fried and baked chicken, catfish, etc.

I don't have much of a sweet tooth but I would imagine their desserts are just as good.

And the wait staff is always friendly.

The only downside is their popularity, which means sometimes you may have to wait before being seated.

I was excited to visit Osteria, but was disappointed after having had dinner at the restaurant. The atmosphere of the restaraunt seems very unclear and like we were dining in an old club, while the cuisine is Italian. 

Service and the meal was descent. I don't think the meatball appetizer for $20 lived up to its hype.

Bacon was 4/5 I liked it a lot.
Eggs were 4/5. 

Brought me BURNT beignets and tried to cover the burn marks with powdered sugar........

Waitress took NO accountability whatsoever?? (She smiled a lot though)

Asked for a pancake instead. That took 15 EXTRA minutes, ONE pancake! 

And it came out tasting like baking soda????

 Manager took off of the bill BUT- we had to SEARCH for the waitress to pay? WTF is going on at this place???

Never again.

This is a hard one to write because we had a very polarized experience.  This place was recommended by the very nice curator at the Southern Food and Beverage Museum.  We decided to split a small plate of the Crispy Skin Duck Confit with seaweed kimchi, avocado and baby squash salad, tempura shiso.  Then follow it up with a 12 hour roasted waguy beef po'boy with pickled onions and horseradish cream for him.  A smoked corned pork belly reuben with sauerkraut, gruyere and Russian dressing on house made rye for me.  The meal began with an amuse-bouche, a small bite of cool soup composed of garlic, confer and lemongrass.  This was unique and tasty getting us excited for what was to come.  The duck confit was delivered with a flourish from the chef and deserved the fanfare.  Oh my that was tasty!  
Things turned the other direction with our sandwiches though.  His was good but nowhere near the flavor development of the other items.  Mine was pretty flavorless.  The rye bread was too thick and too dense.  It overpowered everything on the sandwich.  I decided to try it open face to balance the flavors but the bread just was too much.  I abandoned the bread altogether so I could get a taste of the pork, sauerkraut and dressing but none of them stood out on their own.  It was a disappointing end to what started off so great.  I'm betting there are other fantastic things on their menu, we just chose poorly.

Unfortunately, I wasn't too impressed with this rooftop bar. I have heard great things, so I will assume I caught them on an off night? The music was bland and semi boring. It was a slow Sunday, but took forever for my friends to get their drinks. The team was very friendly though so that helped. The ice cream cookie was good too. Overall it wasn't awful, but I don't know, I guess I was expecting more.

This intimate BYOB rocked the dishes they put out. All were simple, beautifully presented, and flavorsome. The downside is that space is quite small so it can get loud as the evening goes on and at times the service felt rushed.

Nice atmosphere. Quiet, clean and great distancing. Food was ok. Bread basket was lovely with a great assortment. Chicken Parmesan was very good. Fresh noodles and perfectly cooked chicken. The trio was pretty good but had different noodles from the chicken Parmesan entree that weren't quite as good. Prices are high, so you are definitely paying more for the atmosphere. Alfredo was pretty bland. Desserts were very good!  Recommend the lemon cheesecake and chocolate cake!

The pizza is pretty good here, but a little pricey. The salads are amazing!  Location is easy to find and the venue is great with arcade games to keep the kids busy while you enjoy an adult beverage.  Family friendly!

Very delicious! A lot of their dishes lean towards the sweet side, but it works. After a few disappointing Caribbean food experiences in Philly, I finally found the one. 

+ Island wings - crispy, hot and fresh. I live a few blocks away and having them crispy is key. The sweetness works if you're in the mood for sweet wings. Tangy and flavorful.

+ Jerk chicken - A perfect pairing with the braised cabbage and red beans/rice - all of which were seasoned well. The sauce of the dish was delicious that it would be a magic ingredient for any meat and veggies dish.

+ Patties - always good! The curry flavor comes through and is super flavorful, not dry.

Came here for Center City Restaurant Week and was very impressed. Not only is the atmosphere and service terrific with some nice balance between dressy-casual, but also the food was just downright amazing - granted, it would normally be expensive and outside my price range for frequent dining if it weren't for CCRW. 

Some dishes we loved better than others, but rounding up to 5 stars for an overall excellent experience. Favorites were the Korean-fried duck wings, jumbo mayo fried shrimp, and sea bass:

+ Himachi sashimi - the toppings (wasabi vinaigrette & daikon) were a bit overkill and overwhelmed what should have been a delicate sashimi flavor

+ Korean-fried duck wings - as an Asian who is used to eating duck in the Chinese styles, this was a refreshing "Asian fusion" version of duck wings. Perfectly fried to airy and crunchy perfection, in the usual Korean fried chicken way.

+ Chilean sea bass (maitake & truffle jus) - by far the hit of the night. Ultra buttery, "truffle"-y, and fall-apart tender. One of the best fish entrees I've ever had; so simple, yet executed so well

+ Sweet & crispy jumbo shrimp - can't really go wrong with any version of mayo fried shrimps w/ candied walnuts

+ Mango cheesecake - I'm actually not a huge cheesecake fan, but I loved this dish because it achieved such a great subtle fruity note without that overwhelming deli cream cheese flavor that I dislike about cheesecakes. Soft, delicate, and very creamy and delicious.

- Smoky chocolate dome mousse - I was excited by the "smoky" flavor and was looking forward to what they would do with it, but it fell pretty flat and was probably my least favorite dish (I couldn't finish it, and I rarely am unable to finish dessert). The smoky flavor was just wayyy too intense, and i felt like I was eating mousse bbq. That aside, this would have been a terrific dessert.

Good place to eat if you're on the south side . Very friendly staff an I love the food there. I went with my family and the food did not disappoint. I always enjoy going to Habachi grills because it makes eating there entertaining. Def recommend. I would suggest it be cleaner but overall pretty good.

This place seems to make American Chinese meals a little better than other places in town.  
They also have St. Paul sandwiches on the menu.  

The lo mein uses a little smaller diameter noodle.  It is really good.  

Their orange chicken has lots of pieces of little orange peel, but it is not as sickenlying sweet as versions I have tried elsewhere.

Aside from being incompetent he also likes young woman and doesn't care if she's your daughter sitting at the table with you. An expert at ogling and leaning in close to "hear what you are saying", be careful if you land Dennis The Walking Lawsuit as your waiter!

This is a particularly snooty coffee spot. I say this right off the bat because if you consider yourself a coffee snob, you'll probably enjoy this place. Truly! The coffee is unique. 

But if you're like me: pretty easy-to-please, happy with a generic "small coffee" pretty much wherever you go.... I'd do a pass. 

No thanks, don't need a pour-over crafted with beans that passed through the intestinal track of a yak and then roasted over a monk's campfire flame in the hills of the Himalayas. And definitely don't want to hear you talk about it endlessly while I wait, either. 

I can respect the craft, but meh. Another Philly coffee shop that drips with the air of total superiority. Good internet though, will hand em that. Otherwise, pass.

This place has a very nice ambiance and good iced coffee, but the breakfast was a bit lacking. Croissants did not seem fresh, salmon in sandwich did not seem fresh and it was chewy, ratatouille omelet was under seasoned. Overall it's a nice place to grab a drink but probably not your best bet for a hot breakfast.

My husband got spicy tuna roll to go, I love sushi for long time and know the taste how should be right, they mixed spicy tuna with fried bread crumbs (too oily) and lay on the top of the roll. If the tuna was good by itself why they mixed the bread crumbs, it make the potion bigger I guess!!!

My husband got spicy tuna roll Togo, I have love sushi long time and know the taste what should be right, the spicy tuna mixed with fried bread crumbs (too oily) for the top layer on the roll. If the tuna it was good by itself why they mixed the bread crumbs, it make the potion bigger I guess!!!

wait wait wait

p o o r    s e r v i c e

chaotic

sweet potato fries - good but cold
fries - ok but cold
black bean burger - good n spicy... 
double bacon
double bacon cheese
milkshakes - arrived after meal

I ate there twice and both times had the fried eggplant.  First time was so good, as was second, but kind of greasy.  The second time made me sick all night! Turns out it was on kitchen nightmares and rated one of the worst place to eat in New Orleans.  The blonde bartender wasn't get friendly as well.  I will not be going back, ever.  The deliciousness of the eggplant isn't worth what comes after.

I went to Zama with my daughter this week, feeling the need for a sushi fix.  We ordered a variety of rolls and sushi, all of which were OK.  I did not think this restaurant was special in any way, and prices were high. I will keep looking for my favorite sushi restaurant in Philly.  Nothing wrong with Zama, but basically underwhelming.

While I do enjoy the greasy pizza slices, or a mother load sandwich here from time to time, this review is about a particular visit.
Came here with the rest of my department for our company sponsored quarterly lunch.  I believe that we had 12 people that day, and that we put our order in 20+ minutes prior to arriving for lunch.  None of the food was ready when we arrived, so we just got our drinks and sat down waiting for our orders to be called out.  Several orders came out, but none of the 6 lasagnas.  When we checked, they indicated that they were cooking and that it would arrive shortly.  2 came out in the next few minutes, another 2 about 5 minutes later, and 1 more 5 minutes after that.  The last one came out after everyone had finished eating their lunch. 
While waiting, I was able to observe how the lasagna was being made, it was placed into a device that cooked a single piece at a time (pretty cool).  However, I noticed that there was no sauce on the lasagna when it was cooking.  The sauce was added after the lasagna was on the plate.  There was so much sauce on my plate, that the lasagna was drowning in it.  There was supposed to be sides of Sausage, but meat balls were given.  They were decent sized meat balls, but very dry and bland.  There was quite a bit of cheese in mine, which overpowered any other flavor that could have been there.  One of my co-workers showed us a two inch wide maybe four noodles deep "clump" of noodles without sauce or cheese.  Overall, none of the people that ordered the lasagna were happy, in fact a few of them refused to take the left overs home.

I almost feel bad leaving 2 stars for a historic place but alas all I can give is 2 stars. We came in on a weekday for the lunch buffet. Had to wait 25 minutes for a table. Then waited another 10 for a server since we weren't allowed to just get our buffet on. So we waited... we got the buffet and a side of Mac and cheese. 

The Buffett was small. There was salad, greens, fried chicken, sausage, some carrot dish that looked like baby food and tasted like dessert. The salad was lack luster. The fried chicken was good when it was hot. The sausage was super flavorful but had an odd texture and was a bit mealy is n top of being cold. Not bueno. The peach cobbler was good and the Mac and cheese side was super rich but also very plain and tradition and a little greasy. The vanilla bean ice cream was great as well which we got Bc it was my friends birthday. Unfortunately they don't make the ice cream and order it from a supply company so they don't really get credit for it. 

They had beautiful carnival outfits out in the dinning area and lots of art work and a couple pictures of Obama which was cool. But with the wait and the slim pickings... I wouldn't return but it's nice to have checked it off the list so to speak.

My wife and I decided to get out for lunch to a  new franchise restaurant that opened Avon.  Not only do they carry a wide range of wines and flights to chose from.  They have delicious options for lunch and dinner.  The interior is spacious with table eating and bench seating.  Rev
#3984.

On a cold and snowy night during the brewery's first week, with construction all around the place making it difficult to park, I still had a great time at Ellison Brewing!  Despite the challenges, the staff were in good spirits and welcoming.  The crowd was light early in the evening, so I was greeted and helped immediately!

The brewery is the first expansion out of state (Michigan) for this company.  It's located in the former Tow Yard location where Meridian Street angles to become Madison just south of South Street.  Fortunately, they have been told that the road construction should end in about a week, so that will open up access to more parking in the area.  At the time of my writing, there were a few spots along Pennsylvania and a pay lot just north of the business with access off South Street.

Inside, there is a seating area with its own bar to the right as you enter from the elevated entrance on the west end of the building.  There is another bar with seating on the left by the brewing tank area.  That leads back to the second seating area with a view of the kitchen and away from any potential drafts from the entrance.

I chose to order directly from the bar in the first seating area (they do have table service, but I thought I would be more direct.)  I usually order flights of five ounce drinks.  Here, there is no set number in the flight.  All the tap beers were $2 (very good price!) per shorty.  (Note that you can get samples before ordering as well.)  Although they had nine beers to choose from, they had a really nice mix of ales represented.

I started with the Amber Ale (4.7%) which was full of flavor and had a surprisingly darker color than most I've tried.  Full bodied with a very approachable taste.  A great starter!

I moved on to Crescent Fresh IPA (6.2%).  Normally, I don't drink IPA's this early in the flight, but based on what I ordered, this is what my server suggested as next.  The IPA was also a solid, clear choice.  

The third beverage was unlike anything else I've tried locally.  The We've Been Jammed "Fruit Beer" (4.5%) is one of those "dangerous" drinks because it has so much fruit flavor that I didn't notice the alcohol.  It has a nice balance of sour and sweet with a bit of vanilla.  It was refreshing and delicious and is something I would recommend to anyone who isn't a beer drinker in your party as a starting point.

I finished of with the Tiramisu Coffee Stout (8%).  Though not as sweet as the dessert, it had a deep dark chocolate/coffee taste that was really good.  I can imagine pairing this with dessert.

I was going to a catered event immediately after my visit here, so I didn't try any of their food items.  They do offer a variety of appetizers, some entrees, and pizzas.  Hopefully, I will get to check those out on my next visit.

Review #3323

The first time I went to Big Woods was opening week.  5-stars on everything (considering how swamped they were).  Great food and knowledgeable service.  The next three times, the food was okay, but I noticed the place was loud and service was pretty good, but not great.  Last night, I went in a group of four and the drop off was so significant that I could no longer give this a high rating.

The waitress was attentive and did a "good" job, though there was a mix up between our bills that was partially corrected.  The beer was excellent, as usual.  But the food was just not up to standards we saw when the place opened.  Nobody at the table felt the food was that good.  My pizza had a marinara sauce that might have been plain tomato sauce.  No flavor depth even with multiple toppings.

The worst was my wife's fish and chips.  The fish itself was okay, but the breading/batter was soggy.  She tried it and ended up peeling it off because of the texture.  It was like the fish had been cooked and then either reheated or put in a microwave.  I don't know, but it shouldn't have been soggy.  She could have sent it back, but since everyone was already hungry and had started eating, she put up with peeling it.  A great waitress would have noticed the pile of breading on the plate and have asked.  

And the cole slaw, which most places have as a cool and refreshing or at least creamy with a crunch, was soggy and topped with hot pepper flakes.  My wife doesn't like heat, so she only ate a bite of the cole slaw.  I sampled it and it was so different from what I expect from a cole slaw that I passed on a second bite.  Who wants hot flakes on cole slaw?  Put heat on entrees or wings, but why ruin cole slaw?

I may continue buying their beer, but Speedway now has plenty of other good places to get a good meal.

Rev.  #24

This is the second of the Rise'n Roll Bakeries I've been to in the Indy Metro area.  I'm not even that much of a donut fan, but I make an exception for their Cinnamon Caramel donuts/donut holes that fans have labeled "Amish Crack" because the donuts are so addictive!  And if this place is like the one in Greenwood, wait for the ice cream filled donuts in warm weather!

Parking is okay now, but as more shops in the Fishers District (the Yard) open, you may have to park and walk or even use one of the parking garages that should be opening soon.

Inside the shop, you will notice it is long and narrow and it can get a bit crowded in the aisles.  Not only do they have fresh baked donuts/pastries baked in Northern Indiana and driven down daily, but there are lots of local artisan food related items like candies, popcorn, and jellies too.  

While waiting in line, be sure to notice the cool artwork by local (HSE) artist (Ne)Koda Witsken who painted the murals before the grand opening in 2019.  She painted the geometric patterns by the coffee counter and the "Rise and Shine" mural of a horse drawn buggy in a rainbow of colors. (She also did the Mudsock Spirit mural in downtown Fishers!)

Some high quality products as in Greenwood, just a little smaller space that makes it a bit harder to get around when busy.

Review #3603

It's nice to have a decent culinary option in NE, but I hear folks talking about this place like it is the second coming of Christ!

The duck fries were some of best fries I've ever had.  Get them, won't disappoint. The duck sandwich and pork roll burger were both bland and barely mediocre. Salads were grossly overdressed.   

I'd try it again if I were in the NE.

Walked in around 2pm, this place was still busy. 
Recommend fried dumplings, steamed soup buns, they were delicious however the scallion oil with noodles were not authentic, so please do not order it.


Philadelphia
Clean bathrooms.. What else do you need in a rest stop along the turnpike!?!?

I went to Seasons 52 last night with three friends.  Since it was a Friday night, we arranged to meet there at 5pm in order to snag a table at the bar. These booths are first come, first served so if you don't want to hover around diners who beat you to a booth, get there early! The bar has a piano in the center, with live entertainment starting around 6pm on Fridays. 
Megan was our server. She was attentive, and understood we didn't want to be rushed, which worked out great, although we felt the pressure of the hoverers eyeing our booth from their barstools! 
Be prepared to fork over some cash if you order drinks and apps, desserts- our bill per person came out to about $75/pp. heres's what we tried and how we rated out of 10 point scale:
Steak,mushroom blue cheese flatbread: 10
Garlic chicken flatbread:8 (bring breath mints- whoa)
BBQ chicken full size salad: 7. Chicken was dry
duck salad: 7. Ditto on the "dry"
desserts: for $2.50 a pop, fun to try- key lime is best bang for calories and flavor, chocolate peanut butter is smooth and delicious. rocky road with marshmallow was good.   All desserts are fun to try @ $2.50, right there in front of you- everyone tried one. Smart, smart marketing. 
All in all, nice night out- three stars because dinner is much more expensive here than the $$ given by Yelpers. If you want to do try this place on the $$ level, go for lunch!

For our six year anniversary, my husband and I visited P.F Changs for dinner to celebrate. Nice little romantic, candle lit tables always seem inviting for such a celebration. We arrived around 9:30 on Saturday night and there weren't that many tables sat which was nice for us wanting a nice quiet evening to talk.
On a mission, we already knew what we wanted to order seeing as how we wanted to get a few of the same items we tried during the Yelp event we attended awhile back! Chicken Pad Thai, Salt and Pepper Prawns, Shaking Beef...only this time we decided to try the Tempura green beans. And I really...really wanted a lemon coconut sour again! The drink that carries you away to the beach with one sip! 
Now let me start by saying our waitress was very nice... But one critique would be that she seemed distracted by a table of her personal friends which would have been fine if she gave us equal attention, but she kept visiting them and ignoring us. She brought us our drinks, but didn't light our candle, and when a manager passed by with another busser, lighting candles, however they also failed to light ours. 
We waited for our appetizers watching the room only to watch her return to her friends table and light their candle! So we said screw it, and switched our own candle with one on the table next to us. It was our anniversary after all and we wanted that darn candle light!
Our waitress finally came to tell us there was a "problem" in the kitchen, and that they needed to make new, fresh batch of tempura so our appetizer would be a minute more. She then returned to her friends table.
All this aside, our appetizer finally arrived and brought all the happiness and memories that Yelp event brought to the table not to long ago...Wow!!! That sauce, that batter!! They were perfect! Literally perfect. Shortly after that our dinner arrived, and everything was as amazing as we remembered it to be. Leave it to the kitchen staffs abilities to show us again why we love coming here. The food was on point and my drink was just as amazing too! P.F will always get a five star from me because of their tasty food, romantic scenery, and although a bit distracted, very friendly wait staff.

Great selection of beer. Food was below average. Ordered the spicy tuna roll. It's not actually a roll but more of a layered cake with too much going on. We also ordered the lettuce wraps. I've had these at other yard house locations and they are usually pretty good. Unfortunately, these were way too salty. For my dinner, I ordered a french dip sandwich and it was just not good. The meat was thick cut and not shaved. Did not have much flavor. Compared to other beer spots in Indy, it's way over priced. The staff is nice but super uptight. Very corporate feel to the place. We will just call this another downtown chain for convention goers. Maybe the food will improve with time.

I hate to give this less than 5 stars because I honestly love their beers. Specifically, the brawler. We are out of towners that love philly and travel here enough to know our way around the city, and we LOVED the old yards location. Our visit summed up in one word: unimpressed. We had planned on spending all afternoon at yards but we got there and were immediately shuffled upstairs when we asked for a table. Which I thought was fine, we got upstairs ordered our beers after waiting for a few minutes. Which waiting people were specifically requesting other beers and the staff said we don't have those upstairs, they are only downstairs. Which was weird to me since we were shuffled upstairs and no even offered to sit upstairs, and advised it was a smaller beer selection. We played darts, their dart board is so worn the darts were bouncing off and back at us (no not user error- we play often), and it was kind of dangerous, I mean darts are sharp. Anyway, went back to the bar and was ignored by 3-4 staff members for like 5 minutes, I mean they stared right at me and didn't offer a " we'll be with you in a few mins" just walked by and poured several other beers. I walked away. Eventually I came back to the bar and reluctantly grabbed another beer, again only because I like the beer a lot. We left irritated after we finished our second glass. Bigger is apparently not always better- I preferred the smaller location. To be honest, I will return for the love of their brawler, but I won't be happy or excited about it.

I have eaten the spaghetti here 4 times. It's mediocre, good enough when I'm out of other ideas or don't feel like driving any further.

First off, they don't make a meat sauce. 
HELLO!!! THIS IS AMERICA!!! LAND OF BACON AND HAMBURGERS!!!
Someone will comment that REAL Italians don't put meat in their sauce. 
I DON'T CARE!!! THIS IS AMERICA, ONLY CHEAP ITALIAN RESTAURANTS DON'T MAKE A MEAT SAUCE!!!
Secondly, the sauce they do make is very bland and un-remarkable.


I rarely have food delivered because I don't have much faith in the process: cold food, takes longer than promised, screwed-up orders, employees possibly tampering with the food, the whole "TIPPING" shakedown, etc.

The other night I didn't feel like going out so I called this place and had some spaghetti delivered. 
The woman on the phone asked if I wanted to "tip the driver" as I was pre-paying with my card.
I said "No, I don't know how long it's going to take to receive my food or if it's going to show-up hot or cold. I'm not going to PRE-TIP your employee for a job they haven't even accomplished yet".

Rizzoli's charges $3.00 for delivery.
The "DELIVERY CHARGE" should go directly to the drivers!!! There is NO REASON the restaurant should charge their customers extra money for a delivery if it's going into the owners pocket. The "DELIVERY CHARGE" is to pay for their drivers paycheck AND THUS I HAVE ALREADY PAID THE DRIVER FOR DELIVERING ME MY FOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I HATE the "TIPPING" shake-down!!!

The spaghetti showed-up at the last moment AND IT WAS COLD!!!
Now, mediocre spaghetti that is hot and fresh is at least TOLERABLE!
But, mediocre spaghetti that is cold and going stiff is LOUSY!!!

The employee got no tip, I got a lousy meal, and Rizzoli's gets a bad review.

Food was alright, drinks were alright. It's not as hype as people say it is. We each got a drink, 4 (entrees) or small plates and a desert for $90! But a one time visit is a must since it's in Fishers.

My boyfriend and I went here for his birthday dinner and we had high hopes because their food sounds good but the service was just not there. Our waiter was very nice but didn't check on us once we got our food. We asked for a side of ranch and had to flag the waiter down after 25 minutes of not being checked on. A different table sat down and waited almost 30 minutes to be welcomed by anyone. If I was them I think I would have left. The only reason for 3 stars is the food was pretty good. Tasted hot and fresh and came out fairly quick for as slow as everything else was. 

It said they were hiring so maybe they are short staffed but it also wasn't super busy and being a server myself, I just didn't feel like the price was worth what we got.

Well, this isn't even close to as good as the Pescatore on MainLine.
After asking for bread twice, we gave up. Like some other people on here the service is a bit uneven, but the food is ok. It's pretty much standard Italian fare with nothing great and nothing bad. Don't get the wine list pricing , but I guess we would go back for lunch but not dinner.

It gets the job done. The duck has good flavor. The rice is right. It's still got that old school crappy vibe and it just might be the best Chinese food around. I have no desire to try others in Philly bc that is self-predicted to be too many poor meals to get through so I would just come here again if given the choice.

Kaldi's has done it again. Fantastic atmosphere by being at the corner of Citygarden (sit outside and sip your coffee while listening to the waterfall -- you really can't get more peaceful than that. 

They also convinced me to like avocado toast for the first time ever. I did my best never to buy in to this trend, but Kaldi's avocado toast with candied bacon is a showstopper. A simple breakfast or snack while you're working and enjoying the view from the floor-to-ceiling windows around the entire café. 

The ONLY reason this review is not five stars is that there are no outlets in the café at all to power your laptop when you get low. Perhaps this was purposeful so as not to have people hanging around all day, and that's fine, but for people like me who probably stay a max of two hours and just forget to pre-charge their laptop, I was disappointed. However, don't let that stop you from checking this Kaldi's location out. The staff was really friendly (even when I was the annoying guy asking about outlets) and the coffee and food was tremendous as usual.
I did not enjoy this place. I am sorry, it was spectacular once and now the service is terrible. The food was ok but my service was so bad. I will never visit again.

My boyfriend and I ordered take-out...not great, especially for the price. Two entrees and an order of chicken wontons was almost $40. Both entrees had shrimp and chicken. The shrimp was overcooked and the chicken was dry, but there wasn't much of either in the dishes. The chicken wontons were good, but not worth the price of $1/wonton (about $6 for an order). I have absolutely no interest in visiting this restaurant again.

Food was ok. Nothing to write home about. My husband had grouper which he liked. I had chicken sandwich. Not too impressed. For dessert we had key lime. Needs a little help. A little pricey for what you get. Seemed to be popular for shrimps.

Probably the longest way you'll ever have besides sitting at a McDonald's because employees nowadays since corona happened they don't really care because I know they got their job secure because nobody wants to work it's fucking pathetic

No good in every possible way.  

Pros:
- None come to mind

Cons:
- Dated (thought millions was being pumped into remodeling)
- Nasty cigarette smoke
- Made reservations the night before for a large party.  They refused the day of.
- Food isn't good 
- Service was slow with a waitress giving dirty looks
- Beverages sat empty continuously 
- Bill was expensive

Came here again, this time for lunch, and to be honest, it was just okay. In the SFV, we can honestly get higher quality and more quantity for 3/4ths of the price that Zaytoon charges. Again, it's understandable that the food is expensive given it's location, but the food was lacking the day we went.

Okay, so I'm glad that I can say I've been there but I probably won't be rushing back. Let's get something out in the open first: I LOVED Horizons and was horrible depressed when it closed. My gut was bursting when I left that place and everything was absolutely amazing and the atmosphere was so, so romantic and cozy. Vedge? Not so much. I mean, it's nice inside but not as romantic. 

My biggest issue with Vedge wasn't the flavors - they were pretty good. I think it was that I was expecting Horizons again, and this is anything but. Yes, it's Rich Landau, but he's moved up in the world (good for him, I love him!) which means...small, small portions and big, big prices. This is disappointing to me because when the waitress (who was great) told us that she recommended 3 plates per person, I knew we were in trouble. 

The top of the menu was pretty much cold appetizers to share with the table. 3 for $9, it says. Don't think about getting two, or one. If you go with two it's $10. Why? I don't know. The waitress shrugged and said "I don't know why it's like that." So we ended up with the pickled cauliflower, fried shisito peppers and the u-peel lupini beans. I was underwhelmed and even left some of the food on the plate. I was just expecting flavors to be punching me in the face, but they were good to graze on while I slugged back the pomegranate sangria. I ordered it because it was least expensive cocktail on the menu. It was pretty to look at, but overall, a forgettable experience.

The hot kitchen items were the stars of the meal and I think if we ever did end up her again we'd just order these and dessert. My boyfriend had the grilled seitan. I remembered getting the grilled seitan at Horizons years ago. It was the best meal I've ever had. The waitress said these plates were bigger. Okay, they're bigger, but they're still too small. The seitan was absolutely divine, and my tofu was out of this world. I loved the marinade it was in. And the edamame puree was super! The sweet potatoes from the dirt list were okay. I liked the coleslaw like veg underneath of them. It was addicting.

I remembered the legendary vegan cheesecake from Horizons, too. A normal slice of cheesecake in size. This time, however, the cheesecake had some sort of waldorf salad celery gel on it (????) and I didn't like that. And the cheesecake was literally 2 bites. We also shared the uber chocolate chunk, and it came with 2 bites of ice cream, 1 bite of chocolate and some sort of pudding. It was good but I was still hungry after my meal. Saaaad.

I like this place. A causal laid-back vibe. I had the oysters for starters, but I should have tried the chargrilled ones. Then I had a combo platter of fried shrimp and crab cake. They were good, nothing amazing but solid. The GF had the shrimp po-boy, she was drunk and just ate the shrimp off the sandwich. I believe she liked it. Should have tried more different items but there's always a next time. 
Service was decent. Good portion and decent prices. It does tend to get crowed with a long waiting line. 
Nice place to kick back and eat.

I want to start by saying that I did not try any of the beer here so I will have to come back for that. They are known for their beer just as much as their food.

My hubby and I came here for lunch at an awkward time. We came at about 3 PM on a Saturday. It was super slow and there was a sign to seat yourself when you walk in. We missed this at first and stood there looking around and finally saw it once no one greeted us. We sat at a booth and do not be surprised because they are not comfortable at all. There is no cushion so you sit down on a hard wooden board. I'm sure the high chair tops are just as comfortable as the booths.

For starters we ordered the poutine. I prefer traditional poutine without meat in it but my hubby seemed to like it. It was a good size portion. Then my hubby ordered the jumbo chicken wings, which were not very jumbo in my opinion, just regular size wings. The wings do not come with the sauce already on it. The flavor sauce you order comes on the side along with the dressing. I did not like this because you are dipping the wings twice. I would not order the wings again. I ordered the queso Quattro pizza. The pizza was very good! That was the one thing I enjoyed here. 

Maybe because it was super slow but our waiter was super friendly and attentive. Very nice. I did not have high expectations for this place which is why I'm not too disappointed but I would give it another try.

I was fairly excited about going to this place, specifically because I finally figured out how to say the name instead of referring to it as that restaurant that starts with an X near south st. Sadly, I was disappointed. 

There were some highlights. My boyfriend and I walked in and was greeted by a very nice and friendly manager who even assisted us in choosing drinks that ended up being great. Their sangria specifically was fantastic. We then moved onto the guac which we created ourselves with assistance. Holy crap. Avocados, crab, onions, roasted garlic, black truffle and jalapeno. It sounds like way too much but holy crap is was amazing. If our meal ended right here, I would give this place 4 stars for sure. Sadly, it did not. 

The short rib tamale was delicious but barely resembled a tamale. The pork carnitas tacos were a bit dry and pale in comparison to my favorite ones at Cantina and the Pollo Fritta was just awful. I swear I can still feel that flavorless dry fried chicken sitting in my stomach 16 hours later. UGH. 

To sum it up, if I'm in the neighborhood, I would definitely have that guac and sangria at the bar but I will never sit down for a whole meal of food again.

I've been here twice now, once for pick up and once to eat in. Both were good experiences. When I ordered pick up, I did so through the ap. They offer several online specials. 

My online order was a half pizza and a mozzarella salad. I love that you can order as many toppings as you want for one price. I got there 5 minutes early and the order was already ready. The pizza was still relatively warm when I ate it back at the office.

The second time I went, I ate in. This time I also got a half pizza and salad but inside the offer either a Cesar or a Greek. I had the Greek. It was huge! I could have probably just had the salad.

My boss swears by their cauliflower crust. He says it is the best he's ever had. I will still have to try it. I had regular crust both times.

Both times I went I also got a drink. They have several teas and juices as well as sodas. I like flavored teas so it is a great option for me.

I will be ordering from here again.

I have been wanting to check this place out for a while. It is part of Hyde Park United Methodist's downtown campus and it looked like a nice place for a snack or light lunch. It is also minutes away from my job. There is a small complimentary parking lot but if it is full there is street parking all around the block.

Today I was on vacation and had errands to run so I planned to hit the cafe between. I arrived about 1230 and it wasn't super busy. There was a group using a meeting room and then a couple other people like myself just ordering lunch. It is a nice, modern space and there is outside seating too.

The menu is limited but not bad. There are several breakfast sandwiches to choose from or lunch sandwiches or salads. They also have various coffee drinks and they have a soup of the day. Prices are reasonable and the quality was good. I had the turkey sandwich and it was better than any food item I have had at Starbucks. It came with chips. I also ordered a 16 oz cold brew which was nice and strong. Total costs was just under 10 bucks. I had to wait about 5 min for it to come out and a server brought it to me.

I will definitely be back because I like supporting businesses that give back to the community and also because the food was good.

My review will hopefully change in the near future, as I went in with high expectations, having visiting one of these restaurants in St Louis. The restaurants in St. Louis are always PACKED and this one was not. Not sure why. I came across it by chance. They should advertise and get their name out there! My friend from St Louis that's here in Indy now, thought I was in St Louis when I sent a picture. Haha!

The music was LOUD! I could not hear the man behind the counter several times. Which may have led to incorrect food being given to us. Ordered baby back ribs and after cutting into them, they were definitely St Louis ribs. Not the same thing at all. And it had a giant peice of back fat on it. Yuck. St Louis ribs are too rough. I don't like them. The rest of the food was good though-fries, chicken biscuit, Mac and cheese and potato salad. 

I was in there at 8p, they close at 9p, which is SUPER early for downtown Indy on a Friday night. These people working in here were already trying to close up shop!!! Desserts were taken out of the display case and placed in a tub that usually holds dirty dishes. Bread and butter were moved and put away and inaccessible. I didn't feel like asking for it, as they seem preoccupied with fixing their own meals for the end of the night. Hardly any silverware in the tub to take to your table. They yelled at some people walking out to put their trays away and throw away their trash. I'm pretty sure these folks didn't know they were supposed to bus their own tables, as even the trash cans were pulled out and hidden behind the corner. I thought that was unprofessional. Needs some work here, mostly with the staff. So my opinion could definitely change. I'll try it again in a few months and cross my fingers.

View and patio are top notch. I think that's its main staying power. Otherwise it's super pricey by Tucson standards. My friend's salad with fish added was $18! Wowzer. I had a single taco (you can order tacos a la carte) and vegan black beans. The taco was tiny - size of my palm tiny. There are very few options for vegans here. The avocado taco was ok but not worth the $9, with beans included. Their flour tortillas have lard, be careful! I was super happy the waitress knew this. The corn tortilla was a bit bland. One pro tip for you, if you get a soda or like me an iced-tea its free refills. That includes asking for a to go cup at the end so when we walked around the stores we had drinks. Honestly, the only reason to go here is the view but for me I need more from a restaurant.

I tried this place two different times and it was night and day. The first time was amazing. I got the vegan vegetable soup to go. I was very excited to see all the vegan options! The small restaurant was small but stuffed with oriental kitschiness. There was no line and my food came out fairly quickly. The soup was delicious. The vegetables were fresh and still a bit crunchy. The noodles were soft but not over cooked. I did have an issue with the little packets of hoisin sauce being under the noodles. I don't know where those packets have come from or who touched them. Gross. The broth was super flavorful and again, delicious. My first experience was 4 stars! 
My second experience wasn't close to 4 stars. Honestly if this was my first time I'd have a hard time going back. I placed my order over the phone easy-peasy. When I arrived the floors and and a few tables were littered with trash. There was food on the floor and tables, straw wrappers, chopsticks and other bits of trash. I paid for my food and left. This time I decided to try the hot and spicy soup with imitation beef. No veggies, just noodles, "beef", and tofu. I also got a side order of fried tofu. The imitation beef was horrendous. It was bland, chewy and inedible honestly. The rice noodles were overcooked and fell apart into tiny pieces as I tried to move them into the soup. The fried tofu side while crisp, was also very bland and came with those annoying packets. The only saving grace was the broth was delicious. I'll give this place another try eventually but I advise everyone avoid the fake meat. Go for the veggies and keep it simple.

I cant say enough bad things about my experience here last night. Our first choice for our Anniversary was 4th St Bistro, but they were closed. Many people have raved about how awesome La Famiglia was, so we thought we'd try it out.

I called to make a reservation and spoke with a very disinterested gentleman who made our reservation for 8:30. I had to make him repeat everything back to me so I knew he actually made the reservation. We were running slightly late, so I called to let them know. I was informed by another gentleman that they close the kitchen at 8:45, so I better hurry up. This came across somewhat rude to me, but not a huge deal. 

We arrived at 8:40 and were told by the hostess that the kitchen was closed, but if we ordered something immediately they would open the kitchen and "throw something together for us." I informed her that this was our anniversary and we drove 30 minutes to get there and were not looking forward to being rushed. She then told me in a very irritated tone how we should have gotten there earlier and said something about how HER watch said it was 8:50 and restaurant was clearing out. She said something to my girlfriend about how "Since the restaurant was clearing out, did we really want to eat alone?" YES, WE WOULD LOVE TO EAT ALONE. We came there for a quiet, romantic dinner, not to make friends and socialize.

We instead went to the Bimini Steakhouse at Peppermill who were MORE than accommodating even though it was slightly later than they generally stay open. 

I dont care how many people love La Famiglia, I will never go to this establishment and if I want awesome Italian in Reno, I will go to Johnny's instead.

One of New Orleans little neighborhood secrets we found after moving here, mostly enjoyed by just its locals in need of plain ol good sushi. Very fresh and just as good as anything we've eaten in San Diego or Laguna Beach. Some of it might be a little better because of the Cajun twist on some of the rolls. Service is pretty fast, which is nice. Don't expect ambiance however; get your goods and go. But if you need to sit and enjoy, you can. If you get a few curious stares, fear not......it's just that this is a spot locals frequent and they cherish places not overtaken by tourists. Hey....it's Nola though - everybody's welcome! :)

This particular TB is not one of my favorites.  They are always slow no matter if they are busy or not and prices here run about 10% higher than other TB's in the area.  They have also screwed up my order a few times.  On the plus side , staff is generally friendly.

No food, no drink no service. I've never experienced such awful service... or lack of. We ordered food and when it was not delivered after an hour and 15 minutes....we left. It took an hour to get a second round of drinks! There are some serious problems here!!!! We were only a table of 3 and we noticed larger tables around us leaving due to thirst and hunger as well. After waiting for an hour and 15 minutes for our food order, we left and enjoyed a nice meal at Bria. We won't be returning to Bar Louie. EVER!!!!!

I've passed by Queen Donair more times than I can count but never had the urge to stop in. Well, we were crunched for time after a spot we wanted to try was closed for August holidays. We decided to bite the bullet and dropped in for a quick Wednesday lunch. It's located right beside a Just for Fun game shop. 

The inside isn't what I was expecting. A couple arcade games, TV's and plenty of tables. The menu is large with more selection than you'd expect from a donair shop. 

- Chicken donair ($13.50 large mix) - didn't seem that jumbo in size to me. Pretty standard donair. Not bad but not comparable to my go to donair spots. 
- Butter chicken poutine ($11.45) - we decided to try their fusion take on the classic poutine. Chicken was dry and dish was salty. A half decent attempt but I wouldn't get it again. So much for venturing out.

One of your typical Edmonton joints. You can do better if you're in the west end. 2.5 stars.

My first experience with Day By Day was alright. Fairly basic brunch foods done fairly well, nothing special, but still pretty good. My second experience was awful.
