Service: Service was terrible. Waiter was unattentive and got my order wrong, and when the right one came out, it was missing a side. 

Food: Pretty awful. I got the Tiramisu French Toast and was sorely disappointed. I took a couple bites before realizing it wasn't worth the effort to force down. It had the consistency of bread that had been soaked in syrup for a good hour before being served. It was falling apart, but not in the good way. It was akin to eating mush. On the other hand, the baked goods were alright. Took a muffin to go.

Overpriced and bland food. A meat and three should be hearty, plentiful comfort food, no frills just good quality food at a good price. This quasi-cafeteria has limited options which is fine, but they overcharge for scant amounts of food. Just a hint, how about forgetting the individual Mimi cups of side items. I'm tired of 30 cents worth of mac and cheese costing three dollars!! It is purely a money maker poised to make lots of cash and returning little quality. I don't understand what is wrong with giving people what they pay for not less.

First visit for my sisters.  It was Restaurant Week so we thought we would give it a try.  The food was very salty.  The lecon asado was very salty.  The rice was just a ball (instant) topped with shredded pork and plaintains.    My friend raves about the tres leches but the cake was stale.  I do not think I would go back again.

Went for a made to order burger and found staff recooking premade burgers already cooked. When asked staff how they could make a rare burger the cook said "no way possible, it was already cooked"

When asked why they serve precooked burgers stored in a quart plastic just warmed up the staff claims " our manager makes us serve these this way" and shook their head.

Had ordered 2 kids burgers which were sent out burnt, and the size of half dollar. 

No customer service, no fresh burgers and no return visit!

What a complete joke! Food is as unimpressive as it gets! Were it not for being backed by Harrah's this place would never make it based on its food. It's a  nice new building,built out nicely, nice bar, nice employees, but the food stinks. If you advertise home cut fries, serve home cut fries, not frozen ones --- oh yeah and when you can't even turn out halfway decent french fries (underfryed, too mushy) something is seriously wrong! Even the description of the hamburger leaves a lot to be desired ( menue doesnt even indicated cheese, much less a choice of cheese)
The Manning family should be embarrassed to have their name on this place!

I've lived here for 25 years.  Been about 15 years since I ate here. Normally, I take out of town guests to the Harbor.  But, it wasn't too busy and how bad could it be?  How does 'awful' sound?  The hostess and waiter were very nice.  It took a very long time to be waited on.  The lemonade should have been real and not ultra sweet crystal lite.  The waiter completely forgot to bring the water that I requested twice.  Also, excited to see the Beyond Burger on the menu.  Never came.  He said he forgot.  The fried combo (over $45) was truly terrible in taste, presentation etc.  My guests are from out of the country so were polite and ate it.  I understand how tough the food industry is and will never be rude and will always tip well.  When I complain about the food, it's got to be terrible.  Waiter apologized for forgetting the burger and would tell someone about the food.  Almost $100 for lunch.  I should have stayed with the Harbor.
the most ignorant answer NOT after I made a polite complaint, these people will fail the way they conduct business It happens all the time!!!!

One of our favorite spots in all of New Orleans. 

This place got it all, 

The scene 
The food
The cocktails
The location

This time my wife and I went in for lunch and again, fantastic spot.

I ordered the Burger with fries, so light and tasty.

My wife had the spicy chicken plate, so so good.

Again, lunch or dinner this place takes the cake!

Boy has this place gone downhill. Used to be a great place to take friends and business associates for lunch or dinner but no more. Food is bland and service is weak. Got our order wrong which is hard considering we only ordered two dishes.
Restaurant was cold and the chairs were old and worn out looking. Not going back.

Staff is very friendly and helpful.  They get high marks for their management and their staff.  

The food is okay but not great.  

They need better barbecue sauces.  There is no decent sweet sauce.

We had the burgers here. They weren't bad but not much flavor.  The sweet potato fries were pretty good but the larger ones were not cooked all the way through. The service was pretty slow. Overall it was okay but I would probably choose one of the other restaurants before this one.

While the food was good and the service was too, it took quite a while to get our food. If the AC would have been working properly, the wait might not have been such a big deal.  It was hot in there. When the manager tried to be helpful by closing the blinds, it did help but the thick layer of dust on the blinds was disgusting.

* Agave Vanilla Cream Soda at the fountain. Well I'm not a "Stubborn" man, but I could get used to this. They also offer bottled drinks in a cooler and several varieties of snack chips.
* This shop looks a lot like Subway in principle. The difference is that they have TV screens overhead, slower service, and more costly food.
* Taste? I ate the limited time offer, beef barbecue. It was pretty simple. Roast beef, a trace of sauce, and a bun. It was satisfying, especially with a bag of chips and the soda I mentioned. If there's a next time, I might bring a bottle of my own BBQ sauce to give it some zip.
* The bun was more like a baguette, with cornmeal sprinkles on the bottom. You don't say? I do say. A throwback to the olden days of brick oven baking, where a dusting of cornmeal helped prevent the bread dough from sticking to the bricks.
* The place was not terribly busy, but several customers came and went as I had a late late dinner. They have a reward points program for frequent patrons.

Have been staying at Harrah's for years and can only say that I was highly disappointed. The lack of general housekeeping in the hotel was sad. A wine glass that was in the window sill of the 12th floor when I got off the elevator on Wednesday night was still there Thursday morning. My room 1244 was as about as comfortable as you'd expect from a dive, not a major hotel casino. The bed should have been retired from service years ago. And the complete lack of shampoo or other grooming products in the bathroom was sad. As for the signage on the room doors that harken back to earlier days when the rooms had robes and Bose radios they don't any longer so why have them? 
My wife says that this will be the last stay that even for free it wasn't worth it. So instead of burning comps in Reno I'll use them elsewhere.

This is a huge historic bar that also serves awesome food. They have a decent sized free private lot in the back. This place is on the national historic registry. It has been around since 1850. They still have live music Wednesday, Thursday and Friday evenings. Expect to pay a cover during some of those times though (mostly weekends).

The restaurant is located on the outskirt of downtown, in the shadow of Lucas Oil Stadium. As I mentioned, this place is huge. There is tons of indoor seating available and there is a small outdoor patio that you can dine on as well.  The place has a couple of full bars and is well decorated with classic artifacts and memorabilia. In the front is the biggest bar and merchandise store.

They have a huge menu full of some interesting selections including salads, subs, wings and burgers. I went with Vegas Burger with cajun fries.  It was a ton of food. The burger was tasty and the fries were perfectly seasoned. The food was warm and fresh.

There was only one server/bartender working the restaurant and she was very busy, running all over the place. So service was a tad slower than normal, but was OK considering there was only one person working. 

This is a great place to get a bite to eat or cocktail in a historic piece of Indianapolis. I enjoyed my visit here and my meal.  You can't go wrong with free parking in their private parking lot. They have some delicious food and savory drinks.

This is an awesome and fun family restaurant. A piece of New Orleans right here in Indianapolis. They have a large indoor dining area with a full bar and a few tables and chairs on the sidewalk that you can eat.  There is some free street parking available and a decent sized free parking lot off a side street right near the restaurant. The dining area is well decorated with New Orleans/Mardi Gras memorabilia. The dining tables give you a kitchen table feel. Some of the tables in the bar area are more Bourbon Street like. 

The staff there is very friendly and helpful. They brought the Big Easy hospitality with them. They greet the little ones with beads and some Teddy Graham crackers. The menu is packed with cajun favorites such as frog legs, jambalaya, gator, oysters and catfish. They also have some delicious signature cocktails featuring the New Orleans famous Hurricane, be it that they are a bit pricey. 

I ordered the oyster poboy with cajun fries. They bring you some warm bread with butter and a home made vinegar based dip.  The poboy was decent, especially considering that it is in Indiana. The fries were amazing, I highly recommend getting them with the seasoning on them. It gives them a little kick and tons of flavor.

I highly recommend this restaurant. It is a fun place to eat and is family friendly. It is very unique. They have an excellent staff, delicious food and one of the best vibes that you will find.  I really enjoyed my meal here and look forward to coming back.

Our go to for Bahn Mi sandwiches and Pho!  

remind us of being back in the NYC area with authentic vietnamese cuisine.  Fresh bread, right amount of protein fresh veggies.  The pho was just like we are used to and even better then some up north.

If you want good sushi, look else where.  The concept is cool, but the execution is definitely under par.  

Nothing seemed fresh.  Nothing tastes fresh.  And I swear I saw something crawling on the wall when I was getting the soy sauce.

It's not a clean place either.  Come at your own risk.

The place: small and intimate, cozy

The service: on a Tuesday night for dinner was shocked on how slow it was.  With ~10 people it took almost an hour to get our sushi.  The electronic ordering was cool, but when we flagged the waiter down for water in the app, it took forever. Again. It that many people dining. We didn't get the right drink order either.  Overall not too satisfied with the service.  Don't get me wrong.  The guy was nice, it was just sloooooooooow. 

The sushi: Coming from the NYC area I know we can't compare the Tampa Bay Area to NYC.  (God I wish we could) but the sushi isn't bad.  Seemed fresh, just a wee bit too thick.  The portions were small for the price you pay. 

Overall: long wait times, pretty good sushi, rather high prices for what you actually get.  Cmon guys, you're in Pinellas Park, FL.  You'll get better turnaround with better/faster service and maybe 15% less for your food items (for the portion you serve.)

Ugh, I miss the location on 116th street . Since moving back to Indy, I have tried this "new" (read: new to me) location and it's just not the same. The service is very hit or miss, which is so disappointing! Also, the margs just don't pack the same punch.

When yelping about Geno's there are just so many directions that you can take this. One could rant on the awful racism that is plastered all over the establishment. Another direction could be the deplorable customer service they display even in some of their signage which directs you like you are a three year old.

The easiest and most direct route is the fact that the establishment is nothing more than a glorified tourist trap that has made it's name and money on the backs of others claiming to be "true Americans".

For this yelp I'll just focus on the food and leave the other stuff to those with more time on their hands ;)

As many others who have been sucked into this tourist trap I had an expectation of having an excellent authentic Philly Cheesesteak. After all if you didn't grow up in Philly you assume you have only experienced mere imitations at your local sandwich shop or perhaps even frozen food section. Well after eating a cheesesteak from Geno's my first thought was, wow I think I'll stick to the frozen ones.

The cheesesteak tasted a bit like a piece of cardboard you may have munched on when you were five (hey maybe that's why the signs are written that way) with some cheese and lots and lots of grease... Did I mention it was greasy. I was very disappointed but hey it was a $9 learning experience, but for that price I could have picked up two at Wawa and been more satisfied (no, Wawa does not have the best cheesesteaks for those reading this that are not from around here)

Let's face it, no matter what we yelp people will go to Geno's just to say they went there, that's how they stay in business. Just a word to the wise, when you have choked down that greasy cheesesteak, don't bother trying another one, save the 9 bucks for Pat's across the street so you can say you tried them too. Then when your finished with Pat's go and find a real authentic Philly cheesesteak. :) 

If you are wondering where... Hey that's what your yelp is for :) Look up somewhere with good ratings from real Philadelphia residents. I can point you towards Tony Luke's but hey I'm a New Yorker who is transplanted to Delaware, so Im not up on the latest and greatest Philly has to offer.

a tepid place calls for a tepid review. without a doubt, this market is convenient; however, the price inflation combined with sickly looking meat and produce knocks this place down a couple of stars. 

bonus: the dungeons-and-dragons-playing basement dweller cum checkout dude was cordial and polite.

note the location is at 10th and chestnut NOT 11th and chestnut. i learned this during the ~*great snow*~ of october. not cool.

i needed some delicious soup to warm my bones while i was on call when the snow hit. unlike the ABP on penn's campus, this place had one gluten-free selection, and the amount of the soup in the pot was paltry so my kale and chorizo soup was mostly broth with two pieces of chorizo and a tiny bit of kale. the soup's flavor was good; beware, the soup is on the spicy-side.

i bought a side salad which was ok but likely nearing its expiration or sell-by date because the lettuce was a little wilted and soggy. the salad was still passable with the assistance of some light ranch dressing. 

maybe because the weather sucked hardcore, the employees didn't really feel like tidying up the place. it wasn't disgusting but it seemed a little unkempt. the cashier was really friendly and wanted to shoot the shit about the singer of a song that was playing overhead in the store.

pretty basic but consistent food. good for people working in the area who need a fast and relative healthy lunch. i wouldn't go out of my way to come here again, but if i'm in the area, i'd return.

I come here usually after going to the movie theater down the block. There's a parking lot so that's never an issue. The inside is usually decently clean and the bathroom is fine. The employees there I would say are average to above average. The food which is the most important part is typical Taco Bell. The inside has about 15 tables spread around. It's quiet in there and the area is nice.

My favorite is the soft potato tacos and the best part is their only $1.00. They ask for your name after place your order and they will announce upon completion. I find that to be a good idea. I usually sit down and wait. It usually takes about five minutes to get done. I plan on coming back here in the future for sure. I enjoy the fact it's right by a lot of things!

1 star for the food + 1 star for the outdoor seating area. It's your typical pizza, pasta, and burgers place, but the food is just not good! I've been here twice before, and will not be back a third time because I just don't like anything I've tasted. In fact, I think Applebee's (and similar places) taste better than this non-chain restaurant. I feel like this place has potential, but they need a menu overhaul and/or new chefs.

The pizza is always fresh and delicious, but really expensive. You're paying for the fact that they have organic and hormone-free as the standards (and other health conscious options which cost extra, like gluten free). Since it's "thin crust" you literally have to eat a medium pie by yourself to feel full! So, if you don't mind spending nearly $20 for pizza, then I highly recommend it. They also offer online ordering, which makes it very convenient.

This place is awful. My husband and I ordered Nigiri- Tuna, Smoked Salmon, and Kani. We also ordered California Rolls and an appetizer of Tempura Shrimp. It was all terrible. The restaurant is really nice and the employees are super awesome but the chefs have no idea how to make sushi and the food is frozen or just old. The sushi smelled bad and the rice underneath looked dry and not proportion to the fish. The smoked salmon didn't have a hint of smoke flavor or smell and felt like thawed out fish not fresh at all. The tempura batter was too thick and had zero flavor. And wtf is that wasabi? I know most places don't have real wasabi but that green stuff was disgusting.  The California rolls were really loose and the avocado was brown. Really disappointed with the quality. It's obvious there is no real training in the art of sushi. Sad.

Went to Redstone today for lunch with friends. Hostess and service were friendly. Ordered the Brussels sprout, kale, turkey salad with goat cheese, apples and raisins. It was a very feeble offering. Mostly all kale and shaved Brussels sprouts. Did not see any apples, very little turkey and goat cheese. There were good amount of craisins. Extremely disappointed, especially for the $15.50 price tag. Sorry but this is a "one and done" for me.

Had the opportunity to dine here last night, paid by my friends, so I really had no bias in this review. I could have rated it 3 stars but I find that price to quality/quantity is a standard for me. The restaurant plays into the "bistro" theme where small portions command higher prices. We started with a "margarita" pizza as an appetizer. It did meet the definition of pizza as it was round, had dough topped with sauce and cheese. Other than that, MEH. It was undercooked as in not crispy but well in the doughy side. When you picked up a piece, toppings fell off. I then had the Caesar salad with chicken. I've had the same quality salad at other establishments for far less money. The added chicken, at an add on cost, was dry and tough. The establishment was very tight on space and the bistro-like chairs, were entirely uncomfortable. Sorry I will not re-visit nor will I recommend it. My money would have been better spent on some authentic tacos or burritos in Kennet.

Bar food plus some upper crust offerings. Great brews.  The inside can be really noisy.  Opt for the patio instead.  Usually busy so you know it must be good.  A welcome addition to the Westchase area.

Moved back into Westchase and had a $15 "welcome to the neighborhood" coupon.  My wife and I both had the surf shack basket.  The coconut shrimp was good but the fish was inedible.  The grease tasted like it had Not been changed in a year and it was way too greasy.  We both ate 1/2 of one of the pieces.   Told the waitress and all she said was "sorry".  Won't be going back.

Went there mid afternoon on a Saturday.  Even then it was packed so we sat at the bar.  As always chips and sauce to begin.  Chips were good but the sauce is really mamby pamby.  Tasted like puréed tomatoes with absolutely no kick.  This is Mexican?  I had the steak street tacos and wife had a salad.  Wife said the salad was good but small.  Tacos were the same. Someone left two bay leaves in the rice.  Black beans were hard.  Bright spot of the day was the young lady at the bar.  Excellent service.  If only the food was the same.  Okay, but not great.  As a side comment, didn't have one but the  margaritas were really small.  I miss Texas where the Mexican is huge and the margaritas as killer.

Right past the entrance, we pass their showcase of meats which got us in the mood for ribeye (good low keyed sales) we both ordered ours medium rare and that's exactly what we got... good start!
It turned out to be way too salty to enjoy the taste of the steak. They replaced them both without any problem ( if it's a problem for, ask for no spices) Both my wife and I thought that the ribeye was tougher then ribeyes at other restaurants, but it was acceptable.
  
Service was great. This restaurant is one happy, noisy place to eat. Enjoy the experience

Have had take out from here before and food has been good. Fresh and hot. decided to eat in store today, they have eight tables and plenty of room so it seems like a good idea.  This gave me a chance to observe the restaurant while waiting for my food.
First thing I noticed is how run down the place looks...metal chairs, rusty looking, cushions unraveling on bottoms.
Restaurant was clean, which is what counts.
The important part is all about the food, so, be assured that it's all... They make good shrimp dishes as well as General Tso's Chicken. Their shrimp with vegetables dish is good, but in my opinion, to much Broccoli.
I suggest take out rather he eating in store. And it appears that management prefers it as well.

.

Great looking place, great food and awesome service. Stopped in while checking out the area and the beautiful open air shopping mall Wiregrass.  Could not ask for a better place for lunch. Everyone from the hostess to the busboy could not be more pleasant and attentive.

I have never been so disappointed in a restaurant in my life. 
This restaurant was not worth our time and probably gotten better service at mc donalds.
First off they advertise as habachi, but they have no tables to cook at. 
The food we did get was ok, pretty good. Not worth calling home about.
The worst part was the service. It was the worst!
Waitress came to the table said less than 5 words to us. We ordered and she left only to return with the food, which she just dropped off and walked away. She never can back to the table, no one ever acknowledged us. We couldn't get refills on our drinks because there was no one to be found. When the check was dropped the other waiter put it on the table and walked off. Our waitress was standing there doing nothing, just looking at us.
I don't think we heard more than 10 words from both of them together.

HORRIBLE EXPERIENCE WILL NEVER GO BACK

The burger patties are so small that I actually got up and walked to the counter to show them that there wasn't a patty on my Breakfast All Day burger. It was there, just smaller than the egg and hash brown and not visible without taking the thing apart. Fortunately, I discovered this while being ignored while standing at the counter. Good news for both me and the restaurant. I didn't vindicate my wife, who seems to think that I don't spend enough time looking for something before asking for help, and they weren't put into the awkward position of explaining how that li'l patty made up for its lack of size with freshness and magic organic powers.
 
I also had fries with herb parmesan topping, which incidentally costs an extra dollar. It was too much, just made the fries dry and unpleasant to eat. Overall, the burger did taste very good, just not $16.00 good. I had a burger, fries and soft drink, which is $2.50 and the size of a solo cup and, yes, my meal was $16.00. It's not like I haven't spent that much on lunch before, I just expect more when I do. 

I really was hoping to have a better experience as I eat lunch in Brentwood every day. I wasn't greeted when I walked in and generally felt like the staff was indifferent to me being there. It should have been clear that I felt like I had a problem with my order and no one at the counter spoke to me.  It was their second day, so there is likely some room for improvement. It's probably worth a try, just be better aware of what you are ordering and you may can sneak into the $10ish range.

The menu is nothing to get excited about, the choices are average and high priced. The soup is a rip off for the price, the bowl of chicken noodle soup was more like a cup and it was half full and warm, the soups are high priced for what you get.  The restaurant never looks overly clean and the restrooms always seem to need attention.  I am not  a fan.

Stopped in for lunch and it was good. I got a grilled cheese, tomato and bacon on focaccia and it was tasty. Washed it down with a cream soda...the combo was reminiscent of one of my favorite lunches as a kid....only a bit more sophisticated. Hubby had the turkey on a pretzel bun, but remarked that it was a tad dry and could have used more mayor his sweet potato soup made up for it, though. I also had a few of their chocolates...not cheap, but pretty to look at and very tasty. It's a nice addition to Fayette's meal options.

This is the go-to place of a friend and I can see why. We ordered the scallop app and the meatball app. Would have preferred one more of each in the serving, but probably because they were SO good. Our Margherita pizza was one of the best I've had. We opted not to drink on a school night (lol) so it kept the bill down. I look forward to going back and sitting on the patio next time.
Wonderful service and food was great. My only complaint is I wish there were more options for fish entrees. We will be back!

So far, I think the chili garlic tofu is my favorite here.  The food is pretty good, although not out of this world.  Lots of veg and vegan options which is always a plus.  I had a rye and ginger ale with dinner, which was very nice.  And they have local brew Alley Kat on tap.  The staff is very nice and pretty attentive.  I wish the patio were a bit bigger, but there's only so much of the sidewalk that you can take up.  Overall, I like this place but I just don't want to get your hopes too high.

I like the Nachos as an entree.  And the bread pudding for desert.  Others seem to like the salmon quesadillas, but I don't know first hand.  The staff is nice and the food is reliable.  And they are the number one restaurant in Edmonton, in terms of keeping my water glass filled, which is a big deal to me.

3.5 stars - and that's partially because I do miss Chaucer's.  Oh Chaucer, you with your oriental rugs pinned on the ceiling, your free jukebox and your overall lovely and dive-y charm - how I miss you!  You were a definite memory maker (even though I don't exactly remember everything that happened there - though I'm sure it was commemorated in that photo album they kept at the bar...)

But one must move on.  Pub and Kitchen did, though they kept certain remnants of Chaucers, like the bar and the booths (which I appreciate)  It's definitely airier (and most definitely cleaner) and I love the addition of the two big french doors lending much light to the space.  It's a completely different atmosphere which I like (and at times makes me nostalgic for Chaucer's)

What I'm not nostalgic about was Chaucer's cuisine.  This is where the Pabbit has lept and bounded above the former tenant.  Though a bit expensive, the menu (with its tantalizing bar snacks) is lovely (if not a bit too ambitious).

The bar has got a decent beer and wine selection - and speaking of, I also like that the Pabbit has the beer balls to serve Miller Lite on tap.  Not everyone always wants to drink a belgian or micro brew- sometimes, I like to slum it too (beer-wise, of course)  

The outdoor tables are-a-plenty, and I like the big wood slab that runs alongside the wall from across the bar too- it doubles the bar seating and gives you a place to rest your beverage or your snacks.  

The crowd, as aforementionned in other reviews can tend towards the yupperites, but during the week it is simply pleasant.

Oh Chaucer, I'll never forget you - but the Pub and Kitchen has made a decent, clean eatin' and drinkin' place out of you.

Fantastic location.  Overall Solid service (if not a bit, Overzealous).  Over-hyped, Overpriced, chain-style food. Simply Over it.

White tablecloths, tables jammed in the space, there's nothing particularly original (not surprising, of course), special or different about this place.  Big salads, nicely sized pizzas, all at a hefty price tag and the end result is food that tastes like half of what it costs. Blah.

Just what we need.  Another 'chain' type restaurant that pawns itself off as something original. I'm sorry, but that just won't do for this town. 

On a related note, as the amazing and delicious Noble Cookery closes, a Serafina opens.  What's wrong with this picture?

I need my half-stars, Yelp - I'm just saying it's time to be able to award half stars here-  Sometimes a girl just needs a half, you know? That being said, Osteria, is a 3.5 for me.

 Another over-hyped restaurant that might have been at the height of its hey-day a couple years ago.   Like similar restaurants that have experienced much acclaim, followed by a slow backlash, Osteria is another Italian restaurant that is trying to maintain its once-glowing status and relevancy in a sea of more affordable, and equally-as-good Italian BYOBs.

Excellent, on-point service, save for the less than friendly, obviously bored sommelier and the aloof bartenders.  The atmosphere is decidedly and disappointingly a lot more casual than one would expect. 

The first thing that strikes one is that the entire restaurant space and layout needs to be seriously re-evaluated.  Osteria is huge and the space and flow of the restaurant is very poorly conceived.  There is major congestion right as you enter, and the bar is awkwardly located right in the middle of two dining rooms, past the open kitchen.  Attempting to navigate between the spaces is a total traffic nightmare!  (although, as an aside,  they have lovely, clean bathrooms)  The best dining space is in the extended outdoor conservatory dining room, the rest of the dining spaces are split in three and they are tightly packed with tables with a scorching high noise level.

The menu has Vetri brilliance, here and there, especially in the pasta dishes.  The rest of the menu, and for the price tag, does not live up to the Vetri hype.  Nothing on the antipasti menu ever has blown me away, and the Pizza (always hailed as some of the best pizza around), is good, yes, but nothing that knocks your socks off.  In all seriousness, this pizza is maybe only a notch better than pizza at Pietro's.  The pasta, as expected, is really what shines.   Whichever dish you choose, you cannot go wrong there.   

Lastly, they serve one of my favorite deserts ever: the polenta budino with gianduia mousse and candied hazelnuts - if you're a fan of any of these ingredients, I command you to order this!  The cold polenta, and the sweet and salty mix of flavors with the mousse and hazelnuts is downright heavenly.

As you know this place isn't a cheap night out. With cocktails, wine, appetizer & pizza to split, two main dishes and desert to to split for 2 will cost you a pretty penny .  This place, despite some high points, just isn't all that it is cracked up to be (or perhaps once was).  If you're ready to spend, go right ahead, but I'd recommend going to any one of the amazing Italian BYOBs we have at our disposal instead.

really good if you want to go somewhere nice but not over the top or you forgot to make a reservation. 

Very knowledgable oyster shuckers about different varieties. 

never been disappointed. 

Great spot to go after Titans game or down for a concert.

I tried Fuel today for the first time. I ordered a Caesar salad with an addition of chicken. The salad came to a little over $11. It is a little pricey for lunch. The lettuce and tomatoes were great but the croutons were burnt and yet they were all mushy. Not one crouton had any type of crunch and seemed stale. The salad was just ok. It wasn't a terrible salad but it wasn't excellent either.

Have you ever experienced brunch at 1:45 on a Friday afternoon? Wait, that's not important - what I'm trying to say here is that you should come HERE to experience brunch at 1:45 on a Friday afternoon! I met a friend/business associate here for some mid-day food and I was really pleased with the excellent service and the quality of the food. We both had their version of eggs benedict and were so full after the first half that we had them packed up to go (mine tasted just as good a few hours later). 

Great music, a vast and varied selection of Jarritos and tons of menu choices. What's not to love?

You all know about the chicken, here are my five biggest tips

- Please show up before opening to avoid the wait (we arrived at 1206 for a 12pm opening and still waited 38 minutes)
- They close at 5, be aware
- Pretty much only fried chicken here, the catfish and things are at deli/grocery
- They only take 1 card per table
- If you can, avoid the weekend

BONUS 1: It's bigger on the inside than it looks outside, don't let the line intimidate you
BONUS 2: Tell the hostess you're willing to sit at the bar, it's often empty

No food sampled here, but a solid 3 stars.

Let's just get one thing out of the way - don't ask what is on tap.  Because, there are no taps.  So you have been warned.  And pulling the embarrassed "oh that's right, sorry, I forgot" bit has already been done.  Trust me.

That said, the bottle selection (as I recall) has some diversity (who knew Hermann, Mo. had a brewery (Tin Mill) making a really nice doppelbock.  Then again, as of 4 hours or so ago, I didn't know there was a Hermann, Mo.)

The space was minimalistic, though spacious.  I need to come back here and acquaint myself with their food.

Lola Montez would be proud of this place!

The beautiful wife and I finally visited Lola on this hot steamy summer evening.  Walking in, it was fairly empty except for some patrons at the bar.  We were promptly greeted and after wandering about trying to find a table that wasn't in sunlight.

After perusing the menu for a bit, we ordered a couple of drinks (I'll let the beautiful wife review her food and drinks).  I had the Bogen (Don Q Coco Rum with pineapple juice and iced tea).  It was pretty refreshing, especially coming out of the heat.

For an appetizer, we split the spanakopita/portobello dish.  It's spanakopita, wrapped in phyllo, on top of a grilled portobello.  The entire thing is on top of a giant crouton like thing.  And surrounded by a bunch of greens.

Anyway, it's a wonderful blend of flavors and textures.  And it's pretty rich, so splitting isn't a bad idea.

For an entree, I saw they had the infamous lobster corn dog (which will be available via the Yelp Eats! menu -- see http://www.yelp.com/events/saint-louis-yelp-eats).  This also comes with mac and cheese (more about it later).

The lobster corn dog wasn't what you'd think -- it was a small lobster tail, deep fried (?) in a light corn (I assume) breading.  I thought this was pretty tasty, but it was...

1) really small
2) the fried aspect made it taste sort of cheap (there's that mental thing of associating fried seafood with lesser quality)

Fortunately, this is served with a hefty portion of above-mentioned mac and cheese.  This is really good stuff -- very light, but very tasty.

A couple more drinks were consumed:

1) the Castro (Dos Lunas Anejo Tequila, Cointreau, fresh muddled limes and a float of Grand Marnier) -- nice punch to this, but very boozy (be warned)

2) Moto Lofts (Habanero infused Absolut vodka and house Mary mix) -- oh good lord.   This is it.  This is the best freaking Bloody Mary in St. Louis.  Tabasco, you ain't got shit on Habanero.

Service was very friendly and quick to keep drinks filled (Lola may sip, Timothy drinks).  What impressed me was the pacing of the food -- we had nice pauses between courses and never felt rushed.

Look forward to our next visit.

The beautiful wife and I have visited Modesto three times (twice at the bar, once in the dinning room). I just don't know about this place -- I've walked out of there going "two stars, not going back!" to well, going back and thinking "four stars, can't wait to come here again!"

So I'm going with three stars -- there's consistently been enough positives and negatives that they balance out.

Here's a series of thoughts:

1) I like the pinxtos at happy hour (bar area only) -- if you're feeling cheap and/or looking for something to nibble on before moving to another destination, you can get a lot of food for fairly cheap.

2) But, some of the items aren't that great. I'd say that if you see something has aioli on it, chances are, it's going to be pretty tasteless. As the beautiful wife noted in her review, the mushrooms, oysters, and chicken wings are all solid.

3) The happy hour drink specials are OK -- I wish that they'd offer specials on their regular wines by the glass, but that's just me. The Spanish beers they have are by the bottle and are both lighter (I believe a lager and a pilsner). The funniest thing they offer is the $2.50 half pint for draft beer. Maybe that's some traditional thing in Spain, but good lord, it just screams "stupid."

4) Dish of note: the Bistec a la Cabrales (grilled hanger steak with Cabrales cheese and port reduction) -- this was delicious. The steak was perfectly done and the sweetness of the reduction balanced out the cheese nicely. And you get a pretty decent-sized portion for $8.00

5) Service has ranged from friendly to indifferent. Indifferent made one happy hour not so happy. Why so gloomy? Maybe it's all the cheap people who come in and order 10 millions things for $8? Buck up camper, you could be working at another establishment on the Hill and poisoning people with Provel.

6) Lots of parking in their own lot and/or the street.

7) Cocktails -- the coconut caipirinha is wacky delicious. The rest of the cocktail menu is heavy on sweet drinks, so I've just stuck with beer and wine.

Though I know we'll visit here again, I'll always be skeptical of what experience we're about to have...

It's a 2.5 star place.  Is this great seafood?  Hell no.  But was it acceptable?  Sure.  And dammit, the onion rings (the rings here own Red Lobster's cheddar biscuits) and service made me knock this up to 3.

So, the beautiful wife and I played "tourist" on the weekend.  After getting dicked over by Hard Rock, we went to Landry's.  My first though on entering was "I feel underdressed" -- then I remembered, I'm a tourist, I can do whatever I want.

The beautiful wife and I started off with seafood stuffed jalapenos, which were awkward at best.  BUT, they came on top of a beautiful, HUGE pile of thin onion rings.  Yay!  They were great.  Huge fan.  As in I'd drag the wife here and sit at the bar, drink and eat these.

On to the entree -- I had the Seafood Grill -- veggies and seafood grilled.  It was fine.  Better than Red Lobster, worse than just about any other seafood place.  But the scallops on this platter were excellent.  And apparently, I ate "Pontchartrain" but based on what other reviewers have written, this is Tilapia or a related poop-eating fish.  At least I expect to eat poopfish at a place like Landy's.

Anyway, it's a tourist place (and priced accordingly) for those who end up staying at Union Station and don't know where else to go.  You can do worse than Landry's, but you can do a lot better.

This is an interesting place.  I'm still not sure what to make of it.

The beautiful wife and I hit Talayna's for dinner tonight.  When we walked in, we were asking smoking or non-smoking.  We went with no, but then it turned into some sort of situation regarding what server didn't have enough tables.  So we interrupted and went with smoking, just so we could sit.

We got a booth in the bar area, which is vacant, except for one fellow sitting by himself in a booth in the corner.  I don't believe he ordered any food or drink, so I'm not sure if he was real or not.

Anyway, we were deciding on what to drink, and per some discussions earlier, we decided it would be a wine night.  I asked about that and our server presented a wine list.  I swear, I'd kill to have a picture of this.  It was literally a handwritten list that pretty much read "Cabernet, Chardonnay, Chianti..."  And of course, lacking prices.  Crazy.

I ordered a bottle of Chianti, because I'm a lush.  Only to have the server come back and say they don't sell wine by the bottle.  Even better.  Two glasses of Chianti please!

We had some jalapeno poppers to start off with, which were fine.  They have a mix of cheddar and cream cheese.  But, before you get too comfy, they come with a side of marinara.  That's a first.  But hey, they must know something, because the cream cheese poppers with marinara had a pseudo-lasagna taste (well, jalapeno lasagna).

What happened next...it's so hard to talk about.  You see, they brought out a pizza sample.  A sample of St. Louis style pizza.  That's right.  Sitting before us was a bubbling, thin crusted, Provel-topped monstrosity.   What we were to do?  Reject it entirely?  Run?  Claim to be vegans?  As you see often with travel shows, it would be offensive to your hosts if you did not to take a nibble.  So we did.  From the very edge.  I can't say or not if any of that bastard cousin of Cheese Whiz entered my system, but it came close enough.

After some moments of awkwardness, the main event arrived -- a medium, New York style deluxe pizza.  Wait, no.  It was a medium deluxe pizza, but it wasn't New York-style.  This was a thicker crust, cut into narrow pieces.

Now, it wasn't bad, but it wasn't New York-style.  It reminded me more of a better version of Pizza Hut's hand-tossed (yeah, I've traveled down that road, still better than Provel-topped garbage).

Really long story short, it wasn't bad, it wasn't great.  If we wanted a simple, no frills pizza experience, we might come back (or order take out).  But it didn't blow me away.

Haven't been myself recently, but my wife's been a few times, and she says the service isn't as good as previous.  The better staff got shifted to their new place Sakura down the street, we think.

Any updates/commentary/corrobation of that from folks?

Very nice place to watch the sunset and sip on some drinks. 5 stars for atmosphere, service, and drinks. 3 stars for food. The options are very limited. We had the pretzel bites, which weren't bad, but not a great value, and a burger, which was just mediocre. Being able to enjoy the breeze, the view, and the Rays game playing on the bar tv are all reasons we will return.

Chuy's Mexican restaurant is a large national chain
with eleven locations in Florida. This is the newest.
Each location makes their own fresh tortillas.
They give a complementary basket of nachos with
salsa and a garlic aoli sauce. 
There is a large selection of cocktails such as
Sangria, Margaritas, beer, and martinis, and several
frozen libations.
The food and service was very good.
They serve all of the favorites such as fajitas,
burritos,  enchiladas, tacos, flautas, and combinations.
I had the soft taco platter served with refried beans
and Mexican rice. The filling was fajita chicken.
Other fillings available in all their entrees are
fajita steak, pulled chicken and ground sirloin.
The restaurant has plenty of seating. You can see
the fresh tortillas being made thru a window.
There is plenty of parking.

Metro Diner is a combo diner restaurant serving
basic american food with a gastropub flair. 
They have multiple flavors of pancakes, fried
chicken and waffles, eggs Benedict's, omelets,
biscuits and gravy. Lunch and dinner items
Include meatloaf, fried chicken, burgers, sandwiches and salads, shrimp and grits.
chicken pot pie and pot roast. The service is
friendly and quick with servers taking orders with iPads. The food is very good with generous portions.

We've been waiting for them to reopen. Had a Hawaiian pizza and husband ruined it by adding bacon. It made the pizza too salty. Crust was good.  Sauce was tasty. Had antipasti salad. The dressing was just a cup of red wine vinegar. Spiced it up with all the condiments on the table. But then then we discovered these little Italian cookies. Oh my.....I am speechless. Pro tip: off hours are best. We arrived at 3pm on Saturday and parking lot was packed.   We will be back to try again. The pasta entrees at other tables look delish!

When it comes to Pho, I believe there are a lot of great options in the Reno/Sparks area, which makes us noodle-lovers a bit pickier than usual. Nam Van is not the BEST Pho in town, but it's a pretty good standby for the neighborhood.

We came for lunch on a Sunday afternoon. Their Chinese lunch specials are valid even on the weekends (sweet!), but on a chilly fall day, we had our sights set on soup.

We started with the spring rolls. Though not as tightly wrapped as some others I've had, all the usual suspects were included: cucumber, lettuce, rice noodles, pork, and shrimp enclosed in rice paper served with a yummy chili sauce. I'm accustomed to a peanut sauce with spring rolls, so I was missing that a little, but still good nonetheless. 

To drink, we got a Vietnamese iced coffee as well as an Avocado Boba Snow (like a smoothie.) The iced coffee was, again, not served as usual (with that metal contraption that slowly drips the fresh coffee into the condensed milk) - it was pre-made. Still tasty though. The Boba was solid and as good as elsewhere.

I got the combo bun (rice noodle bowl) with beef, shrimp, and egg roll. While they forgot the eggroll, both the beef and shrimp were cooked perfectly. Tasty bowl of food, but a bit underwhelming at about $11. Other Vietnamese places serve quite a bit more food for that price.

My sister got a small bowl of Pho with Rare Beef and added veggies to round it out. The veggies and beef were excellent. However, what should've been the star of the dish - the broth - was disappointing. It did not have the umami and depth of flavor that Pho should. It was salty and warming, but the whole thing reminded me more of a Wonton soup instead of a great Pho bowl.

Overall, I like this place and would come again if I was in the area. However, I wouldn't go out of my way for it. Lucky for us, the Pho market here is competitive!

Great customer service and the concept is fun but I wouldn't eat it again. The dough kind of tasted like lunch-ables pizza and the sauce was salty. I'd save your self the money and settle for a hot pocket.

Great food but be careful, as with much vegan food many unusual fats are added or are the star of the show with less solid food. If you know what I mean. So watch the amounts and ask ingredients and hot or cold..for every dish. I didn't and was surprised at the " interpretation."

Mushroom shawarma was interesting. 

Korean tacos spicy. 


Broccoli well done. 

Thai noodles good  but cold. I like hot.

Cuban coffee cake pineapple mango sorbet was heaven. 

Kyoto Belle nice.

Ave d. Nice. Great chips too.

YO! ..............Don't burn your tongue--it's 

!!!!!!!!searing hot!!!!!!!!!!!!!............................. on awesome brioche.

Came here the morning of Superbowl 52.  Yes, the morning of... as most Philadelphians were just trying to kill time until the game so why not grab a drink and some food?  Note: we were here before they closed at 3:30 for the evening superbowl party, so I can't comment on that... but as for the morning/afternoon, they had a limited menu selection and a great beer list.  I love that they featured some great local beers to the region.  We ended up getting the fries, which my friend loved but I thought were just ok.  I like their affinity for bacon, though.  I don't make it up to Philly as much as I'd like, but this is one I'd return to if I still lived in the city.

I'm from a big Italian family and I'm pretty much the black sheep of the family when it comes to cannolis.  Never was crazy about them.  Until I had a Termini Brother's cannoli.  These are the BEST cannolis you will ever have.

Let me say that again... These are the BEST CANNOLIS YOU WILL EVER HAVE!

Also had a cake from here... tirimisu... amazing.  Even a family member said, "how can this be so good"  It really is that good.

Cannolis for everyone!!
pizza was not good at all service was slower than usual just not the same Garveys I used to go to. Time to find a new bar and grill

Percy Street BBQ  was the 14th location for the food-ie group to eat.  We like to try out new-ish eating experiences as a group and as usual, this place was a lot of fun.  I'm pretty sure each of the 34 of us over-ate.  My mom echoed an admission of the same guilt and said "gluttony is the only sin you pay right away".  I agree.

The entire staff at Percy St BBQ was incredibly attentive, welcoming and friendly.  Percy St. made it clear immediately that they're the place for large groups.  Before the meal the chef, Erin O'Shea, came out to welcome us and introduce the authentic southern cuisine she obviously puts a lot of love into.  We started off with some tasty appetizers: the Jalapeño Cheddar Cornbread, Avocado Salad, & the Devil Eggs which we devoured with the last gulps of our happy hour (5-7pm) drinks.   Honestly, after that I have no clear account of how things wen since we were getting the full Lockhart dinner treatment.  The blitzkrieg-like storm of delicious food seemed never ending.  The dishes of sides were passed around, each new flavor to fit onto our plates.  Dishes were replaced, trays carried out with paper-wrapped goodness that would be all the meat dishes.  The ribs, pork belly, sausage, roast chicken and brisket were each passed around and I watch my platter fill with goodness.  I almost completely forgot to photograph any food due to the feeding frenzy I slipped into.  In my opinion, all the food was really good.  It was all far too good to fill up on the white bread provided to each table, despite knowing it's Texas authentic. 

Though I left there loosening my belt and groaning, I was already planning my return for some choice dishes that had me in this state more than anything.  The avocado salad (because it seemed kind of healthy),   the mac and cheese (because it was way too good to be healthy!), the brisket (it's their most hyped dish that still exceeds said hype - being so damn juicy, tender and flavorful) , the pork belly (crazy good) and the pecan pie (for it's perfect balance of sweet and salty, chewy goodness).  Just re-reading this paragraph, I'm feeling full again and yet still wondering if I could fit in the root beer chili, which to me was also perfect with hot and spicy balanced with just the right hint of root beer.  See? it's easy to get carried away at Percy St BBQ.
For what it is, the donuts are really good.  The chicken is wonderful.  The chicken sandwich is my favorite in the city.  I love federal donuts.

I'll start off with the good. The service was excellent and the restaurant was tastefully decorated and inviting. The food was visually impressive and had decent taste. However, getting into the restaurant was tricky because they blocked off the front door and you had to go through a attached cafe to even get in which was confusing and off putting. The restaurant was so cold, both my friend and I had to keep our jackets on. When I say cold, I'm talking sixty degrees cold on a normal winter day. I asked why it was so cold and they said their heating system was only two units on the wall. I found this to be unacceptable and now realize why they had blocked the front door. They didn't seem to care about fixing the issue or be very apologetic about the matter. The food was also slightly pricey. If they want be in business on Main Street in Roxborough/Manayunk and not cover the basics I'm not sure how long they will be open. They probably deserve a two star review but I did appreciate the service, beautiful interior, and I'll give the food a passing grade.

This is one of the cutest restaurants I have ever been to. Located in a a historic area of Zionsville, this location has a lush little patio that we took advantage of. There was a wait, but we gave our number to the host and they texted us when our table was ready. We took that time to walk around since the area is super quiet and cute. 
We were seated and we got a few margs, which were delicious. I ordered the Dolly Parton nachos, and my partner got a few different tacos. Everything is done very well here, it's a traditional Mexican feel with a modern creative twist. In my opinion, there is still enough of those base flavors in there, and they only made small tweaks to really amplify the dish. Outstanding! Great service, servers are wearing masks.

I love this place. It's a large space, with exposed beams and a huge garage door they love to open, weather permitting. The drinks and baked good here are out of this world, and I feel that all the baristas here are really creative and will definitely come up with something delicious for you if you ask. Amazing spot to come and hang for a bit. The crowd generally is a studious one, if you are wanting a table be sure to come early! See you soon!

This place is as gloomy as they come, despite the huge open space and nice decor. We stopped here on St. Patrick's Day evening around 7:30-8pm and it seemed pretty slow. The three of us stood at the hostess stand for several minutes watching employees stop by to grab menus and leave, not one said a word to us or even bothered to see if anyone was standing by the door. Someone eventually came to take us to a seat and she seemed like she would rather have been literally anywhere else. We were not greeted cheerfully or told any specials, were not brought water, nothing. We just sat at our table for several more minutes waiting for anyone to greet us. 

I'm going to pause right here and say that from here on out I take full responsibility for staying to find out what happened next. All three of us knew exactly what type of dinner we were going to have from this point forward, and we still chose to stay and see what happened next. We read the warning signs, and then promptly disregarded them.

There was muffled music playing on a speaker, it seemed like it was coming from behind the door we were sitting near but it gave the whole room a really strange vibe. Eventually our server came over and she was extremely pleasant and it was actually surprising to have someone in the restaurant be welcoming to us. We were all disappointed that the prices were quite high for the meat and didn't include any sides, and the sides were very pricey, in our minds. We ordered drinks, we ordered food (brisket tacos to start, a corned beef and cabbage special, and a fried chicken sandwich with french fries for me, one of us didn't have dinner, just drinks). The drinks, appetizers, and meal came out all at once. The brisket tasted good, but the slice of meat inside the tortilla was super weird and awkward. There was also just no other flavors with the tacos. There was some cabbage, and of course we were given hot sauce and 4 or 5 different barbecue sauces, but for the price of the 3 tacos I would not say they were worth it at all. 
The corned beef and cabbage special was $12 and there was so much fat on the corned beef I think my brother in law ate 1/2 of it and we fed the rest to our dogs at home. It was a bit tough, not super flavorful. The cabbage was undercooked. He was very disappointed. 
My fried chicken sandwich: I have never in my life had fried chicken that tasted like chalk, but that was the texture of the breading on the chicken and there was NO seasoning in it whatsoever. I added a ton of salt and Lawry's Seasoning to my sandwich, which helped. The bread was SO dry, and the sandwich was so boring I almost fell asleep eating it. 
Here's where we should talk BBQ sauces: the Carolina sauce was just mustard and vinegar. I can't imagine there being one other ingredient in that sauce because it was potently vinegar and mustard. The other sauces were either vinegar or sweet, indistinguishable. 

Now for the fries: for $3.50 I got a very small boat of what I would consider the world's worst french fries. These fries were so saturated with oil it was dripping out of them. They were also cold when I got them. There was a very nice server (manager?) who came up and asked us how everything was tasting and I was honest with him about the fries. He was super apologetic and told me that Brother John's appreciates feedback from their customers. He told met he fries would be taken off the bill and they were removed from the table. A few minutes later he came over with a $10 gift card to return and apologized again. I thought this was a super nice gesture, but because the rest of our food was so grim and the atmosphere was so sad I couldn't bear to break it to him that we probably won't ever return. No bother, because when the bill came to our table we were still charged for the fries. We didn't dispute it. We just paid and left. It's been awhile since I have been to a place I had such high hopes for and been this let down. On to the next, I guess.

Latest Dish is the kind of place where the seating really matters. The quarters for most table are very tight, but there is one nice private two top and a table that can hold about 6 in the left hand corner. Getting these table will vastly improve the dining experience.

We were more for appetizers than dinner. Which were good, but a little over spiced. I would have like to be able to taste more of the food and less of the burn.

There beer menu is big and has enough variety to make most people happy.

We were there on Saturday and the music was turned up way too loud. I've head that it's not always so loud.

How I felt about this Starbucks; divisive. 

The good: nice location in the mall area. Social Distancing of the customer lineup as well as the dining area, the drinks, customer service and cleanliness of the bathroom; right as rain.

The bad / Ugly: the flow of the orders. I mean, Groups of orders weren't given together but separate, patrons who were waiting longer than other patrons had to watch as patrons with shorter orders received theirs quicker. Busy yes, but I know Starbucks can do better than that...maybe it was just a bad day but still...! 

Just stating what I saw was obvious.

Well, after two recent visits in late May to mid June, 2008 I must review and rewrite my previous comments and rating. On both these latest occasions, the "Classic Burgers" were both way overcooked and very dry and shrunken in appearance. The french fries were soggy, limp and tastless. When told of these product lapses from previous visits we were told that "Our fries are fresh, not frozen and the burgers are the same" Having been in Hotel/Food Service business for the past 37 years, this is the situation--- The burgers are plopped on the grill and while cooking, are flattened out by pressing on them with the spatula- thus nothing is left to be juicy- The fry oil is not at the right temperature, thus fries are soggy and soak up excess oil. 
We will not be returning for quite awhile.

Went once for the all you can eat fish. Waited for a long time to be seated, waited just as long for the food to arrive, server was rude and seemed like he didn't want to be there, free cheese cake was okay, not worth the wait. Parking is a nightmare!!!

I hate to give any Mt. Airy small business a bad review. But I ate here three times prior to reviewing, and I have to be honest. The first two times the food was great and the service was decent, but the last time was so terrible that it knocked this review down to two stars. 

I'll say it again to be fair: the beers are great, the beer selection is wonderful and changes often, and the flatbreads are really, really good. I've had some appetizers here like soup, salad, edamame, cheese, and olives and they've always been tasty. 

But this third time...first, I ordered an olive appetizer which was way different than it had been before. Before, it had been a small, tasty serving of various olives. This time, it was a large bowl of completely tasteless olives. I actually sent it back, and I have NEVER sent back a dish in any restaurant. The waiter seemed surprised and made me explain myself several times, which I didn't think was necessary. But whatever, I had a delicious flatbread coming.

Except that it never came. All of my dining companions received their food and were nearly finished by the time we even got an explanation. In fact, it seemed as if the waiter was avoiding us. Finally he came over and said that there was a "mix up" and the pizza would be out in mere minutes. Well, it wasn't mere minutes, but it finally came. I received an apology from two waitstaff about it, and the offer of a free dessert.

Well, okay. I can accept that. I ordered the banana chocolate chip bread pudding. And it took FOREVER to come out. It became comical. I assume they only had to heat it. It took so long that we were just amused at that point. And when it arrived, it was very, very burnt. I received a burnt end. 

I try not to hate on anything "free," but when your free comped dessert takes forever to arrive and is BURNT, what is one to do?

Two out of three weren't bad, but they weren't good either.

I really want to enjoy and review the food here.

The problem is their posted hours!  Several times I have driven here only time find them closed well before their posted closing times.

I ran into this with another authentic Mexican place and asked them there about it.  They told me a secret...

They were huge Liga MX soccer fans.  So if there is a big game on TV that day, they close early.

So on a whim, I checked and a lot of the soccer games start at 7:00pm.

That may explain why I always find this Taqueria closed early!

Do yourself a favor, before driving here google the Liga MX soccer schedule, so you don't waste your time like I have!

So just 2 stars for not being open when you are supposed to...

Yikes! Without a doubt, the worst Indian food buffet I have ever had the displeasure to eat from. Old, stale rice (only one spice pod seen in the full pan), old, frozen, tasteless chicken Tandoori, no spice in the chicken Vindaloo (which, btw, I took the last tiny pieces of chicken and the pan was never refilled the entire time we were there). The whole thing was just awful.
No one came to our table to see if we wanted anything to drink other than the water they placed at our table while we were in the buffet line and no one offered us any naan. I watched every other table (some with just one diner) receive a basket of naan. The only time we saw a server was to ask for the check.
I guess the place used to be Twisted Tandoor which I had heard great things about. I hate it when a subpar establishment tries to grab the shirt-tails of a previous successful restaurant and even use the same name or a version thereof and falls deeply short.

Customer service is excellent!!! Employees carried themselves so professionally and seemed happy to serve you. All the waitstaff seemed like they work as team and check on all customers whether they're the one's who took your order or not.  Place is very clean and has a contemporary feel.  Went for lunch and had sandwiches that were generous in size and tasted great too - except for chicken breast on my sandwich. it actually tasted like it was left over from yesterday - dry & tough.  FRIES WERE AMAZING! This was our first time here but we plan on coming back to try some breakfast next time.

I will never ever go to this place again!!! I've been kicked out multiple times without explanation, while my other friends who I've consistently gone there with, have not experienced the same mistreatment as I have. I've always wondered why, but today got a clear answer! They Are reacist!! My example: While I was dancing and having a good time,my surrounding friends ( white) used a jule (smoking/vaping ), I was the one targeted and got kicked out...but my "friends0 were allowed to stay. ( I only understood this after the bouncer admitted to his reasoning)...These bouncers are racist!!! And I feel strongly enough to comment today and I don't care who thinks I may be over exaggerating or trying to mis characterize what occurred. I'm over it!!! This place needs to be called out. If you are a person of color, they will treat you differently. Over it! Do not support this place.
food is good, but the horrific service is inexcusable. too many good restaurants in st. pete to put up with this.

This was my second time at Belgian Café.  I remember the food being adequate the first time, but yesterday night, the food was abysmal.

I came with a group, but I shared meals with my boyfriend.  I ordered the special, the nachos with chicken confit, and my boyfriend ordered the andouille sausage po' boy.  

I was surprised when my nachos came out to find very little chicken on the dish.  There wasn't much cheese or salsa either!  There was, however, a dollop of weird sour cream/ranch topping that did not compliment the rest of the dish.  The nachos were just cheap, store-bought yellow tortilla chips with a hint of cheese and chicken.  What is the point of ordering nachos if you don't even have a decent layer of cheese?!  I make far better nachos at home with better ingredients, better topping-to-chip ratios, and more topping variety.

My boyfriend's po' boy was not good either.  The bread was noticeably stale.  The sausage was bland.  It came with fries that were giant; they were essentially a potato cut into 4 gigantic slices and then fried.  If we had wanted a baked potato, we would've ordered that.

We ate the food because we were starved.  However, I expect food at restaurants to be tastier and of a higher quality than what I make at home (and I'm a beginner).  This food was much, much worse than my cooking.  

I will not return.

I want to love Ocean World, but the problem is that they are not consistent.   Doesn't hold a candle to Sakura even though the O.W. head sushi chef started there, and he's a gem. I suspect that the difference-maker is which one of the sushi chef prepares the order.  Be cautious about carryout-- they notoriously take longer than they tell you, which is annoying. Female behind the counter is first class, but can't say that for the male manager who rarely smiles or expresses any sincere appreciation. I'd send him back to finishing school. Bottom line for Ocean World is that their sushi is decent, but you can find (much) better.

I'm not much of a fan of buffets and with good reason, a lot of times the food sits out for far too long (I work in a retail industry and I know there is a time limit to how long food can sit out, but sometimes it looks like it's been out longer...) and while I don't think I've truly ever seen food with that problem here it's buffet food and it's just meh. Now, I do like the breakfast buffet that they serve. Now, as I have seen others post some of the patrons can be a bit loud and uncouth so It just depens on when you go (I would avoid Friday and Saturday nights, but that's me) if you want to avoid the crazytown times....

First off, it's easy to miss this place as it sits in the middle of the residential area on Lombard Street. As soon as you walk in, the bar is literally at the front door. Try not to bump into it. Their menu is not huge, but they had what I was in the mood for, which was a salmon sandwich. The salmon was pan-seared and served on a Kaiser roll with guacamole and a tomato. It was good, but it wasn't anything special. I'll probably give a few other items on the menu a chance soon.

If you're looking for gigantic portions of pasta and excellent service, Bellisimo is where it's at. 

Bring your appetite ... Bellisimo's meals include homemade bread and soup or salad - I prefer the salad, though the minestrone is a great option as well. My usual order is chicken piccata over angel hair. Great lemon butter flavor. I've never once been able to finish my meal. One dinner can seriously be broken into three meals. It's crazy.

Parking is simple. Service is tops - we've had Tom as our waiter twice -and he's incredibly attentive and professional. 

In addition to the delicious food, I love the abundance of plants and always enjoy sneaking a peek at the autographed celebrity photos - such a cool '80s touch :-)

I think of all three Pollo locations I visit, this is my favorite. The service is great and food is always fresh and ready to go - no waiting for chicken to be prepared (this actually happened twice in one night at the Ulmerton/Largo location) ... 


I have to agree with some of the other reviewers, they need to staff up and work on their cleanliness appearance. The other Pollo locations have them beat when it comes to neatness throughout the restaurant.

I'm not sure how my last review didn't post but because of my experience today I'm only leaving 3 stars instead of 5. My food today was good my son's was questionable. We both got the mullet dinner. Mine was fine his was oddly sticky. We said something but all in all zero cares were given. She did although ask if the taste was OK and that was it. Makes me question if I'll be back and I usually go several times when I'm here for a visit.

If you have an "American" palate you are not going to like this place. They serve a lot of raw seafood served in lime juice. Most Americans are going to call this acid reflux waiting to happen. On the other spectrum they seem to want to deep fry stuff. It makes no sense. My husband order their version of "paella" but it was bland. They also love cilantro. You are either in with cilantro or out with cilantro.

There are so many other restaurants available, skip this one.

I mean, what should I expect from a cheap breakfast in an airport restaurant? The service was fine and my meal came out quick, but the food is just of poor quality and ridiculously salty overall. I would never come back here again.

First off, social distancing is being practiced with using ever other table. Second, I watched our server continually change gloves between customers and tasks. Third, he wore a mask CORRECTLY! Now on to the food.... DELICIOUS! My small ultimate warrior was perfection. Just the right amount of all ingredients on a lightly crispy crust. LOVE LOVE LOVE!! Clean atmosphere, clean staff, and excellent pizza! We will be back!! Thank you to Daniel for such a great lunch! Hopefully we'll see you again!

Pro's: Fresh, fun atmosphere, easy parking
Con's: I do not have any
Go back?: I am a regular

More...
I have never been disappointed at Oceano. It was Thanksgiving and my husband and I were going to be on our own. No point in cooking...how about something non-traditional? With Dungeoness crab in season, we thought it time to go to Oceano for their amazing crab and shrimp melt. It was a good choice! Perfect temperature, melty and on sourdough. A very nice dill component that is not overpowering made the sammich fresh and yummy. They also have great fries that are always super hot. This sammy is big enough to share, fyi. With a bottle of chardonnay, our Thanksgiving lunch did not disappoint.

Doggone, I cannot seem to remember that I am a local and could have gotten a discount....next time, maybe!

Location, location, location. You can't say Reef is the best sushi on the river. It is however, the only sushi on the river.

Pro's: Location, adequate sushi (see below)

Con's: Dirty, juvenile service, slow kitchen (hot kitchen, not sushi), no effort over years to remedy this, calamari is cooked from frozen

Go back? If I want adequate sushi, must sit by river and don't mind trash all around on the ground (patio and indoors - I took a video of this but it will not upload).

Sunday, May 21, approximately 7:00PM, party of 2

It was an ok time with some irritations noted below. Mostly, I could not help noticing the trash that servers neglected to pick up on the patio and indoors. I am talking chop sticks, chop stick wrappers, napkins, sushi order forms. This was true indoors as well. Why are servers not instructed or simply not picking up trash? If this is not important in the front of the house, what can the kitchen look like? Hate to think about that one... There is a lovely commercial grade carpet at the door with the Reef logo. It is trashed, dirty, needs to be cleaned or replaced. Such a pretty logo but brown with dirt.

"What do you mean by that?":

Juvenile service: Ordered AYCE and sushi came out well before appetizers. Discussed this with server and was told the "hot" kitchen is always slower than the sushi kitchen. So I said "Well then maybe appetizer orders should be put in before sushi orders." Her response? "Yes, you should definitely do that." So this was MY bad. How about asking us for apps when you asked for our drink order? Come to think of it, over 3.5 years of going to Reef maybe twice a year, this has happened every time. After years of this, is there no remedy? How about a separate slip of paper for appetizer orders kept separate from the long sushi order? This way, apps could be turned into the kitchen well ahead of sushi orders.

Reef has an amazing location and some fun roll combinations that are tasty. Quality of maguro was a lower grade, however. Maguro should be as red as rare meat. This was pink. I hate to see the "draw" of the river be what keeps this restaurant alive. Imagine the draw of the river AND amazing sushi, service in a clean environment? It would be the talk of the town and not just a convenient place to eat when you are on the River Walk.

Pro's: Everything
Con's: Not one thing
Go back?: Already becoming a regular

More...
This review is specifically for the new Rancharrah location. I have eaten there twice this week! The first time, I had the Croque Madame....eu la la! So fresh and delicious. The fries are great...can't wait to try the truffle fries sometime soon. I loved it so much, I brought my husband out on Saturday. He had the fish and eggs and LOVED it. I had the cheddar grits with a fried egg and all the other yummies they added to that bowl. Amazing! How do they get a fried egg to look like it is sunny-side up, but is not, but is still cooked right to the edge of the yolk? Unbelievable! The creativity of unique flavors found here is refreshing and a real treat. Sunday morning, I woke up wanting more Perenn but know I can't eat cheddar grits every day...but I was really craving their dark roast COFFEE. Wow. I can go back for coffee...and maybe a little chocolate bouchon.

It was busy when we were there on Saturday. There was a table but it had no chairs. The server went and fetched chairs from outside without our even asking.

There is also a market area where we bought fig and rosemary garlic bread. That was amazing with dinner last night? Who thinks of these combos? So delicious! We also bought the pistachio and pork pate....YUM! Husband wanted the sardines...I'm sure he will like them - not my thing.

There was a mistake on my order which was quickly rectified and to make amends, they gave me a chocolate chip cookie. You guys can screw up my order ANY TIME! Hahahaha.

Perenn is NOT TO BE MISSED IN RENO.

The first thing you must know is that the happy hour menu is ONLY served if you're sitting on a bar stool. Once you walk inside you'll see what I mean.

On that note, their happy hour is one of the best in the city and it's obvious that everyone knows it. 5:55 on a Thursday and the place was packed. $4 glasses of wine were enjoyable, as were the edamame dumplings. Like Christine B noted, the truffle flavors in the broth were delicious. The broccoli was good as well. Wings were okay, and the brussel sprouts- well, Rebecca L couldn't even finish them. They were drenched in vinegar and overly salty. Pass on these. Fried rice bowl was huge for a whopping $4, and included shrimp! Good pick if you're hungry.

I would definitely come back to Sampan, but I'd have to get more selective about my snack choices first.

I've been waiting and waiting for Shake Shack to open, of course it finally did right before my sister's wedding, so I decided I would have to wait a few more weeks.  I finally stopped in after work around 5:20, no line to speak of = time to try it.  I got the shack burger and fries and took them home.  The fries were cold and not very good by the time I got home, so unless you live/work very close, I would advise against take out.  My burger was juicy, and definitely has that Pat LaFrieda taste you get at Pub and Kitchen, but I thought it was super salty, and I thought the cheese was weird.  Next time, I'm going to try a plain hamburger.  And I definitely want to try the sweet treats.  I was worried this would be the downfall of my healthy eating because it's so close to my office, but I don't think it will be a problem.  I think it's better than 5 guys, but not 500 degrees, and In n' Out is still my favorite quick burger place.

Stopped in here on a Saturday night.  I love the atmosphere, very dia de los muertos.  The food and drink selection was solid.  I had a big lunch, so just went with an order of calamari.  It was really excellent, very tender, not at all chewy.  My companion had the chicken sandwich which was surprisingly large.  The fries that were served with it were great, reminded me of boardwalk fries.  I went with Southern Tier Pale Ale as my beverage, they had some left from beer week.

Don't waste your time or money. The ordering process is catastrophic, there's absolutely no guidance from the employees and literally stood waiting for a sandwich for 30 minutes, only to be severely underwhelmed by the sandwich. They say the sandwich has aurugula but it was iceberg lettuce, the mocha tasted like dirty water... hospital coffee or gas station automated coffee is way better than this. Everything was terrible. I ended up throwing the coffee away and the sandwich I ate because I didn't have time to go anywhere else after they wasted 40 minutes making a HAM AND CHEESE grilled sandwich... and there were only two people ahead of me when I ordered. This place is a disaster.

DDD Crew stop #4 on our Dia de los Padres Muertos adventure. Wasn't feelin' it...er...smellin' it. Walked in and my olfactory system was assaulted with an odd mixture of cleaning supplies and spice. Kind of a bleach, pine, cinnamon and clove smell. My girls noticed it too.

Saddled up to the bar and discussed turning to leave but didn't want to be completely rude so we all ordered a shot. Down it and get out the door. A couple of girls ordered Jaeger and two of us asked the bartender to surprise us with something that wasn't sweet. She combined Fireball and Crown - really good!

I'm sure O'Malleys is a great place to hang out but maybe when they aren't cooking up a big smelly pot of either the house specialty or floor cleaner.

One of the more serviceable Mexican restaurants in Nashville. I've been to the one on White Bridge road many times. 

This one delivers that same a-ok Mexican food. Nothing outstanding, but the food is good and the service is fine.

When I first moved to Nashville I'd never seen anything like Flying Saucer. So many beers!
